headline: Model-morphosis | Dsquared
text: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of Milan Fashion Week. Here, the model Alla Kostromichova from Women before (top, bottom) and after makeup by Gordon Espinet and hair by Sam McKnight. (Drag the orange bar up to reveal the full transformation.)

headline: $3 Million Judgment in Immigration Fraud Case
text: A businesswoman in Jackson Heights, Queens, who falsely promised to secure legal immigration status for dozens of illegal immigrants has been ordered to pay $3 million in restitution and penalties by the State Supreme Court, Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo announced on Monday.

headline: And the Winner Is: Dream!
text: If you felt your heartstrings tugged just a bit too insistently during the Vancouver Olympics, you were not alone. Broadcasters and advertisers use the Games as an excuse to unload their stockpile of sentimentality, the kind of emotional words and images that don’t go over so well during, say, the Super Bowl.

headline: Government Work Is Dangerous
text: State and local government workers are much more likely to get hurt on the job than private sector workers, according to a new report from the Labor Department.

headline: Travel Booking for a Good Cause
text: Book a flight, save a life. That’s the goal of MASSIVEGOOD, a new fund-raising initiative that allows travelers to make “micro-contributions” to global health causes when booking a plane, hotel or car.

headline: Want a Better Listener? Protect Those Ears
text: For football fans, the indelible image of last month’s Super Bowl might have been quarterback Drew Brees’s fourth-quarter touchdown pass that put the New Orleans Saints ahead for good. But for audiologists around the nation, the highlight came after the game  when Mr. Brees, in a shower of confetti, held aloft his 1-year-old son, Baylen.

headline: The Upside of Old Age
text: In today’s Cases column, Dr. Marc E. Agronin explores how often we make the wrong assumptions about old age. He tells the story of an elderly woman in a nursing home. He expected her to be grieving for her late husband, but instead found she had thrown herself into new activities and relationships.

headline: Brecht’s Test of Devotion, Set Amid Modern Warfare
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Bertolt Brecht, that famous game changer of the 20th-century theater, often seems to be more honored in theory than in practice, at least in America. This German playwright, poet and thinker fills a fat chapter in any academic history of drama, and his staging innovations have influenced writers and directors too numerous to mention. Certainly no one would dispute his right to his own adjective.

headline: Protecting a Baby’s Ears in a Noisy World
text: During the Super Bowl, the 1-year-old son of New Orleans Saints quarterback Drew Brees was seen sporting ear muffs. As a story in today’s Science Times explains, they were far more than a winter fashion statement.

headline: Broadway Box Office Falls Along With the Snow
text: The heavy snowstorm in the New York City area last week, combined with the end of the traditional February school vacation period, made for a sluggish week at the Broadway box offices, with ticket sales dropping for most plays and musicals compared to the previous week.

headline: Calling the Parents When a College Student Drinks
text: I visited my college-freshman son last week, and over pizza we talked about drinking. Part of pledging a fraternity means being the sober designated driver, I learned, and I was relieved that the the idea had become ingrained in college culture. Kids get it that driving while drinking is dangerous, right? Not exactly, he corrected. What they get is that a single D.U.I. means expulsion, and that’s a concept students respect.

headline: Google Buys Picnik, a Photo Editing Service
text: The online photo editing service Picnik announced Monday that it had been acquired by Google.

headline: Peter Gabriel Says, ‘I’ll Sing Yours, You Sing Mine’
text: For many singer-songwriters there comes a time to make an album of other people’s songs. That’s what Peter Gabriel does with “Scratch My Back” (Virgin), which is being released on Tuesday in the United States. It’s his first solo studio album in eight years in a multitasking career: technology projects, musical collaborations, humanitarian initiatives, parenthood.

headline: Critics' Picks: 'Sunset Boulevard'
text: A. O. Scott looks back at Billy Wilder's classic meditation on celebrity and Hollywood.

headline: Screening May Save Athletes
text: They are young, strong, competitive athletes, in top physical condition. Yet about 90 of them drop dead every year, often in the heat of competition, victims of sudden cardiac death. Now a new study suggests that there is a cost-effective way to lower the death rate significantly: screening athletes with an electrocardiogram.

headline: Screening the Hearts of Young Athletes
text: Every year, about 90 young, seemingly healthy athletes drop dead from sudden cardiac arrest. A screening test likely could prevent many of the deaths, but administering a screening electrocardiogram to all young athletes has been viewed as impractical and expensive.

headline: Human Culture, an Evolutionary Force
text: As with any other species, human populations are shaped by the usual forces of natural selection, like famine, disease or climate. A new force is now coming into focus. It is one with a surprising implication — that for the last 20,000 years or so, people have inadvertently been shaping their own evolution.

headline: 2 Former Pali Capital Analysts Join BTIG
text: BTIG, a New York-based broker-dealer, said Monday that it was expanding its reach into equity research and  hiring two senior analysts, Richard Greenfield and Walter Piecyk, who previously worked at the now-closed Pali Capital, to lead the effort. The firm will focus on the media and telecommunications sectors and plans to eventually expand into other sectors.

headline: Vital Route in Caucasus Is Reopened, Just Barely
text: CHMI, Russia — They have a simple way of putting it in this village six miles from the Georgian border: The road is life.

headline: In Obesity Epidemic, What’s One Cookie?
text: The basic formula for gaining and losing weight is well known: a pound of fat equals 3,500 calories.

headline: Tuberculosis: North Korea Develops TB Laboratory With Help From American Doctors
text: With help from scientists from Stanford University’s medical school, North Korea has developed its first laboratory capable of detecting drug-resistant tuberculosis, scientists involved in the project said last week.

headline: Iranian Authorities Close 2 Opposition Publications
text: The Iranian authorities on Monday closed two major opposition publications, among the last to remain in circulation as the government has suppressed its opponents’ communications in recent months.

headline: Donna Murphy in Encores! Sondheim
text: The Tony Award winner Donna Murphy has been cast in the coming New York City Center Encores! revival of “Anyone Can Whistle,” the Stephen Sondheim-Arthur Laurents musical that closed on Broadway after only nine performances in 1964. Ms. Murphy, who has won two Tony Awards for best actress in a musical  for “Passion” (1994) and the 1996 revival of “The King and I”  will play the role of Mayor Cora Hoover Hooper, which was originally played by Angela Lansbury in her Broadway musical debut. This early Sondheim work was regarded at the time as experimental and absurdist, and both audience and critical reaction tended to be negative. Yet the musical, a satire of small-town life and politics led by the corrupt mayor, also became a cult favorite among some Sondheim fans and others. The City Center production, which also stars the previously announced Sutton Foster (“Thoroughly Modern Millie”), will be the final Encores! show of the season, scheduled to run for five performances April 8 to 11.

headline: Rock Hall’s Archives Find a New Home
text: Some of the most interesting items at the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame and Museum in Cleveland, like Buddy Holly’s high school diploma and Jim Morrison’s death certificate, are usually hidden in storage as part of the library and archive. But by the end of the year those items will have a new home in a high-tech $35 million building the museum will share with Cuyahoga Community College, about two miles from the hall’s lakefront headquarters, The Plain Dealer reported. “We want this to be the world’s pre-eminent research center for rock ’n’ roll,” Andy Leach, director of the hall’s archives, told the paper. The new archives are to open in November or December and take up about a third of the 75,000-square-foot building, designed by Robert Madison, who worked with I. M. Pei on the design of the main museum, which opened in 1995. Abba, Genesis, the Hollies, Jimmy Cliff and the Stooges will be inducted into the Hall of Fame in a ceremony at the Waldorf-Astoria in Manhattan on March 15.

headline: Even More Reasons to Get a Move On
text: “I’m 86 and have walked every day of my life. The public needs to wake up and move.”

headline: A Baldwin ‘Equus’ in the Hamptons
text: Alec Baldwin’s character Jack Donaghy on “30 Rock” may have complicated animal issues  the neutering of his childhood dog, Pop, on his mother’s orders, created all sorts of trauma  but he has nothing on the next alpha male Mr. Baldwin will play. He is to star as the psychiatrist Martin Dysart in a production of Peter Shaffer’s play “Equus” this summer at Guild Hall in East Hampton, N.Y. The play, revived on Broadway during the 2008-09 season starring Richard Griffiths and Daniel Radcliffe, revolves around therapy sessions between Dysart and a young man who has blinded a stable of horses. In a statement, Guild Hall also said Mr. Shaffer planned to rewrite parts of his original script for this production. (He will work in residence at the theater during rehearsals and previews.) Directed by the Tony Award-winning set designer Tony Walton, the production will run from June 8 to July 3 at the John Drew Theater at Guild Hall. Mr. Baldwin, a fixture of the Hamptons, recently joined the Guild Hall board.

headline: Post-Olympic Letdown
text: With its broadcast of the Winter Olympics closing ceremony on Sunday, NBC easily won the night’s ratings race, but its first showing of a high-profile new comedy series, “The Marriage Ref,” didn’t bring home the gold. According to Nielsen’s estimates, an average of 20.5 million viewers tuned in to the Winter Games ceremony from 7 to 10:30 p.m. Immediately following, a “sneak preview” of “The Marriage Ref,” a comedy-reality series whose producers include Jerry Seinfeld, attracted 14.5 million viewers. That was a solid start, but less than what CBS drew with its new reality series “Undercover Boss” (15.1 million) opposite the Olympics. CBS placed second with a lineup that included “60 Minutes” (10.7 million), “The Amazing Race” (10.2 million) and “Cold Case” (9.8 million), while ABC was third and Fox ranked fourth.

headline: French Film Awards Favor ‘A Prophet’
text: The widely praised film “A Prophet” (“Un Prophète”), directed by Jacques Audiard, below, already a grand prize winner at the 2009 Cannes Film Festival, added to its trophy collection on Saturday night when it was named best picture at the César awards, the French equivalent of the Oscars, Reuters reported. The film, about a young man of Arabic descent and his journey through the French prison system, took home nine Césars in all, including those for best director, original screenplay and cinematography, as well as acting awards for Tahar Rahim, who plays the central character, and Niels Arestrup, who plays an aging mob boss whose influence he falls under. The Césars also gave a lifetime achievement award to Harrison Ford but denied James Cameron’s film “Avatar,” which lost out in the best foreign film category to Clint Eastwood’s “Gran Torino.” “A Prophet” has been nominated for the best foreign film Oscar.

headline: Get Ready to Board the ‘Glee’ Express
text: For most musical acts it is traditional to go out on tour first and then get bogged down in personal squabbles and inconvenient pregnancies. But the cast of Fox’s “Glee” is doing things backward. After the characters have endured their first season of trials, tribulations and trimesters, the actors who portray them will hit the road for a series of live performances, the Fox television studio and the show’s co-creator Ryan Murphy said on Monday. The tour, called “Glee Live! In Concert!,” will consist of seven shows, in Phoenix (May 18), Los Angeles (May 20 and 21), Chicago (May 25 and 26) and New York (May 28 and 29). The cast members Lea Michele (Rachel, foreground in photo), Cory Monteith (Finn, foreground), Amber Riley (Mercedes, center), Chris Colfer (Kurt, right), Kevin McHale (Artie), Jenna Ushkowitz (Tina, left) and Mark Salling (Puck) are among the performers expected to appear, and yes, “Don’t Stop Believin’ ” and “Sweet Caroline” are on the set list.

headline: Film Society Honor for Michael Douglas
text: Michael Douglas, below, says that when he’s offered a lifetime achievement prize these days, he does an act of due diligence first. “I normally check how many cardiologists are on the review panel for the award, just to see if they know something that I don’t,” he said Monday in a telephone interview. So Mr. Douglas, 65, the star of “Wall Street,” “Wonder Boys” and “Traffic,” was apparently satisfied with the makeup of the Film Society of Lincoln Center, which has named him the honoree of its 37th annual Chaplin Award Gala, the society said on Monday. The gala, to take place on May 24 at Alice Tully Hall, will recognize Mr. Douglas for his work as an actor as well as a producer of films including “One Flew Over the Cuckoo’s Nest.” Previous honorees include Martin Scorsese, Tom Hanks and Meryl Streep. “They have great, highbrow taste,” Mr. Douglas said of the society, “so I guess I’m going to drag ’em down a little bit. But they’ll get over it.”

headline: Justices Hear Appeal of Ex-Chief of Enron
text: WASHINGTON — Both the law under which Jeffrey K. Skilling was convicted and the way his jury was selected were the subject of skeptical questioning at the Supreme Court on Monday. The law was too vague, several justices suggested, and the jury selection too cursory.

headline: Minor Miracle on Ice: A Stunning Audience
text: The Canadian men’s hockey team’s 3-2 victory over the United States in the gold medal game Sunday mesmerized Americans in a way that the Stanley Cup finals never have.

headline: What We’re Reading: Vanishing Text Messages and Online News Habits
text: Interesting items from around the Web chosen by New York Times technology journalists:

headline: Breeder’s Animal Cruelty Trial to Resume
text: No matter what the verdict at Ernie Paragallo’s trial on animal cruelty charges, state regulators and thoroughbred retirement advocates say New York now is a safer place for aging racehorses.

headline: Two Suspects Entered U.S. After Killing in Dubai
text: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates — At least two suspects in the killing of a Hamas official in a hotel here in January traveled to the United States afterward, according to a person familiar with the investigation.

headline: Barney Frank Has My Vote, BofA’s Chief Says
text: Bank of America‘s chief executive, Brian T. Moynihan, says he plans to vote for Representative Barney Frank of Massachusetts in November, praising Mr. Frank for balancing lender and consumer concerns as chairman of the House Financial Services Committee, Bloomberg News reports.

headline: Off the Menu: Kyochon
text: The Korean fried chicken chain Kyochon, which has more than 1,000 restaurants, including two in Queens, will open its American flagship on Wednesday in a sleek two-story red and white space that cost $2 million.

headline: Scientists Strive to Map the Shape-Shifting Net
text: SAN FRANCISCO — In a dimly lit chamber festooned with wires and hidden in one of California’s largest data centers, Tim Pozar is changing the shape of the Internet.

headline: Movements in Jazz, With Pollock and Coltrane
text: Lar Lubovitch opened his two-week run at the Joyce Theater last Tuesday night with a program underlining his abiding interest in jazz.

headline: A Family Affair, From Acne to Arthritis
text: “Parenthood,” a family drama that begins on Tuesday on NBC, is unexpectedly compelling, even though it looks almost exactly like “Brothers and Sisters” on ABC (but the new show is set in Berkeley instead of Pasadena).

headline: Critics’ Picks Video: ‘Sunset Boulevard’
text: A. O. Scott gets ready for his close-up by looking back at the director Billy Wilder‘s meditation on fame and celebrity, “Sunset Boulevard” (1950). Following the life of Norma Desmond (Gloria Swanson), a star of the silent era whose fame has dissipated, the film looks at the glamor and the tragedy of life in the spotlight. “Sunset Boulevard” was nominated for eleven Academy Awards and won three. Please share your thoughts on the film.

headline: Behind the Rise and Fall of a Class-Action King
text: Peter J. Henning follows issues related to white-collar crime for DealBook’s White Collar Watch.

headline: The Insider | Mike Nouveau
text: The Insider is a recurring profile of tastemakers in the fields of fashion, design, food, travel and the arts. Here, the downtown D.J. Mike Nouveau declares his hardcore love for fashion, Diet Coke and friendship. Nouveau, who can be seen around fashion week wearing Comme des Garçons skirts, had recent gigs such as the 10-year anniversary party for Seven New York; the soft opening of night-life godfathers’ Paul Sevigny and Nur Khan’s Kenmare lounge; and Marc Jacobs’s aftershow at the Standard Hotel’s 18th floor.

headline: Channeling the Smart Set, but Hold the Snobbishness
text: “A voice like a shoe” was the British actor John Standing’s agreeably self-deprecating description of his own singing last Tuesday evening at the Café Carlyle, where he opened a two-week engagement of songs and poems by Noël Coward.

headline: Bids Reported for E.On’s U.S. Operations
text: Duke Energy and PPL Energy are reportedly engaged in competing bids for the German power giant E.On’s American operations, according to SparkSpread, an energy industry news Web site. The Kentucky-based utilities companies owned by E.On could fetch up to $6 billion, making it one of the largest power deals seen in the utility industry for quite some time.

headline: Comic Book Creator Accused of Plagiarism
text: 10:21 a.m. | Updated Nick Simmons, the son of the rock star Gene Simmons and a member of A&E’s “Family Jewels” reality series, sought to make a name for himself in the comic book industry as the writer/artist of “Incarnate,” from Radical Publishing, a manga-influenced story about a group of immortal creatures. But the attempt seems to have backfired.

headline: Anxiety in Greece Over Debt
text: Liz Alderman, Assistant Business Editor of The Times, discusses Greece's debt situation.

headline: Scorecard | Jil Sander Wins!
text: Need further proof that these times are a-changing? As Scorecard knows, critics had exactly zero tolerance for the Caten brothers’ vampy camp fest. All was not completely straight and narrow, however: Raf Simons earned rave reviews for his ironic deconstruction of the iconic representation of the power woman, with shades of Tomb Raider in Wintourian tailoring.

headline: Flowering in the Present, but With Deep Roots in the Past
text: The Cuban singer Omara Portuondo, 79, is still impulsive onstage. At Town Hall on Saturday night, she interrupted her planned set a few times to launch into a song unaccompanied. One, responding to audience requests, was “Amigas,” which she had sung half a century ago when she had hits in Cuba as a member of the four-woman vocal group Cuarteto d’Aida. Now she jumped among all the parts, simultaneously looking back and flaunting what she can do. She sang high and low, whispering and declaiming, hinting at tears and pride: “Sing what is life itself, what is our joy, our truth.”

headline: Pitcher Makes Progress Toward Visa
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Hisanori Takahashi was scheduled to fly to the Dominican Republic on Monday night to get his work visa. By law, he cannot pitch in spring training games in which admission is charged without the visa.

headline: What’s Your Ideal Job?
text: What’s your ideal job? If you’re like most employed Americans, you would say that it’s the one you already have.

headline: Revealing New Facets of a Choreographer’s Gemstones
text: There are many reasons to concentrate on the work of a brilliant choreographer while he or she is still alive. The most obvious is that relatively few dances outlive their maker; the second most obvious is that the dances will acquire different accents when the maker is gone, most of which will probably diminish them. But perhaps the most exciting is to follow, month by month and even day by day, the growing fascination choreographers have with their dancers.

headline: Excerpt: 'Parenthood'
text: The new NBC drama is based on the 1989 drama of the same name.

headline: Where There’s No Smoke
text: Q. When adolescent boys (and others) substitute smokeless tobacco, the kind held inside the lip or cheek, for cigarettes, what are the health effects?

headline: Medvedev Visits France in Bid for Closer Ties
text: PARIS — The president of Russia, Dmitri A. Medvedev, arrived here on Monday with warships, natural gas and a special relationship with Europe on his mind. The French president, Nicolas Sarkozy, greeted him warmly on the start of what will be a three-day visit, intended to enhance the prestige of both men, profit their companies and remind French voters that Mr. Sarkozy’s foreign policy is not beholden to Washington.

headline: Publisher to Halt Printing of Disputed Hiroshima Book
text: The publisher of a book about the atomic bombing of Hiroshima whose author relied on a fraudulent source has said it will stop printing and shipping copies because of further questions about the writer’s sources.

headline: Excerpt: 'Southland'
text: The police drama, canceled by NBC but picked up by TNT, returns for its second run on the cable channel.

headline: In Marja, a Vice President Speaks With Warmth, but Reaps Cool
text: MARJA, Afghanistan — In the battle-scarred district of Marja, where the open fighting stopped just a few days ago, feelings about the war and the previous period of Taliban control are deeply personal, and the message from local people to the Afghan government on Monday was simple: words are not enough; if you expect us to be loyal, we need to see deeds.

headline: Milan Fashion Week | Group Hug 2
text: Sometimes you can tell as much about the state of fashion by the way collections are presented as by the clothes themselves. It can’t be a coincidence, for example, that both Dolce & Gabbana and Ferragamo kicked off their runway shows with nostalgic black-and-white films of cheerful, tireless atelier seamstresses producing “Made in Italy” garments. (The clips were enough to make even the most seasoned national populist propagandist green with envy.) Why the sudden obsession with heritage? It’s not exactly that designers are scaling back to basics — there was enough fur in Milan to outfit a Yeti convention — but fashion houses are undoubtedly playing to their core audiences. And it wasn’t just Dolce & Gabbana, with its emphasis on sensuality and Sicilian tailoring, or Ferragamo, with its quietly elegant town-and-country staples.

headline: How the Men Reacted as the Titanic and Lusitania Went Under
text: Records from two nearly 100-year-old shipwrecks, the Titanic and the Lusitania, have given researchers new insight into human selfishness — and altruism.

headline: Patrolling for Felons and Kudos on Sun-Blinded Streets
text: There’s no other series on television now quite like the TNT cop drama “Southland,” for better and for worse. No show advertises its desire to be taken seriously  its bid for instant-classic status  as insistently as this visually austere account of the daily lives of Los Angeles patrol officers and detectives.

headline: Digital Billboards, Diversions Drivers Can’t Escape
text: Safety advocates who worry about the dangers of distracted driving have a new concern beyond cellphones and gadget-laden dashboards: digital roadside billboards.

headline: Reflecting on a U.S. Win in Portugal
text: Midfielder Yael Averbuch helped lead Sky Blue F.C. to the championship of Women’s Professional Soccer in the league’s first season. Now, Averbuch, a Montclair, N.J., product by way of the University of North Carolina, is on the roster of the United States women’s national team as it prepares for the Algarve Cup tournament in Portugal. She was named to the team by Coach Pia Sundhage after a January training camp in Carson, Calif. Averbuch will be filing to the Goal blog during her trip to Portugal.

headline: Banking on Big Fees From the A.I.G. Deal
text: Few people are happier when a deal is struck than the advisers who helped make it happen. And in the case of the sale of the American International Group‘s Asian life insurance unit to Prudential P.L.C. — the largest deal so far this year — there are more than a few firms to grab fees.

headline: ‘Hero of Ukraine’ Splits Nation, Inside and Out
text: STARYI UHRYNIV, Ukraine — Half a century after his death at the hands of the K.G.B., Stepan Bandera, a World War II partisan, has not lost his ability to rally Ukrainians against Russia — and against each other.

headline: Sand Trap of His Own Making
text: A once formidable professional golfer, brought low by personal scandals, lets a camera follow him around during a rocky comeback attempt in a futile effort to make himself an object of sympathy. A glimpse of Tiger Woods’s future? Maybe, but it’s actually “Being John Daly,” a reality show that has its debut Tuesday on the Golf Channel.

headline: Letting a Grape Be a Grape
text: CUPERTINO, Calif.

headline: For Pennies, a Disposable Toilet That Could Help Grow Crops
text: A Swedish entrepreneur is trying to market and sell a biodegradable plastic bag that acts as a single-use toilet for urban slums in the developing world.

headline: Cheeseburgers and the Common Man
text: The cheeseburger defense is being invoked again at the White House.

headline: Chile Panorama
text: A panoramic view of the devastation in Chile following the 8.8-magnitude earthquake on Feb. 27.

headline: No Crime in Acorn’s Advice to ‘Pimp,’ D.A. Says
text: The Acorn employees in Brooklyn who were captured on a hidden camera seeming to offer conservative activists posing as a pimp and a prostitute creative advice on how to get a mortgage have been cleared of wrongdoing by the Brooklyn district attorney’s office.

headline: A Most Unspeedy Trial Plods Forward
text: Anyone who has ever spent time around courts knows that justice is not always exactly swift. But 44 years?

headline: Photos of the Moment | Girls on Film
text: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.

headline: Did Jets Give Up on Thomas Jones Too Soon?
text: The plot of “Logan’s Run”: An idyllic sci-fi future has one major drawback: life must end at 30.In the N.F.L., it seems that life as a running back must end at 30. So by that measure, the Jets’ Thomas Jones, who will be released by the Jets on Friday, has cheated fate. He has rushed for over 1,000 yards in each of the last five seasons, and he’s 31. With one of the most imposing physiques in the N.F.L., he’s not done. He just had an excellent season: a career-high 1,402 yards with 14 rushing touchdowns despite battling injuries and despite surrendering much of the work load to Shonn Greene.

headline: Don’t Mention the Insurgency, Afghanistan Tells Reporters
text: With the proliferation of 24-hour news channels, the bar for what gets covered live on television these days has been lowered quite a bit since, say, the moon landing. Last year, for instance, people around the planet watched an unboyed balloon float above Colorado for hours. Last Saturday, hours after the catastrophic earthquake in Chile, Chilean television was broadcasting live images of Hawaii’s coastline to its viewers, just in case a deadly tsunami appeared.

headline: Photos of the Moment | Black, White and Gold
text: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of the photographers from Contrasto.

headline: The Ebb and Flow of Preparedness in Earthquake Zones
text: Haiti’s earthquake in January took a poor nation by surprise and plunged it into deep pain and despair. The photos out of Chile after the magnitude-8.8 earthquake Saturday show the devastation that can happen from a powerful earthquake in a country that has long come to expect the earth to move. The death toll has passed 700.

headline: New Evidence Surfaces in New Orleans Killings
text: NEW ORLEANS — Early one morning in June 2006, when this city was only half full and in many areas still desolate from the flooding after Hurricane Katrina, five men were shot to death in an S.U.V. in the Central City neighborhood.

headline: Coffee Party, With a Taste for Civic Participation, Is Added to the Political Menu
text: Fed up with government gridlock, but put off by the flavor of the Tea Party, people in cities across the country are offering an alternative: the Coffee Party.

headline: Evidence in Africa: The Dancers’ Day Off
text: GRAHAMSTOWN, South Africa — Members of the Evidence Dance Company are serving as cultural ambassadors on their State Department-sponsored tour of Africa, but the flip side is that the Americans are being exposed to other cultures, too. “It’s very much about learning from, as well as sharing with,” said Nathan Holt, public affairs officer at the U.S. consulate in Cape Town, who was in Grahamstown Monday to watch the company perform for an audience of schoolchildren from surrounding areas. On their one day off in Senegal, a week ago, the troupe visited what had been a slave house on Gorée Island, just over a mile away from Dakar’s harbor. “You read about this in history in school,” said Arcell Cabaug, the associate artistic director of Evidence. “But it’s very different standing there in the cell. You call feel the pain, imagine the screams. They don’t teach you that.”

headline: Ford Decides Not to Run
text: Updated, 7:50 p.m. | Under intense pressure from Democratic Party officials, Harold E. Ford Jr., the former Tennessee congressman, has decided not to challenge Senator Kirsten E. Gillibrand in the primary this fall.

headline: The Looks of Lowered Expectations
text: Milan

headline: The Aftermath in Chile
text: Tomas Munita, a photographer working for The Times in Chile, covers the devastation in the cities of Talca and Constitucion.

headline: The New News Junkie Is Online and On the Phone
text: The new news junkie looks very different from even five years ago. Now, she is likely to scan the headlines on her phone in the morning, check a handful of different Web sites over the course of the day and click on links that friends have e-mailed or posted on Facebook or Twitter.

headline: Chilean Wine Industry Damaged by Quake
text: As Chile tries to cope with the widespread devastation caused by one of the most powerful earthquakes ever recorded, it may seem trivial to wonder about the country’s wine industry. But wine is an important segment of Chile’s economy, and the Maule Valley, Chile’s oldest wine region, was not far from the epicenter.

headline: G.M. May Invest More Money in Opel
text: GENEVA — General Motors would consider pitching in more money than it previously committed to turn around its Opel/Vauxhall unit, the president of G.M. Europe, Nick Reilly, said Monday.

headline: Why I’m Not Running for the Senate
text: WHEN it was reported two months ago that I was thinking seriously about running for the United States Senate from New York, Democratic Party insiders started their own campaign to bully me out of the race  just as they had done with Representatives Carolyn Maloney, Steve Israel and others.

headline: Error Blocked PlayStation 3 From Using Its Network
text: TOKYO — A software error prevented users of some Sony PlayStation 3 game consoles worldwide from gaining access to the PlayStation Network, which offers downloads of video games and movies, the company said Monday.

headline: Harold Ford Decides Not to Run for the Senate
text: From Michael Barbaro at City Room:

headline: Lehman’s Domestic Drama
text: The battles by Lehman Brothers to save their firm are well-known at this point, thanks to scores of newspaper articles and books on the financial crisis. Now Vanity Fair shines a light on the equally fascinating fighting among their wives.

headline: Clinton Urges Talks on the Falkland Islands
text: BUENOS AIRES, Argentina — Secretary of State Hillary Clinton on Monday urged Argentina and Great Britain to work toward a peaceful resolution to their long-held claims for control of the Falkland Islands, a dispute that resurfaced recently when British oil companies began exploratory drilling in waters near the islands.

headline: Aloft, an Extended, but Sometimes Disquieting, Family
text: WITH my line of work, I’m often in and out of airports, sometimes in Europe, Asia or the Americas, all in the same week.

headline: Google Buys Picnik, a Photo-Editing Service
text: From Nick Bilton at Bits:

headline: Data Shows Camrys Outside Recall Also Had Problems
text: This article was reported by Bill Vlasic, Hiroko Tabuchi and Jo Craven McGinty and written by Mr. Vlasic.

headline: Chinese Editorials Assail a Government System
text: BEIJING — In a country where the press is tightly managed by the state, the identical editorials that appeared Monday in more than a dozen publications calling for reform of China’s onerous household registration system were noteworthy.

headline: Justices Hear Appeal Of Ex-Chief Of Enron
text: Both the law under which Jeffrey K. Skilling was convicted and the way his jury was selected were the subject of skeptical questioning at the Supreme Court on Monday, The New York Times’s Adam Liptak reports.

headline: Vancouver, the Day After
text: VANCOUVER, British Columbia — Perhaps employers had stopped tolerating the “Olympic flu” as an excuse for missing work. Or maybe the rowdy, often drunken, crowds who took over the streets after families left during the evenings of the Olympics’ first week had finally exhausted themselves.

headline: How Safety Agency Investigates Complaints
text: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration receives more than 30,000 complaints each year. About 70 percent are filed through the agency’s Web site online, while the rest are submitted by e-mail, regular mail or through calls to the administration’s hot line.

headline: Iraqis Awash in Gifts From Candidates
text: BAGHDAD — There are many ways to describe the campaign strategies now being employed in Iraq. Subtle is not one of them.

headline: The Hard and the Soft
text: The United States, a nation of 300 million, won nine gold medals this year in the Winter Olympics. Norway, a nation of 4.7 million, also won nine. This was no anomaly. Over the years, Norwegians have won more gold medals in Winter Games, and more Winter Olympics medals over all, than people from any other nation.

headline: New Museum on Life of Chopin Opens in Warsaw
text: A new museum on the life of Frédéric Chopin has opened on the composer’s 200th birthday in his native country, Poland. The interactive, multimedia museum is located in the center of Warsaw, where Chopin moved in infancy from a nearby country estate, and where he spent the first 20 years of his life before moving to Paris.

headline: Growing Criticism of Toyota Feeds Fears of Antagonism Toward Japan
text: WASHINGTON  Ever since the Transportation Department stepped up pressure on Toyota over its recalls several months ago, two delicate questions have hung over regulators: Is the Obama administration trying to help the Detroit carmakers it bailed out last year by attacking Toyota? And, will those attacks lead to new trade tensions with Japan?

headline: Rock and Roll Hall of Fame to Display Obscure Artifacts
text: Visitors to the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame and Museum this year will be able to see obscure artifacts when the museum opens its library and archives in a new building it shares with Cuyahoga Community College.

headline: Nets Will Offer Free Tax Preparation as a Game Promotion
text: With just six victories this season, the Nets are threatening to compile the worst record in N.B.A. history. But Nets executives are still trying to persuade fans to attend the team’s last 12 home games.

headline: Medals for Ads During NBC’s Winter Olympics Coverage
text: THE seemingly continuous commercials during the coverage of the Winter Games on the networks of NBC Universal gave a new meaning to the term “snow job.”

headline: Obama Backs Rewarding Districts That Police Failing Schools
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama said Monday that he favored federal rewards for local school districts that fire underperforming teachers and close failing schools, saying educators needed to be held accountable when they failed to fix chronically troubled classrooms and curb the student dropout rate.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 994 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American on Monday:

headline: And, Cut! Money Woes Delay a TV Reality Show on Subway Workers
text: It is not your typical subway series.

headline: Jeanne Holm Dies at 88; A Pioneer in the Air Force
text: Jeanne M. Holm, the first woman to rise to the rank of general in the Air Force and the first woman to become a two-star general in any United States armed service, died on Feb. 15 in Annapolis, Md. She was 88.

headline: After Blizzards, Untangling a Knotted System
text: I STOPPED counting the number of flight cancellations in February at around 25,000. Just in the first two weeks of the month, 13,000 flights were scrubbed — that alone was the biggest disruption to the air travel system since 9/11.

headline: From Churchgoer to Charges as Church Burner
text: LINDALE, Tex. — Jason R. Bourque grew up in a house full of crosses.

headline: Gold Is Not Only Standard for Olympians’ Advertising Success
text: For Lindsey Vonn, Apolo Ohno and Shaun White, winning medals at the Winter Olympics in Vancouver is their ticket to future endorsements. Their success, good looks and compelling stories should help them add to their growing stable of sponsorship deals with a variety of companies, marketing experts say.

headline: As Republicans Vote, Texas Primary Seems Close No More
text: HOUSTON — It was supposed to be a clash of Republican titans — a vulnerable right-wing governor against a popular and more moderate United States senator — but as voters in Texas go to the polls Tuesday, the governor’s race looks anything but close, and Gov. Rick Perry has a hefty advantage in the polls.

headline: Obama to Highlight Cost in New Health Bill Push
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama this week will begin a climactic push to rally restive Congressional Democrats to pass major health care legislation by hammering the argument that the costs of failure will be higher insurance premiums and lost coverage for individuals and businesses.

headline: For a Suburban Mother of 3, Next Week’s Play Date Is on Broadway
text: By her late 30s, Maddie Corman, a mother of three who spent nearly a decade taking care of her children full time, had pretty much given up hope of ever seeing her name on a Broadway marquee. It was not unlike giving up a long-held dream of setting foot on the moon: Broadway is a reach for any actress, much less one who spent most of her waking hours shuttling around children to karate and play dates rather than auditioning and performing.

headline: Paterson Is Said to Have Ordered Calls in Abuse Case
text: ALBANY — Gov. David A. Paterson personally directed two state employees to contact the woman who had accused his close aide of assaulting her, according to two people with direct knowledge of the governor’s actions.

headline: Little Big Men
text: Not long ago at some ungodly hour of the morning I saw an early Charles Bronson movie (“Showdown at Boot Hill”) in which the tough-guy actor played a bounty hunter driven by the fact that he was very short. Bronson (Luke Welch) spends some time explaining to his love interest that his entire life, including his decision to strap on a gun, has been a response to the humiliations visited on him because of his diminutive stature. Synopses of the movie on the Internet either do not mention this prominent aspect of the plot or touch on it only in passing, perhaps because it seems so much at odds with the figure Bronson cut (often semi-naked) in a series of famous movies — “The Magnificent Seven,” “The Great Escape,” “Hard Times,” “Chato’s Land,” “Mr. Majestyk” and, of course, in what sometimes seemed to be a series of innumerable and increasingly violent “Death Wish” movies.Bronson is by no means the only action star whose larger than life screen persona was or is at odds with his “real-life” statistics. (Just what those statistics are is often debated on Web sites where there may be a three-inch variation in the height assigned to a particular actor.) The pattern was set in the 1930s and ’40s by Edward G. Robinson (“Little Caesar”), James Cagney, George Raft, Humphrey Bogart and Paul Muni — all small men who usually played tough and cruel. Sometimes camera angles obscured the physical facts —

headline: A Belgian Fest
text: "A Town Called Panic" is a Belgian stop-motion animated film starring three enterprising toys: a cowboy, an Indian and a horse. Tonight the movie will be screened as part of the French Institute Alliance Française's ode to Belgian cinema. The series, which runs Tuesdays throughout March, also includes a screening of "When the Sea Rises" which earned director Yolande Moreau two Césars (that's the French equivalent of the Oscar). We recommend a dinner of waffles and Stella Artois beforehand.

headline: Taylor’s Women
text: "More than any other living choreographer just now," Paul Taylor seems to be in love with his dancers, writes Alastair Macaulay. Tonight, see the results of that love at City Center, where Mr. Taylor is celebrating his 80th birthday with a program of rich repertory, two premieres and a little extra attention for the women. "The variety Mr. Taylor finds in his women is astonishing," adds Mr. Macaulay. "Amy Young is a different woman in every dance  mature, immature, anguished, serene  and yet I'm not aware of her acting. Her solo in 'Cascade' is a marvel of both legato and stillness; nothing in 'Esplanade' stays in my head more amazingly than her quick series of backward falls." Catch her, Annmaria Mazzini in 'Changes'  "the single most sensational performance of the season so far"  and Laura Halzack, "the company's most utterly beautiful woman." In "Sunset," Mr. Macaulay writes, "she has only to raise an eye to make us think differently of how these women are amid these men."

headline: Read. Write. Rap.
text: Lil' Wayne once claimed he didn't need to read because of his innate intelligence. But maybe he's not the best role model. The first installment of the Hip Hop Book Club at Goodbye Blue Monday in Bushwick tonight will feature rappers who read. Co-hosted by Kid Lucky and Susan Hwang, the event invites aspiring songwriters to read a book and then compose and perform an original song about it. Go hear hip-hoppers riff on "Frank Miller's Batman: The Dark Knight Returns." Those slated to appear include Breez Evahflowin, Timothy Dark, Core Rhythm, Dan Costello, Susannah Pryce and We Stole the Show. The event is free; Batman-themed snacks and drinks will be provided.

headline: Ways to Respond to Climate Change
text: To the Editor:

headline: Ford Decides Not to Run for Senate Seat
text: Harold E. Ford Jr., the former Tennessee congressman who has sought to parlay his star power and Wall Street connections into a political career in New York, has decided not to challenge Senator Kirsten E. Gillibrand in the Democratic primary this September.

headline: Olympics Show Hockey at Its Best
text: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  This happily hungover city was finally quiet Monday morning after the raucous all-night party touched off by Sidney Crosby’s golden goal at Canada Hockey Place. A little diner on Dunsmuir Street was back to its usual clientele, the occasional office worker stopping in for a coffee to go. Every one of them said the same thing:

headline: Buffett Casts a Wary Eye on Bankers
text: “Don’t ask the barber whether you need a haircut.”

headline: Advice to Fake Pimp Was No Crime, Prosecutor Says
text: The Acorn employees in Brooklyn who were captured on a hidden camera seeming to offer conservative activists posing as a pimp and a prostitute creative advice on how to get a mortgage have been cleared of wrongdoing by the Brooklyn district attorney’s office.

headline: He Knows Where New Yorkers Hide
text: You won’t find Joseph J. Salvo listed in the Yellow Pages under private detectives, but there’s nobody better in New York at finding missing persons. He has turned up hundreds of thousands of them. As director of the population division of the Department of City Planning, for nearly two decades he has aggressively pursued New Yorkers whom the Census Bureau missed in its official count or would not have found unless he told the bureau where to look. The city’s chief demographer, he, along with his staff, keeps other city agencies abreast of population trends. Dr. Salvo is 55 and lives in the Bronx, where he grew up.

headline: Some Black Democrats Suggest Race Is Factor in Pressure on the Governor
text: Some top black New York Democrats questioned on Monday whether calls for Gov. David A. Paterson either to resign or to transfer some of his authority to the lieutenant governor were prompted by a racial double standard.

headline: In Paterson’s Attempt to Reassure the Public, a Flashback to That ’70s Show
text: Richard M. Nixon, the only American president who resigned from office, lived for a time in New York City. He was never a central figure in political life here. Yet 16 years after his death, his spirit endures, certainly the part of him that wallowed in self-pity and that deflected responsibility when things went haywire.

headline: 2,000 Furloughs Linked to Impasse in Congress
text: WASHINGTON — The United States Department of Transportation said it furloughed 2,000 workers on Monday as a politically charged impasse over unemployment benefits interrupted spending on a handful of federal programs and escalated tensions in Congress.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: March 1, 2010

headline: Monserrate Joins Contest for Old Seat in Senate
text: On the surface, José R. Peralta should have had an easy path to winning a special election for the State Senate seat that had been held by Hiram Monserrate in Queens.

headline: Runway at Kennedy Airport Is Shut Down for Repairs
text: Apaamoore Agambila was not thrilled to learn that the largest runway at Kennedy International Airport would be shut down for repairs on Monday. Heavy snowstorms and stricter security measures had already turned flights into major headaches for many travelers this winter. Few expected that closing one of Kennedy’s four runways would help matters in the short term.

headline: Yankees’ Rivera Works at Own Pace Getting Into Game Shape
text: TAMPA, Fla.  Mariano Rivera leaned back in his chair in the clubhouse. His legs were splayed, his hands were clasped, and for 45 minutes Monday morning, Rivera hardly moved. Everyone, as usual, came to him.

headline: State Proposes Closing 55 Parks and Historic Sites
text: Facing historic financial pressures, New York State has identified 41 state parks that it plans to close, along with 14 historic sites, and late last week it began notifying people who had secured campsites in 12 of the parks that their reservations were being canceled.

headline: At Brown, Spotlight on the President’s Role at a Bank
text: PROVIDENCE, R.I. — Across this quiet quadrangle, behind the wrought iron gates and beyond University Hall, lurks a bogeyman of Wall Street.

headline: Hoyer Urges Bipartisanship on Debt
text: Representative Steny H. Hoyer, the House Democratic majority leader from Maryland, called in a speech on Monday for both parties to set aside their deep differences and compromise on a package of future tax increases and reduced spending on benefit programs to avert fiscal calamity.

headline: From Training Camp to Summer Camp
text: TAMPA, Fla. – The Yankees have one responsibility Tuesday: be in street clothes by 10 a.m. That is when training camp turns into summer camp. Following the success of last year’s surprise field trip to a pool hall, Manager Joe Girardi is instituting another mandatory day of fun, food and fellowship.

headline: Right Off the Bat, Reyes Shows He Can Still Run
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  In his abbreviated season of 2009, Jose Reyes came to the plate just 166 times and in only 7 instances with runners on first and second. A leadoff hitter, which is what Reyes has been his whole career, often hits with no one on base and Reyes was no different.

headline: U.S. to Reveal Rules on Internet Security
text: The Obama administration on Tuesday plans to declassify portions of the Comprehensive National Cybersecurity Initiative, created during the Bush administration as a secret effort to harness the nation’s defensive and offensive strategies for protecting commercial and government networks.

headline: Period Described
text: 40 Across: Period described by the clues and answers to 1- and 72-Across (which are the start and end of a word ladder formed by the answers to the 10 asterisked clues)

headline: Home Fires: Writing and Rewriting Iraq
text: This is the first in a five-part series, “Retelling the War,” in which veterans discuss how books, movies and other tales of combat shaped their perceptions of themselves and of war.

headline: In Chile, Life Between the Tremors
text: Santiago, Chile

headline: Santiago Stands Firm
text: Santiago, Chile

headline: Olympian Crosby, Meet Fans of N.H.L. Crosby
text: PITTSBURGH  Sidney Crosby will find out quickly if being an “adopted son” of Pittsburgh means he is forgiven.

headline: Bloggingheads: The Unkillable Bill
text: Timothy Noah, left, of Slate and Byron York of The Washington Examiner debate why Democrats are still pursuing health care reform.

headline: Corrections
text: An article in some editions on Thursday about the renovation of two cast-iron buildings in SoHo gave an imprecise title for a member of the renovation team, the architect Daniel J. Allen. Mr. Allen was the preservation consultant for the project; the main architect was Thomas McKay.

headline: Corrections
text: A music review on Saturday about the Dicapo Opera Theater’s production of “Il Caso Mortara” referred incorrectly to Christopher DeVage, who sang the part of Edgardo. He is a baritone, not a tenor.

headline: In California, Brown Is Said to Be Seeking His Old Job Back
text: SAN FRANCISCO — In a long-anticipated attempt at a political encore, Attorney General Jerry Brown will announce his candidacy for governor on Tuesday, a person close to the campaign said Monday. Winning the office would make him the oldest governor in California history and the first to hold the office in nonconsecutive terms.

headline: Army Ebbs, and Power Realigns in Turkey
text: ISTANBUL — The detention of top military officers in Turkey last week was nothing less than a quiet piece of history. The military, long considered untouchable in Turkey, was pushed from its political pedestal with startling finality.

headline: Corrections
text: A jazz entry in the Listings pages on Friday about the harmonica player Toots Thielemans and other musicians who will be at the Blue Note from Thursday through Sunday misidentified Mr. Thielemans’s nationality. He is Belgian, not Dutch.

headline: Celebrities in a New Theatrical Role: ‘Presenters’
text: Elton John hasn’t seen the Broadway play “Next Fall,” but he has invested a six-figure sum in the $2 million production. Jay-Z, Will and Jada Pinkett Smith, and their business partners have put $3 million into the Broadway musical “Fela!” And Lily Tomlin has just signed on as the lead promoter of a new one-man show off Broadway.

headline: James Shows Knicks Just Why He Is Their Fondest Wish
text: CLEVELAND  It was goodbye, or see you later or, in their dreamiest of dreams, see you in July.

headline: Tajikistan: Observer Says Vote Fell Short of Standards
text: Parliamentary elections over the weekend fell short of democratic standards because of “a high prevalence” of ballot box stuffing and other problems, the main Western observer mission to the election, the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe, said Monday. A political party supporting President Emomali Rahmon, who has ruled since 1992, won about 72 percent of the vote, suggesting continued stability if not democratic progress. An Islamic opposition party also won seats in the new Parliament.

headline: Netherlands: War Crimes Trial Resumes at the Hague
text: The former wartime president of the Bosnian Serbs, Radovan Karadzic, took the stand as his war crimes trial at The Hague resumed on Monday after a four-month delay. “I stand here before you not to defend the mere mortal that I am, but to defend the greatness of a small nation in Bosnia-Herzegovina,” Mr. Karadzic said. In his first formal defense statement, Mr. Karadzic said his people’s cause was “just and holy” as they fought against Muslim neighbors determined to create an Islamic state.

headline: Mexico: ‘Disorder’ Is Seen in Nursery Management
text: The Mexican Supreme Court said Monday that a fire in a day care center that killed 49 children last June was evidence of “generalized disorder” in the federal government’s management of privately run nurseries. The court’s investigation into the fire in the northern city of Hermosillo named a close associate of President Felipe Calderón, Transportation and Communications Minister Juan Molinar, as one of 16 officials who the court said bore responsibility for the fire. Mr. Molinar was the director of the government’s Social Security Institute, which hires private contractors to run most of its day care centers, until a few months before the fire. The court also blamed state and municipal officials, who it said had never checked the day care center for fire hazards.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Monday about Lake Placid, N.Y., and its connection to the Winter Olympics misstated the event at the Vancouver Games in which the Alpine skier Andrew Weibrecht won a medal. Weibrecht won the bronze medal in the men’s super-G, not the downhill.

headline: Corrections
text: The column by Charles M. Blow on Saturday, about race and crack addiction, incorrectly described a character in the movie “Precious.” The abusive mother portrayed by Mo’Nique is not a crack addict.

headline: French Chateau’s Owners Enter a Thicket of Intrigue
text: LA FERTÉ-IMBAULT, France — The tangled oak woods of the Château de l’Écluse are inhabited by a great silence.

headline: Sometimes the Smallest Things
text: Lately I’ve been thinking of the things my parents taught me  all those habits that were handed over to me one by one when I was a child. These are the sorts of thoughts I always have when I’m teaching writing, which is partly the act of revealing bad habits to their surprised owners. What got me thinking this time was the discovery that I’ve been tying my shoes wrong for more than half a century.

headline: Binghamton Skips Conference Tournament
text: A Binghamton University men’s basketball season stained with attrition and controversy has ended without an appearance in the conference tournament. Binghamton announced Monday that the Bearcats would not participate in the America East tournament because of “possible distractions.”

headline: Corrections
text: The column by Frank Rich on Sunday, about the conservative movement, misstated the job status of Tim Pawlenty. He is the current governor of Minnesota, not former.

headline: Corrections
text: NEW YORK

headline: Watching Certain People
text: From 2004 through 2009, in a policy that has gotten completely out of control, New York City police officers stopped people on the street and checked them out nearly three million times, frisking and otherwise humiliating many of them.

headline: The Second Amendment’s Reach
text: Two years ago, the Supreme Court struck down parts of the District of Columbia’s gun-control law. On Tuesday, the court will consider whether that decision should apply everywhere in the country, not just in the federal territory of the nation’s capital.

headline: Reform, on Ice
text: President Obama gave immigration reform only one vague sentence in his State of the Union address. Despite that, and the poisonous stalemate on Capitol Hill, the White House and Democratic Congressional leaders insist that they are still committed to presenting a comprehensive reform bill this year  one that would clamp down on the border and workplace, streamline legal immigration and bring 12 million illegal immigrants out of the shadows.

headline: An Essential Fix
text: The recession dealt a devastating blow to the post-Katrina rebuilding effort in the Gulf states, where scores of affordable housing projects have been placed in jeopardy. Congress can revive the rebuilding effort by extending the deadline for a tax credit program that is supposed to encourage developers and investors to take on these desperately needed projects.

headline: Living With the Haunting Memories of War
text: To the Editor:

headline: Connecting Without Clicks
text: To the Editor:

headline: Toxins and Autism
text: To the Editor:

headline: Marquette Looks to Catch Its Breath at Home
text: Louisville (19-10, 10-6 Big East) at Marquette (19-9, 10-6)

headline: Nazi Film Still Pains Relatives
text: In the history of the cinema, the German director Veit Harlan occupies an especially ignominious position. It is his name that is attached to “Jew Süss,” perhaps the most notoriously anti-Semitic movie ever made, a box office success in Nazi Germany in 1940 that was so effective that it was made required viewing for all members of the SS.

headline: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Back From the Olympics With a Detroit Win
text: It’s always an anticlimax to return to the everyday grind of the N.H.L. after the unrelenting drama of the Winter Games — especially after this year’s unbelievable Olympic final. But return we must, with one game to ease us back in. Home team listed first:

headline: Clijsters Plays on With New Priorities
text: Kim Clijsters did not play a single match on tour in February after her disastrous  and somewhat inexplicable  loss to Nadia Petrova in the third round of the Australian Open. Had it occurred five years earlier, Clijsters would probably have been on the next flight to a smaller event in Memphis, Dubai or Paris to regain her form.

headline: Winning the Peace in Marja
text: After pushing into a Taliban enclave in Afghanistan, American forces must gain support among people with a deep suspicion of the central government.

headline: Marcus Thames, Efficient Slugger
text: TAMPA, Fla. – The other day, one of Bill Chuck’s “Nine to Know” e-mail messages popped into my mailbox, and Fact No. 3 seemed too crazy, too outrageous, to be true. But it was.

headline: Barry Hannah, 1942-2010
text: The Oxford (Miss.) Eagle reports that Barry Hannah has died, days before the 17th annual Oxford Conference for the Book. Hannah and his work are the focus of this year’s conference.

headline: A Country Basks in the Glow of a Hockey Gold
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: Fabian Bachrach, 92, Portraitist Who Photographed Kennedy, Dies
text: Fabian Bachrach, a prominent photographer best known for his portrait of a young senator named John Fitzgerald Kennedy, an image that became the official presidential photo after Kennedy’s election and a ubiquitous memorial after his assassination, died on Friday in Newton, Mass. He was 92 and lived in West Newton.

headline: Leno Returns to ‘Tonight Show’ Perch
text: Jay Leno returned to “The Tonight Show” on Monday with a throwback to “The Wizard of Oz” — and maybe also to “Dallas.”

headline: Word of the Day | commandeer
text: commandeer •\ˌkä-mən-ˈdir\• verb

headline: As Photographed by Fabian Bachrach
text: Fabian Bachrach, a prominent photographer best known for his portrait of a young senator named John F. Kennedy, died at 92.

headline: An Insurance Bid That Invites Risk
text: Insurance is supposed to be about protecting against risk. Try telling that to Prudential of Britain, whose audacious $35.5 billion offer for the Asian life insurance business of the American International Group is reminiscent of pre-crisis mega-deals. The takeover will more than double the size of Prudential and make it the most comprehensive pan-Asian insurer. Transformational indeed, but Prudential will have to convince investors that it has not stretched too far.

headline: Dodd Proposes Giving Fed the Task of Consumer Protection
text: WASHINGTON — In an effort to secure Republican support for an overhaul of financial regulations, the chairman of the Senate Banking Committee on Monday proposed giving the Federal Reserve responsibility for protecting consumers from abusive and deceptive financial products.

headline: For Financial Reform, an Endgame, or Just the End?
text: So here’s the situation. We’ve been through the second-worst financial crisis in the history of the world, and we’ve barely begun to recover: 29 million Americans either can’t find jobs or can’t find full-time work. Yet all momentum for serious banking reform has been lost. The question now seems to be whether we’ll get a watered-down bill or no bill at all. And I hate to say this, but the second option is starting to look preferable, Paul Krugman writes  in The New York Times.

headline: News Quiz | March 2, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page.

headline: At Brown, Spotlight on the President’s Role at a Bank
text: Across this quiet quadrangle, behind the wrought iron gates and beyond University Hall, lurks a bogeyman of Wall Street.

headline: Special Delivery to Freedom
text: WHO was Henry Brown? WHO was James Miller McKim?

headline: Buffett Casts a Wary Eye on Bankers
text: Warren Buffet’s annual letter did more than just review how business went last year for Berkshire Hathaway, it took a shot at the fees that drive deal-making. The rewards are skewed to encourage making the deal whether it’s a good idea or not, which means, for the folks advising corporations on the wisdom of mergers and acquisitions, there are usually more good reasons to strike an agreement than to shelve it, The New York Times’s Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in his latest DealBook column.

headline: Shanghai Opens Doors to Financial World
text: Shanghai’s World Expo is expected to be a tourist bonanza, drawing 70 million people between May and October. But with China’s leaders aiming to turn the city into a globally competitive financial capital by 2020, it is also a golden opportunity to start recruiting bankers and barristers to settle down on the banks of the Huangpu River, Julie Makinen reports in The New York Times.

headline: In Private Equity Hunt, Still a Seller’s Market
text: Private equity firms tell investors that the years after recessions offer the best opportunity to make money. This time may be different, Bloomberg News reports.

headline: PanTerra Pockets $4 Million
text: PanTerra Networks, a provider of cloud-based communications software, has landed about $4 million of a planned $6.5 million fund-raising round, VentureBeat reported, citing a regulatory filing.

headline: Awarepoint Picks Up $10 Million
text: Awarepoint, a maker of wireless systems for locating equipment and personnel in hospitals, announced that it had receiveed $10 million in a round led by a new investor,  JAFCO Ventures.

headline: An Insurance Bid That Invites Risk?
text: Insurance is supposed to be about protecting against risk. Try telling that to Prudential of Britain, whose audacious $35.5 billion offer for the Asian life insurance business of the American International Group is reminiscent of pre-crisis mega-deals, Reuters Breakingviews says. The takeover will more than double the size of Prudential and make it the most comprehensive pan-Asian insurer. Transformational indeed, but Prudential will have to convince investors that it has not stretched too far, the publication suggests.

headline: Trusted Counsel?
text: Wall Street gets most of the guff about potential conflicts of interest. But bankers shouldn’t feel too lonely when white-shoed legal advisers like Cravath, Swaine & Moore work alongside them on deals, Reuters Breakingviews says.

headline: California: Second Officer in Shootout Dies
text: Officer Javier Bejar, 28, of the Reedley police, was taken off life support and died Monday, according to the department’s Web site, four days after he and two other officers were wounded when an arson investigation ended in a shootout in Minkler. A Fresno County sheriff’s deputy, Joel Wahlenmaier, died hours after the shootout. The suspect, Rick Liles, is believed to have fatally shot himself. MALIA WOLLAN

headline: China Merchants Issuing $3.2 Billion in Shares
text: China Merchants Bank, the country’s sixth-largest, will start a $3.2 billion rights issue this week to bolster its balance sheet after a lending binge last year, sending its shares up 3 percent, Reuters reported.

headline: China Car Dealer Zhongsheng Defers $1 Billion I.P.O.
text: Zhongsheng Group, a Chinese dealership that provides services for automakers, including Toyota, put off a $1 billion Hong Kong initial public offering on Tuesday, citing volatile market conditions, Reuters reported.

headline: Nasdaq and S.&P. Positive for the Year
text: Wall Street reached a milestone on Monday that had eluded it for some time: two major stock indexes crossed into positive territory for the year.

headline: Dodd Wants Fed to Oversee Consumer Protection
text: In an effort to secure Republican support for an overhaul of financial regulations, the chairman of the Senate Banking Committee on Monday proposed giving the Federal Reserve responsibility for protecting consumers from abusive and deceptive financial products, The New York Times’s Sewell Chan reported.

headline: Obama Has Chance to Reshape Fed Board
text: The vice chairman of the Federal Reserve announced on Monday that he would retire in June, giving President Obama an expanded opportunity to put his stamp on the central bank as it faces a difficult balance between heading off inflation and addressing high levels of unemployment, The New York Times’s Sewell Chan writes.

headline: What’s Your Personal Learning Plan?
text: Some schools are introducing the electronic portfolio as a means for students to create their own academic plans and chart their progress. What would you put in your own portfolio?

headline: G.M. Triples Opel Investment
text: General Motors on Tuesday confirmed that it would more than triple the amount of money it is committing to turn around its Opel and Vauxhall units — and that, in turn, it would ask for less from European governments.

headline: Allied Irish Posts $3.1 Billion Yearly Loss, Its First
text: Allied Irish Banks posted its first full-year net loss ever on Tuesday after being burned by exposure to Ireland’s property market crash, saying the outlook and environment remained extremely challenging, Reuters reported.

headline: Hedge Funds Post Small Gains In February
text: Global hedge funds posted small gains in February as many prominent managers steered clear of stocks and bet against Europe’s common currency, analysts at Bank of America Merrill Lynch said.

headline: Investors Said to Eye £1 Billion Bid for Manchester United
text: A team of British financiers is working on a £1 billion bid for the football club Manchester United, but the club’s owners are not interested in selling, according to British media reports.

headline: Showcase: The Desert Is the Easy Part
text: The oasis of Dirkou in Niger announces itself as a taste in the air long before it appears. For the Italian photojournalist Alfredo Bini and a convoy of migrants crossing the Ténéré desert last April, this change in humidity was a taste of hope.

headline: U.S. Monitoring Banks’ Sovereign Risk Exposures
text: U.S. regulators are closely monitoring banks’ exposures to sovereign debt risk, the comptroller of the currency, John Dugan, told Reuters on Monday.

headline: Anthera’s Stock Rises in Debut After Price Cut
text: Shares of the drug developer Anthera Pharmaceuticals rose slightly in their market debut Monday after the company cut the price of its initial public offering, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Slim Is ‘Happy’ With Times Company Stake
text: It seems that Carlos Slim Helú has no plans to buy The New York Times Company, despite rumors Monday that the Mexican billionaire was looking to buy the newspaper publisher.

headline: Diageo Plans $900 Million Bid for China Drinks Firm
text: Diageo says it might spend at least £624 million to take over China’s fourth-largest spirits group, Sichuan Shui Jing Fang, and add Chinese white spirits to its portfolio of top brands, Reuters reported.

headline: F.D.I.C. Said to Plan $1.8 Billion Debt Sale
text: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation is planning to sell $1.8 billion of guaranteed asset-backed debt, according to I.F.R., in what may be a step toward restoring confidence in securities closely tied to the financial collapse, Reuters reported.

headline: Yin Hun Zu
text: Chinese term – “married-concealed group” – used to describe young marrieds, usually women, who hide their wedded status for the good of their career.

headline: Andreessen Pushes Document Service for Start-Ups
text: Raising money shouldn’t cost so much money.

headline: Canon Says It’s Still Short of Target in Oce Bid
text: Canon of Japan said it had acquired or been tendered 71 percent of Oce‘s shares in a takeover bid for the Dutch printer maker that closed Monday, short of its target of 85 percent.

headline: A Gallery Brings London’s Grit to Paris
text: Paris and London might be a tunnel away from each other, but it often seems there is little dialogue between the two art worlds. One brand-new gallery aims to change that: the Lebenson Gallery in the Marais, which has the sole aim of introducing Parisians to London art.

headline: Sands Says Pennsylvania Casino Isn’t on the Block
text: Las Vegas Sands says it isn’t selling its Sands Casino Resort Bethlehem in Pennsylvania, which opened in May, The Associated Press said.

headline: Will Rival Bidders Join the Fray for OSI?
text: Will Astellas Pharma have to contend with rivals bidders in its fight for OSI Pharmaceuticals?

headline: British Banks Said to Flout Darling’s Pressure on Pay
text: The chancellor of the Exchequer, Alistair Darling, urged pay restraint and moderation from British banks — and still they raised compensation, Bloomberg News reports.

headline: The Black Sea: Europe’s New Flashpoint
text: Today’s idea: The Black Sea once again figures as a potential fault line for friction between East and West, both economically and militarily, an analyst writes.

headline: Mandelson Urges Changes in British Takeover Law
text: Britain should reform its takeover rules to ensure firms’ long-term interests are prioritized over short-term financial gains, the government’s business secretary, Peter Mandelson, said in a speech to be delivered late on Monday.

text: It seems that some hedge funds are feeling the love for Pfizer.

text: Allrecipes, which bills itself as “the world’s Number One food site,” has taken its iPhone recipe application and, apologies to Emeril Lagasse, kicked it up a notch.

text: Edward L. Glaeser is an economics professor at Harvard.
