text: Your Jokes | Use the comment link below. To allow others to recommend your jokes, send them one per comment, please:

headline: American Envoys in Beijing to Mend Relations
text: BEIJING — Two senior United States officials arrived in Beijing on Tuesday for meetings aimed at smoothing relations with China after months of economic and political disputes.

headline: For 13th Time, Critic of China’s Government Is Barred From Leaving Country
text: BEIJING — Chinese security agents in Sichuan Province detained Liao Yiwu, a prominent author and critic of the government, as he prepared to fly Monday to a literary festival in Germany, human rights activists said.

headline: Power to the People. And Garbage. And Fences.
text: QAIM, Iraq–In the once lawless and still unruly wilds of Anbar Province, Col. Mark R. Stammer had the equivalent of an election-week skip in his step. A South Dakota native, his booming voice was more West Texas than Black Hills, with the twang of a steel guitar, and he had a message to deliver in the town of Qaim: get out to vote.

headline: Geneva Auto Show: Ferrari HY-KERS Hybrid Concept
text: Introduced on Tuesday: Ferrari HY-KERS Hybrid concept

headline: CF Makes New $4.7 Billion Bid for Terra
text: The fertilizer wars are heating up again.

headline: Today in Business Travel
text: Taxes and Fees Grow for Air TravelersThe fees and taxes on airline tickets are already high, and there are proposals to increase them.

headline: High Winds Add to Runway Closure Headaches at JFK
text: The closure of a main runway at John F. Kennedy International Airport was expected to make travel to New York difficult. High winds on Monday made the experience miserable, as delays for arriving flights were averaging nearly two hours on the first day that the main runway was shut down for a four-month, $376 million project to widen and improve the largest of its four runways. At one point, the airport was down to just one runway, due to the wind.

headline: Sampler: Teen’s Punch May Lead to Deportation, and Tech Museum Troubles
text: Jerry Brown Expected to Announce Candidacy | Jerry Brown, the state’s attorney general, is expected to announce on Tuesday that he is running for governor. If he wins, he will be the oldest governor in California history. Mr. Brown, who turns 72 in April, is a former mayor of Oakland and former governor of California. “It’s not much of a career-builder; it’s more of a career-ender,” he said. “But I feel I could bear that better than the other candidates.” [The New York Times]

headline: Tymoshenko Coalition Collapses in Ukraine
text: MOSCOW — The Orange coalition of Western-leaning political factions in Ukraine’s Parliament disintegrated Tuesday, in what could be the first stage in an effort to unseat Prime Minister Yulia V. Tymoshenko.

headline: Markets Struggle as Trading Day Nears an End
text: Reassurances that Greece would take further steps to trim its deficit helped prop up financial markets on Tuesday. But the day’s gains largely evaporated in the afternoon as concern over unemployment and a possible increase in interest rates resurfaced.

headline: Speed Read For Tuesday, March 2
text: Highlights from media coverage in today’s New York Times:

headline: Quality Time With BlackRock’s Fink, Wall St.’s Gray Eminence
text: Much of Main Street’s attention to Wall Street has been focused on a few well-known executives: Lloyd C. Blankfein of Goldman Sachs, Jamie Dimon of JPMorgan Chase, and so on.

headline: State Told to Change How the Mentally Ill Are Housed
text: New York State must begin moving thousands of people with mental illness into their own apartments or small homes and out of large, institutional adult homes that keep them segregated from society, a federal judge ordered Monday.

headline: Barry Hannah, Southern Author, Dies
text: Barry Hannah, the quintessentially Southern author of “Geronimo Rex” and “High Lonesome,” has died, The Associated Press reported. He was 67 and died on Monday at his home in Oxford, Miss. The Lafayette County coroner told The A.P. that Mr. Hannah died Monday afternoon of “natural causes,” but declined to elaborate until he had provided details to the author’s wife, Susan. The coroner said the death was not under investigation.

headline: Chile Says Rebuilding May Cost Tens of Billions of Dollars
text: SANTIAGO, Chile — As the Chilean government employed helicopters and boats to extend aid to earthquake-battered regions, President Michelle Bachelet on Tuesday began to grapple with the enormous cost of rebuilding the country, saying it could extend into the tens of billions of dollars.

headline: The Early Word: Flying South
text: President Obama takes to the air again today, heading to Georgia for the latest installment in what’s been billed as the “White House to Main Street Tour.”

headline: Rose Gray Remembered
text: The British newspapers are filled this morning with tributes to Rose Gray, the formidable chef and cookbook writer who, with Ruth Rogers, founded the River Café in London, and who died on Sunday at 71. The cause was cancer, Ms. Rogers said.

headline: Bain Capital to Buy Dow Unit for $1.63 Billion
text: Bain Capital said on Tuesday that it had agreed to buy Styron, a Dow Chemical unit that makes plastics and rubber, for $1.63 billion in cash.

headline: Now Bagging | Whitney Biennial Tote
text: For a cultural institution interested in promotional items, the tote bag is king. They are to museums and public radio stations what T-shirts are to rock bands, what bumper stickers are to middle school honor rolls. This limited-edition tote ($98) by Tommy Hilfiger celebrates the just-opened 2010 Whitney Biennial and highlights the work of one of its artists, Ari Marcopoulos. A New York photographer of Dutch extraction and a former assistant to Andy Warhol, Marcopoulos is known for the great lengths he’ll go to to get a picture, whether it’s shadowing the Beastie Boys or chasing snowboarders down the Alps. The image on this tote bag comes from “Detroit,” Marcopoulos’s video piece in the Biennial, about two boys who make electronic music in a small Detroit bedroom using little more than foot effect pedals. Marcopoulos was given an advance copy of the bag, which went on sale Thursday, and he approved of it. “I thought it was going to be a really cheap tote bag,” he said. “But it’s functional. And when I wore it, people on the subway were checking me out.”

headline: Surprise! Taylor Swift Nominated For Five Academy of Country Music Awards
text: She may not be, in the words of the head of her record label, “the best technical singer,” but Taylor Swift will have another opportunity next month to appear astounded by her awards-show largess: she’s been nominated for five Academy of Country Music Awards, including entertainer of the year. The nominations, which were announced on Tuesday morning, were most generous to the Nashville group Lady Antebellum, which picked up seven nominations including album of the year (for its self-titled 2008 release) and top vocal group, as well as single record of the year, song of the year and video of the year for “Need You Now.” Miranda Lambert is nominated for six awards, as is Carrie Underwood, the academy’s reigning entertainer of the year, who is once again nominated in that category. Kenny Chesney picked up four nominations, as did Brad Paisley and the Zac Brown Band. The winners will be announced at a ceremony in Las Vegas on April 18.

headline: Geneva Auto Show: Porsche 918 Spyder Plug-In Hybrid
text: Introduced on Tuesday: Porsche 918 Spyder concept

headline: Samurai Shopper | Age of Enlightenment
text: The Samurai Shopper, though possessed of boundless wisdom, is afflicted with a waggish skepticism — chalk it up to experience. I had to abandon the passionate energies and utter stupidity of youth. There wasn’t a choice; birthdays happened. I do miss my younger self, especially the part where I awoke each morning looking radiantly fresh, like a shiny penny in a mud puddle. Now it takes many, many shiny pennies to find illumination, which mainly comes from skin-care counters. Like the Doge’s Palace in Venice, my exterior has borne the insults of time and seeks restoration to the alabaster glory that once was me. Besides, bright people don’t deserve dull skin.

headline: $15 Billion but Not a Lot of Sense
text: The Senate has passed a $15 billion package that is aimed at helping small businesses. There are two key parts. One is the extension of section 179 of the tax code, which allows up to $250,000 of capital expenditures to be expensed immediately instead of being depreciated over time. This will motivate some companies to make capital expenditures that will reduce their tax bills, which is good for the economy. The other part is the suspension of FICA payments for the rest of the year for new hires.

headline: The Palm Pre Plus Creates a Hot Spot
text: Fortunately, when my Internet went dead I had just set up the new Palm Pre Plus from Verizon. Fortunately, I say, because the Plus can act as a wireless hot spot. I used it to temporarily replace my Wi-Fi network and was able to connect my desktop and laptop to the Internet through the phone.

headline: Bits Scan: Pirate Bay, the Internet River and a Google Patent
text: Good morning, Bits readers. It’s Tuesday, and although the weather in New York is mostly cloudy, our technology news is not:

headline: Freakout-nomics
text: If you think conservatives are freaking out over the growing prospects that health care reform will, in fact, happen, wait until you see the freakout over climate change.

headline: Launching a Rocket That Becomes a Boomerang
text: Those of us who have written something freakishly mean — we are legion in an age of snark — and then come to gnaw the bone of regret can identify with Will Leitch. Writing at Deadspin, Mr. Leitch walks back the cat on a  missile he launched long ago at Roger Ebert that was entitled, more or less, “I Am Sick of Roger Ebert’s Fat (something even more nasty and less descriptive) Face.” Mr. Ebert, perhaps the most famous film critic of our age, has lost his voice and part of his face to thyroid cancer and was recently profiled in Esquire to very remarkable effect. Now that Mr. Ebert’s face is no longer fat, Mr. Letich has had time to contemplate his choice of targets — Mr. Ebert had shown him significant professional courtesies over the years — and writes about what it was like to use his keyboard to do something really dumb.

headline: G.M. Triples Opel Investment
text: Under pressure from European governments, General Motors said Tuesday that it would more than triple the amount of money it was committing to turn around its Opel and Vauxhall units while scaling back its request for public loan guarantees, Jack Ewing reports in The New York Times.

headline: Crime and (Fitting) Punishment
text: Not that Hollywood isn’t adept at coming up with its own punishments – what was that latest Michael Bay movie? – but over at Movieline, the Bagger’s pal Mark Lisanti serves up some potential penalties for Nicolas Chartier, the overeager “Hurt Locker” producer who offended the Academy with an e-mail message dissing the (unnamed) competition, “so that we can all get back to the important business of celebrating the underappreciated millionaires toiling in the obscurity of history’s most glamorous industry.” (Hear hear!)

headline: Things You Could Have Watched Instead of Jay Leno
text: Yes, yes, we’re aware that Jay Leno‘s return on Monday night to “The Tonight Show” desk he vacated in May was the most important event in broadcasting since Edward R. Murrow covered the Blitz of London. Assuming you were so caught up in Mr. Leno’s re-debut that you forgot to watch any other late-night television, what did you miss?

headline: Disinflation in Recessions
text: Tim Duy is right — the Fed, and equally importantly the ECB, is seriously underestimating the deflationary danger.

headline: Gowanus Canal Gets Superfund Status
text: The Environmental Protection Agency designated the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn a Superfund site on Tuesday and announced plans to clean up more than a century’s worth of noxious pollutants there.

headline: U.S. Considers Brake Override System
text: The Obama administration may recommend that carmakers install a brake override system that is intended to prevent the sudden acceleration episodes that have led to recalls of millions of Toyotas, the transportation secretary, Ray LaHood, said on Tuesday.

headline: ‘Everything is Perfect’
text: Monologue |  Monday night on “The Late Show With David Letterman” on CBS: Weren’t the Winter Olympics fantastic? The U.S. won a gold medal in downhill economy.

headline: ‘He Often Turned to Prayer’
text: Monologue |  Monday night on “The Jay Leno Show” on NBC: Well, as you may have heard, former Vice President Dick Cheney is doing fine after suffering his fifth heart attack. He is like the Apolo Ohno of heart attacks.

headline: Gowanus Canal Named Superfund Site
text: The federal Environmental Protection Agency announced Tuesday that it was designating the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn a contaminated Superfund site, paving the way for a cleanup of decades-old pollution there. The decision comes as a blow to the Bloomberg administration, which had proposed a cleanup that would avoid such a designation. (See full article.)

headline: Apple Sues Phone Maker HTC Over Patents
text: 11:16 a.m. | Updated  Added response from HTC and a link to the legal documents.

headline: Being Ready, in Quake Zones or Snow Zones
text: Nearly every person on the planet lives in a hazard zone of some sort, with the possibility of a severe storm or shaking ground or bomb or some other disturbance disrupting daily life for many days, if not weeks. Having the capacity, as a household and community, to respond and get by without help for a while is vital. A lot of resilience is afforded through a little planning and investment.

headline: NOW Calls for Paterson to Resign
text: A leading women’s rights group that had once praised Gov. David A. Paterson for his work on violence against women is now seeking his resignation, saying his intervention in a domestic violence case involving a top adviser was inappropriate and disappointing.

headline: After Recalls, Toyota Offers Incentives to Win Back Wary Customers
text: Toyota Motor, estimating that it lost 18,000 sales in the United States last month while its chief competitors enjoyed big gains, introduced incentives Tuesday as it tried to restore consumers’ confidence in its vehicles after three big recalls.

headline: Tuesday Reading
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: TV Watch: A Triumphant Return, Filled With Insecurity
text: Richard M. Nixon may have staged a more elaborate comeback when he resurfaced in 1968 as “the new Nixon,” but it’s hard to recall a more labored victory lap than Jay Leno’s return to “The Tonight Show” on Monday night.

headline: Greece Set to Release Austerity Plan
text: ATHENS — The Greek government will announce new austerity measures on Wednesday aimed at raising additional money to help curb its bloated budget deficit and avert a debt crisis in the euro zone, a government spokesman said Tuesday.

headline: Wrestling With Whisper Campaigns
text: There are mere hours to go until the Oscar polls close, which means all that dirty pool better have done its job by now. Like most sane people, the Bagger doubted that anybody would stoop to whisper campaigns or scare tactics in pursuit of a little gold man, but apparently both are perennial awards-race fixtures. Though he said he was too busy finishing his movie “Black Swan” to pay attention to the Oscar machinations this season (he did vote, however), the director Darren Aronofsky recently clued the Bagger into what he went through when he was promoting “The Wrestler” last year. “There was some Web sites spreading this thing about how a hundred people had walked out of a screening because of the violence,” Mr. Aronofsky said. “Maybe that happened, I have no idea. What people told me is it didn’t happen, or like three people walked out and they were all over 70 or something, which is understandable because the film was very violent. But it got picked up and spread around.”

headline: U.S. Children: Generation Snack
text: Parents are raising a generation of snackers — kids who eat almost constantly throughout the day as they graze on cookies, salty snacks and fruit drinks.

headline: Tailgating Outside the Supreme Court, Without the Cars
text: WASHINGTON — Mike Sacks likes to be the first person in line for big Supreme Court arguments, and he was feeling pretty confident when he arrived at the court Monday morning around 8, 26 hours before the court would hear a big gun control case.

headline: 8 Hurt in Fire in Criminal Court Building
text: Updated, 3:05 p.m. | A two-alarm fire broke out in the basement of the Manhattan Criminal Courthouse around 10:30 Tuesday morning. At least eight people sustained minor injuries, the Fire Department said: five firefighters, two civilians and one prisoner.

headline: Mickey Mouse Fashion
text: You flew all the way down here from New York just to come to this place?” says the guy behind the counter at the Marni outlet in Orlando, Fla., incredulous that two women of seemingly reasonable intelligence — this would be me and my friend Laura — would travel a thousand miles to chase a bargain on a saggy sack dress or a cashmere sweater with elbow patches.

headline: Geneva Auto Show: 2011 Alfa Romeo Giulietta
text: Introduced on Tuesday: 2011 Alfa Romeo Giulietta

headline: Testing the Republican Waters
text: Mortimer B. Zuckerman, publisher of The Daily News, put his toe in the water for the Senate seat in New York and apparently found the temperature to his liking. A story in The Albany Times Union (thanks to Politico for the point) reports that Edward F. Cox, chairman of the Republican Party in New York, has heard from a number of people interested in the seat, including Mr. Zuckerman.

headline: Are Tax Refund Splurges Starting to Come Back?
text: Many Americans used last year’s tax refunds to pay down debt or save for the future. Now, it appears that more plan to spend their tax refunds on big splurges once again.

headline: Microsoft R.&D. Celebrates the Human Body
text: When it comes to R.&D. eye candy, Microsoft is king.

headline: Study Finds Cohabiting Doesn’t Make a Union Last
text: Couples who live together before they get married are less likely to stay married, a new study has found. But their chances improve if they were already engaged when they began living together.

headline: Horror Rappers Angered by ‘Law & Order’ Episode
text: We thought we were discouraged because we had missed Monday’s episode of “Law & Order,” which promised to center on the subculture of Juggalos, the fans of the hip-hop duo Insane Clown Posse who paint their faces like nightmare versions of children’s entertainers. But the episode, called “Steel-Eyed Death,” was an even greater disappointment to the members of the horrorcore music world, who say the show misrepresented them and their musical scene.

headline: Fast Forward to Old Age, Please
text: THE other night at 3 a.m., I was in bed and my husband was frying a couple of eggs on my belly, and I shrieked, “Flip, flip!” and he turned onto his stomach, and I said, “No, not you, the eggs.”

headline: Crudup to Star in ‘The Metal Children’
text: The actor Billy Crudup, whose last major New York performance won him a Tony Award, for Tom Stoppard’s “The Coast of Utopia” during the 2006-07 season, will star in the world premiere production of Adam Rapp’s play “The Metal Children” at the Vineyard Theater in May.

headline: Job Blizzard Watch
text: Last week, I wrote about the potential for blizzard-related February job losses to derail the Democrats’ economic agenda, including their proposed health care overhaul. Goldman Sachs economists now estimate that, when the February jobs report is released this Friday, it will show a decline of 100,000 payroll jobs. Macroeconomic Advisers is predicting that the blizzard claimed between 150,000 and 220,000 jobs.

headline: Beltran Says He Referred Reyes to Galea for Treatment
text: The federal investigation of the Canadian-based doctor Anthony Galea continued to take on a distinct New York tone on Tuesday as the third Met or Yankee in three days acknowledged that he had been contacted or interviewed by the authorities in connection with Galea’s activities.

headline: Junk Food Taxes?
text: Here’s a terrific piece by Tom Laskawy on junk food taxes vs. good food subsidies.

headline: A Novelist-Mother Writes to Calm Her Fears
text: Jodi Picoult writes to protect herself from her fears. Her stories of imperfect mothers — always mothers — struggling to protect their children in a dangerous world are her way of warding off the demons.

headline: Beyond the Grill | Gold Teeth
text: Avant-garde fashion finds inspiration in many quarters, but few designers have been willing to tackle, um, dentistry. Enter the retainer necklace by Jules Kim of Bijules NYC, with its single protruding gold tooth — it would never be “accidentally” thrown away with a lunch tray in the junior high cafeteria. Kim created it especially for her roommate, the fashion photographer Brooke Nipar, who had lost a tooth in a bar fight; she cast it in gold and hung it from a detachable chain so that Nipar could pop it in her mouth or wear it around her neck with pride. Meanwhile, the London artist William Hunt has created a limited-edition set of silver cuff links made from casts of the wisdom teeth he had removed as a “performance” in art school. The three Six Six Six girls, whose macabre design line is named Triskaidekaphobia after the fear of the number 13, offer spiky silver bangles and slinky pendants sculptured from metal baby teeth; the San Francisco gothic brand Loved to Death offers actual human baby teeth set in gold, Victorian-inspired settings. And Dominic Jones’s yellow gold shark fangs interspersed with gold rose thorns are just begging for someone to take a nibble.

headline: ‘Venus in Fur’ May Transfer to Broadway
text: The theater producer Robert Fox, who is known for a sure touch with mounting intimate, small-cast plays on Broadway, is exploring the possibility of transferring the Classic Stage Company’s production of “Venus in Fur” to a Broadway house, Mr. Fox said on Tuesday.

headline: There She Goes (Again), Miss America
text: Once one of the nation’s most desirable singles, Miss America is unattached again and it’s not immediately clear who will pick her up off her feet. On Monday, the cable channel TLC became the latest television broadcaster to drop the long-running Miss America Pageant, Reuters reported. In a statement, TLC said that it was happy to have been “part of the modernization and revitalization of the Miss America Pageant” but was declining to renew its contract to show the event.

headline: A Day at the Arcade for the Yankees
text: TAMPA, Fla. — Repeating as World Series champions is one thing. But far be it from Joe Girardi to select the same activity as last year for the Yankees’ team-building outing Tuesday. Eschewing a return trip to a pool hall, Girardi sent his players and coaches to a local video arcade, where they are competing in three popular games: IndyCar racing, Skee-Ball and Pop-a-Shot basketball. Winners of each competition will receive gift certificates.

headline: Our Contest Winner Claims Her Prize
text: In December, we published newly digitized images of the manuscript for Charles Dickens’s classic tale, “A Christmas Carol.” Readers were invited to spot additions or deletions made to the text by the author just before the story was published in 1843. As a reward for submitting the best response, Hilary Johnson of Mount Vernon, N.Y., was invited for tea at the Morgan Library and Museum with Alison Leigh Cowan, a reporter for The New York Times. Here, Ms. Johnson recalls some observations of her visit.

headline: Senator Relents, and Jobless Bill Passes
text: WASHINGTON — The Senate ended a politically charged impasse over unemployment pay on Tuesday night, voting to allow jobless Americans in danger of exhausting their benefits another month of aid.

headline: Obama to Make Statement, Not Speech, on Health Care
text: President Obama is likely to make a statement at the White House on Wednesday about moving forward with health care legislation, rather than give a speech elsewhere in Washington, D.C., as had been announced on Monday, his spokesman, Robert Gibbs, said.

headline: Life With a Pouch on the Side
text: I’ve got a little plastic secret.

headline: Texas Mother ‘Ecstatic’ About Posthumous Pardon for Wrongfully Convicted Son
text: As The Lubbock Avalanche-Journal reported, on Monday Gov. Rick Perry signed the first posthumous pardon ever issued by the state of Texas, officially clearing a man who had been wrongfully convicted of rape in 1986. The pardon came more than a decade after the man, Tim Cole, died in prison at the age of 39 from complications after an asthma attack, and two years after DNA evidence proved that another man had committed the crime.

headline: Geneva Auto Show: Cadillac Returns to Europe With New Strategy
text: GENEVA – General Motors announced in February that it would create Cadillac Europe to manage import, distribution and marketing of the brand in Europe. At the Geneva auto show this week, the company elaborated on its plans, saying it was hoping to eventually sell only 3,000 cars a year through about 50 dealers.

headline: More on the Bunning Benefits Blockade
text: Carl Hulse files the latest news from Capitol Hill on the impasse over jobless benefits engineered by Senator Jim Bunning, Republican of Kentucky.

headline: Mashing Up the Navi
text: As the Carpetbagger notes, we are deep into the silly season, with Oscar campaigning now veering into a debate over the military efficacy of “Hurt Locker.” The scurrilous tactics rarely change the outcome, so we prefer to walk on the sunny side of the awards season. To wit, when we first saw “Avatar,” it put us in the mind of “Dances with Wolves,” but the Internet has spoken and the designated analogue is actually “Pocahontas,” with a series of the inevitable mash-ups quickly following. But none, as Awards Daily points out, match this one for sheer brilliance of juxtaposition:

text: This low-resolution video promo posted online by Roberta’s Pizzeria in Bushwick is a masterpiece, 2 minutes 18 seconds of the kind of acting, lighting and captioning that would do public-access TV proud. Nothing like those slick restaurant commercials you get on broadcast TV.

headline: ABT to Present Ratmansky’s ‘Bright Stream’ in Washington
text: “The curious specialty of the choreographer Alexei Ratmansky is to envision a 20th-century Soviet Union that might have been, the land that composers once dreamed of optimistically,” Alastair Macaulay wrote last year about the work of Mr. Ratmansky, the Russian artist. Mr. Ratmansky will have the chance to present that vision again, in 2011. American Ballet Theater has announced that it will present the company premiere of Mr. Ratmansky’s production of “The Bright Stream” on Jan. 21, 2011, at the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington. The comic two-act narrative ballet about members of a Russian farm collective in the 1930s, set to music by Shostakovich, was first staged by Mr. Ratmansky for the Bolshoi in 2003. The original production was choreographed by Fyodor Lopukhov and first performed in 1935 in Leningrad. The ballet will also be performed during the company’s spring season at the Metropolitan Opera House, which will run from May 16 through July 9, 2011. Mr. Ratmansky joined American Ballet Theater as Artist in Residence in January 2009.

headline: Time Out for Good Behavior
text: We interrupt the usual stream of disturbing news  which includes Tiger Woods’s emergence from “family therapy,” the New Mexico basketball coach Steve Alford’s being reprimanded for yelling at an opposing player, and Alex Rodriguez’s latest dabbling with the truth in baseball doping issues  to announce that it is National Sportsmanship Day.

headline: Scramble in Chile to Save Quake Victims
text: Three days after an 8.8-magnitude earthquake devastated the city of Concepcion, Chile, the race is on to rescue survivors trapped under rubble.

headline: A New Kindergarten Doesn’t Silence Old Complaints

headline: Lil Wayne Sentencing Is Postponed Again
text: Eventually, the Rolling Stone cover line “Lil Wayne Goes to Jail” will be correct, but not today. On Tuesday a court spokesman in Manhattan told The Associated Press that sentencing for the rapper Lil Wayne had been postponed because of a basement fire at a courthouse.

headline: Greek Troubles Trip Euro, to E.U. Exporters’ Relief
text: The European Commission has told Greece it will have to undertake additional austerity measures it it was to cut its deficit by 4 percentage points, to just under 9 percent of its gross domestic product.

headline: Rose Gray, a Master of Italian Fare, Is Dead at 71
text: Rose Gray, a founder and chef of the River Café in London, a restaurant that transformed the image of Italian cooking in Britain by emphasizing fresh ingredients and authentic country dishes, died Sunday at her home in London. She was 71.

headline: Now Carrying | Steven Alan’s Got a Brand New Bag
text: Steven Alan has a thing for basics. Or, as the New York-based designer puts it, “the perfect ‘blank.’ ” The perfect flannel shirt. The perfect five-pocket jeans. And now the perfect bag. Alan’s latest design is a waxed cotton and leather carry-on valise he created for V Australia, an offshoot of Virgin Airlines. You can hear all about the trip the airline sent Alan on for inspiration — Sydney, the Great Barrier Reef, the Daintree River — but for a designer obsessed with essentials, the real force behind the bag was simple: Where do you put your laptop and your laundry? And how can you wear it like a backpack without it looking like a backpack?

headline: Investigators Are Told of Paterson Bid to Quiet Accuser
text: A key figure in the domestic abuse scandal bedeviling Gov. David A. Paterson told investigators that the governor phoned her to enlist her help in quieting the accuser, according to a person with knowledge of her account.

headline: Building a Better Teacher
text: ON A WINTER DAY five years ago, Doug Lemov realized he had a problem. After a successful career as a teacher, a principal and a charter-school founder, he was working as a consultant, hired by troubled schools eager — desperate, in some cases — for Lemov to tell them what to do to get better. There was no shortage of prescriptions at the time for how to cure the poor performance that plagued so many American schools. Proponents of No Child Left Behind saw standardized testing as a solution. President Bush also championed a billion-dollar program to encourage schools to adopt reading curriculums with an emphasis on phonics. Others argued for smaller classes or more parental involvement or more state financing.

headline: Delaware Broadens Standards for Poison Pills
text: The long-awaited opinion in the Selectica case came out this week from Delaware Chancery Court. Vice Chancellor John W. Noble, in the 71-page opinion, validated the Selectica board’s decision to adopt a net operating loss poison pill and permit this pill to be set off after Versata intentionally crossed the pill’s threshold.

Excellent timing: we were just working on a post about reckless drunks. Apparently acting like one is a quick route to Oscar glory, as Tom O’Neil notes on The Los Angeles Times Gold Derby blog.

text: Let the Leno-Letterman jousting resume. Jay Leno’s return to “The Tonight Show” Monday was watched by about 6.6 million viewers, according to early Nielsen ratings, up about 25 percent from his average viewership in the first quarter last year.

headline: Labor Jumps Into Arkansas Senate Race
text: Organized labor rarely supports challengers to sitting Democrats, but the A.F.L.-C.I.O. announced on Tuesday that it was so dissatisfied with Senator Blanche Lincoln, a Democrat from Arkansas, that it had endorsed Lt. Gov. Bill Halter of Arkansas. He is challenging her from the left in the May 18 Democratic primary.

headline: White House Response to Stimulus Criticisms
text: In a post this morning titled “Wasted Stimulus,” the economist Edward L. Glaeser argued that a big chunk of stimulus spending wasn’t going to the areas that needed it most. Rather, he said, the money is being disproportionately spent on low-density areas that also happen to have low unemployment rates. Jared Bernstein, the chief economic adviser to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., has responded to Mr. Glaeser’s arguments.

headline: Two Earthquakes in Two Months: Comparing the Quakes in Haiti and Chile
text: Overview | How do the earthquakes in Chile and Haiti compare? In this lesson, students perform a gallery walk to learn more about the earthquakes from a specific standpoint, and then do a specific research and presentation project or response activity. Finally, they seek answers to their lingering unanswered questions.

headline: California Ex-Governor Announces Encore Run
text: SAN FRANCISCO — If Attorney General Jerry Brown, who formally announced his candidacy for governor of California on Tuesday, is to succeed in his efforts to return to the job he held for eight years, he will have to convince an angry electorate that a career politician is the right choice at a time when voters here — and nationwide — seem to have little patience for that particular breed.

headline: Real Estate Separation for Jann Wenner and Wife
text: Jann S. Wenner, the founder of Rolling Stone, has been separated from his wife, Jane Wenner, for many years, but recent real estate transactions suggest that the couple may finally be headed toward a more formal parting of the ways.

headline: Mother’s Next Act: Broadway

headline: Grass Fed | Wear Your Beets
text: Last summer, I picked up an album called “Spit in the Face of People Who Don’t Want to Be Cool” by a band called the Beets, mainly because they were from Queens and because I liked the cover art. And because I have a record-buying problem. And possibly because of the food connection. But, honestly, I don’t buy records because they’ve got food on them, or else I’d own some Joy of Cooking albums and would’ve let myself get that “Northern Rocks Bear Weird Vegetable” LP that came out on Sacred Bones Records last year.
