headline: U.S. Plans New Measure for Poverty
text: The federal government announced on Tuesday that it would begin producing an experimental measurement of poverty next year, a step toward the first overhaul of the formula since it was developed nearly a half-century ago by an obscure civil servant in the Social Security Administration.

headline: A Widening Scandal for Governor Paterson
text: Carolyn Ryan, deputy metro editor of The Times, discusses the governor's role in an abuse case involving an aide.

headline: U.N. Official Condemns Gaza Blockade
text: GAZA — The senior United Nations official for humanitarian relief took a tour of Gaza on Tuesday, a year after Israel’s war here, and declared keen concern for what he called the collective punishment of 1.5 million Palestinians due to the blockade enforced by Israel and Egypt.

headline: WTA Sees New Frontier Online and in China
text: Eight months after taking over as chief executive of the WTA Tour, Stacey Allaster came to New York for an exhibition between two of her marquee players — the Billie Jean King Cup at Madison Square Garden — and was happy to be bearing a heartening lack of bad news.

headline: A Blogger in the Senate?
text: It seems that Mickey Kaus, one of the deans of the blogosphere, is going to challenge Barbara Boxer in California’s Democratic primary. I fearlessly predict that he will lose, but I hope he acquits himself well enough (or at least entertainingly enough) to encourage more pundits and policy wonks to throw their hats into the political ring. We’ve reached a point in American life where the line between celebrities, television personalities and politicians is tissue-thin. But when non-politicians who actually know something about policy — be they political journalists, think-tankers or public intellectuals — get involved in government, it’s almost always as spokespeople, speechwriters and policy advisers, rather than as actual candidates for office. National Review’s Rich Lowry flirted with a bid for New York mayor in 2001, and there was a brief “Lawrence Lessig for Congress” boomlet in 2008, but both Lowry and Lessig ultimately decided against running. And there’s certainly no current American equivalent of Britain’s Boris Johnson, the magazine-editor-turned-Tory M.P.-turned-Mayor-of-London — or Michael Ignatieff, the historian, essayist and academic who’s now the leader of Canada’s Liberal Party.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Tuesday, March 2
text: It is an incongruously wry image from a ravaged land: two world leaders presenting a nearly symmetrical picture as they prepared to embrace in Santiago. (That sense of seing two sides of a coin simultaneously is heightened subtly by the bilateral evergreen in the background.) But a real measure of Chileans’ anguish can be seen in Slide 3, by Pilar Olivares of Reuters, as Salome Tomita identified her son among the earthquake victims laid out at a gymnasium in Constitución.

headline: G.M. Goes Back to the Organizational Drawing Board
text: While the leaner General Motors that emerged from bankruptcy has made progress, G.M.’s president, Mark Reuss, sees room for improvement. Consequently, he has made sweeping changes to G.M. North America’s organizational chart. He said his goals are to eliminate layers and allow managers to focus on their specialty, while positioning himself closer to the customer.

headline: 400,000 Will Lose Jobless Benefits Next Week
text: An estimated 400,000 Americans will lose their unemployment benefits in the next week if Congress does not reauthorize unemployment insurance extensions, the Labor Department said in a statement.

headline: A Troubled Shop Reopens, With Stipulations
text: Joseph Malewich will readily admit that he is not a bike guy. His passion lately has been for inventions, he said, such as a small face shield that mounts on a machine gun, made from military-grade titanium.

headline: Supreme Court Still Divided on Guns
text: WASHINGTON — At least five justices appeared poised to expand the scope of the Second Amendment’s protection of the right to bear arms on Tuesday, judging from comments at an unusually intense Supreme Court argument.

headline: Men and Women Suffer Different Travel Illnesses
text: Women and men are prone to different illnesses when traveling abroad, according to a new study published in the March 15 issue of Clinical Infectious Diseases.

headline: For One Week, ‘Idol’ Flips Male and Female Performances
text: “American Idol” viewers who have been looking forward to the return performances of its 10 remaining female contestants (perhaps to help them forget about the 10 remaining male contestants) will have to wait one more night: on Tuesday, Fox said that the show’s male semifinalists will instead perform tonight and the female semifinalists will take the stage on Wednesday’s show.

headline: The Blackout as Revelation
text: In 1965, the lights went out from Ontario to the Eastern Seaboard. Prisoners rioted. Riders trapped in elevators and subway cars took to singing in the blackness. At La Guardia, one runway remained illuminated by a water-powered generator, its solitary glow calling to the sky like the last candle in the last window of all of New York. Streetlamps flickered out, trains slowed to a stop, and a quiet filled the air as the people of Gotham gathered at their windows to reflect upon their still and moonlit city. The birth rate, nine months later, spiked.

headline: You Can’t Weatherproof a Flight
text: AS thousands of passengers who were caught up in last month’s bout of snowstorms along the East Coast can attest, finding a new flight after a major weather cancellation is getting not only harder, but more complex.

headline: Hiking Deep Into Dogon Country in Mali
text: A DRY, biting wind swept in from the Sahara as my young guide, David Dolo; my driver, Mahmadou; and I followed a local animist priest up a rocky trail in Dogon country in central Mali. Below us, the village of Hombori stretched across the yellow plain; above, I could make out hollows in the sandstone cliff face  natural grottoes used as burial chambers for more than a thousand years. After trudging for a half-hour up the punishing cliffside path, we stopped before a cave from which emanated a musty smell. I peered inside at a dozen grinning skulls and, behind them, piles of bones, shreds of clothing, and amulets and totems placed there centuries ago.

headline: 36 Hours in Palm Beach, Fla.
text: PALM BEACHERS may have tightened their Gucci belts in the wake of the Bernard Madoff scandal. The Ponzi scheme cleaned out some local bank accounts, and the recession curtailed the lust for Limoges and other such items. Still, judging by the perfectly clipped hedges that envelop the manicured mansions, residents may be doing with less, but not much less. The tiny island, north of Fort Lauderdale on Florida’s east coast, still boasts some of the country’s dreamiest estates, where the staff lives better than many Americans, cashmere sweaters in trademark pastel greens and pinks go for $800, and Rolls-Royces show up at Publix with regularity in a town where more is never quite enough.

headline: Restaurant Review: Whiskey Soda Lounge in Portland, Ore.
text: At Whiskey Soda Lounge, in Portland’s southeast corner, Asian surf rock blares and psychedelic orange lampshades cast a surreal glow, but it’s the food that’s most striking. Small plates of aahaan kap klaem  Thai pub snacks  arrive one after the next, covering tiny tables, along with potent beverages to wash them down. Here, that means house-brewed fruit vinegars mixed with bracing spirits in concoctions like the Hunny, a cocktail of tequila, grapefruit juice, lime and honey-flavored drinking vinegar ($8). Pair that with Ike’s Vietnamese Fish Sauce Wings ($12), and its salty-sweet, almost caramelized coating, and you have the world’s perfect bar food.

headline: Hotel Review: Aria Resort and Casino in Las Vegas
text: THE BASICS

headline: Tuscany Without the Crowds
text: IT was a cold, foggy morning in Tuscany, and La Foce, a 15th-century villa that sits on 2,000 acres of rolling fields overlooking the storied Montepulciano vineyards, was eerily quiet.

headline: Where Centro Parties at Night
text: UNTIL recently, there was one sound you could count on hearing every night at sundown in Centro, Mexico City’s historic district: the grind of metal gates descending, as stores and restaurants closed. Anyone brave enough to stroll the area at night would have a hard time distinguishing a taquería from a cantina, let alone finding one open for business.

headline: Regulators Reviewing Owner of Derby Favorite Over Loans
text: Kentucky and New York racing regulators are reviewing whether Ahmed Zayat, owner of the early Kentucky Derby favorite Eskendereya, has jeopardized his license to race in those states because of loans he made to two convicted bookmakers.

headline: Buenos Aires for Those Who Shun Steaks
text: IT was over a bowl of delicious, spicy-sweet peanut soup with pesto made from huacatay, or Andean black mint, that I realized the vegetarian diner was now perfectly welcome in Buenos Aires. As a vegetarian traveling in a country where beef takes center stage, I expected my meals to be relegated to an assortment of side dishes  sautéed greens, some variation of potatoes  supplemented by the occasional granola bar. For many, myself included, the diet is not just a daily choice, but a way of life. I am a practicing Jain  a member of an ancient Indian religion that espouses ahimsa, or nonviolence toward all living beings  and my diet forbids all meat, poultry, fish and even eggs, though it does allow milk and cheese.

headline: GMAC’s Chief Gets Payout Comparable to Blankfein’s
text: GMAC, the money-losing auto and real estate lender that was bailed out by the government, awarded its chief executive, Michael A. Carpenter, a pay package comparable in size to the one given to Lloyd C. Blankfein, the chief executive at the highly profitable Goldman Sachs, Bloomberg News reports.

headline: Geneva Auto Show: Hyundai i-Flow
text: Introduced on Tuesday: Hyundai i-Flow concept

headline: Angels Are Different, but Are They Better?
text: TEMPE, Ariz. — Before Tuesday, I had not been to Tempe Diablo Stadium in 11 years. Since then, the Angels have added a lot of championship flags above the windows of the suites behind home plate.

headline: Comebacker Shortens Dessens’s Outing
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — It took the Mets only seven outs into their Grapefruit League season to record their first injury.

headline: Making Broadway Accessible for the Disabled
text: The next time you complain about not being able to see the stage from the nosebleed sections of a Broadway theater, think about not being able to see the stage at all.

headline: Geneva Auto Show: Pininfarina 2uettottanta
text: Introduced on Tuesday: Pininfarina 2uettottanta

headline: In the Belly of the Information Beast
text: Access and information are tightly related, to each other and to feelings of power and status.

headline: Iraq’s Hot New TV Show: Candidate Debates
text: For the first time in Iraq, voters are getting acquainted with their politicians through an old bit of political theater that is something rather new in Iraq: televised debates.

headline: Swimming in Murky Waters Infested With Death and Life
text: A mermaid, who has wandered in from the water and can’t find her way back, lies on a rock, half-dead. This image, described in a conversation, opens Ibsen’s “Lady From the Sea” and could handily serve as a portrait of its heroine.

headline: A Conductor and a Violinist Turn Fresh Eyes on a Beloved Beethoven and a Brahms
text: Vladimir Jurowski appears not to have strained his imagination building programs for his visit to New York with the London Philharmonic. The first of his two concerts, on Monday evening at Avery Fisher Hall, offered two scores that could hardly be more standard: the Beethoven Violin Concerto and the Brahms Symphony No. 2. The second, on Sunday, is a slightly more inventive coupling of Shostakovich and Ravel.

headline: Properties for $280,000
text: A home in Calvert, Tex., a row house in Philadelphia, and a house in Livingston, Mont.

headline: Premiere of a Belber Play Set for Atlantic Theater Company
text: The  world premiere of Stephen Belber’s play “Dusk Rings a Bell,” directed by Sam Gold (“Circle Mirror Transformation”) will be the final show of Atlantic Theater Company’s Stage 2 season, the theater announced on Tuesday.

headline: Symphonic Drama: Rage-Filled Reunion for Slave and His Sister
text: It’s hard to imagine a more riveting performance of Sibelius’s seldom-heard “Kullervo” than the thrilling interpretation given by the Minnesota Orchestra and Osmo Vanska, its music director, on Monday evening at Carnegie Hall.

headline: What You Get for ... $280,000
text: CALVERT, TEX.

headline: 3 Players Make Odd Pairing Singular
text: Schubert’s Piano Trio in E flat (D. 929), written in 1827, was featured in the only public concert known to have been organized by the composer, in March 1828. The following year it was played during an event meant to raise funds for a memorial to Schubert, who died in November 1828. Shostakovich’s Piano Trio No. 2 in E minor had its premiere in November 1944, with the composer as the pianist, and part of the piece was played at his funeral in 1975.

headline: Union Makes Plea for Deal With N.F.L. as Uncapped Season Looms
text: With an uncapped season two days away, the N.F.L. Players Association made a public plea Tuesday for last-ditch negotiations with team owners and renewed a proposal for a one-year extension of the current salary cap, which owners have already rejected. In a statement on its Web site that it also announced on Twitter, the union also offered to negotiate a longer extension if the N.F.L. guarantees that the cap will not go down.

headline: Officials in China at Odds Over Food Scandal
text: SANYA, China — A widening national toxic food scandal that has its roots in this tropical island resort area in the South China Sea has set off a rare case of public sniping between officials.

headline: Disney, Cablevision Go Public in Fight Over WABC Fees
text: The Walt Disney Company and Cablevision each told viewers to take a side — their side — on Tuesday in a brewing battle over distribution payments that are increasingly seen as a vital for television broadcasters.

headline: Obama Offers to Use  Some G.O.P. Health Proposals
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama offered Tuesday to address some of the concerns expressed by Republicans in the health care debate as the two parties maneuvered for advantage heading into the legislative end game.

headline: Ex-Hospital Official Fined in Conflict of Interest Case
text: A former board member of New York City’s public hospital system has been fined $13,500 for his role in soliciting coveted training spots in city hospitals for students from a Caribbean medical school, the city’s Conflicts of Interest Board said Tuesday.

headline: A Casita in Madrid
text: Felipe Rein Acebo-Gomez spent 55 million pesetas ($375,000) renovating his home after buying it.

headline: Grassley Pushes Back
text: The pushback against President Obama’s overtures to Republicans is under way.

headline: In Madrid, the Apartment That Came With a House
text: MADRID  Location may be the most important real estate consideration, but history is also a part of the equation, especially in a place like Madrid. “There was no such thing as horizontal subdivision of real estate in Spain until 1939,” said Felipe Rein Acebo-Gomez, explaining how his second-floor apartment, which he bought in Madrid in 1997, happened to include a 1,300-square-foot three-story house connected to the back of the building with a private garden.

headline: What We’re Reading: Steampunk, Roger Ebert and a City Called Google
text: Tuesday’s roundup of interesting tidbits from around the Web, selected by the technology reporters and editors of The New York Times:

headline: Bill to Create U.S. Tourism Board
text: The number of foreign visitors to the United States in 2009 was 9 percent below 2000. A new bill that passed the Senate last week, and is expected to be signed into law, aims to reverse that trend.

headline: A Non-Action Approach to Wine Making
text: American popular culture loves the man of action, but wine lovers might prefer the man of “non-action.’’ That is how Paul Draper, the chief executive and winemaker at Ridge Vineyards, characterizes his approach to wine. Ridge, which is celebrating its 50th anniversary this week, and Draper, who is marking 40 years with Ridge, are the subject of my column this week.

headline: Now Nominating | Costume Designer Janet Patterson
text: You’ve probably never heard of Janet Patterson, the costume designer who received her fourth Oscar nomination for “Bright Star,” a quiet meditation on the unconsummated love affair between Fanny Brawne and the poet John Keats. With a résumé that includes “The Piano” (1993), Patterson is revered by industry peers, few of whom have met her. Far from prolific, she retreats between movies for years at a time. So it was a surprise when, 13 years after my first approach to interview her, she responded to yet another e-mail entreaty by calling from her home in Sydney, Australia.

headline: Iran Arrests Filmmaker Who Backed Opposition
text: Iranian authorities raided the home of a prominent filmmaker, Jaffar Panahi, early Tuesday morning and arrested him, his wife and daughter, along with 15 guests, the opposition Web site Jaras reported.

headline: Beethoven That Is Robust, if a Little Strange
A Look at the Snarled Past of Armenians and Turks
text: Christopher de Bellaigue’s new book begins with the story of a journalistic blunder, the author’s own. In 2001 Mr. de Bellaigue wrote a long essay for The New York Review of Books about Turkey’s tangled history. It was a topic he thought he knew something about. At the time he was living in Istanbul and working as a foreign correspondent for The Economist.

headline: Hurtling Through Beethoven, With Grace
text: Orchestral musicians often perform while sitting back comfortably in their chairs. But the members of the Leipzig Gewandhaus Orchestra were perched on the edge of their seats, bows flying and heads tossing, during their feisty performance at Carnegie Hall on Saturday evening.

headline: McConnell Brushes Off White House Overture
text: In a reply to President Obama, the Senate Republican leader, Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, on Tuesday said that last week’s heath care summit “gave us an opportunity to show our constituents that there is a better way to proceed with the kind of reforms they truly want.”

headline: Surprise! Taylor Swift Nabs Five Nominations
text: Taylor Swift will have another opportunity to appear astounded by her awards-show largess: she has been nominated for five Academy of Country Music Awards, including entertainer of the year. The nominations, announced on Tuesday, were most generous to the Nashville group Lady Antebellum, which picked up seven nominations, including ones for album (for its self-titled 2008 release) and top vocal group, as well as single record of the year, song of the year and video for “Need You Now.” Miranda Lambert was nominated for six awards, as was Carrie Underwood, the academy’s reigning entertainer of the year, who was once again nominated in that category. Kenny Chesney picked up four nominations, as did Brad Paisley and the Zac Brown Band. The winners will be announced in Las Vegas on April 18.

headline: Cable’s TLC Drops Miss America Pageant
text: Once one of the nation’s most desirable singles, Miss America is unattached again and it’s not immediately clear who will sweep her off her feet. On Monday the cable channel TLC became the latest broadcaster to drop the long-running Miss America Pageant, Reuters reported. In a statement, TLC said that it was happy to have been “part of the modernization and revitalization of the Miss America Pageant,” but was declining to renew its contract to show the event. The competition, which dates to 1921, was among the highest-rated television broadcasts in its 1960s-era heyday, but has been bounced from suitor to suitor since NBC stopped showing it after 1996. ABC ran the pageant from 1997 to 2005, then the country-music channel CMT in 2006 and 2007, before TLC picked it up in 2008. The 2010 pageant, won by Miss Virginia, Caressa Cameron, was watched by 4.5 million people in January, a record for the competition since it moved to cable.

headline: Comic Book Writer Accused of Plagiarism
text: Nick Simmons, the son of the rock star Gene Simmons, sought to make a name for himself in the comic book industry as the writer and artist of “Incarnate,” a manga-style series from Radical Publishing. The attempt may have backfired. Last week the publisher announced plans to halt production of a collected edition of “Incarnate” after Internet message boards filled up with accusations that Mr. Simmons had copied layouts, dialogue and character designs from other manga series, including “Bleach” and “Hellsing.” On Monday Mr. Simmons said in a statement that the similarities were “meant as an homage to artists I respect, and I definitely want to apologize to any manga fans or fellow manga artists who feel I went too far.” He continued, “My inspirations reflect the fact that certain fundamental imagery is common to all manga.” Many readers weren’t buying it. “Note that he doesn’t acknowledge he went beyond ‘homage’ to flat-out copies,” wrote Johanna Draper Carlson, who reviews manga at comicsworthreading.com. (Above left, a drawing from “Bleach.” Right, one from “Incarnate.”)

headline: In Return Engagement, Leno Routs Letterman
text: Let the Leno-Letterman jousting resume. Jay Leno’s return to “The Tonight Show” on Monday was watched by about 6.6 million viewers, according to overnight Nielsen ratings, up about 25 percent from his average viewership in the first quarter of last year. David Letterman’s “Late Show” on CBS was watched by 3.8 million, about average for his program. “The Tonight Show” was the No. 1 late-night offering when Mr. Leno, right, handed it over to Conan O’Brien last spring. In the months that followed, the “Late Show” routinely beat Mr. O’Brien’s “Tonight” in total viewers. In January, after NBC canceled Mr. Leno’s 10 p.m. talk show and announced a plan to move him back to 11:35 p.m., Mr. O’Brien left the network. Mr. Leno’s “Tonight Show” return was heavily promoted during the Winter Olympics on NBC last month, but once the initial interest fades the real competition will begin, as NBC and CBS find out whether “The Tonight Show” can return to the No. 1 spot among total viewers  as if a certain redheaded comedian had never been there.

headline: Crudup to Star in ‘The Metal Children’
text: The actor Billy Crudup, whose last major New York performance won him a Tony Award, for Tom Stoppard’s “Coast of Utopia” during the 2006-07 season, will star in the world premiere of Adam Rapp’s play “The Metal Children” at the Vineyard Theater in May. The play, to be directed by Mr. Rapp for the Off Broadway theater, is about a New York writer who travels to a small American town to defend one of his young-adult novels that has been banned by the school board, a confrontation that turns into a heated debate about religious beliefs and censorship. Mr. Crudup won the Tony for best featured actor in a play in 2007 for his performance as the literary critic Vissarion Belinsky in the first two parts of “The Coast of Utopia.” He had been nominated twice before for best actor in a play, for “The Pillowman” in 2005 and the revival of “The Elephant Man” in 2002.

headline: ‘Venus In Fur’ Eyes Broadway
text: The producer Robert Fox is exploring transferring the Classic Stage Company’s production of “Venus in Fur” to a Broadway theater, Mr. Fox said on Tuesday. The new play, by David Ives, received wide critical acclaim when it opened in January, especially for one of its stars, the newcomer Nina Arianda, who plays a somewhat mysterious actress who becomes caught up in a sexual psychodrama during an audition for a director (played by Wes Bentley, of the film “American Beauty”). Mr. Fox, the lead producer of “God of Carnage” and a lead producer of the new Broadway production “A Behanding in Spokane,” said he had begun talking to New York theater owners about a transfer. Chief among the factors for such a move, he said, would be the availability of “a very intimate house” for the two-character work. He did not specify which theaters he preferred and cautioned that no deal was in place, and that the timing would largely depend on a theater becoming available. The Off Broadway run of “Venus in Fur,” directed by Walter Bobbie (“Chicago”), has been extended twice and is now scheduled to end on March 28.

headline: Shopping With Colin Cowie
text: Gold tableware and home accessories that would bring glamour to any Oscar-night fête.

headline: Elliott Associates Offers to Buy Novell
text: 10:08 p.m. | Updated The hedge fund Elliott Associates said Tuesday afternoon that it had made an offer to buy Novell in a deal that valued the business software company at about $2 billion.

headline: From Hutch to Table
text: A seminar held in Brooklyn taught participants how to raise, slaughter and butcher rabbits; chefs demonstrated what to do with them.

headline: Geneva Auto Show: Lexus CT 200h
text: Introduced on Tuesday: 2011 Lexus CT 200h

headline: Having a Child to Save Another
text: Back when I was a medical reporter for The Times, Laurie Strongin and her husband, Allen Goldberg — and most of all their son Henry — became the faces I saw whenever I wrote about medical milestones. I met them when they were one of the first two families to try a new technology called preimplantation genetic diagnosis, or P.G.D., to have a baby who could donate the bone marrow that Henry, who was born with the genetic disease Fanconi anemia, needed to live.

headline: That Tabletop Glamour
text: ON March 7, movie buffs everywhere will tune in to the 82nd Academy Awards ceremony, and many will hold parties that aim to bring a little of the evening’s glamour into the home.

headline: Singing the Romance in the Russian Soul
text: In opera the Russian mezzo-soprano Olga Borodina is a towering figure: a smoldering Carmen, a seductive Dalila and a commanding Amneris, with a magnetic presence that fills both stage and house. It was fascinating, then, to encounter another side of Ms. Borodina in the recital she presented with the pianist Dmitri Yefimov at Carnegie Hall on Thursday night. Limiting herself to a patch of stage inside the piano’s curve, she projected intense focus and concentration even when her material grew sentimental or impassioned.

headline: A Greek Composer’s Japanese Inspirations
text: Whenever a composer looms large on the contemporary music scene, there is usually a choreographer lurking somewhere in the distance. In the case of Iannis Xenakis (1922-2001), the avant-garde Greek composer who was born in Romania and died in Paris, it is Luca Veggetti, an Italian who in 2008 choreographed a production of Xenakis’s opera “Oresteia” at the Miller Theater.

headline: In Iraq Election, Familiar Faces but New Coalitions
text: As leaders jockey for positions in the new government, current political alliances are not drawn as clearly along sectarian lines as they were in 2005.

headline: Hedge Fund Makes $2 Billion Offer for Novell
text: Elliott Associates offered Tuesday to buy Novell, a business software maker, for $5.75 a share, according to our colleagues on the DealBook blog. But Wall Street expects the $2 billion offer to be raised — Novell’s shares rose as high as $6.07 in trading after the news was announced.

headline: New Musicals That Strike a Somber Chord
text: The dream number from “The Scottsboro Boys,” the musical opening next Wednesday at the Vineyard Theater, is a nightmare: an imprisoned boy is forced to tap dance around an electric chair.

headline: Tribeca Film Group Tries to Build a Distribution Brand of Its Own
text: LOS ANGELES  Entering its ninth year, the Tribeca Film Festival is set to become associated with a new venture to distribute films digitally and in theaters under the Tribeca name. It is also embarking on another initiative to make some offerings available online to the paying public at the same time that they are screening at the festival.

headline: Remembering Barry Hannah
text: Twelve years ago, I talked an editor into assigning me a profile of the great novelist and short-story writer Barry Hannah, who died Monday at 67 at his home in Oxford, Miss. The pretext for the article was a flimsy one; he wasn’t on the verge of publishing anything new. But like many people who have discovered Hannah’s work and fallen in love with it, I’d become a little obsessed with knowing more about him. If the short story, to borrow a phrase from Zola, sits “at the exquisite point where poetry ends and reality begins,” the best of Hannah’s stories were somehow able to operate well over on the poetry side of that equation, laying bare a vision of reality that was hilarious, beautiful, heartbreaking and sometimes terrifying.

headline: Police Spokesman Offers Account of Workshop
text: Last Friday, we ran a post about a workshop given for the benefit of the New York Police Department, among others, on how to deal with emotionally disturbed people, whose encounters with the police often turn injurious or worse. No one from the Police Department showed up; the event’s organizers said that two deputy inspectors from New York City precincts had confirmed they would attend.

headline: Supreme Court Takes Up Gun Control Case
text: An unusually intense Supreme Court argument showed that the justices remain bitterly divided about the meaning and scope of the Second Amendment.

headline: The Na’vi Capture the Online Buzz
text: Online data metrics are notoriously unreliable – do you count clicks or visits? Google searches or blog mentions? – but that doesn’t stop people from using it. Nielsen Media reports that “Avatar” far outstrips the other best picture contenders in online “buzz,” which is presumably counted in the traditional way, via abacus. Its main competition, “The Hurt Locker,” comes in second and – apologies to Harvey Weinstein – “Inglourious Basterds” ranks dead last.

headline: Into the Risk Pool
text: In a critique of high-risk pooling, the preferred conservative approach to insuring the uninsurable, Jonathan Cohn argues that the existing network of state-based pools feature brutal waiting times to enroll, and tend to be outrageously expensive once you’re in them. Then he anticipates objections to his argument:

headline: Leaving Money on the Table With the I.R.S.
text: We’ve written before about all the tax deadbeats out there who owe taxes and don’t pay them. But what about the people who are owed tax money from the government and never claim it?

headline: Why (in Part) People Love Buenos Aires
text: I was there for two days, only — my first trip. While it was sort of obvious which parillas — essentially restaurants specializing in grilled meats — not to go to, it was more difficult to determine which ones were going to be worth a trip.

headline: Facing the Exhaustion of Unemployment Benefits
text: While senators in Washington continued to debate on Tuesday whether to provide more financial help to the unemployed, thousands of New Yorkers were finding ways to cope with the loss of their weekly jobless benefits.

headline: Dubai Police Chief Says He Knows an Israeli When He Sees One
text: Dubai’s police chief, Gen. Dahi Khalfan al-Tamim, said on Monday that the famously open city may soon block people who look or sound like Israelis from entering, no matter what passport they produce.

headline: Brown Scores Three Committee Seats
text: Scott P. Brown, the newest member of the Senate, has received his committee assignments, and there seems to be a theme: The Massachusetts Republican has been given a slot on the Armed Services, the Homeland Security and the Veterans’ Affairs panels.

headline: What We’re Reading…
text: Starbucks is wooing gun fanatics, and other links from around the Web.

headline: Scorecard | Dolce & Gabbana Wins!
text: Remember that “heritage” buzzword Scorecard reported on from the Milan men’s-wear shows? It’s baaack! Dolce & Gabbana closed out the women’s fashion week with a sentimental paean to sensuality and Sicilian seamstresses that left certain members of the fash pack quite literally in tears. Meanwhile, over at Emilio Pucci, Peter Dundas’s super-sexy showing included the founder’s signature prints numbering in the single digits. Bet you can guess how that one went down.

headline: Conjuring Up Elders, With Their Secrets and Surprises Intact
text: Never underestimate the substance, the complexity, of a long life. “Forgotten,” Pat Kinevane’s one-man show at the Irish Arts Center, gracefully illustrates that point with the mimickry, invention and formidable stamina of this actor-playwright, a native of County Cork. A portrait of four elderly people, all in their 80s or older and living in different nursing homes, the play offers recollections and re-enactments, and eventually reveals a latticework of shared destinies.

headline: The Road Ahead (It’s Bumpy)
text: Wondering exactly when the health care debate might reach some sort of resolution? Keep in mind that there are some very basic steps that need to be taken in the days ahead if Democrats, as expected, decide to push forward on their own.

headline: Viacom Will Take ‘Daily Show,’ ‘Colbert’ Off Hulu
text: Unable to make the digital media dollars add up to their liking, Viacom will remove “The Daily Show with Jon Stewart,” “The Colbert Report” and other Comedy Central television shows from Hulu next week.

headline: Kanye West Gets a Few (Thousand) Things Off His Chest
text: At his official Web site, kanyewest.com, Kanye West has posted a statement of purpose titled “Creativity,” in which he mourns the death of the designer Alexander McQueen and seems to address some of his own recent history (though your interpretation may vary), writing, in part:

headline: Wall St. Bailout Eases New York’s Downturn
text: In fall 2008, after Lehman Brothers collapsed and other Wall Street firms seemed ready to topple, New York appeared to be headed for a brutal recession, one that would rival the worst downturns in the city’s history.

headline: Iraq’s Top Cleric Refuses to Influence Elections
text: NAJAF, Iraq — No one man in Iraq has more power to change the outcome of the country’s elections on Sunday than a frail cleric who lives in an ascetic house in this holy city. And yet he has refused to wield it, shaping the relationship between Islam and the state at a crucial juncture in Iraq’s history.

headline: An Indie Takes On Animation’s Big Boys
text: Even in a year with a lot of unlikely Oscar nominees, Tomm Moore is a reach. Mr. Moore, the director of the animated film “The Secret of Kells,” grew up and still lives in Kilkenny, Ireland, a one-cathedral town of a few thousand people about an hour and a half south of Dublin and 5,160 miles from Hollywood.

headline: Postal Service Revives Cutback Plans
text: Faced with growing deficits and rapid erosion of its business, the United States Postal Service on Tuesday reintroduced proposals to cut costs, close post offices, raise rates and eliminate some services, most notably Saturday mail delivery.

headline: A Park for Mr. Green
text: While the name Robert Moses rings synonymous, for better or worse, with the shaping of modern-day New York City, Moses was hardly the metropolis’s first master planner.

headline: If He Can, Above All, to His Own Self Be True
text: What if Shakespeare had never written “Macbeth”?

headline: Apple Sues Nexus One Maker HTC
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Apple has relied on slick applications, and even slicker advertisements, to promote the iPhone and maintain its advantage over rivals like Google in the battle to rule the next generation of smartphones.

headline: Gov. Paterson’s Oath
text: Gov. David Paterson gave New Yorkers his “personal oath” on Friday that he had never abused his office. It now seems clear that, at the very least, he tried to arrange a ham-handed cover-up to avert a scandal involving a top aide. There are also disturbing signs that he or other state officials may have unlawfully intervened to protect the aide from accusations of domestic violence.

headline: Fuel Taxes Must Rise, Harvard Researchers Say
text: To meet the Obama administration’s targets for cutting greenhouse gas emissions, some researchers say, Americans may have to experience a sobering reality: gas at $7 a gallon.

headline: WWS 543, March 3
text: Readings. (doc)

headline: When the Line for Dinner Is a Mile Long
text: NewarkOnce upon a time, any self-respecting aerialist or big-top roustabout ordered pie in the Pie Car. Of course. And heaps of fried chicken. Or beef stew with glorious gobbets of fat, swimming with hefty carrots and an armada of bobbing potatoes. Not to mention buckets of strong, steaming java.

headline: Haunted by What Dad Did in the War
text: The sins of the father weigh heavily and sometimes scarcely at all in the documentary “Harlan  In the Shadow of ‘Jew Süss.’ ” The Harlan of the title is Veit Harlan, a filmmaker who thrived under National Socialism and directed “Jew Süss” (“Jud Süss,” 1940), one of the Nazis’ most notorious anti-Semitic works. He was the only director of the Nazi era to be tried after the war for crimes against humanity. Twice found not guilty, he directed nine more movies in the 1950s before dying in 1964 in a Capri villa with his wife and children by his side. He’s buried in a lovely cemetery with a smashing view of the Mediterranean.

headline: Spoonfuls of Southern Cooking for Obama
text: SAVANNAH, Ga. — Two days after discovering that his cholesterol had climbed 42 points in less than three years, President Obama sat down for a late lunch here today.

headline: Mudslides Bury Villages in Eastern Uganda
text: KAMPALA, Uganda — Torrential rain in eastern Uganda touched off a series of mudslides late Monday night, killing at least 83 people and causing devastation in villages, state emergency officials said.

headline: ‘Hurt Locker’ Producer is Barred From Oscar Ceremony
text: LOS ANGELES — “The Hurt Locker,” a presumed front-runner in the Oscar race since picking up a string of honors from critics and the Hollywood guilds, suffered a last-minute embarrassment on Tuesday as the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences disciplined one of the film’s producers for violating the group’s campaign rules.

headline: Pfizer Said to Set Sights on German Drug Maker
text: Pfizer is reportedly gearing up this week to bid 3 billion euro ($4.08 billion) for Ratiopharm, a generic drug maker based in Germany, according to Bloomberg News, which cited two unidentified people with knowledge of the talks. The move would pit Pfizer, the world’s largest drug maker, against Teva Pharmaceuticals Industries of Israel, the world’s largest generic drug maker, and Actvis of Iceland, another big generic drug maker, both of which are said to be interested in Ratiopharm, according to Bloomberg.

headline: What Apple vs. HTC Could Mean
text: The lawsuit that Apple filed on Tuesday against HTC, the mobile handset maker, opens up a lot of questions about the future of Android phones like the Nexus One and the cellphone market in general.

headline: Is He Mellower? Ask the Guy Missing a Hand
text: FOUR years ago Martin McDonagh, the celebrated playwright whose flamboyantly gruesome dark comedies have brought smashed skulls, child murder and other carefully calibrated outrages to Broadway, shocked the theater world in an entirely new way.

headline: TiVo to Offer Boxes That Go Beyond the Recorder
text: SAN FRANCISCO — TiVo, the Silicon Valley pioneer of digital video recorders, is once again trying to get consumers to pay for another set-top box that combines traditional television programming with a vast array of content from the Web.

headline: For Supermodel With a Temper, No Charges
text: The supermodel Naomi Campbell, who has twice pleaded guilty to assault charges in the last three years, has been accused of letting her temper get the best of her once again.

headline: With Turturro, Italy Knows No Bounds
text: Milan

headline: A Yahoo Birthday Party With Carol Bartz
text: As part of its 15th birthday celebrations, Yahoo on Tuesday invited a group of reporters for a lunch with Carol Bartz, the company’s chief executive. There were plenty of delicious cupcakes but no party hats. And as Ms. Bartz’s public relations handlers warned ahead of the event, there was no news.

headline: ‘The Band’ Helped Writers Find Their Beat
text: MART CROWLEY’s play “The Boys in the Band” opened off Broadway on April 14, 1968, and instantly made theater history: It was, as Clive Barnes wrote in his review in The New York Times, “by far the frankest treatment of homosexuality I have ever seen on the stage.”

headline: States’ Rights vs. Gun Rights
text: The Supreme Court heard oral arguments on a major gun control case on Tuesday. The issue in the case, McDonald v. City of Chicago, is whether the Second Amendment protects the individual right to keep and bear arms against state and city gun laws. The case is considered a sequel to a Supreme Court decision in 2008, District of Columbia v. Heller, which limited what the federal government can do in restricting gun rights.

headline: The Screen’s Now Setting Many a Stage
text: AT “The Orphans’ Home Cycle” titles and dates move across the screen like “Star Wars” credits taking a detour. At “Fela!” newspaper headlines like “Fela Declares Self ‘Black Power Man’ ” pop up on a screen. Even at “Safe Home,” a low-budget, bare-bones production that opened Off Broadway this year, scene changes were announced with 1950s newsreel footage.

headline: USF1 Dream Over?
text: There have been rumors for weeks that the USF1 team would not make it to the grid in Bahrain. In more recent days there have been several more rumors that the operation is closing down. Now, Autosport.com is reporting that the team has indeed ceased to work on the 2010 car, and the employees are on unpaid leave. Keep posted.

headline: Telling 'The Secret'
text: A look inside the Oscar-nominated film "The Secret of Kells."

headline: Disney and Cablevision Take ABC Fight Public
text: The Walt Disney Company and Cablevision each told viewers to take a side — their side — on Tuesday in a brewing battle over distribution payments that are increasingly seen as vital for television broadcasters.

headline: The Netherlands 2,  United States 1
text: Wednesday, 5:17 p.m. ET |Netherlands 2, United States 1

headline: Before the Glow Fades: Figure Skating as Art
text: To the Editor:

headline: Police Strive to Guard Dubai’s Image After Killing
text: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates — The people who killed a Hamas operative in an airport hotel here in January seem to have thought they could pass it off as a natural death, or perhaps just another of this region’s macabre mysteries. They injected him with a muscle relaxant, suffocated him and then smoothed away any signs of struggle, reattaching the hotel door chain as they left the room, investigators say.

headline: Marion Barry Disciplined by Washington Council
text: WASHINGTON — In another twist in a long and troubled career, Councilman Marion S. Barry Jr., the former mayor of Washington, was unanimously censured and stripped of his committee chairmanship by his Council colleagues on Tuesday in response to corruption accusations.

headline: Yes, Luis Castillo Is Still With the Mets
text: Port St. Lucie, Fla.

headline: Selling Breast-Feeding Bras and Emotional Support
text: BRAVADO DESIGNS specializes in breast-feeding bras, which feature cups that unfasten singly and stretchable fabrics that accommodate size fluctuations during pregnancy and nursing. But when it comes to marketing, the bra company emphasizes another type of support: emotional.

headline: Mets’ Obstructed Views in Plain Sight
text: Mets fans had a tough time feeling comfortable in Citi Field last season, mainly because the team performed so poorly. But some fans were also irked that they could not see parts of the field from their seats, especially in left field.

headline: Milk in a Can Goes Glam
text: SWEETENED condensed milk is everywhere. There’s probably a can or two lurking in your cabinets. It is the key to Key lime pie; it brings the sweet to Vietnamese coffee; it went to Rio for Carnaval last month in the shape of brigadeiros, bite-size balls of milk fudge that are a Brazilian national treat.

headline: A Plan to Talk About Jobs, Elbowed Aside by Health Care
text: SAVANNAH, Ga. — By the time March arrived, President Obama was supposed to be entering his third month of the year talking about three things: jobs, jobs, jobs.

headline: Abuse Case Rouses India’s Middle Class
text: PANCHKULA, India — She was a gifted 14-year-old tennis player who idolized Steffi Graf and hoped to turn pro. He was a senior police official and president of the state lawn tennis club. He lured her to his office with a promise of special coaching that could make her tennis dreams come true, then groped her.

headline: Blue Bottle Coffee in Brooklyn Raises Brewing to a Science
text: IT might come as a surprise to most espresso drinkers, but some of the most obsessive figures in coffee take their cues not just from Italy, but from Japan.

headline: The Next Battles for Marja
text: Charlottesville, Va.

headline: Israel: Jerusalem Mayor Delays Demolition Plan
text: The mayor of Jerusalem agreed Tuesday to delay a plan to demolish some Palestinian homes to build a complex that would provide new apartments for the residents. Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu had asked the mayor, Nir Barkat, to allow more time to reach an understanding with the residents of the neighborhood, in East Jerusalem just outside the Old City walls. Mr. Barkat has been negotiating with the Palestinians there, who are living in housing that is illegal under Israeli law. The residents have rejected the plan, fearing that once homes are destroyed, Jewish settlers will be moved in. There are Jewish settler projects on either side of the area.

headline: France: Widow of a Rwandan Leader Is Arrested
text: The French police on Tuesday arrested the widow of Juvenal Habyarimana, the Rwandan president whose plane was shot down in 1994, setting off the massacre of 800,000 Tutsi and moderate Hutu. Agathe Habyarimana, left, has lived in France since then. She was refused political asylum in 2004 and lost her appeal in October because French judges had found she was a central figure in the Hutu government that orchestrated the genocide. Her arrest came a week after President Nicolas Sarkozy visited Rwanda on a fence-mending trip where he admitted that France had made errors of judgment before the genocide. It was unclear if Mrs. Habyarimana would be extradited because France has refused to hand over other suspects for fear they would not receive fair trial.

headline: U.S. Court Rejects Sexual Discrimination Lawsuit
text: A federal appeals court in Manhattan rejected a sexual discrimination lawsuit brought by two United Nations staff members against the organization and three top former officials. The court upheld a lower court ruling that American courts had no jurisdiction in the case because the defendants had diplomatic immunity. Cynthia Brzak, an American, and Nasr Ishak, who has dual French and Egyptian citizenship, worked for the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees in Geneva. They sued on the grounds that their careers suffered after Ms. Brzak accused Ruud Lubbers, the former head of the refugee organization, of sexual harassment, with Mr. Ishak encouraging her to speak out. Mr. Lubbers resigned in 2005 over the allegations, which he denied. The suit named Mr. Lubbers and his former deputy, Wendy Chamberlin, as well as former Secretary General Kofi Annan.

headline: 2010 Iraqi Elections: Expats in Jordan
text: Iraqi refugees in Jordan are preparing to take part in the parliamentary elections, hoping this vote will bring a change to their country and allow them to go back home.

headline: Young Talent Promises to Rekindle Mets-Braves Rivalry
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Chipper Jones is on the back end of his career, but the Atlanta Braves are getting close to introducing the next edition, a ferocious left-handed hitter who could torment the Mets for the next decade. His name is Jason Heyward, a 20-year-old slugging right fielder who has drawn comparisons to Darryl Strawberry and Fred McGriff.

headline: Hideki Matsui Quietly Went to Angels His Way
text: TEMPE, Ariz.  Hideki Matsui wrapped his fingers around his lips, making a megaphone with his left hand. In a deep voice that needed no translation, he bellowed a sound he did not hear often in seven seasons with the Yankees: “Booooooo!”

headline: Yankees Mix Some Fun With the Fundamentals
text: TAMPA, Fla.  Repeating as World Series champion is one thing. But far be it for Joe Girardi to repeat the same activity in the Yankees’ team-building outing Tuesday.

headline: Afghanistan Aims to Ban Live Coverage of Attacks
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Minute-by-minute news coverage by Afghan television stations of two recent suicide attacks proved an embarrassment for the government, showing that it could not stop militants from penetrating even heavily guarded areas of the capital.

headline: The Waiting Is the Hardest Part
text: In the digital age, despair travels many avenues  through airwaves, tweets and blogs. Every electronic artery was clogged Tuesday morning with Knick fans wailing over their team’s humiliating 124-93 loss to the Cleveland Cavaliers.

headline: Hank Rosenstein, Player in First N.B.A. Game, Dies at 89
text: Hank Rosenstein, who played in what is considered the National Basketball Association’s first game, in 1946, as an original member of the New York Knicks, died on Saturday in Boca Raton, Fla., where he lived. He was 89.

headline: Players’ Bid to Keep Salary Cap Is Rejected
text: The N.F.L. Players Association made a public plea Tuesday for last-ditch negotiations with team owners and renewed a proposal for a one-year extension of the current salary cap, which the owners had rejected already. The union also offered to negotiate a longer extension if the N.F.L. guarantees that the cap will not go down. The N.F.L. immediately rejected the offer.

headline: Woods Is Spotted Practicing in Florida
text: PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla.  Tiger Woods, who was reported to have left a Scottsdale, Ariz., rehabilitation facility over the weekend, practiced Monday on the range at Isleworth Country Club, the golf course in the gated community outside Orlando where he lives.

headline: Seeing the Investor Value in Being Green
text: Constructing or renovating a building to make it environmentally sustainable can be a daunting task for any owner, but Jamestown Properties, a German commercial real estate investment company, has decided it will go “green” in nearly its entire $4 billion portfolio of buildings, all located in the United States.

headline: Testaccio Ristorante
text: 47-30 Vernon Boulevard (near Jackson Avenue), Long Island City, Queens; (718) 937-2900, testacciony.com.

headline: Bread and Butter
text: 46 Henry Street (Cranberry Street), Brooklyn Heights; (718) 858-9605.

headline:
Under Fire, Rangel
Appears to Be Losing Grip of Committee
text: WASHINGTON — Caught in a swirl of ethics inquiries, Representative Charles B. Rangel, the dean of the New York Congressional delegation, appeared to be losing his grip on his powerful post as chairman of the tax-policy-writing Ways and Means Committee on Tuesday as Republicans planned to force a vote to remove him from his position.

headline: Home Fires: The War Movie You Don’t Want to See
text: This is the second in a five-part series, “Retelling the War,” in which veterans discuss how books, movies and other tales of combat shaped their perceptions of themselves and of war.

headline: Off the Menu
text: Openings

headline: Devils’ Parise Puts Medal Away and Nose Back to Grindstone
text: SAN JOSE, Calif.  When Zach Parise took his leap into the corner boards to celebrate his goal with 24.4 seconds left that would send the gold medal game between the United States and Canada into overtime, it might have been the moment he took one of the greatest leaps an American hockey player can make  into the country’s sporting consciousness.

headline: Quake Finds Tsunami Forecasts Still Limited
text: A wider network of buoys and better computer models gave forecasters in Hawaii on Saturday a much better picture of the approaching tsunami than they would have had in the past, but they admit that their models were not refined enough to declare whether a full-scale evacuation was really needed.

headline: Dining Calendar
text: To Chase the Chill

headline: A Word From the Wise
text: I was traveling via Los Angeles International Airport  LAX  last week. Walking through its faded, cramped domestic terminal, I got the feeling of a place that once thought of itself as modern but has had one too many face-lifts and simply can’t hide the wrinkles anymore. In some ways, LAX is us. We are the United States of Deferred Maintenance. China is the People’s Republic of Deferred Gratification. They save, invest and build. We spend, borrow and patch.

headline: In Tracking Recovery, Jagged Lines
text: Could the economy be at risk of a double dip?

headline: Scientists Taking Steps to Defend Work on Climate
text: WASHINGTON — For months, climate scientists have taken a vicious beating in the media and on the Internet, accused of hiding data, covering up errors and suppressing alternate views. Their response until now has been largely to assert the legitimacy of the vast body of climate science and to mock their critics as cranks and know-nothings.

headline: Viacom and Hulu Part Ways
text: In the first major fracture between television show owners and the wildly popular Hulu.com, Viacom will remove “The Daily Show With Jon Stewart,” “The Colbert Report” and other Comedy Central programs from the video site next week.

headline: N.C.A.A. Tournament Goes Online, Clip by Clip
text: Even before Warner Wolf took us to the videotape, highlights have served fans as currency of their passion. Did you see that home run? That dunk? That overtime goal? That buzzer beater?

headline: A Victory for a Fan Used to Defeat
text: I sure hope hockey fans in Pittsburgh feel lucky. I really do. Yeah, the Olympics were great, and like all Canadians, I was pumped that we won the gold medal. But now it’s back to reality, a reality where I find myself envying hockey fans in places like Pittsburgh and Tampa Bay.

headline: Evolution by the Grassroots
text: Imagine the Earth without grasses.

headline: Still With Obama, but Worried
text: ORLANDO, Fla. — The nation’s union leaders said on Tuesday that they were “appalled” at remarks made by President Obama condoning the mass firing of teachers at a Rhode Island high school.

headline: Loosey Goosey Saudi
text: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia

headline: What’s a Goal Between Friends?
text: PITTSBURGH  For Pittsburgh Penguins fans, all is forgiven.

headline: Possibility of Senate Run, Nurtured and Abandoned
text: A few weeks ago, Harold E. Ford Jr. had a telephone conversation with his friend Doug Band, the powerful counselor to former President Bill Clinton.

headline: Choptank
text: THE Choptank River runs like a paper cut down the thumb of Maryland’s Eastern Shore, across the Chesapeake Bay from Baltimore, out of Kent County, Delaware, toward points south and west. There is marshland along parts of it, where ducks land in the fall and winter, where crabs once burrowed and oyster spat took hold. Rockfish still cruise its brackish waters, down to the salt. There is a lot of farmland along its shores.

headline: Considering Choptank
text: My restaurant review this week is of Choptank, a restaurant in Greenwich Village that takes its cues from the Chesapeake Bay, Baltimore and the Eastern Shore of Maryland. It is vaguely southern, vaguely devoted to seafood, and casual in a college-educated sort of way. It’s on Bleecker Street, off Seventh Avenue South.

headline: Rustic Kale Soup
text: AT The Modern restaurant at the Museum of Modern Art, Gabriel Kreuther, the executive chef, makes a cranberry bean and kale soup, dotted with crushed cherry tomatoes, that was inspired by a rustic soup he had as a child, growing up on a farm in Niederschaeffolsheim, in the Alsace region of France.

headline: Van Leeuwen Artisan Ice Cream Opens in Brooklyn
text: After dispensing ice cream churned from Hudson Valley milk and cream from their five butter-yellow trucks since 2008, Ben Van Leeuwen, his wife, Laura O’Neill, and his brother, Peter Van Leeuwen, have settled down in Greenpoint, Brooklyn.

headline: Pain d’Avignon Opens Retail Store
text: After 10 years of selling bread to restaurants and shops, Pain d’Avignon has opened a retail outlet in the Essex Street Market on the Lower East Side. You won’t need a waiter at this tiny shop, where you are surrounded by nearly 36 different kinds of breads, rolls and pastries like croissants.

headline: Onetime ‘Rising Star’ Is in Retreat
text: Early one rainy morning in January 1988, a convoy of cars pulled onto the West Side Highway, slowed down and then stopped in all three lanes. Seven people got out. Rush-hour traffic halted. At the same time, just off the highway about 100 men and women blocked Riverside Drive. They wore gas masks and carried placards protesting the stench from a new sewage treatment plant that routinely drifted across West Harlem. In due course, the police arrived, and the seven people on the highway were arrested. Among them was a state senator, David A. Paterson, then 33 and serving his first full term in elected office.

headline: Surreal Day in Court as Fire Delays a Rapper’s Sentencing
text: This may not be quite the way Lil Wayne would describe it, but all heck broke loose at the Manhattan Criminal Court building Tuesday morning.

headline: Gridlock May Be Ending on Consumer Protection
text: WASHINGTON — A proposal to give the Federal Reserve the primary responsibility for protecting consumers from abusive and deceptive financial products emerged on Tuesday as a potential breakthrough after months of partisan gridlock in the Senate over the terms of a broad overhaul of financial regulations.

headline: 3 U.S. Judges Testify in a Death Threat Case
text: His words barely filling the room, the witness timidly held his hand aloft to be sworn in.

headline: Don’t Tell the Kids
text: RABBITS are supposed to be easy to kill. The French dispatch them with a sharp knife to the throat. A farmer in upstate New York swears that a swift smack with the side of the hand works. Others prefer a quick twist of the neck.

headline: Tuscan Rabbit Ragù
text: Adapted from Samin Nosrat

headline: Q & A on Rabbits and Backyard Farming
text: This week Novella Carpenter, who is featured in Kim Severson’s article about eating rabbit, will be taking readers’ questions about rabbits and backyard farming. Please post your questions below.

headline: The State of the Job Market — and of Inventories
text: For a Congressional hearing last month, Lawrence Katz prepared a nice overview of the labor market. But the hearing was never held, because of the blizzard. In my column this week, I mentioned a couple of numbers from Mr. Katz’s analysis. You can read the testimony in its entirety here:

headline: The Outtakes From the Rabbit Cover
text: Tiina Loite is the photo editor for the Dining section of The New York Times. Here she discusses the photography for this week’s cover story about killing and eating rabbits.

headline: The Sea, Lifeblood of Chilean Towns, Turns Deadly
text: TUBUL, Chile — The sea gave this small fishing village life. But last weekend, stirred by the powerful earthquake that rocked Chile, it savagely turned on Tubul, swallowing houses and boats and sending most of its 3,000 residents scurrying for the hills.

headline: Mimi’s Hummus Opens a Market Next Door
text: Mimi’s Hummus is one of the restaurants that have given Ditmas Park, Brooklyn, some allure for diners. Now its owner, Avi Shuker, has added something for shoppers, a beautifully curated little food shop next door. The store, all done in pale wood, is crammed floor to ceiling with products and ingredients, many destined for the Middle Eastern table.

headline: 2 Top Guatemalan Police Officials Are Arrested on Drug Charges
text: MEXICO CITY — Guatemalan authorities arrested the country’s national police chief and the head of its antinarcotics unit on Tuesday on drug charges.

headline: U.N. Is Faulted as Lacking Coordination of Aid and Security in Haiti
text: UNITED NATIONS — Humanitarian efforts by the United Nations in Haiti have lacked sufficient coordination with local organizations in delivering aid and establishing security, according to an independent assessment released on Tuesday.

headline: Indicted Ex-Leader of Bosnian Serbs Calls Atrocities ‘Myths’
text: PARIS — Radovan Karadzic, the Bosnian Serb wartime leader, on Tuesday denied charges that his troops had committed large-scale atrocities during the Bosnian war, brushing aside the accusations as “myths” fabricated by his enemies.

headline: Roman Flavor in Queens
text: "Midpriced Italian restaurants can be as predictable as cupcake places," writes Julia Moskin, "the same five flavors show up all over town. When one breaks the mold, like Testaccio, which opened in December with a Roman menu, we go." Testaccio, in Long Island City, is run by chef Ivan Beacco. The Roman inspiration is evident in the "braised oxtail, flower-like fried artichokes, and soft gnocchi with roasted exteriors, just glazed with tomato and gilded with cheese." Skip the "over-topped pizza" and instead go for the dishes that "get everything right  the smokiness of guanciale in bucatini all'amatriciana, a dressing's vinegary contrast to creamy-firm white beans and chunks of roast pork, an overlay of bottarga on spaghetti with garlic and clams." The location in Queens may seem like a far cry from Italy, but, Ms. Moskin adds, this stretch of Vernon Boulevard is "dark at night, but dotted with bright restaurants  like the original Testaccio, an unfancy neighborhood on the edge of Rome."

headline: Happy Birthday, Chopin
text: How do you pay tribute to one of the greatest composers of all time on the occasion of his 200th birthday? A weeklong series of performances featuring 200 hours of the composer's work performed on five pianos sounds just about right. This week the Winter Garden at the World Financial Center is presenting just such a tribute to Frederic Chopin, who would have celebrated the big 2-0-0 on March 1. The festival, which runs daily beginning at 9 a.m., through Friday, includes an eclectic mix of performers, with Eduardus Halim, Kimball Gallagher, Vassily Primakov, Jeffrey Swann and tonight's featured artist, Christopher O'Riley. The performance by Mr. O'Riley, the host of "From the Top" on NPR, will begin at 7 p.m.

headline: All’s Fair
text: The 2010 Armory Show, which opens on Thursday, promises to be one of the biggest art events of the year, literally. Last year's fine art fair at Piers 92 and 94 drew 56,000 visitors and over 200 dealers. Tonight MoMA is hosting a kick-off event at the museum to celebrate this year's exhibition. The party, which begins at 8:30 p.m., features a live performance by The Walkmen. The New York indie band, which, Ben Sisario writes, plays "exquisitely articulated songs of exhaustion and disaffection," will perform music off its most recent album in the Agnes Gund Garden Lobby. Adding to the mix will be the D.J. Justin Miller and the experimental band Human Rights, featuring members of Beirut, Psychic Ills, No Regular Play, and Volcano the Bear. Tickets for the party, which is also a benefit, start at $100. A shuttle bus will be available to transport guests from the Armory show at Piers 92 and 94 to MoMA.

headline: GMAC Chief Gets $1.2 Million in Pay for 45 Days’ Work
text: GMAC, the auto and home lender, has not reported a profit since 2008. But it gave its chief executive, Michael A. Carpenter, a pay package rivaling that of Lloyd C. Blankfein, chief of Goldman Sachs, the nation’s most profitable securities company.

headline: Calculating Poverty in New York: More by City Standard, and Less by Federal One
text: The number of poor people in New York rose by about 300,000, according to a new measure of poverty by the city that takes into account expenses like housing, medical costs and child care that the federal government does not include in its formulation.

headline: Eight the Hard Way
text: As some commenters have noted, there are a couple of bugs in the Java applet (Play Against the Clock) version of this puzzle. The Across Lite file is correct. Sorry for the inconvenience.

headline: Milan Fashion Week
text: Cathy Horyn's critique of the fall 2010 collections from Milan.

headline: Top Political Adviser Leaving Bloomberg the Mayor for Bloomberg the Firm
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s top political adviser is leaving City Hall after guiding the mayor to his first two electoral victories, leading Mr. Bloomberg’s aborted bid for the presidency in 2008 and promoting, with varying success, the mayor’s education, transportation, budget and environmental agenda.

headline: Ex-Official of Public Hospitals Is Fined in Bid to Aid School
text: A former board member of New York City’s public hospital system has been fined $13,500 for his role in soliciting coveted training spots in city hospitals for students from a Caribbean medical school, the city’s Conflicts of Interest Board said Tuesday.

headline: Producer of ‘The Hurt Locker’ Barred From Oscars for Message to Voters
text: LOS ANGELES  “The Hurt Locker,” a presumed front-runner in the Oscar race since picking up a string of honors from critics and the Hollywood guilds, suffered a last-minute embarrassment on Tuesday as the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences disciplined one of the film’s producers for violating the group’s campaign rules.

headline: Keeping Hope That a Voice Can Reverse Transit Cuts
text: The proposed cuts to New York City’s bus and subway service, considered the most severe in a generation, are entering the court of public opinion this week with a set of hearings being held by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, which is staring at a budget shortfall of nearly $800 million.

headline: In Danbury, Hospital Patient Shoots Nurse
text: An 85-year-old man being treated at a hospital in Danbury, Conn., pulled out a gun in the cardiac care unit on Tuesday and opened fire, wounding a nurse before being tackled by hospital workers, the police said.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: March 2, 2010

headline: Slumbering Pittsburgh Neighborhood Reawakens
text: PITTSBURGH — In the 1950s, the East Liberty neighborhood five miles east of downtown was Pennsylvania’s third-largest shopping district, behind Center City Philadelphia and downtown Pittsburgh, with more than 500 local businesses and a population of 14,000.

headline: Scholar’s School Reform U-Turn Shakes Up Debate
text: Diane Ravitch, the education historian who built her intellectual reputation battling progressive educators and served in the first Bush administration’s Education Department, is in the final stages of an astonishing, slow-motion about-face on almost every stand she once took on American schooling.

headline: Corrections
text: A picture caption on Tuesday with the continuation of an article about the challenges faced by Senator Barbara Boxer, Democrat of California, as she seeks re-election, misstated the number of terms Ms. Boxer has served in the Senate. She is in her third term, not her second.

headline: Corrections
text: A chart on Feb. 20 with the continuation of an article about the F.B.I.’s closing of its investigation into the mailing of anthrax in 2001 misidentified one of the four nucleotides present in DNA sequences that are part of what the F.B.I. contends is a code in notes mailed with the anthrax. The letter "A" represents adenine, according to the F.B.I., not guanine. A corrected version of the chart can be found at nytimes.com/national.

headline: Corrections
text: A picture caption on Tuesday with an article about concerns that digital billboards may be a distraction to drivers described incorrectly the billboards shown. While the billboard at the far right was digital, the others were conventional billboards; the photograph did not show “a succession of digital billboards.”

headline: Interference Seen in Blackwater Inquiry
text: WASHINGTON — An official at the United States Embassy in Iraq has told federal prosecutors that he believes that State Department officials sought to block any serious investigation of the 2007 shooting episode in which Blackwater Worldwide security guards were accused of murdering 17 Iraqi civilians, according to court testimony made public on Tuesday.

headline: A Vote for Peace
text: Northern Ireland has another major hurdle to cross on the long road to lasting peace. On Tuesday, the Belfast Assembly, the province’s governing body, is to vote on whether to approve the formal transfer of police and justice powers from London.

headline: Corrections
text: Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about Canada’s gold medal victory over the United States on Sunday in men’s hockey at the Vancouver Games described the Miracle on Ice incorrectly. The United States’ stunning victory over the Soviet Union at the Lake Placid Games in 1980 came in a medal-round game, not in the semifinals.

headline: Bad Science and Bad Policy
text: The federal law that mandates harsher prison terms for people arrested with crack cocaine than for those caught with cocaine powder is scientifically and morally indefensible. Bills to end the disparity are pending in both the House and Senate. Democrats who worry about being pegged as “soft on crime” will have to find their backbones and push the legislation through.

headline: Fighting Chance
text: Hemmed in by residential development and the nation’s demand for energy, the number of sage grouse has dropped from 16 million to a few hundred thousand scattered across 11 Western states. The United States Fish and Wildlife Service is expected to decide soon whether to place the bird on the endangered species list.

text: To the Editor:
