headline: Corrections
text: Because of an editing error, a picture caption on Tuesday with an article anticipating Sidney Crosby’s first N.H.L. game for the Pittsburgh Penguins since he scored the decisive goal for Canada in its Olympic gold medal victory on Sunday misstated, in some copies, when the photograph was taken. The photograph, which showed Crosby playing against Brooks Orpik of the United States, who is also Crosby’s Penguins teammate, was taken when the teams played on Feb. 21, not in the gold medal game.

headline: Corrections
text: A dance column on Monday about New York City Ballet’s winter season referred incorrectly to the commission of the John Adams work “Naïve and Sentimental Music,” which provides the score for the Peter Martins ballet of the same title. It was commissioned in the late 1990s by the Los Angeles Philharmonic, the Ensemble Modern Orchestra, the Vancouver Symphony and the Sydney Symphony. It was not commissioned by City Ballet.

headline: Graduates Fault Advice of Guidance Counselors
text: Most people who graduated from high school in the last dozen years believe that their guidance counselors provided little meaningful advice about college or careers, a new study has found. And many said the best advice on their futures came from teachers.

headline: Corrections
text: A picture on Tuesday with an article about the Nazi propaganda film “Jew Süss,” whose director, Veit Harlan, is the subject of the documentary “Harlan  In the Shadow of ‘Jew Süss,’ ” was published in error. It showed the documentary’s director of photography, Ludolph Weyer, not the director, Felix Moeller. The article also misspelled the name of the college in Minnesota where Linda Schulte-Sasse, who commented on Harlan, is a professor. It is Macalester College, not Macalaster.

headline: Corrections
text: A picture on Feb. 12 with a report in the “Arts, Briefly” column about the Vail International Dance Festival, where Larry Keigwin will be the artist in residence, carried an erroneous credit. The picture, of Mr. Keigwin, was by Tom Caravaglia.

headline: Britain Grapples With Debt of Greek Proportions
text: LONDON — As Greece’s debt troubles batter the euro, Britain has done its utmost to stay above the fray.

headline: Corrections
text: An obituary on Saturday about Ernst Beyeler, a leading dealer of modern art, misstated the name of the steel magnate and art collector from whom he acquired artworks by Klee, Giacometti and others. It was G. David Thompson, not David G. Thompson.

headline: Survey Finds Few Have Fond Memories of Their High School Guidance Counselors
text: A survey being released Wednesday by Public Agenda, a nonprofit research organization, seems sure to provoke strong emotions among high school guidance counselors and students, to say nothing of high school graduates and their parents.

headline: Corrections
text: An obituary on Saturday about David Soyer, the founding cellist of the Guarneri String Quartet, misstated the given name of the pianist who helped found the chamber music festival at Marlboro College in Vermont, at which Mr. Soyer performed regularly. He was Rudolf Serkin, not Rudolph.

headline: Correction
text: An editorial on Sunday about President Obama’s pending decisions on nuclear weapons policy incorrectly said that nuclear posture reviews are issued every four years. Since the end of the cold war, they have been done in 1994 and 2002.

headline: Corrections
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Does Haiti’s Earthquake Hurt Cambodia?
text: The silver lining to a tragedy like the Haiti earthquake is that it gets Americans focused on that country’s problems and reaching into their pockets to try to help. We may ignore Haiti’s day-to-day needs, but after the earthquake the outpouring truly was magnificent.

headline: Snow Boots to Sockless, Briefly
text: IN the depths of a New York City winter, it’s easy to forget what tropical warmth really feels like — that close, comforting pressure on your bare skin, the humid aroma of vegetal growth and decay, the way vistas both urban and pastoral seem to shimmer, sigh and relax in the heat. You can remember these things, sure, but they seem abstract — faded dreams from another life.

headline: ‘Yes’ for Texas Governor Is ‘No’ to Washington
text: HOUSTON — Senator Kay Bailey Hutchison had all the advantages a year ago when she laid her plans to run for governor: a high popularity rating, a party shaken by President Obama’s victory, a big bankroll and, most important, the backing of influential Republicans, who felt the incumbent governor, Rick Perry, was too divisive and too conservative.

headline: Catching Up With Matsui
text: TEMPE, Ariz. – Johnny Damon asked last week at Tigers camp  if it were true that Derek Jeter was getting married. I said I had no idea. Maybe, Damon joked, Jeter would show up with a drawing of his wife on a sketch pad.

headline: Zuckerman Decides Not to Run Against Gillibrand for Senate
text: Mortimer B. Zuckerman, the real estate and media tycoon, has decided not to run for Senator Kirsten E. Gillibrand’s seat this year, he said in an interview Tuesday night.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 995 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American on Tuesday:

headline: California: White Hood Prompts Inquiry on San Diego Campus
text: The police at the University of California, San Diego, are investigating the discovery Monday night of what appeared to be a Ku Klux Klan-style hood on a statue outside the main campus library. The hood, “crudely fashioned” from a pillowcase, a university statement said, was found along with a rose placed in the statue’s fingers. The campus has been shaken by racial incidents in the past two weeks that have led to student protests and promises by administrators to improve the racial climate at the campus and the nine others in the system.

headline: CF Returns to Terra Fray
text: The battles among fertilizer companies have been rejoined. CF Industries told shareholders in January that it was done chasing its big rival, Terra Industries. The nearly yearlong pursuit included some ungainly moments, as when CF’s nominees to Terra’s board rejected one of CF’s many offers.

headline: In New York, Wall Street Bailout Softens the Blow of a Recession
text: In fall 2008, after Lehman Brothers collapsed and other Wall Street firms seemed ready to topple, New York appeared to be headed for a brutal recession, one that would rival the worst downturns in the city’s history.

headline: Jon Hamm of ‘Mad Men’ Is Becoming the Voice of Mercedes-Benz
text: For three seasons, the actor Jon Hamm has played the 1960s adman Don Draper on the hit AMC TV series “Mad Men.” Beginning on Sunday, he gets to do some advertising work in the real world as the new commercial voice of Mercedes-Benz USA. Mr. Hamm’s voice will be heard in a commercial that Mercedes-Benz USA will run on local ABC stations in the carmaker’s 16 largest markets during the ABC network’s broadcast of the Academy Awards.

headline: Word of the Day | imponderable
text: imponderable •\(ˌ)im-ˈpän-d(ə-)rə-bəl\• noun and adjective

headline: Barry Hannah, Darkly Comic Writer, Dies at 67
text: Barry Hannah, a writer who found wide acclaim with wild, darkly comic short stories and novels set in a phantasmagoric South moving at warp speed, died on Monday at his home in Oxford, Miss. He was 67.

headline: With Leno, Palin Pushes Back Against ‘Family Guy’
text: In an interview Tuesday night on “The Tonight Show With Jay Leno,” Sarah Palin once again criticized “Family Guy,” the Fox animated series, for a joke she believed was directed at her family, and rebuked the news media for not giving her the opportunity to fully explain her opinions on that show.

headline: News Quiz | March 3, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page.

headline: CF’s New Bid Raises Thorny Questions
text: The battles among fertilizer companies have been rejoined. CF Industries told shareholders in January that it was done chasing its big rival, Terra Industries. The nearly yearlong pursuit included some ungainly moments, as when CF’s nominees to Terra’s board rejected one of CF’s many offers.

headline: Greece Set to Release Austerity Plan
text: 5:55 a.m. | Updated George Papandreou, prime minister of Greece, said Wednesday that his government would cut 4.8 billion more euros from its deficit through tax hikes and spending reductions.

headline: Fight Erupts Over Inquiry Into Jakarta Bank Bailout
text: The police fired tear gas and used water cannons to disperse thousands of protesters outside Indonesia’s Parliament on Tuesday, while security guards inside had to break up a fight among lawmakers debating the results of an investigation into a bank bailout, Peter Gelling writes in The New York Times.

headline: Markets Struggled as Trading Day Neared End
text: Reassurances that Greece would take further steps to trim its deficit helped prop up financial markets on Tuesday. But the day’s gains largely evaporated in the afternoon as concern over unemployment and a possible increase in interest rates resurfaced, The New York Times’s Javier C. Hernandez reported.

headline: Standard Chartered Reports Record Gains for Year
text: Standard Chartered met expectations with a record annual profit of $5.15 billion as strong investment banking growth in its core Asian markets offset a jump in bad debts in the Middle East, Reuters reported.

headline: Management Shuffle at Bristol-Myers
text: The drug maker Bristol-Myers Squibb said on Tuesday that its chief executive would retire in May and be succeeded by the chief operating officer.

headline: ‘A Subversive Take on a Cherished Story’
text: WHO directed this new film version of “Alice in Wonderland”?

headline: China to Launch Space Station Module in 2011
text: HONG KONG — The Heavenly Palace, the first module in China’s permanent space station, will be launched next year, a senior aerospace official confirmed Wednesday.

headline: Force10 Networks Plans $143 Million I.P.O.
text: Force10 Networks, a company that provides equipment for computer networks, plans to raise $143.8 million in an initial public offering, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Governments Press Funds on European Bets
text: Hedge funds have been asked by American officials to preserve records of their bets against the euro,  as political pressure increases in Europe and America to gauge the effects of recent speculation on Greek debt and the European currency.

headline: Seeking a Buyer, Swoozie’s Files for Bankruptcy
text: Swoozie’s, a private equity-backed American retailer of luxury gifts and stationery products, filed for bankruptcy protection on Tuesday, saying it was hurt by the under-performance of recently acquired stores in the Northeast, Reuters reported.

headline: Bombers Kill Dozens as Iraq Vote Nears
text: BAGHDAD — Even with Iraqi security forces on a heightened state of alert in advance of Sunday’s national elections, dozens of Iraqis were killed Wednesday in a devastating series of suicide bombings in the restive city of Baquba.

headline: LaSalle Hotel Underwriters Buy Stock
text: LaSalle Hotel Properties, a real estate investment trust, said Tuesday that the underwriters of a recent public stock offering have exercised an option to acquire an additional 802,500 common shares.

headline: What Are Your Beliefs About Marriage?
text: Do you want to get married someday? Why or why not? Do you think a couple should live together before they marry? How young do you think is too young to get married? How long, ideally, should you be married before having children? Read about a recent study that looked at data of men and women, ages 15 to 44, to address some of these questions.

headline: Stylesight Socks Away Another $5 Million
text: Stylesight, the fashion content aggregator and trend forecaster, has raised the second half of a $10 million funding round, PaidContent reported.

headline: Showcase: Walking, Con Brio
text: What the rest of the world calls power walking, New Yorkers call a leisurely stroll. There is an assertiveness to the local pedestrian, borne of having too much to do, too little time to do it and too many tourists in the way. Of course, the manner can be observed among commuters headed toward the Port Authority Bus Terminal at rush hour. But it’s even memorialized in Central Park, where the walking-figure icons look as much like kick boxers as pedestrians.

headline: Juncker to Markets: We Have Tools to Stop You
text: Jean-Claude Juncker, the outspoken prime minister of Luxembourg and head of the eurozone finance ministers’ group, told the German financial daily Handelsblatt that a collapse of the currency zone was an “absurd idea,” and that financial markets could only “blackmail” governments so far before they should be stopped.

headline: Seeing the Investor Value in Being Green
text: Constructing or renovating a building to make it environmentally sustainable can be a daunting task for any owner, but Jamestown Properties, a German commercial real estate investment company, has decided it will go “green” in nearly its entire $4 billion portfolio of buildings, all located in the United States.

text: From Brian Stelter at Media Decoder:

headline: S.E.C. to Beef Up Its New York Office This Year
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission plans to expand its New York office by about 8 percent this year as the financial regulator focuses more heavily on catching cheaters at hedge funds and brokerages, Reuters reported.

headline: Ackman Under Attack Over General Growth Deal
text: General Growth Properties unsecured creditors and suitor Simon Property Group on Tuesday criticized William A. Ackman’s role in the mall owner’s restructuring plan, alleging conflicts of interest given his position as a director and largest shareholder, Reuters reported.

headline: Archimedes Gets $98 Million Injection
text: Archimedes Pharma, a specialty drugmaker, said on Tuesday it had raised £65 million ($98 million) in what marks the largest funding round by a private European biopharma company in the last 15 years, Reuters reported.

headline: Politicians, Lobbyists and Complainers Descend on Beijing
text: BEIJING — With great fanfare and rigid security, China on Wednesday launched its annual exercise in participatory democracy, socialist-style: the opening of the Chinese People’s Political Consultative Congress, a 2,252-member body that advises Communist Party leaders on how to run the nation.

text: Offense

headline: Prague Film Festival Focuses on Human Rights
text: Death by stoning in Iran, the “Socratic method” as taught in a Berlin prison, and a Finnish family’s search for ecologically correct toilet paper and toothpaste are among the topics addressed by Europe’s largest human rights film festival, which kicks off in Prague on March 10.

headline: Aquaponics
text: The co-cultivation of plants and fish in a system that shares water between them.

headline: Bridgepoint Makes Bid for Care UK
text: Care UK, a British health and social care provider, said private-equity investor Bridgepoint Capital made a recommended offer to buy the company for about £281 million ($423 million) in cash.

headline: Warburg Buys Primerica Stake Ahead of I.P.O.
text: Citigroup‘s Primerica Financial has agreed to sell $230 million in stock to the British private equity firm Warburg Pincus, before a planned initial public offering of the insurance unit, Bloomberg News reported.

text: Could Tommy Hilfiger be headed for the “sale” rack?

headline: Grassroots Persecution of Christians
text: Today’s idea: Unlike the systematic Communist and Nazi campaigns of the 20th century, the widespread persecution of Christians in the Muslim world today is more decentralized while often officially sanctioned, an article says.

headline: Video: Iraqi Expats Get Ready to Vote
text: AMMAN, Jordan — In the first of a series of videos by New York Times journalists interviewing Iraqi voters in the run-up to the March 7 parliamentary elections, Reem Makhoul speaks to Iraqis living in neighboring Jordan. They fled the country of their birth because of violence and instability, and are voting for a new government that will – they hope – improve conditions to the point where they can come home.

headline: Greek Cabinet Approves New Austerity Measures
text: The Greek government Wednesday approved new tax increases and a 30 percent cut in holiday pay for public employees as part of a new raft of austerity measures aimed at narrowing its gaping budget deficit, a government official said, Niki Kitsantonis reports in The New York Times.

headline: Is Vornado Considering Bid for General Growth?
text: Is the Vornado Realty Trust planning to throw its hat into the crowded ring for a piece of General Growth Properties?

headline: How Women Saved Social Security
text: Increases in life expectancy might have bankrupted Social Security if it were not for women in the work force, an economist writes.

headline: American Idol: The Top 10 Men
text: Here’s a confession about last week: I liked the guys. No, not the full show, with the full songs, and the full pain, but the end of the night, when five-second performer clips were shown. Maybe it was a wonder of editing, but almost every one of the dozen had at least one great moment, it seemed. Not two, but hey, it’s early yet.

headline: Living With Music: A Playlist by Joe Sacco
text: Joe Sacco is a cartoonist and journalist whose books include “Palestine,” “Safe Area Gorazde” and, most recently, “Footnotes in Gaza.”

headline: Securities Committee Recommends Disclosing Shorts
text: In a report by the Committee of European Securities Regulators released Tuesday, the organization recommended “a pan-European disclosure regime for net short positions in shares.”

headline: R.B.S. Said to Seek $752 Million for Grosvenor House
text: London’s landmark Grosvenor House, once home to the Duke of Westminster and the Grosvenor family, has gone on the block.

headline: An App for Donating Money While You Shop
text: A cellphone app called CauseWorld has figured out a way for advertisers to turn their marketing dollars into charitable donations, and Procter & Gamble, Citi and Kraft are on board.

headline: SouthWest Water Goes Private for $275 Million
text: SouthWest Water said it agreed to be acquired by institutional investors for about $275 million, a deal that would take the water treatment company private, Reuters reported.

headline: Sampler: Layoff Notices in San Francisco, and Teaching How to Kill Rabbits
text: Sonoma County to Check Immigration Status | Starting Friday, the fingerprints of those arrested in Sonoma County will be sent electronically to the Department of Homeland Security and checked for immigration violations. Sonoma will be the first county in the Bay Area to participate in the department’s “Secure Communities” program. Critics say the program gives local law enforcement officials a bigger role in immigration enforcement, which is conducted by the federal government. The program, which began in late 2008, is now used in 10 California counties, including Sacramento, Los Angeles and San Diego. “This is a common-sense approach: Everyone who gets arrested gets checked for immigration status,” said Matt McCaffrey, a sheriff’s captain. “In this case, they’re already in the system for entering into the country illegally or for having a record.” Separately, a United States district court judge will hold a hearing on Wednesday in Oakland on a lawsuit filed by the American Civil Liberties Union, accusing the Sonoma County Sheriff’s Office of routinely holding Latinos longer than the maximum 72 hours for immigration detention. [The Santa Rosa Press Democrat]

headline: Fantasies of the Chicago Boys
text: Ah, Chile. Remember how, during the Social Security debate, Chile’s retirement system was held up as an ideal — except it turned out that it actually yielded very poor results for many people, and the Chileans themselves hated it? Now we have the usual suspects claiming that Chile’s relatively low death toll in the quake proves that — you guessed it — Milton Friedman was right. You see, the Chicago Boys made Chile rich, and that’s what did it.

headline: The Early Word: Jobless Breakthrough
text: America’s unemployed can breathe a sigh of relief Wednesday after Senator Jim Bunning, Republican of Kentucky, dropped his block on extending federal jobless benefits that expired Sunday.

headline: Ferrari Chairman Says Hybrid Is Not a ‘Bourgeois Ferrari’
text: GENEVA — “Ferrari” and “the environment” are not words that normally turn up in the same sentence, but that was the title of a short film that the Italian maker of exotic sports cars showed to visitors at the Geneva auto show on Tuesday.

headline: A Skeptical Arab League Backs Indirect Peace Talks
text: CAIRO — Arab League foreign ministers on Wednesday approved an American proposal that Palestinians hold indirect talks with Israelis, a move that could help restart direct discussions between the two sides that broke down more than a year ago.

headline: Home Is Where the Art Is
text: As The Times reported back in December, galleries all over the city are moving from the storefront to the home front. The latest addition to this mini-movement? Paul Johnson of Johnson Trading, a design gallery on Greenwich Street, just opened a show called “Home” in the Chrystie Street loft he calls, well, his home. The subject of the show is the self-taught 60-something outsider artist Robert Loughlin. Loughlin spent most of his life being a picker (or chineur), one of those people scouring flea markets looking for rare resalable gems among the rummage — always in the hopes of “selling Andy Warhol a cookie jar,” as the writer Irwin Warren put it in his foreword for the show’s program. Johnson started out as a picker himself, and about 10 years ago he began buying pieces from the back of Loughlin’s pickup truck at the old Chelsea flea market. His collection now comprises more than 500 pieces, from chairs, canvases, record covers, advertising posters and other bizarre objects — ivory teeth and baby seats — all scribbled on with Loughlin’s Tom of Finland-esque signature smoking head, obsessively filling every single one of the loft’s 4,500 square feet. To this day, Loughlin still peddles his pieces (for $300 and up) at the Chelsea flea market, but it is unlikely anybody will ever be able to accumulate a collection of similar size or quality as Johnson’s (not to mention as elegantly hung by the decorator to the stars Ricky Clifton). “I definitely have enough now, and I don’t have any more space in my house,” says Johnson when asked whether he’ll continue collecting Loughlin. He pauses, before adding “Unless it’s really good.”

headline: Wall St. Bailout Softens Blow of Recession
text: In fall 2008, after Lehman Brothers collapsed and other Wall Street firms seemed ready to topple, New York appeared to be headed for a recession that would rival the worst downturns in the city’s history.

headline: Rangel Steps Aside From  Post During Ethics Inquiry
text: WASHINGTON — Representative Charles B. Rangel stepped down on Wednesday as chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee after losing support within his party because of ethics violations, shaking up the Democratic power structure in the House and costing New York a powerful seat of influence in Congress.

headline: The Best Public Transportation in Europe is in Munich, Poll Says
text: Munich has Europe’s best public transportation, according to a study published Tuesday. The survey, which covered 23 European cities, found that 9 offered only ‘‘acceptable’’ bus, streetcar and metro services.

headline: Speed Read for Wednesday, March 3
text: Highlights from media coverage in today’s New York Times:

headline: City Pension Vote Lays Groundwork for Labor Battles
text: When the full Board of Supervisors voted Tuesday to pass a ballot proposal that would save San Francisco hundreds of millions of dollars in future pension costs, the initial sponsor of the measure, of all people, sat glumly in his chair, sighing and glowering.

headline: An Animated Irish Invasion
text: There’s quite a bit of backstory on how the little indie “The Secret of Kells” made it to the animation big leagues of an Oscar nomination, as the Bagger discovered by spending some time with the director, Tomm Moore. But there’s even more of a backstory about Irish animation in general.

headline: Bittman on Why (in Part) People Love Buenos Aires
text: “The most amazing thing in a quick trip to Buenos Aires was the French fry list, which our waiter patiently went over with me in a mixture of bad English (his) and bad Spanish (mine), ” Mark Bittman writes in his blog, Bitten. Read more.

headline: Q & A: When There Are Few Insurers to Choose From
text: The American Medical Association last week released its annual study examining competition in the health insurance market. The verdict: competition is dwindling. In 24 of the 43 states studied, the two biggest insurers together covered at least 70 percent of the market. Last year, that was true in 18 of 42 states studied.

headline: Let’s Cast the ‘Gilligan’s Island’ Movie
text: Television’s best-known three-hour tour is about to get its own two-hour big-screen adaptation (well, maybe two-and-a-half hours when you factor in commercials and previews).  A  film version of “Gilligan’s Island,” the classic 1960s CBS sitcom about seven stranded castaways living it up on an uncharted desert isle, is being prepared at Warner Brothers by producers who include the series creator Sherwood Schwartz, Variety reported (registration required).

headline: Geneva Auto Show: 2011 Nissan Micra
text: Introduced on Tuesday: 2011 Nissan Micra

headline: The Envelope, Please.. . .
text: A clutch is one of those things that will be around for a while. They’re just so classic, really — I’ve got clutches from the ’30s, in that envelope style that’s really simple and not too overdone. This one is part of the collection that I just designed for Longchamp, and you can actually stuff a load of things in it and bash it around. The leather is textured to look like shagreen, which I love. Most bags are too heavy to carry things in, and so many of them are stiff, and you know it’s going to take years to mess them up. I like things that are already worn in, something tactile that’s going to be comfortable on your skin. When I was working on the collection, I showed it to my daughter, but she’s a bit — you know. She just said, “Yeah, it’s all right.” She prefers bling and Hello Kitty. She says she doesn’t like Hello Kitty anymore, but I know she really does. I mean, I love it, too. I just nabbed her Hello Kitty makeup bag, in fact. What can I say? I like a mismatch. — As told to Alexandra Marshall

headline: Temporary S.B.A. Stimulus Extension Becomes Law
text: Last night, the Senate finally pushed Kentucky Republican Jim Bunning aside and passed a temporary jobs bill that includes a brief extension of Small Business Administration stimulus provisions. With 21 Republicans behind the bill, the vote tally was 78 to 19, and the legislation was signed into law by President Obama late Tuesday.

headline: Teaching Techniques
text: Doug Lemov, founder of the charter-school network Uncommon Schools, analyzes methods that effective teachers from around the country use to engage students.

headline: Yankees vs. Pirates Lineups
text: TAMPA, Fla. — Manager Joe Girardi unveiled the first of many spring lineups Wednesday for the Yankees’ opener at 1:05 p.m. against Pittsburgh, slotting Curtis Granderson in center field and in the No. 2 spot in the batting order filled so capably last year by Johnny Damon.

headline: Cheese Thief Jailed for 7 Years in California
text: Updated | 11:38 a.m. On Monday, more than a year after a man was arrested outside a market in California with a $3.99 bag of Tillamook shredded cheese in his pants he had not paid for, a judge decided to go relatively easy on him, sentencing him to seven years and eight months in jail.

headline: Bits Scan: Flash Drives, Jon Stewart and Warfare at Activision
text: Good morning, Bits readers. If you’re in New York, make sure to grab your umbrella. Here’s Wednesday’s news roundup:

headline: Anatomy of a Smear Campaign
text: 2:40 p.m. | Updated

headline: More on a Proposed Rule on Retirement Savings
text: Last Friday, the United States Department of Labor proposed a new rule governing investment advisers’ fees intended to help better protect, and increase, workers’ retirement savings.

headline: The Dartmouth Debate: Health Costs
text: The last year has introduced me to a lot of thoughtful students of health care policy. Three who have been particularly incisive are Elliott Fisher and Jonathan Skinner of Dartmouth and Peter Bach of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York. And a debate has recently erupted among them, with Dr. Bach on one side and Dr. Fisher and Mr. Skinner on the other.

headline: Wednesday Reading
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Fed Survey Finds Recovery Plods On
text: A report by the Federal Reserve on Wednesday portrayed an economy that was making hesitant progress but still wrestling with familiar troubles: high unemployment, tepid spending by businesses and consumers, and deterioration in the commercial real estate market.

headline: Help for the Blind, Confusion for Everyone Else
text: Press any of the roughly 2,400 street-corner buttons that claim to control traffic signals for pedestrians in New York, and the chances are only one in four that they will actually work.

headline: Hopes for Alzheimer’s Drug Are Dashed
text: It seemed somewhat unlikely, but in recent years an old Russian hay fever pill had become one of the world’s best hopes for treating the growing epidemic of Alzheimer’s disease.

headline: Battle Over Modern Warfare Game as Two Executives Depart
text: The runaway success of the military themed video game Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 2 has given way to corporate hostilities. On Tuesday, the heads of the game studio Infinity Ward, which produces the Call of Duty games for the publisher Activision Blizzard, abruptly left that company under unclear circumstances, Reuters reported. Activision said that Jason West, the Infinity Ward president, and Vince Zampella, the studio’s chief executive, had both departed.

headline: Ukrainian Parliament Seals Leader’s Ouster
text: MOSCOW — The Parliament in Ukraine passed a vote of no confidence in Prime Minister Yulia V. Tymoshenko on Wednesday, ousting the last of the Orange Revolution leaders from power but almost certainly not from politics.

headline: It Ain’t Just Pie
text: The circus is coming to town — the Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus, that is, opening at Madison Square Garden on March 25. While it’s still a few weeks and a few towns away, our colleague Glenn Collins had a cool article on Diner’s Journal last night about the circus’s Pie Car, a venerable circus-train tradition where nowadays aerialist and roustabout alike graze on everything from dainty salads to 3 a.m. PBJ sandwiches. See full article.

headline: About That Garden …
text: In the beginning, before fish, before man, there was a garden. And the earth brought forth vegetation, beautiful to behold, sustenance for the body. And it was good.

headline: Nine to Know: On Mariano Rivera
text: Bill Chuck created Billy-Ball.com and is a co-author of Walkoffs, Last Licks, and Final Outs. He grew up in New York and now lives with his wife (a Red Sox fan), and daughter (a Yankees fan), two miles from Fenway Park while Bill claims to be Switzerland. His other daughter lives in New York City, away from the fray. You can follow him on Twitter.

headline: Live Updates on N.H.L. Trade Deadline
text: The N.H.L. trade deadline is today at 3 p.m. Eastern and while some big names were moved before the Olympic break (Ilya Kovalchuk to the Devils, Olli Jokinen to the Rangers, J.S. Giguere and Dion Phaneuf to the Maple Leafs), it’s certainly possible that other significant moves could be made today.

headline: The Credibility of Climate Science, Cont.
text: There is an intense debate under way among climate change scientists over how to rebuild public confidence in their work after the damaging disclosures in hundreds of hacked e-mail messages from a British climate research center and the more recent revelations of errors in the latest United Nations report on climate change.

headline: Post-Crisis, the Evolving Structure of Deals
text: In the wake of the financial crisis, deal lawyers have been reconsidering the structure of acquisitions. The result has been a clash of wills between targets and acquirers. Targets have sought to bind acquirers as tightly as possible, seeking to avoid a deal collapse that destroys shares prices,  similar to what happened to many targets amid the crisis.

headline: ‘A Nice Gesture’
text: Monologue |  Tuesday night on “Jimmy Kimmel Live” on ABC: People magazine has confirmed that former President Clinton called Tiger Woods to offer his support during the ordeal. For real. They have things in common, I guess.

headline: Paterson’s Ethics Breach Is Turned Over to Prosecutors
text: Gov. David A. Paterson falsely testified under oath during an ethics investigation into his acceptance of free World Series tickets last fall, according to the State Commission on Public Integrity, which announced on Wednesday that it had asked prosecutors to determine if criminal charges should be brought against the governor.

headline: Can Teachers Be Taught to Teach Better?
text: This week in the Sunday Magazine, writer Elizabeth Green considers the work of education reformers like Doug Lemov who believe that good teaching is not just instinctive — “a kind of magic performed by born superstars” — but, instead, consists of deliberate techniques that can be taught. She writes:

headline: ‘Fans Are Not Happy’
text: Monologue |  Tuesday night on “Late Night With Jimmy Fallon” on NBC: Did you guys watch the season finale of “The Bachelor” last night? Well, fans are not happy that Jake proposed to Vienna instead of Tenley. Yeah, people are very angry that he picked a lady that nobody really likes. And then John McCain was like, “Hey, it happens.”

headline: Gay Marriage Is Legal in U.S. Capital
text: WASHINGTON — It was cold and drizzling outside the City Courthouse just after 6 a.m. on Wednesday, but no one seemed to mind among the same-sex couples waiting for the chance to apply for a marriage license.

headline: ‘A Good-Looking Republican’

text: Senator Michael B. Enzi, Republican of Wyoming, issued a statement on Wednesday expressing disappointment with President Obama’s decision to press ahead with comprehensive health care legislation.

headline: ‘I Love the Biathlon’
text: Monologue |  Tuesday night on “The Jay Leno Show” on NBC: I love the biathlon. That’s the sport that involves skiing and shooting the rifle. Or as Sarah Palin and her husband, Todd, call it, “date night.”

headline: With an Eye on Education, Liu Takes a New Approach
text: Most city officials prefer to announce their investigations after they have completed the work, be it fines assessed by the city’s Conflicts of Interest Board, undercover sting operations initiated by the police or traffic studies conducted by the Department of Transportation.

headline: Seeking Your Questions on Historically Black Colleges
text: More than 100 institutions of higher learning in this country are classified as historically black colleges and universities. That formal designation originated in 1980, when President Jimmy Carter signed an executive order to establish a federal program “to overcome the effects of discriminatory treatment and to strengthen and expand the capacity of historically black colleges and universities to provide quality education.” Last month, President Obama signed an executive order of his own that would add nearly $100 million to the program.

headline: For an Uncapped Season, Uncharted Waters in the N.F.L.
text: Perhaps the clearest indication of what the N.F.L.’s most unusual free-agency period will look like comes from Atlanta, where General Manager Thomas Dimitroff offered a sobering view of the Falcons’ internal calendar.

headline: Rangel Takes Leave From Committee
text: Rep. Charles B. Rangel announced that he will take a temporary leave of absence as chair of the House Ways and Means Committee on Wednesday. (Video: MSNBC)

headline: With Election Looming, Tories Appear to Take a Detour in Britain
text: LONDON — A year ago, it looked as if the next British election would be an easy rout. The Conservative opposition was ahead in the polls by more than 20 percentage points. The prime minister was widely unpopular, the economy was an overstretched disaster, and the government seemed at times to be a chaotic pool of exhausted self-loathing.

headline: And the Best Oscar App Goes to . . .
text: If you are counting down the hours until you hear the words, “the envelope please,” there are a few Apple iPhone apps to help you savor the anticipation.

headline: One Flight Attendant’s Answer to the Carry-On Crunch
text: How do you get a plane full of passengers quickly seated with carry-on bags stowed neatly overhead? Meet Larry Wu, a resourceful Virgin America flight attendant.

headline: Vocabulinks
text: An occasional assemblage of notable vocabulary and linguistic debate from around the Web.

headline: Sade Soldiers On at No. 1 on Billboard Charts
text: Sade’s “Soldier of Love” (Epic) is No. 1 on Billboard’s album chart for the third week in a row. “Soldier of Love” sold 127,000 copies last week, according to Nielsen SoundScan, bringing its three-week total to 820,000. Lady Antebellum’s “Need You Now” (Capitol Nashville) holds at No. 2 with 118,000 sales, and Johnny Cash’s “American VI: Ain’t No Grave” (American/Lost Highway), said to be the last of Cash’s prolific late sessions with Rick Rubin, opens at No. 3 with 54,000. (In another sign of how large Cash looms in pop music, his 1958 song “Guess Things Happen That Way” last week became the 10 billionth song downloaded from Apple’s iTunes store.)

headline: The Story of Eau
text: Nicolas Ghesquière is one of the fashion flock’s great innovators, but his collections almost always carry a whiff of nostalgia. Fittingly, his first fragrance for Balenciaga also demonstrates his particular knack for keeping a respectful eye on the pastwhile forging a path to the future. With inspirations that range from the traditional (violet chypre, patchouli, cedar and carnations) to the more unusual (floor wax and gasoline), the resulting scent is ultimately modern enough for the likes of Charlotte Gainsbourg, his muse and the face of the ad campaign. “It has a sexy presence that’s not at all about romanticism,” he says. “It’s more urban — a little sharp, even a little tough.” More…

headline: N.H.L. Gets Back to Business
text: Under normal circumstances, Wednesday would be one of the biggest unofficial national holidays in Canada. It’s the N.H.L. trade deadline (officially: 3 p.m., Toronto Maple Leafs time), which normally captivates a country thoroughly dedicated to having fun on all that ice. But this year is not normal.

headline: Italy Accuses 7 of Arms Sales to Iran
text: ROME — Seven people accused of selling arms to Iran via several countries in Europe have been arrested in Italy, the police in Milan said Wednesday.

headline: Sully Cleared for Final Approach
text: Capt. Chesley B. Sullenberger III, the US Airways pilot who guided a powerless plane full of passengers to a memorable splash landing in the Hudson River last year, was preparing for his final turn at the helm on Wednesday morning.

text: Mysterious pain, doubting doctors, depression, fatigue and brain fog — six people speak about living with fibromyalgia.

In response, George Packer points out that Bush’s deficit spending wasn’t the only place where Daniels made dubious public arguments in support of his boss’s agenda. There was the cost of the Iraq war as well:

headline: A Stress-Free Oscar Campaign
text: What’s the least stressful way to be part of the Oscar hoopla? Act in a nominated live-action short. At the premiere of “Brooklyn’s Finest” on Tuesday night, the Bagger spoke with one of them, Vincent D’Onofrio. Mr. D’Onofrio appeared in “The New Tenants,” a short directed by Joachim Back and written by and starring the author and surprisingly good actor David Rakoff. His part in the 20-minute film took two days of work.

headline: Jailing a Woman for a Miscarriage?
text: A few readers have e-mailed me to ask for a forum here to discuss the news out of Utah, where the Legislature passed a bill last week (now waiting for the signature of Gov. Gary R. Herbert) that could potentially lead to charges against women because of how they act when pregnant.

headline: Excerpts of Obama’s Speech
text: At our sib-blog Prescriptions, we’ll be blogging about President Obama’s planned speech for 1:45 p.m. today. Meanwhile, the White House has released some excerpts of what he intends to say.

headline: Taliban: Bomb the Ban
text: The Taliban, hardly proponents of the First Amendment when they ruled Afghanistan, have suddenly decided that freedom of speech can be useful, and the Fourth Estate worth protecting.

headline: Kitsch With a Pedigree
text: I WOULD never wear pajamas in the daytime or in the street, but occasionally I envy the life of Julian Schnabel. His look in particular, disheveled and raffish, seems an impossible goal. I have the beard and, currently, the hair of questionable length, but it will never work, because I’m not allergic to structured clothing.

headline: Cab-Share Rollout Lacks Cabs and Sharers
text: Rain, rain, rain, on this day,It seemed to keep all the riders away!

headline: For Heavy Metal, a Light Touch
text: From an outsider’s perspective, the aesthetics of heavy metal music can seem fairly predictable. There are usually copious amounts of black, images of things rotting and references to corpses, funerals and obscure diseases — not to mention inadvertently comical names like Hypothalamus. Religious symbols will almost certainly be defaced. And when a book comes out on a legendary logo designer like Christophe Szpajdel, it will have the appearance of a hymnal, with its flexible, pebbled cover embossed with gold type in some vaguely Gothic font. Well, naturally. The funny thing is what happens once you crack it open — turns out Szpajdel, a 38-year-old Belgian whose day job is in forestry engineering, isn’t all that inspired by death after all.

headline: Travel Deals: Flight Sale on Iberia Airlines
text: Travelzoo has the scoop on a particularly thrifty find: round-trip flights from New York to Casablanca, Morocco for $587 . The deal is good for travel between April 13 and May 20.

headline: Road to Broadway Is Paved With ‘Matzah’
text: Aspiring musical composers and lyricists, take note: Using YouTube to show your performance chops and creativity could lead to gigs on Broadway!

headline: For the Best Yakisoba, Make it Yourself
text: I wish I could give you the name of a restaurant that serves good yakisoba, but despite the fact that this Japanese stir-fried noodle dish is essentially fast food, in this country it’s best made at home. There are literally thousands of versions; this week’s Minimalist column features mine.

headline: Continental to Charge for Exit Row Seats in Coach
text: Continental Airlines announced today that it will charge for exit row seats in coach, starting March 17.

headline: Earthquake Exposes Fault Lines in Chilean Politics
text: SANTIAGO, Chile — With a torrent of criticism over her government’s response to the earthquake and little more than a week to dispel it before leaving office, President Michelle Bachelet on Wednesday intensified her efforts to provide help to the hundreds of thousands of people affected by the disaster and publicly began the fight to preserve her legacy.

headline: Israeli Raid Canceled After Facebook Leak
text: Updated | 4:12 p.m. Israel’s Army Radio reported on Wednesday that a raid on suspected militants in the West Bank planned for Wednesday was called off by the country’s military because a soldier posted details of the operation on Facebook.

headline: U.S. Circulates New Draft Proposal for Iran Sanctions
text: UNITED NATIONS — The United States is circulating a draft of new, tougher sanctions against Iran that concentrate on the banking, shipping and insurance sectors of Iran’s economy and is now waiting for China and Russia to signal that they are willing to start negotiating over the measures, United Nations Security Council diplomats said Wednesday.

headline: Starting Over at 55
text: AFTER 24 years as a marketing manager for Coors, Cinde Dolphin knew what was coming — Miller and Coors had just merged their United States beer operations, and hundreds of jobs were sure to be eliminated.

text: A CNN report Tuesday has rekindled a smoldering debate of national, nay, potentially international significance, one that may affect a generation of future Americans.

text: As Representative Charles B. Rangel temporarily stepped aside as chairman of the powerful House Ways and Means Committee, Democrats were refocusing their strategy on passing legislation to overhaul health care.

headline: Extra Points for Good Catwalking
text: AT some point during the fourth hour of playing a new video-game version of “Project Runway,” a sensation of nausea rolled in, like what happens when you finally pick your face up off the couch after a marathon viewing of the show.

headline: Bad Investment Advice Can Turn a Free Meal Costly
text: TWO financial advisers regaled Marilyn and Paul Johnson a few years ago with free lunches and dinners at local country clubs and a celebrity chef’s restaurant in Kenosha, Wis., 40 miles south of Milwaukee. The Johnsons were fed prime rib and fancy desserts and heard promises of 12 percent returns on sure-thing investments.

headline: Bowersox Still Uncertain for ‘American Idol’
text: Crystal Bowersox, the “American Idol” semifinalist whose sudden illness on Tuesday resulted in the show’s swapping the performances of its female and male contestants this week, may miss Wednesday’s broadcast as well, the “Idol” executive producer Ken Warwick said.

headline: Estate Planning as a Family Conversation
text: FOR many people, estate planning is both a private matter and a morbid topic — not something that parents and their adult children want to discuss. While having these conversations takes a lot of courage, they can help avoid surprises, lead to better financial planning and promote family harmony.

headline: Obama Calls for ‘Up or Down Vote’ on Health Care Bill
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama, beginning his final push for a health care overhaul, called Wednesday for Congress to allow an “up or down vote” on the measure, and sketched out an ambitious — and, some Democrats said, unrealistic — timetable for his party to pass a bill on its own within weeks.

headline: The Online Lineup
text: THE SKINNY Sales of skin care products and services with expert advice from a founder, Lauren Fornes, an esthetician. Recent beauty sales on the Skinny have included Tammy Fender, Lisa Hoffman Beauty and International Orange Spa.

headline: When Life Insurance Is More Valuable as Cash
text: THE children are grown. Each spouse — or a surviving spouse — has enough assets to last a lifetime. Yet a life insurance policy is still in force. It could be used to make gifts to those children now, a down payment on an inheritance, in effect.

headline: Answers About Education Tax Credits and Deductions: Part 1
text: “Ask an Expert” is a recurring feature on Bucks where you have the opportunity to question big-brained individuals about a particular area of personal finance or consumer affairs.

headline: One-Touch Shopping, for Members Only
text: LINDSAY GOEWEY is an ideal member of HauteLook, a private sales Web site: she’s acquisitive, organized and online all the time. And Ms. Goewey, 27, loves a good deal, especially on cosmetics from some of her favorite brands like Stila or Smashbox, or brands she hasn’t tried yet but says she certainly would for 50 percent off.

headline: Russian Olympic Chief Quits
text: MOSCOW — The president of Russia’s Olympic Committee has become the first official to heed President Dmitri A. Medvedev’s demand for resignations after the poor showing by Russian athletes at the Winter Games in Vancouver.

headline: For Shift to Roth I.R.A., Know the Pitfalls to Avoid
text: CONVERTING a traditional individual retirement account to a Roth I.R.A. is a widely discussed financial planning tool right now, but the mechanics can be tricky. The process is new to many people, because until this year, you were shut out of a Roth if your adjusted gross income was more than $100,000.

text: 11/2 green peppers, stemmed and seeded

headline: More Like, ‘How to Fake It’
text: After three episodes, a critical consensus has so far eluded HBO’s latest episodic offering, “How To Make It In America.” But even the haters seem unable to resist “I Need a Dollar,” the show’s opening theme song (embedded above) by the West Coast soul singer Aloe Blacc. “Life is random,” says Julian Farino, the series’ director and one of its executive producers. “That song seems to be one of the things that people have responded to most about our show.”

headline: Burnt Offerings
text: With a very few exceptions like microwave cooking, which was discovered when an engineer was fooling around with a radar set that melted a chocolate bar in his pocket, most kitchen accidents belong in the trash. I hate mistakes when I’m cooking, although I’ve certainly made enough of them. I am forever oversalting the oatmeal or scorching the butter or flipping pancakes into unnatural postures, and each time I want to kick the stove and walk away. The only thing stopping me is my 5-year-old.

headline: At the Capitol, Remembering Murtha
text: The late Representative John P. Murtha was praised as a courageous defender of the military, his constituents and colleagues in a memorial ceremony in the Capitol today.

headline: Now Is a Perfect Time to Reconstruct a Nest Egg
text: THE turbulent economy of the last two years has left retirement accounts across the nation like beaches after a coastal storm — severely eroded.

headline: China’s Cyberposse
text: The short video made its way around China’s Web in early 2006, passed on through file sharing and recommended in chat rooms. It opens with a middle-aged Asian woman dressed in a leopard-print blouse, knee-length black skirt, stockings and silver stilettos standing next to a riverbank. She smiles, holding a small brown and white kitten in her hands. She gently places the cat on the tiled pavement and proceeds to stomp it to death with the sharp point of her high heel.

headline: Reusing Comic Book Images: Homage or Theft?
text: The controversy over Nick Simmons, and whether he inappropriately appropriated images from other manga series to create his own, is a familiar one to comic book readers.

headline: Paris: My Old Lady
text: With the song “Crimson and Clover” playing at Rochas this afternoon, I guess it was pretty clear we were back in the ’60s. Ah, man. As usual, Marco Zanini brings a fine sense of color to everything, now with crystal tones of blue, pink and yellow with leopard and square-toed shoes with a kooky sparkle heel that jutted out, giving a sense of motion. The clothes were sweet and wearable, but it was a weird trip. Why now?

headline: On Second Night, Leno Again Beats Letterman
text: Jay Leno had a solid second night back on “The Tonight Show” on Tuesday night, thanks in part to a special opening monologue from his lead guest, Sarah Palin.

headline: At Blackstone, a Rebound and More Transparency
text: Is the Blackstone Group on the rebound after the excesses of the credit boom and bust? Chris Kotowski, an analyst at Oppenheimer, thinks so, upgrading his rating on the private equity firm’s stock to “outperform” on Wednesday on signs that Blackstone will be able to earn more of its performance fees faster than expected.

headline: Let’s Talk About It: Discussing the Science and Politics of Global Warming
text: Overview | What have you heard about global warming in the news lately? Is the scientific evidence for global warming in question? Are politicians and world leaders doing enough to curb carbon emissions? What does this winter’s unusually cold and snowy weather have to do, if anything, with global warming? In is lesson, students hold a mock talk show on issues related to the science and politics of global warming.

headline: Geneva Auto Show: Ghosn Optimistic About Electric Future
text: GENEVA — Electric vehicles will not only reduce emissions, but they may also help solve another big problem facing Europe’s car industry: too many factories. At least that was the assertion of Carlos Ghosn, chief executive of Renault and Nissan, in a discussion with journalists at the Geneva auto show on Wednesday.

headline: SmartMoney Deal Expands Role of Journal Editor
text: In taking sole control of SmartMoney, the News Corporation is also expanding the influence of Robert J. Thomson, the top editor of The Wall Street Journal, who will oversee the editorial side of SmartMoney.

headline: A Leader of G.M. Is to Retire
text: DETROIT — Robert A. Lutz, the outspoken former Marine fighter pilot behind many of the most eye-catching and popular vehicles that General Motors has introduced over the last decade, intends to retire May 1, the company said Wednesday.

headline: Casting Call: Large-Eared Elephant Wanted?
text: Disney Theatrical Productions and Stephen Daldry, the Tony Award-wining director of “Billy Elliot: The Musical,” are developing an adaptation for the stage of the 1941 classic movie “Dumbo,” a Disney executive said on Wednesday afternoon.

headline: A Note On Climate Policy (Very Wonkish)
text: Basically a clarifying note to myself (pdf), trying to make sense of some big disputes among serious people (as opposed to the nonsense arguments that dominate public debate).

headline: Ballet Theater to Spend the Fall Focusing on the Mouse King and Sugarplum Fairies
text: American Ballet Theater says it will skip its regular two weeks of performances this coming fall and use the time to rehearse its new “Nutcracker” production, which will run at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. After 10 years of fall performances at New York City Center, Ballet Theater moved to Avery Fisher Hall in October. No fall home has been decided on for 2011, said Rachel S. Moore, the company’s executive director. “We’re looking at lots of different places,” she said. Ms. Moore said that the one-time costs of creating sets and costumes for the “Nutcracker,” which is being choreographed by Alexei Ratmansky, also precluded fall performance this year. Overall, Ballet Theater will stage an equal number of performances, Ms. Moore said. The Wall Street Journal reported the skipped fall weeks on Wednesday. The company  will continue with its spring performances at the Metropolitan Opera.

headline: 10th Person Pleads Guilty in Galleon Insider Case
text: A former vice president of Atheros  Communications pleaded guilty on Wednesday to conspiracy and fraud charges in the Galleon Group insider trading case, Reuters reports.

headline: Getting the Most Out of Twitter
text: A COMMON reason given by those who have yet to try Twitter: “I have nothing to say.”

headline: Waiting On Strasburg
text: Washington Nationals fans and fantasy baseball owners who are eagerly awaiting the major league debut of the right-hander Stephen Strasburg, the top draft pick from last June, will most likely have to wait a bit longer.

headline: Rove on Iraq: Without W.M.D. Threat, Bush Wouldn’t Have Gone to War
text: Karl Rove, the chief political adviser to President George W. Bush and architect of his two successful campaigns for the White House, says in a new memoir that his former boss probably would not have invaded Iraq had he known there were no weapons of mass destruction there.

headline: The Trouble With Milan
text: This season the road from the airport lounge to the fashion runway has been particularly short. After the “36 Hour Race” through the London shows, we survived a hectic and hysterical “Fashion Weekend” in Milan, where the calendar of presentations had been collapsed into three days of overlapping shows, impossible delays and events that went way into the night without any breaks for lunch or a sit-down dinner.

headline: Chase (Sort of) Restores Lost Credit Card Rewards
text: Chase used to offer a Cash Plus card that offered 5 percent cash back for purchases made in everyday categories like gas stations, grocery stores and drugstores and 1 percent back on all other spending. But it stopped marketing the card in 2006.

headline: Senators Want ‘Buy American’ Rule in Stimulus
text: Four Democratic senators are calling on the Obama administration to halt spending on a renewable energy program in the economic stimulus package until rules are in place to assure that the projects use predominantly American labor and materials.

headline: House of Style
text: Phillip Lim Age: 36 Occupation: Designer Next Project: A full line of men's shoes for the fall, including utility boots and animal-print sneakers inspired by the photographer Peter Beard.

headline: Appeals Court Backs Landmarks Commission on Designations
text: A court decision chastising the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission for its failure to take action on certain landmark designation requests and calling for new expedited procedures has been reversed on appeal.

headline: Russian Orchestra Tour: From the Bus to the Stage
text: When the great orchestras of Europe glide through the United States on tour, they stay at elegant hotels like Le Parker Meridien near Carnegie Hall, play in grand spaces like Symphony Hall in Boston and can receive more than $100 a day in meal money.

headline: Bilton on ABC: Dos and Don’ts of Digital Etiquette
text: On Wednesday, I debated the dos and don’ts of digital etiquette with Diane Sawyer, the ABC anchor.

headline: Why Old People Should Love Immigrants
text: Earlier today Casey B. Mulligan wrote about how the entry of more women into the work force has helped sustain the solvency of Social Security, which has been otherwise stressed by the size of the retiring baby boom generation and longer life expectancies.

headline: The Man Who Clicks With 7-Year-Olds
text: THE name Marty Hyman may mean nothing to you. But if you, your children or grandchildren have gone to private schools in and around Manhattan over the last 30 years, chances are you’ve either smiled for Mr. Hyman or written him a check.

headline: Developing Nations Setting Torrid Pace for Mergers
text: NEW DELHI — As both companies and countries in the West and Japan stumble under debt and fear, a new enthusiasm for deals has already emerged this year in India, China and other developing countries.

headline: Rangel’s ‘Leave’ May Not Be Temporary
text: After Representative Charles B. Rangel, Democrat of New York, sent a letter to House Speaker Nancy Pelosi on Wednesday morning requesting a “leave of absence” from his post as chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, the presiding officer of the House announced that “the resignation is accepted.”

headline: Dessay Leaves Met’s ‘Hamlet’
text: Natalie Dessay has withdrawn as Ophélie from the Metropolitan Opera’s production of “Hamlet,” by Ambroise Thomas, because of illness, the Met said on Wednesday. Marlis Petersen, who was to have sung one performance, on April 9, will take her place for the first six shows — on March 16, 20, 24, 27, 30 and April 2. Another soprano, as yet to be announced, will sing the last two performances, on April 5 and 9. Simon Keenlyside sings the title role. The Met has not staged the work since 1897.

headline: Handling Investments and Investors’ Fears
text: DANIEL DUNN has been on Wall Street for 25 years, but his route to investments was nontraditional. After earning a degree in clinical psychology from Pace University, he worked at an inpatient ward at a mental hospital on Staten Island and then moved through various careers, at one point selling advertising for a radio station.

headline: Street Art That’s Finding a New Address
text: FOR the current fifth-anniversary exhibition at his New York gallery Jonathan LeVine has filled it with works by 35 artists, most of whom he represents. The space is in Chelsea, but there’s no cerebral conceptualism, cool abstraction or painterly gesture on view.

headline: Pop Goes the Street
text: A look at the world of pop surrealism, narrated by Jonathan LeVine, a gallery owner, and the artists WK and Doze Green.

headline: Monitoring Your Child’s Friendships
text: Sometimes it’s the kids who need help navigating the social shoals of elementary school. Sometimes it’s the parents.

headline: The Voices of Fibromyalgia
text: People who suffer from fibromyalgia experience problems beyond the pain caused by their illness. Their condition is little understood and hard to explain, and often they are disbelieved by doctors. Even friends and loved ones may express skepticism toward the fibromyalgia sufferer, who, burdened with inexplicable pain, may cancel social plans, miss work and recoil from physical affection because it hurts too much.

headline: The ‘Saturday Night Live’ Presidential Reunion
text: We were happy enough at the start of this Funny Or Die video to see the “Saturday Night Live” alumna Maya Rudolph playing Michelle Obama — just to see Ms. Rudolph playing anyone, really. But beyond those first few crucial seconds, there’s a skit reuniting almost every surviving “S.N.L.” cast member who has ever played a United States president: Fred Armisen as Barack Obama; Will Ferrell as George W. Bush; Darrell Hammond as Bill Clinton; Dana Carvey as George H. W. Bush; Dan Aykroyd as Jimmy Carter; and even Chevy Chase as Gerald Ford.

headline: Matching Life Experience With New Careers
text: HEALTH navigator? Conflict coach? Pollution mitigation outreach worker? These emerging jobs aren’t household terms yet, but they are a natural fit for older people looking for new career opportunities, said Phyllis Segal, vice president at Civic Ventures, a nonprofit research group based in San Francisco.

headline: Corporate Deal Makers Head to Emerging Markets
text: As both companies and countries in the West and Japan stumble under debt and fear, a new enthusiasm for deals has emerged this year in India, China and other developing countries,  Heather Timmons and Vikas Bajaj of The New York Times report from New Delhi.

headline: What We’re Reading …
text: Jobs for law school grads, and other links from around the Web.
