text: Q.

headline: Fixing the Wi-Fi on iPod Touch
text: Q. The icon on my iPod Touch shows that I’m connected to my home wireless network, but I can’t open Web pages or do e-mail. What do I do?

headline: Upstate Democrat Retiring Amid Allegations of Misconduct
text: Representative Eric J. Massa, an outspoken freshman Democrat from a Republican-leaning district in upstate New York, abruptly announced Wednesday that he would retire, as he faced allegations that he had harassed a member of his staff.

headline: What States and Cities Are Doing to Help Small Businesses
text: While Washington debates how to help the country’s struggling small businesses, states and municipalities have stepped up with an array of initiatives to stanch closings and save jobs.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Wednesday, March 3
text: There are some faces that you don’t need to see in a news photograph. Her braided corona instantly identifies Prime Minister Yulia V. Tymoshenko of Ukraine, seen in Slide 7 as she left the Parliament after a vote of no confidence in her government. And Candy Holmes’s joy in obtaining her marriage license in the District of Columbia (Slide 10) is evident enough.

headline: Portraits of a Lady | Baron Adolph de Meyer
text: At the turn of the century, magazine and catalog illustrations of the latest fashion collections were rather dry, using models who acted more like cutout dolls. It took the work of Baron Adolph de Meyer to loosen up fashion editorial with challenging portraits in the pages of Vogue, Vanity Fair and Harper’s Bazaar. A rare showing of more than 100 of his society portraits, commercial fashion photography and still lifes recently opened at Robert Miller Gallery (through April 3; robertmillergallery.com).

headline: Trump State Park Fired. Trump Displeased.
text: Although he is known for his high-rises, resorts and golf courses, Donald J. Trump helped create a little-known state park in northern Westchester County, donating the land for public use in 2006.

headline: Oscar’s Box Office Bump
text: As we approach the inexorable glitz hole of what one of our commenters memorably calls a “dog wedding,” it’s worth taking a step back to examine what exactly an Oscar nomination means to a movie. (It’s also worth noting that people in Hollywood actually have dog weddings.) There’s prestige, sure, and the conventional wisdom holds that small films get a much-needed box office bump from awards attention. But it turns out so do blockbusters.

headline: Film and Fashion: Just Friends
text: JEN KAO has seen “Avatar” — twice. Ms. Kao, a New York designer known for filmy knits and aggressive black leather, plans to infuse her next collection, in September, with some of that movie’s violent colors and savage frills.

headline: From California, Chinese Solar Maker Looks East
text: Yingli, the Chinese solar module maker that captured nearly a third of the California market last year, has struck a deal to supply a New Jersey developer with more than 10 megawatts of photovoltaic panels.

headline: Joanna Newsom, the Changeling
text: LARK CAMP is a weeklong gathering of folk musicians held each summer in the Mendocino Woodlands, on the California coast, 150 miles north of San Francisco. Part music-and-dance academy, part freewheeling hoedown, Lark Camp brings together specialists in American and world-music traditions — Cajun fiddlers, hula dancers, Andean panpipe experts, Galician accordionists — who teach workshops and lead late-night jam sessions around campfires beneath the stretching redwoods.

headline: Unions Plan Protests Against Big Banks
text: ORLANDO — In an action it hopes would create jobs and increase economic fairness, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. announced on Wednesday that it will sponsor two “Weeks of Action” against the nation’s major banks.

headline: Striking Poses
text: “I am cursed to be in this Mother Hubbard body,” Alice Neel once remarked of her grandmotherly image. The artist’s sensitivity to nuances of style and gesture informs the portraits in “Alice Neel: Painted Truths,” a retrospective opening on March 21 at the Museum of Fine Arts, Houston. Since her portrait work was largely uncommissioned and did not require that she flatter the sitter, “you get a sense of how people really looked,” says Barry Walker, who, with Jeremy Lewison, curated the show. That’s as true for the cheerful Fuller Brush man and Dachau survivor who showed up on her doorstep in 1965 as it is for the art-world elites who (eventually) posed for her — including the Factory’s Ritta Redd and Jackie Curtis and Andy Warhol himself, seminude and scarred. (Neel was notorious for sweet-talking her subjects out of their clothes.) When faced with truly stylish subjects, like the art-world players John Gruen and Jane Wilson and their daughter, Neel focused on the psychological — the self-assured couple and the young girl, hunched like a figure out of Munch — but she didn’t neglect the clothes. The painting’s pet name: “Six Patent Leather Shoes.”

headline: Taming a Child by Setting Her Free
text: Language is exalted as the miracle maker of “The Miracle Worker,” the potential means of salvation for a knowledge-starved deaf and blind girl named Helen Keller. “One word, and I can put the world in your hand,” Helen’s teacher tells her with fervor. Odd, then, that the sadly pedestrian new production of William Gibson’s 1959 biographical drama is by far most effective when it is wordless.

headline: A Last Bow at the Oscars for Walters
text: On Oscar night it’s a tradition: The stars break down and weep  and that’s before they know if they’ve won or lost.

headline: After Two Cy Youngs, Lincecum Finally Meets Griffey
text: PEORIA, Ariz. – Tim Lincecum was 4 years old when Ken Griffey Jr. made his major league debut in 1989 for the Seattle Mariners, Lincecum’s local team. Lincecum starred at Liberty High School in Renton, Wash., and then at the University of Washington, before winning the last two National League Cy Young Awards for the San Francisco Giants. Still, he had never met Griffey until Wednesday.

headline: Film’s Influence on Fashion, Then and Now
text: Costumes can be protagonists, as in these Hollywood classics.

headline: Why His Face May End Up in Webster’s
text: SOMETIMES you hear a word for the first time and think: “Of course.” How better to describe Paris Hilton than as a “celebutante” or the frequent tabloid target Alec Baldwin as “the bloviator”? (Thanks, New York Post!)

headline: Musical Instruments: Now You See ‘Em, Now You . . .
text: Lovers of historic musical instruments are living on a roller coaster. Weeks after the Victoria & Albert Museum in London permanently shut down its renowned collection on the subject, the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York reopened its musical instrument gallery after eight months of refurbishing.

headline: A New York Snowcation
text: A bus load of skiers and snowboarders have been reveling in the record snowfall this winter.

headline: G.M.’s Vocal Vice Chairman Flies Off Into Retirement
text: DETROIT — Following a 47-year career in the car business that earned him a reputation as an innovative but outspoken maverick, Bob Lutz will retire from General Motors on May 1. The announcement came after a major reorganization that G.M. announced on Tuesday.

headline: Twitter Ban Lifted by Carnival Cruises
text: Carnival Cruise Lines has reversed a rule that sought to prevent travel agents from mentioning the company’s name or its trademarks on social media sites like Facebook and Twitter.

headline: Winter Training: Faster and Safer Indoors?
text: PAUL THOMPSON, a fast marathon runner and cardiologist at Hartford Hospital in Connecticut, finally broke down this year and bought a treadmill. At age 62, he had had it with running on icy mornings when temperatures were in the single digits.

headline: 2 Bermuda Reinsurers Agree to Merge
text: Two  reinsurance companies based in Bermuda — the Max Capital Group and Harbor Point  — announced Wednesday afternoon that they had agreed to merge, forming a combined company that would be renamed Alterra Capital Holdings.

headline: In America’s Gyms, More Than a Touch of Gray
text: IT’S 8:30 on a Tuesday morning at Island Fitness in Coronado, Calif., and the gym’s ambience is about to be transformed almost as markedly as was the 98-pound-weakling-turned-muscle-man in the old comic book ads.

headline: Researchers Identify Fossil of Dinosaur-Eating Snake
text: The discovery of a snake near an egg is by no means unusual, but in this case, the snake was 67 million years old — providing scientists with new information about how snakes in the dinosaur era lived, and what they ate.

headline: Use of the Zone Attacks Perceptions and Ego
text: Man-to-man defense is the red meat of college basketball, with players held accountable on every possession. They crouch  sometimes so low they can slap their palms on the floor  as if defending against a threat more dangerous than an opponent with a basketball.

headline: Iraq Elections: Voter Profile
text: Michael Kamber talks with Iraqis as they get ready for Sunday's Parliamentary elections.

headline: Is It Ever O.K. to Snoop on Your Spouse’s E-Mail?
text: In the tradition of Jenna Wortham’s posts on Internet etiquette, Nick Bilton over on the Bits blog dove into two thorny topics — the dos and don’ts of sending text messages during dinner and the ethics of riffling through the e-mail and text messages of a spouse or significant other — in a discussion with Diane Sawyer of ABC.

headline: A Survivor’s Tale From Chile
text: Karina Murga, 27, was born and raised in Constitución, Chile, where she lived with her mother, daughter and other family members until Saturday. Early that morning, when the 8.8 magnitude earthquake struck Chile and badly damaged Constitución, Karina’s six-year-old Carla was staying with her godmother, Cristina Vergara, and her godmother’s son, Jorge Zurita.

headline: Paris Preview
text: After a long, cruel winter, Paris is awakening to spring. Check out these magical photo exhibitions and enchanted storefronts.

headline: A Plan to Send Flight Data Somewhere Off the Plane
text: Investigators of a French airline accident and aviation agencies from 44 other European countries plan to ask the International Civil Aviation Organization to change the way planes transmit information while flying over oceans. The hope is to prevent airliners from vanishing without leaving clues about what happened.

headline: A Closer Look at Windows Live
text: Every time Microsoft pitches me on some Windows Live product, I groan. What the heck is Windows Live? I mean, what is it this week?

headline: San Francisco’s Overtime Pay Exceeding Expectations
text: At a budget committee meeting on Wednesday, Deputy Controller Monique Zmuda presented to the Board of Supervisors her latest report on the city’s overtime expenditures [PDF] — including pending payments to a firefighter who logged 1,053 hours of overtime in the first 193 days of this fiscal year.

headline: Documentarian Struggles to Climb Mount Weinstein
text: LOS ANGELES  Intrepid documentarians have spied on a mass dolphin slaughter (in “The Cove”), faced off against the food industry (in “Food, Inc.”) and braved the heights of Mount Everest in the sort of antique tweeds worn by men who died there in the 1920s (in “The Wildest Dream”).

headline: Education on the Company’s Dime
text: ROBIN ROUSE just turned 50 and is thinking ahead to retirement from I.B.M. She loves her job in the company’s Cambridge, Mass., office, but she is also honing her film-writing skills, with the company helping to pay for classes.

headline: In Iraq, Voters Are Optimistic, but Cautious
text: In Baghdad, Michael Kamber interviewed Iraqis about their outlook on the upcoming election. On the streets, the mood is subdued but cautiously optimistic that the election would come off without major violence. Many appear somewhat cynical that the election will bring a quick change in their lives.

headline: Congressional Pay Cut Gains Support
text: An increasing number of lawmakers are pushing to dock their own salaries by 5 percent in an effort to show that Congress is prepared to sacrifice as the economy stumbles.

headline: Variations on a Theme
text: A look inside the artist Marina Abramovic’s SoHo loft and her home in upstate New York.

headline: ‘Tammy Wynette’
text: Virginia's in the House

headline: Stand by Your Singer and Her Art
text: Jimmy McDonough wasn’t one of Tammy Wynette’s lovers. He didn’t know her, except from afar. Yet he has managed to arrange a tryst with her in some No-Tell Motel of the spirit, achieving an intimacy that many biographers covet but few enjoy. For evidence of what happens when biographer and subject don’t click so perfectly, compare Mr. McDonough’s sweeping yet uneasy portrait of Neil Young, “Shakey,” an authorized book eager to please its subject, with his freewheeling approach in “Tammy Wynette” to the late, lamented, conveniently elusive “Tragic Country Queen.”

headline: Tech Talk Podcast: Etiquette, Tapes and the F1 Key
text: This week on the Tech Talk podcast, Bettina Edelstein chats with Jenna Wortham of The New York Times about online etiquette questions involving work, home and heartbreak.

headline: Judge Gives General Growth 4-Month Extension
text: 8:25 a.m. | Updated Read an expanded version of this story here.

headline: Why Size Matters
text: Speaking of blurring the line between bloggers and politicians, Ezra Klein and Congressman Paul Ryan just had an interesting online exchange about Ryan’s remarks at last week’s health care summit. The Wisconsin congressman, you may recall, accused partisans of the pending legislation of disguising the real cost of the bill, which may total $2.3 trillion over 10 years once all the subsidies are phased in. Klein responded that yes, “the bill might cost $2.3 trillion” in its second decade, but over that period “it either raises or saves $2.95 trillion, for a net deficit impact of negative $650 billion.” Ryan, he suggested, was using “the classic ‘This Is A Big Number’ technique to imply that the bill is financially irresponsible, when putting the number in context would show just the opposite.”

headline: Excerpt: 'Who do You Think You Are?'
text: The NBC show traces the family trees of celebrities like Sarah Jessica Parker.

headline: A Miniature World Magnifies Dwarf Life
text: KUNMING, China — Chen Mingjing’s entrepreneurial instincts vaulted him from a peasant upbringing to undreamed-of wealth, acquired in ventures ranging from making electric meters to investing in real estate. But when he was 44, the allure of making money for money’s sake began to wane. He wanted to run a business that accomplished some good.

headline: Is Your Family Tree Just a Shrub?
text: At this point there’s probably no stopping the genealogy craze, which for a few decades now has been causing people to go rooting around in their familial past, trying to find out who gave birth to the person who gave birth to the person who was related to the person who gave birth to them. And on Friday night this happy cult may sign up a bunch of new members when an addictive little program called “Who Do You Think You Are?” has its premiere on NBC.

headline: From Snowy to Snowier
text: During last week’s near-record snowfalls, many New Yorkers said “enough.” But Central Park’s 30 inches weren’t enough for some.

headline: Positive Test for Sanofi Prostate Cancer Drug
text: A new drug being developed by Sanofi-Aventis extended the lives of men with advanced prostate cancer in a clinical trial and could become a new last-ditch treatment, researchers reported Wednesday.

headline: Fallen Angels
text: There was a time in the 1990s when angels were impossible to escape. Guardians, muses, articles of trade, they covered T-shirts and bathroom accessories, bloomed on restaurant walls and peered from the edges of book jackets. Lately they may seem to have drifted away, but they’ve merely wandered into the literature of self-help and healing. It is now possible to buy “How to Hear Your Angels,” “Working With Angels,” “In the Arms of Angels” and “Angels 101,” as well as angel dictionaries, encyclopedias and art books.

headline: The Blobs Aren’t Talking
text: TAOS, N.M.

headline: A Choreographer Recycling and Reusing, but Always Reinventing
text: In its current season at City Center, the Paul Taylor Dance Company is presenting three works by Mr. Taylor each evening: 18 in all, spread over 16 performances. He could arrange them as six unvarying triple bills, each of which would have two or three performances. That would be more convenient for this city’s busy dancegoers.

headline: Robert Kennedy Items Removed From Police Exhibit
text: Evidence from the 1968 assassination of Robert F. Kennedy at the Ambassador Hotel in Los Angeles  including the bloody clothes he was wearing when he was shot  has been removed from an exhibition at a Las Vegas casino in response to objections from his family, his son Maxwell Taylor Kennedy said Wednesday.

headline: Footnote
text: Natalie Dessay, below, has withdrawn as Ophélie from the Metropolitan Opera’s production of Ambroise Thomas’s “Hamlet,” because of illness, the Met said on Wednesday. Marlis Petersen, who was to have sung one performance, on April 9, will take her place for the first six shows  on March 16, 20, 24, 27, 30 and April 2. Another soprano, yet to be announced, will sing the performances on April 5 and 9. Simon Keenlyside sings the title role.

headline: Financier to Head Kennedy Center Board
text: David M. Rubenstein, the co-founder and managing director of the Carlyle Group, one of the world’s largest private equity firms, has been selected as the next chairman of the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington, the center announced on Wednesday. In a telephone interview Mr. Rubenstein, 60, said he hoped to attract younger audiences  “people who don’t have hair color like mine”  to the center. He added that he also sees taking the post as a chance to help combat the “increasing divide in Washington between Republicans and Democrats,” since “the arts help bring people together." Mr. Rubenstein, a Washingtonian who has been on the Kennedy Center board since 2004, will succeed the financier Stephen A. Schwarzman after the May board meeting. Mr. Rubenstein helped start the 23-year-old Carlyle Group, which now manages more than $87 billion from 19 offices around the world. He serves on the boards of about 30 major institutions, including the Smithsonian Institution, Duke University, Johns Hopkins University, the University of Chicago, Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts and Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. “I do intend to narrow down the philanthropic commitments I have,” Mr. Rubenstein said.

headline: Little Buddy Heading to the Big Screen
text: Television’s best-known three-hour tour is about to get its own two-hour movie adaptation (well, maybe two and a half hours when you factor in commercials and previews). A film version of “Gilligan’s Island,” the classic 1960s CBS sitcom about seven castaways on an uncharted desert isle, is being prepared at Warner Brothers by producers who include the series creator Sherwood Schwartz, Variety reported. While vintage pop-culture properties do not always make the best movies  see the film versions of “Dukes of Hazzard,” “The Brady Bunch,” “Leave It to Beaver,” “The Honeymooners,” et al.  the “Gilligan’s Island” movie need not be a total washout; for one thing, the Variety report said that the producers were seeking to cast Michael Cera, above, the “Juno” and “Arrested Development” star, as the titular bumbling first mate.

headline: Flying Elephant on Broadway?
text: Disney Theatrical Productions and Stephen Daldry, the Tony Award-wining director of “Billy Elliot: The Musical,” are developing an adaptation for the stage of the 1941 classic animated movie “Dumbo,” a Disney executive said on Wednesday afternoon. Mr. Daldry approached Disney Theatrical several months ago with a concept for a “Dumbo” musical, and they are now in “the very initial stages” of shaping those ideas, according to the executive, who spoke on condition of anonymity because the company does not comment on projects at such an early stage. No creative team  composers, book writers, designers, and so on  has been assembled, the executive said, but doing so would probably be the next step. “Dumbo,” of course, already comes with several songs from the movie, including “Baby Mine”  which was nominated for the Academy Award for best song  as well as “Casey Junior” and “When I See An Elephant Fly.” The film won the Oscar for best original score. It is too early to say when the musical, if ultimately realized, would come to Broadway, or if it would start out in London as “Billy Elliot” did (Mr. Daldry is British) or in another major theatrical city other than New York, the executive said. “Let’s put it this way, ‘Dumbo’ will not be on Broadway in the 2010-11 season, because it’s simply in the very early stages,” the executive said. The New York Post on Wednesday reported Disney’s interest in developing “Dumbo” for the stage, though The Post said that Mr. Daldry had passed on the project because he and Disney could not come to terms. The Disney executive said that Mr. Daldry has always been aboard. "This is Stephen’s idea, and he’s very passionate about it,” the executive said.

headline: Executive Casualties at War-Game Maker
text: The runaway success of the video game Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 2 has given way to corporate hostilities. On Tuesday the heads of the game studio Infinity Ward, which produces the Call of Duty games for the publisher Activision Blizzard, abruptly left that company under unclear circumstances, Reuters reported. Activision said that Jason West, the Infinity Ward president, and Vince Zampella, the studio’s chief executive, had both departed. In a statement and in a regulatory filing reported by Reuters, Activision said it was investigating “breaches of contract and insubordination by two senior employees at Infinity Ward,” but did not name the employees. The game publisher also said it was starting its own business unit to produce future Call of Duty titles, and that the decision was unrelated to the exits of Mr. West and Mr. Zampella. Infinity Ward, which released the original Call of Duty game in 2003, was acquired by Activision that same year. Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 2, which was released in November, became one of the best-selling games of all time, grossing an estimated $310 million in sales in its first day of release and selling more than 12 million copies over all. Activision has two more Call of Duty games planned for 2010 and 2011, neither developed by Infinity Ward.

headline: Turks, Kurds, Armenians: View From a Small Town
text: In 2005, Christopher de Bellaigue, a British journalist, installed himself in a remote, forbidding Turkish town and, by so doing, acquired an anguished intimacy with the region’s peoples and their secret and mythic pasts. This extraordinary intervention — which can be read as old-fashioned Orientalism or, more generously, as a globalized conscience courageously at work or, most accurately, as a bit of both — has a reflexive subplot, namely de Bellaigue’s own intellectual and moral odyssey, which is of an unusually vulnerable and romantic character.

headline: Ballet Theater to Skip Fall Season
text: American Ballet Theater says it will skip its regular two weeks of performances next fall and use the time to rehearse its new “Nutcracker” production, which will be staged at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. After 10 years of fall performances at City Center, the company moved to Avery Fisher Hall in October. No fall home has been decided on for 2011, said Rachel S. Moore, the company’s executive director. “We’re looking at lots of different places,” she said. Ms. Moore said that the one-time costs of creating sets and costumes for the “Nutcracker,” which is being choreographed by Alexei Ratmansky, also precluded fall performances this year. Over all Ballet Theater will stage an equal number of performances, Ms. Moore said. The Wall Street Journal reported the skipped fall weeks on Wednesday. The company will continue with its spring performances at the Metropolitan Opera House.

headline: Sade Soldiers on Atop Billboard Chart
text: Sade’s “Soldier of Love” (Epic) is No. 1 on Billboard’s album chart for the third week in a row. It sold 127,000 copies last week, according to Nielsen SoundScan, bringing its three-week total to 820,000. Lady Antebellum’s “Need You Now” (Capitol Nashville) holds at No. 2 with 118,000 sales, and Johnny Cash’s “American VI: Ain’t No Grave” (American/Lost Highway), said to be the last of Cash’s prolific late sessions with Rick Rubin, opens at No. 3 with 54,000. Also on this week’s chart, the Black Eyed Peas’ “E.N.D.” (Interscope) is No. 4, with 50,000 sales, Lady Gaga’s “Fame” (Interscope) is No. 5 with 48,000, and Lil Wayne’s “Rebirth” (Cash Money/Universal) is No. 6 with 38,000.

headline: End of a Chatty Era
text: After nearly 30 years of pre-Oscar interview specials, Barbara Walters will present her final one on Sunday night.

headline: Bets Are Hedged for a Racing Showdown
text: The Apple Blossom Invitational potentially is a race for the ages: Rachel Alexandra, the reigning Horse of the Year, squaring off for the first time against Zenyatta, the undefeated mare and Breeders’ Cup Classic winner. The money is there  a $5 million purse. A neutral site has been secured, vital in this meeting of East versus West  Oaklawn Park in Arkansas.

headline: Library Science
text: One day, apparently before the rise of Google Book Search, Marilyn Johnson made an odd request at the New York Public Library. She needed to find the symptoms of an imaginary illness called “information sickness,” which she recollected from a 1981 novel by Ted Mooney, “Easy Travel to Other Planets.” She couldn’t find her own copy, so a team of librarians went spelunking in the stacks, wearing miner’s helmets, as Johnson tells it. They surfaced with a copy preserved, strangely enough, on micro­film, and soon Johnson was reading the dimly remembered passage in which a woman keels over, blood gushing from her nose and ears as she raves about disconnected facts. When the woman recovers from her fugue state, she says: “I was dazzled. I couldn’t tell where one thing left off and the next began.”

headline: Stimulus Programs That Roll at Night
text: ON a recent Thursday night in the Adams Morgan neighborhood of Washington, two D.J.’s— Shea Van Horn and Tommy Cornelis — were filling the basement lounge of Napoleon, a bistro, with French electro and house music. The occasion was a monthly party called Maison, and the room was packed: gay men in their 20s, a clutch of American University law students, a preening reality TV star (Paul Wharton) and Omar Popal, the 31-year-old owner of the upstairs restaurant.

headline: 6 More Iranian Activists Reported Arrested
text: At least six human rights advocates were reported to have been arrested in Iran on Wednesday, dampening hopes that the government was easing its campaign of arrests ahead of the Iranian New Year on March 21.

headline: HCA’s Latest Surprise for Its Bondholders
text: March 5, 2:04 p.m. | Updated: HCA and another analyst have taken issue with parts of Gimme Credit’s analysis of HCA’s bond sale. This revised post includes their comments.

headline: So Who’s Next? Patti Smith and Others
text: Two mature women paid the best tributes to Pete Townshend’s songs in “The Music of the Who”: 21 acts performing a selection each on Tuesday night at Carnegie Hall.

headline: Joint Chiefs Chairman Readjusts Principles on Use of Force
text: WASHINGTON — The chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Adm. Mike Mullen, laid out new principles Wednesday for how to use the military in meeting contemporary threats, saying that overwhelming force can be counterproductive if used recklessly.

headline: Meredith Vieira Extends ‘Today’ Contract
text: Meredith Vieira, a host of the “Today” show on NBC whose contract was set to expire in September, has extended her contract by one year, a person briefed on the matter said Wednesday.

headline: A Proposal for Reining In Credit Card Fees
text: The Federal Reserve today announced a proposal that seeks to protect credit card customers from unreasonable fees for paying late or exceeding their limits.

headline: Pop Singer Arrives With a Bundle of Gizmos
text: There’s not much you can say against the laser harp. At the Highline Ballroom on Tuesday night a beam of green light shot up from the floor, then fanned out into eight individual rays. The tiny synth-pop singer Little Boots, wearing a gold lamé gown and face mask, played the melody of her song “Earthquake” by moving her hand among the streams of light; each time she blocked one, it triggered a synthesizer pitch, and she could alter its tone by lowering or raising her hand on each beam.

headline: College Degrees Without Going to Class
text: Online courses have been around for nearly two decades, but enrollment has soared in recent years as more universities increase their offerings. More than 4.6 million college students (about one in four) were taking at least one online course in 2008, a 17 percent increase over 2007.

headline: What We’re Reading: A Customer Strikes Back and an Odd Mayoral Campaign
text: Wednesday’s roundup of interesting tidbits from around the Web, selected by technology reporters and editors at The New York Times:

headline: RealNetworks Drops Fight to Sell DVD Copying Software
text: RealNetworks gave up Wednesday on its battle to sell RealDVD, software that allowed consumers to easily copy the content of DVDs to their computers.

headline: Soldiers’ Stories
text: In a “nasty, dark little room” beneath British Army headquarters in Cairo, a bored Lieutenant Lawrence methodically extinguishes a match between his fingers.

headline: Hurtin’ Words
text: Sometimes it’s hard to be a biographer. Tammy Wynette is known as the queen of country music, a legend and a drag queen staple. The first country artist to go platinum, with more than 20 No. 1 hits, she is beloved and rightfully respected, the Elvis of the Opry, a tiny wisp of a woman who went from beauty school to record sales of more than $30 million, a Horatio Alger hero in sequins. Her appeal springs primarily from two wells: her hardscrabble story and her heartbreaking voice, an idiosyncratic, affecting warble of longing and regret. After you’ve read “Tammy Wynette: Tragic Country Queen,” Jimmy McDonough’s rollicking if reverential biography, the voice remains unimpeachable. The story, not so much.

headline: Virtual Village
text: How do you write an English village novel — if you really want to do such a thing? First, you have to create a character who is a retired major. Yes, create. Who will live in a house called Rose Cottage. Oh, all right, let’s make it Rose Lodge. In a village. Of course. Where the local landowner is an earl. We’ll settle for a lord. Who receives American visitors. In loud tweeds. And there’s a golf club. Naturally.

headline: Acceleration Incidents Cited on Repaired Toyotas
text: Federal regulators said Wednesday that they had received 10 reports of Toyota vehicles accelerating unexpectedly after they were repaired at dealerships.

headline: U.S. Team Won’t Race In Formula One in 2010
text: The first Formula One team based in the United States since the 1970s is not going to make it to the starting grid.

headline: The Talk of the (Seedy Side of) Town
text: In the annals of injustice, as The New Yorker might phrase it, the obscurity into which St. Clair McKelway has fallen amounts to a literary crime. His writing for the magazine rivaled that of his far better-remembered colleagues, Joseph Mitchell and A. J. Liebling, both of whose careers he was instrumental in promoting. From 1936 to 1939, he served as The New Yorker’s managing editor in charge of fact (as opposed to fiction) pieces. During those crucial years he played a major role in solidifying the magazine’s non­fiction style — “the choreography,” as Ben Yagoda describes it in “About Town,” his history of The New Yorker, “of the extraordinary number of facts the writer had collected.” Today he’s all but forgotten.

headline: Behind the Scenes: Altered and Out
text: 12:30 a.m., Thursday | Updated A writer identifying himself as Stepan Rudik has sent a link to the photograph in question, explaining that what was excised in the competition version was a small section of a foot that can be seen under the fighter’s wrapped hand. He added, “I don’t argue the decision of the WPP jury.”

headline: A Bit More on Nujood
text: I was inspired to write about Nujood’s case when I read her book, but the backdrop is my growing concern about Yemen itself. As Al Qaeda finds itself under more pressure in Pakistan and Afghanistan, it may see Yemen as a nice refuge. Indeed, there are signs that that is already beginning to happen. And since the Yemeni government’s authority weakens at the capital’s city limits, and the president has other priorities (such as holding his country together), it’s not a bad spot for extremists.

headline: My Leningrad, Too
text: To the Editor:

headline: Passing Both Ways
text: To the Editor:

headline: Californians Compete for a Shot at Redistricting
text: LOS ANGELES — Here in California, Democrats have just one candidate for governor (and he has already done the job), and state lawmakers from both parties seem incapable of passing even modest legislation without a meltdown.

headline: Gambit in Texan’s Battle to Unseat the Governor
text: HOUSTON — The confetti had barely settled at the victory parties after the Texas primaries on Tuesday when the Democratic nominee for governor, Bill White, took off the gloves and went after Gov. Rick Perry.

headline: Michael Foot Dies at 96; Led Britain’s Labour Party
text: Michael Foot, who led the British Labour Party in the early 1980s, and, after failing to broker a peace between its left and right wings, presided over its crushing defeat at the hands of Margaret Thatcher in the 1983 general election, died Wednesday at his home in Hampstead, north London. He was 96.

headline: Share-a-Cab Program Draws Few Riders
text: Dalbir Singh did not know where to go on Wednesday when he arrived at the corner of East 72nd Street and Third Avenue, seeking one of the Taxi and Limousine Commission’s new share-a-cab stands.

headline: Don’t ‘Wait’; Bid Positively
text: In Monday’s column South opened two clubs, strong, artificial and forcing. North had five spades to the king and five diamonds to the king-queen. But because she and her partner had agreed that a response of two spades would guarantee at least a six-card suit, she was forced to start with two diamonds “waiting.” This bid usually hides zero to seven high-card points but might be made with a stronger hand when the partnership values for a positive response are not held.

headline: Town Finds Good Neighbor in Nuclear Plant
text: VERNON, Vt. — A storm knocked out Kathleen Halvey’s power for eight hours last Wednesday, an event she found both disruptive and prescient.

headline: Investigating Tiny Voices at Air Tower
text: Children love airplanes! It probably seemed like a perfectly good idea to an air traffic controller at Kennedy International Airport to bring his children to work last month — heck, this country has a whole day set aside for that sort of thing.

headline: Mr. Not-Quite Isn’t Right
text: To the Editor:

headline: Senator Proposes Deal on Handling of Detainees
text: WASHINGTON — Senator Lindsey Graham wants to make a deal on detainees with President Obama. If the White House agrees to the bargain, it would be a defining moment for the administration — and could transform how the government deals with terrorism suspects.

headline: In Governors, the Averages Aren’t Good
text: If there were one story line in our endless tale of exploding governors, it would be simpler to decode. Instead, it’s like a political version of Clue. Mr. Spitzer in the hotel room with the hooker. Mr. Rowland in the cottage with the swag. Mr. McGreevey, well, you get the idea.

headline: Ultimate Bush Insider Lifts Veil on Presidency
text: WASHINGTON — Karl Rove, the chief political adviser to President George W. Bush and architect of his two successful campaigns for the White House, says in a new memoir that Mr. Bush probably would not have invaded Iraq had he known there were no unconventional weapons there.

headline: Waterworks Opens Its New Manhattan Showroom
text: IN the beginning — or at least long, long ago — there were pink toilets. Sometimes blue, sometimes maroon. And lo, Barbara Sallick — blessed be Her name among high-end developers, daughter of Samuel Grogins of the Nutmeg Plumbing Supply Company of Danbury, Conn., and wife of Robert Sallick, who worked for Her father — did look around and say, “Bathrooms don’t really need to be blue, pink or maroon” and “In Europe, they are so much more advanced.”

headline: House Votes to Protect Pupils Against Abusive Discipline
text: In a move to provide the first comprehensive protections for children against abusive disciplinary actions by schools, the House on Wednesday easily approved a bill to restrict the use of forcible restraint and seclusion, in which children are held down, drugged or isolated in a locked room to control their behavior.

headline: Shifting Soil Threatens Homes’ Foundations
text: STEVEN DERSE, the owner of a corporate travel business in Nashville, cannot feel his house move, but he can hear it. “It’s an eerie creaking sound,” he said, and it echoes throughout his two-story Georgian-style house.

headline: Preparing to March Over Education Cuts
text: Ramon Quintero, a geography major at the University of California, Berkeley, hopes his 1979 Toyota mini-motor home becomes more than the place he slept in last semester to save rent money and more than just a mural on wheels.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 998 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Tuesday:

headline: U.S. Fears Election Strife in Iraq Could Affect Pullout
text: WASHINGTON — The deadly suicide bombings in Iraq on Wednesday highlight the central quandary facing President Obama as he tries to fulfill his campaign pledge to end the war there: Will parliamentary elections, scheduled for Sunday, throw the country back into the sectarian strife that flared in 2004 and delay the planned American withdrawal?

headline: Ads Posted on Facebook Strike Some as Off-Key
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Facebook, the world’s biggest social network, is selling more ad spots to big companies like Wal-Mart Stores, Procter & Gamble and PepsiCo.

headline: No-Child Law Is a Highlight of Hearing on Education
text: WASHINGTON — Secretary of Education Arne Duncan is presiding over the rollout of the largest competitive grant program in his department’s history, a vast expansion of the government’s direct loan program for college students and sweeping new expenditures on failing schools, teacher quality and other big initiatives.

headline: Valentine Visits Mets; Fans Ask Him to Stay
text: ORLANDO, Fla.  Bobby Valentine stood on the top step of the Mets’ dugout at Champion Stadium, just as he had done many times before. But this time he was wearing a black track suit instead of a uniform, and he was chatting amiably with Manager Jerry Manuel.

headline: The Busiest Day of N.H.L. Trading, but No Blockbusters
text: Two Olympians, defensemen Ryan Whitney of the United States and Lubomir Visnovsky of Slovakia, were dealt for each other Wednesday at the N.H.L. trade deadline. It was the busiest trading day in league history, but few significant players were involved as teams struggled to maneuver under the salary cap.

headline: From Karim Rashid, a Soft-Edged Sconce With an Icy Glow
text: When the New-York based designer Karim Rashid was asked to design a sconce for ITRE, an Italian lighting manufacturer, he said, “I wanted to get out of the square and cylindrical shapes.”

headline: Yanks Begin Auditions for Their No. 2 Hitter
text: TAMPA, Fla.  In Joe Girardi’s ideal lineup, the No. 2 hitter would have some speed and a high on-base percentage, and also be able to hit for power.

headline: Murky Candidacy Stokes Iraq’s Sectarian Fears
text: BAGHDAD — A politician widely accused of running death squads might not be expected to have an easy time running for public office.

headline: Hand-Etched Tableware
text: “The shapes I make evolve from what I have needed or wanted in my house,” said Lisa Neimeth, a 46-year-old ceramicist in San Francisco. When she bought a 60-inch round dining table, she said, she thought a Lazy Susan would be a worthwhile addition. But shopping for one proved to be dismaying. “They were pretty tacky, made of laminated wood or plastic,” she said. So she made her own, hand-etching drawings on them, or pressing found objects like rocks and branches into the material as she does with her tableware, below. Her ceramics range in price from $15 for a bowl, 5 inches in diameter, to $300 for a Lazy Susan, 20 inches in diameter. Information: (415) 682-0599 or lneimeth.com.

headline: A New Home for Secondhand Rose, a Vintage Wallpaper Shop
text: Suzanne Lipschutz’s vintage-wallpaper shop, Secondhand Rose, has been a fixture of downtown Manhattan since 1965. Now, thanks to the recession, it has moved uptown — and upstairs — to a fifth-floor shop on Fifth Avenue.

headline: A New Sample-Sale Web Site
text: Snappy Tuna covers “the whole experience, from prepping a meal to getting it out the door,” said Marcus Greinke of his new Web site, the latest in a growing number built on the sample-sale model. Snappy Tuna specializes in well-known kitchenware and tabletop brands that are discounted up to 60 percent off retail prices, for three days only. Items for sale will include specialty foods, espresso machines and Le Creuset cookware (Menu’s Mini Magma Stone candleholders, above, will sell for $20, compared with $43 at retail). The site is being introduced on March 20, when users can sign up for a free membership and invite friends to do the same. If one of those friends then makes a purchase, Snappy Tuna will issue the referring user a $25 credit. Information: snappytuna.com.

headline: My Building’s Protocol, Altered in a Flash
text: LITTLE LOUIE was a star at my Upper West Side apartment building, where he worked as a doorman. Every day, he parked his red Harley-Davidson outside the front entrance. I always enjoyed looking for it as I walked down the block, but last Thanksgiving, it wasn’t there.

headline: Repeal of ‘Don’t Ask, Don’t Tell’ Policy Filed in Senate
text: WASHINGTON — Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, independent of Connecticut, introduced a bill on Wednesday to repeal the ban on openly gay service members in the military, but at a hearing later in the day Republican lawmakers questioned why lifting the ban was necessary.

headline: Optimistic Mariners Ready for Run at Angels
text: PEORIA, Ariz.  No teams hit more home runs last season than the Yankees and the Philadelphia Phillies, who met in the World Series. Cliff Lee, who won twice in that series, understands that reality.

headline: My Last Letter From Portugal: U.S. Women Win Algarve Cup
text: Midfielder Yael Averbuch helped lead Sky Blue F.C. to the championship of Women’s Professional Soccer in the league’s first season. Now, Averbuch, a Montclair, N.J., product by way of the University of North Carolina, is on the roster of the United States women’s national team as it prepares for the Algarve Cup tournament in Portugal. She was named to the team by Coach Pia Sundhage after a January training camp in Carson, Calif. Averbuch has been filing to the Goal blog during her trip to Portugal.

headline: Upper Deck Settles Suit
text: Upper Deck will pay Major League Baseball Properties a substantial but undisclosed amount of money for issuing three card sets since last year without a license, according to the settlement of a federal lawsuit. The company will also pay baseball $2.4 million to settle previous debts.

headline: Many Potential Successors if Rangel Retires
text: Representative Charles B. Rangel’s decision to relinquish the coveted chairmanship of the House Ways and Means Committee has raised a once-unthinkable possibility: that after 39 years in Congress, he will not seek re-election this year.

headline: Japan Offers New Plan in Okinawa Dispute
text: TOKYO — The Japanese government has approached United States officials with a tentative proposal for resolving a festering dispute over an American air base in Okinawa, the Japanese news media reported on Thursday.

headline: Sets for the Artist Marina Abramovic’s Dramatic Life
text: FOR Marina Abramovic, a 63-year-old Yugoslavian-born performance artist, the star is a potent symbol, and it makes frequent appearances in her work. Ms. Abramovic, whose retrospective, “Marina Abramovic: The Artist is Present,” opens this month at the Museum of Modern Art, constructed and set a large star on fire in an early piece, lying down inside it. During another widely publicized performance, she carved a star around her navel in what she describes as an anti-Communist act.

headline: Sidney Crosby’s Medal-Winning Gear Is Missing
text: PITTSBURGH  It is not certain who has possession of Bobby Thomson’s Shot Heard Round the World from 1951. The whereabouts of the ball that Wilt Chamberlain used to score his 100th point in 1962 remains in dispute.

headline: Darwin Foes Add Warming to Targets
text: Critics of the teaching of evolution in the nation’s classrooms are gaining ground in some states by linking the issue to global warming, arguing that dissenting views on both scientific subjects should be taught in public schools.

headline: Concerns Over ‘Metal on Metal’ Hip Implants
text: Some of the nation’s leading orthopedic surgeons have reduced or stopped use of a popular category of artificial hips amid concerns that the devices are causing severe tissue and bone damage in some patients, often requiring replacement surgery within a year or two.

headline: Upper Deck Settles Suit but Will Distribute Cards
text: Upper Deck will pay Major League Baseball Properties a “substantial” but undisclosed amount of money for issuing three-card sets since last year without a license, according to the settlement of a lawsuit announced Wednesday. The card company will also pay baseball $2.4 million to settle previous debts.

headline: As Use of  Metal-on-Metal Hip  Implants Grows, Studies Raise Concerns
text: About a decade ago, just as a new generation of metal-on-metal artificial hips were starting to be used, some studies noted their potential to produce high levels of metallic ions, causing what were thought to be allergic reactions in some patients.

headline: Divorced Before Puberty
text: It’s hard to imagine that there have been many younger divorcées  or braver ones  than a pint-size third grader named Nujood Ali.

headline: Failing to Fall
text: The narrator of Chaucer’s poem, “The Book of the Duchess,” cannot sleep. As his fitful thoughts come and go, he lies awake. He hasn’t slept for so long, he fears he may die of insomnia. But what is the reason for his sleeplessness? “Myselven can not telle why,” he says.

headline: Tables and Turkish Towels for Sale
text: As the Conran Shop’s move downtown to ABC Carpet & Home gets closer, the discounts get steeper, and starting today, all sale items will be marked down even further, up to 75 percent off the retail price, until the store closes on March 15 (Vincent Martinez’s Sis dining table, originally $1,850, is $463; a black Perspex console table, originally $2,250, is $563; Tod Bracher’s side tables, below, originally about $1,000, are $250); 407 East 59th Street (First Avenue), (212) 755-9079 or conranusa.com.

headline: Mariners Counting On Milton Bradley
text: PEORIA, Ariz. – The Seattle Mariners won 85 games last year while scoring the fewest runs in the American League and pitching to the lowest earned run average. They are built for their spacious ballpark, Safeco Field, with outstanding defense as their primary strength.

headline: Bloggingheads: G.M. vs. Goldman
text: Matthew Yglesias, left, of the Center for American Progress and Timothy Carney of the Washington Examiner discuss government bailouts.

headline: Book on Spitzer’s Downfall Sets Off Angry Replies
text: ALBANY — Nearly two years ago, a disconsolate Eliot Spitzer opened the door of his Fifth Avenue apartment and greeted his senior adviser and old friend, Lloyd Constantine, with these words: “Welcome to a Greek tragedy.”

headline: Fears of Lawlessness Prompt Show of Force in Chile
text: LOS ÁNGELES, Chile — At night, residents huddle around bonfires and guard their streets with torches and sticks, ready to repel outsiders who might try to break into their darkened homes.

headline: L.A. Consequential
text: LOS ANGELES — Not since the Beach Boys were in peach fuzz and crew cuts has it been so safe to live and play in the City of Angels. Believe it: you are more likely to be murdered in Columbus, Ohio, or Tulsa, Okla., than in the nation’s second most populous city.

headline: Former Pakistani Officer Embodies a Policy Puzzle
text: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan — With his white turban, untrimmed beard and worn army jacket, the man known uniformly here by his nom de guerre, Col. Imam, is a particular Pakistani enigma.

headline: Honda Classic Back Atop the Pecking Order
text: PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla.  Not in the last three decades, since the corpulent entertainer known as the Great One was tooling around the fairways of the Inverrary Country Club in a golf cart equipped with a wet bar, has there been a pro-am day like the one Wednesday at the Honda Classic at the PGA National Resort and Spa.

headline: Lawsuits Renew Questions on Immigrant Detention
text: When the Obama administration vowed to overhaul immigration detention last year, its promise of more humane treatment and accountability was spurred in part by the harrowing treatment of two detainees who died in the Bush years.

headline: White House Offers Bill to Restrict Big Banks’ Actions
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration put forward legislation on Wednesday to rein in the size and scope of the nation’s largest banks. But the proposal faces strong resistance in Congress, where lawmakers have shown little appetite for adding to the prolonged debate on overhauling financial regulations.

headline: Justices Weigh Claims Over Torture in Somalia
text: WASHINGTON — After the Supreme Court heard an hour of technical arguments Wednesday about whether foreign officials may be sued in the United States over torture claims, one of the plaintiffs in the case stood on the steps outside and recalled what had happened to him in Somalia in the 1980s.

headline: Reprieve Sought for Space Shuttles
text: Senator Kay Bailey Hutchison, Republican of Texas, introduced a bill in Congress on Wednesday to extend operations of NASA’s space shuttles until replacement rockets become available. The bill would also direct NASA to continue developing a new generation of rockets and spacecraft, which could include the Constellation program that President Obama has proposed canceling. The shuttles are scheduled to be retired this fall. They were to be replaced by rockets and a crew capsule being developed under the Constellation program, which was to return astronauts to the Moon. The Obama administration, instead, has proposed turning to commercial companies for transport to Earth orbit.

headline: Wallace Stevens in New York
text: Before Wallace Stevens became a great poet known for his "verbal ebullience and New England spareness," he was a journalist beating the pavement for the New York Evening Post. Those early years spent in the city informed his later work, and, beginning today, you can see how when New York University and the Poetry Society of America present "Wallace Stevens, New York, and Modernism." The conference, which runs through March 6 and is free and open to the public, includes readings, talks and presentations by literary luminaries like Mark Strand, Edward Hirsch, Elizabeth Willis and many more.

headline: Collecting Like Koons
text: Not all of us can amass an art collection like Jeff Koons. The pop artist has works by Manet, Picasso and Poussin piled up, salon-style, on the walls of his Upper East Side home, not to mention an 1873 Courbet over his flat-screen television. But for those aspiring collectors working on a slightly smaller scale, the Guggenheim is the place to be tonight. The museum is auctioning off 200 works by artists, architects and designers from the exhibition "Contemplating the Void: Interventions in the Guggenheim Museum." The auction, a finale to the museum's 50th anniversary celebrations, will benefit the museum's exhibition programming. First preview the work and then take in a performance by Animal Collective, the artist Danny Perez and Transverse Temporal Gyrus, featuring original recorded music created specifically for this event. The late show at 9 p.m. is sold out but there are still tickets available for the early show at 4:30 p.m. The auction items will be sold online from March 4 through 18 at charitybuzz.com/guggenheim.

headline: Gimme an H
text: "It's easy to feel alive with possibility, or delusional, at the new Hermès store for men, which welcomes wealth in all its glory and repugnance," writes Jon Caramanica. This store, which opened last month across Madison Avenue from the flagship, "is a thoughtful balance of expert craftsmanship and luxury kitsch, a four-floor clubhouse that somehow manages the feel of a high-end department store." Mr. Caramanica suggests picking a desired persona, say a disheveled and raffish Julian Schnabel or Robert Redford in "Out of Africa," and making the fantasy a reality with a few choice pieces, like a rough linen-cotton blend blazer with soft suede beneath the collar. "Soon I was writing scenes of my new life in my head, most ending with a quick nuzzle from Olatz as I come in the door at Palazzo Chupi, before we sneak upstairs for an assignation on her signature crest-appliquéd Egyptian cotton sheets." The store is filled with other aspirational items. "Most dazzling is one of the store's showpieces, a chocolate leather baseball jacket perforated in an H pattern, wearable by rappers and Mediterranean tourists, but probably not you."

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Feb. 19 about the tracing of a series of online attacks on Google and other American corporations to computers at two educational institutions in China misstated I.B.M.’s relationship to an international computer programming competition recently won by students at one of the institutions, Shanghai Jiaotong University. The competition, known as the “Battle of the Brains,” has been sponsored by I.B.M. since 1997, but its history dates back to 1970. It was not “organized” by I.B.M.

headline: It’s Polluted, but the Canal Is Home, and Inspiration
text: The rain had stopped; the streets were empty. A block from the Gowanus Canal, a woman called Terri squinted into the headlights of passing cars, searched for clients and found none.

headline: The Democrats’ Choice
text: Republicans’ lock-step opposition to comprehensive health care reform seems to be as much a matter of politics as principle. But either way, they have made clear that there is no dialogue or any possible compromise that will persuade them to change their minds.

headline: Political Policing
text: The controversy swirling around Gov. David Paterson has fallen on a long-festering problem in New York’s state government: the State Police. Whatever else comes out of this political mess, the Legislature must move decisively to remake the department, which sometimes has seemed as much an instrument of cover-up and vendetta as a functioning law-enforcement agency.

headline: Ex-Chairman Rangel, Pushed From Below
text: Representative Charles Rangel had a bit of a surprise to offer as he grudgingly surrendered his gavel as chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee. The powerful lawmaker, admonished for breaking House ethics rules, insisted that he first told Speaker Nancy Pelosi of his willingness to step aside months ago when the investigation began into various allegations of misbehavior.

headline: Cleaning the Gowanus
text: The Environmental Protection Agency’s decision to designate Brooklyn’s Gowanus Canal as a Superfund site clears the way for a federally mandated cleanup of one of the nation’s most polluted waterways. Mayor Michael Bloomberg’s administration had proposed a voluntary cleanup in hopes of avoiding the Superfund label. The federal approach is better  slower perhaps, but more comprehensive and far more likely to get done.

headline: How to Treat Those Who Aid Torture
text: To the Editor:

headline: Backlog of Mining Cases
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Dutch in Afghanistan
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Paterson Scandal and Domestic Violence
text: To the Editor:

headline: Free Speech for Whom?
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Health Insurance Mandate With a Choice
text: Princeton, N.J.

headline: And the Gender-Neutral Oscar Goes To...
text: Pasadena, Calif.

headline: New York’s Choking Loophole
text: NEW YORKERS have heard a stream of grave accusations this week that our governor tried to obstruct a domestic assault case against his aide David Johnson. But one element of this story has received less attention than it deserves: After Mr. Johnson’s girlfriend called 911 and reported that he had ripped off her clothes, thrown her against a dresser and choked her, Mr. Johnson was not even arrested.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Wednesday about the outcome of the Republican primary for governor of Texas described incorrectly the location of a polling place, Thomas C. Clark High School. It is in San Antonio; it is not in a wealthy suburb.

headline: Traders Seek Out the Next Greece in an Ailing Europe
text: Is Spain the next Greece? Or Italy? Or Portugal?

headline: Corrections
text: Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about the stabbing death of Aregawi Gebre-Yohannes, an opposition candidate in Ethiopia’s coming elections, referred incorrectly to Birtukan Mideksa, an opposition leader, who is serving a life sentence on charges of fomenting violence in the aftermath of the disputed 2005 elections. Birtukan Mideksa is a woman.

headline: Literally
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — Anything can happen in a Thursday puzzle, and today’s looks ominous right from the start. The grid has an unusually high count of 40 black squares. Is this some wildly original high-concept puzzle that will take ages to figure out?

headline: Story Prize Is Awarded to Mueenuddin
text: The Pakistani-American author Daniyal Mueenuddin was named the winner of the Story Prize on Wednesday night for his collection “In Other Rooms, Other Wonders,” the award’s organizers said in a news release. Mr. Mueenuddin’s work, a series of eight interconnected stories about the power dynamics surrounding the estate of a landowner in Pakistan, was chosen from among 78 books entered by 53 publishers and imprints. Mr. Mueenuddin receives $20,000 with the prize; awards of $5,000 each went to the finalists Victoria Patterson, for her collection “Drift,” and Wells Tower, for “Everything Ravaged, Everything Burned.” The Story Prize, given annually to a collection of short fiction written in English, has previously been awarded to Edwidge Danticat, Jim Shepard and Tobias Wolff, among other authors.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Wednesday about a surprising reversal by the education historian Diane Ravitch of almost every position she once took on American schooling misstated the number of books she has either written or edited since leaving government in 1993. It is 18, not 5. (That is how many she has written.)

headline: Corrections
text: An article in some editions on Sunday about the United States’ victory in the four-man bobsled at the Vancouver Games, its first gold medal in the event in 62 years, misidentified the pilot of the team that won Olympic gold in 1948, in St. Moritz, Switzerland. He was Francis Tyler  not Patrick Henry Martin, a pusher on the sled.

headline: Corrections
text: An appraisal on Dec. 31 about David Levine, the caricaturist for The New York Review of Books who died on Dec. 29, misidentified the object the philosopher Ludwig Wittgenstein is shown kicking away in a Levine drawing from 1969. It is an academic cap, not a book. (A reader pointed out the error in a recent e-mail message.)

headline: Westchester Snowstorm Is Bonanza for Tree Removers
text: OSSINING, N.Y. — The unusually prolonged, nasty storm across Westchester County last week took an immediate toll. People and businesses were left without power, homeowners saw their property damaged and commuters had to navigate mazes of blocked roads.

headline: Trusted Adviser or Stock Pusher? Finance Bill May Not Settle It
text: You have probably seen the television commercial, the one where you seem to be watching an intimate conversation between family members. But at the end, you learn that the conversation was actually between a broker and his client.

headline: New Panel on Charter May Revisit Term Limits
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg on Wednesday rolled out a roster of longtime loyalists, educators, political operatives and community leaders to serve on a 15-member charter review commission that is expected to alter the city’s term limits law.

headline: Corrections
text: The Vital Statistics column on Tuesday, about rising birthrates, misstated the percentage of single babies born prematurely in the year under study and referred incorrectly to premature births among twins and triplets. Among single babies born in the United States in 2007, 1 in 9 (11.1 percent) were premature  not 2 in 10. And 1 of 8 twins, and 1 of 3 triplets, were born very prematurely (before 32 weeks of gestation)  not prematurely (before 37 weeks).

headline: Great Fun With the Guessing Game
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  It has been a good week for the LeBron James tea-leaf-reading club, chock full of hints, innuendo and breathless intrigue.

headline: Russia: Leniency for Journalist’s Killer
text: Ibragim D. Yevloyev, a police officer convicted of fatally shooting an opposition journalist in August 2008, began serving a two-year sentence of house arrest on Wednesday after Ingushetia’s Supreme Court ruled that the original penalty, two years in a penal colony, was too harsh. The decision infuriated friends of the victim, Magomed Y. Yevloyev, and prompted a protest from the Committee to Protect Journalists.

headline: Roster Switch Lifts Knicks, by Leaps and Bounds
text: Dismantling the Knicks after this season has always been the plan. But even Coach Mike D’Antoni seemed a bit shell-shocked recently when discussing his team’s inept play.

headline: Shutting Off of Sprinklers Is Cited in Fire at Courthouse
text: Part of the sprinkler system in the basement of a Manhattan courthouse was illegally disconnected, allowing a fire that erupted there to grow before firefighters arrived to control it, the authorities said Wednesday.

headline: At Death-Threat Trial, Internet Radio Host Says F.B.I. Encouraged Rants
text: The family of a federal judge had just been brutally murdered. And as Harold C. Turner remembered it, it seemed an opportune time for the F.B.I. to make use of his secret role as a confidential informant.

headline: Editors’ Note
text: A commentary published on Feb. 7, 2008, in the Arts section discussed the impact of the recently deceased Maharishi Mahesh Yogi on the Beatles and their music. The article mentioned in passing Alexis Mardas, known as “Magic Alex,” who worked on various inventions for the Beatles in the late 1960s and traveled with the group to the Maharishi’s ashram in India in 1968. While expressing skepticism about his work as an inventor during that period, the article did not accuse Mr. Mardas of engaging in fraudulent dealings or criminality, either then or at any subsequent time.

headline: Corrections
text: EDITORS' NOTE

headline: For Movie Stars, the Big Money Is Now Deferred
text: LOS ANGELES  When Wolfgang Puck lays out the annual post-Oscar banquet in Hollywood on Sunday, he might want to think about doggie bags.

headline: Canada: Parliament Reopens
text: Canada’s Parliament, temporarily shut down two months ago by Prime Minister Stephen Harper, resumed work on Wednesday. Mr. Harper had said he wanted to “recalibrate” his government’s economic agenda. But opposition parties charged that Mr. Harper shut down the legislature to avoid uncomfortable questions about Canada’s treatment of Afghan detainees and to concentrate on gaining favorable publicity for the Winter Olympics that ended in Vancouver, British Columbia, on Sunday. The shutdown killed all legislation making its way through the parliamentary process. The new session began with Governor General Michaëlle Jean reading a speech outlining the government’s broad legislative agenda, which includes spending cuts.

headline: Controversial Architect Is Barred by City
text: Robert M. Scarano Jr., a Brooklyn architect who has long been criticized by community groups for flouting zoning laws, was barred by the Department of Buildings on Wednesday from filing construction plans — threatening, at least temporarily, his ability to work as an architect in the city.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: March 3, 2010

headline: For a Restaurateur to Be, a Vegetable Garden That Won’t
text: In the beginning, before fish, before man, there was a garden. And the earth brought forth vegetation, beautiful to behold, sustenance for the body. And it was good.

headline: Honduras: Letter on Opponent Attacks
text: Human Rights Watch said Wednesday that attacks on opponents of last year’s coup in Honduras have continued since a newly elected government took office. In a letter to the Honduran attorney general, Luis Alberto Rubí, the human rights group said that three people had been killed and eight had been detained and attacked over the past month in what appeared to be politically motivated episodes. Most of the victims were members of the National Popular Resistance Front, a coalition of labor and other social groups that protested the coup. Human Rights Watch said that a unit of the attorney general’s office was researching some of the cases, but said that investigators had “faced several obstacles in the past to investigate cases of alleged human rights abuses.”

headline: Rodriguez’s Return to Field Clouded by Questions Off It
text: A few minutes before the Yankees’ first spring training game Wednesday, their starting lineup was introduced at Steinbrenner Field in Tampa, Fla. Derek Jeter came first, followed by Curtis Granderson and Mark Teixeira.

headline: Plenty of Ads to Go Around on Oscar Night
text: SOME months back, with the national mood more “Up in the Air” than “Up,” there were doubts about ABC’s ability to sell commercial time during its presentation of the coming 82nd annual Academy Awards. Those worries were exacerbated by the low tune-in — 36.9 million viewers — for the 2009 show.

headline: Leaving the Dorm Behind
text: Inside the bachelor pad that was transformed from Craigslist mishmash to sophisticated living space.

headline: From Bachelor Pad to an Adult’s Home, for $8,000
text: COLIN KELLY, a 2008 Columbia law school graduate, had furnished the living room in his apartment in the financial district much the same way he did his student housing. “I don’t get anything until I need it,” Mr. Kelly, 27, told this reporter on a visit to his apartment not long ago. “And when I get it, I get the cheapest thing.”

headline: Belatedly, Voter Explains Why He Chose Cabrera Over Mauer for M.V.P.
text: PEORIA, Ariz. – When the Twins’ Joe Mauer accepted his American League Most Valuable Player award at the New York baseball writers’ dinner in January, he joked in his speech that he should have had a better series in Seattle.

headline: Gene Chenault, Who Changed Rock Radio, Dies at 90
text: Gene Chenault, who with his business partner, Bill Drake, reshaped rock radio in the 1960s with prepackaged programming that delivered more music and fewer commercials to hundreds of stations, creating the automated format common today, died on Feb. 23 in Tarzana, Calif. He was 90 and lived in Encino, Calif.

headline: F.D.A. Cracks Down on Nestlé and Others Over Health Claims on Labels
text: The Food and Drug Administration on Wednesday released 17 warning letters to food manufacturers, making good on a vow to crack down on misleading labels on food packages.

headline: Theodore Cross Dies at 86, a Champion of Civil Rights
text: Theodore L. Cross, a publisher, investor and entrepreneur who also had parallel careers as a writer on civil rights issues and a noted photographer of birds, died on Sunday in Fort Myers, Fla. He was 86 and had homes in Princeton, N.J., and on Sanibel Island, Fla., and Nantucket.

headline: Arnold Beichman, Political Analyst, Dies at 96
text: Arnold Beichman, a prominent political analyst, author and newspaper columnist known for being ardently anti-Communist, died Feb. 17 in Pasadena, Calif. He was 96 and lived in Naramata, British Columbia.

headline: Vieira Agrees to Continue With ‘Today’ Till Fall 2011
text: NBC’s prime time is still a problem, but at least the network can rest assured that its morning show is safe for another year.

headline: Robert Crafton III, Bassist and Rapper, Dies at 47
text: Robert Crafton III, a bassist, songwriter and rapper whose rhythms and rhymes helped the 1980s hip-hop group Newcleus redefine the sound of electro-pop, died on Feb. 23 in Brooklyn. He was 47.

headline: European Court Ready to Hear Yukos Case
text: MOSCOW — Yukos Oil had a poor track record defending its rights in Russian courts. Once the largest company in the country, it fell out of favor with the government of Vladimir V. Putin, then the president, in 2003 and within four years had been bankrupted and sold at auction.

headline: Beware: Activists Are on the Hunt
text: Activist shareholders are back — and for good reason. As the proxy season heats up, pot-stirrers like Carl Icahn and Ron Burkle are raising a fuss at companies like Genzyme and Barnes & Noble. Easy pickings from the credit bubble’s bursting may be gone. But the activists remain a formidable bunch.

headline: Cautious Steps Expected on Bank Liquidity in Europe
text: FRANKFURT — The European Central Bank is likely to outline additional steps on Thursday to siphon off more of the huge amounts of cash it provided to banks during the financial crisis, while carefully trying to avoid upsetting the still-fragile system and economic recovery.

headline: Mall Operator Given Extra Time to Reorganize
text: A federal judge on Wednesday granted General Growth Properties four more months of exclusivity to file its bankruptcy reorganization plan, giving the company, a mall operator, some breathing room as it fends off an unsolicited $10 billion takeover bid from the Simon Property Group.

headline: U.S. Team Won’t Race in Formula One in 2010
text: USF1, which was to be the first Formula One team based in the United States since the 1970s, will not make it to the starting grid. USF1, based in Charlotte, N.C., was granted a franchise last summer in the expectation that it would begin competition in 2010, but it has been shut down less than two weeks before the start of the season. A request by USF1’s founder, Ken Anderson, to retain its franchise but delay entry until 2011 was rejected by F.I.A., Formula One’s governing body.

headline: Who Helped When the Great Ship(s) Went Down?
text: WHO “thought only of themselves” and who “were more likely to help women and children” among the people on board when the famous ships the Titanic, above left, and the Lusitania, above right, went down?

headline: In Iraq, Early Vote Is Marred by Attacks
text: BAGHDAD — Iraq opened its polls early on Thursday for hundreds of thousands of soldiers and police officers responsible for protecting the country’s electorate, and they came under assault themselves.

headline: Moderate Quake Rattles Taiwan
text: BEIJING — A moderate earthquake shook southern Taiwan on Thursday, knocking out electric service to more than half a million customers and causing a fire in a textile factory, although injuries appeared to be limited, government agencies said.

headline: 2009 Paycheck for Wells’s Chief More Than Doubles
text: Wells Fargo, the fourth largest United States bank by assets, paid its chief executive, John Stumpf, compensation worth $21.3 million for 2009, a package that probably makes him the highest-paid American bank executive, according to materials filed with  regulators, Reuters reported.

headline: White House Offers Bill to Restrict Big Banks’ Actions
text: The Obama administration put forward legislation on Wednesday to rein in the size and scope of the nation’s largest banks. But the proposal faces strong resistance in Congress, where lawmakers have shown little appetite for adding to the prolonged debate on overhauling financial regulations, Sewell Chan reports in The New York Times.

text: BEIJING — China’s official military budget will rise by just 7.5 percent in 2010, a government spokesman said Thursday, a rate that is about half the official increase in recent years and the first to fall below 10 percent since 1989.

headline: Mesofacts
text: Facts (such as population size) that change gradually over time.Writing for The Boston Globe, Samuel Arbesman introduced readers to a third kind of fact in between those that are fixed (the height of Everest) and those in constant flux (the temperature): “facts that change slowly.”

headline: Greece Embarks on New Debt Issues
text: Greece’s debt agency announced Thursday that it would issue 8 billion euros in bonds with a coupon of 6.1 percent to mature in 2015, a day after its government announced new austerity measures worth 4.8 billion euros to battle its rampant deficit.

text: A Novell buyout is long overdue, Breakingviews says. The software maker’s shares have languished for 20 years, yet it generates healthy profit and has no debt.

text: MANILA — This capital city and several neighboring provinces will experience blackouts in the coming days as the country grapples with a drought that has devastated more than a dozen provinces, drying up rivers and reducing the water levels in lakes behind hydroelectric dams.

headline: USF1 Dream Definitely Over – For the Moment
text: The Fédération Internationale de l’Automobile, which governs the Formula One series, has now announced it clearly: the USF1 team will not make it to the grid this year. It may not even make it next year. The F.I.A. will start a process to open a grid spot to a team next year. Indeed, that means that if USF1 considers trying for next year, it will likely have competition from Stefan GP.

headline: A Grittier Side of Paris, from Doisneau’s Lens
text: The line wraps around the block as what seems like every Frenchman in the city waits to see the work of the “bard of picturesque Paris” — otherwise known as the beloved French photographer Robert Doisneau — at the Fondation Henri Cartier-Bresson (2, impasse Lebouis, 75014; 33-1-56-80-27-00; henricartierbresson.org).

headline: Greece Moves Ahead With Bond Sale
text: Greece said Thursday that it was planning to offer new 10-year benchmark bonds to refinance its huge public debt, in a move that will test the government’s — and the European Union‘s — credibility with investors.

headline: Hong Kong Exchange Says 4Q Net Profit Up 3%

headline: WaMu Shareholders Push for Annual Meeting
text: Shareholders of Washington Mutual have filed a complaint against the savings bank holding company for not convening an annual shareholders’ meeting for nearly two years, Reuters reported, citing court documents.

headline: State Street Pays Departing Chief $5.4 Million

headline: Nortel Gets O.K. to Sell Division to Genband
text: Nortel Networks has been cleared to sell nearly all of its carrier voice over Internet protocol (VoIP) and Application Solutions business globally to Genband for $282 million, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Brain Science vs. Criminal Law
text: Today’s idea: Advances in neuroscience put it increasingly in conflict with criminal law: If all our mental states can ultimately be reduced to neurophysiological conditions, and there is really no such thing as free will, how can people be held accountable for crimes?

headline: American Idol: The Top 10 Women
text: Like Willis Reed at Madison Square Garden in 1970, Crystal Bowersox emerged during the introductory segment of Wednesday night’s “American Idol,” an apparition-turned-real that held promise for the rest of the night. On Tuesday, she’d been hospitalized, and it wasn’t clear if she’d be able to perform. “Idol” executives said that if she couldn’t pull it off, she’d be eliminated — the fair decision, but for a season already on the brink of mediocrity, a potentially devastating one.

headline: TV Industry Faces Drastic LED Shortage
text: According to a new report from the iSuppli research firm,  the television industry will soon experience “an acute undersupply” of LEDs, the solid-state lighting source used in LCD TVs to create superior video imagery compared to standard LCD TVs, which use fluorescent lamps.
