headline: New Rules Trouble Some Defense Lawyers for the Poor
text: Last month, the mayor’s office unveiled new guidelines for assigning public defenders to represent indigent criminal defendants. Now, some defense organizations are voicing their displeasure, fearing that the new rules will take work from experienced lawyers and overburden less experienced ones.

headline: Scenes From the Demonstrations Over Education Cuts
text: In the Bay Area on Thursday, it was hard to go anywhere without running into people marching or a teacher handing out flyers, all part of the national protest over education cuts, as we wrote in a continually updated blog post.

headline: Rolling Waves and Rolling Homes
text: THE side-by-side oceanfront plots at the Montauk Shores condominium park are steps from the prime surfing at Ditch Plains Beach. One sliver holds a vintage trailer, known as the “green monster,” that is on the market for $495,000. The other has an unheated 300-square-foot cottage, with one bedroom and a sleeping loft, listed at $635,000. Peter Moore, an agent at the Corcoran Group, who with his wife, Lois, listed the properties, suggested that, with warmer weather in the offing, they should be snapped up together, by “somebody that loves to surf” — and with deep pockets.

headline: Greens Get a Boost Under the Glow of the Supermarket
text: Gene E. Lester, a plant physiologist with the Department of Agriculture’s Agricultural Research Service in Weslaco, Tex., was in the produce aisle of his local grocery store when a thought occurred to him.

headline: In New Jersey, the Telephone Challenge
text: THE phone, once a real estate agent’s primary — well, only — mode of communication with a client, is making a comeback of sorts in these lean times.

headline: Scientists Propose a More Efficient Way to Make Ethanol
text: Producing ethanol from corn is relatively easy: the corn’s abundant sugars are readily fermented into alcohol. But using what is essentially a food crop to produce fuel has been criticized as a misuse of resources that can harm both agriculture and the environment.

headline: Surveys and Polls Galore Before the Oscars, But None Can Predict How to Win Your Office Pool
text: Before the Super Bowl, advertising, marketing and media companies typically release the results of polls, surveys and analyses about the commercials during the big game. With signs pointing to a possible large upturn in viewership for the Academy Awards, to be broadcast by ABC on Sunday, there is a similar outpouring of data related to Oscar and movie ads.

headline: Massa Says He’ll Resign on Monday
text: Representative Eric Massa, Democrat from upstate New York, abruptly announced this afternoon that he would resign effective Monday — rather than simply not seek re-election as he had said earlier this week — because of an ethics inquiry.

headline: On Assignment: Into the Maw at Marja
text: Using one another as pillows, like a family huddled together for warmth in a house without heat, most of the Marines were catching a little sleep before their mission was to begin. But one sat wide awake at the edge of their huddle.

headline: Now Popping Up | Markt and Smithshop
text: Traditionally the province of Fifth Avenue, Times Square or, lately, the Port Authority bus terminal, the pop-up shop has been slowly migrating to a more unorthodox setting: the art world. To wit, the perennially veiled A Shaded View on Fashion blogger Diane Pernet has curated Markt, a fashion-centric installation now in its second incarnation at New York’s Scope Art Fair. The exhibition spotlights (and sells) the work of burgeoning designers, including Sandra Backlund, Lamija Suljevic and Six Scents Parfums. In addition to Backlund’s horsehair vest and Suljevic’s brocade dresses, fairgoers can purchase a video work from electroclashers Chicks on Speed and digitally generated photographic illustrations from Hormazd Narielwalla now through Sunday.

headline: Wedding Plan: Jump a Broom or Eat Goat?
text: LIKE weddings, wedding movies have their traditions: the dress is white and, usually, so are the characters.

headline: Report of Boat Capsize Looking Murky
text: The day after high school students reported seeing a boat with two people on board capsize in the freezing waters of Jamaica Bay on Thursday, setting off a frantic search, nothing about the accident was certain — including whether there was anyone on the boat, or even whether there was a boat.

headline: Starless Ensemble Plays Shine, With Limits
text: For the third time this season, the Off Broadway theater Playwrights Horizons has received rave reviews for a production, “Clybourne Park,” and has added performances to meet audience demand. What Playwrights doesn’t have are tiny casts led by movie stars, the formula that many Broadway producers consider essential for a play to make money in an era of high ticket prices and stiff competition.

headline: Hunters Revel in the Sounds of Silence
text: A BEDROOM door: That’s what Meghan Galewski and James Gonzalez wanted most.

headline: Coyotes Take a Turn in the N.H.L.’s Safety Net
text: In 2003, Jeff Holbrook, the chief spokesman for the Buffalo Sabres, received a call from the team’s finance department. Could he ask the coach to extend practice by half an hour?

headline: Sunday Preview
text: In the summer, Tuscany is full of Americans. But as Danielle Pergament recently discovered, the best time to visit may be wintertime, when the landscape is surprisingly green, locals fill the cafes, and the cuisine is at its best.

headline: The Renter Roadblock
text: IT seemed like a smart idea at the time.

headline: We Three Things | In Stitches
text: We Three Things is a roundup of three items from the current visual landscape that share a common theme. Shapton, a former art director of the New York Times Op-Ed page as well as an author (“Important Artifacts and Personal Property From the Collection of Lenore Doolan and Harold Morris, Including Books, Street Fashion, and Jewelry”), illustrator and publisher, connects the dots.

headline: Timing a Move After a Lease Expires
text: Q.

headline: When in Doubt, Add Chocolate
text: FOR years I thought that the deeper, darker and more ganache-like a chocolate pudding was, the more I would like it. I wanted pudding as dense as a chocolate truffle and just as rich.

headline: Photos of the Moment | Florian and Storytailors
text: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Alexandra Catiere.

headline: A Meeting of ‘Giselle’ and Hasselhoff
text: There are several narrators in David Neumann’s “Big Eater,” which flits from one subject to the next with a slapdash efficiency that can also be theatrically cloying. But the character described in the program as “the man in the woods” is the most affecting. Played by Frederick Neumann  of Mabou Mines and Mr. Neumann’s father  he is shown intermittently throughout the evening-length work on video, as he makes his way through nature.

headline: Byrd Defends Use of Reconciliation
text: Senator Robert C. Byrd, 92, Democrat of West Virginia and a fierce protector of Senate rules and precedents, is defending the Democrats’ plan to use a parliamentary maneuver called budget reconciliation to finalize major health care legislation.

headline: Making Another Dive Into Evils of the Deep
text: It used to be easier to make video game sequels.

headline: Amanpour Is Mentioned as a Candidate for ABC’s ‘This Week’
text: Christiane Amanpour of CNN may be the newest name on ABC’s list of “This Week” candidates.

headline: Columbus Symphony Makes Severe Cutbacks
text: The Columbus Symphony Orchestra has taken drastic action to stay in business. It said on Friday that it had lopped off 13 weeks of its season, translating to a 23-percent pay cut for its musicians and a $1.5 million reduction of its $9 million budget next season. Its season will run for 25 weeks instead of 38. The orchestra said that its reduction, which was negotiated with the musicians, will eliminate three paid weeks of vacation for the players, five weeks of playing for BalletMet and Opera Columbus performances; and five weeks of special one-off concerts. Subscription concerts will be preserved, the orchestra said. The cuts are a particularly draconian example of the trimming going on around the orchestra world after the recession.

headline: New Yorker to Head Museum in Kansas City
text: The Nelson-Atkins Museum of Art in Kansas City, Mo., which completed a critically praised expansion in 2007 and has been adding aggressively to its collection as part of an extended 75th anniversary celebration, has looked to New York for its next leader, choosing Julián Zugazagoitia, right, the director of El Museo del Barrio in East Harlem. Mr. Zugazagoitia (pronounced zoo-gah-zah-GOY-tee-a) will replace Marc F. Wilson, one of the nation’s longest-serving museum directors, who last year announced his decision to retire after 28 years and after shepherding a $385 million capital campaign to strengthen the museum’s endowment and transform its Beaux-Arts complex with a glass-block addition by the architect Steven Holl. Mr. Zugazagoitia, 46, has run El Museo for almost eight years, a period of sweeping change for a small institution founded in 1969 as a haven for Puerto Rican culture. It has expanded its mission to focus more generally on Latino and Latin American art and under Mr. Zugazagoitia’s leadership it has substantially increased its budget, endowment, donations and audience. The museum reopened last fall after its own makeover, a $35 million renovation that added a new facade and courtyard and modernized its galleries. Sarah F. Rowland, chairwoman of the Nelson-Atkins board, said that the museum’s search committee had chosen Mr. Zugazagoitia from a field of about a dozen finalists because “his training and temperament are exactly what we had been looking for  his commitment to the arts is so broad.” Mr. Zugazagoitia said that he was excited about the chance to take over “an encyclopedic museum, the breadth and depth of whose collection is astounding.”

headline: Paris Review Editor
text: Lorin Stein, an editor at Farrar, Straus & Giroux whose youth belies his influence in the publishing industry, was named the editor of The Paris Review, the prestigious literary magazine, its board of directors said on Friday. Mr. Stein, 37, has edited several high-profile authors at Farrar, Straus; in 2007, three of the five fiction finalists for the National Book Award were works he edited. As editor of The Review, Mr. Stein will succeed Philip Gourevitch, the author and journalist who announced in November that he was stepping down. In a telephone interview on Friday, Mr. Stein said: “Part of what The Review is for me is not just a place for writers to publish things and for readers to read them, but at its best it can be a gateway drug. My whole life has been in the shadow of that experience.”

headline: Lennon Auto Ad Angers Some Fans
text: A European automobile commercial featuring John Lennon has drawn swift outrage from fans, as well as a rapid defense from his son Sean Ono Lennon, below. The commercial, for the Citroën DS-3, which is being promoted with the slogan “Anti Retro,” includes footage of John Lennon criticizing people’s nostalgia for the 1960s and ’70s. In the ad, which began showing in Britain in February, he says, “Once a thing’s been done it’s been done.” He adds: “Looking backwards for inspiration, copying the past  how is that rock ’n’ roll? Do something of your own. Start something new.” The BBC reported that the commercial drew the ire of viewers who said that the singer’s widow, Yoko Ono, was exploiting his image. On Twitter, Sean Ono Lennon wrote: “I realize why people are mad. But intention was not financial, was simply wanting to keep him out there in the world.”

headline: New Plot Twist in Cussler Case
text: The longstanding legal dispute between the author Clive Cussler and Crusader Entertainment took a new twist this week when a California appeals court reversed a lower court order that Mr. Cussler pay Crusader $5 million after a ruling that he had acted in bad faith in dealings over the movie “Sahara.” The appeals court upheld the trial court in rejecting Mr. Cussler’s claim that he was owed $8.6 million by Crusader. The ruling, which came on Wednesday from a three-judge panel, sent the dispute back to the lower court to determine who, if anyone, had actually prevailed in the case. That determination would affect the assignment of responsibility for legal costs. Mr. Cussler filed suit against Crusader in 2004, asserting that it had violated its contract with him in making a film based on his novel “Sahara” and its fictional hero Dirk Pitt. Crusader then filed a cross-complaint that accused Mr. Cussler of contractual violations.

headline: ‘The Surrendered’
text: Chapter 1

headline: A Blow to Britain’s Snoop Dogg Ban
text: The rapper Snoop Dogg’s long-running battle to be allowed into Britain took a turn in his favor this week when a tribunal there said it was wrong for him to have been denied entry into the country three years ago, Reuters reported. In 2006, a public disorder at Heathrow Airport involving members of Snoop Dogg’s entourage resulted in the rapper’s arrest, and his being denied a visa to enter the country in 2007 when he arrived on a tour with Sean Combs. The travel restriction on Snoop Dogg, above, was lifted in 2008 but challenged twice by Britain’s Border Agency, whose decision was deemed wrong by an Asylum and Immigration Tribunal. The agency said on Friday that it was “disappointed by the tribunal’s decision in this case,” and would consider an appeal.

headline: CBS Best on ‘Idol’ Night
text: Despite competition from Fox’s “American Idol” results show, CBS eked out a first-place finish in Thursday’s prime-time ratings. According to Nielsen’s estimates, the lineup of “Survivor” at 8 p.m. (12.7 million), “CSI” at 9 (15.6 million) and “The Mentalist” at 10 (14.8 million) helped CBS average the most viewers over all, even as Fox’s “Idol,” at 8, delivered the largest audience of the night (19.3 million) and continued to dominate among viewers 18 to 49. Fox lagged behind in the 9 p.m. hour, however, as “Kitchen Nightmares” drew 8.1 million viewers, lowering the network’s average. ABC placed third with new episodes of “Grey’s Anatomy” (11.8 million) and “Private Practice” (7.7 million), while NBC ranked fourth.

headline: Chic in Review | Desmond Tutu, Designer
text: All the fashion news of the week that’s fit to reprint.

headline: The Trippy ’60s in a Guggenheim Time Machine
text: Let no one forget that Animal Collective is an arty, experimental band. Its 2009 album and EP, “Merriweather Post Pavilion” and “Fall Be Kind” (both on Domino), brought the band within hailing distance of pop, using intelligible vocals and blissful electronic hooks. But so far this year Animal Collective has largely set aside songs in favor of sound collages and visual-arts collaborations.

headline: Ex-Building Inspector Charged With Selling Training Certificates
text: A former city building inspector was arrested Friday and charged with selling scores of safety-training certificates to be used by New York construction workers who never completed the required training, federal prosecutors and the city’s Department of Investigation said.

headline: Emmy Awards Will Be Live on Both Coasts
text: The East Coast and the West Coast will be able to watch the Emmy Awards together this year.

headline: 2010 Iraqi Elections: Voter Profile
text: Full Coverage

headline: For Lighting, an Exception to ‘Buy American’
text: The Department of Energy has waived a “buy American” requirement for government projects receiving money from last year’s stimulus bill so that recipients can purchase energy-efficient lighting products for public buildings and roadways.

headline: Chicken and Vegetable Cobbler
text: Mark Bittman simplifies the chicken pot pie.

headline: How to Top Chicken Pot Pie
text: CHICKEN pot pie, like so many other dishes, was a way to stretch chicken by encasing it in less expensive, more filling dough.

headline: The Spirit of Freaknik Comes to TV
text: Growing up in Florida in the 1980s and ’90s, Faheem Najm was too young to attend Freaknik, the annual spring party that drew hundreds of thousands of revelers to Atlanta’s parks and colleges, and eventually sent them spilling out into its streets.

headline: It’s Proxy Season: Will You Vote?
text: It’s proxy season, that time of year when shareholders — big and small — get to vote on various corporate issues.

headline: The Week in Pictures for March 5
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in the New York City region. Subjects include Gov. David A. Paterson, a suburban mother who is fulfilling a dream, snow, and the Gowanus Canal.

headline: Fake Former Presidents Use Comedy for a Cause
text: The kings of presidential comedy were reunited last weekend  with a little nudge from the chairwoman of the Congressional Oversight Panel.

headline: Amiable Tramp Drifting Through Postwar Japan
text: DO you have to be Japanese to appreciate Tora-san? Evidently not, since that amiable drifter, played by Kiyoshi Atsumi in 48 films (a record for most appearances by an actor in a single role) made between 1969 and 1995, has enough of a following in the West for an American distributor, the admirable independent company AnimEigo, in Wilmington, N.C., to begin issuing the Tora-san films on DVD. The first volume contains the first four features in the series: “Tora-san, Our Lovable Tramp” (1969), “Tora-san’s Cherished Mother” (1969), “Tora-san, His Tender Love” (1970) and “Tora-san’s Grand Scheme” (1970).

headline: Taking on the Wilderness, Both Without and Within
text: Wolves seem to be having something of a moment. In January there was “Clash: Encounters of Bears and Wolves” on PBS’s “Nature,” which looked at how the reintroduction of wolves into Yellowstone National Park has given the grizzlies there competition. Last month came the movie “The Wolfman,” with Benicio Del Toro as the man-beast. And on Sunday the Smithsonian Channel offers “Running With Wolves,” a film about Gudrun Pflueger, who has been researching wolves in British Columbia and Alberta, Canada, for years.

headline: Delahunt Makes Retirement Official
text: BOSTON – Democratic Representative Bill Delahunt officially announced on Friday that he would not seek re-election, setting off what is sure to be a frenzied race for his seat.

headline: A New Global Sound: Synth, Soul and Sample
text: Four years ago, when Jason Derülo was a competitor in the long-running amateur-night talent competition at the Apollo Theater, one of his go-to numbers was “Love,” by Musiq Soulchild. That song from 2000, one of the first breakthrough moments of neo-soul, was slow and decorous and no-frills, the choice of a young R&B singer uninterested in testing himself.

headline: Greece Won’t Sell Islands to Cover Debts
text: After meeting Germany’s chancellor, Angela Merkel, in Berlin on Friday, Greek Prime Minister George Papandreou rejected calls from German politicians to resolve his country’s debt crisis by selling off some Greek islands.

headline: Pitfalls of the Spirit Awards
text: LOS ANGELES— Before we head off to the Spirit Awards, we thought it would be worth looking into how exactly those flibbertigibbets get awarded. While the voting is not as complicated as the Academy’s preferential ballot system, there are some pitfalls, as Steve Pond described in the Wrap.com.

headline: Little Help in Japan for Owners of Toyotas With Acceleration Problems
text: TOKYO — Feeling her Toyota Mark X station wagon lurch forward at a busy intersection, Masako Sakai slammed on the brakes. But the pedal “had gone limp,” she said. Downshifting didn’t seem to work either.

headline: Celtic Tale Becomes Video Game for the Stage
text: You don’t have to be an old fuddy-duddy to realize that experimental theater’s fervent embrace of multimedia, which produces all kinds of innovative, fascinating work, has its drawbacks.

headline: When You Make a Falsecard, Do It Without Hesitation
text: Perhaps the hardest part of finding an effective falsecard is thinking of the play in the first place. The second-hardest is making the falsecard in tempo; any pause risks giving the game away.

headline: Setting Wind Power Records in Texas
text: Texas, the nation’s wind-power leader, set a new record for wind generation this morning, when — at 6:37 a.m. — about 19 percent of the electricity on the state’s main grid was supplied by turbines.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, March 5
text: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

headline: Scenes From a Nomination
text: Clips of the acting nominees and best picture nominees for the 2010 Academy Awards.

headline: In Her Opinion...
text: Joan Rivers’s comments about celebrities’ red-carpet looks at recent awards shows.

headline: Bears Are Big Spenders in Free Agency
text: Now the N.F.L. knows what happens during free agency without a salary cap: the Chicago Bears turn into the Washington Redskins and the Redskins morph into the Bears.

headline: Flawed Security Exposes Vital Software to Hackers
text: McAfee, a leading maker of Internet security software, warned this week that software systems used by many companies to store and manage their intellectual property are being actively targeted by hackers and are in need of significantly increased security focus.

headline: For Older Workers, a Longer Job Search
text: Older workers are much less likely to be unemployed than younger workers. But when older people do lose their jobs, they’re likely to be out of work for much longer than their younger counterparts.

headline: Voting Your Shares May Start to Matter
text: What would happen if all the small investors banded together and cast their ballots during proxy season, the time of year when all shareholders get to vote on corporate issues? How much of an impact would they have?

headline: Cravath Is Allowed to Keep Advising Air Products
text: 12:28 a.m. | Updated It won’t decide the ultimate course of the battle between Air Products and Chemicals and Airgas, but a Friday afternoon ruling by Chancellor William B. Chandler III of Delaware’s Court of Chancery gives Air Products and its principal legal adviser a victory to crow about.

headline: Taxicab Confessions
text: I slid over toward the man in the gray suit, making sure not to look him in the eye. Between us lay only a few inches of cushion and an awkward silence. “I’ve never done this before,” I said, though it wasn’t entirely true. “I’d feel less awkward if — could I ask your name?”

headline: For NBC’s ‘Community,’ a Dramatic (and Funny) Announcement of a Second Season
text: This is what it looks like when your television show is renewed for another year.

headline: Old-Fashioned Bulwark in a Tide of Foreclosures
text: TO walk the streets of Brownsville and East New York, Brooklyn, is to see neighborhoods ravaged by foreclosure, homes boarded up and marshals’ notices taped to doors. Yet in the midst of this pain sit several swaths of well-tended homes, about 3,000 in all, each with a driveway and statuary and garden. Not one of their owners has lost a home.

headline: Disney-Cablevision Dispute Takes a Personal Turn
text: The distribution spat between the Walt Disney Company and the cable provider Cablevision started to look more like a spat between two chief executives on Friday, one day before Cablevision’s contract to carry the ABC station in New York City was set to expire.

headline: Former Book Designer Says Good Riddance to Print
text: A recent blog post by Craig Mod, a self-titled computer programmer, book designer and book publisher, offers a thoughtful and distinctive perspective on the move of books from paper to interactive devices like Apple’s iPad.

headline: Pen Down, Brain Off
text: Rebecca Stead’s novel “When You Reach Me” won the Newbery Medal in January for the most outstanding contribution to children’s literature of 2009. The book is set on the Upper West Side, where Ms. Stead, 42, grew up and still lives with her husband, Sean O’Brien, a lawyer, and her sons, Eli, who turns 9 on Monday, and Jack, 11. ELISSA GOOTMAN

headline: For NBC’s ‘Community,’ a Dramatic (and Funny) Announcement
text: Dan Harmon, an executive producer of NBC’s “Community,” filmed himself telling his cast that the freshman year sitcom had been picked up for a second season — but only after pretending to deliver bad news about its demise. He uploaded the video Friday afternoon:

headline: Male Bonding, Over Meatballs
text: Located at 84 Stanton Street, on a busy block of the Lower East Side, this month-old restaurant likes to keep things simple: It serves meatballs — naked meatballs, sauced meatballs, meatballs pressed on buns, meatballs on the side — but, only and exhaustively, two-ounce, spicy, homemade balls of meat. “People love meatballs,” said Michael Chernow, a co-owner, stating what to many is the obvious. “They’re simple, fun, familiar, and they bring you back to home.” ALAN FEUER

headline: Not Your Banks’ Bailouts: Stores Too Loved to Fail
text: The bike store had become a wine bar. The new apartments were breathtakingly expensive. Then kids from the neighborhood formed a protective guard around a gnarly old candy store on Avenue A and Seventh Street in Manhattan.

headline: A Plush Boudoir Welcomes the Curious
text: OYSTER BAY

headline: Reviving the Exotic to Critique Exoticism
text: “Lalla Essaydi: Les Femmes du Maroc,” an exhibition at the Jane Voorhees Zimmerli Art Museum, draws attention to one of the most interesting if puzzling developments in contemporary art: a revival of exotic, often historical imagery of people from faraway places in the name of a critique of exoticism.

headline: At Caramoor, a Focus on Songs of the Belle Époque
text: LEGEND has it that, after writing “Fascination” in 1904, Maurice Ravel sold it for quick cash and collected no royalties, leaving its authorship in dispute. Today, in any case, it is often thought of more as a crooner’s staple or a musical prop (as in Billy Wilder’s 1957 farce “Love in the Afternoon”) than as a work of art.

headline: Uncommon Insight, Coming From a Dog
text: You may want to ask yourself whether you can trust a confessed dog fanatic to review  “Sylvia,”  the Long Wharf Theater’s current attraction. So I want to reassure you that I am sometimes not completely entranced by plays, movies and books about my favorite animal. Sometimes.

headline: Killing Pythons, and Regulating Them
text: Florida officials are stepping up efforts to deal with the  python population in the Everglades, measures that include a special hunting season that begins on state lands on Monday. But wildlife officials say that the big snakes, which prey on a number of threatened and endangered species from wading birds to wood rats, have reproduced faster than hunters can kill them.

headline: Jewish Film Festival Grows to Extravaganza
text: “ANYBODY can download a film from the Internet,” says Harriet J. Dobin. So in her first full year as director of the Hartford Jewish Film Festival, she has done more than winnow some 100 entries down to 30 features and shorts. She has used the selections, which will be screened starting March 13, as a framework for related events — talks, concerts, parties — that “give people a reason not to sit at home.”

headline: A Cafe Learns to Bake
text: The breads, pastries and other treats at the newly opened Cidade Café in Ossining — all made on the premises and reasonably priced — have already attracted a following.

headline: Mannerly Italian With a Few Surprises
text: LIMONCELLO, whose lemon yellow and white striped awnings might be more at home on Capri than in Mamaroneck, now occupies the building where Ye Olde Tollgate Steakhouse once thrived. To call Limoncello a throwback would be unkind, but aspects of this new-traditional Italian remind me of venerable restaurants with names like Manaro’s and Nino’s, with their formal waiters, veal Marsala and big plates of spaghetti. I mean this as a compliment.

headline: Miami Board Looks to Close Two Hospitals
text: MIAMI — At risk of running out of money in May, Miami’s public health care system is considering closing two of its five hospitals and laying off 4,487 employees — a third of its work force, the chief executive said Friday.

headline: An Authentic Neapolitan Taste
text: In a town brimming with pizza parlors, Marzano’s, a Neapolitan pizzeria that opened in November, is a standout.

headline: Amid Italian Classics, a Few Surprises
text: THOUGH there are many Italian restaurants in Connecticut, the cuisine is so rich and varied that the arrival of a new one is still an event.

headline: Biscotti for a Variety of Tastes
text: Of the nine kinds of biscotti made at Marzullo’s Pasticceria in Williston Park, one in particular reminds Gandolfo Marzullo of his native Sicily.

headline: Tastes of Turkey, From the Sea
text: KUMKAPI, a Turkish restaurant that opened in Hewlett in December, is named for a section of Istanbul known for its fish restaurants. Remember that when you order: Seafood is definitely the way to go here.

headline: G.M. Plans to Reinstate 661 Dealerships
text: General Motors said Friday that it planned to reinstate 661 dealers that it cut last year as part of its bankruptcy reorganization, The New York Times’s Nick Bunkley reports.

headline: Bollywood Soars Toward Hollywood
text: MUMBAI

headline: A Vibrant Culture of Food Blogging
text: AT Bistro 55, an upscale restaurant in Rochelle Park, the staff is accustomed not only to customers talking on cellphones, but also to people using phones to take pictures of the food, according to Lorenzo Catlett, the general manager.

headline: Rivers Takes Aim at Stars’ Outfits at Oscars
text: JOAN RIVERS was not impressed with the flouncy tea-length Zac Posen dress that Tina Fey sported at the Golden Globes earlier this year. “I hope she was going for laughs, because she got them,” Ms. Rivers pronounced. “She looked like a decorative toilet seat cover.” Nor did she admire the purple Bottega Veneta gown that Sandra Bullock wore to the same event: “It looked like Prince’s old prom dress.” And Adam Lambert, all glammed up in Dolce & Gabbana at the Grammys? She got right to the point: “If Elvis and Elvira had a kid, this would be it. He looks like a gay Col. Sanders.” Yes, the sage of the red carpet is back.

headline: Oscar Casts Its Glow on a Regular Guy
text: LOS ANGELES

headline: For Auto Towns, Emissary Is Ambassador of Hope
text: MORAINE, Ohio — Few places are more emblematic of the rise of American manufacturing, and its gradual decline, than this once-bustling industrial suburb of Dayton — within sight of the hill from which the Wright Brothers first tried to fly their innovative contraption, even before Kitty Hawk.

headline: The Cavalry Can’t Save Them
text: Paris

headline: Liz Cheney’s ‘Al Qaeda Seven’
text: While it’s unclear whether it’s been Dick Cheney’s health problems or relatively low profile in recent weeks, but the left side of the blogosphere hasn’t had much to say about its Republican bête noire lately. So imagine the relief when another member of Cheney family decided to step into the breach:

headline: Massachusetts Democrat Won’t Seek 8th House Term
text: BOSTON — Representative William D. Delahunt, a seven-term Democrat, announced Friday that he would not seek re-election, setting off what is sure to be a frenzied race for his seat.

headline: Events in Westchester
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around the Hudson Valley. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com, or by mail to Westchester Calendar, Metropolitan, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: In Paris, Daring to See the Bright Side
text: Paris

headline: Women in Uniform
text: As modern peacekeeping has evolved, the number of female police officers in U.N. missions around the world has doubled during the past five years.

headline: Events in New Jersey
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405; or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: A Sport Recoils From a Punch and Its Publicity
text: WACO, Tex. — Shortly after noon Friday, Brittney Griner unfolded herself from the passenger seat of a two-door Honda sedan driven by her Baylor teammate and fellow freshman Kimetria Hayden. Without a hitch in her conversation or her step, Griner disappeared behind the doors of the Ferrell Center and into the cocoon spun by her college basketball family.

headline: Events in Connecticut
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Connecticut. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com, or by mail to Connecticut Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: Events on Long Island
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Nassau and Suffolk Counties this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com, or by mail to Long Island Weekly, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: Clinton Presses Region to Recognize Honduras
text: MEXICO CITY — Secretary of State Hillary Clinton ended a five-day tour of Latin America Friday with a lightning trip to Guatemala, where she promised Central American presidents more help to fight drug trafficking and repeated her call for more countries to recognize the new government of Honduras.

headline: A Cover Ad That Mimics a Newspaper’s Front Page
text: The entire first page of The Los Angeles Times on Friday was an ad that looked, in part, like the front page of The Los Angeles Times, as the newspaper again tested the accepted limits on where ads can be published and how they can blur the boundary with news.

headline: Ex-Leader Is Top Rival to Premier in Iraq Vote
text: BAGHDAD — The serpentine career of Ayad Allawi, who served briefly as Iraq’s interim prime minister five years ago, has taken another unlikely turn: a secular Shiite with little taste for campaigning, he stands a strong chance of winning the most votes in Sunday’s parliamentary elections as the leader of a coalition that is attracting deep support from Sunni Muslims.

headline: Knicks and Nets Are Two Halves of an N.B.A. Hole
text: Kenny Smith developed his point-guard skills on the blacktops of Queens and drew his basketball conscience from Midtown Manhattan.

headline: Consumer Groups Urge Regulation of Nonbank Financial Institutions
text: WASHINGTON — While much of the Congressional debate over consumer financial protection has focused on banks, lawmakers have been grappling behind the scenes over whether and how to regulate payday lenders, debt collectors, check-cashing outlets, title and installment lenders and even pawnbrokers.

headline: Willie Randolph’s Arm Finally Gives Out
text: PHOENIX – The Oakland Athletics’ Ben Sheets was not the only person in uniform here Friday recovering from surgery on a torn right flexor tendon. The other was Willie Randolph.

headline: Dysfunction Displaces Work in Distracted Albany
text: ALBANY — To wander into the grand pile of stone that is the State Capitol, to walk its cavernous sandstone and marble halls, is to find an absurdist play in its third act.

headline: Paterson Insists He’ll Clear His Name
text: Gov. David A. Paterson insisted Friday that he had no plans to step down as his staff tried to carry on the business of state amid a fiscal crisis and the cloud of multiple investigations.

headline: Disney and Cablevision Snipe at Chiefs in Contract Talks
text: The distribution spat between The Walt Disney Company and Cablevision started to look more like a spat between two chief executives on Friday, a day before Cablevision’s contract to carry the ABC station in New York City was set to expire.

headline: $400 Hourly to Get Them Off the Sofa
text: Lesley Mitler, a longtime recruiter for Wall Street and a former C.P.A., is a practical person, someone who describes herself as risk-averse. Why, then, did she decide that midrecession would be the right time to build a new luxury service?

headline: Ex-Building Inspector Is Charged With Fraud
text: A former city building inspector was arrested on Friday and charged with selling scores of safety-training certificates to be used by New York construction workers who never completed the required training, federal prosecutors and the city’s Department of Investigation said.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Friday about concerns that a House ethics committee report could expose the earmark process to greater abuses misstated the political party of Representative Jeffrey Flake of Arizona, who has introduced measures to impose a moratorium on earmarks. He is a Republican, not a Democrat.

headline: In What Can We Trust?
text: Note: Dick Cavett is filling in for Gail Collins, who is on vacation.

headline: Home Fires: Cut the War Film Some Slack
text: This is the fourth in a five-part series, “Retelling the War,” in which veterans discuss how books, movies and other tales of combat shaped their perceptions of themselves and of war.

headline: European Buyers of Airbus Plane Agree to Cover Its Cost Overruns
text: PARIS — European Aeronautic Defense and Space, the parent company of Airbus, said Friday that buyers of its A400M military transport plane had agreed to a 10 percent price increase, a measure that will help cover substantial cost overruns and allow the troubled project to continue.

headline: U.S. Aiding Somalia in Its Plan to Retake Its Capital
text: MOGADISHU, Somalia — The Somali government is preparing a major offensive to take back this capital block by crumbling block, and it takes just a listen to the low growl of a small surveillance plane circling in the night sky overhead to know who is surreptitiously backing that effort.

headline: Corrections
text: Because of an editing error, the Beliefs column last Saturday, about criticism of the argument made by Marc A. Thiessen, a Roman Catholic and former speechwriter for President George W. Bush, that waterboarding suspected terrorists is permitted under Catholic Church teachings, misstated in some editions where one of those critics, the philosopher Christopher O. Tollefsen, referred to the 1993 encyclical Veritatis Splendor. He cited the encyclical in a telephone interview; he did not make the reference in an essay in the online magazine Public Discourse.

headline: Tenor Adopted and Disowned by Yankees Leaves Town
text: Ronan Tynan became a walk-on Yankee star in 2000, when he stepped onto the field with his artificial legs and clarion voice and belted out “God Bless America” during the seventh inning stretch of important games.

headline: Corrections
text: Because of an editing error, the High & Low Finance column on Friday, about corporate resistance to the Internal Revenue Service’s efforts to get more information about companies’ tax returns, misstated the right an opposing side has to subpoena documents prepared for litigation. Those documents normally cannot be subpoenaed, not the reverse.

headline: Corrections
text: Schedule information on Friday with an art review of the “Civil Rights” solo show by Craig Norton at Jim Kempner Fine Art in Chelsea included outdated information on the closing date. The show has been extended and will run through March 14; it does not end today.

headline: Corrections
text: An art review on Friday about the Independent contemporary-art fair, at 548 West 22nd Street in Chelsea, misstated the surname of an artist who has a film piece displayed by the Parisian gallery gb agency. He is Robert Breer, not Breen. In some copies, a picture caption with the review included an erroneous credit. The picture on the left, showing a still from the film “Con Leche” by Jordan Wolfson, was from the Johann König gallery; it was not by Michelle V. Agins of The New York Times. (The picture on the right, of a work by Jeppe Hein, was by Ms. Agins.)

headline: Corrections
text: NATIONAL

headline: Congressman Accused of Harassment Resigns
text: Representative Eric J. Massa, a freshman Democrat from upstate New York who faces an investigation after being accused of harassing a male aide, said Friday that he would resign next week.

headline: Never Too Many Fans
text: TINSLEY MORTIMER was literally sparkling, thanks to her pink Dior dress with glittering bows at the shoulders. Her long blond hair was, as usual, set in carefully placed curls. She had rings on her fingers, though her left ring finger was now empty.

headline: Two Officers Are Charged in Robbery at Warehouse
text: The two men waving pistols and police badges at workers inside a warehouse stocked with perfume in New Jersey last month were not fibbing when they yelled, “N.Y.P.D.! Hands up!” according to the authorities.

headline: Hoping to Graduate From Guards to Gauguins
text: The guards at the Metropolitan Museum of Art are easy to ignore, and that is not totally by accident. Their blue uniforms, red clip-on ties and thick plastic identification cards do not distract the eye from the stunning works they are paid to protect.

headline: One Family’s Two Old World Bakeries Battle Over a Modern Prize
text: There are two Italian bakeries that bear the name Artuso, one in Yonkers and one in the Bronx, that are redolent of certain Old World fragrances — the anise, sesame and rum that fill their cannoli, sfogliatelle and other pastries.

headline: Seeking a Future for a Symbol of a Grander Past
text: DETROIT — The last train pulled away more than 20 years ago from Michigan Central Station, one of thousands of “see-through” buildings here, empty shells from more auspicious times.

headline: Haitians in U.S. Double Up to Take In Their Own
text: Carmelle Lajoie shared her house in Queens with her husband, their four children, her brother and her mother. That was before she took in her 11-year-old niece, an American citizen who was airlifted from Haiti after the earthquake in January.

headline: Owner of Crane Company Faces Manslaughter Charges
text: The owner of a crane company has been indicted on manslaughter charges in connection with a crane collapse in 2008 that killed two construction workers, a law enforcement official and a lawyer briefed on the case said Friday.

headline: Autonomy of Consumer Watchdog Is in Dispute
text: As Congress and the White House battle over the outlines of an agency to protect consumers from deceptive financial practices, their biggest hurdle is figuring out how independent it should be.

headline: Why the Rainmaker Is Now the Gatekeeper
text: YOU probably won’t be finding Julianna Smoot wearing Comme des Garçons, showing up at New York Fashion Week or posing for Vogue and Vanity Fair. And at least for now, you won’t find her posing or doing interviews at all.

headline: South Africa: A.N.C. Denounces Unions’ Allegations
text: In an escalation of venomous feuding within the alliance that has governed South Africa since 1994, the African National Congress denounced “with contempt” on Friday allegations leveled by the trade union federation Cosatu that some in the A.N.C. were seeking to oust President Jacob Zuma. The A.N.C. leads the alliance. The trade unions, which have long complained that their policy views are ignored, have made their dissatisfaction increasingly public, particularly with A.N.C. leaders they regard as corrupt.

headline: Inside Scientology
text: A tour of the Church of Scientology’s international spiritual headquarters in Clearwater, Fla.

headline: Senecas See Comeback Over Sale of Cigarettes
text: There is a relatively short list of people who like mail-order cigarettes: teenagers, adults evading sales taxes and the Seneca Nation of Indians of western New York, which dominates the national market.

headline: Ex-Mayor Gets 15 Years for Bribery; City Pays Price
text: BIRMINGHAM, Ala. — Residents here were not terribly surprised on Friday when Larry Langford, the former mayor, was sentenced to 15 years in prison and fined $360,000 by a federal judge, ending a long-running bribery case that shook local government and state Democratic politics.

headline: What May Accumulate in the Mouth
text: The Hoosier Folk-Child! — Rich is heIn all the wealth of poverty!

headline: In Illinois, Race Is Set for Governor
text: CHICAGO — A full month after votes were cast in a primary, the race for governor was at last set here Friday. The campaign will pit a conservative downstate Republican lawmaker against the sitting Democratic governor, who must overcome a dire state budget gap as well as memories of the ousted Democratic governor Rod R. Blagojevich.

headline: Corrections
text: Because of an editing error, the Mortgage column last Sunday, about alternatives to foreclosure being offered by some banks, referred incorrectly to a senior vice president at Wells Fargo. The official, J. K. Huey, is a woman.

headline: A Writer Invites Russia to Engage Its Painful Past
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Russia

headline: Corrections
text: The “Living In” article last Sunday, about Kew Gardens, Queens, misidentified the express subway station two stops west of Kew Gardens. It is Forest Hills, not Flushing. The article also misstated the number of holes at the Forest Park golf course. There are 18, not 9.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: March 5, 2010

headline: U.S. Sees a Terror Threat; Pakistanis See a Heroine
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Relations between the United States and Pakistan often have a through-the-looking-glass quality, where almost nothing appears quite the same from the other side. The latest example is the case of Aafia Siddiqui.

headline: Israel: Police and Palestinians Clash at Holy Site
text: The Israeli police and Palestinian youths clashed at a Jerusalem holy site on Friday after the youths threw stones at Jewish worshipers, according to the police. About 15 officers were lightly injured, a police spokesman said, while Palestinian news agencies reported up to 50 youths slightly hurt. The confrontation occurred at the plaza known to Muslims as the Holy Sanctuary and to Jews as the Temple Mount. Tempers have flared and rocks have been thrown in Jerusalem and in the West Bank city of Hebron since an Israeli declaration that two holy sites in the West Bank would be renovated as part of a group of Israeli national heritage sites.

headline: Bloggingheads: Down With ‘Avatar’!
text: Walter Kirn, author of “Up in the Air,” and Susan Orlean, author of “The Orchid Thief,” discuss blockbusters vs. smaller films.

headline: Mets Prospect Emerges in the Span of Seven Outs
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — The expectation surrounding Jenrry Mejia took a quantum leap forward Friday when Mets Manager Jerry Manuel and the pitching coach Dan Warthen made it clear that they think Mejia has the talent to pitch in the major leagues this year.

headline: Australian Court Finds Damages in a Vioxx Case
text: Merck’s Australian unit failed to warn a doctor about heart risks associated with its painkiller Vioxx, a court in Melbourne found, and might be ordered to pay almost 290,000 Australian dollars ($261,000) in damages. The Federal Court awarded the amount to Graeme R. Peterson, 59, in a case against Merck Sharpe & Dohme (Australia), the plaintiff’s law firm, Slater & Gordon, said Friday. The court found that Vioxx contributed to Mr. Peterson’s heart attack in 2003, according to the judgment. Merck said in a statement that it would appeal. Merck, based in Whitehouse Station, N.J., withdrew Vioxx in 2004 after a study showed it doubled the risk of heart attacks and strokes.

headline: Andrew Jaffe, Who Brought Clios to Adweek, Is Dead at 71
text: Andrew Jaffe, who presided over the expansion of the advertising trade magazine Adweek and helped revitalize the industry’s venerable Clio Awards, died on Feb. 26 in Norwalk, Conn. He was 71 and lived in New Canaan, Conn.

headline: Nets Laud Future Newark Home as a Bridge to Brooklyn
text: NEWARK — For a team that has won 6 of its 61 games this season, the future is all the Nets have.

headline: Met Guards Are True Artists
text: An exhibition at a gallery on Central Park West in Manhattan features works created by guards from the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

headline: Saved by the Coast Guard
text: To the Editor:

headline: Does the Mideast Need a Therapist?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Refereeing the Health Care Debate
text: Even before the health care showdown begins, Republican lawmakers have begun questioning the fairness of the Senate parliamentarian, the obscure but well respected career expert who must referee from the wings when points are challenged in floor debate.

headline: How the Tea Party Is Not Like the New Left
text: To the Editor:

headline: Ethics and Torture
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Battle Over ‘Don’t Ask, Don’t Tell’
text: To the Editor:

headline: ‘If You Bring in the Cops’
text: United States and NATO troops have chased most of the Taliban out of the Afghan city of Marja. The fighting was hard. But what comes next will surely be harder  leaving behind an honest and competent Afghan administration that can win back the loyalty of local people.

headline: So Much for Jobs, Jobs, Jobs
text: It is possible to put a positive spin on the jobs numbers for February, released on Friday. The unemployment rate, though still elevated at 9.7 percent, held steady. The economy shed 36,000 jobs last month, but the pace of job loss is moderating. An average of 27,000 jobs have been lost each month over the past four months, compared with 727,000 jobs a month, on average, over the same period a year earlier.

headline: Trading Away Productivity
text: Washington

headline: Justice for Judges
text: New York judges have not seen a pay raise since 1999, not even a token cost-of-living increase. They have justly complained about it. Legal scholars have pointed out how damaging it is to the cause of justice. Editorial pages, like this one, have denounced lawmakers’ baldly political tactic of linking the salaries of judges to their own.

headline: Cops vs. Kids
text: If you don’t think the police in New York City need to be reined in, consider the way the cops and their agents are treating youngsters in the city’s schools.

headline: Sheets Brings New Mind-Set to A’s Team in Need of Change
text: PHOENIX — Every day he reports to work at Phoenix Municipal Stadium, Ben Sheets greets his fellow Oakland Athletics this way: “Good morning, champions!” His teammates, who are coming off a last-place finish in the American League West, love him for it.

headline: Shaky Starts for Yankees’ Phil Hughes and Joba Chamberlain
text: TAMPA, Fla. — Joba Chamberlain battled a stomach illness for three days, and his pitching statistics were sickly Friday in his first exhibition appearance this spring.

headline: Giants Sign Rolle to Strengthen Their Secondary
text: The Giants, apparently concerned about Kenny Phillips’s ability to return from a left knee injury, signed the Pro Bowl safety Antrel Rolle to a five-year contract Friday night.

headline: Amid Record Low Scores, Player Takes High Road
text: PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla. — High on the list of things unlikely to happen again any time soon at the brutal Champion Course at PGA National? How about a quartet of golfers’ each tying the course record in tournament conditions?

headline: Trendspotting | Suits Off the Rack
text: Not much in fashion’s panoply has the cool authority of a trouser suit — or its potent sex appeal.

headline: Suits Off the Rack
text: NOT much in fashion’s panoply has the cool authority of a trouser suit — or its potent sex appeal. In the mid-1990s, during his tenure at Gucci, Tom Ford was quick to mine the pantsuit’s allure, executing variations with a ’70s-tinged rock-star air. At Balmain in Paris this week, Christophe Decarnin reprised that rock ’n’ roll theme, placing his louche stamp on strong-shouldered, hip-slung versions in banker stripes for day, and Lurex streaks for evening.

headline: Raimund Abraham, Architect With Vision, Dies at 76
text: Raimund Abraham, an architect who was known primarily for his visionary drawings of mostly unrealizable projects but whose Austrian Cultural Forum, a slim skyscraper in Midtown Manhattan completed in 2002, was hailed as one of the most exciting New York buildings in decades, died on Thursday in Los Angeles. He was 76 and lived in Manhattan and Mazunte, Mexico.

headline: Ruth Kligman, Muse and Artist, Dies at 80
text: Ruth Kligman, an abstract painter who for decades seemed to know everyone and be everywhere in the art world and who was the lone survivor of the 1956 car crash that killed Jackson Pollock, her lover at the time, died Monday at Calvary Hospital in the Bronx. She was 80 and lived in Manhattan.

headline: Chain Disdain
text: News Parody | From The Onion:

headline: Obama Urges Action on Health Care
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama pressed Congress on Saturday to “finish its work” on health care, dismissing criticism from Republicans as he sought to build a case that the legislation would be friendly to families and small businesses.

headline: Russian Oddka
text: Mondo Video | It’s singing in the shower meets Lawrence Welk meets the Slavic world and it’s gone viral. He’s quite possibly the Russian Rick Astley:

headline: State of the Bengals: What the 2009 Film Revealed
text: Offense

headline: Classic Ad: Nash Ambassador
text: In the Automobiles section this Sunday, Richard S. Chang writes about a radio host in upstate New York, Rich Conaty, and his 1950 Nash Ambassador Custom, a fine example of the company’s superstreamlined Airflyte styling in the postwar years. Mr. Conaty’s obsession with Nash automobiles began when he was a boy in Queens, hooked on the “Superman” television series:

headline: The Saturday Word: Back to Health Care
text: This was supposed to have been the year that Democrats focused on jobs, but after passing a jobs bill Thursday and relishing Friday’s better-than-expected unemployment numbers, lawmakers have resumed their full-fledged health care brawl.

headline: Nine to Know: Jason Bay
text: Bill Chuck created Billy-Ball.com and is a co-author of Walkoffs, Last Licks, and Final Outs. He grew up in New York and now lives with his wife (a Red Sox fan), and daughter (a Yankees fan), two miles from Fenway Park while Bill claims to be Switzerland. His other daughter lives in New York City, away from the fray. You can follow him on Twitter.

headline: 2010 Iraqi Elections: Why I Will Vote
text: BAGHDAD — I didn’t vote in the 2009 provincial elections. I think I was busy, or I didn’t really care. This time is different. The vote will decide who rules the country for the next four years – the first to lead, in theory, without American soldiers. “Your vote is golden,” Iraqis are being told. I really believe that, despite my disappointment with Iraqi leaders and all the chaos of the political process here.

headline: Bloc Takes On Entrenched Kurdish Parties in Iraq
text: KIRKUK, Iraq — A third political movement is waging a surprisingly strong challenge in Iraq’s autonomous Kurdistan region, threatening decades of domination here by two entrenched and, many say, corrupt parties.

headline: ‘A Vote Before Easter’
text: Monologue |  Friday night on “Late Night With Jimmy Fallon” on NBC: I’m not sure if you guys have heard the latest update on healthcare reform, but Democrats are saying they hope to get a final healthcare vote before Easter. Well, I don’t know. Two resurrections is a lot to hope for, don’t you think?

headline: ‘Her Own Reality Show’
text: Monologue |  Friday night on “The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson” on CBS: Sarah Palin is getting her own reality show. It’s going to be called “So You Think You Can See Russia?”

headline: ‘Two Hosts This Year’
text: Monologue |  Friday night on “The Late Show With David Letterman” on CBS: They have two hosts this year for the Academy Awards. Who says Obama isn’t creating jobs?

headline: ‘The Price of Lobster’
text: Monologue |  Friday night on “The Jay Leno Show” on NBC: As you may have heard, the House has passed a $15 billion jobs bill. That’s the good news. The bad news? All those new jobs, fixing Toyotas.

headline: Allison Braley and Scott Thompson
text: Allison Moran Braley and Scott Anthony Thompson were married Saturday in New York. Kim Kirkley, a Universal Brotherhood minister, officiated at the Manhattan Penthouse.

headline: Vanessa Menkes, Alexander Orlofsky
text: Vanessa Rachel Menkes and Alexander Stephen Orlofsky were married Saturday evening in Miami Beach. Rabbi Robert A. Davis officiated at the Miami Beach Resort and Spa.

headline: Kirsten Menkes and Jamie Firsten
text: Kirsten Alexandra Menkes and Jamie David Firsten were married Saturday evening by Rabbi David Cooper at the Canon Theater in Toronto.

headline: Sarah Siegel, Adam Lubow
text: Sarah Siegel, a daughter of Elizabeth Siegel and Edward Siegel, both of Shaker Heights, Ohio, is to be married Sunday to Adam Lubow, the son of Lynn and Greg Lubow of Tannersville, N.Y. Cantor Diego A. Mendelbaum is to officiate at the Villa Montaña Beach Resort in Isabela, P.R.

headline: Jennifer Parnes, Anthony Jones
text: Jennifer Lynn Parnes and Anthony Christopher Jones were married in Brooklyn Saturday evening. Rabbi Allen Block officiated at Stage Six at Steiner Studios in the Brooklyn Navy Yard.

headline: Karen Salomon, Buckley Ratchford
text: Karen Rachel Salomon and Buckley Thomas Ratchford were married Monday in New York. Tulis McCall, a minister of the Universal Brotherhood Movement, officiated at the couple’s apartment.

headline: With Haitian Schools in Ruins, Children in Limbo
text: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti — Thousands of schools in and around this devastated capital could remain closed for months or never reopen, according to Haitian and United Nations education officials. That leaves vast numbers of children languishing in camps or working in menial jobs as they struggle to survive.

headline: Palestinian Sees Lesson Translating an Israeli’s Work
text: JERUSALEM — Six years ago, when violence was the order of the day here, Elias Khoury’s 20-year-old son, George, was killed in a Palestinian terrorist attack. The Khourys are Palestinian, so the murder of George — who was out for a jog and shot from behind by gunmen in a car — produced an apology. Sorry, the killers said, we assumed the jogger was a Jew.

headline: Now Screening | Junya Watanabe
text: The fall 2010 collection from Junya Watanabe at Paris Fashion Week.

headline: Philippine Rebels Kill 11 Soldiers
text: MANILA — Eleven soldiers were killed and several others were wounded Saturday in a firefight with Communist guerrillas in a province south of Manila, Philippine Army officials said.

headline: Elyssa Goldberg, Jeffrey Ruzal
text: Elyssa Beth Goldberg and Jeffrey Howard Ruzal were married Saturday evening at the University Club in Manhattan. Rabbi Elliott J. Cosgrove officiated.

headline: Gail Schultz and Henry Smokler
text: Gail Gussie Schultz and Henry Samuel Smokler were married Saturday at the Carlyle Hotel in New York. Rabbi Andrew S. Davids officiated.

headline: Message Maven Finds Fingers Pointing at Him
text: WASHINGTON — David Axelrod was sitting at his desk on a recent afternoon — tie crooked, eyes droopy and looking more burdened than usual. He had just been watching some genius on MSNBC insist that he and President Obama’s other top aides were failing miserably and should be replaced.

headline: Loryn Wolff, Elliot Sperber
text: Loryn Allison Wolff and Elliot Jason Sperber were married Saturday evening at the Shelter Rock Jewish Center in Roslyn, N.Y. Rabbi Michael A. White performed the ceremony.

headline: Haiti's School Problem
text: The earthquake that leveled much of Port-au-Prince left Haiti's already fragile educational system in shambles.  A few schools have reopened, but class remains out of reach for most students.

headline: The Mother Figure of Morne Lazarre
text: Rea Dol leads an effort to feed and care for the people of Morne Lazarre, a poor neighborhood in Port-au-Prince.

headline: Photos of the Moments | On With the Shows
text: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Kevin Tachman.

headline: Olga Ramos and Felipe Azenha
text: Olga Enid Ramos and Felipe Saes Azenha were married Friday evening in Miami Beach. The Rev. Joaquin Perez, an Apostolic Catholic priest, officiated at the Miami Beach Botanical Garden.

headline: Split Decisions
text: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE — George Bredehorn returns with another of his Split Decision challenges.

headline: The Posting Hour
text: You know you’ve scaled the ranks of the sleepless elite when your editor notices the berserker late night time-stamps on your Facebook posts and asks you to contribute to a forum on insomnia. How flattering! How alarming! Isn’t it remarkable that, despite how isolated and alone we feel in our wakefulness, our numbers are so great we warrant our own special exploration? Fellow night owls, we have arrived. Three hoots for the weary.

headline: Lauren Pestronk, Adam Wilner
text: Lauren Danielle Pestronk, a daughter of Isabel Pestronk and Jimmy Pestronk of Upper Saddle River, N.J., was married Saturday evening in New York to Dr. Adam Jeremy Wilner, the son of Nicole M. Wilner and Dr. Alan H. Wilner of Hicksville, N.Y. Rabbi Lee Friedlander officiated at the Mandarin Oriental New York.

headline: Margot Lowenstein, Jonathan Simmons
text: Margot Allison Lowenstein, a daughter of Rochelle Lowenstein and Douglas Lowenstein of Chevy Chase, Md., was married Saturday evening to Jonathan David Simmons, the son of Jeffrey Simmons of Newtown, Pa., and the late Judith Simmons. Rabbi Elliot M. Strom officiated at Halcyon House, a historic house in Washington.

headline: Candice Smith, Scott Dias
text: Candice L. Smith and Scott E. Dias were married Saturday at All Saints Episcopal Church in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. The Rev. Sherod Mallow, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Skis That Provide Grip When Waxes Don’t Work
text: WHISTLER, British Columbia  As large, wet snowflakes fell onto the finish area at the cross-country skiing venue at the Vancouver Olympics, Tjere Smevold appeared to be more than a little exasperated. Although he is the chief ski waxing technician at Swix, the Norwegian company that dominates that business, he said there was only one solution for the day’s conditions, and it did not involve any of his waxes.

headline: Let’s Dig In
text: In the mid-1990s, when I still lived in Washington, I equated sanity with an old pair of paddock boots. I would put them on whenever I returned from covering the collections. They were part of a general cosmopolitan rumpledness I affected in order to stay in touch with the girl who once thought she wanted to marry a farmer (or a vet) and have five children and lots of dogs.

headline: U.S. Enriches Companies Defying Its Policy on Iran
text: The federal government has awarded more than $107 billion in contract payments, grants and other benefits over the past decade to foreign and multinational American companies while they were doing business in Iran, despite Washington’s efforts to discourage investment there, records show.

headline: A 96-Team Tournament? Now That’s Madness
text: It is never a surprise when sports officials act out of greed — the outrageous prices at New York’s two subsidized ballparks, the gouging at the coming World Cup of soccer in South Africa, for example.

headline: Straightening the Record
text: Dorothy Jane Mills was supposed to feel honored last Monday when the Society for American Baseball Research included her husband, Dr. Harold Seymour, in the inaugural class of the organization’s new de facto Hall of Fame. She was supposed to feel thankful that her assistance with Seymour’s seminal three-volume history of baseball, published sequentially from 1960 through 1990, would be acknowledged during his induction.

headline: Photos of the Moment | Wig Out
text: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Skye Parrott.

headline: Profiting From Iran, and the U.S.
text: The New York Times identified 74 corporations that have done business both in Iran and with the U.S. government over the last decade.

headline: Ahmadinejad Calls 9/11 ‘A Big Fabrication’
text: Perhaps concerned that his repeated suggestions that the Holocaust might not have happened have become less shocking over time, Iran’s president, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, upped the ante on Saturday, telling intelligence officials in Tehran that the destruction of the World Trade Center on Sept. 11, 2001, was staged.

headline: Coach Did Odd Jobs on Way to a Top Job
text: RICHMOND, Va. — When the Richmond men’s basketball team gathered at midcourt during a recent practice, it was difficult to discern the head coach from his players.

headline: Model-morphosis | Lanvin
text: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of Paris Fashion Week. Here, the model Edita Vilkeviciute from DNA Model Management before (top, bottom) and after makeup by Pat McGrath and hair by Guido Palau. (Drag the orange bar up to reveal the full transformation.)

headline: The Swaps That Swallowed Your Town
text: AS more details surface about how derivatives helped Greece and perhaps other countries mask their debt loads, let’s not forget that the wonders of these complex products aren’t on display only overseas. Across our very own country, municipalities, school districts, sewer systems and other tax-exempt debt issuers are ensnared in the derivatives mess.

headline: Letting Women Reach Women in Afghan War
text: CAMP PENDLETON, Calif. — The Marines in a recent “cultural awareness” class scribbled careful notes as the instructor coached them on do’s and don’ts when talking to villagers in Afghanistan: Don’t start by firing off questions, do break the ice by playing with the children, don’t let your interpreter hijack the conversation.

headline: Overseer of Boxing, Supporter of M.M.A.
text: Melvina Lathan, the chairwoman of the New York State Athletic Commission, has a passion for boxing that “began in vitro,” she says, and would lead her to be a judge of 83 championship fights around the world.

headline: Photos of the Moment | Backstage Bash
text: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.

headline: G.M. and Ford Channel Toyota to Beat Toyota
text: Milford, Mich.

headline: A Spring Training Pilgrimage Amid Changing Times
text: Decades ago, friends of my parents in New York would book an annual spring trip to Florida, brimming with anticipation about baseball adventures ahead. The fun of the trip was its casual itinerary, with a stop at the Pittsburgh Pirates’ base in Bradenton and a drive up to St. Petersburg, where the Mets’ camp was.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, March 7
text: Sunday’s talk shows hold no surprises as the political guests talk about (drum roll, please) health care and the 2010 midterm elections.

headline: The ‘Real’ Take on Methane and Warming
text: With a valuable reality check on Arctic methane in the climate context, Realclimate.org (in this case David Archer) illustrates the value of having scientists step into the uncomfortable, but unavoidable, arena of direct public communication. In the post, Dr. Archer, who has tested his chops with a couple of books for general audiences (I forgive him for recycling “Global Warming: Understanding the Forecast,” the title of my 1992 book on climate ;-) , tries out a nice analogy relating carbon dioxide and methane emissions to various troubles that can endanger a driver:

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: ‘Precious’ Dominates a More Staid Spirits Awards
text: LOS ANGELES— In a bit of Oscar presaging, “Precious: Based on the Novel ‘Push’ by Sapphire” and “Crazy Heart” were the big winners at Film Independent’s Spirit Awards on Friday. “Precious” took best feature, best director for Lee Daniels, best first screenplay (Geoffrey Fletcher), best actress (Gabourey Sidibe) and best supporting actress (Muh-nique, as the presenter, Pierce Brosnan, called Mo’Nique). “Crazy Heart” won best first feature and best actor for Jeff Bridges, who did double-duty by performing a song from it. Mr. Bridges and Muh-nique are Oscar locks; Ms. Sidibe has been much-nominated this season but has rarely made a trip to the podium, so it was especially sweet for her.

headline: No Road Map Necessary
text: I WAS born in South Korea. When I was 2, my family, including my grandparents, emigrated to Brazil for a better life. My father saw more opportunity there.

headline: Pinstripes Then, Now and Forever
text: Goose Gossage, the former Yankees relief pitcher who was inducted into the National Baseball Hall of Fame in 2008, spends much of his time making appearances around the country with Wish You Were Here Productions and sharing stories with other retired players like David Cone, Don Larsen, Graig Nettles and Mickey Rivers. Every February, he heads to the Yankees’ training camp to work as a special instructor. JOE BRESCIA

headline: In Basra, Iraqi Shiites Face Off Again
text: BASRA, Iraq — Two years ago, Uday Awad was in prison after having been arrested along with Shiite militia members during street battles here against government security forces. Though he was never charged with a crime, he said Iraqi Army officers tortured him over a seven-month period.

headline: Reports Say Afghan Official in Showcase City May Have Criminal Background
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — As the United States and its Western allies renewed their commitment to the Afghan war in recent months, they stressed that it cannot be won without good government. They reiterated that stand in recent weeks as allied troops flooded the city of Marja, setting it up as a showcase for a new strategy of taking territory, then holding it through strong local leadership.

headline: An Office? She’ll Pass on That
text: This interview with Meridee A. Moore, founder of Watershed Asset Management, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant. Watershed is a $2 billion hedge fund based in San Francisco.

headline: Villegas Surges Ahead at the Honda Classic
text: PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla.  Rarely does the thin edge between potential and performance snap into focus the way it has at the Honda Classic, and not even the thick smoke wafting over the PGA National Resort and Spa from a controlled burn in a nearby state park could obscure the story line Saturday.

headline: Neither Men Nor Mice
text: LAST fall, while working with corporate women across various industries, job levels and generations, an age-old issue re-emerged at a near-fever pitch. Women were obsessed about being labeled a “bitch,” and to a degree I hadn’t seen since the 1990s.

headline: Getting Older Without Getting Old
text: FACEBOOK now has more than 400 million active users, up from only 50 million as recently as 2007. If social networking still resembled a young, hip downtown nightclub scene — one day a site is hot, the next it’s not — we might expect the crowds to decamp soon. Facebook would become another Friendster, still around but ghostly, forgotten by most.

headline: The Corporate Side of Snooping
text: IT’S easy to understand how Washington reporters can become jaded. They are constantly being spun by the same gang of politicians and lobbyists who dominate the nation’s capital.

headline: Paris: Body Mapping
text: Funny that I should mention “lumps and bumps,” the Comme des Garçons collection from the late ’90s, in the last post: Rei Kawakubo’s fall 2010 show seemed to transplant that concept to a new view of human anatomy and inner strength. “Inside decoration,” Ms. Kawakubo said backstage of coats and sheer black tops clustered with shapes that brought to mind muscles, kidneys and brain matter. Or maybe those channeled and bunched skirts were meant to evoke intestines. Either way, the show was fascinating and well done.

headline: Tarnishing Hockey’s Golden Moment
text: Enjoy hockey’s Olympic moment while it’s still aglow because its luster is beginning to fade. Instead of looking forward to the splendor of the world’s best players again representing their nations in 2014 in Sochi, Russia, the N.H.L. is leaning toward secession from the Winter Games.

headline: Prime Number
text: 197: The amount, in thousands of dollars, that the typical married couple at age 65 should expect to spend on uninsured health care costs over the rest of their lives, according to the Center for Retirement Research at Boston College. This total includes insurance premiums, out-of-pocket costs and home health care costs, but it does not include nursing home care. Including the cost of nursing home care, typical lifetime health care costs shoot up to $260,000, the center estimated.

headline: Bad in School? Detention With Mozart
text: Disciplinary problems at a school in Derby, Britain, have dropped by about 60 percent since the school began piping classical music into a detention room for troublesome students, the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation reported. But music lovers are complaining that the school is alienating students from the music of Mozart, Ravel and other giants. Brendan O’Neill, author of a recent essay, “Weaponizing Mozart” in Reason Magazine, told the CBC that the school was “using great achievement to whack people across the head.” The headmaster, Brian Walker, said the music has relaxed his students. “I am sure that, with some of them, sitting in silence listening to the music lets them reflect more about the reasons they are in detention,” he told The Daily Mail.

headline: The Kite Makers
text: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti

headline: Quotations of the Week
text: “It’s a long way to Phoenix from here.” —Bonnie Chapman, a waitress at the Golden Nugget, a restaurant in Wickenburg, Ariz., explaining why business has picked up since the state closed its highway rest stops in a desperate move to solve a budget gap.

headline: New York Isn’t Silicon Valley. That’s Why They Like It.
text: The two dozen or so people arranged around wooden tables, warming their hands and bellies with steaming mugs of coffee and plates of homemade biscuits, looked like just another Sunday brunch set in New York. But members of this group had braved knee-deep snow to gab about cutting-edge ideas and as they introduced themselves the roll call sounded like a Who’s Who of digital start-ups: Foursquare, Hot Potato, Six Apart, Flickr, Flavorpill, Trust Art, Vimeo.

headline: A Connoisseur of Awards Show and Depressing Films
text: LOS ANGELES— Though it may be a while before he takes home any mainstream trophies, John Waters is an awards-show addict. “I voted in the Oscars, the Spirit Awards, the Writers Guild, the Directors Guild, the Razzies,” he told the Bagger Friday night at Film Independent’s Spirit Awards. “I voted in every awards there are.”

headline: Correction: The Cost of Doing Nothing on Health Care
text: An article last Sunday about the cost of doing nothing to change the health care system misstated when health care premiums are likely to be nearly a quarter of a typical family’s income. A premium of $24,000, projected for 2020, is a quarter of what a family is expected to earn then, not of what it earns today.

headline: Yankees’ Cervelli Sustains a Concussion
text: TAMPA, Fla. — Yankees catcher Francisco Cervelli was taken to a Tampa-area hospital for a precautionary CT scan Saturday afternoon after he sustained a concussion when he was hit in the head by a pitch.

headline: Lessons at Indian Hospital About Births
text: TUBA CITY, Ariz. — After less than two hours in the maternity ward, with her boyfriend, his mother and a nurse-midwife by her side, Jacquelynn Torivio gave birth to a five-pound, five-ounce son with his grandmother’s dimples and a full head of shiny black hair.

headline: A Squandered Talent Claimed by the Street
text: Michael Chatfield was largely unknown outside of his neighborhood. He did not play high school basketball, and his college career consisted of one unremarkable season at a junior college in Oklahoma.

headline: Arabia: Inshallah, Obama
text: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia

headline: The Moral Ambiguity of Looting
text: “The law, in its majestic equality,” wrote the 19th-century novelist Anatole France, “forbids the rich as well as the poor to sleep under bridges, to beg in the streets and to steal bread.”

headline: A Farewell to Europe? Not So Fast
text: IN 2008, during the worst of the financial crisis, portfolio diversification was of little help to stock investors as equity markets fell almost in lock step around the world.

headline: Giants and Rolle Have Leadership in Mind
text: “He is an outstanding person who will bring leadership, versatility and more big play ability to our secondary.” — General Manager Jerry Reese

headline: The Up-or-Down Vote on Obama’s Presidency
text: WEDNESDAY’S health care rally was one of President Obama’s finest hours. It was so fine it couldn’t be blighted even by his preposterous backdrop, a cohort of white-jacketed medical workers large enough to staff a hospital in one of the daytime soaps that refused to be pre-empted by the White House show.

headline: Mom, Apple Pie and Mortgages
text: FOR decades, the federal government has subsidized housing — particularly owner-occupied housing. This has been especially true during the continuing financial crisis, with Fannie Mae, Freddie Mac and the Federal Housing Administration propping up the housing market by issuing guarantees for investors on most new mortgages.

headline: Democrats Need a Rally Monkey
text: “Wake Up and Stand Up.” So urges the bold motto of a seedling movement calling itself the Coffee Party, a leftish alternative to the Tea Party movement.

headline: Seoul Police Link 1,700 Pairs of Shoes to 2 Feet
text: SEOUL, South Korea — In South Korea, where people often remove their shoes before entering homes, restaurants or funeral parlors, it is a nagging problem: people walking off with others’ shoes, either by mistake or, sometimes, intentionally.

headline: Bob Biniak, a Member of Skateboarding’s Z-Boys, Dies at 51
text: Bob Biniak, a leading member of the Zephyr Skate Team, a California group whose aggressive, surfing-inspired approach to skateboarding during the 1970s reinvented the sport and was celebrated in two films, died Feb. 25 in Jacksonville Beach, Fla., where he was visiting friends. He was 51.

headline: School’s Shake-Up Is Embraced by the President
text: A Rhode Island school board’s decision to fire the entire faculty of a poorly performing school, and President Obama’s endorsement of the action, has stirred a storm of reaction nationwide, with teachers condemning it as an insult and conservatives hailing it as a watershed moment of school accountability.

headline: Iran’s Ace (or Deuce): Its Oil Reserves
text: Diplomacy and energy are never far apart in the Persian Gulf. So, as American officials seek new international sanctions against Iran this week, it’s probably wise for them to remember how much the world’s global energy map has changed over the past decade.

headline: China’s Bank Chief Says Currency Is Unlikely to Rise
