text: BEIJING — China’s central bank governor indicated Saturday that the government was unlikely to detach the value of China’s currency from that of the dollar anytime soon, echoing Prime Minister Wen Jiabao’s statement on Friday that exchange rates would remain “basically stable” for now.

headline: ‘Mad as a Hatter’: The History of a Simile
text: Is the Hatter mad?

headline: Russia Confirms Killing of Militant Leader in Raid
text: MOSCOW — Russia confirmed Saturday that its forces had killed the militant leader Aleksandr Tikhomirov, who under the name Said Buryatsky is believed to have trained suicide bombers in the North Caucasus. And Russian officials said they had proof that his organization was behind the bombing of a luxury train in November.

headline: How Jerry Brown Became ‘Governor Moonbeam’
text: SAN FRANCISCO — On Tuesday, when Jerry Brown — California’s once and would-be-future leader — declared he was running to win back his old job, he brought with him more than questions about his age (71) and his record of political service (40 years and counting).

headline: Egyptian Leader’s Surgery in the News Is News Itself
text: CAIRO — Egypt’s longtime president, Hosni Mubarak, was recovering in a hospital in Germany on Saturday night after what doctors called a successful operation to remove his gallbladder, according to Egypt’s official MENA news agency.

headline: Algebra in Wonderland
text: Oxford, England

headline: The Unbearable Lightness of Leading
text: One oddity of the report: Mr. Obama weighed 179.9 pounds with his shoes and workout attire on, which is not the usual way to measure a patient’s weight.

headline: Between Germany and Greece, a Chorus of Sturm, Drang and Pathos
text: In recent days, novel solutions to the Greek debt crisis have surfaced, though perhaps not the constructive ones European leaders desperate to hold their struggling union together were hoping to hear.

headline: Reconciling With the Past
text: WITH President Obama and Congressional Democrats intent on one last push for health care reform, the main Republican talking point is outrage over the likely use of the reconciliation process to pass a separate House-Senate compromise. The Republicans’ best hopes of killing health reform rest on the use of a filibuster in the Senate. But bills considered under reconciliation cannot be filibustered and therefore can pass the Senate by a simple majority vote.

headline: Amateur Video Shows Flooding in Chile After Last Week’s Earthquake
text: Amateur video, shot in the coastal town of Penco, Chile last Saturday has emerged showing the impact of a tsunami triggered by the 8.8 magnitude earthquake:

headline: Home Fires: Narrative and Memory at War
text: This is the last of a five-part series, “Retelling the War,” in which veterans discuss how books, movies and other tales of combat shaped their perceptions of themselves and of war.

headline: The Pulse: Stroger Makes It Official Dynasty’s Days Are Past
text: First, Todd Stroger, the Cook County Board president, lost the backing of the mostly white Democratic power structure that he and his father had served for decades. And now, not long after his failed run for another term, Mr. Stroger has also given up the right to lead the political foot soldiers who long served his family’s South Side political dynasty.

headline: Clock Ticking on Disney-Cablevision Talks
text: Three million cable customers in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut will see their ABC station go to black (or something like it) early Sunday morning unless The Walt Disney Company and Cablevision either strike a deal or extend their tense contract negotiations.

headline: The Pulse: In the Recession, Proposing a Moratorium on Fix-Ups
text: Complaints from businesses about a city zoning department demand that they install costly decorative fences and make other costly changes has prompted the City Council to consider a moratorium on the fix-up program.

headline: Timeline: Scientology
text: As it has expanded across the United States and the world, Scientology has drawn controversy.

headline: Leaving the Church, But Not the Faith
text: A lifelong Scientologist, Christie King Collbran worked for the Sea Org, the elite corps who help run the Church. But, after 13 years, she grew disillusioned with the Church's leadership and left.

headline: Carp Solution Could Provide Financial Benefits
text: Proposals to block Asian carp from invading the Great Lakes have largely focused on the costs and inconvenience of closing off Chicago-area waterways into Lake Michigan. But now business and environmental groups are exploring a possible upside: a broadly based infrastructure investment that would benefit much of northern Illinois.

headline: An Award to Tie the Room Together
text: LOS ANGELES— Jeff Bridges will never live down the Dude, nor does he want to.

headline: Defectors Say Church of Scientology Hides Abuse
text: CLEARWATER, Fla. — Raised as Scientologists, Christie King Collbran and her husband, Chris, were recruited as teenagers to work for the elite corps of staff members who keep the Church of Scientology running, known as the Sea Organization, or Sea Org.

headline: Come to Order

headline: Henri Salmide, 90, Dies; German’s Defiance Saved a French Port
text: PARIS — Henri Salmide, a former German naval officer who defied orders to blow up the French port of Bordeaux in 1944, died on Feb. 23. He was 90 and lived in Bordeaux.

headline: For Aldermen, a 50-50 Chance They’ll Look Good
text: If you’re not doing anything the evening of March 19, you might consider a visit to the Johalla Projects Gallery in Wicker Park for the opening of the “Aldermen Project: 50 Aldermen/50 Artists” show.

headline: Making Tough Choices for Higher Education
text: James Warren is a longtime Chicago journalist and the publisher of The Chicago Reader.

headline: Journalistic Shoplifting
text: ZACHERY KOUWE, a Times business reporter for a little over a year, resigned last month after he was accused of plagiarizing from The Wall Street Journal. An internal review of his work turned up more articles  he said he was shown four  containing copy clearly lifted from other news sources.

text: To the Editor:

headline: Letters: An Airwave Auction

headline: Out of Office, but Still the Toast of the Town
text: Willie L. Brown Jr. was a poor boy from Texas when he made his way to San Francisco at 17. He went on to become one of the most powerful politicians in California, serving for three decades in the State Assembly, including 15 as speaker, before leaving politics in 2004 after two terms as mayor of San Francisco. During his time in office, he was equally adept at making back-room deals and smiling his way through various red-carpet events with swarms of reporters and photographers. Now 75, a columnist for The San Francisco Chronicle and as gregarious as ever, Mr. Brown remains one of the city’s most influential and nattily dressed figures. (His words have been edited and condensed.) GERRY SHIH

headline: Fretting About the Last of the World’s Biggest Cats
text: Could this Chinese Year of the Tiger be the last one with actual tigers still afoot in the world’s wild?

headline: Pete Stark Is Often His Own Worst Enemy
text: Long before he first ran for Congress nearly four decades ago, Pete Stark was not one to fit in. Don’t expect him to change now.

headline: A Germanic Interlude at the Spirits
text: LOS ANGELES— So, as we were saying, Jeff Bridges will never live down the Dude. Not only did he make a “Big Lebowski” reference on stage at the Spirit Awards on Friday, he displayed some of that characters trademark chill-ness after the show ended. The Bagger and Mr. Bridges were walking and talking when we were interrupted by a man with a microphone and a video camera, an attractive woman in a gown standing to his side.

headline: Colleges and Schools Try to Do More With Less
text: When San Francisco State University’s theater arts department commissioned Mark Jackson to adapt and direct a production of “Romeo and Juliet,” he came up with the unusual idea of creating a version of the tragedy for 14 actors, all cast in the role of Juliet. But because of budget cuts at the university, less money is available for items that affect the look of a production, like sets, lights and costumes. So to save on wardrobe, Mr. Jackson has had to readjust his core creative concept: now he has just eight actors for his new show, “Juliet.”

headline: Willie Brown and Other Highlights From Sunday’s Bay Area Pages
text: Sunday Routine: Willie Brown | Willie L. Brown Jr. was a poor boy from Texas when he made his way to San Francisco at 17. He went on to become one of the most powerful politicians in California, before leaving politics in 2004 after two terms as mayor of San Francisco. Now 75, Mr. Brown remains one of the city’s most influential and nattily dressed figures.

text: The fall 2010 collection from Dior at Paris Fashion Week.

headline: Man Trying to Break Up a Fight Is Killed in the Bronx
text: A Bronx man who the police said was trying to be “a good guy” by breaking up a fight early Saturday was fatally stabbed by one of the people involved in the fight, according to the authorities.

headline: Signs of a Thaw in the Wardrobe Recession
text: There are signs that people may soon be back to surveying their wardrobes with a more unforgiving air, followed by a trip to the store.

headline: In Harlem, Epicenter for Charter Schools, a Senator Wars Against Them
text: When hundreds of parents went to Albany last month to rally for charter schools, they were greeted by a parade of politicians offering encouragement and promises.

headline: Picture This: A Nose on the Loose
text: It has become commonplace at the Metropolitan Opera for directors and designers of new productions, especially modernist high-concept ones, to be lustily booed by a sizable contingent of the audience during opening-night ovations.

headline: Obama Wields Analysis of Insurers in Health Battle
text: WASHINGTON — To bolster the case for a far-reaching overhaul of the health care system, the Obama administration is seizing on a new analysis by Goldman Sachs, the New York investment bank, recommending that investors buy shares in two big insurance companies, the UnitedHealth Group and Cigna, because insurance rates are up sharply and competition is down.

headline: Now Screening | Lanvin
text: The fall 2010 collection from Lanvin at Paris Fashion Week.

headline: Correction
text: An article last Sunday about the rise of Islamic militancy among the frustrated youth of Pakistan omitted a passage at the continuation in some copies. The full passage should have read: “ ‘The situation is now quite confusing,’ said Tariq Parvez, director of the National Counterterrorism Authority in Islamabad, Pakistan’s capital. ‘We can no longer talk in terms of organizations. Now it’s a question of like-minded militants.’ The result has been deadly. In 2009, militant attacks killed 3,021 Pakistanis, three times as many as in 2006.” (The full article is at nytimes.com/world.)

headline: Correction
text: A map last Sunday with the This Land column, about the skier Hannah Kearney, who won the first gold medal for the United States in this year’s Olympics, mislabeled, in some copies, the state in which her hometown of Norwich is located. As the article noted, it is Vermont, not Florida.

headline: Young Grandmaster-to-Be Bows to Formidable Older Foe
text: Older chess players are not an endangered species, but there is no doubt that chess is increasingly dominated by young men (and women). The world’s top-ranked player is 19, and more prodigies are emerging everywhere.

headline: The Mets’ Future Suddenly Feels Far From Barren
text: VIERA, Fla. — One of the enduring traditions of sports is the art of casting blame on former coaches, executives and players for whatever went wrong in the past. Certainly, the Mets are not immune to that tendency, with everyone from Davey Johnson, Bobby Valentine and Joe McIlvaine to Jim Duquette, Willie Randolph and most recently Tony Bernazard being tagged with guilt for various failures after they left.

headline: Patricia Travers, Violinist Who Vanished, Dies at 82
text: At 11, the violinist Patricia Travers made her first solo appearance with the New York Philharmonic, playing Lalo’s “Symphonie Espagnole” with “a purity of tone, breadth of line and immersion in her task,” as a critic for The New York Times wrote in 1939.

headline: Paris Fashion Week | Lanvin
text: Suzy Menkes discusses putting women first and the Winter 2010 collection with Lanvin's star designer, Alber Elbaz.

headline: N.H.L. Will Discuss Hits to Head at Annual Meeting
text: When N.H.L. general managers convene for their annual three-day meeting Monday in Boca Raton, Fla., one item on the agenda will occupy most of their time: what, if anything, to do about hits to the head.The general managers will see several presentations, one the result of two years of independent medical study, as they seek to make policy recommendations to the league on the controversial issue.

headline: A Banking Battleground
text: Despite the power of big banks, small institutions still dominate huge swaths of the country and hold nearly half of bank deposits overall.

headline: Departing Chilean President Defends Government’s Actions After Quake
text: SANTIAGO, Chile — A week after this country was devastated by an 8.8-magnitude earthquake, President Michelle Bachelet defended her government against charges that it had put politics before people’s needs.

headline: Do We Need a Gender-Neutral Oscar for Acting?

headline: The Spread of Superbugs
text: Until three months ago, Thomas M. Dukes was a vigorous, healthy executive at a California plastics company. Then, over the course of a few days in December as he was planning his Christmas shopping, E. coli bacteria ravaged his body and tore his life apart.

headline: Dreaming the Possible Dream
text: The thing I love most about America is that there’s always somebody who doesn’t get the word  somebody who doesn’t understand that in a Great Recession you’re supposed to hunker down, downsize and just hold on for dear life. I have a couple of friends who fit that bill, who think a recession is a dandy time to try to discover better and cheaper ways to do things. They both happen to be Indian-Americans  one a son of the Himalayas, who came to America on a scholarship and went to work for NASA to try to find a way to Mars; the other a son of New Delhi, who came here and found the Sun, Sun Microsystems. Both are serial innovators. Both are now shepherding clean-tech start-ups that have the potential to be disruptive game changers. They don’t know from hunkering down. They just didn’t get the word.

text: To the Editor:

headline: If Reform Fails
text: As the fierce debate on President Obama’s plan for health care reform comes to a head, Americans should be thinking carefully about what happens if Congress fails to enact legislation.

headline: Voters in Iceland Reject Repayment Plan
text: LONDON — Iceland’s voters expressed their outrage on Saturday against bankers, the government and what they saw as foreign bullying, overwhelmingly rejecting a plan to pay $5.3 billion to Britain and the Netherlands to reimburse customers of a failed Icelandic bank.

headline: Igawa Working to Be Pitcher Yankees Thought He Was
text: TAMPA, Fla. — When Kei Igawa and his big price tag arrived from Japan three years ago, he occupied a dressing stall on the main row in the locker room at Yankees’ training camp.

headline: A Banking Battleground
text: For the last year, big banks have grabbed a huge share of the headlines, and of federal bailout funds. But they don't - yet, at least - hold all of the nation's money. Small banks still dominate huge swaths of the country and hold nearly half of bank deposits over all.

headline: Paterson Rewards Redemption With a Pardon
text: Gov. David A. Paterson announced on Saturday that he had pardoned a man whose rise from poverty and street crime in Chinatown to success as an information technology executive was about to end in deportation.

headline: Iraq's Parliamentary Elections
text: In the final hours before the first Parliamentary elections in four years, the race in Iraq is still too close to call.

headline: Correction
text: The Evening Hours column last Sunday misidentified the guest shown with Heather Mnuchin at the Winter Ball held by the Director’s Council of the Museum of the City of New York on Feb. 23. She is Ulla Parker, not Coralie Charriol Paul.

headline: Corrections
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Jets Trade Kerry Rhodes to Arizona Cardinals
text: On Friday, Jets General Manager Mike Tannenbaum said the Jets would pay a $2 million roster bonus next week to keep safety Kerry Rhodes on the team. Then he uttered the key words: “unless something happens.”

headline: Correction
text: The Deconstructed feature last Sunday, about Electronic Benefit Transfer cards, which replaced paper food stamps, referred incorrectly to the average monthly allotment in New York City and to the amount of time it takes to get a card. The allotment is $289 per household, not per individual, and applicants usually get cards within a month after requesting them  not the same day.

headline: Lull in N.F.L. Signings as Teams Reassess Capless Market
text: With the biggest names counting their riches after a frenzied first day of free agency, the N.F.L. caught its breath Saturday.

headline: Correction
text: An article last Sunday about the actress Diane Keaton referred incompletely to the creation of the “Annie Hall” look. While Ms. Keaton is closely identified with the look, Ruth Morley was the costume designer for the film and the two women collaborated on the style; Ms. Keaton did not “single-handedly” invent the look.

headline: Reader Comments on my Antibiotics Column
text: My Sunday column is about the diminishing effectiveness of antibiotics, and the concern that our agricultural policies (stuffing livestock with antibiotics) will entail huge public health costs. The rise of antibiotic-resistance is well-known (it’s a great example of evolution), and was recently documented by my Times colleague Andrew Pollack in the case of gram-negative bacteria.

headline: Could Plagiarism Software Have Spared The Times an Embarrassment?
text: Craig Silverman, the editor of Regret the Error, a Web site that reports on accuracy and honesty in the press, says most plagiarism by journalists is caught only when someone complains.  That’s what happened last month at The Times, which had to endure the mortifying experience of having a bitter cross-town rival, The Wall Street Journal, point out the theft of half a dozen passages from one of its news articles.

headline: Video: Iraq’s Parliamentary Elections
text: Video: Iraq’s Parliamentary Elections

headline: Vows: Margot & Jon
text: Margot Lowenstein and Jon Simmons met at a dinner, after which they began spending time together. But where he saw romance, Margot saw only friendship. Jon soon proved her wrong.

headline: Detroit’s Iconic Ruins
text: Detroit is debating how best to save Michigan Central Station, a gracious relic of the industrial age that has been idle and deteriorating for more than 20 years.

headline: The Real Contest Occurred After the Game
text: ALBANY — The MAAC quarterfinal game between top-seeded Siena and ninth-seeded Manhattan did not leave too much to talk about. Manhattan (11-20) jolted out to a 12-point lead over Siena (25-6), talked a bit of trash and then turned in a listless second-half performance in a 78-61 loss.

headline: Queens Man Charged With Assaulting 13-Week-Old
text: A 23-year-old man was charged with assaulting his 13-week-old daughter, whose injuries included 17 fractured ribs and a lacerated liver.

headline: As Iraq Tallies Vote, U.S. Says Pullout Plans Are ‘on Track’
text: BAGHDAD — Defying a sustained barrage of mortars and rockets in Baghdad and other cities, Iraqis went to the polls in strength on Sunday to choose a new Parliament meant to outlast the American military presence here.

headline: Boys and Girls High Wins First P.S.A.L. Title Since 1979
text: Among the rosary beads, folded hands and fiery flames tattooed into Boys and Girls High School guard Mike Taylor’s skin are the words “Lights Out” on his left shoulder. On Saturday afternoon at Madison Square Garden, Taylor said they served as a reminder for him and his team in the Public School Athletic League championship game against Cardozo High.

headline: Sex Offender Allowed to Live Near School
text: A convicted sex offender has moved into a home across the street from Wildwood Elementary School in Piedmont, infuriating parents, who are asking school officials and the police why the 2006 state law mandating a minimum distance of 2,000 feet between schools and the residences of sex offenders is not being enforced.

headline: The Knicks Make the Nets Look Like a .500 Team
text: Every once in a while, the basketball gods show scheduling mercy. The clouds on otherwise dreadful seasons parted a fourth and final time this season for the Knicks and the Nets when they met Saturday night, guaranteeing one team a victory.

headline: WABC Returns to Cablevision
text: 8:49 p.m. | Updated The Walt Disney Company and Cablevision announced they had agreed in principle to a new contract governing WABC about 15 minutes after the Academy Awards telecast started on Sunday night.

headline: Iraq Elections: Courting African Iraqis
text: BASRA, Iraq– During the past few weeks, most of the country’s major political candidates or their aides have come to Zubair, a poor, mainly-Sunni neighborhood on the outskirts of this oil-rich Shiite city, to campaign to a population that is as disaffected as any in Iraq.

headline: A Sex Offender, a School and the Law That Cannot Keep Them Apart
text: Sunday’s Bay Area Report features an article about an East Bay community’s bewilderment as a convicted sex offender is allowed to move into a home across the street from an elementary school.

headline: No Deal on ABC Is Reached by Disney and Cablevision
text: The Walt Disney Company at 12:01 a.m. on Sunday pulled its ABC station from Cablevision — potentially leaving about three million cable customers in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut without access to the Academy Awards — after failing to reach an agreement with the cable provider on a new contract.

headline: Iraqi Elections – Change in Kurdistan?
text: SULAIMANIYA, Iraq – “Go, go to vote, for renewal and change” starts a song that has rallied voters, particularly the young, around the political movement trying to end the decades-long domination of the two parties in Iraq’s Kurdistan region in Sunday’s elections.

headline: Iona Knocked Out of MAAC Tournament
text: ALBANY — A season of progress for the Iona Gaels ended earlier than expected on Saturday night. Sixth-seeded Niagara knocked off third-seeded Iona, 68-64, sending the Gaels home early from the Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference tournament and leaving their postseason future uncertain.

headline: In Spring, Hong Kong Festivals Bloom
text: Hong Kong’s cultural calendar is dry as a desert most of the year. Then comes spring, and with it, a festival of festivals. Along with the Hong Kong Arts Festival, which continues through March 28, there are a handful of major events dedicated to film, literature and other media, all happening in the next month or so.

headline: Tigers in Peril
text: Could this Chinese Year of the Tiger be the last one with actual tigers still afoot in the world’s wild?

text: “I wear my heart on my sleeve. This is me.”— Jake Delhomme, choking back tears

headline: Joy Amid Destruction
text: Those with skills, strength and luck will be the ones to thrive after Haiti’s destruction, while small, handmade treasures will bring some measure of joy.

headline: Iceland Voters Reject Repayment Plan
text: Iceland’s voters expressed their outrage on Saturday against bankers, the government and what they saw as foreign bullying, overwhelmingly rejecting a plan to pay $5.3 billion to Britain and the Netherlands to reimburse customers of a failed Icelandic bank, Sarah Lyall reported in The New York Times.

headline: Hamilton Almost Quit Formula One
text: It was one of the many Formula One scandals last year, the first of the racing season. It was the Lewis Hamilton lying incident, when the reigning world champion told a story to the press about what happened on track at the Australian Grand Prix that differed from what he told the racing stewards during an inquiry afterward.

headline: Now Screening | Comme des Garçons
text: The fall 2010 collection from Comme des Garçons at Paris Fashion Week.

headline: Iraqis Vote in Spite of Attacks
text: In a pivotal test of Iraq's democracy, Iraqis went to the polls in large numbers despite a wave of bombings across the country.

headline: The Message From Planet Jim
text: Inside James Cameron’s head, there’s a place called Planet Jim (a description provided by one of his minions in the video clip below). It is a fundamentally extraterrestrial place in the purest sense of that word — ranging from the oceanic abyss to the depths of outer space. It is often depicted in shades of “James Cameron blue.” The largest audience in the history of entertainment has been there now, thanks to “Avatar.” His ability to captivate so many people has led him to the Academy Awards ceremony tonight with nine Oscar nominations.

headline: President Obama Congratulates Iraqis on Vote
text: In a statement released by the White House Sunday morning, President Obama praised Iraqis’ resolve as they defied a wave of bombings across the country and turned out to vote in parliamentary elections that are seen as a crucial test of Iraq’s democracy nearly seven years after the American-led ouster of Saddam Hussein.

headline: Photos of the Moment | Rainbow Connection
text: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.

headline: Visual Books
text: Images from the books under review in Steven Heller’s Visuals column.

headline: Photos of the Moment | Viktor & Rolf
text: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Kevin Tachman.

headline: Life for a Rule 5 Pick: Thanks for Coming, Now Leave Your Cap
text: TUCSON — Zach Kroenke’s career appears to have followed a fairly steady course. Drafted by the Yankees in 2005, he pitched at each level of their farm system, from the Gulf Coast League to Class AAA, earning regular promotions. A left-handed reliever, he is 25-15 with a 3.30 earned run average in five seasons.

headline: Clashes Kill Dozens in Central Nigeria
text: DAKAR, Senegal — Dozens of villagers in central Nigeria were killed early Sunday, victims of apparent reprisal attacks over recent clashes between Christians and Muslims. A government spokesman said there were more than 300 dead, but that figure that could not be independently verified.

headline: Now Screening | Viktor & Rolf
text: The fall 2010 collection from Viktor & Rolf at Paris Fashion Week.

headline: Rookies on the Awards Circuit Slog
text: LOS ANGELES— Confession: In her civilian life, the Bagger goes out approximately seven nights a week, but four months of non-stop Carpetbagging, in heels, has taken its toll, and we crashed a bit on Saturday, a rare rainy day in Los Angeles. A nap was in order, which meant we missed things like a tea for Mo’Nique, attended by Oprah and Alfre Woodard, where everyone wore pearls and white gloves. (O.K., so we weren’t invited anyway.)

headline: Crossover Nightmares
text: The Russian baritone Dmitri Hvorostovsky is one of the most vocally gifted, sophisticated and charismatic singers around. He’s a favorite at the Metropolitan Opera and has an international following as a superb classical artist. So, I never imagined that one day I would be forced to use foam rubber noise-reduction ear plugs to listen to him.

headline: And the Razzie Goes to…
text: Sandra Bullock may not beat out Meryl Streep Sunday night for a best actress Oscar, but she’s already racked up one victory this weekend. On Saturday, Ms. Bullock accepted in person the dubious honor of worst actress at the Razzie Awards for her role in the comedy “All About Steve.”

headline: The Singer-Songwriter Known as Sparklehorse Is Dead at 47
text: Mark Linkous, a singer-songwriter whose music, released under the name Sparklehorse, was renowned in the indie-rock and alt-country worlds for its dark, allusive themes and fragile beauty, committed suicide on Saturday in Knoxville, Tenn. He was 47.

headline: Consumer Groups Urge Regulation of Nonbank Finance
text: While much of the Congressional debate over consumer financial protection has focused on banks, lawmakers have been grappling behind the scenes over whether and how to regulate payday lenders, debt collectors, check-cashing outlets, title and installment lenders and even pawnbrokers, The New York Times’s Sewell Chan reports.

headline: Viewing the Iraqi Elections Across the Middle East
text: Were Arab leaders and voters disappointed, angered, or inspired by what appears to have been a successful vote in Iraq? The answer appears to be none of the above. While newspapers from the Arab world made mention of the elections, many led their Web sites with news of the weekend’s fighting in Jerusalem.

headline: A Tame Night for the ‘In the Loop’ Gang
text: LOS ANGELES— There’s not much that can be reprinted from our dinner with the cast and writers of “In the Loop,” mainly because we were laughing too much to write stuff down. A British satire about a certain war in the Middle East, nominated for a screenplay Oscar, “In the Loop” is known for its bawdiness. The dinner, on Saturday night, was more tame – just a few jokes about Hitler as a motivational speaker and Jeff Bridges’s mustache being the best part of “Crazy Heart” – you know, the usual. And Armando Iannucci, a screenwriter and the director, did note that when Miramax executives wanted to buy “In the Loop” after its Sundance premiere last year on the condition that the filmmakers re-edit it, he told them to go expletive themselves.

headline: Qaeda Operative Arrested in Pakistan
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — An operative of Al Qaeda believed to be an American was arrested in the sprawling southern city of Karachi in recent days by Pakistani security officials, Pakistani officials said Sunday.

headline: New York Isn’t Silicon Valley. That’s Why They Like It.
text: The two dozen or so people arranged around wooden tables, warming their hands and bellies with steaming mugs of coffee and plates of homemade biscuits, looked like just another Sunday brunch set in New York.

headline: Rural Pride and Poverty and a Hen’s Empty Nest
text: Ron Rash was the seasoned author of nine books of fiction and poetry before his 10th, the stunning 2008 “Serena,” established him as one of the best American novelists of his day. With its stark Appalachian setting, piercing language and coolly ferocious title character, “Serena” was a big book filled with bleakly beautiful details. Mr. Rash’s artistry was blinding enough to eclipse his craftsmanship.

headline: ‘Alice’ Grabs Imax Screens From ‘Avatar’
text: LOS ANGELES  The hunger for 3-D pictures, a blockbuster publicity campaign and curiosity about another madcap performance from Johnny Depp pushed “Alice in Wonderland” to a stratospheric No. 1 at the weekend box office.

headline: Two Men Who Adore Her, One Woman in the Middle
text: Melissa Errico’s formidable beauty is probably the most persuasive element in the Irish Repertory Theater’s revival of George Bernard Shaw’s breakthrough comedy “Candida.” It does not require the suspension of any disbelief whatsoever to imagine that Ms. Errico’s naturally Victorian gorgeousness  pure white skin, rosebud lips, luxurious tresses, nipped waist and shapely curves  would inspire adoration in men of any number of ages and philosophies. Unfortunately little else in this alternately sluggish and overwrought revival is equally convincing.

headline: Waiting and Watching, With Dance Ticket in Hand
text: Jon Jaques is a senior on the Cornell basketball team, which wrapped up the Ivy League title and a berth in the N.C.A.A. tournament on Saturday. As he did last season, Jon has been blogging for The Quad throughout this season. You can also follow him on Twitter.

headline: Of Youth, Frocks and Politics: A Not-So-Ordinary Life
text: Next stop Dumbo, for those of you participating in the city’s unofficial spring festival of gay theater.

headline: Madonna Plays the Muse
text: LOS ANGELES— “Collaboration. I like being his muse,” Madonna told us, explaining her relationship with photographer Tom Munro at a private party and opening last night, to celebrate the photographer’s first book, a collection of celebrity portraits. (Partial proceeds of of the book will go to Madonna’s charity, Raising Malawi, and M.E.A.K.) Madonna, wearing black fishnet stockings, leather skirt and dark sunglasses at 10 p.m. in a dark room, blew off the Weinstein Company party at Soho House and the Summit Entertainment reception for “The Hurt Locker” at the Mondrian, for the gallery opening, where she spent most of the time on the lap of Steven Klein, another celebrity fashion photographer.

headline: Supply, Demand, and Unemployment
text: I hear through the grapevine that the usual suspects at the WSJ have put out something along the lines of “Krugman says that unemployment benefits won’t raise unemployment, but in his textbook he says they will, neener neener.” Are they really that stupid? Probably not — but they you think that you, the reader, are that stupid.

text: Rebecca Wilder is right:

text: Jonathan Chait on Mike Allen:

headline: Finding Your Roots
text: For more than 2,500 years, mathematicians have been obsessed with solving for x.  The story of their struggle to find the “roots” — the solutions — of increasingly complicated equations is one of the great epics in the history of human thought.

headline: Praise of Mary at Eventide Resounds Across 400 Years
text: Normally, classical music groups try to avoid duplicating competitors’ programming, but this year early-music groups are lining up to celebrate the 400th anniversary of Monteverdi’s Vespro Della Beata Vergine (Vespers of the Blessed Virgin). The high-energy performance by Boston Baroque at the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine on Saturday evening was the third in New York since January, with more in the offing.

headline: Sharing the Ball, at Any Speed
text: RICHMOND, Va. — When Richmond Coach Chris Mooney was on a recruiting visit to Princeton as a high school senior in 1989, he watched a group of Tigers basketball players in an intense four-on-four game.

headline: New CDs
text: BROKEN BELLS

headline: Violins Face Off Against Laptops in a Friendly Improvisational Duel
text: Drone chords are accommodating and diplomatic. They’re the secret handshake between Westerners and Easterners, soft-eyed hippies and aggro noise merchants, improvisers and composers. They’re also totems, full of their own significance. And bullies.

headline: Celebrating the Genius of Balanchine by Viewing It With Fresh Eyes
text: WASHINGTON  The dancing of the Suzanne Farrell Ballet in works by George Balanchine (and, occasionally, other choreographers) is not spectacular. It performs at the Kennedy Center (to which it is attached) for one week each season and then does a little touring; it is a pick-up group to which some dancers return each year like swallows; its roster includes no luminaries of major caliber. If you go to this company expecting the iridescence that Ms. Farrell had as a supreme interpreter, you leave disappointed.

headline: Celebrities at the Gate, Weinstein Company Edition
text: LOS ANGELES— “You know, I’m one of the few people who really, genuinely likes Harvey Weinstein,” Christoph Waltz, the smoothly villainous Nazi in “Inglourious Basterds,” said at the Weinstein Company party at the Soho House on Saturday night, just as Mr. Weinstein was passing within earshot.

headline: Winner Understood Opponent’s Psychology
text: Most members of the American Contract Bridge League’s Hall of Fame are marquis names. A few are lower-profile experts well respected by their peers.

headline: A Human Landscape of Rippling Bodies and Meditative Minds
text: Shelley Senter returned to New York last year after a 13-year stretch in California, making her the perfect choreographer to open “Back to New York City,” the latest incarnation of Platform 2010, Danspace Project’s guest-artist-organized series.

headline: A Bit Wry and Rough at the Edges
text: Barefoot, his shirt untucked, a hat pulled down over his forehead, the 43-year-old alt-country singer-songwriter Todd Snider looked the epitome of a scruffy modern troubadour ambling along a rutted Southern highway on the way to nowhere.

headline: Slaying the Dragon Called Subtlety With Large-Scale Heroics
text: Even the ballads went boom when Muse performed at Madison Square Garden on Friday night. Muse, a three-man English band formed in the early 1990s, never misses a chance for melodrama.

headline: 14 Down: ‘Law & Order’ Rapper
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — I’ve invited Louis Lana, the division C* champion at the recent American Crossword Puzzle Tournament, to solve today’s puzzle, record his time and share a few thoughts. You’ll find his report at the end of this post. Joon Pahk and Dan Feyer, the division B and A champions respectively, will do likewise with the Tuesday and Wednesday puzzles.

headline: Harrah’s Strikes Deal to Push Back Debt Payments
text: 11:59 a.m. | Updated Harrah’s Entertainment, the highly leveraged casino operator owned by the private equity firms Apollo Global Management and TPG, has reached a deal with its lenders to push back big payments on its debt load until 2015, Bloomberg News reported on Sunday.

headline: Voting Under Fire in Baghdad
text: Sorting out the results of the election may take time, but voters and politicians took the ballot itself as a victory.

headline: Stevie Wonder Honored in France
text: Almost 30 years after he was first named to receive the Commander of Arts and Letters award, Stevie Wonder, above, accepted it from the French Culture Minister Frédéric Mitterrand on Saturday, Agence France-Presse reported. Mr. Wonder was first named a Commander in 1981, but his formal decoration had been delayed because of scheduling conflicts. Mr. Wonder dedicated the award, one of France’s highest cultural honors, to his mother, who died in 2006; he said he first came to Paris in 1964 with her. Mr. Wonder was also in Paris to receive a lifetime achievement prize at a musical awards show on Saturday. Mr. Mitterand praised Mr. Wonder as “music’s familiar genius,” Agence-France Presse reported, and Mr. Mitterrand added, “as citizen, administrator and culture minister I just called to say we love you.”

headline: Renewed: ’30 Rock,’ ‘Office’ and ‘Community’
text: NBC’s Thursday night sitcoms will all be back for the 2010-11 television season that starts next fall. The network announced Friday evening that it had ordered new seasons of “The Office,” “30 Rock” and “Community.” Its fourth Thursday sitcom, “Parks and Recreation,” had already received a renewal order. “The Office” and “30 Rock,” with Tina Fey, above, have turned into hits for NBC, but the renewal was less certain for “Community,” the freshman sitcom about a community college starring Joel McHale and Chevy Chase. Dan Harmon, an executive producer of the series, filmed himself telling his cast that the series had been renewed, but only after pretending to deliver news about its demise. “I’m not good at, like, bad news,” he intoned, “but”  dramatic pause  “all of you have to work with Chevy again for another season.”

headline: Bullock Wins Worst Actress Razzie
text: Even before the Oscars began, Sandra Bullock racked up one victory. On Saturday she accepted in person the dubious honor of worst actress at the Razzie Awards for her role in the comedy “All About Steve.” “I think this is an extraordinary award,” Ms. Bullock said at the Barnsdall Gallery Theater in Hollywood, The Associated Press reported. “And I didn’t realize that, in Hollywood, all you had to do was say you’d show up, and then you’d get the award. If I’d known that, I would have said I was appearing at the Oscars a long time ago.” Other winners  or losers  included “Transformers: Revenge of the Fallen,” which took home the worst picture award; worst actor went to all three Jonas brothers for “Jonas Brothers: The 3-D Concert Experience.”

headline: This Summer at Williamstown
text: The Williamstown Theater Festival in Massachusetts has announced its 2010 summer season. This season, the festival’s 56th, will be the final one for Nicholas Martin as artistic director. He will direct Thornton Wilder’s “Our Town” on the main stage (July 28 through Aug. 8), with a high-profile cast including Becky Ann Baker, Dylan Baker, Jessica Hecht and Campbell Scott as the townsfolk. The festival begins June 30 with a main-stage production of “A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum,” directed by Jessica Stone, with the Tony-nominated actor Christopher Fitzgerald. Beginning June 23 Judy Gold will perform her new one-woman play, “It’s Jewdy’s Show,” on the Nikos Stage, a follow-up to her “25 Questions for a Jewish Mother.” Also in the lineup, Amy Herzog’s “After the Revolution,” a new play about three generations of a radical leftist family, which was developed from the festival’s fellowship project last summer, and “Samuel J. and K.,” by Mat Smart, also to be presented on the Nikos Stage.

headline: ‘Precious’ Dominates Spirit Awards
text: “Precious: Based on the Novel ‘Push’ by Sapphire” and “Crazy Heart” were the big winners at Film Independent’s Spirit Awards on Friday. “Precious” took best feature, best director (Lee Daniels) , best first screenplay (Geoffrey Fletcher), best actress (Gabourey Sidibe) and best supporting actress (Muh-nique, as the presenter, Pierce Brosnan, called Mo’Nique). “Crazy Heart” won best first feature and best actor for Jeff Bridges, who did double duty by performing a song from it. “An Education” won best foreign film. “(500) Days of Summer,” which was shut out of the Oscar race, won best screenplay. Woody Harrelson won best supporting male for “The Messenger” and the Coen brothers were given the Robert Altman award, though they didn’t show to pick it up. Roger Ebert, who with his wife, Chaz, sponsored a prize for young filmmakers, got a standing ovation; his clip reel of witheringly negative reviews was one of the funniest parts of the evening. The Indie Spirits, in their 25th year, are known as the looser precursor to the Oscars, but they seem to have grown more staid as they have gained in stature. This year instead of being held in a tent by the beach in Santa Monica, the event was glammed up and held in ... a tent above a car park, as the host, Eddie Izzard said.

headline: WNET.org Cancels ‘Worldfocus’
text: WNET.org, the New York public broadcaster, is canceling “Worldfocus,” its weeknight newscast seen on public television stations, effective April 2. It will have been on the air for 18 months. The show won several awards for its international news coverage but began without all its financing in place and never attracted enough corporate and foundation support to be sustainable. Neal Shapiro, the president and chief executive of WNET.org, acknowledged a shortfall of “a few million dollars” in a statement Friday announcing that “Worldfocus” was being shut down, adding, “We had the misfortune of launching a brand new program into the teeth of the recession.” “Worldfocus” was anchored first by Martin Savidge and now by Daljit Dhaliwal. It was an important project for Mr. Shapiro, who was criticized by some internal critics who said he had diverted resources to support it, leading to extensive layoffs elsewhere at WNET. Mr. Shapiro denied any link. WNET.org said that some “Worldfocus” resources would go to the WNET-produced “Need to Know,” a new program that joins PBS’s Friday night public-affairs lineup in May.

headline: The Oddball Shapes of Ken Price
text: A look at the artist’s ceramics and sculptures.

headline: The National Enquirer Earns Some Respect
text: The call came into The National Enquirer’s Los Angeles tip line — the kind advertised in the supermarket tabloid with the promise “We’ll Pay Big for Your Celebrity Gossip” — in late September 2007. The message was that a woman named Rielle Hunter had been hinting at an affair with John Edwards, then a candidate for president.

headline: Ask a Theater Historian
text: We are no longer taking questions for this feature.

headline: Oscar Parties and the Pentagon Papers Man
text: Daniel Ellsberg, the subject of the Oscar-nominated film “Daniel Ellsberg: The Most Dangerous Man in America” and a newbie at the Oscars, has been trying to get a hang of the Oscar party circuit since he arrived in Los Angeles on Tuesday. He told us by e-mail that he’s having a blast. But he was having some trouble getting into any parties.

headline: A.I.G. to Sell a Major Life Insurance Unit to MetLife

headline: Live Blogging the Oscars
text: The Carpetbagger is at the 82nd annual Academy Awards in Hollywood Sunday evening and will be filing updates all evening. Check back here regularly for dispatches from the red carpet, announcements of the winners and commentary from special guest stars, including A.O. Scott, the co-chief film critic of The New York Times.

headline: Educated and Fearing the Future in China
text: As China’s economy recovers, employers are competing to hire  low-skilled workers, but many of China’s best and brightest, its college graduates, are facing a long stretch of unemployment.

headline: Adjusting to Reality
text: THE danger of having the government regularly disperse hundreds of billions of dollars is that we can grow careless about how we spend a mere $14 billion. A case in point is a plan to pay out checks to everyone receiving Social Security, Supplemental Security Income and disabled veteran benefits. The reason? To compensate them for not receiving a cost-of-living adjustment this year.

headline: Breaking the Story That Isn’t
text: Reporters have always kept an eye on other reporters. For a journalist, the only thing more interesting than what you are working on is what your competitor is working on.

headline: No Leeway Given in Picking Dalai Lama
text: BEIJING — The new governor of Tibet said Sunday that the Dalai Lama did not have a right to choose his successor however he wanted, but instead must abide by the “requirements” of Tibetan Buddhist tradition, Xinhua, the state news agency, reported.

headline: China Blames U.S. for Strained Relations
text: BEIJING — The blame for friction in Chinese-United States relations “does not lie with China,” and it is up to the United States to take steps to repair the frayed ties, China’s foreign minister repeated Sunday.

headline: Afghanistan’s President Receives a Mixed Reception in a Visit to Newly Won Marja
text: MARJA, Afghanistan — Once a Taliban refuge, Marja has come a long way since the Marines invaded four weeks ago, so much so that the Afghan president, Hamid Karzai, arrived Sunday with top American and Afghan officials to speak to several hundred residents crammed inside a mosque.

headline: G.I.’s, New to Iraq, Hear the Election Explosions
text: BAGHDAD — “You’re hearing a lot of booms out there,” Lt. Ryan P. Alexander told his soldiers, briefing them ahead of their platoon’s anticipated operation as mortar fire and explosions rained on Baghdad early on Sunday while Iraqis began voting in the parliamentary elections.

headline: Most in Chile’s Capital Unhappy With Quake Response
text: SANTIAGO, Chile — Most Chileans here in the capital are not satisfied with their government’s response to the devastating earthquake last month, saying the government of departing President Michelle Bachelet was late and inefficient in delivering aid and in re-establishing order, according to a poll published Sunday by a leading Chilean newspaper.

headline: Rapid Rise of Children With Cellphones
text: The proportion of children with cellphones has nearly doubled since 2005, an increase driven in large part by boys, according to Mediamark Research and Intelligence, a market research company.

text: OAKLAND, Calif. — Tim Westergren recently sat in a Las Vegas penthouse suite, a glass of red wine in one hand and a truffle-infused Kobe beef burger in the other, courtesy of the investment bankers who were throwing a party to court him.

text: QUIMPER, France — HB-Henriot is one of the oldest companies in France, an artisanal producer of faïence — hand-painted glazed earthenware — since 1690. The company was founded here in Brittany for its waterpower and riverbed clay.

text: WASHINGTON — Seeking to exploit the Internet’s potential for prying open closed societies, the Obama administration will permit technology companies to export online services like instant messaging, chat and photo sharing to Iran, Cuba and Sudan, a senior administration official said Sunday.

headline: Bloomberg Says a Soda Tax ‘Makes Sense’
text: As the battle over the state budget and the looming multibillion-dollar gap becomes more intense, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has stepped up his call for the Legislature to pass a penny-per-ounce tax on soda to stave off major service cuts to education and health care.

headline: Ian Kennedy Looks Back
text: TUCSON – Ian Kennedy’s last start in the major leagues was on Aug. 8, 2008. It was a night that colored many fans’ perception of him. He gave up five runs in two innings of a 10-5 loss in Anaheim, Calif., and when he met with reporters afterward, he insisted he had made good pitches and was not upset.

headline: A.I.G. Sells Unit to MetLife
text: The American International Group agreed Sunday to sell a second major insurance unit, this one to MetLife for about $15.5 billion, the two companies confirmed Monday. It was the second deal the insurer has struck in one week, raising about $51 billion to repay its taxpayer-financed rescue.

headline: U.S. Reaches Out to Tokyo’s Real Power
text: TOKYO — Even as Japan’s new leaders have promised to transform the way the nation is governed, they have left one thing unchanged: the prime minister, like many before him, is backed by a shadowy leader who is widely seen as really running the country.

headline: All-Star Catcher Crouches, Waiting for the Offers to Roll In

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Thursday about President Obama’s efforts to get health-care legislation enacted misstated the television network on which Representative Bart Stupak, a Michigan Democrat, said in an interview that Mr. Obama had to be “more flexible” on tightening provisions on abortion in the bill. It was Fox Business Network, not Fox News.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Thursday about metal-on-metal hip replacements misidentified the Minnesota city that is home to the Mayo Clinic, where doctors say they have treated patients over the last year for problems related to metal debris from the devices. The clinic is in Rochester, not Minneapolis.

headline: ‘The Hurt Locker’ Wins Big at Oscars
text: LOS ANGELES  “The Hurt Locker,” a little-seen war film with big backing from the critics, pushed past “Avatar” and other crowd-pleasers to win the best picture Oscar at a Sunday night ceremony here, while its director, Kathryn Bigelow, became the first woman to win the directing award.

headline: Juggling Act for Obama in Filling Fed Board Openings
text: WASHINGTON — To fill three seats on the Federal Reserve’s board of governors, the Obama administration is balancing seemingly contrary needs.

headline: S.U.V. Hits 5, Killing One, in Church Parking Lot
text: A sport utility vehicle suddenly accelerated while backing up in a church parking lot in Brooklyn on Sunday afternoon, killing a woman and injuring four other people, including two children, the authorities said.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Thursday about plans by the Canadian filmmaker Barry Avrich to make a documentary about Harvey Weinstein, the co-founder of Miramax Films, referred incompletely to the distribution history of Mr. Avrich’s documentary about the entertainment kingpin Lew R. Wasserman, “The Last Mogul.” It was released in 2005 in four theaters in the United States by ThinkFilm and Kino, and two more in Canada by Alliance Films. It was not released solely by ThinkFilm in just two theaters in the United States.

headline: Corrections
text: Because of an editing error, a Spare Times entry on Friday about rehearsals of “Hamlet” at the World Financial Center omitted the name of the organization for which Debra Simon is artistic director. It is arts>World Financial Center.

headline: Corrections
text: Because of an editing error, an art review on Friday about the Armory Show, at Piers 92 and 94 in Manhattan, misstated the given name of the artist whose sculpture of a dog lifting its leg is displayed at the Hauser & Wirth booth. He is Richard Jackson, not Paul.

headline: Seton Hall’s Bobby Gonzalez Is a Divisive Figure in the Big East
text: SOUTH ORANGE, N.J. — In Bobby Gonzalez’s first season as Seton Hall’s men’s basketball coach, he likened his loyalty to his players to a scene from “A Bronx Tale,” in which a local crime boss galvanizes his neighborhood cohort to defend his bar from a motorcycle gang. After showing the bloody sequence on a television in the locker room before a game, Gonzalez smiled.

headline: Obscure Budget Proposal Threatens Senior Centers
text: The Bloomberg administration is scrambling to come up with contingency plans to close as many as one-fifth of the city’s 321 senior centers after being caught off guard by an obscure state budget proposal that would slash the centers’ financing by nearly 30 percent.

headline: Trial Is Elusive in an Assemblyman’s Drunken-Driving Case

headline: A Charlie Chan Film Stirs an Old Controversy
text: The revival of a 42-year-old documentary on the fictional Chinese detective Charlie Chan has reignited the controversy surrounding that character specifically and, more generally, the portrayal of Asian-Americans in Hollywood.

headline: For Juveniles in Family Court, Judges Seek Safer Alternatives to Prison
text: Standing to address Judge Daniel Turbow in Family Court in Brooklyn, a city prosecutor confidently listed the reasons why the 16-year-old boy in the courtroom should be sent upstate to a juvenile prison.

headline: Locked, Loaded, and Ready to Caffeinate
text: For years, being able to carry a concealed handgun has been a sacred right for many gun enthusiasts. In defending it, Charlton Heston, the actor and former president of the National Rifle Association, used to say that the flock is safer when the wolves cannot tell the difference between the lions and the lambs.

headline: College Acts to Disregard Fiscal Need in Admissions

headline: UConn Advances by Tying Record, and Shrugs
text: HARTFORD  The Connecticut women’s basketball team tied its N.C.A.A. record for consecutive victories Sunday by winning its 70th straight game. Not that Coach Geno Auriemma was, or is, counting. The surest way to stop such a streak, he said, is to start worrying about it.

headline: Program Will Pay Homeowners to Sell at a Loss

headline: For Web and Public TV, Brief Films That Dramatize Issues

But beginning on Monday, the organization will present a series of brief, fictional films that cast social issues into the future, in the hopes of drawing a younger audience not necessarily interested in public television.

headline: Deal to Save Everglades May Help Sugar Firm
text: When Gov. Charlie Crist announced Florida’s $1.75 billion plan to save the Everglades by buying out a major landowner, United States Sugar, he declared that the deal would be remembered as a public acquisition “as monumental as the creation of the nation’s first national park, Yellowstone.”

headline: Wartime Pope Has a Huge Fan: A Jewish Knight

He shares one car and a small house in a no-frills neighborhood with his wife, Meredith, and wryly describes himself as “an average schlemiel, just a Jewish kid from Queens.”

headline: Villegas’s Perfect Week Ends With 5-Stroke Win

headline: Major League Baseball to Stream ESPN Events

headline: Experimental Clocks Tell Straphangers if the Wait May Soon Be Over

headline: At the Last Minute, a Disney-Cablevision Truce

headline: Arkansas’s Senator in Middle, Hit on All Sides
text: HELENA, Ark. — When the subject of Senator Blanche Lincoln came up at a women’s luncheon last week at the historic Pillow-Thompson House in this Mississippi River town, there was an awkward pause in the chatter.

The memo, obtained by Politico.com, is exceptional for its candor about the crassness of the multibillion-dollar politicking industry.

headline: On the Importance of Being Counted
text: In mid-March, the Census Bureau will mail census forms to the nation’s 134 million households. With 10 questions, the form is one of the shortest in the history of the decennial count, dating back to 1790. But will people fill it out and mail it back? They should.

headline: Mass-Market Epiphany
text: Mysticism is dying, and taking true religion with it. Monasteries have dwindled. Contemplative orders have declined. Our religious leaders no longer preach the renunciation of the world; our culture scoffs at the idea. The closest most Americans come to real asceticism is giving up chocolate, cappuccinos, or (in my own not-quite-Francis-of-Assisi case) meat for lunch for Lent.

headline: An Irish Mirror
text: Everyone has a theory about the financial crisis. These theories range from the absurd to the plausible  from claims that liberal Democrats somehow forced banks to lend to the undeserving poor (even though Republicans controlled Congress) to the belief that exotic financial instruments fostered confusion and fraud. But what do we really know?

headline: Biologics Boondoggle
text: EVERYONE knows that an easy way to save money on medicines is to buy generics rather than brand-name drugs. Makers of generics estimate that over the past decade they have saved the American health care system about $734 billion. Yet, we continue to spend more on drugs  in part because of the increasing use of so-called biologic medicines, which cost, on average, 22 times as much as ordinary drugs. In 2008, 28 percent of sales from the pharmaceutical industry’s top 100 products came from biologics; by 2014, that share is expected to rise to 50 percent.

headline: Nothing Flashy, but Siena’s Rossiter Gets the Job Done

headline: Strangers in the Net, Exchanging Glances
text: ARE social networking sites bringing us together, or only fake bringing us together?

headline: Suicide Bomber Rams a Pakistan Building
text: LAHORE, Pakistan — A suicide bomber rammed an explosives-laden truck into the main gate of a safe house used for interrogation by the Pakistani military in the city of Lahore early Monday. The explosion killed at least seven people, including guards, the police said, and flattened the building.
