headline: Officials Step Up Enforcement of Rights Laws in Education
text: Seeking to step up enforcement of civil rights laws, the federal Department of Education says it will be sending letters in coming weeks to thousands of school districts and colleges, outlining their responsibilities on issues of fairness and equal opportunity.

headline: Philip Langridge, British Operatic Tenor, Dies at 70
text: Philip Langridge, an English tenor who was renowned for roles by Benjamin Britten and was an eloquent interpreter of Handel, Mozart, Schubert, Janacek and Stravinsky, died in England on Friday. He was 70 and lived near Guildford, southwest of London.

headline: Aaron Cohen, Official and Engineer With NASA, Dies at 79
text: Aaron Cohen, an engineer who worked on the spacecraft used in the Apollo moon program and who later, as director of the Johnson Space Center, helped NASA recover after the Challenger explosion, died Feb. 25 at his home in College Station, Tex. He was 79.

headline: Word of the Day | insularity
text: insularity •\ˈin(t)-su̇-lər, -syu̇-, ˈin-shə-lər\• noun

headline: Why Does JPMorgan Trade at Book Value?
text: JPMorgan Chase shares have been stuck trading around book value, or assets less liabilities, since last summer. Put in perspective, that’s not all bad.

headline: Mark Linkous, Leader of Sparklehorse Band, Dies at 47
text: Mark Linkous, a singer and songwriter whose music, released under the name Sparklehorse, was renowned in indie-rock and alt-country circles for its haunted, allusive themes and fragile beauty, committed suicide on Saturday in Knoxville, Tenn. He was 47.

headline: Supersizing the Show (Austerity Is So 2009)
text: The Academy Awards ceremony on Sunday night was one enormous Hollywood stimulus package. Not one host but two, 10 best picture nominations instead of five, two tributes to dead film luminaries and even an unexplained homage to the horror film, a genre that is very much alive. (Of course, the costly “Avatar,” with the biggest worldwide grosses of all time, was the ultimate public works project: W.P.A. in 3-D)

headline: Looking Ahead
text: IN WASHINGTON The prime minister of Greece, George Papandreou, below, will speak at the Brookings Institution about his country’s economic situation and other topics (Monday). Mr. Papandreou is also scheduled to meet with President Obama at the White House (Tuesday).

headline: How-To Hamlet
text: "If you happen to be walking through the World Financial Center in Lower Manhattan in the next several weeks," writes Steven McElory, "be aware that a sword fight may erupt near you." If so, do not panic; you are actually seeing actors from the New York Classical Theater production of "Hamlet," starring, in the title role, Justin Blanchard, who will be rehearsing at the 3.5-acre center through March 25. The company, which has held open rehearsals in Battery Park and Central Park for years, is hoping to lure viewers by giving them a sneak peak at the process of how theater gets done. "Throughout the season, the company will use an empty storefront at 1 New York Plaza as a production office and costume shop. Passers-by can wander into the office and observe costume fittings, take part in scheduled discussions with members of the creative staff and even  if they are so inclined  learn about more mundane aspects of putting on a show, like sending out mailers and doing paperwork."

headline: Grace Notes
text: Suzan-Lori Parks' new play "The Book of Grace" is about a young man returning to South Texas to confront his father. It will premiere at The Public Theater later this month. Get an early look at the show when the writer of "365 Plays/365 Days" and "Topdog/Underdog" appears tonight at the 92nd St. Y for a conversation.

headline: The Nose Knows
text: William Kentridge, writes Anthony Tommasini, "belongs at the Met." The South African artist directed the company's production of Shostakovich's early opera "The Nose," which opened on Friday, and his sets and videos that animate the staging "received the heartiest bravos." The choice of Mr. Kentridge is another example of how Peter Gelb, the company's general manager, has made it a priority to recruit directors from theater and film. "With Mr. Kentridge, whose work can now be seen in an extensive exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art, Mr. Gelb has brought in a major visual artist. Stop-action animation and theatrical design are central to Mr. Kentridge's work, and he has unleashed his imagination on Shostakovich's bitterly satirical and breathless opera." The music is intriguing, too: "you are not likely to hear a more insightful, ornery and, when appropriate, achingly poignant account of Shostakovich's still-shocking score than the performance the conductor Valery Gergiev drew from the Met orchestra and chorus and the large cast: some 30 artists, singing about 80 solo roles." Tonight a lecture about the production will be held at the Opera house beginning at 6.

headline: Gates and Afghan Leader Review Plan for a Kandahar Offensive
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates met here on Monday with President Hamid Karzai and Gen. Stanley A. McChrystal to review plans for a major American-led offensive in the city of Kandahar, the spiritual heart and birthplace of the Taliban, an operation General McChrystal indicated could get under way this summer.

headline: Disney-Cablevision Fight Is Far From the Last
text: The tentative agreement between The Walt Disney Company and Cablevision for WABC is just the latest in a string of recent feuds between media giants over transmission fees.

headline: Juggling Act to Fill Fed Board Openings
text: To fill three seats on the Federal Reserve‘s board of governors, the Obama administration is balancing seemingly contrary needs, Sewell Chan reports in The New York Times.

headline: Kraft Said to Face Inquiry Over Cadbury Plant
text: Kraft Foods is being investigated by British regulators on whether the company misled employees and investors in its battle to take over Cadbury, The Wall Street Journal said, citing people familiar with the matter.

headline: China Said to Plan Nullifying Loan Guarantees
text: China plans to nullify all guarantees local governments have provided for loans taken by their financing vehicles, a sign of increasing concern about the credit risks in such debt, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: News Quiz | March 8, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page.

headline: Readers’ Comments on the Academy Awards
text: As Hollywood gathered to celebrate its finest at the 82nd annual Academy Awards, NYTimes.com readers and Twitter users weighed in on the Cablevision-Disney dispute, the pacing and presentation of the ceremony and the triumph by Kathryn Bigelow, director of “The Hurt Locker.”

headline: Academy Award Winners
text: "The Hurt Locker," Jeff Bridges and Mo'Nique were among the winners at the 2010 Academy Awards.

headline: Pakistan Government Site Is Attacked
text: LAHORE, Pakistan — A suicide bomber rammed an explosives-laden truck into the main gate of a safe house used by one of Pakistan’s security agencies for the interrogation of suspects in Lahore early on Monday.

headline: In Deal on Everglades, a Dream Is Deferred
text: When Gov. Charlie Crist announced Florida’s $1.75 billion plan to save the Everglades by buying out a major landowner, United States Sugar, he declared that the deal would be remembered as a public acquisition “as monumental as the creation of the nation’s first national park, Yellowstone.”

headline: Art Off Guard
text: WHO have created a new art journal called Sw!pe Magazine: Guards’ Matter, along with an accompanying art exhibit? WHO is the artist who created the painting pictured above?

headline: Q. and A. With Manhattan Athletic Director Bob Byrnes
text: Seton Hall men’s basketball Coach Bobby Gonzalez, who has become a divisive figure in the Big East, took his first head-coaching job at Manhattan under Athletic Director Bob Byrnes. The two worked together for seven years before Gonzalez went to Seton Hall. Byrnes talked on Saturday night about the challenges of managing Gonzalez and how he was happy with his departure despite Manhattan’s on-court success during his tenure.

headline: After MetLife Deal, A.I.G.’s Next Step Is Unclear
text: As DealBook reported Sunday, the American International Group agreed to sell a second major insurance unit, this one to MetLife for about $15.5 billion. It was the second deal the insurer has struck in one week, raising about $51 billion to repay its taxpayer-financed rescue.

headline: When Is Looting Morally Okay?
text: “If crushed bodies were the enduring images of Haiti’s earthquake, the most memorable ones of Chile have been of looting,” writes Donald G. McNeil Jr. “When are desperate people entitled to help themselves? And to what?” Tell us what you think, below.

headline: Iraq Election Video: ‘Voting Day’
text: ELECTION DAY

headline: An Office? She’ll Pass on That
text: In The New York Times’s most recent Corner Office Q&A, Adam Bryant talks with Meridee A. Moore, founder of Watershed Asset Management, a $2 billion hedge fund based in San Francisco.

headline: Shell and PetroChina Bid $3 Billion for Coal Gas Firm
text: Arrow Energy of Australia said Monday that it had received a takeover offer worth about $3 billion from a company owned by Royal Dutch Shell and PetroChina, the state-run gas and oil giant.

headline: Indian Group Essar Said to Mull London I.P.O.
text: Essar Group, the Indian conglomerate, is working towards an $8 billion (£5.3 billion) listing of its oil and power businesses in London, The Sunday Telegraph reported.

headline: Global Hedge Fund Assets Now Total $1.89 Trillion
text: Global hedge fund assets rose 10 percent in the second half of 2009 to hit $1.89 trillion by the year’s end, Hedge Funds Review reported, citing a new survey from Hedge Fund Intelligence.

headline: Why Does JPMorgan Trade at Book Value?
text: Jamie Dimon needs an even better postcrisis, Breakingviews says. The chief executive of JPMorgan Chase runs one of the only major banks in the United States that did not post a quarterly loss during the crash.

headline: Farkas Said to Agree to Deal for Centerline Holding
text: Andrew Farkas, the American real estate investor, has agreed to a deal to buy Centerline Holding, a provider of financial and asset management services in real estate, by investing $100 million in equity in the company, The Wall Street Journal reported. Mr. Farkas will also assume $180 million of Centerline’s debt, the newspaper said.

headline: Posterous Receives $4.4 Million
text: Posterous, the blogging platform that would like to be to posting what Google is to search, has received $4.4 million in new financing, in a round led by Redpoint Ventures Trinity Ventures and a group of angel investors, PaidContent reported.

headline: Sure-Fire Crowd Pleaser: Reining in Wall Street
text: For President Obama and Congressional Democrats, public opinion this past year has mostly gone in the wrong direction — on his job performance, on health care and economic stimulus, on midterm elections.

headline: Quake Kills 51 in Eastern Turkey
text: ISTANBUL — At least 51 people died when an earthquake of 6.0 magnitude struck early Monday in eastern Turkey, officials in the region said.

headline: How Pandora Slipped Past the Junkyard
text: Tim Westergren recently sat in a Las Vegas penthouse suite, a glass of red wine in one hand and a truffle-infused Kobe beef burger in the other, courtesy of the investment bankers who were throwing a party to court him.

headline: Paris: Minimalism Talks
text: Yesterday was a pretty interesting and confusing day. First, there was the Céline show, where Phoebe Philo’s slim, terse coats with high necks and off-center buttons caught my attention. The designer means business; the clothes are sharp, graphic and intelligent — we like all those qualities and they seem particularly desirable now.

headline: On Assignment: A Perilous Route to Marja
text: A concrete corner of a demolished building juts from the earth out of what appears to be the middle of nowhere. (Slide 8.) In its sturdy solitude, perhaps — at another time or place — it could be a monument to a great war, a solemn reminder of destruction and loss. But on this day it provided cover from sniper fire. Or shade. Or both. This is Marja.

headline: Prudential Accelerates Hong Kong Listing
text: Prudential, the British insurer, said it had brought forward its planned listing on the Hong Kong stock exchange, and now aimed to complete the move before it offers its bumper $21 billion rights issue in May, Reuters reported.

headline: Got Comments?
text: This weekend, co-vocabularists have generously shared their beloved and beloathed slogans.

headline: HBOS Investment Portfolio Set to Sell, Report Says
text: The remains of  the investment portfolio of the British mortgage lender HBOS could be sold this week, and the private equity group Coller Capital believed to be in the best position to buy what is left, The Sunday Times reported.

headline: Bidders Said to Line Up for Anglo’s Zinc Assets
text: Anglo American, the global miner, said it had received “strong interest” in its zinc assets, but would not confirm that Vedanta Resources and HudBay Minerals were the front-runners to acquire them, Reuters reported.

headline: F.D.I.C. Said to Urge Pension Funds to Invest Banks
text: United States regulators are encouraging public pension funds that control more than $2 trillion to inject capital directly into the banking system by buying failed lenders, Bloomberg News reported, citing people briefed on the matter.

headline: Awareness Rises, but Women Still Lag in Pay
text: Companies in the United States, Spain, Canada and Finland lead the world in employing the largest numbers of women from entry level to senior management, according to a report published Monday by the World Economic Forum.

headline: A Dutch Novel Celebrated at 150
text: The opening lines of the satirical novel “Max Havelaar” are so well-known in Dutch that even a relatively new arrival to the Netherlands, with scant knowledge of the country’s literary tradition, can recite them by memory: “Ik ben makelaar in koffie, en woon op de Lauriergracht, no. 37.” Translation: “I am a coffee broker, and live at No. 37 Lauriergracht.” A simple declarative statement to open up one of the first works in any language to bring an exploitative colonial system under moral scrutiny; the novel has since become a cornerstone of the literary tradition of the Netherlands. Eduard Douwes Dekker, or Multatuli as he is known, finished writing the book 150 years ago. This year, a couple of events mark that anniversary.

headline: Don’t Bother Bill Polian With the Probabilities
text: At a sports analytics conference at M.I.T. on Saturday, Bill Polian, the Colts’ president, said he thought Bill Belichick made the right call on the infamous 4th-and-2 play in Indianapolis. But according to him, “All of the statistical analysis that’s done over the course of a season means nothing.”

headline: A Running of the Bulls in March?
text: Bulls may get more room to run this week on the anniversary of the March 2009 lows — if United States stock investors see more signs of stability after Friday’s rally on smaller-than-expected job losses, Reuters reported.

headline: Dubai Debt Deal Reported Due This Week
text: Dubai World, the troubled state-owned conglomerate, expects to put its debt plan to creditors as early as this week, but the final proposal is being delayed by efforts to accurately value the assets of Nakheel,  its real estate unit, Reuters reported, citing bankers.

headline: Citi Exec to Join Morgan Stanley, Report Says
text: Gary Shedlin, who was most recently chairman of Citigroup‘s investment banking effort for financial institutions, focusing on client relationships, is departing to join Morgan Stanley , Bloomberg News reported, citing a person with knowledge of the matter.

headline: Ford Adds Security and Other Features to Sync
text: The Internet is coming to cars – and so are security systems to keep viruses and hackers out.

headline: Q&A: Making Movies in Windows 7
text: Q.

headline: Bank of New York Mellon Snaps Up BHF Unit
text: Bank of New York Mellon may continue shopping around for more deals, even after it sewing up its second acquisition of the year.

headline: Schools’ Nonfiction Problem (True Story)
text: Today’s idea: Too much “Harry Potter” and “Twilight”? Educators say the young should read more nonfiction to soak up knowledge of the real world and truly master language.

headline: JPMorgan Tops List of Biggest Hedge Fund Managers
text: JPMorgan Chase is the king of the hedge fund castle, at least in terms of heft, according to a recent ranking by Pensions and Investments magazine.

headline: What’s at Stake in Conference Tournaments
text: Atlantic Coast (March 11-14, Greensboro, N.C.) Duke is the favorite to be the fourth No. 1 seed in the N.C.A.A. tournament. Maryland, Clemson, Florida State, Wake Forest and Virginia Tech should all be in, but Georgia Tech probably needs to win at least two games in the conference tournament.

headline: Santander Said to Lead Bids for RBOS Branches
text: Banco Santander of Spain is leading the bids to acquire 320 bank branches in Britain from the Royal Bank of Scotland, The Times reports, without citing sources.

headline: The World’s Best Countries for Women
text: In honor of International Women’s Day, an economist looks at ways to measure which countries do best by women, and why.

headline: Senate Tackles Jobs Package
text: Even the supposedly easy stuff is turning out to be hard for Congressional Democrats.

headline: CCMP to Acquire Infogroup, Report Says
text: CCMP Capital Advisors, a private equity firm, has agreed to acquire Infogroup,  a data and marketing company, for roughly $460 million, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing people familiar with the situation.

headline: Sampler: Funeral Fund to Settle, and Solar Panels for Alcatraz
text: The Origins and Evolution of the Moonbean Name | Jesse McKinley explores the history of a nickname for Jerry Brown, which was given to him in 1976 by Mike Royko, the syndicated Chicago columnist who later asked that people stop using it. With Mr. Brown announcing last week that he would seek to become California’s next governor, the “Governor Moonbean” sobriquet was resurrected by some as a description of someone who is unpredictable. Mr. Brown, who is the state’s attorney general, said the name, to him, symbolized other qualities, like being “creative and not hidebound to the status quo.” He added: “Moonbeam also stands for not being the insider, but standing apart and marching to my own drummer. And I’ve done that.” [The New York Times]

headline: Why Won’t People Share?
text: Wondering why the city’s cab-sharing experiment fizzled last week? A few Upper East Side residents offered a theory: location, location, location.

headline: Fact, Fiction and Kapuscinski
text: Last week, news of the publication in Poland of “Kapuscinski Non-Fiction,” a new biography of the legendary Polish foreign correspondent Ryszard Kapuscinski, sparked a series of reports in the English-language press that treated the book as an exposé that revealed the author of “The Emperor,” “The Soccer War,” and “Shah of Shahs” as a liar who passed off fiction as journalism.

headline: Toll From Religious and Ethnic Violence in Nigeria Rises to 500
text: DAKAR, Senegal — Officials and human rights groups in Nigeria sharply increased the count of the dead after a weekend of vicious ethnic violence, saying Monday that as many as 500 people — many of them women and children — may have been killed near the city of Jos, long a center of tensions between Christians and Muslims.

headline: Speed Read for Monday, March 8
text: Here are some highlights from Monday’s edition of The New York Times:

headline: Oscars: Red Carpet Fashion
text: Looks from the red carpet before the 82nd Academy Awards at the Kodak Theater in Los Angeles.

headline: Media Equation: What If Your Publication Becomes the Story?
text: In his Media Equation column, David Carr asks what happens when your own newspaper or magazine becomes the story. One recent example involved The New York Times, which was working on stories about New York Gov. David A. Paterson. The actual stories, when they ran, were nothing like the wave of rumors that preceded them. And that’s just one recent example.

headline: The Early Word: Iraq’s Election and Health Care
text: It’s back to the daily grind in Washington, but all eyes are turned toward early election returns in Iraq, although final results aren’t expected for days.

headline: Nissan Recalling 600,000 Trucks
text: Nissan is recalling about 598,000 trucks, according to the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

headline: The Wrong Marx
text: Incoming | Help yourself to some Marxist-Socialist humor by Jesse Eisenberg on McSweeneys.net:

headline: Cast of ‘Hair’ Sings Goodbye
text: When Sasha Allen began singing “Aquarius,” the opening number of “Hair: The American Tribal Love-Rock Musical,” on Sunday afternoon, it was hard to tell at first whether the teardrop was just a bit of sparkly makeup under her left eye. As she got deeper into the song and the cast joined in behind her, though, it was clear that it was a welling, uncontrollable tear. Followed by many others, it glistened down her cheek. Elsewhere chins quivered. When the song was done, Ms. Allen was wiping her eyes, the audience was on its feet for the first of several standing Os, and many in the young, exuberant cast were openly sobbing.

headline: Submit Your Funny Caption
text: Booming Suburb | Tell us what’s going on in the picture above (use the comment link below). It’s the latest of the uncaptioned images we’re posting each Monday. For your caption to be considered, follow the guidelines. The latest funniest captions are at right.

headline: Ford Adds Security and Other Features to Sync System
text: From our colleagues at Gadgetwise:

headline: Hesitation on Wall Street Leaves Shares Flat
text: Lacking a clear consensus about the strength of the recovery, Wall Street fell into a seesaw pattern on Monday.

headline: A ‘Jewish Kid From Queens’ Becomes a Vatican Ally
text: At home here on Long Island, he is Gary L. Krupp, medical equipment dealer, now retired after a career of ups and downs. He shares one car and a small house in a no-frills neighborhood with his wife, Meredith, and wryly describes himself as “an average schlemiel, just a Jewish kid from Queens.”

headline: Candidates Speculate on Results of Iraq Vote
text: BAGHDAD — Even before the votes were tallied, Iraq’s candidates and coalitions began positioning themselves in an evolving political landscape on Monday. Some claimed victory, and a few conceded defeat in an election on Sunday that the top American officials here called a milestone that kept the withdrawal of American troops on pace.

headline: U.S. Airports Expand Passenger Full-Body Screening
text: According to the Associated Press, the Transportation Security Administration announced nine more U.S. airports that will receive body-scanning technology: Fort Lauderdale, Fla.; San Jose, Calif.; Columbus, Ohio; San Diego; Charlotte, N.C.; Cincinnati; Los Angeles; Oakland, Calif.; and Kansas City.

headline: Strike Ban to Lift at Lufthansa
text: According to Bloomberg, Lufthansa pilots who walked out last month in a dispute over pay and job guarantees have said they will not strike when a court ban ends today, as long as talks continue. The German airline grounded hundreds of flights from Feb. 22 to 25 even as a labor court ordered pilots to end a planned four- day walkout after one day.

headline: Another View: The Best Way to Protect Borrowers
text: Patricia A. McCoy, a law professor at the University of Connecticut, makes the case for setting up an independent Consumer Financial Protection Agency.

headline: Shaved, From New York, It’s Zach Galifianakis
text: It was the most surprising cultural moment of the weekend. (Other than “The Hurt Locker” upsetting “Avatar” at the Academy Awards, of course.) The comedian Zach Galifianakis had spent the duration of his “Saturday Night Live” hosting gig with his familiarly furry beard in tow — only to appear for the final skit of the evening with only a mustache.

headline: The Minimalist March
text: A clean, linear silhouette was the story at Stella McCartney this morning. Minimalism must be catching, like the common cold. Ms. McCartney’s showopened with a sleek, notched, above-the-knee coat in taupe wool (shown with bare legs and beige patent sling-backs) and moved to graphic camel and black striped tops with slacks. There were some interesting color mixes — a structured vest/top in burnt orange wool over a salmon turtleneck with black stirrup pants — and some see-through panels here and there. Shifts were super short, possibly as short as a sexy Balmain dress, and that worked against the clean message.

headline: Ask About the Gowanus Canal
text: This week, Jack S. Nyman, the director of the Steven L. Newman Real Estate Institute at Baruch College, City University of New York, responded to readers’ questions about the development, economics and the future of the Gowanus area.

headline: Photos of the Moment | Life From Paris
text: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Greg Kadel.

headline: Unemployment Rising as Portugal Plans Cuts
text: Portugal said on Monday that the number of people making an initial request for an unemployment check rose to 22,323 in January from 12,346 in December, nearly doubling as the country prepared to impose an austerity program to tame its budget deficit.

headline: The Oscars’ ‘Kanye’ Moment Explained
text: It’s the incident that’s already being called the Kanye West moment of the 2010 Academy Awards: when “Music By Prudence” was named the winner of the award for best documentary short, Roger Ross Williams, a producer and the director of the film, took the stage and began giving his acceptance speech.

headline: The Limits of Rahmism
text: AS A DOZEN or so top White House officials gathered in Rahm Emanuel’s corner West Wing office one morning in early January, the president’s political director, Patrick Gaspard, reported on the latest poll numbers in Massachusetts. With less than two weeks until a special Senate election, the Republican candidate was gaining momentum — just nine percentage points behind the Democrat in a new Rasmussen survey. The Democrats were in danger of losing the seat held for nearly half a century by Senator Edward M. Kennedy.

headline: Scuba-do!
text: In the 1964 film “Goldfinger,” James Bond emerges from the sea and removes his scuba suit, only to reveal a party-perfect tuxedo underneath. This spring, Bond could simply wear his neoprene to the casino. Gucci translated the scuba look into leather vests and jackets, Dsquared showed neoprene life vests, and Italo Zucchelli at Calvin Klein transformed the utilitarian wet suit into modern outerwear.

headline: Monday Reading
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: How a Lawyer Can Help You Sell Your Business
text: In my guide to selling a business, I recommend that no one consider either buying or selling a business without seeking the advice of a certified public accountant and a lawyer. I recently had the opportunity to chat with Harry Styron, who has been practicing law for 20 years, about the ownership-transfer process.

headline: Biden Visits Mideast to Push Peace Talks
text: JERUSALEM — Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. began a five-day visit to the Middle East on Monday, part of a concerted American effort to restart Israeli-Palestinian peace talks and keep Israel focused on relying on sanctions against Iran’s nuclear program rather than on unilateral military action.

headline: Three Proven Steps to Advance the World’s Women, on International Women’s Day
text: Today is International Women’s Day, and in fact the 100th anniversary of International Women’s Day. It’s a date that is much better known abroad but is beginning to get more traction in the U.S. as well.

headline: No Free Lawyers for Most Swiss Animals
text: On Sunday, voters in Switzerland overwhelmingly rejected a proposal to appoint lawyers to represent abused animals in court in every region of the country. As The Lede explained last week, only Zurich currently employs a lawyer to speak for animals.

headline: Lending Scheme to Bring Solar to Cambodia’s Poor
text: With access to solar-powered energy products for Cambodia’s rural poor extremely limited, the solar energy company Kamworks and the Cambodia Mutual Savings and Credit Network are partnering to provide low-interest loans to customers hoping to outfit their homes with solar panels, while Kamworks will provide and install the equipment.

headline: Domingo Has Polyp Removed From Colon
text: Placido Domingo disclosed his medical problem on Monday: a “localized malignant polyp” in his colon. A spokeswoman said surgeons used laparoscopic surgery to remove the polyp and that Mr. Domingo was released from Mount Sinai Hospital on Sunday. He is expected to fully recover, said the spokeswoman, Nancy Seltzer. On Feb. 22, she said Mr. Domingo, 69, a busy tenor, conductor and opera company manager, would undergo “preventive surgery” after suffering sharp abdominal pain. At the time, she declined to provide details on the nature of his ailment, citing Mr. Domingo’s privacy. Doctors have required at least six weeks of rest, and Mr. Domingo hopes to return to the stage on April 16, depending on how fast he heals, in Verdi’s “Simon Boccanegra” at Teatro La Scala in Milan, the spokeswoman said Monday.

headline: Quote Unquote | Better Than Sex
text: – Gabourey Sidibe on the gorgeous Marchesa gown she wore to the Oscars. We can’t argue there.

headline: Boy in Bronx Dies in 2nd Hit-Run Accident in 23 Hours
text: For the second time in less than 24 hours, a person was killed by a hit-and-run driver in the city.

headline: Junta Says Election Law Is Complete in Myanmar
text: YANGON, Myanmar — Myanmar said Monday that a long-awaited election law was complete, paving the way for the country’s first elections in two decades, a major step toward what the junta bills as its route toward democratic rule.

headline: Brake Override in Action: Stomach-Churning, but Effective
text: On Thursday, I looked at the history and examined some technical elements behind an electronic brake override system, which has been in the news quite a bit lately since Toyota’s nightmare with sudden unintended acceleration. Soon after writing that post, I got a demonstration of an override system at work.

headline: Plagiarism Suit Against ‘Avatar’ Is Dismissed in China
text: Well, at least the weekend wasn’t a total loss for James Cameron. He didn’t go home on Sunday night with as many Academy Awards as expected for his hit film “Avatar,” and not all the Oscar winners from the film remembered to call him a visionary at the podium. But he won’t have to share his “Avatar” profits with a Chinese writer who said the movie plagiarized his work.

headline: Travel Deals: $10 JetBlue Flights from New York
text: In celebration of JetBlue’s 10th anniversary, the airline is offering $10 fares on all remaining seats between Kennedy Airport in New York and the airline’s first 10 destinations. Travel must be booked online by midnight tonight, Central Time, for travel tomorrow or Wednesday, March 9 or 10.

headline: Winter’s Greens
text: This time of year many of us scratch our heads when opening that box of delivered produce, wondering if there’s anything new to make with the greens inside.

headline: Children With Cellphones
text: The technology section of the Times reports that the proportion of children with cellphones has nearly doubled, from 11.9 percent in 2005 to 20 percent in 2009.

headline: Rejection of Technologies Won’t End Debate
text: World soccer’s governing body moved from consideration to decisiveness Saturday, abandoning experiments with technology and firmly ruling out the use of video review or goal-line sensors.

headline: For Paterson’s Aides, Business Almost as Usual
text: ALBANY—On Friday, Morgan Hook, one of Gov. David A. Paterson’s press aides, held a brief conference call at 1 p.m. with the dozens of public information officers scattered around state agencies and departments in Albany. Such calls are usually led by the governor’s communications director, Peter E. Kauffmann — who resigned on Thursday.

headline: Retired General Is Picked for T.S.A.
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama has chosen a retired Army intelligence officer, Maj. Gen. Robert A. Harding, to lead the Transportation Security Administration, a job officials call the most important unfilled position in the administration.

headline: Jailed for Taking Kids to Jury Duty
text: Carmela Khury was called for jury duty in a Michigan murder trial, and she was having a complicated morning. Her mother, who had been watching Khury’s 8-month-old son and 3-year-old daughter, needed emergency oral surgery, and then the backup baby sitter fell through after Khury’s husband had already left for work.

headline: White House Easter Egg Debut
text: GLENSIDE, Pa. — To everyone who has been waiting with bated breath for the unveiling of the design of this year’s White House Easter egg, your wait is over.

headline: Haitian Up
text: “Toughen up” – a phrase coined by medics in Haiti in the aftermath of the January 2010 earthquake.

headline: Featured Recipe: Spare Ribs With Olives, Lemon and Rosemary
text: Sometimes you snack on olives, and — if you’re adventurous — you might marinate them and pick at them more often. But when you start cooking with olives, you get an entirely different view of them. In this dish they play a lead role, adding their distinctive salty bitterness to the lovely combination of acidic lemon and piquant rosemary, all of which bring life to the rich but somewhat one-dimensional flavor of pork.

headline: Should Scientists Fight Heat or Stick to Data?

headline: A Kanye Moment at the Oscars
text: This would probably be what the producers consider an unintentional watercooler moment. In what probably put his film on the map more than winning the Oscar itself, the short documentary winner Roger Ross Williams got Kanye’d when accepting his award for “Music by Prudence.” As Mr. Williams, the director, was making his speech, Elinor Burkett, the producer, jumped onstage with him and began talking over him, shades of Kanye West interrupting Taylor Swift at the Video Music Awards last year. Salon has the back story: the two have been fighting for a year; there was a lawsuit about the creative control of the film that was settled out of court. Ms. Burkett, who lives in Zimbabwe, where the movie was shot, claims she gave Mr. Williams the idea for the project, a charge he disputes. In any case they didn’t talk in advance to determine who would be the one person to come onstage to accept the award. (The Academy allows only one person to speak.)

headline: Old Jokes Home: The Oscars Gags That Wouldn’t Die
text: There was something about the running repartee between Steve Martin and Alec Baldwin at Sunday’s Academy Awards show that had a certain timeless quality to it — which is to say, many of their jokes sounded as if they could have been written at any time and for any occasion since the invention of the talkie.

headline: Monday Puzzle: Fun on Display
text: Today we have some light fun based on the standard seven-segment number display used in digital LCD and LED clocks and calculators. The idea for this puzzle and some of the questions in it come from Dr. Kurt Eisemann, an emeritus mathematics professor from San Diego.

headline: Part 1: Answers on Historically Black Colleges and Universities
text: More than 100 American institutions are classified by the government as historically black colleges and universities through a formal program intended “to overcome the effects of discriminatory treatment and to strengthen and expand the capacity of historically black colleges and universities to provide quality education.”

headline: Plagiarism Suit Against ‘Avatar’ Is Dismissed in China
text: Well, at least the weekend wasn’t a total loss for James Cameron. He didn’t go home on Sunday night with as many Academy Awards as expected for his hit film “Avatar,” and not all the Oscar winners from the film remembered to call him a visionary at the podium. But he won’t have to share his “Avatar” profits with a Chinese writer who said the movie plagiarized his work.

headline: Voluntary End-of-Life Measures Banned at Catholic Hospitals
text: In the book I discussed last week, Zoe FitzGerald Carter’s “Imperfect Endings,” a woman growing increasingly incapacitated from Parkinson’s disease deliberately stops eating and drinking so she can die in her home with her children and grandchildren nearby. It’s a controversial decision, both within her own family and in the society at large, but it’s a legal one — and a personal one that doesn’t require any bureaucracy’s blessing.

headline: Hands-Off Approach Is Getting Perilous
text: Normally, it is not easy to draw parallels between Nascar and the N.H.L. Culturally, they are about as far apart as Lady Gaga and Bing Crosby. As sports, the only similarity is that sweat is involved. In both, however, significant factions have a hearty belief in frontier justice, that the inmates should not only have keys to the asylum but also plan the menu. Players should police their own game, or in the words of Nascar’s vice president for competition, “Boys, have at it.”

headline: Kurt Busch Survives Late Crashes to Win in Atlanta
text: The Kobalt Tools 500 at Atlanta Motor Speedway on Sunday might be better remembered for the ongoing feud between Carl Edwards and Brad Keslowski than the winner, Kurt Busch. According to The Associated Press, the feud can be traced to a race last year at Talladega, in which Keslowski won after colliding with Edwards. In Atlanta on Sunday, the two made contact twice. The first incident came early and sent Edwards to the garage. He emerged late in the race (and more than 150 laps down from the leaders). With three laps to go, he clipped Keslowski’s car at 190 miles and hour. Keslowski’s car launched into the air, flipped and crashed in front of the grandstands. Nascar ordered Edwards to stop his car. “That’s not cool,” Keselowski said afterward. “He could have killed someone in the grandstands.” Nascar will decide on Monday whether to discipline Edwards. (The Associated Press)

headline: Women Who Drink Gain Less Weight
text: Dieters are often advised to stop drinking alcohol to avoid the extra calories lurking in a glass of wine or a favorite cocktail. But new research suggests that women who regularly consume moderate amounts of alcohol are less likely to gain weight than nondrinkers and are at lower risk for obesity.

headline: Paris Fashion Week | Group Hug 2
text: Two days ago, Junya Watanabe held a military parade of long green coats and parkas, not unlike the ones seen at Dries Van Noten a few days before. Then, all of a sudden, as if possessed by some primordial, unspoken understanding, every fashion editor and her assistant’s assistant began wearing — you guessed it — olive green, military-inspired gear. Some have already sunk their manicured claws into pre-fall samples; others scoured their closets for long-forgotten fatigues; one editor drove to a vintage military store in Montparnasse immediately after the Watanabe show, and handed the second-hand loot to the driver, so that he could throw it into the washing machine to achieve that elusive degree of casual distress.

headline: This Brand Doesn’t Mind Being in the Soup
text: The world was treated to a terrific game when the United States and Canadian hockey teams played each other at the Winter Olympics. But Canadians and Americans can cooperate, too, as demonstrated by a campaign for a venerable brand.

headline: What We’re Reading…

headline: Houston, We Have Face-Lift
text: Here is a question I’ve been pondering for some time now: Is there any moral high road to be taken when it comes to plastic surgery? Does one get anypoints for not yielding to the unforgiving demands of our culture and its disdain for the stigmata of age by letting one’s DNA play itself out? Does it make one a better — a more profound — person? Would we love Catherine Deneuve more if she had consented to letting us see her age onscreen? Do we love her less for trading in her fragile beauty for a plumped-up, smoothed-out visage that tells us little about the content of her character? And what has happened to the whole category of aesthetics that once went by the name of ravaged beauty? Women like Simone Signoret and Melina Mercouri, who wore the wreckage of their former glory — their nasolabial folds, lined foreheads and slack jawlines — proudly. Then again, perhaps you are one of the lucky ones, someone destined to age with a complex grandeur, like Georgia O’Keeffe; how will you ever know if you run for the scalpel the minute you spot a crow’s-foot around your eyes or a marionette line above your lips?

headline: New Discovery Series Will Have a Seven-Channel Debut
text: To promote its sweeping new nature series “Life,” the Discovery Channel will share the first episode with six of its sister channels. A total of seven cable channels owned by Discovery Communications will simultaneously show the first episode of “Life” on Sunday, March 21, the company announced Monday.

In this lesson, students reflect on their talents, achievements and experience and create two résumé versions – traditional and technology-enhanced – to learn how best to showcase their talents and ambitions.

headline: Taking Flash in a Basketball Pass to Ohio State
text: COLUMBUS, Ohio — Samantha Prahalis, a long-haired linebacker, would rush on a slant, knocking runners off their feet and absorbing quarterbacks. At 60 pounds and 10 years old, she was slight but slippery, slaloming her way into the backfield for five or six tackles a game behind the line of scrimmage. To the prepubescent boys she played against, Prahalis was the predator; they were the prey. The defense that she headed was known as Monster 52.

headline: Vain Glorious | Salon Treatment
text: Sally Hershberger knows a thing or two about beach hair, having worked on countless photo shoots with Herb Ritts, Steven Meisel and Annie Leibovitz. “I can’t stand it when hair doesn’t have any movement to it,” says the celebrity stylist, who is also an avid water-skier. Of course, it helps to have an ocean breeze — not to mention one of Hershberger’s legendary $800 haircuts. But the next best thing, and a heck of a lot cheaper, might very well be her new line of Salon styling products. There’s Texture Blast, which Hershberger says gives “insane volume”; Smooth Fix, for that non-greasy red-carpet-worthy shine; Luxe Layers for blowouts; and Shape Up for — what else — body building. Erin Bogart, a colorist in Hershberger’s New York salon who specializes in “surfer hair” — strategically streaky with sun-kissed tips — digs the Mineral Spray for that saltwater treatment without the salt.

headline: Sneezes, Hiccups, Laughs and a Chamber Group
text: Suggesting that advances in technology have had an impact on classical music is stating what has long been obvious. As the piano was improved, Beethoven and Chopin produced works that tapped into its new possibilities. Novel implements afforded further expressive potential: Ravel’s saxophone, Strauss’s wind machine, Respighi’s phonograph and Varèse’s magnetic tape. The sampling keyboard, which can digitally reproduce any sound, was a revolution unto itself.

headline: Doctor Leads Quest for Safer Ways to Care for Patients
text: Dr. Peter J. Pronovost, 45, is medical director of the Quality and Safety Research Group at Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore, which means he leads that institution’s quest for safer ways to care for its patients. He also travels the country, advising hospitals on innovative safety measures. The Hudson Street Press has just released his book, “Safe Patients, Smart Hospitals: How One Doctor’s Checklist Can Help Us Change Health Care from the Inside Out,” written with Eric Vohr. An edited version of a two-hour conversation follows.

headline: How Little They Know the World

headline: A Little Black Box to Jog Failing Memory
text: PITTSBURGH — On a cold, wet afternoon not long ago, Aron Reznick sat in the lounge of a home for the elderly here, his silver hair neatly combed, his memory a fog. He could not remember Thanksgiving dinner with his family, though when he was given a hint — “turkey” — it came back to him, vaguely, like a shadow in the moonlight.

headline: Massa Says Health Care Stand Contributed to His Resignation

headline: Where Women Do Most of the Hard Work…
text: One of the puzzles of the developing world is that women frequently do some of the hardest physical labor. Hauling water, for example, is “women’s work” in culture after culture. And anybody who has tried to haul a couple of buckets of water four miles from the nearest well know how excruciatingly heavy water becomes after a few hundred yards.

headline: C.F.T.C. Settles Bank of Montreal Trading Case
text: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission said Monday that it had settled the charges against the supervisor of a Bank of Montreal natural gas trader who cost the bank around 680 million Canadian dollars (about $660 million United States) after the trader was accused of mismarking and misvaluing the bank’s natural gas trading book for years.

headline: Massa Exits, but Also Blames Health Care Stance
text: Representative Eric Massa, the Democrat from upstate New York who has said he will resign office effective this afternoon in the wake of an ethics inquiry, is also now claiming that his vote against health care legislation has contributed to his problems. He now asserts that Democrats wanted him out of office because he opposed their health care proposals.

headline: Going Global, Stateside
text: Training to communicate across cultures has long been part of the preparation for executives moving overseas to work. But now, the training is increasingly for employees who may never leave the country, yet will work closely with companies and people around the world.

headline: Violence Is Not Religiously Motivated, Nigerian Archbishop Says
text: Updated | 7:07 p.m. As my colleague Adam Nossiter reports, hundreds of Nigerians were killed this weekend in ethnic violence near the city of Jos, in central Nigeria’s Plateau State.

headline: To Keep Moving, Look Beyond the Physical
text: I have long known (though I’ve yet to give up trying) that it is almost impossible to motivate smokers to quit for good by regaling them with the health hazards of tobacco. And now I’ve been told by readers of last week’s column, “Even More Reasons to Get a Move On,” that repeated sermons on the health benefits of physical activity may get some folks started but are unlikely to keep them at it.

headline: David Foster Wallace Papers Are Bought
text: The private papers of the writer David Foster Wallace, above, who committed suicide at 46 in 2008, have been acquired by the Harry Ransom Center at the University of Texas, Austin. The archive contains drafts of books, stories, essays, poems, letters and research, including the handwritten notes for “Infinite Jest,” the novel that first gained him attention. There is also a copy of his dictionary, in which he circled words, and heavily annotated copies of books by Don DeLillo, Cormac McCarthy, John Updike and others. Mr. Wallace’s writing journal, which includes personal reflections, story ideas, names and plots, as well as articles on boredom, tax shelters and credit-card fraud are also included.

headline: Lupone to Appear With City Ballet
text: She’s done Broadway, now it’s on to the ballet. On Monday, New York City Ballet announced that Patti LuPone, below, will make her New York City Ballet debut in a new production of “The Seven Deadly Sins” as part of the company’s 2011 spring season. The Tony-nominated director and choreographer Lynne Taylor-Corbett, who has previously choreographed two works for the company, “Mercury” in 1992 and “Chiaroscuro” in 1994, will create the new production. “The Seven Deadly Sins,” a sung ballet in seven scenes, was composed by Kurt Weill to a German libretto by Bertolt Brecht in 1933 and was first performed in Paris and produced, directed and choreographed by George Balanchine. The ballet features a character portrayed by both a singer and dancer. Ms. LuPone will be the singer; a dancer has yet to be announced. The original production featured Lotte Lenya as the singer and Tilly Losch as the dancer. Balanchine revived the work in 1958 with Allegra Kent in the role of the dancer. The schedule of performances and the rest of the 2011 spring season will be announced later.

headline: Lyondell Says Its Plan Is Better Than Reliance Bid
text: LyondellBasell Industries says it rejected a takeover bid by Reliance Industries because it has a superior reorganization plan that would leave the chemical maker valued at about $15.2 billion, Bloomberg News reports.

headline: Against Oscars, Rival Networks See No Gold
text: CBS, NBC and Fox struggled in the ratings on Sunday opposite ABC’s coverage of the Academy Awards, which dwarfed all other shows with an audience of about 41 million, the biggest in five years. According to Nielsen’s estimates, CBS was runner-up on the night, earning its most viewers at 8 p.m. with a new episode of “The Amazing Race,” which drew 8.1 million. Fox ranked third with a lineup of mostly reruns, including two episodes of “The Simpsons” at 8 and 8:30 (4.8 million). NBC finished fourth with “Dateline” from 7 to 8:30 (5.8 million) followed by the 2003 movie “Bad Boys II,” which averaged 3 million viewers.

headline: The Bowery in Boston
text: Boston is about to get a bit of the Bowery. The Bowery Presents, the company that puts on concerts at the Bowery Ballroom, Terminal 5 and other spaces in New York, has signed a long-term deal with the Royale club in Boston to be the exclusive presenter of live music there. The Royale, which until recently was called the Roxy, is a 1,000-capacity space on Tremont Street with an open floor and a U-shaped balcony. Known to Boston clubgoers as a late-night dance haunt, the Royale will be outfitted for live music and have about 100 concerts a year, said Jim Glancy, a partner in the Bowery Presents. The Royale will be the company’s first space outside the New York region. (It also helps run the Wellmont Theater in Montclair, N.J.) The Bowery will open a small office in Boston to run the Royale shows and book events for larger spaces. “It’s a fantastic market,” Mr. Glancy said. “The type of music we book totally lends itself to Boston.” That music is mainly rock, but as at Webster Hall in New York the Royale will continue to put on its own dance events independent of the rock shows. (After renovations the Royale will have its official reopening on Saturday, a dance night.) The first announced concert booking for the Royale is the reunited Public Image Limited on May 4 and 5, but Mr. Glancy and another Bowery partner, John Moore, said they expected to book others in April.

headline: Plácido Domingo Is Released After Surgery
text: Plácido Domingo, left, disclosed his medical problem on Monday: a “localized malignant polyp” in his colon. Nancy Seltzer, a spokeswoman, said surgeons used laparoscopic surgery to remove the polyp and said Mr. Domingo was released from Mount Sinai Hospital in New York on Sunday. He is expected to recover fully, Ms. Seltzer said. Last month she said Mr. Domingo, 69, a busy tenor, conductor and opera company manager, would undergo “preventive surgery” after suffering sharp abdominal pain while in Tokyo. At the time she declined to provide details about his ailment, citing Mr. Domingo’s privacy. Doctors have required at least six weeks of rest, and Mr. Domingo hopes to return to the stage on April 16, depending on how fast he heals, in Verdi’s “Simon Boccanegra” at Teatro La Scala in Milan, Ms. Seltzer said Monday.

headline: Northrop and EADS to Drop Bid for Tanker
text: The Northrop Grumman Corporation said on Monday that it would not bid for a $40 billion contract to build aerial refueling planes for the Air Force, leaving its rival, Boeing, as the likely winner of one of the Pentagon’s largest contracts.

headline: ‘Avatar’ Plagiarism Suit Dismissed in China
text: James Cameron didn’t go home on Sunday night with as many Academy Awards as expected for his hit film “Avatar,” and not all the Oscar winners from the film remembered to call him a visionary at the podium. But he won’t have to share his “Avatar” profits with a Chinese writer who said the movie plagiarized his work. A court in Beijing has thrown out a lawsuit brought by the writer Zhou Shaomou, who said that the film closely resembled his novel “The Legend of the Blue Crow,” which he wrote in 1997 and published online in 1999, The Global Times of China reported. The author said his novel and “Avatar” shared 80 percent of their material, and was seeking 8 percent of the movie’s total revenue. A Chinese representative for 20th Century Fox, which released the film, told The Global Times that the story line for “Avatar” was first devised in 1995, two years before Mr. Zhou wrote his novel.

headline: Architectural Records Saved at Last Minute
text: The archives of the architectural firm that designed the World Trade Center have been rescued from shredding at the 11th hour. The firm, Yamasaki Associates, in Troy, Mich., was founded in the 1950s by the modernist architect Minoru Yamasaki, who in addition to the Twin Towers designed the Century Plaza Hotel in Los Angeles. Mr. Yamasaki died in 1986, and his office was closed in January. Ted Ayoub, one of the last employees of the firm, contacted the Society of Architectural Historians, which in turn contacted the State Historic Preservation Office in Michigan. Mark Harvey, Michigan’s state archivist, assembled a crew to drive a truck from Lansing to Troy, with one day’s notice, to save the archive from being shredded.

headline: Oedipus Has iPhone (and Rage)
text: Near the end of “Blind,” moments after the half-naked main character has had feverish sex with his mother, then choked her to death (per her wishes) after she crushed his eyeballs with her thumbs midcoitus, he crawls across the floor to the telephone, somehow dials, reaches a maid in his palace and, in bloody pain, asks, “Could you come up here, please?”

headline: The A-to-Z Cure
text: One thing I do when I can’t sleep is play alphabet games. I try to list various things from A to Z: countries, rock groups, prescription drugs, movies, books, celebrities whose first and last names begin with the same letter… you get the idea. I don’t mind repeating categories from one night to another. Diseases might seem to be an unlikely insomnia game category, but for some reason, it’s one of my favorites. I like to combine ailments that terrified me in childhood (lockjaw) with ones that I didn’t know about until I was an adult (Ebola). And there are certain ailments that are never, ever on the list. Ever.

headline: Culture Shock | A Taste of Japan Off the 405
text: I couldn’t fly to Japan for the weekend. But from LAX, it was only a 10-minute drive to Torrance, Calif., which might be the next best thing. Home to the American subsidiaries of both Honda and Toyota, Torrance has thousands of Japanese residents. And now it has a hotel — the Miyako Hybrid — designed specifically for Japanese business travelers. (The “hybrid” in the name is meant to suggest that, like a hybrid car, the hotel is energy efficient.) By staying there, I hoped to recapture some of the excitement I felt during my first trip to Japan, in 1989, when I didn’t want to sleep, lest I sacrifice a minute of exploring.

headline: LuPone to Appear With City Ballet
text: She’s done Broadway, now it’s on to the ballet. On Monday, New York City Ballet announced that Patti LuPone will make her New York City Ballet debut in a new production of “The Seven Deadly Sins” as part of the company’s 2011 spring season. The Tony-nominated director and choreographer Lynne Taylor-Corbett, who has previously choreographed two works for the company, “Mercury” in 1992 and “Chiaroscuro” in 1994, will create the new production. “The Seven Deadly Sins,” a sung ballet in seven scenes, was composed by Kurt Weill to a German libretto by Bertolt Brecht in 1933 and was first performed in Paris and produced, directed and choreographed by George Balanchine. The ballet features a character portrayed by both a singer and dancer. Ms. LuPone will play the singer; a dancer has yet to be announced. The original production featuring Lotte Lenya as the singer, and Tilly Losch as the dancer. Balanchine revived the work in 1958 with Allegra Kent in the role of the dancer. The schedule of performances and the rest of the 2011 spring season will be announced at a later date.

headline: Backstage Beauty | High-Brow Makeup
text: The eyebrow moved into view as a beauty focal point during the spring 2009 shows: models at Marni had theirs filled in with mauve powder and punctuated with a bold, brown line, while at Diesel Black Gold, brows were painted blue. Next came the bleached-brow craze of fall 2009, which, while not an office-appropriate look, probably generated a spike in the sales of Jolen Crème Bleach. This spring is clearly time to put down the tweezers, thanks to the likes of Alexander Wang, whose models sported thick brows scored with pencil. And looking ahead to fall 2010, the brow is bolder than ever, whether aggressive or playful.

headline: Her Thoroughly Modern Music Inspired by Gospel and Opera
text: The theater composer Jeanine Tesori is such an artful chameleon that an audience unfamiliar with her work would be hard pressed to connect her disparate musical styles to the same hand. What do the zippy ersatz-1920s show tunes of “Thoroughly Modern Millie” have in common with the pre-Motown and New Orleans-flavored proto-funk of “Caroline, or Change”? And how are these connected to the high-gloss style of her songs from “Shrek the Musical”? The short answer is that they’re not really.

headline: David Foster Wallace Papers Go to University of Texas
text: The private papers of the writer David Foster Wallace, who committed suicide at 46 in 2008, have been acquired by the Harry Ransom Center at the University of Texas, Austin. The archive contains drafts of books, stories, essays, poems, letters and research, including the handwritten notes for “Infinite Jest,” the novel that first gained him attention. There is also a copy of his dictionary, in which he circled words, and heavily annotated copies of books by Don DeLillo, Cormac McCarthy, John Updike and others. Mr. Wallace’s writing journal, which includes personal reflections, story ideas, names and plots, as well as articles on boredom, tax shelters and credit-card fraud are also included.  As part of the deal, Mr. Wallace’s publisher, Little, Brown and Company, is donating editorial files related to the author. Material for “The Pale King,” the novel that is being assembled posthumously by Mr. Wallace’s editor, will be sent to the center after the book’s scheduled publication in the spring of 2011.

headline: Bright Start for Maine

Nobody in Mr. Bovell’s time-skipping saga, sensitively directed by David Cromer (“Our Town”), is ever far from an umbrella, making this Lincoln Center Theater production entirely apposite for the city’s long, strange and soggy winter.

headline: The Maestro of Weekend Meal Delivery
text: Mark Goreczny, 23, respects his elders — all 17,713 of them. They are too frail or disabled to walk to the grocery store, too poor to order takeout, so Mr. Goreczny makes sure they get a free hot meal delivered to their door on weekends and holidays and during emergencies like blizzards, when the city government’s weekday meal delivery program shuts down. As the program officer for the nonprofit group Citymeals-on-Wheels, Mr. Goreczny is a kind of postmaster of chow, helping to coordinate a complex delivery system that pauses for neither snow, nor rain, nor his friends’ weekend plans.

headline: The Dark Side of Home Subsidies
text: Home ownership in the United States ranks up there with motherhood and apple pie. The government has championed it for decades through tax breaks, mortgage guarantees and, most recently, the herculean task of keeping Americans in their homes after the housing market collapse. But government subsidies of the American Dream also have a darker side: when things head south, taxpayers end up stuck with the costs.

headline: Experts Urge Keeping Two Options for Terror Trials
text: WASHINGTON — Leading Congressional Republicans are arguing that getting tough on terrorism means trying all foreign terrorism suspects before military commissions. But national security officials who served in the Bush administration say that taking away the criminal justice option would weaken the government’s hand.

headline: A Nonfrivolous Suit
text: Supporters of tort reform  and late-night comedians  like to make fun of what they say are frivolous lawsuits. One they particularly like to lampoon is the case of the woman who sued McDonald’s after she was scalded by too-hot coffee. What they don’t talk much about is just how hot the coffee was or that the 79-year-old woman was hospitalized with severe injuries. The two sides ultimately settled.

headline: Solar Industry Learns Lessons in Spanish Sun
text: PUERTOLLANO, Spain — Two years ago, this gritty mining city hosted a brief 21st-century gold rush. Long famous for coal, Puertollano discovered another energy source it had overlooked: the relentless, scorching sun.

headline: New Plan for Mall Operator to Exit Bankruptcy
text: The largest shareholder and the largest unsecured creditor in the mall operator General Growth Properties intend to enhance the company’s reorganization plan to emerge from bankruptcy as an independent company, the company confirmed Monday night.

headline: Texas Instruments Raises View on Profit
text: Texas Instruments, the chip maker, said on Monday that profit and sales in its current quarter would be at the high end of its forecasts, helped by increasing demand for phone systems and industrial machinery.

headline: Defending the Dolphins
text: When "The Cove" won the Oscar for best documentary on Sunday, the star of the film and dolphin activist Ric O'Barry held up a sign while the producer, Fisher Stevens, was giving his acceptance speech. It read "Text Dolphin to 44144," which automatically signs people up to receive information about the fight against the dolphin hunting practices in a Japanese village, on which the film is based. Tonight you can learn more about the issue at Asia Society where the documentary will be shown. A panel discussion will follow the screening with Louie Psihoyos and Mr. O'Barry, and moderated by New York Times reporter Andrew C. Revkin.

headline: Chaos of War
text: "With 'The Surrendered,' " writes Michiko Kakutani, "Chang-rae Lee has written the most ambitious and compelling novel of his already impressive career  a symphonic work that reprises the themes of identity, familial legacies and the imperatives of fate he has addressed in earlier works, but which he grapples with here on a broader, more intricate historical canvas." The backdrop is the chaos of the Korean War and Mr. Lee chronicles the "cruel, heartbreaking events of war with harrowing, cinematic immediacy, making palpable the excruciating violence and the huge footprint it leaves on people's lives." Tonight, the author will be at Barnes & Noble on Broadway and 66th Street.

headline: Breaking Through
text: " 'The Temperamentals,' Jon Marans's eminently likable docudrama about gay identity in the age of Eisenhower, begins with a classic vision of mid-20th-century uniformity: five guys in off-the-peg suits, as anonymous as the standard-issue, metal-frame chairs on which they're seated," writes Ben Brantley. "Discovering what lurks beneath gray flannel is both the theme and the story-propelling engine of 'The Temperamentals,' which chronicles the creation of the Mattachine Society, the breakthrough gay-rights organization. And in Mr. Marans's play the journey to such knowledge is hardly (you should pardon the expression) a straight line." The characters in the drama, currently at New World Stages, are based on real people and "lovingly incarnated by a cast led by Thomas Jay Ryan and Michael Urie."

headline: Shell Joins PetroChina in an Offer in Australia
text: Arrow Energy of Australia said Monday that it had received a takeover offer worth about $3 billion from a company owned by Royal Dutch Shell and PetroChina, the government-run gas and oil giant.

headline: Nascar’s Call for Aggressiveness Is Met by a Crash
text: In the midst of a ratings and attendance slump, Nascar went back to its bad-ol’-boy roots this season in the hope that more aggressive driving would draw fans back to the sport. The message to the drivers before the start of the season was a simple one.

headline: Throwing Exit-Row Seats Into the ‘For Sale’ Bin
text: CONSIDER the exit-row seat, that prize catch of the frequent-flying business traveler because it offers extra legroom.

headline: For Lil Wayne, Third Sentencing Date Yields a Year at Rikers
text: The rapper Lil Wayne made his final public appearance as a free man for at least the next eight months on Monday afternoon, greeted by a chaotic scene in front of a Manhattan courthouse.

headline: W.P.S. Optimistic After Its Off-Season Shuffling
text: Year 2 of the Women’s Professional Soccer league began with the opening of preseason training camps last weekend. The regular season opens  April 10.

headline: Holder of a Title, Yes, but Not a Heisman
text: I’M a former member of USA Boxing’s national team. I joined when I was 15 years old, and before that I never thought I’d go anywhere. By the time I was 21, I had visited 23 countries. All that travel changes a person for the better.

headline: In Chile’s Capital, Damage Is Inside and Invisible
text: SANTIAGO, Chile — From outside, there is no sign that the century-old building where Cecilia Painaqueo lived with her four children was damaged by one of the strongest earthquakes ever recorded. But inside her second-floor apartment, the bedroom walls collapsed and the wooden ceiling buckled.

headline: Fed’s Reach May Be Curbed Under Plan
text: Several high-ranking members of the Senate Banking Committee have reached a tentative consensus on a plan that would strip the Federal Reserve of regulatory powers over all but the very largest banks, those with more than $100 billion in assets, people briefed on the negotiations said on Monday night.

headline: Canadian Doctor Brings a Sudden Chill to Yankees’ Carefree Spring
text: Bradenton, Fla.

text: Offense

headline: Frank Williams, Architect of Skyscrapers, Dies at 73
text: Frank Williams, an architect whose sleek towers incorporating crisp geometric shapes in many of their facades made a significant mark on the New York skyline, died on Feb. 25 in Manhattan. He was 73.

headline: Oscar Winners Try to Keep Whale Off Sushi Plates
text: SANTA MONICA, Calif. — It is sport among black belt sushi eaters here to see just how daring one’s palate can be. But even among the squid-chomping, roe-eating and uni-nibbling fans, whale is almost unheard of on the plate. It also happens to be illegal.

headline: The Big East’s Big Spenders? Just Check Out the Standings
text: When the men’s Big East Conference tournament expanded to 16 teams last year, the prevailing notion was that the move would give coaches a shot to save their jobs and allow players a chance, albeit an unlikely one, at a charmed five-day run for an N.C.A.A. tournament bid.

headline: 11 Down: Chewy Confection
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — We have another guest solver with us today — Joon Pahk, a physics teacher at Harvard and the division B* champion at the recent American Crossword Puzzle Tournament. His comments appear at the end of the post.

headline: Bloggingheads: Money for Nothing
text: William D. Cohan, left, author of “House of Cards” and a contributing columnist to The New York Times, and John Gillespie, author of “Money for Nothing,” discuss the mismanagement of corporate boards.

headline: Corrections
text: Because of an editing error, a picture caption on Monday with an article about the turnover by Myanmar’s military junta of state-owned assets to private businesses misidentified a junta member shown in the center of the photograph as he greeted U Tay Za, a Myanmar businessman who may benefit from the privatization. He is Maj. Gen. Thein Swe, the transport minister, not Senior Gen. Than Shwe, the top leader, who was not in the photograph.

headline: Corrections
text: Because of an editing error, an article on Feb. 27 about rising thefts of oysters along the Atlantic coast in France misstated the size of the Ernea II, the boat that French gendarmes were using to patrol the oyster beds along Arachon Bay. It was 10 meters long, not 11 feet.

headline: Do You Miss Him Yet?
text: I know you’re not supposed to, but I just love to say I told you so.

headline: So Where’s Consumer Protection?
text: If six of the biggest banking industry lobbying groups are in perfect lockstep on an issue, do they most likely have the best interests of consumers at heart?

headline: Corrections
text: Because of an editing error, a picture caption on Saturday with an article about the gunman who opened fire on Thursday at an entrance to the Pentagon, wounding two police officers before he was killed by the police, misstated, in some editions, the surname of the chief of the Pentagon Force Protection Agency. He is Richard Keevill, not Keevil.

headline: District Attorney Blames Greed in Fatal Crane Collapse
text: As the owner of a New York City crane company pleaded not guilty to manslaughter charges on Monday, several lawyers said it was rare for a company owner to face such serious charges in connection with a fatal accident.

headline: Critics’ Picks Video: ‘Aliens’
text: Long before there were Na’vi, there was “Aliens.” A. O. Scott looks back at James Cameron’s 1986 science fiction film that explored imperialism and gender politics, among other themes. Mr. Scott calls the film’s main character, Ripley (Sigourney Weaver), “a manifestation of Mr. Cameron’s improbable but undeniable feminist streak.” Please share your thoughts on “Aliens.” Do you prefer it to “Avatar?”

headline: Corrections
text: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about a wraparound ad in The Los Angeles Times that simulated a front page misidentified the post held by Geneva Overholser, who commented on the ad. She is director of the journalism school at the Annenberg School for Communication and Journalism at the University of Southern California, not director of the overall school, which is led by a dean.

headline: Record Win for UConn; Moral One for the Irish
text: HARTFORD — Notre Dame was within 10 points of Connecticut with less than four minutes to play Monday, which qualifies as a real barnburner for the Huskies. An uneasy buzz began to swirl inside XL Center.

headline: Police Kill Man Carrying a Fake Gun at a School
text: A 22-year-old man was fatally shot by the police outside a Brooklyn elementary school on Monday afternoon after he pointed a fake gun at an officer, the authorities said.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Monday about the Academy Awards ceremony on Sunday referred imprecisely to the character in “Inglourious Basterds” played by Christoph Waltz, who won the award for best supporting actor. The Nazi officer he plays speaks four languages, not two. In some copies the article also misstated part of a comment by Ben Stiller, who wore makeup to appear like a Na’vi in “Avatar” when he presented the award for best makeup. He said that it seemed like a better idea “in rehearsal,” not “at the time.”

headline: Corrections
text: A picture caption on Saturday with an article about Baylor University center Brittney Griner, who was suspended for two games for punching Jordan Barncastle of Texas Tech in a women’s basketball game on Wednesday, may have left an incorrect impression. Although it showed the two players involved in the altercation, it was from a different game, on Feb. 17.

headline: Corrections
text: An obituary on Saturday about the architect Raimund Abraham misidentified the location of one of his homes. It is in Mazunte, Mexico, not Mexico City.

headline: Correction
text: An Op-Chart on Sunday, about the use of reconciliation to pass bills, misidentified the majority party in Congress in 1997. The Republicans controlled both houses, not the Democrats.

headline: Suicide Raises Legal Issues in Indian Artifacts Cases
text: SALT LAKE CITY — Every person’s life is a mix of the things revealed and unrevealed, secrets spilled or kept. Ted Gardiner, who committed suicide last week, was no exception.

headline: Pierre Is Again a Starter, Ready to Face the Doubters
text: GLENDALE, Ariz. — Every morning in spring training, Chone Figgins’s alarm clock wakes him up at 5:30. And every morning at the same time, he hears the garage door open and his roommate, Juan Pierre, leave for work. So when does Pierre wake up?

headline: State Insurance Experts See Flaw in Obama’s Plan to Curb Health Premiums
text: WASHINGTON — At the heart of President Obama’s drive to rein in health costs is a proposal for federal review and regulation of health insurance premiums, with a new agency empowered to block excessive rate increases.

headline: Loose Ends From Tampa (and Bradenton)
text: TAMPA, Fla. — When Joe Girardi met with reporters in his office after Monday’s 7-5 victory against Philadelphia, he hadn’t yet heard the result from the split-squad game against the Pirates. Told that four pitchers had combined to throw a one-hitter, Girardi’s first words were: “I hope we won. Did we win?”

headline: Obama Plans Florida Forum to Discuss NASA’s Future
text: President Obama will spell out his vision for the future of American astronauts in space at a conference that the administration is planning for Florida next month.

text: To the Editor:

headline: Iraqis Vote
text: Final results from Iraq’s parliamentary election may not be available for days, but this much we can already say for sure: Iraq’s citizens once again showed tremendous courage and determination, defying bombs and a flawed pre-election process to cast their ballots.

headline: Television Is Not Free and Does Not Want to Be
text: The proliferation of “free” media on the Internet seems to have convinced an entire generation that the old hacker slogan from a quarter-century ago, “information wants to be free,” can be an organizing principle for the information economy of the future.

headline: The Emotion of Reform
text: We all have our emotional hot and cold spots. If you asked me about the New York Mets, you’d see a glow in my eyes. If you asked me about banking reform, words might come out of my mouth, but you’d notice me nodding off midsentence.

headline: Healthy Solution: Taxing Sodas
text: Seldom does one idea help fix two important problems, but a proposal to tax sugary soft drinks in New York State is just that sort of 2-for-1 solution. The penny-per-ounce tax on sodas and other sweetened drinks is a way to raise desperately needed money for the city and state in a bad economy. It also could help lower obesity rates, which have soared in recent years.

headline: Hawks’ Johnson, Free Agent to Be, Lurks as a Prize Without the Hype
text: Joe Johnson wonders what if. The course of the N.B.A. might have been altered when he broke an orbital bone near his left eye in the playoffs five years ago.

headline: Siena Rallies to Capture Third Straight MAAC Title
text: ALBANY — Fairfield Coach Ed Cooley did not hesitate when he was asked about the daunting task of playing top-seeded Siena on its home court in the Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference tournament championship game.

headline: Man Killed and Girl Hurt in Shooting Outside a Grocery
text: A 24-year-old man was killed and a 10-year-old girl was wounded in the arm in a shooting outside a grocery store in Brooklyn on Monday night, the authorities said.

headline: Obama Turns Up the Volume
text: President Obama challenged wavering members of his party on Monday not to give in to political fears about supporting health care legislation, asserting that the urgency of getting a bill through Congress should trump any concern about the consequences for Democrats in November.

headline: Letters Capture Grief for President Kennedy
text: BOSTON — Days after President John F. Kennedy was killed, Dr. Ira Seiler sat at his desk and wrote a letter of condolence to his widow, Jacqueline Kennedy.

headline: Even Orphanages Spawn Orphans in Haiti
text: Photographer Lynsey Addario has spent most of the last 10 years photographing major conflicts and humanitarian crisis, but she hesitated to go to Haiti immediately after the earthquake.

headline: Nan Martin, an Actress Known for Her Strong Roles, Dies at 82
text: Nan Martin, a veteran stage, television and film actress whose Broadway credits include “J.B.” and “Under the Yum-Yum Tree” and who played Ali McGraw’s snooty mother in the film “Goodbye, Columbus,” died on Thursday at her home in Malibu, Calif. She was 82.
