headline: Dr. Barton Childs, Who Studied Inherited Diseases, Is Dead at 93
text: Dr. Barton Childs, a founder of pediatric genetics and an important contributor to the understanding of inherited diseases, died on Feb. 18. He was 93, lived in Baltimore, and taught at Johns Hopkins University for nearly 70 years until shortly before his death at its hospital.

headline: General Managers Mull Ban on Some Hits to Head
text: BOCA RATON, Fla. — The N.H.L. general managers opened their annual meeting Monday leaning toward recommending a rule change that would penalize some hits to the head deemed legal under current rules.

headline: K-Rod Returns to Camp
text: JUPITER, Fla. — Mets closer Francisco Rodriguez returned to work Monday after being partly quarantined with conjunctivitis in both eyes. Rodriguez contracted the illness more than three weeks ago, when he was home in Venezuela, but could not completely shake it, he said, until this past weekend.

headline: Netherlands: New Building for World Court
text: The International Criminal Court on Monday unveiled the design for its new headquarters, a sprawling campus of six buildings on the outskirts of The Hague. The Dutch government has donated the land, the former site of military barracks, and the member countries of the court are to share the estimated $125 million cost. The world’s first permanent criminal court is expected to move from its current buildings in 2015. A Danish firm, Schmidt, Hammer, Lassen, one of three finalists, won the design competition, which had drawn 171 entries from around the world.

headline: News Quiz | March 9, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page.

headline: Good News for Cervelli
text: TAMPA, Fla. — Francisco Cervelli, who sustained his second concussion in four months Saturday when he was hit in the head by a pitch, was cleared Monday by the Yankees’ medical staff to resume physical activity. Cervelli was examined Monday by a neurologist, and all testing came back clean, the Yankees said.

headline: Carlyle Taps Ex-Morgan Stanley Trading Chief
text: 8:01 a.m. | Updated The Carlyle Group confirmed on Tuesday that it has hired Michael Petrick, Morgan Stanley’s former chief of trading and sales and known as Mitch, as its global head of credit alternatives and capital markets, a new position that will oversee 24 funds and $19 billion in assets.

text: DoubleVerify, an online advertisement monitor, has nabbed $10 million in a second round of funding led by Institutional Venture Partners, PaidContent reported.

headline: A Boost for Contingent-Capital Deals?
text: Ever since the financial crisis struck, regulators the world over have argued for an overhaul of bank capital. So-called contingent capital, which can absorb losses while keeping a bank in business, was promoted as a solution in the United States and elsewhere.

headline: Six Flags’s C.F.O. Takes Stand in Bankruptcy Battle
text: Six Flags put its chief financial officer on the stand to defend its reorganization plan against attacks by some bondholders, with ownership of the theme park company at stake, Reuters reported.

headline:
As Biden Visits,
Israel Unveils Plan for New Settlements
text: JERUSALEM — Hours after Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. vowed unyielding American support for Israel’s security here on Tuesday, Israel’s Interior Ministry announced 1,600 new housing units for Jews in East Jerusalem. Mr. Biden condemned the move as “precisely the kind of step that undermines the trust we need right now.”

headline: Where Do You Stand on Unconcealed Handguns?
text: Lately, the debate over gun control and the rights afforded by the Second Amendment have focused on the specific issue of unconcealed weapons. What do you think about the open-carry movement?

text: Microchip Technology on Monday raised its purchase price for Silicon Storage for the second time, in a move to trump a competing bid from a private-equity firm for the maker of flash memory cards used in digital cameras and MP3 players, The Associated Press reported.

text: Liberty International, Britain’s biggest shopping mall owner, said Tuesday that it was going ahead with a plan to split its portfolio into two separate listed companies, as it battles to bounce back from the worst property crash in decades, Bloomberg News reported.

text: Maurice R. Greenberg, the former chief executive of the American International Group, will testify on Wednesday over a sham transaction involving the insurer and a unit of Warren E. Buffett’s Berkshire Hathaway, a judge ruled.

text: JAKARTA, Indonesia — Counterterrorism forces have shot and killed one of Southeast Asia’s most-wanted Islamic militants, Indonesia’s president said Wednesday.

headline: U.A.E. Government to Support Dubai
text: The United Arab Emirates’ finance minister said Tuesday that the federal government would  support Dubai as it grapples with a $26 billion debt restructuring and expects the matter to be resolved soon, Reuters reported.

headline: Under Glass: The Arcades of Paris
text: From the mid-19th century onward, as a wealthy middle-class discovered the joys of shopping, architects built a network of glass-roofed arcades — the Paris Galleries — on the edges of the vast central food market known as Les Halles.

headline: Daimler Sells Stake in Tata Motors
text: Daimler says it has sold all of its shares in India’s Tata Motors to various groups of investors through the capital markets, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Shanks Says It Ended Talks With Carlyle
text: Shares in the Shanks Group fell the most in nine years in London trading after the company reported the end of takeover talks with a fund managed by the United States leveraged-buyout firm Carlyle Group, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Doubts About ‘Digital Natives’
text: Today’s idea: Assumptions about the rise of a cognitively different generation of “digital natives” may be wrong, an article says.

headline: Krugman: An Irish Mirror for the Crisis
text: Everyone has a theory about the financial crisis, Paul Krugman writes in his latest Op-Ed piece in The New York Times. These theories range from the absurd to the plausible — from claims that liberal Democrats somehow forced banks to lend to the undeserving poor (even though Republicans controlled Congress) to the belief that exotic financial instruments fostered confusion and fraud. But what do we really know?

headline: British Report Criticizes Initiative
text: Peter Mandelson, the British business secretary, has come under fire after a parliamentary committee released a report accusing his department of doling out more than £300 million ($448 million) to poorly performing venture capital funds, according to press reports.

headline: Merkel and Juncker Take Swipe at Credit Default Swaps
text: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany said Tuesday that the European Commission may have to decide on whether and how to regulate credit default swaps, the derivatives that traders have been using to bet against the ability of certain European countries to pay their debt.

headline: Paulson and Soros Like NovaGold
text: It seems that both John Paulson and George Soros have a good feeling about NovaGold Resources‘ prospects.

headline: YSL: Atonement
text: In one of his early collections for Saint Laurent, the designer Stefano Pilati worked Christian symbols into his clothes, including the outline of a cross in the back of a coat. So it wasn’t surprising that people again saw religious references in his fall 2010 show: the many somber capes, yoked white blouses with full sleeves, the preponderance of black, hats that brought to mind a nun’s cap, and the gold chains from which dangled a single figure (in fact, a silhouette of a woman). The press notes  referred only to the protection elements in the show, most obviously the clear plastic rain covers over some of the tailored pieces. But, of course, religion is protection, too.

headline: Speed Read for Tuesday, March 9
text: Here are some highlights from Tuesday’s edition of The New York Times:

headline: Euro Unity? It’s Germany That Matters
text: Ten years after the euro, it’s still all about Germany, which isn’t the way it was supposed to be, Celestine Bohlen of Bloomberg News writes in her latest column.

headline: Red Pencils Ready?
text: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style.

text: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style.

headline: Samurai Shopper | Kiss and Makeup
text: Nicolas Degennes is a rock star. He’s not in a band, though he spends loads of time backstage. He does live gigs, but his only instruments are buckets of savoir-faire and a genius for innovation. Degennes is the artistic director of Givenchy’s Le Makeup. He’s the inventor of Phenomen’eyes, that mold-breaking mascara with the mace-like, spiked applicator. He travels in very arty circles, and I bet he brings the house down wherever he goes. Women love him. Men love him, too. It’s because he talks to people, not at them. He also listens, makes eye contact, smiles. He’s unaffected, un-jaded, un-snobby. For a Frenchman, this is nothing short of miraculous.

headline: Regarding ‘The Nose': An ArtsBeat Discussion
text: “The Nose,” an opera by Dmitri Shostakovich that had its premiere in Leningrad in 1930 and is based on a short story by Nikolai Gogol written in 1836, is one of the Metropolitan Opera’s new shows this season. As well as alchemy involving three different genres — four if you include stagecraft — the production bridges three centuries. It has the added element of direction and co-design by the contemporary South African artist William Kentridge, which involves video animations and a fair bit of 21st-century technology.

headline: Caution Rules as Major Indexes Inch Forward
text: On the one-year anniversary of the stock market’s plunge to 12-year lows, Wall Street found itself at another crossroads. This time, the question for investors was not so much whether the economy would turn around, but just how strong a recovery would be.

headline: Energy Department Defends Funding of Foreign-Owned Renewables Projects
text: Amid mounting criticism, the Energy Department last week defended its allocation of stimulus funding to foreign companies developing renewable energy projects in the United States.

headline: Airline Luggage Went Unscanned in Denver
text: Denver airport officials say hundreds of bags were loaded onto airplanes in late December without being run through security scanners.

text: Full Coverage

headline: Japan Says It Allowed U.S. Nuclear Ships to Port
text: TOKYO — Japan ended decades of denials on Tuesday by confirming the existence of secret cold war-era agreements with Washington that, among other things, had allowed American nuclear-armed warships to sail into Japanese ports in violation of Japan’s non-nuclear policies.

headline: Jury Selection in L.I. Killing Raises Larger Issues
text: Jury selection in the case involving the killing of Marcelo Lucero, a 37-year-old Ecuadorean immigrant stabbed to death in November 2008 in Patchogue on Long Island, has brought up issues larger than the usual excuses to avoid jury duty.  Prospective jurors have repeatedly pointed to their views on Latino immigration to be dismissed from the case.

headline: JetBlue and Delta Seek Exemption from Tarmac Time-Limit Rule
text: JetBlue and Delta want temporary exemptions from a new U.S. government rule that will limit the time passengers can be held on the tarmac. They say delays caused by the closure of the main runway at John F. Kennedy International Airport in New York could cost them millions of dollars in fines.

headline: Uproar in India Over Female Lawmaker Quota
text: NEW DELHI — The upper house of India’s Parliament passed a bill Tuesday that would amend the Constitution to reserve one-third of the seats in India’s national and state legislatures for women, after the measure stirred two days of political chaos that could whittle the governing coalition’s majority to a dangerously thin margin.

headline: Reporter Breaches Amsterdam Airport’s Security
text: PARIS — Dutch airport officials announced new security measures on Tuesday, after a Dutch investigative journalist reported smuggling a refilled liquor bottle through the heightened security checks at the airport where a young Nigerian boarded a flight for the United States on Dec. 25 with explosives in his underwear.

headline: Europe Is Said to Close Debt Sales to Wall Street
text: European Union nations are shutting major Wall Street banks out of their debt sales, The Guardian reports. No large American bank ranks among the top nine leading the sales of sovereign bonds, according to data from Dealogic.

headline: Google’s Toolkit for Translators Helps Feed Its Machine
text: Te Taka Keegan, a university lecturer in New Zealand, is betting that Google can help him preserve the Maori language of his ancestors.

headline: Early Word: The Push Continues
text: President Obama continued his fervent push to bring about a comprehensive overhaul of the health care system on Monday, traveling to suburban Philadelphia in the latest attempt to lobby skeptical Democrats.

headline: Another View: Vice Chancellor Strine Gets It Right
text: Manan Shah and Benjamin M. Grossman, attorneys at Jones Day, argue that Delaware has a better legal approach to corporate governance and executive compensation than Washington.

headline: Post-Oscars, Letterman Has His Own ‘Elinor Burkett’ Moment
text: Congratulations, Elinor Burkett: you’re not only an Academy Award recipient, you’re also a running joke.

headline: App of the Week: M.L.B.’s Utility Player
text: Just in time for the first pitch, MLB.com has released its 2010 At Bat phone apps, with versions for the iPhone and BlackBerry Storm 1 and 2 and Android phones.

headline: Icebergs at 11 O’Clock!
text: Paris is cold enough this week but Karl Lagerfeld decided to make it a bit colder this morning at Chanel with a misting set of icebergs seeming to float in an Arctic-blue sea. The setting was the Grand Palais, and the bergs were hidden from the audience under a huge wooden box that mechanically rose when the show started. It was a lavish production, needless to say, with classic tweeds, cute knits and thick fur chaps dragged through the enormous wading pool by the models. All the fur, by the way, was fake. Any comment about climate change and melting ice caps was probably unintended. The Ice Hotel in Sweden provided inspiration. When asked backstage if he had ever visited the hotel, Mr. Lagerfeld, dressed in a Dior peacoat and bleached jeans with a vintage Cartier stickpin in his black tie, shivered and said no.

headline: In Defense of ‘Up in the Air’
text: The biggest loser Sunday night at the Oscars wasn’t “Avatar.” It was “Up in the Air,” which was shut out in every category after looking like a shoo-in for a statuette when it first came out. The backlash against Jason Reitman’s movie seemed to build steadily across the last couple months, and it took an interesting form: It attacked what seemed like the film’s greatest strengths, casting them as artistic liabilities instead.

headline: Post-Oscars, Letterman Has His Own ‘Elinor Burkett’ Moment
text: Congratulations, Elinor Burkett: you’re not only an Academy Award recipient, you’re also a running joke.

headline: Now Wearing | Fashion Victims
text: Fashion doesn’t get more vividly macabre than RP/Encore’s line of taxidermy accessories. The artist Reid Peppard makes ghoulish bow ties and pendants from an assortment of rodents and birds collected from the London streets by her cat, Panasonic, and other eagle-eyed friends. “I get texts saying: ‘I’ve just found a dead pigeon on Old Street,’ ” says the 23 year-old Californian, whose beastly collections have names like Vermin, Park and Pet. “It takes chutzpah to wear my work, so most of my customers are men.” Still, her creations have been commissioned for Lady Gaga, and the Balenciaga designer Nicolas Ghesquière has posted her work on his Facebook page. So next time you’re on the checkout line, wear a bow tie with a dead mouse and watch the crowds part — it casts a whole new light on the term “killer accessory.”

text: Hey, where was this impressive guy Obama last year?

headline: With CR-Z, Honda Will Find Out if U.S. Is Ready for a Sporty Hybrid
text: Americans don’t want sporty hybrids.

headline: Greens Gain Nutrients in the Supermarket
text: This sounds too hilarious and ridiculous to be true, yet it appears to be so: spinach and other greens actually increase their nutrient levels in supermarkets, because photosynthesis continues even after harvest, and (of course) even under artificial light.

headline: Ryan and the Zonkers
text: When I was in college, we sat around eating, among other things, Screaming Yellow Zonkers; they weren’t especially tasty, but the copy on the boxes was fun. Among the instruction was the Disappearing Zonkers Trick:

headline: How We Got Everyone Focused on Cash Flow
text: In my last post I talked about how, every year, we pick a critical number or ratio to improve. This year, we’re focusing on cash flow. The idea is to pick a metric that we’ve been doing poorly on, compared with our competition, and turn it around. We do that by tying everyone’s bonus plan to our performance.

headline: Second Pension Fund Sues Goldman Over Pay
text: Goldman Sachs Group was sued on Monday by a large union pension fund that accused the Wall Street investment bank of overpaying its executives, Reuters reported.

headline: Quote Unquote | Shoulder Pads Optional
text: –John Galliano defines style to Vogue UK. We’ll pass on the McDonald’s. But the next time Tom Brady wears Manolo Blahniks we will be the first to tune in.

headline: Congo Dam Projects Evolve and Draw Critics
text: BHP Billiton, the Australian company that is one of the world’s largest mining companies, appears set to build a $3.5 billion hydroelectric plant in the Democratic Republic of Congo to power a $5 billion aluminum smelter.

headline: No Phoning in the Library, Except to Send Donations
text: If you want to make a donation to the Brooklyn Public Library, you can do it in a text message. This method of fund-raising has helped recently in earthquake-ravaged Haiti, but officials believe it is the first time a library has given it a try.

headline: ‘A Major Space Conference’

headline: ‘Not Nearly as Bad’
text: Monologue |  Monday night on “The Jay Leno Show” on NBC: Record ratings for the Oscars last night. Kathryn Bigelow won best director for her film about the Iraq war. But in her speech, she forgot to thank the two people without whom this film could never have been made — Bush and Cheney.

headline: Tuesday Reading
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Get Your Fresh, Delicious Whale Meat Here
text: Whale meat sushi is pale pink, fatty, and extremely hard to find, probably because it is extremely illegal. But the filmmakers who made “The Cove,” which just won an Oscar for best documentary feature, know where to find it. They ran a sting operation at The Hump in Santa Monica which led to a federal investigation that looks likely to end in charges against the restaurant, Jennifer Steinhauer reports.

headline: Sampler: Napa Wineries Face Foreclosure Risk, and Easing Polar Bear Depression
text: ‘I’m Gay,’ Republican Lawmaker Says | State Senator Roy Ashburn, Republican of Bakersfield, told a radio program Monday that he is gay, making him the first openly gay Republican legislator in Sacramento. “I’m gay,” he said. “Those are the words that have been so difficult for me for so long.” Mr. Ashburn, whose confession appeared to come out of his arrest last week in Sacramento for suspicion of drunken driving, said he had voted against gay rights measures because that is what he believed his constituents wanted. On the Senate floor on Monday, colleagues of both parties shook his hand and slapped his back. [The Sacramento Bee]

He has put his thumb on the scale in favor of Ms. Bowersox, a plucky 24-year-old semifinalist from Elliston, Ohio, who we’re totally hoping runs away with the whole ball of wax. headline: Another Missed Opportunity for Takahashi
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — For the second time this spring it appears Hisanori Takahashi will miss out on a chance to start, although that opportunity will come at some point before spring training is over. Takahashi, the Mets’ Japanese left-hander, was originally scheduled to start last Wednesday in Orlando but his inability to get a visa in time canceled that opportunity. The Mets were concerned he would be too tired.

headline: UConn and the Common Good
text: To start, it should be noted that the Connecticut women’s basketball team has been linked to no nefarious doctors in Canada. It did not intentionally cause a Nascar crash, nor has it been suspended by the N.H.L. for crushing someone’s head. It played no apparent role in the global financial crisis.

headline: ‘The Cove’ Moves to the Dragon’s Lair
text: LOS ANGELES — “Long version of the World’s Shortest Oscar Acceptance Speech” was the subject line of a message that Louie Psihoyos, the director of the Oscar-winning documentary “The Cove,” about a secret dolphin-killing ground in Japan, sent around to friends on Monday. “We made this film to give the oceans a voice,” it begins, going on to highlight the problems of oceanic pollution and ask the people of Japan to watch the movie.

headline: Climate Goal Is Supported by China and India
text: WASHINGTON — China and India formally agreed Tuesday to join the international climate change agreement reached in December in Copenhagen, the last two major economies to sign up.

text: DOGO NA HAWA, Nigeria — Nightmare images haunt this dusty sun-baked village, fresh memories of tall young men emerging from darkness to slash the unarmed with long knives in a frenzy of ethnic and religious hatred.

headline: How Low Can You Go?
text: The dropped crotch is shaping up as the new decade’s most influential trouser trend. But as pant fronts fall, even dedicated followers of fashion are hard pressed to describe the differences between dhoti, samurai, Zouave and harem pants. Some critics claim the dropped crotch screams fashion victim, but in fact it owes its exaggerated form to utility. Designed for easy movement and comfort in hot climates, it’s an unexpectedly practical wardrobe addition. And you never have to worry about a wedgie.

text: All you pop-star wannabes, take note: making it big isn’t cheap.

text: Twins closer Joe Nathan’s season is in doubt after it was disclosed Tuesday that he has a “significant tear” of the ulnar collateral ligament in his right elbow.

text: Remember back, if you will, to a simpler time when you watched TV on TV and your unemployed friends didn’t flood your work inbox with mildly funny Web videos. To a time otherwise known as the B.L.S. era — Before “Lazy Sunday.”

headline: Hoyer Dismisses Massa’s Claims as ‘Untrue’

headline: Meet and Greet | Chanel’s Laetitia Crahay
text: Laetitia Crahay talks like a hurricane, passionately blustering her way through a stream of gabbling about what she loves and hates. And she pretty much loves or hates everything. Since she started working with her fashion-school-dropout classmate Olivier Theyskens to set up his renegade brand in 1997, she has turned herself into one of the most creative forces in fashion. Now 33, she heads up accessories and jewelry at Chanel, and is the artistic director of Maison Michel, the tiny millinery firm that Chanel invested in in 2006 as part of an effort to preserve traditional craftsmanship in Paris.

headline: Man to Plead Guilty in Letterman Extortion Case

text: The New York Times Company named Robert H. Christie as its new communications chief on Tuesday. He had been the chief spokesman for Dow Jones & Company, a unit of News Corporation.

headline: Automakers and Airplanes, and Privacy
text: When the top bosses of the three Detroit automakers flew their private jets to a meeting in Washington in November 2008 to ask the government for bailout money, they received a lambasting from politicians and excoriating coverage in the media. Sixteen months later, the fallout is being felt beyond the auto industry.

headline: Rock and Roll All Nite, Potty Every Day: Kiss Band Mates Plan a Kids’ Show
text: They call him Doctor Love. They call his partner the Starchild and, occasionally, the Bandit. And as of now, they can call Gene Simmons and Paul Stanley, the lead singer and the rhythm guitarist of the rock band Kiss, something else: children’s show producers.

headline: Awards for Costume and Set Designers
text: The veteran Broadway and film costume designer Albert Wolsky, who has two Academy Awards to his credit for “All That Jazz” and “Bugsy,” will receive the T.D.F./Irene Sharaff lifetime achievement award next month at a ceremony that will honor several other designers as well. The Theater Development Fund, the not-for-profit group that runs TKTS and has an extensive collection of costumes for rent, announced the recipients of the design awards on Tuesday.The other honorees are: • Ming Cho Lee, who will receive the Robert L. B. Tobin Award for sustained excellence in theatrical design. Mr. Lee, who first worked on Broadway as a technical assistant for the musical “Happy Hunting” during the 1956-57 season, was the set designer for the original Broadway production of “Mother Courage and Her Children” in 1963 and more than 20 other Broadway shows, including the musicals “Billy” and “Two Gentleman of Verona” and the play “K2,” for which he won a Tony Award for his set design of a ledge on the famous mountain.• Alejo Vietti, who will receive the young master award recognizing his work as a costume designer in New York and regionally, including the Off Broadway productions “Nightingale” and “Rooms: A Rock Romance.”• John David Ridge, who will receive the artisan award. Mr. Ridge is a Hollywood and theater costume designer who was nominated for a Tony for best costume design in 1999 for the revival of “Ring Round the Moon.”

headline: Making Stuffed Mushrooms
text: I associate stuffed vegetables with two very different milieus: southern France and the red-sauce Italian restaurants of my childhood. The first is a place of rosé wine, summer squashes, tomatoes, onions and little peppers, all filled with herb-scented vegetable stuffings, and sunshine. The second is, or was, a place of quart bottles of Hoffman soda, veal parmigiana, dim, reddish light — and stuffed mushrooms.

headline: Erin Callan: the Greta Garbo of Wall Street
text: Whatever happened to Erin Callan? The former chief financial officer of Lehman Brothers, known for her overachieving star quality and limited financial experience, was pushed out in June 2008, a few months before the firm imploded. Ms. Callan resurfaced for a bit at Credit Suisse and then just seemed to fall off the face of the earth.

headline: House Considers Judge’s Impeachment
text: The House will take up the impeachment on Friday of a Louisiana federal judge accused of seeking and accepting bribes and perjury, the majority leader, Steny Hoyer, said on Tuesday.

headline: A Storehouse to Help Those Who Help the Poor
text: A low-slung building along a desolate industrial stretch of Port Morris is packed to the rafters with everything from office furniture, dishes, clothing, books and toiletries — all stockpiled by the international Christian relief group World Vision.

headline: The First Player I Ever Met
text: MESA, Ariz. – Bob Dernier was the first baseball player I ever met. I was 7 years old and he was the rookie leadoff hitter for the Philadelphia Phillies. He was signing autographs at Magarity Chevrolet in Flourtown, Pa. I could not fathom the idea that Bobby D. was right down the street in my hometown.

headline: Ohio State Employee Kills Co-Worker, Then Self, Police Say
text: An Ohio State University custodian who had been told he was being fired killed a co-worker and wounded another before killing himself early Tuesday morning at a university maintenance building, officials said.

headline: State Submits to a Study of Test Scores
text: It is an annual ritual: the State Education Department releases the latest results of its standardized math and reading tests, showing dramatic improvements at nearly every level. Critics and skeptics cry foul, pointing out that the results on national tests are much less rosy.

headline: Part 2: Answers on Historically Black Colleges and Universities
text: More than 100 American institutions are classified by the government as historically black colleges and universities through a formal program intended “to overcome the effects of discriminatory treatment and to strengthen and expand the capacity of historically black colleges and universities to provide quality education.”

headline: Notre Dame Considers Not Going It Alone
text: On what could be a slow basketball day at the Big East men’s basketball tournament, the biggest news on Tuesday may have come from Notre Dame Athletic Director Jack Swarbrick. With the Big Ten and the Pacific-10 considering expansion, he said, Notre Dame is being forced to consider giving up its football independence, among a range of options.

headline: The Morning Skate: Will Head Check Ban Take Shape as a Triangle?
text: How might the N.H.L. general managers, who continue their meetings Tuesday in Boca Raton, Fla., define what is, and what is not, an illegal shoulder check to the head? One glimpse into their thinking after the first day was provided by the Hockey Hall of Fame coach Scotty Bowman, interviewed on FAN 590 radio in Toronto on Tuesday morning by Gord Stellick and Elliotte Friedman.

headline: Andy Richter Isn’t Finished With Jay Leno Yet
text: Andy Richter, the normally genial comedian and longtime sidekick to Conan O’Brien, has finally found someone who pushes him too far. And that someone is Jay Leno.In a conversation on Tuesday on “Live With Regis and Kelly,” Mr. Richter made it clear he was still upset about the recent late-night shake-up at NBC that returned Mr. Leno as the host of “The Tonight Show,” leaving Mr. O’Brien — not to mention Mr. Richter — out of a job at the network.

headline: Facebook Will Allow Users to Share Location
text: Starting next month, the more than 400 million Facebook users could begin seeing a new kind of status update flow through their news feed: the current locations of their friends.

headline: Israel Intends to Build Civilian Nuclear Plants
text: PARIS — Israel, widely believed to have nuclear weapons and possessing no oil, said on Tuesday that it intended to develop civilian nuclear plants for energy, offering to build one as a joint project with Jordan, under French supervision.

headline: On the Causes of Climate Deadlock
text: For years, there’s been a building drumbeat of criticism of the media for failing to tell the climate story “right,” and thus perpetuating public disengagement and, in turn, allowing elected officials to relax and avoid pushing for meaningful actions to blunt greenhouse emissions.

headline: Iraqi Officials to Begin Releasing Vote Tallies on Wednesday
text: BAGHDAD — Iraq’s electoral commission said Tuesday that it would announce partial results of parliamentary elections on Wednesday, providing an incomplete picture of the vote that will nevertheless provide the broad outlines of the country’s political landscape.

headline: Inside Out | Shades of Grandeur
text: Rita Konig is a decorator based in New York who has written about style for British Vogue, The Telegraph and Domino.

headline: Power Button Wins Condom Wrapper Design Contest
text: The NYC condom package design contest wrapped up Tuesday. After tallying more than 15,000 online votes, the New York Department of Health and Mental Hygiene announced that a design by a Queens man showing a power button would adorn six million limited-edition free condoms set for release this year.

headline: Leibovitz Reaches Deal With Private Equity Firm
text: The photographer Annie Leibovitz, whose messy finances almost cost her the rights to her work and her homes last year, has reached an agreement with Colony Capital, a Los Angeles firm not known for bailing out artists, to help her restructure her debt, The Financial Times reported Tuesday.

headline: Sorgi Goes From Backing Up One Manning to the Other
text: The Giants needed a backup for quarterback Eli Manning, who hasn’t missed a game since becoming the starter on Nov. 21, 2004. They turned to the player who is better prepared to be an unused backup than anybody else in the N.F.L.

headline: Sabathia Struggles in Second Start
text: TAMPA, Fla. – In his second start last spring, the Tigers hammered C.C. Sabathia for five runs and six hits in one and two-thirds innings. It was a spring training game, so he did not think the results, however poor, would be a big deal. The next day, one headline on the Internet read, “Sabathia Already Has Fat in Fire.”

headline: Romance in the Desert
text: LOS ANGELES— “Which magazine will be first to assign cute profile of wacky editor-couple Bob Murawski and Chris Innis?” the Bagger’s spendthrift pal Jon Caramanica tweeted on Oscar night. And lo and behold, this is close enough. New York magazine offers a Q.&A. with the Oscar-winning editing winners, who got married after working on “The Hurt Locker.”

headline: South Florida Rolls in Big East Opener
text: Time after time, the South Florida junior guard Dominique Jones got out on the fast break and finished at the rim against DePaul. He approached from all directions, absorbing fouls and charging hard at a soft Blue Demons zone when the Bulls settled into a halfcourt set.

headline: Consequences of an Airport Kiss
text: Theirs was a whirlwind New York City Christmas, but while true love is timeless, vacations are not. Sadly, it came time for one of the lovebirds to fly home to California, and the other, Haisong Jiang — love-struck as if Cupid hit him not with an arrow, but with a two-by-four to the head — saw his beloved to the security line at Newark Liberty International Airport.

(You can read them here and here.) After all, I learned firsthand when my son was born that friendships can sustain you and disappoint you as your life transforms.

headline: Vain Glorious | A Scar Is Born
text: In the play “Time Stands Still” (at the Samuel J. Friedman Theater through March 27), Laura Linney plays Sarah Goodwin, a war photographer badly injured by a bomb blast in Iraq. From the beginning, the director, Daniel Sullivan, and Linney knew that Goodwin’s visible scars would be an important facet of the production, so the actress suggested calling in Mindy Hall, an accomplished (and as of this past Sunday night, Academy Award-winning) makeup artist who Linney had worked with on four films, including “Kinsey.” “I knew Mindy would be able to come up with something a) the theater would be able to afford, b) that would look realistic and c) that I would be able to put on myself,” Linney said. Applying the extensive shrapnel marks to her face, arm and leg has become something of a pre-performance meditation for the actress. “I love the quiet time it gives me before every show,” she says. “I tend to get to the theater early anyway, but this gives me an excuse to get here even earlier. And you know, it’s just me alone. It becomes a sort of starting point.”

headline: Letterman Offers a Comment on Extortion Case
text: David Letterman released a statement through his spokesman Tom Keaney, following the court appearance on Tuesday by Robert Halderman, in which he pleaded guilty to an effort to extort Mr. Letterman and received a sentence of six months in prison.

headline: Airport Built, It’s Time to See if the Traffic Comes
text: The first new international airport in the United States in more than decade is set to open in May near Panama City, Fla., a community of 37,000 people on the state’s panhandle. That is no small feat given the environmental, regulatory and financial hurdles involved in building runways and terminals, as well as community opposition to planes flying overhead.

headline: Debating the Nuclear Waste Problem
text: With Nevada’s Yucca Mountain facility apparently out of the picture as a nuclear waste repository, government nuclear experts say interim measures might be needed for a very long time.

headline: Bringing a Taste of New York to Johannesburg
text: JOHANNESBURG  Adam Levy was a teenager growing up in Melrose, a whites-only suburb in northern Johannesburg, when Nelson Mandela was released from prison 20 years ago. Today Mr. Levy  much like the city itself  has traded the racial restrictions of the apartheid era for a far more colorful (and cultural) urban existence.

headline: Browns Cut Quarterback Anderson
text: Cleveland’s new football guru Mike Holmgren is putting his imprint all over the Browns, terminating the contract of the former starting quarterback Derek Anderson on Tuesday.

headline: Vatican on Defense as Sex Scandals Build
text: ROME — Defending itself against a growing child sexual abuse scandal in Europe, one that has even come close to the brother of Pope Benedict XVI, the Vatican said Tuesday that local European churches had addressed the issue with “timely and decisive action.”

headline: Now Showing | The World According to Gursky
text: Since medieval times, the desire to make maps of the world remains a story of both necessity and art. If the recent surge of books about maps is any indication, cartographic art is for all ages. How better to visualize human history and keep track of one’s empire while contemplating opportunities for expansion? Andreas Gursky’s latest body of work pushes his penchant for wide-angle photography to encompass the ever-increasing scope of his Weltanschauung, or worldview. Verging on 13 feet by 8 feet, Gursky’s photographs are cinematic in scale, and their exhibition at Gagosian in Beverly Hills, Calif., is apt for a town filled with connoisseurs of cinematography (and movie moguls who can afford them).

headline: A Travel Blog for the Hipster Set?
text: Does the world really need another travel blog? Perhaps, if you like offbeat travel articles written by novelists and poets who view travel through their idiosyncratic artistic lens.

headline: LifeLock Settles With F.T.C. Over Charges of Deception
text: WASHINGTON — LifeLock, the company that broadcast its chief executive’s Social Security number as part of its claim that it could protect anyone against identity theft, agreed on Tuesday to pay $12 million to settle charges that it misled consumers about the effectiveness of its service.

headline: Daniels Offers Advice to Republicans
text: Gov. Mitch Daniels of Indiana offered a piece of advice to fellow Republicans: “Lay down the philosophical swords” to begin rebuilding the party and tackle the nation’s immense challenges. But he urged Republicans to not become too emboldened by the discontent in the electorate.

headline: Caricatured Commentary: Minstrel Meets Modern
text: In “Neighbors,” a simultaneously overheated and undercooked new play that’s part of the Public Theater’s Lab program, the young playwright Branden Jacobs-Jenkins tries to trace in bold strokes how the poisons spread by disgraced racial stereotypes continue to contaminate American culture and the American family.

headline: The Secret to Having Happy Employees
text: About 10 years ago I was having my annual holiday party, and my niece had come with her newly minted M.B.A. boyfriend. As he looked around the room, he noted that my employees seemed happy. I told him that I thought they were.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Tuesday, March 9
text: It is a departure for Pictures of the Day to open with a black-and-white image. It is also a departure for this particular photographer: Luke Sharrett, a prolific New York Times intern. He said he had only transmitted black-and-white files two or three times in the seven months he has been working in The Times’s Washington bureau. But Mr. Sharrett said that Tuesday’s occasion — the burial in Arlington National Cemetery of Cpl. Jacob H. Turbett, a Marine who was killed Feb. 13 in Helmand Province in Afghanistan — warranted the somber cast of monochrome.

headline: Where the Jobs Are
text: Job openings rose in January, according to a new Labor Department report. As a result, the number of unemployed workers per available job dipped slightly to 5.4, from about 6 workers per job opening in December:

text: In honor of International Women’s Day, which was Monday, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development’s Factblog has been dissecting data on women’s role in the world.

text: As they set their energy budgets for next year, the owners of hundreds of buildings in New York will be eligible to join Con Edison’s hourly pricing plan for electricity service, broadening a program that allows customers to monitor electricity usage as it changes over a day and pay rates that reflect that data.

text: After saying on Friday that the Broadway revival of “The Miracle Worker” might close unless ticket sales improved, the lead producer of the show said on Tuesday that it would continue running even though the box office remained slow over the weekend.

text: An unusual study done in 49 remote Hutterite farming colonies in western Canada has provided the surest proof yet that giving flu shots to schoolchildren protects a whole community from the disease.

text: This is the big week for awards — in computing as well as movies. The Turing Award, often called the Nobel prize of computer science, was announced on Tuesday and the 2009 winner was Charles P. Thacker.

headline: Divining the Academy’s Intent
text: LOS ANGELES — Now that everyone’s had a chance to shake off his or her red carpet hangovers — telltale signs include an aversion to bright lights and publicists — the post-mortems are rolling in. Why did “The Hurt Locker” beat “Avatar”? The demographics of the Academy are one reason, as the Bagger’s pals Brooks Barnes and Michael Cieply reported on Tuesday. At Time.com, Richard Corliss adds “the shock of the new” – the membership’s rejection of cinematic innovation – to his list of reasons.

headline: PBS Considers Editor of Newsweek as Host
text: The editor of Newsweek, Jon Meacham, is negotiating to add a television job to his schedule. He is in final talks to be a host of a new PBS Friday-night public affairs series called “Need to Know,” said executives familiar with the production who wanted to stay anonymous because the contracts had not been signed. The co-anchor for the program, which begins May 7 at 8:30 p.m., is expected to be Alison Stewart, formerly of “The Bryant Park Project,” NPR’s short-lived morning show, and before that anchor of “The Most” on MSNBC. The new series will be produced for PBS by WNET.org of New York from a new street-side studio at Lincoln Center. Mr. Meacham, who won the Pulitzer last year for his book “American Lion: Andrew Jackson in the White House,” is not leaving the magazine, said a Newsweek spokesman, Frank DeMaria.

headline: Firm to Help Restructure Annie Leibovitz Debt
text: The photographer Annie Leibovitz, right, whose messy finances almost cost her the rights to her work and her homes last year, has reached an agreement with Colony Capital, a Los Angeles firm, to help her restructure her debt, The Financial Times reported on Tuesday. Under the deal, Colony  which manages about $30 billion in assets, mostly in real estate  will become Ms Leibovitz’s only creditor and will help her market her catalog of celebrity-heavy photographs. Ms. Leibovitz averted a foreclosure last summer after she missed a deadline to repay $24 million in loans she owed to Art Capital Group, a lender that used the rights to her photos and her real estate as collateral. Art Capital sued her in July 2009, saying she had not paid hundreds of thousands of dollars due under its agreements with her. Colony, which also controls the rights to the Neverland Ranch in California, told The Financial Times that it plans to manage sales of Ms. Leibovitz’s photographic holdings and pursue other business ventures for her so that she can concentrate on her career.

headline: ‘View From the Bridge’ Recovers Its Investment
text: The critically acclaimed Broadway revival of “A View From the Bridge,” starring Liev Schreiber and Scarlett Johansson, has recouped its initial $2.3 million investment, the producers announced. The 14-week limited engagement began preview performances at the Cort Theater on Dec. 28 and opened on Jan. 24. It is scheduled to close on April 4. Shows that have enjoyed similar runaway box-office success and recouped so far this season have included the new play “A Steady Rain,” starring Hugh Jackman and Daniel Craig, and a revival of “Hamlet” with Jude Law in the title role. New commercial productions lacking major stars, like the plays “Brighton Beach Memoirs,” “Oleanna” and “Superior Donuts” and the musicals “Finian’s Rainbow” and “Ragtime,” closed without recovering the upfront spending by producers and their investors.

headline: Seeing in the Dark
text: For me, sleep has never come easy — perhaps because I’ve never let it.

headline: ‘Spartacus’ Is Delayed as Star Has Cancer
text: The Starz cable channel said on Tuesday that it would delay production of the second season of its series “Spartacus: Blood and Sand” so the actor Andy Whitfield, left, who plays the title character, can begin treatment for non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma. Starz said in a news release that Mr. Whitfield “discovered the cancer during a routine checkup” and that his doctors “have stated his condition is very treatable and was detected in its early stages.” Starz began showing “Spartacus,” an action series about that Roman slave turned revolutionary, in January. The show quickly became a hit for the cable channel, drawing record ratings for its debut and seeing its audience grow.

headline: The Dark Side of the Courtroom
text: Had EMI paid closer attention to the skeptical lyrics of Pink Floyd’s “Have a Cigar”  not to mention the better part of that group’s back catalog  it might have known that the band is not endlessly trusting of record labels. Instead, EMI found out the hard way when Pink Floyd filed suit against the label in a dispute over how its online royalty payments and marketing costs for its music are calculated, Reuters reported. In a hearing at High Court in London on Tuesday, Robert Howe, a lawyer for Pink Floyd, said that a clause in the band’s contract “expressly prohibited” the “unbundling” of its songs in any configuration other than how they were originally produced and released. Mr. Howe said that EMI believed this “applies only to the physical product and doesn’t apply online,” adding that the argument “makes no commercial sense.” Pink Floyd first signed with EMI in the late 1960s, going on to record hit prog-rock albums like “The Dark Side of the Moon” and motivating the sale of millions of black light lamps and posters. The band more recently renegotiated its contract in the late 1990s, when online retailers like iTunes were still in their infancy. Reuters said that sales of Pink Floyd’s back catalog are exceeded only by another popular British combo: the Beatles.

headline: Kiss Colleagues Plan Kids’ Show
text: They call him Doctor Love. They call his partner the Starchild and, occasionally, the Bandit. And now they can call Gene Simmons and Paul Stanley, the lead singer and the rhythm guitarist of the rock band Kiss, something else: children’s show producers. Mr. Simmons and Mr. Stanley, above from left, have had collaborations like the songs “Hotter Than Hell,” “Love Gun” and “Lick It Up,” but now they have a deal with the Canadian production company E1 Television to create a show for young viewers that will also serve as a merchandising tie-in, The Hollywood Reporter said. The show, a comedy series yet to be titled, will be produced and distributed by E1. In a statement to The Hollywood Reporter, Mr. Simmons said: “Kiss continues to be the juggernaut of licensing and merchandising, from Kiss M&M’s to Kiss Dr Pepper. Kiss is a band, but also the only music brand.”

headline: ‘Men’ Takes Charge
text: The CBS sitcom “Two and a Half Men” attracted its largest audience in three years on Monday, leading the night’s ratings with 17.5 million viewers, according to Nielsen’s estimates. CBS won the night over all, benefiting not only from its 9 p.m. ratings for “Two and a Half Men” but also from “The Big Bang Theory,” the night’s second-highest-rated show with 16.3 million viewers, at 9:30. Fox was runner-up on the night, leading the 8 o’clock hour with “House” (12.8 million), which edged ahead of CBS’s other comedies. But Fox’s “24” lagged behind at 9 with 8.9 million viewers. ABC ranked third with its two-hour special, “The Bachelor: Jason and Molly’s Wedding” (9.3 million). At 10, ABC’s “Castle” (9.1 million) outperformed NBC’s “Law & Order” (5.2 million) but trailed CBS’s “CSI: Miami” (11.9 million). NBC placed fourth on the night..

headline: Coffee Grounds + Spores = a New East Bay Business
text: Last year, in an ethics class at the University of California, Berkeley’s Haas School of Business, Alex Velez and Nikhil Arora heard a visiting lecturer mention that women in Colombia and parts of East Africa were growing mushrooms from coffee grounds to fight malnutrition.

headline: Carlyle Said to Seek Buyers for Arinc
text: The private equity firm Carlyle Group has hired Goldman Sachs to seek buyers for Arinc, its military contracting and aviation business, Bloomberg News reports, citing unidentified people with knowledge of the matter.

headline: Designer Potholes
text: There is the time of year when the swallows return to San Juan Capistrano and the mud daubers to Luckenbach, Tex. There is the season of the cherry blossom — and the season of the pothole.

headline: St. John’s Eliminates a Fading UConn
text: For all the athleticism that UConn’s lineup brought into Tuesday’s game against St. John’s, it was the unit’s collective apathy that was most striking on the court.

headline: Fashion House Opens Hotel in Milan
text: Italian fashion designers continue to moonlight as hoteliers. There is the Hotel Missoni, which opened in Edinburgh last year, and the Hotel Armani, expected to open this month in Dubai. The latest is the Maison Moschino, which opened in Milan in late February.

headline: H.P. Barks, Then Bites Apple on the iPad
text: Such is the hype around tablet computers that Hewlett-Packard and Apple have taken to beating each other up over products that no one can even buy yet.

headline: Imaginarium of Mr. Arsham
text: In Daniel Arsham’s world, nothing is what it seems. A smooth wall suddenly looks as if it is being stretched like fabric. A solid white cube gives the impression that it’s been eaten away. An Arcadian landscape populated only by a kangaroo is invaded by a rectangular slab that hovers in midair. A gouache rendering of Le Corbusier’s modernist monastery La Tourette is pictured inside a cave. Arsham’s work blurs the lines between art, architecture and performance, and explores issues of natural versus manufactured or intention versus happenstance. It has attracted impressive collaborators — Merce Cunningham, the choreographer Jonah Bokaer and the fashion designer Hedi Slimane — as well as the art dealer Emmanuel Perrotin. Arsham’s third solo exhibition at Perrotin’s Paris gallery, “Animal Architecture,” opens on March 20. And to think, he’s only 29.

headline: Live Updates From the Big East Tournament
text: Four games are on the schedule Tuesday at the Big East men’s basketball tournament. The Times’s Pete Thamel and Kevin Armstrong, along with Zach Hillesland, a former Notre Dame forward, will provide analysis and updates throughout the day. Readers are invited to join the conversation in the comment section below. The schedule:

headline: Gates Tours Market in Former Taliban Town
text: NOW ZAD, Afghanistan — Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates took a stroll on Tuesday through a village market in this former Taliban sanctuary in Helmand Province, but the lone street of shops was so sleepy that it looked as if everyone had been told to stay home.

headline: Alabama-Style Rap, Without the Punches
text: Sweaty, drinking from a pitcher of beer and spilling his syllables in rapid, often inscrutable fashion, the Alabama rapper Yelawolf was doing the absolute best he could on the stage at Brooklyn Bowl on Monday night, given the circumstances. After he finished playing one of the standout tracks on “Trunk Muzik,” his latest mixtape  an unprintably titled song with a beefy, bellowing chorus, horn stabs and military-march drums  he was vexed.

headline: Beady Eyes That Just Can’t Help It
text: The word taxidermy derives from two innocent Greek roots  taxis (arrangement) and derma (skin)  that when combined suggest something slightly sinister. Taxidermy was Norman Bates’s hobby in “Psycho.” Jeffrey Dahmer, the serial killer, practiced it on his neighbor’s pets. In horror movies, taxidermy often crowds the walls, derangement made manifest.

headline: Back Together, and It Seems Like 1993
text: Sometimes the only way to take a measure of a band is hearing it play a gig. Most times, actually. But Harvey Milk, from Athens, Ga., seems a special case.

headline: The Lithium Chase
text: For many years, few metals drew bigger yawns from mining executives than lithium, a lightweight element long associated mostly with mood-stabilizing drugs.

headline: Strolling Through Castles and Labyrinths
text: The concert presented by Max Lifchitz and his North/South Chamber Orchestra at Merkin Concert Hall on Monday night was billed as a 30th-anniversary gala. Since founding North/South Consonance in 1980, Mr. Lifchitz, a Mexican-born composer, conductor and pianist, has devoted copious effort to promoting the work of composers underserved elsewhere, through a regular series of concerts in New York and on CDs released by North/South Recordings.

headline: First Lady to Hit Graduation Circuit
text: Michelle Obama is scheduled for a bit of a graduation tour this spring, with three commencement speeches on her itinerary.
