text: Chapter 1: Schwendeman's Taxidermy Studio

headline: Six Months in Jail for Letterman Plot
text: Saying that he felt “great remorse for what I have done,” a former CBS producer pleaded guilty on Tuesday to trying to extort $2 million from David Letterman by threatening to reveal details about affairs that Mr. Letterman had with members of his staff, including a former companion of the producer.

headline: Fighting a War of Words About a Lot of Words About a War
text: A momentous passage in American journalism strides stiffly across the stage of New York Theater Workshop in “Top Secret: The Battle for the Pentagon Papers,” a fact-packed drama by Geoffrey Cowan and Leroy Aarons, journalists with distinguished careers that have extended into academia and other realms.

headline: Christie’s Wins Bid to Auction $150 Million Brody Collection
text: After a four-month battle between the auction giants Sotheby’s and Christie’s, the art collection of the Los Angeles philanthropist Frances Lasker Brody will be sold at Christie’s in New York in May. Valued at well over $150 million, it includes a 1932 painting by Picasso that is considered a seminal work from one of the high points of that artist’s career. Also coming to auction are rare examples by Giacometti, Matisse and Braque.

headline: Iranian Filmmaker Speaks Out on Prisoners
text: Abbas Kiarostami, a celebrated Iranian filmmaker who has won numerous international awards for films like “Close-Up” and “Through The Olive Trees,” published an open letter in a Tehran newspaper on Tuesday calling for the release of Jafar Panahi and Mahmoud Rasoulof, two directors recently detained by the authorities.

headline: S.E.C. Accuses Ex-Trader of Taking Kickbacks
text: A former stock loan trader at Morgan Stanley and Bank of America in New York received well over $100,000 of cash kickbacks by steering orders to other brokerage firms, the Securities and Exchange Commission said in a lawsuit filed on Tuesday, Reuters reports.

headline: Historic Building in Surrey
text: A four-bedroom two-and-a-half bath historic house in Surrey, England, is on the market for 999,950 pounds ($1.5 million).

headline: I Tickled Aide, but That Was All, Massa Says
text: Updated, 6:21 p.m. | Representative Eric J. Massa, who resigned from Congress amid allegations of sexual misconduct, vehemently denied any wrongdoing during a television appearance on Tuesday even as he described having tickle fights with staffers in a house they shared.

headline: Same Phantom, Different Spirit
text: LONDON  To think that all this time that poor old half-faced composer hasn’t been dead at all, just stewing in his lust for greater glory. Being the title character of “The Phantom of the Opera,” the most successful musical of all time, wasn’t enough for him. Oh, no. Like so many aging stars, he was determined to return  with different material and a rejuvenated body  to the scene of his first triumph. So now he’s back in the West End with a big, gaudy new show. And he might as well have a “kick me” sign pasted to his backside.

headline: Scorecard | Céline Wins!
text: Whether we care to admit it, it’s clear that the weekend’s catwalk spectacular had a little competition from another international promenade — of the red plush variety. So today Scorecard asks: What show made editors not regret catching the early-morning Oscars telecast from Paris? The showmen duo Viktor & Rolf presented Kristen McMenamy on a rotating runway in a carapace of 23 layers that gave new definition to the idea of 3-D dressing, while at the more tightly edited Céline showing, fashion’s own Kathryn Bigelow, Phoebe Philo, made chic severity approachable. And the award goes to. …

headline: Lohan Sues E*Trade Over Super Bowl Ad
text: Lindsay Lohan is suing E*Trade Financial over a popular television commercial that made its debut during Super Bowl XLIV and has appeared subsequently during coverage of the Winter Olympics and other programs.

headline: Somalia Food Aid Bypasses Needy, U.N. Study Says
text: As much as half the food aid sent to Somalia is diverted from needy people to a web of corrupt contractors, radical Islamist militants and local United Nations staff members, according to a new Security Council report.

headline: Properties for $175,000
text: Properties in Heber City, Utah, Seneca Falls, N.Y., and Milwaukee.

headline: What You Get for ... $175,000
text: HEBER CITY, UTAH

headline: A Female Parliamentary Majority in Just One Country: Rwanda
text: As my colleague Lydia Polgreen writes, the upper house of India’s Parliament passed a bill on Tuesday that would amend the Constitution to reserve a third of the seats in India’s national and state legislatures for women. Such a provision may sound extreme, but it is nothing new: According to the Quota Project, about half of the world’s countries currently use some type of electoral quota for their national legislatures, in some cases enforced by political parties. (India has previously experimented with quotas for women in local elections.)

headline: Tacos in the Morning? That’s the Routine in Austin
text: Austin, Tex.

headline: State Police Losing Its Second Chief in Two Weeks
text: The New York State Police lost its second leader in a matter of days on Tuesday when the agency’s acting superintendent, Pedro J. Perez, announced that he would retire, effective Friday.

headline: Sidewalk Standoff in East Jerusalem
text: An Israeli court case finds that land owned by a Palestinian should be turned over to Jews who claim it was an ancestral home.

headline: A New Frontier for Indie Rock, Down in Mexico
text: It was a scene of classic do-it-yourself Brooklyn concert promotion: In a small apartment in Bedford-Stuyvesant, a dozen young workers who could pass for American Apparel models crowded onto sofas one afternoon last week, typing furiously on laptops as they completed preparations for a rapidly approaching indie-rock festival.

headline: All Ramps and Spirals and Mosquito Landings
text: PARIS  There’s something both touching and disturbing at the heart of “Claude Parent: Graphic and Built Works,” a marvelous exhibition at the Cité de l’Architecture et du Patrimoine, Paris’s architecture museum, and it has to do with what the show tells us about our diminished cultural expectations.

headline: New Honor for the Designs That Get Movies Moving
text: LOS ANGELES  Can an introduction be an art form? The people who hand out film awards are beginning to think so.

headline: Obama Tries to Give Energy Bill a Push
text: President Obama, who is still hoping to get an energy bill through Congress this year, met Tuesday at the White House with lawmakers from both parties to try to push the process along.

headline: In Leno-Letterman Ratings Competition, a Split Decision
text: The ratings competition between Jay Leno and David Letterman got much tighter on Mr. Leno’s second Monday night back on NBC’s “Tonight Show.” Mr. Leno eked out a win over Mr. Letterman among total viewers, but among the viewer groups that NBC considers the real measure of success, Mr. Letterman was the winner.

headline: Plunging Into Uncharted Depths of Character
text: THE actress Elizabeth Marvel was 30 and newly arrived in Los Angeles a decade ago, after years on the New York stage, when producers of her CBS television series “The District,” began making a very Hollywoodish demand: Get Botox.

headline: A New Anthology of Gastronomica Magazine
text: “The Gastronomica Reader” (University of California Press, $39.95), an anthology of more than 40 essays from the thought-provoking food magazine of that name founded in 2001, edited by Darra Goldstein, is a volume to browse and absorb.

headline: Jazzman Turns 80, Pondering Music’s Metaphysics
text: Ornette Coleman is sitting at a table in the middle of his spacious loft, a fourth-floor aerie above the garment district bustle on West 36th Street in Midtown Manhattan.

headline: N.H.L. General Managers Nearer to Acting on Some Hits to the Head
text: BOCA RATON, Fla. — N.H.L. general managers moved closer Tuesday to recommending measures to penalize certain shoulder checks to the head, league officials said.

headline: Abbott to Buy Facet Biotech for 67% Premium
text: Abbott Laboratories announced late Tuesday that it had agreed to buy Facet Biotech for a net price of $450 million in cash, in a move aimed at expanding its drug pipeline, including for treatments for multiple sclerosis.

headline: Attacking Lawyers From the Right and Left
text: Is it fair to criticize lawyers for having represented Guantánamo detainees?

headline: Bank of America to End Debit Overdraft Fees
text: In a move that could bring an end to the $40 cup of coffee, Bank of America said on Tuesday that it was doing away with overdraft fees on purchases made with debit cards, a decision that could cost the bank tens of millions a year in revenue and put pressure on other banks to do the same.

headline: Some Unsettled Ghosts of Theater Past
text: ON a bitter Friday night last month about 50 people gathered in LaGuardia Community College’s main theater for a workshop presentation of “The Really Big Once,” Target Margin Theater’s new show exploring the making of Tennessee Williams’s 1953 play “Camino Real.” The result of an intense collaboration with the director Elia Kazan, “Camino Real,” with its carnivalesque mix of characters like Don Quixote, Camille, Casanova and Lord Byron, was a spectacular flop on Broadway. It received scathing reviews, closed within two months and haunted both men with “what ifs” for years to come. And yet this dreamlike play has endured, inspiring generations of experimentally minded theater artists.

headline: Alexander McQueen’s Final Show
text: Today, in a gilded salon in Paris, small groups of editors were invited to view the 16 pieces that Alexander McQueen had been working on before his death a few weeks ago. Artworks by Jean Fouquet, Sandro Boticelli, Stephan Lochner, Hans Memling, Hugo van der Goes and Hieronymus Bosch were captured digitally and transferred onto red, gold and silver dresses embellished with ornate embroideries. At this point, not much more can be said about the brilliance of McQueen’s work — consider, for example, a plumed dress for which each individual feather was painstakingly covered in gold leaf. Here is a slideshow of McQueen’s final collection.

headline: Trendspotting | Futuristic Visions
text: Designers in Paris seemed tuned to a frequency from cyberspace, steeped in sci-fi references.

headline: Variety Is Sued Over a Bad Review
text: Publishing a bad film review is one thing. Charging the filmmakers to promote the movie and then panning it may be quite another.

headline: R2D2 Would Love It
text: DESIGNERS in Paris this week seemed tuned to a frequency from cyberspace, so steeped were they in sci-fi references. Some paid homage not only to “Tron Legacy,” the forthcoming Disney release, and its companion video game, but to television fare like “Caprica.” Others found inspiration in vintage films like  “Blade Runner”  and even  “Metropolis.”

headline: Can Sackcloth Have Fur Trim?
text: PARIS

headline: Cheap and Tasty on the East Side
text: WHEN looking for Manhattan’s latest in cheap and tasty food, the East Village and Lower East Side have always been good places to start. New spots pop up all the time, catering to the area’s young eaters, who often have just a few bucks in their pockets. Some recent arrivals are very good.

headline: Retro Modern
text: First things first. Marc Newson goes to the fridge of his newly designed kitchen. “Do you want a drink?” he asks, and pulls out a lager. It’s 7 p.m. His wife, the stylist Charlotte Stockdale, is just putting their 2-year-old to bed. He’s unwinding. Tomorrow morning he flies to Italy to finish work on the speedboat he’s designing for Riva.

headline: What We’re Reading: Barbie, Steve and Carly
text: Tuesday’s roundup of interesting tidbits from around the Web, selected by the technology reporters and editors of The New York Times:

headline: Fresh Pork Rinds and Lard Dough at the Greenmarket
text: In the interest of not letting anything go to waste, Flying Pigs Farm in Shushan, N.Y., near Vermont in the Battenkill River Valley, has started selling fried pork rinds  chicharrones  along with meat and sausages from its heritage pigs. These tangled strips, below, are crisp, decidedly porky and salty, perfect for munching just as they are with beer. Stored airtight, they will keep for several days without losing their crunch.

headline: Bee Desserts Opens in the West Village
text: Little moist, chocolate-covered honey cakes wrapped in foil are the signatures at Bee Desserts, a cafe and bakery that Claudia Steves opened a few weeks ago. It replaced La Palette, a spot she owned for several years.

headline: Keith McNally Opens Pulino’s Bar & Pizzeria
text: For nearly two years Keith McNally has been performing one of his usual scavenging jobs for Pulino’s Bar & Pizzeria: exposing old brick and installing vintage light fixtures, wired glass, a new “old” tin ceiling and bottles  brown spirits, not wine, here  along the walls. The restaurant has 110 seats inside. During construction, deliveries were addressed to Kate Pulino, Mr. McNally’s project manager. And the name stuck.

headline: Strip House
text: EVERYTHING is new in New York save for that which is old, and when something goes from one to the other, the transition can be sudden and surprising: a wet foal that’s suddenly distinguished and large, a horse that rides with the weight of history on its back.

headline: Decaf With Pedigree and Flavor
text: AT coffee drinkers’ high school, the decaf crowd always sits at the losers’ table.

headline: Off the Menu
text: Openings

headline: New York Is Finally Taking Its Coffee Seriously
text: NEW YORK used to be a second-string city when it came to coffee. No longer.

headline: A Glossary of Coffee Terms
text: AFFOGATO

headline: Granderson Excited to Face Former Teammates
text: TAMPA, Fla. – Curtis Granderson said he had three games marked on his mental calendar. The first comes Wednesday, when he returns to Lakeland, Fla., to play the Tigers for the first time since being traded in December.

headline: An Eviction Stirs Old Ghosts in a Contested City
text: JERUSALEM — Having been removed in favor of Israeli nationalist Jews, members of the Palestinian Ghawi family have been sheltering this winter in a tent on the sidewalk opposite their home of more than five decades in the East Jerusalem neighborhood of Sheikh Jarrah.

headline: Not That Kind of Strip House
text: My restaurant review this week is of Strip House, the Greenwich Village steakhouse that opened a full decade ago in the space that was Asti, an Italian restaurant with singing waiters. (The restaurant had a role in the Tom Hanks movie, “Big.”)

headline: Dining Events From March 10 to 16
text: Talking Beef

headline: Upset by U.S. Security, Pakistanis Return as Heroes
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — A tour of the United States arranged by the State Department to improve ties to Pakistani legislators ended in a public relations fiasco when the members of the group refused to submit to extra airport screening in Washington, and they are now being hailed as heroes on their return home.

headline: On Rabbits as Food
text: To the Editor:

headline: Toyotas Are Safe (Enough)
text: Several months ago, a 63-year-old Harvard professor lost control of his 2005 Toyota Highlander, crashed into another car and died, along with two family members. Now the government is trying to decide whether Highlanders of this vintage are prone to sudden acceleration and should be added to the lengthy Toyota recall list.

headline: ‘Mad Men’ Dolls in a Barbie World, but the Cocktails Must Stay Behind
text: AFTER three seasons, “Mad Men,” the television series about advertising in the 1960s, has attained a level of popular-culture cachet. There have been magazine cover articles, calendars and an episode of “The Oprah Winfrey Show” all devoted to it, spoofs on “The Simpsons” and “Saturday Night Live,” and even a “Mad Men” category on “Jeopardy.”

headline: Pennsylvania Woman Tied to Plot on Cartoonist
text: WASHINGTON — A Pennsylvania woman who called herself JihadJane was tied Tuesday to an alleged assassination plot against a Swedish cartoonist who depicted the prophet Muhammad atop the body of a dog.

headline: Health Care’s Obstacle: No Will to Cut
text: For anyone who cares about medical costs — which is to say anyone who cares about the take-home pay of American families or about the budget deficit — President Obama’s health reform plan is a terribly mixed bag.

headline: In Ad, Democrats Cite G.O.P. Indifference to High Health Costs
text: Democrats are using examples of soaring health insurance premiums to link Republicans to the problem side of the health care equation.

headline: Hooping Already Has Its Own Jane Fonda
text: LIKE millions of Americans, Marisa Tomei used to play with a Hula-Hoop as a child. And like most of those same Americans, she hadn’t hooped since.

headline: Ex-Congressman Describes Tickle Fights With Aides
text: Former Representative Eric J. Massa of New York, who resigned from Congress amid allegations of sexual misconduct, vehemently denied any wrongdoing during a television appearance on Tuesday, even as he described having tickle fights with staff members in a house they shared.

headline: European Leaders Call for Crackdown on Derivatives
text: Goldman Sachs had a bright idea for its clients: buy credit-default swaps — those controversial instruments that helped trip up the American International Group — in case certain nations ran into financial trouble.

headline: Breezy Love, or the Sacking of the Bees
text: Birds do it. Bees do it. Beetles, bats and light summer breezes do it.

headline: A Small Scandal Overshadows a Big One, and a Governor Gets Breathing Space
text: It was late on Tuesday afternoon of last week when a lawyer turned to a man named Matthew Nelson, who had been testifying under oath at the office of the State Commission on Public Integrity.

headline: New Rules Sought on TV Retransmission
text: Trying to prevent the kind of brinkmanship that had ABC removing its affiliate station from millions of New York area homes hours before the Oscar broadcast, a group of television providers asked the government Tuesday to revamp the rules governing the retransmission of stations.

headline: Champagne Bubbles Are Extra
text: WHEN the world was young, there was a phenomenon loosely referred to as the Magical World of Television. Pains were taken to dazzle the eye. Chandeliers appeared extra-prismatic, with mescaline auras.

headline: Times Co. Appoints a Corporate Spokesman
text: The New York Times Company named Robert H. Christie as its senior vice president for corporate communications on Tuesday, hiring him away from Dow Jones & Company, the News Corporation unit that publishes The Wall Street Journal.

headline: Rollins Puts Away His Crystal Ball
text: Kissimmee, Fla.

headline: Broad Plan Urged to Fight New York’s Fiscal Crisis
text: ALBANY — New York could borrow billions of dollars to address its urgent budget shortfall and a financial review board would be established to impose new discipline on future spending under a five-year financial rescue plan that Lt. Gov. Richard Ravitch will present Wednesday.

headline: Santana, Though Rusty, Passes Test
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — The early signs for Johan Santana were not very good Tuesday, but as Mets fans may recall, Santana is a lot more reliable in September than in March.

headline: Francisco Cervelli’s Concussion Has Yanks’ Attention
text: TAMPA, Fla. — For the most part, Francisco Cervelli had a normal day Tuesday. In the morning, he stretched with teammates on a back field and played catch with Jorge Posada, took batting practice in the indoor cages and worked out with a medicine ball in the weight room.

headline: Film Review at Heart of Suit Against Variety
text: LOS ANGELES — In a step that is unusual even for litigation-heavy Hollywood, the maker of “Iron Cross,” a small independent film that has yet to find a distributor, charged in a complaint filed on Tuesday that the trade paper Variety had damaged the movie.

headline: Red Sox to Cubs, Millar Embraces Another Challenge
text: MESA, Ariz. — The Chicago Cubs’ clubhouse opened to reporters at 8 a.m. on Tuesday at HoHoKam Park, but Kevin Millar was not available. He was gathering his teammates for a version of “American Idol,” with Millar as a judge.

headline: Delay on Arms Pact Slows Reset of U.S.- Russia Ties
text: WASHINGTON — When President Obama got on the telephone with President Dmitri A. Medvedev of Russia last month, he was under the impression that they were finally close to wrapping up a long-delayed arms control treaty that he had originally expected to sign in December.

headline: Health Care Reform and the ‘Doc Fix’
text: The Democrats’ health care reform plan uses some accounting gimmicks that are fair game for criticism, as I note in my column this week. That said, though, one of the most common criticisms strikes me as pretty flimsy.

headline: David Kimche, an Israeli Adept as Spy and Diplomat, Dies at 82
text: JERUSALEM — David Kimche, a former Israeli spymaster and senior diplomat who was involved in some of the country’s most delicate foreign escapades, including the Iran-contra affair, which shook the Reagan administration in the 1980s, died on Monday at his home in Ramat Hasharon, a suburb of Tel Aviv. He was 82.

headline: St. John’s Rolls On, With No Fight From UConn
text: The saddest thing about the floor-burn victory by St. John’s on Tuesday is that it may not count for much. Connecticut was so apathetic that there is almost no way to gauge just where St. John’s is at the moment.

headline: Reyes Gets Encouraging News From Specialists
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Mets shortstop Jose Reyes has received encouraging news about the tests on his thyroid gland, his agent said Tuesday night.

headline: Paging Mr. Herman!
text: In his original 1985 review of "Pee-wee's Big Adventure," Vincent Canby wrote that the film "is the most barren comedy I've seen in years, maybe ever. It introduces motion picture audiences to a popular California comic named Pee-wee Herman, who seems to have put together his public personality by ransacking the wardrobes of his betters." Mr. Canby goes on to add, "Like Marcel Marceau, he appears to be physically slight and he often wears lipstick, but, unfortunately, he won't stop talking and  worse  laughing at his own gags. Like Jacques Tati, he wears pants that are too short, and like Jerry Lewis, he behaves as if he were a child trapped inside the body of a man. Like them all, he desperately wants to be funny but, unlike them, he isn't." Well, many fans of Paul Reubens, who has recently begun to perform again in Los Angeles, may choose to disagree. Tonight the Museum of Modern Art is screening the film, Tim Burton's feature debut.

headline: Triple Steps
text: "It's hard to think of a better modern/contemporary triple bill than Merce Cunningham, William Forsythe and Maguy Marin," writes Claudia La Rocco, "And hard to think of a company better suited to tackling such diverse choreographers than the Lyon Opera Ballet." This week the company returns to the Joyce Theater for the first time in more than 15 years. Go especially to see "Beach Birds" (1991), which makes the program "a must-see event; any chance now to see Cunningham's choreography seems precious, as his own company is in the early stages of its farewell international tour before disbanding in 2012. Soon, it seems, repertory ensembles like Lyon will be the main way in which we see Cunningham's miraculous dances live."

headline: Java Huts
text: New Yorkers can finally raise their chins when discussing their city and coffee in front of their West Coast brethren. "New York used to be a second-string city when it came to coffee," writes Oliver Strand. "No longer. Over the last two years, more than 40 new cafes and coffee bars have joined a small, dedicated group of establishments where coffee making is treated like an art, or at least a high form of craft." Head to places like the Bluebird Coffee Shop in the East Village, where "the espresso is so plush and bright that it tastes sweet on its own" or Third Rail Coffee in the West Village, which features "elaborate designs in the cappuccino's foam." Or try unusual spots like Saturdays Surf in SoHo and Moomah in TriBeCa. The coffee awakening means that "New Yorkers can now drink coffee that is made from some of the best beans available in the United States and freshly roasted in town." We'll drink to that.

headline: Another House Democrat Demands Abortion Restrictions
text: Representative Dan Lipinski, Democrat of Illinois, warned party leaders on Tuesday that he would vote against major health care legislation if it does not include tight restrictions on the use of federal money for insurance coverage of abortions.

headline: In Swirl of Paterson Scandal, 2nd State Police Superintendent Quits
text: The acting superintendent of the New York State Police announced his retirement Tuesday, becoming the second senior agency official to leave office since it was revealed that the agency had intervened in a domestic abuse case involving a top aide to Gov. David A. Paterson.

headline: In Illinois, Democrats Widen the Net
text: CHICAGO — This place is desperate to shed its political reputation for cronyism, insiders and backroom deals, a way of life once boiled down by a ward boss this way: “We don’t want nobody nobody sent.”

headline: Retaliation in Nascar Draws Only Probation
text: After imploring drivers to be more aggressive on the racetrack this season to help rebuild fading fan support, Nascar reinforced that message Tuesday by issuing a slap-on-the-wrist three-race probation to Carl Edwards for deliberately wrecking Brad Keselowski on Sunday at Atlanta Motor Speedway.

headline: State Agrees to Let the City Finish Brooklyn Bridge Park
text: After months of wrangling, state officials have agreed to let New York City finish building — and paying for — Brooklyn Bridge Park, in the hope of speeding its progress.

headline: Excerpts: Applications for No. 2
text: Applicants to be the Illinois Democrats' lieutenant governor nominee reflect a diversity of often unconventional qualifications for office.

headline: With Warning, a Hip Device Is Withdrawn
text: A unit of Johnson & Johnson, just months after saying it was phasing out an artificial hip implant because of slowing sales, has warned doctors that the device appears to have a high early failure rate in some patients.

headline: Another Rise in City Pupils Graduating in Four Years
text: For the fifth year in a row, New York City students’ on-time graduation rates have increased, showing small but steady gains, rising to 59 percent last year from 46.5 for the class of 2005, according to figures that state and city education officials released on Tuesday.

headline: Minister Withdraws as Investor in Aqueduct Casino
text: The Rev. Floyd H. Flake, one of New York’s most influential black pastors, announced on Tuesday that he had removed himself as an investor in the company that was chosen by Gov. David A. Paterson to build and operate a casino at the Aqueduct racetrack in Queens.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: March 9, 2010

headline: An Italian Antihero’s Time to Shine
text: ROME — By at least one amusing new metric, Michelangelo’s unofficial 500-year run at the top of the Italian art charts has ended. Caravaggio, who somehow found time to paint when he wasn’t brawling, scandalizing pooh-bahs, chasing women (and men), murdering a tennis opponent with a dagger to the groin, fleeing police assassins or getting his face mutilated by one of his many enemies, has bumped him from his perch.

headline: G.O.P. Sounds Out a Democrat for Governor
text: The Republican nomination for governor, which had for months seemed all but locked up by former United States Representative Rick A. Lazio, became a more unsettled contest on Tuesday when top New York Republicans met with the Suffolk County executive, Steve Levy, as a potential challenger to Mr. Lazio.

headline: As Fed Eases Loan Aid, Policy Challenges Arise
text: ARLINGTON, Va. — The Federal Reserve has terminated nearly all of the extraordinary lending programs it created in 2007 and 2008 to combat the credit crisis. But it now faces critical decisions in coming months about when and how to tighten monetary policy, according to two Fed officials.

headline: Offense Leads the Way as Seton Hall Moves On
text: Seton Hall guard Jordan Theodore has developed a reputation for being a whirl on the court. On Tuesday night, he was a steady hand, hitting all four of his 3-point attempts as his number was constantly called by Coach Bobby Gonzalez.

headline: Rodriguez Says He Is at Ease Amid Scrutiny
text: Alex Rodriguez said Tuesday that although federal investigators want to meet with him about his ties to a Canadian doctor who is under investigation for possibly distributing performance-enhancing drugs, he was at ease with the situation.

headline: It’s New York. It’s the Stadium. It’s the Pinstripe Bowl.
text: There was no welcome mat for sour thoughts at Yankee Stadium on Tuesday when the Yankees announced that the newest postseason college football game, the New Era Pinstripe Bowl, will be played there on Dec. 30.

headline: U.N. Honors the 101 Who Served and Died in Haiti
text: UNITED NATIONS — It took nearly 15 minutes to read the full roll call of the dead, as a photograph of each person, with the years of their birth and death, flashed on a screen in the darkened hall. White candles flickered on a dais covered with white hydrangeas, orchids and lilies.

headline: New York Triathlon Blocks Club From Using Similar Name
text: Apparently there is room for only one New York City Triathlon group in this town.

headline: In Britain, a Debate Over Care for the Elderly
text: LONDON — Every Tuesday, Janet Isobel Bishop walks the few blocks from her rented one-bedroom apartment in Notting Hill to a painting course, followed by tai chi lessons. The classes are paid for by the British government, just like the weekly one-hour visits she receives from a caregiver, who also helps her clean her home.

headline: 11 Down: Cricketer’s Need
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — Our final guest solver this week is Dan Feyer, winner of the 2010 American Crossword Puzzle Tournament. His notes about today’s puzzle appear below.

headline: Willie Davis Is Dead at 69; Was Snider’s Successor
text: Willie Davis, who succeeded Duke Snider as the center fielder for the Los Angeles Dodgers and used his blazing speed to steal 20 or more bases 11 straight years, led the National League in triples twice and set a record of three stolen bases in a World Series game, was found dead on Tuesday at his home in Burbank, Calif. He was 69.

headline: Henry Wittenberg, Champion Wrestler, Dies at 91
text: Henry Wittenberg, an Olympic gold and silver medalist who became one of America’s greatest amateur wrestlers while he was a New York City police officer, died on Tuesday at his home in Somers, N.Y. He was 91.

headline: No. 1 UConn Improvises to All-Too-Familiar Tune
text: HARTFORD — Kalana Greene, Connecticut’s senior guard, does not run up and down a basketball court as much as she bounces on the soles of her blue high-tops, fiercely vaulting from one spot to another, often displaying exquisite timing.

headline: 2 Reports of Trouble in Stopping Priuses
text: Just as Toyota was trying to reassure customers about the effectiveness of its recalls, two new reports of unintended acceleration emerged this week.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Monday about Iraq’s parliamentary elections on Sunday misstated a comparison in voter turnout to the last parliamentary elections, held in December 2005. The turnout on Sunday was lower, not higher. (Precise figures from Iraq’s election commission, which were not available until Monday, showed 62 percent of eligible voters cast ballots on Sunday, while 76 percent did in December 2005.)

headline: Attacks on Detainee Lawyers Split Conservatives
text: A conservative advocacy organization in Washington, Keep America Safe, kicked up a storm last week when it released a video that questioned the loyalty of Justice Department lawyers who worked in the past on behalf of detained terrorism suspects.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Sunday about United States government contracts and other benefits received by companies doing business in Iran misstated the date Honeywell, the aviation and aerospace company, notified the State Department that, while a British subsidiary would finish a refinery project in Iran, it would not undertake new projects there. It was January 2009, not last January.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on March 1 about attempts by Mohamed ElBaradei, the Egyptian diplomat and former director general of the International Atomic Energy Agency, to press Egypt’s leadership for more political freedoms after returning to his country misstated the year that the government first allowed challengers to run against President Hosni Mubarak, who has ruled for nearly 29 years. It was 2005, not 2006.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Monday about the future of catcher Joe Mauer, who is in the final year of his contract with the Minnesota Twins, erroneously attributed a distinction, in some copies, to Tony Oliva, who played for the Twins in the 1960s and 1970s. While Oliva was one of baseball’s top hitters, he is not in baseball’s Hall of Fame.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Tuesday about the Academy Awards ceremony on Sunday night, in citing past ceremonies where there was a sense of drama leading up to the award for best picture, misidentified the film that won that award at the ceremony in 2005. It was “Million Dollar Baby,” not “Crash,” which won the following year.

headline: New York's Best Coffee
text: Where to find great coffee in the city, day after day.

headline: Corrections
text: The TV Watch column in some copies on Monday, about the broadcast of the Academy Awards ceremony, which included a tribute by James Taylor to stars who had died in the past year, erroneously included Jean Simmons among those who died in 2009. She died this year, in January.

headline: Corrections
text: A picture caption in some copies on Monday with a fashion column about what female stars wore to the Academy Awards ceremony misidentified an actress in a silver outfit. She was Kate Winslet, not Amanda Seyfried. A credit in some copies misspelled the given name of the photographer who took the picture of Zoë Saldana. He is Andrew Gombert of the European Pressphoto Agency, not Andre.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Saturday about a video on the Funny or Die comedy Web site (funnyordie.com) that features presidential impersonators from “Saturday Night Live” and was intended to promote financial reforms referred imprecisely at one point to the involvement of the Congressional Oversight Panel. As the article noted elsewhere, the video was partly a result of a conversation between the director Ron Howard and Elizabeth Warren, chairwoman of the panel. No one else from the panel was involved.

headline: Applying for an Illinois Election
text: Monica Davey, Chicago Bureau Chief of The Times, discusses the Democratic Party's unusual tactic of soliciting online applications for the lieutenant governor nomination.

headline: Corrections
text: An obituary on Saturday about Andrew Jaffe, who presided over the expansion of the advertising trade magazine Adweek, misstated the history of the Clio Awards, which Mr. Jaffe took over for BPI Communications in 1997. Wallace A. Ross, who founded the awards in 1959, sold them in 1972; his company did not administer the Clios when ceremonies were disrupted and canceled in 1991.

headline: Corrections
text: An obituary on Friday about the nuclear engineer Thomas H. Pigford misspelled the surname of one of his stepdaughters. She is Janvrin Demler, not Janvrin Deler.

headline: Corrections
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: A One-Track Senate
text: THE Senate is badly gummed up. Major policy initiatives  health care reform and financial regulation, to name but two  are stalled in endless negotiations. There’s a big reason for this torpor: the filibuster. But there’s a solution: the filibuster. Don’t be confused. The two aren’t the same.

headline: Pilgrim Non Grata in Mecca
text: I was tempted to turn my abaya into a black masquerade cloak and sneak into Mecca, just hop over the Tropic of Cancer to the Red Sea and crash the ultimate heaven’s gate.

headline: Meet the Candidate: A Convicted Abuser
text: Former State Senator Hiram Monserrate’s story would seem to rule him out of any race for public office.

headline: In Support of Scientology
text: To the Editor:

headline: How to Use the New York Police Dept. Database
text: To the Editor:

headline: Financial Advisers
text: To the Editor:

headline: Darwin, Climate and the Skeptics
text: To the Editor:

headline: It’s Up to Iraqis Now. Good Luck.
text: Of all the pictures I saw from the Iraqi elections last weekend, my favorite was on nytimes.com: an Iraqi expatriate mother, voting in Michigan, holding up her son to let him stuff her ballot into the box. I loved that picture. Being able to freely cast a ballot for the candidate of your choice is still unusual for Iraqis and for that entire region. That mother seemed to be saying: When I was a child, I never got to vote. I want to live in a world where my child will always be able to.

headline: The Great Prostate Mistake
text: Tucson

headline: Saving the Post Office
text: Many Americans rely on six-days-a-week mail delivery and expect to have a post office just around the corner. But if the United States Postal Service is going to survive the transition to the Internet age  without requiring billions of dollars of federal subsidies  Congress must allow it to cut some services, close some offices and make other sensible changes.

headline: Laws, Lies and the Abortion Debate
text: It has been three years since the Supreme Court’s conservative majority abruptly departed from precedent to uphold a federal ban on a particular method of abortion. Emboldened, foes of reproductive freedom are pressing new attacks on women’s rights and health.

headline: An Advocate for Equal Justice
text: Providing poor defendants effective appointed counsel is more than a constitutional obligation. It is a concrete measure of the nation’s commitment to equal justice under law. Yet indigent defense offices across the nation have been allowed to sink into crisis. They have fallen victim to insufficient financing, overwhelming caseloads and a slew of policies that hamper effective representation.

headline: The Fired Teachers
text: To the Editor:

headline: John Thorbjarnarson, a Crocodile and Alligator Expert, Is Dead at 52
text: Let’s say you are a boy who collects frogs and snakes from a neighborhood bog and who keeps a spectacled caiman and boa constrictor as pets. Further, you take the boa into the family pool to cavort, although the human swimmers might have used a different verb.

headline: Q&A: Shirley Tafoya, President of Travelzoo North America
text: Whenever I offer tips on cheap travel deals, one name keeps popping up on the blog comments: “Why is Travelzoo not mentioned in this article?” There’s simple reason: I never got around to checking out the site. That is, until last week, when I was poking around the Web.

headline: A Consumer Bill Gives Exemption on Payday Loans
text: WASHINGTON — Senator Bob Corker, the Tennessee Republican who is playing a crucial role in bipartisan negotiations over financial regulation, pressed to remove a provision from draft legislation that would have empowered federal authorities to crack down on payday lenders, people involved in the talks said. The industry is politically influential in his home state and a significant contributor to his campaigns, records show.

headline: Airbus’s Parent, Still Confident, Blames Cost Overruns for Net Loss in 2009
text: PARIS — Huge cost overruns at two of its biggest aircraft programs pushed European Aeronautic Defense and Space into a steep loss for 2009. But EADS, the parent company of Airbus, expressed confidence on Tuesday that new financing for its A400M military transport plane and a recovery in demand for commercial aircraft would help restore it to profitability this year.

headline: Eurotunnel Eked Out Profit in Tough ’09
text: PARIS — The Eurotunnel Group said on Tuesday that it managed a profit in 2009, despite repercussions from a 2008 fire and the disastrous breakdown of Eurostar trains at the height of the year-end travel season.

headline: After Victory Over Disney, Group Loses Its Lease
text: For a few days last fall, the Campaign for a Commercial-Free Childhood celebrated a big victory: the tiny advocacy group had successfully pushed the Walt Disney Company to offer full refunds to everyone who had bought the company’s popular Baby Einstein videos from June 2004 to September 2009.

headline: Federation Updates Its Drug Policy. Why?
text: The World Chess Federation, the governing body of the game, released new “antidoping rules” for players on Tuesday. The rules replace, or update, previous guidelines.

headline: Statues Seem Ready to Leap, but Police Say They Won’t
text: They stand about six feet tall and look like naked human beings. Over the next few days, 27 of them will be scattered across rooftops and ledges of buildings in Midtown Manhattan — including the Empire State Building — as part of a public art exhibition.

headline: Florida Ponders Tax as Tool to Aid Family-Values Films
text: MIAMI — The movie “Bait Shop” had too much boozing to earn the extra rebate from Florida’s “family friendly” program of incentives for film production. “Confessions of a Shopaholic” was, well, just too violent.

headline: Kroger’s Sales Rise, but Profit Declines 27%
text: The Kroger Company said on Tuesday that its fourth-quarter profit fell 27 percent as rising health care and labor costs offset a 7 percent increase in sales.

headline: Parliamentary Hurdle Could Thwart Latest Health Care Overhaul Strategy
text: WASHINGTON — The White House and Democratic Congressional leaders said Tuesday that they were bracing for a key procedural ruling that could complicate their effort to approve major health care legislation, by requiring President Obama to sign the bill into law before Congress could revise it through an expedited budget process.

headline: Q. and A. With Ken Nye of Ninth Street Espresso
text: After reading Oliver Strand’s exploration of the dozens of new places in New York serving meticulously crafted coffee, you might be dying for a cup. Or you might find yourself wondering about the intricacies of great espresso, the secrets of roasting and what it takes to run a top-tier coffee bar. Ken Nye at Ninth Street Espresso can take care of your thirst for knowledge and coffee.

headline: Time to Celebrate? Not in a Big Way
text: Anniversaries are a good time to reminisce. The global stock market rally is now a year old — the lows were hit on March 9, 2009 — and that certainly brings back memories. It’s easy to see why the MSCI World Index has surged 71 percent in that period.

headline: Google Opens App Store for Business Software
text: Google on Tuesday introduced an online store for business applications in an effort to further push its own suite of productivity software into companies and to compete with Microsoft.

headline: Google Maps Adds Directions for Cyclists
text: Cycling enthusiasts tend to be a passionate bunch. So it is not surprising that there are lots of questions about biking information on Google Maps forums. One group, called googlemapsbikethere.org, has collected more than 51,000 signatures asking Google to add biking directions to its maps.

headline: MGM Said to Be Considering a Prepackaged Bankruptcy
text: With about 10 days to go before the next round of bids are due, Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer is still considering other options to help reorganize its almost $4 billion debt load. The options include a potential stand-alone bankruptcy plan, people with direct knowledge of the matter said Tuesday.

headline: Word of the Day | whorl
text: whorl •\ˈhwȯr(-ə)l, ˈwȯr(-ə)l, ˈ(h)wər(-ə)l\• noun

headline: A Push to Supplement Tuesday Voting With Weekends
text: SAN FRANCISCO — San Francisco would become an electoral test tube under a proposed ballot measure to establish a second day of voting in next year’s general election, the Saturday before the traditional Tuesday in November.

headline: Many Nations Passing U.S. in Education, Expert Says
text: One of the world’s foremost experts on comparing national school systems told lawmakers on Tuesday that many other countries were surpassing the United States in educational attainment, including Canada, where he said 15-year-old students were, on average, more than one school year ahead of American 15-year-olds.

headline: Bruce J. Graham, Chicago Architect Who Designed Sears Tower, Dies at 84
text: Bruce J. Graham, whose integration of modernist design and sophisticated engineering in buildings like the John Hancock Center and the Sears Tower transformed the skyline of Chicago and reasserted the city’s pre-eminence as a world architectural capital, died on Saturday at his home in Hobe Sound, Fla. He was 84.

headline: Loss Dims Future of Rutgers Coach
text: With Rutgers’ 69-68 loss to Cincinnati on Tuesday night in the first round of the Big East Tournament, the school now faces a decision on the future of Coach Fred Hill.

headline: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Night of the Comebacks
text: Nine games on Tuesday, and six of them were comeback victories. Home teams listed first:

headline: MGM Said to Consider Prepackaged Bankruptcy
text: With about 10 days to go before the next round of bids are due, Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer is still considering other options to help reorganize its almost $4 billion debt load. They include a potential stand-alone bankruptcy plan, people with direct knowledge of the matter said Tuesday, Michael J. de la Merced reports in The New York Times.

headline: Edgar Wayburn, a Leader in Saving the Wilderness, Dies at 103
text: Edgar Wayburn, a physician who joined the Sierra Club to take a burro trip and then went on to become a major figure in the conservation movement, leading campaigns that preserved more than 100 million wild acres, died Friday at his home in San Francisco. He was 103.

headline: Irish Rethinking Football Independence
text: Calling the state of college sports the most unstable he has seen in 29 years, Notre Dame Athletic Director Jack Swarbrick said Tuesday that the Irish were considering giving up their football independence.

headline: Correction
text: An article last Wednesday about Blue Bottle Coffee opening a coffee bar and roaster in Brooklyn misstated its Web address. It is bluebottlecoffee.net, not bluebottle.net.

headline: Is the Fred Hill Era Done at Rutgers?
text: It was hard to listen to Rutgers Coach Fred Hill early Wednesday morning and not think that he sounded a bit delusional. Hill has won 13 Big East games in his four years as Rutgers coach. His team finished No. 14 in the league this year and won’t be playing in any postseason games after going 15-17.

headline: Letters of Condolence From 1963
text: WHO wrote letters of condolence to Mrs. Kennedy in the months after John F. Kennedy’s assassination in 1963? WHO went through the archives of those letters to publish 250 of them?

headline: News Quiz | March 10, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page.

headline: Apollo Said to Buy Citi’s Real Estate Unit
text: Apollo Management agreed to buy Citigroup’s real estate investment unit in a move that would more than triple the value of the private-equity firm’s property assets, a person with knowledge of the deal told Bloomberg News on Tuesday.

headline: Time to Celebrate? Not in a Big Way
text: Anniversaries are a good time to reminisce, Breakingviews says. The global stock market rally is now a year old — the lows were hit on March 9, 2009 — and that certainly brings back memories.

headline: In Europe, Calls for Crackdown on Derivatives
text: Goldman Sachs had a bright idea for its clients: buy credit-default swaps — those controversial instruments that helped trip up the American International Group — in case certain nations ran into financial trouble.

headline: Wintrust Raises $182.9 Million in Offering
text: Wintrust Financial, which operates community bank subsidiaries, said Tuesday it sold 5.8 million shares in a public offering that netted about $182.9 million, The Associated Press reported.

headline: As Fed Eases Loan Aid, Policy Challenges Arise
text: The Federal Reserve has terminated nearly all of the extraordinary lending programs it created in 2007 and 2008 to combat the credit crisis. But it now faces critical decisions in coming months about when and how to tighten monetary policy, according to two Fed officials.

headline: Equity One to Launch Stock Offering
text: Equity One, the shopping center owner, said Tuesday it would sell 4.2 million shares of stock in a public offering, The Associated Press reported.

headline: What Signs of Seasonal Change Are You Seeing?
text: The temperature in New York City has nudged above 50 for five days in a row now, and after a winter of record snow, many New Yorkers are feeling giddy. What signs of seasonal change are you seeing where you live? What is your reaction to them?

headline: Geely Said to Lock in Volvo Financing
text: Zhejiang Geely Holding, the Chinese carmaker that struck a deal with Ford in December to by its Swedish unit Volvo, has finally secured the necessary financing, people with knowledge of the matter told DealBook.

headline: V.C.’s Shower FirstRain With Financing
text: FirstRain, an investment research service, has landed a $7.3 million tranche of an expected $8.8 million financing round, VentureBeat reported, citing a regulatory filing.

headline: Todacell Rings Up Another $1 Million
text: Todacell, a smartphone advertising network, has rounded up an additional $1 million to top off an existing $1 million round that the start-up landed in June, PaidContent reported.

headline: Zhang Hong’s Letter About His Editorial
text: This letter, by Zhang Hong, a Chinese journalist who was fired after writing an editorial that criticized China’s household registration system, was released Tuesday to selected Chinese and foreign journalists and translated by the New York Times Beijing bureau.

headline: Citi Brings Former Tribridge Manager on Board
text: Citigroup has tapped a former hedge fund manager at Tribridge Investment Partners, John Liptak, to lead the bank’s Asia- Pacific distressed and special situations group, Bloomberg News reported, citing an internal memo.

headline: Citi Said to Plan $2 Billion Securities Sale
text: Citigroup, seeking to bolster capital after repaying bailout funds to the Treasury, is selling trust-preferred securities as rising investor demand drives borrowing costs to near the lowest in almost five years, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: U.S. Regulators Said to Tell Banks to Keep Cash
text: While banks like JPMorgan and Goldman Sachs have enough liquidity to consider raising dividends or buying back stock, regulators have told U.S. banks to preserve their cash for the moment, The Financial Times reported, citing unidentified sources.

headline: American Idol: A Place Holder Departs?
text: Let me start with a positive: this will be Paige Miles‘s last week on “American Idol.” That’s good news – for her, for the viewers, for the “Idol” system that allowed her to make the top 24 without properly vetting her in the court of popular opinion. Despite Simon’s continued insistence that Ms. Miles has one of the best voices of this season, she’s been inconsistent and charmless, and her rendition of “Smile” this week was awkward and shaky, a final affirmation of her place-holder status.

headline: Gartmore Swings to Profit in 2009
text: Gartmore Group, the London-based fund manager that went public in December, returned to profit in 2009 and said it was seeing strong inflows into its hedge funds, according to press reports.

headline: ‘Love Never Dies’
text: Photos from Andrew Lloyd Webber’s sequel to “The Phantom of the Opera.”

headline: Showcase: God Is in the Details
text: Godless? New York? Please. The city where Mitzvah Tanks patrol the streets and subway evangelists shout “Hallelujah” over the roar of trains and supplicants eke out nooks in which to place their prayer rugs and face the Kaaba at Mecca; the city where St. Pat’s is both an event and a landmark? God (or at least one man’s self-proclaimed interpretation) is evident outside Trinity Church at the head of Wall Street. And there are New Yorkers who would look at this simple sidewalk shadow and see a heavenly manifestation. God, you might say, is everywhere.

headline: Stanford and Madoff Groups Team Up for Lobby
text: Who should pay for the lies told by swindlers and the mistakes made by their investors?

headline: Palestinians Hold to Plan for New Talks
text: RAMALLAH, West Bank — Palestinian leaders meeting with Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. here on Wednesday harshly condemned Israel’s decision, announced a day earlier, to add 1,600 housing units for Jews in East Jerusalem, but they gave no indication that they would stay away from the approaching indirect peace negotiations with the Israelis.

headline: Caution Rules as Major Indexes Inch Forward
text: On the one-year anniversary of the stock market’s plunge to 12-year lows, Wall Street found itself at another crossroads. This time, the question for investors was not so much whether the economy would turn around, but just how strong a recovery would be, The New York Times’s Javier C. Hernandez reported.

headline: Airport Built, It’s Time to See if the Traffic Comes
text: The first new international airport in the United States in more than decade is set to open in May near Panama City, Fla., a community of 37,000 people on the state’s panhandle. That is no small feat given the environmental, regulatory and financial hurdles involved in building runways and terminals, as well as community opposition to planes flying overhead.

headline: C.E.O. Bonuses Fell 22% In 2009, Study Says
text: U.S. consumer, financial and technology companies slashed bonuses for their chief executives by more than half in 2009, a leading firm that tracks pay data said on Tuesday, as companies moved to more closely tie executive pay to performance.

headline: A.I.G. Said to Devise New Formula for Bonuses
text: The American International Group will soon adopt its new “forced ranking” system to determine bonuses and rate employee performance, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing people familiar with the matter.

headline: Digital Billboards: A View From the Industry
text: To the Editor:

headline: Britain’s Northern Rock Returns to Profit
text: Northern Rock, the nationalized British mortgage lender, said on Wednesday that it returned to profit in the second half of 2009 as interest income rose and losses on loans fell, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Paris: McQueen Was Here
text: Someday there will be a retrospective of the fashion of Alexander McQueen, and if it ends with the 15 pieces shown here in a small salon the survey will indeed feel complete. The final collection of the designer, who committed suicide on Feb. 11, saw him returning to the historical past, in particular medieval symbols of faith and morality.

headline: Finance Reform Bill May Exempt Payday Lenders
text: Senator Bob Corker, the Tennessee Republican who is playing a crucial role in bipartisan negotiations over financial regulation, pressed to remove a provision from draft legislation that would have empowered federal authorities to crack down on payday lenders, people involved in the talks said. The industry is politically influential in his home state and a significant contributor to his campaigns, records show.

headline: Walking the ArtWalk in Hong Kong
text: Hong Kong’s biggest gallery crawl snakes through the city on March 17, when 62 galleries open their doors for the 10th annual ArtWalk (hongkongartwalk.com), an entertaining evening of art, food and drink that raises money for local charities. Tickets, which cost 430 Hong Kong dollars ($56.50, at 7.60 Hong Kong dollars to the U.S. dollar) and are on sale at six sites around town, listed on the event’s Web site, offer access to participating galleries, the bulk of them in and around SoHo, a short walk from the Central district. And 56 area restaurants, each one teamed with a gallery, will offer finger food, wine and beer. John Batten, the organizer of ArtWalk, is expecting a similar crowd to last year’s event, which drew about 2,000 visitors.

headline: Questions Answered: Invented Languages
text: In January, co-vocabularists were invited to pose questions to two experts in the field of invented languages: Paul Frommer (the developer of Avatar’s novel tongue, Na’vi) and Arika Okrent (author of “In the Land of Invented Languages”).

headline: Making a Killing on ‘Death Bonds’?
text: In an unusual type of bond deal that might have had even Freud pondering its morbid implications, companies like the American International Group, Bank of America and GE Capital issue discounted bonds to buyers who have teamed up with someone who is about to die, The Wall Street Journal reports.

headline: Music Without Octaves
text: Today’s idea: An alternative musical system has attracted adherents around the world seeking to move beyond the basic building blocks of Western music and to discover how the brain learns a musical language.

headline: More Wires in Galleon Probe, Report Says
text: Federal prosecutors wired several cooperating witnesses in the Galleon Group insider trading case in order to obtain information on other targets of the investigation, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing people familiar with the matter.

headline: Partial Iraq Vote Results Expected Thursday
text: BAGHDAD — Iraq’s electoral commission is expected to announce partial results of parliamentary elections by Thursday, a United Nations official said, offering an incomplete picture of the vote that will nevertheless provide the broad outlines of the country’s political landscape.

headline: U.S. Defense Chief Visits Saudi Arabia to Bolster Effort Against Iran
text: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia — Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates told the royal family of Saudi Arabia on Wednesday that the United States wanted to help build up the kingdom’s military defenses against the growing threat of Iran, but also needed its help in pressing for new United Nations sanctions on Tehran.

headline: Living With Music: A Playlist by Michael Moorcock
text: Michael Moorcock’s science fiction and fantasy novels include the Cornelius chronicles and the Eternal Champions series, featuring the character Elric of Melniboné. His second Hawkmoon novel, “The Mad God’s Amulet,” will be published in April.

headline: China Mobile Puts $5.8 Billion Into Pudong Bank
text: China Mobile, the world’s largest mobile carrier, said it would pay $5.8 billion for 20 percent of Shanghai Pudong Development Bank and would jointly develop mobile finance and e-commerce businesses with the bank, Reuters reported.

headline: Suspect’s Death Leads to Questions on Indonesia’s Border Security
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia — The fugitive Islamic militant killed by Indonesian security forces traveled to Indonesia from the Philippines within the last few months, police officals said on Wednesday, an admission that raised concerns about the country’s ability to keep known terrorists from moving across its borders.

headline: Did the Minimum Wage Increase Destroy Jobs?
text: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

headline: For Buyout Shops, a Decade to Spend Capital?
text: Buyout shops may have some trouble unloading the half-trillion dollars sitting in their coffers, waiting for deals.

headline: Speed Read for Wednesday, March 10
text: Here are some highlights from Wednesday’s editions of The New York Times:

headline: Sampler: Second Election Day Proposed in San Francisco, and San Jose Voters to Decide on More Gambling
text: San Francisco Considers Two Polling Days | A proposed ballot measure would make San Francisco an electoral test tube  by adding a second day of voting — the Saturday before the Tuesday — in general elections held in November. Other states like Louisiana have similar programs but not for the biennial general elections. Alex Tourk, a political consultant who is organizing the campaign for the measure, said he wanted to increase access to the polls and make it easier for people with work and child care issues to vote. “Weekday voting creates barriers,” he said. The proposal needs 7,178 signatures from registered voters to qualify for November’s ballot. [The New York Times]

text: Your Jokes | Use the comment link below. One joke per comment, please:

headline: Lone Star Puts Korean Bank Back Up for Sale
text: The private equity fund Lone Star plans to resume selling a $3.9 billion majority stake in Korea Exchange Bank, K.E.B. said, in what would rank as South Korea’s biggest banking deal to date, Reuters reported.

headline: The Early Word: Jobs Vote, Health Push
text: A $140 billion jobs bill that would provide tax breaks for businesses and extend unemployment aid through December is up for a vote on the Senate floor Wednesday.

headline: Rhodes Criticizes Jets; Anderson Criticizes Browns Fans
text: Kerry Rhodes and Derek Anderson may have a little extra motivation the next time they face their former teams.

headline: Wal-Mart Is Top GPS Destination, Says One Report
text: To understand societal trends and where America is going, you don’t necessarily need to conduct a census. All one may have to do is look at how people use their GPS devices.

headline: The Future’s So Bright …
text: One day, genetic researchers may be able to manipulate cow cells into growing cruelty-free in-vitro leather, or even magical disembodied hamburgers. But in the meantime, they’ve been teaching Joris Laarman — the science-obsessed Dutch designer whose computer-generated Bone Chair caused a frenzy among collectors in 2007 — how to put their experiments to good use. Laarman’s new biomorphic furniture, on view now at the New York gallery Friedman Benda, includes a lamp coated in genetically modified hamster cells that have been engineered to light up like those inside a firefly. Housed in a glass dome “fed” liquid nutrients and an enzyme, the lamp glows without electricity. “If products can be grown in a lab, we won’t have to use natural resources,” Laarman says. “It’s the most perfect production method there is.” Granted, the lamp’s cells run according to their own biorhythm, “charging” during the day and emitting light at night — so there’s no on and off switch. But hey, anything’s better than compact fluorescents.

headline: California to Regulate ‘Most Potent’ Greenhouse Gas
text: Starting in 2011, California will regulate emissions from electric utility equipment of the gas sulfur hexafluoride — commonly called SF6. It is typically used in high voltage transmission systems in circuit breakers, switches and insulation, according to a recent California Air Resources Board announcement.

headline: Second State Police Superintendent Resigns
text: The acting superintendent of the New York State Police announced his retirement Tuesday, becoming the second senior agency official to leave office in a matter of days, since it was revealed that the agency had intervened in a domestic abuse case involving a top aide to Gov. David A. Paterson.

headline: Market Rises on Sense That Worst Is Behind Big Financials
text: A renewed sense that Wall Street’s biggest financial companies had endured the worst of the economic downturn helped lead the stock market higher on Wednesday.

headline: Corey Haim, Actor, Has Died
text: 12:53 p.m. | Updated Corey Haim, an actor whose status as a teenage heartthrob of the 1980s gave way to harsh adult realities of substance abuse and rehabilitation, has died, the Los Angeles Police Department said on Wednesday. He was 38.

headline: WWS 543, March 10
text: Notes. (pdf)

headline: ‘Spider-Man’ Musical Loses Its Mary Jane
text: The long delays hindering the anticipated Broadway musical “Spider-Man, Turn Off the Dark” has claimed another casualty: The actress Evan Rachel Wood, who was set to play Mary Jane Watson in the show, has dropped out because of a scheduling conflict, according to a statement from the “Spider-Man” producers.

headline: Alberta’s Tar Sands and the Dead Duck Trial
text: In an Alberta court, the oil sands giant Syncrude Canada has entered the second week of a high-profile case brought by federal and provincial prosecutors over the widely publicized deaths two years ago of 1,600 migrating ducks that were trapped in the toxic sludge floating on one of the company’s vast tailings ponds.

headline: Terra Deems CF’s New Bid Superior to Yara’s Offer
text: Terra Industries said on Wednesday that it had deemed a new $4.7 billion takeover offer by CF Industries Holdings superior to a $4.1 billion deal it had already signed with Yara International of Norway.

headline: Panel Proposes Single Standard for All Schools
text: A panel of educators convened by the nation’s governors and state school superintendents proposed a uniform set of academic standards on Wednesday, laying out their vision for what all the nation’s public school children should learn in math and English, year by year, from kindergarten to high school graduation.

headline: ‘Lost’ Watch: Able Was I Ere I Saw Elba
text: Warning: This post contains spoilers.

headline: Google Maps Adds Biking Routes
text: Starting today, Google is offering biking routes in 150 American cities in Google Maps, giving travelers another way to see the sites. According to the Gagetwise blog, “Google Maps will also offer a “view” geared for cyclists that will display bike-friendly routes. A mobile version is likely to follow soon, said Shannon Guymon, a product manager for Google Maps Directions.” Read more…

headline: Model-morphosis | Valentino
text: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of Paris Fashion Week. Here, the model Jacquelyn Jablonski from Ford Model Management before (left, right) and after makeup by Pat McGrath and hair by Luigi Murenu. (Drag the orange bar left to reveal the full transformation.)

headline: Iranian Leader and Gates Trade Jabs in Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — The Iranian president visited Kabul on Wednesday and shot back at American allegations that Iran was providing support to Afghan insurgents, accusing the United States of playing its own “double game.”

headline: Broken Record: Music Chief Is Out at EMI
text: The troubled music company EMI announced Wednesday that Elio Leoni-Sceti, the chief executive of its recorded music division, would step down at the end of the month. The company gave no reason for Mr. Leoni-Sceti’s unexpected departure.

headline: Foreign Leagues May Be Players’ Trump Card
text: Is it time to rethink the summer of LeBron James?

headline: Helped by Olympics, ‘NBC Nightly News’ Has a Big February
text: How many new viewers did the Winter Olympics deliver to NBC’s nightly newscast? About a million, Nielsen numbers indicate.

headline: The Drop Stops: Paterson’s Poll Numbers Level Off
text: Gov. David A. Paterson’s approval rating among voters is as low as it has ever been, according to a Quinnipiac University poll released Wednesday.

headline: From Arms to Entitlements
text: Over the past four decades, the amount of money the United States spends on Medicare, Medicaid and Social Security has more than doubled as a share of the economy. In 1970, the federal government spent 3.8 percent of gross domestic product on these programs. By 2007, the percentage had risen to 8.2 percent.

headline: Wednesday Reading
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Columbus Rallies for a Tie in Concacaf Champions League
text: Do blond strikers have more fun and score more goals?

headline: How Oscar Found Ms. Right
text: KATHRYN BIGELOW’S two-fisted win at the Academy Awards for best director and best film for “The Hurt Locker” didn’t just punch through the American movie industry’s seemingly shatterproof glass ceiling; it has also helped dismantle stereotypes about what types of films women can and should direct. It was historic, exhilarating, especially for women who make movies and women who watch movies, two groups that have been routinely ignored and underserved by an industry in which most films star men and are made for and by men. It’s too early to know if this moment will be transformative  but damn, it feels so good.

headline: Retro Modern
text: First things first. Marc Newson goes to the fridge of his newly designed kitchen. “Do you want a drink?” he asks, and pulls out a lager. It’s 7 p.m. His wife, the stylist Charlotte Stockdale, is just putting their 2-year-old to bed. He’s unwinding. Tomorrow morning he flies to Italy to finish work on the speedboat he’s designing for Riva.

headline: Increasing Yields and Decreasing Fertilizer Waste on Subsistence Farms
text: A new agricultural technology that cuts nitrogen fertilizer waste in half while increasing rice yields is spreading quickly in Bangladesh and is being investigated by 15 other nations, including more than a dozen in sub-Saharan Africa.

headline: Oscar Winners Plot Next Moves
text: We know, we know, you’re still hungry for Oscar news. The Bagger will help you deal with that craving for a few more days. Our first dish: The Los Angeles Times rounds up the future plans of some of the winners.

headline: Rodriguez Says Lawyers Are Scheduling Interview With Authorities
text: Alex Rodriguez said Wednesday that his lawyers were working on scheduling an interview with federal authorities who are investigating a Canadian-based doctor suspected of distributing performance-enhancing drugs. Rodriguez said he hoped the interview would be in Florida and not Buffalo, so it would not interfere with his preparation for the season.

headline: Brown, Senator and G.O.P. Star, Will Write Memoir
text: Scott P. Brown, the Republican politician from Massachusetts who pulled out a surprise victory in January to win the United States Senate seat long held by the Democrat Edward M. Kennedy, will write a memoir about his life and political career, the publisher HarperCollins said on Wednesday. Mr. Brown, who served in the Massachusetts House of Representatives and State Senate before defeating Martha Coakley, the attorney general and Democratic candidate, in a special election, said he would write about his family background and ascent to office, as well as his values and policies of interest to him. “I am humbled to have the opportunity to share my personal story in hopes to inform, encourage and inspire others,” Mr. Brown said in a statement.

headline: White House Spars With the Chief Justice
text: The White House is hitting back against criticism from Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. on Tuesday, when he complained about the political scene surrounding the State of the Union speech when President Obama criticized a Supreme Court decision on campaign financing.

headline: Answers About the Gowanus Canal
