headline: Concocting a Cure for Kids With Issues
text: If you’re the parent of a child who’s having trouble learning or behaving in school, you quickly find yourself confronted with a series of difficult choices.

headline: Tycoon Wins Libel Suit in Ex-Spy’s Murder Case
text: Boris A. Berezovsky, a self-exiled Russian tycoon, won a libel suit in London on Wednesday against a Russian satellite broadcaster that had linked him to the murder in 2006 of Alexander V. Litvinenko, a onetime aide and former K.G.B. operative who was poisoned with a rare radioactive isotope.

headline: ‘South Park’ at 200: Trey Parker and Matt Stone Apologize to No One
text: Maybe the secret to longevity isn’t clean living or exercise, but anger. In its 13 years, “South Park,” the Comedy Central animated series, has thrived on a diet of vitriol — usually directed at it by the targets of its willfully crude satire. In recent seasons the show has taken aim at Tom Cruise and the Church of Scientology, Kanye West (before he imploded at the MTV Video Music Awards) and “Avatar” (saddling it with the uncomplimentary nickname “Dances With Smurfs” before it opened); and been protested by organizations from the Catholic League to the Gay & Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation.

headline: Photos of the Moment | Gallic Chic
text: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Kevin Tachman.

headline: Q. and A.: The Economics of Coffee Bars
text: Ken Nye, owner of Ninth Street Espresso, responds to readers’ questions about coffee and coffee bars:

headline: Yoink if You Want Free Stuff
text: Your spring cleaning and refurnishing efforts could get some help this year from Yoink, a new iPhone app and Web site which lists items nearby that are free for the taking.

headline: ‘Purple, Pink, Green’
text: Monologue |  Tuesday night on “Late Night With Jimmy Fallon” on NBC: The White House unveiled its official eggs for the 2010 Easter Egg Roll on April 5. The official eggs come in purple, pink, green and, why are we talking about Easter eggs instead of health care?

headline: Rove on Rove: A Conversation With the Former Bush Senior Adviser
text: Karl Rove, the former senior adviser and deputy White House chief of staff under President George W. Bush, on Tuesday published a memoir, “Courage and Consequence: My Life as a Conservative in the Fight.” The Times caught up with him in New York to talk about democracy in Iraq, the impact of the C.I.A. leak case and questions about his mother’s suicide and his father’s sexual orientation. This is an edited transcript:

headline: Live Updates From the Big East Tournament, Day 2
text: Four more games are on the schedule Wednesday at the Big East men’s basketball tournament. The Times’s Pete Thamel and Kevin Armstrong, along with Zach Hillesland, a former Notre Dame forward who is now an academic adviser in the athletic department, are at Madison Square Garden and will provide analysis and updates throughout the day. Readers are invited to join the conversation in the comment section below. Georgetown 69, South Florida 49Marquette 57, St. John’s 55

headline: ‘An Elaborate Hoax’
text: Monologue |  Tuesday night on “The Late Show With David Letterman” on CBS: In the morning here at CBS, they have “The Early Show.” Tomorrow on “The Early Show,” host Harry Smith is having a live colonoscopy. I know what you’re thinking: Finally, real breakfast fun. Here we go. Bring it on.

headline: Ex-N.Y. Investment Officer Pleads Guilty to Corruption
text: The former chief investment official for New York State’s comptroller’s office pleaded guilty on Wednesday to a felony for his role in steering investment opportunities in the state’s pension fund to firms connected to former state officials.

headline: ‘Tourism is Way Down’
text: Monologue |  Tuesday night on “The Jay Leno Show” on NBC: Well, big changes announced today for the next Indianapolis 500. All the cars will be Toyota Priuses.

headline: Planet Green Moves Away From Its Eco Theme
text: The two-year-old Planet Green cable channel doesn’t want to be defined by a single color anymore.

headline: Not Noticing That You’re Pregnant
text: These stories make the news every so often, and each time I see one I marvel anew.

headline: Courtside Fan Has a Hand in the Game
text: As if the Toronto Raptors did not have enough to worry Tuesday night, playing the Los Angeles Lakers at the Staples Center, guard Jose Calderon also had to battle a fan sitting courtside for possession of the ball.

headline: The New Yorker and New York Set the Pace in National Magazine Awards
text: Once again, The New Yorker and New York magazine lead in the running for the annual National Magazine Awards, with each magazine named 10 times in the list of finalists released on Wednesday. National Geographic, whose critical acclaim has grown in the last few years, is a seven-time finalist, followed by Esquire, GQ and Wired with six each; and The New York Times Magazine and Vanity Fair with five apiece.

headline: Most Believe God Gets Involved
text: When the “American Idol” judge Simon Cowell recently predicted the departure of the contestant Jermaine Sellers, the young singer shook his head in disagreement. “I know God,’’ he replied, pointing upward.

headline: Home Before He Knew He Was Pardoned
text: On Tuesday night, four days after Gov. David A. Paterson announced that he had pardoned a young information technology executive who had risen from immigrant poverty and street crime in Chinatown, the executive, Qing Hong Wu, still unaware of the pardon, was released from a New Jersey immigration jail where he had been facing deportation.

headline: Kevin Millar’s Unconventional Path to the Pros
text: GOODYEAR, Ariz. – One of the reasons Kevin Millar felt comfortable playing in Chicago – where he will try to end another team’s tortured legacy – was his familiarity with Gary Hughes. It was Hughes, a special assistant in the Cubs’ front office, who signed Millar into professional baseball.

headline: Democrat Drops Out of Race for Murtha Seat
text: Barbara Hafer, a former Pennsylvania treasurer, has withdrawn from the race for the House seat long held by John P. Murtha, according to multiple published reports.

headline: Queen B
text: She may be a fashion-world legend, but Joan Burstein, whose groundbreaking London emporium Browns turns 40 this year, isn’t one to rest on her laurels. She presides over six locations, including a free-standing shoe salon and a men’s shop, where she continues to introduce customers to the latest and greatest designers. ‘‘I like to think I have a good instinct, but I’m still learning every day,’’ she says. ‘‘These are much more challenging times, but they are also a lot more interesting.’’ More…

headline: Horse Owner Convicted of Animal Cruelty
text: Ernie Paragallo, a prominent thoroughbred breeder and owner, was convicted on 33 charges of animal cruelty Wednesday morning for starving and neglecting his horses on his Hudson Valley farm.

headline: Sheen Headed Back to ‘Two and a Half Men’
text: The hit CBS comedy “Two and a Half Men,” which has lately been down one man, will be back to full staffing next week. A publicist for Charlie Sheen told The Hollywood Reporter that the actor would return to the CBS show on Tuesday after he exits a rehabilitation facility and appears Monday in an Aspen, Colo., court to face domestic abuse charges.

headline: Faith No More Kicks Off Williamsburg Concerts
text: The first summer concert at the Williamsburg waterfront this season will be epic, in at least one sense of the word: the reunited Faith No More will perform its first East Coast show in more than a decade on July 5 at North Eighth Street and Kent Avenue on the East River in Brooklyn, the Open Space Alliance for North Brooklyn said on Wednesday.

headline: Does Lack of Insurance Kill?
text: How many people die because they lack health insurance has been a matter of debate recently.

headline: How to Drive a Zamboni
text: Nick Kurczewski, an automotive journalist, takes a step-by-step course on how to drive an ice-resurfacer at the Battery Park City Ice Rink in Lower Manhattan.

headline: Views of ‘JihadJane’ Were Unknown to Neighbors
text: The Pennsylvania woman linked this week to an alleged terrorist plot involving militant Muslims was not known in her neighborhood for extreme religious views. There were no religious books or hangings in her apartment, several neighbors said, and she never spoke about her religion.

headline: Top 10 U.S. Value Cities
text: Looking for a cheap vacation? Try Atlanta.

headline: Safe in Bed?
text: Early on Christmas morning in 2004, a staff member walked into Harry Griph Sr.’s room at the New Perspective assisted living facility in Brookfield, Wis., and found that Mr. Griph had died.

headline: It’s Budget Time, and New Yorkers Are in Full Protest
text: Ever since Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg unveiled on Jan. 28 a budget proposal that he warned would be full of difficult choices, the usual protagonists and antagonists have been gradually ramping up for an annual ritual at City Hall that involves protests, hearings and more protests.

headline: U.S. Charity Is Attacked In Pakistan; 6 Are Killed
text: PESHAWAR, Pakistan — Six Pakistani employees of the American Christian charity World Vision were killed Wednesday and seven others were wounded in an attack on the aid group’s offices in a remote village in northern Pakistan.

headline: California Utility Regulators Not Quite Ready for Fuel Cells
text: While Google, Wal-Mart and other corporations have embraced fuel cells, California regulators have turned down requests from the state’s two biggest utilities to install the technology.

headline: The Perils of March
text: Today we are forming a support group for sports’ downtrodden figures, the insulted and the injured. It will add more college basketball coaches in the coming days (Roy Williams, come on down!) as conference tournaments crush their N.C.A.A. tournament hopes. They can be welcomed by Connecticut’s Jim Calhoun, if he can muster the energy for a hug. Mike Dunleavy, ignominiously fired twice in one season by the Clippers, has plenty of energy but still may be venting it all at the team’s owner, Donald Sterling.

headline: Chevy’s New Lightweight Corvette: The Z06 Carbon Limited Edition
text: Chevrolet introduced a new Corvette model Wednesday that is, according to General Motors, the most nimble-footed of the breed. Known as the Z06 Carbon Limited Edition, this latest Vette is positioned in the gap between the top-of-the-line ZR1 and the less pricey Z06.

headline: Backstage: John Galliano
text: Backstage scenes at the John Galliano fall 2010 show in Paris.

headline: Doctor Leaves UBS for Citi’s Health Care Team
text: Dr. Aradhana Sarin is leaving UBS to join Citigroup’s global health care investment banking team in New York, according to an internal memo obtained by DealBook. Ms. Sarin will be a managing director in the group, reporting to Bill Clark, Michael Hill and Chris Hite.

text: To have and hold on to. More…

headline: Fur’s Rebound on New York Runways

headline: 12-Hour Dostoyevsky Play on Tap for Lincoln Center Festival
text: The Lincoln Center Festival, one of the cultural highlights of New York City in summertime, will mount two North American premiere productions on Governors Island in July: A 12-hour marathon performance of “The Demons,” the director Peter Stein’s adaptation of the Dostoyevsky novel, and a theatrical re-imagining of Pier Paolo Pasolini’s novel and film “Teorema,” by the director Ivo van Hove.

headline: ‘Cautiously Optimistic’ on Ground Zero Project
text: As Gov. David A. Paterson was taking questions on Wednesday morning from members of a Lower Manhattan business group, one audience member wanted to know what, if anything, he was doing about the bureaucratic impasse that has stalled development at the former World Trade Center site.

headline: Former Hevesi Aide Pleads Guilty in Corruption Case
text: ALBANY — David J. Loglisci, the former chief investment officer of the state pension fund, pleaded guilty to a felony violation of state securities law in state court Wednesday morning and is cooperating with Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo’s investigation into pension corruption, Mr. Cuomo’s office said.

headline: Credit Card Rewards for Volunteers
text: If you hold an American Express card, volunteering can do more for you than make you feel good about yourself. It can give you credit card reward points.

headline: Wall Street Journal Sheds a Restaurant Critic
text: Raymond Sokolov, who has reviewed restaurants for The Wall Street Journal since 2006, is leaving the paper. Mr. Sokolov said his editors had told him The Journal was abandoning restaurant criticism, and asked him to report on food trends instead. After thinking it over, he said, he declined this new beat.

headline: Alston Explains Unexplained Exit From Heat
text: Veteran guard Rafer Alston said he isn’t second-guessing last week’s abrupt decision to leave the Miami Heat.

headline: The Rockefeller Republican Health Care Bill
text: Ezra Klein has been getting some grief for two almost back-to-back blog posts: In the first one, he tried to persuade skeptical progressives that the health care bill “represents an enormous leftward shift for American social policy,” only to turn around in the second post and suggest that conservatives are “insane” for freaking out about such a perfectly moderate, not-at-all left-wing piece of legislation. Trying to resolve the apparent contradiction, he writes:

text: Following is the first set of answers from Marc Robinson, the author of “The American Play: 1787-2000.” More answers will be posted tomorrow.

headline: Granderson Gets a Ride in the Jetermobile
text: TAMPA, Fla. – Curtis Granderson got a ride back with some new friends from Monday’s game in Bradenton. Derek Jeter was driving. Alex Rodriguez rode shotgun.

headline: Connecticut Sues Moody’s and S.&P. Over Ratings
text: Connecticut’s attorney general sued Moody’s Investors Service and Standard & Poor’s on Wednesday over ratings that they issued on risky investments, The Associated Press reports.

headline: Swedish Artist Has His Ax Ready
text: Three years ago, after Danish cartoons mocking the Prophet Muhammad enraged Muslims around the world, a Swedish artist named Lars Vilks had trouble finding a gallery willing to show his satirical drawing of the prophet’s head on the body of a dog. On Wednesday, it was suddenly hard to avoid Mr. Vilks’s drawing in Sweden — several Swedish newspapers published it, one day after seven people were arrested in Ireland in connection with a plot to kill him.

headline: Spitzer Documentary on Tribeca Film Festival Lineup
text: A work-in-progress viewing of a documentary about Eliot Spitzer, the former New York governor, directed by Alex Gibney, an Academy Award winner for “Taxi to the Dark Side,” will be shown as a special event at the Tribeca Film Festival, its organizers said on Wednesday. In a news release, the festival said the documentary will explore “the hidden contours of this tale of hubris, sex and power” with “unique access to friends and enemies of the ex-governor.”

headline: Profile in Style | Pierre-Alexis Dumas
text: Despite the fact that his surname is practically synonymous with a Gallic sense of understated elegance, Pierre-Alexis Dumas, the artistic director of one of the oldest and most prestigious family-owned companies in France, doesn’t have much patience for most people’s idea of “luxury.” “When you start to use that word, you’re pretty desperate,” he says. “I have seen so-called luxury products that have failed miserably after three weeks. We are a quality manufacturer. My concern in life is, What does quality mean and how do you achieve it?” It’s a question that Dumas, 43, has been tackling all his life, though it was only in 2006 that he took over the creative reins of Hermès from his father, Jean-Louis. “I grew up in Hermès, so I always relate it to family and home, something that’s very natural and intimate,” Dumas says. “For me, Hermès is about the mystery and miracle of life.” More…

headline: Zamboni Driving Lessons
text: It might have an exotic Italian name, but any similarities between a Zamboni and the glamorous world of Ferrari and Lamborghini ends there. A Zamboni is ponderously slow and definitely not street legal. Its job is to clean and smooth the surface of an ice rink.

headline: No Noise Is Good Noise
text: Do artificial intelligence and Beyonce have a future together?

headline: Chicken Pot Pie Gets Simplified
text: I have nothing against chicken pot pie; in fact I love it. But honestly, I probably haven’t made it in 10 years, because if I’m going to make a crust, I’m going to use it for dessert. Here, then, is chicken pot pie re-envisioned as chicken cobbler, with a super-fast biscuit topping (and, IMHO, better “filling”).

headline: District Attorney Raids Construction Office in Manhattan
text: The Manhattan district attorney’s office raided the offices of Lehr Construction early Wednesday, seizing project records, bidding documents and other records as part of a growing investigation into the interior construction industry.

headline: Obama Pledges U.S. Aid to Haiti
text: WASHINGTON — As the United States military steadily reduces its presence in Haiti, President Obama pledged on Wednesday to remain committed to providing financial assistance and humanitarian relief to help Haitians rebuild and recover from their devastating earthquake two months ago.

headline: When You Can Claim a Credit for the Babysitter
text: In a Bucks post on Tuesday about 10 tax benefits available for parents, one break mentioned was a tax credit of up to 20 to 35 percent, depending on income, of qualifying child care expenses for children age 12 or younger (or older children incapable of caring for themselves).

headline: Wizards Drama Continues
text: Drama, thy name is the Washington Wizards.

headline: An Oscar Bounce for ‘The Hurt Locker’
text: Just what effect does an Oscar have? For “The Hurt Locker,” it should be a palpable one this weekend. The film, which has actually never left theaters since it opened in a very few in June 2009, will open in an additional 35 on Friday, in major markets like New York, Los Angeles, Chicago, San Francisco, Dallas, Houston, Washington D.C., Seattle, Denver, Detroit, Minneapolis and San Diego, as well as in 30 more in Canada. That will take its total in North America to 348 theaters; for comparison’s sake, “Avatar” is playing in 2,163 theaters (although Tim Burton’s “Alice in Wonderland” has scooped up most of its 3-D screens), and “Crazy Heart” in 1,274. The distributors of “The Hurt Locker” decided on the modest expansion in order not to cannibalize DVD sales and rentals, where the best picture winner has already been doing well. It has sold 780,000 copies (including digital downloads), and since its release on Jan. 12, has landed in the Top 10 rental list each week.

headline: Oscars Analysis | Leading Men
text: In years past we’ve bitten our upper lips when watching Hollywood’s royalty attempting their “creative” black tie options, with their tricky vests, shiny suits and odd colored neckties. This year it seems that most of the male attendees at Hollywood’s biggest bash of the year looked to their elegant predecessors when getting ready for their walk down the red carpet. With very few exceptions, our leading men have finally gotten the memo that suit-y straight ties are no substitute for the classic bow tie when hitting the Academy Awards.

headline: Liz Cheney Critiques Justice Department
text: A conservative advocacy organization in Washington, Keep America Safe, kicked up a storm last week when it released a video that questioned the loyalty of some Justice Department lawyers.

headline: Science Academies to Assess Climate Assessors
text: May 3, 8:35 a.m. | Updated  The Interacademy Council has named the committee membership.

headline: Jones, Disgraced Sprinter, Is Joining the W.N.B.A.
text: Calling it a “new part of my journey,” the former sprinter Marion Jones signed a contract to play for the Tulsa Shock of the W.N.B.A. on Wednesday. She is resurrecting an athletic career derailed by her admission that she used performance-enhancing drugs and by a prison sentence for lying about it to federal investigators.

headline: “Fixing Kids” With Vision Therapy
text: In The New York Times Magazine article “Concocting a Cure for Kids With Issues,” Judith Warner writes about a controversial practice called vision therapy, in which some optometrists say they can treat learning disabilities. She reports:

headline: Sebelius to Insurers: It’s Not Too Late to Work Together
text: Kathleen Sebelius, the secretary of health and human services, pleaded with insurance companies on Wednesday to scrap their campaign against President Obama’s health care bill and to work with the White House to pass it.

headline: 3-D Helps Push Global Film Revenues Higher
text: Global movie box-office receipts rose 7.6 percent last year, to $29.9 billion, while the domestic box-office was up more than 10 percent, to $10.6 billion, according to an annual statistical report released on Wednesday by the Motion Picture Association of America.

headline: Mobile Apps That Outperform Web Sites
text: Since the great app rush began, Web companies have scurried to build mobile apps. In some cases, they have realized that their services are better suited to cellphone screens than computers.

headline: Part 3: Answers on Historically Black Colleges and Universities
text: More than 100 American institutions are classified by the government as historically black colleges and universities through a formal program intended “to overcome the effects of discriminatory treatment and to strengthen and expand the capacity of historically black colleges and universities to provide quality education.”

headline: Ford Figo Brings ‘Cool’ to India
text: Ford is betting a large part of its future on a revamped lineup of small cars, such as the 2010 Ford Figo. In colloquial Italian, the name means “cool.” But apart from the cute name and low price tag, the Figo won’t directly translate to boosting Ford’s small car sales in North America. That task belongs to the Ford Fiesta subcompact, which arrives this spring.

headline: Obama Announces a Crackdown on Health Care Fraud
text: President Obama will use a visit to Missouri this afternoon to announce a new plan to crack down on fraud and waste in government health programs, including Medicare and Medicaid.

headline: New Study Sorts Through Obama-Muslim Myth
text: A new academic study finds that Americans who believed during the 2008 campaign that Barack Obama was a Muslim generally held tight to that misconception, despite efforts by the media, fact-checking Web sites and his own campaign to debunk the myth.

headline: Georgetown Ends South Florida’s Dream
text: South Florida came to the Big East tournament feeling as if it belonged.

headline: Fashion Feels Fur’s Warm Embrace
text: LAST month, Johnny Weir, the United States figure skater, switched one of his costumes for the Vancouver Olympics after he said he received threats from anti-fur activists for accessorizing his already colorful wardrobe with just a touch of white fox. At almost the same moment, fashion designers in New York were showing fall collections with so much fur that they seemed to collectively stick a thumb in the eye of political correctness.

headline: Drilling Down, Possum and Economics Edition
text: There are many ways to drill down into a neighborhood.

headline: 2 Multinationals Pull Back From Iran
text: Royal Dutch Shell and Ingersoll-Rand this week became the latest major corporations to announce they would cease or cut back business operations in Iran.

headline: Sebelius to Insurers: It’s Not Too Late to Work Together
text: At our sib-blog Prescriptions, our colleague Robert Pear outlines the appeal made by Secretary Kathleen Sebelius of Health and Human Services to insurance companies on overhauling health care.

headline: Single Parents, Around the World
text: A sizable minority of children in rich countries live with just one parent — a parent who is likely to be female, and also likely to be working.

headline: Allergies Acting Up? The Play’s the Thing
text: Overview | How does the immune system react to allergens, causing allergy symptoms in some people? How can children, parents, doctors and communities respond to allergies, both mild to severe? In this lesson, students conduct a one-question interview to gather data on how much their classmates know about and are affected by allergies. Then, they work in groups to create a play to teach one another, and others in the school community, about allergies, including how the immune system works in people with and without allergies.

headline: Backstage: Hermes
text: A look back stage at the Hermes fall 2010 show in Paris.

headline: Now Reviving | Ellesse
text: The resurrection of a long-forgotten label is one of fashion’s favorite pastimes. (I am still waiting for NAF NAF and Gitano to rise from the ashes.) Now, more than 50 years after its inception, the Italian sportswear label Ellesse has been reborn. Although Ellesse was primarily tied to skiing and tennis throughout the ’70s and ’80s, the former sneaker designer Mauro Massaroto has reimagined the label as hyper-colored cool clothes that jibe with the current frenzy for all things ’90s. I am slightly besotted with the women’s half of the collection. Instead of plaids, flannels and bike shorts, Massaroto (along with the sneaker designer Patrizio Carlucci) go instead for the skater/club kid/track-suits-from-the Salvation Army vibe of the grunge decade. An abundance of velour, stripes, beanies and a baby blue-marigold-fire orange palette are straight out of an X-Girl ad campaign from my junior year of high school. (That is quite possibly my highest form of praise.) Already on my must-have-immediately list:

headline: New Cirque du Soleil Show Is Delayed Again
text: Somewhere in New York, the Allman Brothers Band must be having a good ol’ Southern laugh: the long-gestating Cirque du Soleil show “Banana Shpeel,” whose planned February start at the Beacon Theater pushed the band from its traditional annual residency there, said on Wednesday that it was once again postponing its start date, and will begin performances on April 29.

headline: Lady Antebellum and Sade Remain Atop the Music Charts
text: Six new albums entered the Billboard Top 10 this week, but not one could best the two titles that have dominated the chart for the last five weeks. Lady Antebellum’s “Need You Now” (Capitol Nashville), which was released in February and spent its first two weeks at No. 1, returns to the peak position with 126,000 copies sold, according to Nielsen SoundScan. Sade’s “Soldier of Love” (Epic), the top seller for the last three weeks, falls to No. 2 with 79,000. The top new album is Blake Shelton’s “Hillbilly Bone” (Warner Brothers Nashville), at No. 3 with 71,000.  “My Best Days” (RCA Nashville), the debut album by Danny Gokey, a finalist on “American Idol” last year, opens at fourth place with 65,000. “Almost Alice” (Buena Vista), a collection of new songs by Avril Lavigne, Owl City and others that were inspired by Tim Burton’s new film “Alice in Wonderland,” is No. 5 with 58,000 copies sold, and Lifehouse’s “Smoke & Mirrors” (Geffen) opens at No. 6 with 54,000.

headline: Travel Deals: AirTran and American Airlines Sales
text: AirTran and American Airlines are offering big discounts for numerous flights across the United States, with one-way fares starting at $44 and $39 respectively. Both deals end tomorrow, March 11.

headline: A Second Solution
text: AMMONIA has long been pegged as a manhandler of hair, but hydrogen peroxide, which is in all permanent and demi-permanent color, roughs up hair, too. “The truth is, the most damaging element is not ammonia, it’s hydrogen peroxide,” said Perry Romanowski, an independent cosmetic scientist who blogs under the name of Left Brain at thebeautybrains.com. It’s a lightener that removes most of your natural hue to make way for the hue du jour.

headline: Taking on Hair Color’s Bad Guy
text: PERMANENTLY dyeing hair goes hand in hand with damaging it. The process dries out hair and leaves it jagged. Ammonia — used to open the hair fiber so that dye molecules can nestle in — is as delicate as a can opener. It also smells horrid and sets delicate scalps afire.

headline: Developers Lament Loss of Federal Wind Subsidies in Canada
text: The Canadian Wind Energy Association is expressing disappointment with the federal government’s recent decision not to expand or extend the so-called ecoEnergy program — which delivered subsidies to renewable energy developers — in its new budget.

headline: Tricks to Keep Your Device’s Battery Going and Going
text: If you’re a recent convert to smartphones, you’re probably still discovering all the amazing things that your new BlackBerry, Android phone or iPhone can do. But one thing you most likely found out right away: the more you do, the shorter your phone’s battery lasts.

headline: Psychiatric Solutions Surges on Possible Buyout Bid
text: 4:13 p.m. | Updated Shares of Psychiatric Solutions climbed as much as 25 percent on Wednesday afternoon after The Wall Street Journal reported that the company, which operates mental health hospitals and clinics, was in negotiations to be acquired by the private equity firm Bain Capital.

headline: What We’re Reading…

headline: On Dance: Have Crash Helmet, Will Choreograph
text: During a recent rehearsal on the Lower East Side, the choreographer and dancer Jody Oberfelder came tearing across a small studio like a downtown banshee. Her bright magenta hair was tucked under a striped crash helmet, and she was wearing suspenders with leggings, a huge grin on her face. She was soon joined by similarly dressed dancers, pushing and banging into one another with abandon as if in a mosh pit at a punk concert.

headline: Panel Will Review U.N. Climate Work
text: A group of top scientists from around the world will review the research and management practices of the United Nations climate change panel so that it can try to avoid the kinds of errors that have brought its work into question in recent months, officials said Wednesday.

headline: Who Do You Love, Part II
text: Paul Ryan’s Roadmap for America’s Future has drawn a lot of admiring commentary from self-described reasonable conservatives — which just goes to show that no matter how many times Lucy pulls away the football, Charlie Brown will keep on trying to kick it.

headline: Master Painter
text: He may be a perfectionist when it comes to painting faces, but Peter Philips, Chanel’s global creative director of makeup, is no slave to maquillage. “Although I’m super-meticulous, I’m not afraid to improvise,” he says. “It’s not always the Peter Philips show: sometimes I’m happy to not do much at all.” He’s shown here applying lip liner to Vanessa Paradis, a favorite house muse. headline: U.S. Nears a Crossroads on Trade
