text: Q.

headline: Leaders in House Block Earmarks to Corporations
text: WASHINGTON — House Democratic leaders on Wednesday banned budget earmarks to private industry, ending a practice that has steered billions of dollars in no-bid contracts to companies and set off corruption scandals.

headline: Campaign Finance Freak-Out
text: Is it hyperbole to describe people’s reactions to a Supreme Court decision on campaign finance as “freaking out?”

headline: Paying Nanny Taxes (or Not)
text: I suspect it won’t surprise you to know that parents in Park Slope, Brooklyn, are paying their nannies off the books.

headline: World War II Women Pilots Honored
text: The first women to take controls of American military planes – way back during World War II – received the Congressional Gold Medal at the Capitol today.

headline: Judge Rules the City Owns the Name Tavern on the Green
text: A federal judge ruled on Wednesday that New York City owns the name Tavern on the Green because the former operator of the landmark restaurant in Central Park, Warner LeRoy, had trademarked the name “fraudulently.”

headline: ‘Greed Is Good.’ So Are Cannes Film Awards.
text: Gordon Gekko appears unlikely to return to Wall Street until the fall. Variety reported Wednesday that 20th Century Fox was delaying the release of Oliver Stone‘s “Wall Street: Money Never Sleeps” on hopes that it would be included in the Cannes Film Festival in May.

headline: Mets Reiterate That Reyes Has Elevated Thyroid Levels
text: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla. — In an effort to head off any confusion, General Manager Omar Minaya of the Mets consulted with team doctors and the agent for shortstop Jose Reyes on Wednesday morning, then reiterated what the team said in a statement on Tuesday: that test results showed Reyes had elevated thyroid levels.

headline: Mixed Afghan Signals as Gates Lifts Off
text: Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates took off from Afghanistan Wednesday after a joint news conference with the Afghan defense minister, Abdul Rahim Wardak, sowed confusion. Mr. Wardak said the Afghan army would resume responsibility for most security by October 2011. As Elisabeth Bumiller reports, in “Gates in Saudi Arabia to Discuss Iran,” that would be — by four years — a more ambitious date than one set by President Hamid Karzai (Slide 3). Mr. Wardak later said he meant to say 2015.

headline: Happy Birthday to The Second Pass
text: For all the bustle of its megalopoli, the Internet is mostly flyover country, specked with ghost towns and barren wastes of unread, unsorted data. Some 95 percent of all blogs are abandoned, and starting a successful site and building a real audience is little easier than turning primal forest to fertile pasture.

headline: Photos of the Moment | Steppin’ Out
text: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.

headline: Mohamed Sayed Tantawi, Top Cleric, Dies at 81
text: CAIRO — Sheik Mohamed Sayed Tantawi, Egypt’s chief religious official and leader of Al Azhar University, the oldest and most prestigious center of learning in the Sunni Muslim world, died Wednesday during a visit to Saudi Arabia, Egyptian state media reported. He was 81.

headline: Unanimity to Ban Blindside Hits to the Head
text: BOCA RATON, Fla. — In a move that signals a shift in the culture of professional hockey in North America, N.H.L. general managers on Wednesday unanimously recommended a rule that would penalize blindside checks to the head.

headline: Update: A Tight Race Between Letterman, Leno
text: The late-night competition between Jay Leno and David Letterman remained extremely tight on Tuesday night, as Mr. Leno on NBC’s “Tonight Show” edged back ahead across the board, based on what are known as fast national overnight ratings.

headline: Why Won’t the S.B.A. Lend Directly to Small Businesses?
text: Back in late January, a Florida entrepreneur, Steve Gordon, got the opportunity to take his concerns about the recession straight to the top. If banks won’t make loans to small business, he asked President Obama at a town hall meeting in Tampa, why not have the Small Business Administration make loans directly?

headline: Crosby’s Items Are Found, Solving Canadian Mystery
text: It was not a whodunit. It was a where-was-it?

headline: Comcast Is Absent From Campaign to Change Retransmission Rules
text: Many of the country’s biggest television providers have signed on to a petition asking the government to revamp station retransmission rules. Cablevision, Charter, DirecTV, Dish Network, Time Warner Cable and Verizon all joined the coalition of providers and nonprofit groups in signing the petition on Tuesday.

headline: Marquette Survives the Red Storm
text: From Tuesday’s win over Connecticut to Wednesday’s loss, St. John’s witnessed a range of effort, from the lethargic Huskies to the electric-yellow Lilliputians of Marquette. Buzz Williams’s team burned the Red Storm with backdoor cuts, by rounding off screens and with stop-and-pop jumpers. The Red Storm trailed by as many as 14 points in the first half.

headline: With New Homes, Town Makes Amends for Its Bias
text: HAMTRAMCK, Mich. — Even though more than 50 years have passed since Sallie Sanders was a confused little girl wondering why her family was kicked out of their house for being on the wrong side of the color line here, the pain seems fresh.

headline: Tapas and Dumplings Meet in Berlin
text: If the cuisines of Spain and Asia collided over Central Europe, the results might look something like Dos Palillos, a new restaurant in Berlin.

headline: Spanish Chefs’ Room and Board
text: AT Mas Les Cols, a hotel and restaurant in the Spanish town of Olot in Catalonia, chickens roam free, surrounded by a 13th-century mas, or farmhouse, and a cluster of one-bedroom glass modules. The birds make for a pleasantly rustic element, but their winged brethren don’t fare quite as well in the kitchen nearby. There, the chef Fina Puigdevall has earned two Michelin stars for the artfully reinterpreted Catalan cuisine she creates for her guests.

headline: Now Serving | The Art of Knödel
text: Zipora Fried is not afraid of repetition. As an artist, she is best known for her large, labor-intensive abstract drawings, which she covers in silvery thickets of rapid pencil strokes. One drawing may take weeks to complete. Now she has turned her manual skills to making a dizzying array of dumplings. Unusual pastime, you say? Not for this Israel-born, Vienna-raised, New York-based artist who, after a well-received solo exhibition last year, decided to do something about her longing for food from Austria. A schnitzel’s throw from Schiller’s, her new cafe on Rivington Street is the perfect respite from early spring crowds.Since the heart of Kinski’s Czech-Austrian menu is the humble dumpling, or knödel, served up savory or sweet, it’s a pleasant surprise to see that it’s not about the same protagonist gussied up in various disguises. The sweet-cheese knödel, for instance, is made of soft farmer’s cheese (not unlike ricotta) that has been steamed and rolled in spiced bread crumbs. The apricot and the nougat knödel, although similar on the outside, reveal their respective sweet centers with a gentle slice of a fork. Toward the savory end of the spectrum, the finger-thick strands of the schupfnudeln are in essence billowy, pan-fried gnocchi with rosemary and a touch of lemon.

headline: Sometimes the Theory Fades Away, While the Art Remains Behind
text: The Lyon Opera Ballet, which opened its weeklong season at the Joyce Theater on Tuesday, is presenting two works by internationally celebrated living choreographers, William Forsythe and Maguy Marin. But it starts its triple bill with a staging of “Beach Birds” (1991) by Merce Cunningham, who died last July.

headline: Hello, Columbus
text: A D.J. spins old-school beats in one corner, bottles of white wine chill on ice in another, and abstract paintings hang on the lofty white walls at the Mahan Gallery. If not for the occasional red Buckeyes football jersey in the crowd, you might never guess that this is Ohio. But Ohio it is  Columbus, to be precise. And the Mahan is just one spot in this city’s Short North neighborhood that is challenging all preconceived notions of what passes for cool in the Midwest.

headline: Sri Lanka: Checkpoints in Paradise
text: EVERYBODY out, the military officer ordered us, as we pulled off the bumpy road linking the Tamil-dominated eastern province to Sri Lanka’s hill country. My driver motioned to the back seat, where a police officer we picked up a few miles back was sitting. His presence lent an air of authority, and we were promptly waved through. But the busload of European shutterbugs in front of us  unloading their suitcases and filing out in a single column  was not so lucky.

headline: A View of Abortion From Three Eras
text: Laments over a lack of ideological balance in the theater never have seemed to me to be of great concern. The supposed liberal uniformity of our plays is often overstated, and the rules of drama are different from those of a debating society: both sides don’t need an equal balance. That said, while “Girls in Trouble,” Jonathan Reynolds’s bracing assault on assumptions about the right to choose abortion, is likely too crude to make theatergoers re-evaluate their positions, it did make me reconsider my view of political theater.

headline: Frugal San Francisco
text: DAY after day in January, the rain poured down on the California coast without pause or pity  some of the worst storms to hit the state in a decade. High winds took out power lines and overturned SUVs. Garbage washed up on beaches. Hundreds of people were evacuated from their mudslide-threatened homes. And on one particular Tuesday afternoon, in the Mission District of San Francisco, the heavens focused their fury on a visiting father from Brooklyn  i.e., me  who, so self-absorbed he was blind to the calamities around him, had decided to walk home from the supermarket with his 13-month-old daughter, Sasha, in her stroller.

headline: Restaurant Review: La Enoteca in Rotterdam
text: Lou Borrani, the owner of La Enoteca, is bullish on his city’s foodie scene. “Rotterdam is the culinary capital of Holland at the moment,” Mr. Borrani claims, and he’s doing everything he can at his restaurant to bolster the boast.

headline: 36 Hours in Goa, India
text: FOR many, Goa is synonymous with hippies, hedonism and all-night dance parties held under a full moon. But India’s popular seaside destination offers more than deadheads and clichés. For one thing, Goa is not a single beach, but a rich and varied state  one that offers 63 miles of coastline along the Arabian Sea. Beyond the beaches lies a lush landscape that conceals ancient temples, rich ecosystems and the hilly farmlands that proved irresistible to European spice traders. Centuries before the hippies, there were the Portuguese  and it’s their lingering influence, not the lax laws, that makes Goa such an alluring place.

headline: Where Art and Haute Cuisine Meet in Paris
text: THE rectangular white box beckoned from the exhibition room, mysterious and inscrutable. As winter clouds rolled across the Parisian sky, I watched as visitors to the Palais de Tokyo contemporary-art museum paused before the work  “Untitled (A Curse),” by the American conceptual artist Tom Friedman  and puzzled over its significance. Were we staring at something groundbreaking or derivative? Would this provocative creation be remembered as genius or bunk?

headline: Hotel Review: Ames Hotel, Boston
text: THE BASICS

headline: SoHo Style in Johannesburg
text: BACK in the 1950s, Braamfontein, a suburb perched just north of Johannesburg’s Central Business District, was celebrated for three key cultural institutions  the Civic Theater, the Alexander Theater and the University of the Witwatersrand  which helped keep the quarter artsy, intellectual and mildly integrated even during the era of apartheid. Today, that troika still forms the backbone of Braamfontein’s cultural allure, though its street scene is far more vibrant thanks to a new generation of design shops, restaurants, galleries and residential developments.

headline: Moody’s Warns of Abbott Downgrade After Bid
text: Moody’s Investors Service warned of a possible downgrade of Abbott Laboratories on Wednesday, citing the drug and medical products company’s bid to buy Facet Biotech for $450 million, The Associated Press reports. The agency also affirmed its credit ratings and negative outlook for Abbott.

headline: An Evening of Winning Composers
text: Since 1985 the University of Louisville has administered the annual Grawemeyer Award for Music Composition, a prize that carries a large purse  the last one was $200,000  and ample prestige. To celebrate the 25th anniversary of the award, the university fielded a large, flexible faculty ensemble, the Grawemeyer Players, and on Tuesday evening at Weill Recital Hall the group made its New York debut with a program of works by prizewinners (though not the winning works, which are mostly orchestral scores).

headline: Winnie Mandela’s Remarks Raise Stir
text: JOHANNESBURG — South Africa’s governing party, the African National Congress, said Wednesday that its leaders would talk to Nelson Mandela’s ex-wife, Winnie Madikizela-Mandela, when she returned from abroad about published remarks attributed to her in which she caustically described him as a figurehead who had made a bad deal with the country’s former white rulers.

headline: Hmmm. Did I Write That?
text: A few days ago I commented on the House Foreign Affairs Committee passage of the resolution condemning the Armenian genocide. I generally sided with those who said that the resolution was a bad idea, on the ground that 1.) Congress has better things to do than arbitrate history; and, 2.) instead of helping Armenians, the resolution might get in the way of a Turkish/Armenian thaw that is the most important geopolitical game in the region at the moment.

headline: Scott Brown Lands a Book Contract
text: Senator Scott P. Brown has been in office barely a month, but he already has a story to tell, and HarperCollins is publishing it.

headline: For Sooty Port Areas, Clean Affordable Trucks
text: Truck drivers in New Jersey and New York are now eligible for grants and low-interest loans for purchasing newer, cleaner trucks as part of a $28 million program to improve air quality.

headline: Shopping With Chris Santos
text: The chef, who is also a judge on “Chopped,” went shopping for appealing ways to store knives.

headline: Regarding ‘The Nose’ and the Eye and the Ear
text: “The Nose,” an opera by Dmitri Shostakovich about a bureaucrat who awakens one morning to find his nose missing, which had its premiere in Leningrad in 1930 and is based on an 1836 short story by Nikolai Gogol, opened at the Metropolitan Opera last week. As well as alchemy involving at least three genres, the new production bridges three centuries. It has been directed and co-designed by the South African artist William Kentridge, who employs video animations and a fair bit of 21st-century technology. This is a Kentridge moment in New York: a retrospective is on view at the Museum of Modern Art. On Tuesday three critics for The New York Times  Anthony Tommasini, the chief classical music critic; Roberta Smith, an art critic; and Dwight Garner, a book critic  discussed the music, the art and the literary threads of the work on the ArtsBeat blog, with Daniel J. Wakin, a classical music reporter for The Times, as moderator. Here is an edited excerpt from the conversation, which can be read in its entirety at artsbeat.blogs.nytimes.com/tag/the-nose.

headline: Even Orphanages Spawn Orphans in Haiti
text: When an earthquake hit Haiti on Jan. 12, the photojournalist Lynsey Addario was in India, where she lives. She figured she was two to three days from Haiti and so — though she has spent most of the last 10 years photographing major conflicts and humanitarian crises — she hesitated. She was torn between going as quickly as possible and waiting to explore the longterm effects of the earthquake.

headline: How Goldman Sachs Can Help the Little Guy
text: When people willingly leave their jobs at Goldman Sachs, the once venerated, now often vilified investment bank, it is usually to go run something big in financial services — like, say, the United States Treasury, Peter Carbonara writes in The New York Times.

headline: New Airport, Northwest Florida Beaches International, to Open
text: The first new international airport in the United States in more than decade is set to open in May near Panama City, Fla., a community of 37,000 people on the state’s panhandle. That is no small feat given the environmental, regulatory and financial hurdles involved in building runways and terminals, as well as community opposition to planes flying overhead. Read more…

headline: So Hard to Put Into Words (and Music)
text: It is a sad but certain truth that for pure entertainment value guilt nearly always trumps innocence. Should you require incontrovertible evidence of this basic law of show business, take a look at the new musical from the fabled songwriting team of John Kander and Fred Ebb, which opened Wednesday night at the Vineyard Theater. This solemn, virtuous enterprise is called “The Scottsboro Boys,” and it wears its halo like a barbed-wire hat.

headline: How Gallic Can a Film Festival Get Year After Year? Plenty, It Seems
text: Not until he is kidnapped while on his way to work, held for ransom with a 50 million euro asking price and a severed finger is delivered to his family, do the sins of the spoiled corporate honcho in the French abduction thriller “Rapt” come to light. Inspired by a real-life 1978 kidnapping and updated to the present, “Rapt” is the most compelling film in this year’s Rendez-Vous With French Cinema series.

headline: No More Free Golf for the Not-Quite Disabled
text: In its endless search under the state’s couch cushions for nickels and dimes, Albany says it has found a chunk of change that will add up to a million dollars a year, in the form of park passes issued to disabled people who aren’t really disabled.

headline: Cambodia to Preserve Khmer Rouge Sites for Tourism
text: Cambodia will turn 14 sites used by the murderous Khmer Rouge regime into tourist attractions. Among them are ammunition warehouses and the homes that were used by leaders of the Khmer Rouge, the regime that killed upward of 1.7 million Cambodians during its rule from 1975 to 1979.

headline: Tech Talk Podcast
text: This week’s Times Tech Talk podcast takes a look at the Internet radio outpost Pandora. Bettina Edelstein talks to Claire Cain Miller, a New York Times technology reporter who’s been following the company for years, about how Pandora’s music streaming service works and how it has managed to survive for the last decade.

headline: George W. Bush Re-Enters Policy Arena
text: Former President George W. Bush personally intervened last week in a dispute over the peace process in Northern Ireland in his first known direct involvement in a public policy debate since leaving the White House nearly 14 months ago.

headline: A Place to Bet Real Money on Movies
text: Think that this spring’s “Robin Hood” movie will be a blockbuster at the box office? Next week you will be able to put your money on it.

headline: In Archive and Exhibit, the Dead Live On
text: The Grateful Dead performed the last of their more than 2,300 concerts in 1995 and thus belong increasingly to history, not the present. Two related events make that reality clear: a new exhibition about the band that has just opened at the New-York Historical Society and the recent creation of the much larger archive, housed at the University of California, Santa Cruz, from which it is drawn.

headline: Scorecard | Stella McCartney Wins!
text: Another day of runway shows, another minimalism convert. On Monday, the other half of Paris’s power-woman design duo — Phoebe Philo’s former boss and fellow Chloé alumna — Stella McCartney also pronounced the virtues of restrained chic, a catechism that Scorecard knows the somber wimple-wearing novitiates at Yves Saint Laurent seemed to have more than taken to heart. Oh, Maria (er, Stefano), remember, the love of a man is holy, too!

headline: Barber’s Centenary, Celebrated Intensely
text: Samuel Barber realized the power of his potent Adagio immediately after composing it as the second movement of his Op. 11 String Quartet (the precursor to his version for string orchestra). He then reportedly became uneasy with the popularity of the work, which has become ubiquitous through its use in films, television and pop remixes.

headline: Souvenirs From a Long, Strange Trip
text: The new exhibition at the New-York Historical Society explores a newly available archive of the Grateful Dead.

headline: A Rebel Form Gains Favor. Fights Ensue.
text: ONE snowy night last month, as New Yorkers rushed home in advance of a coming blizzard, more than a hundred artists, scholars and curators crowded into the boardroom of the Museum of Modern Art to talk about performance art and how it can be preserved and exhibited. The event  the eighth in a series of private Performance Workshops that the museum has mounted in the last two years  would have been even more packed if it weren’t for the weather, said Klaus Biesenbach, one of its hosts and the newly appointed director of the P.S.1 Contemporary Art Center. After seeing the R.S.V.P. list, he had “freaked out,” he said, and worried all day about overflow crowds.

headline: How Green Is My Mansion?
text: MITCH KAPOR, the software mogul and philanthropist, has given millions of dollars to environmental groups.

headline: Brooklyn Apartment: A Décor With Provenance
text: Inside the Brooklyn one-bedroom that is a live-work space for the architects Robert Highsmith and Stefanie Brechbuehler.

headline: Snooki Slept Here. Your Turn.
text: There was a collective sigh when MTV recently announced that the “Jersey Shore” cast would not return to Seaside Heights, but head to Miami instead. Well, for those wanting to relive the antics of DJ Pauly D and Co. a little longer, the house’s owners have opened its doors to renters for as much as $2,500 a night.

headline: ‘Neighbors': Not So Shocking After All?
text: When Branden Jacobs-Jenkins’s “Neighbors” began performances last month, it promised to be one of the most incendiary shows of the spring season.

headline: Internet Radio Host’s Case Ends in Mistrial
text: The trial of Harold C. Turner, the incendiary talk show host accused of threatening the lives of three federal judges, has once again ended without a verdict, as a judge declared a mistrial on Wednesday.

headline: Sniffing Out Bedbugs
text: A day in the life of Cruiser, a bedbug-sniffing puggle, and his handler, Jeremy Ecker, the owner of Bed Bug Inspectors.

headline: Marquette’s Hayward Making a Name for Himself
text: Zach Hillesland played forward for Notre Dame before graduating last year. He now works as an academic adviser at the university and is providing analysis for the Quad during the Big East men’s tournament.

headline: Mets’ Mr. April Keeps Slugging
text: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla. — It would be hard to be any hotter than Chris Carter is. Carter, a 27-year-old outfielder who was acquired in the Billy Wagner deal last summer, has hit three home runs on his last three swings, including one Wednesday in a 7-6 loss to the Atlanta Braves.

headline: Sheen Is Headed Back to ‘Two and a Half Men’
text: The hit CBS comedy “Two and a Half Men,” which has lately been down one man, will be back in production with full staffing next week. A publicist for Charlie Sheen told The Hollywood Reporter that Mr. Sheen would return to the show on Tuesday after he leaves an unidentified rehabilitation center and appears Monday in an Aspen, Colo., court to face domestic abuse charges. Mr. Sheen was charged with felony menacing after a dispute with his wife, Brooke Mueller, on Christmas.

headline: Spitzer Documentary in TriBeCa Festival Lineup
text: A work-in-progress viewing of a documentary about Eliot Spitzer, the former New York governor, will be shown at the Tribeca Film Festival. The festival said the documentary, directed by Alex Gibney, an Academy Award winner for “Taxi to the Dark Side,” would explore “the hidden contours of this tale of hubris, sex and power” with “unique access to friends and enemies of the ex-governor.” The festival, which will run from April 21 through May 2, also announced the lineups for its world narrative feature and world documentary feature competitions and its showcase selections. Among the films in competition this year are the feature “Dog Pound,” from the French director Kim Chapiron, about three teenagers held in a detention center, and the documentary “The Two Escobars,” about the soccer player Andrés Escobar and the drug lord Pablo Escobar, directed by Jeff Zimbalist and Michael Zimbalist.

headline: 12-Hour Play for Lincoln Center Festival
text: The Lincoln Center Festival will mount two North American premiere productions on Governors Island in July: a 12-hour performance of “The Demons,” the director Peter Stein’s adaptation of the Dostoyevsky novel, and a theatrical reimagining of Pier Paolo Pasolini’s novel and film “Teorema,” by the director Ivo van Hove. The works are among 45 performances by artists and ensembles from 12 countries that will unfold July 7 to 25 at seven sites around the city. Mr. Stein’s production of “The Demons” (with, above from left, Fulvio Pepe; Alessandro Averone, standing; Giovanni Visentin; Luca Jervolino; and Carlo Bellamio) is expected to be one of the most demanding theatrical pieces in New York this year. The show, running from 11 a.m. to 11 p.m. on July 10 and 11, will feature 26 European actors speaking in Italian, with English supertitles, and have an audience of 467 people. The full schedule is at lincolncenter.org.

headline: 3-D Films Fuel a Rise in Box Office Revenues
text: Global movie box office receipts rose 7.6 percent last year, to $29.9 billion, while the domestic box office was up more than 10 percent to $10.6 billion, according to an annual report released Wednesday by the Motion Picture Association of America, the film industry trade organization. It attributed much of the increase to sales of more expensive 3-D tickets, which accounted for about $1.14 billion, or 11 percent, of the domestic box office total, compared to just $240 million, or 2 percent, in 2008. Total admissions to theaters in the United States and Canada reached 1.42 billion, higher than in the previous four years, but still lower than a recent peak of 1.57 billion in 2002.

headline: Faith No More Kicks Off Williamsburg Concerts
text: This season’s first summer concert at the Williamsburg waterfront will feature the reunited Faith No More performing its first East Coast show in more than a decade. The concert will be on July 5 at North Eighth Street and Kent Avenue on the East River in Brooklyn, the Open Space Alliance for North Brooklyn said on Wednesday. Faith No More, the San Francisco rock band whose hits included “Epic” and “A Small Victory,” broke up in the late 1990s but regrouped last year. Tickets will go on sale at noon on March 19 at ticketmaster.com and the Nokia Theater Times Square box office.

headline: Canada United by TV and Bathroom Breaks
text: It’s no secret that Canadians love their hockey. That was evident during the Olympics, when the gold medal game against the United States was seen on nine networks by an average of 16.6 million viewers — a bit less than half the nation’s population.

headline: Nigerians Recount Night of Their Bloody Revenge
text: JOS, Nigeria — Dispassionately, the baby-faced young man recounted his killings: two women and one man, first beaten senseless with a stick, then stabbed to death with a short knife.

headline: Lady Antebellum Returns to Top of Chart
text: Six new albums entered the Billboard Top 10 this week, but none could best the two titles that have dominated the chart for the last five weeks. Lady Antebellum’s “Need You Now” (Capitol Nashville), which was released in February and spent its first two weeks at No. 1, returned to the peak position with 126,000 copies sold, according to Nielsen SoundScan. Sade’s “Soldier of Love” (Epic), the top seller for the last three weeks, fell to No. 2 with 79,000. Landing in the No. 3 spot, with 71,000 copies sold, is “Hillbilly Bone” (Warner Brothers Nashville), the new album from Blake Shelton, above. “My Best Days” (RCA Nashville), the debut album by Danny Gokey, a finalist on “American Idol” last year, opened at fourth place with 65,000. “Almost Alice” (Buena Vista), a collection of new songs by Avril Lavigne, Owl City and others that were inspired by Tim Burton’s new film, “Alice in Wonderland,” is No. 5 with 58,000 copies sold.

headline: ‘Spider-Man’ Musical Loses Its Mary Jane
text: The long delay hindering the Broadway musical “Spider-Man, Turn Off the Dark” has claimed another casualty: Evan Rachel Wood, below, who was set to play Mary Jane Watson, has dropped out because of a scheduling conflict, according to a statement from the producers. Ms. Wood’s departure, reported by Variety, comes 15 months after it was announced that she would take the role. But in that time the original team of lead producers stumbled in raising the money to mount the show, which is expected to cost about $50 million, by far the most expensive on Broadway. A new lead producer, Michael Cohl, came on board in November to work with the director, Julie Taymor, at the behest of U2’s Bono and the Edge, who together wrote the music and lyrics for the show. The musical was scheduled to begin preview performances last month, but Mr. Cohl announced this winter that the show would be delayed until later this year.

headline: ‘Idol’ Wins a Close Race
text: The Top 8 women competed on “American Idol” on Tuesday, and the Fox reality show led another night in the ratings with 22.6 million viewers, according to Nielsen’s estimates. The network easily dominated the 8 p.m. hour, but CBS earned the most viewers on average throughout prime time. CBS’s “NCIS” challenged “Idol” in the 8 p.m. slot with 19.5 million viewers, while CBS’s “NCIS: Los Angeles” won the 9 p.m. hour with 16.9 million, easily outperforming Fox’s repeat of “Glee” (7.8 million). At 10, “The Good Wife” (13.9 million) lifted CBS far ahead of its competitors as well, including NBC’s “Parenthood” (6.1 million) and “The Forgotten” on ABC (4.9 million). NBC edged past ABC to place third for the night, averaging 7.9 million viewers from 8 to 10 for “The Biggest Loser.” ABC’s “Lost” (9.5 million) won the 9 p.m. slot among the 18-to-49 set.

headline: Pass the Salt Ban?
text: In one of the odder developments to come out of Albany in recent weeks, which is saying something, a Brooklyn assemblyman, Felix Ortiz, has proposed a bill that would make it illegal for restaurants to use salt in the preparation of food. Period.

headline: Disease Cause Is Pinpointed With Genome
text: Two research teams have independently decoded the entire genome of patients to find the exact genetic cause of their diseases. The approach may offer a new start in the so far disappointing effort to identify the genetic roots of major killers like heart disease, diabetes and Alzheimer’s.

headline: Berkeley Doesn’t Recognize Itself in NBC’s ‘Parenthood’
text: When Parenthood made its debut on NBC last week, the collective consensus in Berkeley, where the series is set, was that they got it wrong. The show was just not very Berkeley.

headline: What We’re Reading: What You’re Reading
text: Wednesday’s roundup of flotsam and jetsam from around the Web, as selected by the technology reporters and editors of The New York Times. (And if you don’t like what we’ve picked out, see the first item for a link to Google’s new service along these lines.)

headline: City Owns the Name ‘Tavern on the Green,’ Judge Rules
text: A federal judge ruled on Wednesday that New York City, not Warner LeRoy, owns the name Tavern on the Green, and that Mr. LeRoy, former operator of the landmark restaurant in Central Park, effectively stole the name. The judge said Mr. LeRoy failed to tell the United States Patent and Trademark Office in 1978 that the city owned the name and “fraudulently” made “deliberate misstatements and omissions” to obtain the trademark in 1981. The decision is expected to devastate creditors of the bankrupt restaurant who had hoped that Mr. LeRoy’s family could sell the trademark to raise some of the $10 million owed. Read the full article at Diner’s Journal.

headline: Without Throwing a Pitch, Takahashi Moves Closer to Rotation
text: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla. — Hisanori Takahashi did not throw a pitch Wednesday, but his chances of becoming the Mets’ fifth starter improved slightly.

headline: The Tories and the Tea Partiers
text: Since I recently had some kind words for the British Tories, I should probably rise to Matt Continetti’s anti-Tory bait. Riffing on Jonathan Raban’s relatively-sympathetic New York Review of Books portrait of the Tea Partiers, he writes:

headline: Escobar Is Ready to Return, or Retire if He’s Still Injured
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — The injured Mets reliever Kelvim Escobar said he was very confident he can come back from shoulder soreness to play this season, and hopefully very soon. But in the event he cannot, Escobar can live with it.

headline: Accused Body Snatchers in Cyprus Court
text: Two days after the remains of Tassos Papadopoulos, a former president of Cyprus, were found in a shallow grave on the outskirts of Nicosia, the capital, two suspects accused of stealing the corpse in December were in court on Wednesday.

headline: Interview: ‘My Life With the Taliban’
text: Felix Kuehn and Alex Strick van Linschoten, Western researchers who are living without security protection in Kandahar, Afghanistan, spent the past two years editing and overseeing the translation of the autobiography of Mullah Abdul Salam Zaeef, the former Taliban ambassador to Pakistan and a core member of the early Taliban movement.

headline: A Job Interview to End All Job Interviews
text: Kevin Quinn, the protagonist of James Hynes’s “Next,” is first seen on an airplane that is making its descent into Austin, Tex. He’s wondering whether one of those shoulder-launched missiles with the same name as a cocktail  a Stinger  will hit the plane, which itself reminds him of a can of chips. “A Pringles can with wings, packed full of defenseless Pringles,” is what Kevin sees.

headline: Nine to Know: New York Rivalry Center Fielders
text: Bill Chuck created Billy-Ball.com and is a co-author of Walkoffs, Last Licks, and Final Outs. He grew up in New York and now lives with his wife (a Red Sox fan), and daughter (a Yankees fan), two miles from Fenway Park while Bill claims to be Switzerland. His other daughter lives in New York City, away from the fray. You can follow him on Twitter.

headline: Changing Channels, From Cable to the Web
text: THERE are certain timeless truths about people who don’t own a television, chief among them that they love to tell you they don’t own a television.

headline: Lighting’s Moment
text: Kartell has reduced the price of its popular FL/Y pendant lamp, below, designed by Ferruccio Laviani, from $293 to $149.

headline: Trash Recycled as Art
text: At the Collective, a restaurant opening Mar. 17 in the meatpacking district, ordinary trash has been elevated to recycled art. Visitors will find chairs and sofas cut from bathtubs, above; light fixtures made out of packaging material; and an armchair that mixes a rusty steel frame with wooden mannequin limbs, below.

headline: A Cobble Hill Apartment Where Provenance Presides
text: IN the living room of the apartment in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, that Robert Highsmith, 27, shares with his girlfriend, Stefanie Brechbuehler, 32, and their standard schnauzer, Kingsley, is a weathered Eames lounge chair that once belonged to Mr. Highsmith’s grandfather and still smells faintly of cigarette smoke.

headline: A New Breed of Guard Dog Attacks Bedbugs
text: CRUISER made four house calls on a recent rain-soaked Tuesday. There were two happy endings and two unhappy ones, a fairly typical outcome for a typical day in the life of a bedbug-sniffing puggle.

headline: Children’s Artwork Inspires Line of Wallpaper
text: The Menagerie Collection, a new line of wallpaper from Bholu and Porter’s Original Paints, two Australian companies, was inspired by the artwork of underprivileged children in Ahmedabad, India, where the designer, Jodie Fried, lived for several years.

headline: Brothers Doug and Gene Meyer Design Cushions for Outdoor Furniture
text: Doug and Gene Meyer’s latest project is a line of outdoor fabrics for Link Design Solutions, a manufacturer of teak outdoor furniture.

headline: Homunculights
text: Marcus Tremonto is the latest artist to customize figurines from Kidrobot, the toy and apparel company, with a series of illuminated figures called Lightbotz. Mr. Tremonto, known for designs made with electroluminescent paper and wire that can fetch as much as $100,000, said he applied the same technology to the seven-inch toys: “I took light and used it like a pencil or crayon.”

headline: Proof That Storing Knives Doesn’t Have to Be Dull
text: FINDING a way to store knives that is both functional and attractive has long been a challenge for home cooks of every commitment level. Even Chris Santos, the executive chef of the Stanton Social, a restaurant and lounge in Manhattan, and a judge on “Chopped,” a reality show on the Food Network, keeps the knives he uses at home in what he describes as “a beat-up bag with burns and other war wounds.”

headline: House Beautiful Invites New Yorkers to Take a Seat, Literally
text: HOUSE BEAUTIFUL, a sturdy survivor in the embattled world of shelter magazines, enacted its own stimulus program last week, with the kind of feel-good giveaway associated with the glory days of television. Over three days, a team from the magazine’s marketing department deposited 40 blue chairs around New York City, in a promotional tie-in with its March issue, which is devoted to the color blue.

headline: City’s New School Assignment System: Proximity Can Be a Factor
text: On Wednesday, the San Francisco School Board unanimously approved the creation of a new school assignment system, jettisoning the method that had been in place since 2002.

headline: Slim Tops Gates and Buffett as World’s Richest Man
text: The Mexican billionaire Carlos Slim Helú has taken the top spot in the Forbes annual rankings of the richest billionaires in the world, pushing aside the two perennial leaders, Bill Gates and Warren E. Buffett, even though all three men added greatly to their wealth over the last year.

headline: Democrats Looking to Flip ‘Red to Blue’
text: Facing what seems to be difficult political terrain, the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee is trying to give a boost to some House candidates running for seats now held by Republicans.

headline: ‘Next’
text: As the ground rushes up to meet him, Kevin thinks about missiles again. One missile in particular, a shoulder-fired anti-aircraft missile, blasted from a tube balanced on the bump where some guy's clavicle meets his scapula. What guy — a Saudi? An Egyptian? A Yemeni? Some pissed-off Arab anyway, kneeling in the bed of a dinged-up pickup truck with Texas plates, or crouching on the springy backseat of a rented convertible on a dirt track just outside the airport fence. One of those portable weapons from Afghanistan, back when Afghanistan was somebody else's problem, called . . . something, a Slammer or a Tingler or something like that. Kevin recalls that it's the same name as a cocktail — a Whiskey Sour? A Tom Collins? A shoulder-fired Banana Daiquiri? No, a Stinger, that's it! Four parts brandy to one part crème de menthe in a cocktail glass, or a fat olive-green tube that farts flame out the back while the missile erupts from the front, its backside trailing a wobbly spiral of smoke until the missile gets its bearings and climbs like a sonuvabitch in a long smooth curve into the heat-hazy Texas sky toward the sleek underbelly of Kevin's plane, a Pringles can with wings, packed full of defenseless Pringles.

headline: Putting All Your Conversations on the Small Screen
text: One curse of the digital age is the need to manage multiple continuing conversations — be they via Facebook, Twitter, e-mail, instant messages or text-messaging on your cellphone.

headline: His Day Job Subsidizes All That Other Stuff
text: ON a recent Monday night at the Upright Citizens Brigade theater in Manhattan, the comedian Leo Allen came out to kick off his stand-up showcase, “Whiplash,” and was startled at the packed 150-seat theater. “People are sitting on the floor,” he said, gazing at the cross-legged spectators. “They think Chris Rock’s going to be here or something.”

headline: A Fund-Raiser, Minus the Candidate
text: 9:02 p.m. | Updated

headline: As the Championships Begin, Revisiting a 2009 Highlight
text: The American Contract Bridge League’s Spring North American Championships start on Thursday in Reno, Nev.

headline: Controlling a PC With a Phone
text: Controlling a PC

headline: Chile Leader Enters Changed Political Landscape
text: SANTIAGO, Chile — Chile’s powerful earthquake buried people and homes in a broad section of the coastal south, but it may also have given the country’s new right-wing coalition government a chance to entomb the ghosts of the former dictator Gen. Augusto Pinochet.

headline: More Messages Link Senator to Job Effort
text: WASHINGTON — Previously undisclosed e-mail messages turned over to the F.B.I. and Senate ethics investigators provide new evidence about Senator John Ensign’s efforts to steer lobbying work to the embittered husband of his former mistress and could deepen his legal and political troubles.

headline: Israel’s Challenge to the U.S.
text: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. was unpleasantly surprised in Israel on Tuesday when the country’s Interior Ministry declared that it would expand housing units for Jews in East Jerusalem. Mr. Biden, who earlier that day had expressed American support on Israel’s security needs, condemned the announcement, which had been made without the knowledge of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.

headline: Internet TV: The Basics
text: To hear recent converts talk about it, there is a promised land where TV shows are instantly available on demand, and cost nothing — or far less than the hundreds of dollars that consumers usually pay cable companies each month. Reaching this glorious destination, while far easier than it used to be, can require some technological know-how and an initial outlay of cash.

headline: Trumpeting Catalan on the Big Screen
text: BARCELONA, Spain — Here in the principal city of Catalonia, the native language, Catalan, is heard just about everywhere except in the movies. But that may be about to change because the local government is expected to pass a bill requiring that at least half the copies of every film from outside Europe, including all major American productions, be dubbed in Catalan.

headline: Dealing With More Than Balls and Strikes
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Travis Blackley is fighting for his baseball career, trying to overcome challenging odds to earn a spot on the Mets’ roster. He has not pitched in the major leagues since Sept. 29, 2007, and could probably use any possible edge to his advantage. But there is one thing he will not do, he said, even though he could.

headline: Trying Times for Father of New York’s Governor
text: It has not been easy being David A. Paterson the last several weeks. He was hounded into abandoning an election bid to remain governor because of accusations his administration interfered in a domestic abuse case against a senior aide, has been accused of perjury in a separate ethics case and has fended off demands that he resign.

headline: Spy Chief in Pakistan to Stay On Another Year
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Pakistan’s spy chief has been granted an unusual one-year extension in his job, a move that may also pave the way for a longer term for the head of the army, Gen. Ashfaq Parvez Kayani, who is scheduled to step down this year.

headline: Governor Proposes Rise in Income Tax for Illinois
text: CHICAGO — Gov. Patrick J. Quinn on Wednesday proposed raising the state income tax rate, just one in a long list of painful measures aimed at closing a budget deficit that some now estimate at $13 billion.

headline: Gadgets in Emergency Vehicles Seen as Peril
text: They are the most wired vehicles on the road, with dashboard computers, sophisticated radios, navigation systems and cellphones.

headline: TV May Be the New Google Reader Play’s Best Venue
text: Google announced an experimental Web browsing feature on Wednesday that it will offer as an alternative view to explore content on the Google Reader Web site. The company is praising its simplicity, but the advantage may be in the highly visual way it displays information.

headline: Senate Approves Extension of Jobless Benefits
text: The Senate voted 62 to 36 Wednesday to approve a $138 billion measure that would extend unemployment benefits and provide additional aid to states in lawmakers’ second major effort this year to improve the economy. The legislation would also extend dozens of expiring tax cuts and head off cuts in Medicare reimbursements to doctors. Six Republicans joined 56 Democrats in voting for the bill, which now goes to the House. Senator Ben Nelson of Nebraska was the only Democrat to vote against it.

headline: Massachusetts: New Book for New Senator
text: Senator Scott Brown has been in office barely a month, but he already has a story to tell, and HarperCollins is publishing it. HarperCollins said in a statement that Mr. Brown would write about his family background, early career and his “ascent to the office of Massachusetts senator, one of the biggest political coups of the decade.” Mr. Brown, a Republican, made history in January by snaring the seat held for decades by Edward M. Kennedy, wiping out the Democrats’ supermajority. Mr. Brown in all likelihood will work with a collaborator. The book, for which he will earn seven figures, will be published in 2011. His first step is to submit the deal to the Senate Ethics Committee for approval.

headline: White House Responds to Chief Justice
text: The White House hit back Wednesday against complaints from Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. about a pep-rally-like atmosphere in Congress in January as President Obama delivered his State of the Union address, in which he criticized a recent decision by the Supreme Court. The White House press secretary, Robert Gibbs, said: “The president has long been committed to reducing the undue influence of special interests and their lobbyists over government. That is why he spoke out to condemn the decision and is working with Congress on a legislative response to close this loophole.” Chief Justice Roberts made his remarks Tuesday in response to a question from an audience member at the University of Alabama in Tuscaloosa.

headline: Senate Bill on Finance to Include Agency That Tracks Financial Risk
text: WASHINGTON — Senate Banking Committee members from both parties said on Wednesday that they had agreed to include in their regulatory overhaul bill a new Office of Research and Analysis that would provide early warnings of possible systemic collapses.

headline: Christoph Niemann’s Tough Night’s Sleep
text: Getting a good night’s sleep is actually a lot more complicated than one would think. In an illustrated post from his series, Abstract City, the artist Christoph Niemann counts — and draws — the ways. View the post, “Good Night and Tough Luck.”

headline: My Way
text: From the Abstract City archive: Getting there from here: one artist maps out the most accurate routes for all occasions.

headline: Ex-Players Join Suit vs. N.C.A.A.
text: Eleven former college football and basketball players have joined the former U.C.L.A. basketball star Ed O’Bannon in a class-action lawsuit that argues the N.C.A.A. should compensate former athletes for the use of their images and likenesses.

headline: Obama Gets Tough on Health Care Fraud
text: ST. CHARLES, Mo. — President Obama continued his drive for a health care overhaul on Wednesday, ordering a crackdown on Medicare and Medicaid waste and fraud, while in Washington, House leaders said they hoped to have a completed bill to present to rank and file members Thursday morning.

headline: In Japan, No-Frills Airport Lures Bargain Players
text: MITO, Japan — The sweeping order from the governor was the kind that gives Japanese bureaucrats heart attacks: plans for a three-story airport terminal, painstakingly laid over years, were to be scrapped and replaced with a single-floor layout.

headline: Son’s Sins Don’t Taint Him, Father Insists at Own Trial
text: The phone call came from jail, a son’s plea for help that would sorely test a father’s judgment.

headline: Rewrite of Physics by Einstein on Display
text: JERUSALEM — There are pasted-on half pages, numerous cross-outs and insertions in meticulous penmanship and an open acknowledgment that some of the mathematics was beyond even him. Albert Einstein personally rewrote the laws of physics in a sparsely furnished central Berlin apartment nearly a century ago and the resulting manuscript, profoundly human and surprisingly moving to examine, has been put on display here for the first time.

headline: Learning Is Priority for Rising McIlroy
text: DORAL, Fla. — During his brief and highly publicized professional career, Rory McIlroy has endured much scrutiny. Since turning pro at age 18 in 2007, he has gone under the news media’s electron microscope, inspected for everything from his overflowing curly mane to his aggressive style of golf to his penchant for fast and expensive sports cars.

headline: Bush Intervened in Northern Ireland Dispute
text: WASHINGTON — Former President George W. Bush personally intervened last week in a dispute over the peace process in Northern Ireland in his first known direct involvement in a public policy debate since leaving the White House.

headline: One Last Try for Matt Stairs
text: GOODYEAR, Ariz. – Matt Stairs never did hit a home run for the Montreal Expos, the team that first signed him in 1989. But he hit one for the Boston Red Sox. And 122 for the Oakland Athletics. And at least one for the Chicago Cubs, the Milwaukee Brewers, the Pittsburgh Pirates, the Kansas City Royals, the Texas Rangers, the Detroit Tigers, the Toronto Blue Jays and the Philadelphia Phillies. He even hit six for the Chunichi Dragons.

headline: House Rejects Plan to Leave Afghanistan by Year’s End
text: WASHINGTON — In a strong bipartisan endorsement of the Obama administration’s policy in Afghanistan, the House of Representatives on Wednesday soundly rejected a call to withdraw American troops by the end of the year.

headline: For a Pardoned Detainee, Released but Not Told Why, a Lonely, Happy Trip Home
text: After four months locked in a New Jersey immigration jail facing deportation, Qing Hong Wu, 29, was told by guards to pack his things on Tuesday evening. Fearing that he was being abruptly transferred to a detention center in Texas or Louisiana, like many detainees with families in New York City, Mr. Wu asked other inmates to try to alert his fiancée.

headline: Russia: Arrests in Fatal Train Bombing
text: A Moscow court on Wednesday approved the arrest of 10 suspects in the November 2009 bombing of the Nevsky Express passenger train, which derailed while en route from Moscow to St. Petersburg and killed 28 people. Nine of the suspects were arrested during a federal raid last week on a village outside Nazran, the capital of the republic of Ingushetia. Nine of the suspects are members of the Kartoyev family, and the 10th is an arms-trafficking suspect named Zelimkhan Aushev, according to the news agency Interfax.

headline: Goldman Deal-Maker Now Advocates Regulation
text: For 18 years, Gary G. Gensler worked on Wall Street, striking merger deals at the venerable Goldman Sachs. Then in the late 1990s, he moved to the Treasury Department, joining a Washington establishment that celebrated the power of markets and fought off regulation at almost every turn.

headline: Texas Hoping to Build Momentum
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — Welcome to the opening round of the Big 12 tournament on a drizzly Wednesday night.

headline: Italy: Crackdown on Crime Families in Italy and U.S.
text: In a coordinated crackdown, American and Italian authorities arrested 25 men in Sicily, New York, North Carolina and Florida on Wednesday and charged them with taking part in a range of criminal activities under the umbrellas of the Gambino crime family in the United States and the Santa Maria di Gesù family in Sicily. Robert Settineri, who prosecutors said was a Sicilian Mafia associate, was arrested in Florida and charged by federal prosecutors with money laundering and with obstructing justice by destroying documents related to a large-scale mail and wire fraud. In and around Palermo, Sicily, 20 people were arrested and charged with extortion, drug trafficking, attempted homicide and other crimes.

headline: Los Angeles Electric Rate Linked to Solar Power
text: LOS ANGELES — Los Angeles averages more than 300 days of sunshine a year, and it often seems as if environmentalists outnumber rattlesnakes in many parts of the sprawling city. It would seem, then, that solar energy would be a thriving local industry here.

headline: Louis C. K.
text: Although we love Justin Theroux, we were sad when Amy Poehler's character, Leslie Knope, split up with Louis C. K. on "Parks and Recreation." He's hilarious, and if you needed more proof of the comedian's talents go back and watch the short-lived and totally underrated "Lucky Louie," which ran on HBO in2006 and 2007. Luckily for New Yorkers, tonight the comic will begin a special run at Carolines on Broadway. Go for a laugh and return for Sunday's performance, which will benefit public schools.

headline: Make Some Noise
text: Men's noise choir (with light guitars!); dot matrix cicadas; toy turntables with wrecked records; music in negative fidelity, with walkie-talkies and the Neg Box. All are part of "You're Playing It Wrong: Creative Musical Misuse," a program tonight presented by dorkbot at 92ndStY in Tribeca. Dorkbot is "people doing strange things with electricity," and tonight this electronic art group will offer a selection of historical and contemporary short videos and live performances featuring "inappropriate, inadvisable and occasionally disastrous creative musical mayhem." Sounds like fun.

headline: Where Did I See This Guy?
text: More proof that they don't make 'em like they used to can be seen tonight at BAMcinématek with "That's Montgomery Clift, Honey!" This two-week film series takes its name from the refrain of the Clash song "The Right Profile," released on "London Calling" in 1979, 13 years after the brooding actor's death. ("And everybody say, 'He sure look funny'/That's Montgomery Clift, honey.") The series,  Mike Hale writes, will present 11 of Clift's 17 features, including most of the highlights: "From Here to Eternity," "A Place in the Sun," "Red River" and "The Heiress" (on opening night); of his best performances, only "Indiscretion of an American Wife" is missing. Also on tap are the rarely shown, documentary-style "Big Lift," about the Berlin airlift, and "The Young Lions" and "The Misfits," his two best efforts in the years after his devastating auto accident."

headline: Paris: A Rounder Season
text: Louis Vuitton seemed to provide the perfect bookend to the Milan-Paris ready-to-wear season, which ended tonight. Between Miuccia Pradain Milan and Marc Jacobs at Vuitton we saw the return of the lush, full-hipped woman, her breasts served up like ripe fruit. Do those dry, sober minimalists have a chance next to Laetitia Casta, who opened the Vuitton show in a pinstriped gray sundress? Mr. Jacobs’s full-skirted silhouette, with corsets and sometimes a neat little jacket, was somewhere between Brigitte Bardot and Doris Day. The look certainly caught a sexy mood, but if you seriously thought about dragging those gathered skirts around, you’d be tuckered out by the time you reached the corner to hail a taxi.

headline: China: Protester Is Sentenced
text: A longtime protester from Shanghai has been ordered by the authorities to serve one and a half years of “re-education through labor” for shouting slogans about human rights outside a Beijing courthouse on Dec. 25, according to Human Rights in China, an advocacy group. The protester, Mao Hengfeng, was among a group of demonstrators who assembled outside the sentencing of Liu Xiaobo, one of the most well-known Chinese dissidents and a main author of Charter 08, a manifesto calling for democratic reforms.

headline: Baseball Emissary to Review Troubled Dominican Pipeline
text: Over the past two decades, the Dominican Republic has become the richest exporter of talent to Major League Baseball, providing some of the biggest names in the game. The influx of Dominican players has also caused baseball major headaches over issues involving the largely unregulated youth feeder system in which the use of performance-enhancing drugs; age and identity fraud; and rogue sports agents are commonplace.

headline: Former Hevesi Aide Pleads Guilty in Pension Case
text: ALBANY — The former chief investment officer for the state’s pension fund pleaded guilty to securities fraud on Wednesday, saying he helped steer pension money to political contributors to former State Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi and to companies that paid kickbacks to Mr. Hevesi’s top political consultant, Hank Morris.

headline: Syracuse-Georgetown Game Highlights Big East Matchups
text: The first two days of the Big East tournament are appetizers, teases before the top four seeds arrive Thursday at Madison Square Garden.

headline: In China, Investment to Expand E-Payments
text: China Mobile agreed to buy 20 percent of Shanghai Pudong Development Bank for 39.8 billion renminbi ($5.8 billion) to expand its electronic payment business.

headline: Italy: Law to Protect Berlusconi in Court
text: The Italian Parliament approved a law on Wednesday that would protect Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi, left, and his cabinet from the results of trials that are currently under way, on the grounds that the trials would impede their ability to govern. Mr. Berlusconi’s cabinet advanced the measure after Italy’s Constitutional Court declared unconstitutional a law that granted immunity from prosecution to the prime minister and other senior office holders. The new law allows cabinet officials to postpone for six months any trial in which they have been implicated. Mr. Berlusconi’s opponents criticized the law as designed to enable him to avoid the outcome of two corruption trials in which he is a defendant.

headline: Sushi Spot Is Charged With Serving Whale Meat
text: LOS ANGELES — Federal prosecutors have filed a criminal complaint accusing a Japanese restaurant in Santa Monica and its chef of serving whale meat, a violation of the federal Marine Mammal Protection Act.

headline: Screen Test | Josh Brolin
text: The actor talks to Lynn Hirschberg about watching his first movie, Harvey Milk, Oliver Stone and George W Bush.

headline: Tough Enough
text: In the next few months, you will be starring in three movies: in  “Jonah Hex,”  out June 18, you play a western antihero with a tragic past; in “Wall Street: Money Never Sleeps,” you are a Gordon Gekko-like villain; and in Woody Allen’s new movie, “You Will Meet a Tall, Dark Stranger,” you play . . .

headline: Candidates Number 8, but Quayles Just One
text: PHOENIX — Ben Quayle was born two days after his father, Dan, was first elected to Congress, and remembers well tossing a football with him on Capitol Hill between votes. He could have lived without the constant mocking of his family — particularly the whole potato thing — but his memories of Washington are largely gauzy and pleasant.

headline: Emma Peel and Her Sisters
text: For the finale at Hermès today, Jean Paul Gaultier sent out all the models in a union of bowler hats, fantastic leathers and umbrellas. The opening song came from “The Avengers,” as did the look, and the coats in particular — trench coats in leather, shearling — were up-to-date.

headline: Council Leaders Want Fewer Names on List of Police Stops
text: Two City Council leaders urged Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly on Wednesday to stop keeping a database of people who are stopped, questioned and sometimes frisked in public, but who are neither arrested nor given summonses. The lawmakers, Council Speaker Christine C. Quinn and Peter F. Vallone Jr., chairman of the Public Safety Committee, also want Mr. Kelly to remove the names of those arrested but later found not guilty.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 4,373 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war and 1,003 who have died as part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

headline: Woman Charged in Brooklyn Hit-Run
text: A suspect in a hit-and-run accident that left an employee of the mayor’s office in critical condition surrendered to the authorities Wednesday and was charged with leaving the scene of an accident, the police said.

headline: Before Yankees-Tigers, Old Teammates to See
text: LAKELAND, Fla. — Curtis Granderson was jogging toward the Yankees’ clubhouse after batting practice Wednesday when he felt a tug on his left arm. Johnny Damon wanted to say hi.

headline: Carlos Slim Tops Forbes List of Billionaires
text: Carlos Slim Helú of Mexico beat Bill Gates and Warren E. Buffett for the top spot on Forbes magazine’s annual list of billionaires, becoming the first person from outside the United States to lead the rankings in 16 years.

headline: Kansas City to Close Nearly Half Its Schools
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — The Kansas City Board of Education voted Wednesday night to close almost half of the city’s public schools, accepting a sweeping and contentious plan to shrink the system in the face of dwindling enrollment, budget cuts and a $50 million deficit.

headline: Tanker Deal Gives a Lift to Boeing
text: Northrop Grumman’s withdrawal this week from a $40 billion contest to build aerial refueling tankers provides Boeing with some welcome certainty about its future as a major builder of military aircraft.

headline: Bloggingheads: Be Like Mike?
text: Will Wilkinson, left, of the Cato Institute and David Shenk, author of “The Genius in All of Us,” debate the genetic basis of extraordinary talent.

headline: District Attorney Raids Office of Construction Company
text: The Manhattan district attorney’s office raided the offices of Lehr Construction early Wednesday, seizing project records, bidding documents and other records as part of a growing investigation into the interior construction industry.

headline: Obama’s Student Loan Overhaul Endangered
text: WASHINGTON — With Democratic Congressional leaders and the White House struggling on Wednesday to finalize the details of major health care legislation, House Democrats were desperately trying to prevent another of President Obama’s top legislative priorities – an ambitious overhaul of student loan programs – from becoming a casualty of the health care battle.

headline: Bring in Da Noise
text: Although Matthew Herbert’s music has never even dented the pop charts, he plays sold-out performances in places as diverse as the Sydney Opera House and the Hollywood Bowl. His music has been described as “fluffy electronica,” “smooth Glenn Miller big-band fun” and “wicked chilled-out vibes,” but his compositions include the sounds of human bodies being cremated, chickens being slaughtered and a hundred powerful people saying the word “yes.”

headline: Trends: Collared
text: Maybe a round, buttoned collar reminds you of your fourth-grade teacher, but you can expect to see more of it for fall. The look surfaced at Celine, Yves Saint Laurent, Chloé and Miu Miu.

headline: Navistar Shares Fall After Earnings Report
text: Shares of Navistar International, a maker of commercial and military vehicles, declined Wednesday in New York after its quarterly results missed analysts’ estimates.

headline: Unexpectedly, EMI Moves to Replace Top Executive
text: The struggling British music company EMI announced on Wednesday that Elio Leoni-Sceti, the chief executive of its recorded music division, will step down at the end of March after less than two years in the job.

headline: Another Republican Is Encouraged to Join the Race for Senate
text: Encouraged by state and national Republican Party leaders, Dan Senor, an author, private equity executive and Defense Department adviser in the last Bush administration, is seriously considering a political challenge against Senator Kirsten E. Gillibrand, according to three people told of the discussions.

headline: Teach for the World
text: A drumroll, please. In a moment, the winner of my 2010 “win-a-trip” contest.

headline: 3 Down: ‘The Joy Luck Club’ Author
text: Note with today’s puzzle: When this puzzle is finished, the six circled letters can be arranged to spell an answer to the catchphrase reading diagonally from upper left to lower right.

headline: Albany Is Taking New Budget Proposal Seriously
text: ALBANY — State lawmakers reacted with cautious interest on Wednesday to a broad proposal from Lt. Gov. Richard Ravitch to tackle New York’s staggering long-term budget deficit, but suggested that it would most likely require changes to win legislative approval.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Tuesday about damage in Santiago, the capital of Chile, from the Feb. 27 earthquake misstated Santiago’s population. It is 6.8 million, not 3.3 million.

headline: Memories, and Debris, at Old Yankee Stadium
text: The three excavators lined up Wednesday on the field of ruin that was once Yankee Stadium.

headline: Albany Sides With Owner in a Rent Suit in TriBeCa
text: Several months after the highest court in New York ruled that Stuyvesant Town’s owners were wrong to deregulate apartments while receiving tax breaks, the state’s housing agency has determined that another landlord who once received the breaks had the right to charge market-rate rents.

headline: Texas Conservatives Seek Deeper Stamp on Texts
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — Even as a panel of educators laid out a vision Wednesday for national standards for public schools, the Texas school board was going in a different direction, holding hearings on changes to its social studies curriculum that would portray conservatives in a more positive light, emphasize the role of Christianity in American history and include Republican political philosophies in textbooks.

headline: Forgot to Send a Birthday Card? Phone It In
text: SHORT video messages or greetings for phones could soon be as ubiquitous as texting, or at least that’s what greeting card companies and other firms are hoping as they try out a new mobile service that delivers a brief video, with sound and music, as quickly, easily and often as cheaply as sending a text.

headline: School Costs Fuel a Revolt Over Taxes
text: HASTINGS-ON-HUDSON, N.Y.

headline: The Waiting Game Continues for Curry
text: SAN ANTONIO — Eddy Curry planned to resume his Knicks career Wednesday, with earnest hopes that this comeback would be different from the one he began last November, or last summer, or last March, or in January 2009, or in the fall of 2008.

headline: Lundqvist Pulled as Rangers Lose Fourth in a Row
text: NEWARK — As soon as he plopped on a stool at the end of the Rangers’ bench, done for the night even though it was only the second period, Henrik Lundqvist had a towel draped over his shoulder by an equipment manager. Uncharacteristically, Lundqvist angrily flung it off.

headline: Damon Reflects on Time With Garciaparra
text: LAKELAND, Fla. – About a half-hour after Nomar Garciaparra announced his retirement from baseball on Wednesday morning, Johnny Damon heard the news about his former Red Sox teammate from a group of reporters. Garciaparra signed a one-day, minor-league contract with Boston so he could retire as a Red Sox.

headline: Knocked Out, St. John’s Ponders Coach’s Future
text: Scoreless through the first 31 minutes, forward Justin Brownlee banged home a dunk over Marquette’s front line to give St. John’s its first lead Wednesday in their Big East Conference tournament game. On the Red Storm’s next possession, Brownlee timed a cut along the baseline and exploded toward the rim after D. J. Kennedy penetrated and passed to him. That, too, was punctuated with a slam.

headline: Panel Urges New Look at Caesarean Guidelines
text: A panel of medical experts on Wednesday recommended steps to reverse a trend that has dismayed many pregnant women: the increasing difficulty of finding doctors and hospitals that will let a woman try to give birth normally if she has had a Caesarean section in the past.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: March 10, 2010

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Feb. 25 about the convictions in an Italian court of three Google executives of violating privacy laws because, prosecutors said, the company did not act fast enough to remove from its site a video showing teenagers harassing an autistic boy misstated how much video is regularly uploaded to YouTube, which Google bought in 2006. The company says it is 20 hours every minute, not every hour.

headline: Chinese Exports Increase 46% as Demand From West Rebounds
text: BEIJING — China announced Wednesday that its exports climbed 46 percent in February from a year earlier, a sign that economists said signaled a rebound in consumer demand from the United States and other Western markets.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Friday about a study that indicated that methane is leaking into the atmosphere from the East Siberian Arctic Shelf misquoted a researcher at the University of Alaska, Fairbanks, who, speaking by telephone, gave an estimate of the average atmospheric concentration of methane worldwide. The researcher, Natalia Shakhova, said it was 1.7 parts per million, not 0.6 or 0.7 parts per million.

headline: Corrections
text: Because of an editing error, a picture caption with an article on Friday about the relatively small increase in Chinese military spending announced at the opening session of the National People’s Congress, China’s legislature, misstated the relationship of Mao Xinyu, an officer in the People’s Liberation Army who was shown attending the session, to Mao Zedong. Mao Xinyu is a grandson, not a son.

headline: Scene From 'Mother'
text: A scene from the Bong Joon-ho film "Mother."

headline: Corrections
text: Because of an editing error, a photo caption on Tuesday with an article about an agreement by the Supreme Court to decide whether the father of a Marine killed in Iraq may sue protesters who carried inflammatory signs as they picketed his son’s funeral misstated, in some editions, the location of the funeral. It was Westminster, Md., not Topeka, Kan.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Saturday about the announcement by Representative William D. Delahunt, Democrat of Massachusetts, that he would not seek re-election to an eighth term, misstated the number of towns in Mr. Delahunt’s district in which a majority of voters chose Scott Brown, the Republican candidate, in the January election to fill the seat of Senator Edward M. Kennedy. Twenty-nine towns in the district voted for Mr. Brown, and 12 voted for his Democratic opponent, Martha Coakley. Not all but two towns voted for Mr. Brown.

headline: Corrections
text: The Advertising column on Friday, about a new campaign for Zappos.com, misspelled the surname of the builder of the puppets featured in the campaign, based on incorrect information provided by the agency. He is Randy Carfagno, not Cafagno.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Dec. 28 about legal battles among mobile phone companies implied incorrectly that lawsuits filed by Nokia last October and November against Apple, Samsung, LG and eight other competitors involved patent disputes. While Nokia is involved in numerous patent cases, the lawsuit filed against Apple was the only one of that group involving intellectual property issues. The others involved allegations of price-fixing for LCD screens.

headline: Corrections
text: A fashion column on Monday about what female stars wore to the Academy Awards ceremony misidentified the designer of Mo’Nique’s dress. It was by Tadashi Shoji, not Tom and Linda Platt, who have designed gowns for Mo’Nique for many years.

headline: Corrections
text: A photograph in some editions on Wednesday with an obituary about the architect Bruce J. Graham was published in error. It showed the John Hancock Tower in Boston with sailboats in the foreground, a building Mr. Graham did not design. He designed the John Hancock Center in Chicago.

headline: Corrections
text: An obituary on Tuesday about the actress Nan Martin misspelled the given name of a surviving son in some editions. He is Zen Gesner, not Zan.

headline: Three Airlines Near Deal for an Expanded Alliance
text: BRUSSELS — European antitrust regulators on Wednesday took a step toward approving an expanded alliance between British Airways, American Airlines and Iberia after the airlines offered to give up landing and takeoff slots at airports serving London and New York.

headline: Notre Dame Bounces Back to Eliminate Seton Hall
text: The coaching philosophy of Notre Dame’s Mike Brey once revolved around scoring 100 points. But an injury to the star forward Luke Harangody nearly a month ago forced the Irish to have an extreme makeover.

headline: A Last Chance for the Trade Center to Rise Again
text: AFTER years of false starts and broken promises, we have reached a defining moment in the rebuilding of the World Trade Center. By Friday, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey and the site’s developer, Larry Silverstein, must make a choice: Will they broker a compromise that allows them to move forward with rebuilding the historic heart of our city? Or will they allow their dispute to return to arbitration, condemning the World Trade Center site to years more of delays?

headline: Braking Bad
text: Marina del Rey, Calif.

headline: Caution: No Stops for Miles ... and Miles
text: To the Editor:

headline: How to Strengthen the Afghan National Police
text: To the Editor:

headline: After You
text: Recently, I have been considering the four-way stop. It is, I think, the most successful unit of government in the State of California. It may be the perfect model of participatory democracy, the ideal fusion of “first come, first served” and the golden rule. There are four-way stops elsewhere in the country. But they are ubiquitous in California, and they bring out a civility  let me call it a surprising civility  in drivers here in a state where so much has recently gone so wrong.

headline: Corrections
text: An obituary on March 3 about Hank Rosenstein, an original member of the New York Knicks, using information provided by the team and other sources, incorrectly described the ethnic makeup of the 1946 Knicks team that played in what is considered the first N.B.A. game. Six of Rosenstein’s teammates, not seven, were Jewish; Stan Stutz was not.

headline: Antitrust and Your Vote
text: When the nation’s largest voting machine manufacturer, Election Systems and Software, acquired the voting machine business of Diebold, the nation’s second-largest manufacturer, it set off alarms for anyone who cares about election integrity. The combination meant that 70 percent of the nation’s voting machines would be provided by just one company.

headline: Today’s Tea Partier: A Different Kind of Radical
text: To the Editor:

headline: What Ground Zero Needs
text: Ground zero is no longer the depressing place it was a few years ago. The important public structures are starting to take shape  the memorial to the victims, Santiago Calatrava’s birdlike transportation hub, and 1 World Trade Center (the centerpiece once known as the Freedom Tower), 20 stories high and climbing.

headline: On the Leadership of the President
text: To the Editor:

headline: Diplomacy 102
text: Vice President Joseph Biden Jr. used rare and decidedly undiplomatic language on Tuesday to upbraid Israel after it announced plans to build 1,600 new housing units in a Jewish neighborhood of East Jerusalem. “I condemn the decision. ...,” he said in a statement.

headline: Shelley Duncan Starts Over
text: GOODYEAR, Ariz. – They are not related. But Shelley and Eric Duncan have a lot in common besides their last name. Both were high draft picks by the Yankees, Shelley in the second round in 2001, Eric in the first round in 2003. Both have finally moved on – Shelley to the Cleveland Indians, Eric to the Atlanta Braves.

headline: Corrections
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Correction
text: An article last Thursday about Marty Hyman, a photographer who specializes in school class pictures, misstated his age. He is 64, not 67.

headline: In Battle for No. 5 Starter, Results Don’t Matter Yet
text: LAKELAND, Fla. – One of the first things Manager Joe Girardi said about his evaluation of the No. 5 starter candidates was that statistics would play only a small role. As for why, witness how Phil Hughes approached his fourth-inning matchup with Ryan Raburn of the Detroit Tigers on Wednesday.

headline: Drone Strikes Kill 21 in Pakistan
text: PESHAWAR, Pakistan — Two drone strikes since Monday in North Waziristan have killed at least 21 people, possibly including a top local commander, said a Pakistan security official and residents of the area, a stronghold of Al Qaeda and the Taliban.

headline: Oklahoma Freshmen Ready for N.B.A.? Coach Doesn’t Think So
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo.— There’s been plenty of whispers about whether the Oklahoma freshmen Tommy Mason-Griffin, a point guard, and Tiny Gallon, a power forward, could leave for the N.B.A.

headline: Africa, Here We Come
text: My Thursday column announces that Mitch Smith from the University of Nebraska-Lincoln has won my fourth annual Win-a-Trip Contest. I’ve posted his winning essay below.

headline: Battery Ventures Raises a Fresh $750 Million
text: The venture capital industry may be shrinking, but Battery Ventures is growing.

headline: Barclays Has an Appetite for a U.S. Bank
text: The trans-Atlantic ambitions of Barclays, the British bank, are moving to another level. Barclays became a big player on Wall Street by snapping up Lehman Brothers’ American operations after the firm collapsed in September 2008. The revelation that it is interested in buying a United States bank suggests it wants to become a familiar face on America’s Main Street, too.

headline: TARP Panel Finds Fault With GMAC Bailouts
text: WASHINGTON — A Congressional panel, in a report to be released Thursday, questioned the need for the Treasury Department’s $17.2 billion bailout of GMAC as the company dealt with the collapsing mortgage market in 2008 and 2009.
