headline: Senate Passes Bill That Would Extend Unemployment Benefits
text: WASHINGTON (Bloomberg News) — The Senate on Wednesday approved a $138 billion measure that would extend unemployment benefits and provide additional aid to states in lawmakers’ second major effort this year to help the economy.

headline: Enigmatic Louisville Falls to Cincinnati
text: The most effective Louisville Cardinal on the Madison Square Garden court Wednesday was once told to transfer by Coach Rick Pitino when he was a sophomore. Back then, Edgar Sosa was slapped with the label of being selfish, sloppy and simply too much to put up with.

headline: Corey Haim, Actor, Dies at 38
text: Corey Haim, an actor whose status as a teenage heartthrob of the 1980s gave way to substance abuse and rehabilitation as an adult, died on Wednesday at a hospital in Burbank, Calif. He was 38.

headline: Decision Awaits Oklahoma Guard
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — At last year’s Big 12 tournament, the buzz was whether Oklahoma shooting guard Willie Warren would leave for the N.B.A. draft.

headline: Jones Makes W.N.B.A. Comeback
text: The former sprinter Marion Jones signed a contract to play for the Tulsa Shock of the W.N.B.A.

text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page.

headline: New Strike Paralyzes Greece
text: ATHENS — Most international travel was halted and public services thrown into disarray on Thursday as thousands of Greek workers protesting austerity measures staged a general strike and joined demonstrations in the capital that turned violent.

text: For 18 years, Gary G. Gensler worked on Wall Street, striking merger deals at the venerable Goldman Sachs. Then in the late 1990s, he moved to the Treasury Department, joining a Washington establishment that celebrated the power of markets and fought off regulation at almost every turn, Graham Bowley reports in The New York Times.

text: Senate Banking Committee members from both parties said on Wednesday that they had agreed to include in their regulatory overhaul bill a new Office of Research and Analysis that would provide early warnings of possible systemic collapses, Edward Wyatt and Sewell Chan report in The New York Times.

text: WHAT city, according to this article, trumps all other American cities when it comes to the breakfast taco? WHAT is in a breakfast taco? WHAT do you usually eat for breakfast?

headline: Bank of China Plans New Hong Kong Issue
text: Bank of China wants to issue additional Hong Kong-listed H shares as soon as possible,  in an offering equal to 20 percent of its existing H share capital, the bank’s chairman said Thursday, Reuters reported.

headline: ‘American Idol': The Top 8 Men
text: The short version: Casey James > Lee Dewyze > Michael Lynche > Todrick Hall > Andrew Garcia > Tim Urban > Alex Lambert > Aaron Kelly.

headline: BP Buying Devon Energy Assets for $7 Billion
text: BP said Thursday that it would pay Devon Energy $7 billion for assets in Brazil, Azerbaijan and the Gulf of Mexico, and that the two firms would form a joint venture to develop an oil sands project in Alberta, Canada.

headline: How Would You ‘Sell’ Your School to Potential Students?
text: Because of the growth in charter schools, some New York City public schools are beginning to feel they need to “market” themselves to draw interested students and parents, according to this article. If you were in charge of marketing your school to local families, what aspects of it would you highlight? How?

headline: A Place to Bet Real Money on Movies
text: Think that this spring’s “Robin Hood” movie will be a blockbuster at the box office? Next week you will be able to put your money on it, Joseph Plambeck reports for The New York Times.

text: Shares of Baltic Trading closed down slightly Wednesday after remaining virtually flat during the company’s trading debut, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Eyeblaster Takes Another Shot at I.P.O.
text: Eyeblaster, an online advertising company, is making another run at the public markets. The company said Wednesday that it is planning an initial public offering, though it did not disclose an expected size or price range, The Associated Press reported.

text: BANGKOK — Thailand’s seemingly unending political crisis is likely to reach another moment of tension this weekend with huge opposition rallies that organizers say they hope will paralyze the city and bring down the government.

text: Brian Moynihan can talk the talk, Reuters Breakingviews says. He made a good impression on Wednesday in his first solo presentation since becoming chief executive of Bank of America at the start of the year.

text: Viterra is offering to buy Dakota Growers Pasta for $240 million, a deal that would put Viterra, a Canadian food processing and grain handling company, into the spaghetti business.

headline: China Caps Bankers’ Bonuses
text: China has tightened controls on pay for its top bankers, joining global efforts to try to limit financial risks by linking longer-term performance more closely to compensation, The Associated Press reports.

headline: Lawsuits, Poker and a Boutique Bank’s Death
text: In September 2008, as Lehman Brothers was breaking into a million pieces, a young investment bank was pushing up through the rubble.

headline: CA Acquires Nimsoft for $350 Million in Cash
text: CA, the technology management software company, said on Wednesday that it was buying Nimsoft for $350 million in cash.

headline: Private Equity Executive Pushed to Join Senate Race
text: Encouraged by state and national Republican Party leaders, Dan Senor, an author, private equity executive and Defense Department adviser in the last Bush administration, is seriously considering a political challenge against Senator Kirsten E. Gillibrand, The New York Times’s Michael Barbaro reported, citing three people told of the discussions.

headline: HSBC Says 15,000 Hit by Swiss Data Case
text: HSBC Holdings said the theft of Swiss client data at the heart of a recent tax dispute with France was vastly larger than it had previously acknowledged, involving at least 15,000 clients, David Jolly reported in The New York Times.

headline: At a London Show, Changing the Rules of Design
text: The artist, designer and architect Ron Arad first made a splash in 1981 when, inspired by Marcel Duchamp’s found objects, he bought a couple of red leather car seats salvaged from an old Rover car, attached them to metal frames and called the result “Rover Chair.” Over the years, similar reinventions of everyday objects followed. Now, through May 16, the first major show in London of the Israeli-born, London-based creative maverick is on display at the Barbican Center (Silk Street; 44-207-638-4141; barbican.org.uk).

headline: Unexpectedly, EMI Moves to Replace Top Exec
text: The struggling British music company EMI announced on Wednesday that Elio Leoni-Sceti, the chief executive of its recorded music division, will step down at the end of March after less than two years in the job, The New York Times’s Joseph Plambeck reported.

headline: Three Airlines Near Deal for an Expanded Alliance
text: European antitrust regulators on Wednesday took a step toward approving an expanded alliance between British Airways, American Airlines and Iberia after the airlines offered to give up landing and takeoff slots at airports serving London and New York, The New York Times’s James Kanter reported.

headline: In Early Tally, Tight Iraq Race Deepens Splits
text: BAGHDAD — Iraq’s major coalitions were locked in a surprisingly close race on Thursday, in initial results from elections that deepened divisions across a fractured landscape. Candidates were quick to charge fraud, heightening concerns whether Iraq’s fledgling institutions were strong enough to support a peaceful transfer of power.

headline: A.I.G.’s Taiwan Sale Stalls on Regulations
text: The American International Group has managed to agree to jumbo asset sales this month, but a smaller disposal — that of its Taiwan life insurance unit, Nan Shan Life — remains in regulatory limbo, Bettina Wassener reports in The New York Times.

text: Tullett Prebon of Britain said on Wednesday that it was in “preliminary discussions with a third party,” sending shares in the financial firm up more than 25 percent.

headline: Karzai Meets With Top Officials in Pakistan
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan met with Prime Minister Yousaf Raza Gilani here on Thursday in a show of public friendship, even as the two sides tried to work through underlying tensions over how to deal with the Taliban militants who use the countries’ lawless border region as a sanctuary.

text: Peter Boone is chairman of the charity Effective Intervention and a research associate at the Center for Economic Performance at the London School of Economics. He is also a principal in Salute Capital Management Ltd. Simon Johnson, a senior fellow at the Peterson Institute for International Economics, is the former chief economist at the International Monetary Fund.

headline: Fate vs. Will in Afghanistan
text: Today’s idea: The Afghan war revives an ancient intellectual debate: Can individual agency prevail over determinism — “the belief that historical, cultural, ethnic, economic, and other antecedent forces determine the future of men and nations”?

headline: An Uzbek Mogul Goes High-Tech
text: Alisher B. Usmanov, an Uzbek from a tiny village near the Kyrgyz border, has led the most improbable life, according to a Forbes profile  by Anita Raghavan.

headline: G.M. Chief Says U.S. Will Make Money on Bailout
text: General Motors will pay back roughly $8 billion in debt to the United States and Canada before June and could go public in a way that would allow taxpayers to make a profit on the bailout, the automaker’s chief executive, Ed Whitacre, said on Wednesday.

text: My battalion commander, Lt. Col. Michael Kurilla, gave the directive that my squad leaders, platoon sergeant, and myself had heard countless times: my platoon was to cordon and search a neighborhood that intelligence had indicated might be the whereabouts of a high value target.

headline: BofA Under Pressure to Shrink, Report Says
text: Regulators have told Bank of America‘s chief executive, Brian T. Moynihan, and other executives that the largest U.S. bank by assets must become “much smaller,” Fox Business Network’s Charlie Gasparino reported.

headline: Macquarie Said to Want Expanded U.S. Presence
text: The Macquarie Group, Australia’s largest investment bank, may snap up more U.S. assets and wants to add more bankers in the United States to advise energy, industrial and technology companies, Bloomberg News reported, citing an interview with a top company executive.

headline: Porsche’s Stealth Debut
text: Almost as amazing as the specs on the Porsche 918 Spyder plug-in hybrid concept is the fact that Porsche managed to keep the car under wraps until its world debut last week at the Geneva Auto Show.

headline: Samsung Life I.P.O. Gets Approval
text: The South Korean bourse approved an estimated $4 billion initial public offering by Samsung Life Insurance on Thursday, paving the way for what is likely to be the country’s biggest share float in May, Reuters reported.

headline: Sampler: Drug Cases Dismissed in San Francisco and Can a Big House be Green?
text: More Evidence Found in Santa Clara | Public defenders in Santa Clara County are waiting to see how the cases of accused sex offenders may be affected by the district attorney’s office effort to gather new evidence from the Santa Clara Valley Medical Center. Some new material, known as intake forms, collected by the center’s sexual assault response team were discovered this week. The discovery comes after last year’s revelation that the center had 3,000 videotapes of medical exams of children who were alleged victims of assault. The videotapes have already led to the release of a man  convicted earlier and have put other convictions at risk. An appellate court ruled two years ago that hospital examiners were part of the “prosecution team” and that the district attorney’s office was responsible for making sure evidence was turned over to defendants. “I’m sure they were dismayed at the discovery, and I’m glad to see they are jumping on it,” said the public defender, Mary Greenwood. “We hope and believe the defense perspective will be solicited about the value of what else they find.” [The San Jose Mercury News]

headline: New Strike Paralyzes Greece
text: Most international travel was halted and public services thrown into disarray on Thursday as thousands of Greek workers protesting austerity measures staged a general strike, Niki Kitsantonis reports in The New York Times.

headline: In Hedge Funds, More Closings Than Openings
text: Hedge fund closings outpaced starts in 2009, the second year in a row that more funds shuttered than opened, Pensions & Investments reported, citing new data from Hedge Fund Research.

headline: Speed Read for Thursday, March 11
text: Here are some highlights from Thursday’s edition of The New York Times:

headline: Geithner Said to Warn E.U. on Fund Regulation
text: The U.S. Treasury secretary, Timothy F. Geithner, has written to the European Commission warning that plans to regulate hedge funds and private equity firms could cause tensions with Washington, The Financial Times reported.

headline: In Bond Auction, Signs of Confidence in Portugal
text: Portugal sold more bonds than initially planned Wednesday — at a lower borrowing cost than the previous similar issue — suggesting markets were becoming more confident after the country outlined its strategy to cut a ballooning fiscal gap, Reuters reported.

headline: Sins of Son and, Perhaps, Father in a Brooklyn Court
text: The phone call came from jail, a son’s plea for help that would sorely test a father’s judgment. The son begged his father to retrieve money from a safe that the son said contained tens of thousands of dollars in lottery winnings that would cover the cost of a lawyer.

headline: Pimco Chief Addresses Sovereign Debt Mess
text: Mohamed A. El-Erian, whose company runs the world’s biggest mutual fund, said deteriorating public finances might affect the global economy more than was currently realized, Bloomberg News reported, citing a piece in The Financial Times.

headline: A Different Route to Corn-Based Fuel
text: Jack Huttner, the executive vice president of Gevo, a five-year old company in Englewood, Colo., would like to take over an ethanol plant and, using the same base ingredients that go into corn-based ethanol – corn and natural gas for fuel – manufacture a different molecule: isobutanol.

headline: Arguments Against Dolphin Slaughter
text: Louis Psihoyos, the former National Geographic photographer who won an Oscar on Sunday for “The Cove,” his first documentary film, sat down for a conversation with me at the Asia Society on Tuesday on various aspects of the ongoing slaughter of dolphins in Japan and his team’s work exposing the serving of Sei whale meat at The Hump, a sushi restaurant in Santa Monica, Calif. Here’s video of the discussion:

headline: Gates Meets With Ruler of Emirates on Iran
text: ABU DHABI—Defense secretary Robert M. Gates met here on Thursday with the crown prince of the United Arab Emirates as part of an intensifying American effort to build up defenses with Arab allies and contain Iran’s military might in the Persian Gulf.

headline: U.N. to End Some Deals for Food to Somalia
text: KIGALI, Rwanda — The United Nations World Food Program announced Thursday that it would not give any new contracts to three Somali businessmen who have been accused of diverting food aid to Islamist militants and that the agency would welcome an independent investigation into its Somalia operations.

headline: Strike Disrupts Airports, Subways and Other Transit in Greece
text: Most international travel was halted, and public services thrown into disarray on Thursday as thousands of Greek workers protesting austerity measures staged a general strike.

headline: Fifty-One Herbert Hoovers
text: More than a year ago I coined a phrase that seems to have made its way into the econolexicon; writing about how cutbacks at the state and local level would tend to undermine fiscal stimulus at the federal level, I said that we had fifty Herbert Hoovers.

headline: China Increases Security in Tibet to Prevent Protests
text: BEIJING — For a second straight year, the Chinese government has increased security across parts of the vast Tibetan plateau to dissuade any Tibetans from holding protests this week to mark the anniversaries of ethnic uprisings. Witnesses who have spent time recently in Lhasa, the Tibetan capital, and other Tibetan areas of western China say there are more police and paramilitary forces on the streets, some of them bearing automatic weapons.

headline: Intel Goes ‘Mad’ as Big-Event TV Strategy Continues
text: One of the most notable trends on Madison Avenue so far this year is the embrace of so-called big event television by advertisers, which are seeking to run commercials during the live coverage of major programs like the Grammys, the Super Bowl, the Winter Olympics and the Academy Awards.

headline: Is Sexual Anorexia the Flip Side of Sex Addiction?
text: A panel of experts joined the Consults blog recently to answer readers’ questions about sex addiction. Here, Dr. Drew Pinsky responds to one reader who wonders why too little sex isn’t given the same attention as too much.

headline: Fed Joins A.I.G. Loss-Sharing Pact With MetLife
text: The Federal Reserve Bank of New York is joining the American International Group in a loss-sharing agreement that is part of the insurer’s sale of its American Life Insurance Company unit to MetLife, Bloomberg News reports.

headline: March Madness: The Geek Edition
text: For some of us, the annual arrival of the N.C.A.A. basketball tournament comes in March with mixed emotions: we love seeing adversaries pitted against one another in winner-take-all matches. But we have no idea who the competitors are, possibly because we spent too much time growing up reading fantasy and science fiction novels when we should have been playing sports. (At least, that’s what our gym classmates said.) Finally, there’s a tournament for our crowd.

headline: Thursday Reading

headline: How to Cook Up a Food Celebrity
text: It could have been the Cannes film festival, the way the water glittered in the background and the fans swarmed their favorite stars and the photographers clicked and clicked. One of those photographers, scruffy and lavishly tattooed, appeared suddenly as Katie Lee walked from her grand hotel, where the event’s organizers had ensconced her in a junior suite on a high floor, toward the temporary city of beachfront tents where her presentation would take place.

headline: Aftershocks Jolt Chile as New President Is Sworn In
text: SANTIAGO, Chile — Chile’s new president, Sebastián Piñera, was minutes from being sworn in on Thursday when major aftershocks struck the central coast of this earthquake-ravaged country. But less than an hour after being inaugurated, he appeared on television to announce that troops, relief supplies and even Mr. Piñera himself would be heading immediately to the quake zone.

headline: Ontario’s Clean Water Tech Cluster

headline: Hamas Releases British Journalist

headline: Conan O’Brien Announces Details of National Tour

The second New York appearance at Radio City will be on June 2. The second Chicago date, at the Chicago Theater, is May 20. The second Boston appearance at the Wang Theater is set for June 5.

headline: Microsoft’s Free Sync Service
text: Last week, I wrote about an underpublicized gem in Microsoft's Windows Live suite of free online and offline services and programs: SkyDrive. It's a free, 25-gigabyte virtual hard drive on the Internet, accessible from any computer.

headline: Israeli Ad Riffs on Dubai Assassination

headline: ‘Smokers Are Supposed to Quit’
text: Monologue |  Wednesday night on “Late Night With Jimmy Fallon” on NBC: Hey, today is No Smoking Day, where smokers are supposed to quit cigarettes for the day. Or as Sasha and Malia call it, “Daddy’s in a Really Bad Mood Day.”

headline: ‘Fishing in Rivers and Lakes’
text: Monologue |  Wednesday night on “The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson” on CBS: Some Web sites are saying the Obama administration may ban fishing in rivers and lakes. The new fishing rules haven’t been announced yet, so I’m not sure what’s really going on. On Fox News, they’re saying, “Obama wages jihad on fishing.” On NPR, they’re saying, “Obama protects aquatic unicorns.”

headline: ‘Limbaugh Leaving’
text: Monologue |  Wednesday night on “The Jay Leno Show” on NBC: Earlier today, the president of Haiti was at the White House to meet with President Obama. He said the people of his country need jobs, they need places to live, and they need health care. And then the president of Haiti spoke.

headline: Biden to Leave Mideast Amid Unease
text: TEL AVIV — Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. came to Israel early this week to promote new Israeli-Palestinian peace talks and tighten the bonds between Israel and the United States. He left Thursday amid increased uncertainty over the nature and timing of those talks and with a sense of unease hanging over the American-Israeli relationship.

headline: Fiat Names VW Marketer to Lead U.S. Return
text: Fiat, returning to the United States market late this year, has named Laura J. Soave, VW’s general manager of experiential marketing, to head its operations in North America, reports Reuters. She reports directly to Sergio Marchionne, chief executive of Fiat and the Chrysler Group.

headline: Is Green Insurance Worth the Price?
text: Insurers are increasingly offering insurance discounts if you already own an environmentally friendly home or car as well as additions to standard policies that cover the costs of going green when renovating after a loss.

headline: All You Need Is Luxe
text: Midway through “Imagine: John Lennon,” the 1988 documentary, Lennon and his new bride, Yoko Ono, are seen prancing through a London airport clad in matching white pantsuits. As “The Ballad of John and Yoko” plays in the background — the tune in which Lennon bemoans that he and Ono are criticized for looking like “two gurus in drag” — viewers get a glimpse of a media-savvy peacock. The world’s constant gaze was clearly wearying for Lennon, but that was O.K. because he didn’t always take himself seriously. He knew how to have a good time and how to work a look.

headline: Agency Weighs the Need for a ‘Black Box’ in Cars
text: DETROIT — Federal safety regulators, who allowed auto companies to voluntarily install event data recorders on their vehicles a few years ago, are now looking into whether the systems should be required, the head of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration said on Thursday.

headline: No One Writes Like a Dame: Judi Dench to Publish Memoir
text: It only makes sense that Judi Dench, after accumulating a lifetime’s worth of theater, film and television credits that could easily fill up a book, should finally write one. St. Martin’s Press said it had acquired a memoir from Ms. Dench, called “And Furthermore,” that will detail her professional and private lives, according to a press release from the publisher. Though she has lately come to be known for her role as M in the James Bond franchise, and as Queen Elizabeth in “Shakespeare in Love” (for which she won an Academy Award for just a few minutes of screen time), Ms. Dench will cover the breadth of her acting career in the memoir, from her start with England’s Old Vic theater company in 1957, to joining the Royal Shakespeare Company in 1961 to playing Sally Bowles in “Cabaret” in the 1968 London production (not to mention her performances in “Hay Fever,” “A Little Night Music,” “Amy’s View,” “A Midsummer Night’s Dream” and the television series “A Fine Romance” and As Time Goes By”). St. Martin’s said it would publish “And Furthermore” (along with, we’re sure, a healthy index) in October.

The Times’s Pete Thamel and Kevin Armstrong, along with Zach Hillesland, a former Notre Dame forward who is now an academic adviser in the athletic department, are at Madison Square Garden and will provide analysis and updates throughout the day. headline: New Site Unmasks Chatroulette Players
text: I have a confession to make. I’m addicted to Chatroulette, the buzz-generating Web site created by a Russian teenager that pairs anonymous strangers with each other in a video chat room.

headline: Artifacts | ’80s Repro Men
text: Art has always had its icons, and they didn’t just come from the church. Popular mythology made idols of van Gogh, Pollock and Basquiat, while entrepreneurial types like Warhol, Hirst and Murakami went ahead and branded themselves. Now comes an exhibition that offers a fresh — as in nervy — perspective on the New York stars of the 1980s, whose reactive work not only created a new fashion for art collectors to follow but changed the game for other artists as well.

headline: A Jostled Princess, a Heavy Crown
text: TOKYO — When an official at the Imperial Household Agency suddenly announced last week that 8-year-old Princess Aiko was refusing to go to school because of bullying, he did more than just disclose a mundane problem facing a member of Japan’s ancient and secretive monarchy.

headline: A Pair of Cable Upfront Pitches Suggests a Better Mood on Madison Avenue
text: Are the stars out tonight? They were on Wednesday night and Thursday morning, at a pair of cable upfront presentations that seemed to indicate an improvement in the long-gloomy mood on Madison Avenue.

headline: (Plenty of) Time to Reflect on the Irish Offense
text: So, while Notre Dame elbowed its way back into college basketball’s consciousness by shoving aside Seton Hall in the Big East men’s basketball tournament, it gave everyone time to think. That’s because, in its now distinctive un-mad March style, the Irish create large gaps of unused time between baskets. While the retro style might be pure brilliance by Notre Dame Coach Mike Brey, as some like Yahoo’s Jason King suggest, it was absolutely necessary, writes Stewart Mandel of SI.com, or everyone in Golden Dome land would still be fixating on scrubbing those messy footprints Charlie Weis left all over its football program. Because Notre Dame was going nowhere fast until Brey discovered he could bore opponents into oblivion.

headline: Merlin Olsen, Football Star, Commentator and Actor, Dies at 69
text: Merlin Olsen, the Hall of Fame tackle who anchored the Los Angeles Rams’ Fearsome Foursome, the line that glamorized defensive play in the National Football League, died early Thursday at a hospital in Duarte, Calif. He was 69.

headline: Could Tomlinson Sign With the Jets?
text: When the Jets released Thomas Jones after he declined to take a pay cut, the prevailing analysis was that Jones may have slowed at the end of last season, but the Jets were losing an experienced veteran who was a tremendous locker-room presence. Might they be trying to lure someone just like Jones to replace him?

headline: Tale of Botched Traffic Operation Increases Russians’ Mistrust of Moscow Police

headline: The Hour Approaches for Stage Version of ‘A Time to Kill’

headline: Beckham Grabs the Scarf, but Not the Reins, of Protest
text: It was a highly significant game in the Champions League knockout match between Manchester United and AC Milan last night and Wayne Rooney continued his devastating form with two more goals in what is a 30-goal season so far. Nani made one of the assists of the tournament to set up Rooney’s second, curling the ball into his teammate’s path with the outside of his foot. The 4-0 defeat exposed AC Milan as an aging, blunt shadow of its former team, increasingly reliant on Ronaldinho’s capricious flashes of brilliance.

headline: Beware of Greeks Getting Gifts?

headline: More to Do, and Less to Do It With
text: Money and personnel for the Civilian Complaint Review Board — the independent agency that investigates allegations of police abuse — are in steep decline. The board’s budget has been cut by more than $3 million in the last three years.

headline: Letter: Scott Brown
text: Future historians may well include two Browns from New England who altered the arc of social justice in America: John Brown, the abolitionist whose words and deeds provided the backbone and impetus for the Civil War and an end to slavery; and Scott Brown, the newly elected Republican senator from Massachusetts, who may well be noted as the one whose opposition to national health-insurance reform (despite voting for similar legislation in his home state) ended the last best chance for health care for all. Historians will also note the paradox of Scott Brown unexpectedly replacing Edward M. Kennedy — the greatest champion of the view that health care is a right and the craftsman of the legislation that Brown eventually defeated — and taking a seat once held by Kennedy’s brother John F. Kennedy, whose chief published work was “Profiles in Courage,” a 1950s book that examines various senators who took courageous, principled positions and votes in opposition to their party.

headline: After Tearing Down Roster, Indians Try to Rebuild

Sabathia and Cliff Lee, had been teammates on the Indians just 16 months earlier. Each won an American League Cy Young Award, only to be traded in the swift overhaul of a team that had nearly won a pennant.

headline: Learning to Keep Patients Safe in a Culture of Fear
text: One afternoon during my training, I watched as one of my closest friends, another surgery resident, was led into the office of the department chief. A week earlier she had been on call when a patient developed a rapid and irregular heart rhythm. He became unconscious and would have soon died if my friend had not stepped in and resuscitated him.

headline: Taxes and the Ryan Plan
text: In the last few days, there have been a series of liberal attacks on the tax proposals in Paul Ryan’s fiscal roadmap. For the most part, they’ve been based on this Tax Policy Center report, which suggests that the Ryan version of the tax code would only raise revenue equal to 16.8 percent of G.D.P., rather than the 19 percent that’s required, under the roadmap’s assumptions, to keep the budget balanced. Here’s the statement Ryan issued in response:

headline: Depression’s Upside
text: The propositions juxtaposed by Jonah Lehrer are not mutually exclusive. Depression, as framed in his article, could be an adaptive tendency to rethink decisions and mull over past events, thereby increasing focus. When severe, however, depression could be regarded as a brain disease and the inability to stop repetitive thinking could be seen as a symptom.

headline: Correction
text: An article on Feb. 28 about the benefits of depression misstated the name of a university in Australia where studies have been done on the subject. It is the University of New South Wales, not South Wales.

headline: Her Two Faces: Belter and Crooner

Her bluff was called when people asked her from what part of the city she came, and she naïvely replied “Carnegie Hall.”

headline: The Concierge | Paris for Lovers

headline: The Femivore’s Dilemma
text: Four women I know — none of whom know one another — are building chicken coops in their backyards. It goes without saying that they already raise organic produce: my town, Berkeley, Calif., is the Vatican of locavorism, the high church of Alice Waters. Kitchen gardens are as much a given here as indoor plumbing. But chickens? That ups the ante. Apparently it is no longer enough to know the name of the farm your eggs came from; now you need to know the name of the actual bird.

headline: Births to Minorities Are Approaching Majority in U.S.

headline: Off the Train, a Motley Hub
text: The heart of South Norwalk, Conn., rows of buildings from the late 19th and early 20th centuries on Washington and South Main Streets, packs a lot into a compact area. The upper floors of the buildings have artists’ studios, and, at street level, the collection of restaurants, shops and galleries is diverse enough to please anyone who makes the ride — only an hour or so — from Grand Central Terminal on the Metro-North Railroad ($19.50 round-trip on weekends, $10 for children). It’s all within an easy walk of the station, too — including the Maritime Aquarium, the one relatively new building in the group and the one that enables grown-ups to enjoy browsing and shopping while still entertaining the children.

headline: Hoffmann’s Wednesday: Hockey Night in Minnesota

headline: Executive Departures at Clean Energy Firms
text: The past week has brought a spate of executive departures at renewable energy start-ups, with the president of SolarReserve, a power plant builder, and the chief executives of Clipper Windpower and Aurora Biofuels stepping down.

headline: Like Beltran, Reyes Could Miss Start of the Season
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Jose Reyes’s hyperthyroid condition is not considered serious and no medication is being prescribed to treat it, the Mets said Thursday, but he is still a likely candidate to begin the season on the disabled list.

headline: Microsoft’s Free Sync Service
text: Last week, I wrote about an underpublicized gem in Microsoft’s Windows Live suite of free online and offline services and programs: SkyDrive. It’s a free, 25-gigabyte virtual hard drive on the Internet, accessible from any computer.

headline: The Blogging of the Candidate
text: After years of sitting in a room in Southern California writing a blog for Slate magazine, you’re planning to challenge Senator Barbara Boxer in the Democratic primary in California in June. What led you to get into politics?   I’ve been a blogger since 1999, and it hasn’t done the job. In California, the Democratic Party is worse than it was when I started. The only thing left is the interest groups. It used to be a functioning party independent of labor, and now that has atrophied.

headline: Europe and U.S. Quarrel Over Hedge Funds
text: The European Union on Thursday rebutted criticism by the United States of its plans to tighten the rules on hedge funds, even as Britain sought to water down the regulation to safeguard its own financial sector,  James Kanter of The New York Times reports from Brussels.

headline: Cuomo Hands Paterson Case to an Ex-Judge
text: ALBANY — Facing growing political pressure, Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo on Thursday appointed an independent counsel to take over his office’s investigation into the Paterson administration’s response to a domestic violence case.

headline: Vehicle Built in 1935 as a Flying Car Goes on Sale
text: A contraption built in 1935 to be a flying car is going on the auction block this weekend, reports Wired Autopia, but there is no evidence that the vehicle ever got off the ground.

headline: Part 4: Answers on Historically Black Colleges and Universities
text: More than 100 American institutions are classified by the government as historically black colleges and universities through a formal program intended “to overcome the effects of discriminatory treatment and to strengthen and expand the capacity of historically black colleges and universities to provide quality education.”

headline: More on Happy Employees
text: In my last post, I wrote about my desire to have happy people working for me. Perhaps I could have been clearer when I said that I fire unhappy people. Instead of unhappy, I probably should have said disrespectful (to others, not me), incompetent, unreasonable, undependable, irresponsible, unproductive, dysfunctional (I did say that one), angry, whiny or mean — and beyond a manager’s ability to repair (actually, I said that, too). I think most people understood the context of my post, but there were a few comments or questions that required a response.

headline: Starbucks Fans Can Become ‘Baristas’ on Foursquare
text: Beginning Thursday, latte addicts who visit Starbucks outlets can get more than just a caffeine fix. They will also be rewarded on Foursquare with a barista badge.

headline: Thank You For Being Her Friend: Online Campaign Helps Betty White Onto ‘Saturday Night Live’
text: Call it a victory for democracy or peer pressure, but either way it’s happening: Betty White, the 88-years-young “Mary Tyler Moore” and “Golden Girls” star will host “Saturday Night Live” on May 8, a pre-Mother’s Day episode that will also feature appearances from six veteran female “SNL” cast members.

headline: A Ballet Expatriate Returns Home
text: ANGEL CORELLA has been a star at American Ballet Theater since he joined it in 1995 as a fresh-faced 19-year-old who had until then been a corps de ballet dancer in his native Spain. There were few choices at home for an aspiring ballet dancer. The Victor Ullate Ballet, which Mr. Corella joined at 15, was a small Madrid troupe; the national ballet company was renamed the Compañía Nacional de Danza in 1990 when the contemporary dance choreographer Nacho Duato was appointed director. So when Mr. Corella entered the International Ballet Competition in Paris and won first prize, he promptly decamped to New York.

headline: Nuggets Expect Karl Back Quickly After Surgery
text: Nuggets coach George Karl missed Wednesday’s game against at the Timberwolves, remaining in Denver for cancer treatment.

headline: Close Collaborators With Little in Common
text: IN 2003 the New York choreographer Yasuko Yokoshi met a woman who changed her life. A relationship had brought her to Tokyo for a year, and she was at loose ends. “I wanted to chill out,” she said. “I thought it would be interesting to learn traditional Japanese dance  to just kind of kill time.”

headline: Woman Killed by Train at 77th Street, Police Say
text: Updated, 5:34 p.m. | The police are now saying that the person fatally struck by the train was a woman, not a girl. Inspector James Murtagh, a police official at the scene, said she was in her 40s. He did not offer further details.

headline: Christians Urged to Boycott Glenn Beck
text: 4:51 p.m. | Updated Last week, the conservative broadcaster Glenn Beck called on Christians to leave their churches if they heard any preaching about social or economic justice because, he claimed, those were slogans affiliated with Nazism and Communism.

headline: Israel Charges 2 Soldiers in Gaza War Case
text: JERUSALEM — The Israeli military prosecutor charged two Israeli staff sergeants on Thursday with instructing a 9-year-old Palestinian boy to open several bags the soldiers suspected were booby-trapped during Israel’s military campaign in Gaza just over a year ago.

headline: Courthouse Prison Break, Part 2
text: A suspect escaped from a Staten Island courthouse on Wednesday after he posed as another prisoner during an arraignment and was mistakenly released, according to the authorities.

text: Read all nine volumes of the Lehman examiner’s report online here.

headline: Citigroup’s Chief Is Optimistic on Profit Growth
text: Citigroup is moving from controlling damage to pursuing increased profits. Vikram S. Pandit, Citi’s chief executive, laid out ambitious targets for growth on Thursday afternoon, saying the bank’s return on assets should rise to 1.25 to 1.5 percent in the near future, from the current 1.15 percent. But the bank would not comment on when it would hit those goals or how it would deal with the billions of dollars of bad securities that remain as part of its Citi Holdings.

text: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases, movie trailers, showtimes and tickets: nytimes.com/movies.

text: Last week for National Grammar Day we invited Grammarlogues to write our first guest post, “5 Easy Ways to Learn Grammar With The New York Times.”

headline: London Underground | Emotional Baggage
text: While people love to talk about fashion-design crossovers, good ones aren’t that easy to find — which is why the Crafted Fashion collection from Williams-British Handmade is so refreshing.

headline: Iraqi Elections
text: Early results in the 2010 Iraqi Elections show a close race. New York Times reporter Marc Santora looks at how the narrow margins may lead to new alliances.

headline: A Search for That Casualty, Truth
text: “We’re here to do a job,” says an American soldier in Baghdad, about a month after the United States-led invasion of Iraq and a third of the way into “Green Zone,” Paul Greengrass’s breakneck tour of street-level mayhem and official deceit. “The reasons don’t matter.”

text: President Obama made good on his promise to give his $1.4 million Nobel Prize money to charity, releasing the names on Thursday of the organizations that will benefit.

text: “It is about renewal.”

text: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art.

headline: Ground Broken on Atlantic Yards Project
text: After years of delays and lawsuits, officials broke ground Thursday afternoon on $4.9 billion Atlantic Yards project near Downtown Brooklyn.

headline: Media Decoded: Without Ads, Who Needs Critics?
text: Right after the Oscars, Variety, the trade bible of Hollywood, let go of their chief film critic, Todd McCarthy, a move got the thumbs down from a host of observers. What in the world was it thinking? Let’s discuss.

headline: Deal Gives New Life to Overhaul of Student Loans
text: WASHINGTON — Democratic Congressional leaders struck a tentative agreement on Thursday that breathes new life into President Obama’s proposed overhaul of federal student loan programs.

headline: Irish Arts Center Open Day
text: St. Patrick’s Day is coming soon and the libations will surely be flowing around town this weekend, but there is more to Irish culture than that, you know. On Sunday afternoon the Irish Arts Center in Clinton presents its annual Open Day, a free sampler of Irish culture.

headline: Spare Times
text: AROUND TOWN

headline: Scorecard | Alexander McQueen Wins!
text: Four weeks to the day after Scorecard learned the tragic news of Alexander McQueen’s passing, on the day originally slotted by the Fédération Française for his runway showing, the designer’s final collection was shown in presentation in the rococo environs of PPR’s 18th-century headquarters. With golden feathers, paillettes and embroidery topping prints digitally constructed from the religious iconography of Old Masters, it was a beautiful requiem to a creative genius who made anything else look very much of this world.

headline: Switzerland’s Quirky Transportation Museum
text: LUCERNE, Switzerland — The extraordinary popularity of Geneva’s auto show, which ends this weekend, may seem a bit odd, given Switzerland’s lack of an automobile industry, not to mention its world leadership in gasoline-free forms of transportation, its longtime ban on motor sports and its traditional support of odd laws like the early 1970s edict outlawing Rolls-Royce hood ornaments (because they might hurt pedestrians).

headline: Spare Times: For Children
text: ‘ADVENTURES WITH DORA AND DIEGO’  (Friday through Sunday, and Tuesday through Thursday) The young Latino stars of the Nickelodeon animated television series “Dora the Explorer” and “Go, Diego, Go!” have taken their expeditions into new territory at the Children’s Museum of Manhattan, whose exhibition has separate Dora and Diego environments, including Diego’s Animal Rescue Center and Dora’s Fiesta. Intended for ages 2 to 6, the interactive, bilingual displays are designed to teach language, science and music skills, as well as facts about Latin America. From 10 a.m. to 5 p.m., Tisch Building, 212 West 83rd Street , (212) 721-1223, cmom.org; free with museum admission: $10; $7 for 65+; free for under 1 and members.20100311

headline: ‘Aesop’s Fables’
text: “What goes around comes around,” the triumphant Wolf says sneeringly to the Fox. This may not be Aesop’s wording, but it succinctly captures his message. It also neatly describes the action at the Circle in the Square Theater, where that ancient Greek’s sly and savvy animals are running through the aisles, up and down the stairs and onto the stage in “Aesop’s Fables,” a new children’s musical directed by Theodore Mann and presented by the theater school’s Alumni Ensemble.

headline: After a Taliban Ambush in Afghanistan
text: After an Afghan checkpoint was ambushed by Taliban fighters, two wounded Afghan security officers were transported to the Army’s Combat Outpost Pirtle King, near the village of Tsunek, in northeast Kunar Province. A medevac helicopter took them from there to Jalalabad. Moises Saman, who took this photograph, discussed the opportunities and perils of covering the war as an unembedded photographer in “A Perilous Route to Marja” (Lens, March 8).

headline: A U.S. Moment for Yves Klein
text: Yves Klein, the radical French artist who died in 1962 when he was only 34, has been something of an enigma to Americans. Individual works have occasionally turned up in museum shows in this country, and Upper East Side galleries like Gagosian, Michael Werner and L&M Arts have displayed his work. In contrast to Europe, where several institutions have held shows of his art, such exhibitions have been rare here.

headline: Vocabulary Size
text: Trying to convince speakers of English that they need to expand their vocabularies is one of the oldest strategies for selling word books. The very first English dictionary, A Table Alphabeticall, published in 1604, stated on its title page that its approximately 2,500 words (most of them relatively obscure) were intended for the “benefit and help of ladies, gentlewomen or any other unskillful persons.” For the next 100 years, most published dictionaries were concerned with helping the verbally unsophisticated (or at least the insecure) feel more comfortable with their verbal repertories. These early dictionaries were filled only with “hard” words and did not bother with defining cow or apple, reasoning that everyone knew what words like that meant. Instead they sought to explain to the uninitiated the meaning of terms like desticate (to cry like a rat) and antipelargy (the reciprocal love children have for their parents).

headline: Art in Review
text: MILTON AVERY

headline: Off the Train, a Motley Hub
text: The heart of South Norwalk, Conn., rows of buildings from the late 19th and early 20th centuries on Washington and South Main Streets, packs a lot into a compact area. The upper floors of the buildings have artists’ studios, and, at street level, the collection of restaurants, shops and galleries is diverse enough to please anyone who makes the ride — only an hour or so — from Grand Central Terminal on the Metro-North Railroad ($19.50 round-trip on weekends, $10 for children). It’s all within an easy walk of the station, too — including the Maritime Aquarium, the one relatively new building in the group and the one that enables grown-ups to enjoy browsing and shopping while still entertaining the children.

headline: There’s a New Deal at Roosevelt’s Dorm
text: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  Franklin Delano Roosevelt hardly did any homework as a Harvard undergraduate. While enrolled in classes like General Paleontology and English Letter Writers, he concentrated on editing the school newspaper, dating debutantes and collecting stuffed birds. His roommate, Lathrop Brown, who later was a one-term congressman from Long Island, managed the football team and earned mostly D’s.

headline: Russia Boots Space Tourists
text: Russia says it will no longer allow tourists to accompany astronauts onboard its shuttle missions to the International Space Station.

headline: Muslims, Too, Perished in Nigerian Violence
text: This month, the dead were Christians.

headline: Taking It With You in Ancient Egypt
text: You can’t take it with you. Or so you think if you are an enlightened citizen of the modern world. All your earthly possessions and attainments aren’t going to do you a bit of good after you’ve gone.

headline: That American Dream: Scheme and Scramble
text: Restraint proves a virtue of  and a shrewd if necessary choice for  “Children of Invention,” a modestly scaled, quietly effective independent movie about a struggling single mother and her two children. Directed and written by Tze Chun, making a fine feature debut, the movie offers both a familiar tale of immigrant striving and a topical look at what it means to be working and poor in America while hanging onto a badly frayed thread. Yet while the politics are there, you might be too busy choking back tears to notice.

headline: Leaps of Faith to Transcend Urban Angst
text: A flourishing member of a precious and nearly extinct species has been sighted on Broadway, looking remarkably vital and sure of itself for a creature so often given up for dead. “Next Fall,” which opened Thursday night at the Helen Hayes Theater, is that genuine rara avis, a smart, sensitive and utterly contemporary New York comedy. The question now is whether theatergoers will recognize that “Next Fall” embodies something they’ve been sorely missing, perhaps without knowing it, for years.

headline: F.C.C. Ponders Action on Cable Fee Disputes
text: WASHINGTON — The chairman of the Federal Communications Commission said the agency was considering changes to ensure that cable television customers do not lose access to broadcast stations because of fee disputes between broadcasters and cable companies.

headline: A Vote to Change Some Cocaine Sentences
text: The Senate Judiciary Committee voted unanimously today to reduce the discrepancy that has existed for more than two decades in federal penalties for possession of crack cocaine and powder cocaine.

headline: Remembering Merlin Olsen, the Football Player
text: Andy Barall writes about pro football history for the Fifth Down. Merlin Olsen died of cancer at age 69 on Thursday.

headline: Marquette Outshoots Villanova to Reach Semifinals
text: Marquette and Villanova squared off in a shootout Thursday afternoon as both guard-oriented offenses shot freely. For Villanova, it was Corey Stokes, best known as the Bayonne Bomber, connecting on 6 of 7 3-pointers for 22 points. For Marquette, it was Darius Johnson-Odom, a southpaw who made 5 of 7 from that range for 24 points.

headline: No National Tour for ‘Carnage’
text: The producers of “God of Carnage,” the winner of the 2009 Tony Award for best play and a critical and commercial hit on Broadway, have decided not to mount a national tour of the production at this point, concerned that it would not run in enough weeks to make a tour financially worthwhile.

headline: Always Outrageous, Frequently Disturbing
text: How German was Otto Dix? The question echoes through the retrospective of Dix’s unforgiving art, the first show of its kind ever held in North America, at the Neue Galerie. The answer delivered by this completely engrossing yet sadly flawed exhibition is: deeply, madly, truly.

headline: The Chic of Araby
text: Looking for fashion’s new frontier? Go east, young man.

headline: The Prof Stuff
text: Like many online services, Rate My Professors, the engrossing professor-ranking site, seems at first to be a companion to offline life. Real-life students take real-life classes and hand down judgments of real-life professors in a virtual forum. The site invites reviewers — whose identities as students are never given or verified — to give numerical rankings, from 1 to 5, in four categories: easiness, helpfulness, clarity and the reviewers’ interest in the subject matter before they took the class. You can also assign professors chili-pepper icons if you think they’re good-looking. Even the losers have a place. Professors can rebut bad reviews and upload protest videos under the feeble rubric “Professors Strike Back.”

headline: Museum Sets Grand Stage for Strings and Horns
text: THE oboes and clarinets and flutes and bassoons stand upright, like stalks in a vegetable garden. A motley sisterhood of keyboard instruments  virginals, clavichords, harpsichords  squat on platforms and tables. Curvaceous Strads and voluptuous viols seem to rest seductively against the walls. Oddballs lurk: the sea-dragon-shaped bassoon, the accordion disguised as a cello, the foot-long miniviolins.

headline: Treading Softly Around a Minefield of Emotions
text: Ivy (Zoe Kazan), present in virtually every frame of “The Exploding Girl,” Bradley Rust Gray’s sweet and tentative new film, is home from college for the summer, back in a New York suffused with leafy green in the daytime and red neon at night. Her life is fairly uneventful  she hangs out, works with some children, talks on her cellphone, goes to a party or two, visits a doctor who monitors her epilepsy  but nonetheless complicated.

headline: Time Bandits
text: As a manager at a large company, I work far more than the required 40 hours a week but report only 40. If I reported my actual hours, I could be penalized financially for letting my projects run overbudget. Company policy states that “intentionally submitting inaccurate time reports is an integrity issue.” I see why this forbids claiming to have worked when I did not, but is there a problem with simply declining to mention some hours when I did work? NAME WITHHELD, NEW JERSEY

headline: Man Leaves Midtown Bar
text: A video clip of an individual leaving the Social bar on 8th Avenue Thursday morning.

headline: New U.N. Climate Change Group Is All Male
text: Women at some environmentally conscious nonprofits are indignant that a new group overseeing financing for a United Nations climate change effort has 19 members — none of them women.

headline: Photos of the Moment | It’s a Wrap!
text: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.

headline: Not Your Typical Alpine Hut
text: Gleaming like a metallic glacier at almost 10,000 feet above sea level, the new Monte Rosa Mountain Hut, which opened on March 10, is so mesmerizing that even its impressive view of the Matterhorn seems secondary.

headline: Small Michigan Television Station Is ‘Priced to Sell’ on eBay
text: You don’t need pockets as deep as Comcast’s to get into the TV business. Or even be a millionaire, apparently.

headline: Scarred Bodies, Entwined Souls
text: Out of a mathematical conceit the Italian writer Paolo Giordano has drawn a mesmerizing portrait of a young man and woman whose injured natures draw them together over the years and inevitably pull them apart.

headline: ‘The Solitude of Prime Numbers’
text: Alice Della Rocca hated ski school. She hated getting up at seven-thirty, even during Christmas vacation. She hated her father staring at her over breakfast, his leg dancing nervously under the table as if to say hurry up, get a move on. She hated the woolen tights that made her thighs itch, the mittens that kept her from moving her fingers, the helmet that squashed her cheeks, and the big, too tight boots that made her walk like a gorilla.

headline: Fierce Love: Better Not Make This Mom Angry
text: The last monster to run wild through Bong Joon-ho’s imagination was an enormous creature from the watery deep. A different menace storms through “Mother,” the fourth feature from this sensationally talented South Korean filmmaker, though she too seems to spring from unfathomable depths. Unlike the beast in “The Host”  a catastrophic byproduct of the American military  the monster in “Mother” doesn’t come with much of a backstory, which suggests that she is a primal force, in other words, a natural.

headline: Dancing Around Death, With Elephant in Room
text: Restarting the Seattle grunge band Alice in Chains after the death in 2002 of its lead singer and frequent lyricist, Layne Staley, was a matter of delicate positioning. Jerry Cantrell, the guitarist who founded the band with Mr. Staley and now writes nearly all its material, had to blend respect, mourning and pragmatism. At Terminal 5 on Tuesday, the second sold-out show of a two-night stand, Mr. Staley’s name was not mentioned onstage, but his absence was central.

headline: Friend Request
text: Last winter, in the middle of my intern year, I became Facebook friends with a young man who was dying in the intensive-care unit. An investment banker in his mid-20s, he thought he was healthy until a fluttering in his chest and swollen ankles took him to a doctor. Now he was in the I.C.U. with a rare cardiac condition and the vague possibility of a transplant.

headline: Japanese Master of the ‘Hard Shake’ Comes to Town
text: Though living and working half a world away, the Japanese bartender and cocktail-shaking philosopher Kazuo Uyeda has managed to inspire many a Manhattan barroom argument. Most of them have centered on what is called the hard shake, an ornate and controversial method of shaking drinks devised by Mr. Uyeda.

headline: Performance Art Preserved, in the Flesh
text: With the opening on Sunday of “Marina Abramovic: The Artist Is Present,” a long-building energy wave of performance art hits the Museum of Modern Art full force. The show is a four-decade survey of work by one of the field’s most visible and magnetic figures. And its combination of stressed-out flesh in documentary films and live bodies, some nude, in the galleries, makes pretty radical fare for this institution.

headline: Theater Listings: March 12 — 18
text: THEATER

headline: Once Shocking, Now Poetic
text: Considering how revolutionary Surrealist photography was in the years before World War II, what with its double-exposing, montaging, solarizing and other techniques, it may seem paradoxical that nostalgia would be the mood suffusing “Twilight Visions: Surrealism, Photography and Paris” at the International Center of Photography. But it makes sense.

headline: A Shift Away From Linear Thinking
text: Paris

headline: French Film Spotlight
text: Images from films appearing in the 2010 Rendez-Vous With French Cinema series.

headline: Ray Charles Musical Will Open in November
text: The new production “Unchain My Heart, The Ray Charles Musical” is scheduled to begin preview performances on Broadway on Oct. 8 and open on Nov. 7, directed by Sheldon Epps and with a book by Suzan-Lori Parks, the Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright of “Topdog/Underdog,” the lead producer Stuart Benjamin said on Thursday.

headline: The Diner’s Journal Bake Sale Bake Off
text: It’s always a great day here at Diner’s Journal when baking and politics meet.

headline: Inside the List
text: ABRAHAM LINCOLN, AX SWINGER: “Abraham Lincoln: Vampire Hunter,” Seth Grahame-Smith’s follow-up to the surprise smash hit “Pride and Prejudice and Zombies,” enters the hardcover fiction list at No. 4, and not everybody is happy about it.

headline: Feeling Trapped By Stepchildren
text: Speaking of siblings, Colleen K.,, a 25-year-old mother from Davenport, Iowa, is looking for some advice. Not only is she raising her own three sons, ages 5, 2 and 9 months, but she is also trying to be a part-time parent to her four step-children.

headline: Entertaining With a Folksy Palette of Despondency
text: “Here’s another depressing song,” Stephin Merritt of the Magnetic Fields said at Town Hall on Wednesday night, to a murmur of something like delight. His disclaimer doubled as a statement of principle and, on some level, as low-impact shtick.

headline: Upper Broadway as a Young Boulevard
text: THIRTY years ago, Broadway north of 96th Street was a vibrant but shabby area, its Hispanic groceries and Chinese restaurants mixed with declining Edwardian apartment houses and S.R.O. hotels.

headline: Battlegrounds on ‘Tiny Specks of Earth’
text: At war’s end, the cabbie won’t take money from the Marine returning home from the Pacific. “I might have jumped into Normandy but at least I got some liberties in London and Paris,” the driver, a veteran of D-Day, says pityingly. “You gyrenes, you got nothing but jungle rot and malaria. Welcome home.”

headline: Samsung Unwraps a New E-Book Reader
text: Samsung unwrapped its long-awaited e-book reader for the American market this week, and it’s a curious combination of useful features and an important missing feature.

headline: Glimmerglass Opera Hires Francesca Zambello
text: Francesca Zambello, a busy opera and musical theater director whose work has ranged from Disney’s “Little Mermaid” to Wagner’s “Ring” cycle, has been hired as the general and artistic director of the Glimmerglass Opera in Cooperstown, N.Y., the company said on Thursday. Ms. Zambello will succeed Michael MacLeod, who said in February he would leave this year after five seasons. Ms. Zambello, who is also artistic adviser to the San Francisco Opera, has directed productions at the Metropolitan Opera, the Royal Opera House in London, the Paris Opera and other major companies. Glimmerglass presents four productions a summer.

headline: Timing of Obama Indonesia Trip Questioned
text: With President Obama’s health care bill hanging in the balance, the White House is facing intensifying questions about whether Mr. Obama should take his planned trip to Indonesia and Australia next week.

headline: Broadway North of 96th Street
text: Broadway north of 96th Street is an eclectic mix of several types of architecture from the past century.

headline: Glimmerglass Opera Hires a New Artistic Director
text: Francesca Zambello, a busy opera and musical theater director whose work has ranged from Disney’s “Little Mermaid” to Wagner’s “Ring” cycle, has been hired as the general and artistic director of the Glimmerglass Opera in Cooperstown, N.Y., the company said on Thursday. Ms. Zambello will succeed Michael MacLeod, who said in February he would leave this year after five seasons. Ms. Zambello, who is also artistic adviser to the San Francisco Opera, has directed productions at the Metropolitan Opera, the Royal Opera House in London, the Paris Opera and other major companies. Glimmerglass presents four productions a summer.

headline: St. Olaf to New York: White to Host ‘SNL’
text: Call it a victory for democracy or peer pressure, but either way it’s happening: Betty White, above, the 88-years-young “Mary Tyler Moore” and “Golden Girls” star, will be hosting “Saturday Night Live” on May 8, a pre-Mother’s Day episode also featuring appearances from six “SNL” alumnae. Though a popular Facebook campaign helped build Ms. White’s cause, Lorne Michaels, the “SNL” creator and executive producer, said Thursday that the grass-roots movement wasn’t the sole reason for the booking. “The depth of feeling for her at the show and particularly among the women who are coming back was very deep,” Mr. Michaels said in a telephone interview. He added that he had concerns given the show’s “grueling” schedule, and as a solution invited the former “SNL” performers Tina Fey, Amy Poehler, Maya Rudolph, Rachel Dratch, Ana Gasteyer and Molly Shannon to appear, too. Ultimately, he said, Ms. White’s age wouldn’t prevent her from participating fully. “Mind you, at our show, Pardo’s 92,” he said, referring to the announcer Don Pardo. “A couple people in wardrobe are older than him. So she’s a spring chicken in our world.”

headline: EMI Is Told, Hey, Label, Leave the Tracks Alone
text: Finally: score one for the wealthy rock stars. A British court ruled on Thursday in favor of Pink Floyd, saying that EMI, its longtime record label, could no longer sell songs from the band’s concept albums as singles on the Internet, Reuters reported. On Tuesday, a lawyer for Pink Floyd argued in a High Court hearing in London that the band’s contract “expressly prohibited” the “unbundling” of its songs in any configuration other than the way they were originally produced and released. Judge Andrew Morritt sided with the band, saying its contract was designed to “preserve the artistic integrity of the albums,” according to Reuters. In a statement, EMI said, “We’re huge fans of Pink Floyd, whose great catalog we have been representing for more than 40 years, and continue to represent exclusively and internationally.”

headline: ‘Idol’ Guys Win a Night
text: Performances from the top eight male singers on “American Idol” lifted it to No. 1 in the prime-time ratings Wednesday. According to Nielsen’s estimates, “Idol” drew 20.5 million viewers at 9 p.m., enough to ensure Fox led the night over all even as the network garnered a much smaller audience at 8 for “Human Target” (7.8 million). CBS ranked second, gaining 13.1 million viewers at 9 for “Criminal Minds” and 11 million at 10 for “CSI: NY,” but fewer in the 8 p.m. hour for its comedies “The New Adventures of Old Christine” (7.9 million) and “Gary Unmarried” (6.8 million). NBC placed third on the night with “Mercy” at 8 (6.3 million) and two installments of “Law & Order: SVU,” a rerun at 9 (5.4 million) followed by a new episode at 10 (8.6 million). ABC finished close behind NBC in fourth place with its comedy lineup from 8 to 10, including the standout “Modern Family” at 9 (8.9 million), while ABC’s “Ugly Betty” struggled at 10 with just 4.1 million viewers.

headline: The Name’s Knight. Pat Knight.
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — After Texas Tech’s 80-68 loss Thursday to Kansas in the Big 12 quarterfinals, the Red Raiders were laughing in the locker room.

headline: Conan O’Brien Announces Details of National Tour
text: The fans of Conan O’Brien will not have to wait much longer  though they may have to wait in long lines  to see their favorite late-night comedian perform again: starting April 12 in Eugene, Ore., and including dates at Radio City Music Hall on June 1 and 2, Mr. O’Brien’s 30-city tour is on. And if the title is any indication, it will also be sending a message about how Mr. O’Brien, above, and his Team Coco feels about his abrupt departure from NBC’s “Tonight Show” in January. The name: The Legally Prohibited From Being Funny on Television Tour. The title refers to Mr. O’Brien’s settlement with NBC, which included a provision that he cannot appear on television again until after Sept. 1. But there is no prohibition against going onstage and doing a live show, which is what Team Coco (the name bestowed by rabid fans upset by his leaving NBC) has planned, including some regulars from Mr. O’Brien’s old cast, like his sidekick, Andy Richter, and members of his “Tonight Show” band. Mr. O’Brien announced the details in a message to his followers on Twitter on Thursday morning. Team Coco also sent out a release in which Mr. O’Brien described his reasons for doing the tour. “It was either a massive 30-city tour or start helping out around the house,” Mr. O’Brien said.

headline: What We’re Reading: A Nobel Peace Prize for Us All?
text: Thursday’s roundup of odds and ends from around the Web, selected by the technology reporters and editors of The New York Times:

headline: Cirque Du Soleil Show Is Delayed Again
text: Somewhere in New York, the Allman Brothers Band must be having a good ol’ Southern laugh: the long-gestating Cirque du Soleil show “Banana Shpeel,” whose planned February start at the Beacon Theater pushed the band from its traditional annual residency there, said on Wednesday that it was once again postponing its start date, and will begin performances on April 29. In a news release, Cirque du Soleil said it was turning the production duties for the show over to Marty Schmelky  that is, the fictional producer played by Jerry Kernion in the poorly received Chicago run of “Banana Shpeel.” Mr. Schmelky (or someone playing him) said in a statement that the show “still needs more time to ripen.” (His pun, not ours.) The start date for “Banana Shpeel” has already slipped (O.K., that is our pun) from Feb. 4 to Feb. 25 to March 17 and now to April 29.

headline: The Hour Approaches to Stage ‘A Time to Kill’
text: Though it’s still a bit of a mystery why it’s taken this long for one of John Grisham’s books to be translated into a play, the identity of the theater company that will present the first stage adaptation of his work has been revealed. Arena Stage, the Washington company, will put on a version of “A Time to Kill” as part of its 2010-11 season. The play, which will be written by Rupert Holmes (“Curtains,” “Drood”) and produced by the New York theater impresario Daryl Roth, will be adapted from Mr. Grisham’s 1989 novel, about murder, rape and racism in rural Mississippi, and not the 1996 film version directed by Joel Schumacher. “In the novel it’s possible to go to many different locations in the audience’s imagination,” said Molly Smith, the artistic director of Arena Stage, in a telephone interview on Thursday. Mr. Holmes’s adaptation, she said, is “very focused in the courtroom, and that will intensify the action of the entire piece, so that the audience really becomes the jurors, and at other points are voyeurs on the action.” It will run from May 6 through June 19, 2011.

headline: The Eddie Jordan Job Watch
text: There are phrases that should signal job security trouble for any embattled N.B.A. coach.

headline: Fresh Fish, Frozen Angler
text: Quetico Provincial Park, Ontario

headline: The Works of 10 Abstract Expressionists for Under $5
text: The United States Post Office issued 10 Abstract Expressionist stamps on Thursday. They depict paintings by 10 artists — Joan Mitchell and the usual male suspects, you might say — and look bright and energetic and very abstract. They’re not the first stamps based on modern paintings, or even Abstract Expressionist ones, but the edition is the first to concentrate on these artists as a group. Seeing them made me feel protective. I was even compelled to offer a talking point to the woman who at the Post Office who sold them to me: if she got any guff about them she could mention that the paintings are all at least 50 years old. She seemed impressed. “They’re not new at all,” I said, somewhat defensively. “They’re classics.”

headline: Social Networking Apps That Network
text: So many people get messages from Facebook, Twitter and AIM that it makes sense to consolidate the communications, rather than opening a different app each time. Thursday’s PhoneSmart column reviews iPhone apps for that task.

headline: South by Southwest: A Virtual Playground in Austin
text: Every March, thousands of entrepreneurs and digital types descend on Austin, Tex., for South by Southwest Interactive. They’re hoping to get a glimpse of some of the newest Web and mobile innovations, and perhaps to sample some tacos.

headline: Dealing With Fraud by Denial
text: Years after Charles Ponzi was imprisoned for a fraud that cost victims millions of dollars in 1920, the state of Massachusetts determined it had recovered all the assets it could, and began to distribute them to victims, who stood to receive less than 30 cents for each dollar they invested.

headline: Iraq Elections: Early Results Suggest Very Tight Race
text: Early returns from Iraq’s parliamentary elections suggest a very tight race and a likely scramble among parties to create new coalitions.

headline: How to Choose the Right Apple iPad for You
text: If you are not interested in Apple’s coming iPad and have no intention of buying one, then you may want to skip this post. But if you’re already readying your tent and fold-up chairs to wait outside an Apple store for the company’s latest offering, then please read on.

headline: ‘Our Town’ Is Yours, Too
text: ANYONE who has attended or visited the MacDowell Colony, the nation’s oldest artists’ colony, has daydreamed about owning property in Peterborough. Quaint New Englanders with clapboard exteriors and regal Federal-style homes line quiet country roads. Whitewashed steeples, covered bridges and the preserved 18th-century buildings of its downtown rise against the mountainous backdrop that characterizes the Monadnock region.

headline: Baylor vs. Texas: This One Is Personal
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — The night session of the Big 12 tournament quarterfinals opens this evening with No. 2 seed Kansas State facing No. 7 Oklahoma State.

headline: Paul Taylor Dance Company
text: Perhaps the two books on Paul Taylor currently in preparation will finally reveal something about a choreographer who has worked hard to be inexplicable.

headline: The Rationale Behind CA’s Deal for Nimsoft
text: CA’s $350 million acquisition of Nimsoft, a performance software company, is its third purchase of the year, but this could arguably be its most important, analysts at the 451 Group said in a report to its clients on Thursday. The deal gives CA, which sells technology management software mostly to large corporate clients, an opportunity to expand to a growing market of smaller clients.

headline: Sorting Through the Apple iPad Options
text: Thinking about ordering an Apple iPad on Friday?

headline: How Do You Say ‘Jersey Shore’ in Russian?
text: Anastasia Kurinnaya, shod in a pair of black Aldo booties with five-inch heels, stepped carefully down the 10 rickety plywood stairs that led from the coat check into the grimy basement of Passion, a popular Russian dance club on Coney Island Avenue in Brooklyn.

headline: A Rebel, Brooding and Smoking His Way Out of Bourgeois Normalcy
text: In “Remember Me” love means never having to say you’re sorry, particularly to the audience. The star, as if you didn’t know, is Robert Pattinson, the moody vampire heartthrob from the “Twilight” series, a conceivably promising, certainly watchable actor in need of an immediate acting intervention. Along with working double time as one of the movie’s executive producers and its biggest bait, he plays Tyler, a dreary melancholic who poses and broods in this lugubrious romance cum family melodrama about a boy (sad) and a girl (also sad) who heal (eventually) while steaming up the sheets (discreetly). Along the way, many people die but few matter: most are just part of the warm-up act as well as the means to a shamelessly exploitative end.

headline: Voices of Performance
text: Excerpts from interviews with the performance artists Marina Abramovic, Joan Jonas and Alison Knowles.

headline: When Laid-Back, Low-Key Is Just the Ticket
text: Killington, Vt.

headline: National Book Critics Circle Award Winners Announced
text: 8:19 a.m. | Updated  The British author Hilary Mantel was awarded the National Book Critics Circle Award for fiction at the New School’s Tishman auditorium on Thursday night for “Wolf Hall,” a historical novel about the court of Henry VIII and centered on the king’s adviser, Thomas Cromwell.

headline: Does the Size of a School Matter?
text: View a larger map of the 28 schools that will close under the Kansas City district’s “Right-Size” plan (via www.nbcactionnews.com )

headline: Teamwork Wins Wars and Operas
text: Valery Gergiev has been the artistic and general director of the Mariinsky Theater in St. Petersburg for 22 years. The Mariinsky orchestra, an ensemble that passes on traditions, artistic identity and even instruments from generation to generation, has formed a bond with Mr. Gergiev. When things are working well, the orchestra and the conductor bring out the best in each other.

headline: ‘Gazoo’ Cervelli Opts for Extra Protection
text: TAMPA, Fla. – Francisco Cervelli has a new nickname: Gazoo.

headline: More Layoffs at BusinessWeek
text: As the new Bloomberg BusinessWeek editor Josh Tyrangiel makes plans for revising the magazine, he’s also cutting back on staff.

headline: American Held in Yemen After Shootout
text: Sharif Mobley, a 26-year-old from suburban New Jersey who moved to Yemen two years ago, was arrested there last week in a sweep of suspected militants, according to a spokesman for Yemen’s embassy in Washington. After his arrest, Mr. Mobley complained of being ill and was transferred to a hospital in the Yemeni capital, Sana, the spokesman added. He then tried to escape and killed a security guard before being recaptured after a shootout.

headline: How Shall We Know Him? Through His Dances and More
text: Two books on the choreographer Paul Taylor are in preparation. One is a critical study by Angela Kane, whom the Paul Taylor Dance Company lists as its historian; the other is an authorized biography by Suzanne Carbonneau. Both of these scholars have followed Mr. Taylor’s choreography for years, enjoying close access to him and his associates. It’s fair to expect that their treatments will be sensitive, intelligent, responsible.

headline: Haiti: Kidnappers Free Aid Workers
text: Five days after they were kidnapped in the Port-au-Prince area, two Swiss women, aid workers for Doctors Without Borders, were released unharmed on Wednesday night.

headline: The First 2,000 Wins Are the Hardest
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — There was more significance to Kansas’ 80-68 victory against Texas Tech on Thursday than just advancing to the Big 12 tournament semifinals.

headline: Beethoven and Franck, With Sparkle From Muti
text: For the final week of his visit with the New York Philharmonic at Avery Fisher Hall, Riccardo Muti is conducting a peculiarly balanced program devoted to Beethoven’s Violin Concerto, as enduring a work as you’ll find, and Franck’s Symphony in D minor, a score that has always struck many listeners as diffuse and bombastic. Oddly, at the first performance, on Wednesday evening, Mr. Muti made the Franck seem more vigorous and exciting than the Beethoven.

headline: BP to Pay Devon $7 Billion for Fuel Assets
text: LONDON — BP, the British oil giant, agreed on Thursday to pay Devon Energy $7 billion in cash for oil and gas assets in Brazil, the Gulf of Mexico and Azerbaijan, seeking to increase production.

headline: Cost of F-35 Has Risen 60% to 90%, Military Says
text: The projected cost of Lockheed Martin’s new Joint Strike Fighter has increased 60 to 90 percent in real terms since 2001, blowing well past a level requiring the program to be revamped, Pentagon officials said Thursday.

headline: China Takes February Inflation Signals in Stride
text: BEIJING — Even with a jump in consumer prices in February, there were no signs of a change in China’s economic policy course as it continued its strong recovery, economists and government officials said Thursday.

headline: The Unequal Impact of San Francisco’s Fire-Rehire Plan
text: When San Francisco issued 17,474 pink slips to workers across nearly every city department, on Friday, what was not immediately clear was the disproportionate impact of the move, which hit 98 percent of workers in accounting and information-technology jobs while affecting about four percent of transit workers.

headline: What a Charming Loser, What TV-Sharp Kids
text: Beginning with the paranoid, conspiracy-mongering brother on the alien-attack series “Invasion” and continuing with the slacker best friend of the soul-hunting hero on “Reaper,” Tyler Labine has made a specialty of playing lovable misfits who rise to the occasion.

headline: A Marine Searches for Meaning in the Sands and ‘Steel Rain’ of Iraq
text: “Here is the truth about being a Marine that you won’t find on the local news. We’re loud. We drink too much, fight too much and swear too much. Truth be told, our rifles are the only things we think about more than sex.”

headline: To Take on Botox, Rival Tries Rebate
text: Allergan and Medicis Pharmaceutical are the Coke and Pepsi of vanity medicine.

headline: Take Five: A Children’s Circus Troupe and a Concert in Honor of Female Composers
text: Wondering what to do this weekend? We have you covered:

headline: Kidnapping Melodrama
