text: “Stolen,” Anders Anderson’s dual kidnapping melodrama of tormented fathers a half-century apart, searching for their lost sons, plays like a middling episode of “Law & Order: SVU,” drawn out an extra half-hour and embellished with pretentious literary and cinematic flourishes. The dads, Detective Tom Adkins (Jon Hamm), whose 10-year-old son is snatched outside a diner on the Fourth of July 2000, and Matthew Wakefield (Josh Lucas), whose boy is abducted from a car in 1958 while Matthew is having a stand-up quickie with a floozy, are photographed to look almost alike.

headline: Earthquake’s Burdens Weigh Heavily on Haiti’s Elderly
text: LÉOGÂNE, Haiti — Junie Sufrad, 110 years old, stopped suddenly as she described what life was like in the Haitian countryside before electricity, paved roads and cars.

headline: Azile Saint Vincent de Paul
text: A panoramic view of the Azile Saint Vincent de Paul nursing home in Léogâne, Haiti.

headline: Luxury Models Carry BMW and Volkswagen to a Year of Profits
text: FRANKFURT — Luxury car sales that improved during the fourth quarter helped both BMW and Volkswagen post annual profits on Thursday. But VW continued to struggle when it came to the sale of lower-price cars.

headline: Ground Zero Workers Reach Deal Over Claims
text: A settlement of up to $657.5 million has been reached in the cases of thousands of rescue and cleanup workers at ground zero who sued the city over damage to their health, according to city officials and lawyers for the plaintiffs.

headline: Walking Down the Comedic Aisle
text: Alternately rancid and ridiculous, strident and sickly sweet, “Our Family Wedding” offers plenty that’s old, borrowed and blue; it’s the something new that’s missing.

headline: Board’s Decision to Close 28 Kansas City Schools Follows Years of Inaction
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — Like so many other public school parents, Reshonda Sanders felt confused on Thursday as she tried to comprehend why nearly half of the schools here, including her own alma mater, are to close for good at the end of the year. As the mother of two high school students, she was well aware of the district’s struggles.

headline: Bank Revises Number Affected by Data Theft
text: PARIS — HSBC said on Thursday that the theft of Swiss client data at the heart of a recent tax dispute with France was much larger than it earlier acknowledged.

headline: Death Squad
text: Of all the crimes that sullied the record of the United States military in Iraq — the torture of prisoners at Abu Ghraib, the killings of 24 Iraqi men, women and children by Marines in November 2005 in Haditha — the murder of an entire Iraqi family in the village of Yusufiya may rank as the most chilling. On March 12, 2006, United States soldiers were summoned to a small house in the heart of the insurgent-filled “Triangle of Death” south and west of Baghdad, where they discovered the charred remains of a 14-year-old girl who had been raped, shot to death, then burned with kerosene, along with the bodies of her 6-year-old sister and her parents. At first the killings were attributed to a feud between Iraqis, but after a soldier came forward with information he had gleaned from comrades, the Army arrested the real perpetrators: four soldiers from Bravo Company, a casualty-plagued unit in the Army’s First Battalion, 502nd Infantry, 101st Airborne Division. Press attention centered on the group’s ringleader, Pvt. Steven Green from Midland, Tex., “a petulant loner and a hard-drinking druggie” according to Newsweek, who was afflicted by a “seething, seemingly random rage.” Despite Green’s repeated troubles with the law, he had easily enlisted in an Army hurting for recruits and breezed through basic training. Before his deployment, Green made no secret of his bloodlust, reportedly telling one neighbor, “I’m gonna go over there and kill ’em all.”

headline: Report Details How Lehman Hid Its Woes
text: It is the Wall Street equivalent of a coroner’s report — a 2,200-page document that lays out, in new and startling detail, how Lehman Brothers used accounting sleight of hand to conceal the bad investments that led to its undoing.

headline: Rapid Rise in Seed Prices Draws U.S. Scrutiny
text: During the depths of the economic crisis last year, the prices for many goods held steady or even dropped. But on American farms, the picture was far different, as farmers watched the price they paid for seeds skyrocket. Corn seed prices rose 32 percent; soybean seeds were up 24 percent.

headline: Airline Group, Citing Emerging Markets, Lowers Loss Forecast
text: A leading airline trade group cut its forecast for industry losses this year in half on Thursday because of what it said was a stronger-than-expected economic recovery in emerging markets, especially in Asia and Latin America.

headline: Woman Hired as Coach
text: Calvin Coolidge High School in Washington made the rare move of hiring a woman, Natalie Randolph, to coach its football team. Randolph, who has two years’ experience as an assistant at another area high school, H. D. Woodson, and played four seasons in the Independent Women’s Professional League, will be introduced at a news conference at the school Friday.

headline: Ukraine’s President Forms a Coalition in Parliament
text: MOSCOW — The new Ukrainian president, Viktor F. Yanukovich, put together a coalition in Parliament on Thursday, allowing him to consolidate control over the government and avoid new elections that could have created renewed political instability.

headline: Highway Deaths Are on the Decline
text: The number of highway deaths in the United States fell nearly 9 percent in 2009, according to a preliminary estimate from the Department of Transportation, and the drop since 2005 is 22 percent.

headline: Delay Sought on Dismissal of Catalano Case
text: Federal prosecutors asked a Buffalo court to postpone its decision about whether to dismiss the case against Mary Anne Catalano, the assistant to Anthony Galea, the Toronto doctor who is suspected of providing performance-enhancing drugs to professional athletes.

headline: New Earmark Rules Have Lobbyists Scrambling
text: WASHINGTON — Jolted by a sudden tightening of the rules, lobbyists and military contractors who have long relied on lucrative earmarks from Congress were scrambling Thursday to find new ways to keep the federal money flowing.

headline: U.S. Falters in Screening Border Patrol Near Mexico
text: Federal anticorruption investigators continue to struggle to keep up with the screening of newly hired United States law enforcement officers working on the Mexican border and have fallen far behind in checking current employees as well, federal officials testified on Thursday.

headline: More Than Words
text: In Peter Hanson’s dishy documentary “Tales From the Script,” 46 screenwriters (4 women and 42 men, if you’re wondering) gab agreeably about the tribulations of their profession.

headline: Obama Lists Who Will Get Prize Money From Nobel
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama has made good on a promise to give his $1.4 million in Nobel Peace Prize money to charity, releasing on Thursday the names of the organizations that will benefit.

headline: Kansas Center Has Some Fans in Texas
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — Kansas center Cole Aldrich is often compared to the Boston Celtics Hall of Famer Kevin McHale because both hail from Minnesota.

headline: Up Front: Joshua Hammer
text: As Newsweek’s Jerusalem bureau chief from 2001 to 2004, Joshua Hammer “covered Iraq extensively, embedding with United States troops as the insurgency spiraled out of control,” he explained in an e-mail message.

headline: Outraged by Glenn Beck’s Salvo, Christians Fire Back
text: Last week, the conservative broadcaster Glenn Beck called on Christians to leave their churches if they hear preaching about social or economic justice, saying they were code words for Communism and Nazism.

headline: Talks to Address Trade in Tuna and Ivory
text: Marathon negotiations on protecting the planet’s endangered species open on Saturday in Qatar with tensions bubbling over efforts to ban trade in bluefin tuna and to reopen exports of elephant ivory from Africa.

headline: Lexus, a Toyota Brand, Avoids Taint From Recalls
text: It has been a rough few months for Toyota because of its three big safety recalls. But the automaker’s luxury division, Lexus, appears to have avoided much of the fallout.

headline: Board Extends Deadline for Everglades Land Deal
text: OKEECHOBEE, Fla. — Facing legal challenges and growing deficits, South Florida water officials on Thursday gave themselves six more months to finance a controversial $536 million purchase of land from United States Sugar for the Everglades.

headline: Domestic Dramedy
text: “White on Rice” is an Asian-American domestic dramedy that’s determined to be as culture-neutral as possible. To that end the director, Dave Boyle, who wrote the screenplay with Joel Clark, avoids the genre’s most common markers: the obsession with food, the meddling grandparents, the no-future family business. Unfortunately, what’s left is bland and only occasionally funny. An arrested-development comedy grafted to a wan indie story of a family drifting apart, it would be entirely predictable were it not for the weird shifts in tone and an implausible crisis involving a kitchen knife that pushes the story toward its conclusion.

headline: Getting Obama Right
text: Who is Barack Obama?

headline: Mortgage Bonds  Make a Comeback
text: The market for private-label mortgage bonds in the United States might be ready for revival.

headline: Take This Job and Write It
text: Joblessness may be hovering around 10 percent, with some 29 million Americans out of work or searching for full-time employment, but there’s one group of people whose persistent alienation from regular employment has emerged as a particularly serious problem. I refer, of course, to novelists.

headline: Winter Games Yield Forecasting Insights
text: VANCOUVER, British Columbia — The Winter Olympics and the coming Paralympic Games here have generally not been blessed with wintry weather. But an elaborate weather forecasting service that has been operating for nearly four years meant that the unwelcome conditions were not a surprise.

headline: Instant Ads Set the Pace on the Web
text: Time is now on the side of online advertisers.

headline: Train Kills Woman Trying to Retrieve Bag
text: A 48-year-old woman was hit and killed by a No. 6 train in an Upper East Side subway station on Thursday afternoon after she dropped her bag on the tracks and jumped down to go after it, the police and witnesses said.

headline: Fiction Chronicle
text: TOO MUCH MONEY  By Dominick Dunne.  Crown, $26.

headline: Playing the Odds of Love
text: If you’re going to make a romantic comedy called “She’s Out of My League” about a schlubby nice guy and a pneumatic blonde, the last thing you want is for the audience to be left thinking: “He’s right. She’s way out of his league.”

headline: Rejected on Dance Floor, Man Beats Woman in Bar Restroom
text: It was about two hours before closing time early on Thursday at Social, a Midtown bar, when the man approached a woman as she danced.

headline: Killing by Numbers
text: Statistically as well as temperamentally, the serial killer is almost exclusively an American phenomenon. So while it’s disconcerting to find one of these psychos traipsing around Oslo in Jo Nesbo’s thriller THE ­DEVIL’S STAR (Harper/HarperCollins, $25.99), it’s fascinating to watch this Norwegian author adapt our homegrown monster to a foreign culture.

headline: If Extortion Is Bad, So Is Predation
text: Soon after the man who had tried to extort money from him pleaded guilty to attempted grand larceny, David Letterman pronounced himself satisfied with the outcome. The Manhattan district attorney’s office, he said on his late-night show, handled the case “professionally, skillfully and appropriately.”

headline: Pre-existing Conditions
text: It’s like that old joke: A priest, a minister and a rabbi are discussing the beginning of life. The priest says it begins at conception. The minister says it begins at birth. “And you?” they ask the rabbi. “When do you believe life begins?” He gives a shrug. “When the kids move out and the dog dies.”

headline: A Word About the Wise
text: There are two things I would hope for in a book about wisdom. First, some intellectual enlightenment as to what wisdom really is. Second, some practical ideas on how to be wiser in my own life. This book was a letdown in both respects. Yet reading it proved to be far from a waste of time.

headline: After 12 Holes of Near Perfection, Allenby Feels the Blue Monster’s Bite
text: DORAL, Fla. — As the southeast winds howled across the Blue Monster Course at Doral Resort and Spa, a ball-striking clinic was going on at the W.G.C.-CA Championship. The golfer putting on the exhibition was Robert Allenby, the lean Australian who is perhaps the purest hitter on tour.

headline: Trouble in the Village
text: When the liveliest character in a movie is the heroine’s pet turtle, you know you’re in for some seriously stately filmmaking, and “Delta” does not disappoint. Set in a village on the edge of the Hungarian Danube, this visually demonstrative, emotionally constipated drama observes the fallout when a towheaded prodigal son (Felix Lajko) and his frail younger sister (Orsolya Toth) decide to become better acquainted.

headline: Bundles of Funnies
text: As the modern-day American newspaper comic strip slowly chokes to death, done in by shrinking spaces and exhausted franchises, its more vibrant ancestors are living in renewed luxury. Comic strips are the most ephemeral kind of art; each installment is intended to last only as long as a single day’s paper. Now, though, virtually every major Ameri­can strip of the past century or so is being reprinted in its entirety in handsome, well-designed editions, with better reproduction than it had the first time around.

headline: Time, It Turns Out, Isn’t on Their Side
text: A YEAR ago, I wrote about a job fair at the Sheraton in Midtown Manhattan, where over 5,000 mainly white collar, middle-aged jobless men and women waited in the cold for more than two hours, hoping to find work. The turnout was a sign of desperate times; until then, the organizer, Tory Johnson, who’s been conducting these fairs in 10 cities for a decade, had never had more than 2,000 people at one of these events.

headline: Hidden Meanings
text: Sixty-five years after Anne Frank’s death in Bergen-Belsen, she remains so iconic that objects associated with her have become powerful symbols in themselves. Seedlings from the horse chestnut tree that grew outside the Franks’ hiding place and that Anne could see and took comfort from are to be planted at places like the World Trade Center memorial site and Central High School, the desegregation landmark in Little Rock, Ark. And yet many people have trouble really seeing Anne Frank, preferring to treat her, too, as a symbol — sometimes of universal experience, sometimes of the 1.5 million Jewish children killed in the Holocaust.

headline: A Veteran Judge, Never a Prosecutor, Is Seen as Well Suited to Investigate the Governor
text: The new chief investigator who stepped into the spotlight in place of Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo on Thursday was a judge for a quarter century, not only in title but also in temperament.

headline: Democrats Struggle to Finish Health Bill
text: WASHINGTON — House and Senate Democratic leaders struggled Thursday to stitch together pieces of a final health care bill as rank-and-file Democrats demanded more information about the contents of the bill and its cost.

headline: A Trailblazer of Civil Rights Dies Forgotten
text: COLUMBIA, S.C. — Neighbors were chagrined last week when the police here found the body of a 75-year-old woman who had frozen to death, alone in her house, during unexpectedly frigid weather.

headline: Full Throttle
text: Engaging and appealing? Absolutely. Nonfiction? Not exactly. Young readers might at first assume that “Amelia Earhart: This Broad Ocean,” by Sarah Stewart Taylor, is factual, since elements like the bibliography in the back tend to suggest that. But the reader has to work a bit to filter fact from fiction in this entertaining account of Earhart’s stay at Trepassey, Newfoundland, before she crossed the Atlantic Ocean in 1928.

headline: Obama Links Immigration Overhaul in 2010 to G.O.P. Backing
text: President Obama said Thursday that he would proceed with an overhaul of the immigration system this year if he could attract substantial Republican support. But a leading Republican who supports an overhaul said an immigration bill could not go forward if the president used a legislative shortcut sidestepping Republicans to pass his health care bill.

headline: Children’s Bookshelf
text: 1001 CHILDREN’S BOOKS YOU MUST READ BEFORE YOU GROW UP  Edited by Julia Eccleshare.  Universe. $36.95. (All Ages)

headline: Crosby’s Puck Is Produced; Answers Aren’t
text: Sidney Crosby’s stick and gloves from Canada’s gold medal victory in the Olympics were found Wednesday, and the mystery of their disappearance was innocent enough — they had been misplaced.

headline: Unlikely Rider Steers Long Shot Onto Derby Trail
text: Paul Atkinson spent his mornings last summer combing the backstretches of Southern California racetracks looking for a horse to ride. Any horse would do. Atkinson was 39 at the time and coming off an injury, and had never had much luck around the track anyway.

headline: The Frozen Unknown
text: When European merchants, navigators and chancers began searching for a northern sea route from the Atlantic to the Pacific, Henry VIII was still a bachelor. The mazy waterways were navigable for a scant three months a year, and as late as 1819 only two white men had seen the north coast of Canada. By the time a wooden ship finally pushed through, an indifferent world was looking elsewhere. But the fabled Northwest Passage has returned to the news pages as a warming climate unlocks its deep channels, allowing access to hydrocarbons below the seabed. Anthony Brandt anchors his robust new history, “The Man Who Ate His Boots,” in that modern context.

headline: Imitation of Life
text: “Taxidermy” evokes hunting cabins and mounted white-tailed deer, pheasants in flight and lacquered largemouth bass — kitschy trophies memorializing a good kill — but in “Still Life,” Melissa Milgrom proves that the truth is more complicated and far more interesting. The people in these pages strive “to imitate nature with a fidelity that verges on pathological,” which requires not only a drawerful of glass eyes and fake polar bear claws but also artistic talent and encyclopedic scientific knowledge. The goal is the illusion of life.

headline: A 12-Hour Play, and Endless Bragging Rights
text: Every theater season has its must-must-must-see show, the snob hit that separates the true sophisticates (at least in their own minds) from the cultural chaff. New York will have a doozy of a contender this July: a 12-hour production of a grim Dostoyevsky novel that will be performed only twice, in Italian (with English supertitles), in a warehouse on Governors Island, reachable only after a ferry trip and a 20-minute walk.

headline: Cabrera Tries to Eliminate Damaging Behavior
text: LAKELAND, Fla. — Miguel Cabrera’s locker in the Tigers’ spring training clubhouse is a few feet from the office of Manager Jim Leyland and directly in Leyland’s view.

headline: Obama Social Secretary Ran Into Sharp Elbows
text: WASHINGTON — Long before the State Dinner party crashers and the tension with her White House colleagues and the strain in her relationship with the first lady, Desirée Rogers began to understand she was in trouble when David Axelrod summoned her to his office last spring to scold her.

headline: Clarence Thomas, Silent but Sure
text: Let’s hear it for Justice Clarence Thomas.Notice that I did not say let’s hear from Justice Thomas. February 22 was the fourth anniversary of the last time Justice Thomas asked a question during an argument. His silent presence on the bench has evolved into a weirdly compelling example of performance art.

headline: Tundra Songs
text: Winter isn't quite over, at least not according to the Kronos Quartet. On Saturday night, the Kronos presents "Tundra Songs," a program of music by composers from near the Arctic Circle. Allan Kozinn writes, "The quartet's guests are the Inuit throat-singer Tanya Tagaq, the Swedish band Hurdy Gurdy (Stefan Brisland-Ferner and Totte Mattsson, who use a computer to process the sound of a hurdy gurdy) and Ritva Koistinen, who plays the Finnish kantele (a triangular string instrument)." Go to Zankel Hall at 10 p.m. to listen.

headline: Magnetism
text: "For someone who detests playing live," writes Ben Sisario, "Stephen Merritt of the Magnetic Fields is an unfailingly charming entertainer, breezing through his repertory of caustic bonbons and performing his role as M.C. with perfect drollery." It's not too late to catch the band at Town Hall. Its third and final concert will be tonight.

headline: The Man Behind the Nose
text: There is a William Kentridge moment going on in New York right now. The South African artist has a retrospective at the Museum of Modern Art and his opera directorial debut, "The Nose," about a bureaucrat who awakens one morning to find his nose missing, with music by Dmitri Shostakovich, is a hit at the Metropolitan Opera. Today, go hear from the man himself at the New York Public Library, where Mr. Kentridge will be participating in "Learning from the Absurd: A Conversation with William Kentridge." Mr. Kentridge will discuss Gogol, Shostakovich, and his own creative process. Hosted by Paul Holdengräber.

headline: Bloggingheads: Nigeria’s Failed Schools
text: Dayo Olopade, left, of The Root and Eliza Griswold of the New America Foundation discuss the failures of education in Nigeria.

headline: Upsets Continue as Irish Beat Pitt
text: The upsets continued into the night session at the Big East tournament as No. 2-seeded Pittsburgh fell to No. 7 Notre Dame.

headline: A New Face in the Health Care Debate
text: Senate Democratic leaders on Thursday sought to put a human face on the health care debate, and a cute face at that.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: March 11, 2010

headline: For Haitian, Mission Is to Mend Fences With Diaspora and Streamline Aid
text: His mission is arguably one of the most important facing the Haitian government: reach out to members of Haiti’s global diaspora, estimated at two million people, and harness their newly urgent desire to help their country. Yet Edwin Paraison, Haiti’s minister of Haitians living abroad, is quick to acknowledge that he was handicapped even before he started.

headline: Arizona’s N.C.A.A. Streak Quietly Ends
text: LOS ANGELES — As the buzzer sounded, signifying Arizona’s 75-69 loss to U.C.L.A. in the first round of the Pacific-10 tournament, the Wildcats solemnly followed their coach, Sean Miller, off the court in a single-file line.

headline: After Years of Controversy, Ceremonial Shovels Come Out
text: Inside a tent in the Prospect Heights neighborhood of Brooklyn on Thursday afternoon, the mayor and the governor mingled with celebrities and titans of business, nibbling knishes served in martini glasses, to celebrate the long-delayed groundbreaking of the basketball arena that will be the cornerstone of the Atlantic Yards project.

headline: 19 Across: ‘This Old House’ Topic
text: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — I was rushed for time and decided to test the Wordplay multiple-choice generator, a new program The Times has developed for crossword blogging. I calibrated it for “themeless” and set it to come in at around 200 words. The answers in italics are the ones I agree with the most.

headline: SEC Hopes to Show It Has More Than Kentucky
text: NASHVILLE — It was a dreadful five hours for the Southeastern Conference here Thursday afternoon as one of the league’s marquee players, South Carolina’s Devan Downey, had a disappointing finish to his career and one of its marquee teams, No. 15 Tennessee, had a near-disastrous start to its postseason.

headline: A New Chapter for Bankruptcy
text: THE Obama administration introduced a plan this week to encourage defaulting homeowners to sell their houses at a loss, the latest in a long line of reform packages promising to break the logjam of underwater mortgages. But without major changes to the bankruptcy system, such measures won’t aid the American families torn apart by the economic upheavals of the last two years.

headline: Slot Machines at Aqueduct? No, Not Yet
text: The state’s tortured eight-year quest to install a limited casino at the Aqueduct racetrack in Queens has failed for the third time, with the governor’s office announcing Thursday that its chosen bidder would not be awarded the contract.

headline: Afghan Tribal Rivalries Bedevil a U.S. Plan
text: JALALABAD, Afghanistan — Six weeks ago, elders of the Shinwari tribe, which dominates a large area in southeastern Afghanistan, pledged that they would set aside internal differences to focus on fighting the Taliban.

headline: Bye Bye Bagger
text: The Carpetbagger says goodbye to awards season.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Monday about Gary L. Krupp, an outspoken Jewish supporter of the Vatican’s position that Pope Pius XII, the pontiff during World War II, did all that he could to save Jews from the Holocaust, misidentified the employer of the Rev. John T. Pawlikowski and misstated the organizational title of Rabbi Eric J. Greenberg, two critics of Mr. Krupp’s research. Father Pawlikowski is a professor of social ethics at the Catholic Theological Union in Chicago, not the University of Chicago, and Rabbi Greenberg is the director of interfaith affairs at the Anti-Defamation League, not the associate director.

headline: California: Pledge of Allegiance Is Ruled Constitutional
text: A federal appeals court panel ruled Thursday that the Pledge of Allegiance does not violate constitutional rules separating church and state. The opinion, written by Judge Carlos T. Bea, stated that “the phrase ‘one Nation under God’ does not turn this patriotic exercise into a religious activity.” A different three-judge panel from the same court reached the opposite conclusion in 2002, but the United States Supreme Court reversed it in 2004 on technical grounds. In a biting dissent, Judge Stephen R. Reinhardt, who sided with the majority in 2002, wrote that Congress added “under God” to the pledge in 1954 for unconstitutional religious purposes.

headline: A Way to Bail Out New York
text: New York State is facing a $9 billion budget deficit in the coming fiscal year  a calamitous shortfall that is likely to get worse before it gets better. The state’s credit rating is at risk, and painful budget cuts are inevitable.

headline: Poverty in New York
text: To the Editor:

headline: Health Reform Myths
text: Health reform is back from the dead. Many Democrats have realized that their electoral prospects will be better if they can point to a real accomplishment. Polling on reform  which was never as negative as portrayed  shows signs of improving. And I’ve been really impressed by the passion and energy of this guy Barack Obama. Where was he last year?

headline: Finally, They’re Embarrassed
text: House Democrats are suddenly in a rush to ban corporate earmarks, those just-for-our-donors legislative favors that benefit everybody but the taxpayers. It is the right thing to do, but it is also a classic case of closing the barn door just in time for Election Day.

headline: Driving by the Numbers
text: Cambridge, Mass.

headline: Unemployment Benefits
text: To the Editor:

headline: Haiti, Two Months Later
text: With every day that passes in the mud and rubble of Haiti, the failures of the relief effort are heartbreaking. There are four main strands to the campaign to make sure 1.2 million homeless people are sheltered and safe as the weather turns fierce. All are inadequate.

headline: Should I Get the Prostate Cancer Test?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Preserving Reasonable Gun Limits
text: After serious setbacks to sensible gun control, the top court in Massachusetts on Wednesday made it clear that the Second Amendment does not bar states from protecting children and others against the risk posed by unsecured guns in the home.

headline: The Armenian Genocide
text: To the Editor:

headline: Corrections
text: Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about agreements by China and India to join an international pact to address climate change misstated the number of countries that have formally agreed to be covered by the accord. So far 107 have agreed, not nearly 200.

headline: Defendant Changes Identity and Walks Out of Court
text: It was supposed to be a routine court appearance: Freddie Thompson, who had been arrested in a string of robberies, was to appear before a judge on Staten Island to be arraigned on Wednesday. But before the hearing, he claimed to be another defendant — one facing a considerably less serious charge of marijuana possession — and managed to fool the authorities, the police said.

headline: After Rainout, Yankees Hoping to Play Friday
text: TAMPA, Fla. – The Yankees can deal with one rainout. But two? If their game Friday against Washington in Viera is postponed – thunderstorms are in the forecast – the Yankees will have to overhaul their pitching plans.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Dec. 10 about disquiet in some developing Asian nations over China’s swift economic growth misstated the trade balance between China and the 10 Southeast Asian countries of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, or Asean, from January through September 2009. The most widely cited figures show the Asean countries together ran either a trade surplus of several hundred million dollars with China or a deficit of up to $2.33 billion; the Asean countries over all did not have a deficit of $74 billion with China. (Different factors can be used in calculating the amount of trade, leading to the wide range.) A reader pointed out the error in an e-mail message shortly after the article was published; this correction was delayed for research.

headline: Tomlinson to Visit Jets, Who Have an Opening
text: When the Jets released Thomas Jones after he declined to take a pay cut, the prevailing analysis was that he might have slowed at the end of last season. But the Jets lost an experienced veteran who was a tremendous presence in the locker room. Might they be trying to lure someone like Jones to replace him?

headline: Corrections
text: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about the release of Qing Hong Wu, an immigrant detainee who was pardoned by Gov. David A. Paterson for offenses committed when Mr. Wu was 15, misstated the timing of his reunion with his mother and other relatives. It was 11 p.m. Tuesday, not Wednesday.

headline: Some Binghamton Faculty Push for Exit From Division I
text: In the first formal protest of the scandal surrounding the Binghamton University men’s basketball team, a group of faculty members is collecting signatures to recommend that the university leave Division I athletics.

headline: Corrections
text: An article in some editions last Thursday about Robert M. Scarano Jr., a Brooklyn architect who was barred from filing construction documents with New York City, misstated part of the address of one of his buildings, in East New York, Brooklyn. It is 145 Snediker Avenue, not Street.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Wednesday about increasing demand for lithium, an element that is crucial for the lithium-ion batteries favored for hybrid and electric cars, referred incorrectly to another battery used in such vehicles. That battery is known as nickel-metal hydride, not hybrid.

headline: Mortification Man
text: THIS month Ben Stiller, who has appeared in nine movies that have earned more than $100 million in domestic grosses, served as honorary chairman of Film Independent’s Spirit Awards. The incongruity was not lost on Mr. Stiller, who had some fun with it onstage. “I think it says volumes about the organizers of this event that even though I’ve been in over 350 studio movies during the last five years,” he said, “the Spirit Awards were bold enough to say, ‘You, Ben Stiller, epitomize our core values.’ ”

headline: Corrections
text: Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about Bank of America’s decision to stop charging overdraft fees on debit purchases misstated Citibank’s overdraft policies. Citibank has never charged overdraft fees on one-time debt purchases or A.T.M. transactions; it did not recently modify its policy to appease critics.

headline: FAME School Gets Extension of Its Charter Despite Audit
text: A Fremont charter school that was the subject of a highly critical state audit will be allowed to operate, despite a continuing review by the Alameda County district attorney’s office.

headline: After Millions Spent, a New Food Destination Beckons, but Drivers Beware
text: Harriet Street in San Francisco’s South of Market district is easy to miss. With its ragged flats, modern lofts, a car repair shop and a community center, it is one of those gray mixed-use blocks typical in this part of town.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Monday about ESPN’s choice of the Internet arm of Major League Baseball to handle its streaming video described incorrectly the technology used by Move Networks, which had been providing that service. It uses its own technology, which is compatible with several online video formats; it does not use Microsoft’s Silverlight format.

headline: Corrections
text: An obituary on Thursday about the Egyptian cleric Mohamed Sayed Tantawi misstated the name of a book about Egypt in which Mr. Tantawi is discussed and also misspelled the given name of its author. The book is “No God but God: Egypt and the Triumph of Islam,” not “There Is No God but God,” and the author is Geneive Abdo, not Genevieve Abdo.

headline: Hotels Make Sure These Souvenirs Don’t Spoil
text: All sorts of items are left in hotel rooms. But at places like the Hotel Vitale in San Francisco, housekeepers are likely to find half-eaten wheels of cheese, fresh flowers and, depending on the season, artichokes, grapes or heirloom tomatoes.

headline: Johnny Alf, a ‘Father of Bossa Nova,’ Dies at 80
text: Johnny Alf, an influential Brazilian songwriter, pianist and singer whose delicately swinging music was a precursor to the bossa nova, died on March 4 in Santo André, Brazil, just outside São Paulo. He was 80 and lived in São Paulo.

headline: Corrections
text: An obituary on Wednesday about Willie Davis, who succeeded Duke Snider as the Los Angeles Dodgers’ center fielder, erroneously credited Davis with franchise records in several categories. His career totals in those categories were records for the Los Angeles Dodgers only, not for the Dodger franchise, which was originally located in Brooklyn. Zack Wheat, not Davis, holds the franchise records for hits, at-bats, triples and total bases; Pee Wee Reese holds the record for runs; Duke Snider holds the record for extra-base hits. The obituary also incorrectly described one of Davis’s World Series accomplishments. He stole three bases in one game in the 1965 Series, not three bases in one inning.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,005 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Thursday:

headline: Corrections
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Doris Haddock Is Dead at 100; Walked for Campaign Finance Reform
text: Doris Haddock was almost 89, stoop-shouldered but stiff-spined, when she laced up her sneakers, threw on a backpack and began trekking 3,200 miles across the country on New Year’s Day in 1999 — a one-woman march for campaign finance reform that started in Pasadena, Calif., and ended on the steps of the Capitol in Washington 14 months later.

headline: Will Auburn Get a New Coach for Its New Building?
text: NASHVILLE — Auburn is building a new arena on its campus, but Coach Jeff Lebo might not have a chance to coach there. Lebo finished his sixth season at Auburn here Thursday night with a 78-69 loss to Florida in the first round of the Southeastern Conference tournament.

headline: The Girls Who Kicked in Rock’s Door
text: THE most striking thing about “The Runaways,” a new film about the trailblazing bad-girl rock band from the 1970s that spawned Joan Jett, is how authentic it feels. The clubs are properly scuzzy. The dialogue is properly raunchy. The actors can properly sing. The hair is fried and feathered, the skin spotty from weeks of running on little but potato chips and estrogen. From the adrenaline rush of performing to the monotony of rehearsal, it’s a vivid snapshot of life on the road for ambitious teenagers who are constantly told that rock ’n’ roll “is the sport of men.” (And that’s their own manager talking.)

headline: Notre Dame and Harangody Catch the Bus
text: While he sat out with a knee injury for nearly three weeks, Luke Harangody watched the transformation of his team and his reputation.

headline: An Independent Woman, Nobly Suffering in Silents
text: SHE was perhaps the biggest female star of the silent era. Her dark, depthless eyes gazed from the covers of influential fan magazines, projecting a nobly suppressed pain and longing; in the stories inside, she  or her ghost writers  advised the emerging independent American women of the 1920s on matters of fashion and home décor. She regularly topped the popularity polls, outdistancing rivals like Gloria Swanson, Pola Negri and Mary Pickford. She and her husband, the producer Joseph Schenck, founded their own production company in 1917; by 1924, The New York Times was identifying her as “the highest salaried screen actress.”

headline: From Denmark, Hacker Punk and Hit in Tow
text: AMERICAN cinema’s debt to its foreign-born directors is like sea travel’s debt to the starry night. From Fritz Lang to Ang Lee, filmmakers have come fleeing political oppression, limited opportunity, even bad taste. Far fewer have been driven from their native shores by overwhelming success and the feeling that they had nowhere to go but down.

headline: Kansas State Coasts in the Big 12
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo.— Kansas State Coach Frank Martin accomplished a new feat with his team’s 83-64 romp of Oklahoma State on Thursday night in the Big 12 tournament quarterfinals.

headline: Gardner Bunting Way Into Girardi’s Good Graces
text: TAMPA, Fla. – First, the bad news about Brett Gardner’s spring. He is batting .143 in 14 at-bats. Now, the good news. Both of his hits came on bunt singles, which is exactly what Joe Girardi and the Yankees want to see more of.

headline: Budget Woes Have Schools Expecting the Worst
text: In Elgin on Monday night, it is not going to matter who is bluffing, winning or losing in the heated debate under way in Springfield over the state’s gargantuan budget hole.

headline: Toyota’s Ills Won’t Help G.M.’s Sales, Lutz Says
text: WARREN, Mich. — Robert A. Lutz, a General Motors vice chairman, spent much of his nine years at the company trying to persuade people that its vehicles were just as good as Toyota’s.

headline: White Women Influencing Shift to Minority-Majority Nation
text: James Warren is a columnist for the Chicago News Cooperative.

headline: Enforcement of Landscape Ordinance Comes at a Bad Time
text: For the owner of a Humboldt Park auto repair shop who lost 25 percent of his sales this year, paying $50,000 to fix up the parking lot of his business to comply with the city’s landscaping ordinance would be difficult.

headline: Word of the Day | unprecedented
text: unprecedented •\ˌən-ˈpre-sə-ˌden-təd\• adjective

headline: What to Do With an Empty Storefront? A Makeshift Art Gallery
text: As the recession takes its toll on retailing, empty storefront windows throughout the Chicago area are turning into “pop-up” art galleries, the result of an opportune alignment of interests among artists, landlords and chambers of commerce.

headline: State Regulators Shut Down a City Bank, LibertyPointe
text: State banking regulators on Thursday evening shut down the troubled LibertyPointe Bank, whose chairman, Shaya Boymelgreen, built more than 2,400 apartments in New York City in the last decade. The failure was the 27th in the nation this year but the first in the city in more than a decade, regulators said.

headline: A Familiar Face at the Garden
text: The stars came out at the Big East tournament on Thursday.

headline: West Virginia Pulls One Out
text: Cincinnati Coach Mick Cronin’s order was concise. “Find Butler! Find Butler! Find Butler!” he yelled each time West Virginia had the ball, referring to the Mountaineers’ star senior, Da’Sean Butler.

headline: Administration Said to Settle on No. 2 at Fed
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration has settled on Janet L. Yellen, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco, to serve as vice chairwoman of the Federal Reserve, a senior administration official said on Thursday night.

headline: In Friday’s Bay Area Report: Who’s Minding the School?
text: FAME and the Limits of Charter School Oversight | The Alameda County Board of Education, in a 5-to-0 vote Tuesday, extended the charter of Fremont’s FAME Public Charter School for another five years, even as the county’s senior district attorney said the financial practices that prompted a highly critical state audit were still under review. The situation underscores the paradox of charter-school oversight: The same freedoms that allow these schools to serve as laboratories of new educational practices also give them unusual financial and managerial latitude. The Alameda County school superintendent praised the school — its formal name is Families of Alameda for Multi-Cultural/Multi-Lingual Education — for providing a needed service for students. Nonetheless, the superintendent, Sheila Jordan, said in interviews that FAME’s executive director, Maram Alaiwat, might have engaged in inappropriate activities involving school finances. In addition, three of four members of the school’s board last year, including Ms. Alaiwat, had relatives who either worked there or did business with the school. Experts disagreed on whether, and when, the public school systems that authorize charters could intervene.

headline: A Neighorhood’s Revival Smothered By Parking Rules
text: With the sun beaming down, the lunch crowd sipped café au lait and noshed on les tartines de pain and quiches maison. Festive rouge umbrellas dotted the courtyard as the waiter talked about the slow-cooked specialty of the house, boeuf bourguignon.

headline: Hooping It Up
text: WHO is the Academy Award-winning actress who was “instantly hooked” when she tried Hula-Hooping for fitness?

text: Ten games on Thursday, including a record-breaking performance from the West-leading San Jose Sharks. Home teams listed first:

text: The market for private-label mortgage bonds in the United States might be ready for revival, Breakingviews says.

headline: Administration Said to Settle on No. 2 at Fed
text: The Obama administration has settled on Janet L. Yellen, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco, to serve as vice chairwoman of the Federal Reserve, a senior administration official said on Thursday night.

headline: News Quiz | March 12, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page.

headline: Democrats Push Ahead on Finance Bill
text: Democrats said on Thursday that they would go it alone in an effort to pass an overhaul of financial regulation, increasing the likelihood of a bitter partisan showdown, Sewell Chan reports in The New York Times.

headline: Report Shows How, Collapsing, Lehman Hid Woes
text: It is the Wall Street equivalent of a coroner’s report — a 2,200-page document that lays out, in new and startling detail, how Lehman Brothers used accounting sleight of hand to conceal the bad investments that led to its undoing.

headline: Poll Shows Vast Majority for More Wall St. Regulation
text: An overwhelming majority of Americans wants Wall Street subjected to tougher regulation in the aftermath of the bank bailout and the bonus scandals that have rocked the U.S. financial sector, according to a Harris poll released on Thursday, Reuters reported.

headline: A Bidding War for Terra?  Yara Demurs
text: Yara International, the Norwegian fertilizer company, says it will not increase its offer to acquire American competitor Terra Industries after Terra’s board chose to favor a higher bid from CF Industries, Reuters reported.

headline: InfoGroup’s Founder Resigns From Its Board
text: The founder of database provider InfoGroup has resigned from the company’s board, The Associated Press reported.

headline: What Are Your Favorite Keepsakes From Childhood?
text: In her column this week, Michelle Slatalla writes about throwing away her daughters’ childhood mementos in preparation for a move across the country. What artifacts from your childhood — keepsakes from “the person you used to be” — do you still have? Why?

headline: Abu Dhabi’s Raine Deal Deepens Hollywood Ties
text: An Abu Dhabi state investment fund said on Thursday that it was buying a piece of a young investment house focused on sports and show business, raising the Gulf city state’s bet on the entertainment industry.

headline: Playbor
text: The increasingly blurred distinction between online play and labor.

headline: Farallon Plans Shake-Up, Report Says
text: Farallon Capital Management, the hedge fund with $21 billion in assets under management, is reorganizing its house, with plans to refocus the lion’s share of its investing on credit wagers and risk arbitrage, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: Japanese Coast Guard Arrests Anti-Whaling Skipper
text: TOKYO — The Japanese Coast Guard on Friday arrested an anti-whaling activist from New Zealand who had boarded a whaling ship in the southern Antarctic last month.

headline: Board Extends Deadline for Everglades Deal
text: Facing legal challenges and growing deficits, South Florida water officials on Thursday gave themselves six more months to finance a controversial $536 million purchase of land from United States Sugar for the Everglades.

headline: Pink Floyd Wins Court Battle With EMI Over Downloads
text: The British rock band Pink Floyd won its court battle with EMI on Thursday, with a ruling that prevents the record company from selling single downloads on the Internet from the group’s concept albums, Reuters reported.

headline: Respect Your Elders
text: Infantilism may be a fashion perennial, but if the blogger Ari Seth Cohen had his druthers, every season would be a senior moment. As the founder and editor of Advanced Style, a Sartorialist for the superannuated set, he chronicles the stylish and often eccentric get-ups of a crowd that’s largely ignored by the fashion system. “My eyes have always been drawn to older people,” said Cohen, 28. “And from a style point of view, I find them more interesting because they are of an age where they don’t have to impress anyone and can wear what they want.” In addition to shots of stylish senior citizens on the street, the site features tributes to timeless style icons, including Iris Apfel and Fleur Cowles. The hardest part of showing that true chic does not dim with age? “Trying to explain what a blog is.”

headline: Twin Suicide Attacks Hit Military Sites in Pakistan
text: LAHORE, Pakistan — Two suicide bombings in quick succession rocked an army convoy patrolling a busy market in a heavily guarded, army-controlled area on Friday, the second deadly assault on Lahore in less than a week.

headline: South by Southwest: A Virtual Playground in Austin
text: From Jenna Wortham at Bits:

headline: Leaving Green: Execs Quit Clean Energy Firms
text: Go to Item from Todd Woody at Green Inc.:

headline: Sensata Closes Higher After Year’s Biggest I.P.O.
text: Shares in Sensata Technologies Holding closed up slightly Thursday after raising $568.8 million in the biggest initial public offering so far this year, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Chicago Exchange Files for $300 Million I.P.O.
text: The last major private exchange left in the U.S., the Chicago Board Options Exchange, filed for an initial public offering of up to $300 million Thursday, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Reading and Rating the Roethlisberger Coverage
text: It has been a week since Steelers quarterback Ben Roethlisberger was accused of sexual assault. Here’s a sampling of the news media coverage:

headline: At Paris Fair, Antiques and Ham (Yes, Ham)
text: The modern incarnation of the oldest antiques fair in France, held at the picturesque Île des Impressionnistes (Impressionists’ Island) on the outskirts of Paris, is turning 40 this year. The National Antiques, Bric-a-Brac and Ham Fair, as it is known, starts today and runs through March 21, bringing together an eclectic mix of paintings, furniture, secondhand goods and regional food items.

headline: Cinemark Raises $660 Million for 3-D
text: Cinemark Holdings, a movie theater operator, said late Wednesday that it would boost the number of 3-D screens it operates to between 1,100 to 1,300 by the end of the year, up from 400, after a major round of financing came through, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Norris: Dealing With Fraud by Denial
text: Years after Charles Ponzi was imprisoned for a fraud that cost victims millions of dollars in 1920, the state of Massachusetts determined it had recovered all the assets it could, and began to distribute them to victims, who stood to receive less than 30 cents for each dollar they invested.

headline: Simon Feels No Pressure to Raise Bid for Rival
text: The chief executive of the Simon Property Group said on Thursday a revised plan by the management of General Growth Properties to emerge from bankruptcy would not put pressure on his company to sweeten its own $10 billion offer, Reuters reported.

headline: The Battle Over the Exit Sign
text: Today’s idea: American exit signs are out of sync with the rest of the world because they rely on text, not imagery, and are red, not green. That may be gradually changing, an article says.

headline: To Control Health Care Costs, Trace the Spending
text: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton.

headline: Popcast: Broken Bells, SXSW Preview and More
text: This week: A review of the new CD by Broken Bells, a collaboration between Dangermouse and James Mercer of the Shins; a concept album from outlaw country artist Shooter Jennings & Hierophant; plus a preview of the bands and parties at this year’s SXSW festival.

headline: Stray Questions for: Jo Nesbo
text: Jo Nesbo is a Norwegian novelist; the latest thriller in his Harry Hole series, “The Devil’s Star,” has just been published in the United States.

headline: The Origins of Lehman’s ‘Repo 105’
text: As The New York Times’s article on the court-appointed examiner’s report on Lehman Brothers makes clear, perhaps the most newsworthy element to pop out of the inquest’s 2,200 pages is an accounting trick known as “Repo 105.”

headline: Tip of the Week: Baseball Schedules
text: With Opening Day less than a month away, fans of Major League Baseball can start planning those trips to the ballpark. To download a copy of your favorite team’s schedule and load it right into your Outlook, iCal or Google Calendar, visit www.mysportscal.com/mlb.html.

text: Animation | Answer: to visit their Dada on the other side:

headline: Goldman’s Flamand Said to Start His Own Fund
text: Pierre-Henri Flamand, the London-based head of the largest internal hedge fund of Goldman Sachs, is leaving the investment bank to launch his own hedge fund firm, according to press reports.

headline: Former Boston Provident C.F.O. Pleads Guilty to Fraud
text: A former trader and chief financial officer of the hedge fund Boston Provident has pleaded guilty to charges to two schemes to defraud the firm, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Whitman’s Funds May Present Conflicts, Report Says
text: Meg Whitman, the billionaire Republican gubernatorial candidate in California, has invested her personal fortune in private equity and hedge funds, as well as in “oil, gas, health care and other concerns seeking to influence state policy,” The Los Angeles Times reported, citing an economic-interest disclosure filed by the former eBay chief.

headline: Brian Pitman, Former Lloyds Chief, Dies at 78
text: Brian Pitman, the banker who led Lloyds TSB to become one of Europe’s largest financial groups, has died at age 78, the British Bankers’ Association said Friday. Mr. Pitman died Thursday following a heart attack earlier in the week, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Turning Off the Phone After 20 Years on Call
text: Nancy E. Ryan, a longtime top deputy in the Manhattan district attorney’s office best known for leading the reinvestigation of the Central Park jogger case, will end her tenure in the office Friday.

headline: Sampler: Attorney General to Investigate San Francisco Crime Lab, and More Californians Apply to Out-of-State Universities
text: It’s Official: Gavin Newsom to Seek No. 2 Seat | “We are announcing formally today that I am jumping into the race for lieutenant governor,” San Francisco’s mayor, Gavin Newsom, told KCBS on Friday morning. This confirmed a report in The San Francisco Examiner that the mayor, after dropping from the race to become governor, planned to officially declare for office. “I really feel deeply that my responsibilities at home can be met in the context of this race,” Mayor Newsom told KCBS, referring to his wife and baby daughter. In the June 8 primary, Mr. Newsom, 42, will face Janice Hahn, a Los Angeles councilwoman. On Thursday, Mr. Newsom reported his latest campaign contributions, which included $6,500 apiece from Mark and Susie Buell, who have been major contributors to Democratic candidates for national office, and $4,950 from Peter Ragone, his former press secretary. [KCBS, The San Francisco Examiner]

text: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts on Friday officially sought a listing on the New York Stock Exchange, the final step in its years-long effort to become a publicly traded private equity firm.

headline: Yellen To DC
text: Good news: Janet Yellen will be the Fed’s new #2. She’s open-minded, a good counterweight to the inflation hawks who think that any day now we’ll be partying like it’s 1979. She’s also a distinguished scholar, with much of her work in New Keynesian macro.

headline: Lighten Up
text: The Takeaway Yes, we’re painfully aware of how important it is to maintain structure in our lives, especially these days. But what about the boredom that comes with it? Fortunately, loosening up doesn’t mean you have to look like a slob; this spring’s tailoring is refreshingly, well, untailored.

headline: From New York to Texas, a Seinfeld Odyssey
text: When Otis Raring began searching for a new car, he had some specific needs. He and his wife, Trisha, have two young children and are expecting a third. A minivan seemed like a good choice, but Mrs. Raring wanted one that looked a bit sportier than average. They settled on a Honda Odyssey — the Touring edition. Preferably in black, which she thought made the Odyssey look even less minivanlike.

text: For about one million low-income Medicare recipients, some good news: it’s just gotten easier to qualify for the federal Extra Help program, which provides more generous prescription drug benefits.

text: Several readers had questions for the Consults blogs about healthful cooking methods. Here Harold McGee, The Curious Cook columnist for The New York Times and the author of “On Food & Cooking: The Science & Lore of the Kitchen,” offers expert advice on storing oats and tomatoes and the best way to crush garlic.

headline: ‘The Marriage Ref’ Curbs Everyone’s Enthusiasm
text: There hasn’t been much of a honeymoon period for “The Marriage Ref,” the new NBC comedy-reality series created by Jerry Seinfeld. Though the show, in which celebrities meddle in real-life marital fights, has gotten good notice from some critics (in The New York Times Alessandra Stanley wrote it was “funny, despite a cheesy game show premise”) and scored healthy ratings, other critics and online commenters would prefer to serve it with divorce papers. But at least the show still has the support of its celebrity panelists, right? Right?

headline: Mandela’s Ex-Wife Says Interview Didn’t Happen

Naipaul, in which she was quoted making harsh statements about her former husband, Nelson Mandela, the first democratically elected president of South Africa.

headline: Israelis Block Palestinians From Holy Site

The security crackdown comes after recent clashes following Friday prayers in Jerusalem.

headline: The NBC Sale (the ’30 Rock’ Version)
text: A little over three months since Comcast agreed to buy a majority stake in NBC Universal from General Electric, the deal finally got the “30 Rock” treatment it was bound to get.

headline: Letters: Armrest Battles
text: To the Editor: Regarding, “Excuse Me, Is This Seat Taken?” (Feb. 28): My daughter, who arrived recently on a Delta flight from Las Vegas, told us that she had spent most of the flight in the aisle because of an oversize seatmate. No one offered to find her another seat since the plane was full, nor did anyone offer to refund her fare or cut the price to half since she did not have more than half a seat.

headline: Cost of Stadium Reveals Tensions in South Africa
text: NELSPRUIT, South Africa — Come June, soccer’s World Cup will be hosted by South Africa. Though only 4 of the 64 games are to be played here in Nelspruit, a $137 million stadium was built for the occasion. The arena’s 18 supporting pylons reach skyward in the shape of orange giraffes. At nightfall, their eyeballs blink with flashes of bewitching light.

headline: Lots of Web Traffic in Such a Tiny Town
text: THE images on the Flickr slide show serve up a comforting slice of mid-20th-century Americana: the local banker’s slinky ’56 Lincoln Premiere reflects the summer sun outside the hardware store on Main Street. A spit-shined Divco truck delivers fresh milk from the Borden dairy. On the town’s outskirts, where rents are low and hot-rodders use the county road as a dragstrip, a custom ’55 Ford gets a set of loud pipes at a one-bay speed shop.

headline: Less Motor, More Grip, and It All Makes Sense
text: ONCE upon a time — say, around 2004 — the 340-horsepower S4 was Audi’s 8-cylinder answer to the mighty BMW M3. It seemed pretty crazy at the time, a little car like an A4 running around with a V-8 under the hood.

headline: Pell Grants Would Rise Under Congressional Deal
text: Federal education officials had warned this week that the millions of college students who rely on Pell grants might see those scholarships cut by 60 percent if Congress failed to act on President Obama’s student loan overhaul. Through a tentative deal reached among Congressional Democrats on Thursday, that disastrous situation no longer appears on the near horizon, my colleagues David M. Herszhenorn and Tamar Lewin report in today’s Times.

headline: In Limbo, Until a Startling Reunion
text: Mike Quashie, 79, once the strapping Limbo King, came to a Bronx nursing home weak and lonely, until he ran into a nurse there who used to dance in his troupe in the 1960s.

headline: School Safety Agent Charged in Drunken-Driving Death
text: Updated, 1:23 p.m. | An off-duty school safety agent was charged with aggravated vehicular homicide and driving while intoxicated after a one-car accident in the Bronx on Thursday night that killed a passenger.

headline: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Manga Making News
text: New titles sit atop each of our lists this week. The hardcover edition of “Kick-Ass,” by Mark Millar and John Romita Jr., collects the eight-issue mini-series that chronicles what would happen, in the real world, if a teenager tried to fight crime. The answer, at least at the beginning, is excruciating injuries. The over-the-top adventure, published by Marvel Entertainment’s Icon imprint, uses adult language and depicts intense and bloody violence; the highly anticipated film version opens in theaters on April 16.

headline: Health Costs of California Air Pollution
text: Filthy air in California cost federal, state and private health insurers $193 million in hospital costs, according to a RAND Corporation study released last week.

headline: Movin’ On Up
text: When flat-panel televisions first hit the market, the joke was that while they were so thin that you could actually hang them on the wall, virtually nobody ever did.

headline: High Altitude
text: The middle-aged woman lay in the intensive-care unit, observing the tumult around her. “At least I won’t die alone,” she said to herself. She squeezed her husband’s hand. Though she hadn’t felt well for more than a month, it was not until earlier that day that it occurred to her that she might be dying.

headline: Start Your Engines
text: Despite their 29-year age gap, Clark Gable and Steve McQueen had a few things in common — rural Midwestern upbringings, motorcycle obsessions, nicknames beginning with “King of” — but their cars weren’t one of them. Gable had a rather big, lavish 1935 Duesenberg JN with a boxy nose and external side pipes, while McQueen’s favored status symbol was a sleek 1957 Jaguar XK-SS Roadster, above. Blame World War II: “After the war, these little sporty European cars seemed much more appealing,” says Ronald Labaco, co-curator of “The Allure of the Automobile,” which opens March 21 at the High Museum of Art in Atlanta. In addition to putting visitors within spitting distance of both stars’ former rides,the show traces the cultural and political influences on car design from the ’30s to the mid-’60s — considered the golden age of auto craftsmanship. Among the Mercedes-Benzes and Porsches that seemed ahead of their time, there are cars from long-defunct companies like Duesenberg and Tucker, which, despite their glamour, found themselves drowning under the excesses of bygone eras. Sound familiar?

headline: Excerpt: 'Sons of Tucson'
text: The Fox sitcom follows a loser who is hired by three boys to pretend he is their father.

headline: Terra Finally Accepts CF Industries’ Takeover Bid
text: After more than a year, the Forever War is over. CF Industries Holdings will acquire Terra Industries, a rival fertilizer maker, for $4.7 billion, the two companies said in a joint statement on Friday, ending one of the longest takeover battles in recent memory.

headline: Checking Up on the New Year’s Check List
text: Let’s check in on my New Year’s To-Do List:

headline: Friday Reading
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: 1904: Bouillabaisse
text: This appeared in a Times article called “Bouillabaisse and Chowders: An Eel-Soup Digression — Who Now Get the Best Vegetables and Fruits — A Dear Fish Market.” The author is unknown. You may halve the amount of oil if you find it alarming.

headline: Deciding on Care for Elderly Parents in Declining Health
text: TWO years ago my father, then 83, became very ill. Until then, he had been living alone in a pleasant one-bedroom apartment on the Hudson River, an hour’s drive from my home in Brooklyn.

headline: What You Did for Love (of Theater)
text: In Friday’s article about tough-to-obtain to theatrical events, including to so-called snob hits that become the talk of the cocktail party circuit, some theatergoers and directors recalled the lengths that people would go: Paying $1,000 for an online scalped ticket, sleeping out all night in Central Park. What show was the toughest ticket to snag for you, and what lengths did you go to get it?

headline: Yassky Nominated to Head Taxi Agency
text: Updated, 2:25 p.m. | Former City Councilman David Yassky has been nominated by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg to head the city’s Taxi and Limousine Commission, the mayor  announced Friday morning on his weekly radio program.

text: SAN FRANCISCO — Declaring his candidacy for a job whose very power he questioned, Mayor Gavin Newsom of San Francisco said Friday that he was running for lieutenant governor of California.

headline: Recipe Redux: Bouillabaisse, 1904
text: In 1988, The New York Times ran the Le Bernardin chef Gilbert Le Coze’s famed recipe for bouillabaisse, with its 13 steps and 25 ingredients. And that was pretty much the symbolic end for the Marseillaise fish stew: over the years, chefs made it so complicated that no one actually wanted to eat it, let alone source all the fish and cook it.

headline: Nissan NV: Automaker’s First Commercial Vehicles for U.S.
text: Nissan introduced a line of commercial work vans this week in high-roof and standard configurations. At first glance, the Nissan NV cargo vans, with their high-roof design, look like competition for Ford’s Transit Connect. They’re not. The Transit Connect, which Ford began selling in the United States last year, is an economical light-duty van with 135 cubic-feet of cargo space. The Nissan NV1500, NV2500 and NV 3500 are medium and heavy-duty commercial vehicles that can handle more than twice the payload of a Transit Connect.

headline: Weekend Competition: Park Your Car in Harvard Yard
text: This weekend, co-vocabularists are invited to share the words and phrases that signal social background or class.

headline: A Dispute on Using the Koran as a Path to Jesus
text: January was an ugly month in Malaysia. At least 10 churches were firebombed or vandalized, as was a Sikh temple. Severed boars’ heads — particularly offensive to Muslims, who are not supposed to eat pork — were found on the grounds of two mosques. The cause of this inter-religious strife was a court battle over whether non-Muslims may use the Arabic word “Allah” to refer to God.

headline: Climate Change Threatens Migratory Birds, Report Says
text: WASHINGTON — Changes in the global climate are imposing additional stress on hundreds of species of migratory birds in the United States that are already threatened by other environmental factors, according to a new Interior Department report.

headline: Not Much Hope in New Gaming Sales Report
text: The latest video game sales figures offer all kinds of hell for the gaming industry: overall sales for February were down 15 percent from the same month last year, according to a report from NPD, a market research firm. About $1.26 billion in gaming hardware, software and accessories were sold, down from $1.48 billion in February 2009.

headline: Tee Time
text: In the introduction to “Ripped: T-Shirts From the Underground” (Universe, $30), the no-wave diva Lydia Lunch traces the history of the T-shirt from its silver screen progenitors (Marlon Brando and James Dean) to a London clothing shop called Sex. It was there, circa 1975, that the promoter Malcolm McLaren and the fashion visionary Vivienne Westwood transformed “four juvenile delinquents who had been caught on numerous occasions pilfering overpriced T-shirts” into the Sex Pistols.Thirty-five years on, the D.I.Y. iconography of underground music endures, so much so that the 200 vintage tees in “Ripped” — from acts like Gary Numan, Dead Kennedys, Talking Heads and Plasmatics — look oddly familiar, no doubt thanks to what the book calls “the onset of ironic consumerism.”
