text: The Dining section of the Times wants your recipes. It’s a response to the way parents are responding to the ban that New York City’s Department of Education has put on home-baked goods in schools, which is in turn a response (or overreaction, depending on your point of view) to the fact that you can’t determine the nutrition content of Grandma’s Toll House cookie recipe.

headline: Coping With the Stigma of Tourette’s
text: Dr. Robert A. King and Dr. James F. Leckman of the Yale School of Medicine recently joined the Consults blog to answer readers’ questions about Tourette’s syndrome. Here, Dr. Leckman and Dr. King respond to readers asking about living with the strange movements, tics and vocalizations of Tourette’s, which can be socially difficult and, in some cases, lifelong.

headline: Making Sense of the Census: Ideas for Classes Across the Curriculum
text: Note: The article we are using for this lesson comes from the March 15, 2010 issue of The New York Times Upfront. Upfront is a news magazine for teens published by Scholastic in partnership with The New York Times.

headline: Death Pursues Her
text: Chang-rae Lee is fond of words like “accrete” and “accrue,” words that try to name the slow, almost imperceptible processes by which experience acquires weight, mass and, if you’re lucky, meaning. “Life, gathering,” reads one full sentence in his ferocious and lyrical new novel, “The Surrendered,” and you couldn’t ask for a better two-word description of what good fiction aspires to. This novel, his fourth, gathers life greedily, hungrily, but with a certain stealth: Lee doesn’t bolt it all down at once, as the refugee children in his story do. “The Surrendered,” his largest, most ambitious book, is about the horrors of war and the sorrows of survival, yet its manner is quiet, watchful, expectant, as if everyone, including Lee himself, were waiting to see what might accrue.

headline: Vonn Wins 3rd Straight World Cup
text: For the first time in a long time, Lindsey Vonn felt no pressure in the race start house. There was no momentous import to the outcome of Friday’s World Cup super-G in Garmisch-Partenkirchen, Germany. She did not have to race at all. The last competitor in the field, Vonn was told just before she was to ski that she had already won her third successive World Cup overall championship.

headline: Police Identify Woman Killed by Subway Train
text: Updated, 2:57 p.m. | The 48-year-old woman who was crushed to death by a subway train on Manhattan’s Upper East Side on Thursday afternoon has been identified as Rose M. Mankos, the authorities said. She was a lawyer who had previously worked for the state.

headline: Stimulus Makes People Bad at Math
text: How many people make math errors on their individual income tax returns each year?

headline: The Woman Who Influenced the Influential Choreographers
text: Trisha Brown, Yvonne Rainer,  Meredith Monk and many others studied under her. Merce Cunningham worked with her too. It’s hard to overestimate the influence the dancer and choreographer Anna Halprin has had on New York dance, even though she has made a point of staying far from the city.

headline: Off the Wall
text: Blank space is a blank canvas for Ji Lee. “I’m interested in exploring areas like the back of business cards and ceilings — why are they left empty?” says the renegade graphic designer, who is currently working as creative director of Google’s branding and marketing unit, the Creative Lab. To fill the void above, Lee creates miniature upside-down interiors that he calls “parallel worlds,” placing them on domestic ceilings (on commission) and corporate offices (on the sly). “Decorating ceilings was a common art form that somehow got lost through the reductionism of modernism,” he says. The Lilliputian lairs are meticulously furnished with objects that tell a story about the “room” and its imaginary owner. One installation shows the apartment of a rocker, complete with a guitar, amp, microphone and Jimi Hendrix poster. Another, installed in a home with two small children, features a petit bourgeois living room with velvet sofas and tiny glass cabinets filled with strange furry objects made of cat hair. “The kids love it,” Lee says. “That’s the greatest compliment.” Go to pleaseenjoy.com.

headline: The Fiction of Memory
text: Consider the state of literature at the moment. Consider the rise of the memoir, the incidences of contrived and fabricated memoirs, the rash of imputations of plagiarism in novels, the overall ill health of the mainstream novel. Consider, too, culture outside of literature: reality TV, the many shades and variations of documentary film, the rise of the curator, the rise of the D.J., sampling, appropriation, the carry-over of collage from modernism into postmodernism. Now consider that all these elements might somehow be connected, might represent different aspects of some giant whatsit that will eventually constitute the cultural face of our time in the eyes of the future. That is what David Shields proposes in “Reality Hunger: A Manifesto.” He further argues that what all those things have in common is that they express or fulfill a need for reality, a need that is not being met by the old and crumbling models of literature.

headline: Pushing for ‘Hella’ to Count, in a Big Way
text: In an age when reality television appearances, leaked sex tapes and tickling can be routes to celebrity, a student at University of California, Davis, has entered the spotlight through a scientific endeavor.

headline: Complaint Box | They’re Stealing My Sky
text: We left Manhattan for Brooklyn in 1997. Even then, before it was the rage, it felt like a destination. We kept track of all the things the neighborhoods of Brooklyn had over the metropolis of Manhattan: actual diversity, affordable restaurants, more parking and less pretension. But the best thing, no doubt, every time, was the sky. Brooklyn had sky. Not a sliver of something gauzy above narrow, vertical avenues, but a big sky, clear and vivid, like they brag about in Montana (or maybe New Jersey). The kind of sky with horizons and sunsets and stars. A movie-screen ceiling under which anything could happen.

headline: Abuse Scandal in Germany Edges Closer to Pope
text: BERLIN — A widening child sexual abuse inquiry in Europe has landed at the doorstep of Pope Benedict XVI, as a senior church official acknowledged Friday that a German archdiocese made “serious mistakes” in handling an abuse case while the pope served as its archbishop.

headline: Butchers and Saints
text: The villains of history seem relatively easy to understand; however awful their deeds, their motives remain recognizable. But the good guys, those their contemporaries saw as heroes or saints, often puzzle and appall. They did the cruelest things for the loftiest of motives; they sang hymns as they waded through blood. Nowhere, perhaps, is this contradiction more apparent than in the history of the Crusades. When the victorious knights of the First Crusade finally stood in Jerusalem, on July 15, 1099, they were, in the words of the chronicler William of Tyre, “dripping with blood from head to foot.” They had massacred the populace. But in the same breath, William praised the “pious devotion . . . with which the pilgrims drew near to the holy places, the exultation of heart and happiness of spirit with which they kissed the memorials of the Lord’s sojourn on earth.”

headline: The Identity Thief
text: I live in a town house complex, across from a woman who has become a friend. She copies me constantly — exact replicas of my clothing, furniture, bath towels, artwork, even cookbooks. It’s driving me nuts!

headline: Rain Forces Mets to Revamp Pitching Schedule
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  – The Mets’ game against the Twins in Fort Myers on Friday was canceled. The Mets drove two hours and 45 minutes across the state through heavy downpours, and within 20 minutes of their arrival, the game was called off. So they got back on the buses for the nearly three-hour return.

headline: Surfing's New Wave of Aerialists
text: Competitive surfing is undergoing a major change as a new breed of young surfers introduce amazing aerial tricks that have only been recognized in recent years.

headline: A Day of Surprises at the First Practice Sessions in Bahrain
text: BAHRAIN – The feeling around the paddock at the Bahrain Grand Prix is that this is a weekend of a thousand stories in Formula One. Where to start? I can’t decide, so I won’t. Instead, here are the main points as they occur to me, a roundup of interesting facts and events, in no particular order:

headline: Surfing’s Next Generation Takes to the Air
text: Last spring, on a green wave in the Mentawais, a chain of islands off the west coast of Indonesia, Jordy Smith performed perhaps the most sublime aerial in the history of surfing, a back flip while spinning one and a half times. Video of the flip, known as a rodeo clown, went viral when Yahoo posted it in June.

headline: Wright Arrest Is the Newest Heat Quandary
text: The Miami Heat appear to be playing a bizarre game of “Survivor” as the season winds down. The roster keeps fluctuating, with players being bounced from the lineup for reasons having nothing to do with injuries.

headline: San Francisco Welcomes Frugal Baby
text: The New York Times's Frugal Traveler, Matt Gross, travels with his one-year-old daughter to San Francisco and shows us his special techniques and gears for a baby traveler.

headline: Woods Keeps Golf Guessing
text: Who knew a few months ago that Tiger Woods rumors would become such a cottage industry?

headline: India and Russia Build Ties With Pacts
text: NEW DELHI — India and Russia signed a series of agreements on nuclear, space and military issues on Friday, after a visit by Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.

headline: India Luxury Vacations on Sale
text: If your ideal trip to India has you staying in an opulent room in a mystical setting and being treated like royalty, a set of packages just introduced by the elegant Oberoi Hotels & Resorts is worth a look.

headline: City Moves to End a Bronx Olfactory Nightmare
text: Barbara White no longer dries her clothes outside. Lucretia Jones has stopped holding backyard barbecues. Tanya Fields keeps her windows shut tight year-round.

headline: Even High-Score Borrowers at Risk of Mortgage Default
text: A HIGH credit score won’t necessarily insulate borrowers from the home-foreclosure crisis, according to a new study from FICO, which creates the credit-scoring formula used by most lenders.

headline: China Issues Another Warning to Google on Enforced Censorship of the Internet
text: BEIJING — One of China’s top Internet regulators warned bluntly on Friday that any move by Google to stop censoring its Chinese search engine would be “irresponsible” and would draw a response from Beijing.

headline: Unsafe Baby Slings
text: Motherlode readers were probably not surprised to read in the Style section yesterday that baby-wearing is all the rage in certain mommy circles and is looked on as yet another sanctimonious trend in others.

headline: Not a Solution
text: To the Editor:

headline: Hearts in Darkness
text: On finishing Marti Leimbach’s “Man From Saigon,” a novel about an American reporter, Susan Gifford, sent to Vietnam by a “women’s interest” magazine in 1967, my first thought was that in 2010, at a time when the United States finds itself engaged in a complex, controversial multifront conflict that has now gone on for nearly a decade, Vietnam has at last become a safe ­artistic choice.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: ANGELOLOGY,  by Danielle Trussoni (Viking, $27.95.) With a smitten art historian at her side, the young nun who is the heroine of Trussoni’s rousing first novel is drawn into an ancient struggle against the Nephilim, hybrid offspring of humans and heavenly beings.

headline: Paperback Row
text: DON’T CRY: Stories,  by Mary Gaitskill (Vintage Contemporaries, $15.) Gaitskill “commands her readers’ attention as few fiction writers can,” Kathryn Harrison said in the Book Review, and the reasons are on display here in her third collection of stories. Gaitskill’s characters may go in for shopping, gossip or romance, but their experience is always surprising and sometimes cruel. In their dreams as well as in reality, those characters, especially the women, are often hurt and humiliated. Harrison praised “the fierce artistry of Gaitskill’s writing” and its “introduction of the sublime into the sordid.”

headline: Who’s to Blame at Lehman?

headline: A Lawman, Polite and Ready to Shoot
text: THERE are a few ways to discern that Raylan Givens, the character at the center of the FX series “Justified” is an Elmore Leonard creation. Although he is a deputy United States marshal in a very contemporary milieu, he wears a big old cowboy hat, and his pistol, which he carries in a side holster, comes out only when he gets down to business. Regardless of the circumstance, he doesn’t spend a lot of time waving it around, but when it does reveal itself in a flash, the bodies tend to fall around him. Oh, and one other thing: As played by Timothy Olyphant, the steely gaze of a lawman with mortal tendencies is replaced with a courtly manner and a twinkle of mirth in his eye. In fact just about everybody in “Justified” displays very good manners while doing some very ill-mannered things.

headline: Now Online | T Men’s Fashion Spring 2010
text: Spring has nearly sprung, and here at T we have a glide in our stride. And it’s not just the prospect of good weather. In an increasingly homogenous world, it’s nice to be reminded that there are creative types out there who are prepared to take the heat. This weekend’s issue of T celebrates eccentric energy, wherever we can find it. Biomorphic lamps, off-the-wall rooms, rodent bow ties, lo-fi rock-band T-shirts, untailored tailoring and John Lennon’s nonconformist cool all get their moment in the fashion sun. Elsewhere, we enter the artist Daniel Arsham’s imaginarium, where sleight of hand is the house specialty; Jonathan Wingfield interviews the musician Matthew Herbert, who can make you dance to the sound of slaughtered chickens; and Armand Limnander meets Pierre-Alexis Dumas, Hermès’s artistic director, who is making the venerable French house more relevant than ever. To cap it off, we profile two actors burning up the screen: our cover star Josh Brolin and the French actor and recently announced Chanel poster boy Gaspard Ulliel, who channels the season’s Nouvelle Vague look in a shoot by Paolo Roversi. No wonder we’re hot to trot.

headline: In Defense of the Singing Hamlet
text: AMBROISE THOMAS’S “Hamlet” returns to the Metropolitan Opera on Tuesday night, no doubt to be furiously denounced once again as a travesty of Shakespeare’s tragedy. Composed in 1868 as a five-act French grand opera with all the trimmings and not seen at the Met since 1897, “Hamlet” invariably seems to get bad press, especially in Anglo-Saxon countries. “Pretentious and wearisome,” summed up a critic for The New York Times after the Met premiere in 1884. “We’ve always known that something was rotten in the state of Denmark,” snarled the British critic Edward Seckerson after seeing a revival of the opera at Covent Garden in 2003, “and now we know what it is.” Perhaps the most devastating brushoff came from the French music historian E. Destranges, who, on the occasion of the composer’s centenary in 1911, sniffed that Thomas had done little more than “deposit” music on Shakespeare.

headline: Au Revoir, Paris Fashion Week

Even the bags played on the theme — some of them, in fact, turned out to be hot water bottles. Chanel is one of the few labels that have weathered the crisis well and, thankfully, Lagerfeld uses its considerable resources to constantly up the ante when it comes to creating a visual spectacle.

headline: Now Screening | ‘Damaged Goods’
text: If you’ve never ever imagined porcelain figurines acting out a trenchant class struggle, that’s probably because you’re not the British ceramics prankster Barnaby Barford. Porcelain can be something of a dainty medium, but Barford’s playful, often perverse arrangements — he cuts and remakes mass-market and antique porcelain figurines — turn Hallmark Store staples into subversive art objects. In Barford’s adorable first film, “Damaged Goods” (screened above), a maidenly tchotchke takes a tumble. Will she go the way of Humpty Dumpty? Nine new works from the film are on view at the David Gill Galleries on Loughborough Street in London through March 20.

But by the end of the week, as an international audience of sheiks, oligarchs, Thai queens and Dutch conquistadors finished their supper, it did not add up to a sumptuous meal. Let’s just say there was no new taste sensation.

In November we called it a half-step in the right direction.

headline: Gillibrand Still Trying to Win Over Bloomberg
text: WASHINGTON — He gripes about her in private conversations with his aides and her colleagues on Capitol Hill. He has yet to take up her invitation to sit down for dinner. And his political team is constantly shopping for potential candidates to oust her.

headline: How Important Is It for a Red Wine to Be a Dark Color?
text: One of the most striking characteristics of the 2007 red Burgundies is their relatively pale color. The particular conditions of this vintage compelled most winemakers to treat their grapes with a light hand. That is, they did not try to extract lots of color and tannin from the grapes. As a result, you can easily hold a glass of a 2007, even a grand cru wine, and see your fingers through the wine on the other side of the glass.

headline: WaMu Settles With JPMorgan and F.D.I.C.
text: Washington Mutual said Friday that it had reached a settlement with JPMorgan Chase and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation that is expected to bring Washington Mutual about $6 billion and help resolve its bankruptcy. But the deal could leave WaMu’s shareholders out in the cold, Reuters reports.

headline: Record Number of Tax Filers Owed No Taxes in 2008
text: A record number of federal individual income tax filers in 2008 owed no taxes, according to an analysis of Internal Revenue Service data conducted by the Tax Foundation.

headline: Cabbies Gouge Passengers Out of Millions, Agency Finds
text: Updated, 6:00 p.m. | For the past two years, thousands of taxi drivers overcharged passengers a total of more than $8 million by switching the meter to double the rate, the Taxi and Limousine Commission said Friday afternoon.

headline: Arrest Stokes Concerns About Radicalized Muslims
text: WASHINGTON — The arrest in Yemen of a New Jersey man accused of joining Al Qaeda is the latest in an alarming string of cases involving radicalized American Muslims, a trend some experts link to the duration of the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan.

headline: Hurdles Still Remain for Ground Zero Settlement
text: Sgt. Dawn Sorrento says she looks on the years since the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks as a blur of doctor’s visits, ambushes by illnesses she had never heard of and growing resentment toward the city that challenged her injury claims.

headline: Fish That You Can Invite to a Dinner Party
text: FISH can be finicky dinner-party fare, especially for the distracted cook. Step away for a moment to sip your cocktail and your fillets might go from pearly to parched.

headline: A Look at the Examiner in the Lehman Case
text: The unsealing of a high-profile report on the bankruptcy of Lehman Brothers was the culmination of an exhaustive — and lucrative — 12 months of detective work by Anton R. Valukas and his Chicago law firm, Jenner & Block, The Wall Street Journal reports.

headline: A Move to Protect Low-Wage Workers
text: A coalition of labor unions, immigrant advocacy groups and nonprofit organizations in New York announced their support on Friday for newly introduced legislation that would greatly increase penalties against employers that violate minimum-wage and overtime laws.Supporters of the bill, known as the Wage Theft Prevention and Responsible Employer Protection Act, say that wage violations are all too common because penalties for such violations are small under New York law and because employers that break the law face little likelihood of getting caught.

headline: A Tale of Two Obamas
text: “Saturday Night Live” hasn’t pulled many punches in its treatment of President Obama but Fred Armisen’s impersonation of him has lacked, for some,  the definitive quality that “SNL” predecessors like Darrell Hammond and Dana Carvey brought to their presidential impressions. (You can check out nearly all of the “SNL” presidents in a recent Funny or Die video.)

headline: Lehman Kept Billions Off Books
text: The bank used accounting gimmicks to hide its weakness in the months before its bankruptcy, a report says.

headline: Is Capitalism a Bad Word?
text: The Texas Board of Education voted today to make changes sought by conservatives in the state’s social sciences curriculum, James C. McKinley reports.

headline: UBS Pushes Swiss Officials for an End to Tax Dispute
text: The Swiss banking giant UBS has stepped up its lobbying to pass a treaty with the United States that would resolve a dispute over tax-evading clients, amid signs that the deal is running into trouble in Parliament, The New York Times’s Matthew Saltmarsh reports.

headline: Sunday Preview
text: Are the hills too steep for a stroller? Are the costs too high for a dad on a budget? Matt Gross, who writes the Frugal Traveler column, finds high style on a low budget in San Francisco — this time with his 1-year-old daughter as his travel companion.

headline: Chic in Review | Commander Karl
text: Binns, TomNow designing handbags and T-shirts. Love!

headline: Construction on a Small Scale
text: “Once I had the name, Elgin Park, that inspired how I would grow and photograph the town,” said Michael Paul Smith, referring to the community that is the subject of his wildly popular Flickr portfolio.

headline: Scorecard | Louis Vuitton Wins!
text: Through four international fashion weeks — we may as well just call it Fashion Month — Scorecard has been your trusty guide, reading nearly every review from English-language critics. 240 shows and 1,802 reviews later, we’re happy to report that Marc Jacobs, who took us all over the rainbow with his pared-down dissertation on Americana for his namesake line back in New York, has landed. So what are they wearing in the merry old land of … Paris? Well, for one, these Dorothys aren’t your de rigueur twiggy teens but real women (O.K., Victoria’s Secret Angels and ’90s supermodels) with breasts and hips. That’s a casting tactic Miuccia Prada seems quickly to have forgotten.

headline: Oklahoma State Ready to Move Forward
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo.— Oklahoma State’s Travis Ford was hardly concerned that his team may not bounce back in the N.C.A.A. tournament after its 83-64 blowout loss to No. 9 Kansas State on Thursday night in the Big 12 tournament quarterfinals.

headline: Suspect Held in Attack on Woman in Bar Bathroom
text: Updated, 6:18 p.m. | The police have taken a suspect into custody in the vicious attack of a 29-year-old pediatric nurse from Connecticut who was beaten and left bleeding and unconscious in a bathroom stall at a Midtown Manhattan bar, the authorities said Friday evening.

headline: Sony Adds Motion Control to the PS3
text: Sony unwrapped PlayStation Move this week at the Game Developers Conference 2010 in San Franciscio  and says it will be available this year, most likely in the fall.

headline: What We’re Reading…
text: How the economy affects pop music, and other links from around the Web.

headline: Mommy Is Busy Blogging
text: Once upon a time mothers gathered over backyard fences and shared. Now they gather at places like Motherlode, over virtual cups of coffee, trading worries and secrets with friends they will probably never see.

headline: In an All-Riley Show, Peace, From the Mouths of Babes
text: The Kronos Quartet is ensconced at Carnegie Hall for a Perspectives series that explores the expansive, stylistically borderless repertory for which this ensemble is known, with master classes and a program by student quartets along the way. The group made a down payment on this minifestival in November, when it performed Tan Dun’s “Ghost Opera” and the pageantlike “Chinese Home” during Carnegie Hall’s festival of Chinese music. But the series got under way in earnest on Thursday evening, with a program of Terry Riley’s music at Zankel Hall.

headline: Will New Financial Bill Satisfy Democratic Critics?
text: Senator Christopher J. Dodd of Connecticut, the Democratic chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, could face stiff opposition from some vocal members of his own party if his revised bill on financial regulation does not go far enough to curb the problem of banks that are too big to fail.

headline: A Trip Through Time and Fashion
text: The denizens of “Dear Emissary, ...” might almost be characters in  by turns  a Jane Austen novel, a Fassbinder film or a punk music video. But almost doesn’t count in art, and Walter Dundervill’s new dance-theater work, which opened on Wednesday night at the Chocolate Factory in Queens, largely and pleasurably escapes neat associations to float in its own strange in-between logic.

headline: Kohlberg Kravis Files for Listing on Big Board
text: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts on Friday officially sought a listing on the New York Stock Exchange, the final step in its years of work to become a publicly traded private equity firm.

headline: At the Guggenheim, the Art Walked Beside You, Asking Questions
text: A few Saturdays ago, a teenage visitor to the Guggenheim Museum, a girl in a black beret, slid open the door to the Aye Simon Reading Room and peered in at a group of people in animated conversation. “Is there something going on in here?” she said.

headline: A Movable Feast Has Its Advantages
text: THE New Jersey Symphony Orchestra performs at seven locations throughout the state, rather than being tethered to a single performance space. That is a distinct advantage, in the eyes of Jacques Lacombe, the orchestra’s new music director.

headline: A Chrysalis for Writers in an Old Train Stop
text: SLEEPY HOLLOW

headline: Complex Colors in Simple Settings
text: Gilberto Gil promised a “very simple concert” at the Nokia Theater on Thurday night: just a trio with Mr. Gil and his son Bem Gil on guitars, with his longtime arranger Jaques Morelenbaum on cello.

headline: Playing a Game of ‘Who’s the Adult Here?’
text: One question has to be going through audience’s minds during “Kimberly Akimbo” at the Schoolhouse Theater: How old is Ruth Reid?

headline: Ousted Variety Critic Joins New York Festival
text: Todd McCarthy, the veteran film reviewer for Variety who was let go from that position on Monday, will not be idle for very long. On Friday the Film Society of Lincoln Center said Mr. McCarthy had joined the selection committee of the New York Film Festival. In a telephone interview, Mr. McCarthy said that in fact he had been offered the position by Richard Peña, the program director of the film society, before the Variety separation took place. “That was all done,” Mr. McCarthy said, “and then Monday, this came down.” On the selection committee Mr. McCarthy joins Mr. Peña, the film critics Melissa Anderson and Dennis Lim (who is also a contributor to The New York Times) and Scott Foundas, the film society’s associate program director, who received some of his earliest review assignments at Variety from Mr. McCarthy. Mr. McCarthy said it was still possible he could contribute freelance work to Variety.

headline: Of Suffragettes and Seamstresses
text: SOUTHAMPTON

headline: Problems for New Orleans Art Show
text: Prospect, the New Orleans art biennial that began in 2008 (which included Mark Bradford’s “Mithra”), winning critical praise and generating millions in tourist income for its hurricane-battered home, has become entangled in fund-raising and administrative problems that are jeopardizing its future, The Times-Picayune of New Orleans reported Thursday. The ambitious event, which installed the work of more than 80 artists at sites throughout New Orleans, ended up badly over budget after the bills came due in 2008, owing more than $1 million more than it had raised. Late last month, its founding director, Dan Cameron, announced that the next iteration of the event, Prospect.2, would be postponed until the fall of 2011 from this November because of fund-raising shortfalls. The Times-Picayune reported that several directors who joined the biennial’s board in 2009 to help shore up the finances and raise money for Prospect.2, stepped down in February because of differences with Mr. Cameron over how the project should be managed. Two people with knowledge of the board resignations, who spoke on condition of anonymity because of the sensitivity of the situation, confirmed the basic account of the problems to The New York Times. The Times-Picayune reported that the biennial’s executive director, Barbara Motley, a theater owner who was hired last year to oversee the administrative side of the event so that Mr. Cameron could focus on selecting artists and helping them to realize their works, had also resigned. Ms. Motley told the newspaper that she believed in “organizational charts and management protocols” while Mr. Cameron was “much more organic in his approach to management.”Earlier this month the Contemporary Arts Center in New Orleans announced that it would not renew Mr. Cameron’s contract as its part-time visual arts director. The center’s director said it needed someone to work full-time to oversee its art exhibitions. Mr. Cameron did not respond to telephone and e-mail messages left for him today.

headline: Making Music With Plastic
text: EAST ORANGE

headline: Book Critics Circle Presents Awards
text: The British author Hilary Mantel was awarded the National Book Critics Circle Award for fiction at the Tishman Auditorium of the New School on Thursday night for “Wolf Hall,” a historical novel about the court of Henry VIII that centered on the king’s adviser Thomas Cromwell. Ms. Mantel had already won the 41st-annual Man Booker Prize last fall for the book. The board of the National Book Critics Circle, a nonprofit group of more than 600 professional book reviewers, cited Ms. Mantel for a work that was “original in voice and ambitious in style.” Richard Holmes won the nonfiction award for “The Age of Wonder: How the Romantic Generation Discovered the Beauty and Terror of Science.” Blake Bailey won the biography award for “Cheever: A Life.” Diana Athill won the autobiography award for “Somewhere Towards the End: A Memoir.” The poetry prize went to Rae Armantrout for “Versed,” and the criticism prize was awarded to Eula Biss for “Notes From No Man’s Land: American Essays.”

headline: Ray Charles Musical to Open in November
text: “Unchain My Heart, the Ray Charles Musical” is scheduled to begin preview performances on Broadway on Oct. 8 and open on Nov. 7, the lead producer, Stuart Benjamin, said on Thursday. It will be directed by Sheldon Epps with a book by Suzan-Lori Parks, the Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright of “Topdog/Underdog.” The musical, which had a developmental production at Pasadena Playhouse under the title “Ray Charles Live!” in 2007, imagines Charles, at his last live recording session, where stories from his life pour out and mix with his best-known hits that will be featured in the show. A spokeswoman for the production said that “Unchain My Heart” represents the first musical book-writing effort by Ms. Parks, whose plays also include “Venus,” “In the Blood” and her newest, “The Book of Grace,” which is now in preview performances at the Public Theater. Mr. Benjamin, who worked with Charles for years and produced the Academy Award-winning film “Ray,” said the production would run at a Shubert Organization theater to be announced later.

headline: As Its Arms Makers Falter, Russia Buys Abroad
text: MOSCOW — Ask a Russian what the country makes well, and the answer, more often than not, will be the Kalashnikov rifle.

headline: No to a ‘God of Carnage’ Tour
text: The producers of “God of Carnage,” the winner of the 2009 Tony Award for best play and a critical and commercial hit on Broadway, have decided not to mount a national tour of the production, concerned that it would not run enough weeks to make a tour financially worthwhile. An executive involved in the production, who spoke on condition of anonymity because he was not authorized to discuss tour plans, said the producers had been mulling a national tour for months and lined up “some great actors” for the possible production. (The executive declined to name them.) While some theaters nationally were considering a “Carnage” tour for a spot in their 2010-11 subscription seasons, the producers decided that not enough theaters in major cities would be available for a tour that would need to last at least 26 weeks to make the show profitable. Instead, once “Carnage” closes on Broadway  it opened on March 22, 2009, and is running indefinitely  the play will probably be licensed to regional theaters that can then mount their own productions.

headline: CBS Wins, Despite ‘Idol’
text: CBS edged past Fox in the ratings on Thursday night even as an episode of Fox’s “American Idol” that sent home four contestants garnered the largest audience in prime time. According to Nielsen’s estimates, 19.1 million viewers watched “American Idol” at 8 p.m., but CBS’s back-to-back crime shows “CSI” (16 million) at 9 p.m. and “The Mentalist” (15.4 million) at 10 p.m. won their time slots; CBS’s “Survivor” also earned a solid 12.1 million opposite “Idol.” Fox finished second with a lineup rounded out by “Kitchen Nightmares” (7.6 million). ABC was third with new episodes of “Grey’s Anatomy” (11 million) and “Private Practice” (7.9 million). NBC placed fourth as its new series “The Marriage Ref” (6 million) began to lose the luster on its wedding band.

headline: In the Pew, Peace and Reflection
text: Linda I. Gibbs, 50, one of the city’s six deputy mayors, has a portfolio that includes homelessness, child welfare, aging, hospitals and juvenile justice. On Sundays, she mostly sticks to more cheerful pursuits in Brooklyn. Ms. Gibbs lives in a loft in Brooklyn Heights with her husband of 17 years, Tom McMahon, 55, a government relations consultant, and their two children, Ryann, 16, and Leo, 14. JULIE BOSMAN

headline: N.F.L. Study Raises Questions About FieldTurf
text: Some reason for concern for the new Giants and Jets stadium at the Meadowlands: the N.F.L.’s Injury and Safety Panel has found that the rate of anterior cruciate ligament injuries is 88 percent higher in games played on FieldTurf than on grass. The new Meadowlands stadium will have FieldTurf, the cushy synthetic turf that players usually love.

headline: Through Irish Eyes, America as Evildoer
text: It is a refreshing change to have Tom Molloy, an Irish artist, commenting on America at the Aldrich Contemporary Art Museum. While some of the art in the show is a little dated, dealing with events during the presidency of George W. Bush or earlier, it offers museumgoers an all too rare opportunity to see how an artist in another part of the world sees us. The result is not flattering.

headline: Judging Obama’s ‘Pep Rally’
text: Oliver Wendell Holmes Sr., who had a little first-hand knowledge of cantankerous Supreme Court justices, once wrote that “stupidity often saves a man from going mad.” If true, there’s a great deal of sanity involved in the growing rift between President Obama and the conservatives on the high court. What began with a ruling in First Amendment case and escalated with a simple shake of Justice Samuel Alito’s head …

headline: Dump Fannie and Freddie, G.O.P. Lawmaker Urges
text: Senate Democrats may have ended negotiations with their Republican counterparts over the financial regulatory bill, but House Republicans remain active and vocal in the debate.

headline: The Skyline, Where Eagles Roam
text: New York is getting wild again. The cabaret laws are still strict, and the smoking ban is still in place. But in the last few weeks there have been sightings throughout the boroughs of creatures more commonly seen on the Discovery Channel.

headline: Seeing the Forest Through the Dreamscape
text: A woman (Elizabeth DeMent) explodes onto the stage and across it. She punctuates this entry with three identical but peculiar jumps, each one ending pow! with one leg extended sideways and the torso lurching the opposite way. The combination of precision and looseness is arresting. Furious, wild and absolutely focused, the whole body is making a potent gesture. You immediately follow it as both psychological revelation and wildlife documentary.

headline: Texas Is Looking for Answers
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — The handshake between Texas Coach Rick Barnes and Baylor Coach Scott Drew was brisk Thursday night after the Bears won, 86-67, in the Big 12 quarterfinals to beat the Longhorns for a third time this season.

headline: Disney Cost-Cutting Fells Zemeckis Company
text: Walt Disney Studios pulled the plug on Robert Zemeckis’s motion-capture company on Friday, the latest in a string of cost-cutting moves. ImageMovers Digital, which is based near San Francisco and employs 450 people, will slowly wind down production over the next few months.

headline: Chronicle of a Changing City
text: THE VIRTUAL SENIOR CENTER is what you get when you partner a Microsoft “cyberseniors” program with the formerly sleepy Benjamin Rosenthal Senior Center on Kissena Boulevard in Queens. New cameras, monitors, microphones and Internet connections allow half a dozen homebound senior citizens to join in all the action in the center — mah-jongg, bingo, flirt sessions. And, using donated computers, they recently began logging on to the Web for the first time. “It completely woke me up,” said Adele Lerner, 103, who now talks to her daughter in California every morning by Skype and watches Sabbath services streaming live from a synagogue in Manhattan. Another participant, Milton Greidinger, 86, said the connection had enabled him to find old friends, chat with college girls and order groceries from FreshDirect. “It’s like going from comatose to back to life again,” Mr. Greidinger said.

headline: What We’re Reading: A Cook, a Slacker, Some Bubbly and Fall Colors
text: Friday’s roundup of interesting Web links, as selected by the technology reporters and editors of The New York Times:

headline: California Speaker Promises Change
text: LOS ANGELES — The new speaker of the California Assembly, John A. Pérez, said he will cut the Assembly’s budget by 15 percent, that a Republican lawmaker who wanted to be the Lt. Governor but failed to get confirmed by the Democratically-controlled legislature will have a better shot on his watch, and that being the first openly gay head of a state assembly is historic, but “not dispositive” concerning his approach to governing.

headline: Two Bands Nurtured in a Garden State of Mind
text: In the middle of “The Monitor,” the new album by Titus Andronicus, comes the desperate ramble “Theme from ‘Cheers.’ “ It’s an unhappy song, with the earnest, wired singer Patrick Stickles detailing a love affair with an uncompromising mate: New Jersey.

headline: Nine to Know: Nomar Garciaparra
text: Bill Chuck created Billy-Ball.com and is a co-author of Walkoffs, Last Licks, and Final Outs. He grew up in New York and now lives with his wife (a Red Sox fan), and daughter (a Yankees fan), two miles from Fenway Park while Bill claims to be Switzerland. His other daughter lives in New York City, away from the fray. You can follow him on Twitter.

headline: His Next Act: Driving Out Apartheid’s Ghost
text: CAPE TOWN  Athol Fugard, the renowned South African playwright, paced at the edge of a plywood stage, rubbing his head and listening intensely to two actors run through their lines. Rehearsals for his new play, “The Train Driver,” had begun.

headline: Student Loan Provisions May Ease Passage of Health Care Bill
text: Many House Democrats reacted enthusiastically on Friday to the word that a proposed overhaul of student loan programs would be included with major health care legislation in an expedited budget package to be offered in Congress.

headline: 3-Family Home for Sale (One Family Included)
text: FOR sale: three-family home on a lovely and quiet block of Greenpoint, Brooklyn. Its charms include basement storage space, proximity to the subway and the Polish bakeries of Manhattan Avenue, and the makings of a quaint backyard.

headline: Who’s the Best Mommy of Them All?
text: We all know them. We avoid them on playgrounds. We shudder at their comments on parenting Web sites. They are the perfectly nice women who turn into mothers with strong opinions about how to raise children. Whether it’s VBAC vs. Caesarean, breast milk vs. formula, disposable vs. cloth or wraps vs. strollers, these moms know what they think and will stop at nothing to show you the light.

headline: Carriage Horses Have Their Day at City Hall
text: Manhattan’s carriage horses may soon get an annual five-week vacation and safer working conditions, while their drivers receive a 47 percent pay raise – their first increase in more than 20 years.

headline: A Bronx Island in Many Roles, Even as Itself
text: CITY ISLAND, a tiny and curious enclave in the Bronx, has a cinematic history that is long, if not quite storied: Parts of a 1912 rendition of Shakespeare’s  “Richard III,”  believed to be the oldest surviving complete American feature film, were shot there.

headline: Clinton Rebukes Israel on Housing Announcement
text: WASHINGTON — In a tense, 43-minute phone call on Friday morning, Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton told Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu that Israel’s plan for new housing units for Jews in East Jerusalem sent a “deeply negative signal” about Israeli-American relations, and not just because it spoiled a visit by Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

headline: 3 Rulings Find No Link to Vaccines and Autism
text: In a further blow to the antivaccine movement, three judges ruled Friday in three separate cases that thimerosal, a preservative containing mercury, does not cause autism.

headline: White House Weighs Talks With Taliban After Afghan Successes
text: WASHINGTON — With American troops pouring into insurgent strongholds in Afghanistan and the United States succeeding in killing insurgent leaders with drone attacks in Pakistan, the Obama administration is beginning to consider whether it has gained the upper hand sufficiently to justify an effort to begin talks with the Taliban.

headline: Senate Abortion Restrictions Are Sufficient, Catholic Group Says
text: According to the National Catholic Reporter, Catholics in Alliance for the Common Good, a Washington-based advocacy group, sent a letter to members of Congress on Friday urging support for the Senate-passed health care bill and expressing its view that the bill contains sufficient provisions to prevent the use of federal money to pay for insurance coverage of abortions.

headline: Iraq Election May Leave Kirkuk Status Uncertain
text: KIRKUK, Iraq — Early election results appear to reflect a hardening of divisions between Kurds, Arabs and Turkmens in northern Iraq, potentially complicating efforts by the United States and the United Nations to forge a compromise over the oil-rich city of Kirkuk — a prize claimed by both Iraq’s semiautonomous Kurdistan region and the central government.

headline: Woman Hit by a Train Is Identified
text: The 48-year-old woman who was crushed to death by a subway train on the Upper East Side of Manhattan this week has been identified, the authorities said Friday.

headline: Grapevine Moth Forces Quarantine for Part of Napa Valley
text: BERKELEY, Calif. — The state’s most lucrative crop, grapes, has yet another insect enemy.

headline: He Could Sell a Bridge Over the East River
text: The Lifetime movie “Who Is Clark Rockefeller?” slips by easily enough. The story of how the German chameleon Christian Karl Gerhartsreiter fooled successive flocks of Americans with his invented personas, culminating in Clark Rockefeller, fictional scion of America’s most blue-blooded family, is a natural for the network.

headline: The Obesity-Hunger Paradox
text: WHEN most people think of hunger in America, the images that leap to mind are of ragged toddlers in Appalachia or rail-thin children in dingy apartments reaching for empty bottles of milk.

headline: The Week in Pictures for March 12
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in the New York region. Subjects include the Atlantic Yards groundbreaking ceremony, Lil Wayne’s sentencing, and auditions for a reality show about the Russian population in Brighton Beach, Brooklyn.

headline: For That Post-Workout Hunger
text: To get an idea what kind of shape the Woodbridge-based restaurant chain Muscle Maker Grill is in, consider its recent growth: only two years ago, Colonia was its sole location. Now there are 18 Muscle Maker Grills, stretching from Toms River to Edgewater, according to Robert E. Morgan, the company’s chief operating officer.

headline: Good News, Comrades! Stalin Has a Job for You
text: “Lenin’s Embalmers,” at Ensemble Studio Theater, will not teach you specifically how to embalm yourself so that admirers eight decades later will be able to pay their respects directly to your lifelike face. It will, however, teach you to beware the living, especially those in seats of power who issue orders that carry the whiff of crazy.

headline: Just One Flight Up to Join a Town’s Revival
text: ABOVE: the name has a nice ring to it, and it’s apt for more than one reason.

headline: Sometimes a Penalty Double May Make an Average a Top
text: The winners of the North American Open Pairs on Thursday in Reno, Nev., were Doug Doub of West Hartford, Conn., and Frank Merblum of Bloomfield, Conn. They also won this title in 2001 and were second in 2003.

headline: Where Root Beer Is the Draw
text: Plenty of Westchester restaurants carry beers from Captain Lawrence Brewing Company, an excellent microbrewer in Pleasantville. But only Pumpernickel offers what is possibly my favorite product from the brewery: root beer on tap, made according to the restaurant’s proprietary recipe.

headline: Thai Traditions, Made for Sharing
text: TUCKED into a residential area a few blocks south of Sleepy Hollow’s main thoroughfare, Tyrynda Thai practically glows with the warmth of its aromatic Thai cuisine and welcoming staff.

headline: In Lehman’s Demise, Some Shades of Enron
text: Peter J. Henning follows issues related to white-collar crime for DealBook’s White Collar Watch.

headline: New York Cabs Gouged Riders Out of Millions
text: About 3,000 New York City taxi drivers routinely overcharged riders over two years by surreptitiously fixing their meters to charge rates that would normally apply only to trips outside the five boroughs, according to the city’s Taxi and Limousine Commission.

headline: As the Budget Ax Swings Again, There May Be No Way to Avoid the Pain

headline: Resurgence on the Right Puts Gingrich Back in Style
text: WASHINGTON — Newt Gingrich still relishes stirring the pot of the culture wars.

headline: Like Fast Food, Just Better and Slower
text: AT La Bottega Italian Gourmet, customers who order panini, as Michael Parente, of Lynbrook, did recently, can expect to wait for it. Mr. Parente watched a cook behind the rustic take-out counter slice speck, a type of Italian ham, layer it on ciabatta with fontina cheese and arugula, and place it in the panini press until the cheese melted and the bread crisped.

headline: One on One: Andrey Ternovskiy, Creator of Chatroulette
text: Andrey Ternovskiy, a polite, excited and eager Russian high school student, scoured the Internet trying to find a Web site that allowed random video chats with strangers. When he realized a site like that didn’t exist, he decided to build it. Three months and tens of millions of users later, the 17-year-old is wandering around New York City and (soon) San Francisco talking to investors and programmers about where to take his project next.

headline: Events on Long Island
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Nassau and Suffolk Counties this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com, or by mail to Long Island Weekly, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: Save Station Agent Jobs, 3 House Democrats Urge
text: Three House Democrats have written a letter to the Metropolitan Transportation Authority arguing that the planned layoffs of hundreds of station agents could “compromise the security” of the subways in New York City and asking the agency to “seek an alternative mechanism for closing the budget gap.”

headline: Events in New Jersey
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state. Items may be submitted by mail to New Jersey Calendar, Metropolitan, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405; or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, March 12
text: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

headline: Women Making Gains on Faculty at Harvard
text: Five years after Lawrence H. Summers, then the president of Harvard University, suggested that innate differences might explain why women are less successful in science and math careers than men, Harvard is, in some ways, a different place.

headline: An Olfactory Nightmare May End in the Bronx
text: Barbara White no longer dries her clothes outside. Lucretia Jones has stopped hosting backyard barbecues. Tanya Fields keeps her windows shut tight year round.

headline: For the Dishwasher’s Sake, Go Easy on the Detergent
text: I’VE been writing on some weighty topics lately — too little money, too many choices, too few jobs. It’s time, I decided, to move on to some questions that haunt me almost every day.

headline: Events in Connecticut
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Connecticut. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com, or by mail to Connecticut Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: Events in Westchester
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around the Hudson Valley. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com, or by mail to Westchester Calendar, Metropolitan, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: Richard Stites, Historian of Russian Culture, Dies at 78
text: Richard Stites, who opened up new territory for historians with a landmark work on the Russian women’s movement and in numerous articles and books on Russian and Soviet mass culture, died on Sunday in Helsinki, where he was doing research. He was 78 and lived in Washington.

headline: Where Some Envision Czar’s End, Church Sees Building Site
text: MOSCOW — Visitors from around the world have turned an isolated ravine in central Russia into a pilgrimage site in recent years. They arrive to gaze at the unadorned earth where the Bolsheviks, in one final act to defile the dynasty that they toppled, are believed to have dumped the remains of Czar Nicholas II and his family in July 1918.

headline: Japan: Finance Official Reveals Secret Payment to U.S.
text: Japan’s finance minister said Friday that an investigation revealed that Tokyo had secretly agreed with Washington to shoulder extra costs of Okinawa’s 1972 return to Japan beyond the $320 million stipulated in a treaty. The investigation was part of a push by the Democratic Party government to expose secret pacts made with Washington in the 1960s and 1970s by the Liberal Democrats, whose half-century grip on power the Democrats ended last summer. The finance minister, Naoto Kan, left, said the inquiry had discovered that Tokyo paid $85 million more for the relocation of American military bases on the island.

headline: A Scam as Easy as 3-1-1
text: By flooding the city’s 311 line with phony building complaints, someone has put thousands of homeowners in Queens under a state of bureaucratic siege.

headline: Youthful Pop, Cheek and Crowd Surfing
text: The choreographer Juliette Mapp, the current guest curator of Danspace Project’s Platform 2010 initiative, has emphasized the importance of presenting an intergenerational array of artists in “Back to New York City.” Next week comes the inimitable octogenarian Elaine Summers; on Thursday night the youngsters had the run of the place, when Katy Pyle and Jen Rosenblit, both in their 20s, presented new work.

headline: Exalting 20 Years of Rock, Babies and Cheerleaders
text: For any choreographer working in New York, reaching the 20-year mark is no small feat. For Jody Oberfelder, such an anniversary is occasion to look back in a two-act program, “Heads or Tales,” which highlights dances created throughout her career. Lesson learned: Perhaps the only thing Ms. Oberfelder cares about more than a cartwheel is a headstand.

headline: Five Years After an Incendiary Remark, Signs That Harvard Is More Welcoming to Women
text: Some readers of The Choice may be too young to remember the brush fire that Lawrence H. Summers, then the president of Harvard University, touched off in 2005, when he suggested that innate differences might explain why women are less successful in science and math careers than men.

headline: The Netherlands: Amsterdam’s Mayor Wins Party Post
text: Job Cohen, the popular mayor of Amsterdam, on Friday became the new leader of the Dutch Labor Party, leaving him well placed to become the country’s next prime minister after the June general elections. The government collapsed in February when the Labor Party quit the governing coalition over the continued Dutch military presence in Afghanistan. The 2,000 Dutch soldiers, part of the NATO contingent fighting the war, were scheduled to return home at the end of the year, but after entreaties from the United States, the leading Christian Democrats tried to extend the Dutch military presence. A long cabinet debate prompted the left-of-center Labor Party to walk out, necessitating new elections. Under Mr. Cohen, the Labor Party hopes to regain ground and win enough votes to form the next government.

headline: Heartthrob’s Blog Challenges China’s Leaders
text: SHANGHAI

headline: Tea Party Avoids Divisive Social Issues
text: For decades, faith and family have been at the center of the conservative movement. But as the Tea Party infuses conservatism with new energy, its leaders deliberately avoid discussion of issues like gay marriage or abortion.

headline: On the Street | In Paris
text: A fresh language for 21st-century dress popped up here and there during the Paris fashion shows.

headline: Beltran Remains Confident in Mets Despite Loss of Key Players
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Carlos Beltran planned to call Jose Reyes on Friday to offer support and encouragement as Reyes sat in New York waiting for his overactive thyroid gland to return to normal. Beltran offered similar hope and encouragement for a team that appears as if it will start the 2010 season with the same shortcomings that derailed its 2009 campaign.

headline: History of an Abuse Case
text: The Munich Archdiocese acknowledged mishandling an abuse case in the late ’70s and early ’80s, when the pope served as its archbishop. Information about the priest in the case was provided by the archdiocese, who identified him only with the letter “H.”

headline: Senate Backs Ban on Mail-Order Cigarettes in Setback for Tribe
text: WASHINGTON — By a unanimous vote, the Senate on Thursday passed a bill to eliminate mail-order cigarettes, a victory for public health advocates and a defeat for the New York Indian tribe that dominates the business.

headline: Effort to Widen U.S. Internet Access Sets Up Battle
text: The Federal Communications Commission is proposing an ambitious 10-year plan that will reimagine the nation’s media and technology priorities by establishing high-speed Internet as the country’s dominant communication network.

headline: Federal Panel Finds Bias in Ouster of Principal
text: A federal commission has determined that New York City’s Department of Education discriminated against the founding principal of an Arabic-language public school by forcing her to resign in 2007 following a storm of controversy driven by opponents of the school.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,006 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American on Friday:

headline: New Numbers for Swine Flu
text: About 12,000 Americans died from swine flu between its emergence last April until mid-February, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention estimated on Friday. While swine flu is still being transmitted at low levels and some people still die of it, the third wave that experts had said was possible has not emerged, and is looking unlikely. Seasonal flu activity has been unusually low this winter, suggesting that the H1N1 swine flu strain “crowded out” the usual seasonal H1N1 and H3N2 strains. Little of the third seasonal strain, influenza B, which usually arrives late in flu season, has been seen in the United States. Swine flu has infected 42 million to 86 million people, the C.D.C. estimated.

headline: Climate Change Adds to Bird Stress
text: Changes in the global climate are imposing additional stress on hundreds of species of migratory birds in the United States that are already threatened by other environmental factors, according to a new Interior Department report. The department’s annual State of the Birds report shows that nearly a third of the nation’s 800 bird species are endangered, threatened or suffering from population decline. For the first time, the report adds climate change to other factors threatening bird populations, including destruction of habitat, hunting, pesticides, invasive species and loss of wetlands. The report said oceanic and shore birds were among the most vulnerable to climate change because of rapidly changing marine ecosystems and rising sea levels.

headline: Earliest Return Seen for Woods Is Masters
text: DORAL, Fla. — Tiger Woods, who has been absent from tournament golf since mid-November, will not return to competition before the Masters tournament at the Augusta National Golf Club in mid-April, according to two people with knowledge of his comeback plans.

headline: Facebook Helps Social Start-Ups Gain Users
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — The only thing more challenging than deciphering the names of all the social-minded Web sites battling for attention at the South by Southwest technology conference here — Brizzly, Vicarious.ly, Stalqer, Quora and so forth — would be the chore of signing up for each one individually.

headline: Insurer and Hospital System Reach Accord
text: A contract dispute between one of the country’s largest insurers and a major New York City hospital system has been settled, officials said Friday, ending the prospect that tens of thousands of New Yorkers would be cut off from their doctors and the hospitals they use.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Friday about an examiner’s report detailing accounting maneuvers used by Lehman Brothers to conceal its perilous finances described incorrectly in some editions the assets that were temporarily shuffled off its books. They were mostly high-quality securities that could be easily accepted by other banks, according to the examiner’s report; they were not “troubled” and “mostly illiquid real estate holdings.” The article also misstated in some editions the status of some Lehman executives in the aftermath of the bank’s collapse. They are defendants in civil suits, not plaintiffs.

headline: Corrections
text: Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about Bank of America’s decision to stop charging overdraft fees on debit purchases misstated Citibank’s overdraft policies, and a correction in this space on Friday contained a misspelling that affected its clarity. Citibank has never charged overdraft fees on one-time debit  not debt  purchases or A.T.M. transactions; it did not recently modify its policy to appease critics.

headline: Marilyn Gittell, Advocate for Local School Decisions, Dies at 78
text: Marilyn Gittell, a political scientist and education reformer who in the 1960s was an outspoken advocate of decentralizing New York City’s public school system, died on Feb. 26 at her home in Manhattan. She was 78.

headline: Corrections
Republicans Name 6 to Debt-Reduction Panel
text: WASHINGTON — Republican leaders in Congress on Friday named six lawmakers to the bipartisan debt-reduction commission that President Obama created. The presence of antitax hard-liners among them suggests the hurdles to forging agreement by December on proposals to arrest the unsustainable growth of projected deficits.

headline: Is the U.S. Following in Rome’s Footsteps?
text: David Brooks: Dick, I’m just back from a grueling  five  days during which I took 11 flights — everywhere from Florida to Tucson to Atlanta to Denver to Raleigh ( O.K., I watched Duke crush North Carolina at Raleigh-Durham so that wasn’t so bad).

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Tuesday about digital technology to help people with Alzheimer’s disease and other memory disorders rendered the name of a device incorrectly and referred incorrectly to its marketing. The device, a wearable digital camera that can take hundreds of pictures without the user’s having to click the shutter, is the SenseCam, not Sensecam. Vicon, the British company that licenses the technology from Microsoft, is selling its version of the SenseCam only to researchers; it has not said it plans to market the device to young people interested in logging their lives and posting the results to Web sites.

headline: Don’t Tickle Me, Bro!
text: Welcome to Ticklegate.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Tuesday about aviation industry advertising in the early years of the space age misstated the year of the Apollo 13 mission, in which the crew of a crippled spacecraft was brought safely back to earth. It was 1970, not 1969.

headline: 10 Years Later, Working Toward a Better Count
text: Kulwinder Singh, a 52-year-old Punjabi Sikh who works as a tow-truck operator, approached a young community organizer who was taping a promotional poster for the 2010 census to a wall inside his temple in Richmond Hill, Queens. Mr. Singh looked perplexed.

headline: Corrections
text: A dance entry in the listings on Friday about the 92nd Street Y Harkness Dance Festival misstated who will be performing this weekend. Daniel Charon, Gwen Welliver and Nancy Bannon, in a program curated by Doug Varone, are presenting works with their own troupes; the company Doug Varone and Dancers is not performing.

headline: Corrections
text: Because of a production error, the Food column in The Times Magazine omitted a measurement in a recipe, and a correction in Sunday’s magazine misstates the issue in which the error occurred. The recipe omitted the amount of raw corn kernels needed in Lantern Cracker Jack; it is one-third of a cup. The recipe appeared in the Feb. 28 issue of the magazine, not the March 7 issue.

headline: Corrections
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Violations Are Cited in Generics
text: As American consumers increasingly turn to generic drugs as a way to reduce their medical costs, the continued manufacturing problems of one generic maker stand out.

headline: I.R.S. Says Its Audits of Wealthy Are Rising
text: The Internal Revenue Service is intensifying its scrutiny of wealthy Americans.

headline: 37 Down: NASA’s Opportunity
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — I’ve long held the suspicion that the NW corners in Times themeless puzzles are made a bit tougher to thwart a quick toehold. Not always, mind you, but more often than not.

headline: Paul Ryan’s Redistributionism
text: Perhaps inspired by my criticisms of Paul Ryan’s proposed tax reforms, Jonathan Chait has a long post about how Ryan’s roadmap “clarifies the essence of the Republican Party’s approach to domestic policy issues,” which involves “opposition to the downward redistribution of income.” Noting that Ryan has said kind words about Ayn Rand, he writes that “the core of the Randian worldview, as absorbed by the modern GOP, is a belief that the natural market distribution of income is inherently moral, and the central struggle of politics is to free the successful from having the fruits of their superiority redistributed by looters and moochers.” And he argues: “Every major element of Ryan’s plan reflects this commitment …  Ryan would retain some bare-bones subsidies for the poorest, but the overwhelming thrust in every way is to liberate the lucky and successful to enjoy their good fortune without burdening them with any responsibility for the welfare of their fellow citizens.”

headline: Fate’s Message to the Mets Sounds Familiar
text: Port St. Lucie, Fla.

headline: ‘A Culture of Corruption’
text: So far, there have been six guilty pleas in Attorney General Andrew Cuomo’s investigation of the real and potential abuses surrounding New York’s $129 billion public pension investments. The most important and revealing of these came Wednesday, when David Loglisci, the former chief investment officer of the pension fund, admitted flatly that he had violated state securities law.

headline: Findings on Lehman Take Even Experts by Surprise
text: For the year that it took the court-appointed examiner to complete his report on the demise of Lehman Brothers, officials from Wall Street to Washington were anticipating it as the definitive account of the largest bankruptcy in American history.

headline: Bloggingheads: Does Israel Need Peace?
text: Robert Wright, left, of Bloggingheads.tv and David Frum of FrumForum debate Israeli-Palestinian peace talks.

headline: Editorial: Republicans Wanted
text: On Thursday, President Obama held meetings on immigration reform with immigrant advocates and labor and religious leaders, with Senators Charles Schumer and Lindsey Graham, and with the Congressional Hispanic Caucus. He came out reiterating his “unwavering” commitment to comprehensive immigration reform.

headline: Big Brother in Blue
text: The speaker of the New York City Council and the head of the Council’s Public Safety Committee are calling on Police Commissioner Ray Kelly to get rid of his huge, noxious database of completely innocent New Yorkers who are stopped, questioned and often frisked by the police.

text: After spending months searching for a bipartisan consensus on financial regulatory reform, Senator Christopher Dodd, chairman of the banking committee, is expected to unveil his own bill on Monday, without one Republican supporter.

headline: Something Worse Than Inaction
text: The Obama administration has always had a backup plan in case Congress failed to pass a broad climate change bill. The Environmental Protection Agency would use its Clean Air Act authority to regulate greenhouse gases. Regulation, or the threat of it, would goad Congress to act or provide a backstop if it did not.

text: To the Editor:

text: They were considered the dregs of Lehman Brothers — “bottom of the barrel,” as one banker put it.

headline: Netflix Cancels Contest After Concerns Are Raised About Privacy
text: Netflix’s $1 million contest for the best method to improve its movie recommendations was such a research and business hit that, when the winners were declared last September, the company immediately announced plans for another one.

headline: Suspect Arrested in Attack in Midtown Bar’s Restroom
text: The police arrested a suspect on Friday in the attack on a 29-year-old woman who had been beaten and left bleeding and unconscious in a restroom stall at a Midtown bar, the authorities said.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: March 12, 2010

headline: Increase Expected in Heavy Equipment Sales in China
text: Komatsu, the Japanese heavy equipment maker, said Friday it expected sales in China to rise by half as the country’s 10 percent growth rate drives demand for resources like coal and iron ore. Sales in the year starting April 1 are expected to rise by 40 to 50 percent from the current year, Kazuhiko Iwata, the president of the company’s mining division, said. Mining machinery sales account for about 30 percent of Komatsu’s construction equipment division revenue, which is forecast to be 1.3 trillion yen ($14 billion) this year.

headline: Pacquiao’s Challenger Clottey Follows in Footsteps of Warriors
text: ARLINGTON, Tex. — Even here, with Saturday’s welterweight title fight in Cowboys Stadium, with nearly 45,000 seats sold, with Manny Pacquiao defending his latest world championship, the fight that fell apart looms over the proceedings.

headline: Justice Dept. Tells Farmers It Will Press Agriculture Industry on Antitrust
text: ANKENY, Iowa — The attorney general, Eric H. Holder Jr., traveled to the heart of Midwestern farm country on Friday to declare that the Obama administration was serious about rooting out anticompetitive practices in agriculture.

headline: Its Own Advisers Oppose Consumer Role for the Fed
text: WASHINGTON — As the Senate contemplates creation of a consumer financial protection agency within the Federal Reserve, opposition to the idea has emerged from an unexpected quarter: the Fed’s Consumer Advisory Council.

headline: Tennessee Defeats Mississippi to Reach SEC Semifinals
text: NASHVILLE — Brian Williams, the Tennessee center from the Bronx, suggested there were always subplots in the Vols’ basketball program, disagreements over who owned the brand. Whose team was it, anyway?

headline: Picking Up Momentum, Hoyas Roll Into Title Game
text: Marquette’s margin of error is about as small as its 5-foot-8 point guard, Maurice Acker. Undersize and handicapped by a roster short on overall talent, Coach Buzz Williams’s team has grown into a contender among the Big East’s bullies based on efficiency and feistiness.

headline: Teach for the World Vs. Peace Corps
text: My Thursday column proposing Teach for the World attracted a range of comments and criticisms. One blog noted that the beneficiaries would essentially be American kids and argued that if the aim is to build language and cultural skills, why not do more to expand the Peace Corps? Others noted that if we want to improve education in poor countries, the obvious way to do that is to build local capacity by training teachers — or, I would argue, by deworming kids as has worked so well in Kenya or expanding the conditional cash grants that have been tremendously successful to promote education in Mexico.

headline: Player’s Suspension Ends, but Baylor Falters
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — At the first mention of her name Friday night, Baylor’s Brittney Griner exhaled deeply, as if she had been holding her breath for the past nine days.

headline: Rachel Alexandra’s Security Guard Is Also Pursuing  Ph.D.
text: NEW ORLEANS — It started with an ad on Craigslist, and has led to moonlight yoga sessions in dusty barns on racetracks from here to New York. There is a free-spirited woman involved, a Ph.D. dissertation as well as a horse. Actually two horses, really famous ones.

headline: Granderson Sets a Course to Another Side of Hitting
text: TAMPA, Fla. — Kevin Long started analyzing videotape of Curtis Granderson’s at-bats last November. At the time, Granderson was still playing for Detroit.

headline: Midseason Move Re-energized Mavericks
text: DALLAS — In the heat of the moment, in the heat of his shower stall, Mark Cuban mentally dangled his index finger over an imaginary big red button.

headline: Fulfilling a Vision: Biking 250 Miles of the Bay Trail in Five Days
text: Last September, Stephanie and Tim Reed biked out their Oakland front door and pedaled to the Bay Trail, a 21-year effort to create a continuous, 500-mile hiking and biking trail along the shoreline of the San Francisco Bay, linking the area’s nine counties. With 298 miles completed, the trail is a work in progress with pieces added in chunks, each addition attended by some civic hoopla. Last November, a deal between Chevron and the East Bay Regional Parks District will add two more miles along Point Molate in Richmond, The San Francisco Chronicle reported.

headline: Els Tinkers With Game and Takes Lead at Doral
text: DORAL, Fla. — Ernie Els has made some minor adjustments to his stance in the past week that have yielded major results at the W.G.C.-CA Championship, vaulting him into the lead at the halfway point of the $8.5 million limited-field event at the Doral Resort and Spa.

headline: Mountaineers and Hoyas Are a Step From the Top
text: A day after West Virginia’s football coach suggested the university was considering leaving the Big East, another one of its teams took a step closer to winning the conference’s basketball championship.

headline: Tomlinson Spends Day With Jets
text: Running back LaDainian Tomlinson followed a full day of meetings with Jets officials with dinner Friday night with Coach Rex Ryan and General Manager Mike Tannenbaum. Tomlinson planned to spend the night — there were no late flights available to the West Coast after dinner — but his itinerary for Saturday was unclear.

headline: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Brodeur Solves Pens Yet Again
text: Six games on Friday, highlighted by a clash between the two top clubs in the Atlantic Division. Home teams listed first:

headline: How Jay Leno’s Car Collection Grows

headline: Why Tomlinson and Not Thomas Jones?
text: As Judy Battista reported:  “LaDainian Tomlinson followed a full day of meetings with Jets officials with dinner Friday night with Coach Rex Ryan and General Manager Mike Tannenbaum. Tomlinson planned to spend the night — there were no late flights available to the West Coast after dinner.”

headline: Kissinger Hospitalized in South Korea
text: SEOUL, South Korea — Henry Kissinger, the former United States secretary of state, was hospitalized here because of stomach pains on Saturday. But his condition has quickly improved, said a spokesman for Yonsei University’s Severance Hospital in Seoul.

headline: Elgin Park, a Nice Place to Visit
text: I discovered the small (very small) town of “Elgin Park” the same way millions of others around the world have: someone forwarded me a link to a Flickr slide show. The subject line was “Cars of the past … real or models?”

headline: The Saturday Word: Education Overhaul
text: President Obama will on Monday give Congress an outline for overhauling No Child Left Behind, the controversial education policy former President George W. Bush put in place in 2002.

headline: ‘A Quick Reminder’
text: Monologue |  Friday night on “Late Night With Jimmy Fallon” on NBC: Hey, just a quick reminder. Daylight savings time begins this weekend. Everybody’s setting their clocks ahead an hour, okay? Or if you are Congressman Eric Massa, you are wishing you could set them back about a week.

headline: ‘Two Million Potholes’
text: Monologue |  Friday night on “The Late Show With David Letterman” on CBS: Good news. New York City has filled two million potholes. Now, the bad news is those are the only things that were slowing down the Toyotas.

headline: ‘Priuses for Entertainment’
text: Monologue |  Friday night on “The Jay Leno Show” on NBC: A Federal appeals court has ruled that the phrase “In God We Trust” — you know on our dollar bills — is constitutional. There was a lawsuit to have “In God We Trust” removed from our money. To give you an idea how bad the shape the dollar is in, you know who wanted “In God We Trust” taken off? God. He said, “I don’t want to be associated with this economy!”

headline: Vettel on Pole as Team Strength Becomes Clearer
text: The first qualifying session of the Formula One season clarified a few things that we had only been able to guess about after winter testing last month. There are clearly four teams in the fight for the championship, as predicted, as all the drivers from Red Bull, Ferrari, McLaren and Mercedes made it into the top 10 during the season’s first qualifying session, at the Bahrain Grand Prix today.

headline: Seeing Handpicked as a Bad Thing
text: WASHINGTON — Representative Brad Ellsworth will avoid a primary fight to become the Democratic candidate for the Senate in Indiana, which should be good news for him. But Republicans are preparing to cast him as the tainted product of shadowy dealings in smoke-filled rooms.

headline: Andretti Praises Formula One Expansion
text: Mario Andretti visited the Bahrain Grand Prix paddock today as part of the 60th anniversary celebrations of the Formula One world championship.

headline: Women’s Rights as a Security Issue
text: Hillary Clinton has been pushing hard to reframe women’s rights from “soft issue” to “security issue.” Obviously that’s partly because soft issues are shunted aside, while the security issues are discussed in the Situation Room and get billions of dollars thrown at them. In an interview with Andrea Mitchell released today, Clinton put it this way:

headline: Kristine Gomez, Thomas Crosby
text: Kristine Louise Gomez, a daughter of Nancy O’Connell Gomez and Ralph A. Gomez, both of Miami, was married Saturday evening to Thomas Lincoln Crosby, the son of Linda E. Watt of New York and Benjamin L. Crosby III of Punta Gorda, Fla. The Rev. Thomas L. Brackett, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the Cocoplum Women’s Club in Coral Gables, Fla.

headline: Debbie Almontaser: The Path to Resignation
text: A timeline of key dates, from Ms. Almontaser's appointment as principal of the Khalil Gibran International Academy to her resignation and subsequent fight to be reinstated.

headline: Ann Vincola and Alan Votta
text: Ann Patavino Vincola and Alan S. Votta were married Saturday at the Church of God of Prophecy in Charleston, S.C. The Rev. Bernie Levesque, the church’s pastor, performed the ceremony.

text: Jill Rosenberg and Charles Howard Jainchill were married Saturday evening by Rabbi Mark Mallach at Temple Beth Ahm Yisrael in Springfield, N.J.

Dooner of Toms River, N.J. Daniel J. Furmansky, a Universal Life minister, is to officiate at the Mandarin Oriental Hotel in Washington.

Rabbi Matthew Gewirtz officiated at the Harold Pratt House, an event space in Manhattan.

Gordon and Mark N. Gordon of Newton, Mass. Rabbi Marjorie Berman officiated at the Hyatt Regency at Penn’s Landing in Philadelphia.
