text: Marni Weiss, the daughter of Stephanie and Richard Weiss of Westhampton, N.Y., is to be married Sunday to Michael Friedlander, a son of Suzanne and Leslie Friedlander of North Woodmere, N.Y. Rabbi Mark Wildes is to perform the ceremony at Temple Israel in Lawrence, N.Y.

headline: Lindsay Hoag and Edward Telleria
text: Lindsay Kelly Hoag and Edward Robert Castro Telleria were married Saturday at the Four Seasons Hotel in Boston. The Rev. Victor H. Kazanjian Jr., an Episcopal priest and the dean of religious and spiritual life at Wellesley, officiated.

headline: Emily Stolzenberg, Matthew Shapiro
text: Emily Judith Stolzenberg, a daughter of Merle P. Stolzenberg and Alan M. Stolzenberg of Morgantown, W.Va., is to be married Sunday to Matthew Abraham Shapiro, a son of Mary E. Shapiro and Howard Shapiro of Menands, N.Y. Rabbi Debora S. Gordon is to perform the ceremony at Congregation Berith Sholom in Troy, N.Y.

headline: Arrests in Europe Expose ETA’s Ties to Venezuela
text: CARACAS, Venezuela — The shadowy underworld of Basque exiles in this city is coming under sharp scrutiny after recent arrests in Europe and an indictment this month from one of Spain’s top judges asserting that Venezuelan intelligence officials were involved in training Basque separatists and Colombian guerrillas in Venezuela.

headline: Samantha Wolfert, Justin Grefé
text: Samantha Ann Wolfert, the daughter of Laurie Wolfert and David Wolfert of New York, was married Saturday evening to Justin Sine Grefé, the son of Karen Vogel Grefé and Richard Grefé of Darien, Conn. Rabbi Jonathan Stein officiated at the St. Regis Hotel in New York, with Cantor Bruce Ruben taking part.

headline: Fearing Drug Cartels, Reporters in Mexico Retreat
text: REYNOSA, Mexico — The big philosophical question in this gritty border town does not concern trees falling in the forest but bodies falling on the concrete: Does a shootout actually happen if the newspapers print nothing about it, the radio and television stations broadcast nothing, and the authorities never confirm that it occurred?

headline: Ilana Sausen, Eytan Seidman
text: Ilana Rose Sausen and Eytan Daniel Yosef Seidman are to be married Sunday at Glen Island Harbour Club in New Rochelle, N.Y. Rabbi Joseph I. Eisenbach will officiate, with Rabbi Abraham I. Zigelman, a great-uncle of the bride, taking part.

headline: Sara Lavipour, Scott Hansen
text: Sara Satin Lavipour and Scott Aron Hansen were married Saturday evening by Rabbi Robert N. Levine at Cipriani 42nd Street in New York.

headline: Jennifer Wallner, Adam Saltzman
text: Jennifer Victoria Sophia Wallner and Adam Marc Saltzman are to be married Sunday at the Westward Look Resort and Spa in Tucson. Rabbi Billy Lewkowicz is to officiate.

headline: Chuck Berry Acrostic
text: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE — Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon always have an interesting quote awaiting us in their acrostics. It’s also often revealing or amusing, and sometimes both. Today’s is guilty on all three fronts, and it actually made me chuckle out loud, which is a more refined version of laughing out loud, as befits a New York Times puzzle.

headline: Blagojevich Lawyers Want Trial Delay
text: CHICAGO — Lawyers for the ousted governor of Illinois, Rod R. Blagojevich, say they need more time to wade through millions of pages of documents and hundreds of hours of secretly recorded telephone calls in preparation for his federal corruption trial.

headline: Vatican Sees Campaign Against the Pope
text: ROME — As new details emerged on allegations of child sexual abuse by a priest in the Munich archdiocese then led by Pope Benedict XVI, the Vatican spoke out on Saturday against what it called an aggressive campaign against the pope in his native Germany.

headline: Some Palestinian Jordanians Lose Citizenship
text: AMMAN, Jordan — Muhannad Haddad grew up here, went to school here, got a job in a bank here and traveled to foreign countries with a passport from here. Then one day the authorities said he was no longer Jordanian, and with that one stroke they took away his citizenship and compromised his ability to travel, study, work, seek health care, buy property or even drive.

headline: A Candidate Finds Much Changed, and Little
text: SAN FRANCISCO — In the 32 years since Lowell Darling, an artist, last ran for public office in California, Ronald Reagan was elected president, a bodybuilder was elected governor and the entire state has toddled perilously close to fiscal disaster.

headline: Landrieu Offers Support for Health Care Legislation
text: Senator Mary Landrieu, Democrat of Louisiana and at one point a skeptic of sweeping health care legislation, has written an opinion article in The Shreveport Times in which she makes a strong case in favor of moving forward with a bill.

headline: Prime Number
text: 48: The percent of births in the United States to minority mothers in the 12 months that ended July 2008, according to an analysis of Census Bureau data by Professors Kenneth M. Johnson of the University of New Hampshire and Daniel Lichter at Cornell University. The 50 percent benchmark could be reached as soon as this year, demographers say. Over all, the Census Bureau estimates that minorities will constitute a majority of the nation’s population in about three decades and a majority of Americans under 18 in about a decade.

headline: Prime Number
text: 0.3: The percentage increase in retail sales in February, surprising Wall Street analysts, who had predicted a decline of 0.2 percent. The number was even better — 0.9 percent — when volatile car and gasoline sales were excluded. Sales have increased for four of the last five months and are on track for a 5.8 percent annual growth rate. The surprise gain highlighted a sense that spending habits were changing. The amount of money Americans kept in savings fell in January, and consumer borrowing increased for the first time in a year.

headline: A German Town Battered by Potholes Holds Out Its Hat
text: Hit any potholes lately? Brace yourself for more. With a bad winter behind us and the economy only beginning to shake off its long recession chill, many state and local governments are struggling to find money to fix record numbers of potholes.

headline: Why Would the N.C.A.A. Expand Its Tournament? It’s About the Money
text: Former President Bill Clinton sat courtside at Madison Square Garden on Thursday night, chatting with the Big East commissioner, John Marinatto. Inevitably, the conversation turned to the potential expansion of the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament.

headline: Thrift and Shrewd Moves Again Make  Rockies Contender in N.L. West
text: TUCSON — The Colorado Rockies stormed into the 2007 World Series, winning 21 of 22 games, but they were not really ready to be there. As quickly as they reached the summit, they tumbled.

headline: Quotations of the Week
text: “My question to them is: When is the right time? If not now, when? If not us, who?” —President Obama, on those seeking to delay a health care overhaul.

headline: Issue of Presidency Endangers Iraq’s Tenuous Balance
text: BAGHDAD — Few doubted that the choice of the country’s next prime minister would prove to be one of the most intractable disputes in forging a new government to lead Iraq as the American military withdraws.

headline: New Fraud Cases Point to Lapses in Iraq Projects
text: Investigators looking into corruption involving reconstruction in Iraq say they have opened more than 50 new cases in six months by scrutinizing large cash transactions — involving banks, land deals, loan payments, casinos and even plastic surgery — made by some of the Americans involved in the nearly $150 billion program.

headline: Correction: The Moral Ambiguity of Looting
text: An article last Sunday about the morality of dealing with looting in times of disaster incorrectly stated that a blackout in 1965, which did not bring disorder to New York, resulted instead in a baby boom nine months later. There was no baby boom. A widespread belief that there had been one originated with a New York Times article, nine months after the blackout, reporting that some New York hospitals were experiencing higher than normal numbers of births; later scientific studies, however, found no evidence of a statistically significant spike in the birth rate.

headline: After the Earthquake, a Military Chile Can Love Again
text: At Gen. Augusto Pinochet’s funeral, one of his grandsons, an Army captain also named Augusto Pinochet, gave a eulogy so defiant and aggressive that he was cashiered the next day. Earlier, as the general lay in state in his dress uniform and Chileans filed by his casket to pay their last respects, the grandson of another general, assassinated by Pinochet’s secret police, spat on the former dictator’s cadaver full in the face.

headline: Ellen Murphy and Billy Cheung
text: Ellen Irene Murphy, the daughter of Janis Murphy and William T. Murphy of Garden City, N.Y., was married in Manhattan Saturday evening to Billy Lap Kwan Cheung, the son of Man San Cheung of Forest Hills, Queens, and the late Hon Leung Cheung. The Rev. Richard E. Hasselbach, a priest affiliated with CITI Ministries, officiated at the Yale Club of New York City.

headline: Katherine Cocca, Nathaniel Bates
text: Katherine Camille Cocca, the daughter of Vicki I. Cocca and Stephen L. Cocca of Gowanda, N.Y., was married Saturday to Nathaniel Bates, a son of Deborah Wood Bates and Timothy D. Bates of Noank, Conn. The Rev. Daniel Warren, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the Brierwood Country Club in Hamburg, N.Y.

headline: In Hard Times, Lured Into Trade School and Debt
text: One fast-growing American industry has become a conspicuous beneficiary of the recession: for-profit colleges and trade schools.

headline: English Fans Find an Unlikely Love for a Yank
text: LIVERPOOL, England — Beside the gallant city park in perhaps the world’s most zealous sports neighborhood, an unanticipated love has sprouted this winter and ripened into wistfulness this weekend.

headline: Tweeting From Courtside at St. John’s
text: Last August, St. John’s became the first university to give a news media credential to someone who would cover a team entirely on the social networking forum Twitter. Peter Robert Casey, a basketball fan with more than 56,000 followers at twitter.com/peter_r_casey, has followed Coach Norm Roberts and the men’s basketball team. With no background in journalism, he was nervous about taking on the assignment, but surprised at how he was received.

headline: Africa’s Gift to Silicon Valley: How to Track a Crisis
text: Could wiki technology find Osama bin Laden?

headline: A Star in Japan, Only a Prospect With the Mets
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — The Japanese television network J Sports is planning a broadcast that features Hideki Matsui, an iconic Japanese baseball star, and Hisanori Takahashi, a left-handed pitcher for the Mets.

headline: Illegal Prescription Discovered for Actor Found Dead
text: LOS ANGELES — Investigators say that an illegal drug prescription for Corey Haim, the actor who died unexpectedly last week, was found during an investigation of a fraudulent drug ring responsible for thousands of illegal pharmaceutical sales.

headline: Debate Grows on Nuclear Containment of Iran
text: For a few months in the mid-1960s President Johnson and his aides secretly weighed bombing China’s nuclear sites — perhaps seeking Soviet help — rather than let Mao get the bomb. Then the costs of starting another war in Asia sank in and they decided to try containment — living with a threatening regime while deterring its most dangerous moves.

headline: Parliamentarian in Role as Health Bill Referee
text: WASHINGTON — In the fall of 1968, a serious dark-haired young man arrived in the capital to do what serious young men here do: study law. Alan S. Frumin was calm, analytical and possessed of a dry wit. To his classmates, one trait stood out. He was a whiz at mastering the mind-numbing rules of civil procedure.

headline: Jordan’s No. 23 Just Isn’t the Retiring Type
text: By virtually all accounts, LeBron James is an admirable adult who will bring honor to whatever team signs him for next season.

headline: Prisoner Is Captured in Manhattan
text: A robbery suspect on Staten Island who took on the identity of a fellow prisoner facing less serious criminal charges to trick the authorities into freeing him has been captured by detectives, the police said.

headline: Women’s Rights in Mideast
text: To the Editor:

headline: When Scholarship and Tribal Heritage Face Off Against Commerce
text: OXFORD, Ala. — Overlooking the Interstate and an outdoor shopping mall here stands a sad little hill, bald but for four bare trees and a scattering of stones.

headline: As Health Vote Awaits, Future of a Presidency Waits, Too
text: WASHINGTON — Senator Mitch McConnell, the Republican leader, had a little political advice last week for President Obama and the Democrats: Don’t pass the president’s health care legislation because you would risk losing in the midterm elections.

headline: Improving a Lineup at a Lower Price
text: When a team looks to become  more efficient, removing the team’s two highest-paid players would hardly seem like a good start. But for the Orlando Magic, there is evidence to support doing just that.

headline: Tea-ing Up the Constitution
text: WASHINGTON — Brash and young though it is, the Tea Party movement has already added something distinctive to contemporary political discourse. It has made the Constitution central to the national conversation.

headline: Tomlinson Heads Home to Weigh His Options
text: Running back LaDainian Tomlinson – who spent all day Friday being wooed by the Jets – flew back to San Diego on Saturday morning to consider his options. Tomlinson’s departure is undoubtedly a disappointment for the Jets, who had pulled out all the stops, complete with a tour of the new stadium at the Meadowlands, in hopes of getting Tomlinson to sign on the dotted line before he left town.

headline: The Author of ‘Red Badge’ Loved the Game More Than His Studies
text: English literature scholars and historians have long known that football played a major role in Stephen Crane’s development of his Civil War novel, “The Red Badge of Courage.” Crane told early reviewers he had been coaching and playing quarterback on a team in northern New Jersey while finishing his manuscript.

headline: Mark Twain, Baseball Fan, Had an Eye for a Short-Stop
text: River rafting and billiards, sure. But who knew that the creator of Tom Sawyer and Huck Finn was a devotee of baseball?

headline: Justice Dept. Lawyers Under Fire
text: To the Editor:

headline: Driving Miss Saudi
text: In other capitals of the world, it would not have been an extraordinary scene.

headline: Taking a Nip Out of the Tuck
text: Are Americans experiencing plastic surgery fatigue?

headline: Obama Calls for Major Change in Education Law
text: The Obama administration on Saturday called for a broad overhaul of President George W. Bush’s No Child Left Behind law, proposing to reshape divisive provisions that encouraged instructors to teach to tests, narrowed the curriculum, and labeled one in three American schools as failing.

headline: Explosions Rock Afghan City, Killing Dozens
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — At least four strong explosions rocked Kandahar on Saturday evening, causing buildings to collapse and killing dozens of people, according to Afghan and American officials.

headline: Its Sports Empire Crumbling, Russia Scrambles
text: MOSCOW — A month ago, Russia’s biggest challenge in preparing to serve as host for the 2014 Winter Olympics seemed to be just mustering the resources to build the facilities in Sochi, a downtrodden Soviet-era resort town. Now, a new anxiety is gripping the country: if its athletes perform as badly as they did in Vancouver last month, Russia could be humiliated in its own backyard.

headline: The New Rove-Cheney Assault on Reality
text: THE opening salvo, fired on Fox News during Thanksgiving week, aroused little notice: Dana Perino, the former White House press secretary, declared that “we did not have a terrorist attack on our country during President Bush’s term.” Rudy Giuliani upped the ante on ABC’s “Good Morning America” in January. “We had no domestic attacks under Bush,” he said. “We’ve had one under Obama.” (He apparently meant the Fort Hood shootings.)

headline: Troy Tulowitzki, the Derek Jeter of the Rockies
text: When people asked Joe Torre about Derek Jeter, Torre would invariably mention that veterans looked to Jeter for leadership when Jeter was only a rookie. There was just an aura about Jeter, a sense that he naturally accepted the responsibility of being his teammates’ focal point. Setting an example was never forced, and it was not a burden.

headline: This Reggie Miller Is the Straw That Stirred the Garden
text: Is the ESPN documentary “Winning Time: Reggie Miller vs. the New York Knicks” a hoax? Did the playoff series that it depicts between the Knicks and the Indiana Pacers actually occur or are its claims of a snarling, slicker-heartland rivalry as dubious as U.F.O.’s in Area 51?

headline: Apple’s Spat With Google Is Getting Personal
text: IT looked like the beginning of a beautiful friendship.

headline: Perez Follows Weak Outing With a Promising One
text: The Mets never know what to expect from Oliver Perez. One day he dominates the Yankees or the Phillies and the next outing, he gives up eight runs to the Pirates.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: Private Equity’s Trojan Horse of Debt
text: WHENEVER savvy private equity firms sell debt in the companies they own, buyer beware.

headline: British TV Ads Flaunt Their Arty Side
text: In a recent British television commercial for the Barclaycard credit card, an office worker strips down to his briefs, saunters past his co-workers and enters a storage closet, where he jumps down a chute and sets off on a wild water-slide ride across an urban landscape, sailing down the sides of buildings, whizzing past shoppers and sloshing through a public library to the sound of the 1976 Bellamy Brothers hit “Let Your Love Flow.” When his joyously soggy ride comes to an end, he says, “Can you get me a towel?”

headline: The Office Skirmish: How to Avoid Round 2
text: Q. You recently had a big argument with a co-worker. Though you managed to end it, you still feel uncomfortable around this person. Should you try to discuss it or pretend it never happened?

headline: Perestroika Lost
text: Moscow

headline: Keeping It All in Writing
text: MY father owned several furniture stores, including one in Hollidaysburg, Pa., our hometown. He worked seven days a week, but my two brothers and sister and I always knew that we were the most important thing to him.

headline: Cabbies Cheat? Riders Express No Surprise
text: For Robert Carrizzo, the daily commute from his Midtown office to the Staten Island Ferry is typically filled with precise rituals. But there is always one irritating question mark: the cost of the taxi ride.

headline: Three Good Hires? He’ll Pay More for One Who’s Great
text: This interview with Kip Tindell, chief executive of the Container Store, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: How Men’s Overconfidence Hurts Them as Investors
text: MEN and women invest differently, a growing body of research has found. And in at least one important respect, women may be better at it.

headline: U.S. Woman Held in Plot Is Released, Family Says
text: LEADVILLE, Colo. — An American woman whose family feared that she may have become a radicalized Muslim was detained in Ireland last week in connection with a plot to assassinate a Swedish cartoonist.

headline: Thank You Haggler!
text: The Haggler gets a thank-you video from a (very) young fan.

headline: Who’s Buried in the History Books?
text: Princeton, N.J.

headline: Capturing the Moments of Customer Frustration
text: IN politics, they say the problem is never the crime; it’s the cover-up. Well, the Haggler has a corollary for consumerland: it’s never the manufacturing mistake, it’s the utterly appalling customer service that follows the manufacturing mistake.

headline: Obama and Medvedev Talk About Arms Treaty
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama and President Dmitri A. Medvedev of Russia moved closer to agreement Saturday on a long-stalled arms control treaty that would slash the active nuclear arsenals of both countries by more than one-quarter, officials from both countries said.

headline: Great Time to Buy (Famous Last Words)
text: “IT’S a great time to buy a home.”

headline: Andrée Peel, Rescuer of Allied Airmen, Dies at 105
text: Andrée Peel, a highly decorated French resistance figure who helped save dozens of American and British airmen shot down over France during World War II, died on March 5 in the English village of Long Ashton, outside Bristol. She was 105.

headline: Book Binding
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — I really liked this puzzle’s theme, which has an elegant, extra angle to it.

headline: An Express Lane From Camera to Computer
text: HIGH-SPEED data communication isn’t so speedy by the time it reaches your video player or smartphone.

headline: Talking About Bargaining and H.G.H.
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Mets players attended a union meeting Saturday morning led by Michael Weiner, the executive director of the players association, who said he spent most of the time preparing the players for the next collective bargaining session, which is almost two years away.

headline: A Dream for Music, but Labels’ Nightmare
text: THE Apple iPad, which goes on sale April 3, will access video, applications and Web sites wirelessly — no cords or cables needed. But to move your trusty old music collection onto this wonder gadget and take it with you to work, or on vacation, you’ll have to pull out a U.S.B. sync cable, plug the device into your PC and transfer those music files over.

headline: Managed Care: Get Used to It
text: WE may soon know whether Congress will approve some version of President Obama’s health care plan. No matter what the outcome, there will be an unacknowledged monster lurking in the room: managed care.

headline: Letters: Homeownership’s Future
text: Homeownership’s Future

headline: Correction
text: A picture caption with an article last Sunday about the growth of Internet start-ups in New York City misattributed a quotation. It was Chris Dixon, a co-founder of the recommendation service Hunch, not Caterina Fake, another co-founder, who said, "We are definitely doing our part to get the ecosystem going.” And the article misspelled the surname of the founder of Hot Potato, a social networking start-up focused on live events. He is Justin Shaffer, not Schaffer.

headline: Expanding the Pool: What Coaches Think
text: Many models for an expanded N.C.A.A. tournament have been suggested, and a few coaches have their own ideas about what the tournament should look like.

headline: Partying to Change the World
text: Maybe the most common question I get from readers is: What can I do?

headline: Op-Classic, 1999: Israel’s Best Friend
text: Every week, the Opinion section presents an essay from The Times's archive by a columnist or contributor that we hope sheds light on current news or provides a window on the past.

headline: Rays of Hope in Battling an Agonizing Disease
text: It wasn’t until Ileana Peralta was in junior high school that she summoned the courage to Google her own disease.

headline: Taking Walks on the Wild Side
text: Janet Kessler, a 60-year-old, self-taught naturalist, leaves her cozy cottage in the Noe Valley section of San Francisco before dawn several days a week and walks to parks and other open spaces in hope of spotting coyotes, owls and other wildlife. Since she began photographing coyotes in the city three years ago, she has taken pictures of 11 different coyotes in four city parks. She wrote a small book — “Myca of Twin Peaks” — about one of the coyotes. Her work is chronicled on her Web site, urbanwildness.com. On a recent hike, she shared her views on animals and humans. (Her words have been edited and condensed.) SUSAN SWARD

headline: A Time to Consider Local Fuel Fees
text: Democrats in the Legislature threw a fiscal lifeline to public transit last week, bolstering financing for buses and trains at a time when the state is cutting just about everything else.

headline: National School Standards, at Last
text: The countries that have left the United States behind in math and science education have one thing in common: They offer the same high education standards  often the same curriculum  from one end of the nation to the other. The United States relies on a generally mediocre patchwork of standards that vary, not just from state to state, but often from district to district. A child’s education depends primarily on ZIP code.

headline: Sox Grow Players Better Than the Cubs Do
text: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz.

headline: Taking a Look at Poverty From an Affluent Suburb
text: James Warren is a columnist for the Chicago News Cooperative.

headline: Learning From Lehman
text: On top of everything Lehman Brothers did before it collapsed in 2008, nearly toppling the financial system, it now seems that it was aggressively massaging its books.

headline: Support Network Seeks to Grow Biotech Companies
text: Dr. Boris Pasche had worked for years with a battery-operated device to treat insomnia, but as he followed his research, he discovered that electromagnetic radiation from the apparatus might slow or stop tumor growth in some cancer patients, and he thought he could perhaps build a business around the idea.

headline: The Pulse: Veterans’ Channel Weighed for Cable Access Network
text: Military veterans' groups are working with the Chicago City Council on a project that would start a local cable access television channel dedicated to veterans' issues.

headline: The Pulse: Paralympic Hockey Team Has Chicago Flavor
text: When he was young, Andy Yohe wanted to play hockey in the Olympics some day. But after he lost his legs in 1994, he gave up that dream.

headline: Robbers Make Off With Gems and Cash in Diamond District
text: Two men armed with a pistol robbed a jewelry store in the heart of Manhattan’s diamond district on Saturday, stealing gems and money after binding three employees and a customer, the authorities said.

headline: The Pulse: Obama Comes Under Fire From the City Council
text: President Barack Obama was the target of sharp criticism last week from an unlikely place: his hometown’s City Council, where all members save one are fellow Democrats.

headline: Nebraska Finds Unbeaten Season Is Just Out of Reach
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — It was hard for the third-ranked Nebraska women’s basketball team to feel too bad about the demise of its undefeated record. After winning its first 30 games, Nebraska lost to Texas A&M, 80-70, on Saturday in the semifinals of the Big 12 tournament at Municipal Auditorium, leaving top-ranked Connecticut as the only team with a perfect record.

headline: Wherever You Are, a Game Is Just a Point and Click Away
text: Though chess is one of the world’s oldest games, it is perfectly suited for the Internet age. Boards and pieces are easily displayed on computer screens, and the game is played all over the world. It is not surprising, then, that online chess has boomed.

headline: Ray of Hope in Battling Disease and Highlights of Sunday’s Bay Area Pages
text: New Technologies Provide Hope | Those with Epidermolysis bullosa go through life with much of their bodies wrapped in gauze, like a burn patient. The disease is caused by the lack of the collagen gene that makes the glue that tethers layers of skin together; it makes skin seem as fragile as a butterfly’s wing. A handful of doctors in the United States who deal with EB are experimenting with some of the most advanced technologies in medicine — gene therapy, stem cell therapy and bone marrow transplantation — as a means of eventual treatment.

headline: Justices Will Prevail
text: Washington

headline: Kenneth Dover, a Provocative Scholar of Ancient Greek Literature, Dies at 89
text: Kenneth Dover, an eminent scholar of ancient Greek life, language and literature who became known for his willingness to break longstanding taboos in print, from his frank descriptions of sexual behavior (both the Greeks’ and his own) to his baldly stated desire to bring about the death of a vexing Oxford colleague, died on Sunday in Cupar, Scotland. He was 89.

headline: Yanks’ Montero Looks to Claim Squatters’ Rights
text: TAMPA, Fla. — At home in Venezuela, Jesus Montero loves to hang around his father’s auto repair shop. As a boy, he learned how to take apart and reassemble engines, and he loves how cars purr afterward. When he is finished, they inevitably go faster.

headline: Corrections
text: An article in some editions on Jan. 31 about alternative dining experiences in Westchester County included erroneous information from a partner in Table Local Market of Bedford Hills about the occasional dinners held there, and about the size of its storefront. The owners were forced to end their music evenings  not the dinners themselves  because they lacked the appropriate permits; the dinners are still held about four times a year. They draw fewer than 50 people, not “as many as 100.” And Table occupies 2,000 square feet, not 700 square feet.

headline: Corrections
text: A review in some editions last Sunday of the play “Sylvia” at the Long Wharf Theater in New Haven referred incompletely to one of its stars, Karen Ziemba. She is a Tony Award winner (in 2000, for “Contact”) as well as a four-time nominee.

headline: Blocks by Mississippi St. Put It in Position for a Bid
text: NASHVILLE — Mississippi State center Jarvis Varnado wants to be the second man off the floor. He is the patient shot blocker, the big man who watches, waits for the shooter to jump, and then swats.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, March 14
text: Good Sunday morning. The heat is on. Speaker Nancy Pelosi has pledged to deliver a complete health care bill to Mr. Obama’s desk in 10 days. And with this deadline in mind, White House officials and Congressional whips are out to make their final points on Sunday’s talk shows.

headline: Corrections
text: An article in some editions last Sunday about the Hartford Jewish Film Festival misstated part of the name of a documentary about the Jewish contribution to basketball. It is “The First Basket,” not “The Last Basket.”

headline: Corrections
text: An article in some editions last Sunday about Michael Chatfield, a playground basketball legend who was fatally shot in October at age 31, incorrectly described the Queensbridge housing development in Long Island City, Queens, where he grew up. It is the largest public housing project in North America, not the largest housing project.

headline: Corrections
text: An article last Sunday about the jobs that Chris Mooney worked before becoming head coach of the University of Richmond men’s basketball team omitted part of the name of a previous employer. Mooney taught English and coached at Lansdale Catholic High School in Pennsylvania, not at Lansdale High School. (The public Lansdale High School was incorporated into the North Penn School District in 1956.)

headline: Corrections
text: Because of a production error, the Food column in The Times Magazine omitted a measurement in a recipe, and a correction in Sunday’s magazine misstates the issue in which the error occurred. The recipe omitted the amount of raw corn kernels needed in Lantern Cracker Jack; it is one-third of a cup. The recipe appeared in the Feb. 28 issue of the magazine, not the March 7 issue.

headline: Corrections
text: An obituary last Sunday about the violinist Patricia Travers misspelled in some editions the name of the maker of one of the instruments she played as a child prodigy. He was Guarneri del Gesù, not Guarnari del Gesù.

headline: Huskies Rally to Claim Pac-10 Title
text: LOS ANGELES — When Washington took the court Saturday afternoon, the Huskies were not sure if they had done enough over the previous four months to earn a berth in the N.C.A.A. tournament.

headline: Correction
text: An article last Sunday about how this year’s Oscars race highlights the evolving viewing habits of moviegoers misstated a word in the name of the organization that administers the awards. It is the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences (not Pictures). The article also referred imprecisely to the overall audience of this year’s Super Bowl. It is the most widely watched program in the United States, not the most-watched broadcast ever.

headline: Correction
text: An article on Feb. 28 about the new Fox show “Sons of Tucson” misstated, based on an interview with the show’s producers, the year that Justin Berfield, an executive producer, first read the script for the pilot. He read it in 2008, not 2006.

headline: Corrections
text: METROPOLITAN

headline: Jayhawks Finally Justify Top Billing
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — When the N.C.A.A. men’s tournament bracket is released Sunday, Kansas will almost certainly be the top overall seed. But during the Jayhawks’ first two victories in the Big 12 tournament, they were often more lackluster than impressive, leaving some doubt about what may be college basketball’s most complete team.

headline: Out of Ruin, Haiti’s Visionaries
text: In a disaster, you focus on lives first, all else later. When the earthquake hit Haiti in January, the news was about the dead and missing, miraculous survivals, towns smashed to bits.

headline: The Thrill of Science, Tamed by Agendas
text: A science museum is a kind of experiment. It demands the most elaborate equipment: Imax theaters, NASA space vehicles, collections of living creatures, digital planetarium projectors, fossilized bones. Into this mix are thrust tens of thousands of living human beings: children on holiday, weary or eager parents, devoted teachers, passionate aficionados and casual passers-by. And the experimenters watch, test, change, hoping. ...

headline: Your Reality TV
text: In a new poll, more than 60 percent of respondents said televising Supreme Court proceedings would be good for democracy. We agree, but the court seems determined to keep its work out of the public’s eye.

headline: The Gowanus Canal
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Well-Deserved Oscar
text: To the Editor:

headline: Lost in the Shorthand
text: A RECENT New York Times Magazine article about the Texas State Board of Education said it was driven by a bloc determined to “advance a Christian agenda.”

headline: Nascar’s 190-M.P.H. Beanball
text: Asheville, N.C.

headline: Driving Drunk in Jerusalem
text: I am a big Joe Biden fan. The vice president is an indefatigable defender of U.S. interests abroad. So it pains me to say that on his recent trip to Israel, when Prime Minister Bibi Netanyahu’s government rubbed his nose in some new housing plans for contested East Jerusalem, the vice president missed a chance to send a powerful public signal: He should have snapped his notebook shut, gotten right back on Air Force Two, flown home and left the following scribbled note behind: “Message from America to the Israeli government: Friends don’t let friends drive drunk. And right now, you’re driving drunk. You think you can embarrass your only true ally in the world, to satisfy some domestic political need, with no consequences? You have lost total contact with reality. Call us when you’re serious. We need to focus on building our country.”

headline: A Break in the Action
text: In a welcome distraction from the sneakered treadmill called March Madness, Brendan Olinkiewicz stepped to the foul line for the Shelter Island (N.Y.) Indians. It was the final minute of his final year, and Brendan had never scored a varsity point in his high school career.

headline: The Rise of Superbugs and the Abuse of Antibiotics
text: To the Editor:

headline: The New Guard of Curators Steps Up
text: THE mouth of a giant monster, its razor-sharp teeth glaring overhead and its tongue forming a long red carpet, ushers visitors into the Tim Burton retrospective at the Museum of Modern Art. Although the intentionally lighthearted chronicle of the filmmaker’s work received only mixed reviews when it opened in November, Mr. Burton’s fans don’t seem to care. More than 450,000 people have already attended the show, and by the time it closes on April 26, attendance is expected to exceed that of recent blockbusters like the museum’s “Van Gogh: The Colors of the Night” last year and “Dali: Painting and Film,” in 2008.

headline: New York’s Met, Replicating Art Works Bit by 3-D Bit
text: JUST off the Astor Court in the Metropolitan Museum of Art’s sprawling Asian collections, an unobtrusive door is cut into a white wall, a door most patrons probably never notice. But behind it, up a narrow staircase leading into the oldest part of the museum, one of the newest and most innovative practices in the fields of sculptural conservation and scholarship has been taking shape.

headline: Teenage Girls Explore Their Lives Through a Camera’s Eye
text: TWO months ago, a dozen teenage girls with no formal photography experience were given professional cameras and told to document their world growing up in New York City. Right away, the results were startling.

headline: Rachel Alexandra Loss Imperils Showdown
text: NEW ORLEANS — This was supposed to be an exhibition for Rachel Alexandra, an opportunity for the reigning Horse of the Year to take a lap before an adoring public. She would clear her lungs, limber up her muscles and take another important step toward a showdown with the undefeated mare Zenyatta next month in Arkansas.

headline: A Fellow South African Tracks Down Els at Doral
text: DORAL, Fla. — The west-facing windows in the upstairs restaurant at the Doral Resort and Spa give diners a panoramic view of the Blue Monster course’s 1st and 18th holes in the W.G.C.-CA Championship. As the tournament director Eddie Carbone looked out at the scene Saturday, he was smiling at the lines of fans streaming onto the course and into the grandstands at the 18th green.

headline: Unearthing Lost Treasures in California
text: WHEN the Watts riots swept Los Angeles in 1965, Noah Purifoy, an artist who was in the thick of things as the director of the Watts Towers Arts Center, quickly took to the streets with a friend. Their mission was to gather debris  charred railroad ties, wood from burned-out houses, melted scraps of neon signs and other wreckage that could serve as raw material for sculpture. The resulting artworks soon went on tour throughout the country in a group show, “66 Signs of Neon.”

headline: Restoring a Museum Piece, a Jungle Gym That Once Flew
text: THE Grumman F9F Cougar had seen better days, some of them flying in Navy fighter squadrons in the 1950s. But then it was retired and ended up spending years in a park in New Jersey as perhaps the world’s coolest jungle gym.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: March 13, 2010

headline: The Best Tour Guide May Be in Your Purse
text: SAN FRANCISCO

headline: Amid the Monets, Setting the Stage for Romance
text: WHEN Blake Cohen decided to propose to his girlfriend, Clarissa Lee, there were a couple of obvious possibilities for popping the question.

headline: Long-Separated Portraits, on a Wall Together at Last
text: HARTFORD

headline: Your Comments on my ‘Beads’ Column
text: My Sunday column is about BeadforLife, an organization I first heard about a couple of years ago as a leader in enterprise solutions to poverty. I don’t usually write about just one group, but BeadforLife appealed to me both as a great yarn and because they are taking some innovative approaches — such as starting savings accounts, promoting entrepreneurship and of course deworming kids. BeadforLife also tries to listen to Ugandans, measure its results and tweak its model constantly — all good approaches. And of course, it offers Americans a way to get engaged other than just writing checks.

headline: Vows: Laura & Josh
text: Laura Freeman and Josh Gordon met at college. Five years later, Josh proposed to Laura at a restaurant in Rome, where tucked inside a dessert menu was a photo album filled with their memories.

headline: What, Me Worry? Aceves Plays It Cool
text: TAMPA, Fla. – Alfredo Aceves said he has better things to worry about than how his competition is faring. Like what?

headline: Intense Wind and Rain Blast the New York Region
text: A combination of driving winds and intense rains left nearly half a million customers without power, was blamed for three deaths, and created serious obstacles to traveling distances both short and long around the New York metropolitan area on Saturday.

headline: Teams on the Bubble Will Hope for the Best
text: When the N.C.A.A. tournament men’s field is announced starting at 6 p.m. Eastern on Sunday, these teams are among those on the edge of their seats.

headline: One Analysis of the Google Buzz Mess
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — When Google introduced a new social networking feature called Buzz last month, it hoped that users would leap at the chance to share content with the people they e-mailed with most often. But instead, the company found itself facing a firestorm of angry users and awash in criticism from privacy advocates and bloggers.

headline: Late Drive Gives West Virginia Its First Big East Title
text: West Virginia Coach Bob Huggins grew up in Midvale, Ohio, where he likes to say there are “500 people, 2 stop lights and 9 bars.” His favorite story about the hardscrabble attitude he developed there involves climbing into a local’s pickup truck with no rear-view mirrors.

headline: In Dallas, a Blueprint Gallinari Can Follow
text: DALLAS — The comparison is imperfect, and the path carved by one is not necessarily navigable by the other. But there are strong similarities in height, skill and pedigree, enough that Dirk Nowitzki may provide Danilo Gallinari with a rough template for N.B.A. success.

headline: Dodd to Unveil a Broad Financial Overhaul Bill
text: WASHINGTON — The chairman of the Senate Banking Committee will unveil on Monday a proposal to revamp the nation’s financial regulations that would empower shareholders to have advisory votes on executive pay and to nominate directors for the boards of public companies through company proxy ballots, several people briefed on the draft legislation said Saturday.

headline: Big Victory for Knicks, if That’s Possible
text: DALLAS — The Knicks banished logic long ago, along with their playoff hopes and their pride, so there was no rational way to explain their sudden passion or the seemingly inverted numbers on the scoreboard Saturday night.

headline: Relentless From Start, Pacquiao Retains Title
text: ARLINGTON, Tex. — As Manny Pacquiao dispatched another welterweight contender in the easy manner of a sparring session, the talk turned immediately and emphatically to Floyd Mayweather Jr. As expected. Once again.

headline: No Decision Yet From Tomlinson
text: Running back LaDainian Tomlinson — who spent all day Friday being wooed by the Jets — flew back to San Diego on Saturday to consider his options. Tomlinson’s departure was a disappointment for the Jets, who had pulled out all the stops, complete with a tour of the new stadium at the Meadowlands, in hopes of getting him to sign. Tomlinson has also expressed interest in joining the Vikings.

headline: Henry Kissinger Is Released From Hospital in South Korea
text: SEOUL, South Korea — Henry Kissinger, the former United States secretary of state, was released from a hospital on Sunday after treatment for stomach pains, said a spokesman for Yonsei University’s Severance Hospital in Seoul.

headline: The Hoyas’ Frustrations All Roll Into One Game
text: Austin Freeman, typically a placid presence for Georgetown, slumped his shoulders after one second-half lapse on defense, then grew so agitated the next trip down the court he expressed his disdain for the Hoyas’ effort vocally and with his hands.

headline: An Inauspicious Return to the N.H.L. for Chelios at 48
text: Defenseman Chris Chelios, a 48-year-old veteran of 25 N.H.L. seasons, played in his 26th last week. He was recalled by the Atlanta Thrashers from their Chicago Wolves farm team, where his plus-34 mark was one of the best in the American Hockey League. Chelios is the second-oldest player in league history; Gordie Howe played for Hartford in 1980 at 51.

headline: Stage Scenes: Elizabeth Marvel
text: A look at some of the actress’s past stage performances.

headline: Chinese Leader Defends Currency and Policies
text: BEIJING — Prime Minister Wen Jiabao sharply defended China’s currency and trade policies on Sunday against what he called foreign “finger pointing,” charging instead that developed countries seek to force unfair changes in those policies “just for the purposes of increasing their own exports.”

headline: Matthew Vaughn Takes Action
text: Matthew Vaughn, the director of "Kick-Ass," discusses his approach to the action in the film.

headline: State of the Bills: What the 2009 Film Revealed
text: Offense

headline: Flower Power at a Mumbai Market
text: If Mumbai’s fumes have left you craving a whiff of nature, take a walk through the Dadar flower market, where you can inhale the sharp scent of marigolds and glimpse the immensity of India’s flower trade.

headline: Saving Ryan’s Privatization
text: So, for a few weeks Rep. Paul Ryan was the toast of the punditocracy; his Roadmap was hailed as the serious Republican response to America’s fiscal problems. But it turns out, predictably, to have been a Potemkin plan: it wouldn’t balance the budget, even after two generations. What it would do is massively redistribute income upward, raising taxes and slashing benefits for most Americans, while providing huge tax breaks for the top 0.1 percent of the population.

headline: Israel, China, America
text: In debates over what to do about China’s currency manipulation, one constantly hears the refrain that we don’t dare alienate the Chinese, because they own so much of our debt. What would happen if they took their dollar holdings, equal to around 10% of US GDP, and switched them into other currencies?

text: ART exhibitions are flourishing across the country. Here is a selection of the latest offerings:

headline: Stupid Smelly Mutants

headline: Sunday Notebook: Inauspicious Return for Chelios
text: Defenseman Chris Chelios, a 48-year-old veteran of 25 N.H.L. seasons, played in his 26th last week. He was recalled by the Atlanta Thrashers from their Chicago Wolves farm team, where his plus-34 mark was one of the best in the American Hockey League. Chelios is the second-oldest player in league history; Gordie Howe played for Hartford in 1980 at 51.

headline: To Attract a Crowd, Scour Your Demographics
text: WHEN the Museum of Fine Arts in Houston wanted to create galleries for a display of Asian art a few years back, it wasn’t sure where or how to start.

headline: Small Donations in Large Numbers, With Online Help
text: LAST fall, when the Neversink Valley Area Museum in Cuddebackville, N.Y., set out to raise $11,000 for architectural renderings of a new building, museum officials turned to strangers for fund-raising using the Internet.

headline: An Arts Crawl, All in a Browser
text: SITTING in the lounge at Heathrow Airport last month, MoMA’s chief curator at large and P.S. 1’s director, Klaus Biesenbach, did a quick tour of some artists’ studios, logging on to Studio Visit, a new site that lets artists and collectives exhibit their works on the Web.

headline: Groundbreaking Partnership Unites Decades of Research
text: MOST people associate museums with art and artifacts, not research libraries. But many of New York’s most prestigious museums have extensive collections of books and papers. Four of them  the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Museum of Modern Art, the Brooklyn Museum and the Frick Collection  have combined forces to share resources, save money and make their holdings more accessible to the public.

headline: The Art of the Deal Helps Spread Great Art
text: LATE last month , the High Museum in Atlanta announced that two masterpieces of the Italian Renaissance  Titian’s “Diana and Actaeon” and “Diana and Callisto”  plus 23 other Venetian works would be coming to town next fall, on loan from the National Galleries of Scotland. It was enough to make art lovers swoon.

headline: In Dallas, the Art Is Only Part of the Show
text: The head of the Dallas Museum of Art has put the interests of her visitors first.

headline: A Conversation With Philippe de Montebello
text: WHEN Philippe de Montebello retired at the end of 2008 after 31 years as director of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, he found himself back where he started: in the classrooms of the Institute of Fine Arts at New York University, the very school where he had earned a master’s degree more than 30 years ago.

text: The health care debate heads into the fourth quarter Sunday as talk show guests go head-to-head over one of President Obama’s top legislative goals.

headline: A Master Showman’s Old Masters
text: JOHN RINGLING, one of five brothers who created the Ringling Brothers Circus (which later acquired the Barnum & Bailey Circus), was an avid art collector. With a fortune that placed him among the country’s richest men, Mr. Ringling and his wife, Mable, bought thousands of art objects from 1920 to 1930 and created the John and Mable Ringling Museum in Sarasota, Fla., to display them.

headline: Diabetes Heart Treatments May Cause Harm
text: Three aggressive treatment strategies doctors had expected would prevent heart attacks among people with Type 2 diabetes and some who are the verge of developing it have proved to be ineffective or even harmful, new studies show.

headline: Protests Urge Resignation of Leaders in Thailand
text: BANGKOK — Tens of thousands of protesters poured into Bangkok on Sunday demanding that the government step down in what was one of the largest demonstrations in Thailand’s recent tumultuous history.

headline: Drew Gooden Is Feeling California
text: Since his days as a star at Kansas, Drew Gooden has made an impressive tour of eight N.B.A. teams in eight seasons. In the future, he may want to consider limiting himself to teams that play in California.

headline: Nine to Know: 20-Game Winners
text: Bill Chuck created Billy-Ball.com and is a co-author of Walkoffs, Last Licks, and Final Outs. He grew up in New York and now lives,  with his wife (a Red Sox fan) and a daughter (a Yankees fan), two miles from Fenway Park.   Bill claims he is Switzerland. His other daughter lives in New York City, away from the fray. You can follow him on Twitter.

headline: Rain and Wind Created a Deadly Storm
text: The scenes of devastation in the New York area were so widespread that some compared what they saw to the worst of natural disasters. Nearly everyone had a storm-related tale, mixing inconvenience and a sense of wonder at forces that effortlessly ripped trees from the ground, roots and all. And there were stories of loss and tragedy.
