headline: Nico Rosberg Receives a Little Help From His Friends
text: SAKHIR, Bahrain – As I walked through the paddock half an hour before the start of the race on Sunday, my peripheral vision and hearing were suddenly accosted by a strange sound and sight. I turned and looked at the back door of the Mercedes garage to see five tall young men in a kind of combination between a rugby scrum and the haka dance of the All-Blacks. They were chanting some strange lyrics and song at the top of their lungs. One of the men was wearing the Mercedes racing outfit and a racing helmet.

headline: As Health Vote Awaits, Future of a Presidency Waits, Too
text: WASHINGTON — Senator Mitch McConnell, the Republican leader, had a little political advice last week for President Obama and the Democrats: Don’t pass the president’s health care legislation because you would risk losing in the midterm elections.

headline: Edward Norton on Edward Norton
text: Playing twins in the action/comedy "Leaves of Grass," Edward Norton discusses his approach to comedic roles.

headline: Answers From a Theater Historian, Part III
text: The final installment of answers from Marc Robinson, the author of “The American Play: 1787-2000.”

headline: Senate Republicans Protest Timing of Dodd Bill
text: The Republican members of the Senate Banking Committee on Friday wrote a letter expressing their displeasure with the proposed timetable of Christopher J. Dodd, the committee’s chairman, for his bill overhauling financial regulation.

headline: Giants and Jets Jostle for Hosting Honors at Stadium Opener
text: The Giants and Jets have always been uneasy neighbors and business partners. Now, with the $1-billion-plus stadium they have built together about to open, they can’t even agree about how the host for the stadium opener will be determined.

headline: Learning From Lehman
text: On top of everything Lehman Brothers did before it collapsed in 2008, nearly toppling the financial system, it now seems that it was aggressively massaging its books.

headline: China Issues Warning to Major Partners of Google
text: BEIJING — The Chinese authorities have warned major partners of Google’s China-based search engine that they must comply with censorship laws even if Google does not, an industry expert with knowledge of the notice said Sunday.

headline: Fleshing Out Life in Remote China
text: There are documentaries that set out to explain the world, to shape the chaos of experience into coherent stories or compelling arguments. This kind of movie  dominant just now in American nonfiction filmmaking  performs the journalistic work of advocacy, investigating problems and engaging the sympathy or the outrage of viewers.

headline: Lessons in Love From the London Stage
text: 12:55 p.m. | Updated  LONDON — To watch Judi Dench fall in love these days is to fall in love all over again with Judi Dench. True, the object of her affection may be – not to put too fine a point on it — an ass. But playing Titania in Peter Hall’s hit production of “A Midsummer Night’s Dream” at the Rose Theater here, Ms. Dench makes it clear that in acting, what really counts isn’t whom one loves but how one loves.

headline: ‘Alice’ Wins the Box Office Weekend
text: LOS ANGELES  Hollywood suffered its first major flop of the year over the weekend with the debut of the expensive Iraq thriller “Green Zone,” which sold an anemic $14.5 million in tickets at North American theaters.

headline: Parsing Premier Wen
text: So, here’s what I understand from Wen Jiabao: America must avoid a double-dip recession while also eliminating its budget deficits and, of course, doing nothing to weaken the dollar — because unlike China, we only want a weak currency so as to increase our exports.

headline: Powerless Princeton
text: Or so I hear. Trees down, no electricity for the next few days, a total mess.

headline: A Stunning Landscape, Seen Mostly From Afar
text: Interminably gorgeous and tediously impressive.

headline: Cooperative Energy, Complete With Crowd Surfing
text: The choreographer Juliette Mapp, the current guest curator of Danspace Project’s Platform 2010 initiative, has emphasized the importance of presenting an intergenerational array of artists in Back to New York City. This week the inimitable octogenarian Elaine Summers arrives; last Thursday the youngsters had the run of the place, when Katy Pyle and Jen Rosenblit, both in their 20s, presented new work.

headline: Netanyahu Offers Apology, but No Shift in Policy
text: JERUSALEM — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel told his cabinet on Sunday that the ill-timed announcement of new housing plans for a Jewish neighborhood in East Jerusalem during a visit by Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. last week had been “regrettable” and “hurtful.”

headline: From the Top of the World: Warmth Amid Ice
text: In its Perspectives programs Carnegie Hall encourages the musicians in the spotlight  the composers, soloists or ensembles in charge of each series  to present not only their own work but also other music that fascinates them. For an omnivorous ensemble like the Kronos Quartet, that invitation was bound to be a boon to listeners with adventurous tastes. You can see from the group’s repertory that its collective interests are stylistically borderless.

headline: 20 Years of Babies and Cheerleaders
text: For any dance company working in New York reaching the 20-year mark is no small feat. For the choreographer Jody Oberfelder such an anniversary is occasion to look back in a two-act program, “Heads or Tales,” which highlights dances created throughout her career. Lesson learned: Perhaps the only thing Ms. Oberfelder cares about more than a cartwheel is a headstand.

headline: At Home With Disney and ‘Miss Saigon’
text: A bright, utilitarian voice that sweeps across continents as it conjures the aspirations of the inner princesses in millions of nice young women from Manila to London: no, it’s not Celine Dion, but Lea Salonga, the demure 39-year-old Philippine star whose autobiographical show, “The Journey So Far,” opened a three-week engagement at Café Carlyle on Tuesday evening.

headline: Microtonal Fluctuation in Moods of All Colors
text: There was microtonal mayhem at Bargemusic on Friday night during the adventurous Flux Quartet’s performance in the Here and Now series.

headline: Bizarro Health Reform Arguments
text: As health reform moves to its final, make or break vote — I think it’s going to go through, but I’ll be hanging on by my fingernails all week — Republicans are still denouncing it as a vast, evil government takeover. But they have a problem: Obamacare is very much like the Massachusetts health reform, which was not only implemented by a Republican governor, but by a governor who is a serious contender for the 2012 presidential nomination.

headline: Selection Sunday: Men’s N.C.A.A. Tournament Field
text: 9:51 p.m. |Analyzing the Field

headline: Argentines Take Lebhar Title Thanks to a Second-Day Surge
text: The two-day Lebhar Imp Pairs was won on Saturday at the Spring Nationals in Reno, Nev., by Pablo Lambardi and Pablo Ravenna from Argentina. They only just qualified for the second day but then scored 89.7 international match points to take a 38.88-imp lead into the final session. They gained another 24.95 imps to win by 15.42 over Jon Baldursson and Thorlakur Jonsson from Iceland. Third were Nader Hanna and Robert Lebi from Canada.

headline: Investors Who Foresaw the Meltdown
text: The global financial crisis of 2008, which economists estimate could result in several trillion dollars of losses and which has already cost American taxpayers billions of dollars in government bailouts, was triggered not by war or recession but by a crazy, man-made money machine, built on flawed mathematical models that most financial executives did not really understand themselves. Greedy and heedless, Wall Street firms had been turning subprime mortgages  loans made to people with low creditworthiness or little documentation  into exotic, toxic financial products that they made a fortune laundering and reselling, and they were enabled in doing so by the very ratings agencies that were supposed to police risk. The insanity of this growing and highly leveraged trade in mortgage derivatives continued even as the quality of the underlying loans grew increasingly dubious, even as it became increasingly likely that the American housing bubble was going to pop.

headline: Square Dancing
text: I bet I can guess your favorite math subject in high school.

headline: Panic in Georgia After a Mock News Broadcast
text: MOSCOW — Some people placed emergency calls reporting heart attacks, others rushed in a panic to buy bread and residents of one border village staggered from their homes and dashed for safety — all after a television station in Georgia broadcast a mock newscast on Saturday night that pretended to report on a Russian invasion of the country.

headline: Storm Sweeps Through Metropolitan Region
text: Crews swept across the metropolitan region to remove fallen trees and to restore power to several hundred thousand homes following a devastating storm.

headline: New CDs
text: GORILLAZ

headline: Maastricht Treasure Hunt Lures Collectors
text: MAASTRICHT, the Netherlands  This small Dutch city may be known for its winding cobblestone streets, quaint town square and a church dating as far back as the sixth century, but it is also home to a cavernous convention center where, every March, about 70,000 art lovers flock for the European Fine Art Fair. A supersize event in many ways, this year’s edition has been notable for a few standout sales amid the absence of big-ticket items.

headline: Two Drug Slayings in Mexico Rock U.S. Consulate
text: LA UNIÓN, Mexico — Gunmen believed to be linked to drug traffickers shot a pregnant American consulate worker and her husband to death in the violence-racked border town of Ciudad Juárez over the weekend, leaving their baby wailing in the back seat of their car, the authorities said Sunday. The gunmen also killed the husband of another consular employee and wounded his two young children.

headline: Metal Variety: Death, Doom, Black and Cars
text: COLUMBUS, Ohio  Yob, the three-man doom-metal band from Eugene, Ore., played a show here at Skully’s on Saturday night that left you wondering when you’d heard something as good, and when you might again. It was all graceful molasses cohesion, moving in focused minor-key riffs and strong processional grooves from the bassist Aaron Reiseberg and the drummer Travis Foster, lighted up by Mike Scheidt’s fat, fuzzed guitar tone. His solos were creeping abstraction with a plan, an almost visual display of cathedral-echo notes, bending and decaying and transforming.

headline: One Is Not Enough
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — Fred Piscop is back with another Monday puzzle and I’m here to give you my 20 cents’ worth. That’s enough to cover inflation and, fitting in with today’s theme, it’s a PARADIGMS. What, I can’t do those jokes too?

headline: Super Race Is Off, and It’s a Wise Decision
text: NEW ORLEANS

headline: Browns Send Quinn to Broncos
text: Remember how bright the future looked for the Cleveland Browns two years ago, when they had Derek Anderson coming off a Pro Bowl season and a first-round draft pick in Brady Quinn waiting in the wings?

headline: At the Corner of Grit and Glamour
text: During the past few years Chelsea became a one-stop-shopping destination for high-style contemporary architecture as well as high-end art, and the results can be depressing. For every significant building that went up, the neighborhood seemed to produce a half-dozen or so inferior knockoffs. The feeling on the streets now is the same as it is in most of the galleries: the sheer amount of work, and the mediocrity of most of it, can make the effort of sorting out the good from the bad too painful to contemplate.

headline: GLAAD Media Awards Honor Behar and Nixon
text: Joy Behar and Cynthia Nixon were among the honorees at the Gay and Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation’s media awards in New York on Saturday night. The top award for excellence in media was presented to Ms. Behar, a host of “The View” on ABC and “The Joy Behar Show” on the HLN network, for her contributions to increasing the visibility of lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender people. Ms. Nixon received the Vito Russo Award, given to an openly lesbian, gay, bisexual or transgender media professional who has promoted equal rights. Honors also went to ABC’s “Brothers and Sisters” for outstanding drama series, and Lifetime’s “Prayers for Bobby,” starring Sigourney Weaver and Ryan Kelley, above, for outstanding television movie or mini-series. Other winners included Colman Domingo’s “Boy and His Soul,” for Broadway and Off Broadway theater, and The New York Times, which received an award for overall newspaper coverage, as well as prizes for the writers Frank Rich, Tara Parker-Pope and Benoit Denizet-Lewis.

headline: Royal Opera in London to Stage ‘Anna Nicole’
text: According to the BBC, the Royal Opera House in London plans to stage the world premiere of “Anna Nicole,” based on the life of the former Playboy model Anna Nicole Smith, right, who went from impoverished Texas waitress to oil tycoon’s widow to reality television celebrity. The new work is from the composer Mark-Anthony Turnage and the writer Richard Thomas, a creator of “Jerry Springer: The Opera.” The BBC reported that Mr. Thomas said the production would end with Smith’s death, from a prescription-drug overdose in February 2007 in the midst of lawsuits over her husband’s fortune and the paternity of her daughter. The production is scheduled to open on Feb. 17 with the Dutch soprano Eva-Maria Westbroek in the lead and Antonio Pappano conducting.

headline: ‘Avatar’: Release and Repeat
text: “Avatar” may soon be booked for a second run at digital and Imax 3-D theaters this summer. According to The Hollywood Reporter, James Cameron is in discussions with Fox to work out a re-release of the film, possibly with additional scenes that were cut from the original. In New York on Thursday, Imax’s chief executive, Richard L. Gelfond, said that Mr. Cameron had about 40 minutes of extra material. Only about 10 minutes of film could be added, though, to keep under the 170-minute maximum length a movie can be released in analog Imax theaters. But that is just the amount Mr. Cameron has said he could easily push through postproduction for a director’s cut or for the DVD release, including a scene in which Jake Sully further proves himself to the Na’vi people, and another surrounding a native festival. “Avatar” was taken out of 3-D theaters to make way for the opening of Disney’s “Alice in Wonderland.” At a demonstration of 3-D TV in New York last week, Mr. Cameron told USA Today, “The word we’re getting back from exhibitors is we probably left a couple hundred million dollars on the table as a result.”

headline: Judi Dench Memoir Is Set for October
text: It only makes sense that Judi Dench, below, after accumulating a lifetime’s worth of theater, film and television credits that could easily fill a book, should finally write one. St. Martin’s Press said it had acquired a memoir from Ms. Dench, called “And Furthermore,” that described her professional and private lives, according to a press release from the publisher. Though she has lately come to be known for her role as M in the James Bond franchise, and as Queen Elizabeth in “Shakespeare in Love” (for which she won an Academy Award for just a few minutes of screen time), Ms. Dench covers the breadth of her acting career in the memoir, from her start with the Old Vic theater company in 1957. St. Martin’s plans to publish “And Furthermore” in October.

headline: Permitted to Play, Avery Fuels Rangers
text: The enigmatic legend of Sean Avery grew a little larger Sunday at Madison Square Garden.

headline: In the Wings
text: The producers of “Glee Live! In Concert!” have added shows to tour dates, Playbill reported. In New York a matinee on May 28 and an evening performance on May 30 have been added to Radio City Music Hall dates, while in Los Angeles an additional matinee and evening show have been scheduled for May 22 at the Gibson Amphitheater. ... Emerging Artists Theater has announced the return of “Penny Penniworth,” Charles Dickens’s “lost” epic, by Chris Weikel. Performances of this limited Off Broadway run will be Sept. 8 through Oct. 3 at TADA Theater on West 28th Street in Manhattan (emergingartiststheatre.org). ... Second extensions have been announced for Jonathan Reynolds’s “Girls in Trouble” (now running through April 11 at the Flea Theater in TriBeCa) and for “The Jackie Look,” with Karen Finley (through April 24 at the Laurie Beechman Theater in Manhattan).

headline: Disney Cost-Cutting Fells Zemeckis Company
text: Walt Disney Studios on Friday pulled the plug on ImageMovers Digital, the motion-capture company run by Robert Zemeckis, above right, the latest in a string of cost-cutting moves. ImageMovers Digital, which is based near San Francisco and employs 450 people, will slowly wind down production during the next few months. Mr. Zemeckis’s “Christmas Carol” was a big disappointment for Disney, and despite his pioneering work in motion-capture technology, he has been leapfrogged in the genre by James Cameron and “Avatar.” But Disney said that two extensive movie projects from Mr. Zemeckis, the comedy “Mars Needs Moms!” and a remake of “Yellow Submarine,” would move ahead.

headline: Tomlinson Agrees to Join Jets
text: When LaDainian Tomlinson completed his visit with the Minnesota Vikings last Thursday, he left with a Vikings jersey in hand. On Sunday, he accepted something of far greater value from the Jets — a two-year contract to become their newest running back and perhaps complete his Hall of Fame career with them.

headline: Livingston’s Comeback Is Bright Spot for Wizards
text: WASHINGTON — The Washington Wizards’ season has long been disappointing, disheartening and even felonious (see: Arenas, Gilbert; Trades; Salary Purging). But for a fan base seeking any glimmer of hope, there is one in the comeback of Shaun Livingston, the prodigy point guard whose career was derailed by devastating injuries.

headline: A Smidgen of Sympathy for a Diva on the Skids
text: A previously unknown Tallulah Bankhead  the fabulous monster as crackerjack comic  is revealed to the world in Matthew Lombardo’s play “Looped,” which stars Valerie Harper as that troubled actress in her twilight moments. As she lurches around the recording studio where the play is set in 1965, unable to finish the last bit of work on what will prove to be her final film, Tallulah barks out punch lines with the skill of a stand-up comic with decades of Borscht Belt experience, despite the half-bottle of Scotch flowing through her veins.

headline: Night Lights, Blankets and Lullabies
text: I remember a lamp that stood on the floor in the opened doorway to the bedroom where my sister Liv and I slept. My mother put it there every night so the darkness would never be total. This is an old memory and around it are the usual fogs that dim recollection, but the light offered the hope that blackness would not snuff out the visible world entirely during my anxious transition to sleep.

headline: A Plan in Britain to Block Sites Offering Pirated Music
text: To the consternation of Internet companies and civil liberties groups, lawmakers in Britain are seeking to punish those who illegally copy music.

headline: Socialists Lead in Early Voting in France
text: PARIS — The governing party of President Nicolas Sarkozy appeared to be beaten by the opposition Socialists on Sunday in a first round of regional elections marked by a record abstention, according to partial official results released Sunday night.

headline: Report Faults U.S.’s Efforts at Transparency
text: WASHINGTON — In his first full day at the White House almost 14 months ago, President Obama declared openness and transparency to be touchstones of his administration, and he ordered federal agencies to make it easier for the public to get information on the workings of government.

headline: Shaken Afghan City Seeks More Support From Kabul
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — A day after five lethal bombs shook Kandahar, officials appealed Sunday to the central government to send more security forces and expand intelligence gathering in the southern province, underscoring the increasing violence and lawlessness in the city.

headline: Duplicating Federal Videos for an Online Archive
text: WASHINGTON — Dust off a disc. Maybe it’s video of a Bob Hope Christmas show, or maybe it’s the Apollo 11 moon landing. Insert a blank disc. Duplicate.

headline: The Push-Back on Charter Schools
text: Two recent New York Times articles have described opposition to the thriving charter school movement in Harlem. An influential state senator, Bill Perkins, whose district has nearly 20 charter schools, is trying to block their expansion. Some public schools  in the neighborhood are also fighting back, marketing themselves  to compete with the charters.

headline: A PBS Offering, ‘Earth Days,’ Will Be Seen on Facebook First
text: PBS’s “American Experience” has sent its documentary “Earth Days” on a film festival and 40-city theatrical tour for the last year, before its television broadcast in April. Now the 102-minute film about the origins of the American environmental movement, from director Robert Stone, is planning for another outlet, a presentation on the social networking site Facebook. Users will be able to watch communally and interact with the filmmaker and the “American Experience” executive producer Mark Samels in real time.

headline: Pacquiao’s Focus Turns From Boxing to Politics
text: ARLINGTON, Tex. — The future of Manny Pacquiao — in politics, in boxing, in acting, singing or whatever whim he pursues next — remains clouded. Even his proposed megafight against Floyd Mayweather Jr. stands on shaky footing, far from reality despite worldwide intrigue.

headline: Phillips-Van Heusen Nears Deal for Tommy Hilfiger
text: Phillips-Van Heusen, the big clothing conglomerate that owns Calvin Klein, is near a deal to buy Tommy Hilfiger, once a leading purveyor of colorful preppy clothing, for about 2.2 billion euros ($3 billion) in cash and stock, people briefed on the matter told DealBook on Sunday night.

headline: Tallying the Votes in Iraq
text: As the Iraqi election authorities trickle out results from the March 7 parliamentary election, delays, allegations of fraud and conspiracy theories are fueling public frustration.

headline: Frustration Grows in Iraq at Slow Pace of Vote Tally
text: BAGHDAD — At a vote-counting center in eastern Baghdad, a dozen men representing various political parties sat on a stage in a school gymnasium on Sunday, monitoring the counting of ballots.

headline: To Stop Crime, Share Your Genes
text: New Haven

headline: New Jersey Schools Brace for Governor’s Next Round of Cuts
text: LINDEN, N.J. — When classes let out at 3 p.m., 85 children in a state-subsidized program at Linden’s School No. 1 head down the hall for three more hours of reading, math games, homework help and stepping lessons.

headline: In N.C.A.A. Pools, Picking Underdogs Is Overrated
text: Some people think that the way to win the office pool in the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament is to pick the promising underdogs to win — and they believe they know which underdogs to pick. But two psychology professors have this advice for them: don’t bet on it.

headline: Beckham’s Achilles’ Tendon ‘Totally Torn,’ According to Surgeon
text: Mon., March 15, 3:56 p.m. |Update: ‘Totally Torn’

headline: Taking On China
text: Tensions are rising over Chinese economic policy, and rightly so: China’s policy of keeping its currency, the renminbi, undervalued has become a significant drag on global economic recovery. Something must be done.

headline: Bees in the City? New York May Let the Hives Come Out of Hiding
text: Kathleen Boyer suspects the mailman.

headline: Kentucky Keeps Emotions, and Opponents, in Check
text: NASHVILLE — After back-to-back games in a rowdy atmosphere at the Southeastern Conference men’s tournament, No. 2 Kentucky looks less fragile. The Wildcats, who depend on several freshmen who are wound with emotion, could have come unhinged many times this weekend but managed themselves in the tournament caldron.

headline: With Financial Reform Bill, a Test for Congress
text: WASHINGTON — Senate Democrats will press forward this week on legislation to overhaul the nation’s financial system in a critical test of whether Washington can pass reform.

headline: Bidders Lined Up for a Casino in the Future
text: With Albany’s dysfunction searing their fortunes and reputations, why is the same small group of companies insistent on trying to build and run a slot machine casino at a rundown racetrack in southern Queens?

headline: City Tries to Shut Club It Says Flouts Smoking Ban
text: The Bloomberg administration is moving closer to shutting one of the largest and busiest nightclubs in the city, as part of an aggressive new strategy to revoke the operating licenses of clubs that health officials believe promote smoking.

headline: Political Levers Lock Into Gear in Election Year
text: CAIRO — Egypt’s parliamentary elections are still months away, but the arrests have already started.

headline: A Quiet Evening, Waiting for the Next Angry Man
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Saving U.S. Water and Sewer Systems Would Be Costly
text: WASHINGTON — One recent morning, George S. Hawkins, a long-haired environmentalist who now leads one of the largest and most prominent water and sewer systems, trudged to a street corner here where water was gushing into the air.

headline: China Uses Rules on Global Trade to Its Advantage
text: HONG KONG — With China’s exports soaring, even as other major economies struggle to recover from the recession, evidence is mounting that Beijing is skillfully using inconsistencies in international trade rules to spur its own economy at the expense of others, including the United States.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: March 14, 2010

headline: More Than Onerous
text: After a year of national debate, a handful of House Democrats who oppose abortion may be the ones to decide whether health care reform goes forward or not.

headline: The Fed’s Responsibility
text: Congress passed legislation last year intended to protect consumers from the credit card industry’s most deceptive and unfair practices. The main provisions finally went into effect last month. But the Federal Reserve still has to write new rules intended to stop companies from bleeding customers dry with exorbitant fees for late payments, with charges for exceeding the credit limit, or with “any other penalty fee or charge.” Under the statute, the Fed must write rules to ensure that these fees and charges are “reasonable and proportional.”

headline: For Philippine Family in Politics, Land Issue Hits Home
More Parity Atop the Bracket, but Less Talent on the Bubble
text: The N.C.A.A. revealed the 65-team field for its men’s basketball tournament on Sunday amid vigorous discussions about significantly changing this rite of March by adding 31 teams. Yet the assembling of this year’s field was perhaps defined by the undistinguished nature of the teams on the tournament’s bubble.

headline: City’s Public Housing Agency Gets $305 Million in Aid
text: The city’s largest landlord has secured desperately needed financing that could help steer it out of the red.

headline: Telling Friends Where You Are (or Not)
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — As Jordan Viator roams the conference rooms, dimly lit bars and restaurants here at the South by Southwest Interactive conference, she often pulls out her cellphone and uses the Foursquare service to broadcast her location.

headline: Yoga License Rebellion May Soon Claim Victory
text: When the state notified yoga studios that the instruction of yoga teachers would soon fall under government oversight, the last thing it expected was a battle.

headline: Serious Study in the Bars of Hoboken
text: HOBOKEN, N.J.

headline: Woman Is the Youngest to Cross an Ocean Alone
text: Katie Spotz completed her mission Sunday, becoming the youngest person to row an entire ocean solo, and the first American to row a boat without help from mainland to mainland. After 70 days 5 hours 22 minutes in the Atlantic, Spotz, 22, arrived Sunday in Georgetown, Guyana, in South America.

headline: Jets Say Thanks to Jones — in Kansas City Newspaper
text: The bad news for running back Thomas Jones: The Jets wanted him to take a pay cut after he rushed for more than 1,400 yards last season and when he declined to do so, they cut him. Now, he’s with the rebuilding Kansas City Chiefs instead of a team that made it to the A.F.C. Championship game last season.

headline: Millions Spent to Sway Democrats on Health Care
text: WASHINGTON — The yearlong legislative fight over health care is drawing to a frenzied close as a multimillion-dollar wave of advertising that rivals the ferocity of a presidential campaign takes aim at about 40 House Democrats whose votes will help determine the fate of President Obama’s top domestic priority.

headline: Forget Goofing Around: Recess Has a New Boss
text: NEWARK — At Broadway Elementary School here, there is no more sitting around after lunch. No more goofing off with friends. No more doing nothing.

headline: Trade Papers Struggling in Hollywood
text: LOS ANGELES — Variety, the show business bible, was born nearly 105 years ago when young Sime Silverman, by his own account, was fired by The Morning Telegraph for a review in which he declared a new theatrical sketch by a performer who happened to be one of the paper’s advertisers “N. G. (No Good).”

headline: Make the Bracket Big Enough for Everyone to Have a Shot
text: Floyd Kerr was halfway back from his trip to Winston-Salem, N.C., on Sunday, on schedule to reach Baltimore just in time for the Selection Sunday broadcast.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Friday about pensions in Europe gave an incorrect figure for Germany’s current debt as a percentage of gross domestic product. It is 71.9 percent, as the accompanying chart said, not 69 percent.

headline: Corrections
text: A picture caption with an article on Tuesday about the publication of a book containing about 250 of the more than one million condolence letters received by Jacqueline Kennedy following the assassination of her husband misspelled the surname of the photographer. He was Robert Knudsen, not Kundsen.

headline: A Cable Power’s Global Reach
text: Rupert Murdoch’s deputy, Chase Carey, looked out on the cable television landscape last fall and found a rival he wanted to emulate. Discovery Communications, he said, is “a road map of where I’d like to be.”

headline: Corrections
text: Because of an editing error, the Advertising column on Friday about technology that allows marketers to direct instant online ads at specific Web users misspelled the given name of a Google executive in some editions. He is Neal  not Neil  Mohan.

headline: Talking Back to Your TV, Incessantly
text: Back in 1988, Joel Hodgson, a funny guy in Minneapolis, came up with a local television show called “Mystery Science Theater 3000.” In the goofy plot, a janitor was launched into space by a couple of evil scientists and marooned there, forced to watch an endless run of exceptionally bad B-movies.

headline: Corrections
text: An entry in the “What’s On Today” television highlights on Wednesday about Fred Astaire-Ginger Rogers movies on the Turner Classic Movies channel misidentified the film in which the song “Cheek to Cheek” is performed. It is “Top Hat,” not “The Gay Divorcée.”

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Tuesday about new research on Alzheimer’s disease referred incorrectly to a substance used in an experiment to determine whether the protein beta amyloid  a chief villain in Alzheimer’s  also had a role in fighting infection. As noted in the article’s previous sentence, the substance, Candida albicans, is a yeast, not a bacterium.

headline: Deal Is Near for the Sale of Hilfiger
text: Phillips-Van Heusen, the clothing conglomerate that owns Calvin Klein, is near a deal to buy Tommy Hilfiger, once a leading purveyor of colorful preppy clothing, for about 2.2 billion euros, or $3 billion, in cash and stock, people briefed on the matter said Sunday night.

headline: Cactus League Cluster Has a Cozy Feel
text: Bob Apodaca, the pitching coach for the Colorado Rockies, moved through the autograph line outside the clubhouse door at Hi Corbett Field in Tucson earlier this month. He signed for everybody, posing for photographs and making small talk.

headline: Corrections
text: An obituary on Wednesday about Willie Davis, who succeeded Duke Snider as the Los Angeles Dodgers’ center fielder, erroneously credited Davis with franchise records in several categories. His career totals in those categories were records for the Los Angeles Dodgers only, not for the Dodger franchise, which was originally located in Brooklyn. Zack Wheat, not Davis, holds the franchise records for hits, at-bats, triples and total bases; Pee Wee Reese holds the record for runs; Duke Snider holds the record for extra-base hits. The obituary also incorrectly described one of Davis’s World Series accomplishments. He stole three bases in one game in the 1965 Series, not three bases in one inning.

headline: Peter Graves, ‘Mission: Impossible’ Star, Dies at 83
text: Peter Graves, the cool spymaster of television’s “Mission: Impossible” and the dignified host of the “Biography” series, who successfully spoofed his own gravitas in the “Airplane!” movie farces, died on Sunday. He was 83.

headline: Complaints About Banks Soar. Odd?
text: Consumers filed 42 percent more complaints about banks last year than they did in 2008, according to the Council of Better Business Bureaus. That is a highly unusual rise in complaints; the only two industries that generated more complaints last year — cellphone and television providers — had only single-digit increases over 2008.

headline: Obama Administration Pushes Back on Abortion Claims
text: The abortion issue in the health care debate has mostly focused on how to prevent federal money from being used to pay for insurance coverage for the procedure. But in recent weeks, groups that want to outlaw abortion have sought to build opposition to the legislation by asserting that it would also expand the availability of abortions through government-financed community health centers.

headline: Contractors Tied to Effort to Track and Kill Militants
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Under the cover of a benign government information-gathering program, a Defense Department official set up a network of private contractors in Afghanistan and Pakistan to help track and kill suspected militants, according to military officials and businessmen in Afghanistan and the United States.

headline: A Brief, but Failed, Pass at Bipartisanship

headline: Hollywood’s Political Fictions
text: Americans believe in evil, but we’re uncomfortable with tragedy. We accept that there are wicked people in the world, with malice in their hearts and a devil whispering in their ears. But the idea that many debacles flow from choices made by decent, well-intentioned human beings is more difficult for us to wrap our minds around.

headline: In Tomlinson, Jets Add Another Big Name and Security for Backfield
text: When LaDainian Tomlinson completed his visit with the Minnesota Vikings last Thursday, he left with a Vikings jersey in hand. On Sunday, he accepted something of far greater value from the Jets — a two-year contract to become their newest running back and perhaps complete his Hall of Fame career with them.

headline: A.I.G. May Cut Bonuses by About 30%
text: The American International Group will pay about $46 million in retention bonuses on Monday, or about 30 percent less than previously scheduled, a person with direct knowledge of the arrangements said.

text: Accounts

headline: The Verb Treatment for an Investment House
text: COMPUTER users searching online for information say they are “Googling.” Commercials running in states like Michigan and Ohio suggest that shoppers go “Krogering.” But what will investors make of a campaign that proposes they start “Vanguarding”?

headline: Looking Ahead
text: ECONOMIC DATA Reports will include industrial production for February (Monday); import prices for February and housing starts for February (Tuesday); producer price index for February (Wednesday); and weekly jobless claims, consumer price index for February, fourth-quarter current account deficit, Conference Board leading economic indicators for February, and Philadelphia Fed manufacturing index (Thursday).

headline: This TV Station Could Be Yours for $550,000
text: You don’t need pockets as deep as Comcast’s to get into the TV business. Or even be a millionaire, apparently.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: With Maine as Linchpin, Rotation Remains a Mystery
text: JUPITER, Fla. — Of the many questions surrounding the Mets’ pitching staff, John Maine remains one of the biggest. Johan Santana and Oliver Perez, like Maine, are returning from injuries that cut short their seasons last year. But they have long-term contracts, more dominating pitches and expectations of throwing like aces.

headline: Robert Carter, Priest and Gay Activist, Dies at 82
text: The Rev. Robert Carter, who in the early 1970s was one of the first Roman Catholic priests in the country to declare publicly that he was gay and who helped found the National Gay and Lesbian Task Force, died on Feb. 22 in the Bronx. He was 82.

headline: Auditor Could Face Liability in Lehman Case
text: Lehman Brothers may have collapsed a year and a half ago, but fallout from its demise has created a potential legal liability for its former accounting firm, Ernst & Young.

headline: Robert Rodriguez on 'Predators'
text: Robert Rodriguez, the producer of "Predators," previewed some of the film at SXSW and discussed some of the new characters.

headline: Most Online News Readers Use 5 Sites or Fewer, Study Says
text: The audience for news online tends not to stick to a single site — that much has been known for years. But a new study says that even with a vast array of digital choices, “promiscuous” news consumption goes only so far.

headline: Deal for South American Oil Fields Extends China’s Global Quest for Energy
text: Cnooc, China’s top offshore oil explorer, said on Sunday that it had secured a South American beachhead by agreeing to pay $3.1 billion in cash for a stake in one of the largest Argentine oil explorers, with fields in Argentina, Bolivia and Chile.

headline: A Book Attacking Capitalism Gets Sales Help From a Fox Host
text: “Revolutionary movements do not spread by contamination but by resonance,” write the anonymous authors of “The Coming Insurrection,” a call to overthrow capitalism that first appeared in France in 2005 and was recently published in translation in the United States.

headline: A National Measure, Inextricably Enmeshed With Local Interests
text: WASHINGTON — Take a glance at the political map, and it makes perfect sense that President Obama will open the most critical week in his push for major health care legislation with a visit on Monday to the Walter F. Ehrnfelt Recreation and Senior Center, in Strongsville, Ohio.

headline: In Ending a Slump, Els Merges Past and Present
text: DORAL, Fla. — Every time things became tight Sunday — and there were several — Ernie Els did what he used to do back when the living was easy and he was a dominant player in his 20s and his 30s, winning tournaments and hoisting trophies around the world. He gathered himself, summoned the resolve that defined him and did what had to be done to win.

headline: Skype Is Poised for a Big Initial Stock Offering
text: Skype looks to be Silicon Valley’s best hope for a blockbuster initial stock offering in 2010. With Facebook apparently determined to stay private until next year, Skype is in prime position to steal the scene with a quick flip. Moreover, as a result of clarifying copyright issues and rewriting its code to attack the business market, the company may be worth twice the $2.75 billion it was valued at when eBay sold all but 30 percent of its stake in Skype last year.

headline: News Quiz | March 15, 2010

headline: With Financial Reform Bill, a Test for Congress
text: Senate Democrats will press forward this week on legislation to overhaul the nation’s financial system in a critical test of whether Washington can pass reform, Sewell Chan reports in The New York Times.

headline: In Lehman Report, a Vindication of Short-Sellers?
text: The Lehman Brothers bankruptcy examiner must be popular at the hedge fund Greenlight Capital, Reuters Breakingviews says. David Einhorn, the fund’s founder, had criticized the Wall Street firm’s finances and accounting before it failed in September 2008.

headline: Australia Welcomes China Report on Rio Tinto Deal
text: Australia on Monday welcomed a report by China clearing Rio Tinto and the Australian government of blame for the collapse of a $19.5 billion tie-up between Chinalco and Rio Tinto last June, Reuters reported.

headline: Gulf Sovereign Wealth Fund Starts to Open Up
text: The Abu Dhabi Investment Authority broke with its customary privacy by issuing its first yearly statement Monday, marking one of the biggest steps yet by the world’s largest sovereign wealth fund to increase transparency, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Marketing and Metal
text: Images from the Scion Rock Fest in Columbus, Ohio.

headline: Progress Expected on Rescue Plan for Greece
text: When finance ministers from the 16 euro-zone countries meet Monday to discuss loan guarantees or loans for Greece, they are expected to strike a delicate balance by giving much-needed clarity on how a bailout could be structured while not making a rescue inevitable, Stephen Castle reports in The New York Times.

headline: Arrow Energy May Reject $3 Billion Bid
text: Arrow Energy of Australia plans to  reject a $3 billion joint takeover offer from Royal Dutch Shell and PetroChina as too low, the Australian Financial Review reported. Analysts said that move could prompt the bidders to return with a higher, hostile bid.

headline: Banks Said to Muscle Hedge Funds for Collateral
text: Goldman Sachs Group and JPMorgan Chase, two of the biggest traders of over-the-counter derivatives, are exploiting their growing clout in that market to secure cheap funding in addition to billions in revenue from the business, Bloomberg News reports.

headline: Thai Protesters Shut Down Parts of Bangkok
text: BANGKOK — Antigovernment protesters shut down parts of this capital on Monday, but appeared a long way from achieving their goal of forcing the Thai government to step down.

text: An article in the New York Region section spotlights a high school where kids play overturned five-gallon plastic paint buckets in their school’s “Jaguar Bucket Ensemble.” What extracurricular activities do you do? What do you think you get out of them?

headline: Auditor Could Face Liability Over Lehman
text: Lehman Brothers may have collapsed a year and a half ago, but fallout from its demise has created a potential legal liability for its former accounting firm, Ernst & Young, The New York Times’s Michael J. de la Merced writes.

headline: Book Review: Investors Who Saw Crisis Coming
text: The global financial crisis of 2008, which economists estimate could result in several trillion dollars of losses and which has already cost American taxpayers billions of dollars in government bailouts, was triggered not by war or recession, but by a crazy, man-made money machine, built on flawed mathematical models that most financial executives did not really understand themselves, The New York Times’s Michiko Kakutani writes in her review of Michael Lewis’s new book “The Big Short: Inside the Doomsday Machine.”

headline: This TV Station Could Be Yours for $550,000

headline: UBS Hands Out $52 Million to Board
text: UBS, the Swiss bank that last month reported a third consecutive annual loss, paid 54.9 million Swiss francs ($51.8 million) in bonuses and other awards to executive board members for 2009, Bloomberg News reports.

headline: Trichet Sides With Advocates of Crackdown
text: With political momentum building in Europe to crack down on what many see as risky financial practices, the European Central Bank president, Jean-Claude Trichet, threw his weight behind the movement Friday by forcefully criticizing the banking industry, The New York Times’s Jack Ewing and Julia Werdigier reported.

headline: The Originals | Gary Card
text: “I had a lot of fun with child kidnapping,” says the set designer, illustrator and T contributor Gary Card, speaking of his recent campaign for Comme des Garçons that involved adapting dark Victorian children’s stories. “And people turning into horses and slugs and things — that got my imagination ticking.” The London-based Card, 28, covers the High Street with clients that include Liberty, Stella McCartney, Adidas, Hermès and Top Shop. “What I love about my job is I have the opportunity to make both art and commercial products, and something else that can be a little bit stranger and more off-beat,” he says. In a recent foray into fine art at the London gallery Spring Projects, he exhibited “a gigantic cave made out of white Plasticine, which was then sculpted into 3,000 tiny heads…so you walked through this strange vortex of little white faces staring at you.” In appearance, Card suggests a cross between David Hockney and the British avant-garde pop star Patrick Wolf. But the creative chameleon, who wants to design furniture next, shrugs off the comparison. “My personal style is whatever I find on the floor, really.”

headline: Pockets and Purses Give Up Their Secrets
text: We always suggest you use the Full Screen option — directly above, to the right of the slide counter — to view photos to best effect. But there are times when we urge you to do so. This is one of those occasions.

headline: K.K.R. and Warner Said to Eye Break-Up Bid for EMI
text: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, the private equity firm, and United States music company Warner Music Group are in talks to introduce a break-up bid for Warner’s indebted British rival EMI, The Sunday Times reported.

headline: Moody’s Warns on AAA Ratings
text: The United States, Germany and other major economies could see their top-notch credit rating come under pressure if the recovery in the global economy stalls, Moody’s Investors Service warned Monday, David Jolly reports in The New York Times.

headline: Wachovia Said to Seek to Settle Mexico Probe
text: Wachovia Bank is in talks with the Justice Department to settle complaints relating to the suspected failure of bank controls that enabled Mexican exchange houses to launder drug money, The Wall Street Journal said, citing people familiar with the situation.

headline: Private Equity’s Trojan Horse of Debt
text: Whenever savvy private equity firms sell debt in the companies they own, buyer beware, The New York Times’s Gretchen Morgenson writes in her latest Fair Game column.

headline: In Chicago, Support Network Grows for Biotech
text: Dr. Boris Pasche had worked for years with a battery-operated device to treat insomnia, but as he followed his research, he discovered that electromagnetic radiation from the apparatus might slow or stop tumor growth in some cancer patients, and he thought he could perhaps build a business around the idea.

headline: JPMorgan Fund Targets China and India
text: JPMorgan Asset Management has invested almost a quarter of its $860 million Asian infrastructure fund in China and India assets, as part of efforts to complete investments in the next two years, Reuters reported.

headline: Post-‘Pottery Barn’ Intervention
text: Today’s idea: There is an alternative to Colin Powell’s “Pottery Barn rule” — “you break it, you own it” — referring to America’s postinvasion obligations to Iraq. A security analyst proposes “repetitive raiding” as a model for future interventions.

headline: BofA Said to Eye China Expansion
text: Bank of America, the largest United States bank, plans to seek approval to expand its operations in China, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing people familiar with the situation.

headline: Neuberger to List Distressed Debt Fund, Report Says

headline: Postcard From a Guangzhou Traffic Jam

Mr. Komanoff helped shape and promote a pricing strategy in New York, where Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg sought to start charging drivers for access to Manhattan’s busiest blocks. The effort failed when it was opposed by state officials beholden to car-owning commuters. Below, you can read a “Dot Earth postcard” from Mr. Komanoff, describing his experience there (he shot the photo in a traffic jam):

On Monday the New York festival announced that among the films it had added to its lineup were new works by Edward Burns (“The Brothers McMullen”) and his wife, Christy Turlington Burns. Fortunately for the couple, the two movies won’t be in competition with each other: Mr. Burns’s film “Nice Guy Johnny,” a comedy-drama about a young man and his uncle, will play in the festival’s Encounters program; Ms. Turlington Burns’s documentary “No Woman, No Cry,” which tells stories of childbirth from around the world, will be shown in its Discovery program.

headline: The Originals | Telfar Clemens
text: A boyhood spent in Liberia seems like one of the least exotic things about the 25-year-old designer and D.J. Telfar Clemens, a minimalist who has found inspiration in the strangeness closer to home. “It was really weird — it’s like a melting pot of every different culture,” Telfar says of LeFrak City, Queens, where he was born. “My family still lives in the same apartment. The development was originally 100 percent Jewish, so there’s a lot of black and Jewish mix.” And Red Hook, Brooklyn, where he currently lives, has “kind of like an urban pirate feel,” he says. Somehow those influences come out in his designs as unisex garments made from soft jersey fabric that practically snuggle with the body. “My work is utilitarian,” he says. “Anyone can put it on, female or male, and everything is adjustable so you can tie it in a different way for a different body type.” Clemens’s signature line, as well as his diffusion range, Un.Der T, are available in downtown boutiques and will soon be sold on telfar.net. Coming up for the man who gave the world a two-piece unisex swimsuit? “I’ve always been into sportswear, but I really want to incorporate sportswear with formal wear this season.”

headline: Mancessions, Around the World
text: We’ve written before about how men have borne the brunt of the job losses in this recession in the United States. This is largely because they are more likely to be employed in industries that are sensitive to the business cycle (like manufacturing and construction). Women are more disproportionately employed in industries that generally withstand downturns better (like health care, education and government work).

headline: South by Southwest’s Location-Based Allure
text: Decoder is in Austin, Texas, at the interactive portion of South by Southwest, or SxSW as it is known to its adherents and sponsors. The broad sweep of the conference arrays over music, film, and interactive media for nine days, and right now, we are in the early days, which is mostly deep programming for digital types. We decided to share some of the weekend events in one long post, which is known as a heave in journalistic parlance, but given some of what will take place in the wee hours on Sixth Street — a bar-strewn ribbon in the middle of the city that rival New Orleans’ Bourbon Street — let’s just call it a riff that is a little on the long side.

headline: Case of the Missing Building Numbers
text: In most of this country and much of the world, buildings have numbers on them on the outside. The numbers correspond to the building’s street address. For example, the building at 100 Main Street will often have the numeral “100” affixed to it. These numbers are used to identify the building and to help people find it.

headline: When Hollywood Gets It Right
text: Since my column today uses the release of Paul Greengrass’s “Green Zone” as an occasion to complain about how Hollywood can’t seem to capture the complexities and ironies of real-world politics, it seems worthwhile to mention a few recent exceptions to this rule. This will be a short list: Stephen Frears’ “The Queen” is on it, so is Alexander Payne’s “Election” (yes, it takes place in a high school — what’s your point?), and so is the portrait of Baltimore’s mayoral politics on David Simon’s “The Wire.” (The character of Clarence Royce, the compromised incumbent, is a particularly good example of how a storyteller can be fair to a fundamentally unsympathetic figure.) David O. Russell’s great “Three Kings” doesn’t feature any politicians, but it captures the tragic ironies of our involvement in Iraq with more clarity and sensitivity than any of the movies made about the second Gulf War. Neither Oliver Stone’s “Nixon” nor Mike Nichols’ “Primary Colors” are particularly successful movies, but both make a good-faith effort to portray polarizing figures from our recent past in shades of gray, rather than just black and white. (About the rest of Stone’s forays into political subjects, the less said the better.) And one of the reasons so many people praised — and overpraised — the political themes in “The Dark Knight,” I suspect, is that even an attempt at political ambiguity (and in a superhero movie, no less) seemed impressive, given how rarely Hollywood goes in for anything save caricature.

text: Barack Obama traveled to Ohio today for a health care rally at a senior center, facing a state as well as an age group that are not especially warm toward his efforts on the issue.

headline: Taking Ownership: Correlating Individual Learning to Standards
text: Overview | Should schools across the nation share one set of academic standards for English, math and literacy in science and social studies? How would a rewriting of standards transform American education and the experience of individual students? In this lesson, students learn about academic standards and consider the proposal of new national standards. They then perform a self-assessment, correlating the proposed or existing standards to their own knowledge and skills, and develop personal learning plans to achieve greater mastery.

headline: Readers Look Up and Down at Brooklyn Development
text: Like many Brooklynites, Andrew Cotto moved to the borough because it was a destination with “actual diversity, affordable restaurants, more parking and less pretension.” He felt little remorse for leaving Manhattan behind, especially its crowded skyline.

headline: The Salman Rushdie Digital Archive
text: A video about the Salman Rushdie digital archive created by Born Digital Archive Working Group at Emory University Libraries.

headline: A Brand With Teeth
text: At one point in “A Good Year,” Ridley Scott’s unlikely adaptation of the Peter Mayle novel, the British investment tycoon Max Skinner (played by Russell Crowe) challenges the vintner on his French estate to a game of tennis. Pointing to the laurel logo on the left breast of his shirt, Skinner intones, “Fred Perry,” throwing down the frog-vs.-lobster gauntlet. His French opponent then flips his sweaty visor around to reveal a bright green crocodile logo. “René Lacoste,” he replies. Game on.

headline: Iran Plans to Execute 6 Arrested in Protests
text: Six people arrested in December protests will be put to death, Iranian authorities announced Monday, in what appeared to be strong warning to the opposition ahead of a traditional annual celebration.

headline: A Play About Darfur
text: My previous research assistant, Winter Miller, is and was a playwright. A very persistent one. She had done a fabulous job supporting my work, and she became increasingly interested in writing a play about Darfur — so she asked if she could come along on a trip to the Chad/Darfur border with me, back in 2006.

headline: Vernon Jordan Gets a Big Payday From Lazard
text: 5:01 p.m. | Updated Need another sign that Wall Street is on the upswing? Just look at the preliminary proxy that Lazard filed late Friday afternoon with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: Travel Deals: Hotel Discounts for April and Beyond
text: Marriott is offering 40 percent off at 10 resorts in the Caribbean and Mexico. Rates start as low as $89 a night at the CasaMagna Marriott Puerto Vallarta, and just $98 a night at the St. Kitts Marriott Resort. Book by March 31 for travel between April 1 and Sept. 30. Use the code LLF when making reservations at ParadiseByMarriott.com or (888) 727-2347.

headline: Story Lines to Watch: Coaches
text: Two coaches helped by their teams’ appearances in the N.C.A.A. tournament, one on the rise and one whose job security appeared to have rested on making the tournament.

headline: Farewell, Sweet Shorty; Welcome Home, Rascally Augie
text: For my husband, Arthur, and me, Shorty was The One. He was a dachshund, one of those breeds that you either get or you don’t.

headline: Added Pain When the Patient Can’t Talk
text: SCOUT usually wakes me up around 6 a.m. She licks my face or brings me her squeaky duck, taunting me to chase her with a guttural, “Arrrh, arrrh.”

headline: Urban Flight in Haiti
text: The Jan. 12 earthquake sent hundreds of thousands of Haitians back to their rural hometowns, many of which struggle to accommodate the sudden surge in population.

headline: Union Chief Warns He’ll Back Independent Candidates Against Democrats Opposed to Health Care
text: In an effort to increase pressure on Democrats to vote for the health care bill, Andy Stern, president of the Service Employees International Union, warned on Monday that his powerful union would back some independent candidates this fall against House Democrats who vote against the bill.

headline: Fund-Raisers Push Wavering Democrats on Health Care
text: A loose coalition of political fund-raisers have been reminding Democratic congressmen, many of them freshmen and still undecided over health care legislation, just what’s at stake in the battle — including, perhaps, their re-elections.

headline: It’s Not Just the Economy
text: It has been easy for the last year and a half to blame the difficult small-business environment on the financial crisis and the slow recovery. A big rebound does not seem in sight for most businesses, at least not in the near future. After looking at my business and speaking to other small-business owners, I have come to the conclusion that the problem is not just the economy but also some profound changes that have been progressing for years.

headline: Pro-Kremlin Party on Top, but Opposition Gains Seats
text: MOSCOW — The pro-Kremlin party, United Russia, has again dominated regional elections, according to preliminary results released Monday, though opposition parties have made slight gains in a vote that has been seen as a test of President Dmitri A. Medvedev’s call for greater political pluralism in Russia.

headline: Friskies Advertisement
text: In a new ad campaign, a pet goes on a fantastic journey by eating Friskies cat food.

headline: A Tough Audience in Ohio, Polls Show
text: In choosing to take his health care campaign to Ohio on Monday, President Obama was all but guaranteed to find a skeptical audience, if recent polls are any guide. But maybe that was part of the plan. Read the full story at The Caucus.

headline: Nutrition: Rise in Soda Price Linked to Better Health
text: New research provides evidence that proposed taxes on soft drinks may make young people healthier.

headline: Dolls as a Parenting Tryout
text: The health classes at my son’s high school have been walking around carrying water bottles with tennis-ball heads that are dressed in babylike outfits. It is the school’s way of showing teenagers that real infants are a responsibility for which they are not prepared; they are required to keep their “babies” with them at all times, filling out logs of how often the newborns are fed, changed and soothed back to sleep.

headline: With Twitter as the Messenger, Brisk Sales for Conan O’Brien Tour
text: Conan O’Brien has almost sold out his nationwide comedy tour — and all it took was a few Twitter messages.

headline: At South by Southwest, It’s Not Just About Location
text: The technology reporter Jenna Wortham has been covering the ins and outs of the South by Southwest music and technology conference in Austin, Tex., including an article Monday about location-based services.

headline: How I See Things Right Now
text: Hey, it’s spring break — and I’m recuperating from a very nasty cold.

headline: Obama’s C.D.C. Director, Wielding a Big Broom
text: ATLANTA — No federal health agency changed more during the Bush administration than the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. It got new buildings, new managers and an entirely new operating structure.

headline: The Rental Car Squeeze
text: Tried renting a car lately? In some cases, travelers say, the final bill is double or even triple the amount they thought they had agreed to.

headline: Delivering Nitric Oxide, in Bandages and Socks
text: Nitric oxide is a reactive gas that plays a role in many body processes. In the circulatory system, for example, it acts as a signal that promotes the relaxation of smooth muscle around blood vessels, causing them to dilate, which improves blood flow.

headline: Justice Stevens Weighs Retirement Date
text: Justice John Paul Stevens will soon decide whether he will stay on for another Supreme Court term, the justice told Jeffrey Toobin of The New Yorker.

headline: A Risk of Poisoning the Deepest Wells
text: Fertilizing the oceans with iron has been proposed as a way of fighting climate change. The idea is that iron will promote blooms of phytoplankton that will remove carbon dioxide from the atmosphere through photosynthesis. When the phytoplankton dies and sinks, the carbon will effectively be sequestered in the deep ocean.

headline: Attention, Please! This Is a Zzb Frzzkd Sxpldts!
text: With no warning, the mysterious sirens, accompanied by garbled instructions, startled the residents who live near the Columbia Street waterfront and in nearby Brooklyn neighborhoods sometime after 9 a.m. Monday.

headline: Continental Airlines to Charge for Food
text: Continental Airlines plans to end free hamburgers, barbecue and sandwich rolls for many of its passengers in favor of a food-for-sale program that mirrors what other carriers are already doing.

headline: Where a Meal Can Cost a Fortune, 99¢ Pizza Catches On
text: The signs at the corner of Ninth Avenue and West 41st Street have an unbelievable, you-gotta-be-kidding quality, like free beer or affordable housing — 99¢ Fresh Pizza. Like many things in New York City, they are also too good to be true. They are off by a penny, as one slice actually costs one dollar.

headline: ‘Shortest Railway’ Reopens, 9 Years After Fatal Accident
text: A downtown Los Angeles funicular rail line that shut down nine years ago after a deadly accident resumed service Monday with modern braking technology.

headline: Scientists Defend Climate Panel and Seek Changes
text: Letter-signing campaigns are not necessarily an effective way to shift attitudes on scientific institutions like the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, given that any entrenched camp in the climate policy fight can pull together heaps of signatures from people with PhDs.

headline: The Science Behind a Supersonic Jump
text: Felix Baumgartner will face known and unknown risks when he attempts to break the sound barrier in a jump from inner space later this year.

headline: Mental Melodies
text: Q. Why do I find some of the melodic themes “playing” in my mind for several days after a concert?

headline: When the Only Hope Is a Peaceful Ending
text: This is a very personal story of living gracefully with a fatal diagnosis. When I wrote “Jane Brody’s Guide to the Great Beyond,” I had no idea that I’d be putting its precepts into practice in my immediate family within a year of publication. But as I said in the book, “You never know.” You never know when your time will be up, and so it is best to prepare for the end sooner rather than later.

headline: German Priest in Church Abuse Case Is Suspended
text: MUNICH — The priest at the center of a German sexual-abuse scandal that has embroiled Pope Benedict XVI continued working with children for more than 30 years, even though a German court convicted him of molesting boys.

headline: A Fatal Diagnosis, Followed by Goodbyes
text: In Tuesday’s Science Times, Personal Health columnist Jane Brody writes about her husband’s final days with Stage 4 lung cancer. She begins:

headline: Obama in Ohio to Push Health Care Plan
text: At the opening of what promises to be a week of intense politicking, President Obama arrived in Ohio to declare that “every argument has been made” on his proposed health care overhaul and that it was time for its passage by Congress. Doug Mills of The Times caught the quiet scene(s) on the tarmac at Cleveland-Hopkins International Airport shortly before Mr. Obama’s appearance at a boisterous gathering in Strongsville.

headline: Recalling the Craze for a Game of Chance
text: WOODY ALLEN joked in “Annie Hall” that after he was thrown out of New York University for cheating on a metaphysics final, his mother, a “high-strung woman, locked herself in the bathroom and took an overdose of mah-jongg tiles.”

headline: The Highest Parachute Jump Ever
text: John Tierney of The Times discusses "Fearless Felix," who has jumped off the world's tallest building and is now attempting to break the speed of sound.

headline: For Obese People, Prejudice in Plain Sight
text: As a woman whose height and weight put me in the obese category on the body-mass-index chart, I cringed when Michelle Obama recently spoke of putting her daughters on a diet. While I’m sure the first lady’s intentions are good, I’m also sure that her comments about childhood obesity will add yet another layer to the stigma of being overweight in America.

headline: ABE, Pioneering Robotic Undersea Explorer, Is Dead at 16
text: ABE, a nomadic adventurer that plumbed the world’s oceans on its own, forever changing the way scientists explored the seafloor, was lost at sea March 5 off southern Chile. The autonomous underwater vehicle was about 16 years old and in the off-seasons was stored in Woods Hole, Mass.

headline: Growing Up With an Excess of Mothers Is Liable to Give a Boy a Complex
text: Lisa Grunwald’s Henry House is a Garp of a guy, a male child raised in and warped by a quirky, intensely female domestic situation. Born in 1946 and then placed in an orphanage, he becomes the darling of a college home- economics department at a time when baby wrangling is that department’s primary concern.

headline: Now Showing | Mumbai Fashion Week
text: In America, critics regularly lament the Faustian bargain magazines and designers have entered into with Hollywood, whereby celebrities are used to boost both image and sales in exchange for free clothes and steep fees. But in India, where Bollywood is the most significant cultural force, fashion has to kowtow to celebrity on a regular basis in order to exist at all.

headline: Why Phillips-Van Heusen Is Buying Tommy Hilfiger
text: The Monday announcement of Phillips-Van Heusen‘s $3 billion deal for Tommy Hilfiger puts to rest weeks of speculation that the two clothing companies were in deal talks.

headline: It Ain’t Pretty No More: See Paul Schrader’s Outline for ‘Raging Bull’
text: Once Robert De Niro gave his career-spanning collection of papers and artifacts to posterity, it was only a matter of time before the filmmaker Paul Schrader, his screenwriter on “Raging Bull” and “Taxi Driver,” got into the ring, too.

headline: Twitter to Offer Service That Ties Into Other Sites
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — Twitter is aiming to expand its reach on the Web.

headline: Cleanup Begins in Storm’s Wake
text: On the wall of a windowless auditorium in Manhattan, color-coded maps of the New York region filled two large screens, showing the Consolidated Edison customers who did not have electricity.

headline: In Tight Times, Revisiting Discretionary Spending
text: ALBANY — It is as regular as swallows returning to Capistrano: Every year, no matter how large the state’s deficit or how steep the cuts to critical government services, the Legislature dishes itself a healthy serving of pork. Tens of millions of dollars in earmarked state grants go to favored nonprofits, museums, cultural organizations and Little Leagues, with each check credited to the lawmaker or lawmakers who arrange it.

headline: Seamlessly Wedding Cuban Rhythm to American Jazz
text: Bobby Carcassés is a singer, trumpeter, pianist, conguero and connector in Cuban jazz. As a bandleader, big-band sideman and a founder of the first jazz festival in Cuba, in 1980, he’s spent his career attending to the equal relationship between the guaguancó-rumba-guaracha spectrum and the swing-jazz-blues spectrum.

headline: Alcohol Cited in 2008 Russian Crash
text: MOSCOW — A pilot’s drunkenness was a contributing cause of a commercial airline crash in Russia in 2008, Russian prosecutors said Monday, reaching a conclusion extraordinarily rare in airline crash investigations.

headline: Tree That Survived 9/11 Absorbs Another Blow
text: It was yards from the World Trade Center on Sept. 11, 2001. Against all odds, it survived.

headline: In Cancer Fight, Teenagers Don’t Fit In
text: Simone Weinstein’s ordeal with cancer started in the most banal way: she was tired. She had a hard time getting up in the morning, and did not even have the energy to hang out with her friends.

headline: The Stigma of Being ‘Fat’
text: In Tuesday’s Science Times, Harriet Brown discusses how, in a time of public acceptance and tolerance of differences, the stigma of being obese may be at an all-time high:

headline: Death of the Bookplate?
text: Forget the death of the book. It turns out we have an even bigger problem: the death of the bookplate.

headline: Procter Goes Greener With ‘Friendly’ Persuasion
text: The consumer products giant Procter & Gamble is bringing a sustainability initiative to the United States that takes a different tack from those introduced by competitors like Clorox and S.C. Johnson.

headline: Ex-Chief of Park Ave. Bank Charged With Bailout Fraud
text: A former president of the Park Avenue Bank in Manhattan was charged on Monday with fraud, embezzlement and bribery in what the authorities called the first criminal case of trying to defraud the federal government’s bank bailout program, Benjamin Weiser and Eric Dash report in The New York Times.

headline: With Cancer, Let’s Face It: Words Are Inadequate
text: We’re all familiar with sentences like this one: Mr. Smith died yesterday after a long battle with cancer. We think we know what it means, but we read it and hear it so often that it carries little weight, bears no meaning. It’s one of the clichés of cancer.

text: To the Editor:

text: To the Editor:
