headline: High-Speed Rail Gains Traction in Spain
text: ABOARD THE AVE — Carlos Martínez and his colleagues were enjoying soda and sandwiches in the bar, having chosen not to watch a film —  “Appaloosa,”  with Ed Harris — that was playing on overhead screens. They barely seemed to notice the arid landscape whizzing by or the digital display reflecting their speed, which hovered around 186 miles per hour.

headline: Critics’ Picks Video: ‘The Friends of Eddie Coyle’
text: A. O. Scott looks back at Peter Yates‘s 1973 film “The Friends of Eddie Coyle,” starring Robert Mitchum as the title character, a down-on-his-luck, small-time gun dealer in Boston. Mr. Scott calls the film, based on George V. Higgins’s novel, a “lost classic of the 1970s.”

headline: Drug Helps Diabetics, Trial Finds
text: An inexpensive, generic anti-inflammatory drug from the aspirin family helped patients in a clinical trial manage their Type 2 diabetes and lower their blood sugar, adding to evidence that inflammation plays a role in diabetes, and possibly pointing to new therapeutic approaches to the disease.

headline: Classical Azeri Poetry in Song, From a Team of Father and Daughter
text: The words Alim Qasimov sang on Friday night at Asia Society were nearly five centuries old, written by a poet from Baghdad, Muhammad Fuzuli, who proclaimed, “Let my miserable heart burn in the fire of love.” The poetry’s longing, pain and spiritual seeking became raw and immediate, arriving in bursts of improvisation that made every phrase leap out.

headline: ‘The Happiness Stuff’ That Makes Embraceable Music Irreplaceable
text: You don’t have to be depressing to be deep. The upside-down notion that happy, energetic music may be more profound than Mahleresque harmonic gloom is suggested by a scene from Walter Rimler’s 2009 biography, “George Gershwin: An Intimate Portrait (Music in American Life),” quoted by the piano man Mark Nadler in “Gershwin ... Here to Stay,” the wonderfully buoyant tribute he is performing with K T Sullivan at the Oak Room of the Algonquin Hotel.

headline: A New Leader for Cinema Industry
text: ShoWest, the annual convention and trade show for those in the movie theater business, is renaming itself CinemaCon, Variety reported on Monday. This year’s convention began on Monday in Las Vegas and runs through Thursday. The gathering customarily includes film previews and briefings on the state of the movie industry. Dan Glickman, who is leaving his post as chairman and chief executive of the Motion Picture Association of America, is expected to recap his tenure with the trade association on Tuesday, Variety reported. Mr. Glickman has been replaced on an interim basis by Bob Pisano, who has been the association’s president.

headline: House Budget Committee Approves a Reconciliation Bill
text: By a vote of 21 to 16, the House Budget Committee on Monday advanced a budget reconciliation bill to the next stage of the legislative process.

headline: Despite Improvements, Lack of Access to Toilets Still Presents Health Risks
text: Open defecation — which the World Health Organization describes as “the riskiest sanitation practice of all” — is on the decline in many countries, according to a report released Monday by the W.H.O. and Unicef.

headline: A Supersonic Jump, From 23 Miles in the Air
text: Ordinarily, Felix Baumgartner would not need a lot of practice in the science of falling.

headline: French Award Painful for Actress
text: While Frédéric Mitterrand, the French culture minister, was accidentally stabbing Marion Cotillard at an awards ceremony in Paris, above, Tim Burton took a stab at American cultural sensibilities on Monday. When Mr. Mitterrand presented Ms. Cotillard, the Academy Award-winning star of “La Vie en Rose” and “Nine,” with a pin making her a chevalier in the Order of the Arts and Letters, he mistakenly stuck it too far through her blouse. Agence France-Presse reported that Ms. Cotillard winced and “almost fell off her silver stilettos,” but Mr. Mitterrand offered her an arm for support. (She is expected to make a full recovery.) Mr. Burton, whose film “Alice in Wonderland” opens in France next week, was similarly honored  without injury  and said in his acceptance remarks that he had “always felt a very special place here in my heart for France.” Mr. Burton added: “I always felt the French were looking for the poetry, looking for the meaning, looking for the things that I was trying to do. That’s something that doesn’t really happen in America.”

headline: Carstanjen: Champ. Trump: ALSO-RAN.
text: A Sunday night matchup of reality-show executives was hardly a horse race as an expletive-tossing Donald Trump was whipped by Bill Carstanjen, the chief operating officer of Churchill Downs. According to Nielsen’s estimates an episode of the CBS series “Undercover Boss” featuring Mr. Carstanjen drew 13.3 million viewers, making it the most watched program of the night and beating the season premiere of “The Celebrity Apprentice” (8.3 million), the Donald’s long-running NBC show. CBS won the night over all with a lineup rounded out by “60 Minutes” (11.7 million), “The Amazing Race” (10.2 million) and “Cold Case” (10.2 million). ABC was runner-up with programs that included “Desperate Housewives” (11.8 million). NBC was third, getting a so-so start from its new game show “Minute to Win It”; its debut drew 4.6 million viewers and a second episode was watched by 7.2 million. On fourth-place Fox, the premiere of “Sons of Tucson” (4.5 million) had an even worse showing.

headline: Shakespeare Canon: New Ammunition?
text: An assertion by a professor at the University of Nottingham in England that he has found proof that a play from the 1700s includes reworked material of Shakespeare’s has gained a qualified endorsement from the Arden Shakespeare, a scholarly anthology of his work. The university said on Monday that a new edition of the play, “Double Falsehood, or the Distressed Lovers” by Lewis Theobald, an 18th-century scholar and Shakespeare editor, would be published on March 22 as part of Arden’s Third Series of Shakespeare’s works. Theobald had said the play was based on three lost Shakespeare texts, a contentious claim that may now be backed up by the work of Brean Hammond, a professor of modern English literature at Nottingham. In his book, also called “Double Falsehood,” Mr. Hammond says he has found evidence linking that play to “Cardenio,” a lost collaboration between Shakespeare and John Fletcher that was performed in 1613. Richard Proudfoot, general editor of the Arden Shakespeare, said in a statement that “the inclusion of ‘Double Falsehood’ is our most controversial decision.” He added, “That it represents in some form the otherwise lost play of ‘Cardenio,’ by Fletcher and Shakespeare, is a sufficiently sustainable position to recommend publication in Arden 3 of Lewis Theobald’s avowedly thorough 18th-century adaptation, thus making it accessible for the first time in 250 years.”

headline: TriBeCa Film Festival Rounds Out Schedule
text: The Tribeca Film Festival announced on Monday that among the films it had added to its lineup were new works: one by Edward Burns (“The Brothers McMullen”) and another by Christy Turlington Burns, his wife, left. Fortunately for the couple the two movies won’t be competing against each other. Mr. Burns’s film “Nice Guy Johnny,” a comedy-drama about a young man and his uncle, will play in the festival’s Encounters program; Ms. Turlington Burns’s documentary, “No Woman, No Cry,” which tells stories of childbirth from around the world, will be shown in its Discovery program. Other films the festival announced on Monday include “Last Play at Shea,” a documentary about Billy Joel, the New York Mets and the final season of Shea Stadium in Queens; “My Trip to Al Qaeda,” a documentary by Alex Gibney (“Taxi to the Dark Side”), based on Lawrence Wright’s one-man play of the same title; and “Visionaries,” a documentary by Chuck Workman on the history of avant-garde cinema. This year’s Tribeca Film Festival runs from April 21 through May 2.

headline: Bordeaux Uncorked
text: One of France’s most traditional cities, Bordeaux is loosening up, with an infrastructural face-lift and experimental new restaurants and boutiques.

headline: High School Reunion’s Fake Marine Is Sentenced
text: The man who attended the reunion of the Alhambra High School class of 1988 had not seemed the military type, but arrived at a reunion celebration with the uniform and decorations of a Marine officer, as we described in the Bay Area blog last November.

headline: SXSW: Going to the Movies and Hopefully Getting In
text: Reports from the South by Southwest film festival.

headline: Comics Collectible Acquired, and Savings Depleted, in a Flash
text: Superman and Batman have helped form our images of the ideal hero, so it makes sense that copies of the comic books in which they made their first appearances sold for record prices. Action Comics No. 1, where Superman made his debut, went for a cool $1 million, while Detective Comics No. 27, which featured the first adventure of Batman, went for $1.07 million.

headline: A Souvenir of Caesar’s Killing
text: If you’re the man who organized the assassination of Julius Caesar, your enduring rewards include delivering a funeral oration in a Shakespeare play, a portrayal on Broadway by Denzel Washington and a place in the mouth of Satan (according to Dante’s “Inferno,” anyway). If you merely took part in the murder, at least you got a nice souvenir. On Monday  the Ides of March, naturally  the British Museum in London put on display a gold coin given to one of Caesar’s assassins that may have been worn as a memento by the boastful killer, The Guardian reported. The coin, above, which was struck soon after Caesar’s murder in 44 B.C., depicts on one side the head of Brutus, and on the other, two daggers and the hat of a freeman, a symbol of the conspirators’ belief in the Roman republic instead of the tyranny that Caesar represented to them. The Guardian said that about 60 silver versions of the coin survive, but only 2 gold ones were believed to still exist  one of which is now believed by experts to be a fake.

headline: Lawman Returns to Kentucky, Facing Bad Guys and Skeletons
text: “Justified” opens with a clever piece of misdirection. At first, all we can see is the big Stetson hat of Raylan Givens, the United States marshal played by Timothy Olyphant, as he climbs some stairs. It seems to promise a Western setting  a Texas street or a Utah canyon. But as he reaches the top step, palm trees come into view, and then cabanas, and then the rooftop pool of a Miami Beach hotel. The only cowboys here are of the cocaine variety.

headline: Southern Women, Mostly Older but Not Wiser
text: You’ve got pickup trucks, big hair and church services where worshipers speak in tongues. So what is a reference to Herman Wouk’s “Marjorie Morningstar” (nice prewar Jewish girl from Central Park West) doing here, against a backdrop of a map of the Carolinas?

headline: A New Source for Student Loans
text: President Obama’s plan to have the government provide loans directly to students instead of using commercial lenders was resurrected on Thursday, when Democratic leaders agreed to bundle it into an expedited budget package along with the health care overhaul. Now, the student loan measure, which had been unlikely to pass on its own, could be passed in the Senate along with the health care measure by a simple majority vote.

headline: Portraits, Snapshots and Even a Play
text: Gwen Welliver, Daniel Charon and Nancy Bannon each danced with Doug Varone’s company for more than 10 years. But their own work, as seen in a program organized by Mr. Varone at the 92nd Street Y on Friday night, reveals startlingly disparate styles and influences. So different, in fact, that Ms. Bannon’s piece was a play rather than a dance.

headline: Charles Moore Dies; Depicted Rights Battles
text: The photographs are still shocking.

headline: Culture of Past Eras: Dance, Chant and Song That Span the Centuries
text: As pretexts so often do, this one quickly wore thin. Early Music Exposed, a daylong festival at the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Saturday, ostensibly celebrated the reopening of the André Mertens Galleries for Musical Instruments after an eight-month closing and what the museum calls a refreshed presentation of the Western instrument collection.

headline: C-Span Puts Full Archives on the Web
text: WASHINGTON  Researchers, political satirists and partisan mudslingers, take note: C-Span has uploaded virtually every minute of its video archives to the Internet.

headline: New Signature Theater, Close to the Old
text: It is a far cry from the freestanding performing arts center, designed by Frank Gehry, that was supposed to be the Signature Theater Company’s new home at ground zero and that was expected to cost $700 million.

headline: Anti-Abortion Group Targets House Democrats
text: Americans United for Life, an anti-abortion group, is planning a major print advertising campaign to pressure rank-and-file House members to vote against the Democrats’ big health care legislation unless it includes tighter restrictions on insurance coverage for abortions.

headline: A Chance to Listen to the Future at the Met
text: The Grand Finals Concert of the Metropolitan Opera’s National Council Auditions, the most prestigious voice competition in North America, has drawn the attention of company managers, artist representatives and opera insiders for more than 50 years. For the voice buffs in the audience, it is always fascinating to hear the young finalists and try to sort out, along with the panel of judges, who among them will be the stars of tomorrow.

headline: Dreams Die Hard, Even in Palookaville
text: “Happy in the Poorhouse” is a big, sloppy kiss of a family drama delivered with the warmth and gusto of an overly affectionate aunt.

headline: Special Cover
text: If you think back to the New York fall shows, ages ago, the main coat story was some combination of wool and fur. In Europe, we became aware of volume and texture (the scale of collars at Burberry and Prada, the sweep of the great coats at MaxMara, the smooth cap of the hooded fur vests at Rick Owens, the fuzzy fakes at Chanel). Jean Paul Gaultier made a good show of classic tailoring at Hermès; Phoebe Philo zeroed in on the high collar at Céline.

headline: One on One Interviews: Who Should Be Next?
text: Over the last two months, I’ve been interviewing various people in technology for a series called “One on One.” The posts have included the following technology mavens:

headline: Sands Resort Complex to Open in Singapore
text: Singapore isn’t exactly lacking for high-end lodging, but the Las Vegas Sands hopes to top them all with its new Marina Bay Sands Resort, which features a dizzying array of luxury offerings.

headline: Fending Off Digital Decay, Bit by Bit
text: Among the archival material from Salman Rushdie currently on display at Emory University in Atlanta are inked book covers, handwritten journals and four Apple computers (one ruined by a spilled Coke). The 18 gigabytes of data they contain seemed to promise future biographers and literary scholars a digital wonderland: comprehensive, organized and searchable files, quickly accessible with a few clicks.

headline: Supportive, Loving Band of Bigots
text: “Kiss Bessemer Goodbye” sounds at first like a bittersweet story of parental love and the necessity of letting go. But there’s something ugly going on in this likable if shaky one-act, Repertorio Español’s newest production.

headline: A Host of Mummies, a Forest of Secrets
text: In the middle of a terrifying desert north of Tibet, Chinese archaeologists have excavated an extraordinary cemetery. Its inhabitants died almost 4,000 years ago, yet their bodies have been well preserved by the dry air.

headline: Pelosi: It’s Not About Abortion or Immigration
text: House Speaker Nancy Pelosi held a news conference with children’s advocates at the Capitol on Monday to push for the Democrats’ sweeping health care legislation.

headline: A Different Kind of Housing Puzzle
text: OK, I’m still evaluating the Dodd proposal for financial reform. But here’s my puzzle: the bill, as I understand it, calls for an independent Consumer Protection Agency, with a director directly appointed by the president, but one that is “housed” at the Fed.

headline: Why Make the Longest Jump?
text: Should Felix Baumgartner take a supersonic jump from a helium balloon 23 miles above the Earth? lf so, why?

headline: Curveball
text: I never thought of it that way: Ryan Avent says that my advocacy of a get-tough approach to the renminbi is just like the Bush administration’s push for war with Iraq.

headline: For Cooler Chips, Follow the Grooves
text: For electronics engineers who want to make faster chips, heat is a big hurdle. More calculations mean more electrons moving through semiconductor material, which generates more heat.

headline: Corporate Debt Coming Due May Squeeze Credit
text: When the Mayans envisioned the world coming to an end in 2012 — at least in the Hollywood telling — they didn’t count junk bonds among the perils that would lead to worldwide disaster.

headline: Life’s Journeys, a Lot Less Mysterious
text: I AM 11.6 miles from my destination, otherwise known as a lamp repair store, and according to the Maps app on my iPhone, it should take me 15 minutes to drive there.

headline: Correction: Tuscany Without the Crowds
text: The cover article on March 7, about Tuscany in winter, misidentified the type of fruit that was seen on the bare branches of trees in the garden at La Foce, a 15th-century villa there. They were persimmons, not oranges.

headline: Correction: Buenos Aires for Those Who Shun Steaks
text: An article on March 7 about vegetarian restaurants in Buenos Aires misidentified the neighborhood in which the restaurant Kensho is located. It is in Villa Ortúzar, not Boedo.

headline: Europe Creates an Apparatus to Provide Loans to Greece
text: BRUSSELS — Finance ministers from the 16 countries using the euro as their currency said Monday they were ready to help rescue Greece.

headline: Readers’ Tips for Home Appliance Use
text: What follows is a sampling of e-mail messages written in response to Alina Tugend’s Shortcuts column on Saturday, which offered some tips on the proper use of home appliances like washing machines and dishwashers. The No. 1 tip, from repair people and appliance experts, was to use less soap.

headline: Answers Begin to Emerge on How Thalidomide Caused Defects
text: The word “phocomelia” means seal limb. It describes an extremely rare condition in which babies are born with limbs that look like flippers.

headline: The Vast World of the Tiny, Arranged From A to Z
text: “The minuscule, a narrow gate, opens up an entire world.” This is both Hugh Raffles’s epigraph and the last line of his miraculous book “Insectopedia,” as inventive and wide ranging and full of astonishing surprises as the vast insect world itself.

headline: What We’re Reading: Facebook vs. Google, BlackBerry vs. iPhone
text: If the Internet is like a box of chocolates, here are the nougats and creams that the technology reporters and the editors of The New York Times have been eating on Monday:

headline: Indian Cabinet Backs Foreign Schools
text: MUMBAI, India — The Indian cabinet approved a bill on Monday that would allow foreign universities to set up campuses in the country, a major break with a previous policy in which outside institutions were seen as a threat to the education system.

headline: Twitter Keynote Gets Thumbs-Down — on Twitter
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — A keynote interview with Evan Williams, Twitter‘s chief executive, created a stir during the South by Southwest Interactive conference here on Monday — but it may not have been what conference organizers had in mind.

headline: Q. and A. on Church Sex Abuse Scandal
text: With a sexual abuse scandal once again testing the Roman Catholic Church — this time raising questions about Pope Benedict XVI’s handling of the matter — reporters for The Times are answering readers’ questions about the developments.

headline: Lehman Estate Proposes Reorganization Plan
text: The bankruptcy estate of Lehman Brothers on Monday proposed an initial reorganization plan that would lift the remains of the investment bank out of Chapter 11.

headline: Rebelling Against the Commonly Evasive Feminine Care Ad
text: A COMMERCIAL for U by Kotex, a new line from the 90-year-old feminine care brand, opens with an actress in her early 20s who says, “How do I feel about my period? I love it.”

headline: Pragmatism’s Gift
text: “Pragmatic” is a compliment sometimes paid to politicians (Barack Obama’s supporters describe him that way), and it is often used as an honorific indicating a person of common sense who knows how to get things done. “Pragmatic” is also related (at least etymologically) to pragmatism, the name of a distinctively American philosophy that emerged in the early decades of the 20th century in the work of William James, John Dewey and C.S. Peirce. Pragmatism may or may not be an ethical program depending on whose version you are reading, but it always emphasizes the resources of historically given institutions and practices and de-emphasizes the role played in our lives by supra-historical essentialisms (God, faith, truth, reason, brute fact, overarching theory) even to the extent sometimes of denying their existence.

headline: Owe Someone Money? Just Bump Your Phones
text: People have predicted the death of cash and checks for a long time. But there are certain transactions — like paying a friend back for dinner or buying vegetables at the farmers’ market — for which they remain essential.

headline: UConn Women Are Good for the Game
text: It has become fashionable to say that Connecticut’s 72-game winning streak is bad for women’s basketball, as if greatness can be as choking and stifling as weeds.

headline: Rebuilt Synagogue Is Caught in Disputes Over Jerusalem
text: JERUSALEM — In what appeared to be a case of unfortunate timing, Israel officially inaugurated a rebuilt synagogue in Jerusalem’s Old City on Monday, entangling what was intended to be a festive cultural event with the diplomatic row over new Israeli construction in the contested territory.

headline: An Insistence on Safety in Filling Exit-Row Seats
text: LIKE most business travelers, Richard M. Owens has occasionally sat in an exit-row seat on an airplane and wondered what he would do in a real emergency. He got to find out, he told me, on a harrowing approach into Miami about five years ago.

headline: Medicaid Patients Left in the Lurch
text: The community of Flint, Mich., already reeling from unemployment, is now suffering the effects of state cuts to Medicaid, the government insurance program for the poor and disabled.

headline: ‘Visionary’ Was Forgotten, but Not by One Devotee
text: Things don’t get done easily in New York. Don’t plan, for example, on catching a train at Moynihan Station anytime soon. That replacement for the sepulchral Pennsylvania Station has been discussed for a couple of decades, but talk trumps action. Plenty of other examples of inertia could be cited. Choose your favorite.

headline: Goal at Deutsche Telekom: More Women as Managers
text: Deutsche Telekom, Europe’s largest telecommunications company, said Monday that it would more than double the number of women who are managers within five years, becoming the first member of the DAX 30 index of blue-chip German companies to introduce gender quotas.

headline: Bit by Bit, Coming to Terms With His Elfin Self
text: YONKERS

headline: Key New York Suit Calls Public Defender Programs Inadequate
text: A class-action suit to be argued next week in New York’s highest court has become a test of a national strategy by civil liberties groups to challenge what they say are failed public defender programs in many states.

headline: A Superorganized Traveler Who Once Forgot Something
text: I’M usually an impeccable business traveler.

headline: Defendants Fresh From War Find Service Counts in Court
text: CHARLESTON, W.Va. — When Judge Robert C. Chambers handed down Timothy Oldani’s federal sentence for selling stolen military equipment on eBay, he gave the former Marine a break.

headline: Cleaning a Canal, but Not Writing About It
text: Christos Tsiamis, 59, grew up in the Greek port city of Patras and spent his summers swimming in the Ionian Sea. These days, Mr. Tsiamis’s attention is consumed by a less alluring body of water: the Gowanus Canal, which this month was designated a Superfund site. Mr. Tsiamis, a 22-year veteran of the Environmental Protection Agency, is the project manager charged with determining just how contaminated the Gowanus is, and how best to clean it up. A chemical engineer with a master’s degree from Columbia University, Mr. Tsiamis, who splits his time between Manhattan and Eastchester, N.Y., is also a poet who has published four books of poetry in his native tongue.

headline: A Perpetual Urban Problem: Buildings Without Numbers
text: In most of this country and much of the world, buildings have numbers on the outside. The numbers correspond to the building’s street address, and are used to identify the building and help people find it.

headline: Ethiopia: Opposition Criticizes Verdict in Killing
text: A leader of Ethiopia’s opposition alliance on Monday criticized a court verdict in the stabbing death of an opposition parliamentary candidate, accusing the ruling party of intimidating a key witness. The candidate, Aregawi Gebre-Yohannes, was killed March 2 at his restaurant in the Tigray region. The opposition said the candidate was killed by supporters of the ruling party. The killer, Tsegie Berhane, was sentenced last week to 15 years in prison, said Shimeles Kemal, a government spokesman. Mr. Tsegie was granted leniency because he had confessed, Mr. Shimeles said, adding that the accused was not a member of a party. “It was an arranged and orchestrated court,” said Gebru Asrat, a leader of the Arena party, part of the opposition alliance. He said witnesses who testified had been “involved in the killing.”

headline: Moody’s Says U.S. Debt Could Test Triple-A Rating
text: The gold-plated credit rating of the United States — an article of faith across America and, indeed, around the world — may be at risk in coming years as the nation copes with its growing debts.

headline: The Health Care Letdown
text: Washington

headline: Student Is Accused of Stealing and Selling Valuable Historic Letters
text: William John Scott is a freshman at Drew University. He studies political science. He plays defense on the lacrosse team. He describes himself on Facebook as a night person who likes to party.

headline: Chile Braces for a Major Economic Slowdown
text: TALCAHUANO, Chile — Just a few weeks ago, some 2,000 fishermen who ply the waters of this port city for sardines and mackerel were busy mending their nets and testing their rigs in preparation for the start of the four-month fishing season.

headline: Ex-Chief of Park Avenue Bank Charged With Bailout Fraud
text: A former president of the Park Avenue Bank in Manhattan was charged on Monday with fraud, embezzlement and bribery in what the authorities called the first criminal case of trying to defraud the federal government’s bank bailout program.

headline: Array of Hurdles Awaits New Education Agenda
text: In the blueprint for overhauling federal education policy that President Obama sent to Congress on Monday, his administration seeks to confront some of the major educational challenges that have developed during the eight years that President George W. Bush’s No Child Left Behind law has been a powerful influence on the nation’s public schools.

headline: U.S. Is Reining In Special Operations Forces in Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Gen. Stanley A. McChrystal, the top American commander in Afghanistan, has brought most American Special Operations forces under his direct control for the first time, out of concern over continued civilian casualties and disorganization among units in the field.

headline: Altogether Ooky
text: Charles Addams, "in his mischief," writes Edward Rothstein, "makes the illicit an enchanting, almost whimsical aspect of daily life; we descend into his realm with the same half grin as that doomed office worker, our darker natures finding pleasure in allusions to misery. We enter a world so perverse even wind-up toys commit suicide, bitter matrons ask in department stores to be directed to 'blunt instruments,' and beams of light bearing divine illumination stream from the heavens only to shine on television antennas." That enchantment clearly resonates today. A musical comedy on Broadway about the Addams family's escapades is in previews, the Museum of the City of New York has a major collection of Addams drawings on display and a book "The Addams Family: An Evilution" has been released. Tonight find out more about the man behind Morticia, Gomez, Uncle Fester, Lurch and the others when Kevin Miserocchi, the executive director of the Tee and Charles Addams Foundation and the author of the book, discusses his work at the Museum of the City of New York.

headline: Sing Into Spring
text: "Singers reign at Dizzy's Club Coca-Cola this month and next, appearing with first-rate backing bands," writes Nate Chinen. Tonight, Barbara Carroll kicks off Jazz at Lincoln Center's Sing Into Spring Festival, "practicing her brand of literate jazz cabaret with help from the clarinetist and tenor saxophonist Ken Peplowski, the bassist Jay Leonhart and the drummer Alvin Atkinson." Ms. Carroll performs through March 21; the festival runs through May 2.

headline: Performance Art in Times Square
text: You're going to the Marina Abramovic retrospective, "The Artist is Present," at the Museum of Modern Art and you still don't know who Ulay is? Get up to speed on the German-born performance artist who influenced and collaborated with Ms. Abramovic. Creative Time is presenting three of her films on MTV's huge outdoor screen in Times Square from March 14 to April 14. The first two films, "Light/Dark" (1977) and "Rest Energy" (1980) feature Ulay, Ms. Abramovic's former lover. In the first film, the two kneel opposite each other and then take turns slapping each other at a quickening pace; in the second, they stand opposite each other and "slowly lean apart until they are held only by the tension of a loaded bow that is held between them  its arrow pointed directly at Ms. Abramovic's heart." The final film, "Dissolution," (1997) shows Ms. Abramovic whipping her own back. Watch the films and then go see the artist herself in the flesh.

headline: The Spirit of Sympathy
text: Human beings, the philosophers tell us, are social animals. We emerge into the world ready to connect with mom and dad. We go through life jibbering and jabbering with each other, grouping and regrouping. When you get a crowd of people in a room, the problem is not getting them to talk to each other; the problem is getting them to shut up.

headline: As Medicaid Payments Shrink, Patients Are Abandoned
text: FLINT, Mich. — Carol Y. Vliet’s cancer returned with a fury last summer, the tumors metastasizing to her brain, liver, kidneys and throat.

headline: Residents Grapple With Storm Damage
text: A vicious weekend storm that tore through the metropolitan area left flooding and fallen trees in its wake.

headline: Rodriguez Puts on His Glasses, and Mets Like What They See
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — The Mets had no shortage of injuries last year, including wounded hips, elbows and knees.

headline: Triumph for Drug to Straighten Clenched Fingers
text: It took half a century. But a tiny drug maker on Long Island has finally found a potentially lucrative use for its only medicine: straightening clenched fingers. And, if research proves successful, treating a condition that causes bent penises.

headline: Bringing Movement Back to Clenched Hands
text: As her fingers began curling toward her palm, Karen Mercaldo lost the ability to play the piano, knit and paint. She would poke herself in the eye when washing her face. She could not even wear her wedding ring.

headline: Mexico Is Warned on Drug Detector
text: MEXICO CITY—The British government has notified Mexico that a handheld device widely used by the Mexican military and police to search for drugs and explosives may be ineffective, British officials said.

headline: Race for Monserrate’s Old Senate Seat Winds Down
text: During a forum in Jackson Heights, Queens, last Thursday, candidates for a vacant State Senate seat were given a chance to question one another. One of them, Hiram Monserrate, addressed his leading opponent, José R. Peralta, as “José.” Mr. Peralta addressed him as “Mr. Monserrate.”

headline: Jets’ Ryan Tries to Flatten a Persistent Opponent
text: Rex Ryan was screaming at the official from the sideline. His prospective surgeon was watching on television, afraid he would lose a patient before he could help him.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: March 15, 2010

headline: Mistress of Edwards Ends Silence on Affair
text: WASHINGTON — In an interview with GQ magazine, Rielle Hunter talks publicly for the first time about her relationship with former Senator John Edwards, which began during his presidential campaign.

headline: The Days After
text: The latest election results in Iraq point to a heated and possibly lengthy power struggle between the Shiite coalition led by Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki and the rival secular slate led by Ayad Allawi.

headline: Michael Jackson Estate Signs Deal With Sony
text: Nine months after Michael Jackson’s death, his estate has signed one of the biggest recording contracts in history, giving Sony, Mr. Jackson’s longtime label, the rights to sell his back catalog and draw on a large vault of unheard recordings.

headline: In Ireland, a Hearing on a Plot to Kill a Swedish Cartoonist
text: WATERFORD, Ireland — A late-night court hearing Monday in this quiet Irish town gave new glimpses into the case that American and Irish prosecutors are pursuing against a group of Muslims on both sides of the Atlantic suspected of plotting to kill a Swedish cartoonist who depicted the Prophet Muhammad atop the body of a dog.

headline: Bloggingheads: Death Optional
text: Mike Treder, left, of the Institute for Ethics and Emerging Technologies and Massimo Pigliucci of Lehman College debate radical life extension.

headline: Not Happy to Simply Be There
text: Jon Jaques is a senior on the Cornell basketball team, which is seeded 12th in the East Region and will face No. 5 Temple on Friday in Jacksonville, Fla. Jon has been blogging for The Quad throughout this season. You can also follow him on Twitter.

headline: Charges and Countercharges of Financial Misdeeds Rile Union’s Leadership
text: At first, it seemed like a straightforward matter. Jim McLaughlin, who had led the operating engineers’ union local in Southern California for 17 years, was reviewing some expense accounts and grew convinced that his local’s apprenticeship coordinator had charged more than $2,000 in improper expenses to the apprenticeship program.

headline: At Lehman, Watchdogs Saw It All
text: Almost two years ago to the day, a team of officials from the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Federal Reserve Bank of New York quietly moved into the headquarters of Lehman Brothers. They were provided desks, phones, computers — and access to all of Lehman’s books and records. At any given moment, there were as many as a dozen government officials buzzing around Lehman’s offices.

headline: Amid Democratic Impatience, Senators Move on a Jobs Bill
text: WASHINGTON — The Senate cleared the way on Monday for final Congressional approval of a Democratic plan to spur job creation as Democrats grew impatient with delays in enacting what they hope is the first in a series of economic measures.

headline: UConn Prepares for Historic Trip
text: Connecticut has played in every N.C.A.A. women’s basketball tournament since 1989 and has always had the luxury of playing at least one tournament game a year — and sometimes as many as four — in its home state, before its sizable and adoring fan base.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Monday about a spy network, according to military and business officials, composed of private contractors in Afghanistan and Pakistan established by Michael D. Furlong, a Defense Department official based at Lackland Air Force Base in San Antonio, misidentified the branch of the military in which Mr. Furlong had once served as an officer. It is the Army, not the Air Force.

headline: Corrections
Corrections
text: An article on Monday, about a sales spike for a French book called “The Coming Insurrection” after it was mentioned by the Fox News host Glenn Beck gave an incomplete title for Christopher Balfe. While Mr. Balfe commented on Mr. Beck’s behalf for the article, he is president and chief operating officer of Mercury Radio Arts, Mr. Beck’s production company; he is not “a spokesman” for Mr. Beck.

headline: Galaxy Will Begin to Feel Beckham’s Loss in July
text: David Beckham’s injury will affect the Los Angeles Galaxy on and off the field.

headline: Corrections
text: The Patient Money column on Saturday, about finding housing and care for elderly parents, rendered incorrectly the name of the law firm of Robert S. Bullock, who commented on the availability of Medicaid for nursing home care. It is the Elder and Disability Law Center, not the Elder Law and Disability Law Center.

headline: Arnall Patz, a Doctor Who Prevented Blindness, Is Dead at 89
text: Dr. Arnall Patz, an ophthalmologist whose research upset medical convention but ended up saving countless babies from blindness, died on Wednesday at his home in Pikesville, Md. He was 89.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Thursday about a Congressional panel that questioned the need for the Treasury Department’s bailouts of GMAC in 2008 and 2009 gave an incomplete figure for the overall amount of the government’s financial package. It totaled $17.2 billion. (The word “billion” was omitted.)

headline: Corrections
text: An art review on Friday about “To Live Forever: Art and the Afterlife in Ancient Egypt,” at the Brooklyn Museum, referred incorrectly to the presence of mummies in the exhibition. There is in fact one on display. The review also referred imprecisely to the treatment of organs in some mummifications. They were removed and preserved and then either permanently stored in jars that were entombed with the body, or put back in the body. They were not stored in jars and then returned to the body.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on March 7 about the emergence artists in the Pop Pluralism movement misstated the name of a clothing store in San Francisco that houses a chandelier by Adam Wallacavage. It is RVCA, not RVKA.

headline: Rewriting History in Texas
text: The Texas Board of Education, notorious for its past efforts to undermine the teaching of evolution in public schools, has now moved to revise the social studies curriculum to portray conservative ideas and movements in a more positive light and emphasize the role of Christianity in the nation’s founding.

headline: The Battle Over Textbooks in Texas
text: To the Editor:

headline: Civil Rights in Education
text: In a little more than a year in office, Education Secretary Arne Duncan has used his bully pulpit and a burgeoning discretionary budget to focus state governments on school reform as never before. Mr. Duncan has now promised to energize the Education Department’s Office of Civil Rights, which has done a poor job in recent years of enforcing federal laws that protect poor, minority and disabled students from discrimination.

headline: The Dream of Clean Coal
text: To the Editor:

headline: Workers Crushed by Toyota
text: California has been very, very good to Toyota. It is one of the largest markets in the world for the popular Prius hybrid. Nearly 18 percent of all Toyotas sold in the U.S. are sold in California. The state has showered the company with benefits, including large-scale infrastructure improvements for its operations and millions of dollars for worker training. California is one of the key reasons that Toyota is the wealthiest carmaker on the planet.

headline: Surviving on a Fixed Income
text: To the Editor:

headline: Congress Shortchanges the Indians
text: Last December, after 13 years of lawsuits and painful negotiations, the federal government and representatives of hundreds of thousands of American Indians finally reached a settlement of claims that reached back to the 19th century. Only one more hurdle stood between the Indians and the $3.4 billion that the government agreed to pay them: Congress, which was required to sign off on the agreement.

headline: Ways to React to New Housing in East Jerusalem
text: To the Editor:

headline: Corrections
text: Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about the many questions surrounding the Mets’ pitching staff this season misstated the number of games John Maine won in the 2006 playoffs. It was one, not two.

headline: Immigration Offer Draws Few Haitians
text: Within days of the devastating earthquake in Haiti on Jan. 12, the United States government declared that Haitians living illegally in the United States were eligible for temporary protected status, a special immigration designation that temporarily allows them to work here legally.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Monday about Katie Spotz, who at 22 became the youngest person to row an entire ocean solo, misstated the location of Georgetown, Guyana, in South America, her arrival point on Sunday, in relation to Cayenne, French Guiana, her original destination. It is about 400 miles northwest of Cayenne, not northeast.

headline: Corrections
text: An article in some copies on Sunday about West Virginia’s 60-58 victory over Georgetown on Saturday in the championship game of the Big East men’s basketball tournament misstated West Virginia’s seeding. It was third, not fourth.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on March 5 about first-round play at the Honda Classic in Palm Beach Gardens, Fla., erroneously attributed a distinction to the golfer Oliver Wilson, who was tied for third place at the time. He was not the 2007 Honda champion  that was Mark Wilson.

headline: Corrections
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Charles Moore, Rights-Era Photographer, Dies at 79
text: Charles Moore, a photographer who braved physical peril to capture searing images  including lawmen using dogs and fire hoses against defenseless demonstrators  that many credit with helping to propel landmark civil rights legislation, died on Thursday in Palm Beach Gardens, Fla. He was 79.

headline: One in the Woods
text: The path to ABC Business Schoolwas paid for by a lucky sign:Alterations, Qualified SeamstressInquire Within.

headline: Rock and Roll Hall of Fame Inducts New Members
text: Slouched against the lectern at the 25th annual Rock and Roll Hall of Fame induction ceremony, a shirtless Iggy Pop snarled, “I am the world’s forgotten boy.”

headline: How the Midmajors Reel In Those Stars
text: Dave Telep evaluates high school basketball players for a living. While most fans watch the N.C.A.A. tournament to root for their alma mater or to follow their brackets, Telep sees a referendum on his professional opinion.

headline: Does Woody Johnson Have a Right to Be Upset About Goodell’s Coin Flip?
text: The roommates aren’t getting along. And they haven’t even moved in yet.

headline: Putting Games Online to Try to Satisfy Majority
text: If a flaw existed in CBS’s coverage of the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament, it was the regionalization of games — especially in the first four days.

headline: Giants Get First Game at New Stadium
text: Years from now, the host of the first game at the new football palace in the Meadowlands will be a mere footnote. Right now, though, the right to host that game — and bask in the spotlight that will accompany it — has laid bare the arm’s-length relationship between the two New York teams that will share the stadium and that jointly hope to win the right to stage the 2014 Super Bowl.

headline: 2 Mets Make Case, but Fifth Starter Is Still a Mystery
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Two leading contenders for the fifth spot in the Mets’ rotation pitched on Monday, but neither did anything to clarify who would win the job. Fernando Nieve gave up two runs and five hits with no strikeouts in three innings, and Jon Niese allowed three runs and four hits with two strikeouts.

headline: Der Scutt, Modernist Architect, Dies at 75
text: Der Scutt, an architect who designed several of the most prominent buildings in Manhattan  including Trump Tower on Fifth Avenue and the vast One Astor Plaza overlooking Times Square  died on Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 75.

headline: Defining the Great Midmajor Player
text: The recruiting analyst Dave Telep of scout.com and his intern, Drew Cannon, conducted a study two years ago that showed what makes a great midmajor player. They came up with nine categories, defining the best players who are not in the six power conferences.

headline: Given Chance, Knicks’ Douglas Makes the Most of It
text: PHILADELPHIA — Mike D’Antoni started the season with his old reliable, Chris Duhon, at point guard. He briefly replaced him with Nate Robinson, then switched back to Duhon before Sergio Rodriguez and Tracy McGrady inherited the job.

headline: Yellen May Prove Less Than Dovish
text: Janet Yellen has a reputation as a monetary dove. After all, she thought deflation a risk when she became president of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco and has suggested inflation may be too low now. But Ms. Yellen displays hints of talons beneath her feathers that could change the way the central bank does business.

headline: Protesters Dump Blood at Thai Government Site
text: BANGKOK — Blood was spilled on Tuesday, the third day of mass demonstrations in Bangkok, but not in the way that many had feared.

headline: Word of the Day | bait
text: bait •\ˈbat\• noun and verb

headline: Correction
text: An editorial on Sunday about an examiner’s report on accounting maneuvers that concealed Lehman Brothers’s perilous financial condition repeated an error from the news article on which it was based. The editorial and the article, which was published on Friday, incorrectly described assets that were temporarily shuffled off Lehman’s books. They were highly liquid securities, according to the examiner, not “troubled” assets.

headline: As Concussions’ Toll Lingers, an M.L.S. Career May Yield
text: Alecko Eskandarian recently posted this message on Twitter: “I have a new PS3 and FIFA 10. I haven’t used myself in a video game in ages and this is gonna be fun. But if my character has a concussion I’m gonna be ticked.”

headline: News Quiz | March 16, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page.

headline: Second to Nun
text: WHO is the 5-foot-4, white-haired 77-year-old nun who keeps the Xavier men’s basketball team in line academically? WHO plays that role in your life?

headline: Defining the Great Midmajors Players
text: In Tuesday’s New York Times, Pete Thamel broke down an analysis directed by a national talent evaluator that found striking trends in physiques and skills among midmajors players.

headline: Junk Bond Avalanche Looms for Credit Markets
text: When the Mayans envisioned the world coming to an end in 2012 — at least in the Hollywood telling — they didn’t count junk bonds among the perils that would lead to worldwide disaster, Nelson D. Schwartz writes in The New York Times.

headline: How Polite Are You?
text: Do you R.S.V.P. when people ask you to events? Do you turn off your cellphone at the movies and the theater? Wipe your sweat off machines at the gym? Refrain from talking loudly in public on your phone? Tell us how polite you think you are, and describe what breaches of etiquette drive you crazy.

headline: MagnaChip Eyes $250 Million I.P.O.
text: MagnaChip Semiconductor, which recently emerged from bankruptcy protection, on Monday filed its intent to raise as much as $250 million in an initial public offering, The Associated Press reported.

headline: At Lehman, Watchdogs Saw It All
text: Lehman Brothers executives weren’t the only ones in the building when they were moving billions of dollars in liabilities off their books at the end of each quarter with magic accounting. So were the Feds, The New York Times’s Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in his latest DealBook column.

headline: Financial Engines Prices Above Range in I.P.O.
text: Financial Engines, the portfolio manager and advisory firm, raised about $127.7 million after pricing above its expected range in its initial public offering Monday, Reuters reported.

headline: China’s Redgate Seeks $43 Million in I.P.O.
text: The Chinese advertising company Redgate Media Group will attempt to raise $43 million during an initial public offering this week, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Jewish Museum London
text: Images from the newly expanded museum.

headline: Barclays Said to Have Sought UBS Over Lehman in 2008
text: Barclays, which acquired Lehman Brothers‘ North American assets in its global push to expand, actually had its eyes on other prey, The Financial Times reports.

headline: Does Dominion Deal Put Consol at Risk?
text: Consol Energy is joining the shale gas party. And its $3.5 billion deal to buy assets from Dominion Resources looks like a bargain. But the investors who knocked Consol’s share price are rightly skeptical, Breakingviews says. By hedging its energy bets, the coal company risks confusing investors and sealing in a conglomerate discount, the publication argues.

headline: Dow Manages to Turn Higher at the Close
text: Uncertainty seemed to greet investors wherever they turned on Monday.

headline: Europe Creates Apparatus to Provide Greece Loans
text: Finance ministers from the 16 countries using the euro as their currency said Monday they were ready to help rescue Greece, The New York Times’s Stephen Castle reported.

headline: PepsiCo Adds to Buyback Plan
text: PepsiCo said Monday that it would buy back up to $15 billion worth of its own common stock through June 2013, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Michael Jackson’s Estate Signs Sweeping Contract
text: Nine months after Michael Jackson’s death, his estate has signed one of the biggest recording contracts in history, giving Sony, Mr. Jackson’s longtime label, the rights to sell his back catalog and draw on a large vault of unheard recordings, The New York Times’s Ben Sisario reported.

headline: A.I.G. Closes Transatlantic Holdings Offering
text: The American International Group said Monday it closed a secondary public offering of Transatlantic Holdings for about $452 million, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Oncap’s Deal for Sports Supply May Hit Hurdles
text: Sport Supply Group, a sporting goods supplier in Dallas, said Monday that it had signed a deal to sell itself to private equity firm Oncap Management Partners, a unit of Canada’s Onex, for around $170 million, The Dallas Morning News reported.

headline: EU Puts Off New Rules for Hedge Funds
text: E.U. finance ministers delayed a decision on new rules for hedge funds Tuesday in a reprieve for Britain, which fears that too-tight regulation could drive the industry from London, James Kanter reports in The New York Times.

headline: Nonmilitary Solutions
text: NEW HAVEN, Conn. — The war couldn’t feel farther away. New Haven today is deafeningly quiet – it is Spring Break here, so the student throngs have mostly fled to warmer climes. The final days of class were filled with excited chatter of travel and merriment; other concerns paled in comparison.

headline: The Envelope, Please: Six Applicants for the Class of 2014 Tell Their Own Stories
text: Much of the anxiety of waiting by the mailbox to retrieve decision letters from the nation’s most selective colleges has — like so much of the admissions process — gone digital in recent years. Whether an envelope is considered fat or thin is more likely measured in bytes. And yet, the day that decisions are formally released by many of the most competitive institutions, whether by e-mail or United States mail, remains as it always has: April 1.

headline: The Car-puccino
text: A car that runs on leftover coffee grounds.

headline: Awash in Nervous Anticipation
text: When I am not reading Calvin and Hobbes or watching ice hockey or drinking coffee, I am nervously anticipating the results of my college applications. And let me tell you, the worst part of the pre-college experience is not the essays or the rush to meet the deadlines. It is the waiting. It is in this miserable, hellish period that I scrutinize my accomplishments and failures; quantify myself into SAT scores and G.P.A.s, and wonder with growing horror why the numbers don’t add up.

headline: A Missed Deadline Provides a Costly Lesson
text: Applying to college has been nerve-racking enough, but I inadvertently made my own admissions process even worse. On my very first application I missed an important deadline — to the school I considered my safety, the University of Texas at Austin. And now I worry I may not get in anywhere else. Allow me to explain.

headline: Calpers Votes to Speak Out More Often
text: The board of California’s giant public pension fund voted Monday to remove the limit on the number of shareholder proposals it can issue to companies in its portfolio, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Doubts About Diversity Training
text: Today’s idea: Though diversity training has been widely embraced by corporate America, there’s little evidence so far that it works, sociologists find.

headline: Renault and Daimler Said to Discuss Share Swap
text: Renault and Daimler, the two European carmakers long in talks to collaborate more extensively, may be considering going as far as a share swap, Max Warburton, an analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein, said Monday.

text: Edward L. Glaeser is an economics professor at Harvard.

headline: Former Schering Executives Take Reins at Bausch
text: Two former top executives of drug maker Schering-Plough were named on Monday as  leaders of privately owned eye-care company Bausch & Lomb, Reuters reported.

headline: Former A.I.G. Employees Might Sue Over Payouts
text: Several former American International Group employees might sue the insurer after it gave them less retention bonus money than they should have received, Reuters reported, citing lawyers for the employees.

headline: Home Charging for Electric Vehicle: Costs Will Vary
text: By the end of the year, at least five plug-in cars, including the Nissan Leaf and Chevrolet Volt, are expected to be on the market. And as electric vehicles roll out, their owners will be wiring their homes to accommodate what is called Level 2 charging. The wall-mounted 220-240-volt boxes can recharge an E.V.’s batteries in four to eight hours.

headline: Sampler: Pleasanton Must Grow, and Pink Slips for Teachers
text: The Number of California’s Uninsured Is Up | The state’s unemployment rate has led to a 28 percent jump in the number of the people who are uninsured to 8.2 million in 2009, from 6.4 million in 2007, according to a report from the University of California, Los Angeles. Among those under age 65, 24.3 percent were uninsured in 2009. [The Los Angeles Times]

headline: Hedge Funds May Pull in $222 Billion This Year
text: Hedge funds across the globe could pull in $222 billion in fresh capital in 2010, Bloomberg News reported, citing a new survey by Deutsche Bank.

headline: In Deutsche Report, Billions for Risk-Takers
text: Deutsche Bank says it made net income of 5 billion euros ($6.9 billion) in 2009 and that it expects the banking market to progress slowly toward ”a new form of normality” this year and next, The Associated Press reports.

headline: Steady Fed Policy Provides Scant Impetus for Investors
text: The Federal Reserve’s decision to keep interest rates near zero helped lead the Dow Jones industrial average to a sixth day of gains on Tuesday. But the enthusiasm was restrained, disappointing those who had hoped low rates would give the market reason for a new upward thrust.

headline: U.S. Housing Starts Slowed by Blizzards
text: Home building slowed in February as snowstorms stopped construction in some of the country’s largest markets, a Commerce Department report indicated Tuesday.

headline: Re-Tooling Alberta’s Energy Royalties
text: After a year of intense criticism from the energy industry and its political rivals, Alberta’s embattled Conservative government last week announced it would ease up on provincial royalties in a bid to kick-start investment and create more jobs, especially in the natural gas and conventional oil sectors.

headline: Former Bank Chief Is Charged With Bailout Fraud
text: Charles J. Antonucci Sr., a former president of the Park Avenue Bank in Manhattan, was charged on Monday with fraud, embezzlement and bribery in what the authorities called the first criminal case of trying to defraud the federal government’s bank bailout program.

text: Offense

headline: Passing Health Care Legislation, Tucked in a Rule
text: As they push for a climactic vote on major health care legislation, House Democratic leaders face a bit of a conundrum: rank-and-file lawmakers detest the Senate-passed health care bill, and yet before the Democrats’ overall proposal becomes law, the House somehow has to find a way to approve that Senate bill.

headline: ‘Hot’ Role For White-Hot White
text: Hey, Betty White, how about leaving some work for the rest of Hollywood? Sure, Ms. White, the 88-year-old comedy phenomenon, could have packed it in after her run on “The Mary Tyler Moore Show,” or called it a career after the success of “The Golden Girls” (and the not-quite-success of its spinoff “Golden Palace”). But no: she is now set to appear in a new series for TV Land called “Hot in Cleveland,” The Associated Press reported. The show stars three other comedy veterans of a different generation — Valerie Bertinelli (of “One Day at a Time”), Jane Leeves (“Frasier”) and Wendie Malick (“Just Shoot Me”) — as Los Angeles émigrés who end up in Cleveland. Ms. White, who plays the caretaker of the house they live in, was originally set just for the pilot episode. But as she enjoys a career resurgence that includes a gig hosting on “Saturday Night Live” in May, Ms. White was bumped up to a series regular. “Hot in Cleveland” will start showing on TV Land in June, by which time we fully expect Ms. White to be president of the channel.

headline: Online Hate Sites Grow With Social Networks
text: Terrorists and racists are turning to online social networks and depending less on traditional Web sites, according to a new report on digital terror and hate speech.

headline: Colbert Reports He Anointed San Francisco’s Unwilling Messiah
text: Remember Raj Patel? The man who wrote “The Value of Nothing” then went on a book tour and returned to find himself declared a messiah? It had the same effect on his e-mail in-box that a burst pipe has on a wooden floor — it buckled and nearly collapsed.

headline: Testing Obama, at Home and Abroad
text: WASHINGTON — In the last days of the 2008 presidential campaign, Joseph Biden warned that “It will not be six months before the world tests Barack Obama like they did John Kennedy.” The young new president, his running mate declared, would face “crisis, a generated crisis, to test the mettle of this guy.”

headline: Apple Hires Wearable Computing Engineer
text: Apple has hired Richard DeVaul, a veteran of the wearable computing field and co-founder of AWare Technologies, a technology company focused on creating products for the fitness and “wellness” markets.

headline: Dads in the Delivery Room
text: A few months ago, a French obstetrician suggested that if fathers really wanted to help their partners in the delivery room, they would just stay away. They may think they are helping, Dr. Michael Odent said, but they are probably only making the mothers stressed, slowing their production of the hormone oxytocin, which results in a prolonged labor and an increased risk of Caesarian section.

headline: Israel Objects to U.S. Construction Demands
text: JERUSALEM — The discord between the United States and Israel over Jewish building in East Jerusalem deepened Tuesday with Israeli officials saying they would reject demands by Washington and expressing anger over the public upbraiding of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu by the Obama administration.

headline: Artists Arrive on Governors Island
text: This week, nearly 30 visual and performing artists are moving onto Governors Island, the beginning of a year-round artist studio program organized by the Lower Manhattan Cultural Council. In the newly renovated Building 110, artists will have the use of 20 studios, two rehearsal areas and a large exhibition space with views of Lower Manhattan and New York Harbor. The residencies run from March to July and from August to December; the public can have access to the studios from June to mid-October. The cultural council was selected by the Governors Island Preservation and Education Corporation after a competitive request for proposals.

headline: China Fails to Dispel Mystery About Missing Dissident
text: HONG KONG — China’s foreign minister waded into the mystery over the disappearance more than a year ago of one of the country’s most prominent human rights lawyers, but his remarks on Tuesday shed little light on the lawyer’s fate.

headline: Modernism on a Chain
text: There comes a point in some long-term relationships when gifts of gold and silver jewelry are replaced by those of chrome and leather furniture. The romantic impulse behind giving the gift of Eames isn’t any less sincere. It’s just a different kind of intimacy.

headline: Lincoln on Why God Made Erasers

headline: A Midmajor Study

The full report is below, and as a PDF here. Read more about the report and the players in Pete Thamel’s article.

headline: Drug Giants Lag Where Sales Boom, Study Says
text: The leading drug makers need to move quickly to adapt to a new world order in which some emerging markets are set to overtake some established national markets in pharmaceutical sales, according to a report issued Tuesday.

headline: Blame for Democrats — and Republicans
text: Democrats awoke on Tuesday to a double-barreled shot of criticism on two of the nation’s leading op-ed pages over lack of bipartisanship in the health care debate.

headline: Tuesday Reading

headline: Catholic Bishops Renew Criticism of Abortion Restrictions
text: With the abortion issue still roiling the health care debate on Capitol Hill, the president of the United States Conference of Catholic Bishops has issued a statement criticizing the Senate-passed legislation as insufficient in setting restrictions on the use of federal money for insurance coverage of abortions.

headline: ‘Called for an Overhaul’
text: Monologue |  Monday night on “Late Night With Jimmy Fallon” on NBC: In his weekly radio and Internet address, President Obama called for an overhaul of the “No Child Left Behind” law. It will now be called “The World Needs Janitors, Too.”

headline: ‘Even the Taliban Move Their Clocks Ahead’
text: Monologue |  Monday night on “The Late Show With David Letterman” on CBS: Everybody changed their clocks this weekend for daylight savings. So you move it ahead. And even the Taliban move their clocks ahead. They moved it up to the 11th century. So that’s good.

headline: A Compostable Chips Bag Hits the Shelves
text: One of the obvious environmental downsides of eating chips is the packaging. Billions of bags hit dumpsters every year.

headline: The 2.0 Report | Williamsburg Is the New Williamsburg
text: Should you find yourself wandering the streets of Williamsburg, Brooklyn, these days,you might be reminded of another Williamsburg, the restored historic village in Virginia. With shops like the Brooklyn Kitchen, where you can learn how to pickle vegetablesand butcher your own pig, and Rye, where you can sip an old-fashioned at the 100-year-old oak bar, the neighborhood hasn’t quite returned to colonial times — but chances are your server will have facial hair and woolens that would do an 18th-century blacksmith proud. There are glass blowers (Michael Anchin Glass Company), perfume makers (CBI Hate Perfume) and illegal urban beekeepers who’ve set up shop in East Williamsburgwith that same can-do spirit that got us to the New World in the first place. While you might not hear the resounding fife and drums of our founding fathers, the bars on Bedford Avenue are jammed with Bunyan-bearded hipsters who look as if they moonlight in a fiddle band. And the spirit of Patrick Henry lives on in these Brooklynites, whose call to arms is ‘‘Give me bike lanes or give me death!’’

headline: ‘Two Brain Trusts’
text: Monologue |  Monday night on “The Jay Leno Show” on NBC: Thank you for coming on the Ides of March. You know, this is March 15. It was on this day in 44 B.C., Julius Caesar met his end. He was stabbed in the back by members of the Senate, ironically, while pleading for health care.

headline: Photo Tip: Slowing a Babbling Brook
text: I was going through some old (really old) e-mail the other night and stumbled across an exchange with a helpful Olympus product manager that taught me an important lesson about photography.

headline: Sheen Pleads Not Guilty in Domestic Violence Case
text: The actor Charlie Sheen pleaded not guilty to domestic violence charges in an Aspen, Colo., court on Monday, The Associated Press reported, setting the stage for a trial and leaving unanswered questions about how Mr. Sheen will continue to take part in his CBS sitcom, “Two and a Half Men.”

headline: Cabling Your Mac
text: NewerTech, a Mac accessories maker, has a new solution to make it easier to get video with resolution as high as 1080p from your recent-generation Macintosh onto a big flat screen TV (or any modern digital set).

headline: Epley Said to Leave Deutsche for Nomura
text: Mark Epley, head of Deutsche Bank‘s team that caters to private-equity firms, is leaving to take a job at Nomura Holdings, a person with knowledge of his plans told Bloomberg News.

headline: Citi Said to Shore Up Proprietary Trading Group
text: Never mind the calls from Washington to limit proprietary trading, the business of banks making financial bets using their own capital.

headline: Postcard From the Arctic Sea Ice
text: For several years, Rhett Herman, a physics professor at Radford University, has been leading students on an expedition each spring break to study the condition of the sea ice off the coast near Barrow, Alaska. A blog of this year’s trip and photos and journals from previous trips are online. Below you can read a “Dot Earth postcard” Dr. Herman sent last week (they’ve just returned home). I’ll be adding some of the students’ post-trip thoughts in the comments section. The photo below, by Dr. Herman, shows students using an OhmMapper to generate a cross section view of the ice beneath their feet. (Mythianne Shelton hauling the gear, Susan Christopher at the tail end of the array and Jason McLarty nearby.)

headline: Ocean Adventure Fill-In

headline: By Ancient Ruins, a Gay Haven in Cambodia
text: IT was 10 p.m. in Siem Reap, and while most tourists were tucked in after a long, hot day exploring the temples of Angkor, things were just getting going at a bar called Linga. Pairs of European men in their 30s and 40s wearing unbuttoned collared shirts and checkered krama scarves sipped fruity cocktails and jostled for space with the young Khmer crowd, who huddled around small tables in anticipation of the main event: the Saturday night drag show.

headline: City Health Board Agrees to Require Letter Grades for Restaurant Cleanliness
text: The New York City Board of Health voted Tuesday to rate cleanliness in the city’s more than 24,000 restaurants with publicly posted letter grades, adopting a controversial plan proposed 14 months ago by the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene.

headline: Case Study | Got Your Pickleback
text: Three years ago, Reggie Cunningham, a young rogue in my employ who balladeers about town under the nom de rap of the Mr. Move, asked me to check out the bar where he worked in outer Williamsburg, Brooklyn. The Bushwick Country Club had all the amenities: a trash-strewn backyard featuring a derelict miniature-golf course, Christmas bulbs strung up for lighting, stout in a Styrofoam cup and a staff comprised of what one Yelper described as “an odd assortment of pirates and misfits.” I kinda liked it. It had a gritty, improvisational feel; if you were there, it was probably not by accident.

headline: Rural Haiti Struggles to Absorb Displaced
text: FOND-DES-BLANCS, Haiti — Before the earthquake that changed everything, Chlotilde Pelteau and her husband lived a supremely urban existence. A cosmetics vendor and a mechanic, they both enjoyed a steady clientele and a hectic daily routine, serenaded by the beeping cars and general hubbub of Port-au-Prince.

headline: Capital Export, Elasticity Pessimism, and the Renminbi (Wonkish)
text: I got a little snippy with Ryan Avent yesterday over the remminbi issue; I guess I don’t like being compared to Donald Rumsfeld. In any case, however, I think it would be useful for me to explain how I think about the current China syndrome, and why I believe that most of the responses I hear are missing the point. In what follows, I’ll focus on three questions: the macroeconomics of Chinese currency intervention, the fallacies of elasticity pessimism (which I’ll explain when I get there), and the political economy issue of how to deal with Chinese intransigence.

headline: How the Lehman Report Was Made
text: For Lehman Brothers‘ court-appointed examiner, Anton R. Valukas, to finish his exhaustive report on the decline of the investment bank and its accounting practices, the lawyer reviewed by his own estimate about 34 million pages of e-mail, a tiny fraction of the 350 billion pages he and his team had at their disposal.

headline: Video of Thai Blood-Spilling Protest
text: Opponents of the Thai government, who are known for the red shirts they wear to protests, poured buckets of their own blood under the gates of the prime minister’s office on Tuesday, as my colleague Thomas Fuller reports from Bangkok.

headline: F.C.C. Questioned on Its Far-Reaching Plan to Expand Broadband Access
text: Federal regulators on Tuesday made public the details of their ambitious policy to encourage the spread of high-speed Internet access. But their 376-page proposal, the National Broadband Plan, was met with a chorus of questions, even from the staunchest advocates of its goals.

headline: New Book Serves Up a Fresh Side of Julia Child
text: Whether you followed Julia Child voraciously from the 1961 publication of her first cookbook or only just discovered her through the 2009 movie “Julie & Julia,” a new book is promising a fresh look at the life and career of the beloved chef and author, told through her correspondence with a longtime friend.

headline: Back to School, and Right Back on Vacation
text: The dawn of the new school year means all kinds of traditions — freshly sharpened pencils, new backpacks, tales of summer camp and road trips. This year, it also means two extra days of vacation.

headline: Finding a Method to the N.C.A.A. Madness
text: The affliction is common at this time of year, perhaps even epidemic. It is short-lived, by necessity, but can seriously sap productivity, energy, the ability to focus on anything but the empty bracket staring back at you on the computer screen. Perhaps you even double your agony by trying to pick both the men’s and women’s tournaments — hey, double the chance at the iPad! — and find yourself doubled over with emptybracketitis.

headline: Obama Restores Former Pentagon Line of Succession
text: WASHINGTON — It is a morbid theme, but one that no superpower can ignore. So the Obama administration has quietly reviewed, and revised, the sequence in which Pentagon civilian officials would take command should Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates die unexpectedly, say in a surprise attack.

headline: A Serious Savory Breakfast
text: For whatever reason — I ran out, I had other grains to eat, maybe I was a little tired of it — I went through most of the winter without eating oatmeal for breakfast.  And when I began again, the first morning I turned to maple syrup, which seems the default. But on day two, I woke up with one of those odd cravings, one of those bizarre certainties about what I was going to have for breakfast. The most amazing thing — to me, at least — was that I’d never made this before, yet I knew it was going to be perfect.

headline: Catching Up on Health Care
text: Updated: Protesters descended on parts of the Capitol grounds today, voicing their opposition to health care legislation that is under debate in the House. Some organizers belonged to the Tea Party movement, and some demonstrators were focusing on vulnerable Democratic lawmakers facing tough re-election bids in conservative districts.

headline: When Tics Appear Later in Life
text: Tourette’s syndrome, marked by uncontrollable urges to move the body or vocalize, can be a lifelong sruggle for some. Dr. Robert A. King and Dr. James F. Leckman of the Yale School of Medicine recently joined the Consults blog to answer readers’ questions about Tourette’s. Here, they respond to readers asking about the long-term course of the syndrome.

headline: ArtsBeat: John Grisham Overcomes His Aversion to E-Books
text: As Motoko Rich is reporting on our sister blog, ArtsBeat, the blockbuster author John Grisham, a longtime holdout against e-books, has agreed to allow the Knopf Doubleday Publishing Group to release digital versions of 23 of his backlist titles. “This is one of our most exciting e-book initiatives to date,” Sonny Mehta, chairman and editor-in-chief of Knopf Doubleday, said in a statement, “and is certain to usher in a new generation of Grisham readers and e-book adopters.” Read more.

headline: Emery and Grenier to Star in ‘Gabriel’ for Atlantic Theater

headline: Bolstered by Finance Unit, G.E. May Raise Dividend
text: General Electric, which cut its common stock dividend last year for the first time since the Great Depression, may increase it next year and repurchase stock for the first time since 2008 because of a “snapback” at its GE Capital finance unit, the company’s chief financial officer, Keith S. Sherin, said Tuesday, according to Bloomberg News.

headline: An Alternative to Chemotherapy Takes Venture Competition
text: This past weekend, Carnegie Mellon University’s Tepper School of Business and the Donald H. Jones Center for Entrepreneurship held its McGinnis Venture Competition for start-ups that bring new technologies to market. Three entrants each won $20,000 seed finance offers and $20,000 worth of legal and business consulting services in their respective competition tracks: life sciences, clean tech and general technology.

headline: New Jersey Governor Proposes Deep Spending Cuts
text: TRENTON — Christopher J. Christie, the first Republican elected governor of New Jersey in 12 years, unveiled a $29.3 billion budget on Tuesday that relies almost exclusively on spending cuts to reverse the sagging fortunes of a state he sees as battered by the recession and choking on its tax burden.

headline: A Television Project That Might Make Steve Jobs iRate
text: If Steven P. Jobs wants relief from one of his more merciless satirists, a television set may not be the best place to turn. On Tuesday, the cable channel Epix and the studio Media Rights Capital said they had struck a development deal for a new series called “iCon,” to be written by Dan Lyons, a Newsweek contributor who has sent up the Apple chief executive on his popular blog, The Secret Diary of Steve Jobs, and in his novel “Options: The Secret Life of Steve Jobs – A Parody.” The project, which Epix described in a news release as “a savage satire centering on a fictional Silicon Valley CEO whose ego is a study in power and greed,” is being overseen by Larry Charles, the director of “Borat,” “Religulous” and “Brüno” and a veteran writer and producer of “Seinfeld” and “Curb Your Enthusiasm”; the half-hour, single camera series will be produced by Media Rights Capital.

headline: Doctors and Patients, Not Talking About Weight
text: Doctors recognize obesity as a health problem. So why is it so hard for them to talk to their patients about it?

headline: For Return, Woods Picks Place He’s at Ease
text: An outpouring of support from peers, sponsors and officials greeted the announcement by Tiger Woods that his self-imposed exile from golf would end at the Masters in April — a first step in a return to normalcy on the competitive side of his life.

headline: The Women’s N.I.T. Gets Expansion Fever

headline: Greenberg on Two Years After Bear’s Fall

headline: In Mexico, Promises Do Little to Ease a City’s Pain
text: CIUDAD JUÁREZ, Mexico — In the six weeks since gunmen killed 15 people in a working-class neighborhood here, the police, the governor, psychologists and even the president’s wife have descended.

headline: Hoyer Defends Controversial House Procedure
text: The House majority leader, Representative Steny H. Hoyer of Maryland, defended on Tuesday the use of a procedural tool that would allow the House to pass a sweeping health care bill without a direct up-or-down vote on the legislation.

headline: New Baseball Announcers for TBS
text: TBS, which cut its ties to Chip Caray last November, said on Tuesday that a three-man rotation would replace him on its Sunday afternoon regular-season baseball broadcasts: Dick Stockton, Brian Anderson and Ernie Johnson.

headline: A Recipe Secret Wrapped in a Towel
text: THE so-called Greek yogurt that has become popular in recent years is neither a special kind of yogurt nor uniquely Greek. It’s simply yogurt from which much of the water has been removed, a concoction that in its thickest form can be called yogurt cheese. You can find yogurt cheese in every country that has a history of yogurt making. In addition to being thicker and richer when eaten straight, it makes superior spreads and dips.

text: Kenya’s Lake Turkana Wind Power project – set to become Africa’s largest wind farm – looks to be back on track after securing financing through a new shareholding structure.

text: Stuart Webb, a cameraman for Britain’s Channel 4 News embedded with British troops in Afghanistan, filed a video blog post on Tuesday that showed how he and a colleague, Alex Thomson, attempted to keep their cool while pinned down in a stream during a firefight – by making friends with a frog.
