headline: Know the Score: Looking at South Africa Through the Lens of the World Cup
text: Overview | How is its history of apartheid continuing to affect life and politics in South Africa? How can South Africa best address the range of concerns regarding its hosting of the World Cup? In this lesson, students consider South Africa’s history and the legacy of apartheid along with news about the upcoming World Cup. They then engage in a simulation to generate policy recommendations for the South African government, with respect to hosting this international event.

headline: N.F.L. Picks New Chairmen for Panel on Concussions
text: The N.F.L. further distanced itself from its tumultuous past regarding concussions on Tuesday by selecting two new co-chairmen for a renamed policy committee and accepting the resignation of one of that group’s most prominent members.

headline: Using Cellphone Signals to Track Cars When GPS Cannot
text: The idea that one can locate and track just about anything — your car, your dog, your spouse — using GPS is part of popular lore. Unfortunately (or fortunately, depending on your point of view) that’s not true. GPS signals can be obscured or blocked.

text: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve on Tuesday affirmed its plan to stop buying mortgage-backed securities, expressing a degree of confidence that it could eliminate that pillar of support without undermining the nation’s economic recovery.

headline: Obama and Kaine Meet for Political Lunch
text: President Obama has sought to play down the political aspects of the health care debate, telling audiences again and again in recent days: “I don’t know about the politics, but I know what’s the right thing to do.”

headline: The Beer Belly of America
text: Conservatives know it as the “American heartland.” Elitist liberals know it as “flyover country.” But to serious drinkers, the Midwest should perhaps be known as the “beer belly of America.”

headline: Ahoy, Matey | Let’s Get Nautical
text: A new group of yachts is catering to the boating crowd’s appetite for adventure and design. The 105-foot Necker Belle catamaran (virginlimitededition.com;$88,000 a week), refurbished last year by Sir Richard Branson, has a wine cellar, an outdoor movie theater and a three-person submersible for exploring reefs and wrecks. Reflecting the new emphasis on exploring remote waters, Cape Race (right; mvcaperace.com; $2,000 to $3,000 per person per week) is a converted fishing trawler — outfitted with six generous cabins and a mahogany-paneled saloon — that can cross the Atlantic twice without refueling. And the Panthalassa (camperandnicholsons.com; $200,000 a week), a 184-foot ketch with off-white interiors by Foster & Partners, has an oval stairway that brings sunlight to the lower level, where staterooms are paneled in leather and bathrooms tiled in black marble.

headline: Cedar Fair’s Last-Minute Change of Heart
text: Talk about a wild ride. The amusement park operator Cedar Fair announced on Monday night that it had postponed Tuesday morning’s meeting for unit holders to vote on the company’s acquisition by Apollo Management, saying it wanted to provide more time to solicit votes and proxies. For those unit holders who have already made the trip up to Sandusky, Ohio, for the meeting, they will have a relatively long wait. The meeting is postponed until April 8. Perhaps Cedar Fair will placate these unit holders with some free amusement park tickets in the interim.

headline: The Connoisseur | Buying Time
text: In the universe of fine watches, time moves slowly. Serious European collectors and a growing cadre of wrist-conscious Americans concern themselves exclusively with watches powered by a spring technology invented more than 300 years ago. If it needs a Duracell, a watch snob isn’t interested.

headline: Nebraska, the Unknown Women’s No. 1 Seed
text: It’s an interesting theory: Nebraska’s women’s basketball team is the No. 1 seed in Kansas City regional of the N.C.A.A. tournament, yet the Huskers feel like an underdog.

text: President Obama will give a rare interview on Wednesday to Fox News, the cable network that a top administration official once accused of being a political arm of the Republican Party.

headline: Offshore Wind a Boon to the Shipping Industry
text: With ocean-going trade slackening amid the global recession, shipping companies and shipyard operators in Europe are finding the offshore wind industry to be a welcome ally in weathering the bad times.

headline: The Morning Skate: Will the N.H.L. Fast-Track the Blindside Head Check Rule?
text: Supplemental discipline has dominated many hockey conversations this season, the latest being Alex Ovechkin’s two-game ban following his boarding of the Blackhawks’ Brian Campbell on Sunday. Campbell broke a collarbone and several ribs when he was slammed against the boards. This morning on Toronto radio Fan 590, Scotty Bowman told Gord Stellick and Don Landry (audio here) he attributed plays like Ovechkin’s to post-lockout rules that prohibit defensemen from holding up forecheckers.

headline: Pressure Grows in U.S. Over China’s Currency
text: WASHINGTON — Members of Congress from both parties sought on Tuesday to put more pressure on China to allow an increase in the value of its currency, saying Beijing’s policy of holding the value down to give China an edge in export markets was holding back job creation in the United States.

headline: Google’s Doodles
text: Imagine that you and a fellow Stanford computer science grad have just been given a $100,000 check to bankroll a new business. The Burning Man festival is coming up, and you both want to go. What do you do? If you’re Google’s Sergey Brin and Larry Page, you make a rough sketch of the wooden effigy that’s burned at the festival, add it to your Web site as an as an “Out of Office” sign and set off for the Nevada desert.

headline: Director of Tate Modern Is Leaving
text: Vicente Todoli, who has run the Tate Modern in London for most of the young institution’s existence, has decided to step down, the museum said Tuesday.

headline: For a Few Female Riders, a Saturated First Race
text: Wind whipped sheets of frigid water across Riverside Drive Saturday morning as about 20 female cyclists shivered up to the starting line for their first race, the Grant’s Tomb Criterium, a short-course race around the New York landmark.

headline: A Little Birthday Music for Sondheim
text: From Broadway’s prodigious boy wonder to its beloved aging monarch: For Stephen Sondheim, whose forthcoming 80th birthday on March 22 was celebrated in a thrilling concert at Avery Fisher Hall on Monday evening, it must have seemed like a hop, skip and a jump from one to the other. Inside the hall, where the mood was more exhilarated than elegiac, an unspoken question hung in the air: Where did all that time go?

headline: Funeral Homes Violate City’s Pricing Rules
text: Dying is already a notably expensive proposition. But many funeral homes in the city make it even more expensive than it should be, the Department of Consumer Affairs said Tuesday.

headline: Extended Monotony
text: Time to celebrate: It has now been a year since the Federal Reserve’s Federal Open Market Committee began pledging to keep interest rates “exceptionally low” for “an extended period.”

headline: Colorado Caucuses: Just the Beginning
text: Democrats and Republicans hold precinct caucuses in Colorado tonight, the next step in a chain of events that will eventually lead to nominees for both Senate and governor.

headline: Off the Menu: Tartinery Nolita
text: A little French homage to the great Parisian bread baker, Lionel Poilâne, opened on Tuesday. Tartinery Nolita specializes in the kind of open-face sandwiches called tartines in France. All are made on toasted Poilâne bread, flown in from Paris, and some are inspired by the cookbook, “Les Meilleures Tartines de Lionel Poilane,” by Mr. Poilâne, who was killed in 2002 when the helicopter he was piloting crashed.

headline: There Will Be Floods

headline: Off the Menu: Fatty ‘Cue
text: Some mac and cheese or cornbread with your barbecue? Not at Fatty ’Cue, opening March 23 in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. Try the celery ribbons with yuzu and preserved Chinese cabbage instead.

headline: How Value Investing Paid Off in the Crisis
text: The value investing thesis, championed by the Columbia University professors Benjamin Graham and David Dodd in the 1930s, was simple: find cheap stocks being sold below their intrinsic value, buy them, and then sell them when the market wakes up.

headline: It’s the Bricks That Make Butler Basketball Special
text: INDIANAPOLIS — Hinkle Fieldhouse looks like a red-brick airplane hangar, rising above the neighboring houses at one corner of the Butler University campus. And when a basketball game is played there, the cheers spill through its cracks and its leaky roof and its high windows.

headline: More From Glaeser on America’s Shrinking Cities
text: If you enjoyed Edward L. Glaeser’s post this morning on “right-sizing” the declining city of Detroit, check out his interview on “The Takeaway” about how American cities adapt to shrinking populations. He is joined by Hunter Morrison, an urban planner in Youngstown, Ohio.

headline: Another String Group Unleashes Its Inner Rock Band
text: Watching Brooklyn Rider play music from its new CD, “Dominant Curve,” at the colorfully lighted Angel Orensanz Foundation on Monday evening  just a few days after seeing the Kronos Quartet at Zankel Hall  it was hard not to think about how string quartets have revamped their image in the last quarter century.

headline: Once for ‘Insiders’ Only, an F1 Guide Goes Online for All
text: One of the greatest bits of news to come out of the weekend in Bahrain was that fans finally have access to the most authoritative and certainly the best guide to Formula One statistics online.

headline: Renewing an Old Idea: Common Good
text: The British historian Tony Judt is dying, slowly and painfully, from a variant of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (A.L.S.), better known as Lou Gehrig’s disease. He has written matter-of-factly about his condition — he is now, essentially, a quadriplegic — in The New York Review of Books. At some point he will be able to communicate only by blinking an eye. For now he is dictating his words to assistants.

headline: Portobello and Fried Egg Panino
text: I came up with this recipe one night after putting my son to bed. I had fed him before his soccer practice, too early for me, and by the time he was bathed and in pajamas, I was starving. I looked in the refrigerator and found some portobello mushrooms left over from another recipe test, and I knew I had something to work with. Fifteen minutes later, I sat down to this open-faced sandwich with a little salad on the side — a simple, light and utterly satisfying late supper. It’s a good meal to make when you notice that the portobellos in the refrigerator have seen better days.

headline: Seeing Change in Neighborhoods, Through a Pint Glass
text: When Peter O’Hanlon opened the Blarney Bar in downtown Jamaica, Queens in 1965, he served a mostly white clientele, including the union leaders and members who held their meetings in the back room.

headline: Bridge Over the Visa Moat for Musicians Trying to Enter the U.S.
text: Of the 2,000 bands at the annual South by Southwest Music and Media Conference this week in Austin, Tex., more than 500 are from outside the United States. And to help make their way through the byzantine process of obtaining an American visa, about 200 of them have sent their paperwork, their prayers and $600 to one tiny office on the Lower East Side of Manhattan.

headline: Followers of Sadr Emerge Stronger After Iraq Elections
text: BAGHDAD — The followers of Moktada al-Sadr, a radical cleric who led the Shiite insurgency against the American occupation, have emerged as Iraq’s equivalent of Lazarus in elections last week, defying ritual predictions of their demise and now threatening to realign the nation’s balance of power.

headline: Wine Bargains of the Loire Valley
text: AMONG the many wonderful, distinctive red wines in the world, those from the Loire Valley may well get the least respect in proportion to their superb quality.

headline: Pairings: Stir-Fry Duck With Mushrooms and Broccolini
text: The last time I was in Chinon, I had lunch at a charming restaurant, Au Plaisir Gourmand. The name is fitting: Chinon was the birthplace of Rabelais, who valued indulgence at the table. We began with andouilles (tripe sausages) and continued with lièvre à la royale (hare stuffed with foie gras), as we poured more than one bottle of Chinon. I have never made either dish. But with these wines I still want something bold, earthy and luscious. Did someone say Asian? Starting with duck breast, sliced thick enough to be succulent in a stir-fry, I added mushrooms, broccolini and musky oyster sauce. Unless you worship at the table of Rabelais, the recipe is more than ample for two.

headline: A Home in Sinai
text: A six-bedroom six-bath house in Nabq, on the Sinai Peninsula, is on the market for 3.5 million Egyptian pounds ($640,000).

headline: Study Finds Almost 1 in 4 Uninsured in California
text: The number of uninsured adults and children in California swelled by 28 percent between 2007 and 2009, according to a new report by researchers at the University of California, Los Angeles.

text: By the time the engine in Sebastian Vettel’s Red Bull soured (on lap 34 of 49 looong laps) while he was leading the Bahrain Grand Prix on Sunday, it looked as if Fernando Alonso’s Ferrari was finally closing the gap — something that would have injected real excitement into the final laps of a race that had so far been more like a conga line.

headline: Landmarks Worldwide Go Green on St. Patrick’s Day
text: According to Bloomberg, the London Eye, the Sydney Opera House and the Empire State Building in New York will go green Wednesday in a St. Patrick’s Day promotion by Ireland to lure tourists back after visitor numbers slumped to a five-year low.

headline: More Julia Child, as Told Through Her Letters
text: Whether you followed Julia Child, right, voraciously from the 1961 publication of her first cookbook or only just discovered her through the 2009 movie “Julie & Julia,” a new book is promising a fresh look at the life and career of the beloved chef and author, told through her correspondence with a longtime friend. Houghton Mifflin Harcourt said that on Dec. 1 it will release a book called “As Always, Julia: The Letters of Julia Child and Avis DeVoto,” containing nearly 15 years of correspondence between Ms. Child and Ms. DeVoto, the cook and writer who helped land Ms. Child’s original manuscript for “Mastering the Art of French Cooking” at the publisher Alfred A. Knopf. The letters, written from 1952 to 1965, begin not long after Ms. Child began teaching cooking to American women in Paris and chronicle her travels across Europe with her husband, as well as the development and publication of “Mastering the Art of French Cooking.”

headline: Betty White Lands a ‘Hot’ Role
text: Betty White, the 88-year-old comedy phenomenon, could have packed it in after her run on “The Mary Tyler Moore Show,” or called it a career after the success of “The Golden Girls” (and the not-quite-success of its spinoff “Golden Palace”). But no: she is now set to appear in a new series for TV Land called “Hot in Cleveland,” The Associated Press reported. The show stars three other comedy veterans of a different generation  above from left, Jane Leeves (“Frasier”), Ms. White, Valerie Bertinelli (of “One Day at a Time”) and Wendie Malick (“Just Shoot Me”)  as Los Angeles émigrés who end up in Cleveland. Ms. White, who plays the caretaker of the house they live in, was originally set just for the pilot episode. But as she enjoys a career resurgence that includes a gig hosting on “Saturday Night Live” in May, Ms. White was made a series regular. “Hot in Cleveland” will start showing on TV Land in June.

headline: TV Project Might Make Steve Jobs Irate
text: If Steven P. Jobs wants relief from one of his more merciless satirists, a television set may not be the best place to turn. On Tuesday the cable channel Epix and the studio Media Rights Capital said they had struck a development deal for a new series called “iCon,” to be written by Dan Lyons, a Newsweek contributor who has sent up Mr. Jobs, the chief executive of Apple Computer, on his popular blog, the Secret Diary of Steve Jobs (fakesteve.net), and in his novel “Options: The Secret Life of Steve Jobs  A Parody.” The project, which Epix described in a news release as “a savage satire centering on a fictional Silicon Valley C.E.O. whose ego is a study in power and greed,” is being overseen by Larry Charles, the director of “Borat,” “Religulous” and “Brüno” and a veteran writer and producer of “Seinfeld” and “Curb Your Enthusiasm.” No date was given for when “iCon” will have its debut or when it might be available on iTunes.

headline: City Center to Begin $75 Million Renovation
text: City Center, dedicated by Mayor Fiorello La Guardia in 1943 as Manhattan’s first major performing arts center, is embarking on a $75 million renovation and restoration of its landmark neo-Moorish building on West 55th Street.

text: ASIA is beginning to look a lot more like America  at least when it comes to hotels.

text: Yes, I know that comments have disappeared. It’s some kind of WordPress issue, and will presumably be resolved soon.

headline: A Fresh Look for a Landmark in Macao
text: DOWN a crooked lane across from a shabby beauty shop, the old Macao mansion known as the Mandarin’s House always seemed to have space for newcomers knocking at its gate. Built around 1869, the house and its 60-odd rooms started to fill with renters after 1920. As more tenants moved in, parlors were subdivided, doors were added, staircases were moved. When still more came, they built shacks in the garden.

headline: Taiwan’s Steaming Pools of Paradise
text: THERE is nothing quite as bracing as the smell of rotten eggs in the morning.

headline: Iraq Elections: Sadr and His Rivals

headline: In Vietnam, Cauldrons on Every Corner
text: “YOU like congealed pigs’ blood?” my travel companion asked, pulling me over to a street cart in Ho Chi Minh City. Before I could answer, two bowls of chao, a rice porridge bobbing with slices of pork sausage and cubes of coagulated blood, were plopped in our hands.

headline: New Life in Old Hong Kong
text: WAN CHAI used to be best known among foreigners as an area crowded with seedy bars and massage parlors, but it remained popular for locals, filled with historic tenement blocks, old-fashioned street markets by day and youngsters shooting hoops after school. Now, the Hong Kong neighborhood is thriving, as a nascent cultural scene emerges and as young creative types and entrepreneurs alike are being lured by cheaper rents.

headline: 36 Hours in Phuket, Thailand
text: THE teardrop-shaped island of Phuket has long been known for its dazzling beaches and naughty night life. But for many, it was the catastrophic Asian tsunami in 2004 that finally placed Phuket on the map. Recovery has been swift, and in recent years the island has firmly reasserted itself as a premier beach resort in southern Thailand, with a growing crop of luxury hotels, top-notch restaurants and even a thriving art community.

Spreading the Wealth for a Full-Bodied Bach
text: It is, you might think, the season for Bach Passions in New York. Though high-profile performances of the monumental “St. Matthew Passion,” especially, have abounded in recent years, those who list such events at The New York Times have not yet turned up one.

text: Alright, all you fans of Loire reds, come out from wherever you are hiding. That’s right, I mean both of you!

headline: Tate Modern Loses Director
text: Vicente Todoli, who has run the Tate Modern in London for most of the young institution’s existence, has decided to step down, the museum said on Tuesday. Mr. Todoli, 51, took over the directorship in 2003 after running the Serralves Museum of Contemporary Art in Oporto, Portugal. He said in a statement that he felt the time had arrived for a pause in his career, one that he had initially meant to take before the opportunity to direct the Tate Modern came along. Under his stewardship, the museum, which opened in 2000 in a converted power station on the south bank of the Thames, has organized several major exhibitions that have sought to redefine early modernism, including shows of the work of Kandinsky in 2005 and Duchamp, Man Ray and Picabia in 2008.

headline: John Grisham Embraces E-Books
text: John Grisham, the writer of blockbuster legal thrillers and until now a holdout against e-books, is entering the digital age. In a statement on Tuesday the Knopf Doubleday Publishing Group, a division of Random House, said it would release 23 of Mr. Grisham’s backlist titles, starting with “A Time to Kill” and including “Ford County,” the author’s most recent book, a collection of stories, as e-books. According to Random House, his books have sold more than 250 million copies worldwide. Mr. Grisham had previously hesitated to release his books in e-book form because of concerns about piracy, pricing and the effect of digital editions on physical bookstores.

headline: Filing Those Tax Returns, With Help From the City
text: As rain and wind pelted Eastern Parkway in Brooklyn on Saturday, Julitta Joseph, 66, a sales associate at a Kohl’s department store, lugged a small black rolling suitcase up a flight of stairs to the office of a social-services nonprofit.

headline: Ex-Congressman Enters Race to Unseat Gillibrand
text: As Joseph J. DioGuardi shook hands with friends and supporters at his announcement for his United States Senate bid Tuesday morning, he joked that he had two women to overcome: Senator Kirsten E. Gillibrand and his daughter, Kara DioGuardi of “American Idol” fame.

headline: Kucinich to Announce His Position on Health Care
text: Representative Dennis Kucinich, Democrat of Ohio, voted against the House health care bill in November because he prefers a fully government-run, Medicare-for-all approach. He felt the Democrats’ bill simply did not go far enough to eliminate the mostly private, employer-sponsored health insurance system.

headline: On Language With Ben Zimmer
text: For more than 30 years, William Safire talked back to Americans about how they went about talking. He founded our On Language column in February 1979 and proceeded to write tens of thousands of words about phrases (fashionable and not), usages (proper and not), roots (definitive and not) and his own donnish taste — not! Bill was a democrat — very small “d” — with a passion for everyday discourse and a desire not for the last word but for a conversation about conversation. Long before the Internet came along (and provided him with a fresh trove of linguistic stuff), he built a Web-like community of language mavens who fed him tips, amplified, hondled (that’s for you, Bill!) and filled in from time to time when he took his summer vacation.

headline: Concentrate on the Workout? No, Thanks.
text: WHEN Tina Podlodowski, a public affairs consultant in Seattle, goes to the gym to run on a treadmill, she often brings her Kindle and immerses herself in a mystery novel.

headline: Answers About New Consumer Laws: Part 1
text: “Ask an Expert” is a recurring feature on Bucks where you have the opportunity to question big-brained individuals about a particular area of personal finance or consumer affairs.

headline: Colicchio & Sons
text: TOM COLICCHIO came out of the kitchen at Colicchio & Sons the other night wearing a short-sleeved dishwasher’s shirt and a white apron. His black clogs were scuffed beneath his jeans, and there were burn marks on his forearms. He appeared tired, his angry eyes more sunken than usual.

headline: Xobni Arrives on the BlackBerry
text: For Outlook users who are addicted to Xobni, an add-on service that organizes and searches e-mail messages and contacts, it has been frustrating to use Xobni-less e-mail on smartphones.

headline: The History of the Jewish Star in the Realm of the Union Jack
text: LONDON  One of the first objects you see in the newly expanded Jewish Museum London, which opens on Wednesday, is also one of the museum’s oldest: the remains of a 13th-century Jewish ritual bath (a mikvah) uncovered during a 2001 construction project in the City of London. As seen here, it is a bit too robustly reconstructed, its age and fragmentary character mollified with the use of modern materials and mirrors mounted like rays above its well.

headline: Putting a Price on New Financial Rules for Banks
text: The strength and scope of financial regulatory changes being debated around the world appear to be the biggest swing factors in gauging the profitability of the investment banks, according to a new industry research report from Oliver Wyman, a global consulting firm, and Morgan Stanley.

headline: Rediscovering Salsa, the Soul of Mexico in a Bowl
text: IT’S not easy being a Mexican restaurant in the United States. Some customers are outraged if the menu doesn’t have burritos; others, if it does. Some see authenticity when chips and salsa aren’t on the table; others see a rip-off.

headline: Chocolate-Covered Wine Grapes Offer a Sip in Every Bite
text: The chocolate-covered dried wine grapes recently introduced at Bissinger’s  a centuries-old confectioner that started in Paris and opened in St. Louis in 1927  are lushly delicious and excellent to nibble after dinner with the last sips of red wine or with a glass of vintage port. Children may like them, although it should be noted that they have been infused with shiraz before being dipped in dark chocolate.

headline: A French Chili Sauce With a Mind of Its Own
text: The pungent piment d’Espelette chili defines French Basque cooking as much as anything. It’s the main flavoring in the vibrant Bixi Bixia sauce. White wine vinegar, olive oil, garlic and herbes de Provence round out the ingredients. Use it for the grill, as a dip for bread or as a lively finish for cooked seafood, poultry, omelets, meat or white bean soup.

headline: Kaffeeklatsch
text: To the Editor:

headline: Decaf to Love
text: To the Editor:

headline: Taco With Your Java?
text: To the Editor:

headline: One Man, Four Women and a Roman Holiday
text: The ladies who lunch in Gianni Di Gregorio’s luminous sliver of a film, “Mid-August Lunch,” are Roman women in their 80s and beyond who have gathered in a small condominium in the Trastevere neighborhood. The modest apartment is the home of Gianni (Mr. Di Gregorio), an unemployed 50-something bachelor, and his 93-year-old mother, Valeria (Valeria De Franciscis).

headline: Off the Menu
text: Openings

headline: Anella
text: 222 Franklin Street (Green Street), Greenpoint, Brooklyn, (718) 389-8100.

headline: The Meatball Shop
text: 84 Stanton Street (Allen Street), Lower East Side, (212) 982-8895, themeatballshop.com.

headline: Southeast Asia Is Inspiration at Fatty ‘Cue in Brooklyn
text: SOME mac and cheese or cornbread with your barbecue? Not at Fatty ’Cue, opening March 23 in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. Try the celery ribbons with yuzu and preserved Chinese cabbage instead.

headline: Dining Calendar
text: Onstage Cuisine

headline: On the West Side, Coffee and Doughnuts the Italian Way
text: Having weathered a nightmare of construction delays that cost him nearly a year, David Ruggerio will finally open his latest entry on Columbus Avenue, on March 17. The stars at this handsome little storefront are the bomboloni  Italian filled yeast doughnuts that give the place its name. They are usually about the size of golf balls or a little larger, but in Mr. Ruggerio’s hands they are more substantial puffy pillows about two and a half inches in diameter. The shop offers a dozen fillings, many injected to order, including chestnut, raspberry, Sicilian pistachio, apple and peanut butter, in addition to plain custard. Panini, soup, hot and cold coffee drinks (including flavored lattes) and gelati in fewer flavors than the bomboloni round out the menu.

headline: Kitchen Gadgets Take the Fast-Food Mentality Into the Home
text: CHICAGO

headline: Taking the Bake Out of Bake Sale
text: IN one corner: Reduced Fat Cool Ranch Doritos, Linden’s Chocolate Chip Minis and Stacy’s Cinnamon Sugar Pita Chips. In the other: homemade pumpkin bread, pink cupcakes and spinach tofu empanadas.

headline: A Goat Cheese With a Cinderella Story
text: If you think of goat cheese as soft, fresh and mildly tangy, think again. In some ways goat cheese’s popularity has led to a certain dumbing down, making it a delicate spread, muffling its strongly assertive potential. But a new goat cheese from Quebec, called Le Cendrillon, coated with ash (“Cendrillon” means “Cinderella” in French), demands attention. A soft-ripening cheese that loses it chalky core and takes on a satiny texture and a more pungent, mouth-filling mineral flavor as it ages, it is meant to be put on the cheese board, at room temperature, not in a salad with beets.

headline: Simon Prepares New Offer for General Growth
text: 6:47 p.m. | Updated The Simon Property Group is preparing to raise its $10 billion offer for General Growth Properties in a bid to overcome a rival plan proposed by the bankrupt mall operator in concert with Brookfield Asset Management, people briefed on the matter told DealBook on Tuesday.

headline: Jailed Sri Lankan Opposition Leader Calls Charges Against Him ‘Bogus’
text: Four months ago, Gen. Sarath Fonseka was the commander of Sri Lanka’s army, hailed as a national hero by the country’s Sinhalese majority for putting an end to the long, bloody rebellion by Tamil separatists. Two months ago, after retiring, General Fonseka was barnstorming the country as a presidential candidate. Today, having been arrested just days after failing to win the presidency, he sits in a small room at a military facility in the Sri Lankan capital of Colombo, under armed guard, reduced to communicating with the world through handwritten statements smuggled out for him.

headline: The Perils of Pay Less, Get More
text: As a society gets richer, its tax rates tend to rise.

headline: Salsa Verde
text: 3 tablespoons vegetable oil

headline: Salsa Roja
text: 2 pounds ripe plum tomatoes (or 1 28-ounce can tomatoes)

headline: The Future of the Deficit
text: The Heritage Foundation has put together some good historical numbers on the kinds of spending that the federal government does. Those numbers appear alongside my column this week.

headline: Obama to Attend Yet Another Health Rally
text: If the Republican criticism of the Democrats’ health care bill is relentless, President Obama seems intent on being tireless.

headline: 2 Convictions in a Program With Mexico
text: LOS ANGELES — Two men caught smuggling marijuana at an Arizona border crossing have been sentenced in a Mexican court to 10-year prison terms under a pilot program that sends some Mexican criminal suspects back home for prosecution.

headline: Meals With a Top Chef
text: Colicchio & Sons is the subject of my restaurant review this week. The space used to be Craftsteak, and it retains some of that steakhouse brawn. The food is crazy-good throwdown fare that shows Tom Colicchio, the restaurant’s chef and an owner, to be at the top of his game. It’s worth heading over to Chelsea to give it a try.

headline: Loving Molly, and Getting Her to the Stage
text: THE Texas columnist and humorist Molly Ivins was an outspoken critic of those she saw as nincompoops in politics and big “bidness.” Ivins, who also wrote books like “Molly Ivins Can’t Say That, Can She?” and, with Lou Dubose, “Shrub: The Short but Happy Political Life of George W. Bush,” was feisty and controversial, a mix of bonhomie and sheer audacity. In short, a character.

headline: Divide and Diminish
text: This week, I want to dust off my crystal ball and make a prediction: in the future, the biggest land animals will be smaller than they are now.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 4,374 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war and 1,008 who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Tuesday:

headline: The Fine Art of Selling a Show
text: REMEMBER when a poster with a little French street waif or a pair of cat’s eyes was enough to sell a Broadway show? Now, with advertising trying to stand out on television, the Internet and mobile devices, choosing the right Broadway campaign often means finding a look that is flexible enough for different platforms, and one that also catches attention quickly.

headline: Ad Evolution: 'La Cage aux Folles'
text: A look at some of the rejected poster art for the coming Broadway revival.

headline: Hartford and Discover to Repay TARP Money
text: 7:41 p.m. | Updated Two more big companies — the Hartford Financial Services Group and Discover Financial Services — are preparing to pay back the billions of dollars that they received from the government’s banking bailout.

headline: When Kimmel Visits Letterman, the Subject Is Leno
text: The topic in a guest appearance by one late-night host on another late-night host’s show Tuesday night is how much fun they’ve had recently making fun of a third late-night host — as in Jay Leno.

headline: Excerpt: 'Breaking Bad'
text: Bryan Cranston narrates a scene from the season premiere of the AMC drama.

headline: Somalia’s President Assails U.N. Report on Corruption
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — Somalia’s president on Tuesday blasted a recent United Nations report that characterized the government’s security forces as ineffective and corrupt and said that as much as half the food aid to the country was routinely stolen.

headline: Iraq Elections: Sadr and His Rivals
text: Stephen Farrell and Anthony Shadid look at the recent parliamentary elections and the re-emergence of the Sadrist’s political influence.

headline: Alaska: Aerial Wolf Hunt Begins
text: State employees began an aerial wolf hunt on the Yukon border on Tuesday in what officials describe as an effort to preserve caribou for shooting by hunters. Officials at the adjacent Yukon-Charlie Rivers National Preserve argued against the hunt, saying that the wolves have had a particularly hard winter and need to recover. The state plans to kill as much as 80 percent of the local wolf population in the next week, or 185 wolves; there are an estimated 46,500 caribou. Since 2006 the state has regularly granted hunting licenses or assumed the task itself in planes or helicopters.

headline: Europe’s Public Broadcasters Ask Lawmakers to Make It Easier to Offer Programs Online
text: PARIS — European public broadcasters are calling on lawmakers to make it easier to offer their programming over the Internet, saying cumbersome copyright practices restrict their ability to develop new digital services and prolong the fragmentation of the European television landscape.

headline: Using the Kitchen as a Happy Place Where Couples Bond
text: IN Midtown Manhattan on Thursday, Tupperware will produce a publicity event in which Rick Goings, the kitchenware company’s chief executive, will show Reggie Bush, the New Orleans Saints football player, and Peter Facinelli, the actor who stars in the Showtime series “Nurse Jackie” and in the “Twilight” films, how to prepare a meal using only food, Tupperware products and a microwave oven.

headline: Greece Eager for Details on Loans From Europe
text: BRUSSELS — Greece received a welcome vote of confidence on Tuesday from the rating agency Standard & Poor’s for its deficit-reduction efforts, but the country was still pressing for details on a new loan rescue package from fellow euro-zone members, which remain divided over how it might work.

headline: Rock the Vote, Classic Car Style
text: Are you partial to Packards, or are Pacers more your speed? Do you pine for 1960s Detroit muscle, or does your heart weep for a Saab? Let your voice be heard.

headline: Simon Is Expected to Raise Bid for Mall Operator
text: The Simon Property Group is preparing to raise its $10 billion offer for General Growth Properties, the bankrupt mall operator, in an effort to overcome a rival plan proposed by General Growth in concert with Brookfield Asset Management, people briefed on the matter said on Tuesday.

headline: Leaders’ Lavishness Gives Rise to ‘Lifestyle Audits’
text: JOHANNESBURG — Jacob Zuma, the president of South Africa, has 20 children, three wives and a fiancée. Recently, the matter of how he supports this large and widely dispersed family has been vigorously questioned.

headline: Ailing Euro Seen as a Signal of Deeper Woes on Continent
text: FRANKFURT — It used to be easy to sum up the way European business executives viewed exchange rates: a strong dollar was good; a strong euro was bad.

headline: Lehman Hid Money With Help of Global Rules
text: Lehman Brothers’ now notorious Repo 105 scheme depended on forum shopping. The investment bank wasn’t able to persuade its lawyers in the United States that the relevant repurchase agreements constituted real sales. So it routed them through its British subsidiary. That meant they came under the British legal system, and the law firm Linklaters was able to opine that the transactions counted as sales.

headline: Iranians Defy a Ban in a Display of Dissent
text: Iranians defied a ban on events marking a traditional festival on Tuesday, turning an annual celebration into a show of antigovernment sentiment.

headline: Vatican Official Says Rising Number of Sexual Abuse Cases Could Overload Staff
text: ROME — As hundreds of new allegations of sexual abuse surface in the German church alone, a top Vatican official acknowledged Tuesday that, with only 10 people handling such cases, his office might not be adequate for the task.

headline: Ex-G.M. Chief Is Hired by AlixPartners
text: Fritz Henderson, the General Motors chief executive who oversaw the carmaker’s quick trip through bankruptcy, has been hired as a contractor by AlixPartners, the consulting firm that worked with him on the company’s Chapter 11 plan, according to a court filing made on Friday.

headline: In a Victory for London, Europe Delays Hedge Fund Rules
text: BRUSSELS — European Union finance ministers delayed a decision on new rules for hedge funds Tuesday in a reprieve for Britain, which fears that onerous regulations could drive the industry from London.

headline: Iran Unlikely to Develop a Nuclear Weapon This Year, Petraeus Says
text: WASHINGTON — Gen. David H. Petraeus said Tuesday that Iran would not develop a nuclear weapon this year, but that the country still remained the greatest threat to stability in the Middle East and Central Asia.

headline: Sex Assault Reports Rise in Military
text: WASHINGTON — The Department of Defense released an annual report on Tuesday showing an 11 percent increase in reports of sexual assault in the military over the past year, including a 16 percent increase in reported assaults occurring in combat areas, principally Iraq and Afghanistan.

headline: As Lawmakers Grapple With Financial Overhaul, They Call for More Studies
text: When in doubt, conduct a study.

headline: Hurdles Beyond Cash Remain for Fordham
text: Soon after Fordham’s trustees announced last month that the university would infuse a significant amount of money into its men’s basketball program, Athletic Director Frank McLaughlin received an e-mail message from a former classmate. The writer said he had stopped donating to the team because he was disappointed with its lack of progress. But upon hearing the news, he changed his mind.

headline: China: Film Star Responds to Accusations on Quake Charity
text: Zhang Ziyi, a star of “Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon,” and the best-known Chinese actress internationally, has denied accusations that she committed fraud while trying to raise money for victims of the devastating earthquake that hit Sichuan Province and surrounding areas in 2008. Ms. Zhang’s statements, published Tuesday in The China Daily, were the first by her on a scandal that has riveted many Chinese in the last few months. Chinese Internet users, after scouring public records, have accused Ms. Zhang, who also starred in “Memoirs of a Geisha,” of failing to fully donate $146,000 of her own money that she had pledged to the Chinese Red Cross. They also say she has never handed over $1 million that she said she hoped to raise from foreign donors. Ms. Zhang, above, said in the interview that a “communication glitch” led to her donating only $123,000 of her own money, and she asserted that she had donated the rest since the shortfall came to light.

headline: Underwater Cable an Alternative to Electrical Towers
text: Generating 20 percent of America’s electricity with wind, as recent studies proposed, would require building up to 22,000 miles of new high-voltage transmission lines. But the huge towers and unsightly tree-cutting that these projects require have provoked intense public opposition.

headline: Opportunity in a Fight With Israel
text: WASHINGTON — For President Obama, getting into a serious fight with Israel carries obvious domestic and foreign political risks. But it may offer the administration a payoff it sees as worthwhile: shoring up Mr. Obama’s credibility as a Middle East peacemaker by showing doubtful Israelis and Palestinians that he has the fortitude to push the two sides toward an agreement.

headline: Sticking by Her Teammates
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — Kelsey Griffin’s escape, which she had been diagramming in her mind for three years, came close to fruition during her junior season at Nebraska.

headline: Phoenix Meets the Wrong End of the Boom Cycle
text: PHOENIX — Perhaps it was just a matter of time, but three years after this city’s housing market collapsed in spectacular fashion, commercial real estate has followed it off the cliff.

headline: Church Turned Club Is Now a Market
text: What is perhaps Manhattan’s best-known former house of worship will be reborn this spring as the Limelight Marketplace, with 35 upscale boutiques and restaurants within its lancet-windowed walls on Avenue of the Americas in Chelsea.

headline: How Privacy Vanishes Online
text: If a stranger came up to you on the street, would you give him your name, Social Security number and e-mail address?

headline: Bush Voice in Iraq Eyes U.S. Senate Run
text: In the next few days, a man named Dan Senor is likely to announce that he will be a candidate in the Republican primary for the United States Senate, and New York will be granted a chance to revisit the making of surreal history.

headline: End of Life as We Know It
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — In an effort to do our part and help save the planet, the New York Times crossword is going green with a theme appropriate to the day. I have some notes from the constructor, who happens to also be my co-blogger. He has this week off, so now we can talk about him behind his back.

headline: States’ Rights Is Rallying Cry for Lawmakers
text: Whether it’s correctly called a movement, a backlash or political theater, state declarations of their rights — or in some cases denunciations of federal authority, amounting to the same thing — are on a roll.

headline: The Legacy of Mister Rogers
text: Images and memories of Fred Rogers abound in Pittsburgh, where he lived and worked.

headline: City Restaurants Required to Post Cleanliness Grades
text: The New York City Board of Health voted Tuesday to rate cleanliness in the city’s more than 24,000 restaurants with publicly posted letter grades, adopting a controversial plan proposed 14 months ago by the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene.

headline: Hoping to Sell, Team Owners Face a New Opponent: Recession
text: As a basketball player, Michael Jordan ruthlessly exploited his opponents’ weaknesses. As a businessman, he is now trying to exploit the financially troubled sports world by buying the money-losing Charlotte Bobcats of the National Basketball Association for about $25 million less than they sold for in 2002.

headline: Ex-Analyst Grubman Is Said to Sell His Townhouse
text: Jack Grubman, the former Salomon Brothers analyst who was banned from the securities industry for improper stock touting, has sold his Manhattan townhouse for $19.6 million, The New York Observer reported Tuesday, citing unnamed sources.

headline: Head of Arabic-Language School Resigns
text: The principal of the city’s only Arabic-language public school stepped down abruptly on Tuesday, just days after a federal commission determined that the city had discriminated against the school’s founding principal by forcing her to resign after a flurry of controversy.

headline: Senate G.O.P. Leader Finds Weapon in Unity
text: WASHINGTON — Before the health care fight, before the economic stimulus package, before President Obama even took office, Senator Mitch McConnell, the Republican minority leader, had a strategy for his party: use his extensive knowledge of Senate procedure to slow things down, take advantage of the difficulties Democrats would have in governing and deny Democrats any Republican support on big legislation.

headline: After 3 Suspected Suicides, Cornell Reaches Out
text: ITHACA, N.Y. — All weekend, Cornell University’s residential advisers knocked on dorm rooms to inquire how students were coping.

headline: Democrats to Watch on the Health Care Vote
text: If all of the current 431 House members vote, Democrats will need 216 to pass the legislation. The vote tally is now 218.

headline: Alicia Keys State of Mind
text: Not to knock Jay-Z, but we kind of prefer Alicia Keys's solo version of "Empire State of Mind." It's hard not get all goose-bumpy when she belts, "These streets can make you feel brand new, bright lights will inspire you." So, who wouldn't want to be there when the performer sings those lyrics to her hometown? Hear them tonight when Ms. Keys plays Madison Square Garden beginning at 7:30 p.m. We're hoping for a combined surprise guest appearance from both the "hova" and Stephen Colbert.

headline: Judging the Judge
text: Most people know Tom Colicchio as the chief justice of the "Top Chef" Supreme Court. But before he was a celebrity presiding over a hit reality show and restaurants in New York, Las Vegas and Los Angeles, he was a cook. "And at Colicchio & Sons," Sam Sifton writes, "He is running his kitchen at a level that New Yorkers have not been able to experience since his days at the helm of Gramercy Tavern, the restaurant he opened with Danny Meyer in 1994. For the moment, anyway, Mr. Colicchio's is the must-try New York menu. His restaurant isn't perfect. But it is exciting. And the food is terrifically good." Mr. Sifton suggests ordering the tasting menu, which features sophisticated composed plates. "There are elements of French technique to the cooking here, as well as an appreciable Italian devotion to ingredients. There are Indian flavors, and central European ones; there are nods also at Spain, at the Greenmarket, at North Africa. The result is a menu with an aesthetic that is entirely American. It appropriates all that has come to it, without apology."

headline: Break a Record
text: The most bananas to fit in a pair of pants at once; the most cocktail umbrellas to fit in hair in one minute; the tallest drawing of a midget  have we gotten your attention yet? All of these records were set at previous events hosted by the World Record Appreciation Society. Tonight, head to Joe's Pub to witness more and come up with your own records to break. An eclectic mix of performers will be there, like Ella Morton, who holds the record for the longest time hula hooping on one leg, and Jim Juvonen, who performs the fastest recitation, in order, of every prime number between 0 and 200, not to mention Eliot Gazer, who can perform the most bench presses of a live dog in one minute. Yep. That's right. He did.

headline: Violence Prompts Debate Over Medical Marijuana
text: SEATTLE — A shooting and a beating death linked to medical marijuana have prompted new calls by law enforcement officials and marijuana advocates for Washington State to change how it regulates the drug and protects those who grow and use it.

headline: Kevin Towers Tries for a Nicer Ring
text: TAMPA, Fla. – Kevin Towers wears a National League championship ring from 1998, with “SD” on the face, a reminder that he built a World Series team as general manager of the San Diego Padres. But the wounds from losing that series, to the Yankees in a sweep, remain.

headline: Move Across Hudson Further Isolates Immigration Detainees
text: When federal authorities shut down New York City’s only immigration detention center last month, and sent most of its detainees to a county jail in New Jersey over protests by their advocates, Obama administration officials stressed that the jail was only a short drive from the city.

headline: Democrats Consider New Moves for Health Bill
text: WASHINGTON — As lawmakers clashed fiercely over major health care legislation on the House floor, Democrats struggled Tuesday to defend procedural shortcuts they might use to win approval for their proposals in the next few days.

headline: Winter Ball Never Sleeps or Shivers at Metrodome
text: MINNEAPOLIS — As winter in the Midwest trudged on, with mounting snow and unrelenting cold, a former baseball coach at Augsburg College proved remarkably popular among his ex-peers.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: March 16, 2010

headline: Latest Storms Struck Hard at the Unlucky, More Than Once
text: The storms that whipped through the region over the past three weeks have left a bizarre dividing line between two neighbors in a quiet Westchester County town.

headline: Perfect Together: Tiger Woods and Augusta
text: Tiger Woods and Augusta National.

headline: Ron Lundy, a Rock D.J. in New York, Is Dead at 75
text: Ron Lundy, who wrapped his on-air exuberance in a soft Southern drawl during more than 30 years as a rock ’n’ roll D.J. in New York City, died Monday in Oxford, Miss. He was 75 and lived in Bruce, Miss. (population 2,097).

headline: Christian Soldiers
text: Last Friday night a New York Times headline underwent an online transformation. The article formerly known as “A Christian Overture to Muslims Has Its Critics” acquired a new billing: “A Dispute on Using the Koran as a Path to Jesus.”

headline: Paterson Aide Is Said to Ignore Subpoena
text: ALBANY — A senior aide to Gov. David A. Paterson failed to respond to a subpoena from a state ethics commission requiring him to testify about his role in obtaining World Series tickets last year from the Yankees for Mr. Paterson and others who attended a game with the governor, the commission’s chairman said in a statement issued on Tuesday.

headline: The Red Bulls Are Finally Ready to Open the Arena of Their Dreams
text: HARRISON, N.J. — The first thing you notice about Red Bull Arena is how big it appears from the outside. As you approach the stadium, the new home of the Red Bulls of Major League Soccer, it rises on the horizon like a giant floating silver soufflé. The stadium looks as if it could easily hold 50,000 fans, maybe more.

headline: Sellouts at New Stadium Are Next Battle for Jets and Giants
text: Now that a coin flip has determined that the Giants, not the Jets, will play the first regular-season game at the teams’ new $1.6 billion stadium at the Meadowlands, the next question is whether each team will sell out.

headline: Budget Cut for Fence on U.S.-Mexico Border
text: Citing a plague of “cost overruns and missed deadlines,” Homeland Security Secretary Janet Napolitano said Tuesday that she would cut millions of dollars intended for a high-tech “virtual fence” along the Mexican border that has produced little more than headaches for the federal government.

headline: Terror Suspect Likely to Change Plea
text: WASHINGTON — A Chicago man accused of helping to scout out Mumbai, India, in preparation for a rampage by a Pakistani terrorist group that left 163 people dead in 2008 is expected to plead guilty on Thursday.

headline: Monserrate Loses Bid to Regain Seat
text: Hiram Monserrate, who was expelled from the State Senate after being convicted of assaulting his companion, was handily defeated on Tuesday by José R. Peralta in a special election in Queens for Mr. Monserrate’s former seat.

headline: Corrections
text: A headline on Monday about a report on President Obama’s efforts to make the workings of the federal government more transparent misstated the conclusions of the report by the National Security Archive, a private research group. The report criticized the efforts of federal agencies, saying they had made slow and erratic progress in implementing Mr. Obama’s goals; the report did not criticize the goals themselves.

headline: Administration Seeks Converts to Education Plan
text: Facing intense resistance from teachers’ unions, the Obama administration has begun trying to persuade union leaders, teachers and the public that its proposals for overhauling federal education policies are good for teachers and for public schools.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Tuesday about the first interview by Rielle Hunter regarding her relationship with former Senator John Edwards referred imprecisely to the cancer that Mr. Edwards’s estranged wife, Elizabeth, is battling. While the cancer has metastasized to her bones, it began as breast cancer, not as bone cancer.

headline: Corrections
text: Because of an editing error, an article on Feb. 26 about Congressional scrutiny of President Obama’s space program misidentified the Senate panel where the NASA administrator, Maj. Gen. Charles F. Bolden Jr., testified on Feb. 24. It was the Science and Space Subcommittee of the Committee on Commerce, Science and Transportation  not the Subcommittee on Commerce, Justice and Space.

headline: Big Insurance Rate Increase for Pennsylvania Poor
text: Facing a sharp rise in costs, Pennsylvania has almost doubled the monthly bill for a state health insurance program for poor people who do not qualify for Medicaid and are on a waiting list for a less costly option.

headline: Corrections
text: A news analysis article on Tuesday about the obstacles facing President Obama’s blueprint for overhauling federal education policy misstated part of the name of the organization headed by Dennis Van Roekel. Mr. Van Roekel is president of the National Education Association  not the National Teachers Association.

headline: Tomlinson Is New Part for Evolving Jets Offense
text: In a span of nine days, the Jets released Thomas Jones, a veteran running back coming off his most productive season, and signed LaDainian Tomlinson, a veteran running back coming off his least productive season.

headline: Obama to Take Questions From Fox News
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama will give a rare interview on Wednesday to Fox News, the cable network that a top administration official once accused of being a political arm of the Republican Party.

headline: Corrections
text: Because of an editing error, an article in some editions on Saturday about the identification of the woman who was killed by a subway train as Rose M. Mankos, a Manhattan lawyer, misidentified the law school from which she graduated. It is New York Law School, not New York University Law School.

headline: Corrections
text: A picture caption in some editions on Monday with an article about the damage caused by a storm in the New York region referred imprecisely to a Long Island Rail Road station where power poles were leaning into wires. While it is in Valley Stream, it is known as the Gibson station  not as Valley Stream station. (There is a second station in the village by that name.)

headline: Teams on Mets’ Spring Training Schedule Are Sadly Familiar
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Spring training is all about fresh starts, getting in shape and taking a look at your competitors before the regular season. For the Mets, that last goal is getting harder to meet.

headline: Corrections
text: The Magazines listing in the Most Wanted chart on Monday, ranking publications by ad pages, carried an incorrect label indicating the month. In general, the ad page counts were for the magazines’ April issues  not March  with the exception of National Geographic Traveler, Islands and Spa. The counts for National Geographic Traveler and Islands were for their March issue, and Spa was a double March/April issue.

headline: Corrections
text: A biographical sketch on Saturday with an article about three contenders for seats on the Federal Reserve’s board of governors misstated the years that one candidate, Sarah Bloom Raskin, was a lawyer for the Senate Banking Committee. It was from 1993 until 1997, not until 2003.

headline: Will China Listen?
text: The drumbeat of complaints in Washington about China’s manipulation of its currency  and the deafening silence pretty much everywhere else  might lead one to think that this is just an American problem. It isn’t.

headline: Speeding Up Our Trains
text: To the Editor:

headline: Let’s Fight Over a Big Plan
text: Underlying the latest U.S.-Israel spat over settlements is the deeper  real  problem: There are five key actors in the Israeli-Palestinian equation today. Two of them  the Palestinian Prime Minister Salam Fayyad and the alliance of Iran, Hamas and Hezbollah  have clear strategies. These two are actually opposed, but one of them will shape Israeli-Palestinian relations in the coming years; indeed, their showdown is nearing. I hope Fayyad wins. It would be good for Israel, America and the moderate Arabs. But those three need their own strategy to make it happen.

headline: Time for Change in the Postal Service?
text: To the Editor:

headline: ‘Baby Einstein’ Aftermath: A Tangled Tale
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Good Deal for the Everglades
text: The effort to restore Florida’s Everglades has been revived thanks to the efforts of President Obama and Florida’s Republican governor, Charlie Crist. The Obama administration has committed more than $300 million in new money, and construction on important projects  including lifting a section of the Tamiami Trail to bring freshwater to the Everglades  is under way.

headline: Turning Green With Literacy
text: WHY should we celebrate the Irish?

headline: Why Consumers Can’t Trust the Fed
text: Cambridge, Mass.

headline: Bibi’s Tense Time-Out
text: WASHINGTON

headline: San Patricio
text: On this day of all days in the Irish-American calendar, when ethnic pride swells, let’s raise a toast: Here’s to the Irish, and here’s to the rest of us. May we never forget where we came from. Nearly all of us were Mexicans once. That is: the new immigrants, poor and reviled, propelled by hope and hunger into America’s prickly embrace.

headline: Taxi Rip-Off
text: Taking a taxi in New York City is nearly always an adventure. Sometimes the driver is the best tour guide in the city. Sometimes not. Now comes evidence that thousands of unscrupulous cabbies have been cheating passengers  to the tune of $8 million over two years  by pushing a button that automatically doubled the fares.

headline: Short Hops, Low Fares, Around Asia
text: A long, long time ago — way back in the mid-1990s — when I was living in Southeast Asia, getting around the region was a frustrating process. If I wanted to visit Cambodia, I’d take a bus from wherever I happened to be — usually Bangkok or Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam — and though it never cost more than $6, the daylong ordeal was always so painful I swore I’d never do it again. Then, a few months later, I’d do it again.

headline: Corrections
text: Because of an editing error, a report in the Southeastern Conference men’s basketball tournament roundup on Saturday about Tennessee’s victory over Mississippi on Friday referred incorrectly to comments by Brian Williams of Tennessee about the impact of a teammate’s collapse in September because of a heart problem. The comment  that it was not enough to shock the team into harmony  was a paraphrase of Williams’s views, not a direct quotation.

headline: Corrections
text: A television review on Friday about the HBO World War II series “The Pacific” erroneously included a battle among those fought by the First Marine Division. That division did not fight at Iwo Jima. The review also misstated the role of Col. Lewis B. Puller in the division. While he was a senior officer, he was not the division’s commander.

headline: From Start, Johnson Fit Profile Yankees Wanted
text: TAMPA, Fla. — Even at the start of his career, in the early 2000s with the Yankees, it was obvious Nick Johnson was stubborn at the plate. It remains the only way he knows how to hit. The deeper the count, the more pitches he sees, the more comfortable Johnson feels.

headline: Corrections
text: An Op-Ed article on Thursday, about acceleration accidents in Toyotas, misstated the name of the federal agency investigating the incidents. It is the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, not Transportation Safety Administration.

headline: Corrections
text: An Op-Ed article on Friday, about onboard diagnostic units in cars, incorrectly described safety and emissions inspections for vehicles on the road. Their timing is determined by the states, not the federal government.

headline: Corrections
text: A column by David Brooks on Tuesday about the political maneuvering over the health care bill stated that the 2003 prescription drug bill was passed in the United States Senate by the reconciliation process. The bill passed by simple majority without the use of reconciliation.

headline: Water From Above and Deep Down Below
text: Water undergirds the streets of New York. The Manhattan gridiron plan of 1811 created a dense network of 155 crosstown streets that linked the East and Hudson Rivers over land. And deep below the pavement, enormous water tunnels supply the city. New Yorkers may not ordinarily be conscious of such things, but whether coping with a blustery November day at Fifth Avenue and 59th Street (above) or last weekend’s pummeling, they know that water is still a powerful force.

headline: Lehman Hid Money With Help of Global Rules
text: Lehman Brothers‘ now notorious Repo 105 scheme depended on forum shopping, Reuters Breakingviews says. The investment bank wasn’t able to persuade its lawyers in the United States that the relevant repurchase agreements constituted real sales. So it routed them through its British subsidiary. That meant they came under the British legal system, and the law firm Linklaters was able to opine that the transactions counted as sales.

headline: Clean Your Plate
text: Piero Fornasetti famously adorned his dinnerware with more than 350 variations of a single face: that of the 19th-century singer Lina Cavalieri, known as opera’s greatest beauty. On the other hand, should you set your table with a new MexICON Platter from the design studio DFC Mexico City, you might discover a slightly more startling sight — the face of the telecommunications magnate Carlos Slim, say, or the eyepatch-wearing ’70s soap star Catalina Creel, who resembles “an old woman turning into a fly,” according to the DFC co-founder Tony Moxham. He and Mauricio Paniagua, known for trippy creations like their three-foot-tall table in the shape of a grasshopper, conceived the series as homage to Fornasetti while introducing the world to their hometown heroes. The rest of the cast includes the poet Pita Amor, the architect Luis Barragán (left) and — the lookers of the bunch — the actors Andrés García and Verónica Castro. The group originally included Diego Luna and Salma Hayek, Moxham says, “but we took them out because they’re not as legendary.” Available at thefutureperfect.com.

headline: How Much Of The World Is In a Liquidity Trap?
text: As I’ve written many times in various contexts since the crisis began, being in a liquidity trap reverses many of the usual rules of economic policy. Virtue becomes vice: attempts to save more actually make us poorer, in both the short and the long run. Prudence becomes folly: a stern determination to balance budgets and avoid any risk of inflation is the road to disaster. Mercantilism works: countries that subsidize exports and restrict imports actually do gain at their trading partners’ expense. For the moment — or more likely for the next several years — we’re living in a world in which none of what you learned in Econ 101 applies.

headline: Speed Read for Wednesday, March 17
text: Highlights from Wednesday’s media coverage in The New York Times:

headline: Shelf Life | House Proud
text: The unlovely term “vernacular architecture” describes some of the most unusual buildings ever created by man, from Mongolian yurts and adobe pueblos to igloos, Irish sod houses, and Iranian desert towns. Many of these structures (like a tree-house that soars 140 feet above the West Papuan rain forest) lie at the frontiers of the imagination, while others (like a shanty in Manila held together with urban waste) we’d prefer to forget. The forthcoming book “Buildings Without Architects” (Rizzoli; $23) presents them all as works of grassroots ingenuity. Written by John May, who authored the official history of Greenpeace, the book pegs modish keywords like “energy-efficient” and “sustainable” to ancient buildings, most of which were made of stuff that’s been around since prehistoric times: wood, reed, earth and clay. A house built with used Heineken bottles is a curious exception.

headline: Americans in Edinburgh
text: Elevator Repair Service, the New York theater ensemble that has inventively transformed novels and films into stage productions like “Gatz” (based on “The Great Gatsby”) and “The Sound and the Fury (April Seventh, 1928),” will have a world premiere of its new work, “The Sun Also Rises,” at the Edinburgh International Festival in August. Based on the Hemingway novel, the production is one of several by American artists that will be featured at Edinburgh, which has dedicated this summer’s festival to exploring modern-day cultures of the “New World.” Among the other artists in the spotlight will be the New York-based Wooster Group, presenting “Vieux Carré,” a play by Tennessee Williams; the composer and choreographer Meredith Monk, in her festival debut with “Songs of Ascension,” which uses music, movement and film to examine spiritual enlightenment; and the theater auteurs Lee Breuer and Bob Telson, who will mount their “Gospel at Colonus,” a reimagining of Sophocles’ “Oedipus at Colonus” that had a two-month run on Broadway in 1988 starring Morgan Freeman and an array of soul and gospel singers. The festival is scheduled to run Aug. 13 to Sept. 5.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: 'Treme'
text: David Simon and Eric Overmyer discuss a scene from their upcoming HBO series, set in New Orleans.

headline: The HBO Auteur
text: It was a bright, warm, blue-skied December afternoon in Central City, New Orleans, and in this neighborhood of humble shotgun houses and overgrown empty lots, a convoy of white trucks and trailers idled incongruously while unmarked police cars blocked intersections nearby. On any other morning, a police presence would have meant more bad news: in a city that has one of the highest homicide rates in the United States, this neighborhood — roughly a mile from the French Quarter — has a murder rate that, in recent years, has hit quadruple that of the city as a whole. This morning, however, the 20 drivers, as well as 80 other crew members who hefted and humped a boggling array of gear at the tumbledown corner of Second Street and South Liberty, had anything but murder in mind: they were six hours into a day of filming the third episode of “Treme,” David Simon’s new HBO drama — co-created by the seasoned television writer and producer Eric Overmyer — which is set in post-Katrina New Orleans and will make its debut on April 11. The production was only two scenes into the six on the call sheet; at that pace, they were looking at a 15-hour marathon — yet another in the 11-day ultramarathon that shooting an hour of episodic television on location can demand. As the novelist George Pelecanos, a staff writer on “Treme,” told me of the years he spent on set as a writer-producer on “The Wire,” Simon’s breakthrough series: “If you got out with a 12-hour day, that was the luckiest day of the series. Try doing that for seven months straight. Only young people can do it. You don’t see many people in their 50s carrying around lights.”

headline: The System (Sort of) Works
text: Obviously the health care endgame has become a pretty ugly business, but having dissented from the liberal anguish over our “broken government” when the threat of the filibuster was forcing supporters of health care reform to count to 60 in the Senate, allow me to dissent as well from the conservative dyspepsia over the Democratic Party’s “unprecedented” use of various parliamentary maneuvers (today, reconciliation; tomorrow, “deem and pass”; the day after that, “blue steel”) to get the House and Senate bills reconciled and through. I think it’s a good thing that the countermajoritarian customs of the Senate, as adapted by the minority for a more ideological age, have made it very difficult to pass a sweeping overhaul of America’s de facto constitution. But I also think it’s appropriate that there exists, for an extremely determined but not-quite-super majority, mechanisms that allow legislators to overcome these hurdles and push a controversial piece of legislation through. “Hard but not absolutely impossible” seems like the right bar to set for a bill of this nature. I wish the Democrats had chosen a different path, but in the end, we live in a republic, not a direct democracy: If our elected representatives can really muster enough votes, within the rules, to pass health care legislation even after everything that’s happened — if they believe that strongly, in other words, that this is absolutely and without question the right policy for America — then they have every right to go for it. It may be their funeral, but it’s certainly their prerogative.

headline: Tribeca’s Most Wanted: Ice Cube Brings Football Documentary to Film Festival
text: Ice Cube — a man whose feelings on Los Angeles and its environs are already well documented in song — will have the debut of his new movie about the L. A. Raiders football team at the Tribeca Film Festival, the festival’s organizers said on Wednesday. The documentary, called “Straight Outta L.A.,” chronicles the move of the Raiders from Oakland to Los Angeles in 1982, over the objection of the National Football League, and how the team inspired its new hometown and the burgeoning hip-hop scene. The film, which was produced as part of ESPN Films’ “30 for 30” series, will be shown as the opening movie of the Tribeca/ESPN Sports Film Festival on April 23, and will be shown May 11 on ESPN. The full Tribeca festival runs from April 21 through May 2.

headline: Beware the Snap Draft Decision at the N.C.A.A. Tournament
text: Jonathan Givony is the founder of DraftExpress.com, a Web site dedicated to scouting and analyzing the top basketball players in the world outside of the N.B.A.March 19, 2006. Auburn Hills, Mich. An anonymous 7-footer by the name of Patrick O’Bryant caps off an incredible N.C.A.A. tournament weekend with a career-high 28 point performance, badly outplaying the projected first-round pick and his fellow seven-footer Aaron Gray. His 13th-seeded Bradley team just took down the Big East powerhouse Pittsburgh, after upsetting fourth-seeded Kansas two days earlier.

headline: African Assembly
text: Johannesburg’s Arts on Main complex, with its stylish mix of tenants, has quickly become a culture hub since it opened last summer, bringing life back into the heart of a neglected central business district. The project, the brainchild of the 27-year-old developer Jonathan Liebmann (who’s currently converting a nearby factory into a hotel in time for this summer’s World Cup), occupies five redone warehouses around a central courtyard (above left) on the corner of Main and Berea Streets. The complex’s anchor is the studio of the celebrated South African artist William Kentridge, whose presence has helped draw an elite group of chefs, designers and gallery owners.

headline: Celebrating Sondheim
text: Photos from a birthday concert for the composer Stephen Sondheim.

headline: The Hunt for 216 Votes
text: The Times has published a useful chart describing the Democrats whose votes may make or break health care legislation as it comes up again in the House. It’s worth a close look. Find it here.

headline: Irish Cardinal ‘Ashamed’ of Handling of ’75 Abuse
text: DUBLIN — The besieged leader of the Roman Catholic Church in Ireland said Wednesday that he was “ashamed” of the role he played decades ago in handling accusations of child sexual abuse against a priest who went on to sexually assault scores of children, and he hinted that he might bow to calls for his resignation.

headline: ‘Take Classy Photos’
text: Monologue |  Tuesday night on “Late Night With Jimmy Fallon” on NBC: You guys see the GQ pictures of John Edwards’ mistress, Rielle Hunter? Today, she called them “repulsive,” and says she trusted GQ’s photographer to take classy photos. Yeah, because anytime I’m on a bed in nothing but dress shirt and underwear next to a Dora the Explorer doll, I think, “This is gonna look classy.”

headline: Living With Music: A Playlist by Malena Watrous
text: Malena Watrous is a frequent contributor to the Book Review. Her first novel, “If You Follow Me,” was published this month.

headline: ‘A Close Vote’
text: Monologue |  Tuesday night on “The Late Show With David Letterman” on CBS: Congress is getting ready to vote on President Obama’s health care bill. It’s going to be a close vote. The House Democrats say it could be a real tickle fight.

headline: ‘Significant Inconsistencies’
text: Monologue |  Tuesday night on “The Jay Leno Show” on NBC: Toyota is starting to fight back. Today, they cast doubt on the story of that guy — remember the guy last week that said his Prius accelerated out of control on the freeway? They said they found significant inconsistencies in his story. And let me tell you something, that’s embarrassing when a car dealer calls you a liar.

headline: Violence on the Oncology Ward
text: I’ve read about hospital nurses dealing with violence at work, but I always told myself that was something that happened in the emergency room or the psych ward. In oncology, I reasoned, we have relationships with our patients, and I have always felt safe with them.

headline: Demons and Demonization
text: The usual suspects have been attacking Obama for “demonizing” insurance companies; but saying that people do terrible things isn’t demonization if they do, in fact, do terrible things.

headline: Bachus Calls for Inquiry Into Lehman
text: A Republican legislator has called for a hearing into a court-appointed examiner’s report on Lehman Brothers, and specifically about regulators’ failure to uncover accounting gimmicks used by the failed investment bank, Reuters reported.

headline: March (Money) Madness
text: 11:51 a.m. | Updated

headline: Boston Art Heist Marks 20th Anniversary
text: Most art-museum robberies are the stuff of low comedy, not high crime, and the goods are eventually returned to the walls. But the 1990 heist at the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum in Boston – in which paintings and drawings worth well more than $300 million were taken – has long been the exception.

headline: OMG Magic Garden Reunion!
text: Before there was freak-folk, there were Carole and Paula. Some of the happiest — O.K., maybe not happiest; most retrospectively poignant? — moments of City Room’s collective childhood were spent parked in front of Channel 11 passively frolicking in their Magic Garden, hanging on our pigtailed hosts’ every strum, watching them pluck koanlike riddles from the Chuckle Patch and get fresh with the ur-freak Sherlock the Squirrel, waiting vainly to be shouted out on the hi-to-Johnny-and-Sally-and-Sue segment.

headline: Why You’d Rather Ride With a Woman Than a Man
text: From our colleagues at Freakonomics:

headline: Taliban Hit Back in Marja With a Campaign of Intimidation
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — The Taliban have begun waging a campaign of intimidation in Marja that some local Afghan leaders worry has jeopardized the success of an American-led offensive there meant as an early test of a revised military approach in Afghanistan.

headline: Lawmaker’s Car Costs Taxpayers $2,900 a Month
text: It’s no secret that lawmakers lease cars that are paid for by taxpayers. But Representative Emanuel Cleaver of Missouri recently raised eyebrows with his “mobile office.”

headline: Tea for Two: Dame Edna Everage and Michael Feinstein
text: The stunt-loving producer David Merrick must have smiled from behind the pearly gates last fall. That was when a war of words between Dame Edna Everage and the singer and piano man Michael Feinstein over titles for their new Broadway shows (“It’s All About Me” for her, “All About Me” for him) was discovered to be a hoax coordinated to promote — via carefully timed press releases — a production the two would star in together.

headline: A Virtual Tour of the Biennial, Twitter (and Cameras) Allowed
text: If you’ve wanted to visit the Whitney Biennial but do not live near New York or work a job where you’re never allowed to leave your desk (ahem), the museum and WNYC radio are collaborating on a virtual tour that you can follow from your computer or other Web-enabled device.

headline: G.M. May Make Profit in 2010, New C.F.O. Says
text: General Motors has a “reasonable chance” of turning a profit this year, but the car maker is still a work in progress, the company’s new chief financial officer said on Wednesday, according to press reports.

headline: Stupak Ally in House Approves Senate Abortion Restrictions
text: Representative Dale Kildee, Democrat of Michigan and a strong opponent of abortion, announced on Wednesday that he was satisfied with the provisions in the Senate-passed health care bill that seek to limit the use of federal money for insurance coverage of abortion.

headline: Panel for Better Air Travel Security
text: Frustrated by the long waits, confusion and seeming contradictions of airport security? The U.S. Travel Association, a nonprofit group that represents the industry, has assembled a Blue Ribbon Panel for Frictionless Security to create a vision for a secure, efficient and customer-friendly air travel security screening process.

headline: Answers About New Consumer Laws: Part 2
text: “Ask an Expert” is a recurring feature on Bucks where you have the opportunity to question big-brained individuals about a particular area of personal finance or consumer affairs.

headline: SXSW: Sharing Space With a Hubble Astronaut
text: Reports from the South by Southwest film festival.

headline: Alaïa Time
text: On the very last night of Paris collections, at close to 9:30, the Azzedine Alaïa show got underway before a small crowd in his studio in the Marais. Drinks and hors d’oeuvres were passed. The designer’s St. Bernard was shown to his ample bed in the kitchen and the models hit the improvised runway in the showroom.

headline: Now Screening | Movie Night at Crosby Street
