text: In a previous life, I saw a lot of movies in screening rooms. There was something about sinking into a cool leather lounger in the hush of a Midtown high-rise that made every film seem better than it actually was. I thought “Nurse Betty” was terrific. Mel Gibson’s “Payback”? Loved it.

headline: A Lawyer Who Represents a Friend May Have an Unhappy Client
text: Last May, Efrain González Jr., a former New York state senator, appeared with his lawyer in Federal District Court in Manhattan and pleaded guilty to conspiracy and mail fraud.

headline: Doses of Perspective
text: It is one of those days when perspective seems ready to run off the rails, as helpless as the poor guy going 65 miles per hour on the New Jersey Turnpike on a day when the 90 m.p.h. pack is in a particularly foul mood. Yes, actual humans were professing to feel badly that the poor, disrespected Masters would be sullied by Tiger Woods’s return. The whining about N.C.A.A. seeds and matchups was almost deafening.

headline: Stanford Knows the Drop From No. 1 Can Be Steep
text: Most schools would celebrate being a No. 1 seed in the N.C.A.A. women’s tournament, but Stanford (31-1) is keeping calm about being the top team in the Sacramento regional.

headline: Are ‘Green’ Consumers Less Trustworthy?
text: The Guardian newspaper picked this up recently, and it also makes an appearance in the most recent issue of Conservation magazine: people who buy green products may be, on the whole, more likely to steal and cheat when given the chance.

headline: Answers From a Film Scout
text: Following is the first set of responses from Nick Carr, who for the past five years has worked as a film location scout in New York, combing the streets for every type of locale imaginable for use in feature films and on television.

headline: Vocabulinks
text: An occasional assemblage of notable vocabulary and linguistic debate from around the Web.

headline: Raul Esparza to Join ‘Anyone Can Whistle’
text: Raul Esparza, a four-time Tony Award acting nominee for both musicals and plays, has been cast as the leading man, the mysterious J. Bowden Hapgood, in the coming City Center Encores! production of the Stephen Sondheim–Arthur Laurents musical “Anyone Can Whistle,” Encores! officials said on Wednesday.

headline: Tournament Tipoff: Making the Picks
text: With the opening round of the men's N.C.A.A. tournament fast approaching, The Times's Pete Thamel navigates through the field of 64.

headline: Quote Unquote | Go Figure
text: –Gisele Bündchen discusses how she was able to model immediately after giving birth to her son Benjamin. Her secret? Gisele is superhuman.

headline: Making Regular Yogurt ‘Greek’
text: The excitement over “Greek” yogurt — the ultra-thick, ultra-expensive kind — inspired me to produce a column about making it yourself. I’m not talking about making yogurt, though; I’m talking about making “Greek-style” yogurt from any regular yogurt. The process is simple and easy, and the results are perfect. See this week’s Minimalist column.

headline: Senator Leahy’s Photo Spread
text: Many people know that Senator Patrick Leahy, the Democrat from Vermont, is an avid photographer.

headline: Young Curators Speak
text: Four young Manhattan curators, all in their 30s, talk about their jobs and bringing art to the next generation of museumgoers.

headline: Irish Cardinal Apologizes to Abuse Victims
text: Updated | 5:19 p.m. In a St. Patrick’s Day homily and in a televised statement to reporters on Wednesday, Cardinal Sean Brady, the leader of Ireland’s Roman Catholics, apologized to victims of sexual abuse and “to all those who feel I have let them down.”

headline: Red Bulls Coach Likes One Young Defender in Particular
text: HARRISON, N.J. — Thirty years ago, Hennes Weisweiler of Germany came to the United States to coach the Cosmos and found a young, little-used defender, Jeff Durgan, sitting on the bench. Weisweiler took a liking to the big and rugged player from Washington State and made him a starter.

headline: Ex-Lehmanites: Repo 105 Outrage Inspires Giggles
text: To many observers, the revelation of Lehman Brothers‘ use of an aggressive accounting technique, Repo 105, to make its balance sheet look $50 billion lighter is an outrage.

headline: Workman Hires a New Publisher
text: Workman Publishing, an idiosyncratic independent publisher of titles ranging from the blockbuster “What to Expect” series to novels like “Water for Elephants” and “The Reliable Wife,” has started a succession plan by naming Robert S. Miller, currently president of HarperStudio, as group publisher.

headline: G.M. Tinkers With Augmented Reality System for Cars
text: The research and development labs of General Motors have been working closely with several universities, including Carnegie Mellon University and the University of Southern California, to build an augmented reality system that could assist motorists in difficult driving situations.

headline: The Making of the President, Then and Now
text: “The campaign book deserves to die, and it is doing its duty.”

headline: Student Crossword | War Puzzles
text: What country joined the Allies in August 1916, declaring war on Austria-Hungary? If you know the answer, put it in #45 across.

headline: Houston Rises Again, Cooling Penders’s Hot Seat
text: HOUSTON — When Tom Penders was approached to become the University of Houston men’s basketball coach six years ago, he bolted to the nearest elevator.

headline: At Tammany Hall, Irish Bosses Ran a Well-Oiled Machine
text: A half-century ago, as the Democratic machine, its best days behind it, was being successfully challenged by reformers, Daniel Patrick Moynihan wrote an eloquent essay entitled “When the Irish Ran New York.” It’s particularly appropriate to recall Mr. Moynihan’s nostalgic musings not merely because of St. Patrick’s Day, but because nowadays it appears as if no one is running New York.

headline: G.M. Has ‘Reasonable Chance’ of Profit This Year, Its Chief Finance Officer Says
text: DETROIT — General Motors has a “reasonable chance” of earning a profit this year, the carmaker’s chief financial officer, Christopher P. Liddell, said Wednesday.

headline: Rielle Hunter and the God Within
text: If you can’t bear to read the GQ interview itself, just read Hanna Rosin’s take on the Edwards mistress’s religion of the self:

headline: Another Top Paterson Aide Resigns
text: Marissa Shorenstein, Gov. David A. Paterson’s press secretary and acting chief spokeswoman, resigned on Wednesday. She becomes the fifth top state official to resign in the wake of a scandal over the Paterson administration’s handling of a domestic violence incident.

headline: Xobni Arrives on the BlackBerry
text: At our sibling blog, Bits, Claire Cain Miller reports on the introduction of Xobni Mobile for BlackBerry devices, which will be welcome news for Outlook users who are addicted to Xobni, an add-on service that organizes and searches e-mail messages and contacts.

headline: Pete Thamel’s N.C.A.A. Tournament Picks
text: The Times’s Pete Thamel chose the teams he expects to advance to the Final Four and championship games in Indianapolis after a game-by-game analysis of round one and the regions in this year’s N.C.A.A. tournament.

headline: Greener Pastures
text: This season, stylish travelers are indulging their pastoral fantasies.

headline: What the S.E.C. Gets in Dodd’s Financial Bill
text: Peter J. Henning follows issues related to white-collar crime and securities law for DealBook’s White Collar Watch.

headline: Cracks Bedevil Bloomberg’s Driveway
text: A wave of snowstorms has produced tire-devouring potholes and gaping cracks in roadways across the city.

headline: Patrick McCarthy to Leave Condé Nast
text: Patrick McCarthy, the chairman and editorial director of Condé Nast’s Fairchild Fashion Group and de facto editor of the fashion magazine W, will leave the company at the end of the year.

headline: Jetstar to Expand Routes and Reduce Fares
text: Bloomberg is reporting, Jetstar, a budget carrier and subsidiary of Qantas, plans to expand international routes and lower some fares while also reducing costs, its chief executive said.

headline: Keeping Abe, and the Rest of Us, Honest
text: Abraham Lincoln wrote the letter, an election year paean to the Methodist church, in 1864, at the height of his rhetorical powers, after the Gettysburg Address and before his second inaugural speech. Yet to the modern eye, the letter suffers from some all-too human flaws.

headline: Ludacris Takes Over at No. 1 on Billboard Charts
text: New on the Billboard album chart this week: Lucadris, Gorillaz, Jimi Hendrix and a new project by members of Gnarls Barkley and the Shins.

headline: Broadway Star to Opera Star, All in a Day
text: 2:17 p.m. | Updated  Plantation owner by day; regal ghost by night. It’s not a pitch for a bizarre comic-book hero — it’s the Saturday schedule for David Pittsinger, who may need some super-powered vocal cords to pull it off.

headline: ‘Good Wife’ Watch: Doubts Worth Puzzling Over
text: Tuesday night’s episode of “The Good Wife” was one of the best, in no small part thanks to Martha Plimpton, who was back in the role of Patricia Nyholm, a manipulative lawyer for a greedy (of course) insurance company. This time, she was helping her client weasel out of covering the costs of emergency surgery on a woman’s unborn son – using her own plump, healthy newborn as a prop.

headline: Talk Deeply, Be Happy?
text: Would you be happier if you spent more time discussing the state of the world and the meaning of life — and less time talking about the weather?

headline:
Obama Delays Trip as Report Aids Final Push
on Health Care
text: WASHINGTON — As House Democrats geared up for a possible vote on Sunday to pass health care legislation, the Congressional Budget Office issued an analysis allowing them to point to significant cost savings in the decades ahead, and President Obama postponed a planned trip to the Pacific to keep pressing for approval.

headline: Can’t See the Road? G.M.’s Next-Gen Head-Up Display May Help
text: General Motors is working on a head-up windshield display system that will reportedly make it easier for drivers to see where they’re going when they can’t see where they’re going.

headline: Minute Man | Andrew Block
text: In the second part of our guide to capitalizing on your good taste with an investment-grade watch, T asked Andrew Block, the executive vice president of Tourneau, some time-pressing questions.

headline: Israel Seeks to Mend Rift With the U.S.
text: JERUSALEM — Israeli officials said Wednesday that efforts were under way to calm tensions with the Obama administration and come up with a formula to defuse a diplomatic crisis over building in contested East Jerusalem.

headline: Late for Mass, but With a Good Excuse
text: When Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly arrived a few minutes late to St. Patrick’s Cathedral for Mass on Wednesday morning, Archbishop Timothy M. Dolan gently ribbed him for being tardy.

headline: British Ads Ignore Uncertainties of Climate Change, Watchdog Agency Finds
text: A British advertising watchdog this week criticized a government poster campaign publicizing the dangers of climate change — the latest setback in efforts to raise awareness of the issue.

headline: ‘The Hurt Locker’ Through a Baghdad Lens
text: BAGHDAD — It was Election Day in Iraq and Oscar night in America. It was my sixth day in Baghdad, and like many of the soldiers I was with, it was my first hitch here.

headline: SXSW: The Music Onslaught Begins
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — As the recording business implodes, the South By Southwest Music and Media Festival sprawls. I’m just arriving for this year’s four-day frenzy of bands, bands, bands — day parties, night showcases, after parties, Webcasts, YouTube follow-ups —  punctuated by conversations and breaks for barbecue. I brought a list of prospective bands to see that will be impossible to fulfill and that will probably get tossed away by Friday as more likely candidates come up.

headline: N.B.A. Board Approves Jordan’s Purchase of the Bobcats
text: The N.B.A. board of governors on Wednesday unanimously approved Michael Jordan’s purchase of the money-losing Charlotte Bobcats from Robert L. Johnson. The acquisition placed a $275 million value on the team, and Jordan is increasing his small stake to a majority one.

headline: Travel Deals: Free Train Travel in Ireland
text: For travelers 66 years or older, Tourism Ireland is offering a Golden Trekker Pass: four days of unlimited free train travel on Irish Rail.

headline: Schapiro Says S.E.C. Is Looking Beyond Lehman
text: As details have emerged about how the accounting tactics of Lehman Brothers helped bring about the firm’s demise, Mary L. Schapiro, the chairwoman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, confirmed on Wednesday that the agency was investigating other several companies’ actions in the run-up to the financial crisis of 2008, The Associated Press reports.

headline: Is Passing the Health Care Bill Really a Bad Idea?
text: Gail Collins: David, when I went off on vacation I left you to converse with Dick Cavett. Really, what could be more fun? All the while I was gone I was imagining what a great time the two of you were having. Well, O.K., not all the time. But the thought definitely occurred.

headline: Merkel Urges Tougher Rules for Euro Zone
text: FRANKFURT — Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany, adopting a harsher tone toward Greece than the one expressed by some other European leaders, said Wednesday that Europe needed better rules to police its members, and she tacitly endorsed a proposal to eject wayward countries from the group of countries that use the euro.

headline: Muslim Scholar, Formerly Barred, Coming to New York
text: A prominent Muslim academic barred from the United States for six years under the Patriot Act will speak at a panel at Cooper Union next month, his first public appearance since the restriction was lifted.

headline: Seton Hall, in Turmoil, Fires Gonzalez
text: Seton Hall dismissed Bobby Gonzalez on Wednesday, ending his tumultuous four-year tenure as men’s basketball coach a day after an ignominious first-round loss in the National Invitation Tournament and the arrest of a player who had been kicked off the team.

headline: District by District, Data on Health Care
text: Say you’re a House Democrat, wondering whether to vote for President Obama’s health care bill. Representative Henry A. Waxman has some data for you.

headline: Obama: Everything Is on the Line
text: President Obama has sent an e-mail message thanking members of his Organizing for America group for their efforts in building support for the Democrats’ health care legislation.

headline: Illinois Senate Candidate Mines Health Care Opposition
text: Representative Mark Kirk, the Illinois Republican who is hoping to win Barack Obama’s former seat in the United States Senate, told supporters last week that he intended to “lead the effort” to repeal President Obama’s health care legislation if it passes.

headline: SXSW: No Parking on the Dance Floor
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — It’s not garage rock, just rock in a parking garage, as Broken Bells starts its SXSW run in the concrete surroundings of the Red River Garage. (Tonight the group performs on NPR from Stubb’s.) On its album, Broken Bells is the collaboration of James Mercer from the Shins and Danger Mouse from Gnarls Barkley. Onstage, it’s a seven-man band, and even though they’re striving to replicate the arrangements on the album, down to the oozy keyboard effects, its flesh-and-blood players and bigger crescendos help the songs escape the subdued studio production. The songs are still morose about many human failings, but not so withdrawn, a shading that makes a difference–more psychedelic, less studied. And it doesn’t hurt that, strange but true, this garage has better acoustics than some SXSW clubs.

headline: Can a Recovering Sex Addict Have Sex?
text: When a panel of experts recently joined the Consults blog to answer readers’ questions about sex addiction, one reader asked whether a recovering sex addict can ever have sex again. Sexual addiction therapist Joe Kort responds.

headline: Fed Fights to Keep Oversight of Banks That Aren’t Big
text: WASHINGTON — Officials at the Federal Reserve are trying to alter a Senate proposal that would focus the Fed’s regulatory attention on the nation’s biggest banks and strip away its powers over small and medium-size banks.

headline: The Morning Skate: Head Check Rule Fast-Track Gains Momentum
text: The effort by a group of N.H.L. general managers to accelerate the approval process on the proposed new rule against blindside checks to the head gained momentum yesterday.

headline: Testing 1, 2, 3: Creating Quizzes to Gauge Science Knowledge
text: Overview | How can quizzes be used as learning tools and assessments? What is the educational value of not only taking a quiz, but also creating one? Are there significant differences between interactive and traditional quiz formats? In this lesson, students take an online quiz, then create their own quizzes about scientists or science-related topics. They then take one another’s quizzes and consider their efficacy for introducing a new topic, reviewing material and assessing knowledge in a graded exam.

headline: McChrystal Disagrees With Holder: Bin Laden Is Wanted Alive
text: Gen. Stanley A. McChrystal, the top commander of American and NATO troops in Afghanistan, contradicted the attorney general on Wednesday when he said that actually, the military still wants to capture Osama bin Laden alive.

headline: Now Showing | The Original Diva
text: In a world where Miley Cyrus is considered a diva, a stroll through “Maria Callas: A Woman, a Voice, a Myth” is a refreshing detour. Now here is a woman who was both talent and tempest.

headline: Your Dot: Climate Concerns
text: Here’s another “Your Dot” installment, highlighting a couple of readers’ views of the climate-energy challenge. Robert Robinson, from upstate New York, echoes concerns expressed here by Robert Brulle, a sociologist at Drexel University, who notes that slow environmental changes are absorbed by society incrementally in ways that work against calls for substantial shifts in policy. Len Arends of San Bruno, Calif., compares rising human awareness of a looming problem driven by an unnecessary dependency to the situation of a person entering the first step of a 12-step rehab program.

headline: Paterson Says Gillibrand Threw Him Under the Bus
text: When Gov. David A. Paterson appointed a little-known junior congresswoman named Kirsten E. Gillibrand to the United States Senate last year, he probably expected it to be the beginning of a beautiful relationship.

headline: How to Prepare Your Business for Succession
text: WHEN his father died in 2006, Allen Frechter thought that his work as executor of the estate would be fairly straightforward.

headline: Shopping With Charlotte Moss
text: The interior designer shopped Manhattan's Upper East Side for china and decorative pieces for the table.

headline: Do You Have a Succession Plan?
text: Small-business owners who do not have a succession plan, Ian Mount writes in a just published small-business guide, create a time bomb that can not only destroy their companies but also tear apart their families. “A lot of families fight and fight until the business is gone,” said Jim Clay, who heads the trusts and estates department at the  law firm Morrison Fenske & Sund in Minnetonka, Minn. “It eats up everyone’s inheritances.”

headline: Texts Without Context
text: In his deliberately provocative  and deeply nihilistic  new book, “Reality Hunger,” the onetime novelist David Shields asserts that fiction “has never seemed less central to the culture’s sense of itself.” He says he’s “bored by out-and-out fabrication, by myself and others; bored by invented plots and invented characters” and much more interested in confession and “reality-based art.” His own book can be taken as Exhibit A in what he calls “recombinant” or appropriation art.

headline: Words, Version 2.0
text: A bookshelf for further reading:

headline: Major California Solar Project Moves Ahead
text: California regulators on Wednesday recommended that the state’s first new big solar power plant in nearly two decades be approved after a two-and-half-year review of its environmental impact on the Mojave Desert.

headline: Appreciating Your Value as You Age
text: AGING is an indiscriminate leveler. You might have been a shapely bombshell who made heads turn. You might have honed your intellect and résumé and let looks take a backseat. Still, most of us will pass a mirror one day and wonder who is that stranger with the droopy eyelids.

headline: Waiting for CBO
text: Vladimir and Estragon are getting pretty antsy waiting for the CBO score on the reconciliation package …

headline: It’s Hip to Be a Young, Creative Urbanite!
text: Many would like to see the hipster — the word, to say nothing of the person behind it — go the way of the dodo. Only problem: those who would retire the word can’t help using it.

headline: Setting a Spring Table
text: CHARLOTTE MOSS, the interior designer, is so intrigued with entertaining that years ago she bought Jacqueline Kennedy’s handwritten notes about entertaining at the White House.

headline: Bernanke Defends Fed’s Banking Oversight Role
text: The Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, urged Congress on Wednesday to let the Fed keep all of its banking oversight, arguing that information gleaned from that process helped the central bank guide the economy, The Associated Press reports.

headline: Credit Where It Isn’t Due
text: I’m not usually interested in White House intrigue, and I’m no Kremlinologist, but it does seem bizarre to claim that Democratic consolidation behind Obamacare is a vindication for Rahm Emanuel, of all people.

headline: Democrats Press Ahead With Student Loan Overhaul
text: The drive to pass health care legislation intersected on Wednesday with calls for President Obama’s proposed overhaul of the student loan system.

headline: Violence Follows Fires at Tombs in Uganda
text: Crowds took cover at the Kasubi tombs near Kampala on Wednesday as the army and the police fired at demonstrators. Reuters reported that Ugandan security forces killed two people and wounded five after fire destroyed the royal tombs. The 19th-century Tombs of Buganda Kings at Kasubi are listed as a world heritage site by Unesco. “It is a major example of an architectural achievement in organic materials, principally wood, thatch, reed, wattle and daub,” the citation says. “The site’s main significance lies, however, in its intangible values of belief, spirituality, continuity and identity.”

headline: The Most (and Least) Expensive Vehicles to Insure
text: The Porsche Carrera 911 GT2 two-door coupe is the most expensive 2010 vehicle to insure, according to a new ranking of average premiums for 2010 models that Insure.com released this week.

headline: 4 Banks Face Trial in Italy Over Interest-Rate Swaps
text: An Italian judge on Wednesday ordered JPMorgan Chase, Deutsche Bank, UBS and a banking unit of the German company Hypo Real Estate Holding to stand trial for fraud in their handling of interest-rate swaps acquired by the city of Milan in 2005, The New York Times’s Eric Sylvers reports from Milan. The trial of the four banks, as well as 11 of their employees and two former city officials, will begin May 6.

headline: Dances With Wolf
text: Martin Wolf apparently shares my views about the trouble with Chinese currency policy — and throws Germany into the mix. The difference is that he uses stronger language!

headline: Suspicion of Arson at Royal Tombs Fuels Deadly Clashes in Uganda
text: KIGALI, Rwanda — Riots erupted at venerated burial grounds in Uganda on Wednesday, and witnesses said that police officers shot and killed three protesters.

headline: A Family Triangle of Archetypes Amid the Sandbags of America
text: There is, for the record, a real kitchen sink in Suzan-Lori Parks’s “Book of Grace,” an ambitious, intriguing and annoying play that both embraces and explodes an assortment of theatrical clichés. That sink comes with the other furniture you expect in vintage dramas about American families with Problems that warrant capital P’s: stove, refrigerator, television, sofa, browbeaten wife in bathrobe.

headline: New Finding Puts Origins of Dogs in Middle East
text: Borrowing methods developed to study the genetics of human disease, researchers have concluded that dogs were probably first domesticated from wolves somewhere in the Middle East, in contrast to an earlier survey suggesting dogs originated in East Asia.

headline: Amelia Island Concours Weekend Is All Grown Up
text: The Amelia Island concours weekend in Florida had a considerably different feel this year. After 15 years, it feels like it’s all grown up.

headline: High-End and High-Speed in Spain
text: All aboard a luxury train from Madrid to Barcelona.

headline: The Calm Men Who Bring You Exotic Animals
text: There are moments in “Life,” the Discovery Channel’s follow-up to the widely acclaimed nature series “Planet Earth,” when a viewer can’t help wonder: How in the world did they capture that on camera?

headline: ABC and Amanpour Close to Deal for ‘This Week’
text: ABC News is close to concluding a deal to install the longtime CNN foreign correspondent Christiane Amanpour as the new host of its Sunday political discussion show “This Week.”

headline: Olympian Weighs In on ‘Eat Like Olympians’
text: One of the biggest sponsors of the coverage of the Vancouver Olympics on NBC Universal last month was McDonald’s, which ran a couple of commercials for Chicken McNuggets dozens of times. The spots invited viewers to “eat like Olympians” and promised that “you don’t have to be an Olympic athlete to eat like one.”

headline: Google and Partners Seek TV Foothold
text: Google and Intel have teamed with Sony to develop a platform called Google TV to bring the Web into the living room through a new generation of televisions and set-top boxes.

headline: Berkeley Scientist’s Herbicide Studies Raise Corporate Hackles
text: Accusations are flying over the latest University of California, Berkeley study on the effects of a widely-used weed killer on amphibian sexuality.

headline: Monserrate Reflects a Day After Losing
text: Hiram Monserrate is fully aware that there are a lot of people who wished that his failure to regain his old State Senate seat in a special election in Queens on Tuesday would seal his political career. And he really doesn’t care.

headline: A Hundred Years of Gifts From Finland
text: Finland is pretty hot at the moment, musically speaking. Where nonspecialists once began and ended their lists of great Finnish composers with Sibelius, now Einojuhani Rautavaara, Magnus Lindberg and Kaija Saariaho are creating some of the most inventive and compelling works being written anywhere.

headline: Neanderthal Stars in Smithsonian Exhibit
text: The Smithsonian’s National Museum of Natural History is opening a new permanent exhibit exploring human evolution over six million years.

headline: Opening Arguments
text: The authors of “Face It” aren’t the first to note that modern women are in a bind.

headline: Connecting to a Culture Using 4 Wheels
text: RYAN WASHINGTON, 21, said he can perform over 100 gravity-defying tricks on his skateboard, which has given him a place of honor at the local skate park. “There is no limit to what you can do on a piece of wood with plastic wheels, he said. “Whenever I master a trick, I feel like I am on top of the world.”

headline: City Opera’s Former Director Tracks the Tumult and Breaks Down the Buzz
text: The New York City Opera is never far from the thoughts of Julius Rudel, who was its general director and principal conductor for 22 years, until he stepped aside in 1979, making way for Beverly Sills. I recently met Mr. Rudel, still lively and avuncular at 89, for an interview in his apartment on Central Park West. And the first thing he showed off was his collection of framed sketches of memorable sets from City Opera productions he had conducted. The pictures adorn an entire wall next to his piano.

headline: BlogTalk: O’Bama’s Roots and Health Care
text: We have to start with a nod to St. Patrick’s Day, where in Washington there is no pause from politics. Today, when President Obama and the prime minister of Ireland, Brian Cowen, attended the annual luncheon on Capitol Hill, he managed to get in a few laughs about his own Irish roots and to link the holiday to the current health care debate by invoking the names of Ronald Reagan, Tip O’Neill and the late Senator Ted Kennedy.

headline: Pop Sensibilities, Along With Some Quirky Flair
text: It’s easy to imagine Larry Keigwin choreographing a Beyoncé video, even if you didn’t know he got his start as a backup dancer on Club MTV. Please don’t mistake that for faint praise (who doesn’t love her “Single Ladies”?), only a nod to this witty stylist’s pop sensibilities.

headline: Who Needs Wall Street?
text: Mike Mayo is a veteran of six Wall Street banks. In the wake of the street’s disaster, he found refuge at a boutique brokerage and has lately taken to startling his peers with the question “What part of Goldman Sachs is good for the country?”

headline: Maker of Tylenol Explains Actions Taken to Alleviate Musty Smell of Pills
text: The Johnson & Johnson unit that drew criticism and a federal warning letter in January on the grounds of mishandling quality control problems with Tylenol says it has taken steps to prevent similar incidents in the future, according to documents newly posted on the Web site of the Food and Drug Administration.

headline: A Grain Silo Reborn
text: Eighty feet up, 240 tons of concrete and steel in Olomouc, Czech Republic.

headline: Wachovia to Pay $160 Million in Drug Money Case
text: The Wachovia Bank, a unit of Wells Fargo, has agreed to pay $160 million to settle a federal criminal case accusing it of laundering Mexican drug money, Reuters reports.

headline: Living Against the Grain in the Czech Republic
text: OLOMOUC, CZECH REPUBLIC —  RADIM KRALIK and his wife, Barbora Kralikova, live in a modern concrete box on top of a 1943 grain silo, a stark contrast to the neo-Gothic spires that dominate this small city about 175 miles east of Prague.

headline: Steamed Quinoa, White Bean Salad With Sage and Pan-Fried Winter Squash
text: This is a very simple, satisfying plate of food that relies on foods from the pantry and vegetables that store well. The quinoa and bean recipes make more than one serving. Both are good keepers, so you can eat the leftovers for lunch or dinner the next day. Pan-cooked winter squash has become a favorite in our house; it’ll satisfy any cravings you might have for fries.

headline: The Greening of the White House
text: Even at the White House, there’s no escaping the color green, from the South Lawn to events throughout the day and night.

headline: Audio: Searching for Truth at SXSW
text: Reports from the South by Southwest film festival.

headline: A Mash-Up Culture: Ten to Watch
text: Sampling, mash-ups, redubs and collages are hardly new. In the early 60’s, William Burroughs and Brion Gysin popularized the use of decoupage or cut-ups, pioneered by the Surrealists, as a non-linear creative technique that could be used with words, sounds and images. And with his 1966 movie “What’s Up, Tiger Lily?” Woody Allen redubbed a Japanese spy film, turning it into a story about a dangerous quest to find the recipe for the world’s greatest egg salad.

headline: Living Proof
text: In Friesach, the picture-perfect Austrian town halfway between Vienna and Venice, in the Carinthian Alps, there is a bar that changed my understanding of the word “schnapps.”

headline: This Prince: What a Piece of Work
text: The Metropolitan Opera under general manager Peter Gelb is defining itself through the choice and quality, however debatable, of its ambitious new productions. Yet bringing successful existing productions of overlooked works to the Met is just as important to the company’s artistic mission, not to mention a safer bet. And few operas have been as overlooked as Ambroise Thomas’s “Hamlet.”

headline: Previous Taxi Fraud Cases, but No Red Flags
text: Two New York taxi drivers were convicted in 2008 of swindling passengers by charging higher rates meant for out-of-town trips, but city officials failed to follow up with a broader investigation that might have revealed the scheme to be far more widespread.

headline: China's Economic Growth on the Rise
text: Marcus Mabry and Liz Alderman of The Times discuss whether the Yuan is undervalued in Asia.

headline: Part Concert, Part Talk Show, All Escapism
text: For more than a decade Jo Dee Messina has been in the business of Oprah-fied country, singing songs of empowerment and escape with an eye for psychological detail and a firm sense of dignity. She’s been wronged, and if you don’t mind, she’d like to talk about it.

headline: Back to the Futurists
text: I have always been intrigued by the work of Fernand Léger. His tubular, mechanical paintings from the early 1920s captured his fascination with Futurism yet also his fear of new machines.

headline: Changing the Vatican’s Response to Abuse
text: As the sexual abuse scandal in the Roman Catholic Church continues to unfold, Pope Benedict XVI said he would issue a letter to Irish Catholics on Friday to help “repentance, healing and renewal.”

headline: Body Shop Begins a Campaign Against Sex Trafficking
text: Retail stores are typically happy, shiny lands of make-believe, the better to woo shoppers into opening their wallets and purses. Then there is the Body Shop.

headline: What We’re Reading …
text: Temporary marriages in Shiite Islam, and other links from around the Web.

headline: On the Guggenheim’s Walls, and Now on Yours
text: THIS month, the offerings at Charitybuzz, an auction site that helps nonprofit groups raise money, include a guitar autographed by the Rolling Stones, a dinner prepared by Emeril Lagasse and 193 pieces from an exhibition at the Guggenheim Museum.

headline: For Israel and America, a Disagreement, Not a Crisis
text: Washington

headline: I Want One
text: A Chicago Manual of Style purse: be the envy of all your style- and correctness-obsessed book-industry friends! (Via Brainiac.)

headline: Obama: Not Worried About House Procedural Moves
text: President Obama on Wednesday dismissed Republican criticisms of the parliamentary tactics Democrats may use to push his health care bill through Congress, saying he doesn’t ‘’spend a lot of time worrying about what the procedural rules are.’’

headline: Curator of Collections and Connections
text: IT was a quiet weekday afternoon last month on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, but the ground floor of the brownstone that houses the China Institute was humming. Employees were bustling around with tape measures and installation plans as they readied the institute’s gallery for the show “Confucius: His Life and Legacy in Art.” Willow Weilan Hai Chang, the gallery director, stood in a corner of the tiny two-room exhibition space, talking about that philosopher and his influence on Chinese society.

headline: Reducing the Anxiety of Paying Online
text: Last year, 92 million people bought things online using credit cards, debit cards and services like PayPal and Google Checkout. Millions of others paid bills and wired money electronically from bank accounts with just a few clicks.

headline: On HGTV, Fixing Homes and Hearts
text: “The Grants are getting a divorce,” Ian Kleier says after studying the gossip pages at the kitchen table of his Park Avenue apartment. His wife, Michele, is not surprised. “I had my suspicions,” she says, and starts to list the warning signs while scrambling eggs for “the girls,” the couple’s trio of white Maltese. Ian cuts her off. “It’s not a pretty divorce, and I think you should jump right on top of it.”

headline: Acting Leader of Nigeria Dissolves His Cabinet
text: DAKAR, Senegal — The acting president of Nigeria, Goodluck Jonathan, dissolved his cabinet on Wednesday in the strongest assertion yet of his authority over a country where his rule has been challenged.

headline: Episcopalians Confirm a Second Gay Bishop
text: A majority of bishops and dioceses of the Episcopal Church have approved the election of the church’s second openly gay bishop, the Rev. Mary D. Glasspool, a decision likely to increase the tension with fellow Anglican churches around the world that do not approve of homosexuality.

headline: From an Artist of Anxiety, an Ink-Stained Memoir
text: Jules Feiffer has always been adept at using satire to trace the links between our public and private anxieties, our political and personal preoccupations. In more than four decades of cartoons for The Village Voice, in films like “Carnal Knowledge,” plays like “Grown-Ups” and “Little Murders” and numerous books, he’s given us snapshots of neurotic families and neurotic singles, and a panoramic view of an America reeling from the social and political convulsions of the 1960s and ’70s, Vietnam, the disillusionments wrought by the Kennedy assassinations, Watergate, the Reagan and Clinton years, the gender wars and the fragmentation of the nuclear family.

headline: A Shorter Parade Means Less Green for Some on St. Patrick's Day
text: For a French restaurant with a fairly patrician customer base, Demarchelier, on East 86th Street at Madison Avenue, saw a fair amount of trade on Wednesday from the green T-shirt crowd. In the bar area, Irish music blared and plastic foam cups of beer were raised.

headline: A Shorter Parade Means Less Green for Some on St. Patrick’s Day
text: For a French restaurant with a fairly patrician customer base, Demarchelier, on East 86th Street at Madison Avenue, saw a fair amount of trade on Wednesday from the green T-shirt crowd. In the bar area, Irish music blared and plastic foam cups of beer were raised.

headline: Playing It Cool With a Jawbone in Your Ear
text: The word “apps,” of course, is short for applications, which means programs. But until 2007, nobody used the term apps except the people who wrote them — programmers. It wasn’t until the iPhone came along that apps became shorthand used by normal people.

headline: Detroit Plan Would Close 45 Schools
text: In a continuing overhaul of one of the most troubled school systems in the nation, officials in Detroit on Wednesday announced a plan to close 45 of 172 public schools at the end of the academic year. The move is the latest in a string of efforts aimed at rescuing an academically failing district in the midst of a financial crisis.

headline: More Cash to Go to a Hall Than to Haiti
text: Lang Lang, the celebrity pianist; Christoph Eschenbach, the conductor; and the Schleswig-Holstein Festival Orchestra are taking the stage at Carnegie Hall on Sunday night in a concert trumpeted as a fund-raiser for the earthquake-ravaged Haiti. But what ticket buyers may not realize is that far more of their dollars will go toward concert-hall rent and marketing than to anyone in Haiti, with the biggest chunks going to stagehands and newspaper advertisements.

headline: Geodesics on Globes
text: Konrad Polthier of the Free University of Berlin illustrates the non-uniqueness of locally shortest paths on the surface of an imaginary planet.

headline: ‘Backing Into Forward’
text: Chapter 1: Boy Cartoonist

headline: Finding the Brighter Side of a Dark Schubert Cycle
text: An evening based on Schubert’s “Winterreise” seems an unlikely antidepressant. But Rick Burkhardt, Alec Duffy and Dave Malloy give this gloomy song cycle an amusing theatrical makeover in “Three Pianos” at the Ontological-Hysteric Theater at St. Mark’s Church.

headline: A U.S. Debut for a Dutch Design Duo
text: Tubular benches made from coiled steel frames covered in tennis balls and old blankets given new life as colorful rugs are among the unorthodox furnishings by Atelier Remy & Veenhuizen that will be on view at Industry Gallery in Washington. “Hands On,” an exhibition opening March 20, is the first solo show in the United States for the Utrecht studio founded by Tejo Remy, a designer associated with the influential Dutch company Droog, and René Veenhuizen.

headline: Lighting and Furniture Sales
text: Hable Construction is offering a 25 percent online discount on its brightly patterned storage items and decorative accessories during March (throw pillows, below, originally $125, will be $93.75 when the code “marchon” is entered at checkout); information: hableconstruction.com.

headline: Road Test: Mops
text: The Process

headline: Let Your Conscience Do the Walking in Green Pages
text: Several new books extolling the virtues of green living provide information for readers of all commitment levels.

headline: An Expert on Choice Chooses
text: SHEENA IYENGAR, the S. T. Lee professor of business at Columbia University, was home from work the other day, dressed in a cream-colored twin set and a sparkly gold pencil skirt. She was seated at the head of a long cherry dining table she designed with her husband, Garud Iyengar, a financial engineer who is also a professor at Columbia, in the living room the two had decorated in earthy colors with a mix of furniture found at auction, in India and at a store in downtown Manhattan. There was a clear point of view — a consistent style or discernible taste, if you will — that linked all the objects in the room, including Dr. Iyengar’s outfit.

headline: A Model Apartment Dressed to the Nines
text: THE place smelled terrific. There were Jo Malone candles and tight little bunches of pink roses and calla lilies in short glass cylinders. The beds were freshly made. The stereo was on, but softly.

headline: Eva Zeisel Prints With Wings
text: When David Reid, left, and James Klein, the Long Island City ceramicists behind the KleinReid studio, were given the opportunity to meet one of their design idols, Eva Zeisel, center, they had no idea the encounter would lead to a lasting relationship. But more than a decade after their first meeting in 1999, the three continue to collaborate on a series of projects. Their latest, on sale today, is a limited-edition set of prints of reticulating shapes with classic Zeisel themes of wings and sprouts. The series is called “Lovers’ Suite” because “when we worked on the original porcelain pieces, Eva said, ‘Oh, you want them to make love,’ ” Mr. Klein said. “It’s a graphic description of how two forms interact so they mirror each other. They balance each other, and they come together to create something new and beautiful.”

headline: Bus Route Signs Roll on as Vintage Fabric
text: In England, bus route signs were once printed on rolls of calico cloth.

headline: On Dance: ‘NY Export: Opus Jazz’
text: The city of New York has always served as a kind of living set. And while movies and television have dominated this breathing back lot, dance has used it to its artistic advantage too. Trisha Brown sent a dancer down the side of a building in 1970 and more recently the choreographer Noémie Lafrance mounted a piece in a Brooklyn apartment.

headline: Newly Released Books
text: Matters of right and wrong are at the heart of this month’s crop of new books: What do we owe our fellow human beings at moments of crisis? What happens when authority figures turn a blind eye to the bad behavior of those under them? And, of course, when confronted by slave-holding vampires, is it worth risking the future of the nation?

headline: Crowdsourcing the N.C.A.A. Tournament
text: There are 9.2 quintillion possible outcomes to the N.C.A.A. basketball tournament.

headline: TheStreet.com Says It Faces an S.E.C. Inquiry
text: TheStreet.com, the finance Web site founded by Jim Cramer, disclosed in a regulatory filing on Wednesday that it is the subject of an inquiry by the Securities and Exchange Commission that began this month.

headline: Irish Celebrate Despite Shamrock Shortage
text: Having been particularly hard hit by the global financial crisis, which helped bring about the popping of a local real estate bubble, Ireland has been struggling to regain its footing, and redefine its identity, now that it is no longer an emerging economic powerhouse.

headline: First Fan’s Bracket Is All Business, No Politics
text: WASHINGTON – President Obama selected Kansas to win the N.C.A.A. championship. He presented his bracket on Wednesday at the White House as he took a break from the health care debate, which is one of the few things that has kept him from watching as much basketball as he hoped to this season.

headline: A Geodesic Highway
text: Konrad Polthier illustrates that geodesics are the natural generalization of straight lines.

headline: Just in Time for ‘Play Ball,’ Apps for the Baseball Afflicted
text: Quick, look around the office. Do people appear to be staring into their iPhones with a bit more intensity than just a few weeks ago? Remember how information technology administrators blocked all the fantasy-baseball Web sites in years past?

headline: What to Do When Gmail Overflows
text: Q. My Gmail account has filled up to 97 percent of my free allotment. I am too cheap to pay for more space. Is there a way send all this to another Gmail account as backup and free up space? Help, I only have a few days to spare!

headline: Ludacris Tops Hendrix
text: New on the Billboard album chart this week: Ludacris, Gorillaz, Jimi Hendrix and a new project by members of Gnarls Barkley and the Shins. Ludacris’s “Battle of the Sexes” (Def Jam) enters the chart at No. 1, with 137,000 sales, according to Nielsen SoundScan, followed by “Plastic Beach” (Virgin), the first album in five years by Gorillaz, which sold 112,000. With a new album of unreleased material and a pile of reissues, Hendrix makes a run on this week’s chart. “Valleys of Neptune” (Legacy), a new release with rare studio sessions, landed at No. 4 with 95,000 sales, and four newly reissued Hendrix titles  “Are You Experienced?,” “Axis: Bold as Love,” “Electric Ladyland” and “First Rays of the New Rising Sun”  charted between No. 44 and No. 67. Gary Allan’s new “Get Off on the Pain” (MCA Nashville) opens at No. 5 with 65,000 sales, and the self-titled debut album by Broken Bells, with Danger Mouse and James Mercer of the Shins, bows at No. 7; released by Columbia, it sold 49,000 copies in its first week. Last week’s No. 1, Lady Antebellum’s “Need You Now” (Capitol Nashville), fell two spots to No. 3 with 106,000.

headline: Heldentenor Foundation Is Closing Shop
text: Lauritz Melchior, the greatest heldentenor of his day and a supreme Wagner singer of the 1920s, ’30s and ’40s, knew how tough it was to find his kind of voice, so he set up a foundation in 1964 to seek them out.

headline: Raúl Esparza Joins ‘Anyone Can Whistle’
text: Raúl Esparza, a four-time Tony Award nominee for both musicals and plays, has been cast as the leading man, the mysterious J. Bowden Hapgood, in the coming City Center Encores! production of the Stephen Sondheim-Arthur Laurents musical “Anyone Can Whistle,” Encores! officials said on Wednesday. Mr. Esparza (“Speed-the-Plow,” “Company”) will play opposite the previously announced Sutton Foster (“Thoroughly Modern Millie”) in the revival, which will also star Donna Murphy as the corrupt mayor of a financially bankrupt town. The original 1964 production of “Anyone Can Whistle,” which featured Angela Lansbury in her Broadway musical debut, drew mixed reviews for its somewhat absurdist storytelling and ran for only nine performances. The Encores! revival is scheduled to have five performances April 8 to 11.

headline: 20th Anniversary of a Boston Art Heist
text: Most art-museum robberies are the stuff of low comedy, not high crime, and the goods are eventually returned to the walls. But the 1990 heist at the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum in Boston  in which paintings and drawings worth well more than $300 million were taken  has long been the exception. The biggest art theft in American history, it turns 20 on Thursday, with the whereabouts of a Vermeer painting, three Rembrandts (including his only known seascape; above is its empty frame) and a Manet still unknown. Investigators and the museum are trying new tactics to recover the works, The Associated Press reported. The F.B.I. has resubmitted DNA samples recovered in the case for updated testing, and a longstanding $5 million reward offered by the museum is being publicized anew, with the use of two interstate highway billboards to advertise it. The statute of limitations for prosecuting the thieves  two men who masqueraded as Boston police officers  has long since passed, and federal officials have held out the possibility of immunity, in exchange for information, for anyone subsequently involved in the theft.

headline: Lloyd Webber’s Picasso Finally Set for Auction
text: After the resolution of a four-year-old claim by a German academic that a 1903 Picasso painting had been sold under duress to the Nazis in the mid-1930s, Christie’s announced on Wednesday that it would auction the work, “Portrait of Angel Fernández de Soto (The Absinthe Drinker), ” right, in London on June 23. The portrait, from Picasso’s Blue Period, depicts his friend Angel Fernández de Soto seated at a cafe table, shrouded in tobacco smoke. The Andrew Lloyd Webber Foundation, which the composer founded to benefit theaters and actors, is selling the work, which it bought at Sotheby’s in 1995 for $21.9 million. Christie’s was to have sold the painting in New York in November 2006 to benefit the foundation, but it was forced to withdraw it 24 hours before the auction after the collector Julius H. Schoeps filed a lawsuit saying that it had been forcibly sold by his great-uncle, Paul von Mendelssohn-Bartholdy, a Jewish banker in Berlin. Three years ago Christie’s expected it to bring $40 million to $60 million. Now, after a settlement between the heirs and the foundation, the auction house believes it can fetch around $60.9 million.

headline: Duncan’s Swipe at the N.C.A.A.
text: Education Secretary Arne Duncan took another swing at the National Collegiate Athletic Association and top college basketball programs Wednesday, reiterating a call he made in January to ban from postseason play teams that fail to graduate at least 40 percent of their players.

headline: Movie by Ice Cube at TriBeCa Festival
text: Ice Cube  a man whose feelings on Los Angeles and its environs are already well documented in song  will have the debut of his new movie about the Los Angeles Raiders football team at the Tribeca Film Festival, the festival’s organizers said on Wednesday. The documentary, “Straight Outta L.A.,” chronicles the move of the Raiders from Oakland to Los Angeles in 1982 over the objection of the National Football League, and how the team, which returned to Oakland in 1995, inspired its new hometown and the booming hip-hop scene. The film, produced as part of ESPN Films’ series 30 for 30, will be shown as the opening movie of the Tribeca/ESPN Sports Film Festival on April 23.

headline: Singer’s Busy Day: ‘Hamlet’ and ‘South Pacific’
text: Plantation owner by day; regal ghost by night. It’s not a pitch for a bizarre comic-book hero  it’s the Saturday schedule for David Pittsinger, who may need some super-powered vocal cords to pull it off.

headline: Can Karpov Be President of Chess Federation?
text: The former world champion Anatoly Karpov announced on Saturday that he was running for president of the World Chess Federation.

headline: Banks Face Fraud Charges in Deals Involving Milan’s Debt
text: MILAN — An Italian judge Wednesday ordered JPMorgan Chase, Deutsche Bank, UBS and a banking unit of the German company Hypo Real Estate Holding to stand trial for fraud in their handling of interest rate swaps acquired by the city of Milan in 2005.

headline: Lagerfeld to Help Tod’s With Its Hogan Brand
text: PARIS — Karl Lagerfeld has a new world at his feet: The Italian company Hogan, part of the Tod’s footwear empire, said Wednesday that it had signed the designer for a special collection.

headline: Change Comes to Myanmar, but Only on the Junta’s Terms
text: PYAPON, Myanmar — In the dried mud of the Irrawaddy Delta, workers are welding together the final pieces of a natural-gas pipeline that the country’s ruling generals say will keep the lights on in Yangon, Myanmar’s main city, after years of debilitating blackouts.

headline: Lehman’s Bankruptcy Bill Hits $678.5 Million
text: The bankruptcy tab just keeps growing for Lehman Brothers. The investment firm, which is in the process of liquidating, paid its bankruptcy advisers and lawyers a total of $678.5 million in the 17 months since it collapsed in September 2008, Bloomberg News reports, citing a regulatory filing by the firm.

headline: N.H.L. May Prohibit Blind-Side Head Checks This Season
text: NEWARK — As the N.H.L. moved to speed its proposed rule against blind-side checks to the head for possible passage this season, the man whose actions fueled the effort, the Penguins’ Matt Cooke, sat unfazed in his dressing-room stall at the Prudential Center on Wednesday.

headline: How Smart Could I Make My Dumb Manhattan Apartment?
text: SOMEBODY in my apartment is not very smart, and since I live alone, it is obviously the machines.

headline: Smart Home Devices You Can Set Up Without Calling in the Pros
text: Home automation has been around as long as world’s fairs, but the latest developments — making homes more energy efficient, controlling security on the Internet and running everything off a smart phone — have resulted in more powerful systems that are easier to install and cost less.

headline: SAP Bosses Say It’s Now Pedal to the Metal
text: Pop quiz: You’re the new chief executive of a software maker that has been ridiculed ad nauseam for being years late with a product. What do you do?

headline: German Call for Austerity Has Europe Grumbling
text: PARIS — Across Europe, from profligate Greece to newly strait-laced Ireland, countries are promising deep, painful cuts in public spending even as they face the likelihood of a new recession.

headline: Relax, Legal Scholars: Bobbleheads Are Safe at Yale
text: NEW HAVEN — The oldest item in Yale Law School’s rare book collection is a 1,000-year-old fragment of a medieval manuscript bound inside an Italian guidebook for notaries. The newest is a bobblehead doll depicting William H. Rehnquist, 16th chief justice of the United States.

headline: Time Seems Right for Paypal to Fly
text: The online payment company PayPal would continue to grow if its parent, eBay, let it leave the nest.

headline: Files Logging Scout Abuse Are a Focus in Civil Trial
text: PORTLAND, Ore. — Files kept secret for decades that detail hundreds of claims of child sexual abuse by troop leaders of the Boy Scouts of America are at the center of a civil court case that began here Wednesday.

headline: I Need to Vent. Hello, Facebook.
text: WHAT is the sound of an awkward silence on Facebook? If you have to ask, then you probably don’t have friends like James Gower and Ashley Andrews, high school sweethearts from Spring, Tex., who are both 22 and engaged to be married this May.

headline: Programmers Are Indicted in Madoff Case
text: Two former computer programmers at Bernard L. Madoff’s firm were indicted Wednesday by a federal grand jury in Manhattan.

headline: V.A. Is Fined Over Errors in Radiation at Hospital
text: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission on Wednesday announced its second-largest fine ever against a medical institution — $227,500 — after finding that the veterans hospital in Philadelphia had caused an “unprecedented number” of radiation errors in treating prostate cancer patients.

headline: Pentagon Sees a Threat From Online Muckrakers
text: To the list of the enemies threatening the security of the United States, the Pentagon has added WikiLeaks.org, a tiny online source of information and documents that governments and corporations around the world would prefer to keep secret.

headline: Promising a Rose Garden
text: With the weather finally warming up in the capital after a long, snowy winter, the White House press secretary, Robert Gibbs, joked during his regular press briefing the other day that, “like class, we should move this outside.’’

headline: Economic Overhaul in Myanmar
text: Joseph Kahn, deputy foreign editor, talks to a Times reporter in Myanmar about the changes that are happening in the country.

headline: World Bank Urges China to Bolster Rates and Let Currency Rise
text: HONG KONG — The World Bank recommended higher interest rates and a stronger currency for China on Wednesday, as it raised growth forecasts for the country. China’s rapid economic growth has led to expectations of rising inflation and concerns that a bubble is building in the property industry.

headline: The CFDA Awards Finalists
text: I popped on my BlackBerry and — voila! — there were the finalists for the 2010 Council of Fashion Designers of America awards. So many bold-faced names competing for attention …

headline: As Deflation Fears Persist, Japan Eases Monetary Policy
text: TOKYO — In a bid to shore up a deflation-plagued economy, Japan’s central bank eased monetary policy further Wednesday by increasing a loan program for banks.

headline: Animal Abuse as Clue to Additional Cruelties
text: Responding to growing evidence that people who abuse animals often go on to attack humans, states are increasing the penalties for animal cruelty and developing better methods for tracking convicted offenders.

headline: Drone Strike Said to Kill a Leader of Al Qaeda
text: WASHINGTON — A strike by an unmanned drone last week killed a senior commander of Al Qaeda who had played a significant role in planning the killing of Central Intelligence Agency operatives in late December at a base in Afghanistan, according to American officials.

headline: In the End, Conduct Is What Counts
text: Providence, R.I.

headline: Haiti: Children Reunited With Families
text: The 33 Haitian children taken from their earthquake-damaged homes by American church members in January were reunited with their biological families on Wednesday, officials said. The children, who ranged in age from 4 months to 12 years, were cared for at the SOS Children’s Village in the capital, Port-au-Prince, while social workers investigated their backgrounds. Nine of the 10 Americans arrested by the Haitian authorities while trying to take the children to the Dominican Republic were later released. The leader, Laura Silsby, remains in custody.

headline: Martinez, an Understudy, Is Playing Like a Star
text: FORT MYERS, Fla. — The Mets put an entire story line on the team bus on Wednesday, sending all three contenders for the starting center-field job on the three-hour trip here to face the Boston Red Sox.

headline: Rosneft Stock Falls on Fear of Seizures
text: MOSCOW — Shares in Russia’s state oil company, Rosneft, slumped Wednesday after the company was said to have warned its trading partners that a British court could seize assets under a lawsuit filed by former executives of Yukos Oil.

headline: France: Female Ex-Minister to Join Académie Française
text: Simone Veil, 82, a Holocaust survivor who became a French minister and president of the European Parliament, will become the sixth woman to enter the Académie Française on Thursday. The state-sponsored body oversees French language and usage. The ceremony will be attended by President Nicolas Sarkozy and former President Jacques Chirac and will be televised live. Ms. Veil, who also served on the Constitutional Council, is considered responsible for legalizing abortion in France as minister of health in 1975 and is one of the most popular women in the country.

headline: Ukraine: Venue Offered for Arms Talks
text: Ukraine’s new president, Viktor F. Yanukovich, has offered Kiev as a location for the United States and Russia to sign a revamped nuclear arms reduction treaty, once it has been agreed to. Though the peace agreement is unrelated to Ukraine, having the treaty formally signed in Kiev, the capital, would be rich in symbolism for a country whose recent internal politics became a tug of war between Russia and the West for economic and political influence. Mr. Yanukovich, though he is generally viewed as leaning heavily toward Russia, has promoted the idea of Ukraine as bridge between East and West, rather than a country that falls readily within either sphere of influence. Russian officials welcomed the offer; the United States would prefer Prague, where President Obama gave a speech on disarmament last year, Ukraine’s new foreign minister, Kostyantyn Gryschenko, said Wednesday.

headline: An Apparel Underdog Outfits a No. 15 Seed
text: PITTSBURGH — Amid the Nike swooshes and Adidas three stripes that dominate the N.C.A.A. basketball tournaments, it may be hard to spot the logo of a little-known company that is squeezing its foot in the door of the $4 billion sports-apparel industry.

headline: Little Police Protocol for Out-of-Control Cars
text: SAN FRANCISCO — How does a police officer deal with a driver behind the wheel of a possible runaway vehicle? Probably the same way the officer would deal with any other high-speed pursuit.

headline: A Small Victory in Afghanistan
text: Last week Defense Secretary Robert Gates visited the district of Now Zad in Afghanistan’s volatile Helmand Province. To many, it probably didn’t seem like significant news. Gates reportedly went no farther than a 100 meters outside the forward operating base and there were fully armed Marines posted at short intervals not far from where he was walking. They had probably been in position for at least 24 hours before Gates arrived and the area was likely swept for explosives and insurgents multiple times in the days prior to his arrival.

headline: Austria: Choir Faces Abuse Allegations
text: Eight former members of the Vienna Boys Choir have called an abuse hot line set up by the choir to report that they were sexually abused while they were members of the group, according to Tina Breckwoldt, who is overseeing the hot line. The choir opened the hot line after a local newspaper reported last week that two former choir members claimed that they had been sexually abused while in the choir decades ago. The callers who made the claims, which included accusations of sexual and physical abuse, ranged in age from 33 to 72, Mrs. Breckwoldt said. Some of the alleged perpetrators may have been boys in the choir at the time, she said. The eight calls had been received as of Wednesday. In an open letter on its Web site, the Vienna Boys Choir said that any abuse constituted “an injustice that we deeply regret.”

headline: Governments Turn to ‘Stealth’ Taxes to Fill Gaps
text: France, promising to improve the environment, is planning to introduce a carbon tax. In Finland, where the government says it wants to improve diets, taxes are back on candy and soft drinks. Similarly, Denmark has added tobacco and some fatty foods to the list of taxed products.

headline: The Purists
text: Quite a week for Dennis Kucinich, the liberal Democratic congressman who had been threatening to do to health care what Ralph Nader did to Al Gore in 2000.

headline: Familiar Series
text: Notepad: When this puzzle is done, the answers will include a familiar series of 38 Across (minus the middle square). Connect the squares of this series in order with a line, starting with the circled square. The resulting image will be a pair of 38 Across (WITH the middle square). In addition, the clues all share a feature that provides an additional hint to the puzzle’s theme.

headline: For Early Rounds at Masters, Woods + Two = Delicate Task
text: When Tiger Woods returns to tournament golf at next month’s Masters, which two golfers will be his opening day playing partners — some would say three-ring circus sideshows — during what is expected to be the most scrutinized round of golf ever?

headline: Lawmakers Say Needs of Rural Schools Are Overlooked
text: An Oklahoma senator complained that federal rules on teacher credentials had driven thousands of experienced educators out of rural schools. A North Carolina lawmaker complained that formulas for distributing federal education money favored big-city districts at the expense of poor students in small towns.

headline: Tech Talk Podcast: Recycling a Hard Drive
text: In this week’s Tech Talk podcast from The New York Times, Bettina Edelstein is in a spring cleaning mood. She talks about how to recycle an old computer hard drive into an external backup device. All it takes is a screwdriver and the right enclosure.

headline: Clinton to Meet With Russian Leaders on Arms Control Talks
text: SHANNON, Ireland — With the United States and Russia still haggling over the fine print of a long-delayed arms control pact, Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton left Washington on Wednesday for high-level meetings in Moscow, as the Obama administration tried to push the talks across the finish line.

headline: Deficit Hawk Returns, Much to His Party’s Dismay
text: WASHINGTON — Former Senator Alan K. Simpson, the co-chairman of President Obama’s bipartisan commission for reducing the mounting federal debt, figures that with the country in danger of “going to the bow-wows,” he has bigger things to worry about than whether “Rush Babe” and other conservative critics are “babbling into the vapors” that he is not Republican enough for the job.

headline: China Drawing High-Tech Research From U.S.
text: XI’AN, China — For years, many of China’s best and brightest left for the United States, where high-tech industry was more cutting-edge. But Mark R. Pinto is moving in the opposite direction.

headline: Montana’s Star Guard Has Taken the Ball, and Life, in His Hands
text: SAN JOSE, Calif. — When Anthony Johnson carried the ball into the Weber State frontcourt, with the clock winding down and Montana’s season in his hands, it was not the first time he had to think quickly and ride his instincts.

headline: Comparing the House and Senate Financial Reform Bills
text: President Obama and Congress have vowed to enact the farthest-reaching overhaul of regulations since the Depression.

headline: Linen, Kindly and Cruel
text: LAST week the cold finally broke, which meant the arrival of the first flash of calf on the streets in months. Breathability mattered again, and so the youngish shopper’s fancy turned lightly, and with much hesitation, to thoughts of linen.

headline: U.S. Mulls Own Plan for Mideast Talks
text: WASHINGTON — The angry exchanges between the United States and the Israeli government have rekindled a White House debate over whether — and when — President Obama should propose an American plan to form the basis of negotiations between Israel and the Palestinians, senior administration officials said Wednesday.

headline: "Benihana" by Hyatt and Funny or Die
text: In a series of Web videos from the comedy site Funny or Die, Hyatt will emphasize what can go wrong when people choose the wrong hotel or meeting planner.

headline: "Ultra Lounge" by Hyatt/Funny or Die
text: In a series of Web videos from the comedy site Funny or Die, Hyatt will emphasize what can go wrong when people choose the wrong hotel or meeting planner.

headline: Corrections
text: A headline on Tuesday about state cuts in funding for Medicaid referred imprecisely in some editions to the response of patients whose doctors have dropped out of the program and no longer treat them. While some patients have chosen to forgo health care, they have not themselves dropped out of the Medicaid program.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on March 10 about new security measures at Amsterdam’s Schiphol airport imposed after Alberto Stegeman, an investigative journalist, reported that he had smuggled a refilled liquor bottle through its screening system, misspelled the name of an aviation school in Daytona Beach, Fla., where Robert Raffel, a security expert who complimented Mr. Stegeman for having “imaginatively uncovered a weakness in the system,” is a professor. It is Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University, not Emory-Riddle.

headline: The Funny Side of What Can Go Wrong at the Big Meeting
text: WITH the country in a grim mood about corporate America, Hyatt is adding some humor to its marketing in an effort to get companies to hold meetings again.

headline: Rio de Janeiro Is in Fight Over Brazil’s Oil Riches
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — The battle over Brazil’s newfound oil riches is heating up.

headline: Can’t-Miss Prospect May Make It After All
text: EL PASO — When the basketball world first met Derrick Caracter, in July 2001, he was 13 years old, 6 feet 8 inches and carried around a stuffed orangutan named Ollie.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Wednesday about the deep spending cuts planned by Gov. Christopher J. Christie of New Jersey referred incorrectly to his call for new $310 deductibles and a doubling of some drug co-payments. Those measures would apply to participants in a state prescription-drug plan for the elderly and disabled, not to Medicaid patients.

headline: Bloggingheads: Grading Obama's Strategy
text: Mark Schmitt, left, of The American Prospect and Noam Scheiber of The New Republic evaluate President Obama’s strategy on health care reform.

headline: Corrections
text: An article in some editions last Thursday about a raid by Manhattan prosecutors on the offices of Lehr Construction as part of an investigation into the interior construction industry referred erroneously to Lehr’s criminal record. Although the company was investigated previously for its role in a bid-rigging scheme, and its owners pleaded guilty to bribery in 1998 in connection with that case, a plea agreement allowed the company to avoid charges; it did not plead guilty.

headline: Alex Chilton, Rock Musician, Dies
text: 10:48 a.m., March 18 | Updated Alex Chilton, the mercurial if influential rock musician, whose work spanned an eclectic gamut from the soul songs of the Box Tops to the multiple incarnations of his pop band Big Star, died on Wednesday. He was 59 and lived in New Orleans.

headline: Corrections
text: The Advertising column on Wednesday, about a new advertising strategy for Tupperware, misstated the date, in some copies, for a publicity event in Midtown Manhattan featuring the football player Reggie Bush and the actor Peter Facinelli. It is today; it was not held on Wednesday.

headline: At Villanova, Wright’s Style Is Part Flash, All Candor
text: VILLANOVA, Pa. — In July 2007, Villanova guard Scottie Reynolds, then coming off a rookie-of-the-year season in the Big East, played for Wildcats Coach Jay Wright with the United States team in the Pan-American Games in Rio de Janeiro. During one practice, Reynolds, a meek shooter, failed to perform a defensive drill correctly three times. After the third try, Wright’s silver tongue turned into a leather whip in front of the team.

headline:
Planned Switch
to G.O.P. Stirs New York Governor Race
text: ALBANY — A governor’s race that seemed all but settled is about to be upended again, by a popular Democrat from Long Island who is set to announce that he is switching parties. The move is certain to excite Republican leaders pessimistic about their party’s hopes this fall.

headline: Corrections
text: The Sports of The Times column on Tuesday, about Jets Coach Rex Ryan’s recent bariatric surgery to help him lose weight, misidentified the organization that fined him $50,000 for a gesture he made in January in response to heckling by Miami Dolphins fans. He was fined by the Jets, not by the National Football League.

headline: Studios and Cable Unite in Support of Video on Demand
text: LOS ANGELES — Movie studios, battling a steep decline in DVD sales, have decided the moment has finally come to get out the megaphone for video-on-demand services.

headline: Muslim Scholar, Formerly Barred, Is to Speak in New York
text: A prominent Muslim scholar barred from the United States for six years under the Patriot Act will speak on a panel at the Cooper Union next month, his first public appearance in this country since the restriction was lifted.

headline: Corrections
text: A music review on Tuesday about the Grand Finals Concert of the Metropolitan Opera’s National Council Auditions misidentified, at one point, the soprano who sang selections from Mozart and Wagner. As the review noted elsewhere, she is Rachel Willis-Sorensen  not Leah Crocetto, another soprano in the competition.

headline: The Flooding Returns, and With It, the Questions
text: BOUND BROOK, N.J.

headline: Arthur H. Christy, Special Prosecutor, Is Dead at 86
text: Arthur H. Christy, who as the first special prosecutor under a new ethics law in 1979-80 pursued allegations that Hamilton Jordan, the chief of staff in the Carter White House, had used cocaine at Studio 54, the Manhattan disco, died on March 12 in Manhattan. He was 86.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: March 17, 2010

headline: Feel Ragged? Renew at This Cafe
text: SWEAT SHOP, a tiny new cafe near a trendy stretch of Paris, had barely opened its doors last week when it faced its first fashion emergency. A young woman brought in a teddy bear that had been worn to pieces.

headline: Corrections
text: The cover article in today’s Museums special section about the new generation of museum curators misstates the surname of an artist whose satirical prints were included in “A Woman’s Wit: Jane Austen’s Life and Legacy,” an exhibition that recently closed at the Morgan Library & Museum. He is James Gillray, not Kilroy. Also, a short profile on Page 28 about one of the curators, Samantha Rippner, misidentifies the educational degree she obtained in 2003. It was a master’s degree  not a doctorate.

headline: The Cheat: The Upper (and Lower) Crust
text: At first glance, it is the easiest recipe in the world, a marvel of the Sunday-morning ridiculous: grate potatoes into a pan with butter. Turn them golden brown over medium heat. Serve with eggs, toast, sausage.

headline: And on the Sabbath, the iPhones Shall Rest
text: THE Fourth Commandment doesn’t specifically mention TweetDeck or Facebook. Observing the Sabbath 3,000 years ago was more about rest and going easy on one’s family — servants and oxen included.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Page 12 about the Martin and Osa Johnson Safari Museum in Chanute, Kan., refers to its licensing agreement with American Eagle Outfitters for the company’s Martin + Osa clothing stores. After the section went to press, American Eagle announced that it was closing the stores.

headline: Corrections
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Details Given on Cuts by Christie to Schools
text: Fifty-nine of New Jersey’s wealthiest school districts would receive no direct state aid for their operations next year — in effect, a 100 percent cut — under the governor’s proposed budget, according to state figures released on Wednesday.

headline: What We’re Reading: Girls Talk, Dodd Attacks and Geeks Drink
text: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times jumped from drinking and eating to watching the nighttime sky on Wednesday. In between, there was Twitter and Foursquare and Bing. Another typical day.

headline: N.F.L. Ready to Consider Overtime Rule
text: The N.F.L. competition committee proposal to alter overtime rules for the postseason is likely to be the headline event of the three-day league meeting that begins Monday in Orlando, Fla.

headline: Access, Access, Access
text: First, a question: When in American history did life expectancy improve the most?

headline: The Revolution Will Be Wearable
text: PARIS

headline: Economical and Effective, Chamberlain Stakes Claim
text: CLEARWATER, Fla. — Joba Chamberlain could probably have pitched his way out of the rotation with a poor outing Wednesday against the Philadelphia Phillies. Instead, Chamberlain breezed through four innings, tightening the most important position battle in the Yankees’ spring training.

headline: Sex Scandals to Learn By
text: Let’s consider the story of Representative Eric Massa, a freshman Democrat from upstate New York who made headlines recently when he resigned from office amid talk about sexual harassment of male staffers.

headline: Larger Cash Shortfall Is Projected in Albany as Fiscal Year Nears End
text: ALBANY — New York will end the fiscal year on March 31 with at least $2 billion less in cash on hand than originally projected, the state’s comptroller said Wednesday, burdening lawmakers with another headache and making the prospect of achieving a budget agreement before the next fiscal year begins even more dim.

headline: The Beat Goes Online, Minus the Glitz
text: IN the magazine world, there has traditionally been no more glamorous place to work than Condé Nast. Brandon Holley can attest to that.

headline: Another Aide to Paterson Steps Down
text: ALBANY — The exodus of top aides from the Paterson administration continued on Wednesday when Marissa Shorenstein, the governor’s press secretary and acting chief spokeswoman, resigned and, like other departing senior advisers, implicitly raised questions about the administration’s conduct.

headline: Letters
text: Who Needs Fur?

headline: Despite Criticism, Jets’ Owner Says He Still Trusts Goodell
text: Woody Johnson, the Jets’ owner, tried to move on from the controversy he stoked this week by saying Wednesday that he never meant to question Commissioner Roger Goodell’s integrity when he criticized the secret coin flip that determined that the Giants would host the first game in the teams’ new stadium.

headline: Taxi Agency Missed Scope of Cheating on Fares
text: Nearly two years before the Taxi and Limousine Commission uncovered a widespread scheme to overcharge passengers, city officials investigated two similar cases in which cabbies were found guilty of the same fraud.

headline: He Asked. They Told.
text: Los Angeles

headline: Correction
text: An article last Sunday about Joan Rivers incorrectly identified a government health insurance program in a reference to Ms. Rivers’s reluctance to retire even though she is 76. Her age makes her eligible for Medicare, not Medicaid.

headline: Foundation Promotes Art as Well as Sole Trustee
text: Like the abstract painter who created it, the Judith Rothschild Foundation has never had a very high profile in the art world. Ms. Rothschild, who died in 1993, established the foundation in her will and assigned a friend the mission, as trustee, of using her collection of artworks by masters like Matisse and Mondrian to promote underappreciated artists  a category in which she included herself.

headline: Law Dictates Who Decides on Care for the Incapable
text: It is one of those medical quandaries often faced by families dealing with older and dying parents: Who makes decisions for patients who cannot make their own and have not left written instructions?

headline: A Politically Feasible Jet
text: There has been yet another setback in the Air Force’s long, agonizing process to replace its fleet of Eisenhower-era aerial refueling planes. Northrop Grumman and its European partner, the European Aeronautic Defense and Space Company, dropped out of the competition this month, charging that the new contract specifications are tilted against their much larger Airbus A330 in favor of Boeing’s 767.
