headline: Using Generic Drugs to Save Lives Worldwide
text: To the Editor:

headline: Honest Food Labels
text: Dr. Margaret Hamburg, the commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration, has said one of her priorities is to improve the information on food package labels. Her new crackdown on dishonest nutritional claims by food manufacturers is a welcome sign that she means business.

headline: Out of the Darkness
text: When the sun finally rises, this will be a gray day, a great slab of flint laid across the plains. But the sun is still an hour off, and the snow is salting down just east of Riverton, Wyo. My eyes are straining for sight in the void out there, looking to see what emerges first from the darkness. The answer is the blackest objects  the old tires that ranchers sometimes place beside their cattle guards and the cattle themselves, black Angus stirring in a creek bottom. The cattle look as though they were bred black just so humans could find them easily in the gloom.

headline: Who Is at Fault, the Driver or the Carmaker?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Running for Obama’s Old Seat, and Set on Derailing His Plans
text: Representative Mark Steven Kirk, the Illinois Republican who is hoping to win Barack Obama’s former seat in the United States Senate, has told supporters he intends to “lead the effort” to repeal President Obama’s health care legislation if it passes.

text: Lagos, Nigeria

headline: Mr. Obama and No Child Left Behind
text: President Obama’s blueprint for reworking the No Child Left Behind Education Act of 2002 has good ideas, but it doesn’t have anything close to the rigor that the word “blueprint” would suggest. Whether the president’s plan will strengthen or weaken the program will depend on how the administration fleshes out the missing details  and how Congress rewrites the law.

headline: The Health Debate: Crunch Time
text: To the Editor:

headline: Defense Cites Entrapment in Terror Case
text: The man accused of masterminding a plot to blow up two synagogues in the Riverdale section of the Bronx was offered $250,000 by a paid government informant for his effort, according to papers filed in court on Wednesday by defense lawyers.

headline: Ambulance’s Delay May Be Issue in L.I. Hate-Crime Trial
text: The 911 call came in at 11:55 p.m. on Nov. 8, 2008. Marcelo Lucero, an Ecuadorean immigrant, had been stabbed in the chest near a train station in the Long Island village of Patchogue. The nearest hospital, Brookhaven Memorial Hospital Medical Center, was three miles away. Mr. Lucero appeared to be alive when the Patchogue Ambulance Company arrived at the scene, his eyes opening upon being moved and his breathing fast and labored, according to ambulance company documents.

headline: Amazon Threatens Publishers as Apple Looms
text: Amazon.com has threatened to stop directly selling the books of some publishers online unless they agree to a detailed list of concessions regarding the sale of electronic books, according to two industry executives with direct knowledge the discussions.

headline: In Biathlon, War Veteran Revels in Latest Challenge
text: As a boy growing up in California and then Texas, Andy Soule was not much of an athlete.

headline: Court Says Parents Can Block ‘Sexting’ Cases
text: In the first federal appeals court opinion dealing with “sexting” — the transmission of sexually explicit photographs by cellphone — a three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit ruled Wednesday that parents could block the prosecution of their children on child pornography charges for appearing in photographs found on some classmates’ cellphones.

headline: Illinois: No Delay for Blagojevich Trial
text: A federal judge refused on Wednesday to delay the June 3 corruption trial of Rod R. Blagojevich, the former governor of Illinois. Judge James B. Zagel of Federal District Court denied a request by defense lawyers to postpone the trial until Nov. 3 so they could have more time to review the evidence. He also dismissed their concerns that the trial could be affected by a case before the United States Supreme Court involving the denial of “honest services.” Mr. Blagojevich has pleaded not guilty to charges that he schemed to sell or trade the Senate seat once held by President Obama and used his power to illegally pressure political campaign donors.

headline: The Author Speaks
text: The photographer Jeff Sheng discusses his book, "Don't Ask, Don't Tell."

headline: Celtics Put Brakes on the Knicks’ Modest Momentum
text: BOSTON — After identity shifts and concerns about compatibility and complacency, the prospects of a Knicks revival this season have long been scuttled.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 4,375 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American Wednesday:

headline: Barbaro’s Brother to Race in Florida Derby
text: Hoping to follow the same path that led his famous brother to the Kentucky Derby, Lentenor was among 11 horses entered Wednesday for the Grade I Florida Derby on Saturday.

headline: Manager Tested Positive for Cocaine Last Season
text: The drug test given to Texas Rangers Manager Ron Washington last season that revealed the presence of cocaine was part of a testing program that managers, coaches and clubhouse personnel have been subjected to since shortly after the Mitchell report was released in December 2007.

headline: Henrietta’s Hash Browns
text: 4 medium Yukon Gold potatoes

headline: Scrambled Eggs With Trout Roe
text: 6 tablespoons unsalted butter

headline: Annotate and Share Notes Using an E-Book Reader
text: Samsung recently introduced its long-awaited e-book reader for the American market, and while it has useful features, a big one is missing.

headline: A Broader View of Health Care
text: My Thursday column argues that the crucial element of health care reform is its effort to increase access to the uninsured. Of course, I think it’s also crucial to hold down costs — that helps assure access in the long run — and I think that the Obama plan will help curb costs in the long run. I would have loved to see tort reform part of the package, but even the legislation’s promotion of research into which medical interventions work will over time presumably lead to some cost savings.

headline: HTC ‘Disagrees Strongly’ With Apple’s Patent Claims
text: HTC, the Taiwanese electronics manufacturer, is stepping forward and publicly addressing allegations made by Apple that it infringed on 20 patents related to the iPhone.

headline: James Nachtwey Fights TB, With Pictures
text: James Nachtwey is known for his compelling images of human suffering. He has captured genocide, disease and starvation. Absorbing so much devastation through the lens would numb many photographers, but Mr. Nachtwey is undaunted.

headline: Study Finds College Graduation Gap Between Hispanic and White Students
text: A new study by the American Enterprise Institute, a nonprofit research organization, finds that the percentage of Hispanic students who graduate from college in six years or less continues to trail that of white students. The researchers found that 51 percent of Hispanic students who start college go on to obtain a bachelor’s degree within six years, compared with 59 percent of white students.

headline: Barriers Found to College Degrees for Hispanics
text: The percentage of Hispanic students who graduate from college in six years or less continues to lag behind that of white students, according to a new study of graduation figures at more than 600 colleges.

headline: Last-Minute Soprano Saves the Opera
text: A week before the opening of a rare production of "Hamlet" at the Metropolitan Opera, the soprano Natalie Dessay withdrew because of illness, and the German soprano Marlis Petersen stepped in to play the role of Ophélie.

headline: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Devils Sweep Season Series From Pens
text: Three games on Wednesday, highlighted by the Devils’ utter mastery this season over the Penguins. The fans in Newark ended the game chanting, “You can’t beat us!” On the grimmer side, the Blackhawks lost a defenseman to injury after a questionable hit for the second straight game. Looks like Colin Campbell will have to throw the book at Anaheim’s James Wisniewski, as he did against Washington’s Alex Ovechkin for hurting Brian Campbell. Home teams listed first:

headline: A Lost Bet, and a Familiar Name
text: SAN JOSE, Calif. — Isaiah Thomas appears to be aptly named. Other than being left-handed, Thomas, the Washington Huskies’ point guard, has many of the same qualities of his Hall of Fame namesake — diminutive, determined and not the least bit afraid to get in an opponent’s face.

headline: H. M. Koutoukas, Author of Surrealist Plays, Dies at 72
text: H. M. Koutoukas, a prolific playwright who helped create Off Off Broadway theater in the 1960s with a wildly surreal style of drama, died on March 6 at his home in Manhattan. He was 72.

headline: Tebow Throws for Scouts
text: The former Florida quarterback Tim Tebow completed his first public workout with his new throwing motion Wednesday in Gainesville, Fla., hoping to impress N.F.L. general managers, coaches and scouts. Tebow threw dozens of passes to three former teammates during a 30-minute workout.

headline: Rangers-Islanders in 3D
text: MSG Network will show next Wednesday’s Islanders-Rangers game in 3D, the first time a hockey game has been carried in the technology, the network said. It will be available to Cablevision subscribers and offered to other providers.

headline: Miguel Delibes, Prolific Spanish Writer, Dies at 89
text: MADRID  Miguel Delibes, a prolific and much-honored Spanish novelist who explored human nature through the lives of common folk living in the rich Castilian countryside, died on Friday in his home in Valladolid, Spain. He was 89.

headline: SXSW: Four-Word Reviews
text: Freelance Whales: Could be Lemmy’s breakfast.

headline: Wayne Collett, Track Medalist Barred Because of a Protest, Dies at 60
text: Wayne Collett, a runner who won a silver medal for the United States in the 1972 Munich Olympics and who was then judged to have acted so disrespectfully during the medal ceremony that the International Olympic Committee barred him as a competitor for life, died Wednesday. He was 60 and lived in Los Angeles.

headline: Word of the Day | wizardry
text: wizardry •\ˈwi-zə(r)-dre\• noun

headline: The Cornell Team Enjoys the Ride
text: Jon Jaques is a senior on the Cornell basketball team, which is seeded 12th in the East Region and will face No. 5 Temple on Friday in Jacksonville, Fla. Jon has been blogging for The Quad throughout this season. You can also follow him on Twitter.

headline: Looking Ahead: Day 1
text: EAST

headline: China’s Role in Clean Energy
text: American companies are expanding their clean energy manufacturing facilities in places like China, where labor is cheap and incentives are strong.

headline: City Opera
text: Tonight, New York City Opera opens its spring season with Chabrier's seldom-staged "L'Etoile," "a comic work in the style of Offenbach's opéras bouffes," writes Vivien Schweitzer. "Mark Lamos's colorful production is inspired by Toulouse-Lautrec and features cancan choreography by Seán Curran." Put on your best "Moulin Rouge!"-inspired outfit and go watch the production, conducted by Emmanuel Plasson, featuring a cast that includes the tenor Jean-Paul Fouchécourt as King Ouf, "who enjoys executing his subjects, and Jennifer Zetlan as Laoula, the princess who is supposed to marry Ouf but falls in love with a poor peddler." Of course. Tonight's gala performance begins at 7.

headline: News Quiz | March 18, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page.

headline: Ivanchuk, Carlsen Lead at Amber
text: Magnus Carlsen and Vassil Ivanchuk lead the annual Amber tournament, the year’s most unusual event and a favorite stop for the world’s top players.

headline: Vodou and Rock ’n’ Roll
text: The group Bonga and the Vodou Drums of Haiti is led by the percussionist Gaston (Bonga) Jean-Baptiste. "This Haitian ensemble," writes Amanda Petrusich, "plays mizik rasin, a beguiling mix of traditional Haitian vodou and American rock 'n' roll. Much like the hill-country blues of Mississippi, mizik rasin is built around a hypnotic rhythmic pulse; traditional chants mix with mbira, conch, didgeridoo, cello, reeds, brass, vocals and more." Go to hear the results for free at 8:30 p.m. at the David Rubenstein Atrium at Lincoln Center.

headline: Tell Me a Story
text: If you didn't get enough of the emerald shade on St. Patrick's Day, head to Housing Works Bookstore Café for the Moth StorySlam! where the theme will be all things green tonight. For the uninitiated, The Moth is a not-for-profit storytelling organization that was founded in New York in 1997 by a poet and novelist who happens to be named George Dawes Green. At the slams, stories are scored by three teams of audience-member judges, and a winner is announced. We're hoping for at least one story devoted to Kermie.

headline: Lehman Allowed to Delay Bankruptcy Disclosure
text: A United States bankruptcy judge said on Wednesday that Lehman Brothers could delay until mid-April filing a detailed disclosure statement for its proposed plan to end its bankruptcy, Reuters reported.

headline: ‘The Book of Grace’
text: Photos from the new play by Suzan-Lori Parks.

headline: One of These Has to Be Right
text: There are only 9.2 quintillion possible outcomes to the N.C.A.A. basketball tournament. So it makes sense that someone had to come up with a formula to figure out which is the most likely. Yahoo has built a new tool to find this year’s winner. Hop on over to the Bits blog to see how Predictalot works and comment on why it’s all wrong and your school is going to win it all.

headline: What Can Strangers Learn About You Online?
text: An article from the Technology section warns that the “oceans of personal minutiae” we all publish on Facebook, Twitter and Flickr can be used to reassemble your identity, even down to your social security number. How much could your online identity tell others about you? How well have you protected yourself?

headline: Fed Fights to Keep Oversight of Banks That Aren’t Big
text: Officials at the Federal Reserve are trying to alter a Senate proposal that would focus the Fed’s regulatory attention on the nation’s biggest banks and strip away its powers over small and medium-size banks, Sewell Chan writes in The New York Times.

headline: Bernanke Sees U.S. Backing Fannie, Freddie Debt
text: Current Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac mortgage-backed securities are likely to retain United States government backing should Congress create a new system for financing homes, Federal Reserve Board Chairman Ben S. Bernanke said on Wednesday, Reuters reported.

headline: Hedge Fund Rules Aren’t Dead, Minister Says
text: Hedge funds and private equity may have won a short reprieve after European Union finance ministers agreed to delay a decision on new rules for the industry, but the proposals aren’t dead, Jean-Paul Gauzes, a French member of the European Parliament, told Bloomberg News.

headline: Schapiro Says Lehman Report Will Be ‘Helpful’
text: A Lehman Brothers bankruptcy examiner’s report will help securities regulators in their investigation of large financial firms involved in the Wall Street meltdown, a top regulator said on Wednesday, Reuters reported.

headline: Basel III Rules Will Ease, SocGen Tells Investors
text: Société Générale, France’s second-largest bank by market value, is telling investors that regulators are likely to soften new rules for lenders as governments seek to avoid stifling the economic recovery, Bloomberg News reports.

headline: Geely Said to Eye London’s Black Cab Maker
text: Zhejiang Geely Holding Group, the Chinese carmaker seeking to buy Volvo, may take control of Manganese Bronze Holdings, maker of the iconic London black cab, the British company said.

headline: Videoplaza Reaps $5 Million
text: Videoplaza, which makes software to help publishers optimize the distribution of their video ads, has rounded up $5 million, VentureBeat reported.

headline: For N.J. Fund, a Little More Hedge in Its Bets?
text: New Jersey’s $67 billion pension fund is considering a move to increase its hedge fund investments, as it tries to improve its returns through a decreased reliance on the stock market, Bloomberg News reported, citing a memo prepared for a meeting of the State Investment Council later this week.

headline: Theravance to Sell 7.5 Million Shares in Offering
text: Theravance, a drug developer, said Wednesday it would sell 7.5 million shares of stock to raise money for general corporate purposes, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Magick Man | Kenneth Anger
text: For a man who has spent two-thirds of a century actively pushing himself into the unearthly realm, the filmmaker Kenneth Anger has a pretty firm grasp of the minutiae of the earthly one. He’s 82, he reckons, but when we stop to speak during a break in the schedule of his whirlwind European tour — he’s in London for a show based around his films ”Inauguration of the Pleasure Dome” and ”Invocation of My Demon Brother’‘ at Sprüth Magers in London, a collaboration with Valentino for its autumn-winter show in Paris, and a celebrated guest appearance at the AV festival in Newcastle — he has a recall for the details, facts and figures that make up his constant stream of historical anecdotes and gossip that would put Rain Man to shame.

headline: Rosneft Stock Falls on Fear of Seizures
text: Shares in Russia’s state oil company, Rosneft, slumped Wednesday after the company was said to have warned its trading partners that a British court could seize assets under a lawsuit filed by former executives of Yukos Oil, The New York Times’s Andrew E. Kramer reported.

headline: Merkel Urges Stricter Rules for Euro Zone
text: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany, adopting a harsher tone toward Greece than the one expressed by some other European leaders, said Wednesday that Europe needed better rules to police its members, and she tacitly endorsed a proposal to eject wayward countries from the group of countries that use the euro, Jack Ewing reports in The New York Times.

headline: Finra’s Enforcer Is Stepping Down

headline: N. Korea Is Said to Execute Finance Chief
text: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea has arrested and possibly executed its top financial official as it struggles to contain chaos set off by its botched attempt to halt inflation through a radical currency revaluation, according to news reports Thursday in South Korea.

headline: Teva to Acquire Ratiopharm for $5 Billion

text: A consortium led by the Blackstone Group has agreed to invest about $600 million in a Chinese agricultural company ahead of its planned Hong Kong listing, Reuters reported, citing sources with knowledge of the deal.

Music people who arrived on Tuesday and Wednesday overlapped with attendees of the film and “interactive” (read: Internet start-up) conferences, and to some degree the happenings at all of these things are pretty similar: over-branded parties, free-flowing liquor, networking by text message.

headline: Will the U.S. Become the Next Ireland?

headline: U.S. Citizen Is Released From Prison in Myanmar

headline: In Rome, Revisiting the Spoils of War
text: Roman generals were among the world’s first art collectors. As they captured one Greek city after another, they looted its artistic treasures. Triumphantly, they returned to Rome and paraded their loot — shiploads of marble and bronze statues — through the Forum, where spectators could marvel at its elegance and beauty. These sculptured war trophies served both as visual metaphors for a vanquished enemy, as well as precious symbols of a culture the Romans aspired to surpass.

headline: U.K. Regulator’s Plan Puts It On the Attack
text: The Financial Services Authority, Britain’s securities regulator, said that it would hire more than 400 staff to step up supervision of the largest financial institutions while requiring an almost 10 percent increase in its annual budget, in a plan for this year and next released Wednesday.

headline: With the Lure of Generous Aid, Oklahoma State Beckons
text: The challenges of the impending college application process made themselves far too evident when our ACT proctor instructed, “Now fill in the bubbles to select four schools to which you would like your scores sent.” It was March of my junior year, and I had scarcely seen four colleges in my life, let alone reviewed their application guidelines and exact mileage away from my front door.

headline: Sampler: Boxer’s Opponents Gain Ground and Police Have Few Protocols for Out-of-Control Cars
text: Boxer’s Opponents Gain Ground, Poll Says | A new Field Poll shows that the three candidates hoping to unseat Senator Barbara Boxer have gained ground. Senator Boxer, who is in her third term, trails Tom Campbell, a former congressman, 44 to 43 percent, and leads Carly Fiorina, the former chief executive of Hewlett-Packard, 45 to 44 percent. The survey of 748 likely voters was taken this month and has a margin of error of plus-or-minus 3.7 percentage points. Senator Boxer leads Assemblyman Chuck DeVore, a Republican from Irvine, 45 to 41 percent. [The San Francisco Chronicle]

headline: RandomDorm: Chatroulette for the College Set

headline: Sleep-Deprived and Fighting ‘a Terrible Case of Senioritis’
text: The college admission process is a messed-up, tangled web of lies and secrecy that can drive you insane. If, by writing for this blog, I can help one sleep-deprived anxious senior — someone stressing about a decision that can (and will) change his or her life — to know that he or she is not alone, then my efforts will be worthwhile. But I guess I should start by telling you a little bit about myself.

headline: Air France Attendants May Strike

headline: A Turkish Builder on Istanbul’s Deadly Buildings
text: Ali Agaoglu, a billionaire developer in Turkey, caused a stir last year when he admitted that his family’s company — and most other developers —routinely used inappropriate materials during a building boom in Istanbul in recent decades, creating enormous vulnerability because of the long history of powerful earthquakes in the sprawling city.

headline: Stagflation Versus Hyperinflation
text: I’m a bit late to this, but Mike Kinsley has an odd piece in the Atlantic in which he confesses himself terrified about future inflation, even though there’s no hint of that problem in the real world. He’s not alone: there are a lot of voices predicting imminent hyperinflation in 2009, make that 2010 (and yes, I am keeping a record).

headline: Boehner to Bankers: Stand Up to ‘Punk’ Staffers
text: Opponents of Senator Christopher J. Dodd‘s financial regulation overhaul bill are talking tough, telling bankers how displeased they are without mincing words.

headline: Thai Protests to Continue
text: BANGKOK — Antigovernment demonstrators said Thursday that they would continue their protests at least through the weekend as efforts to mediate the standoff faltered. The mass demonstration, which this week drew tens of thousands of farmers and other protesters, has prevented Prime Minister Abhisit Vejjajiva from entering his office. Protesters, who are known as the Red Shirts, are demanding that the government step down and that elections be called. They said they would parade through Bangkok on Saturday in large convoys of pickup trucks.

headline: Piano Man
text: Attention, Chopin fans: On March 1, the 200th anniversary of the Polish composer’s birth, a new permanent exhibition opened at the Chopin Muzeum in Warsaw. Designed by the Milan firm Migliore + Servetto Associated Architects, the installation displays some 500 items, from musical manuscripts to the composer’s cuff links.

headline: Some Honda Air-Conditioners Dying a Slow Death
text: As she drives her 2002 Honda CR-V on hot days in Southern California, Joan Giglione is steamed. The problem is her car’s air-conditioning — or rather, its lack of air-conditioning.

headline: Museum Innovations Around the World

headline: An Easy Way From PC to TV
Thursday Reading

headline: SXSW: Blessings and Black Angels
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — As the musical portion of South by Southwest got under way, we got several bracing reminders that we weren’t in Kansas, or the interactive segment of the conference. First, the door at Emo’s where the blog BrooklynVegan had set up shop looked as if it were under siege. At 3 p.m. on Wednesday, just hours into what will be many long days and nights of music, people were baking in the sun on the sidewalk and waiting for a shot at seeing the New Jersey rock band Titus Andronicus, those distortion purveyors who took their name from Shakespeare’s bloodiest and most vengeful work.

headline: Report Says China Sold Bad Vaccines to Hospitals
text: HONG KONG — A newspaper article by one of China’s best-known investigative reporters has reawakened a controversy over whether provincial authorities improperly stored vaccines in rooms without air-conditioning, rendering them ineffective, and then let them be administered to children.

headline: Where Does U.S. Foreign Aid Go?

headline: Last Footfall in Nepal
text: THE path is wide, the terrain easy, yet I keep losing my footing, tripping over stones and my own feet because I can’t watch the trail. My eyes refuse to leave the white mountain filling the sky before me, the 24,786-foot Himalayan peak Annapurna III. It dominates the horizon as surely as a sunset does, but with millenniums-old glaciers ringing its crest like a necklace of diamonds, it feels more dazzling than even the brightest setting sun.

headline: Tribeca Festival Announces Short Films
text: “The New Tenants,” which won the Academy Award for live action short earlier this month, will be among the 47 movies to be shown in the Tribeca Film Festival‘s short film lineup, along with works directed by Kirsten Dunst, Domenica Scorsese and others, the festival’s organizers said on Thursday. “The New Tenants,” written by David Rakoff (“Fraud,” “Don’t Get Too Comfortable”) and directed by Joachim Back, tells the darkly comic story of two men who meet their unusual neighbors as they move into a New York apartment; it will play on the festival’s Hard Core program. Other films announced include “Bastard,” written and directed by Ms. Dunst (“Spider-Man”), about a couple in a desert motel; “Roots in Water,” directed by Ms. Scorsese and written by Richard Nelson, about two siblings dealing with the death of their mother; and “A .45 at 50th,” a documentary directed by Joshua Bell and John Cromwell, in which the actor James Cromwell (“The Queen”) recounts his experience with the Black Panther Party. This year’s Tribeca Film Festival runs April 21 to May 2.

headline: Report Finds Shift Toward Extended Families
text: The extended family is making something of a comeback, thanks to delayed marriage, immigration and recession-induced job losses and foreclosures that have forced people to double-up under one roof, an analysis of Census Bureau figures has found.

headline: Warren Buffett Rocks Out
text: He is the biggest of financial rock stars. Now it looks like Warren E. Buffett just wants to rock out.

headline: A Call to Jihad in an American Accent

headline: Final Bill Will Reduce Deficit, Hoyer Says

headline: Knicks Get a Sneak Peek at Giddens

headline: The Architecture of Secularism
text: Last week, inspired by the highly-regrettable religious architecture of Claude Parent, Rod Dreher wrote about his “perverse fascination with ugly churches.” This week, as if by way of counterpoint, Catesby Leigh has a lovely piece about Duncan Stroik, the architect (and Notre Dame professor) behind two new Catholic churches, one in Wisconsin and one at Thomas Aquinas College in California, that actually dare to look like churches — rather than, say, the dreadful Jedi fortresses that pass for cathedrals in Los Angeles and Oakland.

headline: German Archbishop  Expresses Shame Over Scandal
text: BAD STAFFELSTEIN, Germany — The leader of the Catholic Church in Bavaria expressed “deep shame” on Thursday for cases of sexual molestation that have shaken the home region of Pope Benedict XVI, and said he was in favor of changing German law so that church officials would have a greater duty to report suspected child abuse to prosecutors.

headline: No Gang War, but a Turf Battle Nonetheless

headline: Obama Calls Jobs Bill a First Step

headline: Final Bill to Cost $940 Billion Over 10 Years

headline: Our Computers, Ourselves: Imagining the Digital Lives of Authors and Characters

In this lesson, students imagine and simulate the computer desktop, files and Internet habits of a writer or literary character in order to better understand his or her life and/or works.

headline: Building a Community of Commenters

headline: Gay Men and Lesbians Barred From Some Clinical Trials
text: Gay men and lesbians are barred from taking part in many clinical trials that deal with sexual functions and occasionally from other studies as well, researchers are reporting.

headline: The Lou Gehrig of Opera
text: The news that the Lauritz Melchior Heldentenor Foundation is going into retirement, like an aging singer whose career is over, is a reminder of the amazing life of the foundation’s namesake, the Lou Gehrig of opera. Melchior had a set of brass lungs – one way of describing that rare breed, the heldentenor or “heroic tenor,” a man with the stamina and power to soar above an orchestra for many hours in an evening.

headline: Health Care Bill Estimates Out

headline: Grass Fed | Homeburgers
text: I’m sure it was desperation the first time: friends coming over, nothing planned, nothing in the cupboard. What to serve? Burgers and oven-baked fries, cans of beer. Done. Everybody had a good time. Then, on Christmas morning shortly thereafter, the craving for burgers animal-style hit, and me and my girl griddled some up, which seems like a fine tradition to carry forward.

headline: The Worst Time for a Hospital Visit
text: This week in “Doctor and Patient,” I write about how four factors — hospital occupancy, weekend admissions, nurse staffing and the seasonal flu — can not only increase the risk of dying in a hospital but can also interact in variable ways.

headline: Infidelity Month
text: Curious nickname for February 2010, during which sales of British tabloids were boosted by a slew of allegations concerning celebrity adultery.

headline: SXSW: Having a Moment with Carolina Chocolate Drops
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — We had no idea what Carolina Chocolate Drops were, but came to see them as a reminder of the beauty of home cooking. To call them a string band does not really do justice to the flying instruments, the role changes and the strong and sometimes dangerous singing of Rhiannon Giddens at the Galaxy Room on Wednesday. Combing elements of scat and hillbilly yodels, the Drops, as we will call them now that we are friends, were playful with the crowd but seemingly dead earnest in leading a singalong of a “Hi-ho, diddly-eye-o” nature, replete with what looked like clog dancing, although we could not see anybody’s shoes through the mass of bodies. It was our first “having a moment” moment of the festival.

headline: A Tech-Filled Life, Without Power

headline: SXSW: Singular Noun, Full Band
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — South by Southwest hasn’t gotten into full gear when you can still walk down E. Sixth Street without a pair of fullbacks. That’s how it was on Wednesday night, when not every club had lines waiting outside. There were major draws around–the rapper Nas and NPR’s lineup headlined by Spoon (from Austin) along with the Walkmen and Sharon Jones–but I generally skip bands I’ve seen before at SXSW. After some duds, I was rewarded.

headline: Bathroom Humor Fans Rejoice: A Captain Underpants Spin-Off
text: To the joy of millions of young readers and the consternation of untold numbers of foes of the “poop fiction” genre, a spinoff of the Captain Underpants series will be released in August, Scholastic announced on Thursday.

headline: The Road to Distraction
text: O.K., America, ready, set ... stop working! It’s the first day of the first round of the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament, the greatest worker productivity drain since the dawn of working (followed closely by the second day of the first round). It is our unique cultural phenomenon that the entire business world finds it acceptable for your day to be completely derailed agonizing over the fate of Butler and getting intimately acquainted with the field goal percentage of Robert Morris. Let the upsets begin!

headline: Faces of the Dead
text: Nearly nine years passed before American forces reached their first 1,000 dead in the war in Afghanistan. The second 1,000 came just 27 months later, after a troop surge in 2010.

headline: Theater Talkback: The Accent’s the Thing
text: LONDON — It’s only when you come to this city and hear British actors playing Americans that you realize how funny we all talk. I’m kidding, of course, but after listening to the peculiar nasality of some of the accents in the Old Vic revival of John Guare’s “Six Degrees of Separation,” I found myself wondering whether the twang-free voice I’d always assumed I’d been speaking in sounded so very peculiar to the British. I’ve been working on something grander-sounding and mid-Atlantic ever since.Accents can cause unusual problems for actors. First-class training doesn’t necessarily instill the ability to master different voices; it’s a particular aptitude that comes more naturally to some than others. I adored Patti LuPone’s darkly funny performance as Mrs. Lovett in the recent Broadway revival of “Sweeney Todd,” but I have never before heard an Englishwoman of any class or period – fictional or otherwise — speaking with quite the same quirky intonations. (Video of Ms. LuPone and the rest of the cast of the Broadway revival of “Sweeney Todd” is here.)

headline: SXSW: The Music and Its Makings
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — Minimalism had an impish side with Hauschka, a pianist and composer from Düsseldorf who performed with a string quartet at the hushed Central Presbyterian Church on Wednesday night. Hauschka, the stage name of Volker Bertelmann, builds his repeating structures with a Romantic ear — pensive minor chords, inviting melodic lines, slow-cresting dynamics — and, sometimes, a foundation of rock rhythm. Even with their echoes of Philip Glass, the pieces were ingenious and exquisite.

headline: Drawn From Life
text: Truth in the matter of memoir has always seemed evanescent and, more often lately, either elusive or absent. Memories of the self are often in service of other agendas, including the settling of scores and the creation of a hero where a mere man once stood.

headline: Dostoyevsky and Me
text: To study first-year French is to enter a world of savoir-faire, beauty and romance. Instructive filmstrips show master chefs whisking halos of caramelized sugar; or Versailles woodworkers restoring antique marquetry; or Gallic lovers in deux chevaux, illustrating how “to go” and “to be” while tooting off for a weekend in Marseille. But this is not the world of Russian 101. In Russian 101, you get grainy black-and-white photos of concert halls “closed for repairs,” and you learn bitter dialogues like this one:

headline: SXSW: More Four-Word Reviews
text: Nas/Damian (Junior Gong) Marley: Surprise! Bob samples galore.

headline: The Whore’s Secret
text: Some stories need to be told in a whisper. “Blooms of Darkness,” the Israeli writer Aharon Appelfeld’s majestic and humane new novel, takes place in an unnamed Ukrainian city during World War II. As the Germans begin liquidating the city’s Jewish population, Julia, a pharmacist whose husband has already been sent to a labor camp, smuggles her 11-year-old son, Hugo, out of the ghetto. Their journey through the sewer pipes leads them to a house on the outskirts of town, where Julia entrusts Hugo to the care of an old friend, Mariana, before taking flight herself. Mariana, as Hugo will discover, is a prostitute, while the house — known simply as “the Residence” — is a brothel catering to the Nazi occupiers. For the next year and a half, Hugo’s world will contract to the bedroom in which Mariana cossets, neglects and ultimately seduces him, and the closet in which he hides when her clients come knocking.

headline: Sins of the Capitalist
text: Of all the characters Sebastian Faulks introduces in “A Week in December,” his ambitious, entertaining and often scathingly angry new novel, two merit special attention: a young Muslim plotting to attack a London hospital, and a hedge fund manager betting that England’s staunchest bank is about to fail. Guess which one is the villain? If you said the billionaire, give yourself a gold star — assuming you can still afford one. (Have you seen the price of gold lately?) It tells you everything you need to know about the politics of this book, and the reflexive populism of our time, that the capitalist is more reliably loathsome than the jihadist.

headline: At Close Range
text: For the last 45 years, John McPhee has come out with a work of narrative nonfiction about every year and a half. The quantity impresses, but not nearly so much as the quality. McPhee has a nearly cultish following among nonfiction writers, who admire his quirky choice of subjects — often unheralded virtuosos of their own particular domain (a headmaster, a barge captain), or such intimidatingly large topics as the formation of the earth (four books on geology; collected together as “Annals of the Former World,” they won a Pulitzer Prize). We envy his powers of description, the way he transforms technically complex subjects into something readers can hold in their hand and examine at close range. And, perhaps above all else, we marvel at the pains he takes with structure, approaching his subject from oblique angles, slowly building tension, sometimes seeming to wander, but always propelling his narratives forward.

headline: Nuts and Dolts
text: Paranoia is a bipartisan temptation. Amid last August’s town hall frenzy, there was a stir over a poll showing that roughly a third of Republicans believed that Barack Obama had been born outside the United States. Liberals trumpeted the finding as proof of the Republican base’s slide into madness. But conservatives had a rebuttal: As recently as 2007, they pointed out, polls showed that a third of Democrats believed George W. Bush knew about 9/11 in advance.

headline: Mr. Goldman Goes to Washington
text: When offered the job of Treasury secretary in the spring of 2006, Henry M. Paulson Jr., who was then the chief executive of Goldman Sachs, turned it down. President Bush had half a term in office left, the economy appeared strong, and there seemed little the next secretary could accomplish. But then, Paulson had second thoughts — “Do you really want to be 75 and telling people, ‘I could have been Treasury secretary’?” a friend asked — and finally agreed to take the job on condition he be granted more power and visibility than Bush’s previous secretaries.

headline: Studio Visit | Ryan McGinley
text: Ryan McGinley knows from adolescence. As the chronicler of (usually naked) misspent youth, the 32-year-old photographer has made a not-insignificant career out of capturing and exalting this most evanescent of states. T dropped by McGinley’s Chinatown HQ for a sneak peek of “Everybody Knows This Is Nowhere,” his new exhibition of black-and-white nudes, which opens tonight at the Team Gallery in SoHo.

headline: Promised Land
text: My parents bought their first house in 1960, six years after emigrating from Ireland. They’d grown up with a fierce sense of place — of land, family, history — and they were determined to recreate that sense for their children. That little house in the middle of a non­descript block on Detroit’s East Side was going to be their home forever.

headline: Tokyo Vice
text: When I started to read David Peace’s new novel, I had, frankly, absolutely no idea of what was going on. The opening line: “In the occupied city, you are a writer and you are running.” As it turns out, the idea of running — “step by step-step by step” — is endlessly, mind-numbingly repeated and reworked in this novel. A writer is running, clutching the manuscript of a book that refuses to be written, toward the Black Gate of Tokyo, where something of an occult nature is going on. Both the reader and the fictional writer — is it David Peace himself? — are tightly wound in something intensely claustrophobic. I felt as if I were lost, not in Tokyo, but in a particular kind of pulp fiction fantasy.

headline: How to Be Brilliant
text: You’ve probably heard it at one time or another: Most of us use only 10 percent of our brains. More factoid than fact, a claim of unknown provenance and dubious accuracy, the idea sticks around because of the enduring appeal of its underlying premise. We’d all love to think that we’re in possession of tremendous untapped potential, of latent mental powers just waiting to be activated. It seems so convenient, like falling in love with the person you’re already married to, or whipping up dinner from what’s already in your kitchen. You don’t have to leave home, or even change out of your pajamas.

headline: PEN International Fest Announces Line-Up
text: Authors will temporarily give up the writing life for the speaking life when PEN American Center launches its weeklong Voices Festival of International Literature on April 26. Familiar literary stars like Toni Morrison and Salman Rushdie (the festival chairman) are part of the lineup, as are musical performers like Patti Smith and Natalie Merchant, who have recently tried their hands at book writing.

headline: Trust, Underwater
text: In 2004, newly married and having decided to embark on the next phase of adulthood, my wife and I bought a house. This was back in the delirious days of multiple offers and outlandish escalation clauses, when you had to bring your checkbook with you to an open house, just in case someone else tried to buy the place while you were poking around the attic. I called a mortgage broker somewhere in Florida, and she was thrilled to hear from me, practically breathless. I felt as if I were the 10,000th customer to come through line at the Safeway, my arrival heralded by streamers and sirens and all kinds of free stuff falling from the rafters. Did we want a five-year adjustable-rate loan or maybe even rates adjusted on a monthly basis? Why not just pay just the interest rather than the principal? Did we also need a bridge loan for a few months, to hold us over from one house to the next? How about a ‘‘second trust'' — that is, two mortgages instead of one — so we could put less money down, maybe even as little as 5 percent of the purchase price while avoiding the penalty of private mortgage insurance? We might as well open a home equity line of credit on top of the mortgage, she said, so we could borrow another six-figure sum with the tear of a perforated check. Countrywide, the nation's largest lender, would happily give us that free, and, hey, you never knew when you might decide to add a skylight over the kitchen, or maybe a stone turret.

headline: Now Shopping | SCADs of Good Things
text: Savannah, Ga., isn’t only about Girl Scouts, Paula Deen’s calorie-bomb cooking or the intrigue of John Berendt’s “Midnight in the Garden of Good and Evil.” The city is also home to a thriving design scene spawned in large part by the Savannah College of Art and Design. While SCAD, as the 30-year-old college is known, built its reputation as one of the country’s leading design schools, its administration wisely snapped up a number of big, beautiful (and, let’s not forget, historic) buildings that faced probable demolition. As a result, its schools, lecture halls and administrative buildings are seamlessly woven into Savannah’s urban fabric, making the college an integral part of the city and revitalizing several once-derelict neighborhoods.

headline: Angry Young Man
text: It’s Cinco de Mayo in San Jose, Calif., and our man Paul — pundit, cynic, iconoclast — pummels a Mexican at a march for immigration reform, for which infraction he’s charged with a hate crime and hauled off to jail. And so begins “What We Are,” Peter Nathaniel Malae’s first novel, with twofold irony: First, Paul’s father is a Samoan immigrant, which, in this story, inoculates his son against cultural prejudice. Second, in 2006 immigration reform was largely about paths to United States citizenship for illegals, the assumption being that they wanted to stay. Not so much Paul. He is a first-­generation American who lives in a country he cannot stand, and spends much of his time railing against everyone in it, himself included. One of this novel’s organizing tensions is how to reconcile misanthropy with a sense that taking a stand — for people, for values — can suffuse your life with meaning. For Paul, whose heritage is mixed, there is the added problem of how to straddle cultures while still forging an identity of his own. From Page 1, his biggest gripe is that he has no story, no position and, more worrisome, no heart.

headline: The Pasta Cure
text: When we find ourselves coping with pain, the kitchen can become our therapist, food our source of comfort. The joy of cooking was certainly the salve that soothed the emotional wounds that the journalist Paula Butturini endured as she and her husband suffered bullets, police beatings and a battle with depression that almost tore their marriage apart. Butturini tells her story through the lens of food — its restorative powers and its capacity to trigger the brain to remember and hope in times of tragedy and challenge: “And like a potter centering clay on a spinning potter’s wheel, the mere act of cooking centered me,” Butturini writes in “Keeping the Feast,” her blunt and brave memoir. It “kept me close, available, ready to help, kept us fed, kept me sufficiently focused on present tasks so that I wouldn’t panic about the future, kept me going through the slow passing of a string of bad days, weeks and months.”

headline: Summers Slams Boehner’s ‘Punk Staffers’ Comment

headline: Old Dominion Provides Tournament’s First Upset
text: NEW ORLEANS — There was plenty of precedent for Old Dominion upon entering the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament as a No. 11 seed. Other Colonial Athletic Association teams had made noise in the tournament from the same position as the Monarchs. In 2006, George Mason was a No. 11 seed for its magical run to the Final Four, and so was Virginia Commonwealth a year later when it upset Duke in the first round.

headline: Raids Aim to Find Killers of 3 in Mexico
text: MEXICO CITY — They carry both American passports and high-caliber weapons, making them the perfect cross-border assassins. They confuse the authorities by using a coded language that blends English, Spanish and the Aztecs’ ancient tongue of Nahuatl. The threat of prison is no big fear for members of the Barrio Azteca street gang, because they consider the cellblock to be home.

headline: Going Dutch | Stumptown Coffee in Amsterdam
text: Stumptown Coffee Roasters is setting up shop in Amsterdam. Or, to be specific, a pop-up shop, which will open on May 1. Duane Sorensen, the owner of Stumptown Coffee Roasters, said he was approached by Sid Lee, a Montreal-based creative agency with a branch in Amsterdam that happened to have a spare La Marzocco espresso machine kicking around in a little-used storefront. Sorensen flew to Amsterdam with seven Chemex coffee brewers and some beans; he returned with the keys to a shop that’s his through the end of July.

headline: ‘I Am in Control, Mr. Pancho’
text: A truckload of wood arrived from Connecticut with old beams (circa 1900) taken from a Bronx warehouse and red cypress (1890) from a North Carolina wood mill. The next morning, three new guys showed up at the site with insurance, equipment, English and enthusiasm: Juan and Onis Saldaña are brothers, Favian their nephew.

headline: Fredette’s 37 Points Lift Brigham Young

He was fouled hard enough in the second overtime of the Cougars’ N.C.A.A. tournament game against Florida on Thursday that he fell to the floor in a sweaty heap.

headline: Vistas, Tacos and Bowling
text: Once claimed by the Dutch in the 1600s, the gigantic neighborhood of Sunset Park is now home to Brooklyn’s Chinatown, an expanding Mexican community and possibly the city’s coolest bowling alley. Stretching 30 blocks from Green-Wood Cemetery on the northern edge to the border of Bay Ridge, the entire neighborhood is impossible to get to know in one stop. A good way to start is by getting off the D, M, N or R train at 36th Street, southwest of Park Slope, and exiting on the Fourth Avenue side.

headline: Gutierrez to Vote Yes
text: Representative Luis V. Gutierrez, Democrat of Illinois, said on Thursday that he would vote in favor of the Democrats’ health care legislation. Mr. Gutierrez had threatened to oppose the measure because he did not like provisions in the Senate-passed bill that would bar illegal immigrants from purchasing insurance through new government exchanges, even if they paid the full cost with their own money.

headline: Good Timing
text: In the dizzying run-up of watch technology of the last 10 or 15 years, the size of watch cases, the number of diamonds on them and the staggering intricacy of their complications were matched only by the astronomical sums the timepieces commanded. It was in the midst of this spinning tourbillon of activity that a few people tried something a lot simpler, a lot cheaper and a lot more colorful. With neon-bright hues, stretchy silicone bands and novel faces, the new ’80s-inspired watches could have been worn by bands like the Thompson Twins or the Human League. They all but sing, “Don’t you want me, baby?”

headline: The Future of Memory
text: Gizmodo, the technology blog, has a fascinating series this week about memory. Titled Memory [Forever], the blog takes a look at the topic from multiple angles, including memory and our brains, how the Internet remembers and the memory inside computers.

headline: Fine-Tuning Led to Health Bill’s $940 Billion Price Tag
text: WASHINGTON — Love it or hate it, one thing that is indisputable about the Democrats’ big health care legislation is that the cost figures are going to come out right where President Obama said he wanted them.

headline: Asian Art on View, Tea on the Table
text: With the demise last year of the decade-old International Asian Art Fair, New York dealers have formed competing consortiums to promote walking tours of their galleries during the traditional spring Asia Week. Through next weekend, anyone interested in Asian art can ring the doorbells of galleries, mostly in town houses on the Upper East Side of Manhattan and normally open only by appointment, and climb creaky stairs to learn about luxuries produced during the last five millenniums.

headline: Christiane Amanpour of CNN to Join ABC News
text: ABC News has poached one of CNN’s biggest stars, Christiane Amanpour.

headline: Fess Parker, ‘Davy Crockett’ and ‘Daniel Boone’ Star, Has Died
text: Fess Parker, whose television portrayal of Davy Crockett, the American frontiersman, catapulted him to stardom in 1954-55 and inspired one of America’s greatest merchandising fads, in which hundreds of thousands of children wore coonskin caps, died on Thursday. Mr. Parker, who went rustic once again in the 1960s and played Daniel Boone for a new generation of young television watchers, was 85.

headline: Harmony Korine on 'Trash Humpers'
text: The director Harmony Korine talks about the inspiration behind his unconventional film.

headline: It’s Not Easy Being Fat Again
text: Kirstie Alley repeats herself, first as farce, second as tragedy.

text: Full reviews of recent performances: nytimes.com/dance.

headline: 3 Charged With Stealing $1.75 Million From Immigrants
text: Three members of a family in Richmond Hill, Queens, have been indicted on charges that they stole $1.75 million from 19 fellow West Indian immigrants by falsely promising to help them obtain green cards and bargain deals on federally seized property in New York City and Florida, the Queens district attorney announced on Thursday.

headline: Lehman Now Seeks $11 Billion From Barclays
text: Lehman Brothers, which is being liquidated in bankruptcy, said Thursday that it was now seeking a total of $11 billion from Barclays of Britain, including a $5 billion windfall that the firm contends that Barclays received when it bought Lehman’s North American brokerage, Bloomberg News reports.

headline: Writing Stiffs
text: A 2008 study of the creative economy from the National Endowment for the Arts reported that full-time “writers and authors” earned a median annual salary of more than $50,000.

headline: Museum and Gallery Listings
text: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art.

headline: Lost Soldiers
text: Just kids. You step into the barracks thinking big, burly and deep-voiced. And what you get are chubby faces and halfhearted mustaches and voices still cracking, boys hurried into uniforms and handed heavy guns. Sept. 11 was junior high, fifth grade even, a half a lifetime ago. Megan Fox is everywhere, plastered above the bunks, the best that Maxim can offer. Junk food, too, sent A.P.O. (Army Post Office) from home: powdered Gatorade and M&M’s and teriyaki jerky. Underwear and socks. “Love you, bro,” scrawled a sister from California on a care package to Ramadi, Iraq. “Muwah!”

headline: That Drug Kingpin Cancer Patient and Guilty Pleasure of a ‘Bad’ World
text: The first decade of the 21st century has been a boom time for murderers on television. James Gandolfini as the mobster Tony Soprano (“The Sopranos”), Michael Chiklis as the rogue cop Vic Mackey (“The Shield”), Bryan Cranston as the schoolteacher and meth kingpin Walter White (“Breaking Bad”): They’re among the most honored television performances of the era, representing 6 of the last 10 Emmy Awards for lead actor in a drama. (And another, Michael C. Hall as the forensics expert and serial killer Dexter Morgan, has been an Emmy nominee and recently won Golden Globes and Screen Actors Guild Awards.)

headline: ‘The Immigrant, Radical and Notorious Women of Washington Square’
text: Saturday is the first day of spring, which makes this weekend an opportune time to get outside and take a stroll. Instead of just roaming aimlessly, though, how about a walking tour? A wide variety of tours is available on any given weekend in New York, and the number of options usually swells as the weather warms up. One tour in particular this weekend seems especially worth noting, as it also dovetails with Women’s History Month.

headline: Anne-Marie Hess and David Rabkin
text: THE relationship between Anne-Marie Hess and Dr. David Rabkin has always been poetry in progress.

text: AROUND TOWN

headline: ‘That’s Not a Rap Sheet’
text: Your Jokes | Use the comment link below. One joke per comment, please:

headline: Stately Grounds and Atari-Hued Lanes
text: Once claimed by the Dutch in the 1600s, the gigantic neighborhood of Sunset Park is now home to Brooklyn’s Chinatown, an expanding Mexican community and possibly the city’s coolest bowling alley. Stretching 30 blocks from Green-Wood Cemetery on the northern edge to the border of Bay Ridge, the entire neighborhood is impossible to get to know in one stop. A good way to start is by getting off the D, M, N or R train at 36th Street, southwest of Park Slope, and exiting on the Fourth Avenue side.

headline: ‘Books Cook!’
text: In the Atlantic Theater Company’s latest production Will Seefried tells young audiences that each numbered storybook propped onstage has an ingredient hidden behind it. Shout five numbers, he says, and he will mix those concealed items and eat them.

headline: On Character: Bryan Cranston in 'Breaking Bad'
text: The actor discusses a scene from the season premiere of the AMC drama.

headline: A Once Proud Bank, Brought Low
text: Landmark distinction couldn't save the Mount Morris Bank building in Harlem.

headline: Party Central | The Runaways After-Party
text: Scenes from the after-party for the premiere of “The Runaways” in New York.

headline: Spare Times: For Children
text: ‘ADVENTURES WITH DORA AND DIEGO’  (Friday through Sunday, and Tuesday through Thursday) The young Latino stars of the Nickelodeon animated television series “Dora the Explorer” and “Go, Diego, Go!” have taken their expeditions into new territory at the Children’s Museum of Manhattan, whose exhibition has separate Dora and Diego environments, including Diego’s Animal Rescue Center and Dora’s Fiesta. Intended for ages 2 to 6, the interactive, bilingual displays are designed to teach language, science and music skills, as well as facts about Latin America. From 10 a.m. to 5 p.m., Tisch Building, 212 West 83rd Street , (212) 721-1223, cmom.org; free with museum admission: $10; $7 for 65+; free for under 1 and members.20100318

headline: Indonesia Is Left Waiting for Obama’s Trip
text: Boys trained a racing pigeon Thursday in Matraman, the district of Jakarta, Indonesia, in which Barack Obama spent some of his childhood. Indonesians anticipating the presidential visit — whether happily or angrily — will have to wait a few more months, as Mr. Obama postponed his planned Pacific trip a second time to concentrate on trying to pass health care legislation.

headline: Judge Bans Site’s Quick Posts of Wall St. Research
text: A federal judge on Thursday banned a financial Web site, TheFlyontheWall.com, from issuing immediate news about analysts’ reports from Wall Street firms, often before that information was shared with the firms’ clients, Reuters reports.

headline:
Democrats Say Health Bill Will
Pay for Itself in the Long Run
text: WASHINGTON — House Democrats initiated a 72-hour countdown Thursday on their yearlong effort to overhaul the health care system, unveiling a nearly final version of the legislation that promptly won additional support with a promise that the bill would more than pay for itself over the next decade.

headline: A Liberal Price Cut
text: THE worldly and the clever gathered at the dinner parties that William F. Buckley Jr. and his wife, Pat, gave in their Park Avenue maisonette. Yet even though the chairs in the formal dining room are still covered in chartreuse leopard print, it has been quite a while since anyone but a broker or a prospective buyer has spent much time there.

headline: Roasted Red Pepper Filled With Tuna
text: This recipe is an adaptation of a classic Provençal dish. Until recently, I was in denial about the fact that I could no longer get two servings from one can of tuna. When I used to make this dish years ago, tuna was sold in 6 1/2-ounce cans. Now I get a 5-ounce can for the same price, and there are only 3 or 4 ounces of tuna in that can.

headline: SXSW: Imperfect Harmony
text: Reports from the South by Southwest film festival.

headline: On the Road With Seekers and Other Dharma Bums
text: Finally, officially, Saturday is spring, when  I paraphrase Chaucer  tender shoots rise, surprised birds sing, and we hit the road in search of our hearts’ desire. The art world has its own version of such a trek. It’s called Asia Week, and it too kicks off on Saturday, sending devotees hiking around Manhattan in search of galleries with special shows (more than three dozen this year) and museums with Asian fare.

headline: Latest Bill Raises Medicaid Rates for Primary Care Doctors
text: The Democrats’ health care legislation, the latest version of which was unveiled on Thursday, would broadly expand Medicaid, the federal-state insurance program for low-income Americans.

text: Room for a Baker’s Dozen

headline: A Once Proud Bank, Brought Low
text: IT is hard to give up hope on an old friend who is brain-dead, but there is no indecency in performing an early inquest on the 1883 Mount Morris Bank Building, at Park Avenue and 125th Street. Now slashed from six scrumptious red-brick-and-brownstone stories to one, it’s hardly more than a flutter on a hospital monitor.

headline: More Gods, Saints and Epic Flying Heroes
text: Anyone interested in Buddhist sacred art will want to sample some of these special, open-to-the-public exhibitions in Manhattan for Asia Week.

headline: California May Ban Smoking in State Parks
text: What is believed to be the United States’ most far-reaching plan to ban smoking in state parks went before the State Assembly on Thursday, proposed as a way to get cigarette butts off the beach, eliminate secondhand smoke and reduce the threat of wildfires.

text: Reports from the South by Southwest film festival.

headline: A Blue Dog Switches His Vote to Yes
text: Representative Bart Gordon, Democrat of Tennessee and a member of the fiscally conservative Blue Dog coalition, has said that he will vote in favor of the health care legislation. Mr. Gordon opposed the House version of the health care bill in November.
