headline: March Madness on the iPhone
text: As briefly mentioned in Thursday’s Phone Smart column, the CBSSports NCAA March Madness On Demand app ($10) has hit the iPhone, giving users live video of every game in the tournament.

headline: Landmarc’s Marc Murphy on the Question of Grades for Restaurant Cleanliness
text: On Tuesday the New York City Board of Health voted to rate cleanliness in the city’s restaurants with publicly posted letter grades, adopting a plan proposed 14 months ago by the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene.

headline: Why Even Bother Trying to Connect?
text: “Hurt people hurt people.” This nugget of therapy talk is passed from one character to another in Noah Baumbach’s “Greenberg,” offered as an explanation, an excuse and a sort-of apology. While those four words don’t quite sum up the whole of the human condition, they might stand as a concise summary of Mr. Baumbach’s recent movies. The battling pair of married (and then divorced) writers in “The Squid and the Whale,” the warring sisters in “Margot at the Wedding”  they and their loved ones walk through life nursing psychic wounds and brandishing metaphorical knives.

headline: Murray State Beats Buzzer, and Vanderbilt
text: SAN JOSE, Calif. — Cutting down the nets may be troublesome for Murray State, whose guard B. J. Jenkins gashed his hand with scissors after his team won the Ohio Valley Conference tournament.

headline: Polanski Lawyers Cite New Allegations of Judicial Misconduct
text: LOS ANGELES — Lawyers for the film director Roman Polanski, under house arrest in Switzerland awaiting possible extradition to the United States, filed an appeals petition on Thursday revealing the existence of sealed testimony about secret dealings between high-ranking prosecutors and a judge in the 33-year-old sex crimes case.

headline: Where Kipling Reared Mowgli (in Vermont)
text: Dummerston, Vt.

headline: Hiking the Annapurna Circuit
text: The legendary 150-mile Annapurna Circuit trek circles the Annapurna massif in Nepal.

headline: Kyochon Tries to Get It Right
text: What do you do if you spent $2 million on a fried chicken restaurant in Midtown Manhattan, after already having more than 1,000 outlets under your belt, and then have customers tell you that you did not get it right?

headline: Universal’s Strategy Tests Lower Price on New CDs
text: The Universal Music Group, the world’s largest music company, announced plans on Thursday to test broadly whether lower prices — $10 or less — on new CDs will attract consumers who have cut back on buying CDs in recent years.

headline: Center Won’t Play Syracuse’s First Game
text: BUFFALO — Syracuse center Arinze Onuaku walked comfortably through the HSBC Arena Thursday evening, but he said that his strained right quadriceps will prevent him from playing in the N.C.A.A. tournament’s opening round against Vermont.

headline: TriBeCa Festival Shorts
text: “The New Tenants,” which won the Academy Award for live action short this month, will be among the 47 movies in the Tribeca Film Festival’s short film lineup, along with works directed by Kirsten Dunst, Domenica Scorsese and others, festival organizers said on Thursday. “The New Tenants,” written by David Rakoff (“Fraud,” “Don’t Get Too Comfortable”) and directed by Joachim Back, tells the darkly comic story of two men who meet their unusual neighbors as they move into a New York apartment; it will play on the festival’s Hard Core program. Other films announced include “Bastard,” written and directed by Ms. Dunst (“Spider-Man”), about a couple in a desert motel; “Roots in Water,” directed by Ms. Scorsese and written by Richard Nelson, about two siblings dealing with the death of their mother; and “A .45 at 50th,” a documentary directed by Joshua Bell and John Cromwell in which the actor James Cromwell (“The Queen”) recounts his experience with the Black Panther Party. The festival runs April 21 to May 2.

headline: Design Contract Signed for Moynihan Station
text: The architecture firm Skidmore, Owings & Merrill has signed a contract with the Moynihan Station Development Corporation to start design work on the first phase of the new Moynihan Station, the firm announced on Thursday. The project, which was proposed by and later named for Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, calls for converting the Beaux-Arts James A. Farley Post Office  across Eighth Avenue from Pennsylvania Station  into a train station. Skidmore has been working on the project since the 1990s, producing several versions of it. Phase 1 includes extending the west-end concourse beneath the post office to allow access to additional tracks, improving platform ventilation and signal work and upgrading the connector between the post office and Penn Station under 33rd Street. The project will also add two entrances flanking the post office’s grand stair on the west side of Eighth Avenue, along with escalators and elevators leading to Amtrak platforms.

headline: Pen International Fest Announces Lineup
text: Authors will temporarily give up the writing life for the speaking life when PEN American Center begins its weeklong Voices Festival of International Literature on April 26. Familiar literary stars like Toni Morrison, above left, and Salman Rushdie (the festival chairman) are part of the lineup, as are musicians like Patti Smith and Natalie Merchant, who have recently tried their hands at book writing. A few authors are pairing up to interview each other: Ms. Smith and Jonathan Lethem, above right; Colum McCann and Roddy Doyle; and Shirley Hazzard and Richard Ford. Jean-Philippe Toussaint, Philippe Djian, Richard Price and Barry Gifford to talk about how their books were made into films. Popular events are back, like the Translation Slam, which pits contestants against one another as they translate a single work into a different language, and the PEN Cabaret, with Ben Okri, winner of the Man Booker Prize; Ariel Dorfman; and Ms. Merchant.

headline: Good News for Fans of Bathroom Humor
text: To the joy of millions of young readers and the consternation of untold numbers of foes of the “poop fiction” genre, a spinoff of the Captain Underpants series will be released in August, Scholastic announced on Thursday. “The Adventures of Ook and Gluk, Kung-Fu Cavemen From the Future,” by Dav Pilkey, is the first in a four-book deal. In the graphic novel, “written” by the fictional characters George Beard and Harold Hutchins, Ook and Gluk are caveboys in Ohio in 500,001 B.C. who battle an evil corporation from the future and wind up in A.D. 2222. “I think fans of Captain Underpants will be very happy with this new book,” Mr. Pilkey said in a written statement. “It has all the action, laffs and ridiculousness that children love, plus all the unapologetic irreverence and questionable potty humor that grumpy curmudgeons love to complain about.” While Captain Underpants will not appear in the first book, he will be in two of the four, Scholastic said. Tracy van Straaten, vice president for publicity at Scholastic, said the first book would have a printing of one million copies, joining 45 million copies in print of Mr. Pilkey’s eight Captain Underpants books, featuring a superhero in briefs and a red cape. First out in 1997, the books became best sellers despite complaints by some parents and educators about their bathroom humor.

headline: Virtual Biennial, Twitter (and Cameras) Allowed
text: If you’ve wanted to visit the Whitney Biennial but do not live near New York or you work a job where you’re never allowed to leave your desk (ahem), the Whitney Museum of American Art and WNYC radio are collaborating on a virtual tour. On Tuesday, the museum and WNYC will offer what they are calling “a private, curator-led Twitter tour” of the biennial, above, the organizations said in a news release. At its Web site (wnyc.org), WNYC is seeking social-media-savvy listeners, eight of whom will be chosen to comment on the exhibition using Twitter and Facebook, as well as the photo-sharing site Flickr. (As anyone who has been reprimanded for taking a photograph at the Whitney will know, the museum is bending its rules for the occasion.) The rest of us can follow the virtual tour on these Web sites and pose questions to Gary Carrion-Murayari, a curator of the biennial, on Twitter at @WNYCculture, @whitneymuseum or @cmonstah, the Twitter feed of the WNYC contributor Carolina Miranda.

headline: Look, Kids: A Way to Slip Pokémon Past Mom
text: Countless children who do not carry a wallet, do not carry a cellphone and do not even have keys to their own house make sure to carry a Nintendo portable game machine with them wherever they can. And for the few places they can’t (oh, I don’t know, school?), Nintendo has now delivered the ultimate solution  or perhaps the ultimate problem.

headline: Thank You, Friends: A Few More Thoughts About Alex Chilton
text: Among the stray details and remembrances of Alex Chilton, the rock musician of Box Tops and Big Star renown who died on Wednesday, that I couldn’t quite fit into the obituary for him:

headline: Piano and Voice Salute Chopin, Schumann and Those They Inspired
text: Emanuel Ax could easily have celebrated the joint 200th anniversaries of Chopin and Schumann with a series of solo piano recitals. Instead, in three programs at Carnegie Hall, he tried something fresher.

headline: The Next Stage for ‘Fela!’: Olivier Theater in London
text: While the West End has been home to the commercial runs of many successful Broadway musicals, the nonprofit National Theater in London on Thursday announced a rare undertaking for its stages: a production of the new Broadway musical “Fela!” later this year that will star the two actors who now alternate in the title role in New York.

headline: For Bronx Community Organizer, Work and Life Were One
text: One winter day in the mid-1970s, Jim Buckley, a young tenant organizer in the Bronx, went to the offices of Con Ed to try to get an apartment building’s lights turned back on.

headline: Pomp and Pyrotechnics on Point
text: On Wednesday night at City Center, Ángel Corella, one of American Ballet Theater’s stars, was at his most brilliantly charming. The occasion was the New York debut of his own ballet company  Ballet Corella Castilla y León, from Spain. He had choreographed the first ballet, “String Sextet,” as a showcase for the virtuosity of many other dancers. The program’s next offerings, “Walpurgisnacht” and “Sunny Duet,” were short 20th-century Soviet Russian vehicles for further virtuosity. The audience responded lustily to every dancer and the many, many displays of bravura.

headline: Chilling, but It’s Not the Bataan Death March
text: Correction appended | For 65 years, this Associated Press photograph of Allied prisoners of war carrying their fallen comrades on makeshift stretchers has been the visual embodiment of the Bataan Death March, in the early months of World War II.

headline: Theater Listings: March 19 — 25
text: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current shows, additional listings, showtimes and tickets: nytimes.com/theater.

headline: Cross-Cultural Rhythms Amid Relaxed Chemistry
text: Jim Black, the drummer and de facto leader of Pachora, was a force in constant motion at Rose Live Music in Brooklyn on Wednesday night. The hummingbird churn of his fingers on a dumbek, or goblet drum, was punctuated by an array of passing textures: the startled cough of a cymbal grasped in midcrash, or the hurried rustle of a shaker, or the deadening whomp of a detuned floor tom. Mr. Black, with his busy amalgam of Balkan and Middle Eastern rhythms, was working in a mode both familiar and dated. “We’re Pachora. We’re from the ’90s,” he said cheerily at the start of the band’s first set.

headline: ‘Idol’ Elimination Leads the Night
text: Lacey Brown became the first of the final 12 “American Idol” contestants to be eliminated as the hourlong results episode on Wednesday drew 20.1 million viewers, according to Nielsen’s estimates. The show was the top-rated program on the night, lifting Fox to No. 1 in prime time. CBS ranked second with a lineup of mostly repeats. CBS’s “Criminal Minds,” at 9, drew 7.6 million viewers, and “CSI: NY,” at 10, drew 7.5 million. NBC was third, finishing close behind CBS and leading the 10 p.m. hour with “Law & Order: SVU” (9.5 million), while ABC placed a distant fourth.

headline: Wait, Wait, Don’t Torture Me
text: Updating a famous psychological experiment first conducted in the 1960s by researchers at Yale University, French documentary producers managed to trick dozens of people — who were told that they were taking part in a pilot for a new game show that, in fact, never existed — into administering what seemed like painful electric shocks to a fellow contestant.

headline: Proving Their Mettle in the Men-Only Era of Rock
text: “The Runaways,” which takes place mainly in Southern California in the mid-1970s, evokes its moment and milieu with affectionate, almost uncanny fidelity. It’s a sun-baked teenage wasteland of muscle cars and hamburger stands, and the two young 21st-century movie stars who play the main characters seem to fit right in. Dakota Fanning and Kristen Stewart, who are Cherie Currie and Joan Jett, lead singer and guitarist for the band that gives the movie its name, were born a long time after the book had closed on the real-life Runaways, but the seriousness and self-confidence with which they tackle their roles goes a long way toward establishing a sense of authenticity.

headline: Fortunes Improve for ‘Miracle Worker’
text: After two weeks of doubts about the financial viability of the Broadway revival of “The Miracle Worker,” its producers have completed a new round of financing that will allow the play to keep running through mid-April in hopes of appealing to spring vacation theatergoers.

headline: The Casuals
text: It’s all in the jeans — and khakis. More …

headline: Photo of the Week
text: Tourists take photos in front of the Parthenon in Athens.

headline: Doctor Asserts Church Ignored Abuse Warnings
text: ESSEN, Germany — The German archdiocese led by the future Pope Benedict XVI ignored repeated warnings in the early 1980s by a psychiatrist treating a priest accused of sexually abusing boys that he should not be allowed to work with children, the psychiatrist said Thursday.

headline: Baylor Clears Its First Hurdle
text: NEW ORLEANS — As the No. 3 seed in the South Region of the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament, Baylor is a trendy darkhorse pick to make the Final Four.

headline: Kansas State Outmuscles North Texas
text: OKLAHOMA CITY — North Texas won 11 straight games before swooping into the N.C.A.A. tournament, but it discovered Thursday that opponents like Florida Atlantic, Florida International, Denver and Houston Baptist are a little less formidable than Kansas State.

headline: Bake-In! Lower Manhattan, 4 P.M.
text: Wielding pans and signs that read “I love my Mom’s oatmeal cookies” and “No Doritos, no Pop-Tarts,” children and their parents gathered near City Hall Thursday afternoon to protest the new bake sale rules in New York City public schools, which prevent students from selling home-baked goods during school hours.

headline: Searching the Bones of Our Shared Past
text: WASHINGTON  Our species has undergone a significant evolutionary change in the last 150 years. This is scarcely a sigh on the scale of long-term hominin evolution, some six million years of transformation that is the main concern of the impressive David H. Koch Hall of Human Origins, which opened this week at the Smithsonian’s National Museum of Natural History. But without this recent, subtle, quick change, this $20.5 million exhibition would hardly have been possible.

headline: Character and Career, Both Alive
text: IN the first two seasons of the AMC drama “Breaking Bad,” Jesse Pinkman has been party to acts of larceny, blackmail, murder and other felonies; lost his girlfriend as a result of her drug abuse; and fallen back so hard on his own addiction that he eventually ended up in rehab. As Jesse, a seedy, selfish drug maker and dealer endures these hardships, Aaron Paul, the 30-year-old actor who plays him, could hardly be happier.

headline: A.F.L.-C.I.O. Lines Up Behind the New Bill
text: In a telephone news conference on Thursday, Richard Trumka, the A.F.L.-C.I.O.’s president, said that the federation’s executive council had voted overwhelmingly to press Congress to enact the health care legislation.

headline: Il Duce as Young Lover: The Making of a Dictator
text: “The mass loves strong men,” Benito Mussolini once said. “The mass is female.” In “Vincere,” a sustained, alternatingly exhausting and aesthetically exhilarating howl of a film, the veteran Italian director Marco Bellocchio brilliantly personalizes Mussolini’s rise to power through a fictional retelling of his seduction and catastrophically violent betrayal of his reputed first wife, Ida Dalser. Like much of Italy, Dalser abandoned herself to him body and soul. The film’s title  a reference to a popular Italian Fascist song  means to win, as in to defeat, vanquish, surpass. “Win, win, win!” Fascist soldiers would sing, as Il Duce aroused the populace. “At any cost!”

headline: St. Mary’s Flexes Muscles in a Soft Region
text: PROVIDENCE, R.I. — All season, as West Coast basketball toiled in obscurity and futility, St. Mary’s reigned as perhaps the sport’s top program west of the Rocky Mountains. The Gaels finished second in the West Coast Conference regular-season standings, upset Gonzaga in the league tournament final, and looked like a dangerous team in the N.C.A.A. tournament.

headline: Bauhaus Meets Venice Beach
text: “Josef Albers/Ken Price,” a thrilling exhibition at the Brooke Alexander Gallery in SoHo, can make you feel as if your eyes were attached to a bigger, more perceptive brain. It brings together the work of two great artists in a way that enables you to see both more clearly.

headline: What We’re Reading: Hacked Cars and E-Books for the Mac
text: Hacker Disables More Than 100 Cars Remotely — Wired.comNick Bilton says: In Austin, Tex., more than 100 Web-connected cars were disabled by a disgruntled 20-year-old hacker.

headline: Paired Artists, All Around Town
text: The Manhattan shows mentioned in the article:

headline: The Shrine Down the Hall
text: Seven years after the beginning of the Iraq war — and with U.S. troop deaths in Iraq and Afghanistan exceeding 5,000 — a look at some of the bedrooms America's young war dead left behind.

headline: A Subtle Mix of Traditional and Modern Gestures
text: At the start of Yasuko Yokoshi’s “Tyler Tyler,” a woman in a long, full skirt enters with slow, almost ritualistic pacing and places a tiny toy piano on the floor. A man (Kuniya Sawamura) in traditional costume kneels close to her and begins to move with subtle twistings and dippings of the upper body as she sings in Japanese.

headline: A Peek at an Interactive Magazine for the Apple iPad
text: 11:30 p.m. | Correction. A single issue of the VIVmag is $6.

headline: Planting a Johns ‘Flag’ in a Private Collection
text: Less than two months before Christie’s will be selling one of Jasper Johns’s signature “Flag” paintings, the hedge fund billionaire Steven A. Cohen privately scooped up a larger and earlier example of that artist’s seminal image. He bought it from Jean-Christophe Castelli, son of Leo Castelli, Mr. Johns’s legendary dealer. The younger Mr. Castelli inherited the painting from his father, who died in 1999.

headline: Summers Slams Boehner’s ‘Punk Staffers’ Comment
text: From Sewell Chan at The Caucus:

headline: Interlopers on the Skyline
text: LONDON

headline: The Vote Count
text: What are the odds for passage of the reconciliation bill in the House? At the end of  Thursday, The Times counted 196 votes for the legislation, 199 against, and 34 still undecided. Find the full tally here.

headline: Married to Their Colorful Histories
text: When Nathanael West, the author of the comic-grotesque novels “Miss Lonelyhearts” (1933) and “The Day of the Locust” (1939), died in a car crash in 1940, at 37, it didn’t surprise anyone who knew him. He was a notoriously bad driver, the kind of guy who’d blow through 11 straight red lights or take his eyes off the road to talk to someone in the back seat.

headline: ‘Financial Tuneup': A Live Event
text: Some of you may remember a column I wrote last year recommending that we all take an entire day each year to knock off our list of financial to-do’s.

headline: In a Battle of the Exes, the Punches Are Pulled
text: At the beginning of “The Bounty Hunter,” Nicole and Milo  she’s a reporter for The Daily News, played by Jennifer Aniston; he’s a former New York City police officer, played by Gerard Butler, who now plies the unglamorous trade that gives the movie its name  are divorced. It is obvious enough that this condition will reverse itself by the end, but it would have been better for everybody concerned, the audience most of all, if they had just stayed split.

headline: Ask Anthony Shadid About the Iraq Elections
text: Preliminary Results

headline: ‘Lonelyhearts’
text: Chapter 1

headline: A Troubled Victory for Villanova
text: PROVIDENCE, R.I. — From the outside, the Villanova program doesn’t look particularly stable. The second-seeded Wildcats trailed virtually the entire game against No. 15 Robert Morris in the first round of the N.C.A.A. tournament on Thursday, had lost five of seven games heading into the N.C.A.A.’s and have dealt with a flurry of off-court problems.

headline: Live Updates From the N.C.A.A. Tournament, Part II
text: Live updates and analysis from the N.C.A.A. tournament. Pete Thamel in Providence, Thayer Evans in New Orleans and Dave Caldwell in Oklahoma City gave updates, and Zach Hillesland, a former Notre Dame forward, offered analysis about the games from South Bend, Ind. Readers are invited to join the conversation in the comments section below.

headline: Insurer’s Large Public Offering Could Lift Japanese Markets
text: HONG KONG —If things go according to plan, the Japanese insurance group Dai-Ichi Mutual Life on April 1 will stage the world’s largest stock market debut since Visa’s listing two years ago.

headline: Democrats Focus on McConnell in TV Ad
text: Pouncing on an article by The Times’s Carl Hulse and Adam Nagourney about Senator Mitch McConnell’s strategy for a Republican blockade on health care (and other legislative matters), the Democratic National Committee has released a new ad.

headline: Prius Computer Raises Doubts in an Account of a Crash
text: Federal safety regulators investigating the crash of a Toyota Prius in suburban New York said Thursday that the car’s computer showed no evidence of braking by the driver at the time of the crash.

headline: Hacker With Ink on Back and Big Chip on Shoulder
text: Tattoos and body piercings must be pretty far-out stuff in Sweden, the land of midnight sun, icy blondes and enough twisted thinking to plump up three best-selling mystery novels. From the way that most people look at the inked, pierced form of Lisbeth Salander, the main attraction in the movie adaptation of “The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo,” the first book in Stieg Larsson’s so-called Millennium Trilogy, you might even think that our girl had a swastika stamped on her forehead rather than a few modest rings hooked through her nose  you know, like a cow ready for market or, given the murderous milieu, slaughter.

headline: ABC Lures Christiane Amanpour From CNN to Be the Host of ‘This Week’
text: ABC News announced Thursday that it had poached one of CNN’s biggest stars, Christiane Amanpour, and named her the host of “This Week,” the network’s Sunday morning public affairs program.

headline: A Father-Daughter Bond, Page by Page
text: MILLVILLE, N.J.

headline: Judge Denies JPMorgan $28 Million in Fees
text: Questioning Fees In Takeover Deals

headline: Old and New Media Coexisting Nicely, Thank You
text: IT was not that long ago when Madison Avenue believed that Web video — also known as webisodes, online video and Web series — would replace television, or at least put a big dent into the ability of TV to reach consumers.

headline: The World Is Your Oyster? Wrong
text: To thank me for helping them, my neighbors invited me for Sunday brunch. While we were dining, the waiter placed two dozen oysters on the table. My hosts told me they were just for the hostess, and I couldn’t have any. I was dumbfounded!

headline: Citing Recession, U.S. Again Presses China on Revaluing Currency
text: BEIJING — China’s reluctance to allow the value of its currency to rise “is a real concern” to both the United States and the country’s other major trading partners and could be subject to negotiations in coming weeks, the American ambassador to China said on Thursday.

headline: A Hands-On Approach to Health Care Reform
text: To audiences starved for quasi-medical gore, the gruesome “Repo Men” should help fill the void left by “Nip/Tuck,” the recently concluded FX series whose weekly ritual centerpiece showed the slicing of flesh (with perky musical accompaniment) in the cause of beauty . The blood count is higher in “Repo Men,” a dystopic satire, adapted from Eric Garcia’s novel “The Repossession Mambo” (Mr. Garcia wrote the screenplay with Garrett Lerner) and set 20 years in the future in a generically grungy megalopolis.

headline: High-Octane Offense Takes Mercyhurst to Women’s Frozen Four
text: More than any other player on the top-ranked Mercyhurst College women’s ice hockey team, center Vicki Bendus struggles to juggle the hours in her day.

headline: Leaving Office Early, at a Cost to Taxpayers
text: Democracy is “a form of worship,” H. L. Mencken said at his acerbic best. “It is the worship of jackals by jackasses.” And to think that Mencken, who died in Baltimore in 1956, reached that conclusion without the benefit of having observed politics as it is practiced these days in New York.

headline: Germany Backtracks on Europe Rescue for Greece
text: After weeks of backing a European rescue for the financially troubled Greece, Germany shifted course on Thursday, signaling that help should come from the International Monetary Fund rather than Greece’s neighbors.

headline: Lost in Social Minefields Without a Proper Clue
text: Few moviegoers are as demanding as young readers confronted with a film adaptation of a book they love. The makers of the “Harry Potter” and “Twilight” franchises live in terror of the judgment of such audiences, who often demand literal fidelity to the text in question. The minor liberties and omissions of the recent movie version of “The Lightning Thief” provoked withering scorn, at least from a certain fifth grader I know. As for “Diary of a Wimpy Kid”  let’s just say that it’s better that I went to the screening alone.

headline: Two House Democrats Take Opposite Sides
text: Democratic lawmakers continued to stake out positions on the big health care legislation on Thursday.

headline: Gov. Sanford Accepts Fine in Ethics Case
text: Gov. Mark Sanford of South Carolina agreed Thursday to pay $74,000 to settle charges that his personal travel and campaign spending violated state ethics laws, but he continued to deny wrongdoing.

headline: Butler Takes a Page From ‘Hoosiers’
text: SAN JOSE, Calif. — Faced with a helter-skelter pace and case of the tournament jitters, the Butler Bulldogs took a deep breath and channeled their inner Jimmy Chitwood.

headline: Polanski Appeal Alleges More Secret Dealings by Judge in ’77 Case
text: LOS ANGELES  Lawyers for the film director Roman Polanski, under house arrest in Switzerland awaiting possible extradition to the United States, filed an appeals petition on Thursday revealing the existence of sealed testimony about secret dealings between high-ranking prosecutors and a judge in the director’s 33-year-old sex crimes case.

headline: More Teams Would Ruin a Great Thing
text: Providence, R.I.

headline: A Flurry of Calls After a Paterson Aide’s Domestic Dispute
text: The dispute had ended, and his companion had called 911, saying she had been a victim of domestic violence. Sometime before 10 p.m. on Oct. 31, David W. Johnson left the Bronx apartment he shared with the woman and began making a series of phone calls.

headline: Behind the New U.S. Terror Cases
text: Several terrorism cases in recent months have involved American citizens or residents, many from backgrounds that do not fit the expected profile of a jihadist.

headline: A Return to Neil Young’s Stage
text: As concert documentaries go, both “Neil Young: Heart of Gold” (2006) and the new “Neil Young Trunk Show” are luxury goods. Beautifully lighted and meticulously recorded, they look and sound like several million bucks.

headline: Lazio Goes After New Challenger in Governor’s Race
text: ALBANY — The campaign for the Republican nomination for governor was blown wide open on Thursday as the party’s presumptive frontrunner, Rick A. Lazio, lost key support after a last-minute entry into the race by a conservative Long Island Democrat.

headline: Many Calls for Avoiding a Repeat of Bank Bailouts
text: WASHINGTON — The idea of requiring giant banks to develop contingency plans that would spell out their orderly demise in a financial crisis gained support on Thursday from major international regulators.

headline: Life Under a Tyrant, Even After Escaping
text: Mystery, violence, appalling repression, colorful spectacle, a dictator in a jumpsuit  it’s no wonder North Korea has become an increasingly popular subject for documentary makers. In “Kimjongilia,” the director, N. C. Heikin, sets herself apart by adding a new element to the mix: interpretive dance.

headline: Play-by-Play Is Just Part of the Job at Cornell
text: JACKSONVILLE, Fla. — The Badger Network was set up and spread out over a courtside table at Jacksonville Veterans Memorial Arena. There was an array of digital boxes and a pile of headphones neatly in place when Cornell’s Barry Leonard rolled in with all of his gear, stuffed in one bag.

headline: Bloomberg Is Quietly Ending a Charitable Program
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, New York City’s richest man and biggest philanthropist, is quietly pulling the plug on an unusual program that has poured nearly $200 million of his fortune into nonprofit groups across the five boroughs, in a sign of major change under way in his charitable giving plans.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: March 18, 2010

headline: Safety Issues Linger as Nuclear Reactors Shrink in Size
text: MOSCOW — When the Soviet Union introduced its Alfa class submarine — at the time, the world’s fastest — the subs were the bane of American sailors. Now, the reactors that powered those submarines are being marketed as the next innovation in green power.

headline: Pole Positions
text: It may not be an official Olympic sport yet, but tonight a group of artists will make the case that pole dancing isn't just an excuse for Carmen Electra to hawk an aerobic video on television or Elizabeth Berkeley to awkwardly dance on a movie screen. Beginning at 7:30 p.m. at Symphony Space, twelve of the best pole dancers in the United States will, according to the United States Pole Dancing Federation, "show off acrobatic skills and dance moves on 12-foot poles. All competitors perform with remarkable grace and technique, evidently showing the beauty of this sensual dance and fitness form." There is, surely to the disappointment of at least a few, absolutely no nudity involved.

headline: Art Dealer Pleads Guilty in $120 Million Fraud Case
text: A once-prominent art dealer pleaded guilty on Thursday to a $120 million fraud scheme, admitting he sold paintings he did not own and at least once sold fractional shares of a painting that added up to more than 100 percent.

headline: Barnes & Noble Promotes the Head of Its Web Division to Chief Executive
text: Determined to stake out a strong digital future, Barnes & Noble on Thursday named William Lynch, president of the company’s Web division, as chief executive, succeeding Stephen Riggio, who will remain as vice chairman.

headline: Donor to Democrats Pleads Guilty to $292 Million Fraud
text: A once-wealthy businessman and prominent donor to Democratic candidates pleaded guilty on Thursday to stealing hundreds of millions of dollars to buy property in Westchester County, donate to charity and give money to political campaigns.

headline: Allons-y au Ciné
text: All you Franco-cinephiles relax. It's not too late to catch one of the films in Rendez-Vous with French Cinema  the annual festival in its 15th year ends this weekend. "In a Gallic cinema renowned for its appreciation of women," writes Stephen Holden, "this year it is the men's turn in the spotlight." On Friday you can see one of the best, Vincent Lindon, in "Mlle. Chambon." In the film, "Mr. Lindon's character is a happily married mason who fights his attraction to his son's refined, violin-playing teacher (a fluttery Sandrine Kiberlain) whom he meets when he fixes a window in her home. This mild-mannered class study suggests a discreetly buttoned up 'Lady Chatterley's Lover.' "

headline: Brooklyn Noise
text: The Brooklyn group Excepter "specializes in electronic diddles and jerky, mesmerizing noise compositions: this is the sound your stomach might make if you ate a computer," writes Amanda Petrusich. If that wasn't reason enough, go to hear Malkuth, Hidden Fees, Hey Breaker Quintet and D.J. Tres Ills, who will also be performing at Glasslands Gallery in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, on Saturday.

headline: The Universe Up There
text: American space-flight technology has certainly changed in the almost 50 years since Alan Shepard went aloft, and so has filmmaking technology. But “Hubble 3D,” the latest Imax space movie, makes clear that one science has stood stubbornly still: that of the voice-overs for these types of documentaries.

headline: Oversight Agency Bars Provident Brokerage Firm
text: The Financial Industry Regulatory Authority said Thursday that it had expelled Provident Asset Management from the industry as part of a broader investigation into sales by brokers of unsuitable or fraudulent investments to retail customers.

headline: Perez Gains Some Converts
text: JUPITER, Fla. — Here are three words you don’t normally see in a sentence together: Oliver, Perez and consistency. Despite his reputation as an erratic pitcher, Perez is slowly starting to win converts, at least in the Mets’ clubhouse.

headline: At Midnight, All the Doctors…
text: “I’m a sleep doctor.” Silence. There is a pause in the conversation, which is common.

headline: Lehman’s Demise, Dissected
text: What if the biggest rewards on Wall Street went to those who thwarted dangerous and excessive risk-taking instead of to those who enabled, approved or simply ignored it?

headline: A Company Races to Keep a Drug Patent
text: It has been called a case of being a day late and a billion dollars short — potentially one of the costliest blunders in drug industry history. But a court decision this week might be a reprieve for the company involved.

headline: Photographer, Camera, Subjects
text: They say you should never look directly into the sun  unless you’re the star of a teeny-tiny indie and need an excuse to squint and experience visions. Such is the case with Alex Santiago (Nando Del Castillo, strongly recalling a young Peter Gallagher in looks if not acting skills), the dissatisfied fashion photographer at the heart of “Shutterbug.” Alex is the kind of narcissist who halts in the middle of a lovers’ tiff to take candid shots of his sputtering girlfriend; were I her, he wouldn’t require the sun to make him see spots.

headline: Hummel’s Slip Sent Purdue Sliding Down South Bracket
text: SPOKANE, Wash. — It looked like little more than a slip, a buckled knee and a player falling gently to the floor. There was little indication on Feb. 24 how much the season-ending injury to Purdue’s Robbie Hummel would have repercussions across college basketball.

headline: Hostages at the Diner
text: A cheapie hostage drama with a lot more swagger than substance, “The Killing Jar” strains to wring tension from a tired premise and an airless script.

headline: In Health Vote, Democrats Weigh Success vs. Survival
text: WASHINGTON — In the homestretch of the health care debate, one obvious question being asked across the capital is whether Speaker Nancy Pelosi will find 216 votes to pass the bill. For a group of particularly jittery Democrats, the better question may be this: Who will be allowed to slip away?

headline: Clinton and Obama: High Profile Partners
text: President Obama surprised nearly everyone when he picked Hillary Rodham Clinton as his Secretary of State. But they again surprised nearly everyone by forging a partnership of sorts.

headline: Corrections
text: A caption on March 6, 1945, for a photograph distributed by The Associated Press that became one of the most widely published images from World War II, described the scene incorrectly, according to new information provided by The A.P.

headline: After a Bitter Campaign, Forging an Alliance
text: WASHINGTON — On a snowy Thursday shortly before her weekly meeting with President Obama last month, Hillary Rodham Clinton got a distressing phone call: her husband, Bill Clinton, was in a hospital with chest pains and needed an urgent heart procedure.

headline: Woods Buildup Begins With a Familiar Image
text: Tiger Woods will be back on television this weekend during the Transitions Championship, bashing the air with a right-hand uppercut fist pump. The appearance will be brief, almost subliminal, but the statement will be unmistakable, the image powerful.

headline: For India’s Newly Rich Farmers, Limos Won’t Do
text: NOIDA, India — Bhisham Singh Yadav, father of the groom, is stressed. His rented Lexus got stuck behind a bullock cart. He has hired a truck to blast Hindi pop, but it is too big to maneuver through his village. At least his grandest gesture, evidence of his upward mobility, is circling overhead. The helicopter has arrived.

headline: Corrections
text: Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about the effect of the financial crisis on sales of professional sports franchises misstated the amount Michael Jordan is paying to buy the Charlotte Bobcats of the National Basketball Association. It is $275 million  not $300 million, which is the sum Robert L. Johnson paid for the expansion team in 2002.

headline: The Praise of Chimney-Sweepers
text: “I never travel without my diary. One should always have something sensational to read in the train.”

headline: Two Families Are Drawn Together by Bouts With Cancer
text: BUFFALO — While out at the Church Street Tavern down the road from the University of Vermont after a February game, Matt Hahn, an assistant men’s basketball coach with the Catamounts, got to talking with Jon Fjeld, the father of a player. Hahn, who helped recruit Fjeld’s son, Evan, had seen the elder Fjeld around town and knew he had a condominium by a nearby lake, where he and his wife, Susan, stayed.

headline: Corrections
text: A news analysis article on March 2 about an inquiry into a possible military coup attempt in Turkey that has highlighted the divide between the Islamic-inspired government and the country’s secular elite misspelled the given name of a Turkish preacher who leads an Islamic network that some critics say has undue influence on Turkish law-enforcement. He is Fethullah Gulen, not Fetullah.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Wednesday about a report by the Pew Center on the States on prison populations misstated two of the report’s findings. The report found that as of Jan. 1, the population of state prisons was nearly four-tenths of one percent less than it had been a year ago, not 6 percent less. The report also found that in the same period the population of federal prisons rose by 3.4 percent, not by nearly 7 percent.

headline: A Bronx Tale, With Bait
text: A professionally executed farce of the yelling-family variety, “City Island” revolves around a blue-collar clan with more secrets than filters. At the head of the table is Vince (Andy Garcia), a stolid corrections officer and clandestine acting student; facing him is Joyce (Julianna Margulies), the wife who wonders where the passion has gone. Add a daughter (Mr. Garcia’s real-life daughter, Dominik Garcia-Lorido) who’s stripping instead of studying and a teenage son (Ezra Miller) who fantasizes about feeding doughnuts to fat women and you have a household that, even by current comedy standards, strains credulity.

headline: Corrections
text: An article in some editions on March 9 about a court hearing for a man brought to the United States from Nigeria on charges of aiding a Somali terrorist group, Al Shabab, misstated the year that it began fighting the Somali government. Various experts say that clashes began either in late 2006 or early 2007  not in 2004.

headline: Music, Infused With Sorrow and Joy, in Honor of Migrant Dreamers
text: JOHANNESBURG — Hugh Masekela, the legendary trumpeter, blew his horn, sang with bluesy fervor and boogied across the stage on his puffy, 70-year old knees in his “Songs of Migration,” a revival of the music made by those who came from all over southern Africa to dig for gold and search for work here in the continent’s great boom town.

headline: Arizona Drops Children’s Health Program
text: Arizona on Thursday became the first state to eliminate its Children’s Health Insurance Program when Gov. Jan Brewer signed an austere budget that will leave nearly 47,000 low-income children without coverage.

headline: Northern Iowa Ekes One Out Against U.N.L.V.
text: OKLAHOMA CITY — Northern Iowa had plenty of time to break a tie with one final shot, and for a few shaky moments as the Nevada-Las Vegas defense converged, it looked as if the Panthers might turn the ball over. Then the ball sailed to Ali Farokhmanesh.

headline: Japanese Pitchers Could Beef Up Mets’ Staff
text: JUPITER, Fla. — One has a guaranteed contract and the other was invited to camp on a minor league deal, but both Ryota Igarashi and Hisanori Takahashi could end up playing critical roles for the Mets this year.

headline: F.B.I. Faces New Setback in Computer Overhaul
text: WASHINGTON — The Federal Bureau of Investigation has suspended work on parts of its huge computer overhaul, dealing the agency the latest costly setback in a decade-long effort to develop a modernized information system to combat crime and terrorism.

headline: Photo Replay: March 18
text: A view of a day of upsets and tight games in the N.C.A.A. tournament.

headline: Iran’s Opposition Seeks More Help in Cyberwar With Government
text: At a time when the Obama administration is pressing for harsher sanctions against Iran for its nuclear program, democracy advocates in Iran have been celebrating the recent decision by the United States to lift sanctions on various online services, which they say only helped Tehran to suppress the opposition.

headline: Turkey: 20 More Detained in Overthrow Plot
text: The police detained about 20 people on Thursday in a continuing investigation into a supposed plot to overthrow the government with the backing of the country’s powerful military. Active and retired military officers, as well as government workers, were among those detained, the semiofficial Anatolian News Agency said. The investigation has reached out to once untouchable members of the military, along with secular power brokers, as suspects in a plan to overthrow the governing Justice and Development Party, which is rooted in political Islam. The army has strongly denied that it plotted a coup.

headline: Two in Georgia Governor’s Race Were Accused of Misconduct
text: ATLANTA — Two former high school teachers running for governor in Georgia were suspended from their jobs in the past for sexual misconduct involving students, according to state documents.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Monday about expansion plans of the cable company Discovery Communications misstated the financial performance of its international operations since David Zaslav became chief executive in January 2007. Revenue from Discovery’s overseas business increased by about 30 percent during that period; it did not quadruple. (What nearly quadrupled was profit from international operations, which rose to $449.5 million for 2009, from $124.8 million for 2006.)

headline: Lawsuit Cites Mishandling of Football Concussions
text: A former Arena Football League player filed a lawsuit Wednesday alleging that a team doctor mistreated his concussions two years ago, resulting in permanent injury.

headline: Proposed Changes in the Final Health Care Bill
text: A look at key provisions of the Senate bill and the changes proposed in the reconciliation bill passed by the House Sunday.

headline: Corrections
text: A music review on Thursday about Ambroise Thomas’s “Hamlet,” at the Metropolitan Opera, misstated the number of years since it was last performed at the Met. It was 113 years ago, not 103.

headline: Corrections
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Corrections
text: An obituary on Tuesday and in some editions on Monday about the actor Peter Graves misstated the history of the television series “Fury,” in which he starred. It ran from 1955 to 1960 on NBC, not from 1955 to 1959.

headline: School Suspensions Lead to Legal Challenge
text: CHOCOWINITY, N.C. — As school let out one day in January 2008, students from rival towns faced off. Two girls flailed away for several seconds and clusters of boys pummeled each other until teachers pulled them apart.

headline: Jordan Has the Bobcats; Now It’s Rebuilding Time
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — With his $275 million purchase approved by the N.B.A. on Wednesday, Michael Jordan has become the new face of the Charlotte Bobcats. Now comes the hard part: he must remake the image of this troubled franchise both on the court and in the community, where fans have long been jaded about the league.

headline: Thailand: Antigovernment Protesters Vow to Continue
text: Antigovernment demonstrators said Thursday that they would continue their protests at least through the weekend, as efforts to mediate a standoff with the government faltered. The protests, which have drawn tens of thousands of farmers and others, have prevented Prime Minister Abhisit Vejjajiva, left, from entering his office. The protesters, known as the Red Shirts, are demanding that the government step down and that elections be called. They said they would parade through Bangkok on Saturday in large convoys of pickup trucks.

headline: Washington Upsets Marquette on Last-Second Shot
text: SAN JOSE, Calif. — A forgettable night for Quincy Pondexter turned into one with a memorable ending.

headline: Big East Is a Bust on a Day of Buzzer Magic
text: PROVIDENCE , R.I. — Just over two decades ago, top-seeded Georgetown avoided N.C.A.A. tournament infamy here by escaping with a 1-point victory against No. 16 Princeton. It is a signature could-have-been moment in N.C.A.A. tournament history, as the No. 1-seeded Hoyas trailed in the final minute and were an Alonzo Mourning blocked shot from defeat.

headline: SXSW: Two Takes on the Bronx
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — The Bronx, billed as such, is a noisy post-punk band from East Los Angeles, crashing and squalling through hard-headed songs about outcasts and desperate people. But it has an alter ego: Mariachi El Bronx, which released an album last year and showed up Wednesday night at Emo’s in traditional embroidered mariachi costumes with traditional instruments, from trumpet to guitarron. It performs the Bronx’s repertory, but with long-lined melodies and the rhythms of Mexican rancheras and sones. It turns out that Matt Caughtran, the Bronx’s lead singer, doesn’t have to shout; he can carry a tune. And the Bronx taps a side of Los Angeles that many rock bands ignore.

headline: Kentucky Slams Its Way Into Second Round
text: NEW ORLEANS — Before halftime, top-seeded Kentucky had turned the game into a dunkathon. During a 54-second span against overmatched No. 16-seed East Tennessee State, the Wildcats had alley-oops on three consecutive possessions that caused their rabid fans to roar.

headline: Despite Gains, Charter School Is Told to Close
text: ALBANY — Accountability is a mantra of the charter school movement. Students sign pledges at some schools to do their homework, and teachers owe their jobs to students’ gains on tests.

headline: 2 Senators Offer Immigration Overhaul
text: Two senators, a Democrat and a Republican, unveiled the outlines on Thursday of a proposal to overhaul the immigration system, which would require illegal immigrants to admit they broke the law before they could gain legal status and require all workers in the United States to carry a biometric identity card to prove that they are eligible to work.

headline: Decades Later, Guilty Plea in a 1968 Airline Hijacking
text: On Nov. 24, 1968, Luis Armando Peña Soltren boarded a plane to Puerto Rico at Kennedy Airport. Two hours into the flight, he grabbed a flight attendant and held the blade of a pocketknife to her neck.

headline: Notes on Vazquez, Crawford and Jeter
text: TAMPA, Fla. – Carlos Pena of the Rays was 0 for 21 when he stepped to the plate in the second inning on Thursday night at Steinbrenner Field. The Yankees’ Javier Vazquez dropped his arm angle on a fastball, leaving the pitch too far inside, and Pena pounded it over the right-field wall.

headline: Public Hospitals in Miami Tackle Deficit With Pain
text: MIAMI — After warning two weeks ago that it would run out of money within weeks, Miami’s public hospital group has cobbled together a stabilization plan that will keep most services intact through the end of September.

headline: The Changes in Texas’s School Curriculum
text: To the Editor:

headline: Three Vacancies at the Fed
text: With three of seven seats to fill on the Federal Reserve’s Board of Governors, President Obama has an opportunity to put the economy in the hands of experts untainted by the failures that led to the financial crisis. In the process, he can help restore public confidence in the Fed as steward of the economy.

headline: What to Do When Groupthink Leads to Gridlock
text: To the Editor:

headline: Israel and America: A Time of Friction
text: To the Editor:

headline: Why We Reform
text: One way or another, the fate of health care reform is going to be decided in the next few days. If House Democratic leaders find 216 votes, reform will almost immediately become the law of the land. If they don’t, reform may well be put off for many years  possibly a decade or more.

headline: The Broken Society
text: The United States is becoming a broken society. The public has contempt for the political class. Public debt is piling up at an astonishing and unrelenting pace. Middle-class wages have lagged. Unemployment will remain high. It will take years to fully recover from the financial crisis.

headline: Upgrading Water Projects: A View From the Industry
text: To the Editor:

headline: On the Verge of Reform
text: The best chance in decades of fixing this country’s broken health care system has now come down to whether the House’s Democratic majority will approve the already strong Senate version of the bill  with a promise of some changes.

headline: In This (or That) Corner, From Long Island
text: On election night 2005, a beaming Steve Levy stood in a raucous catering hall, soaking in the joy of stunning victories for his Democratic Party. Voters across Long Island had finally tired of Republican misrule and were tossing out its candidates left and right.

headline: From Scandal to Example in West Virginia
text: In 2004, the chief executive of a large coal company spent an appalling $3 million to help elect a judge in West Virginia  a campaign that spotlighted the need to reform the way states elect judges. In 2010, the State Legislature there has approved a pilot program of voluntary public financing for two State Supreme Court elections in 2012.

headline: One Classroom, From Sea to Shining Sea
text: AMERICAN public education, a perennial whipping boy for both the political right and left, is once again making news in ways that show how difficult it will be to cure what ails the nation’s schools.

headline: A Guilty Plea to 2 Terrorism Charges
text: CHICAGO — A Chicago man pleaded guilty on Thursday to helping plan the terrorist attacks in Mumbai, India, that killed 163 people in 2008.

headline: The Many Limbs of Jud
text: SPOKANE, Wash. — A Jud Heathcote love fest broke out this week in Spokane, Wash. Heathcote was the longtime Michigan State coach who led the Spartans (with a gangly guard named Earvin Johnson) to a national championship in 1979.

headline: Correction
text: An article in last Sunday’s Bay Area pages about the Sunday routine followed by Willie L. Brown Jr., the former mayor of San Francisco, misspelled the name of a performer he enjoyed watching. The name of the performer is Bud E. Luv, not Buddy Love.

headline: Tobacco Rule Proposed in ’95 to Go Into Effect
text: WASHINGTON — Fifteen years after the Food and Drug Administration first proposed banning the sale and marketing of tobacco products to teenagers, top government officials announced Thursday that they would finally put the rule into effect.

headline: As Snowboarders Soar, So Does Concern
text: STRATTON, Vt. — One of the uglier crashes of Scotty Lago’s snowboarding career occurred last summer during a halfpipe competition in New Zealand. While attempting a Cab 1080 — a spin of three rotations — Lago struck his upper body hard on the lip of the halfpipe, sending his hat (he was not wearing a helmet) and goggles flying. He fell 20 feet to the bottom of the pipe, striking the back of his head, and tumbling to a stop.

headline: Bill Proposes Increased Aid to the Needy for College
text: The federal government would provide $36 billion in new financing for Pell grants to needy students over the next 10 years under legislation announced Thursday by Congressional Democrats.

headline: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Bruins Beat on Cooke but Lose Badly
text: Eleven games on Thursday night, including the game in Boston, at which the Bruins were expected to visit retribution upon the Penguins’ Matt Cooke for his blindside, concussion-causing hit on Marc Savard 11 days earlier. The Boston writers were certainly calling for blood. Would there be? Home teams listed first:

headline: War Memorials With Neatly Made Beds
text: Karina Lau’s bedroom has not changed. A stuffed teddy bear and floppy-eared rabbit sit on top of her floral bedspread. Angel figurines and framed family photos line her bookshelf and dresser.

headline: Rangers Miss a Chance to Gain Some Ground
text: Paul Kariya’s best days are behind him, but on Thursday at Madison Square Garden he scored a big goal for the St. Louis Blues that damaged the Rangers’ increasingly fragile playoff chances.

headline: Push to Test for H.G.H. Intensifies
text: The push for the blood testing of athletes was front and center in two sports Thursday, with two championship boxers agreeing to undergo such testing and Major League Baseball reiterating that it was moving forward to do the same in its minor leagues.

headline: Nonprofits Add Mentoring to Money to Keep Minorities in College
text: As college admissions season draws to a close, the spotlight has been on students’ getting a foot in the door. Less attention is paid to how many of today’s high school seniors will emerge a few years down the line with diplomas in hand, and what might cause them to veer off track.

headline: Many Calls for Avoiding Repeat of Bank Bailouts
text: The idea of requiring giant banks to develop contingency plans that would spell out their orderly demise in a financial crisis is gaining support from major international regulators, The New York Times’s Sewell Chan reports from Washington.

headline: A Financial Aid Package That Includes Mentoring
text: The New York Times’s San Francisco pages on Friday carry a feature article about the East Bay College Fund. It is a nonprofit organization that awards low-income college students $16,000 over four years and provides mentoring to ensure those students go on to graduate.

headline: Kansas Puts Away Pesky Lehigh
text: OKLAHOMA CITY — Every time Kansas Coach Bill Self got mad at his team Thursday — which was a lot more than expected — he would punctuate the point by hitching up his trousers. Lehigh, its No. 16 seed notwithstanding, did plenty to make Self look mighty uncomfortable.

headline: Idaho: Suit Against Ashcroft Proceeds
text: A federal appeals court declined to block a lawsuit seeking to hold former Attorney General John Ashcroft liable for the 2003 arrest of a man under the material-witness statute. Mr. Ashcroft had asked the full United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit to rehear a 2009 decision by a three-judge panel in the case of Abdullah al-Kidd, a convert to Islam who spent 16 days in detention in 2003 and more than a year under court supervision. In a concurring opinion, Judge Milan D. Smith Jr. called the treatment of Mr. al-Kidd, former University of Idaho running back who was born Lavoni T. Kidd, "chilling." Eight of the 25 judges who voted signed dissents opposing the decision, which suggests that the United States Supreme Court might take an interest in the case if Mr. Ashcroft appeals.

headline: Fess Parker, Who as Davy Crockett Set Off Coonskin Cap Craze, Dies at 85
text: Fess Parker, whose television portrayal of the American frontiersman Davy Crockett catapulted him to stardom in the mid-1950s and inspired millions of children to wear coonskin caps in one of America’s greatest merchandising fads, died on Thursday at his home in the Santa Ynez Valley in California, where he ran a successful winery. He was 85.

headline: With Ban on H.I.V. Immigrants Now History, Relief and Revision
text: John Newman fondly recalled the eight years he taught first and second grades in Vallejo public schools — he felt appreciated, and was once named “Teacher of the Year.” It was the 1990s, before he got sick and was told to leave the United States.

headline: Alex Chilton, Influential Rock Singer, Dies at 59
text: Alex Chilton, a mercurial rock musician whose work ranged from the soul songs of the Box Tops to the multiple incarnations of his pop band Big Star, and who left a legacy more easily measured in artistic influence than in commercial impact, died on Wednesday in New Orleans, where he had been living since the 1980s. He was 59.

headline: Tennessee Wins Ugly Against San Diego State
text: PROVIDENCE, R.I. — When Bruce Pearl arrived at Tennessee, he did so in a whirl of up-tempo basketball and high-scoring performances. The Vols have made the N.C.A.A. tournament in five consecutive years under Pearl, although this edition isn’t going to rekindle any memories of those run-and-gun teams.

text: seep •\ˈsep\• verb

headline: Forget Illinois Shutout; Relive Tourney’s Past
text: Illinois, the entire state, not just the big university, is 0 for the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament this year. What in the name of George Mikan is going on? A state that prides itself on being the Fertile Crescent of basketball talent — from Cazzie Russell and Isiah Thomas to Dwyane Wade — is shut out of the college game’s showcase event? What are the odds that every one of Illinois’s 12 Division I basketball schools would sit out this year’s tournament? Texas, where basketball is a time-killing diversion between football and spring football, has seven schools playing. Hoops hotbeds New Mexico and Utah have two apiece. Our neighbor to the east, with half our population, has three teams playing, and the fabled Indiana Hoosiers aren’t one of them.

headline: Congo: Soldiers Seize Wounded Patients at Gunpoint
text: Government soldiers barged into a hospital in eastern Congo last week, harassed medical workers and removed four wounded patients at gunpoint, Doctors Without Borders[ON] said Thursday. Eastern Congo has recently been hit by an uptick in clashes between government and rebel forces. According to the organization the soldiers accused three patients of being rebels (the fourth was apparently a civilian). "This incident is a violation of basic humanitarian principles; all sick and wounded have the right to medical care," said Philippe Havet, the head of the group's local mission. "After this serious incident, I am afraid they will never be convinced that it is safe for them to seek any medical help." JEFFREY GETTLEMAN

headline: One-Liner Childhoods
text: A new Facebook group was formed last summer, well before  “Parenthood,”  a television series set in Berkeley, made its debut on NBC this month. The group, called “Your Mom Is So Berkeley,” began as an inside joke among friends who grew up there and came up with one-liners about Berkeley mothers, said Roberto Santiago, 33, the page’s creator.

headline: Pittsburgh Looks to Raise Profile With N.C.A.A. Run

headline: Making Kosher Wine, Finding a Path Back to the Fold

headline: Finding Faith While Making Fine Kosher Wine
text: Jeff Morgan, an author, educator and winemaker in Napa Valley, produces Covenant cabernet sauvignon, California’s finest kosher wine. Covenant, the creation of Mr. Morgan and his backer, Leslie Rudd, began as a challenge. In 2002, the two, both nonpracticing Jews, were at a fund-raiser for a synagogue in Napa when Mr. Rudd asked, “Why are kosher wines so bad?”

headline: Helping Those Who Reach College Get Through
text: According to data from the Oakland Unified School District, just 8 percent of black teenagers entering ninth grade will get a bachelor’s degree. Only 34 percent of black male students and 44 percent of Latino male students who entered the combined University of California and California State University system in 2001 had graduated six years later. The rate for white men was 62 percent.

headline: Spun Gold
text: To make the finest suit in the world, you first need the finest wool. Hence Ermenegildo Zegna’s Vellus Aureum award, an annual contest organized by the storied Italian suit-making family to find the highest-quality merino wool on the planet. (Vellus Aureum means ‘‘Golden Fleece’’ in Latin; the prize-winning wool grower receives its fleece’s equivalent weight in gold.) Now celebrating its 100-year anniversary, Zegna has woven together samples of the competition’s top fleeces since 2002 to create one of the lightest fabrics ever worn: the lot’s fibers measure 11.1 microns on average, while a human hair averages a whopping 100 microns. Obviously limited by supply (only about 200 feet of cloth is produced) to an edition of 20 and retailing at $22,500, each made-to-order Centennial Vellus Aureum suit takes 18-plus hours to create and passes through more than 330 pairs of hands. ‘‘Is this the ultimate in men’s-wear luxury?’’ Anna Zegna, the image director of the brand, asks rhetorically. ‘‘Oh, we certainly think so.’’ More…

headline: Art Dealer Pleads Guilty in $120 Million Fraud Case

headline: Tip of the Week: Cleaning Win7
text: If you want to regularly free space on a PC running Windows 7 system with a minimum of effort, schedule the Disk Cleanup utility to run automatically. Go to the Start menu, to Control Panel and click on System and Security. Click on Administrative Tools, double-click on Task Scheduler and type in your administrator password.

headline: Sampler: Bay Area Home Prices Rise, and San Francisco Fights Proposition 16
text: A Plan for the University of California to Handle Prison Medicine | The University of California would benefit by taking charge of an overhaul of the state’s prison medical system and creating a centralized system of managed care, according to a report by NuPhysicia, a Texas consultant hired by the state. An estimated $12 billion could be saved over the next decade with the plan, which includes allowing doctors to have access to patient information anywhere and also to see patients via video, state officials said. “This is definitely a wholesale reform of the prison health-care system,” said Susan Kennedy, Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger’s chief of staff. [The Los Angeles Times]

headline: 40 Years After a Hijacking, a Guilty Plea

headline: Off the Menu: Kenmare

headline: The Daily Show With…Glenn Beck?
text: We’re getting dangerously close to three’s-a-trend territory, people. Not two months after Jimmy Kimmel performed an entire episode of “Jimmy Kimmel Live” in the guise of his late-night rival Jay Leno, Jon Stewart devoted the better part of Thursday’s “Daily Show” to an extended impersonation of his Fox News adversary Glenn Beck.

headline: Prison, Day 1
text: On a dreary February morning in 2004, my fiancé, Larry, and I pulled into the parking lot of the Federal Correctional Institution in Danbury, Conn. After years of legal proceedings and more than a decade after I committed a reckless drug-related crime, I was there, at age 34, to surrender myself to the federal government. Before we got out of the car, I stripped off all my jewelry — my seven thin gold engagement rings; the sapphire ring, a family heirloom; the 1950s man’s watch that was always around my wrist; all the earrings from the extra holes in my right ear that so vexed my grandfather. I wore jeans, sneakers and a long-sleeved T-shirt. With false bravado I said, “Let’s do this.”

headline: Dr. Sunshine
text: In your new book, “The Vitamin D Solution,” you argue that we have become a culture of sun phobes who fear exposure to direct sunlight and slather on too much sunscreen, which you believe has caused a national epidemic of vitamin D deficiency.  Dermatologists have gone so far as to recommend that you should never walk outside without a sunscreen. The American Academy of Dermatology still has that recommendation that you should never be exposed to one ray of direct sunlight without sun protection.

headline: Beep!
text: The beep is an ingenious creation. Like the railroad toot but unlike an old telephone ring, beeps have both a distinct start and finish, marked by the twin plosives “b” and “p,” and an elastic center that can generously expand and contract like an accordion: beeeeeeeep. You can create Morse code in beeps. Beeeep beep beep beep. Beep. Beep. Beep beeeep beeeep beep.

headline: I.M.F. Chief Calls for ‘Fire Brigade’ to Aid European Banks
text: PARIS — Europe should have a “fire brigade” backed by funds from governments and the private sector to deal with failures of large banks, the managing director of the International Monetary Fund said Friday.

headline: No
text: Two of the most basic words in the English language, yes and no, are locked in a constant struggle, embodying abstract forces of agreement and opposition, positivity and negativity, acceptance and denial. Just look at the recent Congressional wrangling over health care reform, where the words have come to stand for much more than simply the up or down votes that legislators may cast. Democrats seeking a final compromise over health care legislation have talked optimistically about getting to yes. “I just wish and hope some of my colleagues will be willing to help us get to yes on this,” Senator Mark Warner of Virginia said. And a House leadership aide told The Huffington Post, “We do have an environment where people can now get to yes.”

headline: When to Call the Police
text: As the general manager of a local eatery, I discovered that a server was defrauding us. When I confronted him, he didn’t actually confess but did offer to repay his ill-gotten gains. I fired him. Must I also report him to the police? Some people have said losing this job is punishment enough, but I think he will steal again at his next restaurant job. Your thoughts? P.S., COLUMBIA, MD.

headline: Stressful but Vital: Picking a Nursing Home
text: The decision is one of the hardest you will ever make. Your spouse, parent or another loved one needs care that assisted living or home health care simply cannot provide. You need to choose a nursing home.

headline: Consumers Buy More Efficient Refrigerators, but Keep the Old Ones Humming
text: Each year millions of Americans with old, inefficient refrigerators in their kitchens buy new, energy saving ones. That may sound like an efficiency boon, but what’s vexing efficiency advocates is that an increasing number of consumers don’t actually get rid of the old fridge.

headline: ‘Sophisticated Travelers’ With No Place to Go
text: There is a certain knack for spotting an airport vagrant. He may be well dressed, striding urgently, with neat luggage in tow. He may be a familiar sight — perhaps too familiar.

headline: Graphic Books Best Sellers: The Force Runs Strong in My Family
text: Two new books this week: “The Invincible Iron Man,” Vol. 1, enters the hardcover list at No. 3 and “Star Wars: Legacy,” Vol. 8, lands on the paperback list at No. 8. “The Invincible Iron Man” collects the first six issues of a new monthly comic book devoted to the armored hero. In the first adventure, he faces off against Ezekiel Stane, an evil genius with Iron Man technology at his disposal. (He’s also the son of Obadiah Stane, the villain in the first “Iron Man” film, so you know he’s got a bone to pick.)

headline: California’s New $5,000 E.V. Rebates: Grab ‘Em Fast
text: The good news for California residents is that they can get a rebate of up to $5,000 if they buy a battery electric or plug-in hybrid car in the next few months. The bad news is that there’s not a lot to choose from because many of the  vehicles, like the Chevrolet Volt, Nissan Leaf and Fisker Karma, won’t be available until the end of the year. By then the $4.1 million allocated in the innovative state program may be exhausted, but more cash is probably on the way.

headline: The Optimist’s Blogger
text: In February 2001, a Brown University graduate with the improbably suave name Lockhart Steele took up occupancy in a one-bedroom third-floor walk-up apartment on Rivington Street, near the intersection with Ludlow. The Lower East Side could still claim, just barely, to be a marginal neighborhood. Storefront synagogues and housing projects were still more typical than bars with ostentatiously unmarked doors. The neighborhood was a good fit for Lockhart Steele: they were both, as they say, in transition.

headline: Icahn Seeks to Buy All of Lions Gate
text: Carl C. Icahn said on Friday that he was now seeking to acquire all of Lions Gate Entertainment, expanding a tender offer for the film company that originally sought only to expand his stake to 29.9 percent.

headline: Friday Reading
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Ask the Contractor

headline: I.M.F. Chief Suggests ‘Fire Brigade’ for Europe’s Banks
text: Europe should have a “fire brigade” backed by funds from governments and the private sector to deal with failures of large banks, the managing director of the International Monetary Fund said Friday, The New York Times’s Matthew Saltmarsh reports from Paris.

headline: A Stake in the Sand
text: The sands found Destin first. They started off eons ago, from the Appalachian Mountains, washing their way down the rivers that flow into the Gulf of Mexico. Winnowed to pure, hardy quartz, the sediment moved with the gulf’s currents and gathered into the necklace of narrow barrier islands that buffer Florida’s Panhandle. Time and tides refined the sand into a soft, sun-bleached powder. By the 1830s, when a Yankee sea captain named Leonard Destin sailed down to the wilderness of the Florida Territory, he discovered beaches as dazzling and white as a fresh blanket of snow. The sight evidently impressed the captain, for his reaction — like that of so many migrants who followed — was to claim a piece of the shore. Destin landed, built a New England Colonial-style house and started a fishing business, becoming the first recorded white settler in the beach town that now bears his name.

headline: Complaint Box | Car Decals
text: I started noticing them a few years ago. They were stuck onto the rear windows of cars and sport utility vehicles, white oval stickers reading “OBX.” It was puzzling to me. What was OBX? An exclusive private school? A secret society? These letters were all over Bergen County, and inquiring minds (my own) wanted to know: What was OBX and how could I get some?

headline: It’s a Guy Thing
text: Guys, we’ve got your playbook. All this time, we’ve been operating under the mistaken assumption that you were choosing to get all belligerent every time our college boyfriend called, or to tune us out as your eyes became glued to the waitress’s breasts showcased in a T-shirt two sizes too small. It stood to reason, we thought, that you could simply choose otherwise, provided, of course, that you wanted to. Now, however, thanks to Louann Brizendine, M.D., author of “The Male Brain” (Broadway Books), we understand that choosing otherwise isn’t an option, because evolution has outfitted you with a brain that is, biologically speaking, not the same model as the one we were issued. (Brizendine’s “Female Brain” was published in 2006, should you ever get the urge to consult it.)

headline: Correction: Beyond the Jimi Hendrix Experience
text: An article on Feb. 28 about Jimi Hendrix misstated, based on information from Janie Hendrix, the president and chief executive of Experience Hendrix, the nature of the plans for a Rock Band video game featuring music by Hendrix. The makers of the video game say they are currently in discussion to “bring more of his music to our platform”; there is currently no plan to release a version of Rock Band devoted to Hendrix.

headline: SXSW: Mosh Pits on a Bridge at 3 a.m.
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — “Should we just keep playing until the cops come?” John Dwyer, the floppy-haired frontman of Thee Oh Sees, said about halfway into the group’s set atop the Lamar Boulevard Pedestrian Bridge. It was after 3 a.m., and the crowd fist-pumped its assent, so Mr. Dwyer bent over his guitar, the lights of downtown flickering behind him, Lady Bird Lake below.

headline: Who Put the Gaga in Lady Gaga? Producer Says He Did
text: Fresh from her prison stint in the video for “Telephone,” Lady Gaga could soon be headed to court — not to face any number of angry grindhouse filmmakers whose works inspired that video, but a lawsuit from a songwriter and producer who says he’s the one who gave her that famous stage name. The Associated Press reported that Rob Fusari, who helped write Lady Gaga songs including “Paparazzi” and “Beautiful, Dirty, Rich,” filed a $30.5 million lawsuit against the singer, saying she has frozen him out of her career as she has become more successful. Mr. Fusari, who has also worked on hit songs like Will Smith’s “Wild, Wild West” and Destiny’s Child’s “Bootylicious,” said in his suit that he was first introduced to the singer Stefani Germanotta in 2006, helping to guide her from a rock musician to a dance artist and nicknaming her Lady Gaga, from the Queen song “Radio Ga Ga.” He said he had received more than $600,000 from Lady Gaga but had not received his full share of song royalties, merchandising revenue and other fees. Representatives for Lady Gaga have not yet responded to the suit, which was filed in a  state court in Manhattan.

headline: SXSW: A Party in a Parking Lot

Typing on the patio of the San Jose Hotel, a mile or more away from the heart of SXSW, we heard what sounded like a noisy, well-sung fairy tale spilling over the wall at about 2 p.m. An investigation turned up a minifestival in the parking lot, where Morning Teleportation was playing.

headline: Gheorghiu to Substitute for Netrebko in Saturday’s ‘La Bohème’
text: If you’ve ever been frustrated by an 11th-hour substitution at the Metropolitan Opera in which a star performer is suddenly replaced by one of seemingly lesser caliber, it may be harder to complain about this particular late change to the lineup: on Friday the Met said Angela Gheorghiu would sing the role of Mimi in Saturday afternoon’s performance of “La Bohème. She is stepping in for Anna Netrebko, who is ill, the Met said. Ms. Gheorghiu, the Romanian soprano, withdrew from the Met’s Richard Eyre-directed production of “Carmen” amid marital problems with her husband, the tenor Roberto Alagna, who starred in that opera; she said last month in a statement that she wanted “to be as prepared dramatically as I am musically” for the production. But there is evidently no bad blood between her and the Met; Ms. Gheorghiu is currently rehearsing for its coming production of “La Traviata,” which opens on March 29, and will sing the role of Juliette in Gounod’s “Roméo et Juliette” for the Met’s 2010-11 season.

headline: The Sidewalk Ends, But Silverstein’s Poems Continue
text: The author who gave us “The Giving Tree” still has a little more left to give: a new volume of poetry and illustrations by Shel Silverstein, the writer and artist of “Where the Sidewalk Ends,” “A Light in the Attic” and “Falling Up,” will be published by HarperCollins Children’s Books in fall 2011, Publishers Weekly reported. Antonia Markiet, a senior executive editor at the imprint, said the new book “will contain between 120 and 130 poems” by Mr. Silverstein,  none of which have been previously published. Ms. Markiet is among the editors who began working with Mr. Silverstein, who died in 1999, in the 1970s (when he was still better known as a writer of songs like “A Boy Named Sue” and an illustrator of Playboy cartoons that would never find their way into a children’s anthology), and previously edited the author’s posthumously published 2005 children’s book “Runny Babbit.” She told Publishers Weekly that Mr. Silverstein had left “a wealth of material in the archives,” adding, “So many fans still write to us and to Shel’s family saying how important his work is to them, that the family decided it was the right time to consider another book from that material.”

headline: March Madness: Using Tournament Brackets to Debate Academic Questions
text: Overview | How can the sports tournament bracket concept be applied to academic questions? How can competition enliven debate over perennial topics in your curriculum? In this lesson, students use the March Madness bracket structure to decide a question in their field of study, holding a research- and debate-based “tournament” to determine the “winners” of each round, until a final “winner” is declared. Along the way, they write essays about the last two topics standing, use the bracket to organize debates, and, perhaps, share their thoughts on N.C.A.A. tournament basketball.
