headline: Paperback Row
text: THE MEDIA RELATIONS DEPARTMENT OF HIZBOLLAH WISHES YOU A HAPPY BIRTHDAY: Unexpected Encounters in the Changing Middle East,  by Neil MacFarquhar.  (PublicAffairs, $15.95.) MacFarquhar, the United Nations bureau chief for The Times, grew up in a Libyan oil town and spent more than 13 years as a correspondent in the Middle East. His knowledge of Arabic and familiarity with the region give him a deep and nuanced understanding of its culture and politics. In this “funny (yet penetrating) account about real Arabs,” as Thanassis Cambanis described it in the Book Review, he “nods to the prejudices about Middle Eastern fanatics and then sets off merrily to dispel them.”

headline: SXSW: The Beatles Meet the Ukulele
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — Let’s admit that I am not a huge fan of the Beatles or the ukulele, but the mash-up between the two at Jaime’s seemed odd enough for a look on Thursday. Roger Greenawalt, a Brooklynite who has produced the likes of Ben Kweller and the Pierces, is also a ukulele aficionado. Reprising a Brooklyn caper in which he played 185 Beatles songs with 60 singers in 12 hours, he set up shop at SXSW to play the Beatles songbook over two days, this time with the Eggmen, an Austin band, and a number of special guests.

headline: The Way Forward for Airgas

headline: The Originals | Rachel Chandler
text: “I feel like I’m really starting to learn something now,” says Rachel Chandler, the 22-year-old New York-based photographer and D.J., of the few months since her recent college graduation. Chandler is developing into a latter-day Kiki de Montparnasse, spending much of her time gallivanting with an international art crowd, all the while making them dance and chronicling their capers in high-demand photos that are regularly featured in Purple Magazine and on Italian Vogue’s Web site. “I know how to work a party,” she says. Chandler’s personal style is as eclectic as the tunes she spins: a Ralph Lauren cable knit sweater that once belonged to her mother, a men’s Dries Van Noten overcoat stolen from an ex, Adidas track pants, her signature blue Belgian loafers. “Well, of course I love Rei, Junya and Yohji,” she says, “but without my parents footing the bill anymore, I have to be resourceful.”

headline: Letters: Tuscany for All Seasons
text: To the Editor: Regarding “Tuscany Without the Crowds” (March 7): In its catalog of great places to stay in the Val d’Orcia, the article didn’t mention the beautiful and reasonably priced monastery of Sant’Anna in Camprena (www.camprena.it), near Pienza. Built in the 15th century and now gracefully restored as an agriturismo, it’s where the Italian segments of “The English Patient” were filmed. Last June I spent a wonderful, crowd-free week there for 60 euros (about $80) a night, including breakfast. All the rooms (many of them former monks’ cells) have splendid views and private baths, and guests have the run of the monastery’s garden and grounds. An extra 20 euros buys you a delicious four-course dinner with a jug of wine.

headline: A New Take on the Old Sabbath Ritual of Unplugging
text: I am typing fast because at sundown (7:20 p.m.), I plan to join in the first National Day of Unplugging and turn my electronic devices off until sundown Saturday. The effort, reported in The New York Times and elsewhere, is the brainchild of Reboot, a nonprofit organization of Jewish professionals who want to adapt the concept of Sabbath traditions to the digital age.

headline: So What’s in the Reconciliation Bill, Anyway?
text: The Times has published an interactive graphic comparing the Senate health care bill with the reconciliation provisions unveiled by House Democrats on Thursday. Many of the most controversial provisions of the Senate bill — its restrictions on abortion, for instance — cannot be addressed via a reconciliation bill. But many others were altered. headline: For Students, a Labor of Love Gets Published
text: The authors of a just-published book are ready for their moment in the spotlight — a book signing on Sunday. They are so ready that, as they talk about how they plunged into the research and organized the material and labored over the writing, it becomes clear that they could hold their own on the C-Span 2 marathon “Book TV.”

headline: SXSW: The Hypnotic Rock of Warpaint
text: Reverb and minor chords are beautiful things for Warpaint, a four-woman band from Los Angeles. The reverb makes the guitars weightless yet enveloping, and when the women use them for high, intertwining, arpeggiated lines, they hint at the gleam of Congolese pop. The minor keys keep the songs pensive and serious. And the songs unfold with architectural clarity, advancing from ethereal to earthy.

headline: Updated: Obama to Meet With House Democratic Caucus
text: 4:53 p.m. | Updated  In the higher mathematics of Washington, it’s usually not a difficult calculation: sending one president to the Capitol is easier, logistically at least, than bringing 253 House Democrats to the White House. And so the easy math has won out: President Obama will meet with House Democrats on Capitol Hill on Saturday, rather than the other way around as the White House had previously announced. The Senate majority leader, Harry Reid of Nevada, is still expected to join them. Presumably, he’ll walk rather than drive.

headline: History Club
text: For years, hotel designers used traditional motifs mainly for contrast — by mixing Louis XIV and Le Corbusier, they seduced trend-seeking travelers with eye-catching compostions. But period promiscuity may be giving way to a new faithfulness. These days, arch has gone back to being a noun, as hoteliers go for real historicism, creating (or recreating) grande dame properties that serve their nostalgia straight up.

headline: Garlic Soup for One

headline: When Baby Is Allergic to Kitty

headline: Ilana Bressman, Richard Isakow
text: Ilana Brooke Bressman, a daughter of Ariel Bernstein and Dr. Robert Bressman, both of Highland Park, Ill., is to be married Sunday evening to Richard Lawrence Isakow, a son of Hilary Isakow and Selwyn Isakow of San Diego. Rabbi Harold Kudan is to officiate at the Hotel Orrington in Evanston, Ill.

headline: Artifacts | Catherine Opie’s ‘Girlfriends’
text: Catherine Opie knows women. Self-possessed, gender-defying women who favor piercings and tattoos, and run in her butch-lesbian-bondage crowd in Los Angeles. The kind of women who attract stares and sometimes abuse. Their hair-raising, Hans Holbein-inspired portraits in Opie’s breakout appearance at the 1995 Whitney Biennial, when “identity politics” were at their height, gave her a notoriety that sent her in pursuit of less polarizing subjects: surfers, California freeways, city skylines, grand western landscapes and even high school football players.

headline: Marissa Mittman, Mark Kornblau
text: Marissa Joy Mittman and Mark Adam Kornblau were married Saturday evening at Cipriani 42nd Street in New York. Rabbi Tom Weiner officiated.

headline: Danielle Cohen, Jonathan Segal
text: Danielle Cohen, a daughter of Iris and Ilan Cohen of New York, was married Saturday evening to Jonathan Segal, the son of Ellen and Barry Segal of Gladwyne, Pa. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein officiated at the Pierre in New York.

headline: Angela Hunter, David Reiter
text: Angela Jane Hunter and David Jason Reiter were married Saturday evening at the Angel Orensanz Foundation in New York. Rabbi Robert S. Widom officiated.

headline: Meet the Crew of Space Shuttle Atlantis
text: The shuttle completed an 11-day mission to repair the Hubble Space Telescope.

headline: Philanthropy in the Form of a Fat Cash Prize
text: NOT long ago, a wealthy philanthropist would be content with having a building named after him or her, or simply donating to medical research. But in the last decade, more of the wealthy have been creating prizes in hopes of drawing attention to a particular cause. It doesn’t hurt that their names are on the prizes.

headline: New Health Bill Permits Children to Remain on Parents’ Insurance
text: At a rally on Friday at George Mason University in Fairfax, Va., President Obama got some of his loudest applause when he talked about a provision in the health care legislation that would allow adult children to remain on their parents’ health insurance policies until the age of 26.

headline: Kisha Cameron and Eric Dingle
text: Kisha Imani Cameron and Eric Lee Dingle were married Friday evening at the Riviera, a caterer in Brooklyn. The Rev. Karim Camara, a Baptist minister and a New York State assemblyman who represents the 43rd District in Brooklyn, officiated.

headline: Patron Turns Home Movies Into a Feature
text: HAVING spent the day climbing ancient temples in debilitating jungle heat, Anne Bass didn’t want to leave her hotel room again. Not even for a dance recital at Preah Khan, the 12th-century complex that is one of the jewels of Angkor, in Cambodia.

headline: French Contenders to Play in Champions League Quarterfinal
text: Could this be the year that a French team wins the European Champions League?

headline: Ratzinger Then, Benedict Now
text: It tells you something about the horror of the Catholic sex abuse scandals — where there always seems to be some fresh awfulness to be exposed — that I’ve been hesitant to say anything about the allegations surrounding then-Archbishop Ratzinger’s handling of a sex abuse case in 1980s Germany. As far as I can tell, the future Pope Benedict’s role in the case seems to be wildly overstated. But of course there’s no way to be sure what tomorrow’s revelations will bring …

headline: Obama's Final Health Care Push
text: In the homestretch of the debate over health care, the top question being asked in Washington is whether President Obama and House Speaker Nancy Pelosi have the 216 votes to approve the legislation.

headline: Travel Deals: Up to 25% Off at Starwood Hotels
text: Starwood Hotels & Resorts is offering up to 25 percent off at its properties worldwide through May 31.

headline: Pod Hotel to Open Near Times Square
text: Yotel, the pod hotel company based in England, is coming to New York City.

headline: Jessica Hinds, Stefan Griswold
text: Jessica deCourcy Hinds, a daughter of Susan M. Lapinski of Manhattan and the late Michael deCourcy Hinds, was married in Manhattan Saturday to Stefan Franklyn Griswold, a son of Genevieve I. Griswold and S. Frank Griswold of San Diego. The Rev. Craig D. Townsend, an Episcopal priest, officiated aboard the Bateaux, a tour boat, docked at Pier 61 on the Hudson River.

headline: Catherine Sadler, Charles Seaman
text: Catherine Tripp Sadler, a daughter of Alice T. Sullivan and Robert E. Sadler Jr., both of Buffalo, was married Saturday to Charles Joseph Seaman, the son of Marietta M. Seaman and Charles W. Seaman of Quogue, N.Y. The Rev. Lynne E. Jones, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of Bethesda-by-the-Sea in Palm Beach, Fla.

headline: Killer of Malcolm X Is Granted Parole
text: After being turned down for parole 16 times, Malcolm X’s only confessed assassin is about to gain his freedom.

headline: On Hiatus
text: This blog is shutting down for a few weeks while I am away.

headline: Sarah Rombom, Stefan Singer
text: Sarah Ariel Rombom, a daughter of Ann R. Cohen of Manhattan and Howard M. Rombom of North Hills, N.Y., was married Saturday evening to Stefan Francisco Singer, a son of Hilarie Horne and Carlos Ricardo Francisco Singer of Santiago, Chile. The Rev. Jesse D. Hendrich, a minister of the Church of Spiritual Humanism, officiated at the Lighthouse at Chelsea Piers in Manhattan.

headline: Report Claims Iran Arms Taliban
text: Updated | Sunday Afghan officials and a man who claims to be a Taliban commander told Britain’s Channel 4 News that Iran was supplying weapons to Taliban insurgents. The Channel 4 News report, embedded below, shows arms, including mortars and mines, Afghan officials in the western province of Herat say they intercepted en route from Iran to the Taliban.

headline: Cornell Rolls to Upset Temple
text: JACKSONVILLE, Fla. — Cornell guard Louis Dale does not look like a desperate player who had to beg colleges to allow him to play for their team. The Southeastern Conference took a pass and so did the Atlantic Coast Conference and the Pacific-10.

headline: On the Street | Green Day
text: Springlike weather arrived a week early for the 249th St. Patrick's Day parade.

headline: SXSW: Court Yard Hounds
text: Court Yard Hounds, who played their first full show ever on Thursday night, aren’t exactly a baby band. They’re two-thirds of the Dixie Chicks: the sisters Emily Robison and Martie Maguire, who have made an album to be released in May.

headline: Yellow Jackets Are Checking Cellphones at the Door
text: MILWAUKEE — Georgia Tech has gone low-tech, at least in the postseason.

headline: West Virginia Overcomes Early Stumble to Win Easily
text: BUFFALO —

headline: Iran Releases Opposition Leaders, Rights Advocates Say
text: In recent weeks, the Iranian authorities have released dozens of high-profile opposition figures who were arrested after the disputed presidential election in June, rights advocates said Friday.

headline: ‘The T.A.M.I. Show’
text: The legendary 1964 concert film, which has been officially out of circulation for decades, will be released on DVD for the first time on Tuesday.

headline: Firing by St. John’s Further Cools Basketball Hotbed
text: St. John’s fired Coach Norm Roberts on Friday morning, leaving four Division I jobs open in the metropolitan area. The second day of the N.C.A.A. tournament coincided with a bleak time in local basketball — an area that regards itself as a basketball hotbed is staring at another empty postseason.

headline: Wall Street Journal Reaches Tentative Contract Accord With Its Largest Union
text: The largest union at The Wall Street Journal has agreed tentatively to a contract that begins with a 17-month wage freeze, the union and the company said on Friday.

headline: Ready for Life’s Encore Performances
text: PALO ALTO, Calif.

headline: A Rare Spirit, a Rarer Eye
text: NECKS craned for a glimpse of Patti Smith as she settled at her customary corner table at Da Silvano in Greenwich Village, a favorite afternoon haunt, earlier this month. The wonder was that the patrons, silver haired and sleekly buffed, could pick her out at all. Ms. Smith was understated, even self-effacing in her mannish jacket, boater shirt and beat-up jeans. Watching her sip hot water and lemon, you could easily have mistaken her for one of any number of androgynous downtown hipsters adopting skinny jeans and boyfriend coats as a low-key urban armor.

headline: Stirling Moss Wins Again – From Hospital
text: Stirling Moss, the long retired British racecar driver, has won again — this time from his hospital bed.

headline: SXSW: Superchunk’s ‘Secret’ Show
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — The “secret” special guest at the Merge Records showcase was not all that secret by the time 7 p.m. rolled around on Thursday night: Superchunk was going to play a rare date. A conga line stretched outside of the Cedar Street Courtyard and down the block.

headline: Live Updates From the N.C.A.A. Tournament: Day 2
text: Live updates and analysis from the N.C.A.A. tournament. Kevin Armstrong in Buffalo, Joe Lapointe in Milwaukee, John Branch in Spokane, Wash., and Ray Glier in Jacksonville, Fla., will provide updates, and Zach Hillesland, a former Notre Dame forward, will offer analysis about the games from South Bend, Ind. Readers are invited to join the conversation in the comments section below.

headline: Could Icelandic Whale Make Its Way Into Danish Pork?
text: March 20, 11:15 p.m. | Updated A couple of readers have noted a news release from the government of Iceland explaining that the records showing shipments of whale meal to Denmark were in error and the shipments were actually fishmeal. Here’s the relevant quote:

headline: 76ers in Need of a Makeover
text: Eddie Jordan is in his first and possibly last season as coach of the Philadelphia 76ers. He makes no predictions or else he may have to own up to them. Still, it would have been hard to foresee the 76ers dovetail as much as they have this season.

headline: Crawford Leads No. 6 Xavier Past Minnesota
text: MILWAUKEE — Minnesota blocked a lot of Xavier shots but did not make enough of its own Friday afternoon and fell to the Musketeers, 65-54, in a first-round N.C.A.A. tournament game in the West Region. Jordan Crawford led Xavier with 28 points but he did much more than score. In addition to his shooting skills, Crawford, a sophomore from Detroit, showed a well-rounded mix of passing, dribbling and rebounding.

headline: The Morning Skate: N.H.L. Gets One Right
text: His eight-game suspension by the N.H.L. for what is commonly called a cheap shot won’t be cheap for Anaheim defenseman James Wisniewski.

headline: Official Calls for European Solution to Greece’s Woes
text: The diplomatic posturing over who should assist financially trouble Greece continued late Friday.

headline: MSNBC: Obama Rallies Support
text: At his final rally before a historic House vote on health care legislation, President Obama compared the overhaul to Social Security, civil rights and Medicare. (Video: MSNBC)

headline: Remembering Those Awesome ’80s
text: JOHN CUSACK didn’t need to make a movie about being trapped in the 1980s to know how that might feel. “It’s almost like a comic nightmare,” he said recently of his new film, “Hot Tub Time Machine,” “which for me is a very real nightmare. Every time I flip through the cable, I have flashbacks.”

headline: Creative Parenting | Family Crafting at the Ace Palm Springs
text: Like a lot of creative parents these days, Karen Kimmel wants a plastic-free, junk-food-free, theme-park-free, all-things-tacky-free life for her family. Which isn’t really surprising: she’s an L.A.-based installation artist whose gallery shows have turned into projects like a cool stencil kit for kids (available at shops like the LACMA Museum Store, Colette and Little Marc Jacobs); she does outreach projects with places like Oakland’s famed Creative Growth Art Center for adults with developmental and physical disabilities; and her husband, James Bond (yes, real name), runs the hipster sneaker stores Undefeated.

headline: When Not to Pay Down a Mortgage
text: This week, the Federal Reserve reaffirmed its intention to stop buying mortgage-backed securities, signaling the likelihood that the mortgage rates you can get today are as good as they’re going to be for a long while. Once the Fed stops buying, after all, rates are likely to go up.

text: In this week’s Your Money column, I take another look at the case for making extra mortgage payments.

headline: A Man and His Miscellany
text: PASSERS-BY invariably slow down in front of the 19th-century saltbox-style house on Cottage Place where John Foxell, a 65-year-old artist, writer and self-confessed eccentric, has lived for a quarter of a century.

headline: Freeze Slows Thaw That Is Swelling Red River
text: FARGO, N.D. — After packing more than a million sandbags and building 20 miles of temporary clay dikes to hold back the surging Red River, swollen from the rapid melting of ice and snow, this city got a lucky break on Friday: a sudden drop to subfreezing temperatures.

headline: One on One: Christopher Poole, Founder of 4chan
text: In 2003, while still in high school, Christopher Poole, known online as “Moot,” started a message board called 4chan. The site includes content that many people find offensive. Nevertheless, or maybe because of it, the site has millions of users and has been responsible for many of the strange memes that have propagated on the Internet, including LOLcats.

headline: Early Backer of War, Finally Within Grasp of Power

headline: What the Viacom-YouTube Spat Unearthed
text: The tech world has been riveted over the last 24 hours by the unsealing of thousands of pages of court filings made as part of Viacom‘s copyright infringement suit against YouTube.

headline: Charlie Trotter Leaves Las Vegas
text: Charlie Trotter has closed Restaurant Charlie and Bar Charlie, his two restaurants in the Palazzo hotel and casino in Las Vegas. The restaurants opened in 2008.

headline: 'Barber of Seville'
text: A video clips from a performance by Joyce DiDonato at Covent Garden. Courtesy of Virgin Classics.

headline: She’s Standing on Her Own Just Fine
text: ONLINE the American mezzo-soprano Joyce DiDonato calls herself Yankee Diva, one hopes with tongue in cheek. (You can visit her at yankeediva.blogspot.com.) While the characterization suggests some of her pluck and gumption, it leaves untouched her sensitivity, grace and kaleidoscopic sense of fantasy. The whole package came into play last July 4 in London, at the season premiere of Rossini’s “Barbiere di Siviglia” at the Royal Opera House, when Ms. DiDonato slipped and fractured a fibula midway through the first act, grabbed a crutch and finished the show to a standing ovation.

headline: BMW Preaches Sustainability in Munich and New York
text: Norbert Reithofer, chairman of BMW’s board of management, caused a minor stir this week when he said that the automaker would build front-wheel-drive cars in the future.

headline: Chic in Review | Their Cups Runneth Over
text: AnthropologieMoving into the Chelsea Market.

headline: Correction: As Plain as the Nose on His Stage
text: An article on Feb. 28 about the artist William Kentridge’s staging of Dmitri Shostakovich’s “Nose” for the Metropolitan Opera misstated the name of one of his alter egos, a character who has appeared in his video works. It is Soho Eckstein, not Eckstine.

headline: Boyd and Bishop to Support House Bill
text: Representative Allen Boyd, Democrat of Florida, who voted against the House’s health care legislation in November, is jumping onto the yes wagon, according to an interview in The Tallahassee Democrat.

text: Images from a new exhibit at the Asia Society.

text: IN Ted Danson’s hands vanity is the most adaptable  and advantageous  of sins.

text: BORROWERS have had fewer mortgage choices in recent years, and now the list is shrinking further.

headline: Purdue Silences the Doubters and Beats Siena
text: SPOKANE, Wash. — For weeks, Purdue’s bandwagon had emptied. Everyone from a doubting N.C.A.A. tournament selection committee to President Obama — who, like countless others, picked the Boilermakers to be upset in the first round — had persistently downgraded their chances.

headline: Sunday Preview
text: The Annapurna Circuit in Nepal is one of the world’s great treks. But by 2012, a road is coming in and the epic hike may be ruined forever. Ethan Todras-Whitehill, a frequent contributor to the Travel section, goes on a 17-day journey that includes a one-day climb over the Thorong La pass, 17,769 feet above sea level.

headline: Palestinians Keep Protesting Israeli Plans
text: The exchange of rocks and tear gas continued in the West Bank, as anti-Israeli demonstrations occurred in Lebanon (Slide 5) and Yemen (Slide 6). Bernat Armangue of The Associated Press last led off Pictures of the Day on Feb. 9, with a photo of a Palestinian trying to grab a weapon from a plainclothes Israeli police officer as he was wrestled to the ground.

headline: Living in: Sea Cliff, L.I.
text: Sea Cliff bungalows and Victorians often come with water views. Many homes have been carefully restored; as one broker put it, “You won’t find as much vinyl as in other communities.”

headline: The Letter by Lehman Whistle-Blower Matthew Lee
text: Few figures have reaped any praise from the court-appointed examiner’s report into Lehman Brothers. But if there’s one person who has looked good in the mess, it’s Matthew Lee.

headline: Remembering the Fallen
text: As we pass the seventh anniversary of the United States-led invasion of Iraq and surpass a death toll of 1,000 in Afghanistan, we remember the service personnel who lost their lives in Iraq and Afghanistan.

headline: SXSW: Band of Horses and Broken Social Scene
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — Let’s get the business out of the way: Band of Horses killed it on the big stage at Stubb’s on Thursday night. Other acts had trouble holding it down at the expansive club – Broken Bells the night before comes to mind – but Ben Bridwell and his mates seemed very happy to be right where they were.

headline: At 108, Still Pulsing With Vigor
text: Seventy-two years ago, a 36-year-old German immigrant named Carl Berner moved into a modest single-family house in Middle Village, Queens.

headline: The Village of Artful Lodgings
text: ON a drive around Nassau County two and a half years ago, Paul and Jill Haining of Jackson Heights, Queens, fell in love with Sea Cliff, a quirky, gingerbread-laced village overlooking Hempstead Harbor on the North Shore.

headline: The Real Brokers of New York, as Seen on HGTV
text: BEHIND every apartment for sale in Manhattan there’s a story. And with its new series “Selling New York” HGTV is hoping to seduce viewers around the country with tales of the city’s opulent residential properties and the intense New Yorkers who buy and sell them.

headline: This Way There Be Dragons
text: AT first glance “How to Train Your Dragon,” the new action-adventure film from DreamWorks Animation based on the whimsical children’s book by Cressida Cowell, does not seem to share much with the Coen brothers’ “No Country for Old Men” or M. Night Shyamalan’s “Village.” But a closer look reveals some similarities. From washed-out landscapes to minimally lighted rooms, the Nordic locations in “Dragon” feel more lived in and rough edged  more realistic  than one typically finds in animation. This comes from the influence of an outsider, the Oscar-nominated cinematographer Roger Deakins. Best known for his work on “A Beautiful Mind,” “The Shawshank Redemption” and Coen brothers’ films, Mr. Deakins had little experience working in animation, save for some consulting on “Wall-E.” But as the co-directors of “Dragon,” Dean DeBlois and Chris Sanders (“Lilo & Stitch”), were thinking of a way to distinguish their film from other animated work, they decided to bring in someone who could see light in a different way. Below Mr. Deakins, Mr. DeBlois and Mr. Sanders discuss how they achieved the film’s look.

headline: Missouri Outlasts Clemson to Advance
text: BUFFALO — Missouri guard Zaire Taylor likes to describe his team’s up-tempo style of play as more “organized chaos” than “helter-skelter.” He believes his Tigers operate best in the open floor, capitalizing on run-outs to the rim and pouncing on turnovers.

headline: Nature’s Wonders, From Every Angle
text: Oprah Winfrey is the big-name narrator of “Life,” an 11-part nature documentary that begins Sunday on Discovery, but the real stars are the camera operators who captured the simply amazing footage, going to rain forests, deserts and just about every other kind of environment to do it.

headline: Dodd Seeks U.S. Inquiry Into Lehman’s Accounting
text: Senator Christopher J. Dodd, the chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, called on Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. on Friday to start an investigation of Lehman Brothers over the accounting maneuvers that contributed to its collapse in September 2008. He also said the Justice Department should look at “other companies that may have engaged in similar accounting manipulation.”

headline: On Long Island, Legislating Fairness in Co-ops
text: CO-OP boards have long had the power to reject an application without explanation, leaving buyers and sellers to wonder whether discrimination was a motivating factor.

headline: In New Jersey, the For-Sale Signs Are in Bloom
text: MAPLEWOOD

headline: Vibraphonist Dazzles, but Without Fanfare
text: Jazz vibraphonists are often firecrackers, crisp and kinetic even when in an introspective mood. Chris Dingman had some moments like that at the Jazz Gallery in the South Village on Thursday night. But in one of the first prominent showcases for his five-piece band, Waking Dreams, he was largely the picture of accommodation and restraint, projecting a kind of adaptive humility.

headline: Financing a Fixer-Upper
text: WITH the current spate of foreclosures have come bargain-seeking buyers, seemingly undeterred by broken pipes, falling bathroom tiles and other detritus from the unceremonious departures of former owners. Whether buying for their own use or as an investment, these hunters say the good timing and low prices make the expenditure of elbow grease worthwhile.

headline: Another Dish of Reality Television Is Served on a New Jersey Plate
text: Thomas A. Edison, whose research lab was in New Jersey, was largely responsible for bringing electricity into people’s living rooms. David Sarnoff, whose research lab was also in New Jersey, was largely responsible for giving people color televisions to make use of that electricity. On Sunday in the afterlife, both men, after decades in heaven, are expected to be reassigned to hell as a result of the premiere of “Jerseylicious,” a witless reality show on the Style Network about a beauty salon in Green Brook, N.J., and the vapid people who work there.

headline: The Everest Advantage
text: CLOSE your eyes and picture your dream apartment. Do you see light streaming through big open windows? Is there a large kitchen? Nice prewar detail?

headline: Young Filmmaker’s Search for Her Worth Is Rewarded
text: AUSTIN, Tex.  In the movie “Tiny Furniture,” a young woman named Aura breaks up with her boyfriend, returns home from college, moves in with her wildly successful artist family in a pristine TriBeCa loft, all the while trying to find a place to stand in the world.

headline: In Haiti, Mental Health System Is in Collapse
text: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti — Inside this city’s earthquake-cracked psychiatric hospital, a schizophrenic man lay naked on a concrete floor, caked in dust. Other patients, padlocked in tiny concrete cells, clutched the bars and howled for attention. Feces clotted the gutter outside a ward where urine pooled under metal cots without mattresses.

headline: Correction: Review of ‘The Infinities’
text: A review on March 7 about “The Infinities,” a novel by John Banville, misstated the author’s relationship to the work of the German writer Heinrich von Kleist. While Banville has adapted work by Kleist, including the play “Amphitryon,” he has not translated it.

headline: Bike Lane Blockers, Beware
text: “Excuse me, sir,” Barbara Ross said to the driver of a black town car parked on Avenue of the Americas near 37th Street. “You are obstructing a bike lane.”

headline: Painting by Numbers to Make a Sexy Scene
text: In her new “Proximity Spiral,” the choreographer Stefanie Nelson explores intimacy using numbers  specifically, the Fibonacci sequence, in which each number is the sum of the two preceding it.

headline: Plane Janes
text: We’re told that there was a magical time long ago when, whatever your seat assignment, flying was first-class. But when did it all end? Last week, Marie Force, the archivist at the Delta Heritage Museum in Atlanta, published an online gallery of photographs of Delta flight attendant uniforms from 1940 to the present. “Delta was one of the more conservative airlines,” Force says. “We didn’t have hot pants.” Still, for almost 40 straight years, the airline’s female flight attendants (something called “stewardesses”) turned heads. In the 1940s, they did it with military-style overseas caps and spectator shoes; in the ’50s, with futurist insignias and stiletto pumps; and in the ’60s, with A-line topcoats, alligator-print boots, Chanel-inspired jackets with three-quarter-length sleeves and the “Delberet,” a pillbox hat designed for Delta by Mea Hanauer, a New York milliner. The ’70s were all about coo-coo colors, bell-bottom pants, Slavic tunics and, weirdly, a yellow raincoat. And then in the ’80s, Delta took a sartorial nosedive that it couldn’t recover from until 2001. Return your seat to its upright position, and take a look.

headline: Forward Helps Badgers Avoid First-Round Exit
text: JACKSONVILLE — Jon Leuer, a 6-foot-10 Wisconsin forward, did not settle for making the biggest offensive play of the game. He had to make the biggest defensive play, too.

headline: Correction: Best Sellers
text: An entry on the paperback advice and how-to best-seller list last Sunday omitted the first part of the title of a book by the staff of Martha Stewart Living. It is “Everyday Food: Fresh Flavor Fast.”

headline: Somehow, Pinstripes Never Fit Arroyo and Cameron
text: BRADENTON, Fla. — After spending eight seasons as the Yankees’ beat writer for The Times, one of the great upsets is that Bronson Arroyo and Mike Cameron never played for the team. Whenever the Yankees needed help in their rotation, it seemed, Arroyo’s name would float around as a trade possibility. Same thing with center field and Cameron.

headline: Stranger Leaves the Guests Both Shaken and Stirred
text: The funniest thing about T .S. Eliot’s 1949 play, “The Cocktail Party,” is that the playwright called it a comedy. At first, it seems as if he meant it, introducing a gathering of urbane, upper-crust Londoners with the style of a frothy drawing-room affair. Scott Alan Evans, the director of the new revival at the Beckett Theater, deserves credit for helping his cast speak its verse, almost unheard of in drama today, with a colloquial wit that comes off rather effortlessly.

headline: Otto Dix | Painting the Town Red
text: If fin de siècle Vienna was all black and gold and decadent, Berlin in the aftermath of World War I was a town painted red: the rouge of lips, swollen scar tissue or the last moments at dusk before the horizon slipped into the darkness of night. From time to time, the Neue Galerie reveals to us that seamy alter ego. The new exhibition dedicated to Otto Dix (1891-1969), the long-overdue first retrospective of the artist in North America, makes the scandals and scars of 1920s Berlin seem entirely fresh.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, March 19
text: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

headline: Modernism for an Egyptian Myth
text: Looking at the program that Christoph Eschenbach and the New York Philharmonic performed at Avery Fisher Hall on Thursday evening, you might think that the only link among the three works was between Berg’s Violin Concerto and Schoenberg’s arrangement of Brahms’s Opus 25 Piano Quartet. Berg, after all, was Schoenberg’s disciple, and his concerto combines Schoenberg’s 12-tone method with a current of Romanticism that ties it to the Brahms. In the Brahms itself, the music’s 19th-century harmonies are tempered by Schoenberg’s overtly modernist brass and percussion touches.

headline: Federal Judge Orders More Talks on 9/11 Deal
text: The federal judge overseeing litigation between the city and workers at ground zero on Friday rejected a settlement, telling lawyers that it did not provide enough compensation to plaintiffs and needed to be renegotiated under his supervision.

headline: Pop History Revealed! Doing Splits!
text: EVEN Michael Jackson couldn’t find a copy. In an interview just before “Thriller” was released in 1982 Mr. Jackson begged a reporter to help him locate a rare videotape of a 1964 James Brown performance because, as Mr. Jackson said, “he got so out of himself.” Years later the producer Rick Rubin would describe this same appearance as possibly “the single greatest rock ’n’ roll performance ever captured on film.”

headline: Female Saudi Poet, Known for Controversial Verses, Reaches Game Show Final
text: A Saudi woman received a death threat last week after she appeared on “Poet of Millions,” Abu Dhabi’s version of the game show “American Idol” — which features aspiring poets instead of singers — and recited a poem attacking clerics for “terrorizing people and preying on everyone seeking peace.”

headline: When Meatloaf Needs a Jolt
text: I LOVE almost everything about meatloaf.

headline: Mortals Erring in Realm of the Gods
text: Many opera productions, especially those of small-scale chamber works, have tried to break down barriers between performers and audiences. At the production of Charpentier’s French Baroque pastorale “Actéon,” which opened at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Thursday night, performed by Les Arts Florissants and the conductor William Christie, the mingling of singers and audience members was uncommonly intimate.

headline: W. Eugene Smith and the Jazz Loft Project
text: As the Book Review’s photography editor, I often choose pictures for the brief art feature that appears on the page with our Fiction or Nonfiction Chronicle. Usually it’s a pleasurable undertaking. As we prepared the issue of March 21, however, the necessity of choosing only one lone photograph to illustrate “The Jazz Loft Project” — Sam Stephenson’s account of the amazingly rich and original body of work accumulated by the photographer W. Eugene Smith between 1957 and 1965 — was somewhat difficult. (In the end, we published not precisely a photograph reprinted in Stephenson’s book, but a detail from one of those pictures, the portrait of Thelonious Monk above, as it had been marked for cropping by Smith himself.)

headline: Walk-Ups on the Market
text: Walk-ups often cost less, or have a special feature.

headline: Number of People Living on New York Streets Soars
text: The Bloomberg administration said Friday that the number of people living on New York’s streets and subways soared 34 percent in a year, signaling a setback in one of the city’s most intractable problems.

headline: 'The T.A.M.I. Show': The Beach Boys
text: The 1964 concert film was filled with acts that became rock legends but it is only now getting a DVD release.

headline: 'The T.A.M.I. Show': Lesley Gore
text: The 1964 concert film was filled with acts that became rock legends but it is only now getting a DVD release.

headline: 'The T.A.M.I. Show': Marvin Gaye
text: The 1964 concert film was filled with acts that became rock legends but it is only now getting a DVD release.

headline: 'The T.A.M.I. Show': Chuck Berry
text: The 1964 concert film was filled with acts that became rock legends but it is only now getting a DVD release.

headline: Chaffetz Accuses Two Democrats of ‘Trading’ Their Votes
text: The depth of emotion in the health care debate was illustrated by an extraordinary exchange on the House floor on Friday.

headline: Undermanned Oakland Cannot Keep Pace With Pitt
text: . MILWAUKEE — For a 14th seed in the N.C.A.A. tournament to upset a No. 3, everything has to go just right.

headline: Who’s Afraid of Marina?
text: Upstairs from the child-friendly wonderland of the Museum of Modern Art’s Tim Burton exhibition, and from the placid, chapel-like room devoted to Monet’s water lilies, the new Marina Abramovic retrospective can be heard before it is seen, and it doesn’t sound inviting. The artist’s screams and moans roll out from the sixth-floor galleries in endless loops, a warning nearly as clear as the three signs advising that the show ahead “may be disturbing for some.”

headline: On the Subway, V Is for Vanished
text: The V train, a weekday-only service that relieved crowding on the E and F lines and was one of the youngest trains in the New York City subway system, was sentenced to death on Friday. It was 8 years old and divided its time between Queens and Manhattan.

headline: Iraqis Gather to Watch Hollywood’s Take on a War That Has Enveloped Their Lives
text: BAGHDAD — Simple pleasures are still elusive here, but on a lazy Friday afternoon — a day before the seventh anniversary of the American invasion of Iraq — about a dozen men went to the movies to watch their war.

headline: Olive Oil Matzo
text: Mark Bittman makes a flavorful matzo-like bread that was inspired by a Sardinian flatbread.

headline: Mistaken Identities and a Madcap Story Fuel an Opera’s Comic Plot
text: Emmanuel Chabrier has long been remembered primarily for his orchestral work “España,” but in recent years the spotlight has shifted to “L’Étoile,” his three-act gem of a comic opera. The work’s charming contours are revealed in Mark Lamos’s vibrant production, which returned to New York City Opera on Thursday evening to open the company’s spring season.

headline: For Families With No Fear of Flying
text: GOVERNMENT CAMP, Ore.

headline: Cars and the City, Imperfect Together
text: DONALD ALBRECHT sees New York — a place where driving across town is the answer to the question of how slow can you go, and where drivers don’t stop on a dime but park in spaces the size of one — as a motor city whose car culture is central to the identity of the automobile itself.

headline: Excerpt: 'Undercover Boss'
text: The reality show has been an unexpected hit for CBS.

headline: Murder Most Improvised
text: Judging from the intermission chatter and the gasps at plot twists, few audience members at a recent performance of “Dial M for Murder” in Northport knew — or remembered — much about the movie based on Frederick Knott’s play. The 1954 Hitchcock thriller, starring Grace Kelly, Ray Milland and Robert Cummings, is one of those films that many people (at least those of a certain age) swear they’ve seen, though they’re hazy on the details.

headline: Now Playing | Band of Sisters
text: “The Runaways,” the long-awaited biopic about the pioneering 1970s L.A. female rock band, finally makes its debut today. And 35 years later, the rampant sexism the teenage group faced is still squirm inducing. First there was Kim Fowley, the band’s obnoxious manager, who insisted that rock ’n’ roll was exclusively the “sport of men.” Then there were the male-dominated music magazines like Creem that dismissed them out of hand and once famously gave them a three-word review: “These bitches suck.” Add to that the litany of lecherous promoters, bands and hit men who looked to the girls for one thing only, and it’s no wonder that the Runaways didn’t just run for their lives.

headline: Lowlifes With a Plan (or So They Think)
text: Theater people may have a different definition of celebrity than people who go to Miley Cyrus concerts or watch “Keeping Up With the Kardashians” do. So for me, the initial appeal of the Steppenwolf Theater Company’s zingy and powerful production of David Mamet’s “American Buffalo” at the McCarter Theater Center was seeing Tracy Letts in the flesh.

headline: Looking at Souvenirs and Seeing Art
text: GREENWICH

headline: Quotations of Vice Chairman Bob
text: Long after the cars he championed have rusted away, some of Bob Lutz’s notable quotes may live on in auto industry lore. Here are some examples:

headline: A Celebration of Bakelite in the City Where It Was Born
text: Yonkers

headline: Where’s the Boss? In Disguise, and at the Top of the Television Ratings
text: The biggest new hit on television is a reality show that did not get a head start in the summer, that remained dormant for half the television season, that seemed to have little chance to appeal to younger viewers, and that had to face formidable competition not only from “Desperate Housewives” on ABC, but also from three straight weeks of the Winter Olympics on NBC.

headline: Reaching Deep Into a Bag of Tricks, Even Magical Ones
text: The word “stage-struck” isn’t generally applied to shows. But it would be hard to find a more apt label for the slap-happy shenanigans in the Yale Repertory Theater’s rendition of Carlo Goldoni’s 18th-century farce “The Servant of Two Masters.” From the moment a couple of Italian-speaking stagehands open a dusty old trunk on a dark, decrepit proscenium stage, releasing clouds of magically twinkling lights, this production revels in the transformative power of theater.

headline: Olive Oil Helps Produce a Classic Flatbread
text: THERE is a wonderful Sardinian flatbread known as carta di musica — sheet music, because it is nearly impossibly thin — that I never thought of making. Something about its ethereal nature made me assume (idiotically, as it happens) that it would be too difficult.

headline: A Mozart Piece to Open the Season
text: When David Stewart Wiley raises his baton next weekend to usher in the Long Island Philharmonic’s spring season, he will be conducting a Mozart piece that is a personal favorite, but one that he has kept in reserve since becoming the orchestra’s music director in 2001.

headline: Olive Oil Matzo
text: Time: 30 minutes

headline: Less Drama in Detroit as Lutz Leaves the Stage
text: THE departure of Robert A. Lutz as vice chairman of General Motors may provoke an emergency call to the paint department: the color is leaking from G.M.’s headquarters.

headline: The Low-Hanging Fruit of Saving Fuel
text: IT’S been a standard trick among miserly drivers for years: shutting off the engine in stopped traffic and at long stoplights instead of burning gasoline while idling. And it is such a straightforward fuel-saver that shutoff systems — with the addition of automated restart provisions — are a standard feature of today’s hybrids.

headline: 500 Horsepower, but Not a Guzzler
text: DOWN at the bottom of the specifications sheet for the Porsche Panamera Turbo, past the eyebrow-raising power rating of the 4.8-liter V-8 and beyond the head-spinning acceleration figures (and 188-mile-per-hour top speed), lies a pleasant surprise: this supersedan, with an E.P.A. rating of 15 m.p.g. in town and 23 on the highway, incurs no federal guzzler tax.

headline: Singing in Tongues, Some of Them Strung
text: We know why you like Joanna Newsom. The reasons are online: one of every five people with positive thoughts about her, it seems, has recorded them digitally. That she’s original, expressive, fearless, beautiful, virtuosic, unaffected, overaffected. That she plays the harp. That she’s made the transition from garage-baroque to full folk-rock art song. That she likes words intemperately, tells jokes and wears prairie and bordello dresses.

headline: ‘Blooms of Darkness’
text: Chapter 3

headline: Friday’s Vote Count
text: As Friday winds down, The Times counts 203 votes in the House for the health care legislation, 204 against, and 24 still undecided. Find the full tally here.

headline: A Health Care Plan So Cheap, They Made Him Raise the Price
text: Hi, America, is it too late to propose a new health care plan? Because Dr. John Muney has an idea. The AMG Medical Group, which he founded last year, offers a $79-a-month buffet of unlimited office visits.

headline: ‘The Genius in All of Us’
text: Chapter 1

headline: The Week in Pictures for March 19
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in the New York region. Subjects include a recess coach, pizza slices for a dollar, and storm damage.

headline: On the Road, There Are No Sundays
text: Steve Earle and Allison Moorer, married musicians, have had a good year. Mr. Earle, 55, recently received his third Grammy Award, for “Townes,” an homage to his hero Townes Van Zandt, and Ms. Moorer, 37, just released her eighth studio album,  “Crows.”  When they’re not off touring the country, they live with their two dogs — Petey, a Chihuahua, and Beau, a blue heeler — on a quiet block off Bleecker Street in Greenwich Village. They are expecting their first child later this month.

headline: The Doctor Who Would Be President
text: With the hospitals in Port-au-Prince overwhelmed with trauma patients from the earthquake, Dr. Guy Theodore is picking up the slack in a remote mountain village.

headline: His Offense: Taking 2 Seats on a Nearly Empty Train
text: One recent night, Ryan David LaMont settled into the wary peace of a post-midnight journey on the No. 2 train. He was not quite alone, since a few other people were on board, but he had rows and rows of seats to choose from.

headline: 4 Women, Discussing Oysters and Men
text: This bivalve-heavy addition to the Mermaid empire — there are Mermaid Inn restaurants serving a broader seafood palette in the East Village and on the Upper West Side — packs them in with a smart, successful trick: $1 oysters at the bar from 5:30 to 7 p.m. (Sundays from 5 to 7 p.m.). Located at 79 MacDougal Street, next door to the ever-mysterious Italian Rifle Club, the oyster bar tends to draw a downtown crowd, including four women who recently got their business degrees and now work together at American Express.

headline: Mattel and Facebook Team to Recommend Toys
text: Fisher-Price, a division of Mattel, began an app for Facebook that is best described as a social scrapbook mashed up with a smart toy catalog.

headline: Checking the Math on Health Care
text: If the health care reform package makes it through Congress, and we should know sometime on Sunday, much of the credit for its salvation will go to Thursday’s report from the Congressional Budget Office that, according to The Times’s David M. Herszenhorn, predicted “a $940 billion price tag for the new insurance coverage provisions in the bill, and the reduction of future federal deficits of $138 billion over 10 years.” It is an article of faith that the budget office resides, pretty much alone among government bodies, in the refined aerie of nonpartisanship, a paragon of technocratic, if not inhuman, objectivity.

headline: BlogTalk: Progressives, Public Option and Abortion
text: On the weekend eve of an historic vote on the health care bill, Republican opponents do not at all sound ready to accept defeat. Or rather, they view defeat as victory, because they can use passage by Democrats, if it happens, as a weapon in the midterm elections. (We’ve been chronicling all developments on the vote-counting and snags as the House moves toward a vote this coming Sunday on our Prescriptions blog.)

headline: Madly March
text: College basketball lifted CBS to No. 1 in the ratings on Thursday night, while NBC earned a rare second-place finish thanks to “The Office” and “The Marriage Ref.” According to Nielsen’s estimates, CBS averaged about 10.3 million viewers in prime time for its basketball coverage. NBC earned its best ratings in the 9 and 10 p.m. hours with its new series “The Marriage Ref” at 10 (7.6 million) following “The Office” at 9 (7.6 million) and “30 Rock” at 9:30 (6.9 million). ABC ranked third for the night just ahead of Fox. A two-hour installment of ABC’s science fiction series “FlashForward” averaged 6.5 million viewers from 8 to 10; a rerun of “Private Practice” at 10 drew 4.3 million. Fox broadcast repeats of “Bones” (6.2 million) and “Fringe” (4.4 million) from 8 to 10.

headline: Fortunes Improve for ‘Miracle Worker’
text: After two weeks of doubts about the financial viability of the Broadway revival of “The Miracle Worker” its producers have completed a new round of financing that will allow the play to keep running through mid-April in hopes of appealing to spring-vacation theatergoers. Dini von Mueffling, the wife of the show’s lead producer, David Richenthal, said in an interview that new promotional efforts would soon be under way to market the production  which tells the story of a young Helen Keller (Abigail Breslin) and her teacher, Annie Sullivan (Alison Pill)  for parents and children, particularly fathers and their daughters. Ms. von Mueffling said she was overseeing the show while Mr. Richenthal takes care of health issues.

headline: Lady Gaga Is Sued
text: Fresh from her prison stint in the video for “Telephone,” Lady Gaga, above right, could soon be headed to court  not to face any number of angry grindhouse filmmakers whose works inspired that video, but a lawsuit from a songwriter and producer who says he’s the one who gave her that famous stage name. The Associated Press reported that Rob Fusari, who helped write Lady Gaga songs including “Paparazzi” and “Beautiful, Dirty, Rich,” filed a $30.5 million lawsuit against the singer, saying she has frozen him out of her career as she has become more successful. Mr. Fusari said in his suit that he was first introduced to the singer Stefani Germanotta in 2006, helping to guide her from a rock musician to a dance artist and nicknaming her Lady Gaga. He said he had received more than $600,000 from Lady Gaga but had not received his full share of royalties and other fees. Representatives for Lady Gaga have not yet responded to the suit, which was filed in State Supreme Court in Manhattan.

headline: Antiquities, Once the Met’s, Go on Display in Rome
text: Sixteen Hellenistic silver-gilt objects once showcased at the Metropolitan Museum of Art had their official Italian debut on Friday at the National Museum of Rome. The pieces, including the one below, are thought to have been looted some 30 years ago from the archaeological site at the ancient Greek colony of Morgantina (modern day Aidone, in eastern Sicily) and were returned to Italy as part of a 2006 agreement between the government and the Met. In recent years Italy has signed similar accords with other American institutions, and archaeologists at Friday’s presentation praised such restitutions as indicative of a cultural sea change that recognizes that “archaeology is context,” according to Malcolm Bell III, a professor at the University of Virginia who helped establish the provenance of the objects, which led to their return. In 1981 and 1982 the Met bought the silver hoard from the American dealer Robert Hecht for $2.74 million. Mr. Hecht is currently standing trial in Rome on charges of conspiracy to traffic in looted artifacts.

headline: Artists on Governors Island
text: This week nearly 30 visual and performing artists have moved onto Governors Island, the beginning of a year-round artist studio program organized by the Lower Manhattan Cultural Council. In the newly renovated Building 110, artists will have the use of 20 studios, two rehearsal areas and a large exhibition space with views of Lower Manhattan and New York Harbor. The residencies run from March to July and from August to December; the public can have access to the studios from June to mid-October.

headline: Gheorghiu in ‘La Bohème’ for Ailing Netrebko
text: If you’ve ever been frustrated by an 11th-hour substitution at the Metropolitan Opera in which a star performer is suddenly replaced by one of seemingly lesser caliber, it may be harder to complain about this particular late change to the lineup: on Friday the Met said Angela Gheorghiu, left, would sing the role of Mimi in Saturday afternoon’s performance of “La Bohème. She is stepping in for Anna Netrebko, who is ill, the Met said. Ms. Gheorghiu, the Romanian soprano, withdrew from the Met’s Richard Eyre-directed production of “Carmen” amid marital problems with her husband, the tenor Roberto Alagna, who starred in that opera; she said last month in a statement that she wanted “to be as prepared dramatically as I am musically” for the production. But there is evidently no bad blood between her and the Met; Ms. Gheorghiu is currently rehearsing for its coming production of “La Traviata,” which opens on March 29, and will sing the role of Juliette in Gounod’s “Roméo et Juliette” for the Met’s 2010-11 season.

headline: More Silverstein Poems
text: The author who gave us “The Giving Tree” still has a little more left to give: a new volume of poetry and illustrations by Shel Silverstein, the writer and artist of “Where the Sidewalk Ends,” “A Light in the Attic” and “Falling Up,” will be published by HarperCollins Children’s Books in fall 2011, Publishers Weekly reported. Antonia Markiet, a senior executive editor at the imprint, said the new book “will contain between 120 and 130 poems” by Mr. Silverstein, none of which have been published. Ms. Markiet is among the editors who began working with Mr. Silverstein, who died in 1999, in the 1970s (when he was still better known as a writer of songs like “A Boy Named Sue” and an illustrator of Playboy cartoons that would never find their way into a children’s anthology), and previously edited the author’s posthumously published 2005 children’s book “Runny Babbit.”

headline: Enticing the Senses, From Stage to Screen
text: “It’s a different world today,” sighed an audience member as dancers, some in shiny, silvery bodysuits or leggings, gently coaxed the public to join an improvised piece full of balloons and good will. It was Thursday night at Danspace Project after a presentation of film and work by Elaine Summers, one of the original members of the Judson Dance Theater.

headline: Killer of Malcolm X Is Granted Parole
text: After being turned down for parole 16 times, Malcolm X’s only confessed assassin is about to gain his freedom.

headline: U.S. Frees Detainees, but Afghans’ Anger Persists
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — The tribal elders had traveled many hours to reach a windswept Afghan military base on the capital’s outskirts to sign their names to a piece of paper allowing them to bring their countrymen home from American detention.

headline: Raising Arizona
text: Page, Ariz., has always looked to me as if it might just slip quietly over the edge into the Colorado River or else pick up and drive away. Heading for town over the Glen Canyon Dam — trying not to look to the left, down to Lake Powell, and certainly not to the right, down the 700-foot chasm into the river — I could see that Page was more or less the same as it was when I was a child: a sprinkling of mobile homes and derelict shopping plazas in a landscape formed over 180 million years into a topography of fractured mountain ranges.

headline: Irish Town Puzzled by Role in Investigation
text: WATERFORD, Ireland — When two North African men under investigation in an alleged terrorist plot to kill a Swedish artist appeared in the gray pillared courthouse here this week, many native Waterford residents reacted as much with puzzlement as dismay, as if Islamic extremism had no conceivable place amid the tranquillity of this quiet old harbor town.

headline: Band Between Buzz and Big Break at South by Southwest
text: AUSTIN, Tex.  In the blog-accelerated time zone that the South by Southwest Music and Media Conference occupies, the cycle of buzz turns so fast that bands caught up in it can find themselves in the paradoxical state of being brand-new and old hat at the same time.

headline: The People’s Court
text: It requires body control, hand-eye coordination, quickness, flat-out speed, endurance and that strange mix of caution

headline: Texas A&M Outshoots Utah State
text: SPOKANE, Wash. — Texas A&M, making an annual habit of making the tournament and reaching the second round, did it again on Friday by easing past Utah State, 69-53, at Spokane Veterans Memorial Arena.

headline: Dessert With an Italian Accent
text: Unless you are well versed in Italian desserts, you might be suspicious of the name Tart & Tufo. Could it be a spelling error? Did the owner of the bright new cafe in Morristown mean tofu instead of tufo?

headline: Intense Flavors of Hunan in a Simple Setting
text: STEPPING into the dining room at Fortune Cookie means submitting to flavor: to hot pepper, to garlic, to smoke and meat fat, the earthiness of mushroom, the sharpness of onion. The smell pervades the place; with each dish cooked, another layer of aromatics is added to the ambience of an otherwise forgettable room.

headline: Unusual Transformation From Granite to Gnocchi
text: THE second-floor balcony at Esca Restaurant and Wine Bar overlooks a dining room that soars two stories high and is accented with elegant pale marble and tile and one stunning slab of onyx. The bar area, off to the side, is eccentric, with one wall fashioned from concrete to look like the interior of an Italian wine cave. This innovative décor combines the traditional with the avant-garde. The food seeks a similar fusion; when it hits the mark, it is enjoyable.

headline: From a Small Establishment, Tempting Mexican Flavors
text: Padre’s Mexican Cuisine is the very definition of a hole in the wall. Two tables, each covered by a colorful chili-pepper-patterned cloth, occupy most of the floor space, with a short L-shaped bar and six stools taking up the remainder. Yet despite its diminutive size, the establishment, which is loosely affiliated with the adjacent Gilson Café Cinema, projects a bright, well-tended look.

headline: An Old Standby Reinvents Itself
text: The Meetinghouse, a fixture in this trim hamlet, long took advantage of its status as the only game in town — with lackluster fare and breezy service. But a recent visit revealed a welcome transformation.

headline: Crossing Thorong La Pass
text: Thorong La, a daunting 17,769-foot pass, is the highest altitude reached by many trekkers in their lifetime.

headline: Big on Puerto Rico and All Its Flavors
text: DON COQUI is big in every way. Its 120-seat dining room takes up much of the second floor of a former industrial building in New Rochelle. Its dishes are so plentiful you could serve four people with some of the entrees. Even its personality is big: It feels like a rocking party on a Friday or Saturday night, with salsa music playing and many diners dressed in their weekend best.

headline: Bottles Made for the Nose
text: You only have to inhale Bouké wines to appreciate the Gallic pun in the brand’s name. Inviting fragrances rise up from each of the four latest releases.

headline: Hamptons Perks With a Shorter Ride
text: VENÚE 56, not far off Exit 56 of the Long Island Expressway in Hauppauge, is halfway between New York City and the Hamptons. That makes the restaurant, which opened in December, a perfect stopping-off place for those heading from the city to the East End. But once they step inside, they may feel as if they have already arrived.

headline: Florida Case Blocks Parole for Molester in California
text: MIAMI — A convicted child molester held a young girl captive for more than 15 years in the 1970s and ’80s, fathering her baby and forcing her to have four abortions, according to a criminal complaint filed in federal court that blocked his release from prison.

headline: Surprising Strength? Don’t Discount Offense
text: At the Spring North American Championships in Reno, Nev., when the premier event, the Vanderbilt Knockout Teams, ends on Sunday, a team that has never won the title will be crowned.

headline: China’s Growth Shifts the Geopolitics of Oil
text: Last summer, Saudi Arabia put the final bolt in its largest oil expansion project ever, opening a new field capable of pumping 1.2 million barrels a day — more than the entire production of Texas. The field, called Khurais, was part of an ambitious $60 billion program to increase the kingdom’s production to meet growing energy needs.

headline: The Right to Counsel: Woman Becomes a Test Case
text: FORT EDWARD, N.Y.

headline: Events on Long Island
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Nassau and Suffolk Counties this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com, or by mail to Long Island Weekly, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: Why We Need to Dream
text: When I can’t sleep, I think about what I’m missing. I glance over at my wife and watch her eyelids flutter. I listen to the steady rhythm of her breath. I wonder if she’s dreaming and, if so, what story she’s telling to herself to pass the time. (The mind is like a shark — it can’t ever stop swimming in thought.) And then my eyes return to the ceiling and I wonder what I would be dreaming about, if only I could fall asleep.

headline: Events in New Jersey
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state. Items may be submitted by mail to New Jersey Calendar, Metropolitan, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405; or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Missing a Son on the Census Form
text: The envelope is larger than the usual, and it certainly got my attention. “U.S. Census Form Enclosed,” it said in large letters; then “YOUR RESPONSE IS REQUIRED BY LAW” in even larger ones.

headline: More Food Banks Helping to Feed Pets
text: The exploding demand among the needy for food banks is rapidly expanding to desperate pet owners who can no longer afford to feed their animals, according to the Humane Society of the United States.

headline: Taking a Children’s Tale to Dark New Depths
text: In John Neumeier’s ballet adaptation of “The Little Mermaid,” the title character undergoes an extreme physical ordeal so that she might live on land. As the orchestra plays a stomping series of cataclysmic chords, a malevolent sea witch wrenches off the mermaid’s fluid blue costume and leaves her almost naked and shivering onstage. With one of her newly acquired human limbs grotesquely contorted over her shoulder, the former mermaid looks like an insect that’s been flayed alive.

headline: Events in Westchester
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around the Hudson Valley. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com, or by mail to Westchester Calendar, Metropolitan, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: Events in Connecticut
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Connecticut. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com, or by mail to Connecticut Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 4,376 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war and 1,009 who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

headline: Congressman Cries Poor, but Lifestyle May Disagree
text: WASHINGTON — Money is so tight, Representative Gregory W. Meeks says, he does not have a savings account with more than a few thousand dollars in it. And yet Mr. Meeks, one of New York City’s most prominent Democrats, lives a life worthy of a jet-setter.

headline: Some See a Real Estate Bubble Forming in Canada
text: OTTAWA — Marie-Yvonne Paint, a real estate agent in Montreal, has the kind of problem most of her counterparts in the United States can only dream about.

headline: Aid for L.I. Attack Victim Took Time, Court Is Told
text: RIVERHEAD, N.Y. — The man in an alley near a Long Island Rail Road train station was breathing rapidly, lying face up in a pool of blood. His hands and feet shook. He had been stabbed in the chest.

headline: Under a New Subway Plan, the V Stands for Vanished
text: The V train, a weekday-only service that relieved crowding on the E and F lines and was one of the youngest trains in the New York City subway system, was sentenced to death on Friday. It was 8 years old and divided its time between Queens and Manhattan.

headline: A Poet Who Doesn’t Do Lofty
text: AFTER Tina Chang puts her 7-month-old son, Roman, to bed, she pads, barefoot, about three feet over to her office, where a desk cohabits with the changing table. She opens the window to take in the sights and sounds of her neighborhood, Park Slope — men arguing on the street, neighbors sipping wine on fire escapes, apartment lights twinkling. She opens a spiral notebook from the 99-cent store and begins scribbling. One night she started with a recipe for black bean sauce, another with the first line of a rejection letter from a literary journal, another with a to-do list.

headline: Appeals Court Rules Fed Must Release Loan Reports
text: A federal appeals court in Manhattan ruled on Friday that the Federal Reserve Board must release a trove of secret documents identifying financial firms that received public money under a trillion-dollar emergency loan program put in place at the height of Wall Street meltdown.

headline: New Efforts on Iran Sanctions Run Into Familiar Snags
text: WASHINGTON — It was Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton who, nearly a year ago, fired the Obama administration’s first warning shots about imposing “crippling sanctions” against Iran.

headline: Leading the Nets’ Cheers, for Everything but Victories
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Marco G. is yelling, because he wants to, because he needs to and because if he stops, someone at the Izod Center just might fall asleep. You’re not supposed to sleep at a professional basketball game.

headline: Don’t Move! If You Know What’s Good for You
text: Touched is what I am by the number of people who thought I had vanished from this place. And especially by the number who were sorry.

headline: Injured Wrist Won’t Sideline New Mexico’s Hobson
text: SAN JOSE, Calif. — X-rays were negative on the wrist New Mexico forward Darington Hobson injured in a hard fall in Thursday’s 62-57 win over Montana, allowing him to start in Saturday’s second-round East Region game against Washington.

headline: China: 4 Face Trial on Organ Trafficking Charges
text: The first Chinese trial involving organ trafficking could take place next month in Beijing, according to a report in China Daily, an official English-language newspaper. Four men have been charged with paying living people for organs and then reselling the organs. If found guilty, the men would be sentenced to at least five years in prison. China Daily reported that last year, about a third of 10,000 organ transplants in China involved living donors, almost six times the number in 2008.

headline: U.S. Plans Spot Tests of Organic Products
text: The Department of Agriculture said on Friday that it would begin enforcing rules requiring the spot testing of organically grown foods for traces of pesticides, after an auditor exposed major gaps in federal oversight of the organic food industry.

headline: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Wings Hold 8th on Last-Second Goal
text: Four games scheduled for Friday night, with an emphasis on the West — especially that last playoff spot, given that both the Red Wings and Flames were in action. There were some last-second heroics, which only served to make the race tighter. Home teams listed first:

headline: Likely Successor Emerges to Lead U.S. Forces in Iraq
text: WASHINGTON — The leading candidate to succeed Gen. Ray Odierno as the top American commander in Iraq is Lloyd J. Austin III, an Army lieutenant general who has done two tours in Iraq and currently serves as a senior aide to the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, senior military and civilian officials say.

headline: Amendments and Impasse May Hamper Banking Bill
text: WASHINGTON — The Senate Banking Committee might face some late nights next week.

headline: Health Care Pushes Other Issues to Margins
text: WASHINGTON — One weekend last month, American forces drove into the Marja area of southern Afghanistan, opening the biggest military operation of the Obama presidency. In the five weeks since then, President Obama has made 38 speeches, statements or other public remarks and never once mentioned the operation.

headline: As Time Grows Short, the Search for Ayes Narrows to a Dozen or So Lawmakers
text: WASHINGTON — The Democratic search for health care votes dwindled to a dozen or so lawmakers Friday as the House leadership and the White House sought to cement victory in a vote now set for Sunday.

headline: U.S. Basketball Prodigy Quits Israeli Pro Team
text: At halftime of a Maccabi Haifa game nearly a month ago, the American basketball prodigy Jeremy Tyler changed out of his uniform and spent the second half in street clothes. Tyler had not played in the first half, and he watched the rest of the game from the stands.

headline: Bloggingheads: You Pass It, You Own It
text: David Corn, left, of Mother Jones and James Pinkerton of Fox News debate whether passing health care reform would hurt Democrats.

headline: Corrections
text: The Vancouver Journal article on Feb. 25, about the apprehension in Vancouver, British Columbia, over large debts accrued because of the Olympics, referred incorrectly to $423 million provided to the organizers by the International Olympic Committee. That amount was the estimated contribution from the I.O.C. for the Games, as reported late in 2009 by the organizers; it was not the amount of emergency funds that the I.O.C. provided to help the organizers break even. (Neither the organizers nor the I.O.C. have disclosed the emergency funds figure.)

headline: So Much Light We Could See to the Other Side
text: All fuel and fire, spine left like a bent arrow, dark matter, the teeth as relic, all of our words bitter fruit. Who could have believed we were made like this. The cosmonaut,

headline: Adviser in Haiti to Americans Is Captured
text: MEXICO CITY — The Dominican authorities said Friday that they had arrested Jorge Aníbal Torres Puello, who acted as a legal adviser for a group of American church members who were detained in Haiti on child abduction charges, even though he himself was wanted on trafficking charges in the United States and El Salvador.

headline: At Stuyvesant, Interpreting Parent-Teacher Night
text: They were too old to be high school students, but not old enough to be the parents. They were lingering near Room 236 at Stuyvesant High School, a group of 20 young people, all of them Asian, standing awkwardly together, waiting for the moment when their peripheral but crucial role would become clear to the main characters at the event, the vaunted parent-teacher night.

headline: Acorn on Brink of Bankruptcy, Officials Say
text: BALTIMORE — The community organizing group Acorn, battered politically from the right and suffering from mismanagement along with a severe loss of government and other funds, is on the verge of filing for bankruptcy, officials of the group said Friday.

headline: Manhattan Judge’s Trial Raises Thorny Election Law Issues Concerning Gifts
text: The jury in the trial of Nora S. Anderson, a Manhattan Surrogate’s Court judge, may have to consider a question on which even election law experts disagree: Are candidates allowed to use monetary gifts or loans from friends toward their campaigns?

headline: Player Draws Double Takes and Triple Teams
text: College basketball observers sound like naturalists who have spotted something startling in the evolutionary soup when they talk about Baylor’s Brittney Griner. After watching her for the first time, Michael Cooper telephoned his former Lakers teammate Magic Johnson to say he had seen the female version of Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, a Laker whose scoring prowess at U.C.L.A. contributed to the N.C.A.A.’s banning the dunk for nine seasons.

headline: Corrections
text: An article last Saturday about an Interior Department report on environmental threats to the nation’s migratory birds referred incorrectly to the reasons for the problem. The study did not cite hunting as a factor. For the first time, the department added climate change to other factors, including destruction of habitat, pesticides, invasive species and loss of wetlands. (Interior Secretary Ken Salazar, who commented on the report, noted that commercial hunting had historically been a threat.)

headline: How to Say Theater in Yiddish? Two Ways
text: Yiddish theater may have faded since its heyday on the Lower East Side, but it still has enough pep to produce a pesky upstart repertory company, as well as a spirited rivalry between it and a veteran troupe.

headline: Nuns Back Bill Amid Broad Rift Over Whether It Limits Abortion Enough
text: WASHINGTON — In breaking publicly with Roman Catholic bishops over the health care bill, a group of nuns has once again exposed the long-running rift between liberal and conservative theology in the Catholic Church.

headline: In Fight for Influence, Special Council Election in Brooklyn Is Filled With Intensity
text: Collectible rabbi trading cards have been used as campaign props, and hundreds of voters attended a debate. An 18-year-old candidate’s jump into politics ended when he was thrown off the ballot after legal challenges from seasoned rivals. There have been allegations of smears and strong-arm tactics to neutralize opposing supporters.

headline: Central Bank in India Raises Interest Rates
text: India’s central bank unexpectedly raised interest rates on Friday for the first time in almost two years and said that with inflation at a 16-month high, the need to control prices was “imperative.”

headline: Corrections
text: An article on March 6 about weak consumer protection rules in Japan referred incompletely to the history of Toyota recalls in that country. While there have been no recalls in Japan related to floor mats, sticky gas pedals or unexpected acceleration, as there have been elsewhere in the world, there have been some recalls related to problems in regenerative braking systems on hybrid vehicles. (In addition to a recall in Japan earlier this year of Prius cars, Toyota has also recalled the Sai hybrid sedan, sold only in Japan; the Lexus HS250h hybrid, sold in Japan and elsewhere; and the plug-in Prius hybrid for similar braking problems. Those recalls affected some 475,000 cars; the recalls outside of Japan affected about eight million cars.)

headline: Altering Tactics, Icahn Seeks All of Lions Gate
text: Carl C. Icahn said on Friday that he was seeking to acquire all of Lions Gate Entertainment, the film company, broadening a tender offer that originally sought to expand his stake to 29.9 percent.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Friday about Cornell basketball’s one-man radio broadcasting operation misstated the name of the arena in Florida where the team played its first-round N.C.A.A. tournament game. It is Jacksonville Veterans Memorial Arena, not Veterans Memorial Coliseum.

headline: Renewed Support for an Everglades Land Deal, but Cost Is Still in Question
text: MIAMI — Gov. Charlie Crist reaffirmed his commitment this week to the $536 million purchase of 73,000 acres of land from United States Sugar, declaring that it would heal both the Everglades and the coastal estuaries that are vital to Florida’s tourist economy.

headline: Corrections
text: An article last Saturday about people who acted as guides as part of the work “This Progress” by Tino Seghal at the Guggenheim Museum misstated the surname of one and misspelled the given name of another. A sixth-grader at the School at Columbia University who took part is Solomon Dworkin, not Bender. A junior at Hunter College High School who also served as a guide is Bram Wasti, not Bran.

headline: Rio Tinto and Chinalco in Deal for Iron Project
text: HONG KONG — Nine months after they scrapped a $19.5 billion alliance, the Anglo-Australian mining giant Rio Tinto and Chinalco of China reached a deal Friday to jointly develop an iron ore project in the West African country of Guinea.

headline: Watching the Shadows
text: Dean DeBlois and Chris Sanders, the co-directors of "How to Train Your Dragon," discuss the lighting design of the film.

headline: Amendments and Impasse May Stall Financial Bill
text: The Senate Banking Committee might face some late nights in the coming week. The committee, which is set to begin consideration of a bill that would overhaul financial regulations, received 359 amendments by the Friday deadline, The New York Times’s Sewell Chan reports from Washington.

headline: Corrections
text: The Editor’s Letter on Page 10 this weekend about the new On Language columnist, Ben Zimmer, omits part of the name of an organization to which he belongs. It is the Dictionary Society of North America, not the Dictionary Society of America.

headline: Corrections
