headline: Without Its Star, Michigan State Beats Maryland at the Buzzer
text: SPOKANE, Wash. — Michigan State’s chances for another springtime march deep into the N.C.A.A. tournament were as broad as the smile on Tom Izzo’s face midway through the second half of Sunday’s game against Maryland.

headline: Cornell Is No Longer a Stretch
text: JACKSONVILLE, Fla. — There was respect for Cornell, sure, but there was never the awe that surrounds elite teams. The Big Red challenged No. 1 Kansas in January and lost by just 5 points, yet it was an Ivy League team, a squad of nonscholarship players, so it was not always clear how much should be invested in it.

headline: One Board, Two Big Swings
text: The final of the Vanderbilt Knockout Teams on Sunday in Reno, Nev., pitted Europe against the United States.

headline: Becoming Comfortable With Emotional Depth
text: It may be foolish for a concertgoer to try to decipher the character of a performer from behavior onstage. But to judge from his concert at Madison Square Garden on Saturday evening, I would guess that the Canadian pop singer Michael Bublé, whose star continues to rise, is still a reasonably humble nice guy.

headline: West Virginia Bangs Its Way Into Round of 16
text: BUFFALO — When West Virginia goes to its man-to-man defense, the Mountaineers play an earnest brand that the CBS broadcaster Bill Raftery relishes announcing. There is a gritty makeup to the way star swingman Da’Sean Butler bumps his man off screens, Devin Ebanks extends his wingspan across the lane, and Joe Mazzulla muscles through oncoming screens.

headline: Evan Turner Leads Buckeyes Into Round of 16
text: MILWAUKEE — Things are breaking Ohio State’s way in the N.C.A.A. tournament, and Evan Turner could be ready to take command of a brighter spotlight on a less-congested stage.

headline: Spilling Beyond a Festival’s Main Courses
text: AUSTIN, Tex.  They came to play: in clubs, churches, parking garages, conference rooms, clothing stores, backyards and streets, from early in the morning to early the next morning. If anything could dispel the notion that musicians are slackers, it’s the South by Southwest Music and Media Conference, four days of nearly nonstop music by performers known and unknown, many of them playing two or three times a day in hopes of ... well, another gig.

headline: 26 Across: Money on a Poker Table
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — We’re privileged to have Patrick Creadon, director of the crossword documentary Wordplay, join us today as a guest solver. Normally, his notes would appear at the end of the post, but I’m not going to keep you waiting. He’s up first, followed by a brief post from me.

headline: A New Light on Woolf
text: An archive of letters from the collections of the novelist Rosamond Lehmann and the diarist and writer Frances Partridge has been opened to the public for the first time at the archive center at King’s College in Cambridge, England, and may shed light on the suicide of Virginia Woolf, The Guardian reported. In a letter written to Partridge on April 3, 1941, shortly after Woolf’s disappearance, Clive Bell, the husband of Woolf’s sister, Vanessa, wrote: “I’m afraid there is not the slightest doubt that she drowned herself about noon last Friday. She had left letters for Leonard and Vanessa,” referring to Woolf’s husband, Leonard Woolf. He added: “For some days, of course, we hoped against hope that she had wandered crazily away and might be discovered in a barn or a village shop. But by now all hope is abandoned.” The collection includes thousands of pages of letters, including some from Woolf, and 30 albums of photographs featuring members of the group of intellectuals at Cambridge that included Lehmann, Partridge, E. M. Forster, and others, and has been acquired by King’s College.

headline: ‘Alice’ Leads the Way in Week 3
text: Alice is living in box-office wonderland for the third week in a row. Despite the sunny weather, audiences turned out again for “Alice in Wonderland” (Walt Disney), Tim Burton’s eccentric 3-D tale starring Mia Wasikowska, right, as Alice, putting it at No. 1 with $35 million in domestic ticket sales over the weekend and a cumulative total of $266 million, according to Team Screenline, a box-office data service. Far behind but still popular was Fox’s “Diary of a Wimpy Kid,” an adaptation of Jeff Kinney’s books about an awkward sixth grader, which brought in $22.5 million in its first week. It was followed closely by “Bounty Hunter,” the Jennifer Aniston-Gerard Butler comedy from Sony, with $21 million in its debut weekend. Eking out only $6.25 million in its second week, Paramount’s “She’s Out of My League” dropped to fourth place, with a cumulative total of $20.25 million. And Universal’s “Repo Men” was a flop, making only $6 million in its first weekend.

headline: ‘Atonement,’ the Opera
text: It started life as a best-selling novel and then became an Oscar-winning film. Now “Atonement,” Ian McEwan’s epic story of love and betrayal during World War II, is being rewritten as an opera, but not by Mr. McEwan, according to BBC News. The composer Michael Berkeley, who will provide the music, said at the Southbank Center in London on Thursday that the poet Craig Raine would write the libretto while Mr. McEwan would have “creative input.” “We’re going to have several meetings with him so he can feed into what we’re doing,” Mr. Berkeley told the BBC. Mr. Berkeley would not identify the German opera house that he said had approached him with the idea last summer, but he added that the same company would most likely hold the premiere of the work, to be sung in English, in 2013.

headline: Mark Morris’s ‘Dido and Aeneas’ in Moscow
text: The Mark Morris Dance Group, above, will make its Russian debut when it travels to Moscow this week with its production of Purcell’s “Dido and Aeneas” as part of the Golden Mask theater festival there. Mr. Morris will conduct the MMDG Music Ensemble, joined by the Trinity Choir of New York, led by Robert Mealy, in performances on Wednesday and Thursday at the Kolobov Novaya Opera Theater. Though costs had kept the company from accepting previous invitations in Russia, a recent grant from the Trust for Mutual Understanding, an organization that helps American nonprofit organizations with travel to Russia and Central and Eastern Europe, made the trip possible.

headline: Mapplethorpe Photos to Stay in Florence
text: A ceremony in Florence on Monday will herald the donation of photographs by Robert Mapplethorpe, above, to two Italian state museums. The Robert Mapplethorpe Foundation contributed the photographs “Von Hackendahl” (1985) and “Derrick Cross” (1985) to the Accademia after they were featured in a recent exhibition that displayed works by Mapplethorpe in the company of sculptures and drawings by Michelangelo. The foundation donated a third photograph, a self-portrait from 1980 of Mapplethorpe wearing lipstick and a boa, to the Uffizi Gallery.

headline: Lady Gaga Hits Back
text: A lawyer for Lady Gaga has responded to a suit filed by her former boyfriend and collaborator, Rob Fusari, who accused her of not giving him his full share of royalties and other fees. On Friday Charles Ortner, a lawyer for the singer, whose real name is Stefani Germanotta, made public papers he filed in court saying that her agreement with Mr. Fusari was “unlawful,” and that the contract was “structured in such a way as to mask its true purpose  to provide to the defendants unlawful compensation for their services as unlicensed employment agents,” The Associated Press reported. In an e-mail message to The A.P. last week, Robert S. Meloni, a lawyer for Mr. Fusari, said, “Rob was no more of an ‘agent’ for her than she is a Roman Catholic nun.” Mr. Fusari, who helped write Lady Gaga songs including “Paparazzi” and “Beautiful, Dirty, Rich,” is asking for $30.5 million in compensation.

headline: Footnotes
text: Pinchas Zukerman, music director of the National Arts Center Orchestra in Ottawa for 11 years, said he signed up for four more. Mr. Zukerman’s contract with the orchestra will now run through August 2015. He continues to perform as a violinist and violist. ... Sarah McLachlan announced that she was making her first album in seven years, Billboard.com reported. Arista Records will release the album, “The Laws of Illusion,” on June 15. Ms. McLachlan is recording the album in Montreal and Vancouver with her collaborator and producer, Pierre Marchand. ... Jennifer Lopez is in talks with Will Smith’s Overbrook Entertainment to star in a remake of “Overboard” next year. According to the Hollywood Reporter, Overbrook and Columbia Pictures will produce the updated version of the 1987 romantic comedy, which starred Kurt Russell as a grubby carpenter who cons a rich amnesiac, Goldie Hawn, into thinking she is his wife. ... Though soap operas may soon become the dinosaurs of daytime drama, at least one is still roaming network television. According to the Hollywood Reporter, “Days of Our Lives” on NBC has been renewed for another year, meaning the show will have a 45th season.

headline: Chinese Art and Life
text: The director of the China Institute’s small gallery uses her life experiences to put on important shows.

headline: Mexican Traffickers Sow Chaos With Blockades
text: MEXICO CITY — Traffic jams are nothing new in Mexico’s largest cities, but drug traffickers intent on frustrating the authorities have added them as a new weapon to their arsenal, blocking city streets and creating long lines of frustrated motorists, law enforcement officials said.

headline: An American Presence at the Olivier Awards
text: Several shows set in, born in or coming to America received Olivier Awards, among the highest honors in the London theater, when they were announced Sunday night.

headline: Bombs Kill 13 Afghans; Elderly Man Dies in Raid
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Bombings killed at least 13 civilians who had gathered to celebrate spring picnics in southern and eastern Afghanistan on Sunday, provincial authorities reported, and a joint NATO-Afghan force shot an elderly man in a house raid on a rural village in Wardak Province.

headline: Bottle of Friendship, Dollop of Revenge
text: When Paul Newman of Westport, Conn., had the idea of marketing his own brand of salad dressing, he recruited Martha Stewart, also of Westport, to conduct a taste-off and make sure people liked the stuff. At the time these two Westport eminences had little else in common. Now they share the dubious distinction of being the subjects of “and Me” books, each written by a self-proclaimed dear friend and Westport neighbor.

headline: Wilpon (Not Mets) Leaves Seinfield Laughing
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — As the Mets owner Fred Wilpon watched his team defeat his alma mater, the University of Michigan, 8-1, on Sunday, he  sat with Jerry Seinfeld for a few innings and at one point had the comedian laughing hard. It is assumed they were not discussing last season.

headline: Top Recruit Will Sign With U.S.C. on Tuesday
text: After not signing a letter of intent with Southern California last week as originally planned, Seantrel Henderson, an offensive lineman considered by most analysts to be the nation’s top high school football recruit, will sign with the Trojans on Tuesday.

headline: Iraq’s Premier Endorses a Recount of the Vote
text: BAGHDAD — Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki endorsed the mounting calls for a recount of Iraq’s parliamentary election, as the latest results on Sunday showed his main competitor with a slight lead.

headline: Music in Review
text: ‘MADAMA BUTTERFLY’ New York City Opera

headline: Army Chief Driving Pakistan’s Agenda for Talks
text: KARACHI, Pakistan — In a sign of the mounting power of the army over the civilian government in Pakistan, the head of the military, Gen. Ashfaq Parvez Kayani, will be the dominant Pakistani participant in important meetings in Washington this week.

headline: Sarkozy Meets With Leaders of His Party After Defeat in Regional Elections
text: PARIS — President Nicolas Sarkozy met with party leaders on Sunday night to discuss how to respond to a severe defeat in regional elections, in which his majority party was defeated in 21 of 22 mainland regions, retaining a majority only in Alsace.

headline: N.C.A.A. Photo Replay: March 21
text: A view of the day in tournament play, with lots of bumping and big shots.

headline: The Report on Upton: Still Fast, Still Young
text: TAMPA, Fla. — Justin Upton shivered with the rest of the soaking fans at Citizens Bank Park in Philadelphia on Oct. 27, 2008. His brother, B. J., was leading off first base for the Tampa Bay Rays in Game 5 of the World Series against the Phillies. As a rainstorm engulfed the field, Justin guessed that his brother’s spikes had to be sinking into the quicksand.

headline: Digitally, Location Is Where It’s At
text: AUSTIN, Tex.

headline: Jerry Adler, Harmonica Virtuoso, Dies at 91
text: Jerry Adler, a harmonica virtuoso whose pure, open sound can be heard on the soundtracks to “Shane,” “High Noon,” “Mary Poppins” and other films, but who labored in the shadow of his more famous harmonica-playing older brother, Larry, died on March 13 in Ellenton, Fla. He was 91 and lived in Sarasota.

headline: As ‘Worldfocus’ Ends, a Call to Save It
text: The announcement by WNET.org, the New York public broadcaster, that its “Worldfocus” program is ending its run after 18 months has prompted a campaign to save the program, a weekday newscast covering international issues.

headline: Tent City at a Golf Club Dramatizes Haiti’s Limbo
text: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti — When Mimrose Marson fled her devastated neighborhood for the Pétionville Club, she never dreamed that her family would sink roots on its nine-hole golf course. The club had a history of land disputes with its neighbors, and the sign on its gate said “Members Only” in English.

headline: Pope’s Letter Does Little to Assuage Anger
text: DUBLIN — Pope Benedict XVI’s weekend apology to sufferers of sexual abuse at the hands of the Roman Catholic Church in Ireland met with a deeply skeptical and often angry response from many Catholics here on Sunday, with one prominent victim calling it ineffectual and demanding that the pope forcibly remove the head of the Irish church if he does not resign.

headline: Fargo Spared as Red River Rises Less Than Feared
text: FARGO, N.D. — The Red River crested here on Sunday at a level slightly lower than predicted, sparing the metropolitan area from widespread flooding and easing fears that had built up during weeks of anxious anticipation.

headline: Xavier Moves Into Elite Company
text: MILWAUKEE — After Xavier survived a Pittsburgh comeback for a 71-68 victory Sunday, Jordan Crawford, the Musketeers’ star guard, mentioned that his Musketeers were in rare company.

headline: Duke Shuts Down Cal
text: JACKSONVILLE, Fla. — California trailed Duke by 7 points when Golden Bears guard Jerome Randle got the ball with space to work, a rare occurrence for him against the Blue Devils on Sunday. It was an irresistible open look at the basket, and Randle, a noted bomber, let fly a 27-foot shot off one leg.

headline: Take $787 Billion. Now Show Where It’s Going.
text: THE Metro-North Railroad in the early ’80s published a pocket schedule of the arrival and departure times between New Haven and New York. In his book “Envisioning Information,” the information-design theorist Edward Tufte devotes an uncluttered half-page to a hard look at that little piece of paper.

headline: Woods Conducts First Interviews Since Accident
text: Tiger Woods answered questions from reporters for the first time in four months Sunday in two separate five-minute interviews shown simultaneously on ESPN and the Golf Channel.

headline: I.M.F. Gives Debt Warning for the Wealthiest Nations
text: BEIJING — The global economic crisis has left “deep scars” in the fiscal balances of the world’s advanced economies, which should begin to rein in spending next year as the recovery continues, the No. 2 official at the International Monetary Fund said on Sunday in Beijing.

headline: Kramer Picks Up the Slack for Purdue
text: SPOKANE, Wash. — Purdue guard Chris Kramer had tried a similar move to the basket just a few minutes earlier. The Texas A&M defense converged and denied him, and Kramer was left on the floor missing one of his shoes.

headline: A Synagogue’s Unveiling Exposes a Conundrum
text: CAIRO — Down a winding alley, deep in a quiet neighborhood of rutted roads and donkey carts, where food vendors sold cheap sandwiches and children chased after a soccer ball, an extraordinary moment passed here with little notice: Jews and Muslims, Israelis and Egyptians sat together and celebrated their shared heritage.

headline: Business of Game Quells Thrill
text: Buffalo

headline: Netanyahu and Obama Will Talk on Tuesday
text: JERUSALEM — During a visit here on Sunday, the Obama administration’s Middle East envoy, George J. Mitchell, extended an invitation for the prime minister of Israel, Benjamin Netanyahu, to speak with President Obama in Washington this week.

headline: Ryan’s Losing Weight, Not His Sense of Humor
text: ORLANDO, Fla. — Jets Coach Rex Ryan arrived at the N.F.L. meetings here Sunday and quickly dispelled the notion that after his lap band surgery, he would no longer be the big, funny guy in the room.

headline: Trying to Do His Part, McGrady Falls Short
text: Tracy McGrady had followed the public-relations playbook to the letter, dismissing questions about emotion and motivation or anything resembling vengeance. The facade cracked late Sunday afternoon.

headline: Twins Give Mauer 8-Year Extension for $184 Million
text: JUPITER, Fla. — The Minnesota Twins are spending $195 million toward the construction of Target Field, an open-air ballpark that will open in Minneapolis next month. They spent nearly as much to retain their best player Sunday.

headline: Mixing In Some Carbon
text: MOSS LANDING, Calif. — It seems like alchemy: a Silicon Valley start-up says it has found a way to capture the carbon dioxide emissions from coal and gas power plants and lock them into cement.

headline: Rain Throws Curveball at Yankees’ Schedule
text: TAMPA, Fla. — Minutes after the Yankees canceled their exhibition game with the Detroit Tigers on Sunday because of heavy rain and a gloomy forecast, the pitching coach Dave Eiland moved through the clubhouse checking in with several pitchers. He spoke with A. J. Burnett, the scheduled starter, as well as Andy Pettitte, who was scheduled for a minor league game Monday. Then he found Joba Chamberlain and Mariano Rivera.

headline: Because Linda Has Nothing to Do With It
text: At Linda’s Place, chances are that one of several sassy and tattooed bartenders will be pouring the beer. John Courtney, a plumber, will likely be sitting at the end of the bar next to his son, John Courtney, also a plumber.

headline: Health Care Reform, at Last
text: The process was wrenching, and tainted to the 11th hour by narrow political obstructionism, but the year-long struggle over health care reform came to an end on Sunday night with a triumph for countless Americans who have been victimized or neglected by their dysfunctional health care system. Barack Obama put his presidency on the line for an accomplishment of historic proportions.

headline: In Health Care Overhaul, Boons for Hospitals and Drug Makers
text: With a sweeping overhaul of the nation’s health care system, Congress would be giving the health care industry as many as 32 million additional paying customers in the next few years.

headline: Corrections
text: Because of an editing error, an article in some editions on Wednesday about an odd dividing line between neighbors on Taylor Road in Greenburgh, N.Y.  those who lost power in last weekend’s storm and those who did not  misstated, in some copies, the surname of a man who did not lose power. He is George Thomas, not Taylor.

headline: Facing a Financial Pinch, and Moving In With Mom and Dad
text: Heather Candella is 26. She was finally getting ready to move out of her parents’ home in Rockland County last year when she was laid off from her digital media job in Manhattan. Saddled with student loans, she took a clerical job, and for the time being, resigned herself to remaining in the nest.

headline: At Rally, Call for Urgency on Immigration Reform
text: WASHINGTON — Tens of thousands of immigrants and activists rallied here on Sunday, calling for legislation this year to give legal status to millions of illegal immigrants and seeking to pressure President Obama to keep working on the contentious issue once the health care debate is behind him.

headline: I Am Become Death, Destroyer of Worlds
text: Or so says someone or other in The Telegraph. Paul Krugman, the Nobel prize-winner who threatens the world.

headline: Corrections
text: A report in the Goal soccer roundup on Tuesday about the effect of concussions on the playing career of Alecko Eskandarian included an incorrect figure provided by Major League Soccer for the average number of concussions sustained by its players each year. Since 2004, there have been an average of 24 concussions a year, the league said after the article was published, not “fewer than 10.”

headline: Back in the N.F.L., Confident of Success
text: RENTON, Wash. — The whirlwind known as Pete Carroll spun into his new office at Seattle Seahawks headquarters, firing off greetings: what’s up, what’s happening, what’s next, let’s do this. He gestured out the window at Lake Washington. He cranked the Foo Fighters on his stereo.

headline: River Ritual in Baghdad
text: BAGHDAD — Hundreds of Sabean Mandaeans, who revere John the Baptist as a great prophet and teacher, celebrated the final day of their annual Festival of Creation on the banks of the River Tigris in Baghdad on Sunday. The five day feast is an important holiday for the small sect which – like Christians and other Iraqi minorities – has suffered violence and persecution in recent years. They bathe to purify themselves.

headline: Power to the People, Even During a Storm
text: For virtually everyone in New York and its suburbs, the power is back on.

headline: For Drug Users, Coalition Serves as Voice in Albany
text: In a borrowed room in Chelsea on a recent Monday night, 13 people sat under fluorescent lights discussing the time-honored art of lobbying and the cold calculus of political persuasion.

headline: Man Accused of Murder in Bronx Toddler’s Death
text: A 23-year-old Bronx man was arrested on Sunday and charged with murdering his companion’s 22-month-old daughter, the police said. The city medical examiner’s office said she had been beaten to death.

headline: 9/11 Scholarships Are a Family Memorial
text: Michael Francis Lynch grew up as a son of the Bronx. He was raised in Throgs Neck, five blocks from the Long Island Sound, as the seventh of 10 children, and attended Cardinal Spellman High School, just off Boston Road.

headline: Stanford Medical School to Expand Ethics Rules
text: The Stanford University School of Medicine plans on Monday to introduce rules that would prohibit its volunteer teaching staff — called adjunct faculty — from giving paid speeches drafted by the makers of drugs or medical devices.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: March 21, 2010

headline: At CUNY Law School, Questions on Costly Move
text: The City University of New York School of Law trains students to be public interest lawyers — the kind who battle bureaucracies and fight injustice.

headline: Big Win for Obama, but at What Cost?
text: WASHINGTON — The House’s passage of health care legislation late Sunday night assures that whatever the ultimate cost, President Obama will go down in history as one of the handful of presidents who found a way to reshape the nation’s social welfare system.

headline: Corrections
text: The Critics’ Choice column last Monday about new CDs, including “San Patricio” by the Chieftains with Ry Cooder, misspelled the surname of the Chieftains’ leader. He is Paddy Moloney, not Maloney.

headline: The Fascist Octopus Has Sung Its Swan Song
text: And, according to Rep. Devin Nunes, Democrats

headline: Corrections
text: An article in the special Museums section on Thursday about a photography program for teenagers omitted part of the name of the museum that offers the program. It is the Studio Museum in Harlem, not Studio Museum Harlem.

headline: A Shelter for Families in Need of a Push
text: Denise Benson runs a no-nonsense, no-frills homeless shelter for the city in Queens. There is no common room for lounging and watching television. Most homeless families meet with their caseworkers several times a week. Staff members escort residents to job interviews and to tour available apartments.

headline: Corrections
text: NEW YORK

headline: For Consumers, Clarity on Health Care Changes
text: American consumers, who spent a year watching Congress scratch and claw over sweeping health care legislation, can now try to figure out what the overhaul would mean for them.

headline: Corrections
text: A report in the “Looking Ahead” column on Friday about the day’s schedule of N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament games misstated the won-lost record of Temple Coach Fran Dunphy in the tournament while he was the coach at the University of Pennsylvania. He was 1-9, not 0-10.

headline: Ivanchuk Holds Lead at Amber
text: Vassily Ivanchuk is one point ahead of Magnus Carlsen, his closest pursuer, with three rounds to go.

headline: Nonprofit Groups Foresee Tough Year
text: A new survey of nonprofit groups suggests that this year will be as challenging for them as 2009, when many organizations suffered from declines in giving, delays in government payments and increased demand for their services.

headline: Despite Much Rezoning, Scant Change in Residential Capacity
text: Five years ago, community groups in South Park Slope, Brooklyn, demanded protection from the new apartment buildings that seemed to be sprouting everywhere, pushing above the neighborhood’s low-rise canopy.

headline: The Relief Visitor: A Vendor Puts His Trust in a Friendly Stranger
text: The friendship started in the way so many do in a fast-moving city of many strangers, with hellos offered in passing.

headline: Legal and Political Fights Loom for Democrats
text: WASHINGTON — The battle over health care is poised to move swiftly from Congress back to the country as Democrats, Republicans and a battery of interest groups race to define the legislation and dig in for long-term political and legal fights.

headline: Cities Vie for Google's Attention With Humor
text: Some cities are using humor to try to convince Google to include them in its plans to build ultra-high speed broadband networks.

headline: Mets Pitcher Wants More Than Just a Peek
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Nelson Figueroa walked up to the clubhouse door of Estadio Nueva Esparta last month and knocked on the door. A small flap opened at eye level, and a security guard asked Figueroa, a star pitcher for the Dominican Winter League champion Leones Del Escogido, for identification.

headline: Metropolitan Diary
text: DEAR DIARY:

headline: Corrections
text: A listing in the Transactions column on the Square Feet pages on March 10 about a recent sale at 111 and 113 East 12th Street in Manhattan misidentified a nearby cross street. It is Fourth Avenue, not Lafayette Street.

headline: Another Long March in the Name of Change
text: WASHINGTON — Forty-five years ago, John Lewis began the third of what became society-shifting civil rights marches from Selma to Montgomery, Ala. On Sunday, the anniversary of that famous trek, he joined hands with fellow House Democrats and marched past jeering protesters into the Capitol to remake the nation’s health care system.

headline: Education First, Beating UConn a Close Second
text: PALO ALTO, Calif. — The multitasking Peter Ogwumike sat behind the scorer’s table at Maples Pavilion on Saturday night, dividing his attention between the present and the future of Stanford women’s basketball.

headline: Hoping for Gift From Google? Go Jump in the Lake
text: The mayor of Duluth, Minn., threw himself into the ice-ringed waters of Lake Superior. The mayor of Sarasota, Fla., immersed himself in a tank filled with bonnethead sharks, simply to one-up him. The mayor of Wilmington, N.C., said that he would even jump out of an airplane — with a parachute, of course.

headline: Yankees Meet With Union on Drug Testing
text: TAMPA, Fla. — Michael Weiner, the new executive director of the players union, stopped by Steinbrenner Field on Sunday to meet with the Yankees as part of his annual tour of clubs in spring training.

headline: Student Loan Bill Poised to Pass in Health Vote
text: WASHINGTON — Along with the major health care legislation, the House on Sunday approved a major revamping of federal student loan programs that eliminates fees paid to private banks to act as intermediaries.

headline: Must-See TV
text: Oh, wow. I was watching John Boehner doing his Glenn Beck imitation, demanding a one-by-one vote to delay reform by an hour or two, and considering bailing out — but then … a standing ovation as Nancy Pelosi walks in.

headline: Still Celebrating Sondheim
text: Sondheim fans who missed the all-star birthday tribute to the composer at Avery Fisher Hall last week can breathe a sigh of relief. There are still plenty of opportunities to celebrate the dean of musical theater's big 8-0, starting with an event today. Five years ago, Symphony Space held a 12-hour marathon of Sondheim's work. The composer himself attended the session along with a lineup of Broadway's best, including Neil Patrick Harris, Elaine Stritch, Patti LuPone, Donna Murphy, Angela Lansbury and many more. Today, Symphony Space Live (symphonyspacelive.org) will feature the program from start to finish with "Wall to Wall Sondheim," with music from "Sweeney Todd," "Sunday in the Park with George," "Into the Woods" and more. Prove your devotion and listen to the whole thing.

headline: Strategic Eating
text: From Agnanti Restaurant in Astoria to Zuzu Ramen in Brooklyn, Choice Eats covers the food scene in New York from A to Z, literally. Foodies will be gathering tonight at the 69th Regiment Armory, Lexington Avenue at 26th Street, for the Village Voice's third annual festival. The tasting event features bites from more than 50 restaurants and delicacies from more than 35 countries, including Cambodia, Vietnam, Italy, Brazil, Tunisia and Russia. Plan strategically and head straight to the eateries that will likely draw the longest lines, like Motorino, Del Posto and Fatty Crab.

headline: Fashionable Listening
text: Fresh from her performance at the South by Southwest Music Festival in Austin, Tex., Karen Elson will appear tonight at Le Poisson Rouge in her first solo show in New York. Ms. Elson, a former model, is known for attracting a seriously hip crowd when she sings with the Citizen Band, and tonight is sure to be no different. Go to check out the fabulous folks and their clothes and stay to listen. Ms. Elson will be performing songs from a forthcoming album, "The Ghost Who Walks," produced by her husband, Jack White.

headline: The Continuing Battle Over Health Care
text: For Congressional lawmakers, the ramifications of the vote to overhaul health care could be as big or even bigger than the vote on the Iraq war.
And the Senate version of health care reform has passed. I assume President Obama will sign it tonight.

headline: A Historic Moment for Health Care?
text: For many, the health care overhaul, which was approved by the House, 219 to 212, and will be signed into law by President Obama, is far from perfect. For some, it’s a disgrace. But for others, it’s a bold effort that expands health care to more Americans than ever in the nation’s history. Whatever the assessments, today’s vote in the House represented change.

headline: In the Rapper Drake, Kentucky Has a Natural Fan
text: NEW ORLEANS — After Kentucky’s 90-60 victory over Wake Forest on Saturday night sent the Wildcats to the N.C.A.A. tournament’s Round of 16, the Grammy-nominated rapper Drake raised two of his fingers in celebration from his second-row seat behind the Wildcats bench.

headline: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Coyotes Win Another Shootout and Tie for 1st
text: Nine games on Sunday, and there were two big, big winners: the Atlanta Thrashers, who won their fourth straight game and have a chance of making the playoffs in the East, and the Phoenix Coyotes, who continued their incredible run to the top despite being wards of the league. They now lead the Pacific Division and are tied for first in the entire Western Conference with the Blackhawks, whom they visit on Tuesday in what has become the N.H.L.’s biggest game of the season.

headline: Big Talent, Big Appetite
text: JUPITER, Fla. – The best-known Mike Stanton in baseball is the one who pitched in more than 1,000 games and helped the Yankees win four World Series. That might be about to change.

headline: The U-2 Spy Plane, From the Cold War to Afghanistan
text: The U-2 spy plane, the aircraft that was often at the heart of cold war suspense, has become a sought-after intelligence gatherer in a very different war in Afghanistan.

headline: Keds Campaign Claims a First, Then Revises
text: WHEN marketing retro sneakers, marketers face a challenge: how do you sell them to consumers too young to be nostalgic for bygone eras?

headline: U-2 Spy Plane Evades the Day of Retirement
text: The U-2 spy plane, the high-flying aircraft that was often at the heart of cold war suspense, is enjoying an encore.

headline: Midmajors Show They Deserve Better Deal
text: George Mason Coach Jim Larranaga, the godfather of the midmajor coaches, has a dream Final Four. He wants Butler, St. Mary’s, Northern Iowa and Cornell to advance to Indianapolis, which would take the feel-good vibes of the first four days of this N.C.A.A. tournament and extrapolate them to unprecedented levels.

headline: States Look Beyond Borders to Collect Owed Taxes
text: When Josh Beckett pitches for the Red Sox at Yankee Stadium, New York collects income tax on the portion of his salary that he earned in New York State.

headline: The TV Doctor With Tweets in Real Time
text: Shows on every major network have tapped Twitter for plotlines and punch lines. This month even Homer Simpson got in on the act, punishing Bart by telling him to tweet his every action “even though I don’t know what Twitter is, and have no desire to find out.”

headline: Show Time for Health Care
text: “We have to pass the bill so that you can find out what is in it.” For Nancy Pelosi, expounding on the virtues of health reform two weeks before Sunday night’s decisive vote, it probably wasn’t the ideal choice of words. But I can almost sympathize with the sentiment.

headline: The House Makes History With Health Care
text: For 100 years America has been talking about a national health care system. It almost happened under FDR, and then under Truman, and then Kennedy and Johnson talked about it before Johnson decided on Medicare instead. Nixon tried, and of course Clinton. And finally, after a century, the House passage of the Senate health reform bill just now, 219 to 212, means that we’re on the eve of quasi-universal health care for the first time.

headline: Fear Strikes Out
text: The day before Sunday’s health care vote, President Obama gave an unscripted talk to House Democrats. Near the end, he spoke about why his party should pass reform: “Every once in a while a moment comes where you have a chance to vindicate all those best hopes that you had about yourself, about this country, where you have a chance to make good on those promises that you made ... And this is the time to make true on that promise. We are not bound to win, but we are bound to be true. We are not bound to succeed, but we are bound to let whatever light we have shine.”

headline: Ex-Offenders and the Vote
text: Millions of ex-offenders who have been released from prison are denied the right to vote. That undercuts efforts to reintegrate former prisoners into mainstream society. And it goes against one of democracy’s most fundamental principles: that governments should rule with the consent of the governed.

headline: To Reduce Partisanship, Get Rid of Partisans
text: Portland, Ore.

headline: Stifling the Economy, One Argument at a Time
text: FRUSTRATED with years of delay and stonewalling, 130 members of Congress last week urged the Obama administration to punish China for manipulating the value of its currency to the detriment of American exports. But this issue does not stand alone; it is part of the larger, murkier world of international trade policy, centered on the Doha round of World Trade Organization negotiations. These talks, which began in 2001, long ago became a quagmire. It’s time to admit the global economy has passed them by and pull the plug on them.

text: AT the beginning of March, New York Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg traveled to Staten Island to fill his administration’s two millionth pothole. It was a milestone for him, but it was also a reminder that a new season is upon us: spring is pothole-filling time.

headline: Fess Parker
text: I don’t remember a single episode of “Davy Crockett,” nor did I own a coonskin cap. As for the famous theme song, it tends to wander away on its own, erratically, once it gets rolling in my head. But I remember Fess Parker. Any account of masculinity, for a certain generation, is incomplete without Mr. Parker, who died last week at age 85. In my memory, he embodies an inexplicable authenticity. This was not just the naïveté of a child viewer, unaware of how TV shows were made or coonskin caps sold. It was something inherent in Mr. Parker.

headline: Wall Street Journal Aims to Win Over The New York Times’s Local Audience
text: Maybe newspapers really are dying, as some media analysts have been predicting for decades, but apparently that does not apply to newspaper wars. A doozy is shaping up at the moment between The Wall Street Journal and The New York Times.

headline: Rush Is On to Be First in iPad Apps
text: It can be difficult to write software for a gadget without being able to touch it. But that has not stopped developers from rushing to create applications for the Apple iPad.

headline: O’Donnell Reportedly Preparing a TV Show
text: LOS ANGELES — Rosie O’Donnell, a former star of daytime talk, is quietly preparing a return to television with two former Warner Brothers syndication executives.

text: Lots of Democrats can point to lots of different moments when they think the health care bill was brought back from the brink of collapse.

text: MENLO PARK, Calif. — Mobile photographers could soon have much better cameras on their cellphones, thanks to technology known as quantum dots.

headline: Bias Called Persistent Hurdle for Women in Sciences
text: A report on the underrepresentation of women in science and math by the American Association of University Women, to be released Monday, found that although women have made gains, stereotypes and cultural biases still impede their success.

headline: Finding in Foreclosure a Beginning, Not an End
text: BOSTON — Jane Petion lived in her home for 15 years and saw its value rise slowly, rise rapidly and, when the housing bubble burst, plunge at a sickening pace that left her owing $400,000 on a house worth closer to $250,000. Last June, her lender foreclosed on the property. The family received notices of eviction and appeared in housing court.

headline: Sharing Sales Tips in a Smaller Circle
text: It is a marketer’s article of faith that the Internet is the best route to a teenager’s cash. Marketers assume that teenage girls chatter about their favorite brands on Facebook and buy items online.

headline: Reining In Greed at Goldman
text: Goldman Sachs doesn’t normally get too much wrong. But the investment bank made a mistake by setting aside 49 percent of revenue in the first half of 2009 for pay for its employees. Goldman is the leader of the Wall Street pack, and it has an opportunity to set an example in the current quarter.

headline: News Quiz | March 22, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page.

headline: Winchester Capital Funds ‘Leverage’
text: Winchester Capital Management is getting some “Leverage.” The firm, which has invested in such feature films as “The Men Who Stare at Goats” and “The Private Lives of Pippa Lee,” has concluded a $14 million deal to inject the TNT drama with fresh capital, The Hollywood Reporter reported.

headline: In Boston, a Lender Steps in After Foreclosures
text: Jane Petion lived in her home for 15 years and saw its value rise slowly, rise rapidly and, when the housing bubble burst, plunge at a sickening pace that left her owing $400,000 on a house worth closer to $250,000. Last June, her lender foreclosed on the property. The family received notices of eviction and appeared in housing court.

headline: Skype Founders Raise $165 Million for New Fund
text: The founders of Skype will launch a second venture capital fund under their Atomico Ventures which will invest in so-called “disruptive” early-stage European technology. Niklas Zennström and Janus Friis, the founders of the company, have raised $165 million for the new fund, The Financial Times reported.

headline: Arrow Agrees to Sell Assets to PetroChina and Shell
text: Arrow Energy, the Australian gas company, agreed on Monday to accept a sweetened 3.5 billion Australian dollar bid by Shell and PetroChina for its Australian assets, the latest in a string of acquisitions and investments in the global energy sector, Bettina Wassener reports in The New York Times.

headline: Take $787 Billion. Now Show Where It’s Going.
text: The Metro-North Railroad in the early ’80s published a pocket schedule of the arrival and departure times between New Haven and New York. In his book “Envisioning Information,” the information-design theorist Edward Tufte devotes an uncluttered half-page to a hard look at that little piece of paper, Noam Cohen reports in The New York Times.

headline: Blackstone May Sell Majority Stake in Center Parcs
text: Blackstone has started testing the waters for the sale of a 1.4 billion pound ($2.1 billion) stake in its Center Parcs property portfolio. The Financial Times reported that the private equity firm has begun feeling out institutional investors on what could result in a sale of about three-quarters of the business.

headline: Reining In Greed at Goldman
text: Goldman Sachs doesn’t normally get too much wrong, Breakingviews says. But the investment bank made a mistake by setting aside 49 percent of revenue in the first half of 2009 for pay for its employees. Goldman is the leader of the Wall Street pack, and it has an opportunity to set an example in the current quarter.

headline: Asian Genco Fully Financed with $425 Million in New Funds
text: Asian Genco has raised $425 million, placing it in the enviable position of being fully funded for its current slate of projects as well as having enough development money to work on new plans.

headline: A Foreign Service for Wall Street
text: Last week, Lehman Brothers‘ bankruptcy examiner released a report showing that the investment firm went to great lengths to hide its shaky finances. In fact, it even managed to evade a team of investigators from the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Federal Reserve who were embedded at Lehman headquarters with the sole purpose of ferreting out accounting sleight-of-hand.

headline: How Often Do You Have ‘Deep Discussions’?
text: According to a post on the Well blog, people who spend more of their day having deep discussions and less time engaging in small talk seem to be happier. How much of your time do you spend having substantive conversations? With whom are you most likely to have these kinds of conversations, and what do you talk about?

headline: Greenberg to Sell A.I.G. Shares to UBS
text: The former chief executive of American International Group, Maurice Greenberg, reached a deal to sell most of the shares he holds in the insurer to a unit of Swiss bank UBS, Reuters reported.

headline: ‘Promising’ I.P.O.’s Set for Two Tech Firms
text: This week will see I.P.O.s from two venture-backed tech firms, Calix Networks and MaxLinear. MarketWatch reported that one analyst has described the offerings as promising deals in a tough market for new issues.

headline: Citi Said to Hire Ex-Nomura Banker for Asia
text: Citigroup hired Nomura Holdings‘s Colin Banfield as head of mergers and acquisitions for the Asia-Pacific region, two people with knowledge of the matter told Bloomberg News.

headline: Moynihan Said to Plan First Trip to China
text: The Bank of America chief executive Brian Moynihan is making his first trip to China this week as the lender pushes to catch up with rivals in the world’s fastest-growing economy, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing people familiar with the situation.

headline: China Poly Seeks $1.4 Billion in Placement
text: The China Poly Real Estate Group, one of the country’s biggest property developers, planned to raise up to 9.6 billion yuan ($1.4 billion) through a private placement of shares to fund expansion, Reuters reported.

headline: U.S. Institutional Investors Said to Seek Europe Funds
text: Hedge fund investments by institutional investors in the United States are increasingly flowing towards European funds, Pensions & Investments reported. Citing an analysis of 212 institutional investors by Preqin, the Web site said that 17 percent of American institutions have a preference for European hedge funds, devoting an average 20 percent of their portfolios to continental managers.

headline: Calera Getting $15 Million Injection
text: Silicon Valley start-up Calera is looking to turn carbon into gold. The New York Times’s Claire Cain Miller reported that the company, which says it has found a way to capture carbon dioxide emissions from coal and gas power plants and lock them into cement, says that Peabody Energy, the world’s biggest coal company, has invested $15 million.

headline: Zhongsheng Said to Raise $369 Million in I.P.O.
text: Zhongsheng Group Holdings, a Chinese dealership providing services to carmakers, raised $369 million when it priced its Hong Kong initial public offering near the bottom of an indicated range, a source familiar with the deal told Reuters on Monday.

headline: A House Divided Over the Health Bill's Passage
text: Democrats were triumphant after the House passed landmark health legislation, but Republicans and protesters warned that the political battle is far from over.

headline: China Begins Trial of 4 Rio Tinto Employees
text: Three employees of Rio Tinto, the British-Australian mining giant, agreed to plead guilty Monday to taking bribes while working for the company in China, stunning confessions on the opening day of their three-day trial here.

headline: Sports Direct Gets Ultimatum on Blacks Leisure Bid
text: Sports Direct, the U.K. sports chain has been given an April 1 deadline to put in a formal offer for its rival, Blacks Leisure, or abandon its takeover attempt. The Telegraph reported that Britain’s Takeover Panel issued the ultimatum after Blacks said it had rejected a 62 pence per share offer by Sports Direct.

headline: The People’s Court
text: At a Utah tennis camp, a novice comes out swinging.

headline: Pierre Cardin: 60 Years and Counting
text: After six decades in the fashion business, Mr. Cardin looks to the future.

headline: Private Equity Said to Eye Kaufhof-Karstadt Merger
text: Investors are interested in acquiring Metro‘s department store chain Kaufhof and Arcandor‘s Karstadt chain, aiming to merge them, Reuters reported, citing two people familiar with the matter.

headline: Credit Suisse Restricts Bankers’ Travel to Germany
text: Credit Suisse said it is restricting bankers’ travel to Germany after authorities there said they had begun 1,100 tax evasion investigations against the bank’s clients and were investigating staff on suspicion of aiding evasion, Reuters reported.

headline: Little Water, and Less, Along the Jordan
text: In his first assignment for National Geographic, the Magnum photographer Paolo Pellegrin has explored what happens when one of the world’s most critical issues — climate change — is superimposed on one of the world’s most volatile regions.

headline: Britain to Open $3 Billion Green Investment Bank
text: Britain’s Labour government will unveil a £2 billion ($3 billion) “green” investment bank in Wednesday’s budget to help Britain’s transformation to a low-carbon economy, a government source told Reuters on Sunday.

headline: Dubai Firm Said to Resist Oaktree Plan for Almatis
text: The owner of Almatis, the German alumina product maker, is trying to block Oaktree Capital Management from taking over the company, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: UBS May Set Up New Renminbi Fund
text: As it looks to increase its presence in China, UBS could set up a renminbi-focused private equity fund and is holding discussions with Beijing’s municipal government on the matter, The Financial Times reported.

headline: EMI Could Stave Off Takeover With Licensing Deal
text: The British music giant EMI is considering licensing its back catalog in the face of a growing cash crisis. The Times of London reported on Sunday that the company is in talks with rival labels to manage the North American library business for a five-year period. A deal, EMI’s owner Terra Firma believes, could help raise 400 million pounds, the Times of London said.

headline: Citigroup Said to Grow Hedge Consulting Team
text: Citigroup‘s head of global prime finance told Bloomberg News that the bank intends to double the size of a team helping pension and government-backed funds manage direct hedge fund investments. Nick Roe said the growth of the consulting team could come together within the next 18 to 24 months.

headline: Bharti Secures Zain Funds as Talk Deadline Nears
text: Bharti Airtel, the Indian telecoms company, said it had tied up the entire financing requirement of $8.3 billion for its planned purchase of Kuwaiti telecom Zain‘s African assets, in a sign of progress as the deadline for the companies’ talks expire next week, Reuters reported.

headline: The Resentment Zone: Losing Means-Tested Benefits
text: Nancy Folbre is an economics professor at the University of Massachusetts Amherst.

headline: Where to Satisfy a Sweet Tooth in Hong Kong
text: Finding a good, authentic croissant in Hong Kong has gotten a little easier. Bakeries in the city are still mostly dominated by chains, but several unique spots have been shaking up the scene, particularly a handful of places specializing in traditional European treats.

headline: Germany to Impose Levy on Banks
text: The German government plans to introduce a levy on banks to ensure that they pay for the costs of any future crises, The Associated Press reported.

headline: How Different Groups of Democrats Voted
text: A look at some important groups in Sunday’s House vote to pass the health care bill approved by the Senate in December.

headline: The Perks of Being a Goldman Kid
text: Working for Goldman Sachs remains a well-paid family affair.

headline: Fraud Suit Against IAC/InteractiveCorp Is Dismissed
text: A class-action lawsuit accusing Barry Diller’s IAC/InterActiveCorp of securities fraud has been dismissed by a Manhattan federal judge, The New York Post reported.

headline: Pre-Modern Blogging
text: Today’s idea: In a way, blogging isn’t all that new, a historian says. Informal writing combining pithiness with provocation stirred up the politics of Renaissance Italy and prerevolutionary France. And in light of the Web, it deserves more study.

headline: The Menu at SXSW
text: Photos from the South by Southwest festival in Austin, Tex.

headline: Marja Embed: Six Weeks in Helmand Province
text: After spending more than six weeks with the Marines and Afghan National Army in Helmand Province, Tyler Hicks and I left Afghanistan in early March. We plan to return a few times this year. Meanwhile, our colleagues will follow developments there, as Rod Nordland just did. But even as the conversation pitches forward, there are items from the opening of the Marja offensive that merit more attention. The limits of space in the newspaper, as well the shortages of electricity and time while on the ground, meant that material worth sharing at the outset never found an outlet.

headline: Goldman Names Wal-Mart Chairman as Board Candidate
text: Goldman Sachs said on Friday that it had nominated Wal-Mart Chairman H. Lee Scott to join its board, as former McKinsey & Company Managing Director Rajat K. Gupta planned to step down.

headline: Bid to Relax International Ban on the Sale of Ivory Is Rejected
text: PARIS — In a victory claimed by conservationists seeking to shield Africa’s elephants from poachers, the main international agency protecting endangered species resolved on Monday to uphold a 21-year-old ban on the international trade in ivory, rejecting efforts by Tanzania and Zambia to dilute the prohibition.

headline: Cornell Goalie Is on Hot Streak at the Right Time

But an argument could be made that the Big Red had the tournament won when Joe Devin opened the scoring 15 minutes 9 seconds into the game.

headline: Meter Runs Out on Taxi Chief; Tips Not Included

Daus, the departing taxi and limousine commissioner of New York City, looked out at the small hearing room in Lower Manhattan on Thursday and exhaled an ambiguous sigh: “I’m going to miss this place.”

The overhaul will, among other things, expand health care coverage for the poor and low-income and tighten controls on insurance companies will affect people differently depending on where one sits in the system. headline: A New Beginning, or a Last Hurrah?
text: Congratulations are in order for the Democrats this morning, but (as my column suggests, in passing) they’re particularly in order for those liberals who came of political age in the Bush era, and who have argued consistently for a more expansive and aggressive approach to left-of-center politics. For them, the passage of the health care bill is as much a victory over the more cautious elements within the Democratic Party as it is a triumph over the Republicans. Peter Beinart had a good piece on this last week, arguing that by choosing to forge ahead with comprehensive reform even after the Massachusetts Senate election, Obama effectively kicked the party’s moderate/Clintonian/Democratic Leadership Council faction (what Beinart labels the “don’t scare the bear” caucus) to the sidelines, and threw in his lot with the new-model progressives:

headline: For Art Handlers, Their Own March Madness
text: The explosive growth of the art world over the last decade has been fueled by rich new collectors, shiny new galleries and sprawling new museum wings. The gears and the grease that keep this big machine humming are people who can be generally described with less glamorous phrases: underpaid, uninsured, overworked and sweaty (not to mention, often heavily tattooed, bearded, hung over and burdened by loan payments for their M.F.A. degrees).

headline: The Nest Isn’t Emptying
text: Heather Candella, 26, was finally getting ready to move out of her parents’ home in Rockland County last year when she was laid off from her digital media job in Manhattan. Saddled with student loans, she took a clerical job, and for the time being, resigned herself to remaining in the nest.

headline: SXSW: A Memorial for Alex Chilton at the Big Star Show
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — The death on Wednesday of Alex Chilton, the singer and songwriter for the Memphis band Big Star, turned a reunion concert into a memorial. Mr. Chilton, who was 59, had his commercial peak when he was 16, singing “The Letter” with the Box Tops before he founded Big Star. While Big Star is regularly categorized as power pop for its obvious Beatles touches, its music also had Memphis twang and soul. Mr. Chilton’s songs used subtle musical twists that only added to the yearning and stubbornness in his songs: starting in one key but suddenly sliding into another, deliberately making tempos and meters fluctuate. They were the kind of songs other songwriters admire.

headline: Starz Seeks Starry Knights for ‘Camelot’
text: Once, there was a spot, for one brief shining moment that was known as Camelot. And even though that spot was declared, in another context, by a different King Arthur, to be “a silly place,” that kingdom and its knights are now set to make a serious return on television. On Monday, the Starz cable channel said that it was preparing a new series called “Camelot,” based on the version of the Arthurian legend recounted in Thomas Malory’s “Morte d’Arthur.” Starz, which has recently found a hit in its sword-and-sandals adventure series “Spartacus: Blood and Sand,” said “Camelot” will be written by Chris Chibnall, of the supernatural British dramas “Life on Mars” and “Torchwood,” and produced by a team that includes Graham King (“The Departed,” “Gangs of New York”) and Morgan O’Sullivan and Michael Hirst (both of the Showtime period drama “The Tudors”). The 10-episode series is expected to begin production in June with episodes to start showing in 2011. No cast was announced — Starz said in a statement that it was seeking “fresh talent combined with established faces” — and no word if this “Camelot” will feature musical numbers with “footwork impeccable.”

headline: Math Puts a Decision From M.I.T. in Context

headline: Johnson Continues Sprint Cup Dominance
text: Jimmie Johnson cruised to his third Sprint Cup win in five starts. At the Food City 500 in Bristol, Tenn., Johnson was sixth with 10 laps to go. But three laps later, he was in front, where he remained for his first win at Bristol. His previous best finish was third. “When we’re winning at tracks that we’re not supposed to, boys better look out,” said Johnson, who also became the 12th Sprint Cup driver to reach 50 wins. (The Associated Press)

headline: Charm Outweighs the Chaos

It was bad enough that North Carolina, Connecticut and Arizona didn’t make the tournament field, but now Kansas didn’t make it out of the first weekend and all but two of the Big East teams have gone shrieking into the night. text: Marines working to rout Taliban fighters from Marja, Afghanistan, dealt with the uncertainty of war against insurgents.  A mute man at a farmer's home with bomb-making supplies added to the confusion.

headline: When Judges Refuse to Be Rubber Stamps

headline: Your Life: The Shirt-Pocket Movie
text: Think of it as Twitter with pictures. With a miniature wearable camcorder called the uCorder, you can document every mundane aspect of your life, from tying your shoes to going into the subway.

headline: Grandson of Ex-Leader Is Arrested in Tehran
text: The grandson of a former Iranian president, Ali Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani, was arrested early Monday after arriving at Tehran’s international airport on a flight from London, where he is a student, the semiofficial news agency Fars reported.

headline: Travelocity Takes on Priceline
text: Travelers willing to book a hotel before learning its name have a new option.

headline: Hong Kong Issues Warning as Air Pollution Sets Record
text: HONG KONG — Air pollution in Hong Kong, one of the perpetual banes of living and working in this Asian financial hub, reached record levels on Monday and remained intense on Tuesday, setting off an official government warning to avoid outdoor activities and physical exertion.

headline: Baseline Unveils New Web Video Research Service
text: Set-top boxes, streaming services – video distribution is quickly evolving, and the entertainment research service Baseline StudioSystems announced on Monday a new semiannual report that it hopes will help investors and content distributors keep track of the myriad developments.

headline: Obama Heads to Iowa to Pitch Health Care

headline: In Bronx, Officer is Shot and Shooter is Dead
text: Updated, 4:27 p.m. | A police officer was shot three times in a housing-project apartment in the South Bronx on Monday by a man who was himself later found shot dead, though it was not clear whether he shot himself or whether officers shot him, the authorities said.

headline: People and Accounts of Note
text: Roger Baxter joined Publicis in the West, Seattle, as executive vice president and chief strategy officer. He succeeds Kevin May, who left to open a consultancy in Seattle. Mr. Baxter had been managing partner at Hall & Partners, New York. Publicis Seattle is part of the Publicis USA unit of Publicis Worldwide, a division of the Publicis Groupe.

headline: Answers About New Consumer Laws: Part 4
text: “Ask an Expert” is a recurring feature on Bucks where you have the opportunity to question big-brained individuals about a particular area of personal finance or consumer affairs.

headline: Beverage Brand Calls on a Coconutty Character
text: Several years ago, a reporter who writes about advertising made up, just for the fun of it, a brand character named Lippy Coconut. Although Lippy was not actually peddling any product, real or imaginary, he was a know-it-all in the vein of Chester the Cheetos cheetah or the red spokescandy for M&M’s.

headline: New Light Shed on North Pole Ice Trends
text: 1:54 p.m. | Updated  The sun rose over the horizon at the North Pole last weekend and the six-month “day” just began there, making this a good time to check in on ice and climate trends up north. I can’t believe it’s seven years now since I spent three days camped on the ice pack near 90 degrees North with a rugged team of climate and cryosphere researchers trying to improve understanding of the complex interface between air, ice and water.

headline: Sentencing of Broker’s Killer Is Delayed
text: Natavia S. Lowery was supposed to be sentenced on Monday for the murder of Linda S. Stein, a former punk rock manager and real estate agent to the stars.

headline: Perseus Signs an EBooks Deal for the iPad
text: Apple’s iBookstore on the forthcoming iPad is set to get larger. The company has just signed a deal with the largest distributor of independent publishers to sell electronic versions of it books on the new device.

headline: Photo Quiz: Giant Garland Edition
text: Welcome to another edition of The Lede’s very occasional photo quiz series, in which you, the reader, are asked to help us write a post explaining why a curious photograph that has moved across the wires in recent days is newsworthy.
