headline: I.M.F. Is More Likely to Lead Efforts for Aid to Greece
text: BRUSSELS — The International Monetary Fund seemed more likely to lead any rescue of Greece after diplomats on Monday struggled to avoid a rift among European Union leaders over aid to the heavily indebted country.

headline: Video: An Afghan Farmer or Bomb Maker?
text: In a series of posts on At War, the correspondent C. J. Chivers reports on the month and a half that he and the photographer Tyler Hicks spent embedded with United States forces in Afghanistan, detailing the first days of Operation Moshtarak, the recent offensive on Marja.

headline: Delightful Evening. Let’s Fight.
text: Warm weather does seem to make people punchier.

headline: The Market Yawns
text: Andrew Leonard has a good point: if Obamacare is such a disaster for the economy, where’s the market reaction?

headline: Levine to Miss More Dates Because of Back Problems
text: James Levine will miss what would have been his final appearances with the Boston Symphony Orchestra this season, withdrawing from three weeks’ worth of performances because of continuing problems with his back, the orchestra said on Monday. Mr. Levine, the conductor and music director of the Boston Symphony and the Metropolitan Opera, missed the opening of the Carnegie Hall season and key dates at the Met last fall when he pulled out to undergo an operation to repair a herniated disk. In March he canceled planned appearances at the Berlin Staatskapelle on the recommendation of his doctors, who said he should not travel while they adjusted his medication as part of his recovery from that surgery. In recent years, Mr. Levine has also had a cancerous cyst removed from his kidney and had rotator-cuff surgery to repair damage from an onstage fall.

headline: Taxes, Taxes Everywhere
text: If you have ever crossed a state border for work, even for a single day, you probably owe income taxes in that state.

headline: Biogen Accepts a Third Icahn Supporter on Its Board
text: Biogen Idec, the biotechnology company, said on Monday that it had come to an agreement with the billionaire investor Carl Icahn under which Mr. Icahn would abandon his threatened proxy fight in return for Biogen’s acceptance of a nominee to its board, Reuters reported.

headline: Bring-Your-Own-Storage Networking
text: Chances are you have a few USB thumb drives floating around your house; it’s also very likely that you use a USB external hard drive for backing up PCs or expanding your storage capacity. Iomega has created an inexpensive way to wirelessly share all these USB drives and create a network-attached storage device without investing a lot of time and money.

headline: MediaNews’s Holding Company Exits Bankruptcy
text: Affiliated Media, the publisher of 54 newspapers including The San Jose Mercury News, said on Monday that it had exited bankruptcy protection, The Associated Press reports.

headline: Mashing Up Real and Digital at SXSW
text: There were more registered attendees for the interactive stream than music at the Austin-based conference, but the best technologies there made real life better.

headline: At South by Southwest, a Spotlight on Navigation
text: South by Southwest Music and Media Conference may be known for music, but registrations suggest that the interactive part of the conference is the most popular. As the week progressed though, it was obvious that the best of new digital technologies, including much-talked-about location-based applications, make the real world an easier place to navigate. Let’s discuss in comments.

headline: Fossil Fuel Interests Paid for Danish Study Critical of Wind Power. Does It Matter?
text: A widely circulated report published last fall by the Center for Political Studies, or Cepos, a Danish research group, concluded that the country’s wind energy figures were incorrect.

headline: Dayton Women Climb One Mountain, Face Another
text: The wild N.C.A.A. women’s tournament ride of the No. 8-seeded Dayton Flyers is about to get crazier.

headline: Carpet Ride | 1950’s Iran
text: In 1956, the Austrian-born photographer Inge Morath traveled to Iran on assignment for Holiday magazine. She wanted to photograph the entire Silk Road, from southern Europe to the South China Sea, and thought of Iran as “a good start.” The resulting images — which reveal the Shah celebrating the Iranian New Year, herders resting in the mountains near Shiraz, and the ruins of Persepolis — are captured in “Inge Morath: Iran” (Steidl, $60).

headline: Trial in Same-Sex Marriage Case Is Challenged
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Officer Says Long Island Teenager Confessed to Stabbing
text: RIVERHEAD, N.Y. — The police officer who patted down the Long Island teenager accused of fatally stabbing an Ecuadorean immigrant in Patchogue in 2008 testified on Monday that the teenager had told him he had a knife. The officer recounted how he found blood on the blade and how the young man then made another admission.

headline: The Morning Skate: Another Dead End for the Rangers
text: Late Sunday afternoon, a couple of hours after the Rangers largely unimpressive 2-1 loss to Boston (Jeff Z. Klein’s Times story here), a middle-aged guy walked into a New York area gym wearing a 1994 Stanley Cup Champions hat. It could not have been a fashion statement because those hats, with the team logo shunted off to the side and huge letters across the front…

headline: Chevron Testing Solar Technologies
text: The oil giant Chevron has transformed an old refinery site in California into a test bed for seven advanced photovoltaic solar technologies, which the company is evaluating for use at its facilities worldwide.

headline: MSNBC: Obama's Remarks After the Bill
text: After the House approved landmark health care legislation on Sunday, President Obama said the passage is "a victory for the American people. And it's a victory for common sense. " (Video: MSNBC)

headline: 59th Street and First Avenue, 12:30 P.M.
text: A pedestrian passed beneath the 59th Street Bridge.

headline: A Charger That is Garlic to “Vampire Draw”
text: Most people know that power chargers for electronic devices draw electricity when plugged into the wall even when they aren’t charging something. But short of unplugging every wall wart not in use, what do you do about it?

headline: Hazards: Lead Found in Indian Spices and Powders
text: Lead has been found in house paint and imported toys, and now it appears Indian spices and ceremonial powders may contain lead at levels that may be hazardous to children.

headline: Problems at the MtyMx Festival in Mexico
text: MONTERREY, Mexico — Since Saturday, the MtyMx festival has occupied Autocinema Las Torres, an abandoned drive-in movie theater here in the southeast part of the city. Organized by the Brooklyn D.I.Y. impresario Todd P in concert with the local promoters Yo Garage, it’s the first festival of its kind, with an emphasis on American indie-rock bands, to be held in this city of about four million, which last week saw an eruption of drug cartel violence and was recently mentioned in a State Department travel advisory.

headline: Parsons of Citigroup Says Pandit Deserves Credit
text: Few chief executives are under as much scrutiny or pressure as Citigroup‘s Vikram S. Pandit. But the bank’s chairman, Richard D. Parsons, has a message for Mr. Pandit’s naysayers: Give him some credit.

headline: Are Aquariums Getting Too Lifelike?
text: On the reefs in the Florida Keys, plenty of snorkelers and scuba divers take in the sights, and others fish with spear guns for sport. But a small third group collects blue-legged hermit crabs, peppermint shrimp and other invertebrates, not for food or fun, but for the aquarium trade.

headline: A Writer Recalls His Mentor, Critic and Father, All in One Complex Man
text: The intense, often conflicted relationship between fathers and sons has already given us compelling memoirs by three prominent contemporary novelists.

headline: U.S. Bolsters Chemical Restrictions for Water
text: The Environmental Protection Agency announced on Monday that it would overhaul drinking water regulations so that officials could police dozens of contaminants simultaneously and tighten rules on the chemicals used by industries.

headline: Fake Area Newspaper Gets Real Television Show
text: The Onion, the satirical news organization that broke the fake story that the smoke monster from “Lost” would receive its own spin-off series and cheekily reported that television critics who praised “The Wire” had never seen the show, is itself headed to the small screen.

headline: Texas Lawmaker Admits ‘Baby Killer’ Remark
text: Representative Randy Neugebauer, a conservative Republican from Texas, revealed on Monday that he was the lawmaker who shouted “baby killer” on the House floor Sunday night as Representative Bart Stupak, a Michigan Democrat, discussed abortion-related aspects of the health care legislation.

headline: ‘Only the Beginning’
text: The battle over health care has only just started, some observers say.

headline: Baby Fat May Not Be So Cute After All
text: Schools have banned cupcakes, issued obesity report cards and cleared space in cafeterias for salad bars. Just last month, Michelle Obama’s campaign to end childhood obesity promised to get young people moving more and revamp school lunch, and beverage makers said they had cut the sheer number of liquid calories shipped to schools by almost 90 percent in the past five years.

headline: Jolts of Cheer From Some Depressives
text: The Rhineland was a source of inspiration for two works on the intelligently constructed program of the Orchestra of St. Luke’s on Sunday afternoon at Carnegie Hall, with Christian Zacharias conducting and performing as piano soloist.

headline: Taxi Scheme May Be Smaller Than First Thought
text: Updated, 5:51 p.m. | The grand New York City taxi fraud may not be as grand as officials first thought.

headline: Perseus Signs an E-Books Deal for the iPad
text: Apple has signed a deal with the largest distributor of independent publishers to sell electronic versions of it books on the new device, report Motoko Rich and Brad Stone on Media Decoder.

headline: Travel Deals: Palomar Chicago Opens with Weekend Discount
text: Kimpton’s Hotel Palomar Chicago is opening on March 24 with discounted weekend rates of $139 a night.

headline: Google Shuts China Site in Dispute Over Censorship
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Just over two months after threatening to leave China because of censorship and intrusions from hackers, Google on Monday closed its Internet search service there and began directing users in that country to its uncensored search engine in Hong Kong.

headline: 10 Ways to Promote Writing for an Authentic Audience
text: We began our daily Student Opinion feature last October, when we moved to the blog format, to create a “safe space” on NYTimes.com — and on the Internet over all — for students 13 and older to voice their views on the news.

headline: Black Writers Ponder Role and Seek Wider Attention
text: The 10th National Black Writers’ Conference begins on Thursday at Medgar Evers College in New York, an anniversary that prompted Walter Mosley to remember his first conference, in the 1980s. He was just one of many unpublished, struggling writers who showed up, he said. An editor had passed on his first novel, about the detective Easy Rawlins, with the rationale that the publishing house already had a black detective novel.

headline: Edible Silver Lake | Foraging for Lunch
text: The burgeoning “town center” of Silver Lake, a neighborhood on the east side of Los Angeles that’s known for its hipster vibe, is concentrated on a short stretch of Sunset Boulevard, anchored at one end by Sunset Junction — home to Café Stella and Intelligentsia Coffee — and at the other by those ubiquitous features of the L.A. cityscape: a taco stand and a mini-mall.

headline: March (Grading) Madness
text: Last week we referred you to a March Madness bracket based on which schools had the highest-paid alumni. Now, thanks to gradeinflation.com (maintained by Stuart Rojstaczer), there is a comparable bracket based on which schools have the hardest-won A’s.

headline: Pioneer Reflects on Future of Reproductive Medicine
text: ENGLEWOOD, Colo. — Dr. Howard W. Jones Jr., the surgeon who, along with his wife, Dr. Georgeanna Seegar Jones, helped to create the first test tube baby born in the United States, turned 99 in December. He is still opinionated, humble and charming, and he has a lot to say about the past and future of the baby-making business.

headline: Executive Shakeup at Nanosolar
text: Nanosolar, a prominent solar start-up in Silicon Valley, said on Monday that it had replaced its co-founder and chief executive, Martin Roscheisen, with Geoff Tate, a veteran of the chip industry.

headline: Why CBS Said No to Tiger Woods Interview
text: Tiger Woods may be one of the biggest stories of the year, but at least one news organization didn’t see the value of landing an interview with him – at least if it was going to be limited to five minutes.

headline: Players Say Head Check Rule Needs Further Tweaking
text: The fast-tracking of the proposed rule against head checks may have hit a speed bump.

headline: Feinberg to Examine Past Pay at 419 Firms in TARP
text: From Eric Dash, a DealBook colleague:

headline: Google Details ‘New Approach to China’
text: As my colleagues Miguel Helft and David Barboza report, in a post on Google’s official blog on Monday, David Drummond, the company’s senior vice president and chief legal officer, announced, “today we stopped censoring our search services—Google Search, Google News, and Google Images—on Google.cn.”

headline: Questions and Answers on the Student Loan Bill
text: Somewhat lost in the House of Representatives’ approval of the health care reform bill on Sunday night was its vote in favor of President Obama’s overhaul of the federal student loan system. Under the measure, fees paid to private banks as intermediaries would be eliminated; the maximum value of Pell grants would rise — though not by as much as in previous versions — and college graduates in low-paying jobs would have an easier time paying back loans.

headline: City to Pay $33 Million to Inmates Who Were Illegally Strip Searched
text: The city announced Monday that it had agreed to settle a lawsuit stemming from the illegal strip search of thousands of nonviolent inmates who were taken to Rikers Island on misdemeanor charges.

headline: Quote Unquote | Carried Away
text: –J. Crew’s Creative Director Jenna Lyons reveals her ambitions for the brand. What we want to know is, would Michelle Obama be allowed to carry a Chanel bag if it came from J. Crew?

headline: Fun Facts About the Tampa Bay Rays
text: FORT MYERS, Fla. – Year after year, the most informative media guide in the majors belongs to the Tampa Bay Rays – who, as I write this, are putting a beating on the Red Sox at City of Palms Park. The Rays load up their player bios with useful tidbits that go beyond the numbers, and I thought I’d share a few:

headline: When Your Looks Take Over Your Life
text: Is there a part of you that you hate to look at and perhaps try to hide from others? Do you glance at your image in distress whenever you pass a reflective surface?

headline: Sabotaging Success, but to What End?
text: “You could say I’ve been unlucky in love,” a young man told me during a recent consultation.

headline: A Player Back at the Casino: He’s Undercover but at Home
text: ATLANTIC CITY  Sitting one afternoon recently in the lobby of Caesars casino here, where the floor is paved with stone to resemble the streets of ancient Rome, Josh Axelrad was trying to resemble someone idle, unemployed and not too bright. He was wearing jeans, a T-shirt and a Ford racing cap at an off-kilter angle. He was not advertising that, stuffed in wads in his pockets and stacked in a money belt around his waist, he was packing $20,000 that friends had staked him to play cards with.

headline: When the Mirror Is Your Enemy
text: “Many of us are embarrassed or dissatisfied with some body part or other,” writes Personal Health columnist Jane Brody in today’s Science Times. “But what if such self-consciousness about a perceived facial or body defect becomes all-consuming, a kind of obsession or paranoia that keeps the person from focusing on school or work, pursuing normal social activities, even leaving the house to shop or see a doctor?”

headline: Goodell Wants a Word With Roethlisberger
text: ORLANDO, Fla. – N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell made clear Monday that he was unhappy with the conduct of Pittsburgh Steelers quarterback Ben Roethlisberger, who is under police investigation after a 20-year-old college student accused him of sexually assaulting her in a Georgia bar. Goodell said that he spoke to the Rooney family, the owners of the Steelers, and planned to speak with Roethlisberger at a later date.

headline: Seeing Body Flaws That Aren’t There
text: In this week’s Personal Health column, Jane Brody explores the strange world of body dysmorphic disorder, or B.D.D., a condition that leads to self loathing and anxiety over minor imperfections. She writes:

headline: Colorado Increases Renewables Requirements
text: In a bid to propel his state to the forefront of the new energy economy, Colorado’s governor is expected to sign one of the most aggressive renewable energy requirements in the country on Monday afternoon.

headline: A Network Storage Drive for Technophobes
text: Some people think NAS is a nasty word, and Jon Christeson is one of them.

headline: Bank Panel Clears Bill on Overhaul
text: WASHINGTON — The Senate Banking Committee voted on Monday to send to the full Senate a Democratic bill to overhaul the nation’s financial system, deferring, for now, an anticipated partisan fight over the legislation.

headline: 16w21 Campaign
text: A saucy new campaign for a high-end apartment building in Chelsea includes short videos featuring cosmopolitan dolls.

headline: Education, Faith and a Likelihood to Wed
text: The National Center for Health Statistics this month published a new analysis of data on marriage and cohabitation that concentrated on relationships in the context of childbearing.

headline: Grassley Wants Obama to Enroll in New Exchanges
text: Senator Charles E. Grassley, Republican of Iowa, said on Monday that he would propose legislation requiring  President Obama and White House officials obtain their health insurance through the government exchanges that will be established under the health care bill Mr. Obama is planning to sign on Tuesday.

headline: After Years of War and Abuse, New Hope for Ancient Babylon
text: The most immediate threat to preserving the ruins of Babylon, the site of one of the Seven Wonders of the Ancient World, is water soaking the ground and undermining what is left in present-day Iraq of a great city from the time of King Nebuchadnezzar II.

headline: Bank Bailout Tax Gains Support in Europe
text: President Obama’s proposal for a direct tax on banks to pay for future bailouts is gathering momentum in Europe, with Germany set to move ahead with its own levy and Britain expected to endorse a similar measure ahead of the Group of 20 meeting next month, The New York Times’s Matthew Saltmarsh reports from Paris.

headline: A Look Inside the Dollhouse (Care to Buy a Condo)?
text: Selling multimillion dollar apartments in this real estate market may not be any fun, but an ad campaign about a new building still can be.

headline: Slim Pickings? You Can Still Eat Well
text: I recently received an e-mail from a reader who cooks on an extreme budget in an area of the country where ingredients are limited. “We can’t afford a lot of fresh vegetables; it’s a stretch to buy brown rice instead of white,” she wrote. “I cook a lot, but I struggle to find new, healthy recipes that use budget ingredients.” I immediately set about to do a week of recipes that cost anywhere from $1 or less to $1.50 per person.

headline: U.N. Says Dirty Water Kills More Than War
text: More people die from polluted water every year than from all forms of violence, including war, the United Nations said in a report Monday that highlights the need for clean drinking water. The report was released to coincide with World Water Day, which serves as the theme for the opening of the slide show and for our featured post this morning, “Little Water, and Less, Along the Jordan.”

headline: Patterns: Nonmelanoma Skin Cancer Cases Soar
text: The most common cancer in the United States is nonmelanoma skin cancer, but the exact number of cases is unknown because they are generally not tracked by cancer registries. Now, a new study reports that Americans are developing those cancers at record numbers, with 3.5 million cases a year in 2 million people, as of 2006. (Patients with a skin cancer often develop another one within the year.)

headline: Car Messages Get a Mixed Reception
text: The ubiquitous yellow “Baby on Board” signs that swung in the back window of so many minivans have given way to other messages alerting drivers that Yankee fans are on board, and even a “Mother-in-Law in Trunk.” The latest vehicle signage vogue includes acronym advertisements for vacation spots, like “LBI” for Long Beach Island or “MTK,” for Montauk, wrote Anne Marie Valinoti in the weekend’s Complaint Box in the Metropolitan section. The advertising, however, may be having a negative effect.

headline: Global Head of Equities at UBS Steps Down
text: Daniel B. Coleman, the global head of equities of UBS, is leaving the Swiss bank after nearly 24 years and will turn over his duties to Neal Shear, the bank’s global head of securities, Bloomberg News reports.

headline: New York Production Set for Latest Kushner Play
text: Tony Kushner’s latest play, “The Intelligent Homosexual’s Guide to Capitalism and Socialism With A Key to the Scriptures,” his first epic-sized work about American life since his Pulitzer Prize-winning “Angels in America” in the early 1990s, will have its New York premiere next spring in a co-production by the Public Theater and the Signature Theater Company, the two theaters announced on Monday.

headline: Tuberculosis: Drug-Resistant Strains Still Spreading at Deadly Rates, W.H.O. Report Says
text: Drug-resistant tuberculosis killed about 150,000 people in 2008, and half of all the world’s cases are thought in be in China and India, the World Health Organization said in a report last week.

headline: Asked and Answered | David Rathman Rumbles in the Jungle
text: Before there was Mike Tyson versus Evander Holyfield, Mixed Martial Arts bloodsport battles and Rocky I-V, there was 1974’s “Rumble in the Jungle.” The “Rumble” featured two of boxing’s greatest icons, Muhammad Ali and George Foreman, pitted in the ring, while the “Jungle” came courtesy of Zaire (now the Democratic Republic of Congo), where the fight took place. The epic bout inspired “The Fight,” a book by Norman Mailer, a song by the Fugees and countless ESPN “SportsCenter” reruns. Now it’s getting the artistic treatment, courtesy of the watercolorist David Rathman.

headline: Baby Fat or Early Obesity?
text: Although most childhood obesity efforts are targeted at schoolchildren, the best time to prevent weight problems may be in early childhood and infancy, reports Roni Rabin in Tuesday’s Science Times. She writes:

headline: Cablevision’s Rainbow Media Said Near a Deal for Gothamist
text: Gothamist, a blog network focused on several large cities (but primarily New York), is close to a sale to Cablevision‘s Rainbow Media for $5 million to $6 million, the Web site paidContent reported on Monday, citing an unnamed source.

headline: Boston’s Latest Pan-Asian Restaurant
text: Ginger Park is proving that, yes, the world does need another pan-Asian restaurant. At least Boston’s South End thinks so, when it’s under the apron of Patricia Yeo.

headline: A Toddler and Her Thumb
text: Sarah Dille teaches A.P. English to high-school students in Austin, Tex. She also writes a charming blog about being a parent to 2-year-old Nora. It’s called “Toddler Summer,” she tells me, because “I started blogging as a summer ‘project’ last year after school had ended and I wondered what the heck I was going to do with all my newfound ‘free’ time after trying to balance work and motherhood for nine months. I hadn’t yet been home with a toddler long enough to realize that ‘free’ time really didn’t exist.”

headline: In Five Extra Minutes, a Number of Possibilities
text: So Monday was the day the five-minute grace period started. That gave time-pressed drivers in New York five extra minutes to move their cars after alternate-side regulations take effect.

headline: Puzzle Holiday
text: Our Quiz Whiz, Pradeep Mutalik, is taking a well-deserved holiday this week.

headline: Health Care Links
text: Megan McArdle offers eight predictions for what health care reform will and won’t mean.

headline: Bond Markets Trust Buffett More Than Obama
text: More fuel for the fiscal hawks, courtesy of Bloomberg:

headline: Banking Panel Sends Financial Bill to Full Senate
text: 5:47 p.m. | Updated The Senate Banking Committee voted 13 to 10 late Monday afternoon to send a proposed overhaul of the nation’s financial system to the full Senate, a quick vote that reflects a change in strategy by Republicans opposed to the measure, The New York Times’s Sewell Chan reports from Washington.

headline: BMW to Supply Diesels for Police Car Venture
text: Carbon Motors and the BMW Group announced at a Washington news conference on Monday that the companies had reached an agreement for BMW to supply 240,000 turbo diesel engines for a police car that Carbon Motors would produce called the E7.

headline: Ready, Set, Hang: The Heavy Lifting Is On
text: The explosive growth of the art world during the last decade has been fueled by rich new collectors, shiny new galleries and sprawling new museum wings. But the gears and the grease that keep this big machine humming are people who can be generally described with less glamorous adjectives: underpaid, uninsured, overworked and sweaty (not to mention often heavily tattooed, bearded, hung over and painfully burdened by loan payments for their M.F.A. degrees).

headline: One Last Nap Amid the Flowers
text: ON the last day of his life, my dog Otto spent the first real morning of spring napping in the garden.

headline: Bin Laden’s Daughter Allowed to Leave Iran
text: Osama bin Laden’s teenage daughter, Iman, has reportedly left Iran — where she had lived under house arrest for eight years with several of her siblings — and is now in Syria, according to a report in Asharq Al-Awsat, a Saudi-owned newspaper newspaper based in London.

headline: Staying the Course Makes Sense for Marketers During Crises, Study Concludes
text: For those wondering why Toyota Motor continues to advertise during the current crisis over its reputation, a coming study suggests that such a course of action could be superior to inaction.

headline: Cablevision Unit Is Said to Be Interested in Acquiring Gothamist
text: Rainbow Media, a unit of Cablevision, is seeking to acquiring the Gothamist network of blogs, a person familiar with the negotiations said Monday.

headline: Star-Heavy Big-Budget Love Story Bucks Trend
text: CULVER CITY, Calif.  The Columbia Pictures lot here is decked with poster art for movies due in the coming months.

headline: Interview: Sergey Brin on Google’s China Move
text: 6:08 p.m. | Updated  Adding more excerpts from interview.

headline: From ‘Greenberg’ to ‘Designing Women’
text: With Greta Gerwig’s star turn opposite Ben Stiller in “Greenberg,” the 26-year-old may have graduated from the microbudget mumblecore flicks that first got her noticed. But she’s still got enough lo-fi spirit to laugh at herself. We caught up with Gerwig last week for a beauty feature in our coming women’s issue, and she related this “unfortunate makeup experience” from the premiere of “Greenberg” at last month’s Berlin Film Festival.

headline: Artists Mine Scientific Clues to Paint Intricate Portraits of the Past
text: Somewhere in England, about 600 years ago, an artist sat down and tried to paint an elephant. There was just one problem: he had never seen one.

headline: In Canada, Local Stations May Negotiate a Cable Fee
text: OTTAWA — Canada’s broadcasting regulator has devised a system aimed at allowing conventional television station owners to negotiate payments from operators of cable and satellite TV systems.

headline: In Therapy, Cellphones Ring True
text: Though the interruption may be jarring, I rather welcome the twang of bluegrass or the toll of church bells coming from a patient’s cellphone during a psychotherapy session. Here’s why.

headline: The Brooklyn Flea Will Stay at One Hanson, Along With Some New Food Vendors
text: One of the great urban experiences New York offered this winter was the Brooklyn Flea in exile. When the weather turned cold, the market moved indoors to One Hanson Place, bringing along its motley host of antiques dealers, artists, designers, vintage-workboot purveyors and–let’s get to the point here–food vendors.

headline: Phone Chats During Therapy
text: Whether at the movies or the doctor’s office, cellphone users are often admonished to turn the devices off. But during visits with a therapist, a brief cellphone conversation may offer a useful glimpse into a patient’s real life, explains Boston psychiatrist Barbara Schildkrout in today’s Science Times. She writes:

headline: Are Shoppers Fairer?
text: In my Findings column, I discuss a study in Science that found wide cultural variations in concepts of fairness. It was measured by observing people in 15 societies around the world participate in a two-player game in which one player, called the dictator, decided how much of the prize to share with the other.

headline: Using Quotas to Raise the Glass Ceiling
text: In 2002, Norway enacted a law requiring that 40 percent of all board members at state-owned and publicly listed companies be women by 2008.

headline: Toyota to Replace Accelerator Pedals for Owners Who Are Unhappy With Repairs
text: DETROIT — After reports of sudden unintended acceleration in cars it has already fixed, Toyota has told dealers to provide replacement accelerator pedals to owners unhappy with repairs, a company document showed on Monday.

headline: Kushner Play to Open in New York Next Spring
text: Tony Kushner’s latest play, “The Intelligent Homosexual’s Guide to Capitalism and Socialism With a Key to the Scriptures,” his first epic-size work about American life since his Pulitzer Prize-winning “Angels in America” in the early 1990s, will have its New York premiere next spring in a co-production by the Public Theater and the Signature Theater Company, the two theaters announced Monday.

headline: For Extinct Monsters of the Deep, a Little Respect
text: Here is a quick paleontology quiz. Which group of animals included large, air-breathing predators up to 50 feet long that bore live young, dominated their world for more than 100 million years and were ultimately exterminated by an asteroid 65 million years ago?

headline: Playing the Victim
text: In today’s Mind column, psychiatrist Dr. Richard A. Friedman explores the puzzling world of self-defeating behavior, when people blame others for their misfortune and feel victimized by bad luck.

headline: On Thin Ice
text: Car enthusiasts in rural New Hampshire race for fun on a frozen pond without corporate sponsors or pit crews. This is "poor man's racing."

headline: Moral Lessons, Down Aisle 9
text: Like Diogenes with his lamp, researchers have traversed the world looking for an honest man — or, more precisely, for people who act in the same fair, unselfish way toward everyone. If you wish to learn to follow this golden rule, which of these strategies is best?

headline: Sixty Years of Pierre Cardin
text: IHT fashion editor Suzy Menkes interviews the fashion icon Pierre Cardin as he celebrates his 60th year in fashion.

headline: Celebrating the Delicate Beauty of the Desert Landscape
text: Few architects have invested more time trying to bridge the gap between the high-tech aesthetics of the West and the traditions of the Middle East than Jean Nouvel.

headline: Microcosm of Housing Crisis on an Arizona Street
text: CAVE CREEK, Ariz. — The uncertain line between hope and despair divides this exurb of Phoenix, where the trim stucco houses used to sell so briskly.

headline: Headed for Auction: Back-Channel Gloom on Revolutionary War
text: Despite King George’s boast that “once these rebels have felt a smart blow, they will submit,” back-channel messages from British generals and diplomatic officials in America during the Revolutionary War, some of them previously unpublished, turn out to have been decidedly more pessimistic.

headline: Hoops Lift CBS
text: CBS led the ratings race on Sunday, aided by its afternoon coverage of the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament. According to Nielsen’s estimates, an overrun of the network’s coverage lasted throughout most of the 7 p.m. hour, earning nearly 14 million viewers in the time slot. Later in the night “60 Minutes” drew just under 13 million viewers, while the CBS reality shows “The Amazing Race” (12.5 million) and “Undercover Boss” (13.6 million) kept the network in first place. ABC was runner-up on the night, benefiting from “Desperate Housewives” (10.8 million), but earning more modest ratings for “Extreme Makeover: Home Edition” (7.4 million) and “Jamie Oliver’s Food Revolution” (6.2 million). NBC ranked third with “Minute to Win It” (5.2 million) followed by “The Celebrity Apprentice” (6.9 million). Fox placed fourth with new episodes of its comedies, including “The Simpsons” (5.7 million) and “The Cleveland Show” (5 million).

headline: Starz Plans ‘Camelot’
text: Once, there was a spot, for one brief shining moment that was known as Camelot. And even though that spot was declared, in another context, by a different King Arthur, to be “a silly place,” that kingdom and its knights are now set to make a serious return on television. On Monday the Starz cable channel said that it was preparing a new series called “Camelot,” based on the version of the Arthurian legend recounted in Thomas Malory’s “Morte d’Arthur.” Starz, which has recently found a hit in its sword-and-sandals adventure series “Spartacus: Blood and Sand,” said “Camelot” would be written by Chris Chibnall, of the supernatural British dramas “Life on Mars” and “Torchwood,” and produced by a team that includes Graham King (“The Departed,” “Gangs of New York”) and Morgan O’Sullivan and Michael Hirst (both of the Showtime period drama “The Tudors”). The 10-episode series is expected to begin production in June with episodes to start showing in 2011. No cast was announced.

headline: An American Presence at the Olivier Awards
text: Several shows set in, born in or coming to the United States received Olivier Awards in London on Sunday night. “Spring Awakening,” which took top honors at the Tony Awards in 2007, was named best new musical. Katori Hall’s “Mountaintop,” which may come to Broadway in the fall, won as best new play. Rupert Goold was named best director for “Enron” (above, a scene from the play), which is scheduled to begin previews on Broadway next month. In the acting categories, Aneurin Barnard was named best actor in a musical for his performance as Melchior in “Spring Awakening”; Samantha Spiro was named best actress in a musical for her performance as the title character in “Hello, Dolly!” Mark Rylance took home the best actor award for his portrayal of a cocky stoner in Jez Butterworth’s play “Jerusalem,” and Rachel Weisz won for her Blanche DuBois in the Donmar Warehouse’s production of “A Streetcar Named Desire.”

headline: Levine Sidelined Again by Back Problems
text: James Levine, right, will miss what would have been his final appearances with the Boston Symphony Orchestra this season because of continuing problems with his back, the orchestra said on Monday. Mr. Levine, the conductor and music director of the Boston Symphony and the Metropolitan Opera, missed the opening of the Carnegie Hall season and major dates at the Met last fall because of an operation to repair a herniated disk. In March he canceled planned appearances at the Berlin Staatskapelle on the recommendation of his doctors, who said he should not travel while they adjusted his medication as part of his recovery from that surgery. In recent years Mr. Levine has also had a cancerous cyst removed from his kidney and had rotator-cuff surgery to repair damage from an onstage fall. The Boston Symphony said that Jayce Ogren would lead its performances March 25 through 27 and that Rafael Frühbeck de Burgos would conduct April 1 through 3 in Boston and on April 5 at Carnegie Hall. A conductor for performances on April 8 through 10 will be announced shortly.

headline: Fake Newspaper to Get Real TV Show
text: The Onion, the satirical news organization that broke the fake story that the smoke monster from “Lost” would receive its own spinoff series and cheekily reported that television critics who praised “The Wire” had never seen the show, is itself headed to the small screen. On Monday the Independent Film Channel announced that it was developing a television series based on The Onion, the humorous weekly newspaper and Web site (theonion.com), as part of a comedy-heavy slate of new programming. The Onion series, called “Onion News Network,” will bring the deadpan sensibility of the Web site’s popular video clips to a show in the vein of authentic news programs like CNN’s “Situation Room” or “Anderson Cooper 360.” “It just seems to us, CNN, Fox News and MSNBC are already doing such great comedy out there, without a whole lot of competition,” said Will Graham, an executive producer of “Onion News Network.” “We thought it was about time that someone really gave them a run for their money.” The IFC series is planned for a 2011 debut.

headline: Nelson to Vote Against Reconciliation Bill
text: One of the big reasons House Democrats wanted changes to the Senate-passed health care bill was the so-called Cornhusker kickback, which provided extra Medicaid money for Nebraska.

headline: Back to Baghdad
text: BAGHDAD — Today I flew into the airport that I helped to build nearly 30 years ago. In 1981 I was a new graduate of Baghdad University’s civil engineering department, and I was appointed a site engineer at the partly-constructed airport.

headline: Hip-Hop Punctuates a Benefit
text: Long before the first note was played at Carnegie Hall on Sunday night, you could tell it was an unusual occasion. A lively, enthusiastic and uncommonly diverse audience filled the auditorium to capacity, with illicit camera flashes indicating the presence of newcomers and curiosity seekers. The event at hand was a concert meant to raise money for earthquake-ravaged Haiti; the chief attraction was the Chinese piano superstar Lang Lang.

headline: From The Jaws Of Defeat
text: Just one more reminder of what a victory Obama and Pelosi pulled off: here’s the Intrade price on passage of Obamacare from the aftermath of the Massachusetts election to actual success:

headline: Downstream Drugs
text: Q. Have any studies been done on possible environmental risks from drugs used for chemotherapy after they pass through the body?

headline: Little Punk Staffers Of The World, Unite
text: OK, now begins the fight on financial reform. We know where the Republican leadership stands: would-be protectors against another crisis are little punk staffers who have no right to dictate to fine, upstanding bankers like the people who, uh, brought the world economy to its knees. Barney Frank has handed out buttons to his staff:

headline: Send Us Your Small-Business Health Reform Questions
text: Earlier today, The Agenda answered a question from a small-business owner about how the new health care law — which President Obama will sign Tuesday — might affect his future. That answer, in turn, begat more reader questions (like this comment about the small-business tax credit). The new law is big and complex, and we suspect there are many more questions out there. So if you own a small business, or work for one, we invite your questions about health insurance coverage and the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act.

headline: Wave of Airline Strikes Sweeps Europe
text: PARIS — Travelers across Europe braced for chaos as a strike by British Airways cabin crew entered its third day on Monday and labor strife spread to other airlines.

headline: High-Speed Rail in Tampa: A Fast Train to a Slow Bus?
text: A journey to the beach questions the usefulness of Florida's public transportation plans.

headline: Answers on the Health Care Overhaul
text: Insights on how the health care overhaul will affect consumers are provided on the Prescriptions blog, where four Times reporters — Tara Siegel Bernard, Jennifer Saranow Schultz, Ron Lieber and Natasha Singer — answered reader questions. And an earlier post on Bucks offers more details.

headline: Taming the Turbulence Inside Pipelines
text: A pipeline may appear calm and quiet on the outside, but inside it’s a roiling mess. At anything other than low rates of flow, a fluid being transported, like oil, water or natural gas, becomes turbulent.

headline: After Mating, Male Pipefish Get Choosy
text: Pipefish, like seahorses and a few other related fishes, are unusual in that it’s the male that gets pregnant. The female deposits eggs in a pouch in the male’s body, where they are fertilized and protected and receive nutrients as they develop.

headline: Laser Treatment May Work for Cataracts
text: Cataracts are the leading cause of blindness in the world, and are often related to aging. In a common form of cataracts, proteins in the lens change over time, developing chromophores — molecular add-ons that absorb color in the blue part of the spectrum. Chromophores reduce the amount of light reaching the retina (and give the lens a yellow-brown appearance), but they also disrupt the structure of the lens proteins, causing light to scatter.

headline: Apollo Seeks $50 Million Offering on N.Y.S.E.
text: Apollo Global Management, the private equity firm led by Leon D. Black, said on Monday that it was seeking a $50 million initial public offering of shares as it aims to migrate to the New York Stock Exchange from Goldman Sachs‘s private market.

headline: U.S. Officials Meet Iraqi Leader After Recount Call
text: BAGHDAD — The two top American officials in Iraq met Monday with Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki after his endorsement over the weekend of a recount in the parliamentary elections incited fears of a political crisis in a country not accustomed to peaceful transfers of power.

headline: On Language and Cancer (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Falling at Mach 1 (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Catching a Catchy Tune (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Lung Cancer’s Toll (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Flock Grows Right at Home for a Priest in Ukraine
text: RUDNO, Ukraine — Let the rest of Europe be convulsed by debates over whether the celibacy of Roman Catholic priests is causing sex abuse scandals like the one now unfolding in Germany. Here in western Ukraine, many Catholic priests are married, fruitful and multiplying — with the Vatican’s blessing.

headline: "Ultra Lounge" by Hyatt/Funny or Die
text: In a series of Web videos from the comedy site Funny or Die, Hyatt will emphasize what can go wrong when people choose the wrong hotel or meeting planner.

headline: "Teppanyaki Chef" by Hyatt/Funny or Die
text: In a series of Web videos from the comedy site Funny or Die, Hyatt will emphasize what can go wrong when people choose the wrong hotel or meeting planner.

headline: What We’re Reading: iPad’s Price, EBay Thieves and Palm’s Decline
text: The tech reporters and editors of The Times found themselves immersed in retail, fashion, real estate and, as always, assessing the power of the Internet.

headline: To Get a Good Seat, Check the Chart
text: EACH year for as long as I remember, I’ve made sure to hit the miles-flown mark to maintain elite status on at least one airline.

headline: Monmouth’s Addition by Subtraction
text: Less is more. The maxim is truer than ever in horse racing, and this summer Monmouth Park is going to prove it. Beginning May 22, the charming track on the Jersey Shore will offer fewer racing dates but for a lot more money: 50 days with $1 million in purse money up for grabs on each of them.

headline: North Korea Says a Detained U.S. Citizen Will Face Trial
text: SEOUL, South Korea — An American citizen arrested in January for illegally entering North Korea will be put on trial, the North’s official news agency reported Monday.

headline: Woods’s Interviews Short on Time and Revelations
text: In five minutes on ESPN and six on the Golf Channel, Tiger Woods did not say much that was new Sunday night.

headline: Google Is Now Searching for Bond Traders
text: Google may be hoping to profit from its vast collection of knowledge. The search giant is seeking to hire bond traders and analysts, according to job postings on its Web site that were unearthed by Business Insider.

headline: Bids in Hand, MGM Weighs Its Options
text: Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, the beleaguered film studio, said in a statement late on Monday that it had received a number of bids as it tries to reorganize its nearly $4 billion debt load.

headline: Apple Adds 2 Publishers to Its Store for E-Books
text: Apple’s iBookstore on the forthcoming iPad is set to get larger. The company has just signed a deal with two more independent publishers to sell electronic versions of their books on the new device.

headline: Rodriguez Will Meet Investigators in Buffalo
text: Alex Rodriguez is scheduled to meet on Friday with federal investigators who want to know about his interactions with Anthony Galea, the Canadian-based doctor whose activities are being scrutinized by a number of federal agencies in the United States.

headline: House Ethics Office Gains, Dismissals Aside
text: WASHINGTON — By most measures, it has been a rough year for Leo J. Wise, the first independent ethics cop for the House of Representatives. Lawyers are denouncing him as dangerous, lawmakers are threatening to cut his already limited powers, and a House committee has so far dismissed all but one case in which his office found evidence of wrongdoing.

headline: Malawi: Trial of Gay Couple Is Allowed
text: The trial of two gay men accused of unnatural acts and gross indecency, Tiwonge Chimbalanga and Steven Monjeza, will proceed on April 3, a magistrate ruled Monday. The defense had asked for the charges to be dropped. The two men were arrested after holding a public engagement ceremony in December and have been jailed ever since. Homosexuality is a crime in Malawi carrying a maximum sentence of 14 years.

headline: U.S. Set to Expand Role in Protecting Air Travelers
text: The federal government is about to take a larger role in protecting airline passengers, starting with a new rule allowing travelers to get off a plane stuck on the tarmac for more than three hours.

headline: Cases Brought by the Office of Congressional Ethics
text: The office, which was created in March 2008, recommended 12 cases for further review last year. The House ethics committee dismissed eight of those cases, and three are under review.

headline: Italy: Guilt in Briton’s Death Reaffirmed
text: A man convicted of murdering a British student in Perugia in 2007 “participated fully” in the crime and sexually assaulted the victim, an appeals court said in reasoning released Monday, the ANSA news agency reported. The man, Rudy Guede, was convicted in 2008 of killing Meredith Kercher, 21. An American college student, Amanda Knox, and her Italian former boyfriend, Raffaele Sollecito, were convicted last year in the case. In ambiguous language that could have an impact on Ms. Knox and Mr. Sollecito’s appeals, the court said Mr. Guede had “played his part in the violence that weakened the victim’s will, until the final tragedy, and also when the knives were brandished,” ANSA reported.

headline: Yankees’ Fifth Starter? Two Make Final Cases
text: CLEARWATER, Fla. — The whole day was nuts. It started with Joba Chamberlain pitching to five teammates — or was it eight? — at a nearly empty Steinbrenner Field. It ended with Phil Hughes serving three home runs to the Philadelphia Phillies at blustery Bright House Field while insisting he had his best stuff of the spring, an assessment Yankees Manager Joe Girardi eagerly agreed with.

headline: Israel: Soldier Is Accidentally Killed
text: An Israeli soldier was accidentally shot dead by fellow soldiers along the Gaza border on Monday in an operation aimed at stopping three Palestinians who were thought to be trying to infiltrate the border fence, an army spokesman said. The three, who were unarmed, were detained. The shooting occurred when a tank team that saw the men along the fence called for reinforcements. The new arrivals thought the soldiers were the infiltrators and shot them. The army has opened an investigation.

headline: A Starter for Mighty Kentucky Now Sits on Cornell’s Bench
text: ITHACA, N.Y. — Mark Coury remembers those Southeastern Conference football Saturdays at Kentucky, the sun splashing down, the smell of barbecue wafting in the autumn air.

headline: Roethlisberger’s Conduct Draws the Ire of Goodell
text: ORLANDO, Fla. — N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell made clear Monday that he was unhappy with the conduct of Steelers quarterback Ben Roethlisberger, who is under police investigation for an alleged sexual assault of a 20-year-old college student in a Georgia bar. Goodell said he had spoken to the Rooney family, the team owners, and planned to speak with Roethlisberger, who has not been charged.

headline: Duke’s Zoubek Breaks Out at the Conclusion of a Checkered Career
text: Brian Zoubek, Duke’s 7-foot-1 center, spent his first three and a half years there dealing with foot injuries that sent his college career onto a path of unfulfilled promise. He had scored more than 2,000 points at Haddonfield (N.J.) Memorial High School and was ranked the 24th-best recruit by Rivals.com.

headline: Drivers Pursue Excitement in the Hard Reality of Winter
text: MILTON, N.H. — To Joe Belanger, racing cars on asphalt is simply something to do until the ponds freeze over.

headline: Election Looming, Tories Put Posh Foot in Mouth
text: LONDON — What could be more embarrassing for a party trying to change its elitist image than the existence of someone like Sir Nicholas Winterton? A Conservative member of Parliament for the last 39 years, Sir Nicholas wandered disastrously off message recently when he decided to share his thoughts on why legislators should be allowed to travel first class to avoid exposure to the common man.

headline: Acorn to Shut All Its Offices by April 1
text: The community organizing group Acorn announced Monday that it would close all its remaining state affiliates and field offices by April 1.

headline: Nine to Know: Jorge Posada and Yankee Catchers
text: Bill Chuck created Billy-Ball.com and is a co-author of Walkoffs, Last Licks, and Final Outs. He grew up in New York and now lives with his wife (a Red Sox fan), and daughter (a Yankees fan), two miles from Fenway Park while Bill claims to be Switzerland. His other daughter lives in New York City, away from the fray. You can follow him on Twitter.

headline: In Your Pocket
text: Now that we’ve passed the midpoint of the spring training season, in all camps there is a hole in the calendar. This hole is a rare jewel in the world of major league baseball: a day off from the grind in the land of fun and sun (Arizona or Florida). And a day off could be just what the doctor ordered.

headline: Now Screening | ‘Everybody Knows This Is Nowhere’
text: Last Thursday’s opening for the new Ryan McGinley show at Team Gallery in SoHo was as oversubscribed as it was over-the-top. But in case you missed the art-world mob scene, which ended with The Man closing down the event, T gave out 10 cameras to a bunch of different New York creatives for this exclusive video from the evening, including the dinner and after-party at Indochine. Open bar’s on us!

headline: N.Y.U. Plans to Expand Campuses by 40 Percent
text: New York University is proposing the largest expansion in its history, with a new tower on Bleecker Street and three million square feet of new classrooms, dormitories and offices in the Greenwich Village area. The plans also call for creating a new engineering school in Brooklyn and a satellite campus on Governors Island, complete with dorms and faculty housing.

headline: 2 Airlines Reach Deal to Give Up Flight Slots
text: Delta Air Lines and US Airways said Monday that they had agreed to give up 20 pairs of takeoff and landing rights at La Guardia Airport and Ronald Reagan National Airport in Washington to gain federal approval for a larger exchange of those rights between the two airlines.

headline: The Democrats Rejoice
text: Parties come to embody causes. For the past 90 years or so, the Republican Party has, at its best, come to embody the cause of personal freedom and economic dynamism. For a similar period, the Democratic Party has, at its best, come to embody the cause of fairness and family security. Over the past century, they have built a welfare system, brick by brick, to guard against the injuries of fate.

headline: From Russia, With Love
text: "The Soviet-born singer and pianist Regina Spektor, from the Bronx, sings obtuse but plaintive folk songs about love and truth," writes Amanda Petrusich. "Ms. Spektor's wit and wobbly, entrancing vocals transcend the work of many of her anti-folk peers." Go listen to Ms. Spektor tonight. She'll be at Fillmore New York at Irving Plaza at 8 p.m.

headline: Tharp on Sinatra
text: There are only two more days left to see "Come Fly Away" before it officially opens at the Marquis Theater on Thursday. Ol' Blue Eyes is the musical inspiration for the latest Broadway production from the choreographer Twyla Tharp, who previously took on Billy Joel, ("Movin' Out") and Bob Dylan ("The Times They Are A-Changin.") Her latest show, about four couples in various stages of love, features original master recordings of Sinatra's voice, a live band and some big names from the dance world, including Holley Farmer, an alumna of the Merce Cunningham Dance Company. Go now, when the dancers are at their most energetic.

headline: Asia Comes to New York
text: It's Asia Week, "a once-a-year flowering of art at Manhattan auction houses, fairs, galleries and museums," writes Karen Rosenberg. Today, take advantage of the offerings first by checking out one of the many related exhibits, like "Humor in Japanese Art," which showcases satirical paintings, prints and sculpture at the Ukrainian Institute of America, or "Pilgrimage and Buddhist Art," at the Asia Society and Museum, which "explores a tradition that dates from the first century A.D.: journeying to the sites of major events of the Buddha's life. It will include ritual objects and travel accessories, like reliquaries and prayer wheels, that have never been seen in public." The show will help prepare you for "The Buddha," a new documentary that will be shown on PBS on April 7. The film by David Grubin is narrated by Richard Gere and features interviews with the Dalai Lama and notable Buddhists like the poets W. S. Merwin and Jane Hirshfield, as well as Robert Thurman and others.

headline: The Mets’ Setup Role Still Needs Setting Up
text: VIERA, Fla. — Since the first few days of spring training, Mets Manager Jerry Manuel said his biggest concern was finding an eighth-inning setup man. But with less than two weeks before opening day, Manuel still does not know which pitcher or pitchers will fill that critical role.

headline: Big Clients Keep Their Head Start
text: Wall Street hates a level playing field. What it loves is an edge, an inside track, that extra something — especially when it comes to information that moves markets.

headline: A Tent City
text: Home to at least 44,000 displaced people, the Petionville Country Club in Haiti offers a portrait of entrenched transience.

headline: U.S. Proposals for Taxes on Banks to Cover the Bailouts Gain Ground in Europe
text: PARIS — President Obama’s proposal for a direct tax on banks to cover the cost of the financial bailout is gaining support in Europe. Germany is set to move ahead with its own levy, and Britain is expected to endorse a similar measure ahead of the Group of 20 meeting next month.

headline: One More Birthday Gift for Sondheim: A Broadway Theater
text: After five decades of critically acclaimed work on Broadway, the composer and lyricist Stephen Sondheim is receiving a rare laurel and one of the few that had not yet come his way: his name on a Broadway theater.

headline: A New Show by Rosie Is Positioned as a Possible Replacement for Oprah’s
text: LOS ANGELES — Rosie O’Donnell’s forthcoming talk show will be squarely positioned as a suitable replacement for Oprah Winfrey, her producers said on Monday, adding a new twist in an effort by local stations to revamp their lineups in a post-Winfrey era.

headline: Casting Vote, and Now Trying to Sell It Back Home
text: QUINCY, Fla. — Irvin D. Newsome, a retired Greyhound bus driver, says he has been voting for Representative Allen Boyd since “as far back as I can remember.” But that will change this November, Mr. Newsome vowed Monday, thanks to the decision by Mr. Boyd, a centrist Democrat, to change positions and support the health care overhaul that passed the House on Sunday night.

headline: For Democrats, a Win Is a Win
text: PASSAGE of the new comprehensive health care reform bill by Congress may not be the “game changer” some joyful Democrats are declaring it to be, but it may at least herald a new game for the 2010 midterm elections.

headline: Russia to Alter System of Penal Colonies
text: VLADIMIR, Russia — In Russian prisons, the inmates are divided into barracks housing a hundred or so men without regard to the severity of their crimes. At night, a guard locks the door and walks away, leaving first-time offenders and people convicted of nonviolent crimes to fend for themselves in a crowd of gang members, hit men and other career criminals.

headline: Turkey’s Governing Party Proposes Changes in the Constitution
text: ISTANBUL — Members of Parliament from Turkey’s religious conservative governing party proposed constitutional changes on Monday that would make it harder to ban political parties and easier to prosecute military officials in civilian courts.

headline: Church Adds More Abuse Cases to Its Inquiry in Germany
text: MUNICH — The investigation into sexual abuse by clergy members in Germany expanded Monday to take in four more priests and two nuns in the Regensburg Diocese in Bavaria after new victims came forward there, the diocese said Monday.

headline: Bloggingheads: Mental Bandwidth Scarcity
text: Glenn Loury, left, of Brown University and Sendhil Mullainathan of Harvard University discuss new social science thinking about poverty.

headline: Rep. Allen Boyd Jr.
text: Second Congressional District of Florida

headline: Nice Address, but Where Is It Really?
text: Too bad Neil Simon stopped with “Lost in Yonkers.” He might have had a fine time giving “Lost in Manhattan” a shot. The comedic potential is certainly there. (Actually, my tastes lean more to the dark humor of Martin McDonagh, but he already has his hands full with Spokane.)

headline: JetBlue to Move West Within Queens, Not South to Orlando
text: If running JetBlue Airways does not work out, perhaps David Barger could try his hand at professional poker.

headline: Taxi Scheme Might Be Smaller Than Commission First Thought
text: The grand New York City taxi fraud may not be as grand as officials first thought.

headline: Officer Shot in the Bronx; Assailant Found Dead
text: A police officer was hit at least three times in a shootout on Monday while responding to a 911 call at a housing project in the South Bronx, but was apparently saved by his bullet-resistant vest, law enforcement officials said.

headline: A Peaceful Refuge in Brooklyn, and All the Noise It Took to Build It
text: It was a soggy morning, but no rain would fall on the parade, the politicians insisted. On this, the long-anticipated official opening day of Brooklyn Bridge Park, no spirit would be dampened — drizzle or no, they said, it was a sunny, sunny day for New York and the world, a celebration of Brooklyn’s present, a harbinger of its future.

headline: State Senate, Trying to Trim Deficit, Offers Budget Plan Cutting $1.4 Billion From Schools
text: ALBANY — School financing, a perennial third rail of state politics, would be cut by $1.4 billion under a plan put forward on Monday by Senate Democrats trying to plug a budget deficit estimated at $9 billion.

headline: After an Injury, Enjoying a Chat in Business Class
text: MY first memory of flying is traveling to Italy when I was about 4 years old. Despite my mother’s efforts to ensure a pleasant flight for all passengers, I was a handful. Why not pull on that older man’s hair? Why not throw my juice across the cabin while screaming at the top of my lungs? I bet if there had been “baby Ambien,” my mother might have tried it on me.

headline: Disability-Claims Inquiry Concluding for L.I.R.R.
text: The Long Island Rail Road will hire an independent examiner to review its safeguards against abuse of the railroad’s disability pension system, under an agreement that all but concludes an 18-month state investigation of the extraordinarily high rate of claims by employees of the commuter line.

headline: City Reaches $33 Million Settlement Over Strip Searches
text: For the third time in a decade, New York City has agreed to pay millions of dollars to settle a lawsuit stemming from the illegal strip searches of thousands of nonviolent prisoners.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: March 22, 2010

headline: 70 Across: Augusta’s Home
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — Interesting — a giveaway answer that needs to be split into three parts. I like it!

headline: Helping His Clients Look Best in Show
text: Dirty dogs become glamour pusses in the hands of Nicholas Lipariti Jr., 26, a lifelong Brooklynite and recently minted dog groomer. Inspired by his mother, who died of lung cancer in the summer of 2008, Mr. Lipariti pursued his dream of working with animals by enrolling in the American Academy of Pet Grooming last summer. He opened a grooming shop, Paws On!, in Gravesend, Brooklyn, but the sputtering economy forced a quick closing. Now he makes house calls, has a loyal client base and works at Puppy City in Gravesend.

headline: The Case for Ending the Mortgage Deduction
text: Mortgages should be made less attractive. That’s one lesson of the recent housing bubble and bust. As long as borrowing seems like the easy road to riches, people will do too much of it. But right now in the United States, the tax code encourages many people to take out big mortgages. That’s why it’s a good idea to put the elimination of the tax deductibility of mortgage interest on the political agenda.

headline: Critics' Picks: 'Bringing Up Baby'
text: A. O. Scott looks back at Howard Hawks's 1938 screwball comedy "Bringing Up Baby."

headline: Americas Development Bank Forgives Much of Haiti’s Debt
text: MEXICO CITY — Haiti received a boost to its balance sheet on Monday when the Inter-American Development Bank, meeting in the Mexican resort city of Cancún, agreed to forgive $479 million of the country’s $1.2 billion in foreign debt.

headline: Dr. James Black, Pharmacologist Who Discovered Beta Blockers, Dies at 85
text: Dr. James W. Black, a Scottish pharmacologist whose discovery of beta blockers and another class of drugs extended the lives of millions of people with heart and stomach disorders and earned him a Nobel Prize in 1988, died on Sunday. He was 85.

headline:
Republicans Face Drawbacks of United
Stand on Health Bill
text: WASHINGTON — Passage of the health care legislation challenges the heart of the Republicans’ strategy this year: To present a unified opposition to big Democratic ideas, in this case expressed in a stream of bristling anger and occasional mischaracterizations of what the bill would do.

headline: The Ongoing Toll From 9/11
text: A House subcommittee has finally begun moving vital legislation to provide long-term health care and compensation for thousands of emergency responders, volunteers and community residents left seriously sickened after the World Trade Center terrorist attack. The 25-to-8 vote cut across regional lines  an encouraging recognition that the 9/11 attack was an assault on the nation and that its victims still need and deserve the nation’s help.

headline: An Absence of Class
text: Some of the images from the run-up to Sunday’s landmark health care vote in the House of Representatives should be seared into the nation’s consciousness. We are so far, in so many ways, from being a class act.

headline: To Transform Health Care in America
text: To the Editor:

text: To the Editor:

text: Berlin

headline: Real Reform in an Election Year
text: The White House and Democratic leaders in Congress won’t have much time to savor their victory on health care reform if they hope to achieve the next big goal: enacting financial regulatory reform before the midterm elections. A year and a half after the country’s banking system nearly imploded, it is still operating under the same inadequate rules and regulations.

headline: Two Rallies
text: A few hundred Tea Party-types clustered on the south end of the Capitol on Sunday, trying to kill health care reform, fouling the crisp spring air with shouts of violence and loathing.

headline: European Disunion
text: A few weeks ago, a solution to Greece’s debt problems seemed close. The Greeks did their part by adopting a tough new austerity program earlier this month. But Europe has not followed through with the needed guarantee that the money Greece must borrow to pay its bills will be safe from default.

headline: Corrections
text: Several articles since September about the troubles of the community organizing group Acorn referred incorrectly or imprecisely to one aspect of videotaped encounters between Acorn workers and two conservative activists that contributed to the group’s problems.

headline: Continuity Pays Off as Twins Keep Mauer
text: FORT MYERS, Fla. — The pen Joe Mauer used to sign his eight-year, $184 million contract here Monday belongs to Joel Lepel, the minor league field coordinator for the Minnesota Twins. Lepel was born and raised in Plato, Minn., and has worked for the Twins for 21 years, mostly as a scout. All of the amateur players he has signed, including Mauer, have used the same pen.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,011 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

headline: Corrections
text: A report in the Prescriptions column on Saturday about a provision of the health-care legislation misstated the age at which adult children would be no longer be covered under their parents’ insurance plans. It is 26, not 27.

headline: Next Big Issue? Social Security Pops Up Again
text: WASHINGTON — Now that landmark legislation overhauling the health insurance system is about to become law, addressing Social Security’s solvency could well become the next big thing for President Obama and Congressional Democrats.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Wednesday about the resignation of the principal of the city’s only Arabic-language school, the Khalil Gibran International Academy, referred incorrectly to an interview that the school’s founding principal, Debbie Almontaser, gave to The New York Post following a controversy over T-shirts with the slogan “Intifada NYC” that were being sold by an Arab women’s group. Ms. Almontaser, who resigned in 2007 shortly after the interview, said she had been pressured by the Department of Education to grant the interview  not to talk about the shirts specifically. (The department denies pressuring Ms. Almontaser to grant the interview.) Because of an editing error, the article and a picture caption gave an outdated location for the school. It is in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, and no longer in Boerum Hill.

headline: Corrections
text: The Sports of The Times column on Wednesday, about Tiger Woods’s decision to resume his golf career at the Augusta National Golf Club in Georgia, where the Masters is held, misstated the history of the club’s membership rules in some editions. After years of pressure, the club eventually opened its membership to African-Americans, but not to women.

headline: Corrections
text: A music column on March 15 about the Scion Rock Fest in Columbus, Ohio, where the Oregon-based band Yob played, misidentified the site of the club Rothko, where Yob played when it last came to New York, in 2005. The club, now closed, was on the Lower East Side, not in Brooklyn.

headline: Corrections
text: A review in the “Art in Review” column on Friday about the Aipad Photography Show New York, at the Park Avenue Armory, misspelled the surname of a photographer who has an electronically animated self-portrait in the show. She is Shirley Shor, not Shore.

headline: Lessons for the Democrats, Some Perhaps Cautionary, After a Signal Triumph
text: WASHINGTON — Among the many lessons Democrats have learned from President Obama’s 14-month slog through the nation’s vitriolic health care debate is that there are two ways for a president to do business in hyperpartisan Washington. One is to go small, and partner across the aisle. The other is to go big, and go it alone.

headline: Corrections
text: EDITORS' NOTE

headline: India’s Woes Reflected in Bid to Restart Old Plant
text: VELDUR, India — “Wherever there is a lamp, there is darkness below it,” said Bava Bhalekar, a fisherman and local leader in this village roughly a hundred miles south of Mumbai. “The tragedy is that while our village has this project, we ourselves don’t have electricity.”

headline: Health Measure’s Opponents Plan Legal Challenges
text: Officials in a dozen states who oppose the health care bill say they hope to block it in court by arguing that requiring people to buy health insurance is an unprecedented intrusion by the federal government into people’s lives — the equivalent of going a step beyond simply regulating automobiles to requiring people to buy a car.

headline: Stimulus Plan for Rail Line Shows System of Weak Links
text: TAMPA — The drive from Orlando to Tampa takes only 90 minutes or so. Despite the short distance, the Obama administration awarded Florida $1.25 billion in stimulus money to link the cities with a fast train to help kick off its efforts to bring high-speed rail service to the United States.

headline: F.D.A. Asks Pediatricians to Stop Using a Diarrhea Vaccine for Now
text: WASHINGTON — Federal drug regulators on Monday asked the nation’s pediatricians to stop giving children a diarrhea vaccine until federal scientists can figure out why the product contains apparently harmless but extraneous pieces of a pig virus.

headline: Justices to Weigh Law on Gaining Citizenship via Parents
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday agreed to decide if mothers and fathers may be treated differently in determining whether their children may claim American citizenship.

headline: Few Fled Companies Constrained by Pay Limits
text: For months, Wall Street banks and the troubled automakers feverishly protested that their top executives would flee if they were not lavishly rewarded for their talents. New data, however, suggests the departures were more of a trickle than a flood.

headline: Ruling Strikes Down Georgia’s Cap on Malpractice Awards
text: ATLANTA — The Georgia Supreme Court ruled Monday that the state legislature may not limit the amount of money that juries award to victims of medical malpractice.

headline: Wolfgang Wagner, Director of Bayreuth, Is Dead at 90
text: Wolfgang Wagner, an opera director and impresario who for more than half a century ran Bayreuth, the international music festival conceived by his grandfather, Richard Wagner  and known most recently for the dynastic power struggle that was more toweringly operatic than anything the senior Mr. Wagner could have written  died on Sunday in Bayreuth, in southern Germany. He was 90.

headline: Massachusetts: Ex-Customs Official Faces Jail Over Household Help
text: A former official with the Department of Homeland Security, Customs and Border Protection was convicted Monday of encouraging her housekeeper to stay in the country illegally. Lorraine Henderson, 52, of Salem, oversaw immigration enforcement at airports and other international points of entry in three states until she was suspended because of the charges in 2008. According to the United States Attorney’s Office, Ms. Henderson was warned in 2006 that the housekeeper was in the country illegally, and ignored a colleague’s warning that she should fire her. Ms. Henderson faces up to five years in prison, three years’ probation and a $250,000 fine. Sentencing is June 17.

headline: Robert M. White, Who Broke Limits in Flight, Dies at 85
text: Robert M. White, who played an important role in the development of manned spaceflight as the first pilot to fly a winged craft into outer space, died Wednesday in Orlando, Fla. He was 85.

headline: "Get Jersey Shored" by MTV
text: MTV is promoting the Jersey Shore lifestyle in a series of commercials called "Get Jersey Shored."

headline: "Get Jersey Shored" by MTV
text: MTV is promoting the Jersey Shore lifestyle in a series of commercials called "Get Jersey Shored."

headline: Betting the Situation Will Not Get Lost in Translation
text: THE Jersey Shore is about to be exported.

headline: Word of the Day | anthem
text: anthem •\ˈan(t)-thəm\• noun

headline: Theater to Be Named in Honor of Sondheim
text: After five decades of critically acclaimed work on Broadway, the composer and lyricist Stephen Sondheim, below, is receiving a rare laurel and one of the few that had not yet come his way: his name on a Broadway theater. At a gala performance on Monday night of the new Broadway musical “Sondheim on Sondheim,” the director James Lapine and the musical book writer John Weidman were to announce that Henry Miller’s Theater, which re-opened on Broadway last fall after a nearly complete overhaul, would be renamed the Stephen Sondheim Theater. According to a statement by Mr. Lapine and Mr. Weidman, a small group of “Stephen Sondheim devotees” contributed to the Roundabout Theater Company’s musical production fund to rededicate the theater in Mr. Sondheim’s honor. (Neither a list of donors nor the precise sum was disclosed.) Roundabout has a long-term lease to operate and oversee programming for this 1,055-seat theater, on West 43rd Street between Broadway and Avenue of the Americas. Roundabout has produced several of Mr. Sondheim’s works, including “Assassins” and “Pacific Overtures.” Mr. Sondheim, who turned 80 on Monday, has won an Academy Award, several Tony and Grammy awards, and the Pulitzer Prize for drama.

headline: News Quiz | March 23, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page.

headline: Big Clients Keep Their Head Start
text: Here’s what happened: A while ago, a group of banks sued a Web site called theflyonthewall.com to prevent the site from publishing news headlines about their stock upgrades and downgrades. Last week, Judge Denise Cote, of the United States District Court in New York, ruled in favor of the banks. The decision could have big implications for who gets Wall Street’s hottest tips, and when, The New York Times’s Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in his latest DealBook column.

headline: The 411 on SXSW
text: WHO are playing at the South by Southwest Music and Media Conference? WHO is pictured performing in the photo above?

headline: Few Fled the Companies Constrained by Pay Limits
text: For months, Wall Street banks and the troubled automakers feverishly protested that their top executives would flee if they were not lavishly rewarded for their talents. New data, however, suggests the departures were more of a trickle than a flood, Eric Dash reports in The New York Times.

headline: Its Star Shaky, Baylor Turns to Supporting Cast
text: BERKELEY, Calif. — Baylor’s freshman center Brittney Griner blocked 14 shots Monday night — an N.C.A.A. women’s tournament record — but the first person that Coach Kim Mulkey hugged in victory was a junior guard, Melissa Jones.

headline: Time Warner Said to Lead MGM Bids Over $1 Billion
text: Time Warner, Lions Gate Entertainment and billionaire Len Blavatnik’s Access Industries put up rival bids of $1.2 billion to $1.5 billion for studio Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, sources familiar with the matter told Reuters on Monday.

headline: Phillips-Van Heusen Profit Beats Quarter’s Forecasts
text: Phillips-Van Heusen, the apparel maker, posted earnings that beat Wall Street expectations, boosted by the strength of its Calvin Klein brand around the world, Reuters reported.

headline: MtyMx Music Festival
text: An ambitious undertaking collected small- and medium-size indie-rock bands and planted them on a little-used stretch of land for three days in Monterrey, Mexico.

headline: Somaxon to Launch Offering to Fund Drug Plan
text: Just days after receiving Food and Drug Administration approval for Silenor, biotech company Somaxon Pharmaceuticals made plans to sell four million shares to pay for marketing  the insomnia drug, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Corrections
text: An obituary on Thursday about Wayne Collett, an American runner who was barred from competing again in Olympic competition after he was judged to have acted disrespectfully during a medal ceremony in Munich in 1972, misspelled the given name and surname of the sports information director at the University of California, Los Angeles, where Collett had been a track and field star. He is Marc Dellins, not Mark Dellims.

headline: Editors’ Note
text: The Paul Krugman column on Monday, about the health care bill, quoted Newt Gingrich as saying that “Lyndon Johnson shattered the Democratic Party for 40 years” by passing civil rights legislation. The quotation originally appeared in The Washington Post, which reported after the column went to press that Mr. Gingrich said it referred to Johnson’s Great Society policies, not to the 1964 Civil Rights Act.

headline: Four Suspended From Labour Party in U.K. Scandal
text: LONDON — Caught by concealed cameras as they offered to trade influence for cash, three former government ministers have been suspended from Prime Minister Gordon Brown’s Labour Party, setting off a new political furor Tuesday as Britain edges toward elections.

headline: Icahn Raises Stake in Take Two
text: Carl C. Icahn, the activist investor, has again added to his stake in Take Two Interactive Software, upping his bet in the struggling video game publisher, Reuters reported.
