text: Lebanon’s cosmopolitan capital is finally getting its groove back.

headline: First Interstate Revs Up for $130 Million I.P.O.
text: First Interstate BancSystem, a bank holding company, is expected to raise about $130 million in an initial public offering on the Nasdaq Stock Market this week, The Associated Press reported.

headline: E*Trade: Deal or No Deal?
text: Analysts appeared divided Monday on what the appointment of a new chief at E*Trade Financial meant for the takeover speculation that has been swirling around the company for some time.

headline: Zale Said to Mull Deal With Sun Capital
text: Zale, which expected to have secured funds to steady its finances by late May, is considering a financing proposal from Sun Capital Partners, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: Capturing the Elusive Bill Cunningham
text: Bill Cunningham is probably the most honest photojournalist in New York. But he can also be pretty deceptive.

headline: Opera Mini Browser, Coming to an iPhone Near You
text: Opera Software on Tuesday announced that it is submitting its Opera Mini Web browser to Apple for use on the iPhone.

headline: Do You Support or Oppose the Health Care Reform Bill?
text: On Sunday night, after a year of wrangling, the House of Representatives voted along party lines to approve health care reform legislation. What do you think of the bill? What do you think of the partisanship reflected in the vote? What questions do you have?

headline: Brink’s Sets Date for Vote on Sale to Tyco
text: Brink’s Home Security Holdings said Monday its shareholders will vote May 12 on the company’s plan to sell itself to Tyco International, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Babcock and VT Recommend $2 Billion Deal
text: Babcock International of Britain, a company involved in ship-building and nuclear power, said Tuesday that it had  agreed with the board of VT, a defense services firm, on the terms of a takeover bid worth £1.33 billion.

headline: Legg Mason’s Miller Likes Health Care Stocks
text: Legg Mason‘s Bill Miller, a celebrated value investor, thinks cheap health care stocks should perform well in the next few months now that legislative uncertainty about reform in the sector has been removed, Reuters reported.

headline: Human-Flesh Search Engines
text: Chinese vigilantes who seek vengeance via the Net.

headline: Regulators Prod L.B. Foster’s Portec Deal
text: L.B. Foster, which makes rail and construction products, said Monday it has received a second request for information from U.S. antitrust regulators regarding its proposed acquisition of Portec Rail Products, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Muller Says Saab Could List Within a Year
text: Victor Muller, chief executive of Spyker Cars, the Dutch sports car maker that arranged to buy Saab from General Motors this year, said he hoped to list the company within a year, a Swedish newspaper reported Tuesday.

headline: State of the Colts: What the 2009 Film Revealed
text: Offense

headline: Handling Holy Week in Rome
text: During Holy Week, multitudes descend on the Vatican, and therefore Rome. Beginning on Palm Sunday (March 28) and continuing until Easter Sunday (April 4), the already numerous springtime visitors will be joined by tens of thousands of pilgrims, eager to participate in the liturgical calendar’s most important events. Crowds at St. Peter’s Basilica and the adjacent Vatican Museums are inevitable, but with a bit of planning, avoiding the throngs is possible.

headline: Judge Orders Talks in Yellowstone Club Case
text: A U.S. bankruptcy judge has ordered three days of settlement talks in May for the tangle of legal claims arising from the bankruptcy of the ultra-exclusive Yellowstone Club, The Associated Press reported.

headline: U.S. Detainee in North Korea Was a Teacher
text: SEOUL, South Korea — An American citizen facing trial in North Korea for entering the country illegally is a Christian who taught English at a South Korean primary school, former colleagues said Tuesday.

headline: Berkshire Buys Beer and Wine Distributor
text: Berkshire Hathaway announced late Monday that McLane, its subsidiary, had struck a deal to acquire Kahn Ventures, which distributes wine, beer and spirits in Georgia and North Carolina. The company did not disclose how much it had agreed to pay.

headline: The Context of Content
text: Today’s idea: It’s not just content but increasingly its technological context that shapes how books, music and movies are experienced, a blogger says. And amateur online reviewers are ahead of the curve in recognizing this.

headline: Dai-Ichi Life Raises $11 Billion in I.P.O.
text: Dai-ichi Mutual Life Insurance, Japan’s second-largest life insurer, is set to raise 1.01 trillion yen ($11 billion) after it priced the shares for its initial public offering at $1,553, in the middle of a tentative price range, according to news media  reports.

headline: Icahn to Push for Sale of Biogen, Report Says
text: Fresh from winning a deal with Biogen Idec to add a director to the biotechnology company’s board, Carl C. Icahn has once again turned his attention to the notion of selling off the firm, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Pragmatic Libertarians
text: Edward L. Glaeser is an economics professor at Harvard.

headline: Google Faces Fallout as China Reacts  to Site Shift
text: Google pushed. Now China is pushing back.

headline: Toshiba Eyes Nuclear Alliance With Gates Start-Up
text: Toshiba is in talks with a start-up backed by Microsoft chief Bill Gates to jointly develop advanced nuclear reactors, the Japanese electronics maker said Tuesday, helping send its shares higher, Reuters reported.

headline: Will Ellison Go To the Boards for the Warriors?
text: Now that the Golden State Warriors have hung out the for-sale sign, will Oracle chief Larry Ellison make his move on the N.B.A. team?

headline: Speed Read for Tuesday, March 23
text: Here are some highlights from Tuesday’s editions of The New York Times:

headline: New York Auto Show Preview: Camp Jeep Is Back
text: For those off-road enthusiasts who’ve missed the theme park atmosphere of Camp Jeep at the New York auto show, the news is good: the portable mountains, the fake fallen logs and the steep wedges will return to the Jacob Javits Center for this year’s show.

headline: Sampler: Smoking May Be Banned on Beaches, and School-Time Curfew Proposed in Richmond
text: California to Consider Smoking Ban on Beaches | Smoking on 64 state beaches and 278 parks may be banned if California lawmakers sign a smoking bill into law. Violators will receive a $100 fine. Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger has not said he will sign the bill, which faces one more vote in the State Senate. But enforcement could be difficult, because the parks system has no money for additional staffing or warning signs, said Roy Stearns, a spokesman for the state parks system. [The San Francisco Chronicle]

headline: Investors’ ‘Wish List’  Said to Anger P.E. Firms
text: A trade group representing private equity investors has fired a shot across the bow of the industry, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: State-Run Bank in Athens Won Big With C.D.S.’s
text: Hellenic Post Bank, a lender controlled by the Greek state, bought about 950 million euros worth of credit default swaps, insuring itself against the nation’s sovereign debt, according to documents seen by Kathimerini, a major Greek daily.

headline: At Rio Tinto Trial in China, Door Closes Tighter
text: SHANGHAI — Prosecutors argued for a second day in court that four employees from the British-Australian mining giant Rio Tinto accepted millions of dollars in bribes and stole commercial secrets from Chinese companies, but the closed nature of the trial made it difficult to assess the nature of the evidence they presented in the high-profile case.

headline: British Investor Group Takes Issue With Bank Fees
text: An influential group of of institutional investors in Britain is calling for a re-examination of the advisory fees paid to investments banks in mergers and acquisitions, arguing that in some cases they may be influencing the outcome of takeovers, The Financial Times reported.

headline: A Bit About ‘That’
text: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style.

text: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style.

text: Q.

headline: Today in Business Travel
text: U.S. Set to Expand Role in Protecting Air TravelersNew rules protecting fliers, including a requirement that passengers be allowed to leave planes stuck on the tarmac more than three hours, will take effect April 29.

headline: Dubai Chefs Find Alcohol Ban Distasteful
text: The Dubai authorities plan to step up enforcement of a law enacted in 2003 prohibiting restaurants from using alcohol in food preparation, according to media reports.

headline: Obama Family Takes in ‘Addams Family’
text: So the Obamas are fierce for Broadway this week: After taking in “Memphis” on Sunday afternoon, Michelle Obama, her two daughters, Sasha and Malia, and her mother, Marian Robinson, attended another new musical on Monday night: “The Addams Family.”

headline: In Response to California Fuel Regulation, Cargo Ships Chart More Precarious Routes
text: In an apparent effort to skirt a new clean-fuel regulation in California, an increasing number of ships traveling to and from one of the nation’s busiest port complexes — at Los Angeles and Long Beach — are abandoning a long-established shipping lane, choosing instead to travel along a riskier route that traverses a Navy weapons testing and training area.

headline: Senate Democrats Urge School Spending Cuts
text: State Senate Democrats put forward a plan on Monday that would cut school financing by $1.4 billion to try to plug a budget deficit estimated at $9 billion.

headline: Wall Street Gets a Little Momentum
text: Investors snapped up industrial and materials stocks on Tuesday, helping the Dow soar to a 18-month high.

headline: Volkswagen to Issue $6 Billion in Preferred Shares
text: Volkswagen said Tuesday that it would offer 65 million new shares in an issue that would increase its capital by about 4.5 billion euros ($6 billion).

headline: The Early Word: How a Bill Becomes a Law
text: The prospects looked dicey more than a time or two, but President Obama signs into law this morning the health care overhaul that has consumed debate in Washington for months.

headline: Breaking Even Worse: Aaron Paul in The ‘Weird Al’ Yankovic Story
text: In a recent interview, Aaron Paul, an Emmy-nominated star of “Breaking Bad,” told me he had been searching high and low for his next role, one that wouldn’t pigeonhole him as the lovable drug dealer he plays on that AMC series. (“In other words,” he said, “yes, I’m definitely unemployed.”)

headline: Lions Gate Rejects Latest Icahn Offer
text: Lions Gate Entertainment said Tuesday that its board had voted unanimously to reject the tender offer made by Carl C. Icahn to buy the company for $6 a share. Lions Gate previously rejected Mr. Icahn’s bid to raise his stake to 30 percent, and it called the latest offer, for the entire company, “financially inadequate and coercive.”

headline: Inside Out | New York in Bloom
text: Rita Konig is a decorator based in New York who has written about style for British Vogue, The Telegraph and Domino.

headline: Why Virtual Nerd Declined a $70,000 Competition Prize
text: It’s hard to imagine a scrappy start-up entering a prestigious business plan competition, working hard to advance, winning the competition — and then walking away from a $70,000 investment prize. But that’s exactly what Virtual Nerd did after winning the 2008-9 Olin Cup competition at Washington University in St. Louis.

headline: Ice Racing Fill-In
text: Fill in the missing words in this article from the Sports section about ice racing.

headline: The Order That Changed Everything
text: If there was a single event that guaranteed Democrats the 216 votes they needed to adopt major health care legislation, it was the agreement that President Obama would issue an executive order clarifying federal policy banning the use of taxpayer money for abortions.

headline: Christian Science Church Seeks Truce With Modern Medicine
text: Since the founding of their church 131 years ago, Christian Scientists have been taught to avoid doctors at all cost. It is a conviction rooted so deeply in church dogma that dozens of members have endured criminal prosecution rather than surrender an ailing person to what they see as the quackery of medical science.

headline: Hill vs. Jennings, Redux
text: For a player with a brief résumé and no history of mischief-making, Jordan Hill generates an impressive amount of controversy and consternation.

headline: Body Found After Brooklyn Fire
text: Firefighters at the scene of a three-alarm fire in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, early Tuesday found the body of a man behind a house, the Fire Department said. No cause of death was immediately available. Eight firefighters sustained minor injuries in the blaze, which began around 1:20 a.m. on 56th Street between Third and Fourth Avenues and engulfed three connected wood frame homes.

headline: More Sellers Put Homes on Market, but There Are Fewer Buyers
text: The volume of home sales is slumping even as the number of properties on the market is rising, which is putting new pressure on prices, according to economic data released Tuesday.

headline: Ex-Nazi Guilty in Wartime Murders
text: BERLIN — As German authorities pursue suspected Nazi war criminals to the last, a court in Aachen convicted an 88-year-old former SS soldier on Tuesday on charges of killing three Dutch civilians in reprisal for attacks by Dutch resistance fighters in 1944.

headline: Tuesday Reading
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: ‘Calling It Armageddon’
text: Monologue |  Monday night on “Jimmy Kimmel Live” on ABC: President Obama won one of the great — they’re calling it — the “great legislative victories of the last 50 years” last night. He won health care reform approval to extend coverage to millions of uninsured Americans, or as the Republicans are calling it “Armageddon.” Personally, I think it’s great. Maybe now, I can finally get a gynecologist to see me.

headline: Columbia, Michigan and Connecticut Among 25 Colleges to Add Common Application
text: Students applying to Columbia, the University of Michigan, the University of Connecticut and 22 other institutions in the next admissions season will, for the first time, be able to use the Common Application.

headline: ‘They Got a Little Rowdy’
text: Monologue |  Monday night on “The Late Show With David Letterman” on CBS: Yesterday in Washington, D.C., history was made. Congress actually worked on a Sunday.

headline: New Rosie O’Donnell Show Aims for Winfrey Timeslots (and Audience)
text: Rosie O’Donnell’s forthcoming talk show will be squarely positioned as a suitable replacement for Oprah Winfrey, her producers said on Monday, adding a new twist in an effort by local stations to revamp their lineups in a post-Winfrey era.

headline: ‘Some of Those Other Perks’

headline: The Originals | Henry Conway
text: Henry Conway stepped into the British consciousness out of a white horse-drawn carriage, dressed like Beau Brummel, completely upstaging Paris Hilton (whose party it was supposed to be). The fact that he had been involved in a financial scandal that cost his Tory father his seat as a member of Parliament made the tabloids apt to pay attention: London’s Evening Standard gave the picture its front page. But as Conway, 27, himself observed in a different context in his fashion column for SuperSuper magazine, “Where there’s muck, there’s brass.” After dark, the event promoter socializes with the likes of Princes William and Harry at his Thursday-night wheeze at Mayfair’s hip Mahiki Club. And he will soon debut a Friday party cheekily called Royal Jelly at Bungalow 8. He is also the co-author of a book on the history of knitwear and appears as a fashion expert on highbrow arts programs like the BBC’s “Newsnight Review.” “I am a slightly old-school cultural commentator,” Conway says over the phone from London, not before mentioning he’s just had an appointment with “Victoria Beckham’s facialist.” But he doesn’t see a conflict between his roles as budding public intellectual and private party host. “I think you do have to experience life to be able to judge it and pass judgment on it.”

headline: Caesarean Births Are at a High in U.S.

headline: Alexie Wins PEN/Faulkner Fiction Prize
text: Sherman Alexie was named the winner of the PEN/Faulkner Award for Fiction on Tuesday for “War Dances,” a collection of stories and poems. Mr. Alexie’s book, along with books by the other finalists, Barbara Kingsolver, Lorraine M. López, Lorrie Moore and Colson Whitehead, was selected from about 350 novels and short story collections published by American authors in 2009. Mr. Alexie, who also won the National Book Award for Young People’s Literature in 2007 for “The Absolutely True Diary of a Part-Time Indian,” will receive $15,000 from the PEN/Faulkner Foundation.

So go now, while it’s still all about renting a little chalet of your own. And yes, there’s still tons of snow: ski season ends in late April.

Rehired after the State Supreme Court has ruled the oath requirement unconstitutional, Mr. Muscatine later helped mediate the warring forces in the days of the Free Speech Movement in the mid-1960s.

headline: Palermo Privata
text: It sits on the north shore of Sicily on a fan-shaped stretch of land between two towering stone promontories, and it’s been there, in one form or another, for almost 3,000 years. Empire after empire has trodden upon the place: Greeks, Phoenicians, Carthaginians, Romans; then Vandals, Normans, Moors, Spaniards; then Italians, the United States Army; and since the end of World War II, Cosa Nostra, whose influence over the place is only recently waning. For millennia it’s been built up and knocked down, robbed and bombed, patched up and left to fend for itself. So it is a spectral city, a city of ghosts and ruins, amid which the living citizens slip quietly and for the most part without expression; an inward city, not unkind but very private — Italia insulare, as they call it. Palermo can be very beautiful, in a decaying, Hubert Robert way; on sunny days the sky overhead is Mediterranean enamel blue; the food is wondrous. But above all, Palermo is full of secrets and very strange.

headline: Palermo Privata
text: An insular city full of art and ruins reveals quiet wonders around every piazza.

headline: ‘The Reality of Reform': Understanding the Health Care Law
text: Overview | How will health care reform change life and politics in the United States? What does the new law mean for individuals, families, businesses and insurers, as well as for politics and government leaders? In this lesson, students gauge their background knowledge of the health care reform act and take a close look at the legislation to clarify their understanding. They then execute a project on historical context, local reaction and/or the key players, and finish by creating collages of images and quotations that illuminate the issues.

headline: Pop’s Hair Apparent | Justin Bieber
text: Despite recent attempts to assume the vacant King of Pop throne (most notably by the members of the House of Jonas), it’s been a bleak interregnum. But a Justin Bieber-led restoration may soon be on the cards. As the impish prince of teen idolatry, Bieber — the 16-year-old YouTube breakout star turned bona fide pop royalty — has captured the popular imagination, sending teenage girls (real and honorary) into paroxysms of passion and mall-security guards into nervous fits every time he makes a public appearance. T paid court to Bieber, whose eagerly awaited new album, “My World 2.0,” is out today.

headline: Off Sardinia, an Island With Wilder Shores
text: IT was half an hour after sunset in Sant’Antioco, one of the most undeveloped corners of Sardinia, and we were lost. I had driven out of the ancient Ligurian fishing port of Calasetta minutes earlier, following a strip of asphalt that dipped and rose through empty grassland and Mediterranean scrub. Quickly, the paved road leading south along the sea petered out, and my two sons and I found ourselves on a dirt path barely wide enough for our car.

headline: With This View, Who Needs Legroom?
text: WINDOW seat or aisle? Ever since I was a small child, there’s been only one answer. Sure, the aisle is a bit roomier, and it’s easier to get up to stretch your legs. But for me, it’s all about the views, especially those entrancing last few minutes before touchdown.

headline: Book Review: The Lunatic Express
text: Anyone who has ever griped about freeway traffic or being elbowed on the subway should spend some time with the journalist Carl Hoffman’s book. The majority of humankind, it is sobering to remember, has little choice in modes of transportation as they commute to work, and every day an alarming percentage don’t make it home.

headline: In Brazil: Unspoiled Beach Fit for the Chic
text: THE sun was blazing at the Tostex beach club in Bahia, Brazil, and the tanned and toned partygoers were lounging on rustic queen-size beds, fighting off the unrelenting mosquitoes on an otherwise lazy day. A scruffy D.J. from São Paulo who went by the name Julião swayed in his thatch-roofed booth and cranked up a funky remix of Laurent Garnier’s saxophone-infused song “The Man With the Red Face.”

headline: Silent Days on the Sea in Venezuela
text: THE stereo died with a wheeze, the lights clicked out, and suddenly there was only darkness and the sound of the wind rustling through palm trees. The air was soft and warm, fluid against the skin. Stars began to rise against the inky blackness around them. The moon poured down.

headline: Pasta With Broccoli and Chickpeas

headline: In Spring, the Vituperation Blooms
text: Since the early days of cycling, drivers of four-wheeled vehicles and others have complained about sharing the road with their two-wheeled brethren. Then as now, these complaints occasionally grew into demonization — literally, in the case of one 1893 depiction of a bike rider terrorizing traffic as a frog-faced “demon of the wheel.”

Among those who joined him around the desk were 11-year-old Marcelas Owens of Seattle, who became an advocate for health care reform after his mother died without health insurance.

headline: In Baghdad, the Crime Scene Team
text: BAGHDAD — In the aftermath of a roadside bomb on Monday, the gray-uniformed members of the Iraqi police forensic unit known as the Crime Scene Team — a “CSI Baghdad,” of sorts — were on the job. The bomb, which went off during the morning rush in one of Baghdad’s busiest squares, was planted at the foot of a newly built blast wall outside of a bank. The wall directed the blast out into the highway just as a convoy was passing, shopkeepers said. Iraqi medical officials reported several people injured, but no one was killed.

headline: ‘Dancing’ to a Record
text: With a cast of competitors including Kate Gosselin, Buzz Aldrin and Pamela Anderson, the new season of ABC’s “Dancing With the Stars” broke a series record and averaged 23.9 million viewers on Monday night, according to Nielsen’s estimates. That was up by more than a million compared with the season premiere a year ago. The ABC crime series “Castle” benefited from the strong showing, leading the 10 p.m. hour with 12.9 million viewers, also its largest audience ever. The two shows combined to give ABC the most Monday-night viewers it has had in more than nine years. CBS was second, drawing its best ratings for “Two and a Half Men” (14.4 million) and “The Big Bang Theory” (13.4 million). Fox finished in third, and NBC fourth.

headline: Classical Music Station to Rely on Listeners
text: KING-FM, a longtime classical music station in Seattle, announced on Tuesday that it would switch to a listener-supported public model in the summer of 2011. The board that oversees the station, which operates as part of a nonprofit organization, had been studying possible changes for a couple of years. The move continues a decade-long trend among classical stations. Last year, WQXR in New York and WCRB in Boston were sold to public radio operators. (WQXR was sold by The New York Times Company.) Besides KING-FM, there are only 18 commercial classical radio stations in the United States. Marc Hand, an industry consultant at Public Radio Capital, said classical stations tended to have older listeners than other formats; those listeners, he said, were less appealing to advertisers but more apt to be the kind of dedicated, passionate supporters who give money to public radio. “I think this move really makes for a station that’s more economically viable,” he said.

headline: The Supersizing of the Last Supper
text: How far back should a study go to show that food portions have increased over time? Ten years? Fifty years? What about all the way back to the Last Supper? A new article in The International Journal of Obesity doesn’t turn the clock back quite that far but looks at nearly a thousand years’ worth of paintings depicting the meal and concludes that the sizes of portions, plates and bread “increased dramatically” over those years. The study, conducted by two brothers  Brian Wansink, a professor of consumer behavior at Cornell and director of the school’s Food and Brand Lab; and Craig Wansink, a professor of religious studies at Virginia Wesleyan College  looks at 52 Last Supper paintings made between about 1000 and 1800, including famous depictions by Leonardo (detail, above), Titian and El Greco. After the size of the food in the artworks was indexed against the average size of the disciples’ heads (which can vary from painting to painting), the study found that the main courses grew by 69 percent, the plates by 66 percent and the bread by 23 percent. The authors are careful to qualify what these findings mean. “We can say that plates and the amounts grow in the paintings,” Craig Wansink said on Tuesday in a telephone interview. “Does that mean in terms of the actual culture and time that food itself increased? I don’t think we have the social and historical data to back that up. But we do have the data to show that food took on increasing prominence.”

headline: Two Fewer Episodes of ‘Two and a Half Men’
text: The CBS comedy “Two and a Half Men” will produce two fewer episodes because of Charlie Sheen’s stint at a rehabilitation center, the program’s executive producer, Chuck Lorre, said. Warner Brothers Television, which produces “Two and a Half Men,” said the series resumed production last week. In late February Mr. Sheen, one of the show’s stars, entered rehab in what his spokesman called a “preventative measure.” In an interview on Monday, Mr. Lorre said: “Instead of doing 24 shows this year, we’ll be doing 22. But 22 is a full order. They had asked us to produce two additional episodes, which we normally do. But we won’t do it this year.” Mr. Sheen pleaded not guilty last week to charges of domestic violence stemming from a dispute with his wife and is scheduled to be tried in July.

headline: Robin Wright Set for Broadway Debut
text: Robin Wright, below, a star of films including “The Princess Bride,” “Forrest Gump” and “The Private Lives of Pippa Lee,” will make her Broadway debut in a revival of the Lanford Wilson comedy “Talley’s Folly,” planned for the 2010-11 season, its producers said on Tuesday. The play, about a wealthy, rebellious Missouri woman who is courted by a tax accountant, will also star Richard Schiff (“The West Wing”), who will also be making his Broadway debut. The revival is to be directed by Marshall W. Mason, a veteran interpreter of Mr. Wilson’s work, who directed the original Broadway production starring Trish Hawkins and Judd Hirsch at the Brooks Atkinson Theater in 1980.

headline: Sherman Alexie Wins Pen/Faulkner Prize
text: Sherman Alexie, below, was named the winner of the PEN/Faulkner Award for Fiction on Tuesday for “War Dances,” a collection of stories and poems. Mr. Alexie’s book, along with books by the other finalists, Barbara Kingsolver, Lorraine M. López, Lorrie Moore and Colson Whitehead, was selected from about 350 novels and short story collections published by American authors in 2009. Mr. Alexie, who also won the National Book Award for Young People’s Literature in 2007 for “The Absolutely True Diary of a Part-Time Indian,” will receive $15,000 from the PEN/Faulkner Foundation.

headline: Chris Evans Is Cast as Captain America
text: When casting mega-budget comic-book adaptations, Hollywood tends toward either established if offbeat stars (Michael Keaton in “Batman,” Robert Downey Jr. in “Iron Man”) or freshly scrubbed newcomers (Chris Hemsworth in the coming “Thor”). You can decide which category this falls into: Chris Evans, left, whose films include “Cellular,” “London” and “The Nanny Diaries,” has been cast as Captain America, the star-spangled Marvel Comics hero who wields a mighty shield, The Hollywood Reporter said. Mr. Evans beat out a long list of prospective candidates that was said to include everyone from John Krasinski of “The Office” to Chace Crawford of “Gossip Girl.” Mr. Evans will play the role in a 2011 “Captain America” movie as well as a planned “Avengers” film that will also feature the heroes Iron Man, Nick Fury, Thor and the Hulk. And he has experience with superheroes, having played the Human Torch in two “Fantastic Four” movies.

headline: As War Loomed, 3 Leaders Wandered Lost
text: The decades leading up to World War I were, across Europe, an era of dwindling dynasties and triumphal facial hair. King George V of Britain and Czar Nicholas II of Russia each possessed impeccable Vandyke beards; people had trouble telling the men apart. In Germany, Kaiser Wilhelm II had so elaborate a mustache, teased into an upward-slanting W, that it earned its own name: “Er ist erreicht!” or “It is achieved!”

There are titles to treasure and those to avoid among the 27 features and 11 shorts, many of which have been cherry-picked and rather less discriminately culled from other festivals, including Cannes and Berlin. Among the bigger draws is the price of admission: if you’re a member of either institution, you can nibble or binge at $10 a pop (but you’ll have to smuggle your popcorn past the guards at the Modern).

text: The Bronx man who wounded a police officer in a shootout this week was killed by the police and not by a self-inflicted wound, the city medical examiner’s office has determined.

headline: Capitals Questioned About Their Ties to Chiropractor in Steroids Inquiry
text: Detectives questioned Washington Capitals players, coaches and officials on Tuesday about their ties to a chiropractor who has treated several of the team’s players and was arrested earlier in the day on charges of distributing illegal performance-enhancing drugs.

headline: India's College Exam Season
text: As the middle class has steadily grown, so has the pressure to compete for the limited slots in the country’s system of higher education.

headline: Dozen Council Members Form a Bloc for Liberals
text: Frustrated by what they say are plutocratic policies that have squeezed the neediest New Yorkers, the City Council’s most liberal members are establishing a new bloc to champion a progressive agenda on housing, economic development, labor and civil rights issues.

headline: Legislator Accused of D.W.I. Goes on Trial
text: When Assemblyman Adam Clayton Powell IV was taken to a police station house early one morning in March 2008, he seemed groggy, agitated and desperate to learn the results of an alcohol breath test that he had taken that morning, a video of him there shows.

headline: In a Switch, Manhattan Lost People, Census Says
text: Manhattan reversed a decade-long streak of population gains and lost residents last year, even as New York City and its metropolitan area lost fewer people to other places than at any time since at least 1990, according to census estimates released on Tuesday.

headline: China’s Internet Giants May Be Stuck There
text: SHANGHAI — Even before Google began threatening to shut down its search service in China, it was not fitting in.

headline: Nuggets Seek Championship While Karl Battles Cancer
text: There is no telling what the moment will be like, the day the Denver Nuggets gather for a playoff game in May and find out their coach will not be on the bench. They only know what the feeling was like that morning in February, when George Karl gathered the team and announced he had throat cancer.

headline: Gridlock May Not Be Constant, but Slow Going Is Here to Stay
text: If you are thinking of driving in Manhattan on a Wednesday, perhaps to take in a Broadway matinee, think again: it is the most congested day of the week.

headline: India: Pollution Fine Sought Against Coca-Cola
text: A state government panel recommended Tuesday that Coca-Cola’s Indian subsidiary be fined $47 million for damage to the water and soil in a southern Indian village that it said had been caused by one of the company’s bottling plants. The plant, which opened in 2000 and closed five years later, polluted the groundwater and soil around the village of Plachimada, in the state of Kerala, the panel said. Coca-Cola said in a statement that it was unfortunate “that the committee in Kerala was appointed on the unproven assumption that damage was caused, and that it was caused by Hindustan Coca-Cola Beverages.” According to the panel, the bottling plant discharged a sludge that contained toxic chemicals like cadmium and lead. After villagers complained that the water table had dropped and farms were less productive, the village council decided not to renew the plant’s license.

headline: Obama to Sign Executive Order in Private
text: There was plenty of hoopla in the East Room of the White House on Tuesday when President Obama signed the health care bill into law. But when Mr. Obama signs an executive order that secured the votes of some anti-abortion Democrats, he will do so in private.

headline: China: 2 Protests by Students in Tibetan Areas
text: Groups of students in two Tibetan areas of Gansu Province, in western China, have held separate protests after Chinese security forces imposed lockdowns at boarding schools before the anniversaries of previous Tibetan uprisings, according to a report by the International Campaign for Tibet, an advocacy group. The report, based on information obtained by Tibetans in exile with ties to people in Gansu, was similar to an earlier report of the protests by Radio Free Asia.

headline: Fancy Feet
text: Marilyn Monroe, Joan Crawford, Marlene Dietrich and Queen Elizabeth all wore them. We're talking about Delmans, the salon shoe line founded by Herman Delman in 1919. Today at the Museum at the Fashion Institute of Technology shoe lovers can take a guided tour through "Scandal Sandals and Lady Slippers: A History of Delman Shoes," which explores the company's history and its greatest era of success in the 1930s through the 1950s. Around 50 shoes, dating from 1926, are presented along with period advertisements. A pair of "suede, instep strap sandals from circa 1939 performs a similar function. Boasting red, white, green, and blue color sections, four tiny bows are sequenced delicately down the vamp while a narrow ankle buckle strap, oval toe, and triangular heel maintain the shoe's elegant silhouette."

headline: Taste of Cuba
text: Does just reading the word plantain make your mouth water? Than Pilar, the tiny Cuban restaurant that opened this fall in Brooklyn, is your spot. "Accompanying nearly every entree are sticky-sweet maduros, made with plantains so ripe, their peels are almost black. The spongy flesh is browned until lightly caramelized," writes Ligaya Mishan. There are also crisp tostones, "slices of green plantains that have been fried, flattened and fried again." Even the grilled cheese "gets a helping of the fruit, between gooey layers of Cheddar and Gruyère." If that sounds like too much, go for the subtle cream of plantain soup. "It proved an unexpected delight, the sweetness of the fruit sublimated into an earthy broth." The kitchen is headed by Ricardo Barreras, who runs Pilar with his wife, Lizbeth Moreno. Mr. Barreras grew up in Miami and his parents are from Camagüey, Cuba. "In scale and in spirit, Pilar recalls Cuba's paladares, small family-run restaurants often operated out of private homes. The cooking takes time, so be prepared to linger."

headline: Get Your Clogs On
text: "Clogs, which began as a collaboration between Bryce Dessner and Padma Newsome, both members of the indie-rock band the National, is something of a classical ensemble, although it borrows heavily from rock, avant-garde, folk and world traditions," writes Amanda Petrusich. The group released its fifth album, "The Creatures in the Garden of Lady Walton" earlier this month and will be performing songs at the Bell House tonight beginning at 8 p.m. Clogs will be joined by the vocalist Shara Worden of My Brightest Diamond.

headline: Switzerland: Green Light for a Proton Collision Course
text: After spending $10 billion and making preparations for 16 years, scientists hope to start the world’s biggest physics experiment next Tuesday. Beginning that morning, engineers will try to collide protons in the Large Hadron Collider, a 17-mile underground racetrack, in the hopes of recreating primordial particles and forces beneath the French and Swiss countryside outside Geneva, CERN, the European Organization for Nuclear Research, said Tuesday. The collider was designed to accelerate protons to energies of seven trillion electron volts and then smash them together, but design flaws will keep the collider running at only half power for the first two years of its operation. A long shutdown to bring the collider up to its full potential is planned for 2012.

headline: At Some New York Schools, Wait Lists Grow Longer
text: It was once an unspoken social compact — move to the right school zone and your child was guaranteed a spot in the right school.

headline: Turkey: Sharp Divisions Over Constitutional Changes
text: Turkey’s Islamic-oriented governing party and the country’s staunchly secular judiciary traded barbs on Tuesday over whether to overhaul the country’s Constitution. Senior judicial bodies, responding to constitutional changes proposed Monday by the leadership of the governing Justice and Development Party, called the proposals unlawful and a direct challenge to the judiciary’s independence. But Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan, left, argued that the proposals derived from international practices and would promote a more democratic state.

headline: Facebook and Twitter Keep Calipari Ahead of the Game
text: When Kentucky Coach John Calipari was talking to a group of 15 Chinese basketball coaches at his home last November, one pointed to Calipari’s hulking German shepherd, Dash.

headline: California, in Financial Crisis, Opens Prison Doors
text: LANCASTER, Calif. — The California budget crisis has forced the state to address a problem that expert panels and judges have wrangled over for decades: how to reduce prison overcrowding.

headline: Stance by China to Limit Google Is Risk by Beijing
text: BEIJING — This is a nation that builds dams, high-speed rail lines and skyscrapers with abandon. In newly muscular China, sheer force is not just an art, but a bedrock principle of its seemingly unstoppable rise to global prominence.

headline: Israel Absorbs Twin Rebukes From Top Allies
text: WASHINGTON — Israel found itself at odds with its two most stalwart allies on Tuesday as Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu culminated a tense visit to Washington with a face-to-face session with President Obama that apparently failed to resolve the impasse between the two over a comprehensive Middle East peace plan.

headline: Violence in the Land of Sleep
text: On the night, several years ago, that I tackled my nightstand, I should have known better. Jolted awake in the dark, my wife Alice peered over the covers to where I lay spread-eagled on the floor. I had lunged with open arms from our bed while still asleep, truly, I later mused, the consequence of an overactive imagination, all the more because my days playing football were long over. Alice joked that we should dust off the kids’ bed rails.

headline: In Chicago, Obama Aide Had V.I.P. List for Schools
text: When Arne Duncan, the secretary of education, was chief executive of the Chicago Public Schools, his office kept a log of nearly 40 pages listing the local politicians and business people and others who sought help getting children into the city’s most selective public schools.

headline: Strip-Searches: The Truth Comes Out
text: In July 2002, the city ordered 20,900 disposable gowns for use in the city jails. This was supposed to be the start of a cheap solution to a big problem.

headline: For Once, the Mets Get Good Health News: Reyes Is Returning Quickly
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — The word started swirling around the Mets’ clubhouse about an hour before the first pitch Tuesday, and players were starting to get excited. Was it true? Jason Bay said to Jeff Francoeur. Was Jose Reyes on his way back already?

headline: Obama Signs Health Bill
text: Before signing landmark legislation into law, President Obama gave a short address on the need for overhauling health care. (Video: MSNBC)

headline: Binghamton Will Keep Men’s Team in Limbo
text: The SUNY chancellor, Nancy Zimpher, recommended Tuesday that tighter controls be placed on the system’s athletics, but the unsettled Binghamton men’s basketball program will probably remain in flux into next year.

headline: Prosecutors to Seek Three-Month Jail Term for Arenas
text: Gilbert Arenas of the Washington Wizards is scheduled to be sentenced on Friday for a felony count of carrying a pistol outside his home without a license. In preparation, both sides filed court memorandums on Tuesday.

headline: In Germany, Xenophobia Diverted by Open Doors
text: VÖLKLINGEN, Germany — Everything seemed to be in place for a protracted xenophobic row and attendant media frenzy in this depressed industrial town near the French border.

headline: U.S.C. Lands Henderson
text: Seantrel Henderson, a 6-foot-8, 340-pound left tackle widely considered to be the nation’s top high school recruit, signed with Southern California as expected. Henderson had delayed signing a letter of intent, saying he and his family wanted to wait until U.S.C. appeared last month before an N.C.A.A. infractions committee investigating the Trojans’ athletic department, football program and men’s basketball program. It is not believed that penalties will be known until next month.

headline: Moderate Inflation Versus Hyperinflation
text: Via Ryan Avent, I learn that Mike Kinsley isn’t too happy with my critique of an earlier column in which he expressed anxiety about inflation.

headline: Against ‘Pro-Israel’
text: Are you anti-Israel? If you fear that, deep down, you might be, I have important news. The recent tension between Israel and the United States led various commentators to identify hallmarks of anti-Israelism, and these may be of diagnostic value.

headline: 57 Down: Like Russian Winters
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — In 1936, Executive Order 7523 designated a plot of land in Missouri as the Jefferson National Expansion Memorial. In 1948, the crossword superstar Eero Saarinen was selected to design a monument for the park. Ground was broken in 1963. In 2009, Peter A. Collins began construction of a tribute to the monument, and his effort reached completion … today.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Saturday about a growing demand by pet owners for food banks to provide food for animals as well as humans misstated the given name of the executive director of the Petco Foundation, the philanthropic arm of the pet store chain. He is Paul Jolly, not Peter Jolly.

headline: Energized by Cornell, and It’s Not Over Physics
text: On Sunday, as Cornell’s stunningly strong basketball team was trouncing the University of Wisconsin and edging closer to the third round of the N.C.A.A. tournament, Todd L. Wolleman, class of 1980, was stuck in a vineyard in the Hudson Valley, surrounded by rows of vines and fellow Cornell graduates at an alumni event.

headline: Corrections
text: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about a request by defense lawyers to dismiss, under entrapment rules, a federal case against four men arrested in a plot to blow up two Bronx synagogues referred incorrectly to a request for a response from the United States attorney’s office in Manhattan. A spokeswoman declined to comment; the office did not fail to respond.

headline: Mets Get a New Sponsor for Spring Stadium
text: The Mets’ tradition at Tradition Field in Port St. Lucie stretches back to 1988. But traditions apparently are not what they used to be.

headline: Former Chief Crane Inspector Admits Taking Bribes for Lies
text: A former chief crane inspector for New York City’s Department of Buildings pleaded guilty on Tuesday to taking bribes from a company in exchange for falsely certifying cranes that had not been inspected and issuing crane operator’s licenses to people who had not completed examinations.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Monday about the impact of the health care legislation on various industries misstated the potential effect on the generics drug industry of a proposal that was omitted from the legislation the House adopted. That proposal would have placed new restrictions on patent settlement agreements with makers of brand-name drugs; it would not have benefited the generics industry.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: March 23, 2010

headline: Corrections
text: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about Cornell’s 78-65 victory over Temple on Friday in the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament misstated the name of the Birmingham, Ala., school attended by Cornell guard Louis Dale. It is the Altamont School, not Altamont High School.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on March 16 about digital archives from Salman Rushdie on display at Emory University misstated part of the name of the Emory library that has the archives. It is the Manuscript, Archives, and Rare Book Library  not the Manuscript, Archives and Rare Book Collection.

headline: Corrections
text: A report in the “Arts, Briefly” column on Friday about the PEN World Voices Festival of International Literature next month misidentified an author in one event. Richard Price will be among the authors talking about how their books were made into films, not Richard Ford. (As the report noted, Mr. Ford is one of the writers who will pair up to interview each other.)

headline: Corrections
text: A listing in the Long Island Calendar in some editions on Sunday for a performance by the American Chamber Ensemble scheduled for this Saturday misstated the location, phone number and Web site of the venue. It will be held at the Steinway Piano Gallery in Melville, on Long Island, not at the Steinway Piano Gallery in Westport, Conn. The Melville gallery is at 505 Walt Whitman Road; the phone number is (631) 424-0525 and the Web site is steinwayshowrooms.com/spg-long-island.

headline: Corrections
text: An obituary on Monday and in some editions Sunday about Stewart L. Udall, a former interior secretary, referred incorrectly to Mr. Udall’s support for John F. Kennedy’s 1960 campaign for the Democratic presidential nomination. He backed Mr. Kennedy in Arizona’s county and state conventions, not in a presidential primary. (Arizona did not hold a Democratic primary for that election.) And the version of the obituary on Sunday omitted one of his four surviving sons. Besides Tom, Scott and Jay, he is survived by Denis.

headline: Corrections
text: An obituary on Friday about the actor Fess Parker included several errors. Mr. Parker’s daughter is Ashley Parker Snider, not Parker-Snyder. Eddy Arnold  not Eddie  was the singer who recorded one of many versions of “The Ballad of Davy Crockett,” the theme from a series of episodes of the television show “Disneyland” in which Mr. Parker starred in the 1950s. And a line from that song should have read: “Raised in the woods so’s he knew ev’ry tree”  not “Raised in the woods so he knew every tree.”

headline: Correction
text: An Op-Ed essay on Sunday, about Google Translate, misidentified the mathematician who is considered the father of machine translation. He was Warren Weaver, not William Weaver.

headline: Corrections
text: NATIONAL

headline: Want to Use My Suit? Then Throw Me Something
text: NEW ORLEANS — Just after dusk on Friday night, Tyrone Yancy was strutting through one of the more uncertain parts of town in a $6,000 custom-made suit.

headline: Pakistan’s War of Choice
text: Peshawar, Pakistan

headline: Kitchen Confidential No More
text: THE New York City Board of Health has voted to require the city’s 24,000-plus restaurants to post at their front doors letter grades reflecting the results of their sanitary inspections. The grades range from A (for the highest level of cleanliness) to B (passing) to C (failing).

headline: Hail the Conquering Professor
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Virginia: New Trial Sought in ‘Fatal Vision’ Case
text: The 1970 murders of an Army doctor’s pregnant wife and two daughters were the basis for “Fatal Vision,” the best-selling book and mini-series. Now, the former doctor, Jeffrey MacDonald, who is serving three life terms, is requesting a new trial based on new DNA evidence and affidavits from witnesses who say they heard others confess to the crimes. A three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit, in Richmond, will hear arguments on March 30. Mr. MacDonald, 66, has maintained that hippies who were high on drugs killed his family. His lawyers, who have been receiving legal assistance from the Innocence Project, said Tuesday that DNA showed that he was not the source of hairs found at the scene. Prosecutors argue that the DNA should not be admitted.

headline: I’ll Take a Manhattan (or Any Other Drink, if It’s Free)
text: It sounds almost like an urban legend, a hazy rumor passed down through the ages, from Manhattan tippler to Brooklyn stoop-sitter to thirsty arriviste: you can, they whisper in a voice that sounds of whiskey and Pabst, drink free in New York City.

headline: Catholic Abuse Accusations Declined in 2009
text: Roman Catholic bishops in the United States received fewer accusations of sexual abuse by the clergy in 2009 than in any other year since 2004, according to an annual audit based on self-reporting from Catholic dioceses. The audit documented 398 accusations, most decades old, about 286 offenders. The church says it spent about $104 million in connection with the abuse scandal in 2009. As the Catholic Church in Europe copes with an outbreak of abuse cases, the American bishops say reforms they made at the height of their scandal in 2002 are working.

headline: A Proper Count of Inmates
text: The Census Bureau took an important first step toward electoral fairness when it announced that it would publish data on prison populations earlier than in the past, in time for the next round of legislative redistricting. This data, which will become available in the spring of 2011, will make it easy for state lawmakers to draw honest legislative districts made up of real residents instead of falsely inflated districts made up partly of prison inmates whose homes are often far away.

headline: The Day After
text: It is worth pausing to dwell on what happened in the White House on Tuesday: President Obama, just over a year into a tumultuous presidency in which he was sometimes wrong-footed and often adrift, signed the most momentous social legislation in many years.

headline: A Tea Party Without Nuts
text: President Obama’s winning passage of national health care is both exhilarating and sobering. Covering so many uninsured Americans is a historic achievement. But the president had to postpone trips, buy off companies and cut every conceivable side deal to just barely make it happen, without a single Republican vote. If the Democrats now lose seats in the midterm elections, we’re headed for even worse gridlock, even though we still have so much more nation-building for America to do  from education to energy to environment to innovation to tax policy. That is why I want my own Tea Party. I want a Tea Party of the radical center.

headline: An Openly Gay Bishop, and a Church’s Message
text: To the Editor:

headline: Trade Schools Run for Profit Come Under Fire
text: To the Editor:

headline: Fixing Missile Defense
text: It is always encouraging to see a commitment to the Sisyphean task of getting the most out of America’s gargantuan defense budget and reining in costs on expensive, badly managed or poorly performing programs.

headline: The Politics of the Health Overhaul
text: To the Editor:

headline: Cornell’s President, on Suicide Among the Young
text: To the Editor:

headline: Google and China
text: Google’s decision to stop censoring its search service in China on Monday was a principled and brave move, a belated acknowledgment that Internet companies cannot enable a government’s censorship without becoming a de facto accomplice to repression.

headline: More Universities Accept Common Application
text: Columbia University, the University of Michigan and the University of Connecticut are among 25 colleges and universities that will, for the first time, permit applicants to use the Common Application, beginning Aug. 1, the nonprofit organization that produces the form said Tuesday. A total of 414 colleges and universities will accept the application, which saves students time by allowing them to submit the same essays to any institution that accepts it. Because of its ease of use, the central form has also been blamed as contributing to the sharp increases in applications to selective colleges in recent years. Columbia is the last of the eight Ivy League schools to adopt it.

headline: Tough Bill Advances in Arizona on Illegal Immigrants
text: LOS ANGELES — The Arizona Legislature gave preliminary approval Tuesday to a proposal that would allow the police to arrest illegal immigrants on trespassing charges simply for being in the state.

headline: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Big Wins for Hawks and Bruins
text: Ten games on Tuesday, but two of them stand out, big time. First, the clash in Atlanta between the ninth-place Thrashers, winners of four straight, and eighth-place Bruins, whose last game was a big victory over the pursuing Rangers. Second, the apocalyptic clash for leadership of the West between the astonishing Coyotes, winners of nine straight, and hiccupping Blackhawks, who have managed just 10 points from 10 games since the end of the Olympics.

headline: 3 Senators Are Subpoenaed on Aqueduct Casino Deal
text: ALBANY —Three senior State Senate Democrats have been subpoenaed by the office of the state inspector general as part of an investigation into the awarding of a casino contract at the Aqueduct racetrack in Queens, people briefed on the matter said on Tuesday.

headline: Bankruptcy Ruling in Student Loan Case
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Tuesday made it easier for people who say they cannot repay their student loans to receive bankruptcy protection. But the case arose in an unusual way, and the ruling is unlikely to have a broad impact.

headline: Ex-Times Lawyer, an Army Nominee, Is Queried on Leaks
text: WASHINGTON — Senate Republicans on Tuesday grilled President Obama’s nominee to be the Army’s general counsel, Solomon B. Watson IV, over the publication of two articles in The New York Times disclosing classified information when Mr. Watson was the newspaper’s chief legal officer.

headline: Easy Victory After Intense City Council Race
text: David G. Greenfield, the executive director of the Sephardic Community Federation, was elected Tuesday to succeed City Councilman Simcha Felder of Brooklyn in a seat that represents the Orthodox Jewish strongholds of Borough Park and Midwood and the ethnically mixed neighborhood of Bensonhurst.

headline: Hard Stone, Soft Hearts
text: There are many ways to declare love on the streets of New York. A small concrete patch on the Upper East Side may be all you need. Or perhaps Central Park better frames your expansive affection, whether you express it formally or casually. (Note the left side of the park picture. There are two couples shown at Bethesda Terrace.)

headline: Word of the Day | figurative
text: figurative •\ˈfi-g(y)ə-rə-tiv\• adjective

headline: 3 on Houseboat Die on Long Island
text: Three people were discovered unconscious on a houseboat docked in a Long Island harbor on Tuesday evening and later pronounced dead, the authorities said.

headline: European Central Bank Is Said to Consider New Rules on Swaps
text: The European Central Bank may try to get European Union rules amended so that countries can’t use swaps to cut excessive budget deficits, capitalizing on a debate sparked by Goldman Sachs Group‘s swap arrangements with Greece, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Supplying ‘Miniature Oceans’
text: HOW many people in the United States have saltwater aquariums and HOW many licensed collectors in Florida help supply them?

headline: News Quiz | March 24, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page.

headline: A First Step on Fannie and Freddie
text: Despite growing pressure from Congress to act quickly, the Obama administration is moving tentatively to develop a plan to reshape Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the mortgage-finance companies taken over by the government 18 months ago, Sewell Chan reports in The New York Times.

headline: Corrections
text: A report in the Food Stuff column last Wednesday about Bomboloni, an Upper West Side pastry shop, misstated the price of its namesake sweet. Bomboloni are $1 each, or six for $5  not five for $6.

headline: Corrections
text: An article last Wednesday about efforts to overturn a restriction on the sale of homemade food at bake sales in New York City schools referred incorrectly to an action planned by the City Council. Gale A. Brewer, a Democratic council member from Manhattan, said she will introduce a resolution asking the Department of Education to overturn the regulation; the council has not scheduled a hearing about the regulation.

headline: Corrections
text: An article last Wednesday about salsa misstated Felipe Mendez’s role in the restaurant La Superior in Brooklyn. He is an owner  not the chef, a job held by Nacxitl Gaxiola.

headline: Britain Raids a Leading Hedge Fund
text: The London office of one of the world’s largest hedge funds, Moore Capital Management, was raided by British regulators and the police on Tuesday in the latest episode of a crackdown on insider trading, Landon Thomas Jr. reports in The New York Times.

headline: Wall Street Gets a Little Momentum
text: Investors snapped up industrial and materials stocks on Tuesday, helping the Dow soar to a 18-month high.

headline: O.E.C.D. Mulls Guidelines for Banks on Client Taxes
text: The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development is considering coming up with a code of conduct for banks on how they help clients with taxes, a senior official said on Wednesday, Reuters reported.

headline: Why Are Women Underrepresented in Science and Math Fields?
text: A recent report by the American Association of University Women found that although women have made gains, stereotypes and cultural biases still impede their success in science, technology, engineering and math (the so-called STEM fields). Does your own experience bear out these findings? Why do you think fewer women go into these fields?

headline: Moore’s Founder: Stalks Prey and Likes Polo
text: Following the news that Moore Capital Management, one of the world’s largest hedge funds, was raided by British regulators and the police in a crackdown on insider trading, The Wall Street Journal takes a moment to profile Moore’s founder, Louis M. Bacon.

headline: Standard Life Heads Into Hedge Funds
text: Standard Life is entering the hedge fund arena.

headline: Daimler to Pay $185 Million to Settle Corruption Charges
text: The German carmaker Daimler has agreed to pay about $185 million in fines, and two of its subsidiaries will plead guilty to bribing foreign government officials, to settle a multiyear corruption investigation, The New York Times’s Charlie Savage reported, citing a person familiar with the case.

headline: Profile in Style | David de Rothschild
text: By the time you read this, David de Rothschild will be floating somewhere in the middle of the Pacific Ocean on the Plastiki, a 60-foot catamaran made primarily from used plastic bottles. Assuming, that is, all goes as planned. ‘‘The boat only averages five knots,’’ he says with a laugh about the ambitious 11,000-mile itinerary. ‘‘That’s about six miles an hour.’’ But the 31-year-old heir to the Rothschild banking fortune is no stranger to adventure. Having visited some of the most beautiful places on the planet — in 2005 he trekked across Antarctica via the South Pole — he now travels to some of the most blighted, sharing his stories and spreading awareness through his Web site, adventureecology.com. In 2007 he took a team to Ecuador to explore the effects of oil drilling. The Plastiki expedition will take him and his crew to the Eastern Garbage Patch, an island of trash in the Pacific Ocean twice the size of Texas. ‘‘The list of problems is big,’’ he says optimistically, ‘‘but the list of solutions is even longer.’’ More…

headline: For One Biotech, an Expiration Date With a Twist
text: Capstone Therapeutics, a small biotechnology firm, has developed a radical new therapy  for investors, Breakingviews says.

headline: At Rio Tinto Trial in China, Door Closes Tighter
text: Prosecutors argued for a second day in court that four employees from the British-Australian mining giant Rio Tinto accepted millions of dollars in bribes and stole commercial secrets from Chinese companies, but the closed nature of the trial made it difficult to assess the evidence they presented in the high-profile case, The New York Times’s David Barboza writes.

headline: Plea Anticipated by Former I.B.M. Executive
text: A former high level executive at I.B.M. is likely to enter a plea to end the case against him after agreeing to waive indictment in what prosecutors call the largest insider trading case in hedge fund history, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Renovation in Store on Fire Island Pines
text: Among gay men, Fire Island Pines is a legendary place of romance, rowdiness and high real estate prices.

headline: Kurdish Spring Festival Is Political, Too
text: Tens of thousands of Kurds gathered in the southeastern Turkish city of Diyarbakir on Sunday to celebrate Nowruz. This festival, on the first day of spring, is known as the Kurdish new year (and is transliterated many more ways than that). It offers the Kurdish community a chance to demand broader rights and to express support of the outlawed Kurdistan Workers’ Party, or PKK.

headline: Executive Shake-Up at Nanosolar
text: From Todd Woody at Green Inc.:

headline: JPMorgan Eyes Tax Refund Deal, Report Says
text: JPMorgan Chase is closing in on a deal with the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. that could result in a tax refund of about $1.4 billion for the bank, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing people familiar with the talks.

headline: Avis Sews Up $580 Million Bond Sale
text: Avis Budget Group on Tuesday said its rental car financing subsidiary completed a multiclass offering of about $580 million in asset-backed bonds, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Report Says Migrants in Malaysia Face Abuse
text: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia — Amnesty International said in a report released on Wednesday that migrant workers faced exploitation and widespread abuse in Malaysia, and it accused the government of not doing enough to protect them.

headline: Frankfurt Bourse Leans Toward Prague
text: Deutsche Börse said Tuesday that it had decided to move some operations to Prague to save 100 million euros ($134 million) a year, with the cost-cutting measures affecting hundreds of its staff members.

headline: GMAC Said to Plan Sale of Unit to Wells Fargo
text: GMAC Financial Services, the U.S. auto finance company, agreed to sell its factoring business unit to Wells Fargo, Bloomberg News reported, citing two people with direct knowledge of the matter.

headline: Banks See Need for Overhaul (of Their Image)
text: One of Wall Street’s main lobbying groups is starting an image-improvement campaign aimed at showing the financial industry as trustworthy and a positive force after more than a year of being chastised in Washington, Bloomberg News reports.

headline: The New Mix

headline: Sampler: California Begins Its Prison Inmate Reduction Plan, and Walnut Creek Pot Club Closes
text: State Begins Releasing Inmates | In recent weeks, California has started an effort to reduce its inmate population of 167,000 by 6,500 this year. Some prisoners may be released early for completing drug or education programs. Part of the plan includes changing how the state handles parolees, many of whom, at the moment, return to prison on technical violations, according to criminal system experts. California is the only state that places all prisoners on parole at release, but now hundreds of low-level offenders will be released without close supervision from their parole officers. The effort represents a “seismic shift,” said Joan Petersilia, a criminologist at Stanford Law School and a longtime scholar of the state’s prisons. The prison system costs the state $8 billion annually, about 11 percent of the state budget. [The New York Times]

headline: A Physics Maven’s Take on Skeptical Science
text: I’ve been meaning to highlight a particularly interesting blog on climate, Skeptical Science, and finally have the chance. What’s appealing about it is the simple way its Australian creator, John Cook, has cast his journey. It’s basically a list of reference-laden responses to the many assertions made by one or another of the variegated camps rejecting the need for action to curb greenhouse gases. There is a conventional blog stream covering developments as they occur. But most useful, perhaps, in a world of information overload, is the basic litany of 101 (and counting) skeptics’ arguments and responses. (Users of iPhones might say the most useful element is the popular new Skeptical Science application for the phone.) Here’s one example from the online list:

headline: The Tiger Bubble
text: Not too long ago, 2010 was shaping up as a good year for Tiger Woods. After knee surgery in 2008, Woods returned to competitive golf in 2009 and logged six victories. He led the PGA Tour in prize winnings for the ninth time and was voted player of the year by his peers for the 10th time in his 14 years as a pro. Because of the fortuitous location of this year’s marquee tournaments, Woods seemed primed to approach and maybe even equal Jack Nicklaus’s record of 18 major championships. In addition to the Masters at Augusta, Ga., where Woods has won four times, the 2010 United States Open will be played in June at Pebble Beach, in California; in 2000, the last time it was played there, Woods won by 15 strokes. The British Open will be held in July at the Old Course at St. Andrews, Scotland, which has hosted the tournament twice in the last decade; Woods won both times, by a combined total of 13 strokes.

headline: Winfrey Settles Lawsuit Brought by Former Headmistress
text: You may see Oprah Winfrey next week on her syndicated talk show, but you won’t be seeing the broadcasting queen in a Philadelphia courtroom. On Tuesday Ms. Winfrey settled a defamation lawsuit filed by the former headmistress of a school she set up in South Africa, who had said that the talk show host had defamed her after a sex-abuse scandal there, Reuters reported. Nomvuho Mzamane ran the Oprah Winfrey Leadership Academy for Girls in South Africa at its founding in 2007 but left after students there said they were being abused by another staff member. After Ms. Winfrey held a news conference and said that Ms. Mzamane had ignored the students’ complaints, Ms. Mzamane said Ms. Winfrey had defamed her and made it difficult for her to find another job. A statement from lawyers representing both women said the dispute had been settled “peacefully to their mutual satisfaction” and both women had withdrawn their complaints, according to Reuters. Terms of the settlement were not disclosed. A trial was scheduled to begin on Monday in federal court in Philadelphia, where Ms. Mzamane was living when she filed the suit.

headline: An Initial Change to The Economist’s Anonymous Voice

As former editor Bill Emmott once explained to David Shaw of the the Los Angeles Times back in 2003, it’s a matter of motivating writers to take ownership over the whole enterprise, not just their own bylined corner of it:

headline: Sympathy For Bart Stupak
text: Yes, the executive order that Stupak accepted as cover for his pivotal health care vote is probably meaningless. And yes, the health care bill, as passed, effectively tilts public policy in a more pro-choice direction: The fact that women are required to write a separate check for abortion coverage means that public money isn’t literally paying for abortion, but it doesn’t change the fact that federal dollars are being spent in ways that make it much easier to obtain abortion-covering insurance. (And that’s without getting into the tangled issue of community health centers.) But what struck me most, at the end, wasn’t the folly of Stupak’s decision to compromise his pro-life principles by voting “yes,” but the extraordinary loneliness of his position before he folded.

headline: Thinning Out
text: I’ve been looking at the April issues, the month for taxes and shaping up and being sexy (in 60 seconds!), and I’m feeling strangely energized, if not entirely hopeful about the future of magazines. I enjoyed Alexandra Jacobs’s piece about Polyvore in the style issue of The New Yorker. (I also was excited to see the piece on Brunello Cucinelli; interesting business, with annual sales of more than $200 million, reports RebeccaMead, and I know a lot of women who like the clothes, expensive though they are. But I was bored reading about him.) One thing in the Polyvore piece that amused me was the description of the company’s office, the atmosphere of tact and friendliness — unlike magazine offices which, as Ms. Jacobs noted, “are widely perceived to be snake pits.” But looking at clothes and brands and trends on a computer screen is a different experience, isn’t it? Magazines are diva pits, flesh-and-blood places, and they are probably less so today than 10 or 20 years ago, and of course that outsized feeling and passion for clothes is what helps stir the imagination of designers and editors alike. I guess things are thinning out now, and not just magazine pages. Polyvore is a useful site for people, but it does, as Ms. Jacobs’s reporting suggested, reflect a remote, blunt, user-friendly time.

headline: Gospel Album Makes Debut at No. 2 on Charts
text: This week an unusual arrival is on the upper reaches of the Billboard album chart: gospel music. “Here I Am” (Verity) by Marvin Sapp, a veteran singer and preacher from Grand Rapids, Mich., reached No. 2 in its first week, with 76,000 sales, Nielsen SoundScan reported. It is the first time that a gospel album has been in the Top 10 since November 2008, when “The Sound” from Mary Mary reached No. 7, according to Billboard. It credits the sleeper radio success of Mr. Sapp’s 2007 song “Never Would Have Made It” with the new album’s sales. (“Thirsty,” the album that contained “Never Would Have Made It,” peaked at No. 28.)Also on this week’s chart, Lady Antebellum’s “Need You Now” (Capitol Nashville) returns to No. 1 for a fourth time with sales of 93,000, bringing its eight-week total to just under 1.5 million. Ludacris’s “Battle of the Sexes” (Def Jam), last week’s top seller, dropped two spots to No. 3 with 61,000. “The Edge” (Razor & Tie), a compilation of 32 songs by hard rock bands like Jet, Korn and Godsmack, opened at No. 4 with 53,000, and “The Fame” (Interscope) from Lady Gaga is No. 5 with 48,000 sales in its 73rd week of release.

headline: Grant Ensures Anglo-Saxon Treasure Will Go to Museums
text: Not long after Terry Herbert found the Staffordshire Hoard, a collection of more than 1,500 pieces of gold and silver Anglo-Saxon treasure, in a farmer’s field in Britain, Mr. Herbert, an out-of-work metal detectorist, said, “I’ve had people go past and go, ‘Beep, beep, he’s after pennies.’” Now we know that Mr. Herbert’s discovery is worth just a bit more than that. On Tuesday Britain’s National Heritage Memorial Fund gave a grant of £1.285 million (about $1.9 million) to two museums that will keep the treasure, having raised a total of £3.3 million (about $4.9 million) to keep the collection intact, The Guardian reported. The Birmingham and Stoke-on-Trent museums will pay that money to Mr. Herbert and Fred Johnson, the farmer in whose field the hoard was found, having raised donations from around the world in a campaign that began in January. David Starkey, the historian who started the fund-raising campaign, told The Guardian, “This is by far the most important archaeological discovery in Britain since the Second World War.” He added, “Frankly they’d have been demented not to give the money.”
