headline: China and Russia Pressed Iran to Accept U.N. Deal
text: MOSCOW — Russia disclosed on Wednesday that Russian and Chinese envoys had pressed Iran’s government to accept a United Nations plan on uranium enrichment during meetings in Tehran early this month but that Iran had refused, leaving “less and less room for diplomatic maneuvering.”

headline: Google Alerts Gmail Users to Suspicious Logins
text: Google has introduced a new security feature that alerts Gmail users whose e-mail accounts may have been broken into by a malicious intruder and helps them regain full control.

headline: Oakland to Be Overrun With Runners
text: A a tractor-trailer from Baltimore loaded with tables, mileage signs, water tanks and other race paraphernalia will pull into Oakland on Wednesday. Mile markers will sprout, and streets will be painted with turn-here arrows. The inaugural Oakland Running Festival opens this weekend, and more than 6,000 runners have registered for a variety of races: a marathon, a half-marathon, a relay, a 5K and a children’s race. The marathon, the first in Oakland in 25 years, has caught on as a way to support the city, the East Bay Express reports.

headline: Financial Overhaul Is Next Priority of Democrats
text: WASHINGTON — Buoyed by passage of landmark health care legislation, the Obama administration and Democrats in Congress said Wednesday that an overhaul of financial regulations was the next legislative priority.

headline: Republican Opts Not to Join Senate Race
text: Dan Senor, a private equity executive and former military adviser to President George W. Bush, has decided not to challenge Democratic Senator Kirsten E. Gillibrand in the election this fall, he said in an interview on Wednesday.

headline: Jets to Be Featured on HBO Show
text: The Jets will be featured on the HBO series “Hard Knocks” next season, according to three people with direct knowledge of the negotiations. The team will announce its selection Thursday with what it billed as a “major news announcement.”

headline: How Not to Run an S.E.C. Investigation
text: Peter J. Henning follows issues related to white-collar crime and securities law for DealBook’s White Collar Watch.

headline: New Bow on a Minimal Box
text: FROM the late 1970s through the early ’90s, despite some wide financial mood swings, Calvin Klein occupied an infinity of clean white space in the design world. Everything the brand touched was reflective of the spare architectural minimalism (that had yet to be mass produced by places like West Elm). The sumptuously erotic black-and-white Herb Ritts ads created a nostalgia for an easy Utopian future, full of startlingly intimate moments — snapshots of seaside romps with surreally beautiful lovers in various stages of undress. The designer’s wife at the time, invariably described as “the leonine Kelly Klein,” was admired for looking casually ravishing with loose hair, natural makeup and little or no jewelry. The Calvin Klein brand was a heady mix of white sand, cloudless skies, stress-less luxury and urgent passion.

headline: Eco-Tripping | Brazil Three Ways
text: When it comes to sustainability, Brazil walks the walk: Eighty-five percent of its electricity comes from renewable sources, and it’s a top producer of environmentally sensitive products like vegetable-dyed leather and Amazonian cocoa butter. Now tourism is also going green, with a wide array of new conservation initiatives and eco-lodges proliferating across the country. Here, a regional sampler.

headline: Reid Admits He Is Listening to Trade Offers for His Quarterbacks
text: ORLANDO, Fla. – One of the intriguing puzzles of this off-season surrounds what the Philadelphia Eagles will do with their three quarterbacks. Coach Andy Reid reiterated Wednesday that Donovan McNabb is the starting quarterback and Reid said he can still envision McNabb, backup Kevin Kolb and third quarterback Michael Vick all returning for the 2010 season. That, Reid said, is a pretty good situation for a coach.

headline: Assemblyman’s Drunken-Driving Trial Begins
text: Arguments and testimony in the drunken-driving trial of Assemblyman Adam Clayton Powell IV started on Wednesday morning with a prosecutor telling jurors that although Mr. Powell was not “a fall-down drunk” on the night he was arrested two years ago, he still was in no condition to get behind the wheel of a car.

headline: Travel Deals: Save on a Spring Vacation
text: Airlines and hotels are offering spring vacation deals.

headline: Wadsworth Atheneum Announces $16 Million Renovation Project
text: The Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford, Conn., which has emerged from several years of financial struggle and staff upheaval, has announced plans for a $16 million renovation project that will result in the addition of 8,000 square feet more gallery space, a 14 percent increase, and the complete reinstallation of the museum’s permanent collection, said Susan L. Talbott, the museum’s director.

headline: Senate Republicans Block Hearings
text: For the second consecutive day, Senate Republicans angry over the health care legislation blocked Senate committees from meeting on Wednesday, including an Armed Services Committee session that top officers stationed in Hawaii and Korea had traveled to Washington to attend.

headline: A Good Excuse to Stay Home From the Gym
text: WHEN Laurie Davis wakes up in the morning, she sometimes feels like skipping her workout. But two days a week, hitting the snooze button is not an option: she knows that at 7 a.m., Yvette Rose will ring the buzzer at her Manhattan apartment with hand weights and resistance bands in tow.

headline: Lineup Announced for Newport Jazz and Folk Festivals
text: Right on schedule, George Wein’s jazz and folk festivals are returning to Newport, R.I.

headline: Bone May Reveal a New Human Group
text: A previously unknown kind of human group vanished from the world so completely that it has left behind the merest wisp of evidence that it ever existed — a single bone from the little finger of a child, buried in a cave in the Altai mountains of southern Siberia.

headline: At Penn in 1979, a Freshman Mistake
text: Barron H. Lerner, a professor at Columbia University and the author of “When Illness Goes Public,” contributes to the health pages of Science Times.

headline: Gooden Arrested After Traffic Accident
text: Dwight Gooden, the former pitching star who has battled drug and alcohol problems, was arrested Tuesday and faces several charges, including driving while under the influence of drugs, after an accident in Franklin Lakes, N.J.

headline: When the Middle of the Street Is the Perfect Meeting Place
text: There are two veteran doormen who work directly across the street from each other at the western end of 86th Street near Riverside Drive. The doormen, Michael Korson and Felix Torres, work similar schedules.

headline: Financial Overhaul Is Next Priority of Democrats
text: Buoyed by passage of landmark health care legislation, the Obama administration and Democrats in Congress said Wednesday that an overhaul of financial regulations was the next legislative priority, The New York Times’s Sewell Chan reports from Washington.

headline: League Moves to Add Relevance to Week 17 Games
text: The N.F.L. is so intent on preventing teams from resting theirstarters in late-season games that it plans to schedule only divi-sion games in Week 17, Commissioner Roger Goodell said Wednesday.

headline: Reyes Gets Back to Work at Mets Camp
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Jose Reyes returned to the Mets on Wednesday after a two-week absence while he recovered from thyroiditis, and immediately went back to work getting ready for the coming season.

headline: Saudis Arrest 113 Militants
text: CAIRO — Saudi Arabia said Wednesday that its security forces had arrested 113 militants with ties to Al Qaeda who had been planning attacks against oil operations and security facilities in the eastern part of the kingdom.

headline: Baseball Changes Schedule for League Championship Series
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. – The postseason schedule change announced by Major League Baseball on Wednesday is specific to one day. The off day that had been scheduled between Games 4 and 5 of the League Championship Series has been eliminated.

headline: Pondexter Makes the Most of His Time at Washington
text: For a big man on campus — one of the biggest men, really — to sit in a makeup chair for nearly an hour, then put on a pair of ballet tights and take the stage for the Pacific Northwest Ballet’s “Nutcracker” shows that Quincy Pondexter has a certain level of comfort in his own skin.

headline: African Teams Certain on World Cup, but Not on Coaches
text: A World Cup campaign is usually a four-year process that starts when a national team engages in torturous self-examination immediately after its ouster from the last championship. Coaches are fired (or their contracts are not renewed) and aging players retire from the international scene. Even the winner is often in need of a new manager to enliven the roster and refresh tactics for the interspersed continental championship and next phase of World Cup qualifying.

headline: HBO Film Documents Immigration Battle
text: Updated The opening minutes of “The Senators’ Bargain,” a documentary film appearing tonight on HBO2, show Senator John McCain at a Congressional hearing in 2006, reading out loud from a newspaper article describing the death from broiling in the desert that befalls many immigrants trying to cross the border illegally.

headline: The Morning Skate: N.H.L.’s Fast-Tracked Rule Change Skips a Stop
text: Nothing comes easy in the National Hockey League and the proposed rule on blindside hits to the head is the latest example.

headline: Dress to Regress | A Photographer’s Fashion Flashbacks
text: It doesn’t take a mountain of fashion magazines or even a slim volume of Roland Barthes to understand that a mere outfit can be profound. Just look back at your wardrobe over time. (Thanks, Facebook, for making this painfully easier.) The prom dress in which you lost your virginity, the hideous interview suit for the job you never got — clothes become shorthand for experiences, and powerful triggers of memories. The universality of “I dress, therefore I am” is what propelled Ilene Beckman’s 1995 memoir, “Love, Loss and What I Wore,” to the best-seller list, and then to a Broadway play by Nora and Delia Ephron. Now comes the photographer Jeannette Montgomery Barron’s series of photographs and written recollections, “My Mother’s Clothes.” A group of still lifes depicting the wardrobe of her late mother, the prominent Atlanta socialite Eleanor Morgan Montgomery Atuk, “My Mother’s Clothes” will be on display in July at Jackson Fine Art in Atlanta and published as a book in March 2010.

headline: College Rejections of the Rich and Famous
text: The Wall Street Journal has published an amusing (and, at times, even comforting) article today under the headline, “Before They Were Titans, Moguls and Newsmakers, These People Were … Rejected.” For those readers of The Choice who’ve gotten rejection letters themselves in recent weeks, the article may be something of a salve for raw wounds.

headline: Gunmen Kill Iraqi Soldiers on Guard in Baghdad
text: BAGHDAD — Gunmen shot and killed five Iraqi Army soldiers at a military checkpoint in south Baghdad on Wednesday as the country prepared for election results scheduled to be released Friday.

headline: Hacking a GTO With an iPod Touch
text: Combine electronics aficianado with muscle-car enthusiast and you’ve got Dave Phipps.

headline: Xavier Women Add Midmajor Magic
text: Add another college to the double Round of 16 club: Xavier.

headline: Harold W. McGraw Jr., Publisher, Dies at 92
text: Harold W. McGraw Jr., who as leader of McGraw-Hill, his family’s publishing business, helped build it into a billion-dollar enterprise in the 1970s and ’80s, died on Wednesday at his home in Darien, Conn. He was 92 .

headline: Dear New Yorkers, Census Is Looking for You
text: City officials say New York is on track to grow to a record 8.4 million people when the 2010 census is tallied, but you wouldn’t know it from the early returns. In parts of Soundview in the Bronx, Manhattan’s Lower East Side and Ocean Hill, Brooklyn, not a single census questionnaire has been returned with the deadline for mailing in the forms just a week away.

headline: City Council to Lose Its Home (Temporarily)
text: At City Hall, democracy is about to leave the building.

headline: Behind Consumer Agency Idea, a Tireless Advocate
text: WASHINGTON — Ask Elizabeth Warren, scourge of Wall Street bankers, how they treat consumers, and she will shake her head with indignation. She will talk about morality, about fairness, about what she calls their “let them eat cake” attitude toward taxpayers. If she is riled enough, she might even spit out the Warren version of an expletive.

headline: The Sweet Smell of Success
text: David Brooks: Gail, I usually don’t describe what I look like as I converse with you (believe me, these are mental images you do not want lodged in your brain) but at the moment I am sitting at my desk, at home, dressed in a suit, with cookie crumbs falling all over my keyboard.

headline: The Battle Over Bottled Water
text: Published in recognition of World Water Day, a video called The Story of Bottled Water (at right, on top), made its debut on YouTube this week, using animation and snappy narration to convey what its makers consider to be the evils of bottled water. (It comes from the same folks who produced ”The Story of Stuff” — an eco-themed viral video sensation from last year.)

headline: Terra Firma Lawsuit Against Citi to Remain in N.Y.
text: 3:10 p.m. | Updated with statements A federal judge on Wednesday dismissed a motion by Citigroup to dismiss a lawsuit by the private equity firm Terra Firma over the takeover of British music label EMI. The bank had argued that the legal battle belonged in England, not the United States.

headline: IPhone App to Sidestep AT&T
text: For a little $1 iPhone app, Line2 sure has the potential to shake up an entire industry.

headline: Recipe: Louisiana Brown Jasmine Rice and Shrimp Risotto
text: 6 tablespoons butter

headline: Ithaca Celebrates Cornell Run With ‘Nerd Discounts’
text: So, Cornell does not have Kentucky’s basketball tradition, multiple national championships or players primping for the N.B.A. scouts. But the city of Ithaca, N.Y., is celebrating what Cornell does have (smart people) and offering a handful of discounts for the nerd crowd.

headline: New Kits for Container Gardens
text: As more people have started growing their own vegetables, more kits for indoor/outdoor gardening have hit the market.

headline: On Dance: In New ‘Stars’ Season, a Different Moon Walk
text: There’s only been one episode of performances so far this season, but “Dancing With the Stars” has already broken a series record, averaging 23.9 million viewers on Monday night. As in years past, the show, now in its 10th edition, pairs 11 quasi-celebrities with 11 professional dancers, and promises to deliver a hard-to-resist mix of spray tans, awkward moves, cheesy comments and sequins.

headline: Connecticut Continues Demolishing Opponents
text: Maybe No. 1 Connecticut should do something nice, show a benevolent side in the N.C.A.A. women’s tournament.

headline: It’s Official: 2009 Was Worst Year for the Newspaper Business in Decades
text: It’s no surprise that 2009 was the worst year the newspaper business has had in decades, but the scale of the damage, shown in figures released Wednesday by the Newspaper Association of America, is stunning.

headline: States Differ on Marijuana for PTSD
text: DENVER — A decade ago, Colorado became one of the earliest states to legalize medical marijuana. Its neighbor New Mexico did so more recently. But that does not mean the two states agree on all the medicinal merits of cannabis.

headline: A Collector of Scoops Steps Down
text: “THERE were times when I got bad reviews in Women’s Wear Daily,” Calvin Klein recalled in an interview this week, “but at least I always felt their criticism was written fairly, because that’s what Patrick McCarthy did.”

headline: Google Calls for Action on Web Limits
text: A top Google executive on Wednesday called for rules to put pressure on governments that filter the Internet, saying the practice was hindering international trade.

headline: Answers About Changing Careers in New York
text: Following is the first set of responses from Michele LoBianco, who teaches “Recession Proofing Your Career” at the School of Continuing and Professional Studies at New York University.

headline: Samurai Shopper | London Trawling
text: It was Napoleon who dismissed England as “a nation of shopkeepers.” Wait, you tiny, arrogant Corsican, a nation of shopkeepers is catnip to Samurai Shoppers. Forget “a nation”: one slab of Oxford Street offers opportunity galore to divide and conquer. No icy, pricey, star-studded Dover Street Market wares here; Oxford Street features fashion in heavy rotation: affordably trendy, cheerfully commercial.

headline: Steve McQueen: 30 Years Gone, Not Close to Forgotten
text: Steve McQueen, the hard-driving, hard-living existentialist hero of a generation of action movies, would have been 80 years old today. McQueen, an avid and accomplished motor racer, died in 1980 of a heart attack after surgery to treat mesothelioma, a form of cancer associated with inhaling asbestos fibers. Early racing suits, his motorsports contemporaries have noted, were dipped in a chemical solution that contained asbestos to make them fire-retardant.

headline: World’s Best Airports in Asia, Says Survey
text: Asia dominated the Skytrax World Airport Awards, which are based on more than nine million customer surveys.

headline: Israeli Military Tries Two Soldiers for Conduct During Gaza War
text: Updated | Thursday | 7:53 a.m. As the Israeli newspaper Yediot Ahronoth’s Web site Ynet News reports, Israel’s military put two of its own soldiers on trial on Wednesday for allegedly forcing a 9-year-old Palestinian boy to open bags they suspected might contain explosives during a raid in Gaza last year.

headline: Exhibit A: Exploring and Learning at Science Museums
text: Overview | What do science museums have to offer? How can visiting a science museum complement classroom curriculum and reinforce science standards? What can students get out of a trip to a science museum? In this lesson, students reflect on the exhibits, learning experiences and purposes of science museums, then prepare for and visit a local science museum where they engage in an open-ended scavenger hunt. Afterward, they develop scripts for a museum guide to use with visitors or generate ideas for their own science museum.

headline: Talking to the Chief of Yelp, the Site That Businesses Love to Hate
text: Yelp! What happens when an online review site itself becomes the subject of harsh public scrutiny? Such is the case of Yelp, the review site that carries the motto, “Real People. Real reviews.” In recent weeks, Yelp has been hit with three class-action lawsuits from businesses claiming that Yelp sales representatives tried to press the businesses into advertising by offering — or threatening — to manipulate reviews. Jeremy Stoppelman, a Yelp co-founder and its chief executive, has seen the tables of Web 2.0 turned against his company as angry business owners have taken to Internet boards to pan Yelp. A condensed version of a conversation with Mr. Stoppelman follows.

headline: China and Google
text: Americans tend to think of China as this vast, unstoppable, titanic force. Some would add menacing. But the confrontation unfolding today between China and Google is a reminder that the Politburo sees the situation very differently. They see a fragile China besieged on all sides, challenged at home, desperately needing to churn out economic growth to sustain its political model. In short, they see vulnerability where we tend to see invincibility — and that’s one reason they took so tough a line on Google.

headline: The Bumpy Blending of a Family
text: This morning, Pamela Kripke explored how parenting changes after a divorce, particularly when there are no male role models in the house. In a guest post this afternoon, Jennifer Cullen writes about parenting changes after a new marriage, specifically when a new dad moves in. A mother of two and a stepmother of one, Cullen thought she knew what she was getting into when she remarried three years ago. She’s learned a lot since then.

headline: Here’s Your Chance to Review Yelp
text: In an interview published on Wednesday, Jeremy Stoppelman, co-founder and chief executive of Yelp, encourages business owners not to fear the online review site but to embrace it: “Focusing on that one review you feel is unfair,” Mr. Stoppelman told Kermit Pattison, “misses the value, which is the whole symphony of opinions you get on your page.”

headline: Pizza Fit for a First Family
text: posted by brossramirez on TwitVid

headline: Take a Play, Then Adorn It With Opera
text: The English were wary of the Continental taste for opera in the 17th century, but they liked the idea of adorning plays with music. What composers and theater producers came up with is a curious compromise that Roger North, a writer at the time, called “semi-opera.” In this hybrid form, a play is presented straightforwardly, as spoken text, with masques  parades of songs, choruses and dance  interspersed within each act. The masques are an alternative universe: often, the play unfolds in the real world and the masques in the realm of the supernatural. And though the play’s actors might remain as observers, they cede the stage to the singers and dancers and rarely interact with them.

headline: An Afghan Voice for American Troops
text: Marja may have receded in the public consciousness, but it is no less critical in the battle for Afghanistan. Mauricio Lima, shooting for Agence France-Presse—Getty Images, filed this photograph of Nekqadama, a contract interpreter for the Marines in Marja. He is also responsible for Slide 8. (Lens has covered the recent offensive in Helmand Province in “Into the Maw at Marja” and “A Perilous Route to Marja.”) The many layers and planes in Mr. Lima’s first photo give it a dreamlike quality. His previous appearance in Pictures of the Day, last November, also showed how capable he is of transforming an unpromising setting — in this case the streets of São Paulo, Brazil, during a blackout — into something evocatively moody.

headline: Fuld Was Reportedly Nervous During Lehman Inquiry
text: Richard S. Fuld Jr., Lehman Brothers‘s longtime chief executive, may have felt “vindicated” by the court-appointed examiner’s inquest into his firm’s demise. But according to Fox Business Network, getting to that point was a bit of a struggle.

headline: No Envelope, at Least Not Today
text: Eighth-grade students will indeed have to wait at least one more day before they can find out just where they will attend high school next fall.

headline: Playing Games With an Afro-Brazilian Leap Into the Capoeira Circle
text: Jelon Vieira, the artistic director of DanceBrazil, has described capoeira as a fight that is like a dance and a dance that is like a fight. The form, which combines elements of dance and martial arts, is also something of a game, in which the movement is instantly identifiable: low shifts from side to side, whipping cartwheels into back flips, handstands, sweeping legs and sideway kicks. When the right sort of suppleness meets speed, a dancer appears to float in the air.

headline: Orchard Beach in the Bronx, 1 P.M.
text: Michael Marricco relaxes on a deck chair in Orchard Beach.

headline: 68 and Still Twisting, With a Bit Less Gusto
text: “I haven’t been in a situation like this since March 1962 at the Copacabana,” announced the eternally cheerful Chubby Checker shortly after taking the stage of Feinstein’s at Loews Regency on Tuesday evening. Mr. Checker (real name Ernest Evans), who was dressed head to toe in blue denim, is now 68 and has the mixed blessing of his name being synonymous with a flurry of early-’60s dance novelties, beginning with the epochal “Twist.”

headline: Gritty Polish for a Tennessee Williams Jewel
text: The gauzy draping that usually trims productions of “The Glass Menagerie” has been packed up and put away. Do not come to the Laura Pels Theater, where the Roundabout Theater Company’s terrific new revival of Tennessee Williams’s career-igniting play opened on Wednesday night, looking for a standard dose of weepy Southern lyricism.

headline: Eco-Tripping | The Dream Team
text: A few years ago, it was enough not to wash the towels every day. But it takes much more for hotels to earn their green stripes these days: those towels are now organic cotton, for starters, and the water to wash them is filtered and reused. Toilets are low flow, cleaning products are sulfate-free, hybrid cars meet guests at the airport, gardens are organic, and everything is recycled. Of course, it’s the rare hotel that actually does it all. But what if one did? Herewith, the hypothetically perfect eco-hotel.

headline: A Danish Popsicle, Served Quickly Before It Melts
text: The members of Alphabeat took a bow and left the stage on Tuesday night at Santos Party House, and no one in the crowd moved an inch.

headline: Finding Her Groove in Africa and a Violin
text: Regina Carter bookended her first set at Dizzy’s Club Coca-Cola on Tuesday night with duologue, plucking or bowing her violin alongside the Malian kora player Yacouba Sissoko. The graceful symmetry of their exchanges came with a transparent subtext. Ms. Carter had landed at the club with a new agenda: to put a personal spin on African folk music, as she does throughout her forthcoming album, “Reverse Thread” (E1), due on May 18. Presenting Mr. Sissoko as a partner was a way to signal her intentions.

headline: Shopping With Stephanie Moffitt
text: On a trip to New York, the design director of Mokum, an Australian textiles company, looked for interesting work by designers from her part of the world.

headline: Arts Oasis in a Sporty Town
text: THE landscape of the uptown district of Charlotte, N.C., is dominated by mega-sports domes like the Bank of America Stadium, home to the Carolina Panthers, and the much-ballyhooed Nascar Hall of Fame, a 150,000-square-foot entertainment complex set to open May 11.

headline: Design From Down Under in New York
text: AT least once a year, Stephanie Moffitt, the design director of Mokum, an Australian textiles company, travels to the United States from her home in Sydney to present her firm’s latest collection to showrooms across the country.

headline: National Parks Get Quarters
text: The 50 State Quarters Program has a sequel.

headline: Musicians as Movers, Navigating the Clutter
text: Success breeds imitation, the adage goes. In music that concept has produced a variant: any sufficiently distinguished piece, no matter how unorthodox its instrumental requirements, will spawn ensembles to play it, creating a demand for further similarly constituted pieces.

headline: Suit Accuses Goldman of Having ‘Mommy Track’
text: Goldman Sachs was accused of sex discrimination in a lawsuit filed on Wednesday by a former vice president, who contended that the firm had consigned her to a “mommy track” that led to her firing while she was on maternity leave, Reuters reports.

headline: Rice Dreams in Louisiana
text: When you own a 150-acre farm, having a change of heart about how you do things is a slow, costly process. When you’re a third-generation rice farmer in rural Louisiana — a state with just 23 organic farms — deciding to try to grow brown rice without pesticides or chemical fertilizers is enough to get you certified not organic, but insane.

headline: Spaghetti With Edamame, Parsley, Garlic and Olive Oil
text: This is a quick pasta to throw together if you have frozen shelled edamame or peas in your freezer, and it’s a dish that I find irresistible. You can find frozen edamame at most supermarkets; the green soybeans are a terrific source of protein and isoflavones. Seek out organic edamame.

headline: What's New
text: A look at some of the films featured in the first week of the New Directors/New Films festival.

headline: 36 Hours in Naples, Fla.
text: IF you filtered all the glitz out of Miami, you’d get Naples, Fla. This small Gulf-side city has a pleasingly anodyne quality that’s worlds away from the cosmopolitan bustle found only a two-hour drive due east, on the opposite coast. Affluent Midwesterners, who have adopted Naples as a getaway from nasty Northern weather, bring a certain oh-gosh air to town. Don’t be surprised if you keep seeing the same faces over and over  these snowbirds might move at a slower pace than the Miami set, but they get around.

headline: Lawyer Convicted of Visa Fraud
text: For the illegal immigrants who came to the lawyer, the benefits were immediately apparent. The immigrants, many of whom were from Pakistan and India, were able to live out in the open, work, pay taxes and travel abroad. And of course there was the glimmering prospect of a shortcut to citizenship.

headline: A Solemn Mass, From Rossini, With Bounce
text: Rossini’s “Petite Messe Solennelle” is a peculiar score, both as a 19th-century Mass and as a work of Rossini’s. One of Rossini’s few large works that was not written for the opera house, it has sections that sound as if they should have been: at times, the soloists and chorus seem on the verge of throwing on some costumes and hopping onto a scenery-filled stage. But elsewhere, the piece offers the solemnity promised in its title, conveyed in beautifully shaped solo writing and robust choral settings.

headline: Britain’s Widening Insider Trading Inquiry
text: Britain’s investigation into a purported insider trading ring, an inquiry that has sent tremors throughout London, got a little bigger on Wednesday.

headline: Interest in Toyotas Starts to Revive
text: Toyota’s effort to regain the car buying public’s trust with incentives appears to be working.

headline: English-Style Club Hits Miami
text: The Ivy at the Grove, 3159 Commodore Plaza, Coconut Grove, Fla; (786) 552-9993.

headline: Blockbuster Dips a Toe in the Mobile Stream
text: Blockbuster, the video-rental chain plagued by debt and unprofitable stores, is placing a bet on a mobile future.

headline: Democrats Promote Overhaul’s Benefits to Older Americans
text: As Senate Republicans attack Democrats over proposed cuts in Medicare spending in the big health care legislation, Democrats on Wednesday sought to highlight some immediate benefits for Medicare beneficiaries. At a news conference at the Capitol, the Senate majority leader, Harry Reid of Nevada, said seniors were some of the “biggest winners” in the health care overhaul.

headline: White Beans With Swiss Chard and Rice
text: This brothy dish isn’t quite brothy enough to qualify as a soup — it’s more of a filling stew. I like to combine beans and greens, but this time I threw in some rice, which makes the dish all the more comforting and filling.

headline: Black Bean Soup With Cumin and Tomatoes
text: Black beans are a great low-budget staple; ask anyone from southern Mexico or Brazil. They are loaded with anthocyanins, the phytonutrients found in blue and dark red foods (such as blueberries, red grapes, and red cabbage) that are being studied for their antioxidant properties. This is a simplified version of a black bean soup from the Veracruz region of Mexico. If you want spice, use the chipotle or serrano chile, but the dish is tasty with or without the extra heat.

headline: Jim Marshall, 74, Photographer of Rock Stars, Dies
text: Jim Marshall, a photographer who took some of the most famous images of rock and pop musicians, including Jimi Hendrix setting his guitar aflame at the Monterey International Pop Festival and Johnny Cash at San Quentin State Prison, died on Tuesday night in a hotel in New York. He was 74.

headline: Medea Story Sways to a 19th-Century Island Rhythm
text: The lilting calypso playing before the show starts clues you in: Full of music and wordplay, Steve Carter’s 1990 “Pecong,” a retelling of the Medea story set in the Caribbean at the end of the 19th century, is too cheerful to work as high Greek drama.

headline: On the Job With Patrick McMullan
text: How does one become the pre-eminent society photographer in New York City? Times video followed Patrick McMullan on a recent work night to find out.

headline: Patrick McMullan Snaps but Never Bites
text: THERE are a few fundamental tenets to being a successful New York party photographer. First, don’t take a picture of a married mogul wearing leather chaps. And never photograph an heiress if her nipple is showing or if she has passed out after drinking four double vodkas.

headline: Bank of America to Reduce Mortgage Balances
text: Bank of America said on Wednesday that it would begin forgiving some mortgage debt in an effort to keep distressed borrowers from losing their homes.

headline: Film Industry Group Asks Feds to Prevent Futures Trading on Box Office Results
text: The Motion Picture Association of America, the film industry group, has asked the federal commission that oversees futures exchanges to prevent the trading of futures contracts based on movie box-office receipts, calling such trading “unbridled gambling.”

headline: Hunting Down an Elusive iPhone Signal
text: Bar-Hopping

headline: Q&A:  Bolstering Coverage for the iPhone

headline: A Cheesy Horror Turkey Becomes a High-Flying Cult Hit

headline: Pelosi Names 3 to Obama’s Deficit Panel
text: All 18 members of President Obama’s bipartisan commission on reducing the national debt have been named now that House Speaker Nancy Pelosi on Wednesday announced three Democratic lawmakers as her choices.

text: The Times’s Jodi Kantor profiles consumer advocate Elizabeth Warren whom, she calls the “chief conceiver of and booster for a new consumer financial protection agency.” In addition to the article, we produced a video about Ms. Warren’s crusade.

headline: At Home With Wendy Burden

headline: Policy Change to Benefit Playwrights
text: With American playwrights and theaters perennially pinched for income, the Public Theater and Roundabout Theater Company in New York are changing policies to help writers earn a better living while allowing theaters to retain a financial stake in new plays when they go on to future theatrical, film or television productions.

headline: Justin Bieber’s Manager Is Arrested in Tweeting Case
text: Let it be known that if you are the manager of a teenage pop star and can’t tweet fast enough, you may face criminal penalties. That is what Scott Braun, the manager of the 16-year-old singer Justin Bieber, below, discovered on Wednesday when he was arrested on charges stemming from a November event at which Mr. Bieber’s fans stampeded during his appearance at a mall in Garden City, N.Y., The Associated Press reported. At that time the police told Mr. Braun to send out a message on Twitter saying the event was canceled. A lawyer for Mr. Braun said he sent two tweets in seven minutes, but prosecutors say it took him nearly two hours to post the messages. Mr. Braun surrendered to the Nassau County police on Wednesday and is awaiting arraignment on charges of reckless endangerment and criminal nuisance. He could be sentenced to up to a year in jail if found guilty.

headline: Winfrey Settles Lawsuit With Ex-Headmistress
text: You may see Oprah Winfrey next week on her syndicated talk show, but you won’t be seeing her in a Philadelphia courtroom. On Tuesday Ms. Winfrey settled a defamation lawsuit filed by the former headmistress of a school she set up in South Africa, who had said that Ms. Winfrey had defamed her after a sex-abuse scandal there, Reuters reported. Nomvuho Mzamane ran the Oprah Winfrey Leadership Academy for Girls in South Africa at its founding in 2007 but left after students said they were being abused by another staff member. After Ms. Winfrey said at a news conference that Ms. Mzamane had ignored the students’ complaints, Ms. Mzamane said Ms. Winfrey had defamed her and made it difficult for her to find another job. A statement from lawyers representing both women said that the dispute had been settled “peacefully to their mutual satisfaction,” according to Reuters. Terms of the settlement were not disclosed. A trial was to begin Monday in federal court in Philadelphia, where Ms. Mzamane was living when she filed the suit.

headline: A ‘Jail’ for Children Stirs a Ruckus in Brooklyn
text: Playground controversies usually involve bickering parents, unruly dogs or bullies.

headline: ‘Idol’ Wins the Night
text: Fox dominated the ratings on Tuesday night as “American Idol” faced light competition. The two-hour episode of “Idol,” with the Top 11 performers, delivered an average of 23.8 million viewers, according to Nielsen’s estimates. CBS had second place with reruns of “NCIS” (12.8 million) and “NCIS: Los Angeles” (11.2 million) while NBC ranked third with “The Biggest Loser” (8 million) and “Parenthood” (7.1 million). ABC placed fourth with a lineup that included “Lost” (9 million).

headline: Wadsworth Atheneum Plans Renovation
text: The Wadsworth Atheneum, below, in Hartford, which has emerged from several years of financial struggle and staff upheaval, has announced plans for a $16 million renovation project that will result in the addition of 8,000 square feet more gallery space, a 14 percent increase, and the complete reinstallation of the museum’s permanent collection, Susan L. Talbott, the museum’s director, said. In 2003 the Wadsworth had planned an expansion that would have cost $120 million and required the museum to close for two years, but that plan was abandoned, along with a later plan that would have spread the museum into the former Hartford Times building. The museum  American’s oldest public art institution, opened in 1842  operated with budget deficits for several years and went through five directors and three acting directors in a decade as it tried to find its footing in a city with a high poverty rate. Composed of five separate but contiguous buildings built over more than a century, the museum will remain open during the renovation, which is expected to be completed by the end of next year.

headline: Grant Ensures Treasure Will Go to Museums
text: Not long after Terry Herbert found the Staffordshire Hoard, a collection of more than 1,500 pieces of gold and silver Anglo-Saxon treasure, in a farmer’s field in Britain, Mr. Herbert, an out-of-work metal detectorist, said, “I’ve had people go past and go, ‘Beep, beep, he’s after pennies.’ ” Now we know that Mr. Herbert’s discovery, part of which is at left, is worth just a bit more than that. On Tuesday, Britain’s National Heritage Memorial Fund gave a grant of £1.29 million (about $1.9 million) to two museums that will keep the treasure, having raised £3.3 million (about $4.9 million) to keep the collection intact, The Guardian reported. The Birmingham and Stoke-on-Trent museums will pay that money to Mr. Herbert and Fred Johnson, the farmer in whose field the hoard was found, having raised donations from around the world in a campaign that began in January. David Starkey, the historian who started the fund-raising campaign, told The Guardian, “Frankly they’d have been demented not to give the money.”

headline: Chart Gets Religion
text: This week an unusual arrival is on the upper reaches of the Billboard album chart: gospel music. “Here I Am” (Verity) by Marvin Sapp, below, a veteran singer and preacher from Grand Rapids, Mich., reached No. 2 in its first week with 76,000 sales, Nielsen SoundScan reported. It is the first gospel album to be in the Top 10 since November 2008, when “The Sound” from Mary Mary reached No. 7, according to Billboard. It credits the sleeper radio success of Mr. Sapp’s 2007 song “Never Would Have Made It” for the new album’s sales. Also on this week’s chart, Lady Antebellum’s “Need You Now” (Capitol Nashville) returns to No. 1 for a fourth time with sales of 93,000, bringing its eight-week total to just under 1.5 million. Ludacris’s “Battle of the Sexes” (Def Jam), last week’s top seller, dropped two spots to No. 3 with 61,000. “The Edge” (Razor & Tie), a compilation of 32 songs by hard-rock bands like Jet, Korn and Godsmack, opened at No. 4 with 53,000, and “The Fame” (Interscope) from Lady Gaga is No. 5 with 48,000 sales in its 73rd week of release.

headline: Lineups Announced for Jazz, Folk Festivals
text: George Wein’s jazz and folk festivals in Newport, R.I., have set their lineups for the summer. The folk festival will return to Fort Adams State Park on July 31 and Aug. 1, with Richie Havens, top left; Sharon Jones, top right; and Levon Helm, John Prine, the Swell Season, the Preservation Hall Jazz Band, Yim Yames (otherwise known as Jim James of the band My Morning Jacket), Doc Watson and Calexico, among others. Steve Martin, who won a Grammy Award this year for his bluegrass album, will play the opening concert on July 30 at the International Tennis Hall of Fame. The CareFusion Newport Jazz Festival will run the next weekend (Aug. 6-8) with Wynton Marsalis, above left; Herbie Hancock, above right; and Chris Botti, Jamie Cullum, Ahmad Jamal, Mark O’Connor, Jason Moran and Ben Allison. Mr. Wein, 84, who helped found the jazz festival in 1954 and the folk festival five years later, is once again the impresario for both, and at the jazz festival he will perform with Howard Alden, Randy Brecker, Randy Sandke and Bob Brookmeyer. CareFusion, a medical technology company, is also sponsoring Mr. Wein’s jazz festival in New York from June 17 to 26. Tickets for the Newport festivals go on sale Friday. More information: newportfolkfest.net or newportjazzfest.net.

headline: Wall Street Journal’s Local News Section for New York to Arrive on April 26
text: The Wall Street Journal will begin printing a local news section for the New York market on April 26, not April 12, as previously reported, according to two people briefed on the matter.

headline: Robert Culp, ‘I Spy’ Star, Is Dead at 79
text: Robert Culp, who, as the debonair secret agent Kelly Robinson on “I Spy,” was half of one of the first racially integrated casts on  television to feature an African-American in a lead role, died, The Associated Press reported. He was 79.

text: The antiques dealer turned curator Corey Daniels lives in a house defined by Early American charm.

headline: Posada’s Move Down the Salary Chain
text: TAMPA, Fla. — Joe Mauer’s eight-year, $184 million contract extension with the Minnesota Twins means Jorge Posada will not be the highest-paid catcher in baseball next year. It is believed Mauer will make $23 million in each year of the deal, dwarfing Posada’s $13.1 million annual salary. And it ends the rumors that Mauer would end up with the Yankees as a free agent after the 2010 season.

headline: From the Vanderbilt in Reno, a European Success Story
text: Last Sunday, the final day of the Spring North American Championships in Reno, Nev., the Vanderbilt Knockout Teams was captured by Pierre Zimmerman from Switzerland, Michel and Thomas Bessis (father and son) and Franck Multon from France, and Geir Helgemo and Tor Helness from Norway. They won by 104 international match points to 94 over Martin Fleisher of New York; Michael Kamil of Holmdel, N.J.; Bobby Levin of Lake Ariel, Pa.; Steve Weinstein of Andes, N.Y.; Chip Martel of Davis, Calif.; and Lew Stansby of Dublin, Calif.

headline: What Black Writers Should Be Taught in Schools?
text: The 10th National Black Writers’ Conference begins this week at Medgar Evers College in New York, and among the topics the group will discuss is how to expand the list of black writers taught in schools. What works by black writers are taught in your school now? Do you think more should be added? What works and authors would you suggest? Why?

headline: No Method to Her Method
text: NOAH BAUMBACH’S new movie is called “Greenberg,” but it is equally  maybe even more so  the story of Florence Marr. Roger Greenberg, the title character, has the more familiar face by far; he’s played by Ben Stiller, a big movie star sliding comfortably into a small, sharp movie. But Florence’s face is the first one we see. She wanders into the frame pulling a large, slow-moving dog and is then captured in close-up as she negotiates Los Angeles traffic on the way to her job as the household assistant of a well-to-do family with a house in the hills.

headline: Direct Route to Lisbon Bypasses the Art House
text: IT says something (not good) about the state of foreign film distribution in the United States that the Portuguese director Pedro Costa has become one of the most exalted figures in world cinema without having a single one of his creations open in a commercial theater here. Instead his work has been disseminated through not-for-profit institutions like Anthology Film Archives (which presented a Costa retrospective in 2007) and the New York Film Festival (which showed his newest film, “Ne Change Rien,” a documentary about the French actress and singer Jeanne Balibar, in the fall).

text: “LET’S face it, I’m a green drag queen who uses a lot of beauty products and loves them," said Chloé Jo Davis, who blogs about environmental and vegan issues. “No offense, but we don’t want to look like stinky hippies. In my bathroom, I want products that are good for me, good for the earth, that will make me look glam. And, the product, too, has to look good."

His first reaction was one that might be expected. “I admit it: I screamed,” he writes in “Insectopedia,” his new compendium of thoughts about the creepy-crawly. “Wouldn’t you?”

headline: They Can’t Wait to Tell You
text: WHEN he copped to yelling “baby killer” at Representative Bart Stupak during debate over the health-care bill on Sunday, Representative Randy Neugebauer became the latest member of a fast-growing club, the Interrupters.

headline: Container Gardens Get Spring Started Indoors
text: ON a recent Saturday, over a cup of tea, I redefined the farm-to-table food movement. It didn’t take much. All I did was move my herb garden — that is, the farm — to my dining room table. Potting mix, dirt, seedlings, water. Everything. Without boasting, I think I can say that food does not get more local than this.

headline: Cherie DeCastro, Singer With DeCastro Sisters, Is Dead at 87
text: Cherie DeCastro, the last surviving member of the DeCastro Sisters, whose sultry ballad “Teach Me Tonight” sold millions of copies in 1954, died on March 14 in Las Vegas. She was 87.

headline: Niese Impresses in Bid to Start
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Jon Niese had a crisp two-inning stint in relief Wednesday during the Mets’ 5-2 victory over the Astros, and afterward Manager Jerry Manuel made it clear that Niese’s hold on the fifth starter’s spot was becoming more secure.

headline: A Showroom for Linens With a Global Pedigree
text: Ironically, a lot of beauty has come out of Bernie de Le Cuona’s divorce in 1992. After briefly working as an interior designer and furniture importer, Ms. de Le Cuona decided to strike out on her own as a textile designer. “I had to support myself,” she said. A year spent in India served as a crash course in fabrics and dyeing techniques. Now, in addition to overseas showrooms in London, Milan, Moscow and St. Petersburg, Ms. de Le Cuona, a native South African, has opened one in Manhattan — her first in the United States.

headline: Factory Blueprints Become Art Prints
text: Kevin Busta, a Cleveland boilermaker turned furniture maker, has released a limited-edition series of photos printed on old industrial blueprints. “Birds on A Wire,” above, is a 30-by-84-inch photograph printed on an original blueprint for a locomotive engine; it sells for $5,200 and is part of an edition of five.

headline: Chilewich Creates Mats for Dogs
text: Sandy Chilewich didn’t create her new pet mats so that Scooter, her black-and-white Havanese, could be chic. Ms. Chilewich, a Manhattan designer who makes place mats, floor mats and bags from woven vinyl, had a more practical motivation. “When we make custom floor mats, we have scrap left over,” she said. The Pet Mat ($35) was the answer, since it is relatively small, at 24 by 14 1/2 inches.

headline: The Diffa Dining by Design Show and Dinner
text: THERE were many fantastical table settings at the Diffa Dining by Design benefit exhibition and dinner in Manhattan Monday night, but the most inventive accessory was a bare-chested young man who sat, eyes closed and legs crossed, in a yoga pose at the Poggenpohl for MMPI “Morocco in New York” display. There were tables and potted trees on either side, and tent-like drapes behind him.

headline: Inside Designers’ Homes
text: Michele Keith, a writer who has been covering home furnishings and design for more than a decade, often found herself examining an interior design project and wondering whether the designer’s own home was as beautiful as the one he or she had created for the client. “I didn’t know,” Ms. Keith said earlier this week. “Do they try something new? Or are designers like the cobbler’s children and have no shoes?”

headline: Furniture, Fabrics and Beds on Sale
text: Flair, a store that carries new and vintage furnishings, is having its first warehouse sale, through March 28, with about 250 items on sale (a midcentury button-back chair, originally $3,600, is $2,150; a 1940s mirrored screen that was $5,800 is $3,400); 78 Grand Street (Wooster Street), (212) 274-1750 or flairhomecollection.com.

headline: Nets Official Confronts Fan Over a Display
text: Brett Yormark, the Nets’ chief executive, knows his team is dreadful. At 7-63 — with a chance to succeed the 9-73 Philadelphia 76ers of 1972-73 as the most futile N.B.A. team ever — that is a hard conclusion to avoid.

headline: A Small Screen Empire
text: The film producer Jerry Bruckheimer has become equally prolific in television thanks to procedural dramas.

headline: What We’re Reading: Facebook Promotes Happiness — and Syphilis?
text: Facebook Data Team: Continuing our Study of Happiness — Facebook DataClaire Cain Miller says: Canadians are happiest the day before Thanksgiving, plus other happiness nuggets from Facebook.

headline: 2 JWT Executives to Open Their Own Agency
text: Two longtime senior executives at JWT in New York, part of the WPP Group, are leaving to start their own agency in a departure that comes as a huge surprise.

headline: Megan Mullally Departs ‘Lips Together, Teeth Apart’
text: The actress Megan Mullally, who won two Emmy Awards playing Karen on the NBC television show “Will & Grace,” has quit the forthcoming Broadway revival of the play “Lips Together, Teeth Apart,” its producer, Roundabout Theater Company, announced on Wednesday evening.

headline: Simple Steps to Fix Social Security
text: With millions of jobs disappearing in this recession and more people taking early retirement, Social Security is expected to pay out more in benefits in 2010 than it takes in in payroll taxes, an event that wasn’t expected until 2016. This effect may be reversed as the recession eases, but this tipping point reminds us of where things are headed. With more baby boomers retiring, by the end of this decade outlays will exceed revenues every year regardless of the condition of the economy. By 2037, Social Security’s surplus, currently at $2.5 trillion, will be exhausted.

headline: Sid Fleischman, Children’s Author, Dies at 90
text: Sid Fleischman, a Newbery Award-winning author who never set out to write for children but flung himself into the field on a dare, died at his home in Santa Monica, Calif., on March 17, the day after his 90th birthday.

headline: Japan Leader Aims to Root Out Bureaucrats
text: TOKYO — Six months after his party’s historic election victory, tumbling approval ratings and mounting troubles threaten to make Yukio Hatoyama end up as just another unpopular Japanese prime minister. But in at least one crucial area, political experts say his new government has surpassed its predecessors: challenging the nation’s powerful and entrenched bureaucracy.

headline: Advertisers Show Interest in iPad
text: Advertisers initially approached new media as if they were going duck hunting, tiptoeing cautiously into the waters of mobile phones and the Internet.

headline: College Breaks a Tradition of Silence Before Games
text: GOSHEN, Ind. — At the small liberal arts college here known for its pacifist Mennonite traditions, sporting events have never begun with the same pregame routine as almost everywhere else — cheering hoopla for the home team, complete with a ritual salute to the flag and the playing of the national anthem. Usually, the Goshen College Maple Leafs just huddle and head out to play.

headline: Seeking Lower Fuel Costs, Ukraine May Sell Pipelines
text: MOSCOW — In recent years, state-owned natural gas pipelines in Ukraine have been the source of such tension that a midwinter fight between Russia and Ukraine over pricing — often leading to Russia’s shutting the valves and leaving people in Europe freezing — has become an annual ritual.

headline: Washington’s Pondexter Makes 4 Years Pay Off
text: When Quincy Pondexter walked into Washington Coach Lorenzo Romar’s office last spring for his after-the-season meeting, he saw documents Romar had prepared for him to sign and send into the N.B.A., requesting an evaluation of his prospects for the draft.

headline: Tech Talk Podcast: iPad Apps, Computer Genius and Robots
text: In this week’s New York Times Tech Talk podcast, Jenna Wortham, who covers digital culture for The Times, tells Bettina Edelstein about the rush to build apps for Apple‘s iPad. It poses a special challenge to developers, most of whom have been unable to get their hands on the device.

headline: El Salvador Leader Apologizes for Archbishop’s Assassination
text: MEXICO CITY — Thirty years after a sharpshooter fired a single shot at Óscar Romero, the archbishop of San Salvador, killing him as he celebrated Mass, El Salvador’s president apologized Wednesday for the assassination that helped push the country toward civil war.

headline: Military to Revise ‘Don’t Ask, Don’t Tell’ Rules
text: WASHINGTON — Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates will announce measures on Thursday to make it more difficult for the military to expel openly gay service members, an interim plan while the Pentagon examines repeal of the “don’t ask, don’t tell” policy, officials said.

headline: Switch Banks? You Might Find There’s a Perk in It for You
text: THIS should be a golden age for banks that want to persuade people to ditch their checking accounts and start fresh elsewhere.

headline: MGM Asks Lenders for More Time as It Weighs Bids
text: As expected, Metro Goldwyn Mayer on Wednesday asked its lenders for more time to reorganize its debts, as it considered three takeover bids, none of which was likely to satisfy creditor demands, people briefed on the matter told DealBook.

headline: After Health Vote, Threats on Democrats
text: WASHINGTON — Democratic lawmakers have received death threats and been the victims of vandalism because of their votes in favor of the health care bill, lawmakers and law enforcement officials said Wednesday, as the Congressional debate over the issue headed toward a bitter and divisive conclusion.

headline: Ding! Mail. OMG! It’s Steve Jobs.
