headline: Possible G.O.P. Candidate for Senate Will Skip Race
text: Dan Senor, a private equity executive and former military adviser to President George W. Bush, has decided not to challenge Senator Kirsten E. Gillibrand in the election this fall, he said in an interview on Wednesday.

headline: Time for an Insurance Checkup, as Needs and Options Change
text: FEW things in our financial lives could be as tedious yet as important as reviewing the policies that insure what we own. Hours spent poring over pages written in arcane language can seem totally wasted. So we don’t do it.

headline: Attorney General Moves to Forefront of Virginia Conservative Resurgence
text: RICHMOND, Va. — In campaigning to become Virginia’s attorney general, Kenneth T. Cuccinelli II made no secret of his conservative views, winning enthusiastic endorsements from the National Rifle Association and the National Coalition for Life.

headline: Vatican Declined to Defrock U.S. Priest Who Abused Boys
text: Top Vatican officials — including the future Pope Benedict XVI — did not defrock a priest who molested as many as 200 deaf boys, even though several American bishops repeatedly warned them that failure to act on the matter could embarrass the church, according to church files newly unearthed as part of a lawsuit.

headline: Free Speech Debated After Ann Coulter Cancels Appearance
text: OTTAWA — A decision by Ann Coulter, the conservative American political commentator and writer, to cancel an appearance at the University of Ottawa set off a debate over freedom of speech in Canada on Wednesday.

headline: A Financial Report Card, Right in Your Tax Return
text: MOST of us would like an answer to this question: Am I on the royal highway toward realizing my long-term financial goals — building up savings for the children’s education and for retirement, for example — or am I bumping along a back road that ends far short of my goals?

headline: Court Weighs Timing of Death Row Appeal
text: WASHINGTON — As is his custom, Justice John Paul Stevens did not ask a question on Wednesday until the lawyer before him had almost finished his argument. When Justice Stevens did speak up, it was in a seeming effort to guide his colleagues on the Supreme Court toward what he considered to be the central argument advanced by the death row inmate in the case.

headline: Bloggingheads: G.O.P.’s Misplayed Hand
text: Joshua Cohen, left, of Stanford University and Brink Lindsey of the Cato Institute discuss why the G.O.P. lost the fight over health care reform.

headline: Times Co. Settles Claim in Singapore
text: The New York Times Company has settled a claim by leaders of Singapore’s government that they were smeared by an Op-Ed piece in The International Herald Tribune, publishing an apology in The Herald Tribune on Wednesday and paying about $114,000 to the leaders.

headline: Ad Duel for Florida G.O.P. Senate Candidates
text: With Florida’s primary now five months – to the day – away, the two leading Republican Senate candidates in the Sunshine State spent Wednesday firing political punches at each other.

headline: Research Offers Clue Into How Hearts Can Regenerate in Some Species
text: Doctors who have treated heart attack patients with injections of stem cells have had little success so far in making the heart regenerate its stricken tissues. Researchers have now discovered that in nature, hearts are regenerated in a quite different way, one that does not depend on stem cells.

headline: West Virginia Star Finds There’s More to Life Than Pizza
text: NEWARK, N.J. — When Da’Sean Butler was a freshman at West Virginia, his father, Ira Puryear, gave him a credit card to use in case of emergency.

headline: Researchers Puzzled by Role of Osteoporosis Drug in Rare Thighbone Fractures
text: The case reports first surfaced about two years ago and they were frightening. A few orthopedists reported that women taking osteoporosis drugs to prevent broken bones were showing up with rare and serious fractures of their thighbones. The bone was snapping like a twig, sometimes splintering. Often there was no trauma, like a serious fall, to bring it on.

headline: Britons Cling to Services, Despite Debt
text: LONDON — Britain operates one of the largest welfare states in Europe. And that, it seems, is just fine with many of the British.

headline: Europe Looks at the I.M.F. With Unease as Greece Struggles
text: PARIS — With Greece facing a looming deadline to roll over $27 billion in debt, the countries of the euro zone are arguing nastily among themselves about whether and how to toss Greece to the tender mercies of the International Monetary Fund.

headline: Assemble a Paper Trail, and Make Sure Your Heirs Can Follow It
text: NO one wants to think about dying. But refusing to look at the documents that will determine where your money goes when you pass away will not make you live longer. It will just make sorting through everything more difficult for your heirs.

headline: New Overtime Rule Encounters Opposition
text: ORLANDO, Fla. — Coaches grumbled that a new rule had been forced on them, and even a few owners seemed a little stunned at how rapidly things had moved. But the N.F.L.’s new overtime rules for the postseason — and the momentum to change overtime in the regular season — were the result of Commissioner Roger Goodell’s legislative skills.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,013 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

headline: Reyes’s Arrival Boosts Morale
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — A flash of energy and good cheer brightened the Mets’ clubhouse Wednesday morning. After a two-week absence, Jose Reyes was back, bouncing along as he greeted teammates with his infectious smile and earnest hugs.

headline: Albany’s Pork Handouts
text: It pays to live in the home district of the New York Legislature’s big shots. According to a new analysis by several citizens’ groups, Senate and Assembly leaders grabbed much bigger chunks of political pork than lesser members did. This is yet another in a long list of reasons to oppose member items, as pork is known in Albany.

headline: Gone in a New York Nanosecond
text: When online registration for the 2010 New York City Triathlon opened at 12:01 a.m. last Nov. 1, Annabelle Fry manned two computers in hopes of doubling her chances at getting in. Fry successfully logged in, but as she filled out the application, all 5,600 slots were taken.

headline: Tracking Cash Purchases Without the Receipts
text: CALL it the last frontier in budgeting.

headline: Behind Consumer Agency Idea, a Scourge of Wall St.
text: Ask Elizabeth Warren, scourge of Wall Street bankers, how they treat consumers, and her no-nonsense bob will shake with indignation. She will talk about morality, about fairness, about what she calls their “let them eat cake” attitude towards taxpayers. If she is riled enough, she might even spit out the Warren version of an expletive.

headline: Woods Is Getting Ready; So Are the Hecklers
text: ORLANDO, Fla. — When Tiger Woods returns to the golf course, someone — an aggrieved fan, an ambitious bettor, an exhibitionist looking for a “SportsCenter” moment — will want to be the first to do the inevitable.

headline: Pelosi Chooses Three for Debt Panel
text: All 18 members of President Obama’s bipartisan commission on reducing the national debt have been named now that the House speaker, Nancy Pelosi, has announced three Democrats as her choices. They are Representative John M. Spratt Jr. of South Carolina, a moderate who is chairman of the House Budget Committee; Representative Xavier Becerra of California, a liberal lieutenant of Ms. Pelosi who is vice chairman of the House Democratic Caucus and a member of the Budget and Ways and Means Committees; and Representative Jan Schakowsky of Illinois, a liberal who is on the Energy and Commerce Committee.

headline: F.B.I.’s Crime-Fighting Web Site Focuses on Bank Robbers
text: Bank robberies may be down from a recent peak, but the Federal Bureau of Investigation is nevertheless making a push to track down suspects, enlisting the public’s help through a new Web site.

headline: Kentucky: Cheney Backs a Candidate
text: Former Vice President Dick Cheney endorsed Trey Grayson in the Republican primary for the Senate on Wednesday, calling him “the real conservative in this race.” In a statement, Mr. Cheney indicated that Mr. Grayson, Kentucky’s secretary of state, would be stronger on national security and fiscal issues than his opponent, Rand Paul.

headline: Texas: Condemned Man Gets a Stay
text: Less than an hour before Hank Skinner was to be put to death for the murder of his girlfriend and her two sons, the United States Supreme Court blocked his execution on Wednesday, giving him another chance to gain access to DNA evidence. Prosecutors and the state courts have repeatedly refused to let him test blood, fingernail scrapings and hair found at the scene of the killings against his genetic markers. The justices ordered the execution postponed until they decide whether to review the case. Mr. Skinner maintains he was sleeping on a sofa in a vodka-and-codeine haze when the killings took place on New Year’s Eve in 1993.

headline: Texas: Housing Ban Is Struck Down
text: A federal judge in Dallas struck down an ordinance on Wednesday in the suburb of Farmers Branch that would have barred illegal immigrants from renting housing there. The judge, Jane J. Boyle of Federal District Court, issued a permanent injunction, finding that the ordinance violated the Constitution by regulating immigration, which she found to be “an exclusively federal power.”

headline: How to Self-Diagnose Your Financial Health
text: YOU probably get an annual physical. Your doctor will ask about your concerns, take your blood pressure and 30 minutes later you’re out of the paper gown and off to work — maybe with a new prescription for Lipitor.

headline: Quarters Will Feature Parks
text: The United States Mint will start circulating quarters honoring national parks and other national sites in April. In all, the America the Beautiful Quarters Program plans to release 56 quarters through 2021, eventually highlighting sites in all 50 states, the District of Columbia and five United States territories. The first quarter will recognize Hot Springs National Park in Arkansas.

headline: Japan, Struggling With Debt, Approves a $1 Trillion Budget
text: TOKYO — The Japanese government on Wednesday pushed a record 92.3 trillion yen ($1 trillion) budget through Parliament aimed at stimulating growth in the long-stagnant economy. It means another round of spending and adding to Tokyo’s already substantial public debt.

headline: Skepticism and Optimism Meet With Mets
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.

headline: House of Anger
text: Unfairly or not, the defining images of opposition to health care reform may end up being those rage-filled partisans with spittle on their lips. Whether the outbursts came from inside Congress — the “baby killer” shout of Rep. Randy Neugebauer, and his colleagues who cheered on hecklers — or outside, where protesters hurled vile names against elected representatives, they are powerful and lasting scenes of a democracy gasping for dignity.

headline: Transit Agency Approves Cuts, and More Bad News Looms
text: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority formally approved on Wednesday a slate of severe service cuts that will eliminate two subway lines and dozens of bus routes in the city and create longer, more-crowded trips for the region’s transit riders.

headline: Fly Moves
text: "If I could see only one show this spring, I'd be hard pressed to talk myself out of 'No Time to Fly,' a new solo choreographed and performed by the singular Deborah Hay, who has been creating ensemble work for the past few years,"  Claudia La Rocco writes. "Hats off to Danspace Project and the guest curator Juliette Mapp for inviting this native New Yorker and ceaseless experimenter to be a part of the Back to New York City series." Ms. Hay, a former dancer with Merce Cunningham, and one of the most influential artists to come out of the Judson Dance Theater, will perform on Thursday at 8 p.m.

headline: The Old Days
text: Hip-hop fans nostalgic for the glory days should head uptown to Maysles Cinema for the final night of the "Under the Influence of Ego Trip" film series. On Thursday night the series will screen "Public Enemy and LL Cool J Live in Europe," a 1987 film never before screened in the United States. Also on the bill is 1986's "Big Fun in the Big Town," directed by Bram van Splunteren. The film features rare footage of Grandmaster Flash, Run-DMC, Doug E. Fresh and the Get Fresh Crew, Biz Markie, Russell Simmons, Schoolly D and others. The screening will be followed by a discussion with Doug E. Fresh, Mr. van Splunteren and Schoolly D, as well as Bill Adler, a former executive at Def Jam Records, and then a reception sponsored by Sugar Hill Ale.

headline: Part Play, Part Opera
text: "The English were wary of the Continental taste for opera in the 17th century," writes Allan Kozinn, "but they liked the idea of adorning plays with music. What composers and theater producers came up with is a curious compromise that Roger North, a writer at the time, called 'semi-opera.' " He goes on to say that "the staging of Purcell's 'Fairy Queen' that opened at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Tuesday evening makes a powerful argument for the hybrid form." Jonathan Kent directs this production of the 1692 adaptation of Shakespeare's "Midsummer Night's Dream," which features William Christie conducting his ensemble, Les Arts Florissants, and is the centerpiece of the new BAM Opera Festival. Go to listen to the music and look out for the masques, or mini-dramatic interludes. They "are freewheeling and almost vaudevillian in spirit," Mr. Kozinn writes, especially the "Masque of Seduction"  "presented at one point by an army of choristers in bunny costumes, offering what appeared to be a quick tour of the Kama Sutra."

headline: Mobs Are Born as Word Grows by Text Message
text: PHILADELPHIA — It started innocently enough seven years ago as an act of performance art where people linked through social-networking Web sites and text messaging suddenly gathered on the streets for impromptu pillow fights in New York, group disco routines in London, and even a huge snowball fight in Washington.

headline: U.S. Presses Israel on Housing as Dispute Widens
text: WASHINGTON — With Israeli officials saying that construction on a contentious Jewish housing project in East Jerusalem could begin at any time, President Obama pressed Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu on Wednesday to give a written commitment to rein in any further building and to move ahead on peace talks with the Palestinians.

headline: Start Saving Early, and Keep an Eye on Shifting Needs
text: EVEN economic oracles would have trouble predicting their retirement needs with a high degree of precision.

headline: Coburn’s Erectile Dysfunction Amendment Is Killed
text: It was, by all accounts, the most politically volatile amendment proposed to the health care legislation so far: a proposal by Senator Tom Coburn, Republican of Oklahoma, to bar federal health programs and the future federally regulated insurance exchanges from covering the cost of erectile dysfunction medication for convicted sex offenders.

headline: Social Security to See Payout Exceed Pay-In This Year
text: The bursting of the real estate bubble and the ensuing recession have hurt jobs, home prices and now Social Security.

headline: Retain Your Records No Longer Than You Must
text: I’VE long been a pack rat when it comes to saving financial documents. I have a file cabinet full of old cellphone and credit card bills, brokerage firm and bank account statements and health insurance benefit forms.

headline: The Importance of Being Counted (Pop. 842)
text: SAN ANTONIO, Fla.

headline: Gallinari and Douglas Give Knicks Hope
text: If this is a renaissance, the Knicks picked a peculiar time for it. Their losing record is assured, the playoffs are a near impossibility, and the season is down to 11 seemingly meaningless games. There is  little to gain now.

headline: Cornell Counts on Closeness Against Kentucky
text: ITHACA, N.Y. — There are some days at the old, ramshackle house here on Dryden Road when things get so dirty that even 15 college guys cannot cope. In their rickety three-story dwelling, where 14 members of the Cornell basketball team and a team manager live near campus, teamwork involves cleaning with a shovel, scooping up the empty Mountain Dew cans and Subway wrappers as if they were another snowdrift.

headline: After Arrests, Taliban Promote a Fighter
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — The Taliban’s supreme leader has replaced his top deputy with a relatively young but hardened fighter, an indication of the Taliban’s determination to push ahead with its insurgency despite the recent arrests of a handful of high-level commanders in Pakistan, according to Afghans and Pakistanis close to the Taliban.

headline: The Predator Priest Who Got Away
text: An interactive timeline tracing the case of the Rev. Lawrence C. Murphy, who admitted he sexually abused deaf boys at his boarding school for 22 years.

headline: ‘At the Movies’ Is Canceled
text: The balcony is closed, this time for good. After nearly three decades, “At the Movies,” the syndicated television program that introduced many viewers to the film critics Gene Siskel and Roger Ebert, as well as to film criticism in all its thorny and contentious glory, will cease production this summer, the studio that produces the show said.

headline: California’s Overcrowded Prisons
text: Though prison overcrowding has long plagued California, a budget crisis is forcing the state to take unprecedented steps to shrink the prison population.

headline: Robert Culp, Star in ‘I Spy,’ Dies at 79
text: Robert Culp, who teamed with Bill Cosby as a secret agent in the hit 1960s television series “I Spy” and starred as one of the sexually adventurous title characters in the 1969 film “Bob & Carol & Ted & Alice,” died on Wednesday in Los Angeles. He was 79.

headline: A Grand Achievement, or a Lost Opportunity?
text: WASHINGTON — When the last swords in the great health care clash finally clatter to the ground, and Congressional Democrats head home to savor their victory, a question that may still nag at them — and the party’s liberal base — is whether they missed a last, best chance to create the government-run insurance plan known as the public option.

headline: General Works to Salvage Iraq Legacy
text: JOINT SECURITY STATION LOYALTY, IRAQ — In the muddled aftermath of Iraq’s election, the American commander here, Gen. Ray Odierno, landed at this base on the edge of Baghdad and reviewed the plan to close it.

headline: Unions Make Strides as They Attack Banks
text: When the city of Los Angeles started looking into its complex financial contracts with banks earlier this year, some council members turned to an unusual corner for financial advice: labor unions.

headline: China Says It Will Not Adjust Exchange Rate
text: WASHINGTON — Despite mounting pressure in Congress for the Obama administration to declare China a currency manipulator, the Chinese government is giving no indication that it will change its exchange rate policy.

headline: British Regulator Makes 7th Arrest in Trading Inquiry
text: The Financial Services Authority, Britain’s top markets regulator, arrested a seventh person in an insider trading inquiry that has already ensnared workers at Deutsche Bank, Exane and the hedge fund Moore Capital Management.

headline: Remembering Dan Naddor
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — Dan Naddor, the author of today’s puzzle, is no longer with us. He died of cancer complications on Dec. 29. But that doesn’t mean he’s done making us laugh.

headline: Former Chairman, Once Convicted, Returns to Samsung
text: SEOUL, South Korea — Lee Kun-hee, the former chairman of Samsung who was convicted of corruption last August but pardoned by President Lee Myung-bak four months later to help a campaign for the 2018 Winter Olympics, returned to the helm of Samsung Electronics on Wednesday.

headline: Two New Towers May End the Impasse at Ground Zero
text: Port Authority and other government officials and the developer Larry A. Silverstein have reached a tentative agreement that could resolve a 16-month impasse at ground zero and allow two new skyscrapers to be built on the site.

headline: With a Little Star Power, Top Brass Ask for Ideas
text: EXECUTIVES at Allstate, known, after their famous slogan, as “the ‘good hands’ people,” are looking for a few good advertising ideas — and are making that clear in attention-getting fashion.

headline: Corrections
text: An article in some editions on Saturday about Lt. Gen. Lloyd J. Austin III as the leading candidate to succeed Gen. Ray Odierno as the top American commander in Iraq misspelled the surname of the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. He is Adm. Mike Mullen  not Mullin.

headline: Rodriguez Limits Discussion to Baseball
text: TAMPA, Fla. — Alex Rodriguez knew questions were coming about his coming interview with federal investigators regarding the Canadian-based doctor Anthony Galea. So Rodriguez stopped in front of his locker in the Yankees clubhouse early Wednesday afternoon to get them over with.

headline: A Census Question
text: To the Editor:

headline: How Immigration Is Changing the Face of America
text: To the Editor:

headline: Too-Busy Bees
text: IN the past five years, as the phenomenon known as colony-collapse disorder has spread across the United States and Europe, causing the disappearance of whole colonies of domesticated honeybees, many people have come to fear that our food supply is in peril. The news on Wednesday that a Department of Agriculture survey found that American honeybees had died in great numbers this winter can only add to such fears.

headline: School Standards: National or Local?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Brave New Health Care World
text: Change is so traumatic.

headline: Suicide Among the Young: How to Try to Prevent It
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Fight Is Over, the Myths Remain
text: Ann Arbor, Mich.

headline: The Pope and the Pedophilia Scandal
text: Pope Benedict XVI’s latest apology for the emerging global scandal of child abuse by predatory priests  an issue that the Roman Catholic Church should have engaged years ago  is strong on forgiveness but far short of the full accountability that Catholics need for repairing their damaged church.

headline: From Mrs. Obama’s Garden
text: A year ago, Michelle Obama and pupils from a Washington elementary school dug up a patch of the South Lawn to plant a White House vegetable garden. Mrs. Obama’s stated goal  apart from providing food for her family’s meals and for formal dinners  was to promote healthful, locally grown fruit and vegetables and healthier eating by kids at a time of rising rates of childhood obesity and diabetes.

headline: Escaping From Poverty
text: Before I ask for a drumroll and reveal “the secrets” of fighting poverty, a bit of background:

headline: Prosecutors Gone Wild
text: Schools across the country are understandably concerned about students “sexting”  sending sexually suggestive photos and text messages by cellphone. But a Pennsylvania school district went too far when it referred several female students for criminal prosecution after their images showed up on other students’ phones and they refused to participate in an antisexting education program. A federal appeals court was right to rule last week that parents had the right to block the district attorney from prosecuting the girls.

headline: Coyote Takes TriBeCa
text: WABC-TV

headline: Cornell Adds Fences to Bridges to Deter Suicides by Students
text: Cornell University this week erected temporary fencing along three university-owned bridges that cross the deep gorges on its campus, where three students have jumped to their deaths in recent weeks.

headline: Racial Slurs Preceded L.I. Attack, Victim’s Friend Testifies
text: RIVERHEAD, N.Y. — Walking in Patchogue with a friend shortly before midnight on a Saturday in November 2008, Angel Loja saw some young people approaching them.

headline: Players on Committee Favor Fast Approval on Head Checks
text: N.H.L. punishment for blind-side checks to the head is becoming increasingly likely. Key members of the union on Wednesday endorsed the league’s move to speed approval for suspensions for such head checks starting immediately, rather than wait for the beginning of next season.

headline: Mets Increase the Food Offerings, if Not the Homers
text: It should come as no surprise that sports teams are in the business of getting fans to part with as much of their money as possible when they visit the stadium: tickets, parking, scorecards, T-shirts and, of course, food and drinks.

headline: Corrections
text: A headline and an article on Wednesday about President Obama’s signing the health care overhaul into law misstated the number of pens he used. It was 22, not 20. (The president handed out 19 as mementoes, kept one for himself and set two aside to be archived.) The error was repeated in a caption on the front page.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on March 3 about a survey by Public Agenda, a nonprofit research group, of the opinions of high school graduates in the last dozen years toward their guidance counselors referred incorrectly to two ratios cited in the survey. The ratio of students to counselors that is considered optimal by the American School Counselor Association is 250 to 1, not 100 to 1. The average student to counselor ratio nationally is nearly 470 to 1, not 265 to 1.

headline: Albany Senate to Release Some Files on Aqueduct
text: ALBANY — Senate Democrats said on Wednesday that they would make public some documents related to the controversial awarding of a casino gambling contract at the Aqueduct racetrack in Queens, even as they waged a legal battle to quash subpoenas from the state inspector general’s office, which is investigating the Aqueduct deal.

headline: Midge Costanza, a Top Assistant to Carter, Dies at 77
text: Midge Costanza, a top assistant to President Jimmy Carter whose habit of criticizing her boss and whose fractious relations with his inner circle of advisers led her to resign after less than two years on the job, died Tuesday in San Diego. She was 77.

headline: Ex-Bouncer With a Death Stare Has Led Kansas State’s Resurgence
text: As the first American-born member of his Cuban family, Kansas State Coach Frank Martin worked nearly every job imaginable while growing up in Miami.

headline: Inquiry Could Lead to Court-Martial for Ex-Army Surgeon
text: The former military surgeon and Medtronic consultant accused of falsifying research about the benefits of a bone-growth product used on soldiers injured in Iraq is now under investigation for a possible court-martial, officials at the Walter Reed Army Medical Center said Wednesday.

headline: Paterson and Legislature at Odds as Budget Deadline Nears
text: ALBANY — The prospects of approving a state budget on time faded rapidly on Wednesday, as Gov. David A. Paterson said that his differences with the Legislature over spending were too great to bridge by the March 31 deadline. State officials, meanwhile, began preparing an emergency measure to keep the government functioning after the deadline.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: March 24, 2010

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Tuesday about a Toyota policy on replacing accelerator pedals in models recalled for pedal repairs referred incorrectly to the beginning of the policy. It was put into place in February, when the company announced its repair program, not earlier this month.

headline: 3-D vs. High-Definition at the Garden
text: There were two versions of 3-D hockey at Madison Square Garden on Wednesday night when the Rangers played the Islanders. One was in the Theater, where 2,600 fans, advertisers, members of the news media and others watched on a giant screen that was not ideal for 3-D.

headline: Citibank Branch Property Is in Tunnel Planners’ Sights
text: New Yorkers who would like to see the number of bank branches in the city reduced at any cost may have a new reason to support efforts to build an $8.7 billion train tunnel between Manhattan and New Jersey.

headline: Corrections
text: The Your Money column on Saturday, about whether to pay off mortgage debt early, included an incorrect calculation in an example of tax treatment of mortgage interest. A household in the 35 percent tax bracket paying $20,000 a year in mortgage interest would reap tax savings of $7,000, not $7,500, making the net cost $13,000, not $12,500.

headline: Delay for Notices About High School
text: Eighth-grade students will indeed have to wait at least one more day before they can find out where they will attend high school next fall.

headline: Point Guard’s Injury Leaves West Virginia Thin in Backcourt
text: SYRACUSE — Darryl Bryant, West Virginia’s starting point guard, was on crutches Wednesday watching his teammates practice at the Carrier Dome. The loss of Bryant, known as Truck, to a broken right foot in practice on Tuesday could not have come at a worse time for the Mountaineers —  two days before a Round of 16 matchup in the N.C.A.A. tournament against Washington — or to a more crucial position.

headline: Corrections
text: A music review on Tuesday about a fund-raising concert for Haiti at Carnegie Hall on Sunday night by the pianist Lang Lang and the Schleswig-Holstein Festival Orchestra referred incorrectly to the orchestra’s performance. Its American debut was on Friday night at the Tilles Center for the Performing Arts on the C. W. Post campus of Long Island University in Brookville, N.Y. The Carnegie Hall concert was not its American debut.

headline: Audit Faults Bookkeeping by Office Under Morgenthau
text: The Manhattan district attorney’s office exhibited a “lack of transparency” in dividing $448 million in settlement accounts between New York City and New York State between January 2007 and December 2009, according to an audit released on Wednesday by City Comptroller John C. Liu.

headline: Corrections
text: A listing of credits on Wednesday with a television review of the documentary “The Senators’ Bargain,” using information provided by HBO2, included three misspelled surnames. The film is part of the series “How Democracy Works Now” and the series coordinating producer is Rachel Salmon, not Solomon. One of the sound editors is Michael Feuser, not Fevser. And the colorist/online editor is Savvas Paritsis, not Paritis.

headline: Is the Stagnation in Poverty Real?
text: The premise of my Thursday column — that the proportion of people living in poverty has stagnated since the 1970’s — is sometimes contested by conservatives. They note that since the poverty threshold was devised in the 1960’s, a range of programs have been introduced to alleviate poverty: free school lunches, food stamps, earned income tax credits, and so on. None of those safety net programs are counted in determining whether someone lives below the poverty line, and so — the argument goes — the proportion of people living in poverty is hugely overcounted.

headline: Healthy Banks Gear Up to Buy Weaker Rivals
text: As the list of America’s problem banks balloons, healthy institutions are gearing up to capitalize on the misfortune of others. Just look at First Interstate BancSystem, the first bank to begin an initial public offering since before the financial crisis. It may use the proceeds to pick off failed rivals.

headline: Corrections
text: A picture from The Associated Press on March 2 with an article about new research on selfishness and altruism, based on the behavior of men aboard the sinking ocean liners Titanic and Lusitania, was published in error. It showed the Mauretania  not its sister ship, the Lusitania.

headline: Mount Sinai Shows Interest in St. Vincent’s Hospital
text: Representatives of Mount Sinai Medical Center have taken an interest in St. Vincent’s Hospital Manhattan, the struggling Greenwich Village institution that has been looking for a partner so it can stay afloat, officials said Wednesday.

headline: Jim Marshall, Rock Photographer, Dies
text: Jim Marshall, whose images of musicians in the 1960s and 1970s helped define rock ‘n’ roll photography, died at 74.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Tuesday about new research that suggests early intervention is crucial to preventing obesity referred incorrectly to a plan by the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation to spend $500 million to fight childhood obesity. It plans to spend that amount by 2015  not over 14 years.

headline: Corrections
text: An obituary on Wednesday about the pharmacologist James W. Black misstated the year he was born. It was 1924, not 1934. (The headline and the obituary correctly noted that Dr. Black, who was born on June 14, was 85.)

headline: DNA Testing Leads to Arrest in 1981 Killing
text: A 56-year-old man already serving time for two murders was charged on Wednesday in a third killing, the strangulation of a Bronx woman nearly three decades ago.

headline: Corrections
text: An obituary last Thursday about Wayne Collett, an American runner who was barred from competing again in Olympic competition after he was judged to have acted disrespectfully during a medal ceremony in Munich in 1972, misspelled the given name and the surname of the sports information director at the University of California, Los Angeles, where Collett had been a track and field star. He is Marc Dellins, not Mark Dellims.

headline: Corrections
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Canada: Bill in Quebec Would Ban Veils in Dealings With Officials
text: In the latest of a series of measures related to religious displays, the province of Quebec introduced legislation on Wednesday requiring people to show their faces to receive government services. The bill does not make specific reference to Muslim women, but Premier Jean Charest told reporters that the law “respects the principle of equality between men and women.” Although Muslim women who cover their faces are not prominent in Quebec, there has been considerable controversy in the province about the practice.

headline: Correction
text: An article last Thursday about home automation overstated Dan Levine’s role in the founding of CytexOne, a company that installs such systems. He was one of the company’s founders, not its sole founder. An accompanying list of do-it-yourself home automation devices referred incorrectly to Indigo Touch, an app for the iPhone and iPod Touch. It is made by Perceptive Automation, not by Insteon, which is a home-automation technology.

headline: Corrections
text: The Skin Deep column last Thursday, about women and aging, misspelled the surname of the feminist author who said of a woman’s later years, “If you are going to pretend it’s youth, you are going to miss it.” She was Betty Friedan, not Freidan.

headline: Looking Ahead: Round of 16
text: EAST

headline: Take a Few Hours and Unlock Some Cash
text: To be a modern American consumer is to be plagued by a never-ending, guilt-inducing stream of undone tasks.

headline: In New Orleans, Getting Serious Over Suits
text: Many Mardi Gras Indians have become fed up with seeing their elaborate costumes on calendars and expensive prints without getting anything in return.

headline: Consultations on Myanmar Produce Opposing Views
text: China and Britain emerged from closed Security Council consultations on Myanmar with opposite views on that country’s expected elections in the fall. Li Baogong, the new Chinese envoy to the United Nations, described the vote as a domestic matter and an “important step” toward national reconciliation and democracy. The British ambassador, Mark Lyall Grant, told reporters that the new electoral laws in Myanmar, formerly known as Burma, “fall well short of what the international community expected in a free and fair process.” Britain, which called the session, accused the military junta running the country of writing the laws specifically to make it difficult for Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the opposition leader and a Nobel laureate, to participate. Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi, above, said this week that she opposed registering her party for the elections. Her comments came hours after Myanmar’s highest court refused to accept a lawsuit filed by the party that sought to revoke five new election laws.

headline: France: Man Accused of Hacking Twitter Accounts
text: After an investigation of months conducted jointly with the F.B.I., French authorities on Tuesday detained a 25-year-old Frenchman accused of hacking the Twitter accounts of several high-profile people, including the official account of President Obama and an account for Britney Spears, French media reported Wednesday. The man, known by the alias Hacker Croll, is accused of infiltrating the accounts on Twitter, a social networking Web site, in April 2009. French authorities have not revealed his real name. The man was released Wednesday but is set to face charges in court in June. He could be sentenced to up to two years in prison if convicted.

headline: Jim Marshall, Rock ’n’ Roll Photographer, Dies at 74
text: Jim Marshall, a photographer whose images of Jimi Hendrix, the Rolling Stones, Johnny Cash and others in the 1960s and ’70s helped define their subjects as well as rock ’n’ roll photography itself, was found dead on Wednesday morning in a Manhattan hotel. He was 74.

headline: Word of the Day | consistent
text: consistent •\kən-ˈsis-tənt\• adjective

headline: Richard Engquist, ‘Kuni-Leml’ Lyricist, Is Dead at 76
text: Richard Engquist, whose witty way with a lyric sparked the Off Broadway musicals “Kuni-Leml” and “Little Ham,” died on March 18 in Brooklyn. He was 76.

headline: At the Top of This Cornell Class
text: SYRACUSE, N.Y. — The storyline has been worn to threads: Cornell, the Ivy League champ and round of 16 surprise, has some smart kids on its roster.

headline: G.O.P. Forces Another House Vote on Package of Changes to Health Bill
text: 2:50 a.m. |Reconciliation Bill Will Have to Go Back to House

headline: Shares Fall on Worries About Sales and Europe Debt
text: Shares on Wall Street pulled back from their recent winning streak on Wednesday amid concerns about debt problems in Portugal and disappointing home sales in the United States, The New York Times’s David Jolly and Javier C. Hernandez reported.

headline: Buck’s Show May Be Over
text: After three episodes, Joe Buck says he does not expect his HBO show “Joe Buck Live” to continue. “There’s only another nine months on that contract anyway, so I don’t think it’s that big of a deal either way,” he told the St. Louis sports talk station 1380 AM on Wednesday. Asked if he would miss it, he said: “No, not really. There was a lot more behind the scenes, a lot more effort and hassle than I ever expected.”

headline: Rio Tinto Trial Ends in China, but Verdict Awaits
text: The trial of four employees of the British-Australian mining giant Rio Tinto ended in Shanghai on Wednesday afternoon, but a verdict had not been reached on charges that the group accepted millions of dollars in bribes from Chinese steel companies and stole commercial secrets, The New York Times’s David Barboza writes.

headline: News Quiz | March 25, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page.

headline: Three from Alstom Questioned in U.K. Bribery Inquiry
text: Three executives of the British unit of Alstom, the French transport and power equipment conglomerate, have been questioned on suspicion of bribery, corruption, money laundering and false accounting, British officials said Wednesday.

headline: Unions Make Strides as They Attack Banks

headline: The Influential Books Game
text: More than a week ago, Tyler Cowen kicked off an irresistible blogospheric listing exercise: In this case, the theme is “10 books which have influenced your view of the world.” You can find Matthew Yglesias’s list here, Will Wilkinson’s list here, Matt Continetti’s here, and many more at this link. My own follows below. Note that these are not my 10 favorite books, nor the 10 best books I’ve ever read, but the books that quickly came to mind — I was following Cowen’s “go with your gut” admonition — as having shaped my writing or pushed me in one intellectual direction or another over the years. As an experiment, I’ve also tried listing them in rough chronological order, starting with the books that influenced me as a child and working my way upward (or downward, perhaps) toward adulthood. And like many people, I’ve cheated and gone over 10 — in my case, by doubling up on a few that share an author or a theme.

headline: Sampler: Voters to Decide on Legalizing Marijuana, and the Mud Claims a Ghost Town
text: Voters to Decide on Legalizing Marijuana | For the second time in 40 years, voters in California will decide whether to legalize marijuana, after a ballot initiative — which proposes to legalize pot and allow it to be sold and taxed — qualified to be on the November ballot, state officials announced Wednesday. Supporters turned in 694,248 signatures from every county except Alpine. Officials in Los Angeles County, where the signatures were submitted Wednesday night, estimated 523,531 signatures were valid. To qualify for the November election, the ballot needed 433,971 signatures. Richard Lee, an Oakland marijuana entrepreneur, has spent $1.3 million to put together the campaign. “We’re one step closer to ending cannabis prohibition and the unjust laws that lock people up for cannabis while alcohol is not only sold openly but advertised on television to kids every day,” he said. [The Los Angeles Times, The San Francisco Chronicle]

headline: Speed Read for Thursday, March 25

headline: Theater Talkback: Costume Drama
text: Even before he opens his mouth, you can tell that the central character in Martin McDonagh’s “Behanding in Spokane” is bonkers. Of course, it’s kind of a giveaway that he’s being played by Christopher Walken, that master interpreter of psychos. But look closely at what he’s wearing, and how he’s wearing it. Everything is at least secondhand, and nothing really fits, including that big black coat and those oversize, way-too-short pants. Yet his clothes seem as much a part of him as his skin, or a carapace for an armadillo. This guy lives in those duds and probably has for a long, long time.

headline: Nearly 30 Years After a Grisly Murder, A Charge
text: In the autumn of 1981, the partly clothed body of a 36-year-old woman was found in a shack on an abandoned lot just down the road from Crotona Park in the Bronx. She had been strangled with a scarf that was wrapped around her neck and tightened with a chisel.

headline: How They Got the Shot

But the stories behind them – and the lengths photographers have gone to capture them – are often more of a mystery. A new exhibition at Hasted Hunt Kraeutler in New York, “Great Photographs of the 20th Century: Staged and Startled,” looks under the skirts of 22 such photos by the likes of Richard Avedon, Irving Penn, William Eggleston, Steven Klein and Tina Barney.

headline: Maazel to Join Munich Philharmonic as Chief Conductor
text: Lorin Maazel, the venerated maestro who ended his term as the music director of the New York Philharmonic last year, will not be sitting on his laurels for very long. On Wednesday, the City Council of Munich voted unanimously to approve Mr. Maazel’s appointment as chief conductor of the Munich Philharmonic Orchestra, the orchestra said on its Web site. His appointment will be effective with the 2012-13 season. In a statement, Christian Ude, the mayor of Munich, said the orchestra had succeeded in signing up “one of the world’s pre-eminent conductors” who will “motivate and inspire excellence.” Mr. Maazel, who was a highly visible figure in Munich when he served as the chief conductor of the Bavarian Radio Symphony, added in his own statement that “the quality of the orchestra is unsurpassed,” and that following in the footsteps of previous conductors like Sergiu Celibidache, who conducted the Munich orchestra until his death in 1996, “represents a challenge” that he will take on “with joy.”

headline: Andy Warhol’s Daimler Works Are Shown After 22 Years
text: In 1986, Daimler-Benz commissioned the pop artist Andy Warhol to make a series of paintings to celebrate the automaker’s centennial. The plan was for 80 works, and the subjects would be 20 of Daimler’s most important cars, including the Benz Patent Motorwagen of 1886, the first car ever built. But Warhol died on Feb. 22, 1987, of a heart attack shortly after gall bladder surgery. At the time of his death, he had completed only 35 silkscreens and 12 large-scale drawings. They were his last works.

headline: Correction | DVD Column
text: The DVD column last Sunday, about the movie “African Queen,” misidentified the countries that comprise German East Africa, the setting of the film. Current-day Rwanda, Burundi and the continental portion of Tanzania sit on the territory that was German East Africa; Congo does not sit on the former colony.

headline: Deconstructing the Sandwich

headline: The Coach King Feels the Bruises and Thanks You
text: It’s not that runway debuts are unusual, but when the debut is by Reed Krakoff, the executive creative director of Coach, more attention is paid than to a struggling small fry. Reviews in February for Mr. Krakoff’s collection for his own label were noticeably ungloved. “Heavy” and “clunky” noted Women’s Wear Daily, while a commenter on its blog spat out zzzz’s. Style.com sensed a Phoebe Philo influence. Suzy Menkes called the collection “a work in progress.” Scott Schuman, on his  Sartorialist blog, praised the designer for hitting “that sweet spot of design that is just aspirational enough while still being something that you can imagine in everyday life.”

headline: Kiner Recalls Spring Training in the ’40s

headline: Beyond the Cheese Steak Wars in Philadelphia

headline: No Poll Will Decide This Tournament
text: As the N.C.A.A. tournament’s Round of 16 gets ready to tip off, let’s pause for a second to absorb the tournament’s beauty. Sure, the selection process seems suspiciously rigged in favor of the big-conference teams. And yes, it is really a gigantic business venture wrapped in the warm and fuzzy story line of “shining moments” and it will most likely be obliterated when the N.C.A.A. scraps the 65-team format in favor of a horrific 96-team money grab. But — and this doesn’t sound novel except when you compare it with Division I college football — teams actually play one another to win a national title and there is no poll involved.

headline: Accusations Fly Between Parties Over Threats and Vandalism
text: IVY, Va. — The authorities here confirmed Thursday that a gas line had been deliberately cut at the home of a brother of a Democratic congressman who voted for the health care bill, making it potentially the most dangerous of many acts of violence and threats against supporters of the bill in the last week.

headline: Yankees Name Hughes as Fifth Starter
text: SARASOTA, Fla. — Phil Hughes will be the Yankees’ fifth starter. Manager Joe Girardi confirmed that Thursday morning after the Yankees arrived here to play the Baltimore Orioles. Girardi told Hughes and Joba Chamberlain, who are not on the trip, just before the team bus left.

headline: Without Warning, Ambivalence Takes Hold
text: I’m beginning to realize, painfully and with much confusion, that the end results of my college decisions won’t be so crazily important in the overall trajectory of my life. It’s so odd to actually commit this revelation into words, because I’ve invested so much of my life and energy into this self-divesting process. I feel like I’ve betrayed myself in some way by admitting that all those terrible months of preparation, stress and waiting don’t really amount to that much.

headline: Households Facing Foreclosure Rose in 4th Quarter
text: The ranks of those facing foreclosure swelled by a quarter-million households in the fourth quarter, new government data shows.

headline: Radioactive Leak Is Fixed at Vermont Plant
text: Technicians have found and fixed two holes in an underground pipe that were allowing radioactive tritium to flow into the groundwater at the Vermont Yankee nuclear reactor, the plant’s owner, Entergy, said Thursday.

headline: New Face for ‘That Face’
text: The actress Elizabeth Marvel has departed the coming Off Broadway play “That Face” because of television and film commitments, she said on Thursday. Laila Robins (“Frozen,” “Heartbreak House”) will replace her in the central role of a manipulative mother in the Manhattan Theater Club production.

headline: Europeans Reach Deal on Rescue Plan for Greece
text: BRUSSELS — After months of fractious debate, the 16 countries that use the euro agreed on a financial safety net for Greece, combining bilateral loans from those European nations with cash from the International Monetary Fund.

headline: Assemblyman Convicted on Impaired Driving Charge
text: Assemblyman Adam Clayton Powell IV was found guilty on Thursday of driving while ability impaired but cleared of more serious drunken driving charges, ending a two-year legal odyssey that began with his arrest in 2008.

headline: Shortlist Unveiled for ‘Lost’ Man Booker Prize
text: These were the ones that almost got away. In an act of literary reparation, the Booker Prize Foundation, the organization that bestows Britain’s most prestigious book prize, has named a shortlist of books published in 1970 that were never eligible for the Man Booker Prize because of a change in the award calendar.

headline: Polls Show Public Still Skeptical of Health Care Law
text: While President Obama promotes health care legislation in Iowa today, polls taken since the bill passed find somewhat more support for the measure, but also reveal a nation still skeptical of overhauling the health care system.

headline: Bin Laden Derides Obama and Threatens Americans in New Tape

headline: Unemployment Rate Drops Again
text: New York City’s unemployment rate dipped in February, raising hopes that the effects of the long recession are waning and the pace of hiring may pick up soon.

headline: Phish in 3-D That Everyone Can See
text: Hmm. Can you think of any reason why the fans of a popular jam band might enjoy the experience of seeing their favorite musicians in a movie presented in 3-D? Off the top of our heads, we couldn’t, but we’re still reasonably certain that a new 3-D film featuring Phish in a coming-at-you concert will find its audience.

headline: Democrats Praise Health Care Law’s Benefits
text: With the finish line in sight, Senator John D. Rockefeller IV seems pretty happy about the status of the health care debate. And he wasn’t afraid to talk about it this morning.

headline: Canadian Bacon (Plus) | Smoked Meat in Toronto
text: In my first hour in Toronto, I ate these things: stewed rabbit, blueberry-buckwheat pancakes, crisp ribbons of translucent guanciale and billowy mounds of smoked ricotta. And this was all just the first dish. Brunch at Hoof Café — the new offshoot of Grant van Gameren and Jen Agg’s Black Hoof, across the street — is a decidedly meat-focused affair. Stranger than this strange assemblage, which also included more blueberries and some syrup and — why not? — candied celery and which seemed to suggest the chefs were smoking more than cheese, was the fact that it all sort of worked. Not brilliant, but sweet and smoky and meaty and an oddly comforting way to begin the first meal of the day. The lines out the door should have tipped me off: Toronto is in the throes of a serious love affair with all things meaty.

headline: Obama’s Remarks in Iowa City on Health Care
text: Following is a text of President Obama's remarks Thursday at a health care rally in Iowa City, Iowa, as released by the White House:

headline: Cantor Accuses Democrats of Exploiting Threats
text: The Congressional clash over threats and vandalism against lawmakers in the aftermath of the health care vote took a new turn Thursday as the No. 2 House Republican accused Democrats of recklessly exploiting the incidents for political gain.

headline: What’s Possible Is Not Always What’s Best
text: Just because a thing is possible, doesn’t mean that we have the wherewithal to actually pull it off.

headline: Skillsoft’s Primer on Irish Deal-Making

headline: Congress Wrestles Over Small-Business Jobs Bill
text: Small businesses got a bit of good news on Wednesday when the House of Representatives passed a short-term job-creation bill. While the thrust of the legislation, which would cost $19 billion over 10 years, is infrastructure programs like “Build America Bonds,” a financing program for local governments, small businesses won $3.6 billion in tax breaks.

headline: Some Skaters Skip Worlds for Post-Olympic Whirl
text: Evan Lysacek, the men’s figure skating gold medalist at the Vancouver Games, did not try to defend his title at the world championship this week in Turin, Italy. He had other plans.

headline: Pushcart Prize
text: This is the story of competing notions of the Indian-American dream. Place the accent on American, and you imagine the seedbed of modest beginnings flowering into modest, even immodest, empires. Place the accent on Indian, and you imagine rigid confinement within what is considered, even today in India, a low-class occupation — a chaat walla, preparing snacks from a vendor’s cart, buzzed by flies. It all begins with that deceptively simple word: “chaat.”

headline: Ambac May Seek Bankruptcy After Regulators Step In
text: The Ambac Financial Group warned again on Thursday that it might seek bankruptcy protection after state regulators took control of some of the bond insurer’s most troubled assets, The Associated Press reports. The news sent the company’s already devalued stock into a tailspin.

headline: Inflation and Inflation
text: So, while I still think you should read the better text on inflation, I took a look at Mankiw, 2nd edition, which is the version close to hand. He divides the discussion of inflation — monetary, Zimbabwe-type inflation is in Chapter 28, 70s-type stagflation in Chapter 31 — but the analysis is essentially the same as in my book, and similarly makes it clear — though not quite as clear — that they’re very different phenomena.

headline: The Wizarding World of Harry Potter Will Open to Muggles in June
text: Universal Studios Orlando in Florida said Thursday that its high-profile “Harry Potter” expansion would open on June 18 and feature a centerpiece ride sending guests soaring over Hogwarts Castle, albeit in a virtual experience. Read more…

headline: Remix, Reuse, Recombine: Holding a Seminar on Mash-Up Culture
text: Overview | How are the dynamics of the Web affecting how we read, think and create? What is a “mash-up,” and what does this trend mean for our culture? In this lesson, students reflect on the cultural changes being forged by digital media and prepare and participate in a Socratic seminar on the issues. They then create their own mash-ups and reflect upon what is lost and gained through “recombinant” or appropriation art.

headline: Will Republicans Support Financial Reform?
text: Chris Dodd seems to think he can pull in some GOP senators, and some political commentators agree. But my bet is no. Republicans will still, I believe, be eager to deny Obama any further successes; and they’re eager to curry favor with bankers who don’t want their actions monitored by little punk staffers. And I don’t think financial reform can be done through reconciliation, so the GOP doesn’t have to worry about a Democratic success despite unified opposition.

headline: Toyota Creates Quality Task Force
text: Toyota, which has been making a variety of moves after its recalls associated with sudden unintended acceleration in its vehicles, has created  a new North American task force charged with improving vehicle quality issues.

headline: ‘Gatz’ to Kick Off Public Theater’s New Season
text: In addition to a previously announced new play by Tony Kushner, the Public Theater announced on Thursday five other productions for its 2010-11 season, including the critically acclaimed “Gatz” – a six-and-a-half-hour staging of “The Great Gatsby” – as well as new plays by Lisa Kron, Rinne Groff  and Stephen Adly Guirgis.

headline: 3 Ex-Madoff Employees Plead Not Guilty in Fraud
text: A former executive with Bernard L. Madoff‘s investment firm and two other former employees pleaded not guilty on Thursday to charges that they were involved in his enormous Ponzi scheme, The Associated Press reports.

headline: Brooklyn Woman Charged in Beating Death
text: Updated, 4:16 p.m. | A 35-year-old home health care worker in Brooklyn was arrested on Thursday on charges she fatally beat the 67-year-old woman she was supposed to be caring for, according to a law enforcement official. She tried to cover up the crime, the authorities said, by saying a man broke into the apartment.

headline: Spain Allows Case Against Noted Judge
text: MADRID — Spain’s Supreme Court announced Thursday that an investigating magistrate could proceed with a case against a crusading judge known internationally for indicting Osama bin Laden and the Chilean dictator Augusto Pinochet, according to court papers.

headline: Elements of Style
text: With daytime temperatures steadily edging higher each week, it’s time to start thinking seriously about one’s warm-weather wardrobe. Specifically, what hip, intelligent T-shirt do you want to throw on to bolster your SPF for a summer of outdoor reading?

headline: New Ways to Gauge the Finite Atmosphere
text: I recently became aware of fascinating efforts by Adam Nieman to help society appreciate environmental challenges in fresh ways by visualizing volumes that are otherwise abstractions. In 2003 he created the image above, illustrating the volume of the world’s oceans and atmosphere (if the air were all at sea-level density) by rendering them as spheres sitting next to the Earth instead of spread out over its surface. To my eye, this helps powerfully convey the finite nature of these shared global assets. In general, I think there’s great merit in conceiving and testing new ways to communicate visually on the keystone issues of this blog (energy and climate, population and consumption, the relationship between humans and other life). Click here for his globe showing all the world’s land types as “islands” (and note how tiny the urban islet is).

headline: Student Loan Overhaul Approved by Congress
text: WASHINGTON — Ending one of the fiercest lobbying fights in Washington, Congress voted Thursday to force commercial banks out of the federal student loan market, cutting off billions of dollars in profits in a sweeping restructuring of financial-aid programs and redirecting most of the money to new education initiatives.

text: This past week, I thought about a scene from one of my favorite films, “Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory.” In the scene, a mysterious machine — covered in brightly colored fabric to hide its innermost workings — spins, squeals and squeaks, until: pop! Out comes the Everlasting Gobstopper, a condensed nugget of infinite flavor.

headline: Cerberus to Buy Massachusetts Hospital Group
text: Caritas Christi Health Care, the second-largest hospital group in Massachusetts, said Thursday that it had agreed to be acquired by the private equity firm Cerberus Capital Management in an $830 million deal that hospital officials said would allow the chain to reduce its debt and make major improvements.

headline: Colicchio & Sons Evolves Some More
text: Tom Colicchio’s reuse of the old Craftsteak space has been a work in progress. When it opened, the menu was a la carte. Then Mr. Colicchio made an attempt to go prix-fixe, charging $78 for three courses, only to return to the original a la carte format a couple of weeks ago, shortly before Sam Sifton’s three-star review in the Times.

headline: Study Shows Building Boom Before Market Crashed
text: A new report shows just how striking the changes in the real estate market have been in New York in recent years. The report, by New York University’s Furman Center for Real Estate and Urban Policy, reveals that the city gained a remarkable number of new housing units, and then watched the market fall faster than at any time in recent history.In a 140-page report released on Thursday morning, Furman Center researchers found that the city gained 170,000 new housing units from 2000 to 2008. But by 2009, the building boom ground to a halt. Building permits being issued dropped by 90 percent from 2008 to 2009. The city issued fewer permits for new housing units than any time since 1992.

headline: Frum Forced Out at Conservative Institute

headline: Trying to Put Nutrition on the Lunchroom Menu
text: “Jamie Oliver’s Food Revolution” on ABC is about the eminently serious topic of what we feed our children. That isn’t the sexiest subject for a prime-time reality show  even one hosted by the Naked Chef  so the series has been shaped as a culture clash between an abrasive British interloper and a city of stolid, overweight Americans. Those expecting a substantive look at our school lunch programs won’t find it on the menu, but Mr. Oliver’s travails in the Huntington, W.Va., system can be entertaining in their own right.

headline: Design for Eisenhower Memorial Is Selected
text: One of four designs by Frank Gehry for the Eisenhower Memorial has been chosen by the Dwight D. Eisenhower Memorial Commission for a four-acre site at the base of Capitol Hill in Washington, the commission announced Thursday. Mr. Gehry was selected in March 2009 after a competition through the General Services Administration’s Design Excellence Program, which asked him to create several options. In making its selection, below, the commission said it considered aesthetic and thematic issues, environmental impact and estimated construction costs. Still subject to final approval, the memorial will be between Fourth and Sixth Streets SW, south of Independence Avenue. Groundbreaking is planned for August 2012, with an opening scheduled for Memorial Day 2015.

headline: A Contemporary Composer, and a Visit From Ophelia
text: Carnegie Hall has been giving the brilliant English composer, conductor and pianist Thomas Adès an unusual showcase for his varied talents. In the second of three concerts, at Zankel Hall on Wednesday evening, Mr. Adès led members of the excellent Ensemble ACJW and guest musicians in works of his own and of the contemporary Irish composer Gerald Barry as well as music by Purcell and Brahms.

headline: App Study | Tipping Tips
text: For Americans accustomed to traveling in Europe, leaving a few extra coins on a dinner bill has finally developed into a reflex. But remove us from the Continent and all kinds of tipping head scratchers present themselves. What’s a customary gratuity for scuba guides in Costa Rica, cooks for an Andean trek or doctors and nurses in Romania (if you press their flesh with a few bills, they’ll press yours)? Beyond the exotic, travelers remain flummoxed by such courtesies as tipping the chambermaid (do so during your stay, not just on departure) and how much to give the concierge ($5 to $10 per request, more if it’s challenging, and as much as $150 at a luxury hotel, if you’ve really put him to the test).

headline: Beyond the Bunny: Bach and Organs and Sacred Songs

text: Abandoned neighborhoods. Boarded-up harbor facilities. An oil refinery submerged under several feet of brackish water. The Statue of Liberty slowly sinking into the sea.

You might be able to make more money by investing the potential extra payment in stocks and bonds, though. Ron Lieber, the Your Money columnist, explains.

headline: G.E.’s Love Note to New Deutsche Executive
text: Investment banks love trumpeting big new hires, but Deutsche Bank took things a step further on Thursday when it announced that John Utendahl, a trader turned relationship banker, would be joining the German bank as vice chairman, TheStreet.com reports.

text: When Eric Ziebold, the chef of CityZen, one of Washington’s most buzzed-about restaurants, opens up a Southern-accented restaurant, local foodies don’t waste any time reaching for their forks.

headline: Home Inventory

Put a copy of the video someplace safe other than a computer, in case of fire or a hard drive cash. And add up the replacement costs for all of those items to make sure you have enough insurance. Ron Lieber, the Your Money columnist, explains.

headline: Amid the Hilly Landscape, Hidden Gems
text: Like its famous Little Red Lighthouse, which is tucked under the George Washington Bridge, Washington Heights conceals its treasures almost too well. But whatever the reason for the modesty, this neighborhood of overflowing plates and Latin rhythms opens up with a little bit of investigation, and some of its secrets are surprising: a jazz club in a living room, for example, and a debutante’s vandalism.

Just how much Top End there is is open to debate, the kind that gets worried out with maps drawn in the dust. While I was there last September, I saw dust maps that gave the

headline: David Frum, AEI, Heritage And Health Care
text: David Frum* has been fired by the American Enterprise Institute; one has to assume that this is a response to his outspokenness about the Republican failure on health reform.

headline: A Fair Shrinks, but Still Wanders Far
text: It remains to be seen if we’re living in the twilight of the art fairs. But lately these bellwether organisms have been shifting shapes, changing locations, shrinking or even ceasing operations. In addition, organized clusters of gallery exhibitions, like that of the Asian Art Dealers concluding this weekend, are gaining ground.

headline: Mom and Pop Thrillers in Topsy-Turvy World
text: Early in “Caught,” Harlan Coben’s crazily hyperactive new thriller, a wholesome teenage girl named Haley McWaid disappears from her happy New Jersey home. She’s the kind of girl who has a lot of sports trophies in her bedroom and keeps them neatly arranged. Mr. Coben, who occupies the family-guy niche among thriller writers, often takes note of such workaday domestic details.

text: The British celebrity chef tries to overhaul a West Virginia town's diet in this ABC reality series.

headline: In Galleries, More Treasures From the East
text: If “Confucius: His Life and Legacy in Art” at China Institute Gallery has a knockout visual attraction, it is the set of hefty enamel-on-copper altar vessels from the Qing dynasty (1644-1911). The set has five components: a round-bellied incense burner; two vases with slithery dragon handles; and a pair of candle holders with bell-shaped bases, capacious receptacle trays and spikes on top.

headline: S.E.C. Plans to Review Derivatives Used in Funds
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission announced Thursday that it was reviewing the use of swaps and other derivatives by mutual funds, exchange-traded funds and other investment products that are often marketed to individual investors.

headline: Losing It
text: For 12 years, I had a job I loved as the editor of House & Garden, a magazine that celebrated the good life. It would be an understatement to describe this enterprise as part of a company not primarily in the business of philosophical, spiritual or moral soul-searching. Condé Nast’s roots and branches are in the material world. The good life at House & Garden generally meant cultivating your own backyard rather than being involved in the body politic. I pushed against the limits of making a so-called shelter magazine by publishing articles about spiritual issues and the environment, but I always felt clear-eyed about how things stood. I spent more than a decade in the belly of the beast of muchness and more. That was a precarious place to be when the real estate bubble began to leak.

headline: McNally Play Is Postponed After Mullally Quits
text: The Broadway revival of Terrence McNally’s play “Lips Together, Teeth Apart” has been postponed for the spring season, the Roundabout Theater Company announced on Thursday. The decision was made after the actress Megan Mullally quit the show this week because of frustration with the inexperience of a co-star, the comedian Patton Oswalt, whom she tried to have replaced, according to four people familiar with her departure.

headline: Just Looking | Eva Hesse
text: Last week, a group of art-world heavy hitters (editors, writers, curators, etc.), led by the peripatetic London-based Swiss art dealer Ivan Wirth, were gathered around a large table in the back room of his New York gallery, Hauser & Wirth on East 69th Street, gazing with rapt attention at fragmentary objects that were close to nothing. Hauser & Wirth represents the estate of the sculptor Eva Hesse (1936-70), and assembled on the table were essentially outtakes from her studio— delicate, insistently handmade studies in papier-caché (a version of papier-mâché), cheesecloth and bits of adhesive. Not quite works in their own right, they were still riveting in their suggestion of themes that had preoccupied Hesse throughout her decade-long career (cut short by her death from brain cancer at age 34): plasticity, an engagement with ephemeral materials, the elusive and incomplete nature of memory, and a redolent corporeality.

headline: Palin Will Be Keynote Speaker at Anti-Abortion Group’s Gathering
text: The Susan B. Anthony List, an anti-abortion organization that this week rescinded its support for Representative Bart Stupak, announced earlier today that Sarah Palin, former governor of Alaska, will be its keynote speaker at a May 14 breakfast here in Washington.

headline: Georgia Tech Coach Turns Down St. John’s
text: St. John’s struck out on its first attempt in its search for a new men’s basketball coach Thursday morning when Georgia Tech Coach Paul Hewitt turned down an offer.

headline: Envisioning an Abstraction Who Was Also a Man
text: You be nice to me, and I’ll be nice to you. Doesn’t that sound like a smart way to run the world? The Chinese philosopher Confucius thought so some 2,500 years ago. He also believed that education, hard work and respect for the past were essential; that excessive anything  money, fun, religion  led to trouble; and that social harmony was best achieved when people interacted courteously, but basically minded their own business.

headline: Carnegie Benefit for Haiti: Tracking the Numbers
text: On Sunday night, the Chinese pianist Lang Lang announced from the stage of Carnegie Hall, at a concert billed as a benefit for victims of the Haiti earthquake, that the generosity of the participating artists and some corporations had “allowed us to raise $100,000 for Unicef so far.”

headline: McNally Play Is Postponed After Mullally’s Departure
text: The Broadway revival of Terrence McNally’s play “Lips Together, Teeth Apart” has been postponed for the spring season, Roundabout Theater Company announced on Thursday. The decision was made after the actress Megan Mullally quit the show this week because of frustration with the inexperience of one of her co-stars, the comedian Patton Oswalt, whom she tried to have replaced, according to four people familiar with her departure. Read more here.

headline: Lorin Maazel to Lead Munich Philharmonic
text: Lorin Maazel, below, the venerated maestro who ended his term as the music director of the New York Philharmonic last year, has been appointed chief conductor of the Munich Philharmonic Orchestra, the orchestra said on its Web site. His appointment will be effective with the 2012-13 season. Mr. Maazel, a highly visible figure in Munich when he served as the chief conductor of the Bavarian Radio Symphony, said in a statement that “the quality of the orchestra is unsurpassed,” and that following in the footsteps of previous conductors like Sergiu Celibidache, who conducted the Munich orchestra until his death in 1996, “represents a challenge” that he will take on “with joy.”

headline: Design for Eisenhower Memorial Is Selected
text: One of four designs by Frank Gehry for the Eisenhower Memorial has been chosen by the Dwight D. Eisenhower Memorial Commission for a four-acre site at the base of Capitol Hill in Washington, the commission announced Thursday. Mr. Gehry was selected in March 2009 after a competition through the General Services Administration’s Design Excellence Program, which asked him to create several options. In making its selection, below, the commission said it considered aesthetic and thematic issues, environmental impact and estimated construction costs. Still subject to final approval, the memorial will be between Fourth and Sixth Streets SW, south of Independence Avenue. Groundbreaking is planned for August 2012, with an opening scheduled for Memorial Day 2015.

headline: Public TV to Finance Regional News Projects
text: The Corporation for Public Broadcasting, looking to counter what it sees as a decline in local journalism and original reporting nationwide, says it will provide money to set up seven regional reporting projects teaming public radio and television stations. The Local Journalism Centers, as they are being called, will hire reporters and editors to report on issues of regional relevance, including the reinvention of the industrial upper Midwest economy, efforts in upstate New York to attract innovative businesses, and agribusiness in the Great Plains. The ideas for what to cover came from the stations themselves, said Patricia Harrison, the president and chief executive of the corporation. “These stations are looking at issues they think need a much deeper dive than they are getting now,” she said. The corporation, which administers federal funds for public broadcasting, will invest $7.5 million in the project over two years, with $3 million more coming from local stations.

headline: Phish in 3-D That Everyone Can See
text: Hmm. Can you think of any reason why the fans of a popular jam band might enjoy the experience of seeing their favorite musicians in a movie presented in 3-D? Off the top of our heads, we couldn’t, but we’re still reasonably certain that a new 3-D film featuring Phish will find its audience. “Phish 3D,” which will receive a theatrical release in April, offers footage from the band’s Festival 8 concerts in Indio, Calif., in October and November  this time with effects that require only the wearing of special glasses to be seen. Compiled from more than 16 hours of performances, “Phish 3D” has a downright economical running time of just over two hours (though your overall experience may vary) and will include songs from the band’s start-to-finish cover of the Rolling Stones album “Exile on Main Street,” as well as its acoustic set. Sneak preview screenings for “Phish 3D,” will take place on  when else?  4/20, followed by its official opening on April 30. More information can be found at phish3dmovie.com. Tickets do not include admission to post-screening drum circles.

headline: ‘Idol’ Finalist Eliminated
text: The “American Idol” finalist Paige Miles failed to make the cut on Wednesday as the show’s results episode attracted the night’s largest audience in prime time, 21 million viewers, according to Nielsen’s estimates. Fox finished No. 1 for the night over all, even as its action series “Human Target” (6.8 million) struggled opposite CBS’s “Survivor” (10.9 million). CBS ranked second with a lineup that also included reruns of “Criminal Minds” (8.3 million) and “CSI: NY” (7.6 million). NBC placed third and ABC was fourth.

headline: Shortlist Unveiled for ‘Lost’ Booker Prize
text: In an act of literary reparation, the Booker Prize Foundation, which bestows Britain’s most prestigious book prize, has named a shortlist of books published in 1970 that were never eligible for the Man Booker Prize because of a change in the award calendar. A three-judge panel unveiled the shortlist for the so-called Lost Man Booker Prize on Thursday, featuring six authors whose works are still in print. They are: “The Birds on the Trees” by Nina Bawden, “Troubles” by J. G. Farrell, “The Bay of Noon” by Shirley Hazzard, “Fire From Heaven” by Mary Renault, “The Driver’s Seat” by Muriel Spark and “The Vivisector” by Patrick White. The winner, to be announced May 19, will be chosen by voters who make a selection on the Man Booker Prize Web site (themanbookerprize.com).

headline: ‘Gatz’ to Kick Off Public Theater’s 2010-11 Season
text: In addition to a previously announced new play by Tony Kushner, the Public Theater on Thursday named five other shows for its 2010-11 season, including the critically acclaimed “Gatz”  a six-and-a-half hour staging of “The Great Gatsby”  as well as new plays by Lisa Kron (the author of “Well”), Rinne Groff and Stephen Adly Guirgis. The season will begin with “Gatz,” a production by Elevator Repair Service. It will be presented with two intermissions and a dinner break four times a week from Sept. 26 to Oct. 31. Ms. Kron’s new play, “In the Wake,” described by the Public as a wry meditation on love and country, will be directed by Leigh Silverman and run Oct. 19 to Nov. 21. The Tricycle Theater Company’s play “The Great Game: Afghanistan,” about the culture and history of that nation as portrayed by an amalgam of playwrights and people involved in the American-led war there, will run at the Skirball Center for the Performing Arts from Nov. 30 to Dec. 19. Ms. Groff’s play “Compulsion,” about the legacy of Anne Frank, will run from Feb. 1 to March 6, 2011, and will be directed by the Public’s artistic director, Oskar Eustis. The Public’s season will conclude with Mr. Guirgis’s new play (the title includes an obscenity), a presentation by LAByrinth Theater Company and the Public, scheduled to run in the spring of 2011.

headline: 4 Schools Eliminate Waiting Lists
text: The wait is over. At least for some.

headline: Monkey Business in a World of Evil
text: You don’t really think about Curious George saving the day, as the title of the new exhibition at the Jewish Museum puts it. A “good little monkey,” he is called in the classic series of picture books by Margret and H. A. Rey, but he was no savior. He was a mischief maker, an innocent, born in the jungle and lured into the strange world of humans.

headline: How Cornell Got So Good
text: SYRACUSE — When Cornell takes the floor Thursday for the most important moment in the program’s history against top-seeded Kentucky in the Round of 16, two of the people responsible for building the Big Red’s storied senior class will be nearby.

headline: No Slaying Required: A Viking Aids an Enemy and Wins a Friend
text: The story told by “How to Train Your Dragon”  the new 3-D feature from DreamWorks Animation  is a fairly standard one, exploring themes that are so familiar in the universe of all-ages cinema that they hardly need elaborating. The hero, a young Viking named Hiccup (voiced by Jay Baruchel), is a misfit adolescent who proves his mettle, pleases his hard-to-please father (Gerard Butler) and saves the world while learning important lessons and rattling off some wisecracks.
