Supporting characters include a spitfire love interest (America Ferrera), a gaggle of goofy friends (including the inevitable Jonah Hill and Christopher Mintz-Plasse), a crusty old mentor (Craig Ferguson) and a cute nonhuman sidekick.

headline: Live Updates From the N.C.A.A. Tournament’s Round of 16
text: Live coverage and analysis from the N.C.A.A. tournament. Pete Thamel will provide updates from Syracuse, and Billy Witz from Salt Lake City. Two longtime Quad contributors who have played in the tournament, Stephen Danley (Penn) and Zach Hillesland (Notre Dame), will also weigh in.

headline: Palin to Star in a Documentary Series About Alaska
text: Pretty soon Sarah Palin, the former Alaska governor, will be Sarah Palin, the Alaska documentary host.

headline: Museum and Gallery Listings
text: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art.

headline: A Life to Live, This Side of the Bars
text: AS we were about to leave the prison that day, one of the guys asked, somewhat apologetically, if any of us would mind stopping at Trader Joe’s before heading back to New York. I had been going to the Federal Correctional Institution in Danbury, Conn., for six months and had no idea there was a Trader Joe’s nearby.

headline: Pat the Enormous Bunny
text: You, too, can meet Herbie the ginormous Flemish rabbit at the Prospect Park Zoo this weekend. Herbie, 18 pounds and, according to a zoo spokeswoman, Fran Hackett, “such a mush,” is a regular in the lineup these days at the zoo’s Live Animal Encounters program, held four times an afternoon on Saturdays and Sundays.

headline: Jazz Listings
text: Full reviews of recent jazz concerts: nytimes.com/music.

headline: Classical Music/Opera Listings
text: Full reviews of recent music performances: nytimes.com/music.

headline: Pop and Rock Listings
text: Full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music.

headline: Lions Gate Appears to End Bid for MGM
text: Lions Gate Entertainment appears to have dropped out of the bidding for Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer.

headline: Times May Change, but Regret Endures
text: “Hot Tub Time Machine” is the poignant story of three men, adrift in their 40s, who try to recapture the lost joys and squandered possibilities of their youth. I’m not entirely joking, though the movie itself is a nonstop barrage  somewhere between a riot and an orgy  of crude, obnoxious gags and riffs. If you are a connoisseur of sexual, scatological or just plain stupid humor, you will find your appetite satisfied, even glutted. But viewers of a certain age and background  let’s say those who know the lyrics to “Jessie’s Girl” by heart, even if they never really liked that song  are likely to endure the merry anarchy with a twinge of pained, slightly nauseated nostalgia.

headline: Movie Listings
text: MOVIES

headline: Gang Colors in the Set, Part of a Rapper’s Scheme
text: There aren’t many generators of good will in New York currently more effective than “Beamer, Benz or Bentley,” the creeping, slightly sinister collaboration between Lloyd Banks and Juelz Santana, a radio staple and the foundation for dozens of remixes.

headline: A-Rod’s Landlord Swings for the Bleachers
text: WHAT do Alex Rodriguez, the highest-paid player in baseball, and Henry Silverman, the billionaire who founded the Cendant Corporation, have in common? Besides piles of money, they share a landlord — Leroy Schecter, the 82-year-old steel magnate who owns the apartments they rent at 15 Central Park West.

headline: Schrager Checks In and Out
text: IAN SCHRAGER, the hotelier and long-ago co-founder of Studio 54, says on the Web site for his eponymous real estate company that he always made it a habit to live in his hotels for a while “in order to shake them down and make sure they functioned correctly.” So it should come as no surprise that he now lives in a building he developed, 40 Bond Street, a condo that he describes as “a radical redesign of a traditional cast-iron building.” His perch in the place, which has hotel services, is a triplex penthouse.

headline: Heat-Toting Ocean Currents Chugging Along
text: Here’s a brief update on the great heat-toting oceanic currents that at one time were thought to be at risk from human-driven warming of the climate. There’s been no slowdown at all through much of the past decade and probably none since the early 1990s, according to new work using methods developed by Joshua Willis at NASA’s Jet Propulsion Laboratory.

headline: A D.J.’s Place, With Sound-Proofing
text: ADAM GOLDSTEIN, better known as DJ AM, was a disc jockey to the stars. He worked on albums for Madonna and Will Smith. He dated Nicole Richie and Mandy Moore. And as if that weren’t enough fodder for the tabloids, he appeared on a reality TV show as a recovering addict.

headline: Final Season for ‘At the Movies’
text: THE balcony is closed, this time for good. After nearly three decades, “At the Movies,” the syndicated television program that introduced many viewers to the film critics Gene Siskel and Roger Ebert, as well as to film criticism in all its thorny and contentious glory, will cease production this summer.

headline: Dance Listings
text: Full reviews of recent performances: nytimes.com/dance.

headline: ‘Caught’
text: Prologue

headline: Despite Authoritarian Rule, Myanmar Art Grows
text: YANGON, Myanmar — The dance music thundered through a crowd of thousands of drunken fans, past the pavilions where skinny women in impossibly high heels gyrated around metal poles and into the streets filled with taxis that ferried partygoers to this free, whiskey-soaked concert in the park.

headline: Erasmus Hall and Its Offspring
text: PASSERS-BY can glimpse it only through iron gates, but the 1786 Erasmus Hall Academy, on Flatbush Avenue off Church in Brooklyn, appears to be the oldest school structure in New York. Empty for years and now dilapidated, the academy building is a designated landmark, enclosed within the vast courtyard of the Gothic-style Erasmus Hall High School, another landmark. Together they anchor a pinwheel of scholastic architectural history spanning two centuries.

headline: ‘Never Look Away’
text: Detective Duckworth and I headed north, but in under a mile he put on his blinker and turned down a narrow gravel road that went down, then up, winding all the time. The inside of Duckworth's car smelled of french fries. The smell made me feel sick to my stomach.

headline: Whitney Biennial Events
text: In the video “Detroit,” the artist Ari Marcopoulos captures two adolescent boys crawling around in a smallish room, manipulating the pedals of an amplifier to create distorted tones that veer between simply noise and coherent song.

headline: Where the Water Tanks Were
text: FOR co-ops desperate for new ways to increase income, consider what the St. George Tower in Brooklyn Heights has decided to do. The co-op board for the Tower, a 27-story building at 111 Hicks Street, looked up one day and decided to sell the enclosed former home of the building’s water tanks for reuse as a 30th-floor penthouse apartment with a roof terrace. The price tag is $2.495 million.

headline: St. Mary’s Is Running With the Giants
text: MORAGA, Calif. — As a reggae band jammed and the tangy aroma from a barbecue grill wafted through the commons, students at St. Mary’s College seemed to be making good use of the three hours each Wednesday when no classes are scheduled. It is called community time, and as the students soaked up the sights, smells, sounds and sunshine of a beautiful spring day, it was hard to tell this was midterm week.

headline: Spare Times
text: AROUND TOWN

headline: Just a Friendly Game of Paintball
text: SARASOTA, Fla. — While Alex Rodriguez is speaking with federal investigators in Buffalo on Friday morning, his manager and general manager, along with Yankee staffers and a few baseball writers, will be playing paintball at a suburban Tampa facility.

headline: ‘46 Circus Acts in 45 Minutes’
text: Where’s Jack Bauer?

headline: More Doctors Giving Up Private Practices
text: WASHINGTON — A quiet revolution is transforming how medical care is delivered in this country, and it has very little to do with the sweeping health care legislation that President Obama just signed into law.

headline: Spare Times: For Children
text: FOR CHILDREN

headline: Reyes, Day 2: All Is Well
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Jose Reyes went through his second day of working out Thursday and added a little zip to it. Reyes took ground balls at shortstop and hit with the other players for the first time. Afterward he ran harder than he did the day before, and reported no problems.

headline: Conflicting Demands Test Netanyahu
text: JERUSALEM — After contentious meetings in the White House, Israel’s prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, returned home on Thursday with the politically explosive task of responding to an unyielding American demand that he limit Israeli building in East Jerusalem.

headline: Bernanke Hints at Timing and Pace of Exit Strategy
text: The Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, hinted on Thursday that the central bank might be open to selling part of its huge portfolio of mortgage-backed securities when the time comes to start tightening credit,  Sewell Chan of The New York Times reports from Washington.

headline: Theater Listings: March 26 — April 1
text: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current shows, additional listings, showtimes and tickets: nytimes.com/theater.

headline: What We’re Reading …
text: 1. A female breadwinner raises the likelihood of divorce, according to a study of German couples. Not such a great pattern considering the continuing international mancession.

headline: Two Centuries of Schools
text: A block in the middle of Brooklyn has two centuries of civil architecture.

headline: Reaching the End of the Trail
text: EVEN as I proposed the ski trip to my brother, I worried I was out of my mind. It had been eight years since I’d skied, and I’d never been very good. At my best, intermediate trails were a challenge. On top of this, my last ski trip with my three sons had been a disaster. My oldest, Ben, an eighth grader at the time, had gone barreling off the trail, hitting a tree. I spent one of the worst nights of my life as a father, in an emergency room in Albany, waiting to see if Ben’s back was broken.

headline: Inside the List
text: ALPHA DOG: Duane Chapman, the star of the hit A&E reality show “Dog the Bounty Hunter,” scored a No. 1 best seller in 2007 with “You Can Run but You Can’t Hide.” Now Dog is back with a new book, “Where Mercy Is Shown, Mercy Is Given,” which enters the hardcover nonfiction list at No. 15.

headline: Line2 for iPhone
text: David Pogue tests Line2, an iPhone application that allows users to set up a second phone line, which can make calls over the AT&T network or over the Internet.

headline: Arundathi Jayatilleke and Michael Gelfand
text: IT was September 1998, and Michael Gelfand was racing up the steps of Harkness Tower at Yale. The steep climb led to a carillon lesson, which itself would lead to an audition for the Guild of Carillonneurs, who play the 54 bells in the tower. Suddenly he stopped and stared.

headline: S.E.C. Reviews Derivative Use by Some Funds
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission announced Thursday that it was reviewing the use of swaps and other derivatives by mutual funds, exchange-traded funds and other investment products that are often marketed to individual investors,  Edward Wyatt of The New York Times reports.

headline: Better Ways to Help the Public Lose Weight
text: It seems like everywhere we turn — whether it’s bans on school bake sales, required calorie counts in fast food chains, or First Lady Michelle Obama toiling in her White House garden — we are being told to watch our weight. There’s even the national Campaign to End Obesity, which is “dedicated to reversing America’s costliest medical condition” and advocates for “federal policies that promote healthy weight.”

headline: False Security of Wealth: A Tale Turns Cautionary
text: In “Bluebeard,” a sly rethink of the freakily morbid fairy tale, the filmmaker Catherine Breillat makes the case that once-upon-a-time stories never end. Divided into two parallel narratives  one focuses on Bluebeard and his dangerously curious wife, while the other involves two little girls in the modern era revisiting the tale  the movie is at once direct, complex and peculiar. It isn’t at all surprising that Ms. Breillat, a singular French filmmaker with strong, often unorthodox views on women and men and sex and power, would have been interested in a troubling tale about the perils of disobedient wives. Ms. Breillat never behaves.

headline: Proposed Tax Breaks for Ponzi Victims
text: Tens of thousands of Ponzi scheme victims across the country would get special tax breaks under a bipartisan bill introduced in the Senate on Thursday by Senators Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York, and Jon Kyl, Republican of Arizona.

headline: What We’re Reading: Wii Movies, Spam and Dog Collars
text: This bunch of headlines sound as if they were written by the folks at The Onion, but only one really was. Here’s  what caught the eyes of the tech editors and reporters of The New York Times on Thursday:

headline: Chávez Critic Is Arrested, Then Freed, in Venezuela
text: CARACAS, Venezuela — Agents from Venezuela’s military intelligence agency on Thursday arrested Guillermo Zuloaga, the owner of the independent television network Globovisión and one of the country’s most influential critics of President Hugo Chávez, heightening concerns over an intensifying clampdown on news organizations and opposition political leaders.

headline: Love Triangle Devised by a Wary Wife
text: There are grown-up moviegoers who will appreciate “Chloe”  a titillating piece of fromage directed by Atom Egoyan from a script by Erin Cressida Wilson  for its psychological insights and its ideas about identity and desire in modern life. There are also teenage boys who get a hold of Playboy for the articles.

headline: Shelby Criticizes Reform Bill, Saying It Won’t End ‘Too Big to Fail’ Problem
text: WASHINGTON — The Democratic bill to overhaul the nation’s financial system would not end the “too big to fail” phenomenon or adequately protect taxpayers from having to bail out large companies, a leading Republican senator said on Thursday.

headline: U.S. Plans Big Expansion in Effort to Aid Homeowners
text: The Obama administration on Friday will announce broad new initiatives to help troubled homeowners, potentially refinancing several million of them into fresh government-backed mortgages with lower payments.

headline: Pay Surges for Credit Suisse Chief Executive
text: The Credit Suisse Group’s chief executive, Brady Dougan, received 19.2 million Swiss francs ($18 million) in compensation last year, increasing his salary almost sevenfold.

headline: Bin Laden Threatens Any Americans Held
text: WASHINGTON — In a 74-second audio message released on Thursday, Osama bin Laden threatened to kill any Americans held by Al Qaeda if Khalid Shaikh Mohammed, the chief planner of the Sept. 11 attacks, is executed.

headline: Restlessness in Russia’s Western Outpost
text: KALININGRAD, Russia — Amid the sagging Soviet-era apartment blocks and hulking government buildings here, it can be difficult to imagine that this was once a German city graced with gingerbread-style facades and Teutonic spires.

headline: As Murkiness Descends, Ghosts Grow Restless
text: A moody little number, “The Eclipse” makes good on its name by sometimes obscuring its themes and even point, which can have its charms though also severe drawbacks. Ciaran Hinds, an actor with a thousand and one gloomy (glum, dour, sour, grim, deathly) faces, plays Michael Farr, a widower who lives quietly with his two children and photos of his dead wife hanging on the kitchen wall. A teacher and writer who does less scribbling than instruction, Michael (and his dog) has started to hear things go bump in the night, leading him into the shadows where a figure suggests he might be haunted in more ways than one.

headline: U.S. and Pakistan Agree to Reinforce Strategic Ties
text: WASHINGTON — Pakistan and the United States wrapped up two days of high-level talks on Thursday, with a raft of economic development initiatives, an agreement to hasten deliveries of military hardware and a promise to put their often mistrustful relationship on a new footing.

headline: 'Logarithms? You Understood Those?'
text: David, Bruce Willis's character from "Moonlighting," on logarithms.

headline: Prejudice’s Poison
text: How do domestic abuse and chronic alcoholism drive entire neighborhoods to ruin? How can drug trafficking and ethnic violence transform a vast public housing complex into a war zone? These are the sorts of questions raised by the gutsy Scottish writer Denise Mina in two series of sociologically freighted novels set in Glasgow. Each comes with its own locally born and bred (and nearly broken) female protagonist, one a social worker and the other a reporter, who approach crime by going to the root of it and asking how a civilized society can allow such injustice to flourish.

headline: Hughes Earns Decision: He’s Yanks’ Fifth Starter
text: SARASOTA, Fla. — If Phil Hughes was the front-runner for the Yankees’ fifth starter job all along, he never acted that way. He kept working and throwing his changeup, which improved as spring training went along.

headline: Up Front: Linda Gordon
text: Earlier this month, Linda Gordon won the Bancroft Prize in American history for her book “Dorothea Lange: A Life Beyond Limits.”

headline: A Studio, Animated
text: Don Hahn and Peter Schneider, the director and producer of "Waking Sleeping Beauty," discuss some of the illustrations featured in the film.

headline: Tentative Deal Struck for 2 Ground Zero Towers
text: The Port Authority, government officials and the developer Larry A. Silverstein reached a tentative agreement Thursday that would allow for the construction of two new skyscrapers at ground zero with up to $1.6 billion in public financing and subsidies.

headline: Choosing Not to Forget What Is Painful to Recall
text: On a street off Washington Square, a bell tolled 146 times on Thursday, once for each woman and man who died in the great fire there so very long ago. Dozens of schoolchildren read the names of the victims, one by one, then laid carnations upon a makeshift memorial. A fire truck raised its ladder in tribute but only so far — a reminder of a rescue effort that fell tragically short.

headline: Playground ‘Jail,’ Drawing Outrage, Gets a Face-Lift
text: Playground controversies usually involve bickering parents, unruly dogs or bullies.

headline: A Look at Famous Fables That Sing on the Screen
text: “Waking Sleeping Beauty” is a moderately engaging documentary about the renaissance of Disney animation during the golden decade (1984-94) that yielded “The Little Mermaid,” “Beauty and the Beast,” “Aladdin” and “The Lion King.” Directed by Don Hahn, the producer of “Beauty and the Beast” and “The Lion King,” the movie is a sly retrospective exercise in corporate self-congratulation masquerading as an insider’s tell-all.

headline: The Widening Scandal in the Church
text: To the Editor:

headline: Paperback Row
text: SHADOW AND LIGHT,  by Jonathan Rabb (Picador, $15.) It’s 1927, and Nikolai Hoffner, a detective inspector for Berlin’s criminal investigations unit (and the protagonist of Rabb’s earlier novel “Rosa”) is asked to investigate the suspicious death of a producer at a film studio. The producer, it develops, has ties to a right-wing militia and a secret society that is trying to take over the studio so it can promote its ideological agenda, and even Hoffner’s own son has become a Nazi. Our reviewer, Joshua Hammer, found the plot overly complicated but praised Rabb’s “gift for capturing the intoxicating — and toxic — atmosphere of post-World War I Berlin.”

headline: Ryan Happy With HBO’s ‘Rex in City’
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Jets Coach Rex Ryan stood behind the lectern in a packed auditorium, so the room was all his. Even though he is slimmer than he was three months ago, his sense of humor has not shriveled — and neither has his bravado.

headline: City’s Unemployment Rate Fell Last Month to 10.2%
text: New York City’s unemployment rate dipped again in February, raising hopes that the effects of the long recession are waning and the pace of hiring may pick up soon.

headline: Fiction Chronicle
text: SAFE FROM THE NEIGHBORS  By Steve Yarbrough.  Knopf, $25.95.

headline: Council Approves Legislation to Hold Process Servers Accountable
text: It is a fairly unglamorous and lightly regulated task: serving legal papers to people who have been sued. Debt collection agencies and lawyers often farm out the work to private companies, which deliver the papers in person or by mail. They are known, in legal parlance, as process servers.

headline: Before McDonald’s
text: How important was Fred Harvey? Stephen Fried’s “Appetite for America” says that as the nation’s first popular champion of fine dining, he invented chain restaurants, chain hotels and chain bookstores; glamorized train travel; pioneered cultural tourism; and as the writer Frank Waters put it, “introduced America to Americans.” Harvey Girls, who staffed company restaurants at railroad depots throughout the West, were “the first major female work force in America.” Prior to ­Coca-Cola, “Fred Harvey” was our biggest brand name.

headline: Between Ordinary and Ecstatic
text: Contemporary American poetry is sometimes panned for being mundane. With all the splendor and terror in the world, why should we care about some guy’s memories of high school, or the quality time he spends with his cat? Glancing over it, you might suspect that Edward Hirsch’s poetry would lend evidence to this view. Hirsch will begin a poem with a line like “Today I am pulling on a green wool sweater” or “Traffic was heavy coming off the bridge.” Neither opening seems to burn with that hard, gemlike flame.

headline: City Council Is Losing Its Home, Temporarily
text: At City Hall, democracy is about to leave the building.

headline: A Mind of His Own
text: Many scientists are cautious to a fault when it comes to telling us what they’re unsure of, playing down any novel finding that hasn’t been verified by another scientist. Not so Louann Brizendine. She is a neuro­psychiatrist (the prefix makes any title sound smarter) who has put her professional training behind a breezy, incautious account of how the brain, urged on by hormones, makes men and women act completely differently. You’d never know from reading Brizendine that beneath the sea she blithely sails are depths that researchers have only just begun to chart.

headline: The Land of Lock and Key
text: Prisons are sacred places. There our society claims control over the lives of men and women; there we assume the roles of gods. And whether the prison sprawls over thousands of acres like the penitentiary farms of the Deep South, or compresses its convicts on tight tiers, the air within holds a particular density, a palpable weight created not only by the crimes the inmates have committed but also by the ownership we have taken of the convicts, whether we acknowledge it or not.

headline: Traveling Woman
text: She was neither the first nor the last diplomatic wife to receive the directive, later reduced to six words: “Pay, pack and follow, at convenience.” The version that reached Louisa Catherine Adams in January 1815 was less succinct — her husband was John Adams’s son after all — but she could hardly have complied more swiftly. In three weeks she had crated up the St. Petersburg household, settled the accounts and prepared to set off, across 2,000 miles, to join her husband in Paris. It was winter. Europe remained pockmarked by the Napoleonic Wars. With her Mrs. Adams would take knives and forks; hidden bags of gold and silver; a governess; two servants, one of them trustworthy; and 7-year-old Charles Francis Adams, whose third language was English. They set out late on the afternoon of Feb. 12. It was Mrs. Adams’s 40th birthday.

headline: Consumed
text: Gabrielle Zevin’s timely new novel is full of holes, beginning with its title, “The Hole We’re In.” The holes start small — in stockings, a nightgown, the backyard — but as they keep appearing, they grow deeper and harder to ignore. So does the metaphor. During the bubble years, encouraged by cheap credit and instant gratification, we got used to living beyond our means, ignoring the consequences. “The Hole We’re In” criticizes our rabid consumer culture, as well as the people who’ve bought into it without examining the actual or hidden costs.

headline: Please Pass the Baby
text: Perhaps you’ve heard of a controversial animal study that took place half a century ago at the University of Wisconsin. Known as the “wire mother” experiment, it was overseen by a psychologist named Harry Harlow, who separated baby rhesus monkeys from their birth mothers and placed them with mother surrogates: one a cylinder of rolled chicken wire, the other a block of wood covered in terry cloth, both rigged, in alternating experiments, to provide or withhold milk. The scientists wanted to see how important “contact comfort” was to an infant’s attachment to its mother — whether, given the choice, a baby preferred a “mother” that fed it or one that cuddled it. The babies, they were surprised to discover, overwhelmingly chose softness over sustenance.

headline: What Lies Beneath
text: “Moby-Dick” is often viewed as a singularly American creation. Part of the beguiling genius of “The Whale,” a rhapsodic meditation on all things cetacean, is that Philip Hoare so suggestively explores the English origins of Herman Melville’s masterpiece while providing his own quirky, often revelatory take on the more familiar aspects of the novel. But “The Whale” is about much more than the literary sources of “Moby-Dick.” Always in the foreground of Hoare’s narrative is the whale itself, a creature that haunts and fascinates him as he travels to old whaling ports in both Britain and America, where he speaks with cetologists, naturalists, museum curators and former whalers on a quest to understand the whale, the cosmos and himself.

headline: With Justices for All
text: In 1937, a few months after his landslide re-election to a second term, Franklin Roosevelt set out on one of the boldest and most dangerous courses of his presidency. The conservative Supreme Court had already struck down a series of New Deal programs. Roosevelt feared that the mostly aged justices would go on to destroy the rest of his legislative achievements before he would have a chance to make any new appointments. As a result, he proposed a “reform” of the courts that would, among other things, have added an additional justice to the Supreme Court for every current justice over the age of 70. It became the most controversial proposal of his presidency — so much so that it nearly paralyzed his administration for over a year and destroyed much of the fragile unity of the Democratic coalition.

headline: Toronto Plays Itself
text: Atom Egoyan, the director of "Chloe," discusses his use of Toronto locations in the film.

headline: On the Seventh Day
text: It is the Fourth Commandment of the time-honored Ten. Remember the Sabbath day, to keep it holy.

headline: Honor Among Base Stealers
text: Professional baseball is a society, of sorts, and “The Baseball Codes” is a book of casual sociology. The premise is that ballplayers, managers, coaches and various other participants in the culture of baseball are all clued in to a value system, a mode of behavior that defines a gauzy ideal: the right way to play the game.

headline: Can We Work It Out?
text: A number of years ago on a camping trip with another couple, I had a dreadful fight with the man who was then my boyfriend while we were hiking up the mountain. Well ahead, we paused in a clearing to holler at each other, when the other couple poked their heads through the brush. Later, mortified, I apologized to my friend. “Oh, please,” she replied. “I was grateful!” Eavesdropping on our battle, she and her boyfriend had consoled themselves: “At least we don’t argue about that.”

headline: American Terror Suspect Traveled Unimpeded
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — An American charged with helping plan the 2008 terrorist attacks in Mumbai, India, moved effortlessly between the United States, Pakistan and India for nearly seven years, training at a militant camp in Pakistan on five occasions, according to a plea agreement released by the Justice Department last week.

headline: Who’s White?
text: Nell Irvin Painter’s title, “The History of White People,” is a provocation in several ways: it’s monumental in sweep, and its absurd grandiosity should call to mind the fact that writing a “History of Black People” might seem perfectly reasonable to white people. But the title is literally accurate, because the book traces characterizations of the lighter-skinned people we call white today, starting with the ancient Scythians. For those who have not yet registered how much these characterizations have changed, let me assure you that sensory observation was not the basis of racial nomenclature.

headline: Paterson Seen With Key Role in Abuse Case
text: This article is by Danny Hakim, William K. Rashbaum and David Kocieniewski.

headline: ‘Cap and Trade’ Loses Its Standing as Energy Policy of Choice
text: WASHINGTON — Less than a year ago, cap and trade was the policy of choice for tackling climate change.

headline: Audit Faults ‘Honor System’ for Aid to City’s Homeless
text: The Bloomberg administration has done a poor job of monitoring nonprofit agencies that provide services to the homeless, doling out more than $152 million in “handshake deals” in 2008 to providers that did not have contracts, according to an audit released on Thursday by John C. Liu, the city comptroller.

headline: To Sweeten Its Proposal, N.Y.U. Offers School Space
text: In the first move of what will most likely be a major charm offensive, New York University, which is proposing to expand in size by 40 percent over the next 20 years, announced on Thursday that it would donate space in a future university building for a new Greenwich Village elementary school.

headline: Treaty Advances Obama’s Nuclear Vision
text: WASHINGTON — The arms control treaty being completed by the United States and Russia represents another step toward closing the books on the defining struggle of the final half of the 20th century. But it also marks the opening of a broader campaign to counter the emerging threats of the 21st century.

headline: Mets’ Rodriguez Guides Juan Urbina and His Teammates
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — On March 2, Francisco Rodriguez received a call from a cellphone inside the Penitenciaria General de Venezuela, a maximum-security prison in San Juan de los Morros, Venezuela.

headline: About Obesity
text: For a movie about a man who doesn’t let any food go to waste, “Lbs.” has spent an awfully long time on the shelf. Cast in 2000, filmed beginning in 2001 and first shown at Sundance in 2004, it arrives in theaters six years later just in time to capitalize on Michelle Obama’s anti-obesity campaign.

headline: U.S. Official Defends Contractors’ Mission
text: SAN ANTONIO — A Defense Department official who is suspected of using private contractors in Afghanistan to help track and kill militants has denied that he did anything wrong, and he asserted that all his work had been approved by top American military commanders.

headline: It’s a Bird!
text: "Birdemic: Shock and Terror" is a would-be thriller about avian rampage. Directed and written by James Nguyen, the movie was made for just $10,000 as a tribute to Mr. Nguyen's favorite director, Alfred Hitchcock. "Since 'Birdemic' was discovered at the 2009 Sundance Film Festival  where Mr. Nguyen brought it anyway and showed it in bars after it was rejected by the festival's selection committee  it has become a cult hit on the midnight movie circuit," Dave Itzkoff writes. "Crowds in Austin, Tex., Phoenix and Los Angeles have thrilled to its stilted dialogue, substandard production values and young heroes who defend themselves with coat hangers." The movie has "spawned a discussion about why, of all the Z-grade movies that are made each year, this particular one should find favor with audiences. What has made Mr. Nguyen a latter-day anti-genius to rival Edward D. Wood Jr., whose 1959 horror dud "Plan 9 From Outer Space" became legendary for its countless defects?" Find out tonight and Saturday when IFC Center screens the movie at midnight.

headline: Cultural Mashup
text: "Growing up in Benin, Angélique Kidjo didn't hear only African music," Jon Pareles writes. "From America there were soul and Santana; from India there were Bollywood musicals. Her father loved jazz. They all had an effect on the music she would make herself, with her strong, wide-open voice riding African-rooted but thoroughly international arrangements." She "now applies her grown-up style to songs she learned from Miriam Makeba, Aretha Franklin and Curtis Mayfield, among others; the guitars and drums often have an Afropop lilt." Tonight listen to these songs as well as others from her new album, "Oyo." She'll be at Town Hall.

headline: Cyclone Hits
text: Come Sunday, it will officially be spring, at least in our humble opinion. That's when the Coney Island Cyclone, the beloved roller coaster, will open for the season. The festivities begin at 11:30 a.m., with the first roller-coaster ride kicking into gear at noon. Go early: The first 100 riders go free. The ride is generally open from noon to 8 p.m. daily, depending on the weather. Hours vary during the spring and summer.

headline: Lawmaker Is Acquitted of Drunken Driving but Convicted of Lesser Charge
text: A Manhattan jury acquitted Assemblyman Adam Clayton Powell IV on Thursday of drunken driving but found him guilty of a lesser charge, driving while ability impaired.

headline: Pope May Be at Crossroads on Abuse, Forced to Reconcile Policy and Words
text: ROME — Even as Pope Benedict XVI, faced with a sexual abuse scandal spreading across Europe, has called on victims to come forward and urged clerics to cooperate with civil justice, those strong words are running up against the complexities of his past.

headline: China Officials Wrestle Publicly Over Currency
text: BEIJING — Signs are emerging of conflicting views among China’s leaders over whether to allow the country’s currency to rise against the dollar.

headline: Duke Feeling Pressure to Advance
text: HOUSTON — Duke is well aware that its last national championship came nearly a decade ago.

headline: Vivian Blake, 54, Founder of Jamaica Drug Gang, Dies
text: Vivian Blake, a former top leader of the Jamaican Shower Posse, which United States prosecutors say was responsible for more than 1,400 drug-related killings in this country in the 1980s, died Sunday night in Kingston, Jamaica. He was 54.

headline: Emirate Offers to Help Restructure Dubai World
text: Dubai moved on Thursday to recapitalize two companies at the heart of a financial crisis that shook global markets last autumn, saying that it would inject up to $9.5 billion into Dubai World and its property subsidiary and would seek to repay all creditors within eight years.

headline: Past Decade Was Warmest on Record, Meteorological Agency Reports
text: The last decade was the warmest on record, the World Meteorological Organization said in a report on Thursday. The finding by the association, a United Nations agency, corroborates research by NASA’s Goddard Institute for Space Studies, which has already said that its measurements show that the period from 2000 to 2009 was the warmest since modern instrumental recording of temperatures began in the 1850s.

headline: France: Sarkozy Rival Forms New Party
text: Former Prime Minister Dominique de Villepin, left, announced a new center-right party on Thursday, confirming expectations he is likely to challenge Nicolas Sarkozy for the presidency in 2012. The two, both ministers under Jacques Chirac, are bitter rivals. Mr. Sarkozy was hurt by a bad showing in regional elections, and while Mr. de Villepin said he was “uneasy with the politics practiced today by the majority,” he is considered more of a spoiler for Mr. Sarkozy than a real challenger.

headline: U.S. and E.U. Agree to Expand Open Skies Accord
text: BRUSSELS — The European Union and the United States agreed Thursday to expand a three-year-old accord that allows airlines to operate more freely across the Atlantic.

headline: Mexico: Guards Suspected in Jailbreak
text: Guards may have helped about 41 prisoners escape from a state prison on Thursday in Matamoros, across the border from Brownsville, Tex., officials said. The break occurred before dawn, and there was no sign that prisoners had scaled the walls, said José Ives Soberón Tijerina, the Tamaulipas State secretary of public security.

headline: Two Sides to One Performer
text: The Puerto Rican comedy “Manuela and Manuel” is Almodóvar Extra Lite: a candy-colored ode to tolerance and self-affirmation that will vacate your brain faster than you can say, “un Cosmo, por favor.” Though its tone wavers, telenovela-style, between farcical and sentimental, and it’s at least 15 minutes too long, the film is easy enough to sit through. That’s partly because of the director Raúl Marchand’s vibrant palette  predominantly red, orange and lime-green  and mostly because of the permanently arched eyebrow of the Mexican actor Humberto Busto, who plays the title character(s) and gives the film a point of view and a core of feeling.

headline: Legal-Marijuana Advocates Focus on a New Green
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Perhaps only in California could a group of marijuana smokers call themselves fiscal realists.

headline: California’s Dairy Industry Takes Old Question to New Extreme
text: FOR years, the question “Got milk?” was actually asking consumers “Got enough milk?” — reminding them to drink milk by comically exaggerating the perils of running out. Now the “Got milk?” campaign is taking the opposite tack, by comically exaggerating the perils of never running out.

headline: Which Side of History?
text: Which of these assertions is the less plausible?

headline: Memo to Pope Described Transfer of Pedophile Priest
text: MUNICH — The future Pope Benedict XVI was kept more closely apprised of a sexual abuse case in Germany than previous church statements have suggested, raising fresh questions about his handling of a scandal unfolding under his direct supervision before he rose to the top of the church’s hierarchy.

headline: A Gay Love and Marriage Tale
text: For the first 10 minutes or so of “Just Say Love,” a film version of a stage play by David J. Mauriello, you might think you’ve found that rare gay film that has a sophisticated sense of humor and avoids the formulaic gunk that makes most of this genre unwatchable. There are a couple of witty lines as Doug (Robert Mammana), a rugged-looking married carpenter, sits down on a bench next to Guy (Matthew Jaeger), a gay man who reads Plato, and strikes up a conversation that eventually leads them into a sexual relationship.

headline: Average Con Ed Bill to Rise by $10 Over 3 Years
text: The monthly power bill for a typical New York City household will rise by more than $10 over the next three years under a new rate plan approved by regulators on Thursday.

headline: Bloggingheads: Real Cost Controls?
text: Matthew Yglesias of the Center for American Progress and Jonathan Chait of The New Republic debate health care reform’s cost control mechanisms.

headline: Three More Decide to Sue Bloomberg L.P.
text: Three more women have been permitted to join a class-action lawsuit that accuses Bloomberg L.P., the financial services and media company founded by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, of discriminating against pregnant employees, a federal judge said Thursday.

headline: House Democrats Who Rejected Health Bill May Face Trouble From Their Friends
text: WASHINGTON — The New York City Council speaker, Christine C. Quinn, agreed a few weeks ago to host a fund-raiser for a fellow Democrat who faced the prospect of a tough challenge this fall, Representative Michael E. McMahon of Staten Island.

headline: Officers on Border Team Up to Quell Violence
text: United States law enforcement authorities, seeking to avert a spillover of drug violence from Mexican border cities, are cautiously trying out new cross-border cooperation with the Mexican federal police, according to senior Homeland Security officials. The efforts will include coordinated operations and expanded intelligence sharing.

headline: India Tunes in as Its Top Striker Is Welcomed by M.L.S.
text: In terms of international celebrity or soccer pedigree, Sunil Chhetri is no David Beckham. He is not even Landon Donovan. As imports go, he is a work in progress. But because Chhetri, a star of India’s national team, generates such feverish interest in his country, the Kansas City Wizards of Major League Soccer timed their announcement of his signing more for the Indian news cycle than the domestic one.

headline: Playground’s Jail Theme Is Gone, but Perplexity Lingers
text: Building a playground is not as simple as installing a set of vertigo-inspiring monkey bars: These days, the world of playground design is rife with debate over how high the slides should be, whether the equipment should be brightly colored (kids say yes) or blend in with the environment, and whether themes like castles and rocket ships stimulate or stifle the imagination.

headline: Alaskan Thrills
text: A small picture vibrating with grand passions, “Godspeed” transforms the vast lawlessness of the Alaskan wilderness into a playground for damaged souls and Old Testament mischief.

headline: Health Worker Accused in Killing
text: A home health care worker in Brooklyn was arrested on Thursday on charges that she beat the 67-year-old woman in her care to death, the authorities said.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: March 25, 2010

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Tuesday about New York University’s plans to expand referred incorrectly in some editions to the size of the expansion in Greenwich Village. The total square feet, about three million, is a little more than that in the Empire State Building, not more than two Empire State Buildings. The article also referred imprecisely to another N.Y.U. project, in which the building on Macdougal Street that housed the Provincetown Playhouse theater is being turned into a research center for the law school and will also have a theater. While the facade of the Provincetown Playhouse entrance was preserved, the rest of the building’s facade was destroyed, not preserved.

headline: Green Has Setback in Comeback Attempt
text: The comeback effort of the professional golfer Ken Green was dealt another blow Tuesday when he learned that his request for a major medical exemption on the Champions Tour had been denied.

headline: Young Love Flowers
text: Floating uneasily between ghost story and gay tragedy, “Dream Boy” marvels as young love flowers on a dunghill of homophobia, incest and religious repression. The material may be florid, but its execution is sensitive as Nathan (Stephan Bender), the new kid on the school bus, locks eyes with Roy (Max Roeg), the silky-haired driver and farm boy next door. Algebra homework leads to a snuggle in the cemetery, and it’s not long before the natives are compelled to intervene.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Tuesday about the difficulties and successes over the past year for Leo J. Wise, the chief counsel and staff director for the Office of Congressional Ethics, misspelled, in some editions, the surname of the lawyer who defended Representative Sam Graves, Republican of Missouri, against conflict-of-interest accusations. He is Elliot S. Berke, not Burke.

headline: Corrections
text: The Goshen Journal article on Thursday, about a decision by Goshen College, a small Mennonite school in Indiana, to break with tradition and play an instrumental version of the national anthem before sporting events, misstated part of the name of a baseball team from Michigan that defeated the Goshen Maple Leafs on Tuesday. The team is the Siena Heights Saints, not the Sierra Heights Saints.

headline: 1 Across: Nightclub in the Trump Taj
text: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — Henry Hook is a puzzling force of nature. I’ve never met him in person, but I’ve met a number of his puzzles, and they always confirm my opinion that he’s one of the most clever and witty constructors … ever.

headline: In Possible Retirement, the Likelihood of an Election-Year Confrontation
text: WASHINGTON — No announcement has been made, but the widely anticipated retirement of Justice John Paul Stevens in coming weeks has the White House, Senate and lobbying groups bracing for an election-year confrontation over the future of the Supreme Court.

headline: Fix Health Reform, Then Repeal It
text: Washington

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Monday about TV Guide Network’s purchase of the first syndication rights to the HBO comedy “Curb Your Enthusiasm” misstated the genesis of the series “Politically Incorrect.” It began on Comedy Central and ran on ABC before being canceled; it was not an HBO show.

headline: Now Comes the Hard Part
text: Ann Arbor, Mich.

headline: An A.I.G. Lesson From Wisconsin
text: An A.I.G. Lesson

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Wednesday about the possibility that China’s Internet companies will have difficulty becoming global brands misidentified, in some editions, a Chinese social networking site with more than 70 million users. It is Kaixin001.com  not Kaixin.com, a competing company.

headline: Pecora Faces Tough Task at Fordham
text: Tom Pecora struck a happy pose in a reception hall at Fordham with his wife, two of his children, the athletic director, the university president and nine players from a basketball program that usually ends its season with March sadness.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on March 18 about a dispute between Amazon.com and publishers over e-book pricing misspelled the name of the chief executive of Idea Logical, which advises publishers on e-book matters. It is Mike Shatzkin, not Shatkzin.

headline: Corrections
text: A music review on Wednesday about “Fred and Ginger in So Many Words: The Astaire-Rogers Songbook,” part of the Lyrics and Lyricists series at the 92nd Street Y, misstated the title of Deborah Grace Winer, who wrote and hosted the show. She is the series’ artistic director, not the Y’s artistic director. (The Y does not have a position with that title.)

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Tuesday about a coming film by the writer-director James L. Brooks misstated a word in what is said to be the title. As the article noted elsewhere, it is “How Do You Know,” not “How Do We Know.”

headline: A New Life in Ballet
text: Even if you don’t know your pliés from your battements frappés, the dance sequences in “Dancing Across Borders” are a delight. More problematic perhaps is a true-life narrative about a wealthy white woman (Anne Bass, a prominent Manhattan patron of the arts) who plucks a happy teenager (Sokvannara Sar, known to everyone as “Sy”) from his home in Cambodia and installs him in the School of American Ballet in New York.

headline: What the Boss Learned
text: To the Editor:

headline: Going to Extreme
text: I admit it: I had fun watching right-wingers go wild as health reform finally became law. But a few days later, it doesn’t seem quite as entertaining  and not just because of the wave of vandalism and threats aimed at Democratic lawmakers. For if you care about America’s future, you can’t be happy as extremists take full control of one of our two great political parties.

headline: Reimagining What Washes Up
text: The Hudson River was as mean as usual this winter, roughing up the Manhattan shore and playing into the hands of Tom Loback, a sculptor who works in flotsam and jetsam. Nothing pretentious. Just more of his fragile, gone-tomorrow driftwood works to puzzle and please along the river rocks down from the apartment towers north of West 100th Street.

headline: The Return of History
text: Some brilliant scholar has to write a comprehensive history of modern economics because the evolution of this field is clearly one of the most consequential things happening in the world today.

headline: Loosening the ‘Don’t Ask’ Shackles
text: The Pentagon is taking a major step to ease the discriminatory burdens on gay and lesbian service members by ending the pernicious use of anonymous tips and biased hearsay to drum them from the military.

headline: Records in Real Time
text: The Freedom of Information Act has done a lot to make government more transparent. But in Washington  where need-to-know is the favorite status symbol  most agencies still ignore the legal deadlines and take months, even years, to respond to requests.

headline: Haiti’s Misery
text: The emergency in Haiti isn’t over. It’s getting worse, as the outside world’s attention fades away.

headline: Here Comes the Recess Coach
text: To the Editor:

headline: Health Insurer on AIDS
text: To the Editor:

headline: Fact of Life in Mootopia
text: The California Milk Processor Board moves past the "Got Milk?" campaign.

headline: Corrections
text: An obituary and a headline on Monday about the former Nepalese prime minister Girija Prasad Koirala misstated his age, and the obituary misidentified his place of birth. Mr. Koirala was 85, not 86, and he was born in the state of Bihar, India  not in Biratnagar, Nepal. (As the obituary noted, Mr. Koirala was born in 1925, but he was considered to be 86 in Nepal, where by custom people are regarded as 1 year old at birth.)

headline: Corrections
text: An obituary on March 10 about Willie Davis, who succeeded Duke Snider as the Los Angeles Dodgers’ center fielder, misstated, in some copies, the surname of a longtime sports columnist at The Los Angeles Times who wrote critically about Davis. He was Jim Murray, not Maury.

headline: Correction
text: Thomas L. Friedman’s column on Wednesday, about empowering centrists and independents, misstated the terms of a recent California ballot initiative. It rescinded the State Legislature’s power to configure districts for the State Senate, State Assembly and Board of Equalization, not for Congress.

headline: Corrections
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Audit Finds Vulnerability of EnergyStar Program
text: WASHINGTON — Does a “gasoline-powered alarm clock” qualify for the EnergyStar label, the government stamp of approval for an energy-saving product?

headline: Fresh Air for Myanmar's Music
text: Young people in Myanmar dance to musician Thxa Soe's different beat.  His western-style electronica is tolerated, and even enjoyed, by the government of the authoritarian state formerly known as Burma.

headline: It’s Done: House Passes Reconciliation Bill
text: The House of Representatives on Thursday gave final approval to the budget reconciliation bill containing a package of changes to the Democrats’ sweeping health care overhaul. The bill, which Democratic leaders hailed as a landmark achievement, now goes to President Obama for his signature.

headline: Ivanchuk and Carlsen Tie for First at Amber
text: The two-players who had jockeyed for the lead throughout the elite tournament ended in a dead heat.

headline: Photo Replay: March 25
text: A look at the first day of play in the Round of 16, when the upsets kept coming.

headline: Political Tide Could Wash Away Utah Senator
text: SALT LAKE CITY — Senator Robert F. Bennett parked his white Acura, walked through the doors of Bryant Middle School and stood alone as he began the obstacle course that will determine his political fate.

headline: Using Balanced Effort to Slow Washington, West Virginia Cruises
text: SYRACUSE — The Washington Huskies were perhaps the least-heralded double-digit seed in the Round of 16. For a team that had won 14 of its last 16 games, it barely received recognition outside of the Pacific Northwest.

headline: Interview With Senator Bennett of Utah, Facing Re-election
text: Senator Robert F. Bennett, Republican of Utah, faces a difficult re-election to a fourth term. He must persuade 3,500 party activists to support him before his name will be placed on the ballot. In an interview with Jeff Zeleny this week in Salt Lake City, he discussed the challenges and the state of politics today. These excerpts are condensed and edited.

headline: Keeping the Upsets Coming, Butler Beats Syracuse
text: SALT LAKE CITY — When Syracuse took its place along the free-throw line for the national anthem, half the Orange players were facing toward the flag in a corner of the arena. The other half — along with Coach Jim Boeheim — were facing the opposite direction.

headline: Achilles’ Heel for Duke?
text: HOUSTON — It’s always worrisome when a player expresses concern about his shooting technique.

headline: When Star Is Covered, Cue 3-Point Shooter
text: ST. LOUIS — When Northern Iowa’s senior guard Ali Farokhmanesh chose to pull up for a 3-pointer with 35 seconds left in the Panthers’ second-round game against top-ranked Kansas on Saturday, he had a fan in Ohio State guard Jon Diebler.

headline: Correction
text: The Mortgages column last Sunday, about the decision by Freddie Mac  one of two government-sponsored companies that set lending standards for mortgages  to stop backing interest-only mortgages, misstated the percentage of the company’s loans that were delinquent at the end of last year. It was 3.98 percent, not 7 percent.

headline: Hospitals Chief Expects to Cut 3,900 Jobs
text: New York City’s public hospitals will be forced to cut 3,900 jobs over two years — a tenth of the work force — if state budget cuts go through, the system’s president said Thursday.

headline: Republicans Lobby Against Recess Appointment
text: All 41 Republican senators urged President Obama on Thursday not to name a lawyer for the A.F.L.-C.I.O. and the Service Employees International Union to the National Labor Relations Board during the Easter recess. Last month, the Democrats fell eight votes short of the 60 needed to overcome a threatened filibuster of a vote for the lawyer, Craig Becker. Two Democrats, Blanche Lincoln of Arkansas and Ben Nelson of Nebraska, joined Republicans in the 52-to-33 vote. In a letter to Mr. Obama, Republican senators said that because of his union work, Mr. Becker “could not be viewed as impartial, unbiased or objective” in labor board cases. Seven of the 10 members named by President George W. Bush were recess appointees.

headline: Murder Case May Proceed in Georgia
text: A divided Georgia Supreme Court will allow a capital murder case to go forward despite the defendant’s claims that a lack of state financing for death penalty lawyers deprived him of access to effective counsel and a speedy trial.

headline: Valerie Hegarty: ‘Cosmic Collisions’
text: In shows at the now-defunct Guild & Greyshkul, Valerie Hegarty took over the architecture in kudzulike fashion. Sculptures of trees and plants emerged from fissures in the walls and floors; sublime seascape paintings were made to look shipwrecked in the gallery.

headline: New Hampshire: Spring Breaks
text: The ice broke on Lake Winnipesaukee on Wednesday, the earliest date since residents started keeping tabs in 1888, and a tantalizing signal of warmer days ahead. “It’s a passage of spring coming, and everyone’s been locked up in cabin fever all winter long,” said David Emerson, who owns Emerson Aviation in Gilford and is responsible for calling the date the ice is out. Mr. Emerson declares the ice “out” when it clears enough for a cruise ship to navigate among five docks. The previous record was March 28. The date not only promises better weather, but also a big payday for the winners of the many local betting pools. Mr. Emerson guessed that bettors didn’t expect such an early date, saying, “I don’t think I made anyone happy this year.”

headline: Ed Paschke
text: There he goes again  Larry Gagosian, that is  putting on a show that a New York museum should have done. This time the subject is Ed Paschke (1939-2004), whose toxically glowing paintings of circus freaks, extreme dandies, tattooed ladies and hairy, wingtip shoes explored the dark side of Pop Art. Along with Jim Nutt and Roger Brown, Mr. Paschke was one of the strongest talents to emerge from the Chicago Imagist school of the 1960s.

headline: California: Cable Cars to Be Idled
text: Passengers will be rerouted from San Francisco’s cable cars onto less charming buses starting in January as the cable system is upgraded. The cars, a picture-postcard element of the city’s tourism industry, carry riders to and from Fisherman’s Wharf, up and down steep hills, and to the pier where boats depart for Alcatraz Island. The San Francisco Municipal Transportation Agency will spend $24 million on the cars’ underground infrastructure and electrical systems. The agency expects the upgrade to be completed by June.

headline: Anya Kielar: ‘Face’
text: In her third galley solo, Anya Kielar builds on her past interests in theater, fashion, photography, strong color, early modernist styles and deceptively simple fabrication methods. Her new high-octane monochrome reliefs and an eye-strewn folding screen also present a lively combination of recklessness and rigor. It is hard to say who might emerge from behind the six-panel screen  which is mostly purple and leavens its popping eyes with stencil-like silhouettes of breasts, gloves, socks and the odd bit of texture or textile. The possibilities include Bette Davis, Florine Stettheimer and Lotte Lenya.

headline: Marcia Hafif: ‘From the Inventory: Black Paintings, 1979-1980’
text: Marcia Hafif’s Black Paintings from 1979-80 may have improved with age, but I can’t say for sure. I don’t actually remember having seen them, although they were shown at the Sonnabend Gallery, then in SoHo, in 1981. Ms. Hafif, who is 80, is much more associated in my mind with bright colors and often smaller canvases.

headline: Season in Balance, Rangers Are Saved by Rally
text: NEWARK — Because of Erik Christensen, the Rangers still live.

headline: ‘Dancing Across Borders’
text: Even if you don’t know your pliés from your battements frappés, the dance sequences in “Dancing Across Borders” are a delight. More problematic perhaps is a true-life narrative about a wealthy white woman (Anne Bass, a prominent Manhattan patron of the arts) who plucks a happy teenager (Sokvannara Sar, known to everyone as “Sy”) from his home in Cambodia and installs him in the School of American Ballet in New York.

headline: The Glory Days of Football
text: MORAGA, Calif. — When Omar Samhan was asked where St. Mary’s upset of Villanova ranked in the college’s history, he did not take time to ruminate.

headline: ‘Lbs.’
text: For a movie about a man who doesn’t let any food go to waste, “Lbs.” has spent an awfully long time on the shelf. Cast in 2000, filmed beginning in 2001 and first shown at Sundance in 2004, it arrives in theaters six years later just in time to capitalize on Michelle Obama’s anti-obesity campaign.

headline: Will Police Pay Increase Raise Hackles? And Highlights From Friday’s Bay Area Report
text: An Awkward Time For a Wish to Come True | Three years ago, Gary P. Delagnes made a prediction to the members of the police union he heads: That in July 2010 the San Francisco police would be members of the “highest-paid major police department in the country.” But the police are reaching their long-awaited economic summit when the city is in an economic abyss. Gerry Shih reports that with a  record $522 million budget gap facing the city, some in city government are pushing for the police to give up the 4 percent raise scheduled to take effect July 1 or to face layoffs that could result in a $17 million savings. Despite recent sharp cuts in controversial overtime payments, total police compensation has been rising for the past five years, city data show. In 2009, 52 members officers and members of the command staff took home more than $200,000, with one retiring deputy chief taking home more than $500,000. “When I sit down with my constituency,” said Supervisor David Campos, who was on the police commission before running for district office, “the feeling I get is they want the police, but they don’t want the police being the best compensated in the country when we’re shutting down gyms and pools.”

headline: ‘Manuela And Manuel’
text: The Puerto Rican comedy “Manuela and Manuel” is Almodóvar Extra Lite: a candy-colored ode to tolerance and self-affirmation that will vacate your brain faster than you can say, “un Cosmo, por favor.” Though its tone wavers, telenovela-style, between farcical and sentimental, and it’s at least 15 minutes too long, the film is easy enough to sit through. That’s partly because of the director Raúl Marchand’s vibrant palette  predominantly red, orange and lime-green  and mostly because of the permanently arched eyebrow of the Mexican actor Humberto Busto, who plays the title character(s) and gives the film a point of view and a core of feeling.

headline: Word of the Day | cadaverous
text: cadaverous •\kə-ˈdav-rəs, -ˈda-vər-əs\• adjective

headline: At the University of California, Some Would Rather Pay Than Protest
text: Here’s a story where doing a little math is bound to prompt discussion.

headline: ‘Just Say Love’
text: For the first 10 minutes or so of “Just Say Love,” a film version of a stage play by David J. Mauriello, you might think you’ve found that rare gay film that has a sophisticated sense of humor and avoids the formulaic gunk that makes most of this genre unwatchable. There are a couple of witty lines as Doug (Robert Mammana), a rugged-looking married carpenter, sits down on a bench next to Guy (Matthew Jaeger), a gay man who reads Plato, and strikes up a conversation that eventually leads them into a sexual relationship.

headline: ‘Godspeed’
text: A small picture vibrating with grand passions, “Godspeed” transforms the vast lawlessness of the Alaskan wilderness into a playground for damaged souls and Old Testament mischief.

headline: ‘Dream Boy’
text: Floating uneasily between ghost story and gay tragedy, “Dream Boy” marvels as young love flowers on a dunghill of homophobia, incest and religious repression. The material may be florid, but its execution is sensitive as Nathan (Stephan Bender), the new kid on the school bus, locks eyes with Roy (Max Roeg), the silky-haired driver and farm boy next door. Algebra homework leads to a snuggle in the cemetery, and it’s not long before the natives are compelled to intervene.

headline: Even as Costs Rise, University of California Remains a Bargain
text: Alexander Dobranic, an undergraduate politics major at the University of California, Santa Cruz, is not taking math this spring. But he knows when numbers — like the tuition and fee increases that have led to protests and vandalism on U.C. campuses this winter — don’t add up.

headline: As Budget Gaps Widen, San Francisco Police Salaries Grow
text: Three years ago, Gary P. Delagnes, the president of the San Francisco Police Officers Association, made a bullish prediction after successfully negotiating a lucrative four-year contract: After a scheduled 4 percent pay raise phased in on July 1, 2010, Mr. Delagnes wrote in a note to the officers, the force would most likely fulfill a 20-year mission to become the “highest paid major police department in the country.”

headline: Looking Ahead: Round of 16
text: MIDWEST

headline: That Buzzing Could Sweeten Tomorrow’s Tea
text: If you spy a dark-haired woman gliding down Mission Street, past the taquerias and bodegas, in a white, head-to-toe bee suit  picture a hazmat suit crossed with a fencing mask  chances are it’s Cameo Wood, en route to a beehive. Ms. Wood, the 32-year-old proprietor of the Mission District shop Her Majesty’s Secret Beekeeper, cares for 15 hives in “borrowed spaces” around San Francisco. These are hidden away in friends’ backyards, in a restaurant garden, and on the roofs of government buildings and apartment complexes.

headline: Rematch With Different Look
text: The last time Tennessee faced Ohio State in the N.C.A.A. tournament, in 2007, the Buckeyes had Greg Oden dominating inside and Mike Conley Jr. making sure everything flowed smoothly.

headline: Kentucky’s Defense Stymies Cornell
text: SYRACUSE — Top-seeded Kentucky’s road to a national championship took a favorable turn Thursday night.

headline: Street Repair Falls Victim to Budgets
text: San Francisco motorists may have to be prepared for more potholes in their already bumpy streets unless the city comes up with more money.

headline: South Korea’s Formidable ‘Double Dragon’
text: Ki Sung-yueng and Lee Chung-yong are on parallel and still rising career arcs that may peak the 2010 World Cup in South Africa.

headline: Johnny Maestro, Brooklyn Bridge Singer, Dies at 70
text: Johnny Maestro, the pure-toned tenor who as the lead singer for the Crests, the Del-Satins and the Brooklyn Bridge recorded rock ’n’ roll hits like “Sixteen Candles” and “The Worst That Could Happen,” died Wednesday at his home in Cape Coral, Fla. He was 70 and had lived in Islip, N.Y., until seven years ago.

headline: After a Dispiriting Lull, the Blackhawks Surge
text: Maybe it was that John McDonough.

headline: Mountaineers Advance By Slowing Things Down
text: SYRACUSE — Against Washington’s relentless pressing defense and quick transitioning offense, West Virginia knew it might struggle to maintain its style of basketball.

headline: Downstate Republican Faces Rough Road in Race for Governor
text: As Bill Brady made his way through a crowded ballroom at the Hilton on Michigan Avenue the other evening, heads did not turn to glimpse a political big shot. The Republican nominee for governor of Illinois, at least for now, is an unfamiliar face in the city.

headline: Taking Xavier’s Best Shots, Kansas State Survives
text: SALT LAKE CITY — Kansas State defeated Xavier on Thursday night, but the Wildcats did not really win their way to the West Regional final. They survived.

headline: With Insurance Comes a New Need: More Primary-Care Doctors
text: Hours before President Obama signed the health care bill Tuesday, George Butler, a retired steelworker, was the first patient to enter Evanston-Rogers Park Community Health Center. By 9 a.m., all of the 22 black and gray molded plastic seats were filled.

headline: Reform Plan for Pensions Has Critics
text: The remarkably swift reform of the state’s pension plans, thrust through Wednesday by Mike Madigan, the Illinois house speaker, does virtually nothing to make up a shortfall in funds, some of the state’s leading pension-reform advocates said.

headline: ‘Come Fly Away’
text: Photos from Twyla Tharp’s new Broadway musical, set to the music of Frank Sinatra.

headline: News Quiz | March 26, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page.

headline: Big Banks Said to Be Named in Municipal Bond Case
text: Documents obtained by Bloomberg News in an antitrust case against a group of Wall Street firms named JPMorgan Chase, Lehman Brothers and UBS as conspiring to pay unfairly low rates on investments made by state and local governments.

headline: Purdue’s Tall Task
text: HOUSTON — Purdue has a tall task on Friday against top-seeded Duke in the N.C.A.A. tournament’s South Region semifinals.

headline: Northern Iowa Takes Many Paths to Victory
text: With the news that Kalin Lucas, Michigan State’s leading scorer, is out with a ruptured Achilles’ tendon, I decided to go back to the tape and take a more in-depth look at Northern Iowa.

headline: Energy Sector Said to Drive Asia Deals This Year
text: Mergers and acquisitions jumped to $520.4 billion in the first quarter, accompanied by a big shift in global deal-making as emerging market and energy-focused takeovers made up a growing slice of activity, Reuters reported.

headline: Shelby Says Dodd Bill Won’t Cure ‘Too Big to Fail’
text: The Democratic bill to overhaul the financial system would not end the “too big to fail” phenomenon or adequately protect taxpayers from having to bail out large companies, a leading Republican senator said on Thursday, Sewell Chan reported in The New York Times.

headline: Taylor Swift’s Unlikeliest Fan
text: HOUSTON — The colorful personality of the gregarious St. Mary’s center Omar Samhan has been on full display during his 10th-seeded team’s improbable run to its appearance in the N.C.A.A. tournament’s Round of 16.

headline: What Are the Most Memorable Photographs You’ve Ever Seen? Why?
text: We ask today’s question because we’ve been thinking about this article from the Week in Review about the power of the still image, as well as the Sunday Magazine series of heartbreaking photographs of the bedrooms of young American soldiers who died in Iraq and Afghanistan. What photographs — whether serious or playful, and whether taken by a professional or an amateur — have made the biggest impression on you? Why?

headline: UBS Cuts 200 Jobs in Its U.S. Brokerage Unit
text: UBS, the Swiss banking giant, has slashed about 200 jobs in its brokerage unit in the United States, a source told Reuters.

headline: A.I.G.’s Near Collapse Yields Gold for Wall Street
text: Auctions of American International Group‘s assets have generated more than half a billion dollars in fees since its near collapse in September 2008, with every major Wall Street bank getting a piece of the action, estimates from Freeman Consulting show.

headline: Dubai May See Dawn
text: Dubai may be close to ending its nightmare, Breakingviews says. As part of the proposal to restructure debts of $23.5 billion at the emirate’s flagship company Dubai World and its subsidiary Nakheel, the government is offering to convert more than $10 billion of loans it has made to the group into equity and inject $9.5 billion of new money. Lenders could still face some losses, but it could have been much worse, the publication suggests.

headline: Ontario Teachers’ Buys British National Lottery
text: The Ontario Teachers’ Pension Plan, Canada’s largest pension plan, said Thursday it would buy Camelot, the British national lottery operator, for 389 million pounds ($576 million), Reuters reported.

headline: The Vanishing Point
text: Australians call the northernmost chunk of their continent the ‘‘Top End,’’ a breezy moniker, as though Australia were a boiled egg sitting upright in an egg cup waiting tobe cracked open with a silver spoon. Just how much Top End there is is open to debate, the kind that gets worried out with maps drawn in the dust. While I was there last September, I saw dust maps that gave the Top End most of Australia north of the Tropic of Capricorn — about a third of the continent. Others included only Cape York and the rather wind-swept-looking peninsula that includes the roistering town of Darwin, the capital city of the Northern Territory.

headline: Pope May Be at Crossroads on Abuse, Forced to Reconcile Policy and Words
text: ROME — Even as Pope Benedict XVI, faced with a sexual abuse scandal spreading across Europe, has called on victims to come forward and urged clerics to cooperate with civil justice, those strong words are running up against the complexities of his past.

headline: D.O.J. Said to Examine Calpers Transactions
text: Justice Department investigators in Los Angeles are scrutinizing certain investment transactions of public pension funds, including the California Public Employees’ Retirement Fund, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing people familiar with the matter.

headline: Plainfield to Return Money to Investors, Report Says
text: Plainfield Asset Management, the hedge fund run by Max Holmes, is planning to wind down its current portfolio and start over with its remaining funds, The New York Post reported.

headline: Wisconsin Quarantines $64 Billion in Ambac Assets
text: State regulators in Wisconsin said they are taking control of roughly $64 billion of the worst assets at the bond insurer Ambac Financial Group, Reuters reports.

headline: London Suspects May Have Been Front-Running
text: The arrest of seven individuals and raids on 16 offices by British regulatory agencies this week could be tied to the front-running of block trades, Bloomberg News reported, without identifying its source.

headline: Are ‘Covenant-Lite’ Loans Back on the Menu?
text: Is investor appetite for “covenant-lite” loans, which impose fewer financial requirements on the borrower, returning?

headline: Selling Saints: Yves Smith Debunks ‘The Big Short’
text: Michael Lewis’s “The Big Short: Inside the Doomsday Machine,” the best-selling book that profiles investors who predicted the financial crisis and made billions from it, has come under heavy flak in a recent review by Yves Smith.

headline: Higher One Plans $100 Million I.P.O.
text: Higher One Holdings is planning an initial public offering of up to $100 million, even as pending legislation could change its business, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Strategic Defaults
text: Tactical mortgage defaults whereby borrowers walk away from home loans they can afford to repay.

headline: Rhetoric, but Scant Funds, for Wind Power
text: The head of New England’s power grid said Thursday that alternative energy is popular, but is not being funded, leading to uncertainty in the market.

headline: Tentative Deal Struck for 2 Towers at Ground Zero
text: The Port Authority, government officials and the developer Larry A. Silverstein reached a tentative agreement Thursday that would allow for the construction of two new skyscrapers at ground zero with up to $1.6 billion in public financing and subsidies, The New York Times’s Charles V. Bagli reported.

headline: Northern Iowa Is No Fluke
text: Stephen Danley played basketball at Penn from 2003 to 2007.

headline: In Paris, Kitano’s Crazy Universe
text: The first-ever museum show of the Japanese artist, comedian and filmmaker Takeshi Kitano, now running at the Fondation Cartier in Paris through Sept. 12, reveals a carnivalesque universe of painting, installations, interactive games — including a giant, interactive sewing machine — all from the artist’s famously outlandish imagination.

headline: Broadcast Company Will Fund Local Reporting Projects
text: From Elizabeth Jensen at Media Decoder:

headline: Man Group Said to Mull Deals With SAC and GLG
text: The Man Group has been in preliminary deals talks with Steven A. Cohen’s SAC Capital Advisors and GLG Partners, as the world’s biggest publicly listed hedge-fund manager seeks out possible acquisitions and other deals in the United States, Bloomberg News reported, citing two people with knowledge of the discussions.

headline: Gores Said to Seek New Deal Talks With Polycom
text: The Gores Group was hoping to reopen talks with Polycom about a merger between the largest independent video-conferencing equipment company and one of the private equity firm’s portfolio companies, Siemens Enterprise Communications, The Financial Times reported.

headline: UBS Taps Credit Suisse Banker to Head Swiss Unit
text: UBS has poached a banker from rival Credit Suisse to lead its Swiss operations, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: I.C.B.C. Profit Jumps on Lending Boom
text: Industrial & Commercial Bank of China, the world’s biggest lender by market value, reported a surge in fourth-quarter profit, fueled by a lending boom and lower provisions against sour assets, Reuters reports.

headline: Germany’s Mitteleuropa Redux
text: Today’s idea: “Germany is achieving by stealth what it failed to achieve in the past thousand years of intra-European struggles,” an analyst writes: enduring dominance in continental matters.

headline: Stray Questions for: Lauren Groff
text: Lauren Groff is the author of a novel, “The Monsters of Templeton,” and a story collection, “Delicate Edible Birds.”

headline: State of the Giants: What the 2009 Film Revealed
text: Offense

headline: Tip of the Week: Rescheduling With Google Calendar
text: Google Calendar has helped people set up meetings and coordinate schedules online over the years, and now the company has a brand new way to reschedule those meetings.

headline: Sampler: Pitching Marijuana for the Revenue, and the Last Day for Google Broadband Applications
text: Marijuana Proposal Appeals to Need for Green | Proponents of the ballot measure to legalize marijuana in California won’t dwell on the drug’s safety or social acceptance. Instead, they will focus on money: They say that taxing its sales could raise $1.4 billion and ease the $20 billion state deficit. The measure, which qualified for the November ballot on Wednesday, would allow licensed retailers to sell up to one ounce at a time, a transaction that would be subject to tax. “We need the tax money,” said Richard Lee, founder of Oaksterdam University, a trade school in Oakland for marijuana growers. Mr. Lee backed the ballot measure’s successful petition drive. “Second, we need the tax savings on police and law enforcement, and have that law enforcement directed towards real crime.” Some are not so sure. “We just don’t think any good is going to come from this,” said John Standish, president of the California Peace Officers Association. [The New York Times]

headline: Treasury Said to Have Plan for Sale of Citi Stake
text: The United States Treasury may unveil a preset trading plan next month for the sale of its 27 percent stake in Citigroup, Bloomberg reported, citing people with direct knowledge of the matter.

headline: Flash Mobbed
text: WHAT are flash mobs?

headline: Why Goldman Wants a Branch in Warsaw
text: Goldman Sachs is looking to open a branch office in Warsaw, in a move to take advantage the Polish government’s plans to sell $10 billion worth of assets in share offerings this year, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Speed Read for Friday, March 26
text: Here are some highlights from Friday’s editions of The New York Times:

headline: Rio Tinto Executive Admits to Taking Two Bribes
text: SHANGHAI — Stern Hu, an executive at the British-Australian mining giant Rio Tinto, has said in court that he accepted two large bribes in late 2008 and early 2009 totaling about $1 million from Chinese steel mills in exchange for agreeing to sell them long-term supplies of iron ore, his lawyer said Friday.

headline: Report Supports Overhaul’s Savings Estimate
text: The Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a liberal-leaning fiscal policy research group in Washington, put out a point-by-point refutation on Thursday of claims from opponents of the new health insurance law that its projected savings, especially from Medicare, are based on budgetary gimmicks and will never be realized.

headline: Afghan Marksmen — Forget the Fables
text: The recent Marine operations in and near Marja brought into sharp relief a fact that contradicts much of what people think they know about the Afghan war. It is this: Forget the fables. The current ranks of Afghan fighters are crowded with poor marksmen.

headline: A Strange Thing About the Rain in F1
