text: It is a little ironic that in the midst of a soul-searching moment in Formula One about whether or not the series is boring, many people have spoken about how artificial things like a reverse grid or rain can help spice up the spectacle.

headline: Moore’s Rifat Denies Insider-Trading Accusations
text: Julian Rifat, the hedge fund trader arrested as part of a major investigation by British financial authorities, on Friday denied accusations that he took part in insider trading.

headline: Q. and A.: Bill McKibben on CO2 and the Future
text: Bill McKibben, an environmentalist and long-time advocate for action on climate change, believes we can still reverse the growing concentration of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere, which the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration now estimates at 390 parts per million.

headline: Allawi Victory in Iraq Sets Up Period of Uncertainty
text: BAGHDAD — The secular party of Ayad Allawi, a former interim prime minister once derided as an American puppet, won a wafer-thin victory in Iraq’s election, setting the stage for a protracted period of political uncertainty and possible violence that could threaten plans to withdraw American troops.

headline: Tata Nano Goes Up in Smoke
text: 11:23 a.m. | Updated

headline: Open Note to Student Commenters and Your Teachers: Thank You!
text: When our blog first launched in October, we weren’t sure how the whole daily Student Opinion question thing would go. Would anyone write in? Would real kids actually come and post thoughtful and honest comments, or would we get dutiful, dull writing from students answering only because a teacher was checking it off in a grade book?

headline: Building a Maxwell: It’s a Team Sport
text: IT took a small army of restorers from across the country to bring the Andersons’ Maxwell project to fruition.

headline: History That’s More Than the Sum of Its Parts
text: ON the surface, it sounds like a nearly impossible task: assembling a rare brass-era car from scratch, using century-old parts that were tracked down one by one from all the dusty, rust-ridden corners of the collecting world.

headline: To Curb Grade Inflation, Safety Tests Get Tougher
text: WHEN a straight-A student starts bringing home report cards riddled with Cs, it’s cause for concern.

headline: Gas-Pump Freedom (Restrictions Apply)
text: DRIVING the Mini E in and around New York City highlights both the promises and the pitfalls of electric cars.

headline: Scoring the Electric Mini Acid Test
text: TURNS out there’s a sure-fire way to get the public excited about electric cars: let people have them. After reviewing 1,800 applications on a company Web site, BMW’s Mini division selected 450 people last year to lease its all-electric Mini E for a full year in New York, New Jersey and greater Los Angeles.

headline: The Early Word: Reconciled
text: And it’s done.

headline: Read This Post or You’ll Get Syphilis
text: It’s Friday, and as hard as you’ve worked all week, let’s face it: you could have worked harder. There’s always something you could have done better — a pithier memo, a firmer handshake with that client, a smoother edge on all those collated documents.

headline: Meatpacking District, 12:50 A.M.
text: The sidewalks of Hudson Street pulse beneath stiletto heels.

headline: Toyota Slows Production in Europe as Sales Lag
text: TOKYO — Toyota Motor said on Friday that it would idle three plants in France and Britain for a total of 14 days to reduce inventory amid recent recalls and a slump in European sales.

headline: U.S. Growth in 4th Quarter Revised Slightly Lower
text: Economic growth in the last quarter of 2009 was slightly less robust than previously thought, the government said on Friday. But corporate profit in the quarter rose significantly, providing hope that businesses might begin hiring again.

headline: OMG! ’30 Rock’ Knows The New York Times Exists!
text: For a moment, everything about this “30 Rock” clip was going just right: Cheyenne Jackson was in it, and he was joking about Canadians and singing about hockey. And then he mentioned The New York Times! And then…oh. Joke’s on us. Well, like the man said, it’s just an honor to be mentioned in the same breath as Dave Coulier.

headline: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Rangers Stay Alive on Drury’s Late Goal
text: The New York Rangers were just 17 seconds from virtual elimination, but somehow they saved their season. That was merely the the most dramatic among Thursday’s 11 games. Home teams listed first:

headline: The Strange Case of the Playground Jail
text: Building a playground is not as simple as installing a set of vertigo-inspiring monkey bars: These days, the world of playground design is rife with debate over how high the slides should be, whether the equipment should be brightly colored (kids say yes) or blend in with the environment, and whether themes like castles and rocket ships stimulate or stifle the imagination.

headline: The Times of London to Charge Online
text: The Times of London will charge readers for Internet access starting in June, News Corporation announced on Friday, putting Rupert Murdoch at the forefront of a movement to erect toll gates on news sites.

headline: Rwanda Lodge Opens Near Monkey Forest
text: While mountain gorillas draw tourists to the north of Rwanda, the new Nyungwe Forest Lodge, bordering a lush rain forest preserve, seeks to bring well-heeled safari goers to the country’s south.

headline: Ristretto | The Daily Grind
text: In Ristretto, Oliver Strand, the curator of the Times Topics coffee page, explores the world of coffee gadgets, coffee beans and why it’s never been easier to get a perfect shot of espresso.

headline: American Scout for Mumbai Attacks Was Jokingly Called ‘Agent Headley’ by Friends
text: As my colleague Jane Perlez reports, an American man admitted last week that he had helped to plan the Mumbai attacks by making several surveillance trips to the city, shooting video of targets and taking coordinates with a GPS unit.

headline: China Bars Noted Scholar From Planned Trip to U.S.
text: BEIJING — A prominent Chinese scholar and film critic who was scheduled to speak at an academic conference in the United States this week said Friday that she had been barred from leaving China as punishment for her commentary on human rights and free speech.

headline: A Bold U.S. Plan to Help Struggling Homeowners
text: Will it work this time?

headline: Energy Star Found Wanting?
text: In case you missed it, Matt Wald reported on Friday that auditors were able to easily earn the Energy Star label for a host of bogus products, including the “air purifier” pictured above — essentially a heater with a feather duster attached to the top.

headline: Graphic Books Best-Sellers: ‘Twilight’ Gets Really Graphic
text: “Twilight” fans rejoice – you now have another arena in which to engage in the eternal Team Edward vs. Team Jacob debate. This week marked the release of “Twilight: The Graphic Novel” Vol. 1, which stakes its claim at No. 1 on the hardcover list. This  adaptation of Stephenie Meyer’s vampire saga, adapted by the Korean artist Young Kim, sold 66,000 copies in its first week of release, according to its publisher, Yen Press. (It probably didn’t hurt that the graphic novel went on sale just a few days after the DVD release for “The Twilight Saga: New Moon.”) An excerpt from the comic adaptation, in which Bella is introduced to her new high-school cafeteria (and the Cullen family) can be found here.

headline: Transportation Department Embraces Bikes, and Business Groups Cry Foul
text: Transportation Secretary Ray LaHood has announced a “major policy revision” that aims to give bicycling and walking the same policy and economic consideration as driving.

headline: Pelosi Signs Reconciliation Bill
text: 10:33 a.m. | Updated

headline: She’ll Be the Judge
text: If previous years at the Wharton Business Plan Competition are any indication, the feedback of Madi Ferencz — a competition judge, marketing veteran and a serial entrepreneur — will be highly coveted at this year’s event (semifinals in early April, finals April 28). One reason is that her consumer-goods expertise provides some contrast to the opinions offered by her fellow judges, most of whom are high-tech-focused venture investors and entrepreneurs.

headline: Ice Racing in New Hampshire
text: Ice racing in New Hampshire, academic exams in India, the malevolent uses of sound and a 90-year-old cab driver.

headline: Ultraslim Speakers for Your Ultraslim TV
text: So you just plunked down a bundle for that new superthin LED-backlit LCD or plasma TV, and you have even mounted it on the wall. What do you do to keep that slim look when it comes to audio equipment?

headline: Through a Glass, Busily
text: “YOU have to hit the ground running,” the artist Kiki Smith said recently, referring to her process. “You have to have multiple things happening, so you’re not just standing around.” It’s hard to imagine this is much of a risk for Ms. Smith, 56. So far this year, at least, she has hardly stood still.

headline: Doctors Offer Thoughts on Cutting Health Care Costs
text: IN persuading Congressional Democrats to pass the health care overhaul, President Obama addressed one of the most pressing issues facing the country: providing broader access to medical insurance for as many as 32 million Americans who do not now have it.

headline: I Loathe the ’80s With John Cusack
text: Everybody who lived through the 1980s is in some way nostalgic for that decade, right? Cabbage Patch Kids, hair metal, “Miami Vice,” the disintegration of the Warsaw Pact – good times.

headline: Shelf Life | Rough Justice
text: The work of Alex Ross, a celebrated artist in the comic book industry, is a wonder to behold. His painted pages have graced the pages of “Marvels,” a limited series exploring the early days of Spider-Man, Captain America and their ilk from the perspective of a photojournalist; “Kingdom Come,” which looked at the future of Superman and Batman and found a world overrun by irresponsible super humans; and countless comic book covers. Each time, fans have been treated to lush paintings of favorite heroes that seem as realistic as photographs.

headline: Complaint Box | Religion on the Field
text: Now that the Boys of Spring are prepped for the 2010 season, I am, too.

headline: Earning Her Food
text: I’m a city girl from New York. I’m also 82 and half-blind, so what am I doing deer hunting with my son, Sam, at the end of October in Montana? We’re in the foothills of the Swan Mountains near Kalispell, south of Glacier National Park. For the last four days, Sam and I have been tramping dawn to dusk over tree debris that loggers call “clear-cut.” We haven’t eaten since we left his cabin before dawn. Now it’s snowing, and I’m wet, tired and bloody cold.

headline: The Marrying Kind
text: My mother has a sly way of backing into major announcements. “I’m renovating my kitchen” was her way of introducing the fact that she and her beau were moving in together several years after my father died. A year or so later she said, “I’m spending the morning finishing paperwork, so this afternoon we can go ring shopping,” which was her way of warning that a sapphire solitaire would soon grace her ring finger.

headline: Trust Busting
text: A company shows anxiety on its face — that is, on its Web site, which has become the face of the modern corporation. Visit sites for recently troubled or confused enterprises, including Maclaren, Toyota, Playtex, Tylenol and, yes, John Edwards, and you’ll find a range of digital ways of dealing with distress.

headline: Out of Africa
text: Since its publication in 1958,  “Things Fall Apart,”  the story of a Nigerian yam farmer who is unable to accept the changes wrought by British colonialism, has become the best-selling novel ever written by an African.  Well, I hear such exaggerated comments. I just leave them alone.

headline: Bedbug Disclosure
text: Creepy crawlies; grade creep.

headline: Crossfire
text: Starbucks has lately found itself in the middle of a debate between advocates of “open carry” gun rights and of gun control; the former have held armed meet-ups at several of its locations, and the latter have demanded that the coffee chain prevent this from happening. Seeking to duck these fresh salvos in the long debate over how firearms fit into American life, the company has issued a statement that such matters ought to be worked out “in the legislatures and courts, not in our stores.” Well, sure. But drawing a line between official institutions of lawmaking and the daily sphere where citizens move about is not so easy. And one thing the pistols-and-Frappuccino moment has demonstrated is that this is acutely true for a business with an image carefully devised to blur the line between public space and commercial space.

headline: Letter: The Limits of Rahmism
text: When things go wrong, everyone looks for a scapegoat, and the consensus, as Peter Baker reports, seems to be that everything is somehow Rahm Emanuel’s fault. I think the administration’s problems are overblown. Yes, there have been growing pains and some communication difficulties, but not all is lost by any means. Blaming any one person, even the chief of staff, is terribly unfair and typical of the Washington finger-pointing game. It doesn’t do anything to contribute to the serious dialogue needed to address the significant problems that we face as a country.

headline: Letter: Issues With a Fix for Kids With Issues
text: Expensive, unproven approaches like vision therapy need to be questioned in order to protect the welfare of children and families and to uphold evidence-based treatment as central to quality care. Judith Warner’s article on vision therapy referred to a convergence-insufficiency treatment trial as a “gold standard,” but this single study, which recommended in-office therapy for convergency insufficiency, should not be used to substantiate all uses of vision therapy. As Warner notes, valid research shows that the most common reading disorder, dyslexia, is caused by problems with language processing, memory and attention, not with the eyes or visual system.

headline: Bottled vs. Tap
text: From our Green Inc. blog comes this summary of the debate between advocates of tap water and those of bottled water. The first group includes most people I know, an increasing number of restaurateurs, and the United Nations, and the second includes the bottled water industry.

headline: Letter: How to Cook Up a Food Celebrity
text: I found myself returning repeatedly to the lead photograph in Frank Bruni’s wonderful article about the foodie Katie Lee. Gillian Laub’s marvelous photograph of this young lady hell-bent on celebrity lets us know that Lee is one tough cookie.

headline: Letter: The Femivore’s Dilemma
text: Who exactly are the “femivores”? Do they eat only female things? Eat women? They sound like self-cannibalizing stay-at-home moms, which is probably not what the new pioneers of the domestic frontier have in mind.

headline: Dear Poppa. Sincerely, Jerry
text: Not every fan letter written to Ernest Hemingway merits its own display in a museum, but when its author is J. D. Salinger a little pomp and circumstance is understandable. On Sunday, the John F. Kennedy Presidential Library and Museum in Boston will put on display a note from Salinger to Hemingway, written in 1946, that recounts a meeting between the authors and possibly hints at the coming publication of “The Catcher in the Rye,” The Associated Press reported.

headline: Letter: On Language
text: You have honored the memory of William Safire in a fashion worthy of his legacy. You did not with thoughtless urgency pass the On Language baton to a self-appointed heir apparent salivating in the wings. Nor did you suspend the column altogether as some sort of respectful gesture to the master.

headline: Twists and Turns on Way to Arms Pact With Russia
text: President Obama was angry. He was on the phone with President Dmitri A. Medvedev last month to finalize a new arms control treaty with Russia, only to be confronted with new demands for concessions on missile defense. A deal that was supposed to be done was unraveling.

headline: Second Round of British Airways Strikes to Begin
text: British Airways is bracing for a second round of strikes, to last four days starting at midnight, as its chief executive is accused of trying to break the union. Read more…

headline: Pakistani Forces and Militants Clash at Border
text: PESHAWAR, Pakistan — Taliban militants battled Pakistani security forces for control of a security outpost in a tribal region near the Afghan border, leaving five Pakistani security officials and dozens of Taliban fighters dead, Pakistani authorities said Friday.

headline: Weekend Competition Q&A: A Bissel Yiddish?
text: This weekend, in the run-up to Passover, co-vocabularists are invited to share their love of Yiddish and pose questions to an expert on the language.

text: TOKYO — For more than 17 years, Toshikazu Sugaya, a soft-spoken former kindergarten bus driver, lived behind bars, serving a life sentence for the murder of a 4-year-old girl.

text: Oh dear. Lewis Hamilton was apparently so happy about being the fastest driver in the practice session at Albert Park in Melbourne on Friday that he went out to celebrate, and to show off in his road car on the streets of Melbourne.

text: Ask a friend to help you to set up a home wireless network, and his eyes will likely glaze over, perhaps he’ll fidget a bit, and then offer to loan you some money to call the Geek Squad.

headline: A Matter of Life and Death: Suicides in the Army
text: The Army faces a battle over the life and death of its soldiers. The battle is not being waged in Iraq and Afghanistan, but in the minds and tortured souls of soldiers contemplating suicide. Last year the Army again reported an increase in suicides, and in response the Army now requires every soldier to complete an online assessment of his or her physical, mental and spiritual well-being.

headline: Pelosi Signs Reconciliation Bill
text: At our Prescriptions sib-blog, colleague David M. Herszenhorn reports on the signing by House Speaker Nancy Pelosi of the final revisions to the health care bill in a ceremony earlier this morning.

headline: Chart: Video Clips of Pavement’s Reunion
text: Last year the 1990s indie rock band Pavement announced it was reuniting, and earlier this month it played its first few shows in New Zealand and Australia. Naturally, audience-made videos were quickly posted on YouTube. Rather than wait for Pavement’s set at the Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival on April 18, the artist Andrew Kuo — a longtime fan — rates the clips:

headline: Andy Warhol’s Ferragamos
text: You can’t buy these shoes without knowing the story behind them. Sure, they’re elegant, in an Old World, spaghetti Bolognese, “Where’s Michael?” kind of way. “But what’s with those specks of paint?” someone might ask you. “What kind of an animal would paint while wearing full-grain Italian calfskin shoes?” Although there are many expensive men’s shoes that now bear his name, Salvatore Ferragamo (1898-1960) designed only one style for men in his lifetime, and you’re looking at it. Andy Warhol owned a pair and, naturally, he painted in them. And then Warhol died. And then, in 2006, the Ferragamo family bought those paint-specked Warhol shoes at an auction. And now, authorized copies are available for $990 at the Ferragamo flagship store on Fifth Avenue in New York. Call (212) 754-5200.

headline: Among Kentucky’s Stars, Respect for Cornell
text: SYRACUSE — In the locker room following Kentucky’s shaky 62-45 win over Cornell in the Round of 16 on Thursday, Wildcats center DeMarcus Cousins wanted to finally put to rest more talk about the Big Red’s collective I.Q.

text: In this week’s New York Times Magazine I write about the changed meaning of the word “wife.”

text: SEOUL, South Korea — A South Korean Navy patrol ship sank near the disputed western maritime border with North Korea early Saturday after suffering damage to its hull, South Korea’s military said.

headline: Chrysler Offers Reinstatement to 86 Dealerships It Told to Close
text: DETROIT — Chrysler, which eliminated a quarter of its United States dealerships in the company’s bankruptcy last year, said on Friday it would let as many as 86 of those dealers reopen.

headline: Pope Had ‘No Knowledge’ of Transfer, Vatican Says
text: ROME — The Vatican on Friday reaffirmed its position that the future Pope Benedict XVI “had no knowledge” of a decision to allow a known pedophile priest to resume pastoral duties when the pope was archbishop in Munich in 1980.

headline: Taxes and the Deficit Commission
text: House Democrats named their three members of the new White House deficit commission this week, which completes the commission’s roster. The commission will have 18 members (10 Democrats and 8 Republicans) and is scheduled to issue its recommendations by the end of this year. Below, you’ll find a full list of members.

headline: They’re No Longer Upsets
text: Here is the truest sign yet that men’s college basketball may be completely turned on its head: Butler pulls off a Round of 16 upset in the N.C.A.A. tournament that should warm the hearts of underdog lovers everywhere, knocked off a No. 1 seed (even if it was a seriously flawed Syracuse), is coached by a guy who looks as if he got his driver’s license three days ago, plays in a gym straight out of a “Leave It to Beaver” episode and yet the Bulldogs walked off the court in Salt Lake City with no more dragon-slaying hoopla than if they just had just defeated Youngstown State in December.

headline: Doctors’ Remedies for Rising Costs
text: Today’s Patient Money column considers the pressing problem of rising health care costs, an issue brought to the fore by the past year’s health care reform debate. How can the country reduce medical costs while not compromising quality?

headline: In Racing Four Wide, N.H.R.A. Takes a Gamble
text: O. Bruton Smith, the audacious racing mogul, has built a dragstrip near Concord, N.C., that is a little different from most other drag strips, and its opulence is just one attribute. The zMax Dragway, already nicknamed “The Bellagio of Drag Strips,” has four lanes, not two, and all four will be used at the same time this weekend at the inaugural N.H.R.A. Four-Wide Nationals.

headline: It’s Not Dry Yet
text: FEW modern myths about art have been as persistent or as annoying as the so-called death of painting. Unless, of course, it is the belief that abstract and representational painting are oil and water, never to meet as one.

headline: Oh, Grow Up
text: I’m a junior in college far from home, but I try to stay close with my old friends. Some of them think I’ve become pretentious, and that my politics and tastes in food, drink and clothing have become elitist. I admit that I’ve changed since high school, but I think of it as growing up. I felt awkward and insecure then; now I’m more comfortable with myself. Still, I’m afraid of alienating my oldest friends. What should I do?

headline: Naughty by Nature
text: ‘I started out in the south, but the island kicked me up here a few years ago,” says Cathy Bilsky, who runs Cathy’s Angelite Om, a shop in the old plantation town Honokaa, on the northeastern coast of the Big Island of Hawaii. Like many locals, Bilsky, who came here from Michigan (by way of California), tends to anthropomorphize the island. Her store is piled high with jagged rocks, posters of Ganesh and signed autographs from fans like Andy Dick, who scribbled, “Cathy, I love you!” on his photo. “This just felt like home when I got up here,” she says as she kneads my shoulders with one of her crystals.

headline: Two Experimentalists Under One Roof
text: SINCE its opening in 2005 the Baryshnikov Arts Center has been resolutely multidisciplinary in its programming. Still, the building is named after a man who is synonymous with dance, and it was something of a surprise to learn three years ago that Mikhail Baryshnikov had asked the Wooster Group, the venerable experimental theater collective, to take up residence in a newly acquired and still-to-be-renovated theater in the building in Midtown Manhattan.

headline: A Head Full of Pictures, an Eye for the Stage
text: The singular downtown artist David Greenspan has made a name for himself as an actor for hire in productions like the off-kilter musical “Coraline” last year and Target Margin Theater’s 2006 extravaganza “Faust.” (The review in The New York Times called his Mephistopheles “irresistible” even though “you know you shouldn’t go near him.”) But he’s also known as the cerebral playwright (and star) of sparely staged works like “The Myopia,” which the Foundry Theater presented in a critically praised revival this winter. Changing modes so regularly (he’s now performing in Michi Barall’s “Rescue Me” at the Ohio Theater), does he also change his approach?

headline: London Underground | The White Cubicle
text: A ladies’ restroom in an East End pub is not the most likely site for art, but then the White Cubicle Toilet Gallery does not follow many rules.

text: KABUL, Afghanistan — American and NATO troops firing from passing convoys and military checkpoints have killed 30 Afghans and wounded 80 others since last summer, but in no instance did the victims prove to be a danger to troops, according to military officials in Kabul.

headline: As It Turns Out, Maybe You Can Judge a Book by Its Cover
text: Which of these facts is more surprising: that there is an annual contest held by The Bookseller magazine for the year’s most bizarrely titled book, or that a volume about Nazi eating utensils didn’t win it? Sorry, “Collectible Spoons of the Third Reich” by James A. Yannes, but you received only enough votes to place third in the online competition for the Diagram Prize for Oddest Book Title of the Year, the magazine announced on Friday in a news release. A plurality of the votes — 1,912 of the 4,553 ballots cast at TheBookSeller.com — went to “Crocheting Adventures With Hyperbolic Planes” by Dr. Daina Taimina.

headline: The Return of China
text: In the coming decades China will likely surpass United States as the world’s biggest economy. That may seem strange and uncomfortable to many Americans, but it wouldn’t be the first time China dominated the global economy.

headline: ‘Fighting Obesity’
text: Monologue |  Thursday night on “Late Night With Jimmy Fallon” on NBC: Michelle Obama is going to be honored for her anti-obesity campaign at Nickelodeon’s Kids’ Choice Awards, hosted by Kevin James. I mean, seriously — fighting obesity at a show hosted by Kevin James. That’s like fighting adultery at a show hosted by Jesse James.

headline: Restricted, but Not Deterred
text: Besides being a dictator, a political thorn for the West and a Dr. Evil-like figure of pop culture ridicule, the North Korean leader Kim Jong-il is also a film buff. Other dictators have taken an interest in cinema as a propaganda tool  Stalin exploited Sergei Eisenstein and Hitler hired Leni Riefenstahl  but Mr. Kim has gone further.

headline: ‘The Pentagon Will Ease Up’
text: Monologue |  Thursday night on “The Tonight Show With Jay Leno” on NBC: Secretary of State Hillary Clinton was down in Mexico earlier this week. Nothing important. She has to go down there every year at this time to drag Bill back from spring break.

headline: Judge Voids City School Closings
text: Updated, 3:16 p.m. | A Manhattan judge on Friday reversed a city decision to close 19 schools for poor performance, ruling that education officials engaged in “significant violations” of state education law and failed to follow proper process in closing the schools.

headline: Now Online | T Travel Spring 2010 Issue
text: It’s all about . . . Back to the land, starting with our cover story on Hawaii’s Big Island, an off-the-grid wonderland where Mother Nature went a little bit nuts. Then we head down under to Australia to commune with the cane toads in the awe-inspiring Top End, and to Lake Powell, a no less jaw-dropping corner of the American West. We check in with the urban refugees yearning to buy the farm (for a weekend), pay a visit to the schnapps makers of the Austrian Alps, and get to know the environmental adventurer David de Rothschild. Not that we’ve entirely forgotten the charms of city life: There’s a stop in newly energized Bordeaux, France; a wander through the half-closed doors and shadowy lanes of Palermo, Italy; and a rip-roaring meet-and-greet with the movers and shakers of Beirut. And because you can’t go back to the land if you don’t take care of it, there’s T’s first-ever guide to eco-tripping.

headline: Baylor’s Udoh Is No Samhan, On or Off Court
text: HOUSTON — While St. Mary’s center Omar Samhan is outgoing off the court and powerful on it, Baylor’s forward/center Ekpe Udoh may just be his foil.

headline: Shepard Fairey Returns to New York (With Permission)
text: The artist Shepard Fairey has become a museum darling but is still close enough to his street-art roots to have been arrested, jailed overnight and sentenced to two years of probation last year in Boston for pasting his work on buildings before a retrospective at the city’s Institute of Contemporary Art. Now – as he prepares for a May exhibition at Deitch Projects in New York, that gallery’s final show as its owner, Jeffrey Deitch, closes the business to take over the Los Angeles Museum of Contemporary Art – Mr. Fairey is planning to put up street art the polite way, by asking building owners.

headline: Lang Lang Offers Up a Polonaise for Haiti
text: The pianist Lang Lang was the headliner at a concert designated as a benefit for Unicef at Carnegie Hall on Sunday night, and was joined onstage for one song by Wyclef Jean, one of the prime movers behind the Hope for Haiti Now concert and telethon and the resulting album. While expenses for the Carnegie concert exceeded proceeds from ticket sales, contributions from corporations including Sony, with whom Mr. Lang signed a recording deal this year, and Columbia Artists Management, which represents Mr. Lang, have meant that, under Mr. Lang’s auspices, Unicef has received around $100,000.

headline: A Fight for a Church Is Evoking Introspection
text: When news spread the other day that work crews were draping black steel netting over the facade of Our Lady of Loreto Church, the people fighting to save the building from demolition found themselves stymied — and reflecting on a yearlong campaign at the brink.

headline: Energy Star Rating Questioned
text: A Government Accountability Office investigation shows that many appliances backed by the Energy Star program are not tested for efficiency. (Video: NBC)

headline: Bullet Fired at Cantor’s Window Was ‘Random’
text: When Representative Eric Cantor of Virginia, the second-ranking Republican leader in the House, held a news conference Thursday to accuse Democrats of exploiting the threats and vandalism they have faced since passing the health care bill, to reap publicity and partisan advantage, he got quite a bit of publicity himself by announcing that a bullet had been shot through the window of one of his Richmond campaign offices earlier in the week.

headline: What Lang Lang Brings to Chopin’s ‘Heroic’ Polonaise
text: Lang Lang’s approach to the grand opening bars of Chopin’s “Heroic” Polonaise, which he is offering as a single on iTunes with a portion of the proceeds going to Unicef, is worthy of the titular appellation. What comes afterward, though, has less to do with heroism than with Mr. Lang’s flamboyant dexterity and what it allows him to do. He tugs and teases at bars and phrases like an over-caffeinated stylist with a jittery hand and a reality show.

headline: Of Water, Electricity and the Time of Day
text: Water accounts for an astonishing percentage of electricity use — 19 percent in California, for example — partly because of all the energy needed to pump it.

headline: ‘Appetite for America’

headline: The Impact of Images: Considering the Place of Photojournalism Today
text: Overview | In a world where digital cameras and amateur photos are as ubiquitous as the cell phones that carry them, has photojournalism lost impact? Or has the proliferation of images only made us more receptive to, and appreciative of, professional work? In this lesson, to commemorate the seventh anniversary of the Iraq war, students look at and respond to photos of fallen soldiers’ bedrooms. They then create and present creative photo essays.

headline: Blasts Kill Dozens at Cafe and Restaurant North of Baghdad
text: BAGHDAD — A day of high drama here was marred by a pair of explosions that ripped through a cafe and a restaurant in a violent town north of Baghdad on Friday, killing 43 people and wounding at least 65 others, the authorities said.

headline: Santa Clara County to Consider Restricting Toys With Fast Food
text: Ken Yeager, the president of the Santa Clara County Board of Supervisors, has been on Fox, CNN and MSNBC in recent days because of a proposal he has floated that the county restrict fast-food restaurants’ tendency to use toys to reward children for making unhealthy food choices.

headline: Netanyahu Remains Firm on Jerusalem Housing
text: JERUSALEM — The prime minister of Israel, Benjamin Netanyahu, stood firm Friday on his government’s policy of continued building in East Jerusalem, a major point of contention with the Obama administration. His office said the policy remained unchanged.

headline: Some Tax Considerations to Keep in Mind for 2010
text: The discussion this tax season has been dominated by some big changes in tax and other laws. One allows some taxpayers to convert their regular retirement account to a Roth I.R.A., which would incur a tax bill now but the gains would then accumulate tax-free. Another is the expiration of the estate tax for 2010. And with the passage of the health care overhaul this week, there is now the prospect of surcharges for higher earners (though not until 2013).

text: The Moviegoer is a regular column on new and noteworthy films, actors and directors by John Anderson.

headline: Bush Returns to the Viral Video Charts
text: Video of former Presidents George W. Bush and Bill Clinton visiting earthquake survivors in Haiti this week has returned Mr. Bush to the viral video charts for the first time since he left the White House.

headline: In Germany, a Highway Threatens the Mosel Wine Region
text: Despite the chill pouring in through the open window next to my desk, spring is here. For me, that means thoughts turn to riesling, German riesling in particular.

headline: The Morning Skate: Rivalries and Head Checks Refuse to Fade Away
text: Hockey news away from the N.H.L. has been somewhat more uplifting lately. Echoing the gold medal Olympic clash, rival teams of U.S. and Canadian servicemen in Afghanistan have squared off in a street hockey games, part of a morale-boosting tour for Canadian troops that runs through this weekend. The delegation includes includes 15 N.H.L. alumni, Maple Leafs executives and the Stanley Cup. National Public Radio’s “Morning Edition” ran a piece on the tour today (audio) and Maple Leaf Sports and Entertainment executive Tom Anselmi has been blogging from Afghanistan and his posts include some video with Leafs General Manager Brian Burke and Hockey Hall of Famer Lanny McDonald.

headline: Fitch Expects Financial Overhaul to Cut Bank Risks
text: The proposed overhaul of American financial regulations should reduce the extent of risk-taking by the biggest banks and may bolster their credit ratings, Fitch Ratings said Friday, Reuters reports.

headline: Music Manager Sues Axl Rose
text: The company that managed Axl Rose’s career in Guns n’ Roses for much of the last two years has sued him to collect what it says is $1.9 million in unpaid fees. Front Line Management, whose founder and chief executive is Irving Azoff — who is also executive chairman of Live Nation Entertainment, which merged with Ticketmaster last month — filed suit in Los Angeles Superior Court on Thursday, saying that Mr. Rose is in breach of an oral contract that obliged him to pay Front Line 15 percent of his gross earnings as a performer. The suit says that Mr. Rose has not paid the management fees on recent concerts in Asia, South America and Canada, which grossed $12.5 million. A spokesman for Mr. Azoff declined to comment further on the suit, and representatives for Mr. Rose — including his new manager, Doc McGhee — did not respond to inquiries.

text: Chapter 1: Welcome Home, Henry

headline: ‘The Sabbath World’
text: Part 1: Time Sickness

headline: RadioShack Jumps on Report of Possible Sale
text: Shares of RadioShack rose as much as 9.5 percent on Friday after The New York Post reported that the consumer electronics chain was considering strategic alternatives including a possible sale of the company for more than $3 billion.

headline: Greeks, Romans, and Financial Reform
text: I’m trying to wrap my mind around the details of financial reform, and in particular the difference between the Frank bill, already passed by the House, and the Dodd bill. And I keep coming back to an odd analogy, involving ancient history.

headline: Travel Deals: Guided Tour of Dubai
text: Friendly Planet Travel, a tour operator based in Pennsylvania, is offering a six-day Dazzling Dubai sightseeing tour starting at $1,499, including round-trip airfare from New York on Emirates Airlines. The package also includes accommodations at the Fairmont Dubai, modeled after an Arabic wind tower, and tours with an English-speaking guide. For departures from Houston, add $130, for Los Angeles or San Francisco, add $200.

headline: Taxing CO2 Emissions at Europe’s Borders
text: Is the time approaching when the European Union will impose greenhouse gas controls on products and services imported from parts of the world that lack such regulations?

headline: We Made It Ourselves | Say Head Cheese!
text: In her column, We Made It Ourselves, Charlotte Druckman writes about restaurants and small businesses with interesting house-made treats.

headline: In Long Island, Gatsby Would Feel Right at Home
text: KINGS POINT

headline: Perspective On Interest Rates
text: Scary-sounding story in the WSJ about spiking interest rates. But, oddly, no perspective on how this looks in terms of the history of interest rates since the crisis — just charts of the last few days.

headline: Financial Tuneup: Should I Take Less Risk?
text: All of us need to take some time every so often to knock things off of our financial to-do list. To help, we’ve created a series of articles and an interactive checklist to get you started.

headline: Protecting an Array of Gems in the Bronx
text: IN the 1970s, when the Hunts Point section of the Bronx became associated with drugs, crime and prostitution, a group of bow-front row houses in the 800 block of Manida Street remained an oasis of tranquillity.

headline: Karen Elson Is Dressing the Part, and Singing It
text: LIFE is unfair and everybody knows it, but should you require a refresher, you need only to watch Karen Elson, the redheaded supermodel, design muse and wife of Jack White of the White Stripes, sing.

headline: A Tense Baghdad Learns Election Results
text: Even before the results of the parliamentary elections were released in Iraq, supporters of Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki were protesting in Baghdad (Slide 1). After it was announced that former Prime Minister Iyad Allawi’s coalition had won the most seats, Mr. Maliki denounced the results as fraudulent. Both the first and second photographs in this slide show were taken for The Times by João Silva.

headline: Europeans Vow Effort to Bring Economies Closer
text: BRUSSELS — Jolted by the Greek debt crisis and alarmed at the prospect of bailing out a fellow member state, European Union leaders on Friday promised new efforts to coordinate policies to bring their divergent economies closer.

headline: Living in NoLIta
text: NoLIta, framed by Houston, Lafayette and Kenmare Streets and the Bowery, is short on green space, but long on “little spots that have kind of become New York landmarks,” as one resident described  it.

headline: Seller as Lender
text: FOR most home sellers, their ties to a property end at the closing. But for a few others the attachment can continue on for years, because they also assume the role of banker.

headline: In Canada, TV Goes Deep on Climate
text: In a world of shrinking conventional coverage of (non-medical) science and the environment, it was refreshing recently to become aware of the The Agenda with Steve Paikin, a popular current-affairs program on public television in Ontario — particularly its five-hour string of shows devoted to some of the prime facets of the climate challenge.

headline: Touring the ‘Road to Freedom’
text: “Road to Freedom: Photographs of the Civil Rights Movement, 1956-1968,” an exhibit of 150 images organized by the High Museum of Art in Atlanta that capture the struggle for equal rights, will be on display from March 28 through Aug. 11 at the Bronx Museum of the Arts.

headline: Willpower, and Maybe a Camera, to Get Rid of Your Unused Junk
text: I HAVE a strange affinity for those reality shows where teams of people go into incredibly messy homes, see masses of clutter, get it all cleared out and then end up with beautifully redecorated homes that look like stage sets.

headline: A Time Capsule Invaded
text: VISIT NoLIta early enough on a weekday, before all the boutiques stir to life at 11 or even noon, and you might feel as if you had traveled back in time 75 years. Weathered walk-up tenement buildings cast shadows over the side streets; homeless men trudge through on their way to the Bowery; pizza shop workers settle in for a day at the ovens.

headline: Turning Up the Heat Over a ‘No’ Vote
text: In the continuing fallout over the vote to overhaul health care, several influential Democratic groups are pressing a veteran Albany lawmaker to cancel a fund-raiser she was planning for a Democratic congressman who voted against the measure.

headline: On the Street | Toe Dance
text: In New York, the comfort factor drives fashion. In the French capital it's all about status and taste, regardless of discomfort.

headline: Fired From the ‘Mommy Track’
text: A friend called me last night to tell me she was denied a promotion because she was engaged. Planning her wedding, she was told, would mean she would be too distracted to do her new job properly and would probably end up having babies and leaving the company anyway.

headline: All in the Family
text: IT was happenstance that brought Kevin Cheng to Astoria, Queens. A friend had an extra bedroom in his apartment, which was on the ground floor of an attached two-family row house.

headline: Advantage for Taiwan Automaker Lies in the Country’s Tech Sector
text: Early this month, Luxgen, a Taiwanese automaker, issued a news release about its presence at the Dubai auto show, which took place last December.

headline: In East Orange, Seeds for Redevelopment Are Planted
text: EAST ORANGE

headline: One Composer, Served Two Ways
text: Lincoln Center’s split-focus Beethoven symphony cycle, which began on Thursday evening at Alice Tully Hall, is a fantastic case study in how a slight tweak can make a commonplace programming idea seem compelling, and how marketing overdrive can then make the whole idea look silly.

headline: Renovations Make a Comeback
text: THE Columbia is a tall yellow-brick condominium at the corner of Broadway and West 96th Street, populated by many families and professionals. On weekday mornings, the lobby bustles with kids scurrying to school and grown-ups hurrying to work. Lately, though, there has been an addition to the hubbub: Contractors, lines of them, waiting for authorization to ascend the elevator to the apartments they are in the process of renovating.

headline: ‘Everyday Rapture’ May Replace ‘Lips Together, Teeth Apart’
text: “Everyday Rapture,” a critically acclaimed musical built around the actress Sherie Rene Scott‘s experiences with religion, theater and fame, is a leading contender to replace the postponed Broadway revival of “Lips Together, Teeth Apart” in Roundabout Theater Company’s spring season, according to two people with knowledge of Roundabout’s planning.

headline: Domesticated Kitsch
text: BACK in the 1970s, when Jeff Nesmith was growing up in Birmingham, Ala., a defining image of his childhood was the paint-by-numbers version of Leonardo’s “Last Supper” that hung above the sofa in his grandmother’s living room. The “artist” was his mother, an ardent practitioner of the paint-by-numbers craze that swept the nation in the postwar years, and the small oil was heavy on the lurid greens and purples.

headline: Crash Devastates a Kentucky Family
text: For years, John and Sadie Esh lifted up their Mennonite community in central Kentucky with mellifluous gospel singing. Their congregation of 20 families likewise embraced them when their son Johnny died and again when their house burned down.

headline: Theodore S. Hammer
text: Mr. Hammer, 64, is a managing partner at HLW International, an architectural, interior design and engineering firm based in New York.

headline: California Climate Law Would Add Jobs, Study Suggests
text: California’s climate change law won’t decimate the state’s economy and will help increase job growth modestly over the next 10 years, according to a state air control group study released this week.

headline: Theater Sale Draws Scrutiny
text: NORWALK

headline: Cheyenne Jackson Gets His New York Times Profile. (Sort Of.)
text: On Thursday’s “30 Rock,” Danny Baker, the earnest sketch comedy performer played by Cheyenne Jackson, is told that he’s going to be profiled in The New York Times. (“As filler,” Danny says, “because of dwindling ad sales.” Ha ha ha.) But due to the nefarious machinations of Danny’s television colleagues, we never learn if he gets his profile article after all.

headline: Aplomb in a Showcase for Technique
text: The guitarist Ralph Towner has always, it seems, made music of glowing introspection. Since at least the early 1970s, when he began recording for the German label ECM, he has practiced a pristine, self-sufficient style, endlessly awake to his instrument’s acoustical properties. This makes him an ideally transfixing solo performer, though he works no less as an ensemble player, notably in Oregon, his long-running band.

headline: One Word: Eyjafjallajokull
text: These are particularly dark days in the land of fire and ice, as the people of Iceland, or at least the travel agents among them, like to refer to their country.

headline: Sweat Equity, the Movie
text: THERE are low-budget films, there are micro-budget films, and then there is “Breaking Upwards.” It may be hard to imagine how someone could make a feature-length romantic comedy in New York City for just under $15,000, but Daryl Wein and Zoe Lister-Jones managed to do it.

headline: Hefty Tax Break Spared in Health Care Bill
text: The health care bill that passed this week offers subsidies to people with low income so they can afford health insurance. To help pay for those subsidies, people with large incomes will have higher tax bills.

headline: Pasta With Sardines
text: Mark Bittman makes a Southern Italian dish with ingredients you can find in your pantry.

headline: What’s in Your Health Savings Account?
text: This week’s Your Money column is about how health savings accounts managed to survive the health care reform process and looks at who else may get access to the tax breaks they offer.

headline: Alone, Exploring Fleeting Moments
text: A few years ago, Deborah Hay, one of the courageous choreographers responsible for Judson Dance Theater, the radical 1960s movement, pulled back from performing to apply her solo methodology to other dancers.

headline: Courts Take On Campaign Finance Decision
text: WASHINGTON — Two federal courts here issued decisions on Friday addressing the impact of Citizens United, January’s big Supreme Court campaign finance ruling, on a new issue — whether the government may constitutionally restrict the size of contributions to groups that spend money to support political candidates.

headline: Palin and McCain, Together Again
text: TUCSON — Senator John McCain and Sarah Palin embraced on stage here on Friday as they made their first joint campaign appearance since their presidential race, with Ms. Palin assuring Republicans in Arizona that Mr. McCain should not be dispatched from office by a conservative challenger.

headline: Bringing Back a Concerto From a Youngster, Mozart
text: There are many reasons repertory falls through the cracks. Mozart’s charming Keyboard Concerto No. 6 in B flat has perhaps simply been overshadowed by his later masterpieces in the genre. The work received its New York Philharmonic premiere on Thursday evening at Avery Fisher Hall, with Jeffrey Kahane performing and conducting from the piano.

headline: Credit Suisse Proves a Willing Lender to Directors
text: Directors at Credit Suisse borrowed a bit more money from the generous Swiss banking giant last year, the bank’s annual report shows. Nine directors accounted for about $23.7 million in loans (based on the current exchange rate of 93.4 cents to the Swiss franc), up from the seven directors who owed about $22.2 million at the end of 2008, according to the annual report, which was filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission on Friday.

headline: Our Lady of Loreto Church
text: Take a look at the frescoed ceilings and fine Italian statuary of the Brooklyn church.

headline: Lindpere Is the Red Bulls’ Traveling Man
text: UPPER MONTCLAIR, N.J. — The whistle stops in Joel Lindpere’s soccer career are not on anyone’s top 10 list of interesting travel destinations.

headline: A Pasta Dish Hiding in the Pantry
text: AT least once a week I scrounge for dinner without shopping, a cooking style that I suppose is counter to current trends but one that admirably displays the benefits of my dedication to pantry stocking.

headline: Sunday Preview
text: The shallow waters of Los Roques national park, off the Venezuelan coast, is considered one of the world’s great saltwater fly-fishing spots in the world.  Sam Sifton, the restaurant critic for The New York Times, wades into untouched shoreline, and reels them in.

headline: Sinatra, Focused on Sex and Sizzle
text: The choreography for the new dance musical “Come Fly Away” is overwrought. That’s hardly surprising; it’s by Twyla Tharp, whose artistic temperament has always been marked by ambition and excess, often with exciting results. It’s hard to imagine anyone in the audience falling asleep for a moment: the music, nearly all Sinatra songs, is loud, and the dancing’s energy is whiz-slam high.

headline: Quote Unquote | A Follower of Fashion
text: –The stylist Nicola Formichetti describes how, as a student, he would cut class to stalk Alexander McQueen. That’s one way to pursue a fashion education.

headline: Oh Dad, Poor Dad: What Will CBS Name His Show?
text: CBS is testing a TV show inspired by a Twitter feed with a name that is normally unprintable on this Web site. Let’s just call it “Shocking, Obscene and Hilarious Statements My Dad Says.”

headline: Bill on School Lunch Is Scaled Back. Criticism of School Lunch Isn’t.
text: It’s been an unusually tough month for the people who make school lunches.

headline: Send Us Your Videos: What Do You Want to Know?
text: The new health care legislation will significantly impact the delivery ofhealth care in America. But most people do not understand how the changes will affect them. The Times wants to hear your questions, via video submissions, and help answer them.

headline: Cities Rush to Woo Google Broadband Before Friday Deadline
text: Update 10:45 p.m. Adding final count of communities expressing interest in the Google Fiber project.

headline: Cooking Timers, Golf Tethers, Windup Toys: It’s All Rhythm
text: Time and again during the concert that So Percussion presented at Zankel Hall on Thursday night, you found yourself smiling in a quiet amazement that could verge on disbelief. Sometimes this had to do with a sound whose origin you simply could not determine. In other instances the response had more to do with the extremes of imagination and resourcefulness demonstrated by Dan Trueman and Steven Mackey, the composers of two new pieces on the program.

headline: High School Gardening — for Credit
text: Starting this week at Princeton Public High School, students can take gym class in the garden.
