headline: AT&T to Take $1 Billion Charge for Health Care
text: AT&T said Friday that it would take a $1 billion noncash accounting charge in the first quarter because of the health care overhaul and that it might cut benefits it offers to current and retired workers, The Associated Press reports.

headline: Metropolitan Opera Receives $30 Million Gift
text: The philanthropist Ann Ziff has given $30 million to the Metropolitan Opera, the largest single gift from an individual in its history.

headline: If Declarer Has a Secret, Keep It
text: The Machlin Women’s Swiss Teams was won at the Spring Nationals in Reno, Nev., by Phyllis Fireman of Chestnut Hill, Mass.; Migry Zur Campanile of New York; Shannon Cappelletti of Dania Beach, Fla.; Shawn Quinn of Houston; and Martine Verbeek and Wietske Van Zwol from the Netherlands.

headline: Marty Lederhandler Dies; At D-Day and 9/11
text: Marty Lederhandler of The Associated Press — “I never want to stop saying that,” he declared on his retirement — was there on June 6, 1944, and on Sept. 11, 2001, and on a remarkable number of occasions in between. (Including Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller’s honeymoon flight to Venezuela.)

headline: In NoMad, a Bar With a Pub Vibe
text: IT’S really no wonder that rock stars from abroad, like Bono for one, might feel at home in the new Ace Hotel in the neighborhood labeled NoMad (for north of Madison Square Park). Not only are the hotel rooms outfitted with Gibson guitars, turntables and vinyl records, but the Lobby Bar also has a comfy pub feel throughout its vast space, and the adjoining Breslin Bar serves British-inspired cuisine.

headline: Letter From Austin | SXSW Standouts
text: Coming to South by Southwest in search of a record deal seems so last-century. While the festival used to serve a key A&R purpose in showcasing bands for labels, it long ago evolved into more of a showcase for already-established acts to show off their wares. But further down the totem pole from Hole and Stone Temple Pilots, upstart acts still come. The Brooklyn singer-songwriter Alina Simone, who released an album of Russian punk songs in 2008, was back for her fourth South by Southwest because, she said, “something weirdly good” always seems to happen there. In years past, she picked up a nice write-up in Billboard magazine and found a manager.

headline: ‘Solar’
text: The place was emptying, and he was not ready. Someone very old with snow in his beard and a damp, unlit cigarette on his lower lip came in muttering ill-temperedly, snatched Beard's bag, took it out to a sled hitched to a snowmobile, and drove off. Both the waitress and Jan had disappeared, and Beard was the only person in the lobby. This was a long-forgotten experience from his school days, not only being late but feeling ignorant and incompetent and wretched, with everyone else mysteriously in the know, as though in league against him. Fatso Beard, always last, useless at team games. With that memory came added clumsiness and indecision. Although he was dressed in ski clothes of many layers, he was expected to climb inside this extra skin, even to wear his own boots inside another pair. There were inner gloves and giant outer gloves, a heavy balaclava made of carpet underlay to wear over his own, and goggles, and a motorcycle helmet.

headline: Answers From a Career Counselor, Part 3
text: Following is the third and final set of responses from Michele LoBianco, who teaches “Recession Proofing Your Career” at the School of Continuing and Professional Studies at New York University.

headline: Greeks, Romans and Financial Reform
text: From Paul Krugman on The Conscience of a Liberal:

headline: Survival Tales Told in Snapshots: Czech Jews Enduring the Holocaust
text: We have seen these images before, wizened men and women recalling unspeakable events that occurred when they were teenagers, sometimes tartly mocking their own cluelessness.

headline: Manager Sues Axl Rose
text: The company that managed Axl Rose’s career for much of the last two years has sued him to collect what it says is $1.9 million in unpaid fees. Front Line Management, whose founder and chief executive is Irving Azoff  who is also executive chairman of Live Nation Entertainment, which merged with Ticketmaster last month  filed suit in Los Angeles County Superior Court on Thursday, saying that Mr. Rose, left, is in breach of an oral contract that obliged him to pay Front Line 15 percent of his gross earnings as a performer. The suit says that Mr. Rose has not paid the management fees on recent concerts in Asia, South America and Canada, which grossed $12.5 million. A spokesman for Mr. Azoff declined to comment further on the suit, and representatives for Mr. Rose  including his new manager, Doc McGhee  did not respond to inquiries.

headline: Dear Poppa, Sincerely, Jerry
text: Not every fan letter written to Ernest Hemingway merits its own display in a museum, but when its author is J. D. Salinger a little pomp and circumstance is understandable. On Sunday, the John F. Kennedy Presidential Library and Museum in Boston will put on display a note from Salinger to Hemingway, written in 1946, that recounts a meeting between the authors and possibly hints at the coming publication of “The Catcher in the Rye,” The Associated Press reported. In the letter, a young Salinger writes to “Dear Poppa” that he is in a hospital in Nuremberg, Germany, and says “the talks I had with you here were the only hopeful minutes of the whole business.” There are flashes of Salinger’s wit throughout: he asks Hemingway how his latest novel is coming along and warns him not to option it to Hollywood. (“You’re a rich guy,” he writes. “As Chairman of your many fan clubs, I know I speak for all the members when I say Down with Gary Cooper.”) Salinger also writes that he has “a very sensitive novel in mind, and I won’t have the author called a jerk in 1950.” (“I am a jerk,” he continues, “but the wrong people musn’t know it.”) Thomas Putnam, the director of library, told The A.P. there was no indication whether Hemingway ever wrote back.

headline: Artist Looks to Be Legal
text: Though the artist Shepard Fairey, right, has become a museum darling, he’s still stayed close enough to his street-art roots to have been arrested, jailed overnight and sentenced to two years of probation last year in Boston for pasting his work on buildings before a retrospective at the city’s Institute of Contemporary Art. Now, as he prepares for a May exhibition at Deitch Projects in New York, Mr. Fairey is planning to put up street art the polite way, by asking building owners. “This is your chance to experience the art and be a part of the OBEY phenomenon, in addition to contributing to the enhancement of the urban landscape,” said an announcement this week on Mr. Fairey’s Web site (obeygiant.com), referring to the name of his studio and his trademark posters. His crew is looking for sites in Manhattan and Brooklyn where owners would allow artwork to be pasted  work that, depending on the kind of material to which it is glued, could last for years. In the past, Mr. Fairey has received permission to paste in some locations in Boston, Cincinnati and Pittsburgh. He might be leaving behind his illicit means for good, or he might just be keeping a low profile until his other legal trouble blows over: a civil lawsuit and a criminal investigation stemming from his use of an Associated Press photograph without permission to make his well-known Barack Obama “Hope” poster.

headline: Transgender Comedy Not Amusing to Some
text: A film selected for the 2010 Tribeca Film Festival, “Ticked-Off Trannies With Knives,” is having a similar angry effect on some transgender people and their supporters, prompting the Gay and Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation to call for the film’s removal from the lineup. In a listing for “Ticked-Off Trannies,” a comedy by Israel Luna, the film is described as a “campy homage to the exploitation films” in which “a group of transgender women are violently beaten and left for dead,” but then “the violated vixens turn deadly divas.” That summary alone was enough to prompt many angry comments at the festival’s Web site, tribecafilm.com. In a statement, GLAAD said, “The film, its title and its marketing misrepresent the lives of transgender women and use grotesque, exploitative depictions of violence against transgender women.” It urged its members to contact the festival and demand that the film be pulled. The festival responded in a statement: “The filmmakers provided a copy of this film to GLAAD in February, and for weeks the organization had been supportive to the filmmakers. In fact, GLAAD representatives advised the film’s producer, director and cast on how to describe the film to its core constituency.” The festival added that it “looks forward to the film’s premiere” next month.

headline: CBS Wins Thursday
text: CBS led Thursday night in the ratings with its live coverage of the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament, while medical dramas helped lift ABC to second place. According to Nielsen’s estimates, an average of 11.1 million viewers tuned in to CBS over the course of prime time, fewer than ABC’s “Grey’s Anatomy” (11.4 million) in the 9 p.m. hour but more than either “Private Practice” (8.8 million), on ABC at 10, or ABC’s science fiction series “FlashForward” at 8 (6.2 million). NBC was third, and Fox was fourth.

headline: Judging Books by Their Titles
text: Which of these facts is more surprising: that there is an annual contest held by The Bookseller magazine for the year’s most bizarrely titled book, or that a volume about Nazi eating utensils didn’t win it? Sorry, “Collectible Spoons of the Third Reich” by James A. Yannes, but you received only enough votes to place third in the online competition for the Diagram Prize for Oddest Book Title of the Year, the magazine announced on Friday. A total of 1,912 of the 4,553 ballots cast at TheBookSeller.com went to “Crocheting Adventures With Hyperbolic Planes” by Dr. Daina Taimina. In a statement, Philip Stone, charts editor of The Bookseller, said that Dr. Taimina’s book had won the prize, awarded to a work published in 2009, because, “very simply, the title is completely bonkers.” Second place went to “What Kind of Bean Is This Chihuahua?” by Tara Jansen-Meyer. Other top vote-getters included “Afterthoughts of a Worm Hunter” by David Crompton and “The Changing World of Inflammatory Bowel Disease” by Ellen Scherl and Marla Dubinsky.

headline: Election Results in Iraq
text: Even with a declared winner, Iraq’s parliamentary election left almost everything unresolved, and months of tense political maneuvering lie ahead.

headline: For 3-D Travelers, a Cosmic Journey
text: In the standard histories of the universe there are so many impossible things to believe before breakfast, as the White Queen put it in “Through the Looking Glass”  black holes, antigravity, dark matter and all those sneaky subatomic particles zipping through us  that the strangest and most amazing part of the universe gets short shrift. That would be us, collections of space junk, somehow perceiving and pondering the grandiosity that gave us birth in a sort of intellectual and emotional equivalent of the snake eating its tail.

headline: The Mystery Cabinet of the Gowanus Canal
text: The former headquarters of the National Packing Box Factory on the banks of the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn have not pumped out a packing box in decades.

headline: Now Accessorizing | Rabbit Is Rich
text: If the bunny in the book looked anything like this, it’s no wonder Alice went headlong down the rabbit hole. The jewelers Soraya Silchenstedt and Candice Pool (their line is called Finn) made this 18-karat-gold and diamond pendant for a friend who wanted them to replicate the stuffed animal belonging to her 5-year-old. “She was a bit sad at the time,” Silchenstedt says, “so it had to be really beautiful.” The resulting piece, inspired by the mask Candice Bergen wore to Truman Capote’s Black and White Ball and photos of rabbits gamboling in the snow, contains 3.5 carats of sparklers of various sizes that are meant to represent snowflakes. Call it bling for the hippity-hop set. It’s $9,875 at Barneys New York.

headline: Iraqi Election Results: Reactions From Around Iraq
text: As Rod Nordland and Timothy Williams write in The New York Times, the secular coalition led by former Prime Minister Ayad Allawi won the most seats in Iraq’s parliamentary elections, narrowly edging out the incumbent Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki, who angrily denounced the results as fraudulent.

headline: The ‘CSI’ Treatment for the E.R.
text: LOS ANGELES

headline: Reyes Runs as Trainers Hold Their Breath
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Jose Reyes continues to advance in his conditioning work, getting closer each day to playing in a game. On Friday Reyes ran almost full speed in a straight sprint in the outfield and looked fine doing it, even if the trainers might have been holding their breath.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, March 26
text: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

headline: Economic Desperation, Reshaping Morality
text: My colleague Jesse McKinley has a fascinating article today about how legal-marijuana advocates are promoting the fiscal virtues of their cause. Not coincidentally, another banned substance was legalized in the wake of major economic upheaval: alcohol, during the Great Depression. The “Noble Experiment” known as Prohibition ended in 1933, when a legalized alcohol market promised more job opportunities and additional sales tax revenues for governments under stress.

headline: For ‘24,’ Terror Fight (and Series) Nears End
text: If any one show has represented the post-9/11 era on television, it is “24,” the Fox drama that has offered counterterrorism as entertainment for nine years.

headline: Moody’s Cuts Ambac Debt to Its Lowest Rating
text: Moody’s Investors Service on Friday cut the senior unsecured debt of the Ambac Financial Group to its lowest rating above default after the bond insurer’s major subsidiary was hit with a state regulatory action, The Associated Press reports.

headline: Zimbabwe Shrugs Off Gay Rights
text: JOHANNESBURG — Zimbabwe’s president, Robert Mugabe, said Thursday that any thought of putting gay rights in the nation’s new constitution was “madness,” and Prime Minister Morgan Tsvangirai, who often disputes almost everything Mr. Mugabe says, this time seemed to agree.

headline: As Obama Hails Arms Pact, Applause in Kremlin Is Faint
text: MOSCOW — On a Friday that began in Washington with a triumphant presidential news conference about the conclusion of arms talks with Russia, Moscow seemed to have its mind on other things.

headline: Filipino Political Scion, Set to Assume the Mantle
text: QUEZON CITY, the Philippines

headline: At End of the Day, a Show and a Superhero Had to Retire
text: It arrives near the end of every season of “24.” Call it the moment: the unmarked but discernible instant at which you know you can relax.

headline: Heather Rieman, Thaddeus Ferber
text: Heather Ann Rieman and Thaddeus Ethan Ferber are to be married Sunday at Reflections at the Buttes, an event space in Tucson. The Rev. Mark M. Canfield, a minister of the United Church of Christ and an uncle of the bride, is to officiate, with the participation of the Rev. Richard Van Horn, an Episcopal priest.

headline: He’s Sensitive About the Pancakes
text: Richard Melville Hall, known to all as Moby, recorded his 2009 album,  “Wait for Me,”  in his studio in NoLIta, which now doubles as his crash pad while his apartment up the street is being refurbished. A self-professed dweeb, Moby, 44, broke onto the music scene by creating hypnotic dance music and popularizing electronica. His 1999 album,  “Play,”  went multi-platinum. A longtime vegan, he recently co-edited “Gristle,” a collection of essays about the hazards of eating meat. He also has a Web site, mobygratis.com, offering free music to independent filmmakers, and he is running a competition to select a new video for the title song on “Wait for Me.”

headline: Kerry McNamara, Brian Gallagher
text: Kerry E. McNamara and Brian M. Gallagher were married Friday at St. Francis de Sales Parish in Far Rockaway, Queens. Msgr. John J. Brown, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Jennifer Mastin, Brian Giglio
text: Jennifer Ellen Mastin and Brian Michael Giglio were married Saturday at Holy Trinity Catholic Church in Washington. Msgr. Alan Placa performed the ceremony.

headline: A Relationship as Serious as a Heart Attack
text: SYRACUSE — When Kentucky and West Virginia take the court in Saturday’s East Region championship game, two of college basketball’s winningest coaches will share a moment in the spotlight for only the ninth time in their careers.

headline: Can ‘No’ Revive the Republicans?
text: Well, Karl Rove isn’t one to let a downpour dampen his parade. “Democrats are celebrating victory,” the Republican strategist wrote in The Wall Street Journal after President Obama signed the health care reform package. “The public outcry against what they’ve done doesn’t seem to bother them. They take it as validation that they are succeeding at transforming America. But we’ve seen this movie before and it won’t end happily for Democrats.”

headline: Live Updates From the N.C.A.A. Tournament’s Round of 16
text: Live coverage and analysis from the N.C.A.A. tournament. Ray Glier and Kevin Armstrong will provide updates from St. Louis, and Thayer Evans from Houston. Two longtime Quad contributors who have played in the tournament, Stephen Danley (Penn) and Zach Hillesland (Notre Dame), will also weigh in.

headline: Kristen Olson, Joseph Lyons
text: Kristen Elizabeth Olson, the daughter of Linwood L. Olson and John E. Olson of Houston, was married in Austin, Tex., Saturday to Joseph Hurley Lyons, the son of Elaine Hurley Lyons and Paul V. Lyons of Milton, Mass. The Rev. Mike Rinehart, a minister ordained by Riverbend Church, a nondenominational congregation in Austin, officiated at the Lady Bird Johnson Wildflower Center at the University of Texas at Austin. William B. Koffel, a Roman Catholic deacon, took part in the ceremony.

headline: Coyote Bound for Undisclosed Location
text: The female coyote who was captured Thursday after roaming the streets of Lower Manhattan is resting comfortably at a shelter uptown, but where she is headed next is a secret. Officials at the parks department refused to say Friday where in the city they intend to release her.

headline: Alexandra Harris, Matthew Shear
text: Alexandra Lynn Harris, the daughter of Ruth J. Harris and Eric I. Harris of Manhattan, was married Saturday evening to Dr. Matthew James Shear, a son of Beatrix W. Shear and Stephen B. Shear of Short Hills, N.J. Rabbi Dr. David M. Posner officiated at the Pierre in Manhattan.

headline: Keeping a Closer Eye on Employees’ Social Networking
text: A service released earlier this week by Teneros, an online communication services company, makes it much easier for companies to keep tabs on their employees’ social networking activities.

headline: A Library That Most Can Only Dream Of
text: You, over there, mouthing off about the death of print. Keep it down; this is a library. Not just any library: This is Battery Park City’s public library branch, the city’s newest, greenest one yet, and it’s quite a sight to behold.

headline: Liana Sheintal, John Bryant
text: Liana Sheintal, a daughter of Kimberly D. Sheintal and Jonathan Sheintal of Sarasota, Fla., was married there Saturday night to John Whigham Bryant, the son of Mary W. Bryant and Robert W. Bryant Jr. of Princeton, N.J. Rabbi Brenner J. Glickman officiated at the Cà d’Zan Mansion at the John and Mable Ringling Museum of Art.

headline: Elizabeth Vicens, Jonathan Bashi
text: Elizabeth Vicens and Jonathan S. Bashi are to be married Sunday afternoon in Brooklyn. Rabbi Jeffrey F. Gale is to officiate at Stage Six at Steiner Studios, an event space at the Brooklyn Navy Yard.

headline: Brian Distelberg and Ryan McAuliffe
text: Brian Joseph Distelberg and Ryan Patrick McAuliffe were married Saturday at the Harvard Faculty Club in Cambridge, Mass. Phoebe Kosman, a friend of the couple who received permission from the Commonwealth of Massachusetts to perform the ceremony, officiated.

headline: Lauren Druyan, Scott Lustig
text: Lauren Ann Druyan, the daughter of Eileen Druyan of Old Westbury, N.Y., and the late Chaim Druyan, was married Saturday evening to Scott Brandon Lustig, the son of Marsha Lustig and Tom Lustig of New Rochelle, N.Y. Rabbi Dan Sklar officiated at the Angel Orensanz Foundation in Manhattan.

headline: Carolyne Beaty and Todrick Hilton
text: Carolyne Suzanne Beaty and Todrick Shawn Hilton were married Saturday evening at the Biltmore Ballrooms in Atlanta. The Rev. Darlene Henderson, a Baptist minister, officiated.

headline: Anne Marie Cablitas and Michael Simsuangco
text: Anne Marie Reyes Cablitas, a daughter of Carmen R. Cablitas and Zosimo A. Cablitas of Saddle Brook, N.J., was married Friday to Michael Roy Simsuangco, a son of Elsa N. Simsuangco and Roy L. Simsuangco of Carteret, N.J. The Rev. Colin Kay, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Anne’s Church in Fair Lawn, N.J., where he is parochial vicar.

headline: Tammy Yahner, David Snyder
text: Tammy Lynn Yahner and David Lawrence Snyder were married Saturday morning. The Rev. Gerald Donnelly, an interfaith minister, officiated at the Carolina Inn in Chapel Hill, N.C.

headline: Jennifer Flandro, Scott Sampson
text: Jennifer Lynn Flandro and Scott Paulik Sampson were married Saturday evening in Brooklyn. The Rev. Joanna Fernandes, an interfaith minister, officiated at the Montauk Club.

headline: Chic in Review | Steven Klein Goes Gaga
text: Babies “R” UsSelling a T-shirt that reads, “Someday I’ll Be Trashed at Prom.” Look for product placement on “16 and Pregnant.”

headline: Risa Heller and Ryan Toohey
text: Risa Beth Heller and Ryan Frederick Toohey were married Saturday evening at Coach Insignia, a Detroit restaurant. Rabbi Joshua L. Bennett officiated, with Rabbi Paul Yedwab taking part.

headline: Elizabeth Scarlett and Andrew Klingle
text: Elizabeth Scarlett and Andrew Thomas Klingle were married Saturday by Msgr. J. Patrick Keleher, a Roman Catholic priest, at the Newman Center at the State University of New York at Buffalo, where the bride is an associate professor of Spanish literature and culture in the department of Romance languages and literatures.

headline: Excerpt: '24'
text: This is the final season for the counter-terrorism series, Fox announced.

headline: Jaclyn Cohen, Nathan Nussbaum
text: Jaclyn Ida Cohen and Nathan Coleman Nussbaum are to be married Sunday afternoon at the Down Town Club in Philadelphia. Rabbi Seymour Rosenbloom is to lead the ceremony, with Rabbi Rachel Nussbaum, the bridegroom’s sister, participating.

headline: Becky Strauss, Max Lipkind
text: Becky Irene Strauss and Max Gregory Lipkind were married Saturday evening. Rabbi Mayer I. Perelmuter officiated at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx.

headline: Alicia Lowery and Eric Rosenbaum
text: Alicia Trinette Lowery and Dr. Eric John Rosenbaum were married Saturday evening at the Yale Club in New York. Rabbi Jeffrey J. Sirkman officiated.

headline: Juliette Levy, David Millman
text: Juliette Levy and David Martin Millman were married Monday at the Foundry, a restaurant in Los Angeles. Hannah Ceri Jones, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for this event, officiated.

headline: Elizabeth McArdle, Richard Rainey
text: Elizabeth Ann McArdle, the daughter of Judy A. McArdle and Jack J. McArdle of Ardsley, N.Y., was married Saturday evening to Richard T. Rainey, a son of Carol N. Rainey and Dr. Jon M. Rainey of Cleveland Heights, Ohio. The Rev. Stephen Sauer, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of the Immaculate Conception in New Orleans.

headline: Melissa Rosenstein, David Benin
text: Dr. Melissa Greer Rosenstein and David Joshua Benin were married Saturday evening at the Metropolitan Building in Long Island City, Queens. Rabbi Darby Jared Leigh officiated.

headline: James Beller Jr., Christopher Wolf
text: James Lee Beller Jr. and Christopher Wolf were married Saturday evening at the Jefferson Hotel in Washington. Judge Paul L. Friedman of the United States District Court for the District of Columbia officiated.

headline: Allison Bond, Scott Bischoff
text: Allison Martin Bond, a daughter of Gloria V. Bond of Darien, Conn., and Kenneth W. Bond of Bronxville, N.Y., was married on Saturday to Jonathan Scott Bischoff II, the son of Elizabeth K. Bischoff and J. Robert Bischoff of Wilson, N.C. The Rev. Dr. Terry L. Wilson, a Baptist minister, performed the ceremony at St. Luke’s Chapel in Charleston, S.C.

headline: Emilio Morenatti, Honored and Recovered
text: This has been the week for Emilio Morenatti.

headline: The Week in Pictures for March 26
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in the New York City region. Subjects include an unlikely friendship, a jail-themed playground, and a coyote in the city.

headline: What Meeting? A-Rod Still in Tampa
text: TAMPA, Fla. — There was no Alex Rodriguez sighting in Buffalo on Friday because the Yankees’ third baseman did not meet with federal investigators as planned. About 3:30 p.m., Rodriguez jogged into the outfield at Steinbrenner Field for stretching with the rest of his teammates. And he was in the lineup, batting cleanup against the Phillies.

headline: Civil Rights Battles, in Black and White
text: Some of the most gripping images in “Road to Freedom” went unseen for decades. Pictures showing a mob attacking and setting fire to a bus carrying Freedom Riders in Anniston, Ala., are chilling in their step-by-step precision. Yet they were locked away in the files of a law firm.

headline: Nuclear Labs Raise Doubts Over Viability of Arsenals
text: In a challenge to the White House, the nation’s nuclear weapons laboratories have warned Congress that federal programs to extend the life of the nation’s aging nuclear arsenal are insufficient to guarantee the viability of the weapons for decades to come.

headline: Palin Speaks in Favor of McCain
text: John McCain hopes Sarah Palin's credibility with the Right will help him win the nomination of his party for the Senate seat he currently holds. (Video: MSNBC)

headline: McCain Recuits Palin for Tough Race
text: Senator John McCain taps former running mate, Sarah Palin, to help him win the nomination of his party for the Senate seat he currently holds. (Video: MSNBC)

headline: Chet Simmons, a Founding Force of ESPN, Dies at 81
text: Chet Simmons, a television sports executive with ABC and NBC who became ESPN’s first president and then the first commissioner of the upstart United States Football League, died Thursday in Atlanta. He was 81 and had homes in Atlanta and Savannah, Ga.

headline: N.Y.P.D. Confidential
text: CASE file: His night began in the bars of Staten Island, and by 2 a.m., he was buying crack cocaine. Inside his car, he flicked a lighter and inhaled. He picked up a woman; they got high together. She left after he spotted the authorities.

headline: 4 Charged in Incident at Office of Senator
text: NEW ORLEANS — The conservative activist who in January had been accused of tampering with the telephone system of Senator Mary L. Landrieu — a felony — will instead face only misdemeanor charges in the case, federal prosecutors said Friday.

headline: Deciding Who Will Lead a Health Care Leader
text: BOSTON — Here in the cradle of health reform, where universal coverage was pioneered, this year’s tightening race for governor is focused on the question that now confronts the nation: how to keep spiraling costs from bankrupting the experiment.

headline: Police Say Stray Bullet Hit Office of Lawmaker
text: On Thursday, Representative Eric Cantor of Virginia, the second-ranking Republican leader in the House, said that Democratic members of Congress were not the only ones who had been the targets of threats and vandalism in recent days. He said that he had been threatened, too, and that a bullet had been fired through the window of his campaign office in Richmond.

headline: Kandahar, a Battlefield Even Before U.S. Offensive
text: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan — American forces have begun operations to push back Taliban insurgents in this most important southern province, the birthplace and spiritual home of the Taliban, and a full-scale offensive is expected in coming weeks.

headline: From Deep in the Closet to a Needy Girl’s Prom
text: Trapped in closets all over New York, and probably the world, are ghosts from thousands of prom nights, Sweet 16 parties, weddings.

headline: Charting Dante’s Descent Through 9 Circles of Hell
text: Last June, a small group gathered outside the E3 Expo, the electronic entertainment conference at the Los Angeles Convention Center, to protest Dante’s Inferno, a video game based on the 14th-century poem about the underworld. They held signs like “EA = Electronic Anti-Christ,” referring to Electronic Arts, maker of the video game. Other signage included “Play Dante’s Inferno, Go to Hell” and the assonant “Trade in your PlayStation for a pray station.”

headline: After a Supreme Court Loss, Washington’s Gun Laws Pass Muster
text: Washington can restrict the right of its residents to own guns — again — a federal judge ruled Friday.

headline: Harry Carpenter, the ‘Voice of Boxing’ in Britain, Dies at 84
text: LONDON — Harry Carpenter, a popular sportscaster for the BBC who was hailed as the voice of boxing in Britain and who announced some of the sport’s biggest fights, died on March 20 in London. He was 84.

headline: Biologist Wins Templeton Prize
text: Francisco J. Ayala, a biologist and former Roman Catholic priest whose books and speeches offer reassurance that there is no essential contradiction between religious faith and belief in science, particularly the theory of evolution, has won the 2010 Templeton Prize. The John Templeton Foundation awards the annual prize, worth about $1.5 million, to “a living person who has made exceptional contributions to affirming life’s spiritual dimension.” Dr. Ayala is an evolutionary biologist and a geneticist at the University of California, Irvine.

headline: Maine: Interest in Phone Warning Cools
text: The Maine Senate on Friday joined the House and voted down the bill. With Gov. John Baldacci also opposed, the measure is dead. The Technology Association of America, representing nearly 1,500 technology companies, praised the decision, with Kim Allman, a lobbyist for the group, issuing a statement that said: "We are glad to see that the state legislature in Maine has taken a stand by recognizing that the body of scientific evidence as a whole does not indicate a public health risk caused by mobile phones. Requiring unnecessary labels on wireless devices sold there would have only misled consumers by implying that the federal safety standards are insufficient.

headline: Seizures of Illicit Cash Rise
text: Customs authorities along the border with Mexico seized $85 million in illicit cash in the last year, the first year of the Obama administration’s enforcement plan, Department of Homeland Security officials said Friday. It was a 22 percent increase over the previous year. More than $29 million of the money was seized leaving the United States, in the first year of expanded inspections of southbound traffic, including screening of all rail shipments to Mexico. Drug seizures in Pacific waters off San Diego increased sixfold, to 57,437 pounds, the officials said.

headline: Chronicle of a Changing City
text: IMoveGreen, a new E.P.A.-certified moving company in the Bronx, would like to add a fourth R word to the environmental mantra “reduce, reuse and recycle”: relocate. In addition to using biodegradable packing materials, reusable plastic boxes and hybrid vehicles, the business donates part of the proceeds from each move to pay for tree-planting in the Brazilian rainforest. As a result, clients need not worry as much about their carbon footprint — leaving them free to be stressed instead about, say, where to put all those books. Jeffrey E. Sitt (above), the owner, said that his rates were comparable to those of other movers and that he would happily move Manolos as well as Birkenstocks. “I am not a tree hugger at all,” he said. “The goal of iMoveGreen is to encourage a simple premise: Be respectful of the environment when moving to a new home.” And if, after unpacking, you do discover a scarcity of the city’s least renewable resource — storage space — Mr. Sitt’s green self-storage company, iStoreGreen, which opened in Brooklyn in 2008, can help with that too.

headline: In Subway Ads on Abortion, a Pretense of Neutrality
text: The woman in the ad is young and has a short, hip haircut, the kind you see all over the East Village. Her solemn face is half in shadow. “I thought life would be the way it was before,” the copy reads. And then: “Abortion changes you.”

headline: Panel Suggests That U.S.O.C. Add Members to Its Board
text: A panel led by Paul Tagliabue, the former N.F.L. commissioner, has recommended expanding the United States Olympic Committee’s board to 15 members from 11, according to a report released Friday.

headline: What We’re Reading: Steve Jobs, Eric Schmidt and Barbed Wire
text: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times were obsessing about people on Friday:

headline: West Virginia Rides a Guard in Full Revival
text: SYRACUSE — Joe Mazzulla introduced himself to the college basketball world in the N.C.A.A. tournament two years ago when he slapped his palms against the court to mock the Duke tradition after West Virginia upset the Blue Devils.

headline: F.D.A. Says Millions Got Unapproved Heart Pills
text: Doctors in the United States wrote more than four million prescriptions last year for nitroglycerin tablets, heart drugs placed under the tongue to reduce the chest pain angina or to stop a heart attack.

headline: Purging the Pharmacy of Unapproved Drugs
text: If consumers want to know for sure whether the drugs that pharmacists are using to fill their prescriptions have been approved by the Food and Drug Administration, they can check the F.D.A.’s Web site.

headline: Cigarettes and Hearts Ablaze
text: Smoking cigarettes, which the zeitgeist has determined is unsexy, can nonetheless be a good relationship starter. There’s the business of bumming, the shared sense of exile from polite (nonsmoking) society and, of course, the romantic opportunities of asking for a light. The following poems about cigarettes and romance were “found” last week in the Missed Connections section of craigslist.newyork.org. They are printed verbatim, with only line and stanza breaks added; their titles are the subject headings. ALAN FEUER

headline: Toyota Cuts Production in Europe After Sales Slump
text: Toyota Motor said on Friday that it would idle three plants in France and Britain to reduce inventory amid recent recalls and a slump in European sales. The company will suspend output for four days in early April at its factory in Valenciennes, France, and for five days in May at its Burnaston and Deeside factories in Britain, according to a Toyota spokeswoman, Ririko Takeuchi. Toyota also plans to halt one of the two assembly lines at Burnaston for five days in early June, Ms. Takeuchi said.

headline: After a Long Layoff, Woods Can Learn From Hogan
text: A frenzied celebrity media throng will await Tiger Woods next month at the gate to the Augusta National Golf Club. Golf history, embodied in the spirit of the resolute Ben Hogan, awaits him on the first tee.

headline: Sales Fall at American Apparel
text: American Apparel said sales at its existing stores fell in the fourth quarter and will fall further this year. American Apparel, which operates 281 clothing stores, said that sales at stores open at least a year will probably drop 10 percent in the first quarter. Comparable-store sales, excluding the effects of currency fluctuation, fell 7 percent in the fourth quarter, the company said.

headline: Differences Set Aside, Palin Lends McCain Aid
text: TUCSON — They have rarely spoken in 17 months. Their relationship, as America now knows, turned testy before they parted ways. But as at many family reunions, the old feelings were set aside as Sarah Palin embraced Senator John McCain here on Friday and argued that he should not be unseated by a conservative challenger.

headline: A Hamlet’s Eyesores Prompt a Revolt
text: MASTIC BEACH, N.Y. —

headline: Its Underdog Days Over, Butler Is Thinking Big
text: SALT LAKE CITY — Butler Coach Brad Stevens has not yet thought about taking a tape measure to the rims at Lucas Oil Stadium, the site of next week’s Final Four, just to remind his team that they are indeed 10 feet above the floor.

headline: On Sandlot Day, Children Call Their Own Shots
text: Every year, it seems, youth sports become more organized. Uniforms fit better. Seasons stretch another week or two. Even the quality of the snacks has improved at many recreation fields.

headline: Why Is This Matzo Different?
text: EIGHTEEN minutes. The whole process must be completed in 18 minutes, to echo the Jews’ rushing out of Egypt, too quickly for the bread to rise. The flour and water — nothing else — are combined, the dough rolled, perforations made and, poof!, after a brief trip through a 1,000-degree oven: matzo.

headline: Voices From the City’s Ethnic News Media
text: SINCE the beginning of time, political scandal has been an important source of nutrition for the press. And so it is for New York’s ethnic newspapers. They often report such items, however, with a dual focus on the United States and their homelands. In the past month, a Caribbean paper analyzed the troubles of Representative Charles B. Rangel, an Indian newspaper pondered a New York politician’s reaction to routine political misbehavior in India, and a Korean paper explored the struggles of Mr. Rangel and Gov. David A. Paterson through their impact on striving minorities — like its own readers. KIRK SEMPLE

headline: Talent Agents a New Force in the Video Game Industry
text: LOS ANGELES — It happened to the motion picture industry in the 1930s and the music trade in the 1960s. Talent agents, initially brushed off as nothing more than opportunistic middle men, succeeded in making themselves vital parts of the machinery, helping the fast-growing but messy businesses mature.

headline: Coach Says Race Was Factor in Ouster
text: The suspended coach Kevin Broadus has filed a racial discrimination complaint against Binghamton University with the New York State Division of Human Rights.

headline: Saarinen’s Work, in 2 Parts, at Yale
text: Eero Saarinen was one of the most exciting and prolific architects of the 20th century, and the current show of his work at the Yale University Art Gallery and the Yale School of Architecture Gallery further cements his reputation.

headline: Voters May Prefer a Crusader in the Governor’s Race. But Which One?
text: ALBANY — For months, Democratic strategists who support Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo have envisioned a governor’s race this fall defined by a candidate who was a crusader for political reform far removed from Albany’s culture of scandal and dysfunction.

headline: Honoring a Long Life? But She’s Just 30 Plus 71
text: Among the ceremonial duties of the consul general of Barbados in New York is a charming custom rooted in the colonial history of that island nation. When a Barbadian here turns 100, the consul attends the birthday party, and each subsequent one, bearing flowers and a proclamation celebrating the person’s life and longevity.

headline: At the Heart of the Home
text: Stony Brook

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Thursday about the fallout from the Roman Catholic sexual abuse scandal in Europe misstated the estimated number of children in Ireland who were victims, according to two government reports last year. The report said the children numbered in the tens of thousands, not the “hundreds of thousands.”

headline: Layers of Contradiction in L.I. Hate-Crime Trial
text: RIVERHEAD, N.Y. — The crime seemed brutally simple: Seven high school students attacked two Hispanic immigrants in Patchogue in November 2008, prosecutors said, after a night of “Mexican hopping,” a sport made of assaulting Latino men in Suffolk County on eastern Long Island.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: March 26, 2010

headline: For Years, Deaf Boys Tried to Tell of Priest’s Abuse
text: They were deaf, but they were not silent. For decades, a group of men who were sexually abused as children by the Rev. Lawrence C. Murphy at a school for the deaf in Wisconsin reported to every type of official they could think of that he was a danger, according to the victims and church documents.

headline: Where the Littlest Composers Learn Composure
text: LIKE many 8-year-olds, Chantal Loaiza is occasionally given to shyness. But as she moved about her classroom in a school behind St. Gabriel’s Roman Catholic Church in New Rochelle last month, dictating to the visiting musicians how she wanted her work-in-progress played, she sounded every bit the confident composer. And that was music to Jon Deak’s ears.

headline: Alberto Arroyo, Jogger Familiar in Central Park, Dies at 94
text: Alberto Arroyo claimed to be the first person to jog around the Central Park Reservoir, and by the time he died in a Manhattan nursing home at 94 on Thursday, who could dispute him? What is certain is that generations of runners came to treasure the leathery-skinned gentleman with flowing white hair and matching mustache as a peculiarly New York institution.

headline: Corrections
text: An article last Saturday about Representative Gregory W. Meeks, a Queens Democrat whose spending habits have drawn the scrutiny of ethics watchdogs, misspelled, in some editions, the name of the model of leased car that he drives. It is a Lexus, not a Lexis.

headline: Port Authority Official Criticizes Towers Deal
text: The news on Thursday that the Port Authority and the developer Larry A. Silverstein had ceased hostilities and come to a tentative agreement at ground zero was greeted with a great deal of fanfare. But judging from a blistering note the next morning from the Port Authority’s vice chairman, the next 120 days are going to be anything but peaceful.

headline: The Storytelling Trance
text: HAMILTON TOWNSHIP

headline: New Era Involves Fun and Games for Yanks
text: TAMPA, Fla. — Before questions about Alex Rodriguez took the smile off his face, Brian Cashman, the Yankees’ general manager, circulated through the team’s clubhouse Friday afternoon checking on those who participated in a nonbaseball, off-site activity that morning — a game of paintball.

headline: Lawmakers Recess and Prepare to Defend Health Votes
text: WASHINGTON — Members of Congress headed home on Friday for a two-week recess during which they will try to shape public opinion and defend their votes for or against the new health insurance law.

headline: Judge Blocks Closing of 19 New York City Schools
text: A judge on Friday blocked the closing of 19 schools for poor performance, finding the city engaged in “significant violations” of the new state law governing mayoral control of city schools.

headline: An Ear for the Music of the Adirondacks
text: Mike Holober, artistic director of the Westchester Jazz Orchestra, has climbed 45 of the 46 so-called High Peaks in the Adirondacks. So it was only natural that when he wrote the orchestra’s first original work, he found inspiration in the northern high country, particularly Lake Tear of the Clouds, the Hudson River’s source, and the nearby Opalescent River — two shimmering spots with which he is well acquainted.

headline: Spring Came Too Soon for the Syrup
text: WEST BRATTLEBORO, Vt. — It’s on the calendar. It’s widely advertised. This year, everybody knows about it but the trees. And they are the central characters in Vermont’s annual maple syrup open house this weekend, when tourists descend on the state to watch trees being tapped and sap being boiled.

headline: Some States Find Burdens in Health Law
text: Because of the new health care law, Arizona lawmakers must now find a way to maintain insurance coverage for 350,000 children and adults that they slashed just last week to help close a $2.6 billion budget deficit.

headline: Corrections
text: The Patient Money column last Saturday, about choosing a nursing home, referred incorrectly to an organization where Janet Wells, who commented on the issue, is director of public policy. The advocacy group is known as NCCNHR (formerly the National Citizens’ Coalition for Nursing Home Reform). It is not the National Consumer Voice for Quality Long-Term Care, which is a slogan used on the organization’s Web site.

headline: Catholic Order Admits Its Founder Abused Boys Over Decades
text: ROME — A powerful Roman Catholic religious order acknowledged in a statement on Friday that its founder, a close ally of the late Pope John Paul II, molested seminarians and fathered several children, and it expressed “sorrow and grief” to anyone “damaged by our founder’s actions.”

headline: Corrections
text: An article in some editions on Friday about Butler’s victory over Syracuse on Thursday in the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament misspelled the surname of a Butler player in some copies. He is Willie Veasley, not Veazley.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Friday about the reaction on the campus of St. Mary’s College in Moraga, Calif., to its success in the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament misstated the given name of the college president. He is Brother Ronald Gallagher, not Robert.

headline: Mets Reliever Takahashi Has More Pitches Than He Knows What to Do With
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — During his 11-year career in the major leagues, Rod Barajas has caught future Hall of Famers, Cy Young Award winners, the gifted, the mediocre, the terrible, and everyone in between.

headline: Looking for Rodriguez? Don’t Head to Buffalo
text: For hours on Friday, reporters in Buffalo staked out the airport and the downtown offices of the United States attorney. They surveyed the building where one of Alex Rodriguez’s lawyers works. They were hoping to catch a glimpse of Rodriguez as he slipped into a meeting with federal investigators but, in the end, never spotted him.

headline: Corrections
text: A headline last Saturday with an Inside summary for an article about a University of Northern Iowa basketball player whose father played volleyball for Iran in the 1980 Summer Olympics misidentified the location of the university. It is in Cedar Falls, not Cedar Rapids.

headline: Rebel Music
text: Music may be the universal language, but those of us who spend our lives with it are expected to know it in depth, from early on. Many composers, whether traditional or experimental, have been steeped in Western classical music from the cradle. That was not the case with me.

headline: Arnold Forster, Who Fought Anti-Semitism With B’nai B’rith, Is Dead at 97
text: Arnold Forster, an American Jewish leader, lawyer and writer who was a longtime executive of the Anti-Defamation League of B’nai B’rith, died on March 7 in the Bronx. He was 97 and lived in New Rochelle, N.Y.

headline: 41 Across: They’re Made by Origami Artists
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — A big part of any solve is the number of correct assumptions one makes along the way. If one’s assumption quotient (A.Q.) is high, it might mean a good day. If it’s low, things could take a while. Let’s take a look at how I fared today, as an example:

headline: Corrections
text: An architecture review on Friday about “Rising Currents: Projects for New York’s Waterfront,” at the Museum of Modern Art, misspelled the surname of an architect who took part in a research project on which the show is based. He is Adam Yarinsky, not Yarinksy. The review also omitted a firm that was a partner in the design shown in a series of images of Lower Manhattan in 2080. Besides Architecture Research Office, dlandstudio also developed the design.

headline: In Hardscrabble Town, Refined Comfort Food
text: BACK in the 1940s, when “mall” was just a word for shady promenade and downtown Haverstraw was still a shopping hub for Rockland County, the sturdy old brick building that houses Union Restaurant and Bar Latino was a clothing store called Pressler’s. It’s safe to say the Presslers would not recognize the place today.

headline: Fresh and Bountiful
text: Anyone interested in cutting food costs will be happy with the prices and the variety offered at La Marqueta, a sparkling new market in Mount Kisco.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Page 36 this weekend about ways to prevent the next financial crisis misstates the amount of the TARP bailout fund established in 2008. It was $700 billion  not $787 billion, which was the size of the stimulus package approved in 2009.

headline: Only Soy Died for These Dishes
text: When Nilsa Rodriguez was growing up in Jersey City, fast food was everywhere, she said. So when Ms. Rodriguez, 46, opened Subia’s Organic Market and Cafe there in 2003 with her twin sister, Yvonne, and their brother, Eddie, 50, “We wanted to show people who eat meat they could have healthy options,” she said. (Subia is their mother’s original name; their parents ran a bodega on the premises for many years.)

headline: Corrections
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Carb-Counting Stops Here
text: It might not be possible to live on bread alone, but you may feel inclined to do so when you enter Collinsville Baking Company, where attractive loaves — of ciabatta, rye, six-grain, semolina, whole wheat, country French and more — are piled high on racks behind the counter.

headline: From Wölffer, Four Stars
text: Mother Nature was benevolent to Wölffer Estate Vineyard in 2005 and 2007. Roman Roth, the winemaker, captured the grapes’ richness in two chardonnays and two merlots. These strikingly delicious wines, from Sagaponack, on the South Fork, almost certainly will display more nuance in coming years.

headline: Nice and Spicy, but Short of Scorching
text: LEMON LEAF slipped into Mineola last June and took root on Mineola Boulevard, a Thai newcomer in a neighborhood that is a stronghold of Portuguese restaurants. It was not crowded on my visits, but it deserves more attention, for this is a very good place. (The Lemon Leaf Grill in Carle Place is under the same ownership.)

headline: Tennessee Fells Another Favorite
text: ST. LOUIS — Tennessee’s Bobby Maze was stepping to the free-throw line with 13 seconds left in a 1-point game with Ohio State, but the Volunteers’ J. P. Prince was bent over, hands on his knees and out of gas at the other end of the floor. Wayne Chism, the senior forward, yelled, “Come on J. P.” for Prince to come up the floor.

headline: British Airways Cabin Crews Are Set to Resume Walkout
text: PARIS — British Airways cabin crews will resume their walkout for an additional four days beginning Saturday, labor leaders said Friday, after talks with management failed to resolve a dispute over pay and working conditions.

headline: Culinary Surprises and Peruvian Charm
text: WHILE Peruvian cuisine may not be one of the world’s most distinguished, the fare at Quechua (named for the old Inca language and culture) in Norwalk is worth exploring. From the bright abstract rugs on the walls to the warm welcome of our waitress, Quechua exudes good cheer. And its many personal touches, combined with pleasant culinary surprises, raise this sprightly little storefront restaurant a few notches above the usual.

headline: Baylor Celebrates Win, Then Plays Another Half
text: HOUSTON — With Baylor already well on its way to the Round of 8, Bears Coach Scott Drew did a little early celebrating Friday night.

headline: Donald P. Kelly, Master of Leveraged Buyouts, Dies at 88
text: Donald P. Kelly, a Chicago businessman who in the 1980s helped oversee the $6.2 billion leveraged buyout and breakup of the Beatrice Companies food conglomerate, died March 18 at his home in Naples, Fla. He was 88.

headline: The Words of a Victim
text: Steven Geier, 59, is among the former students of St. John’s School for the Deaf who has accused the Rev. Lawrence C. Murphy of sexual abuse. He spoke Thursday to David Callender, a reporter covering the story for The Times, in Madison, Wis. The following is a transcript of their conversation. It has been edited and condensed, and it contains mature language.

headline: In Seoul, Green Transit Is Mayor’s Pet Project
text: SEOUL — On a recent morning, the mayor of Seoul stopped by a local amusement park to inaugurate an electric tram system to ferry tourists around the grounds, replacing an old noisy one that belched exhaust. Music blared. A phalanx of TV crews trailed him.

headline: Bloggingheads: Google vs. China
text: Robert Wright, left, of Bloggingheads.tv and Robert Kagan of the Carnegie Endowment debate information technology and freedom in China.

headline: Derailing Help for Consumers
text: Washington

headline: A Budget for New York’s Future
text: Like New Jersey, California and almost every other state, New York faces a devastating budget deficit this year  a shortfall estimated at $9 billion and growing. Lt. Gov. Richard Ravitch warns that if the budget isn’t realigned soon, the state will be out of cash by June 1, maybe earlier.

headline: State Budget Stalls on Finding $1 Billion More in Cuts
text: ALBANY — New York State lawmakers ended the week with little progress toward striking a budget deal on time, as the Paterson administration demanded that the Legislature find additional cuts of at least $1 billion, people involved in the negotiations said Friday.

headline: Lawmakers Head Warily for Home
text: Members of Congress are heading into recess with no guarantee that the hateful rancor and violent incidents that marred passage of health care reform will not haunt them anew in their home districts. Democrats subjected to death threats and vandalized offices will have discreet police protection.

headline: Mr. Obama and Israel
text: After taking office last year, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel privately told many Americans and Europeans that he was committed to and capable of peacemaking, despite the hard-line positions that he had used to get elected for a second time. Trust me, he told them. We were skeptical when we first heard that, and we’re even more skeptical now.

headline: Another Win Puts Nets Step Further From History
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — For a late-season matchup of teams whose combined winning percentages do not add up to .500, Friday night’s Nets-Pistons game at the Izod Center had an unmistakable air of consequence, the scent of history in the unmaking.

headline: Toast of a Wine-Making Tradition in Italy
text: VALPOLICELLA, ITALY — There can’t be many places in the winemaking world where they start crushing red grapes early in February. The vines are dormant in the northern hemisphere. In Australia the grapes are ripening, but it’s a bit early for the vintage. In Chile, Argentina and South Africa, the harvesting of the reds is usually just getting underway in March and April.

headline: St. John’s Pivots on Its Coaching Search
text: The search for a new St. John’s coach has switched from one locked in on a big-name hire to an exploratory phase.

headline: Another  T.S.A. Nominee Withdraws
text: President Obama’s choice to lead the agency that guards United States airports abruptly withdrew his nomination on Friday night amid questions about his work as a defense contractor, the second time the White House has lost a nominee for the critical security post.

headline: Duke Grinds Its Way Back to Familiar Territory
text: HOUSTON — When Duke received the third No. 1 seed for the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament instead of its fellow top seed Syracuse, it caused a wave of discord.

headline: Spartans Writing a New Ending Without a Key Player

headline: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Wings One Win Closer to Safety

text: British Airways cabin crews began their second walkout in a week on Saturday to protest cost-cutting plans that include a wage freeze and cuts to in-flight staffing.

headline: Red Bulls Sign Academy Player
text: One day before their first Major League Soccer game in their new stadium, the Red Bulls signed a second player, striker Juan Agudelo, from their youth development academy.

headline: The Saturday Word: Recess
text: With two major victories under his belt this week, President Obama enjoys a getaway at Camp David while Congress is also on recess.

headline: Red Hot Patriot
text: Last night I went to see Red Hot Patriot, a one-woman show with Kathleen Turner as the late Molly Ivins (I was there along with a big ACLU contingent). To be honest, I was worried — the play could easily have been either too preachy or too cute. But it got the tone just right. And Kathleen Turner was awesome.

headline: FinReg Reading
text: On the whole, I don’t like the term FinReg for financial reform — it sounds too DC-ish, not catching the huge importance of the issue. But it is what all the insiders are calling it.

headline: Home Run Leaders by Team
text: Bill Chuck created Billy-Ball.com and is a co-author of Walkoffs, Last Licks, and Final Outs. He grew up in New York and now lives with his wife (a Red Sox fan), and daughter (a Yankees fan), two miles from Fenway Park while Bill claims to be Switzerland. His other daughter lives in New York City, away from the fray. You can follow him on Twitter.

headline: ‘It’s a Little Expensive’
text: Monologue |  Friday night on “Late Night With Jimmy Fallon” on NBC: President Obama was at a bookstore in Iowa yesterday, and he bought a $37 pop-up book for Press Secretary Robert Gibbs’ son. When he gave it to him — this is true — Gibbs said, “It’s a little expensive, sir.” And Obama said, “I can handle it.” And then he called the president of China and said, “Can I borrow $37? Yes, I am calling collect.”

headline: ‘Standard Stump Speech’
text: Monologue |  Friday night on “The Tonight Show With Jay Leno” on NBC: Well, President Obama’s out on the road selling his healthcare plan to the American people. One of the biggest criticisms of this almost 3,000 page bill is it’s so complicated, it’s so complex, nobody really understands it. To give you an idea of how confusing this healthcare bill is, more Americans now understand the plot of “Lost.”

headline: More About Bond Vigilantes
text: Yesterday I criticized the WSJ for writing as if a fairly small rise in long-term interest rates spelled doom, doom I tell you, for deficit spending. Brad DeLong has a nice chart. But maybe I can make the case a bit clearer by comparing the current scary, scary rate rise with something that happened back in 2003. Then as now, the economy was growing, but without yet generating job market improvements.

headline: A Health Legislation Fail-Safe Works, but Not as Expected
text: WASHINGTON — Just a few months into his first term in 1993, President Bill Clinton went to Senator Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia, the protector of Senate rules, to ask permission to use a fast-track budget process known as reconciliation to enact a bold health care overhaul.

headline: Next Year in the White House: A Seder Tradition
text: WASHINGTON — One evening in April 2008, three low-level staff members from the Obama presidential campaign — a baggage handler, a videographer and an advance man — gathered in the windowless basement of a Pennsylvania hotel for an improvised Passover Seder.

headline: Brown and Party Show Signs of Life
text: LONDON — For all but the first few months of the three years he has been at 10 Downing Street, Prime Minister Gordon Brown has been cast by many of Britain’s leading political pundits as a man doomed to lead the Labour Party to a crashing general election defeat by the opposition Conservatives, ending 13 years of Labour rule.

headline: Agencies Suspect Iran Is Planning Atomic Sites
text: WASHINGTON — Six months after the revelation of a secret nuclear enrichment site in Iran, international inspectors and Western intelligence agencies say they suspect that Tehran is preparing to build more sites in defiance of United Nations demands.

headline: As Archbishop, Benedict Focused on Doctrine
text: MUNICH — When Pope Benedict XVI was archbishop of Munich and Freising, he was broadly described as a theologian more concerned with doctrinal debates than personnel matters. That, say his defenders, helps explain why he did not keep close tabs on a pedophile priest sent to his archdiocese in 1980 and allowed to work in a parish.

headline: Wheel of Acrostic
text: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE — If you’ve solved the puzzle, you can go right to Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon’s notes at the bottom for a little background information and a question.

headline: T.S.A. Could Be Leaderless for Months After the Withdrawal of a Second Nominee
text: WASHINGTON — The agency that guards airline security inside the United States is likely to remain without a Senate-confirmed leader for months to come after President Obama’s nominee for the position abruptly withdrew late Friday night amid questions from Congress about his work as a defense contractor.

headline: Obama Chooses Health Policy Scholar as the Director for Medicare and Medicaid
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama will soon name Dr. Donald M. Berwick, an iconoclastic scholar of health policy, to run Medicare and Medicaid, the programs that serve nearly one-third of all Americans, administration officials said Saturday.

headline: Why I Joined the Tea Party
text: Many of the Tea Party movement's leaders were jolted into action by economic dislocation, like a job loss or the housing downturn. Diana Reimer is one example.

headline: With Scrutiny, Vatican Faces Test of ‘Moral Credibility’
text: ROME — As Pope Benedict XVI faces growing pressure to address his role in the handling of sexual abuse cases over the years, the Vatican acknowledged on Saturday that its ability to handle the crisis was a crucial test of its “moral credibility.”

headline: With No Jobs, Plenty of Time for Tea Party
text: SOUTH BEND, Ind. — When Tom Grimes lost his job as a financial consultant 15 months ago, he called his congressman, a Democrat, for help getting government health care.

headline: Jets’ Woody Johnson Leaps Into the Limelight
text: For years, Woody Johnson was known as the reclusive billionaire owner of the Jets. He ran one of the most secretive organizations in football, the headquarters lined with a barbed-wire fence. So this month, when Johnson verbally slapped the N.F.L. over a clandestine coin flip and invited HBO’s cameras into training camp with full access, his behavior seemed so out of character.

headline: Hey, PayPal, Why Verify?
text: HAVING recently spent a lot of time on the phone booking an assortment of reservations, the Haggler has been pondering some travel-related mysteries.

headline: Death of a Loophole, and Swiss Banks Will Mourn
text: WITH all the hoopla over the health care bill, hardly anybody noticed that a job creation bill that President Obama signed on March 18 makes it much harder for United States citizens to avoid taxes by hiding money in overseas bank accounts.

headline: In Midwest, College Boards of a Different Sort
text: ST. LOUIS — Michigan State forward Delvon Roe has caught some glimpses of Tennessee this season and its handiwork on the backboards. He understands Tennessee makes itself at home on the glass in most games, but he did not necessarily want to hear about it. Roe smiled a wicked smile, and sat up a little straighter in his chair, almost insulted at the suggestion there is another formidable rebounding team out there besides the Spartans.

headline: Sometimes, You Have to Say ‘My,’ Not ‘Our’
text: This interview with Debra L. Lee, chairwoman and chief executive of BET Networks,, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: Push to Eat Local Food Is Hampered by Shortage
text: EAST MONTPELIER, Vt. — Erica Zimmerman and her husband spent months pasture-raising pigs on their farm here, but when the time came to take them to slaughter, an overbooked facility canceled their appointment.

headline: A Clash of Facial Hair in the West
text: SALT LAKE CITY — When Butler and Kansas State take the court for today’s West Regional final, it will be an interesting clash of playing styles, coaching styles and hairstyles.

headline: Seeking a Safe Masters for Woods
text: ORLANDO, Fla. — The silver-haired man striding with purpose some 20 yards in front of Phil Mickelson on Friday, clad in khaki pants and a pastel golf shirt, could have easily passed for an honorary observer, a walking scorekeeper or even an unusually fit member of the news media covering the Arnold Palmer Invitational from inside the ropes.

headline: Urban Forager | Seize the Day Lily
text: Update, 3:46 p.m., March 29| After publishing this post, City Room was informed that it is illegal to harvest plants in city parks. Details here.

headline: Nation’s Pride in a Single Pitch
text: URASOE, Okinawa — A year later, the play lives on in Japan and South Korea, where the World Baseball Classic has taken on a megalife in its fledgling four-year existence that far surpasses the impact the tournament has had in the United States.

headline: Imagining an Israeli Strike on Iran
text: In 1981, Israel destroyed Iraq’s nuclear reactor at Osirak, declaring it could not live with the chance the country would get a nuclear weapons capability. In 2007, it wiped out a North Korean-built reactor in Syria. And the next year, the Israelis secretly asked the Bush administration for the equipment and overflight rights they might need some day to strike Iran’s much better-hidden, better-defended nuclear sites.

headline: Patchwork Defense May Weave Playoff Tale
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Everything starts with Raymond Felton. He was the consolation prize in the 2005 draft, picked directly behind the All-Star point guards Chris Paul and Deron Williams.

headline: Along Expected Lines, Celebrations and Protests
text: BAGHDAD – As it goes in Iraq, the celebrations and protests following Ayad Allawi’s election victory were expressions of sectarian identity, displays in which the rhetoric of politics, religion and violence were often indistinguishable. And each was a prelude to a what could be a tough fight over weeks or months to form the next government. Here are two perspectives on Iraqi reactions.

headline: No Fun and Games for the Hitting Coach
text: TAMPA, Fla. — The morning after a night game is rough on most people. Saturday, Kevin Long, the Yankees’ hitting coach, had a worse time than anyone else. At 6:15 a.m., he was in the trainers’ room getting treatment for the pulled left hamstring he sustained playing paintball on Friday. Long was embarrassed enough about being hurt, and he wanted to be in and done before any players arrived.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, March 28
text: It’s no surprise here that health care remains the dominant topic on Sunday’s talk shows as Democrats relish a hard-won victory and both parties vie for victory over the topic in November’s elections.

headline: Art That Needs No Hook or Pedestal
text: The Museum of Modern Art’s architecture and design collection contains thousands of things that have shaped the way we think about form: a Wedgwood cup, a Tiffany lamp, the Band-Aid, the Q-tip, a Bell helicopter, a New York City manhole cover, the classic chromium public-toilet flush valve.

headline: Carrots, Sticks and Lower Premiums
text: FOR all the debate lately, one basic fact about America’s health care crisis is rarely mentioned. Namely, the one thing that could really reform health care is you, collectively speaking: People living healthier lives.

headline: Replacement Bones, Grown to Order in the Lab
text: IF a lover breaks your heart, tissue engineers can’t fix it. But if sticks and stones break your bones, scientists may be able to grow custom-size replacements.

headline: Car’s Familiar Profile Returns to Nascar
text: CONCORD, N.C. — Nascar’s Sprint Cup series will sport a new look on Sunday at Martinsville Speedway. Make that a new, old look.

headline: Trying to Tame the Unknowable
text: THE economy is recovering, in baby steps, from the financial crisis and deep recession of 2008 and 2009. A big question still looms on the horizon: What can policy makers do to prevent this kind of thing from happening again?

headline: Leave the Budget to the Experts
text: The New York Legislature and Gov. David Paterson are deep into negotiations over the state’s finances, but one thing is already certain: there will be sharp cuts and palpable pain across the state. To move forward, we must change Albany’s budget process.

headline: The Wisdom of the Short-Sellers
text: SHORT sellers profit by finding stocks or other securities that will underperform the market. But how do the short-sellers accomplish this? A new study provides some answers.

headline: Fleeing Rebels Kill Hundreds of Congolese
text: TAPILI, Congo — Depleted by an American-backed offensive and seemingly desperate for new conscripts, the Lord’s Resistance Army, one of the most infamous armed groups in Africa, has killed hundreds of villagers in this remote corner of Congo and kidnapped hundreds more, marching them off in a vast human chain, witnesses say.

headline: Don’t Let Lawmakers Draw Their Districts
text: In 2002, at the end of my fourth term as a New York state senator, I heard that the Senate majority leader, Joseph Bruno, wanted to talk to me. It was the beginning of the decennial state redistricting, and Mr. Bruno showed me a map of his plan for Brooklyn  which had my district cut into pieces and allocated to other senators.

headline: Lady Vols’ Bad Start Only Gets Worse
text: MEMPHIS — Since being suspended for two games after punching an opponent in the face earlier this month, Baylor’s 6-foot-8 center Brittney Griner had grown somewhat timid, reluctant to fully exert herself, knowing the referees would pay her increased scrutiny.

headline: End the Unions’ Sweetheart Deals
text: New York’s painful fiscal crisis should be an opportunity to restructure state finances for the benefit of future generations.

headline: Mubarak Returns to Egypt; Succession Debate Persists
text: CAIRO — President Hosni Mubarak arrived back in Egypt on Saturday, three weeks after undergoing an operation in Germany, ending a period of intense speculation over the state of his health but maybe not about the future of his country’s leadership.
