headline: Overspending Is a Bipartisan Affliction
text: New York has some of the highest state and local taxes in the country, as well as high (and rising) debt from years of borrowing. Why? Because both political parties have electoral bases that support spending.

headline: When Does Political Anger Turn to Violence?
text: The mercury is running high, all right, and it has nothing to do with the weather.

headline: From a Step Back, a Leap Forward
text: THE idea subverts the old notion of a steady climb up the corporate ladder: Sometimes you have to go backwards in order to get ahead. It’s how many careers play out these days.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: An Urge to Lead
text: PEOPLE often ask me, “Are you Mexican or American?” I say, “I’m Texan.” Most of my family has been in south Texas since it was a territory of Mexico.

headline: Struggling Towns Must Evolve or Die
text: When Buffalo hosted the 1901 Pan-American Exposition, it was the eighth-largest city in the United States and rightly called itself a “city of the future.” But for the past half-century, it and other upstate industrial cities have been losing jobs and people. Today, nearly two-thirds of the state’s population has concentrated in just 12 downstate counties.

headline: Pro-Business Lobbying Blitz Takes on Obama’s Plan for Wall Street Overhaul
text: WASHINGTON — With the Obama administration looking to score another major legislative victory, an array of pro-business groups and fiscal conservatives are mounting a well-financed campaign to scale back or block altogether the Democrats’ plan to overhaul regulation of the financial industry.

headline: File Under Vile
text: OK, I finally got around to reading Douglas Holtz-Eakin’s op-ed on health care reform. It’s much worse than I thought; time to scratch Holtz-Eakin off my shrinking list of reasonable, reasonably honest conservatives.

headline: At the Vatican, Up Against the World
text: Of the many heartbreaking details in the latest round of outrage over child sexual abuse in the Catholic Church, one stands out as particularly emblematic: a tidy window into Church leaders’ mindsets; a bracing glimpse of what went wrong.

headline: No More Aid for the Affluent
text: Long after the recession and political crises are history, Albany will continue to be pressed fiscally, unless changes are made in three big areas of state spending: Medicaid, education and employee benefits, which together account for 70 percent of the budget.

headline: Someone, Take Charge
text: In the words of Lt. Gov. Richard Ravitch, who should know because he was there, Albany’s current financial woes are “much worse” than those of New York City in the dark days of the 1970s. The scale of the budget shortfall is bigger, and there is no government that can help the state the way the state helped the city 35 years ago.

headline: Dealing With The Debt: A Brief Note
text: I get a lot of worried mail along the lines of “how on earth will we ever be able to pay off our debt”? Look, there are real worries — but the math per se isn’t very hard.

headline: Can New York Be Saved?
text: Three out of four New York residents think their state is headed in the wrong direction, recent polls suggest. No wonder: Its economy, like the rest of the nation’s, is only now coming out of a severe recession, and unemployment still sits at nearly 9 percent. Lawmakers are struggling to narrow a $9 billion budget deficit. And the state’s leadership has been hamstrung by corruption, resignations and squabbling. The Op-Ed editors asked seven experts to describe what they would do to save the state.

headline: A Master of the Slow Game Who’s a Speed Demon, Too
text: The best players in the world are ranked on their ability to play slow, or classical, chess, in which each side has at least a few hours for a game. None of them are slouches at blitz chess, in which an entire game lasts five minutes or less, but it puts a premium on tactical skill and quick thinking  which is usually the forte of younger players.

headline: Obama: A Giant-Killer, Feeling His Oats
text: WASHINGTON — Is this it, then? He hath slain the health-care Goliath. Does that mean, a year and a half into the job, that President Obama has acquired the political savvy and tactical confidence to take on other juggernauts?

headline: A Papal Conversion
text: Denver

headline: Shake, Rattle, Seattle
text: AS an engineer who advises companies on how to make their buildings survive earthquakes, I have visited the aftermath of nearly every key quake since 1970, observing how new and old buildings have performed when the ground shook beneath them. I try to learn from each new disaster how to change our design techniques, construction practices and building codes to reduce future losses of life and damage. From my perspective, the shock that hit Chile in February was the most important earthquake of the last 100 years.

headline: Google Searches for a Foreign Policy
text: WASHINGTON — When Google announced last week that it would shut its censored online search service in China, it was doing more than standing up to a repressive government: it was showing that, with the United States still struggling to develop a foreign policy for the digital age, Internet companies need to articulate their own foreign policies.

headline: Why the Line2 App is Up and Down
text: 6:08 p.m. | Updated Peter Sisson now reports: “We found another solution to keep out the hackers without taking away the free trial.”

headline: The Rage Is Not About Health Care
text: THERE were times when last Sunday’s great G.O.P. health care implosion threatened to bring the thrill back to reality television. On ABC’s “This Week,” a frothing and filibustering Karl Rove all but lost it in a debate with the Obama strategist David Plouffe. A few hours later, the perennially copper-faced Republican leader John Boehner revved up his “Hell no, you can’t!” incantation in the House chamber  instant fodder for a new viral video remixing his rap with will.i.am’s “Yes, we can!” classic from the campaign. Boehner, having previously likened the health care bill to Armageddon, was now so apoplectic you had to wonder if he had just discovered one of its more obscure revenue-generating provisions, a tax on indoor tanning salons.

headline: Indonesia’s Islands Are Buried Treasure for Gravel Pirates
text: Islands in the Indonesian archipelago are literally disappearing as thieves dig them up and sell the sand and gravel for construction projects in China, Thailand, Hong Kong and Singapore, The Times of London reports.

headline: Prime Number
text: 69.2: The percentage increase in the size of the main course in 52 paintings of the Last Supper over the last millennium, a study in the International Journal of Obesity found. The study, by the brothers Brian Wansink of Cornell University and Craig Wansink of Virginia Wesleyan College, also found that plate size increased by 66 percent and bread size by 23 percent. Brian Wansink says the findings suggest that the phenomenon of serving bigger portions on bigger plates — which pushes people to overeat — has occurred gradually over the millennium as food has become more abundant and affordable.

headline: A Nope for Pope
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Hole in None
text: Horton Smith won the first Masters Tournament at Augusta National Golf Club, on March 25, pocketing the $1,500 prize for a score of 284 over 72 holes. But for a little luck, the day could have belonged to Billy Burke, the 1931 Open champion. Here’s how The Times reported it:

headline: Quotations of the Week
text: “If the anti-incumbent tide is as strong as some people think it is, I will be swept out, despite all my efforts. If the anti-incumbent tide is a lot of conversation, but has no center of gravity as a true political movement, then I’ll be just fine. There’s no way to know.”—Senator Robert F. Bennett, Republican of Utah.

headline: Hobby or Necessity?
text: If you think this latest Israeli-American flap was just the same-old-same-old tiff over settlements, then you’re clearly not paying attention  which is how I’d describe a lot of Israelis, Arabs and American Jews today.

headline: A Fight to Save a Church in Brooklyn
text: Former parishioners try to save Our Lady of Loreto Church, built by Italian immigrants with their own hands in the early 1900s.

headline: What Makes It Itch?
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — Sometimes it’s worth taking an extra moment to fully consider what the Sunday puzzle’s title may mean. In the case of today’s, deciphering that CH added to IT forms ITCH is a pretty good hint of what’s to come.

headline: Vols Looking for Hopson to Find His Rhythm
text: ST. LOUIS — Tennessee Coach Bruce Pearl has recruited one McDonald’s all-American, Scotty Hopson, the 6-foot-7 sophomore guard.

headline: Q&A With Red Bulls Coach Hans Backe
text: Hans Backe, the new coach of Major League Soccer’s Red Bulls, is an itinerant soccer lifer. He has zealously followed the game in a coaching career that has lasted nearly 30 years — taking him from his native Sweden to Norway, Denmark, Greece, England, Mexico and now the United States.

headline: Williams Works Way Back Into Vols’ Rotation
text: ST. LOUIS — Brian Williams is the magic act of the Tennessee basketball program. Now you see him. Now you don’t.

headline: Live Updates From N.C.A.A. Tournament’s Round of 8
text: Live coverage and analysis from the N.C.A.A. tournament. Pete Thamel will provide updates from Syracuse and Billy Witz will provide updates from Salt Lake. Two longtime Quad contributors who have played in the tournament, Stephen Danley (Penn) and Zach Hillesland (Notre Dame), will also weigh in. You can follow Pete Thamel on Twitter throughout the tournament.

headline: Q. & A. With Woody Johnson
text: For the profile on the Jets owner Woody Johnson in The Times on Sunday, I interviewed him on three occasions over two months. I met Johnson once at the new stadium, where we conducted the first interview and took a tour, and twice at his office in New York, which has both a fish tank and a fantastic view of St. Patrick’s Cathedral. Over all, we spent about five hours talking about his family, his tenure as owner of the Jets, his hobbies, Johnson & Johnson, his charity work. No topics were off limits.

headline: Butler Back in the Big Time
text: Butler’s run to the Final Four may be unlikely, but basketball fans in Indianapolis with long enough memories recall the Bulldogs playing on the same stage as Big Ten and other major-conference teams in the 1950s and ’60s. And in those days before ESPN — heck, in those days when no one on our block had a color TV — a Butler fan could watch the Bulldogs about as often as he could see Indiana and Purdue.

headline: Palin Rallies Tea Party Crowd in Nevada
text: SEARCHLIGHT, Nev. — Several thousand people converged on this small town on Saturday for what was billed as a showdown with its most famous native, and one of the highest ranking Democrats in Congress, Senator Harry Reid.

headline: States Seeking Cash Hope to Expand Taxes to Services
text: In the scramble to find something, anything, to generate more revenue, states are considering new taxes on virtually everything: garbage pickup, dating services, bowling night, haircuts, even clowns.

headline: 4 People Arrested and 30 Guns Seized in Brooklyn Raid
text: Police officers searching a two-story house opposite an elementary school in Brooklyn on Friday night discovered scores of guns, bullet-making materials and an odd array of weapons more appropriate to a Western or a spy novel, including antique firearms and an umbrella with a dagger hidden in its handle, officials said on Saturday.

headline: Palin Rallies Tea Party Activists in Reid’s Nevada Hometown
text: SEARCHLIGHT, Nev. — Several thousand people from as far away as Illinois converged on this small town on Saturday for what was billed as a showdown with its most famous native, and one of the highest-ranking Democrats in Congress, Senator Harry Reid.

headline: Butler Goes Home to Indianapolis for Final Four
text: SALT LAKE CITY — As Butler’s buses rolled to the Indianapolis airport earlier this week, they passed Lucas Oil Stadium, the site of the Final Four. Hanging from the side of the stadium is a sign that reads: The Road Ends Here.

headline: Nominee to Disability Council Is Lightning Rod for Dispute on Views of Autism
text: When President Obama nominated Ari Ne’eman to the National Council on Disability, many families touched by autism took it as a positive sign. Mr. Ne’eman would be the first person with the disorder to serve on the council.

headline: New Hampshire Budget Gap Fuels Fight Over Gambling
text: Like several other states, New Hampshire has been wrestling with ways to address its budget deficit and has been considering new forms of gambling to help fill its treasury and add jobs.

headline: Elinor Smith, One of the Youngest Pioneers of Aviation, Is Dead at 98
text: In the days of rickety open-cockpit biplanes seemingly held together by baling wire, 8-year-old Elinor Patricia Ward got her first flying lesson — at her kitchen table in Freeport, N.Y., on Long Island.

headline: In Partisan Battle, Clashes Over Health Lawsuits
text: ATLANTA — Reflecting the bitter partisan divide over health care, governors in at least six states are at war with attorneys general from the other political party about whether to join litigation challenging the new federal health insurance mandate.

headline: Illinois Democratic Party Chooses a Familiar Name as Lieutenant Governor Nominee
text: CHICAGO — In the end, the winner of the Illinois Democratic Party’s open audition to be the nominee for lieutenant governor was not one of the some 200 unknowns who had stepped forward, among them a brick salesman, a police officer and a violinist. Instead, party leaders on Saturday chose a name familiar across the state: Sheila Simon, the daughter of former Senator Paul Simon.

headline: Quake Accentuated Chasm That Has Defined Haiti
text: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti — The lights of the casino above this wrecked city beckoned as gamblers in freshly pressed clothes streamed to the roulette table and slot machines. In a restaurant nearby, diners quaffed Veuve Clicquot Ponsardin Champagne and ate New Zealand lamb chops at prices rivaling those in Manhattan.

headline: Obama Bypasses Senate Process, Filling 15 Posts
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama, making a muscular show of his executive authority just one day after Congress left for spring recess, said Saturday that he would bypass the Senate and install 15 appointees, including a union lawyer whose nomination to the National Labor Relations Board was blocked last month with the help of two Democrats.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Page 36 this weekend about ways to prevent the next financial crisis misstates the amount of the TARP bailout fund established in 2008. It was $700 billion  not $787 billion, the size of the stimulus package approved in 2009.

headline: Correction
text: Because of a transcription error, the Boss feature last Sunday about Eric Hippeau, chief executive of The Huffington Post, misstated his description of the company’s growth rate. He said that its revenue and its traffic have roughly doubled each year in its four-and-a-half-year history  not that they have doubled over that entire period. The column also misidentified the magazine where Mr. Hippeau was once publisher. It was PC Magazine, not PC World.

headline: Correction
text: An article last Sunday about Patti Smith misstated the title of one of her songs. It is “Because the Night,” not “Because of the Night.”

headline: Defending Champions in Rally Disqualified
text: The 20th edition of the Rallye Aïcha des Gazelles in Morocco came to a close Thursday, with the official prizes awarded Saturday in Essaouira after the defending champions were disqualified for cheating. The winners of the nine-day, all-women road rally were Christine Laloue and Claudine Amat of France. The defending champions, Corentine Quiniou and Florence Migraine Bourgnon, were disqualified after the officials determined they had been manipulating their satellite tracking device and setting back their odometer.

headline: Corrections
text: MAGAZINE

headline: Unquestioned Recruiter, Oft-Questioned Coach
text: HOUSTON — After a 90-79 first-round loss to Purdue in the N.C.A.A. tournament two years ago in which his team’s poor transition defense resembled that played in an Amateur Athletic Union game, Baylor Coach Scott Drew was frustrated.

headline: Other Voices: Sorting the Victims and Villains
text: Re “The Acorn Sting Revisited” (March 21):

headline: The Boys Have Fallen Behind
text: Around the globe, it’s mostly girls who lack educational opportunities. Even in the United States, many people still associate the educational “gender gap” with girls left behind in math.

headline: Credit Ratings: The View From Standard & Poor’s
text: To the Editor:

headline: Arms Control’s New Era
text: The negotiations took a lot longer and were more grueling than anyone expected, but the United States and Russia have finally agreed on a nuclear weapons agreement to replace the Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty. Although the deal makes only modest cuts in both countries’ arsenals, President Obama deserves credit for reviving an arms control process that his predecessor disparaged as a cold-war relic. He is now leading the way on reducing the nuclear threat.

headline: Making Haiti Whole
text: A donors’ conference at the United Nations this Wednesday is meant to be the beginning of the long, slow birth of a new Haiti. Representatives of the Haitian government, the United States and other nations and aid organizations will be discussing large, ambitious, farsighted plans. Participants will be asked for lots of money: $11.5 billion to start, $34.4 billion over 10 years.

headline: An Exceptional Nominee
text: The first major appeals-court nomination fight of the Obama presidency may be shaping up over Goodwin Liu, a highly qualified teacher and legal scholar. Mr. Liu, nominated to the San Francisco-based United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, is raising hackles on the right because of some of his legal views, and because he is seen as a strong candidate for the Supreme Court in the near future. The White House and Senate Democrats should fight hard for the confirmation.

headline: In Finance Reform, an Opportunity for Democrats
text: To the Editor:

headline: Human Currency in Mexico’s Drug Trade
text: Mexico City

headline: Afghan Poppies, American Dilemma
text: To the Editor:

headline: Centrist Voices, Drowned Out by Hyperpartisans
text: To the Editor:

headline: Player Ratings: Red Bulls vs. Chicago
text: HARRISON, N.J. — A frosty night for the first M.L.S. game at the new $200 million, 25,000-seat Red Bull Arena. The temperature was 39. By the end of the game it was 38 degrees (but the WeatherBug said it felt like 28). Club missed an opportunity for the perfect opening promotion … Red Bull Long Underwear Night!

headline: Correction
text: A short article in the In Transit column last Sunday about the Marina Bay Sands Resort in Singapore, using information from a publicist, misstated the number of rooms at the resort, which has scheduled a “preview opening” on April 27 and a grand opening on June 23. The Marina Bay Sands will have 2,560 rooms — not 963, which is the number of rooms expected to be open for the preview.

headline: Vows: Brian & Ryan
text: Brian Distelberg and Ryan McAuliffe met at Harvard eight years ago. They agreed to a date at a coffee shop and realized sparks over mugs. Being each other's first love, they've been together ever since.

headline: Solid Outing Hints at Chamberlain’s Relief Role
text: LAKELAND, Fla. — In his first relief appearance since losing the fifth starter’s job to Phil Hughes, Joba Chamberlain made two mistakes even before he reached the mound Saturday. He threw too many warmup pitches in the bullpen, and then he miscalculated the distance to jog in from the bullpen in right-center.

headline: Reyes Feels Ready to Play, but Mets Are in No Rush
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Moments before Jose Reyes burned across the outfield of Field No. 2 at near top speed, he walked past General Manager Omar Minaya, who was driving a golf cart from one end of the Mets complex to another. The two spoke for a moment in Spanish as Reyes, backpedaling in the opposite direction, yelled to Minaya that he was ready to play.

headline: A High Profile for Fehr in the Players Union
text: For Donald Fehr, it was a subtle shift but a potentially significant one.

headline: For Nets, Lottery Is No Sure Thing
text: By recording their ninth victory Friday night, the Nets avoided becoming the worst team in N.B.A. history. But they entered Saturday’s game against the Chicago Bulls with a chance to finish in a tie for that distinction with the 1972-73 Philadelphia 76ers if they did not record a victory in the last 10 games.

headline: Technology Can Improve Health Care
text: In 1900, an American man could expect to live on average until he was 45 years old. By 1940, that life-expectancy number had jumped to 62 years, while for women the average number increased from 51 years to 66 years.

headline: Crane Falls Against Financial District Building
text: A crane tipped and fell against a commercial building in Lower Manhattan on Saturday evening. There were no injuries, the police said, but four buildings and part of a fifth were evacuated and traffic was rerouted.

headline: Ai, a Steadfast Poetic Channel of Hard Lives, Dies at 62
text: The prominent American poet Ai, whose work  known for its raw power, jagged edges and unflinching examination of violence and despair  stood as a damning indictment of American society, died on March 20 in Stillwater, Okla. She was 62 and lived in Stillwater.

headline: A Race for Assembly, Strikingly Varied
text: Given the dysfunction in Sacramento, it is a little surprising that anyone with stature in a community would want to run for the Legislature these days. But in the Democratic Party primary to represent a Peninsula district in the Assembly, three such gluttons for punishment have stepped forward.

headline: Blanche Thebom, Star at the Met and Beyond, Dies at 94
text: Blanche Thebom, a mezzo-soprano who was discovered singing in a shipboard lounge as a teenager and went on to sing more than 350 performances with the Metropolitan Opera, died on Tuesday at her home in San Francisco. She was 94.

headline: Closing of Auto Plant Forces Suppliers to Scramble
text: For the last nine years Doc Skinner, a plant manager at the Vuteq California Corporation in Hayward, has supervised the 65 employees who build interior trim parts for the Toyota Tacoma truck. But that part of his résumé is no longer likely to secure his financial future.

headline: After a Long Ride, the Fantasy of a Perfect Day
text: Markos Moulitsas is founder and publisher of Daily Kos, the largest liberal blog in the United States, with one million to three million unique visitors a month. Mr. Moulitsas, 38, started his blog in 2002 after a stint at law school persuaded him that it would be “a cold day in hell” before he ever worked as a lawyer. Born to a Salvadoran mother and a Greek father, he is the co-author of “Crashing the Gate: Netroots, Grassroots and the Rise of People-Powered Politics.” He lives in Berkeley with his wife and two children. (His words have been edited and condensed.)

headline: The Male Half of the Sky
text: The idea for my Sunday column, about why boys fail, arose in part when Sheryl and I were on book tour peddling our book “Half the Sky.” We would talk about how women in poor countries were being left behind, and so often some member of the audience would say something like: But why are boys in this country lagging?

headline: Audio Aesthetics a Bit Removed From the Standard Do-Re-Mi
text: On a craggy outcrop in the Marina, the sounds of the sea become art. “The Wave Organ,” a sprawling waterfront sound-art installation created with materials from a demolished cemetery, has been quietly performing an oceanic symphony since 1986. Pausing to cup an ear to one of many protruding pipes amid the installation’s sun-blanched granite and marble terraces, you hear a strange liquid music. It alternately whispers like wind passing through conch shells, gurgles like an old man laughing and assaults the senses with cataclysmic thunderclaps.

headline: No Meltdown for You
text: HOUSTON — Although tradition-rich Duke has not been to a Final Four since 2004 or won a national championship since 2001, Coach Mike Krzyzewski insists that he does not feel any added pressure this N.C.A.A. tournament.

headline: In Sunday’s Bay Area Report
text: Plant Closing Forces Suppliers to Scramble | New United Motor Manufacturing, which is jointly owned by Toyota and General Motors, will close on Thursday — throwing 4,700 people out of work. Some of its suppliers are rushing to create new markets and products. It is a race against time, but some may succeed if they are nimble enough to reinvent themselves.

headline: Seeking Edge on School? It’s Just a Fact of Life
text: As I took my kindergartner to Ravenswood Elementary School last week, most parents were ignorant of the latest Chicago Public Schools “scandal.” The few who knew weren’t aghast to learn that there’s gambling in Casablanca.

headline: A Promise of Jobs Remains Only Partly Fulfilled
text: When Ronald Bender and about 260 other workers were unexpectedly laid off from a North Side window factory 15 months ago, they staged a sit-in and gained national attention as symbols of a work force battered by hard times.

headline: A Graffiti Artist Hides; Reporter Seeks
text: It came to me in one of those terrifying flashes of clarity that drive some people to drink and and others to gorge on pie: My life had become a cut-rate Samuel Beckett play.

headline: West Virginia Ends Half-Century of Waiting
text: SYRACUSE — After West Virginia’s loss at Connecticut on Feb. 22, West Virginia Coach Bob Huggins sat his team in a circle in the locker room. Huggins has broken a few chairs and made some power forwards blush with his language over the years, but that day he calmly reminded the Mountaineers of their potential.

headline: The Pulse: Scrutinizing the Numbers in Caterpillar’s Complaint
text: Caterpillar Inc. of Peoria has jumped to the forefront of manufacturing companies complaining about the cost of the federal health care overhaul. On March 18 the company sent a letter to Speaker Nancy Pelosi and Representative John A. Boehner, the Republican leader, saying mandated changes would cost it “$100 million in the first year alone.”

headline: The Pulse: Massage Measure Advances, but Only Up to a Point
text: Despite the opposition of Mayor Richard M. Daley's top zoning official, the City Council's zoning committee last week endorsed a proposed ordinance meant to deter new massage parlors near residential neighborhoods.

headline: South Korea Searches for Survivors of Sunken Navy Ship
text: The South Korean Navy continued its search for survivors of a sunken patrol ship in waters near the disputed western maritime border with North Korea on Sunday. Hopes were dimming for 46 missing sailors, and the mystery of what caused their ship to break in half in a blast and sink Friday evening remained unresolved.

headline: Rare Lapse by Lundqvist Costs Rangers
text: TORONTO — Henrik Lundqvist has saved the Rangers countless times in his five years in the N.H.L., never more often than this season.

headline: Nets’ Winning Streak, Their First of Season, Ends at 2
text: CHICAGO — Having secured their ninth victory of a desperately forgettable season Friday night against Detroit, the Nets will not go down as the most futile team in N.B.A. history.

headline: A True Spartan, Playing Through Pain
text: ST. LOUIS — When Michigan State Coach Tom Izzo whistles the start of “War,” a five-minute practice drill in which five players in the paint block out five hard-charging perimeter players, he sends Delvon Roe, his 6-foot-8, 220-pound “soldier,” off the floor.

headline: Does This Bank Watchdog Have a Bite?
text: For now at least, the nation’s front line for consumer financial protection resides on the 34th floor of a downtown office tower in Houston amid cubicles surrounded by posters that read, “Improving the Customer Experience — Be a LEADER in every call.”

headline: No Closure for Wizards in Arenas Case
text: WASHINGTON – The Gilbert Arenas saga is over, at least as far as the judicial system is concerned, and that was enough for Ernie Grunfeld, the Washington Wizards president, to declare “closure.” The truth is more complicated.

headline: Mountaineers Are Comfortable With Being Favorites
text: SYRACUSE – With half of the Final Four set, the early read here is that West Virginia will be considered the resounding favorite. Butler joined the fray earlier Saturday, but even with a home-court advantage in Indianapolis it’s hard to consider the Bulldogs favorites.

headline: Day Traders 2.0: Wired, Angry and Loving It
text: Remember the day traders?

headline: Baylor’s in the Zone, and Duke Is Ready
text: HOUSTON — With third-seeded Baylor’s 1-2-2 zone having stifled a strong shooting team in 10th-seeded St. Mary’s on Friday night, Duke got plenty of questions Saturday about facing it.

headline: Vasily Smyslov, Former World Chess Champion, Dies at 89
text: Vasily Smyslov, the seventh world chess champion, who was known for both the artistry of his play and the solidity of his technique, died Saturday at a hospital in Moscow. He was 89.

headline: Lobbying Blitz Takes On Obama’s Wall St. Overhaul
text: With the Obama administration looking to score another major legislative victory, an array of pro-business groups and fiscal conservatives are mounting a well-financed campaign to scale back or block altogether the Democrats’ plan to overhaul regulation of the financial industry, The New York Times’s Eric Lichtblau and Edward Wyatt report from Washington.

headline: The Word on Obama’s Recess Appointments
text: Sometimes, nominees get held up because they are controversial, like Craig Becker, a labor lawyer who Republicans thought might relate too well to one side in issues brought before the National Labor Relations Board. Sometimes, nominees for tax-related jobs get held up because a senator is angry about a ban on candy-flavored cigarettes in Canada. And sometimes, a president’s political base doesn’t like who he has chosen. President Obama’s 15 recess appointments, announced on Saturday, were held up for a variety of reasons. Here’s a roundup of the new officials:

headline: Kirkuk: Arabs, Baathists, Insurgents and Turkmens United Against the Kurds
text: KIRKUK, Iraq — “Amazing” and “surprising” were some of the words exchanged Saturday by many jubilant Arab and Turkmen residents of this hotly disputed northern Iraqi city.

headline: Not Liking the Stool
text: HOUSTON — Duke Coach Mike Krzyzewski “hated” the stool that he sat on during his top-seeded team’s victory against fourth-seeded Purdue in the N.C.A.A. tournament’s South Region semifinals on Friday night.

headline: Keeping It Clean at Baylor
text: HOUSTON — As a small private Baptist university, Baylor is sometimes mocked by opposing fans for its religious affiliation.

headline: Button Wins Wild Australian Grand Prix
text: MELBOURNE – After two weeks of criticism over a processional race at the season opener in Bahrain and accusations that the Formula One’s new rules had made the series a bore, the second race of the season proved to be one of the most exciting in the last decade.

headline: Tulipmania at Amsterdam Museum
text: Tulips were as important a part of the Dutch Golden Age as canal houses. They were treasured as possessions, speculated upon as commodities and revered as subjects for artists. Though so-called “tulipmania” has died down, aspects of the obsession continue. Every spring, Dutch crowds and tourists flock to the Keukenhof gardens to take in endless fields of flowers, and the flowers are the subject of a small ongoing exhibition at the Rijksmuseum (Stadhouderskade 42; 31-20-674-7000; www.rijksmuseum.nl), simply titled “Tulips in Amsterdam.”

headline: Rajon Rondo’s Sticky Fingers
text: Kentucky is one of the most storied programs in college basketball, and the Celtics are one of the most storied franchises in professional basketball. So the fact that Boston point guard Rajon Rondo owns the single-season record for steals for Kentucky and the Celtics is saying something.

headline: Ask About Growing Indoor Plants
text: This week, Tibor Fuchs, president of the Metropolitan New York Chapter of the Indoor Gardening Society of America, responded to readers’ questions about growing plants and keeping them alive inside.

headline: Thai Premier Faces Off With Leaders of Protests
text: BANGKOK — Prime Minister Abhisit Vejjajiva of Thailand met Sunday with leaders of the antigovernment protest movement here, the first significant effort to defuse two weeks of street protests.

headline: Former Giants Linebacker Cliff Livingston Dies at 79
text: From an obituary that will be appearing in The Times.

headline: 2 Are Killed in Stabbings on Subway in Manhattan
text: Two men were fatally stabbed early Sunday morning in a brawl on a subway car in Lower Manhattan, and by the evening detectives were questioning two men in connection with the deaths, a law enforcement official said.

headline: Video: Why I Joined the Tea Party
text: In an article published today, The Times’s Kate Zernike examines  the influences of economic dislocation on people who have joined the Tea Party movement. Many were jolted into political action. We produced a video featuring one member, Diana Reimer, who has become a leader in the effort.

headline: Looking Ahead: Round of 8
text: Midwest

headline: Bucks Improvise, and Improve
text: After guard Michael Redd sustained a knee injury against the Lakers on Jan. 10, the Milwaukee Bucks were four games under .500 and preparing to play the rest of the season without one of their most talented and highest-paid players.

headline: In Afghan Trip, Obama Presses Karzai on Graft
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — President Obama personally delivered pointed criticism to President Hamid Karzai in a face-to-face meeting on Sunday, flying here for an unannounced visit that reflected growing vexation with Mr. Karzai as America’s military commitment to defeat the Taliban insurgency has deepened.

headline: Smear Today, Gone Tomorrow
text: That was fast. Via Jon Chait, I learn that a whole smear campaign against me was born and died before I even heard about it.

headline: Crist, Rubio Spar Over Spending in Debate
text: MIAMI — Spending, spending, spending – Social Security spending, $787 billion in stimulus spending and a $134 hair cut.

headline: Democrats Defend Appointments
text: A leading Republican predicted Sunday that President Obama’s appointment of 15 officials while sidestepping Senate confirmation would make it more difficult to get bipartisan support for future legislation.

headline: Poor 3-Point Shooting Is Kentucky’s Downfall
text: SYRACUSE — In the teary locker room following a loss in the East Regional championship game Saturday night, Kentucky’s players shrugged off a dismal shooting performance as just one of those nightmarish nights.

headline: The Wisdom of the Short-Sellers
text: Short-sellers profit by finding stocks or other securities that will underperform the market. But how do the short-sellers accomplish this? A new study provides some answers, Mark Hulbert writes in his Strategies column in The New York Times.

headline: North Korea Warns South Over Buffer Zone
text: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea accused the United States and South Korea on Monday of creating provocations by allowing tourists and journalists into the heavily armed buffer zone that has divided the Korean Peninsula since the armistice signed more than a half century ago.

headline: Live Updates From N.C.A.A. Tournament’s Round of 8
text: Live coverage and analysis from the N.C.A.A. tournament. Ray Glier and Kevin Armstrong will provide updates from St. Louis and Thayer Evans will provide updates from Houston. Two longtime Quad contributors who have played in the tournament, Stephen Danley (Penn) and Zach Hillesland (Notre Dame), will also weigh in. You can also follow Pete Thamel on Twitter throughout the tournament.

headline: Iraqi Exiles Celebrate in New York
text: NEW YORK — It was 10:30 a.m. on Friday when our political cinema professor at the Arthur L. Carter Journalism Institute at N.Y.U. gave us a five-minute break before watching the movie Battleship Potemkin.

headline: Chinese Activist Surfaces After a Year in Custody
text: BEIJING — Gao Zhisheng, the Chinese rights activist who has been missing for more than a year, has resurfaced near his hometown in northern China.

headline: Telecom Industry Seems Ripe for Consolidation
text: Naguib Sawiris, the chief executive of Orascom, the Egyptian group that runs wireless phone networks around the world, believes the global industry of mobile operators is about to enter a turbulent period of Darwinian struggle, The New York Times’s Kevin J. O’Brien reports from Berlin.

headline: Freed American in Iraq Expected to Return to U.S.
text: BAGHDAD — An American civilian who had been kidnapped and held for more than two months by a Shiite militia group was released several days ago, and will return within a week to the United States, the American military said.

headline: Geely of China Agrees to Buy Volvo From Ford
text: The Ford Motor Company reached an agreement on Sunday to sell its Volvo subsidiary to a Chinese conglomerate, in the clearest confirmation yet of China’s global ambitions in the auto industry, The New York Times’s Keith Bradsher reports from Hong Kong.

headline: Washington Mutual Files Chapter 11 Plan
text: Washington Mutual filed a Chapter 11 reorganization plan, two weeks after resolving a $4 billion dispute with JPMorgan Chase and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, The Associated Press reports.

headline: Opinions About Chamberlain Are Not a Secret Anymore
text: TAMPA, Fla. — Lesson No. 1 for Yankees pro personnel director Billy Eppler: In the land of pinstripes and Joba Chamberlain, leave yourself some wiggle room.

headline: Search Continues for Head of Abu Dhabi Fund
text: Rescuers searched a Moroccan hillside lake on Sunday for the head of the world’s largest sovereign fund, the Abu Dhabi Investment Authority, two days after his plane crashed into it, Reuters reports.

headline: Crist and Rubio Spar Over Spending in Debate
text: MIAMI — Gov. Charlie Crist and Marco Rubio faced off Sunday in the first debate of the race to become Florida’s next senator, and each unleashed a line of attack based on dollars and cents.

headline: Obama Speaks in Afghanistan
text: President Obama makes a surprise trip to Afghanistan and addresses U.S. troops at Bagram Air Base in Afghanistan. (Video: MSNBC)

headline: New CDs
text: ALAN JACKSON “Freight Train” (Arista Nashville)

headline: Broadway’s Unlikely Hit Gives Hope to the Bold
text: Bipolar disorder, electroshock therapy, a yearning for peace of mind: these are not the usual elements of a successful Broadway musical. Yet “Next to Normal,” which passed its one-year mark on Broadway on Saturday and is preparing for a national tour in November, now qualifies as a hit: it has earned back its $4 million capitalization, the producers said last week.

headline: Unearthing the Sex Secrets of the Périgord Black Truffle
text: The black truffle of Périgord, the cynosure of every foodie’s dreams, is about to yield its most intimate secrets to a team of French and Italian researchers who have decoded its genome. Surely a great day for gastronomy and yet — truffle-lovers be advised — some of the new discoveries may reveal more than you really wanted to know.

headline: Power Tools
text: If you were an avid television watcher in the 1980s, you may remember a clever show called “Moonlighting.”  Known for its snappy dialogue and the romantic chemistry between its co-stars, it featured Cybill Shepherd and Bruce Willis as a couple of wisecracking private detectives named Maddie Hayes and David Addison.  While investigating one particularly tough case, David asks a coroner’s assistant for his best guess about possible suspects.  “Beats me,” says the assistant.  “But you know what I don’t understand?”  To which David replies, “Logarithms?”  Then, reacting to Maddie’s look: “What?  You understood those?”

headline: A Composer Who Knows His Way Around a Piano
text: This season Carnegie Hall’s Keyboard Virtuosos I series has already presented recitals by Murray Perahia, Vladimir Feltsman and Emanuel Ax. Maurizio Pollini appears in April.

headline: Funk, Jazz and Bollywood With Rhythms of Africa
text: It took about an hour before Angélique Kidjo had the crowd on its feet en masse at Town Hall on Friday night, but once she did there was no turning back. Dedicating her next song, “Afirika,” to the great South African singer Miriam Makeba, she slipped into the wings and reappeared on the floor, belting her way up and down the aisles. Then she summoned any and all comers onto the stage for “Agolo,” and kept them there for “Tumba,” which became an amateur dance-off, utopian in its welcoming exuberance.

headline: Learning About War Through a Camera Lens
text: Tatjana Soli’s haunting debut novel begins where it ought to end. In this quietly mesmerizing book about journalists covering the war in Vietnam, the first glimpses of the place are the most familiar. The year is 1975. Americans are in a state of panic as North Vietnamese forces prepare to occupy Saigon. The looters, the desperate efforts to escape this war zone, the mobs surrounding the United States Embassy, the overcrowded helicopters struggling to rise above the chaos: these images seem to introduce Ms. Soli’s readers to a story they already know.

headline: Michigan State Soothes Its Aches With a Little Perseverance
text: ST. LOUIS — In order to return to the national semifinals, Michigan State Coach Tom Izzo duct-taped his defense, rotated 11 players onto the court and overcame rocky relationships with point guard Korie Lucious and shooting guard Durrell Summers. Izzo called the loss of point guard Kalin Lucas to a ruptured Achilles’ tendon last weekend “traumatizing,” but he kept it all together to exceed expectations again.

headline: A Discard Proves Crucial in the Swiss Teams
text: The Open Swiss Teams event at the end of the Spring Nationals in Reno, Nev., was won by John Diamond of Boca Raton, Fla.; Brian Platnick of Evanston, Ill.; Eric Greco of Philadelphia; Geoff Hampson and Fred Gitelman of Las Vegas; and Brad Moss of San Anselmo, Calif.

headline: JPMorgan Says Dubai Plan May Be ‘Negative’ for Banks
text: The debt-restructuring plan of Dubai World may prove to be “negative” for its bank creditors because loan repayments will be financed by asset sales and dividends, according to JPMorgan Chase, Bloomberg News reports.

headline: Invigorated by Challenges, an Eager Symphony Steps Up
text: This season the big news in American classical music has been driven by Gustavo Dudamel at the Los Angeles Philharmonic and Alan Gilbert at the New York Philharmonic. Amid all the talk of innovations at these and other orchestras, the continued success of the San Francisco Symphony Orchestra under Michael Tilson Thomas, in his 15th year as music director, has perhaps been taken for granted.

headline: Obama's Visit to Afghanistan
text: President Obama made an unannounced visit to Afghanistan, his first as commander in chief.

headline: Exuberant Alienation Wearing Sneakers and Jeans in the Big, Bad City
text: It takes a particular kind of work to let students’ youthful qualities shine through without obscuring their prodigious technical abilities. In the latest installment of “Juilliard Dances Repertory,” on Thursday night at the Peter Jay Sharp Theater, that work was Jerome Robbins’s “N.Y. Export: Opus Jazz.”

headline: In Praise of a Virile Star of the Bolshoi
text: Ballet galas are not for the fainthearted. Full of Big International Stars and Big International Egos, high on technical tricks and low on artistic integrity, they are like a buffet of delicious dishes that makes you feel full in no time.

headline: City Critic | Reading Green
text: A tour of the new, environmentally friendly public library in Battery Park City.

headline: From a Cooing Voice, New Moods and Knots
text: Norah Jones had just finished oozing her way through “Sunrise” on Saturday night at the Theater at Madison Square Garden when an audience member piped up with some surprising news.

headline: Famous Features
text: “[Pippi Longstocking] had no mother and no father, and that was of course very nice because there was no one to tell her to go bed just when she was having the most fun, and no one who could make her take cod liver oil when she much preferred caramel candy.”

headline: Going Clubbing by Staying at Home
text: The crowd was about 50 strong, dressed somewhere between postwork casual and preclub glam, when Nicole Atkins plugged in her guitar on Friday evening and began to play. She hawked her CDs between songs, and the sound system was run by a Knitting Factory employee  all pretty typical for Ms. Atkins, a New Jersey-bred songwriter who has reams of critical acclaim but is still struggling for her big break.

headline: Closing Date for ‘The Miracle Worker’
text: After only 21 preview performances and 38 regular performances, the Broadway revival of William Gibson’s play “The Miracle Worker” will close at Circle in the Square Theater next Sunday, the producers David Richenthal and Dini von Mueffling said on Sunday. The show cost $2.6 million to mount and will close at a total loss to its producers and investors, a spokesman for the show said.

headline: Sound and Fury Signify Significance at Red Bull Arena
text: HARRISON, N.J. — The new Red Bull Arena can create a sensory overload for spectators.

headline: Japanese Team Wins Pritzker Architecture Prize
text: Kazuyo Sejima and Ryue Nishizawa, partners in the Japanese architectural firm Sanaa, have won the 2010 Pritzker Architecture Prize, the profession’s highest honor.

headline: Styles That Are Centuries, or Even Just a Day, Apart
text: “Beethoven Then and Now: The Complete Symphonies,” the weekend festival presented by Great Performers at Lincoln Center that offered concerts by two orchestras, first in period style, then in modern style, seemed intended to invite close comparisons. But with variables more often multiplied than curtailed, it allowed, in the end, for only the broadest judgments.

headline: ‘Robin Hood’ to Open Cannes Film Festival
text: The premiere of “Robin Hood,” from the director Ridley Scott, will be the opening film of the 2010 Cannes Film Festival, Reuters reported. And though Robin’s men look more menacing than merry in this script by the “Green Zone” screenwriter, Brian Helgeland, the film is not there to be judged, festival organizers said in a statement. The movie, starring Russell Crowe as the thief with a heart of gold and Cate Blanchett as the headstrong Maid Marian, will screen out of competition when it opens the festival on May 12, before a worldwide release on May 14.

headline: ‘Corpus Christi’ Canceled in Texas
text: A Texas university class production of “Corpus Christi,” by Terrence McNally, below, has been canceled by college officials citing “safety and security concerns for the students as well as the need to maintain an orderly academic environment,” The Austin Chronicle reported. “Corpus Christi,” Mr. McNally’s 1998 play depicting a gay Jesus figure, was scheduled to be performed on Saturday as part of a directing class at Tarleton State University in Stephenville, Tex. But early on Friday, Lt. Gov. David Dewhurst condemned the performance, saying in a press release that “no one should have the right to use government funds or institutions to portray acts that are morally reprehensible to the vast majority of Americans.” Although Tarleton’s president, F. Dominic Dottavio, first defended the students’ right to perform a play he considered “offensive, crude and irreverent,” university officials changed course late Friday night, canceling the performance after receiving threatening calls and e-mail messages, according to The Star-Telegram. In 1998 the first New York production of “Corpus Christi,” at the Manhattan Theater Club, was canceled amid intense protests by religious groups. The show was reinstated after an outcry from artists and civil liberties organizations.

headline: ‘Dragon’ Rules the Box Office
text: “How to Train Your Dragon” (above) was No. 1 at the North American box office over the weekend despite softer than expected ticket sales of about $43.3 million. Some Wall Street analysts expected opening-weekend sales of up to $60 million for this 3-D picture from DreamWorks Animation, on a par with the studio’s last release, “Monsters vs. Aliens.” A variety of factors may have dented “How to Train Your Dragon,” from a sudden glut of 3-D pictures to the decision last week by many theater chains to raise ticket prices. Animated titles also do better when they feature broad comedy, something this movie lacked. Still, positive reviews will likely help “How to Train Your Dragon” in the weeks ahead, when many children are out of school for spring break. “Alice in Wonderland” (Walt Disney Studios) was second with about $17.3 million for a new total of $293 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box-office statistics. The MGM comedy “Hot Tub Time Machine” was third with about $13.7 million, a so-so result considering the hefty promotional muscle the beleaguered studio put behind it. Sony’s “Bounty Hunter” was fourth with about $12.4 million ($38.8 million total), and “Diary of a Wimpy Kid” (20th Century Fox) was fifth with about $10 million ($35.8 million total).

headline: Lebanese Artist Wins Spalding Gray Award
text: The 2010 Spalding Gray Award has been given to Rabih Mroué, below, an actor, director, playwright and visual artist in Beirut known for controversial work that reflects his country’s political climate. The Lebanese Interior Ministry banned his 2007 performance piece about that country’s civil war, “How Nancy Wished That Everything Was an April Fools’ Joke,” written with Fadi Toufic. (The ban was later reversed.) The award, named after Gray, the monologist who died in 2004, is sponsored by a consortium that includes Kathleen Russo, Gray’s wife; Performance Space 122 in New York; the Walker Art Center in Minneapolis; the Andy Warhol Museum in Pittsburgh; and On the Boards in Seattle. It comes with a stipend to create a new work and provides for a full production of that work by each organization.

headline: Judge Orders Prince to Pay Promoters
text: Prince must pay Irish concert promoters $2.95 million for canceling a 2008 show, according to a ruling by a judge in Dublin on Friday, The Associated Press reported. High Court Justice Peter Kelly decided to make public a confidential settlement between Prince and MCD Productions after the promoters complained that Prince had not paid them. The original settlement, signed on Feb. 26, stemmed from Prince’s cancellation just a few days before the concert, at Croke Park stadium in Dublin in June 2008, with no explanation. MCD said 55,000 tickets had been sold, it had paid $950,000 to book the stadium and it had already paid Prince $1.5 million. Justice Kelly also ruled on Friday that Marc Geiger, Prince’s agent at William Morris, was not liable. Testifying in February, Mr. Geiger said he had warned Prince of MCD’s frustration, and Prince replied: “Tell the cat to chill. We will work something out.”

headline: Closing Date for ‘The Miracle Worker’
text: After only 21 preview performances and 38 regular performances, the Broadway revival of William Gibson’s play “The Miracle Worker” will close next Sunday at Circle in the Square Theater, the producers David Richenthal and Dini von Mueffling said on Sunday. The show cost $2.6 million to mount and will close at a total loss to its producers and investors, a spokesman for the show said. The story of a young Helen Keller (Abigail Breslin, above left) learning to communicate under the guidance of her teacher, Annie Sullivan (Alison Pill, right), “The Miracle Worker” opened on March 3 to mixed reviews and never managed to attract much of an audience. The show’s grosses during full weeks of eight performances were uneven, ranging from $165,000 to $256,000. Mr. Richenthal had secured financing this month to keep the show running through mid-April in hopes of capturing a share of the school vacation market. He then left New York to tend to health issues, leaving his decision-making authority about the show to Ms. von Mueffling, his wife. In response to questions about why the show would not run until at least until mid-April, Ms. von Mueffling said in a statement: “In spite of additional advertising, ticket sales did not pick up as much as we thought they would. Closing is the only fiscally prudent choice, as difficult and sad a decision as it is.”

headline: Is the Health Care Law Unconstitutional?
text: Just minutes after President Obama signed the health care legislation into law on Tuesday, 13 state attorneys general, led by Bill McCollum of Florida, filed a federal lawsuit challenging the law’s constitutionality. Virginia’s attorney general, Kenneth Cuccinelli, filed a similar suit the same day. Both complaints charge that Congress has no power under the Constitution’s Commerce Clause to require that all Americans buy health insurance or pay a penalty.

headline: For a B&B That Doesn’t Exist, the Online Reviews Keep Coming
text: One recent TripAdvisor review of the agrotourism destination Schrute Farms awarded four stars, lavishly praising the food, while another yielded just one star, casting aspersions on the owners’ sanity. This wild disparity is especially odd because Schrute Farms doesn’t even exist.

headline: In Britain, Family Buys 2nd Ailing Paper
text: When Alexander Lebedev and his son, Evgeny, took over The Evening Standard of London 14 months ago, the media coverage focused on the father’s status as a former K.G.B. agent and Russian oligarch, and on both men’s taste in beautiful women. Many news reports asked whether they would be an unhealthy influence on one of Britain’s major newspapers.

headline: Euro Trashed
text: Tübingen, Germany

headline: Golf Course Designed by Tiger Woods Runs Into Problems of Its Own
text: Tiger Woods has long maintained a cloak of exclusivity, charging top dollar to top sponsors. The same is true for his golf course company, Tiger Woods Design, which since opening in 2006 has designed three courses, two outside the country: in Dubai, United Arab Emirates, and Ensenada, Mexico.

headline: Cliff Livingston, Key Part of Giants in 1950s and ’60s, Is Dead at 79
text: Cliff Livingston, who played in four National Football League championship games as a linebacker for the Giants in the 1950s and 1960s, died March 13 at his home in Las Vegas. He was 79.

headline: Another Advantage for the Biggest Banks
Donald N. Frey, Designer of the Mustang, Dies at 86
text: Donald N. Frey, the engineer who spearheaded the design and development of the Mustang, the spunky, stylish, affordably priced “pony car” that the Ford Motor Company rolled out in the mid-1960s in one of the most successful car introductions in automotive history, died March 5 in Evanston, Ill., where he lived. He was 86.

headline: Not Creating Content. Just Protecting It.
text: Should we be surprised that the biggest fight over freedom of expression in years involves Google, a company that produces algorithms rather than articles?

headline: Scandal Tests Catholics’ Trust in Leadership
text: ARMAGH, Northern Ireland — As the sexual abuse scandal sweeps through the Roman Catholic Church in Europe and the United States, there are few places where dismay and confusion among worshipers strikes as deep a chord as here in Armagh, seat of the embattled cardinal whose fate has become closely entangled with the widening controversy facing Pope Benedict XVI.

headline: Scientists Say F.D.A. Ignored Radiation Warnings
text: WASHINGTON — Urgent warnings by government experts about the risks of routinely using powerful CT scans to screen patients for colon cancer were brushed aside by the Food and Drug Administration, according to agency documents and interviews with agency scientists.

headline: A Game That Has Been on Ice for 21 Years
text: When Delbarton’s Mike Pendy and St. Joseph’s Kenny Blum were supposed to take the opening face-off in the New Jersey high school hockey championship game, their hamstrings were 21 years younger and there was no need to reintroduce themselves or discuss children and careers.

headline: Stocks Soar, but Many Analysts Ask Why
text: The unemployment rate remains locked in a range that recalls the economic doldrums of the early 1980s. Housing is stuck in a ditch, with foreclosures rising. And consumers are still reluctant to part with the little cash they do have.

headline: UConn-Tennessee Is a Rivalry Worth Resuming
text: DAYTON, Ohio — They are immediately identifiable by one name, Pat and Geno, like Brazilian soccer players and legendary cheesesteak joints of the same appellation in south Philadelphia.

headline: Accused in a Ponzi Scheme, Fugitive Extradited to Serbia
text: A notorious fugitive Serbian banker accused of stealing more than $130 million in a Ponzi scheme was extradited to Serbia from the Netherlands on Friday, the Dutch authorities confirmed Sunday.

headline: A Time for Contrition
text: During a frustrating argument with a Roman Catholic cardinal, Napoleon Bonaparte supposedly burst out: “Your eminence, are you not aware that I have the power to destroy the Catholic Church?” The cardinal, the anecdote goes, responded ruefully: “Your majesty, we, the Catholic clergy, have done our best to destroy the church for the last 1,800 years. We have not succeeded, and neither will you.”

headline: Rift Exposes Split in Views on Mideast
text: JERUSALEM — When Israel announced new housing units for Jews in East Jerusalem at the start of a visit this month by Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu apologized for the timing and expressed regret at the embarrassment. Mr. Biden accepted his explanation, and the two sides seemed prepared to move on.

headline: Coverage Now for Sick Children? Check Fine Print
text: WASHINGTON — Just days after President Obama signed the new health care law, insurance companies are already arguing that, at least for now, they do not have to provide one of the benefits that the president calls a centerpiece of the law: coverage for certain children with pre-existing conditions.

headline: Nets’ Likely Owner Faces a Nation
text: Mikhail D. Prokhorov, a basketball-loving Russian billionaire who is expected to be approved as the majority owner of the Nets next month, moved into the American spotlight Sunday with a profile on CBS’s “60 Minutes.”

headline: Dreaming of Cuban Profits in Post-Embargo World
text: CANCÚN, Mexico — Would Americans’ playing bingo in a Havana retirement home violate the Cuban government’s socialist ethos? How about avowed capitalists living on their 401(k) accounts in condominiums along the Cuban coastline? Or, horror of horrors, fast food outlets offering Big Macs, Whoppers and buckets of fried chicken along the seaside Malecón?

headline: Butler’s Coach: Competitiveness Wrapped in Calm
text: SALT LAKE CITY — It did not take Tracy Stevens long to discover how important basketball was to her husband, Brad. On their third date, as sophomores at DePauw University in Greencastle, Ind., he took her to a high school basketball game more than an hour and a half away.

headline: Best Cookin’ Show Ever
text: “Cookin’ Cheap” was true to its name. It was a TV show about cookin’, and it was cheap. It came from a public television station in Roanoke, Va., in 1981, and went national for a while on PBS. That was when I saw it, and was floored.

headline: Wrapping Things Up From the Midwest
text: ST. LOUIS — A few odds and ends from the Midwest Regional championship game:

headline: Overqualified? Yes, but Happy to Have a Job
text: GRANDVIEW, Mo. — Don Carroll, a former financial analyst with a master’s degree in business administration from a top university, was clearly overqualified for the job running the claims department for Cartwright International, a small, family-owned moving company here south of Kansas City.

headline: The Legal Assault on Health Reforms
text: No sooner had President Obama signed comprehensive health care reform than the attorneys general of 14 states scurried to the federal courts to challenge the law. Their claims range from far-fetched to arguable and look mostly like political posturing for the fall elections or a “Hail Mary” pass by disgruntled conservatives who cannot accept what Congress and the president have done.

headline: The Talent to Contend, and the Experience to Win It All
text: SYRACUSE

headline: North Koreans Use Cellphones to Bare Secrets
text: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea, one of the world’s most impenetrable nations, is facing a new threat: networks of its own citizens feeding information about life there to South Korea and its Western allies.

headline: Obama Team Is Divided on Anti-Terror Tactics
text: WASHINGTON — Senior lawyers in the Obama administration are deeply divided over some of the counterterrorism powers they inherited from former President George W. Bush, according to interviews and a review of legal briefs.

headline: After Gang Crackdown, Police Become Targets
text: HEMET, Calif. — By the time four city trucks were set ablaze next to Hemet City Hall last week, the police here had become familiar with their new life under siege.

headline: Duke Prevails Against Baylor; Returns to Final Four
text: HOUSTON — When Duke’s Mike Krzyzewski was asked Thursday where his top-seeded team ranked among the other Blue Devils squads that he had coached, he declined to speculate.

headline: Europeans Woo U.S., Promising Relevance
text: BRUSSELS — Stung by a perception of America’s indifference to its historical alliance with Europe, senior European leaders are calling for a rebalancing of the relationship, promising the Obama administration that the Europeans can be partners for global challenges ranging from security to climate change.

headline: Sony Pursues a Bold Success to Match Its Scale
text: NAGOYA, Japan — The airy new Sony store in this central Japanese city has floor-to-ceiling windows, sleek white counters and friendly employees, called stylists, who offer advice and tailored counseling on Sony gadgets.

headline: Looking Ahead
text: A HOLIDAY  Markets will be closed in the United States in observance of Good Friday.

headline: After Google’s Move, a Shift in Search Terms
text: HONG KONG — Chinese searches for politically delicate terms peaked the day Google stopped filtering its search results, but the government pressed on with a campaign to remove online praise of the company.

headline: In New York, Breaking a Law on Roommates
text: Doua Moua, 23, played a menacing gangster in a Clint Eastwood movie, but Mr. Moua swears he really is a nice, gentle and rules-abiding fellow. At least he was until he moved to New York City and unwittingly slipped into a world of lawlessness.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes the regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills on Monday, and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Why Senate Democrats Sound Like Republicans on the Budget
text: ALBANY — The districts represented by Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver and John L. Sampson, his fellow Democrat and the Senate leader, lie just a few miles apart in New York City. But when it comes to their priorities for the state budget, the two men inhabit different worlds.

headline: For Federal Prosecutor, Low-Key Style in High-Profile Job
text: It should have been the culmination of a distinguished prosecutorial career.

headline: Corrections
text: Because of an editing error, an article on March 19 about the release of a naturalized American citizen, Nyi Nyi Aung, from prison in Myanmar referred incompletely to his sentence. While Mr. Nyi Nyi Aung, a pro-democracy advocate, was released a month after being sentenced to five years, he was to have served only three years. (A judge decided that several sentences would run concurrently.)

headline: Conquering 46-Part Goal, Peak by Icy Peak
text: LAKE PLACID, N.Y. — The ice on Mount Jo glittered in the bright sunlight. The woods echoed with the crunching sound of the crampons worn by the two hikers. It was an easy climb, despite the thick slabs of ice stretching across the trail.

headline: Corrections
text: A headline with a report in the World Briefing column on Thursday about legislation that would severely restrict the practice of full Muslim veiling in the Canadian province of Quebec misstated the status of that legislation. As the report noted, it has been introduced, not passed.

headline: In a Test of Sales Savvy, Selling a Red Brick on YouTube
text: AN agency whose founder went door to door to sell stoves before he got into advertising — and was so good at it that the company asked him to write a manual for the other salesmen — is creating a contest that celebrates selling.

headline: An Overhaul Passes, the Vitriol Lives On
text: WASHINGTON — Congress has voted, President Obama will hold a last signing ceremony on Tuesday, and still, Americans are struggling to make sense of the health care debate — what it means for them and their families, for businesses and the economy, for states, for lawmakers in the November elections, for Mr. Obama and his presidency, for the nation’s future, and in a most elemental way, for the future of civil democracy.

headline: Accounts, People and Miscellany
text: Accounts

headline: Crane Operator’s License Is Suspended
text: City officials on Sunday suspended the license of a worker who had been operating a 250-foot-high crane before it crashed into a 25-story building in Lower Manhattan, saying he had failed to secure it properly before leaving the site for the day.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: March 28, 2010

headline: New Tool Could Help in Testing for H.G.H.
text: A test similar to one used in cancer treatments has antidoping officials encouraged that they have found a new, and important, way to catch athletes using human growth hormone.

headline: Metropolitan Diary
text: DEAR DIARY:

headline: Free Advice on Money for Those With Little
text: For three years, Juan Maldonado worked in a sleek skyscraper in Midtown, reconciling stock trades at a Lehman Brothers subsidiary that managed $216 billion in assets. These days, he toils in a cramped, decidedly unglamorous office in southeastern Queens, helping the poor and the unemployed stretch budgets that often amount to a couple of hundred dollars a week.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on March 17 about studies included in legislation moving through Congress that would impose tighter financial regulation overstated the effect of the studies that are included in the House bill. While the House legislation indeed calls for dozens of studies, some of which consumer advocates contend could delay implementation of laws and regulations to address the underlying causes of the financial crisis, the House bill does not include dozens of studies “that will effectively delay for up to two years the possibility of addressing those problems.”

headline: Corrections
text: An article in some editions on Friday about the Rangers’ 4-3 shootout victory over the New Jersey Devils on Thursday in the National Hockey League described Rangers center Erik Christensen’s participation in shootouts incorrectly. His shootout attempt in the game was his third of the season, not of his career. (He is 18 for 34 in his career.)

headline: Upper West Side Church Offers Homeless a Home, and More
text: Crystal Chatwood and Eugene Thomas had hitchhiked from Georgia to Florida in search of work, and finding none, had taken a ride north to New York with another couple. The couple dropped them off in Central Park, promising to return in a few hours.

headline: Seton Hall Hires Iona Coach; McCaffery Leaves Siena
text: Of the three prominent New York metropolitan area college basketball jobs open, two have been filled with local coaches considered strong in the area.

headline: In the Park, Honoring a Legend of Jogging
text: Relatively few runners ventured out in the cold, gray drizzle to circle the Central Park Reservoir on Sunday, but many of those who did stopped, some in tears, to pay tribute to one of the reservoir’s most colorful and enduring figures.

headline: Corrections
text: An obituary on Thursday about the actor Robert Culp referred incorrectly to the 1972 movie “Hickey & Boggs,” which Mr. Culp directed and in which he starred with Bill Cosby. It was a crime drama, not a comedy. The obituary, using information from Mr. Culp’s agent, also misidentified the city where Mr. Culp’s son Jason lives. It is New York City, not Los Angeles.

headline: Corrections
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: A Start-Up Has Survived to Beam Up Your Gestures
text: SUNNYVALE, Calif. — Making computers see humans has not been easy for Canesta.

headline: Pitching Issues Remain as Mets Prepare to Come North
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — With a week to go until opening day, the Mets are still facing the same questions about their starting rotation they did in the off-season. Twenty-five games into spring training, no one seems exactly certain what the staff will provide this year.

headline: Democrats Cheer Now, but Grim November May Lie Ahead
text: In politics, as in sports, the thrill of victory sometimes pales alongside the agony of defeat. In 2010, Democrats remain on track to experience both.

headline: What if No One Went to the Office? Inc. Magazine Finds Out
text: Max Chafkin, a senior writer for Inc. magazine, couched the idea as a sort of joke: for his article on virtual offices, perhaps the entire magazine staff should work remotely while making the issue?

headline: For Yankees, Next Choice Settles Left and Center
text: TAMPA, Fla. — In the next few days, Yankees Manager Joe Girardi will decide the second-most interesting position battle in camp, one pushed into the background by the Phil Hughes-Joba Chamberlain drama for fifth starter.

headline: Lawmakers Face Fallout at Home From Health Vote
text: Representative Alan Grayson, a Florida Democrat who supported President Obama’s health care bill, drew shouts of “amen” as he returned home on Friday. But his supporters did not publicize a speech he delivered Saturday morning, out of fear it would be disrupted by protesters.

headline: Women and Islam
text: As a follow up last year's Muslim Voices series, BAMcinématek is presenting "The Female Perspective." The series features six films that look at the role of women in Islam. They include, Dave Kehr writes: Havana Marking's "Afghan Star," a documentary on an Afghan singing competition; "Persepolis," Vincent Paronnaud and Marjane Satrapi's animated adaptation of Ms. Satrapi's account of growing up during the Iranian Revolution; and tonight, Jafar Panahi's gracefully subversive "Offside," about a group of young women trying to penetrate the male-only confines of a Tehran soccer stadium.

headline: Threepenny at 30
text: The life of a literary magazine is always precarious. But The Threepenny Review, which was started by Wendy Lesser in 1980, is celebrating 30 years of publishing fiction, poetry and criticism. Go to McNally Jackson Books tonight to enjoy an evening of readings by Ms. Lesser, Daisy Fried, Mary Gaitskill, Ethan Iverson, James Lasdun, Richard Locke and C. K. Williams. The event begins at 7 p.m.

headline: Curious George Goes to the Museum
text: "You don't really think about Curious George saving the day, as the title of the new exhibition at the Jewish Museum puts it. A 'good little monkey,' he is called in the classic series of picture books by Margret and H. A. Rey, but he was no savior. He was a mischief-maker, an innocent, born in the jungle and lured into the strange world of humans," writes Edward Rothstein. "But as the exhibition points out, at least outside of the books' frames, Curious George really did save the day, and more than once. In early September 1939, just after World War II began, the Reys  a husband-and-wife team of German Jews living in Paris  sought refuge at Château Feuga, an old castle owned by some friends in southern France. At such a time, Hans A. Rey wrote in a letter, 'it feels ridiculous to be thinking about children's books.' But that is what they were doing, prolifically, including a book about a monkey named Fifi, who later became known as Curious George." Make an early trip to the museum to find out more about the history of the couple and their beloved creation and to get there before Passover begins. The museum closes at 2 p.m. on Monday and stays closed for the first, second, seventh and eighth days of the holiday.

headline: Six Districts, Two Sides, One Weekend
text: A week after passing sweeping health care legislation, members of the House returned to their districts to find a bewildering cross-current of political forces awaiting them.

headline: In Uncertain Times, Jazz Keeps Rolling
text: Carlos Boozer could have left the Utah Jazz last summer, could have been traded at midseason and could still walk away in July. He didn’t, he wasn’t and he hasn’t yet, but his uncertain status provides a handy guide to Utah’s championship aspirations.

headline: Ford Agrees to Sell Volvo to a Fast-Rising Chinese Company
text: HONG KONG — Ford Motor reached an agreement on Sunday to sell its Volvo subsidiary to a Chinese conglomerate, in the clearest confirmation yet of China’s global ambitions in the auto industry.

headline: Finding Natural Gas, Safely
text: The Environmental Protection Agency will soon begin a much-needed study of the effects on water quality and public health of a method of extracting natural gas called hydraulic fracturing. An E.P.A. investigation in 2004 was rightly seen as superficial and skewed toward industry, which provided much of the underlying data. This one must be comprehensive and transparent.

text: To the Editor:

headline: Punks and Plutocrats
text: Health reform is the law of the land. Next up: financial reform. But will it happen? The White House is optimistic, because it believes that Republicans won’t want to be cast as allies of Wall Street. I’m not so sure. The key question is how many senators believe that they can get away with claiming that war is peace, slavery is freedom, and regulating big banks is doing those big banks a favor.

headline: Count Us in Favor
text: At least there is one area in Congress where bipartisanship is possible. The 2010 census started only two weeks ago, and a bipartisan group in Congress has already introduced a smart bill to improve the 2020 count.

headline: Analysts Ask if the iPad Can Live Up to Its Hype
text: SAN FRANCISCO — When the Apple iPad goes on sale on Saturday, most of the major questions surrounding the device will have been answered, save for one: can it live up to the hype?

headline: Mergers of Wireless Companies Are Expected to Rebound

headline: More Clicks to Escape an E-Mail List
text: It takes more clicks to be removed from an e-mail list than it once did, the online marketing firm Responsys says. In a study of 100 large online retailers, the firm found that the proportion requiring three or more clicks to unsubscribe had grown more than fivefold since 2008. And the proportion letting users opt out with a single click shrank to 3 percent, from 9 percent, over that period.

headline: Article on Footage of Shooting in Zambia Raises Questions for Media
text: Does a journalist’s confidentiality agreement with sources cover footage of an apparent killing?

headline: The Force of Water, the Power of Words
text: If words were water, the drought problems so lengthily discussed in the new play by Kia Corthron, “A Cool Dip in the Barren Saharan Crick,” would evaporate pretty quickly. The title alone would suffice for a sponge bath. The subject of water actually consumes a large portion of the dialogue in this venturesome but disjointed drama about a young African man studying theology and ecology, and the American family that harbors him during his college years.

headline: Ballet Stars Now Tweet as Well as Flutter
text: In the rarefied world of ballet, where dancers are expected to speak with their bodies, sometimes it seems that aloofness is something to aspire to. Lately, though, the ribbons are loosening. Courtesy of Twitter, dancers are starting to make themselves heard. It isn’t always dainty.

headline: Subway Blasts Kill Dozens in Moscow
text: MOSCOW — Huge explosions during morning rush hour in two subway stations in central Moscow killed more than 33 people on Monday, officials said, raising fears of a renewal of terrorism here.

headline: Death of a Loophole, and Swiss Banks Will Mourn
text: With all the hoopla over the health care bill, hardly anybody noticed that a job creation bill that President Obama signed on March 18 makes it much harder for United States citizens to avoid taxes by hiding money in overseas bank accounts.

headline: Accused in Ponzi Scheme, Fugitive Extradited to Serbia
text: A fugitive Serbian banker accused of stealing more than $130 million in a Ponzi scheme was extradited to Serbia from the Netherlands on Friday, the Dutch authorities confirmed Sunday.

headline: WaMu-JPMorgan Tax Break Said to Trip on F.D.I.C.

To find updated news and more background, visit the Times Topics pages on the Roman Catholic Church Sex Abuse Cases, Pope Benedict XVI and the Roman Catholic Church.

headline: General Growth Said to Be Near Bankruptcy Exit Plan
text: General Growth Properties is getting closer to filing a bankruptcy exit plan, with its board planning to meet on Monday to give final approval to the proposal, sources familiar with the matter told Reuters.

headline: Moscow Attack a Test for Putin and His Record Against Terror
text: MOSCOW — The brazen suicide bombings in the center of Moscow confronted Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin with a grave challenge to his record of curbing terrorism, and raised the possibility that he would respond as he had in the past, by significantly tightening control over the government.
