text: There seems to be two women’s N.C.A.A. Tournaments going on: one that has No. 1 Connecticut utterly destroying all opponents, and a second filled with exciting, tense games.

headline: Debate Between Media and Apple Over iPad Hardly a Flash in the Pan
text: As our colleague Brad Stone points out, no one knows what kind of sales the iPad will gin up out of the gate on Saturday, and it’s just as tough to guess what forms of media will be on this newest form factor in computing.

headline: G.M. Previews the 40 M.P.G. 2011 Chevrolet Cruze Eco
text: It’s not exactly the Son of Volt, but the 2011 Chevy Cruze Eco will continue General Motors’ theme of green when it is formally introduced Wednesday at the New York auto show.

headline: Militia Charged With Plotting to Murder Officers
text: CLAYTON, Mich. — David B. Stone Sr. and his wife, Tina, made no secret about the fact that they were part of a militia, neighbors say. The couple frequently let visitors in military fatigues erect tents in front of their trailer home at the intersection of rural dirt roads, and the sound of gunfire was routine.

headline: Robert Plant to Bring Joy to the World
text: Robert Plant still isn’t reuniting Led Zeppelin, but he is digging deep into his past for the name of his next project. Coming off a highly successful collaboration with the bluegrass singer and fiddler Alison Krauss, Mr. Plant will next hit the road with a group called the Band of Joy, a name cribbed from the  1960s band from Birmingham, England, in which he performed with the future Led Zeppelin drummer John Bonham. In a news release Mr. Plant said the lineup for the new Band of Joy would include the singer Patty Griffin, the instrumentalist and vocalist Darrell Scott, the bassist Byron House, the drummer Marco Giovino and the guitarist Buddy Miller. The band will begin a 12-city tour on July 13 in Memphis and conclude on July 31 in Miami; it is also preparing a new album on which Mr. Miller will serve as co-producer and that will be released by Rounder Records in the late summer or early fall.

headline: Ex-I.B.M. Executive Pleads Guilty in Galleon Case
text: 2:12 p.m. | Updated with Mr. Moffat’s court statement A former I.B.M. senior executive pleaded guilty on Monday to providing confidential information about Advanced Micro Devices and Lenovo to a hedge fund consultant accused of participating in a wide-ranging insider trading scheme.

headline: Times Square’s Homeless Holdout, Not Budging
text: As long as there have been homeless people sleeping in Times Square, there have been social workers and city officials trying to persuade them to leave.

headline: Big Ears
text: Images from the music festival in Knoxville, Tenn.

headline: Man Killed by Train at 116th Street
text: Updated, 2:21 p.m. | Southbound service on the No. 1 train was back to normal by 1:43 p.m., the Metropolitan Transportation Authority said.

headline: TripAdvisor Reviews Pour in for Schrute Farms
text: The agrotourism destination Schrute Farms, which “belongs” to Dwight Schrute of the NBC series “The Office,” is doing big business — for TripAdvisor. In 2007, TripAdvisor set up a review page, thinking it would be good for a quick laugh or two. Reruns and DVDs keep inspiring new visits to the site and there are now over 600 reviews. Read more…

headline: Four Who Endured
text: While you consider the wreckage that is probably your N.C.A.A. tournament bracket -- in our Times staff picks, it is possible to have one Final Four team correct and be in the top five. Seriously — take a bit of comfort in the complete zaniness that is the Final Four. The truly big-time, blueblood team that made it, Duke, was being written off a year ago as a has-been basketball power. Injury-riddled Michigan State might be considered a powerhouse, except its team is being held together with chewing gum and baling wire. West Virginia won the Big East tournament, which in retrospect looks like Albert Pujols’s winning a tee ball game. And then you have Butler, whose coach looks barely older than his players, who all look 12, and can be found charmingly chest-bumping them after victories.

headline: Drone Strikes Are Legal, U.S. Official Says
text: A map showing U.S. drone strikes in Pakistan from a study by The New America Foundation. Enlarge.

headline: Teaching Boys Where They Learn
text: Any parent of a son was probably not surprised to read Nick Kristof’s column this weekend, about how boys have slipped well behind girls by many academic measures in the U.S. and Western Europe.

headline: The False Safety of Bonds
text: One of the things that I’m most worried about right now is people taking money that they want to keep safe and trying to find investments that earn a yield that’s a little higher. This is called “stretching for yield,” and it can be be a dangerous game, especially if you don’t understand the rules.

headline: Interview: Mia Hansen-Love
text: Mia Hansen-Love, the director of "The Father of My Children," discusses the dual meaning of the film's title.

headline: The Originals | Diablo Cody
text: Diablo Cody is in on the joke. And this stripper-turned-writer is as agile on the page as she was on the stage: among her current projects are developing the sudsy “Sweet Valley High” books into a film, while simultaneously writing an original screenplay called “Young Adult,” about a divorced author of teen fiction who returns to her hometown to chase her now-married high school boyfriend. This is the kind of career-as-meta-gag that smart young writers dream of, but almost nobody can pull off. Cody, a Los Angeles resident (who in an earlier life was Brook Busey from Chicago), made her name with the Oscar-winning screenplay for “Juno.” She followed up with the Showtime series “United States of Tara,” a writerly tour de force about a suburban mom (played by Toni Collette) with multiple personalities, now in its second season. “It’s safe to say that I need everything to be embellished, creatively or otherwise,” says Cody, 31. “Just like I’m inclined to put on too much jewelry or get too many tattoos, I need my writing to be a little over-the-top.

headline: Using Hands and Heads to Help Hearts
text: A campaign intended to better acquaint the public with the technique of hands-only cardiopulmonary resuscitation is getting some, well, helping hands.

headline: Emergency Bill Passed to Keep Government Running
text: ALBANY — The State Senate approved emergency legislation on Monday to keep essential government services functioning after the March 31 budget deadline, an indication that lawmakers do not expect to quickly reach a budget deal with Gov. David A. Paterson.

headline: Mental Health Experts Applaud Focus on Parity
text: Even without the new health care law, mental health advocates were getting ready to celebrate parity — a law requiring benefits for substance abuse and mental illnesses to be on par with benefits for medical illnesses.

headline: TimesCast | March 29, 2010
text: From the newsroom of The New York Times.

headline: ‘Come Fly Away': One Show, Two Opinions
text: Twyla Tharp has been choreographing to the music of Frank Sinatra since the 1970s, but “Come Fly Away” brings her Sinatra dances to Broadway for the first time. Charles Isherwood, a New York Times theater critic, hailed it as “a major new work of pop dance theater,” while the Times’s chief dance critic Alastair Macaulay called the choreography  “less sensational than sensationalistic … this is intimacy perverted into exhibitionism.”

headline: Amazing Race for the Rest of Us
text: Ever watch CBS’s reality show “The Amazing Race,” and say to yourself ,“I could do that?” Here’s a chance to prove it.

headline: Bolshoi Theater Plans Reopening in Fall of 2011
text: Closed since 2005 for a renovation project that has run years behind schedule, the Bolshoi Theater, the Moscow home of both the Bolshoi Ballet and Bolshoi Opera, is now aiming to reopen in October 2011, Agence France-Presse reported. “We are assuming that the Bolshoi Theater’s historic building will be opened on Oct. 2, 2011,” the theater’s deputy general director, Anton Getman, said, according to Agence France-Presse. “I will not risk naming an earlier date,” he said, “but we must do all that is in our power to let the public in on Oct. 2, and we will,” adding that performers and staff members might be allowed access to the building as soon as June or July. Before you get your hopes up, keep in mind the star-crossed history of the theater’s $700 million restoration, which has taken nearly 5 years of its 185-year existence: originally planned to be finished in 2008, the repair work was delayed, and last year prosecutors opened an investigation into the possible embezzlement of funds intended for the project.

headline: Main Opposition to Boycott Myanmar Election
text: BANGKOK — After months of internal debate, members of the party of Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the long-detained pro-democracy leader, defied Myanmar’s junta by announcing Monday that they would boycott the country’s first elections in two decades.

headline: Roethlisberger Skips Steelers’ Voluntary Workout
text: In their long, championship-filled history, the Pittsburgh Steelers have certainly had better days than this.

headline: Bank of America Moves to Expand in Asia
text: Bank of America has hired four new executives in its global banking business, including three people in Asia, as part of its continued push into international banking, Reuters reports.

headline: Options Expand for Affordable Long-Term Care
text: More than most 41-year-olds, Elizabeth Priaulx thinks about her eventual need for long-term care. A lawyer in Washington, she has coped well with cerebral palsy since childhood, but has lately developed painful arthritis as a consequence of the disease.

headline: The Position of the Church
text: New York’s Archbishop Timothy Dolan, blogging on the sex abuse scandal:

headline: Obama to Throw First Nats Pitch
text: For the first time, President Obama will throw out the first pitch at a Washington Nationals season opener — against the Phillies next Monday.

headline: The Price of Face Time
text: ALBANY — How much does it cost to buy face time in the capital?

headline: A Letter From U.N.C., and the Agonizing Wait to Open It
text: Midway through a ski vacation with my friend and his family earlier this month, I called home to Texas to check in with my parents. They told me I had received a college decision letter, only my second so far.

headline: A French Culinary Movement Gains Traction
text: A fascinating piece about the de-snobbification of French food (which is happening, and will continue to do so, regardless), by The New Yorker’s Adam Gopnik.

headline: Media Equation: Google and Free Speech
text: In today’s Media Equation column, David Carr writes:

headline: Mootopia
text: This milk commercial takes place in a make-believe land of plenty called Mootopia in a new campaign for the California Milk Processor Board.

headline: Idiot-Proofing Financial Regulation
text: Ezra Klein expresses some skepticism about my skepticism. I worried that no financial reform will work if the government is dominated by people who don’t believe in regulation; Ezra counters that the FDIC has been pretty robust to idiots in power.

headline: Now Booking | The Exedra Milan
text: Were Lady Gaga on the prowl for a sense-dislocating set for a new video, she couldn’t find one more suitably psychedelic than the Exedra Milano, the newest member of the Boscolo hotel group. In transforming what was an 11-story bank into a canny hybrid of “Alice in Wonderland” fantasy and space-age chic, the architect Italo Rota tickles the modernist tradition of Gio Ponti, who designed Milan’s landmark Pirelli Tower (which, in turn, inspired New York’s Pan Am building). The hotel made its debut in October.

headline: Greece Raises $6.7 Billion in Bond Sale
text: Just days after European Union leaders agreed to stand behind Greece as it struggled to restore its public finances, the authorities in Athens put their new guarantee to the test Monday, selling 5 billion euros of seven-year bonds to refinance debt.

headline: Ethics Report Faults Ex-Congressman
text: WASHINGTON — Nathan Deal, a former Republican congressman who is running for Georgia governor, resigned from the House last week in a move that seemed certain to end an ethics investigation that could have proved politically embarrassing.

headline: Good News On Mandates
text: One big concern about health reform has been the argument that the individual mandate — which is essential to keeping the risk pool broad enough — won’t work, because the penalties for noncompliance are too weak. But Austin Frakt does some calculations which seem to suggest that the penalties for noncompliance under Obamacare are, if anything, slightly stronger than under Romneycare — and that since gaming of the system doesn’t seem to be a large problem in Massachusetts, it probably won’t be a big problem nationally.

headline: CKX Confirms Sales Talks
text: CKX, the owner of the “American Idol” and “So You Think You Can Dance” franchises, confirmed on Monday that it is holding talks to sell itself, after media reports said that the entertainment company was negotiating with its chief executive and One Equity Partners, a private equity firm owned by JPMorgan Chase.

headline: Man Accused of Threatening Cantor
text: Federal authorities in Philadelphia announced that a local resident has been charged with threatening to kill Representative Eric Cantor, the No. 2 Republican in the House, according to wire service and news reports.

headline: Chinese Court Hands Down Stiff Sentences to Four Mining Company Employees
text: SHANGHAI — Four employees of the British-Australian mining giant Rio Tinto, including an Australian citizen, were found guilty by a Chinese court on Monday of accepting millions of dollars in bribes and stealing commercial secrets.

headline: Application for the Forgetful Driver
text: Plenty of portable navigation devices and iPhone apps can help you with those senior moments when you forget exactly where you parked the car. The trouble with those apps is that you still have to remember to mark your parking spot in the navigation system or smartphone before you walk away. But soon you won’t even have to remember to do that.

headline: Getting More Fish in Your Diet
text: Nutritionists are increasingly enthusiastic about the benefits of omega-3 fatty acids, present in fatty, cold water fish such as tuna, mackerel and salmon, as well as in some nuts and vegetable oils. The benefits of regularly eating these foods include lower triglyceride levels and a reduced risk of coronary artery disease, studies have found. Experts are also researching a possible role for omega-3s in boosting the immune system and protecting against hypertension, depression and other ailments.

headline: The Morning Skate: Honors for Ex-Devils Coach Pat Burns
text: If you have a half-hour or so, spend it with this segment from Ottawa radio Team 1200’s “Three Guys in the Morning” earlier today (audio). You’ll hear a terrific conversation in which the hosts, John “J.R.” Rodenburg, Steve Warne and Jim Jerome, talk with Pierre McGuire and Hall of Famer Larry Robinson. Robinson and McGuire discusses a couple of coaching greats, Pat Burns and Scotty Bowman, some coaching philosophy and a host of other hockey topics.

headline: Ethics Report Faults Ex-Congressman
text: Remember the Georgia Congressman who announced his resignation from Congress, but then postponed it until he could vote against the health care bill in the House last week? Well, the Republican Congressman, Nathan Deal, did in fact call it quits in the hours after the final vote last weekend. But that move, done so that he could run for the Republican gubernatorial nomination in Georgia, didn’t silence an ethics inquiry that had been swirling around him.

headline: Confronted by Team, a Spartan Responds
text: ST. LOUIS — They do not always do things delicately at Michigan State, whether rebounding in bruising fashion or calling out a teammate for playing without enough passion.

headline: Index-Finger Cooks, Pizza Bumps, Speed-Scratch Products, & Lazy Food
text: Novel terms associated with convenience cooking.

headline: New Directors/New Films Video: Mia Hansen-Love
text: The French director Mia Hansen-Love brought her latest film to the New Directors/New Films festival this year, “The Father of My Children.” The film explores the business and home life of a film producer and how the pressures of his job, including mounting debts and increasing demands, lead to a tragic end. “Father” is inspired by the life and death of the French film producer Humbert Balsam. Ms. Hansen-Love discussed her film — which will be released in theaters May 28 — and the dual meaning of its title:

headline: Should You Hire Someone Who’s Overqualified?
text: Is it actually a good idea to hire someone who is technically “overqualified” for a position?

headline: Democrats Try to Split Bankers on Financial Bill
text: Even with Congress in recess for two weeks, the battle over financial regulatory overhaul continues to heat up. Democrats are going on the offensive, accusing industry lobbyists of improperly portraying community banks as victims of the financial regulatory legislation, when Wall Street is writing the checks to halt the bill.

headline: Financial Tuneup: The Gym Cancellation Follies
text: All of us need to take some time every so often to knock things off our financial to-do list. To help, we’ve created a series of articles and an interactive checklist to get you started.

headline: Florida State Gets Next Crack at Undefeated Connecticut
text: Hey Florida State, congratulations on reaching the final eight in the N.C.A.A. women’s tournament for the first time. Your “reward,” however, is facing the steamroller also known as No. 1 Connecticut (36-0) on Tuesday.

headline: Fatty Foods May Be Addictive
text: More evidence that junk food may be addictive, as reported by CNN and others, here.

headline: Where Everyone Majors in Murder
text: This is the week when millions of college applicants will find out whether they got into their first-choice schools, were put on the waiting list or were rejected. Anyone whose heart is set on Hudson University will be disappointed.

headline: Panel in Iraq Moves to Disqualify 52 Candidates
text: BAGHDAD — A government commission sought Monday to disqualify six people who had won seats in Iraq’s parliamentary election and 46 other candidates because of what it called their ties to the banned Baath Party.

headline: Two Colts Remain Atop Derby Contenders
text: On this year’s Kentucky Derby trail, two colts have towered over the current crop of 3-year-olds. Eskendereya was a crushing eight-and-a-half-length winner in the Fountain of Youth in Florida; Lookin at Lucky easily came from behind to win the Rebel Stakes by a head.

headline: Overhaul Will Lower the Costs of Being a Woman
text: Being a woman is no longer a pre-existing condition. That’s the new mantra, repeated triumphantly by House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, Senator Barbara A. Mikulski and other advocates for women’s health. But what does it mean?

headline: Artifacts | Antony Gormley’s Human Pop-Ups
text: All too often, “public art” means some clueless civic agency has plunked an annoying bronze obstruction in the path of New Yorkers already pressed for space. Well, surprise! The 31 life-size nude figures that popped up this week in the Flatiron district are not just giving public art a good name. They are giving pedestrians reason to scream with delight.

headline: Subway Blasts Kill Dozens in Moscow
text: Female suicide bombers set off explosions at two Moscow subway stations during the morning rush hour, killing more than three dozen people.

headline: An Accelerated Transition at Seattle’s Intiman Theater
text: Whatever Bartlett Sher had to teach Kate Whoriskey, she evidently learned it faster than anticipated: on Monday, the Intiman Theater in Seattle announced that its interim arrangement under which Mr. Sher (the director of Broadway’s “South Pacific” and “Light in the Piazza,” and the Metropolitan Opera’s “Tales of Hoffman”) and Ms. Whoriskey (who directed the Off-Broadway production of “Ruined” for Manhattan Theater Club) would share the title of artistic director, and Ms. Whoriskey would take over from Mr. Sher next year, was being accelerated. The theater has made Ms. Whoriskey its artistic director, effective immediately, and she will select its remaining plays for the season; Mr. Sher was named the theater’s artistic director emeritus. “Working with Kate over the past months has affirmed for us that that we are ready now to move forward with her vision for the theater as the sole artistic director,” the theater’s board president, Kim A. Anderson, said in a statement. On Sunday, the producers of the Broadway revival of “The Miracle Worker” that Ms. Whoriskey directed at Circle in the Square theater said it would close April 4.

headline: Ilgauskas Trade Highlights Salary Cap Quirks
text: Cleveland traded Zydrunas Ilgauskas to Washington on February 17, as part of a three-team deal that also brought Antawn Jamison to the Cavs. Ilgauskas was included in the trade for financial reasons only, with his salary providing the ballast needed to make the trade legal. Sure enough, Ilgauskas was waived on February 25, without playing a single game for the Wizards.

headline: In All Those Pages, a Surprise or Two
text: Tucked inside the huge health reform bill signed into law last week were many surprising and little-noticed provisions that will affect consumers in ways large and small. It emerged that chain restaurants, for example, would have to disclose the calorie counts of items on their menus. Who knew? Here are some other examples:

headline: A Cycling Snob Unmasked
text: One of New York’s best known yet most elusive cyclists is about to emerge from the shadows.

headline: Rothschilds Bring in Outsider to Run the Show
text: More than 200 years ago, a German banker, Mayer Amschel Rothschild, sent his five sons to different European cities to guarantee the survival of what became one of the most prominent banking dynasties, The New York Times’s Julia Werdigier reports from London.

headline: Bradford Awes Observers in Pro Day Workout
text: Ah, the internet. It brings all the mundane activity of a college pro day to your living room and office. On Monday, the world got a look at Sam Bradford, the Oklahoma quarterback who is coming off major shoulder surgery to reconstruct the AC joint. His workout was the most eagerly anticipated this side of Tim Tebow’s because Bradford, unlike Tebow, could be the first overall pick by the St. Louis Rams.

headline: What Can Benedict Do?
text: That’s Rod Dreher’s question, prompted by my column today:

headline: Travel Deals: Kids and Art Lovers Package in Boston
text: The Renaissance Boston Waterfront Hotel, a 492-room hotel along the city’s recently renovated harbor, is offering two packages starting at $189 a night: one for couples who love art and another for parents and pint-sized travelers.

headline: Playwrights Horizons Announces More of 2010-11 Lineup
text: In addition to mounting the previously reported New York premiere of Edward Albee’s play “Me, Myself & I,” Playwrights Horizons on Monday announced four additional productions for its 2010-11 season, including new plays by Adam Bock (“The Drunken City”) and the actor David Greenspan (“Coraline”).

headline: Interview: Laura Poitras
text: Laura Poitras, the director of "The Oath," discusses her documentary which profiles Abu Jandal, the former bodyguard of Osama bin Laden.

headline: On Second Thought, Don’t Eat the Plants in the Park
text: On Saturday, we published a post informing people that the shoots of the day lily flower now pushing out of the ground in parks around the city were delicious to eat. Several commenters asked why we were promoting an illegal and destructive activity.

headline: A Piece of Mets History, Rewritten in Stone
text: Last season, fans hammered the Mets for not incorporating enough of the team’s history into Citi Field. Now that the team has been working to fix the problem, some fans wonder if they should try a little harder when it comes to accuracy.

headline: No Matter What, We Pay for Others’ Bad Habits
text: “I’m tired of paying for everyone else’s stupidity,” is a comment I read on the Internet last week after the health care bill was passed. It summed up the views of many Americans worried about shelling out higher premiums and taxes to cover the uninsured. Why should we pick up the tab when so much disease in our country stems from unhealthy behavior like smoking and overeating?

headline: Dozens Killed in Moscow Subway Attacks
text: If a single face can stand in for Muscovites whose city was upended by terrorist attacks, this scarred commuter may be the one. Female suicide bombers set off huge explosions in two subway stations in central Moscow during the Monday morning rush, Russian officials said, killing more than three dozen people and raising fears that the Muslim insurgency in southern Russia was once again being brought to the country’s heart. There is a slide show devoted to the bombings.

headline: R.N.C. Spends Thousands on Private Jets, Limos and Clubs, Report Shows
text: The Republican National Committee opened an investigation on Monday into why money from donors was paid to reimburse a $2,000 tab at a risqué California nightclub earlier this year, party officials said.

headline: Law May Do Little to Help Curb Unnecessary Care
text: Dr. Robert Colton, an internist in Boca Raton, Fla., has a problem, and he knows it. His patients come in wanting, sometimes demanding, tests and treatments that are unnecessary, just adding to the nation’s huge health care bill. He even has patients, he says, who come in and report that their chief complaint is, “I need an M.R.I.”

headline: ‘Come Fly Away': Quantity Is Not Quality
text: The Times’s Charles Isherwood and Alastair Macaulay are discussing “Come Fly Away,” which opened last week at the Marquis Theater. Previous posts are here.

headline: Salmon Fillets With Tomatillo Salsa
text: Tomatillos have an acidic flavor that goes beautifully with salmon. The colors are great together too. Be sure to seek out wild salmon, which is in season now.

headline: Potato and Tuna Purée
text: This is comfort food at its finest, similar to a tuna noodle casserole but dressed up and simpler at the same time. It’s inspired by the rich Provençal salt cod purée called brandade, which often includes potatoes. But salt cod is hard to come by here, and it’s expensive and salty.

headline: Brooklyn Building Collapse Injures Four
text: A three-story building in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, that was being renovated collapsed Monday afternoon, critically injuring a worker who was trapped in the rubble and leaving three other people with minor injuries, according to the Fire Department and witnesses.

headline: A Tale of Two Democrats
text: Across the country, politicians returned home to face the aftermath of their health care reform votes.

headline: Baked Trout With Tomatoes and Olives
text: Although this Provençal staple is traditionally a summer dish made with fresh tomatoes, you can make it successfully with canned tomatoes. The dish is a nice way to warm up your winter table and a great way to serve farmed trout, an easy fish to find.

headline: G.O.P. Opens Inquiry on Club Expenditure
text: WASHINGTON — The Republican National Committee on Monday opened an investigation into why party money, which donors contributed to help win seats in the midterm elections, was used to pay a $2,000 tab at a risqué Hollywood club in late January.

headline: The Planet Be Damned. It’s All About Me.
text: Ian McEwan has long had a penchant for creating unsavory, disreputable characters: children who bury their mother in the basement (“The Cement Garden”), a Machiavellian sadist who preys on a pair of middle-class tourists (“The Comfort of Strangers”), a dead woman’s conniving former lovers (“Amsterdam”), an adolescent girl who makes false accusations against a man that will alter his life and the life of her entire family (“Atonement”).

headline: Tuna and Pepper Stew
text: This recipe is loosely based on a Basque tuna soup called marmitako, a fisherman’s dish with simple origins. It was originally made with bread and tuna, but in later years was greatly enhanced with the arrival of peppers, tomatoes and potatoes from the New World. Every cook has a version of this dish, and I am no exception. Fresh albacore tuna from North America are often lower in environmental contaminants than other types of tuna and the most eco-friendly choice.

headline: From Rage to Relief: View From a Nurse’s Station
text: Several weeks ago on the hospital floor where I’m a nurse, we had a V.I.P. patient whose spouse expected, and got, the red-carpet treatment. The patient’s spouse made many demands, but what struck most of us as particularly galling was the meal service both received. Day after day, meal after meal, a hospital employee wheeled a china-laden cart into that patient’s room. It looked like room service at a fancy hotel.

headline: At Columbia, Sarkozy Calls for Change at U.N.
text: President Nicolas Sarkozy of France presented ideas on a new world governance structure on Monday to students at Columbia University. Mr. Sarkozy’s address was part of the university’s World Leaders Forum, which since 2003 has attracted several heads of state, among them Iran’s president, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad. The visit from Paris was far less controversial, but the message nonetheless relatively radical.

headline: Scoop du Jour | Thierry Marx Leaves Bordeaux for Paris
text: Thierry Marx is finally moving to Paris. The French chef and Bruce Willis lookalike, who has impressed diners who have made the trek to Cordeillan-Bages in Bordeaux with his inventive molecular fare since 1996 (read about it here), has always seemed too big of a talent even for the grand 18th-century chateau owned by the Lynch-Bages wine-making family. (Imagine if Thomas Keller were stuck in Yountville.) A year from now, he will be installed at the Mandarin Oriental in Paris, which is scheduled to open in 2011 on the rue Saint-Honoré. Whether he brings his two Michelin stars — or his signature dish of Aquitaine beef wrapped in plastic with burning cabernet vines — with him remains to be seen.

headline: Oakland to Discuss Plan to Reach Aggressive Greenhouse-Gas Reduction Goal
text: As of November 2009, at least 139 cities in the United States had climate action plans, including Portland and Chicago. Oakland doesn’t have one yet, but it does have a goal: by 2020, the city seeks to reduce greenhouse gas emissions to 36 percent of what they were in 2005. That goal is more aggressive than those of either San Francisco or Berkeley, which both have climate action plans.

headline: Consumers’ Big Question: What’s in It for Me?
text: More than a week after President Obama signed the sweeping new health care law, which will eventually provide insurance coverage for 32 million uninsured Americans, many of us are still scratching our heads. What just happened? And how and when will we start feeling its effect?

headline: ‘Come Fly Away': The Nature of the Event
text: The Times’s Charles Isherwood and Alastair Macaulay are discussing “Come Fly Away,” which opened last week at the Marquis Theater. Previous posts are here.

headline: The Professor’s Appeal Saves Him With One Arsenal Fan
text: The harmony of 60,000 voices that drifts out of the Emirates Stadium in London every other week is evidence that sport can bring people together.

headline: Playing Musical Chairs to Capture Beethoven’s Spirit
text: The ostensible lure of the four-concert series the conductor Ivan Fischer presented with the Orchestra of the Age of Enlightenment and the Budapest Festival Orchestra at Lincoln Center was the chance to hear all nine Beethoven symphonies performed in close proximity by two exemplary ensembles representing different traditions: the period-instrument band and the modern orchestra.

headline: Disabled Immigration Detainees Face Deportation
text: For lawyers offering free legal information at large immigration detention centers in remote parts of Texas, the task is difficult enough: coaching hundreds of detainees on how to represent themselves at assembly-line deportation hearings. But the lawyers soon discover a more daunting problem: many detainees are too mentally ill or mentally disabled to understand anything.

headline: Readers Separate Church From Home Plate
text: “Are you saying Jesus Christ can’t hit a curveball?” asked Eddie Harris in the baseball movie classic “Major League.” Mr. Harris was in the locker room with his teammate Pedro, who was trying to explain how Jobu, his god, would help him hit the ball straight. Like Pedro and Mr. Harris, many players today appeal to a higher power when on the field. But what is God’s role inside the diamond?

headline: Nets Executive Has New Take on Brown Bagger
text: In the long, strange trip known as the Nets’ 2009-2010 season, Tuesday may turn out to be a red-letter day on the weirdness calendar.

headline: Russia’s Fear of Female Bombers Is Revived
text: MOSCOW — The two powerful explosions that tore through Moscow’s subway on Monday revived a peculiar fear in the Russian capital, one that goes beyond the usual terrorism worries of a metropolis: the female bomber.

headline: 2-Man Cast Shares Stage With a Vivid Character
text: “I wonder,” Mark Rothko muses, staring at one of his canvases. “Do you think they’ll ever forgive me?”

headline: José Saramago, Litblogger
text: Can a blog rise to the level of literature?

headline: Finger Family Takes Aim Again at Bank of America
text: 5:44 p.m. | Updated The Finger family of Houston, a relatively large and very dissatisfied shareholder in Bank of America, sent a scathing letter to shareholders in advance of the bank’s annual meeting in late April, urging them to vote against the re-election of one board member and to vote for a provision to make it easier to claw back executive compensation.

headline: Rubber Soles | 50 Years of Dr. Martens (The Musical)
text: By the time Britain’s skinheads completed their devolution from hard-edged dandies to racist hooligans, their cherished Dr. Martens boots had gone viral. Before long, the list of D.M. devotees would span the length of the screw-up spectrum: “Mods, glams, punks, ska, psycho-hillbillies, grebos, Goths, industrialists, nu-metal, hardcore, straight-edge, grunge, Britpop” and on and on, says Martin Roach, D.M.’s de facto historian. Now, Dr. Martens is marking its 50th anniversary. To celebrate, the company has commissioned covers of 10 “cult” songs from acts like the Human League, Buzzcocks, the Pogues and even the Cold War Kids. (Full details here.) The songs and music videos drop on Thursday at drmartens.com. For an exclusive-to-T taste, watch profiles of three of the cutting-edge acts involved in the project.

headline: 10 Mexican Students Killed in Another Violent Weekend
text: MONTERREY, Mexico — Mexico reeled Monday from another bloody weekend of drug-related killings that was made even more horrible by the baffling massacre of 10 young people and children traveling in a pickup truck in Durango State.

headline: Making Sense of the Health Care Law
text: Confused by the new health care law? Today’s special section on health reform in Science Times helps you figure out what it might mean for you.

headline: Making a Spiritual Connection With Matzo
text: There was the flour, the water, and the intention of turning them into unleavened bread to be consumed during Passover. But what made this matzo-making operation different from all others?

headline: Ads for Community Papers, but Are They Local?
text: The story of newspapers’ woes is well known, and the news is almost continually dire. As major media organizations erect digital fortifications — across the pond and right in our back yard — community newspapers, those bastions of local event photos and pothole exposés, find themselves no less threatened by changing reading habits and the negative prognoses they engender.

headline: Baird Lures 2 Executives From Morgan Stanley
text: Baird Private Wealth Management has lured two executives from Morgan Stanley Smith Barney to join its office in Scottsdale, Ariz., Reuters reports.

headline: For Photographers, the Image of a Shrinking Path
text: By the time Matt Eich entered photojournalism school in 2004, the magazine and newspaper business was already declining.

headline: Robert Plant’s New Band Has an Old Name
text: Robert Plant still isn’t reuniting Led Zeppelin, but he is digging deep into his past for the name of his next project. Coming off a successful collaboration with the bluegrass singer and fiddler Alison Krauss, Mr. Plant, left, will next hit the road with a group called the Band of Joy, a name cribbed from the 1960s group from Birmingham, England, in which he performed with the future Led Zeppelin drummer John Bonham. In a news release Mr. Plant said the lineup for the new Band of Joy would include the singer Patty Griffin, the instrumentalist and vocalist Darrell Scott, the bassist Byron House, the drummer Marco Giovino and the guitarist Buddy Miller. The band will begin a 12-city tour on July 13 in Memphis and conclude on July 31 in Miami; it is also preparing an album.

headline: ‘Rent’ Controversy Inspires a Musical
text: The nonprofit New York Theater Barn will hold a benefit performance on April 5, offering a full reading and songs from a new musical that the troupe is developing. The show takes its inspiration from a 2008 controversy in Rowlett, Tex., over a local high school’s plans to produce a version of “Rent,” the Tony Award-winning musical. High school drama clubs across the country have run into opposition trying to mount productions of “Rent: School Edition,” a slightly toned-down adaptation of the Broadway show, which featured straight and gay characters who cope with drug addiction, infidelity, homelessness and AIDS. New York Theater Barn’s project, “Speargrove Presents,” is described by the company as a humorous, heartfelt account of a debate over “Rent” in a small Texas town. The benefit will be at the Julia Miles Theater on West 55th Street.

headline: ‘The Walking Dead’ Rises on AMC
text: With a schedule that includes “Mad Men” and “Breaking Bad,” the AMC channel has often been credited for its brains, which should make the newest additions to its original programming lineup very happy.

headline: New Booking Site for Down Under
text: Need to get from Alyangula to Wagga Wagga?   A new online travel site, Wotflight.com makes it easier to search for flights within Australia.

headline: Playwrights Horizons Adds Four Shows
text: In addition to mounting the New York premiere of Edward Albee’s play “Me, Myself & I,” as previously reported, Playwrights Horizons on Monday announced four productions for its 2010-11 season, including new plays by Adam Bock (“The Drunken City”) and the actor and writer David Greenspan (“Coraline”). After opening the season with the Albee in August, Playwrights Horizons will produce “After the Revolution” by Amy Herzog, about a family confronting its history with Marxism. Mr. Bock’s “Small Fire,” about a woman losing her senses, will follow. Next up will be “Kin,” about the relationship between a Texas poetry scholar and an Irish personal trainer, by Bathsheba Doran (“Living Room in Africa”). Mr. Greenspan’s new play, “Go Back to Where You Are,” is described by the company as a melancholy comic romance about a chorus boy (played by Mr. Greenspan) from ancient Greece in purgatory who is dispatched after 2,000 years to mix with a vacationing family in the Hamptons. A sixth production is to be announced later.

headline: TriBeCa Festival Adds ‘Freakonomics’
text: Does a documentary film adapted from a best-selling nonfiction work about the application of economic theories and models to unusual real-life situations stand any chance at the box office? Attendees of the Tribeca Film Festival will get an early chance to answer that puzzler. On Monday, festival organizers said the film version of “Freakonomics,” by Steven D. Levitt and Stephen J. Dubner (both are contributors to The New York Times), is to be shown at its closing-night gala on April 30. The film, making its world premiere at the festival, includes segments directed by Alex Gibney, Morgan Spurlock, Rachel Grady and Heidi Ewing, Eugene Jarecki and Seth Gordon.

headline: A One-Woman Job at Intiman Theater
text: Whatever Bartlett Sher had to teach Kate Whoriskey, she evidently learned faster than anticipated. On Monday, the Intiman Theater in Seattle announced that the interim arrangement under which Mr. Sher would share the title of artistic director with Ms. Whoriskey, who was to take over next year, was being accelerated. The theater has made Ms. Whoriskey its artistic director, effective immediately, and she will select its remaining plays for the season; Mr. Sher was named the theater’s artistic director emeritus. “Working with Kate over the past months has affirmed for us that we are ready now to move forward with her vision for the theater as the sole artistic director,” the theater’s board president, Kim A. Anderson, said in a statement. On Sunday, the producers of the Broadway revival of “The Miracle Worker,” directed by Ms. Whoriskey at Circle in the Square theater, announced it would close on April 4.

headline: Basketball and ‘Boss’ Help CBS Win
text: N.C.A.A. men’s basketball, “60 Minutes” and “Undercover Boss” lifted CBS far ahead of its competitors in the ratings on Sunday. CBS began the night in the lead thanks to a half-hour overrun of its basketball coverage from the afternoon, earning an average of 18 million viewers from 7 to 7:30 p.m., according to Nielsen’s estimates. Coming next, CBS’s “60 Minutes” remained on top with 14.5 million, while “The Amazing Race” garnered 13 million viewers in the next hour. At approximately 9:30, CBS’s “Undercover Boss” delivered the night’s largest nonsports audience with 16.1 million viewers. NBC lagged behind but finished in second place over all, attracting 7.3 million viewers for “Celebrity Apprentice,” after episodes of “Dateline” (4.5 million) and “Minute to Win It” (5.8 million). ABC was third with mostly repeats, and Fox ranked fourth.

headline: Bolshoi Theater Planning Fall 2011 Reopening
text: Closed since 2005 for a renovation project that is running years behind schedule, the Bolshoi Theater in Moscow, home of both the Bolshoi Ballet (backstage in 2001, above) and Bolshoi Opera, is now aiming at October 2011 for its reopening, Agence France-Presse reported. “We are assuming that the Bolshoi Theater’s historic building will be opened on Oct. 2, 2011,” the theater’s deputy general director, Anton Getman, said, according to Agence France-Presse. “I will not risk naming an earlier date, but we must do all that is in our power to let the public in on Oct. 2, and we will.” Before you mark your calendar, though, keep in mind the star-crossed history of the theater’s $700 million restoration, which has taken nearly 5 years of its 185-year existence: originally planned to be finished in 2008, work was delayed and last year prosecutors opened an investigation into the possible embezzlement of funds intended for the project.

headline: Performers in Two Distinct Worlds, Real and Projected
text: Choreographers have long been fascinated by the illusions that can be spun from the intersections of light and the moving body. That fascination goes back at least to Loie Fuller at the end of the 19th century, but lives on in the work of Alwin Nikolais, Mummenschanz, Pilobolus and Momix.

headline: F.D.A. to Examine Menthol Cigarettes
text: For the cigarette industry, the menthol debate is about to flare up again.

headline: Downsizing Sacred Works for Intimacy of a Chapel
text: The Chopin and Schumann bicentenaries and the Barber centenary have received ample attention this year, but let us not overlook Giovanni Battista Pergolesi, who was born in 1710 and lived only 26 years. He is best known for music he did not actually compose: the suite movements that Stravinsky thought were Pergolesi’s when he reconfigured them in “Pulcinella” turn out to have been by Domenico Gallo, and the popular “Concerti Armonici” were discovered to have been by Unico Wilhelm van Wassenaer.

headline: Among Weathercasters, Doubt on Warming
text: The debate over global warming has created predictable adversaries, pitting environmentalists against industry and coal-state Democrats against coastal liberals.

headline: New Directors/New Films Video: Laura Poitras
text: “The Oath,” directed by Laura Poitras, looks inside the life of Abu Jandal, a Yemeni taxi driver who was once the bodyguard for Osama bin Laden. The film also peers deeper into United States government interrogation methods at Guantanamo and poses further questions about how America is handling terrorism in after 9/11. Ms. Poitras spoke about how she came to make a documentary involving Abu Jandal and Al Qaeda, when it wasn’t her original intention:

headline: Daring Acts and Hard Sells
text: It’s brash. It’s bold. It’s untamed. It’s the chaos of merchandising that swallows visitors entering Madison Square Garden to see “FUNundrum!,” the new offering from Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus. While the show turns out to be the best the troupe has presented in years, to get to it you’ll have to fight through hawkers in the lobby, along the hallways and up and down the aisles, each insistent on selling you (or rather, your children) a reminder of an experience you haven’t yet had, with all the subtlety of an air horn blown into a megaphone.

headline: Weather Forecasters on Global Warming
text: April 7, 9:59 a.m. | Updated  The Colbert Report has weighed in on meteorology and climatology:

headline: Road Warriors Recruit for Military
text: The words “military business travel” may conjure up images of soldiers strapped in airplane cargo holds. But when recruiters for the four branches of the United States military go on business trips, it’s often hard to tell them apart from civilian travelers.

headline: The New Landscape of Health Care
text: Tuesday’s special section in Science Times helps you make sense of the health care overhaul.

headline: Making Some Hits From 1500 Sound Fresh Again
text: The Tallis Scholars have long been stars in the world of early music. The group’s performance on Friday evening at St. Bartholomew’s Church on Park Avenue, conducted by Peter Phillips, showcased this choir at its luminous best.

headline: Will the Moscow Attacks Help Putin?
text: “The terrorists will be destroyed,” Prime Minister Vladimir Putin of Russia vowed on Monday, after two female suicide bombers set off blasts that killed dozens in two Moscow subway stations at rush hour.

headline: When Styles Converge and Diverge
text: Watching pieces by choreographers who have all worked with an influential mentor is a little like seeing a family. In a certain light, or at a certain angle, in the way a head tilts or someone stands, you spot the resemblances clearly. At other moments independence prevails.

headline: At Hyundai, New Models — and a New Marketing Boss
text: The coming New York auto show  —  officially, the New York International Auto Show, April 2 to 11 at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center — is bringing automotive executives from around the world to peddle their wares in New York City. Among them is the newest marketing executive at a major marque, Christopher J. Perry of Hyundai Motor America.

headline: E.P.A. Delays Plants’ Pollution Permits
text: WASHINGTON -  The Environmental Protection Agency said Monday that it would not require power plants or other industrial sites to obtain federal pollution permits for emitting greenhouse gases before next January.

headline: Learning More About the New Law
text: Now that Congress has adopted the big health care legislation, a lot of people are looking for more information about the bill in hopes of figuring out what it means for them, or how their members of Congress voted.

headline: ‘Addams Family’ Has Another $1 Million Week
text: The new Broadway musical “The Addams Family” grossed more than $1 million last week for the third week in a row, a strong showing for a production that is still in preview performances – spurring stage whispers along the Rialto that the Nathan Lane-Bebe Neuwirth musical might be critic-proof (at least as long as the two stars are in it).

headline: Critics' Picks: 'Singin' in the Rain'
text: A. O. Scott looks back at the 1952 musical.

headline: Park Place
text: Inserting a new house into a once-industrial neighborhood isn't always an easy task. Designing something exponentially fancier than its surroundings makes no sense, but going the faux-former-factory route is just as bad. Luke Ogrydziak and Zoe Prillinger of Ogrydziak/Prillinger Architects, a 10-year-old San Francisco firm, navigated a graceful middle ground in their design for this 6,000 square-foot, three-story house and private art gallery in the city's South of Market district. Its plain, rugged materials, elegant proportions and openness to its surroundings make it an asset to its setting -but a suitably unobtrusive one.

headline: Musicians Without Borders
text: KNOXVILLE, Tenn.  Combining the essences of different kinds of music used to be a stroke of creativity. Now it’s almost a rule of commerce. The word eclecticism has been used so much for the last 30 years that it has become meaningless  a sad, grasping pile of obstruents and sibilants, like a dying fire’s last pops and hisses.

headline: ‘All About Me’ to Close Sunday
text: The new Broadway musical “All About Me,” in which pianist Michael Feinstein and entertainer Dame Edna Everage have dueling acts on stage, will close this Sunday after 27 preview performances and 20 regular performances.

headline: 6 Teenagers Are Charged After Classmate’s Suicide
text: It is not clear what some students at South Hadley High School expected to achieve by subjecting a freshman to the relentless taunting described by a prosecutor and classmates.

headline: Local Agglomeration
text: Aha. I have to give a talk in a couple of weeks at the American Association of Geographers, and found myself thinking of a sign one sees while driving into New York. I was researching the history of the North New Jersey embroidery industry, and discovered that someone has a Flickr picture.

headline: Alstom at Center of Web of Bribery Inquiries
text: The detention last week of three executives at the British unit of the French industrial giant Alstom was the latest in a tangle of investigations regarding possible bribes paid by the conglomerate to secure contracts around the world, according to investigators in several countries.

headline: Critics’ Picks Video: ‘Singin’ in the Rain’
text: A. O. Scott gets a glorious feeling when he looks back on “Singin’ in the Rain” in Critics’ Picks this week. The film, which takes place during Hollywood’s transition out of the silent era, is best known for its musical numbers. It’s made up of “one showstopper after another,” Mr. Scott says. “The lyrics are witty, the music is beautiful, the choreography is spectacular,” he continues. Please share your thoughts about “Singin’ in the Rain.” Do you consider it one of the best musicals ever made?

headline: Oak Hill Investment Names Managing Partner
text: Oak Hill Investment Management said Monday that it had hired Mark J.P. Anson as a managing partner and chairman of its investment committee.

headline: Space Invaders
text: We are aboard the spaceship Kaleidoscope, leaving the earth’s orbit at warp speed as intergalactic flight attendants comfort the giddy and slightly disoriented passengers. The rocket’s engines rumble, the earth simulation rooms are readied for the homesick, and bubbles pour forth from the ceiling. Welcome to “Flight 18,”  a free-spirited experimental theater piece and joyride.

headline: For Filmmaker, Ethiopia’s Struggle Is His Own
text: WASHINGTON  Among the courses Haile Gerima teaches at Howard University is one called “Film and Social Change.” But for Mr. Gerima, an Ethiopian director and screenwriter who has lived here since the 1970s in what he calls self-exile, that subject is not just an academic concern: it is also what motivates him to make films with African and African-American themes.

headline: Don’t Be Narrow-Minded
text: Via Brad DeLong, I see that Greg Mankiw seems to favor narrow banking: require banks to hold all their deposits in liquid, short-term assets, thus obviating the risk of financial crises.

headline: Ears Looking at You
text: There is a cacaphony of headphones on the market, with choices that range from sleek in-ear to old-school on-ear, in materials from blingy crystal to crafty wood.

headline: Limits Eased on Pakistani Scientist
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — A Pakistani court on Monday eased some travel restrictions on Abdul Qadeer Khan, the scientist and pioneer of Pakistan’s nuclear arsenal who admitted six years ago that he had been running an illicit proliferation network. But the court maintained a prohibition on news interviews with him about his past nuclear activities, according to lawyers involved in the case.

headline: Mad as Hell and Ready to Fight the Gods
text: There are few good guys in Greek mythology. Or good gods, for that matter. One of the great motifs of the ancients was that the gods were just as, uh, human, as the rest of us. In fact they are generally less moral than humans because they have been corrupted by their power.

headline: Greece Raises $6.7 Billion in Bond Sale
text: Just days after European Union leaders agreed to stand behind Greece as it struggled to restore its public finances, the authorities in Athens put their new guarantee to the test Monday, selling 5 billion euros of seven-year bonds to refinance debt, The New York Times’s David Jolly reports.

headline: Has Viral Gone Viral?
text: Over the last year, we’ve seen the rapid development of the real-time Web, incorporating the spread of news, status updates and the entertainment we share and consume. It’s as if the idea of “going viral” has, well, gone viral itself.

headline: S.E.C. Questions Wall St. Firms About Accounting
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission is questioning Wall Street firms about whether they employed accounting strategies like those that Lehman Brothers was accused of using to hide leverage, Bloomberg News reports.

headline: Report Conveys Despair’s Reign in a Torn Haiti
text: “The Quake” makes its debut on PBS’s “Frontline” on Tuesday night, only two and a half months after the earthquake that pulverized parts of Haiti. Reported by Martin Smith, it’s an intelligent, conscientious, elegantly produced throwing up of the hands.

headline: Common Sense and Insider Trading
text: Two years ago, I wrote about Oleksandr Dorozhko and an opinion by a federal judge who thought he should be allowed to keep his ill-gotten gains:

headline: Repo Men, Exposed?
text: The S.E.C.’s division of corporate finance appears to have read that huge report on Lehman Brothers. And now it wants to know if Lehman’s repo game was common.

headline: A New Chance to Strengthen an Eroding Bond
text: At a wedding recently, I met a woman, a freelance photographer in her early 40s. She was intrigued by my work as a doctor and began asking me questions related to her own health. When she showed me a picture of herself with her four children, I realized why. This gaunt woman had lost almost 20 pounds in the month since the photo had been taken and, despite efforts to stop the weight loss, was still losing more.

headline: What We’re Reading: iPad Fanboys and Facebook Likeboys
text: The clickstream of the Times technology journalists is overflowing like a New York storm sewer:

headline: Televised Debates Come to British Politics
text: A half century after John F. Kennedy and Richard M. Nixon squared off on the small screen, this year British politicians are going head to head in live televised debates for the first time ever ahead of an election.

headline: Icahn Defends His Lions Gate Bid as Fair
text: The billionaire investor Carl C. Icahn shot back again at Lions Gate Entertainment on Monday for rejecting his $6-a-share takeover offer, telling Reuters that the bid was a fair price and that the only reason that the movie studio’s stock has been trading above $6 was because of him.

headline: Judge Invalidates Human Gene Patent
text: A federal judge on Monday struck down patents on two genes linked to breast and ovarian cancer. The decision, if upheld, could throw into doubt the patents covering thousands of human genes and reshape the law of intellectual property

headline: Somalis Protest Against Shabab in Mogadishu
text: MOGADISHU, Somalia - Hundreds of enraged protesters marched through the streets of Mogadishu on Monday to protest against the Shabab, a militant Islamist insurgent group, in one of the largest demonstrations in recent years.

headline: Mets Considering Feliciano for Setup Role
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Manager Jerry Manuel dropped a big hint Monday that Pedro Feliciano could become the Mets’ eighth-inning setup man. He said Feliciano, who has been almost unhittable this spring, was among the candidates, which was not exactly a declaration. But then Manuel made sure reporters knew that he told them something fairly important.

headline: Twin Bombings in Moscow
text: Suicide bombers at two subway stations killed dozens in central Moscow during rush hour Monday.

headline: British Candidates Debate Hard Choices on Finances
text: LONDON — All three agreed, at least, that things were going to be tough and that hard choices and painful cuts would have to be made. But none of them — not Alistair Darling, the chancellor of the Exchequer, nor the two men who hope to succeed him, George Osborne of the Conservative Party and Vince Cable of the Liberal Democrats — ventured to say exactly where and when the cuts would come.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,016 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans:

headline: CNN Fails to Stop Fall in Ratings
text: CNN continued what has become a precipitous decline in ratings for its prime-time programs in the first quarter of 2010, with its main hosts losing almost half their viewers in a year.

headline: Early Diagnoses of the New Law
text: Love it or hate it, the health care overhaul is the most significant piece of domestic legislation to emerge from Washington in decades. The new law is also ferociously complex: the original Senate bill, which served as the blueprint for most of the changes, ran well over 2,000 pages.

headline: Lack of Video Slows Hunt for a Killer in the Subway
text: While there were some conflicting witness accounts, the police believe the man who fatally stabbed two others with a knife during a subway brawl early Sunday morning fled the train at the Christopher Street station.

headline: In New York, Salvation Is Not Nigh. Our Messiahs Just Aren’t Up for It.
text: A custom observed at Passover Seders on Monday night involved filling a cup of wine for the prophet Elijah and opening the front door to usher him in. Tradition holds that Elijah is a harbinger of the Messiah. As such, his arrival is fervently awaited. Among Jews, it has been awaited for a good many centuries. If waiting were an occupation, believing Jews could enjoy enviable job security.

headline: A Standout Player Who Is Happy Blending In
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — For the first time in Jason Bay’s recollection, perhaps in his entire career, he was roundly booed. It happened here March 11, when the Mets played the Red Sox and many of the Boston fans in attendance chose to express their displeasure with Bay’s decision to leave the Red Sox with a sustained, grumbling boo when he came to the plate.

headline: A Lawyer Rejoins a Cause That First Gripped Her 70 Years Ago
text: Ileta Green woke up Monday morning feeling anxious and dizzy, but when she arrived at the Supreme Court building in Brooklyn, she felt the pressure dissipate. There, waiting for her by the foreclosure settlement room on the third floor, was Shirley Adelson Siegel, a small 91-year-old woman in a silk scarf and a brown leather cap. “Hello, dear,” Ms. Siegel said, smiling at Ms. Green. “You’re looking well.”

headline: Companies Push to Repeal Provision of Health Law
text: An association representing 300 large corporations urged President Obama and Congress on Monday to repeal a provision of the health care overhaul that prompted AT&T, Caterpillar and other companies to announce substantial charges for the current quarter.

headline: A Back Hall Where Rules Are Ignored
text: ALBANY — The sign just outside the door to the State Assembly chamber’s back hallway could not be clearer. “All lobbyists must use east entrance to chamber,” it reads, adding, “This is west side.”

headline: Teenager Testifies About Attacking Latinos for Sport
text: RIVERHEAD, N.Y. — It was a Friday night in November 2008, and three Long Island teenagers looking for something to do ended up talking about going “beaner hopping.”

headline: He Opened a Door and Found a Long Career
text: In the nearly 50 years since 460 East 79th Street was built, the doors have been replaced. The doorman has not. Steve Keschl first opened the doors there in a professional capacity in June 1960, when he was 33 and the building was newly completed. Today, Mr. Keschl is 83, and he is still a doorman at the 20-story tower, now a condominium building. The lobby has two chairs, but Mr. Keschl does not sit in them, neither during his five-day-a-week shift nor during two interviews. He said it wouldn’t look right.

headline: S.E.C. Looks at Wall St. Accounting
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission said on Monday it had started an inquiry into about two dozen financial companies to determine whether they followed accounting practices similar to those recently disclosed in an investigation of Lehman Brothers.

headline: Former Cabdriver Pleads Guilty in Crash That Killed Rider
text: A former New York taxi driver admitted on Monday that he had stopped taking his medication and had a seizure just before the cab he was driving crashed nearly four years ago, killing a 20-year-old Pace University student who was a passenger.

headline: Ex-I.B.M Executive Pleads Guilty to Fraud in Galleon Trading Case
text: A former I.B.M. senior executive pleaded guilty on Monday to providing confidential information about Advanced Micro Devices and Lenovo to a hedge fund consultant accused of participating in a wide-ranging insider trading scheme.

headline: Bloggingheads: Neurowar
text: John Horgan, left, of the Stevens Center for Science Writings and George Johnson, author of “The Ten Most Beautiful Experiments,” debate applying neuroscience to warfare.

headline: New York Is Denied Grant of $700 Million for Schools
text: Among the 16 finalists for the competitive federal education grant known as Race to the Top, New York came in second to last on Monday, leaving the state out of the money but with plenty of blame to spread around.

headline: Williamsburg Building Collapse Injures 4
text: A three-story brick building in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, that was being renovated collapsed on Monday afternoon, critically injuring a worker who was trapped in the rubble and leaving three other people with minor injuries, the Fire Department and witnesses said.

headline: Woods Fuels Minor Surge in Masters Ticket Prices
text: When Tiger Woods declared on March 16 that he would emerge from golf hibernation at the Masters, Dalton Daves of Little Rock, Ark., was offering four tickets to next Wednesday’s final practice round on eBay for $1,400.

headline: New E.P.A. Scrutiny Is Set for a Chemical in Plastics
text: WASHINGTON — The Environmental Protection Agency plans to add bisphenol-A, or BPA, a plastic widely used in food packaging and plastic bottles, to its list of chemicals of concern because of potential adverse impacts on the environment and human and animal health.

headline: Iraqi Ex-Premier Looks to Past in Fighting Critics
text: BAGHDAD — Ayad Allawi has seldom spoken publicly about the night more than 30 years ago when a pair of ax-wielding assassins turned his London bedroom into an abattoir.

headline: Spurt of Home Buying as End of Tax Credit Looms
text: DES MOINES — Nine hundred days after putting their house on the market, Andrew and Jane Palestini were beginning to think they might be stuck in Iowa forever.

headline: Counting the ‘Blessings’ of Insomnia
text: Drip, drip, drip — that’s what insomniac thoughts feel like, a leaky faucet behind the eyes. Last night the ideas were plinking; forehead-pounding regrets over past deeds, horrid fantasies, car crashes of expectations, unrealizable longings. It’s sheer torture. I don’t deserve it! Drip: Or maybe I do.

headline: A Club With a Hollywood Tint
text: WEST HOLLYWOOD, Calif. — It is, admittedly, a rare occasion when the phrase “understated elegance” shares space in the same review as “half-naked girl hanging from a net across the ceiling.” But these sorts of descriptions appear in tandem in a number of reviews of Voyeur, the high-priced, bondage-themed club where the Republican National Committee spent nearly $2,000 in February, according to Federal Election Commission filings.

headline: A Guiding Voice Amid the Ruins of a Capital City
text: MOGADISHU, Somalia — A veiled female journalist (who also happens to be wearing a snug denim skirt) sits in a soundproof studio with a fuzzy microphone in front of her face.

headline: The Time to Let Moore Be Moore
text: DAYTON, Ohio — When Connecticut’s Maya Moore committed early defensive lapses against Iowa State, Coach Geno Auriemma said nothing. When she committed a clumsy offensive foul, he stood with his arms folded, mute.

headline: For Star Power, Look to Bench, Not the Court
text: INDIANAPOLIS — When savvy coaches break down an N.C.A.A. tournament they always recommend picking the team with the most sure-fire N.B.A. draft picks. Recently, North Carolina won national titles in 2005 and 2009 with future N.B.A. stars.

headline: Get on Your Dancing Shoes
text: We're usually quick to delete the e-mail promotions we get from the many different tourism boards  that's true even for you, Alaska House  but we couldn't resist this one from the Singaporeans. From noon to 5 p.m. today, Matt Harding, the viral video celebrity known for dancing in front of major landmarks around the world, will be in Times Square for a flash dance in support of Singapore's travel board. Join him in an impromptu groove-fest. Participants can also record their own dance moves on video and enter them into a contest with the chance to win an all-expenses-paid trip to the country.

headline: Remembering McQueen
text: Armadillo heels made famous by Lady Gaga, plumed dresses covered in gold leaf, and a final collection that was a "vision of Gothic glory." The death of Alexander McQueen was a major loss for the fashion world. Pay tribute to the designer by visiting Housing Works Thrift Shop in Hell's Kitchen today. The store's window displays will feature a selection of over 30 gowns and accessories by Mr. McQueen in a silent auction. Bidding for the clothes began on March 29 and runs through April 11.

headline: Keep It Rockin’
text: "Anyone who didn't make it to the musical smorgasbord of South by Southwest this month can still benefit from one of its byproducts: post-festival tour routing," writes Ben Sisario. "Many of the 2,000 or so bands that passed through Austin, Tex., for SXSW stay on the road, playing shows for gas money home or as part of a continuing tour. Tonight check out Micachu and the Shapes, featuring Mica Levi, "a British music-school survivor who makes fascinating, fractured post-post-punk out of little chunks of noise pollution. The band was one of the breakout acts at South by Southwest in 2009; it's a sign of how fast things move that there was no need to return." He'll be at Le Poisson Rouge at 6:30 p.m.

headline: Berlusconi’s Coalition Makes Gains in Italy Regional Vote
text: MILAN — Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi’s center-right coalition made significant and unexpected gains Monday in regional elections that called some 40 million Italians to the polls, wresting four regions from the opposition.

headline: State Debt Woes Grow Too Big to Camouflage
text: California, New York and other states are showing many of the same signs of debt overload that recently took Greece to the brink — budgets that will not balance, accounting that masks debt, the use of derivatives to plug holes, and armies of retired public workers who are counting on benefits that are proving harder and harder to pay.

headline: A Quiet and Steady Hand at the Controls for Duke
text: HOUSTON — Jon Scheyer has an undisputed reputation among his Duke teammates for being a clutch performer in football and in soccer.

headline: R.N.C. Dismisses Aide Over Outing to Club
text: A Republican Party spokesman said Monday evening that a staff member has been dismissed following a February outing to a risqué Hollywood nightclub, where a party donor submitted a $2,000 tab and asked for reimbursement from the Republican National Committee

headline: Afghan Leader Is Seen to Flout Influence of U.S.
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — This month, with President Hamid Karzai looking ahead to a visit to the White House, he received a terse note from aides to President Obama: Your invitation has been revoked.

headline: The Issue of Liquidity Bubbles Up
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Sabathia Opts for Afternoon Game and the Chance to Hit
text: TAMPA, Fla. — On a typical split-squad day, a veteran starting pitcher gets to choose where he would prefer to pitch. If the games fall as they will on Tuesday, when the Yankees play Atlanta in Lake Buena Vista in the afternoon and face Toronto at Steinbrenner Field at night, most pitchers will probably take the home game over the 90-minute bus ride up Interstate 4.

headline: Teixeira Leaves Game After Taking Pitch on the Elbow
text: Baltimore Orioles starter Jeremy Guthrie hit Mark Teixeira on the right elbow with a pitch in the second inning of the Yankees’ 11-7 victory on Monday.

headline: How TV Makers Are Selling the Idea of 3-D at Home
text: THE consumer electronics world thrives on the latest new thing. And this year that would be 3-D. It was once considered a quirky technology gone nowhere, but, because of the popularity of “Avatar,” television makers now are racing to bring multidimensional viewing to the living room.

headline: President Obama in Kabul
text: President Obama’s visit to Afghanistan on Sunday was a long overdue, and desperately needed, attempt to persuade President Hamid Karzai to clean up his act.

headline: An Education Basic
text: Nearly 600,000 students in the New York City area take the bus or subway to school. For years, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority has given most of them three free rides per school day. With the transit agency facing severe budget deficits and paring staff and services, it has threatened to eliminate all student passes. Officials say it would save $214 million a year.

headline: Lehman Says Debtor Claims May Decline
text: Lehman Brothers Holdings, which has been reviewing demands from creditors for payment, said in a regulatory filing on Monday that unsecured claims might fall to $260 billion as it rejects inappropriate claims.

headline: Physical Reactions
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — I mentioned Elizabeth Gorski’s name yesterday. Here she is with today’s puzzle, with what I like to think of as an Olympics theme. You know, the “Cops, in slang” thing. I can’t tell if that’s funny or not. For heaven’s sake, do not click here to listen to that theme song. It will take days to get the tune out of your head.

headline: Godfather of iPod Severs Final Ties With Apple
text: An era is formally ending at Apple. Tony Fadell, one of the creators of the iPod and iPhone, is breaking off his nine-year affiliation with Steve Jobs & Co.

headline: Regulators Reject a Drug Maker’s Plan to Use Its Alertness Pill to Overcome Jet Lag
text: Air travelers for now may have to rely on coffee instead of a wonder drug to help them function in new time zones.

headline: Corrections
text: An article in some editions on Sunday about a Tea Party Express rally in Nevada at which several speakers denounced Democrats for portraying Tea Party members as angry and violent paraphrased incorrectly from comments by one speaker who said that he doubted an account of how Representative John Lewis was treated during a Tea Party rally outside the Capitol recently. The speaker said he did not believe that protesters had shouted racial epithets at Mr. Lewis; he did not say the account was about protesters spitting at the congressman. (A spokesman for Representative Emanuel Cleaver II of Missouri said Mr. Cleaver had been spat on by a protester outside the Capitol. )

headline: Corrections
text: A Congressional Memo article on Thursday about the decision by Democrats to pass a health care bill that did not include the government-run insurance plan known as the public option misstated the number of new customers that private health insurance companies are expected to gain under the new law. It is 16 million, not 30 million. (The Congressional Budget Office estimates that about 30 million to 32 million uninsured people will be covered by the new law.)

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Wednesday about a new study on traffic patterns in Manhattan based on data gathered by GPS devices on cabs referred imprecisely to the holidays that were excluded from calculations to determine the weekday with the fastest traffic during the period studied. While federal holidays were excluded, not all holidays were. (Yom Kippur, which was on Monday, Sept. 28, 2009, was included in the study. The report ranked that date as the weekday with the fastest traffic.)

text: March 29, 2010

headline: The Sandra Bullock Trade
text: Two things happened to Sandra Bullock this month. First, she won an Academy Award for best actress. Then came the news reports claiming that her husband is an adulterous jerk. So the philosophic question of the day is: Would you take that as a deal? Would you exchange a tremendous professional triumph for a severe personal blow?

headline: Moscow Under Attack
text: Moscow

headline: ‘Alive, Alive’
text: Moscow

headline: Right of Passage
text: A Mississippi school board was grossly discriminatory and mean-spirited when it told Constance McMillen that she could not attend her high school prom with her girlfriend. A ruling by a federal judge that Ms. McMillen’s constitutional rights had been violated is a welcome sign that gay people are continuing to make progress toward equality. It should also be a warning to school districts nationwide about the cost of discrimination.

text: To the Editor:
