text: To the Editor:

headline: 3 Officers Seek to Add Defendant in Abuse Lawsuit
text: Lawyers for three police officers named in a civil rights lawsuit by a man alleging sexual abuse filed a motion on Monday in federal court in Brooklyn that seeks to make an officer likely to testify against them a defendant in the case as well.

headline: Corrections
text: An article last Wednesday about the sale of commercial properties on Fire Island misstated the role that John Whyte, a previous owner of the properties, played in the Pavilion, a discotheque that was included in the recent sale. Mr. Whyte bought the Pavilion in the late 1980s; he did not build it in 1981.

headline: Two Springs
text: Lately, I’ve been studying celestial navigation, the seafaring kind that requires a sextant, a chronometer, and a nautical almanac. It’s a way of adding a little trigonometry to a life that’s mostly addition and subtraction.

headline: Is Social Security Ripe for Reform, Too?
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Magic Potion
text: With the marathon effort to overhaul the health care system behind us, it is time for the Obama administration to move quickly and powerfully to the monumental task of putting Americans back to work.

headline: Parking Rules for Passover
text: Because of the first and second days of Passover, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended on Tuesday and Wednesday in New York City. Other regulations remain in effect.

headline: Originally a Yankee, Thames Eagerly Pursues a Return
text: SARASOTA, Fla. — Every winter, Marcus Thames begins his off-season training by watching the same videotape for inspiration.

headline: Corrections
text: A picture caption in some editions on Monday with an article about Duke’s victory over Baylor on Sunday in the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament gave an incorrect identification from The Associated Press in some copies for the Duke player shown celebrating with a raised fist. He is Andre Dawkins  not Nolan Smith, a teammate. (A photograph of Smith appeared in other editions.)

headline: Even in Distant Lands, the Welcomes Are Warm
text: UNTIL the age of 18, I never traveled outside of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. But in the last four decades, I’ve clocked more than two million miles and have been in more than 120 countries. Last year, I was in South Africa, Zambia, Cambodia, Vietnam, India, Sri Lanka, Nepal and Bangladesh, all countries in which Room to Read has programs.

headline: Corrections
text: A report in the “Arts, Briefly” column on Monday about the cancellation of a production of Terrence McNally’s play “Corpus Christi,” which features a gay, Jesus-like figure, at Tarleton State University in Texas, misstated the name of a newspaper that reported on the cancellation along with The Austin Chronicle. It is The Fort Worth Star-Telegram, not The Austin Star-Ledger. (There is no Austin newspaper with that name.) The report also referred incorrectly to the distance between Stephenville, Tex., where Tarleton State is located, and Austin. They are about 140 miles apart; Stephenville is not “near” Austin.

headline: Corrections
text: A listing of Easter concerts in some copies on Friday misstated the given name of the music director of a choral concert at Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York on Good Friday. He is Mitchell Crawford, not Michael.

headline: Company That Owns ‘American Idol’ Is Planning a Sale to a Private Equity Group
text: The “American Idol” television brand may soon be in the hands of private equity.

headline: Corrections
text: Two pictures in the “Living Here” listings in the Escapes pages on Friday were reversed. The yellow house pictured at the bottom is the five-bedroom house in Woodstock, Vt., listed for $2,395,000. The brown house shown above it is the four-bedroom house in Floyd, Va., listed at $995,000.

headline: Corrections
text: NATIONAL

headline: Tenth Victory Means Nets Are Bad, Not Historic
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — History will reflect that the Nets of 2009-10 are bad. It will also now reflect that they are not the worst team in N.B.A. history.

headline: Jazz Gains From Every Knicks Loss
text: SALT LAKE CITY — Six years ago, the Utah Jazz made a fairly inconsequential trade with the Phoenix Suns that will, at long last, produce a consequential result and another cringe-worthy moment for Knicks fans.Call it the final stanza of the Stephon Marbury curse.

headline: Citigroup Exit May Be Profitable
text: Uncle Sam is ready to get out of Citi. The Treasury is set to sell its 27 percent stake in Citigroup about two years after rescuing it.

headline: To Afghanistan, in Darkness and Secrecy
text: Something had come up, I told my visiting guests on Friday. I’d unexpectedly been detailed to cover a political story and would not be able to join them for the rest of the weekend.

headline: Lehman Brothers Objects to Billions in Claims
text: Lehman Brothers Holdings said Monday it believes that claims from creditors against its bankruptcy estate should be cut to $605 billion, according to a document filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: News Quiz | March 30, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page.

headline: St. John’s Set to Hire Lavin as Its Coach
text: The seemingly endless St. John’s men’s basketball coaching search appears close to completion. The university is poised to hire the former U.C.L.A. coach Steve Lavin. The two sides met Monday for several hours in Manhattan and were optimistic about completing a deal.

headline: Rare Struggles for Argentine Powers
text: Two of the most popular teams in Argentina — River Plate and Boca Juniors — and their legions of frenzied fans are not a happy bunch these days.

headline: MaxLinear Closes Initial Public Offering
text: MaxLinear said Monday that it closed its initial public offering of more than 6.4 million shares at a price of $14 per share, The Associated Press reported.

text: Five games on Monday, including a perfect pair of results for the 10th-place Rangers as No. 9 Atlanta and No. 8 Boston both lose. Home teams listed first:

headline: Corrections
text: A theater entry in the Listings pages on Friday about “Love Is My Sin,” which is in previews at the Duke on 42nd Street and opens on Thursday, misstated the number of Shakespeare’s sonnets adapted for the work by the director Peter Brook. It is 31, not 29.

headline: The Issue of Liquidity Bubbles Up
text: Conspicuously absent from any regulatory legislation floating around Capitol Hill is the precise level of capital that banks should hold for every dollar they lend, called a capital ratio, The New York Times’s Andrew Ross Sorkin writes from Washington in his latest DealBook column.

headline: UBS Said to Generate $2.3 Billion on Fixed-Income Unit
text: UBS generated about $2.3 billion of revenue at its fixed-income division in the first quarter as Switzerland’s biggest bank rebuilt the unit following record losses, people with knowledge of the situation told Bloomberg News.

headline: Blasts Could Derail Medvedev’s Softer Tack in the Caucasus
text: MOSCOW — When two bombs ripped through Moscow subway stations at rush hour on Monday morning, Russia’s leaders reached for the kind of hunt-them-down-and-kill-them statements that propelled the country through two brutal wars in the Caucasus.

headline: Word of the Day | sententious
text: sententious •\sen-ˈten(t)-shəs\• adjective

headline: WaMu II: Resurrected on a Tax Break
text: Washington Mutual, the biggest bank failure in history, may have a second life after bankruptcy.

headline: Bharti Deal Approaches, but Trips on Gabon
text: Bharti Airtel‘s $9 billion expansion into Africa faced a potential new hurdle on Monday as the government of Gabon raised a regulatory objection to the deal, Reuters reported.

headline: The Neue Look
text: Renée Price, the director of the Neue Galerie, devotes almost as much time to the museum’s shop as she does to the museum’s exhibition program. She’s drawn to ‘‘things I would like in my own home,’’ and gets ideas everywhere: in the shower, at meals (a recent breakfast hatched a Bauhaus-style egg cup) and at cocktail parties. ‘‘I’m always looking for ways to reinterpret the amazing things in our collection.’’ More…

headline: Lloyds Chief Could Stay for Another Year
text: The Lloyds Banking Group will keep Eric Daniels as its chief executive for at least another 12 months, The Financial Times reported. This statement comes despite the recent commencement by Sir Win Bischoff, the bank’s chairman, of an “emergency succession plan” for the C.E.O.’s role.

headline: BlogTalkRadio Pockets $1.9 Million
text: BlogTalkRadio, a site that allows users to create free talk radio podcasts and listen to talk radio shows, has landed $1.9 million in a second round of funding, TechCrunch reported.

headline: V.C.’s Answer Yes to Quora
text: Quora, a start-up that offers a collection of Q&A’s that can be edited by users, has nabbed $11 million in a first round of funding, PaidContent reported.

headline: Why Is This Seder Different From All Other Seders?
text: WHO has attended the Passover seders in the Obama White House?

headline: Warren Says to Expect Commercial Real Estate Trouble
text: Elizabeth Warren, head of Congressional oversight for TARP and a major backer of the idea of a consumer protection agency, told CNBC on Monday that the U.S. economy still had a hard road ahead.

headline: Glamazon Grandmothers & the Twiggy Effect
text: Glamorous, fashion-following grannies.

headline: Primerica 1 of 4 I.P.O.’s Set for This Week
text: Citigroup‘s spinoff of its Primerica unit, a commission-based network of independent sales representatives selling life insurance and investment products, is one of four companies expected to go public this week, as the market for initial public offerings appears positioned for a comeback, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Do You Socialize More Virtually Than in Reality?
text: Some experts in child development and others have observed that spontaneous play and “childhood culture,” including games that have been passed down from generation to generation, are disappearing. What do you think about this?

headline: Jupiter Star Puts Half His Fund In Cash
text: Philip Gibbs, Jupiter Financial‘s high-profile investor in financial stocks, has put more than half his fund into cash as uncertainty around the U.K. election and western governments debt hamper visibility, Reuters reported.

headline: Investec Seeks to Buy Rest of Rensburg
text: Investec, the South African specialist banking group, has agreed to pay around £218 million ($328 million) to buy the 53 percent stake in Rensburg Sheppards that it doesn’t already own, The Financial Times reported.

headline: D.S.M. Sells Fertilizer Arm for $418 Million
text: Royal D.S.M., the Dutch chemicals company, says it will sell its fertilizer and melamine businesses to Egypt’s Orascom Construction Industries for 310 million euros ($418 million), The Associated Press reported.

headline: Iranian Diplomat in Pakistan Is Freed
text: LONDON — An Iranian diplomat seized by gunmen in a little-known 2008 case in northwest Pakistan has been freed by Iranian agents “after complex intelligence operations,” state-run Iranian television reported on Tuesday without describing in detail how the envoy was released.

headline: RDG Capital Said to Sweeten Offer for Benihana
text: RDG Capital, a New York Investment firm led by Russell Glass, has sweetened its offer for Benihana, the Japanese steak house chain founded by Rocky Aoki, The New York Post reported.

headline: Citi Exit Will Profit U.S., but Bank Still Needs Work
text: Uncle Sam is ready to get out of Citi. The Treasury is set to sell its 27 percent stake in Citigroup about two years after rescuing it.

headline: Optimism About Recovery Lifts Shares
text: A brighter outlook for the American consumer and signs that foreign debt troubles were easing helped propel Wall Street higher on Monday, The New York Times’s Javier C. Hernandez reported.

headline: China Said to Execute Thousands in ’09
text: HONG KONG — China executed more people last year than the rest of the world combined, according to a report published Tuesday by Amnesty International.

headline: State of the Eagles: What the 2009 Film Revealed
text: Offense

headline: Grand Prix Circuit Returns to Istanbul
text: “A rolling, moving, flowing, twisting, cool track.” That’s how the racing writer Brad Spurgeon, who writes for The Times’s Formula One blog, describes the Istanbul leg of the Grand Prix season.

headline: AXA and NAB Advance on $12 Billion Australia Deal
text: One of the biggest acquisitions in Asia this year cleared a crucial hurdle on Tuesday, as National Australia Bank secured the agreement of AXA for a deal that would effectively carve up the Asia-Pacific operations of the French insurance giant, Bettina Wassener reports in The New York Times.

headline: British Banks Face Refinancing Challenge, Fitch Says
text: Major British banks face a challenge to refinance more than £300 billion ($448.4 billion) of government-backed financing over the next two to three years, Fitch Ratings said in a report published on Monday.

headline: Fed Official Prescribes Global Approach on Banks
text: Not only does the financial reform bill fail to specify or raise capital requirements for large banks, it also does not address the systemic risk presented by their size,  said Richard W. Fisher, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas.

headline: Ungaro Owner Said to Hold Talks With Italian Financier
text: The owner of Emanuel Ungaro, the French fashion label suffering under a load of debt, recently held deal talks with Matteo Marzotto, an Italian financier, The New York Post reported.

headline: Teach Your Neighbors Well
text: Edward L. Glaeser is an economics professor at Harvard.

headline: Good Marks for Moyhihan at Bank of America
text: When Brian T. Moynihan agreed in December to step into the top spot at Bank of America, he had a challenge ahead of him: rebuilding Bank of America’s image after a year marred by a taxpayer bailout and lawsuits by shareholders unhappy with its acquisition of Merrill Lynch, not to mention the task of regaining the trust of clients and raising morale among its beleaguered bankers.

headline: R.B.S. Fined for Sharing Price Data
text: Royal Bank of Scotland has been fined £28.6 million ($43 million) for violating competition laws by sharing price data with Barclays, Britain’s Office of Fair Trading said on Tuesday.

headline: Ireland Set to Announce Bad Bank Plans
text: Finance Minister Brian Lenihan of Ireland will set out his plans on Tuesday to free the country’s banks of troubled real estate loans and revive the financial system, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Private Equity Firms to Sit Down With Investors, Report Says
text: Executives of the Carlyle Group, TPG, Avenue Capital Group and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts are planning a meeting on Tuesday with investors who are seeking lower fees and more control over their investments, Bloomberg News reported, citing three people briefed on the gathering.

headline: In Dubai, Troubled Nakheel Names a New Board
text: A council overseeing the restructuring of Dubai’s chief conglomerate said on Tuesday that a new board had been named to lead the deeply indebted Dubai World property development unit Nakheel through its restructuring, The Associated Press reports.

headline: Q&A: Recharging the Zune on the Road
text: Q.

headline: Can Using the Wrong Octane Fuel Lead to Disaster?
text: Last week, Gunnar Heinrich, who runs the site Automobiles De Luxe, wrote that a 2010 Cadillac SRX Turbo he had borrowed from General Motors for a review sustained serious internal damage during a test drive and that he had to be plucked from the side of a mountain road.

headline: Sampler: The Man Behind Software Evading Government Censors, and Tony the Tiger Is Pulled From a Moat
text: Debt Threatens the Future of States | California is among a handful of states showing signs of debt overload similar to the debt that took Greece to the brink. In California, the debt looks manageable on the surface — just 8 percent of the total economy — but that does not take into account the big unstated debts, like the shortfall in its biggest pension fund. If that is counted, the state’s debt burden quadruples to 37 percent of the economic output, according to estimates. [The New York Times]

headline: Speed Read for Tuesday, March 30
text: Here are some highlights from Tuesday’s edition of The New York Times:

headline: S. Korean President Visits Waters Where Ship Sank
text: SEOUL, South Korea — President Lee Myung-bak became the first South Korean head of state to visit the disputed western waters off the Korean Peninsula as he visited to urge rescuers on Tuesday to continue searching for 46 sailors believed to be trapped in a naval vessel that sank after a mysterious explosion four days earlier.

headline: The Hunger of Dustin Keller
text: Jets tight end Dustin Keller, who is a budding restaurateur, will write a food column once a month for the Fifth Down. He’ll also answer football questions from readers. Post your question in the comments section, and he’ll answer a sampling within a week. Dustin starts off with a look at one of his favorite restaurants in New York: Peter Luger Steakhouse in Brooklyn.

headline: The Chatty Effect
text: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style.

headline: The Chatty Effect
text: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style.

headline: Bloggers Assess the 2010 Mets, Part 2
text: As opening day draws near, The Times will be previewing the Yankees’ and Mets’ coming seasons from all angles, with analysis from Tyler Kepner, Ben Shpigel, David Waldstein and others. But with so much happening this off-season, there are a lot of opinions to go around. As we did last season, we have reached out to Yankees and Mets bloggers for their thoughts on the 2010 season.

headline: How I Found My New Office Space With Twitter
text: I started Backup My Info! from my small apartment on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. After signing up a few clients, I hired my first engineer who worked with me in my apartment. I worked from my bedroom desk, and he worked from my kitchen table. I removed all of the pictures from my walls and replaced them with white boards that we used for strategy sessions. My floors were lined with duct tape that I used to hide and secure the network cords that ran between the bedroom and the kitchen. That year, my revenue reached $20,000, which was less than half my engineer’s salary. Looking back, I’m not sure how we did it. But necessity is necessity, right?

headline: 2 Emirates Exchanges Are Discussing a Merger
text: Owners of the Abu Dhabi Securities Exchange and Dubai Financial Market are discussing a possible consolidation, Dubai Financial’s executive chairman, Essa Kazim, said on Tuesday, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Carbon Trading and the Great Recession
text: The recession brought with it a slowdown in industrial production, and that has translated into far fewer greenhouse gas emissions in 2009 than in previous years.

headline: European Collider Begins Its Subatomic Exploration
text: PASADENA, Calif. — After 16 years and $10 billion — and a long morning of electrical groaning and sweating — there was joy in the meadows and tunnels of the Swiss-French countryside Tuesday: the world’s biggest physics machine, the Large Hadron Collider, finally began to make subatomic particles collide.

headline: Greenpeace Takes Aim at Koch Industries
text: You’ll likely hear a lot about this today and in coming weeks. Greenpeace has unveiled a new report highlighting Koch Industries, one of the biggest industrial conglomerates you’ve probably never heard of.

headline: ‘Napoleon’ Star Departs Comedy Central Series
text: 9:32 a.m. | Updated Was it the 100-episode commitment? Representatives for Jon Heder, the “Napoleon Dynamite” star, said he had left a new Comedy Central series that was about to go into production, one that sported a pedigree of prominent comic talents and for which the cable channel had the option to order as many as 100 episodes.

headline: New York Falls Short in Race to the Top
text: New York came in second to last among the 16 finalists for the competitive federal education grant known as Race to the Top on Monday, leaving the state out of the money but with plenty of blame to spread around.

headline: The Early Word: Break Out the Pens
text: Another Tuesday, another bill signing.

headline: EBay Introduces a New Classifieds Site and More Mobile Apps
text: On Tuesday, eBay plans to unveil a new classifieds site, called eBayClassifieds, to replace its old site, Kijiji, in the United States. It will also introduce two new mobile apps, one for listing and selling items for sale and another for posting or searching classifieds. A third app, for the iPad, is to be released April 3.

headline: Bo Bo Bey Bo! Jeff Goldblum Scats!
text: You can keep your kiddie productions of “Scarface,” your anonymous ChatRoulette balladeers and your button-down network anchors slow-jamming the news. If there were any justice on the Internet, this clip of Jeff Goldblum, the “Law & Order: Criminal Intent” star and jazz pianist, leading the studio audience of “Late Night With Jimmy Fallon” in an impromptu scat session would be the viral video of the morning.

headline: Domesticities | Park Place
text: Inserting a new house into a once-industrial neighborhood isn’t always an easy task. Designing something exponentially fancier than its surroundings makes no sense, but going the faux-former-factory route is just as bad. Luke Ogrydziak and Zoe Prillinger of Ogrydziak/Prillinger Architects, a 10-year-old San Francisco firm, navigated a graceful middle ground in their design for this 6,000 square-foot, three-story house and private art gallery in the city’s South of Market district. Its plain, rugged materials, elegant proportions and openness to its surroundings make it an asset to its setting -but a suitably unobtrusive one.

headline: Wall Street Manages to Stay on Positive Side
text: Wall Street ended slightly higher on Tuesday as an energized technology sector helped offset worries about foreign debt.

headline: More New York Chefs Open in Las Vegas
text: Some chefs are still willing to bet on Las Vegas.

headline: Strauss-Kahn Says I.M.F. Would Dictate Greek Terms
text: The International Monetary Fund would lay down the terms of assistance it provides Greece, the managing director, Dominique Strauss-Kahn, told Bloomberg News, reflecting tensions with European leaders over a possible rescue.

headline: Mixed Report on January Home Prices
text: Housing prices are still inching up, but few analysts are presuming the trend will last.

headline: The Heresies of John Cassidy
text: Last week, Reihan Salam predicted the appearance, among left-of-center writers, of “thoughtful, honest assessments of flaws in the Affordable Health Care for America Act that were largely overlooked” during the beat-the-Republicans phase of the debate. Now John Cassidy, The New Yorker’s financial writer, has delivered an impressive two-part contribution to the genre. Cassidy supports the health care bill on moral grounds, but he has deep doubts about its fiscal sustainability. On this front, he makes two points that many right-of-center wonks have been hammering on for a while now. First, the individual mandate is “a bit of a sham,” and lots and lots of people will probably just pay the modest fine (or dodge it) until they get sick, at which point they’ll show up demanding their guaranteed insurance policy, sending costs skyrocketing. Second, the subsidies for the individual market are so much more generous than the existing tax deduction for employer-provided health care that employers will have an enormous incentive to offload their employees onto the new exchanges:

headline: Obama Defends Health Care Law
text: President Obama defended his health care program in an interview broadcast on Tuesday morning, portraying it as a “centrist approach” that Republicans are opposing mainly because they want “political benefit in November.”

headline: A Financial Crunch for Photojournalists Is Transforming the Profession
text: In an era of shrinking magazine and newspaper circulation and dwindling advertising revenues, among the hard hit professions is photojournalism. Long romanticized as a creative, exhilarating and peripatetic way of making a living, the life of today’s photojournalists is one of financial struggle and social deprivation. There are just not enough lucrative assignments out there.

headline: Key Bloomberg Aide to Leave City Hall
text: Updated, 12:01 p.m. | Edward Skyler, who managed much of New York City’s government over the last four years as Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s most powerful aide, plans to leave City Hall by the end of April, said a person told of his plans Tuesday morning.

headline: Director of Transgender Film Will Change Its Trailer
text: The director of “Ticked-Off Trannies With Knives,” a movie planned for the Tribeca Film Festival that has set off a war of words before being screened there, said he would amend its trailer so that it would not refer to real-life victims of violence.

headline: Bermuda Tourism Still Sluggish
text: The global recession is continuing to take a bite out of Bermuda tourism. The British territory’s government said that air arrivals in 2009 decreased almost 11 percent compared with the previous year.

headline: Ryanair Ends Cellphone Usage
text: Ryanair has suspended its on-board cellphone service after the Swiss company that provided the technology elected to terminate the contract, the airline said Monday. The service, which went live in February 2009, had enabled Ryanair passengers to make and receive voice calls and text messages on 50 of the airline’s fleet of 230 Boeing 737 planes.

headline: ‘Campaigning for Select Republicans’
text: Monologue |  Monday night on “Jimmy Kimmel Live” on ABC: Former Gov. Sarah Palin has been very busy. She’s been campaigning for select Republicans, including John McCain, who’s in the middle of a tough Senate race in Arizona. How does he introduce her? “And now, the young woman who cost me the presidency, Sarah Palin!”

headline: Tuesday Reading
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: ‘Transportation Trouble’
text: Monologue |  Monday night on “The Late Show With David Letterman” on CBS: Did you hear about this? President Obama, big surprise visit to see the folks in Afghanistan. Did you read all about that? That’s kind of exciting. It turns out he was shooting an episode of “Undercover Boss.”

headline: ‘Pretty Quick Trip’
text: Monologue |  Monday night on “The Tonight Show With Jay Leno” on NBC: President Obama made a surprise visit to Afghanistan this past weekend. I guess after the last 14 months in Washington, he wanted to go someplace where there was less fighting.

headline: London Dance Journal: Hurtling Monks and Other Unhappy Tricks
text: LONDON – Surely not since Bénédictine liqueur was invented at a medieval French monastery have monks produced anything so commercial as “Sutra.” It’s an hour of physical-theater silliness that could be exciting fun if it weren’t doused in solemnity and mystique. At the end the audience went wild while I rushed for fresh air.

headline: Tougher Emissions Rules for Ships Operating in North American Waters
text: The International Maritime Organization gave the final go ahead on Friday to a plan for creating a North American emissions control area extending 200 nautical miles from the coasts of the United States and Canada.

headline: Product Red Gives Marketing Students a Chance to Practice What They Study
text: A publisher is sponsoring a contest that will enable marketing students to put some of their studies to good use by suggesting a product that could be sold to help raise money to fight AIDS.

headline: Charlie Vergos, Memphis Barbecue King, Dies
text: Charlie Vergos, founder of the Rendezvous barbecue restaurant in Memphis, died on Saturday. He was 84.

headline: Financial Tuneup: What You Need to Shred
text: All of us need to take some time every so often to knock things off our financial to-do list. To help, we’ve created a series of articles and an interactive checklist to get you started.

headline: The Financial Times: A Newspaper With Good Business News — About Itself
text: On Monday, Decoder came across a rare sight in the wilds of Manhattan: a happy publishing executive.

headline: Economists Who Say “Ni!”
text: OK, it’s actually the economists who say “Inflation!” But isn’t it all too predictable that with almost 10 percent unemployment and ongoing disinflation — at this rate we could be looking at deflation in the core rate by next year — what the shadow open market committee is warning about is … inflation.

headline: Live From Tribeca, It’s ‘Saturday Night’
text: 3:40 p.m. | Updated The May 1 broadcast of “Saturday Night Live” may be a repeat, but it doesn’t mean that its cast will get the weekend off. On May 2, some “SNL” performers will be at the Tribeca Film Festival for the premiere of “Saturday Night,” a documentary directed by James Franco that goes behind the scenes at that sketch show. Mr. Franco and the “SNL” stars will also be on hand for a question-and-answer session following the screening, the festival organizers said on Tuesday.

headline: Confidential Aqueduct Ranking Released
text: ALBANY — The Paterson administration has released a confidential document that assessed the various bidders vying for the rights to operate a casino at the Aqueduct racetrack in Queens.

headline: Health Reform Revelations
text: One of the side benefits of health reform is that it has acted as a character test. If, for example, you thought of Mitt Romney as a person of character, his desperate attempts to disavow what is essentially his own policy proposal have cured you of that affliction. And as Menzie Chinn points out, Robert Samuelson’s hysterical reaction to what is, when all is said and done, a fairly modest — and paid for! — expansion of social insurance tells what what really lies behind his constant harping on the long-run fiscal issue.

headline: Samurai Shopper | Ears Looking at You
text: There is a cacaphony of headphones on the market, with choices that range from sleek in-ear to old-school on-ear, in materials from blingy crystal to crafty wood.

headline: Particle Physics Fill-In
text: Fill in the missing words in this article from the Science section about the Large Hadron Collider.

headline: Disappointing Roach
text: I really don’t know what to say about Steve Roach’s column on China today. It doesn’t sound as if he’s read anything those of us calling for a tough stand on the renminbi have written. The whole thing is laid out as if China critics were focused on the US-China bilateral imbalance, when I’ve made it very clear that this is not at all the right thing to focus on:

headline: Roundabout Extends Run for ‘The Glass Menagerie’
text: The Roundabout Theater Company’s revival of Tennessee Williams’s “The Glass Menagerie,” starring Judith Ivey as Amanda Wingfield, will extend its run by two weeks through June 13, the theater has announced. Directed by Gordon Edelstein, the production had its start at the Long Wharf Theater and received rave reviews there and at Roundabout for Ms. Ivey’s performance. The show is running Off Broadway at Roundabout’s Laura Pels Theater.

headline: At Key West Beach, Wondering Who’s a Vagrant
text: KEY WEST, Fla. — Quality of life for Steve Sanderson means securing a good sleeping spot that a new arrival will never find. For Denise Skinner, it means l-i-v-i-n with a view of the ocean from the mattress in her cherry red Jeep. “It’s heaven out there,” she said last week, squinting out her back window. “It’s heaven.”

headline: Paying for the Bad Habits of Others
text: It’s easy to blame the nation’s health care woes on people who don’t take care of themselves. But personal responsibility for one’s health is a surprisingly complex notion, writes Dr. Sandeep Jauhar.

headline: Eagles in Our Midst
text: In a recent City Critic column, I went in search of some unlikely new visitors to Manhattan: bald eagles.

headline: A ‘Second Life’ For ‘Twilight’ Fans
text: You can burn it, bludgeon it or behead it, but a lucrative literary franchise just doesn’t stay down. (Same goes for vampires apparently.) If you’ve admired the way the four volumes of Stephenie Meyer‘s “Twilight Saga” fit neatly on your bookshelf, you’d better make room for a fifth. On her Web site Ms. Meyer writes that she will be publishing a new work set in the “Twilight” universe, to be released by  Little Brown & Company on June 5. The novella, called “The Short Second Life of Bree Tanner,” is told from the perspective of the title character, a newborn vampire who turns up briefly in the third “Twilight” novel, “Eclipse.” Ms. Meyer said the story was originally written for “The Twilight Saga: The Official Guide” but was ultimately too long to include in that book. If the unsettling notion of newborn vampires keeps you from ever cracking open this book, know that one dollar from each copy sold will go to — where else? — the American Red Cross.

headline: London Dance Journal: A Ballet Company to Watch
text: LONDON — The British company Ballet Black was founded in 2001 “to provide role models to young, aspiring black and Asian dancers.” The company’s profile has risen markedly in the last two years, and in January it won the Critics’ Circle National Dance Award for outstanding company.

headline: False Charges of Racism, Tanning Edition
text: So a guest on Glenn Beck claimed that health reform is racist because it imposes a special tax on indoor tanning salons.

headline: King and Court Lose Subjects at CNN
text: As Bill Carter reported this morning, CNN’s prime-time ratings have gone off a cliff. Is it about Larry’s ties, Anderson’s hair, or something more far reaching? Let’s discuss in comments.

headline: The Choice and Colleges That Change Lives on Minnesota Public Radio
text: Jacques Steinberg, New York Times education writer and moderator of The Choice, and Marty O’Connell, executive director of Colleges That Change Lives, discussed this year’s admissions and financial aid process in a one-hour interview broadcast live today on Minnesota Public Radio.

headline: Why Being Female Is a Pre-existing Condition
text: Being female is essentially a pre-existing condition that inflates a woman’s health care costs, explains Denise Grady in today’s Science Times. She writes:

headline: Charles Ryskamp, Director of Morgan and Frick, Dies at 81
text: Charles Ryskamp, a literary scholar and art collector who was the director of two of New York’s most prestigious small museums, the Pierpont Morgan Library and the Frick Collection, for nearly 30 years, died Friday in Manhattan. He was 81 and lived in Manhattan and Princeton, N.J.

headline: Head of Abu Dhabi Fund Found Dead
text: The Moroccan authorities recovered the body of the director of the world’s largest sovereign wealth fund on Tuesday, five days after a glider he was riding in plunged into a lake south of the Moroccan capital, Rabat, The Associated Press reports.

headline: Justices Set Aside Ruling on Mutual Fund Fees
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Tuesday ruled that courts have a role, though a limited one, in policing the compensation of mutual fund investment advisers.

headline: Nissan Leaf Electric Car Priced at $32,780
text: The 2011 Nissan Leaf battery electric car, which will go on sale in the United States in December, will have a suggested retail price of $32,780, a Nissan spokesman, Mark Perry, said Tuesday morning. Nissan prefers to describe the price as $25,280 inclusive of a $7,500 federal income tax credit.

headline: Stewart Returning to Broadway in Mamet Play
text: Patrick Stewart will return to Broadway next season for the first time since his Tony Award-nominated turn as Macbeth in 2008, starring in the David Mamet play “A Life in the Theater,” according to a statement on the Broadway’s Best Shows Web site.

headline: A Winning Streak Ends
text: A couple of months ago, during the mayhem of college applications, Samantha, one of my best friends, said: “Brian, don’t worry. You are going to get into every college you apply to.” And no, that did not make me arrogant or anything like that, but that statement did boost my confidence a little bit.

headline: Interview: Eric Mendelsohn
text: Eric Mendelsohn, the writer and director of "3 Backyards," discusses his film that tells a trio of stories in suburbia.

headline: How One Marijuana Cigarette May Lead to Deportation
text: ELMONT, N.Y. — When a police officer in this Long Island suburb found a marijuana cigarette in Jerry Lemaine’s pocket one night in January 2007, a Legal Aid lawyer counseled him to plead guilty. Under state statutes, the penalty was only a $100 fine, and though Mr. Lemaine had been caught with a small amount of marijuana years earlier as a teenager, that case had been dismissed.

headline: When a Friend Feels Too ‘Ugly’ to Socialize
text: Dr. Katharine A. Phillips, professor of psychiatry at Brown Medical School, recently joined the Consults blog to answer readers’ questions about body dysmorphic disorder, or B.D.D., a psychological condition in which perceived body flaws may make it impossible for people to work, go to school, socialize or have relationships. Here, she responds to one reader concerned about a friend who is obsessed with perceived flaws in his face.

headline: Obama Signs Bill on Student Loans and Health Care
text: ALEXANDRIA, Va. – President Obama signed legislation Tuesday to expand college access for millions of young Americans by revamping the federal student loan program in what he called “one of the most significant investments in higher education since the G.I. Bill.”

headline: Lowering the Health Costs of Womanhood (and Then Manhood)
text: My colleague Denise Grady has an article today about provisions in the new health law prohibiting health insurance discrimination by sex, meaning that women will no longer be charged a higher premium simply because as a group they often consume more medical services than men.

headline: What a Zoo
text: Between the bike-path-taking coyotes and midnight opossums, it seems the wilds are increasingly invading the city. As Melissa Cooper on Out Walking the Dog writes, even the trees have spikes!

headline: Access to Google Is Interrupted in China
text: SHANGHAI — Google’s search engine was inaccessible in much of China late Tuesday. The exact cause of the disruption was not fully clear, but it led to speculation that the site was being blocked by the country’s Internet censors.

headline: Dispatch | Israel by Design
text: Israel offers many good reasons to visit: breathtakingly diverse landscapes, endless historical and religious sights, and plenty of incredibly friendly and beautiful people. Recently the country added another feather to its cap of landmarks: its first museum devoted entirely to design. The project, in the Tel Aviv suburb Holon, is part of an ambitious plan to put the wealthy but otherwise bland municipality on the global culture map; in fact, an interesting group of international architects has already been invited to submit proposals for a new town hall on an adjacent lot.

headline: TimesCast | March 30, 2010
text: From the newsroom of The New York Times.

headline: Justices Set Aside Ruling on Mutual Fund Fees
text: 5:45 p.m. | Updated The Supreme Court ruled on Tuesday that courts have a role, though a limited one, in policing the compensation of mutual fund investment advisers, The New York Times’s Adam Liptak reports from Washington.

headline: Q&A: Swapping an Apartment for One in Rome
text: Q.

headline: Supreme Court Punts
text: Mutual fund managers tend to get paid multiples of what the same managers charge for managing similar pension funds.  That is true even though a 1970 law imposes a fiduciary duty on fund directors to negotiate fair fees.

headline: Manhattan Cocktail Classic — The Main Event
text: Need to brush up on your ice-carving skills? Your cocktail photography not what you want it to be? Not sure what sort of martini goes well with that filet mignon? Take heart.

headline: Inside the Backyard Farms Greenhouse
text: Even as snow falls outside, workers harvest tomatoes year-round at Backyard Farms in Madison, Me.

headline: Teixeira to Have Treatment on Sore Elbow
text: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla. — Mark Teixeira’s right elbow remained sore Tuesday morning from the Jeremy Guthrie pitch that plunked him Monday night in Sarasota, Fla. Manager Joe Girardi texted Teixeira to check on him; Teixeira will report to Steinbrenner Field on Tuesday afternoon for treatment.

headline: Javits Expansion Will Allow Auto Show to Grow for 2011
text: Ferrari was turned away from the New York auto show this year, said Chris Sams, a spokesman for the event, because the Italian supercar maker applied late for a stand and there was no room remaining.

headline: The Last Piece in Place
text: President Obama signed the budget reconciliation bill containing a package of revisions to the big health care legislation after giving a speech at Northern Virginia Community College, a setting aimed at drawing attention to the education component of the bill.

headline: Hello, 311, I Want to Complain About Being No. 2
text: Who says you can’t fight City Hall? Win or lose, New Yorkers never stop trying. The city ranked second, behind San Francisco, in the number of calls per capita to 311 complaint centers, according to a recent survey.

headline: Kaiser Permanente Invests in Solar Power
text: Kaiser Permanente, the biggest nonprofit health maintenance organization in the country, is going solar.

headline: Agency Gets Outpost Outside New York, Again
text: MDC Partners is tinkering with its lineup of agencies again, combining two of its shops in Atlanta to give one of its largest agencies, Kirshenbaum Bond Senecal & Partners, its first office outside New York in four years.

headline: Properties for $675,000
text: Houses in Chicago, Coupeville, Wash., and Titusville, N.J.

headline: An Easy Pantry Dinner
text: It’s not a problem being lazy if you have a well-stocked pantry. Some appealing  traditional dishes, like the pasta with canned sardines featured in this week’s Minimalist column, don’t require a shopping trip.

headline: The Dark Man Behind the Sunny Ballet
text: LONDON — To what extent should we dwell on the psyche of the artist who makes the art?

headline: The Ten Missing Player Questions
text: ESPN The Magazine’s annual N.H.L. player survey has become a must-read, and this year’s edition is no exception. The 20-question survey gives players an opportunity to weigh in anonymously on a wide variety of topics. Readers will be treated to several shocking revelations, not the least of which is that ESPN apparently remembers that the N.H.L. exists.

headline: Skinner and Boston College Part Ways
text: Gene DeFilippo, the Boston College athletics director, sat with Al Skinner last Wednesday and came to a mutual agreement that Skinner would no longer be the men’s basketball coach. They agreed to keep the news quiet as Skinner interviewed for the position at St. John’s on Friday, but as Skinner fell behind Steve Lavin as the leading candidate there, DeFilippo said he could wait no longer to reveal Skinner’s fate.

headline: What You Get for ... $675,000
text: CHICAGO

headline: Build Your Own NYT Linked Data Application
text: Now that we’ve published nearly 10,000 of our tags as Linked Open Data, you’re probably wondering what kind of cool applications you can build with this data. To help you get started (and since linked data applications are a little different from your average Web application), we thought we’d provide a sample application and detailed information about how we built it.

headline: Watchdog Group Seeks Justice Dept. Scrutiny of Ex-Georgia Congressman
text: Legal troubles for Nathan Deal, the former congressman running as a Republican for governor in Georgia, may not be over yet.

headline: Pros and Amateurs Debate: Is Photography in Trouble?
text: 2:40 P.M. Updated with additional reader responses and blog responses.

headline: Battle Continues Between Cohen and Ex-Wife
text: It may be hard to feel sorry for the billionaire hedge fund manager Steven A. Cohen, but his personal life is complicated. A nasty divorce from 20 years ago continues to haunt him, threatening his $13 billion financial empire, SAC Capital Advisors, which he rules with his current wife from his 32,000-square-foot mansion in Greenwich, Conn.

headline: Bomb Pulse
text: A spike in carbon-14 levels, caused by atmospheric atomic bomb tests, which can be used to calculate the age of an organism.

headline: Toyota Sees Sales Rebounding
text: Toyota, which introduced generous incentives in a bid to attract customers after a string of recalls, said on Tuesday that its sales in the United States probably rose by a third in March.

headline: Second Acts | Veronique Branquinho for Camper
text: Veronique Branquinho’s announcement that she was closing up shop because of the recession was one of the ones that had fashion insiders bemoaning the most. But the queen of Antwerp cool seems to be enjoying a new chapter of her career.

headline: More Health Care Pens for Lawmakers
text: ALEXANDRIA, Va. – For those keeping count, that’s yet another pen for Speaker Nancy Pelosi and Senator Harry Reid. Only this time Mr. Reid was not on hand to collect it.

headline: CNN: Look Out Below
text: Have people lost their taste for news? Half of CNN's audience has gone missing.

headline: 96th St. Station on the 2 and 3, 11:40 A.M.
text: NY See: Flooding at the West 96th Street subway station at Broadway on Tuesday morning.

headline: Northeast Storm Sets Records, Stops Traffic and Makes Life Miserable
text: A wind-driven deluge broke rainfall records across the Northeast on Tuesday, flooding roads and basements almost as quickly as it snapped umbrellas inside out, and compounding the lingering damage from a storm two weeks ago.

headline: ‘Come Fly Away': What’s Entertainment?
text: The Times’s Charles Isherwood and Alastair Macaulay are discussing “Come Fly Away,” which opened last week at the Marquis Theater. Previous posts are here.

headline: This Year in Kigali:  A Rwandan Seder
text: Josh Ruxin is the director of Rwanda Works and a Columbia University expert on public health who has spent the last few years living in Rwanda. The following is an account of a Seder he recently celebrated in Kigali.

headline: Chrysler Says It Expects to Break Even This Year
text: Chrysler, which began its path into bankruptcy a year ago, expects to break even this year, its chief executive, Sergio Marchionne, said on Tuesday.

headline: Back in Iraq, With Fresh Eyes
text: Yasmine Mousa is an Iraqi-Canadian journalist who left Iraq in 2003. On March 22 she wrote about her arrival back in Baghdad. Here she records impressions of her first week back home.

headline: Publisher of Departures Magazine Is Retiring
text: Ed Ventimiglia, the publisher of the luxury magazine Departures, is taking a departure of his own. He will retire from American Express Publishing in June.

headline: Ireland Lays Out a Plan to Help Banks
text: Ireland announced sweeping measures on Tuesday to tighten control over the financial sector, which has been hurt by the global economic crisis and the collapse of the Irish real estate market.

headline: Abandoned Animals in Colombia
text: The New York Times's Simon Romero visits Villa Lorena, an animal refuge in Cali, Colombia, that often takes in the castoff pets of the country's drug lords.

headline: As Schools Stay Open, Space May Become Scarce
text: New York City public schools are on spring recess until April 7, but that doesn’t mean a clean break from anxiety for either the city’s Department of Education officials or many public school parents.

headline: Hotel Review: Capella Telluride, in Colorado
text: THE BASICS

headline: Mauritius Dreaming
text: SOMEWHERE near the Tropic of Capricorn, a gust of warm wind blew down on the old French colonial town of Mahébourg, rushing across strange, jagged brown hills and lightly rustling green fields of sugar cane. It carried the smell of damp vegetation  a result of a typical morning sun shower  as it rippled offshore and gently undulated the translucent curaçao waters of the Indian Ocean around our slow-chugging motorboat.

headline: With the Surfers on Costa Rica’s Untamed Coast
text: SOME vacation destinations attract tourists. Others attract disciples. The surfer town of Puerto Viejo de Talamanca and the tiny beach communities southeast of it, on the Caribbean coast of Costa Rica, are of the latter variety.

headline: A Czech City Reclaims Its Past
text: HUGE hunks of rusting iron and coal dust might not seem like ideal catalysts for a cultural revival. But a former mining town in the Czech Republic that once epitomized Communist-era bleakness is embracing its industrial heritage, with a little help from punk rock, an all-night party street and a “castle” made of steel.

headline: Motels Boost the Thread Count
text: PLATFORM beds with crisp white sheets and taupe coverlets; 32-inch flat-screen TVs; bright colors on the walls and mod furnishings that maximize space. No, it’s not the latest boutique hotel. It’s the new look of Motel 6.

headline: Developer Defends Ethiopian Hydro Project
text: Responding to complaints about the Gibe III hydroelectric dam project in Ethiopia, Salini Costruttori, the Italian hydropower developer behind the project, issued a statement late last week arguing that the project’s critics are opposed to Africa’s development.

headline: Roots of an Iraqi’s Reputation as ‘Saddam Lite’
text: In an interview with my colleagues Rod Nordland and Tim Arango in Baghdad on Monday, Ayad Allawi, the former Iraqi exile who may become Iraq’s next prime minister, described an incident from his past that has burnished his reputation for toughness. In 1978, he managed to fight off two ax-wielding assassins sent to kill him after he broke with Saddam Hussein’s Baath Party.

headline: Restaurant Review: Sea Change in Minneapolis
text: It’s not every gastronome who wants to savor a bowl of grilled swordfish cassoulet while staring at a 25-foot-tall photo of Arthur Miller. Yet there he is, either grinning or wincing (it’s tough to tell with Mr. Miller), outside the windows of this restaurant, which opened last July on the ground floor of the Guthrie Theater.

headline: 36 Hours in San Antonio
text: SAN ANTONIO, the country’s seventh-largest city, features a trio of popular attractions: the River Walk (a meandering canal lined with restaurants and bars), Market Square (said to be the largest Mexican-style market outside of Mexico) and the Alamo (no explanation necessary). But get beyond the obvious tourist stops, and this old city offers excellent Chicano art, 19th-century-style shopping, church music that goes way beyond hymns, and plenty of that famous Texas hospitality.

headline: Technology Coalition Seeks Stronger Privacy Laws
text: SAN FRANCISCO — A broad coalition of technology companies, including AT&T, Google and Microsoft, and advocacy groups from across the political spectrum said Tuesday that it would push Congress to strengthen online privacy laws to protect private digital information from government access.

headline: China’s Ancient Jewish Enclave
text: THROUGH a locked door in the coal-darkened boiler room of No. 1 Hospital of Traditional Chinese Medicine in Kaifeng, there’s a well lined with Ming Dynasty bricks. It’s just a few yards deep and still holds water. Guo Yan, 29, an eager, bespectacled native of this Chinese city on the flood plains of the Yellow River about 600 miles south of Beijing, led me to it one recent Friday afternoon, past the doormen accustomed to her visits.

headline: Several Wounded in Gaza by Israeli Gunfire
text: GAZA — Several Palestinians were wounded by Israeli army fire in Gaza on Tuesday as they demonstrated close to the border with Israel, according to Palestinian medical officials and the Israeli military. But it was unclear who was responsible for the death of a Palestinian youth, 14, who was apparently shot in another part of the border area.

headline: McNabb, and the Eagles’ Indigestion at Quarterback
text: The quarterback situation in Philadelphia is like a Chinese buffet. At first glance, there’s a bounty of delectable options:

headline: The Secret Rock and Roll Life of Creed Bratton
text: It takes a special sort of person to even be in the running for the weirdest person on “The Office,” but Creed Bratton has arguably claimed that mantle: the character (who shares his name with the actor who portrays him) turns up only once or twice an episode, usually to say something totally outrageous to the camera, make a leering remark about a female co-worker or just to impersonate the Joker from “The Dark Knight.” But he always makes an impression.

headline: Insurers to Comply With Rules on Children
text: WASHINGTON — Under pressure from the White House, health insurance companies said Tuesday that they would comply with rules to be issued soon by the Obama administration requiring them to cover children with pre-existing medical problems.

headline: What We’re Reading…
text: New York taxi medallion prices hit a record high, and other news from around the Web.

headline: State of Play in the Galleon Insider Trading Case
text: Peter J. Henning follows issues related to white-collar crime and securities law for DealBook’s White Collar Watch.

headline: Grass Fed | Who Eats Princess Cake?
text: Parenthood has brought with it a whole new vocabulary: technical terms for types of discharge, baby-related brand names that double as class signifiers, all kinds of goofy parent-speak that one can elect to adopt (“neck cheese,” say, for the stink between a newborn’s folds) or discard (see “neck cheese”). So when my friend Julie told me she was getting a princess cake for her daughter’s first birthday, I shunted the term in and out of the revolving door of my mind, figuring she meant something pink and frilly and possibly topped with Barbie wearing a crown.

headline: ‘Come Fly Away': Subtlety Isn’t Everything
text: The Times’s Charles Isherwood and Alastair Macaulay are discussing “Come Fly Away,” which opened last week at the Marquis Theater. Previous posts are here.

headline: Koch Industries Responds to Greenpeace
text: Earlier today, we wrote about a new Greenpeace report that takes aim at Koch Industries, an industrial conglomerate based in Wichita, Kan.

headline: Creed Bratton's 'Bounce Back'
text: Creed Bratton, the musician and actor best known for his work on "The Office," discusses his new album in a mockumentary style video.

headline: Answers About New Consumer Laws: Part 5
text: “Ask an Expert” is a recurring feature on Bucks where you have the opportunity to question big-brained people about a particular area of personal finance or consumer affairs.

headline: A Fjord View in Oslo
text: A  3,000-square-foot five-bedroom house overlooking Oslo Fjord is on the market for 10 million kroner (around $1.67 million).

headline: House Hunting in ... Norway
text: A 3,057-SQUARE-FOOT FIVE-BEDROOM HOUSE OVERLOOKING OSLO FJORD

headline: A Big Empty Warehouse in Brooklyn Holds Dreams of Industrial Jobs
text: New York is trying to entice developers to buy the former Federal Building No. 2 in Brooklyn, a massive structure that is zoned for light industrial busnesses.

headline: Once Again, Mr. Stanford Wants New Lawyers
text: R. Allen Stanford, the Texas financier accused of running a huge Ponzi scheme, is changing lawyers again and he wants to be tried someplace other than Houston, The Houston Chronicle reports.

headline: Sports Injuries: When to Tough It Out
text: YOU have been playing a lot of tennis recently, and now you think you have tennis elbow. Or you’re a swimmer with an aching shoulder. A cyclist with sore knees. A runner with pain in your heel.

headline: What Is Bike Culture?
text: With an increasingly permanent network of lanes and legal access to office buildings around the city, the bicycle is becoming more entrenched as a mode of transportation. An entity no less mainstream than the United States Department of Transportation is on board, recently describing bicycles and pedestrians as “equals” to trains, planes and automobiles and encouraging further development of cycling infrastructure at the state and federal level.

headline: Ford Shifts and Gains Ground in Asia
text: CHONGQING, China — The sprawling Ford assembly plant here runs two shifts a day every day except Sunday, with workers putting in as many as 10 hours a day. Employees take turns having lunch so production almost never stops at potential bottlenecks, like the building where cars are painted.

headline: Charleston Symphony Orchestra Suspends Operations
text: The Charleston Symphony Orchestra in South Carolina has canceled the rest of its season and suspended operations, saying it has run out of cash to pay its expenses, The Post and Courier of Charleston reported. The board president, Ted Legasey,  said in a telephone interview on Tuesday that the critical issue was a decline in fund-raising. He said that major gifts were down 60 percent from last season, creating a shortfall of about $400,000.  People who had purchased tickets for the final concert of the CSO’s season, on April 17, are being offered refunds.

headline: Branford Marsalis to Compose Music for ‘Fences’ Revival
text: The Grammy Award-winning saxophonist Branford Marsalis announced on Tuesday that he will make his Broadway debut this spring as the composer of original music for the forthcoming revival of August Wilson’s “Fences.”

headline: F.B.I. Investigates Militia Groups
text: Members of a Christian militia were indicted on sedition and weapons charges on Monday in connection with an alleged plot to murder law enforcement officers.

headline: Sarkozys Eat Half-Smokes at Ben’s Chili Bowl
text: Someone really needs to tell world leaders that people mostly go to Ben’s Chili Bowl at 4 in the morning when they need sustenance to cushion the impact of a night of bad behavior.

headline: Izzo Refutes Rumors of Oregon Offer
text: EAST LANSING, Mich. – Michigan State coach Tom Izzo refuted rumors Tuesday of any impending deal for Oregon to hire him as coach.

headline: Through Cage Bars, an Exotic Peek Into Drug Wars
text: CALI, Colombia — Of all the animals that come to die under Ana Julia Torres’s samán trees, the ocelots are among the most numerous. There are eight of them here, seized from the estate of a murdered cocaine trafficker, who apparently collected them in the belief that any self-respecting drug lord should always have eight ocelots in his dominion.

headline: Now Screening | “The Man Next Door”
text: “Space and light and order. Those are the things that men need just as much as they need bread or a place to sleep,” the architect Le Corbusier once said. But what happens when one man’s search for light disturbs the sense of space and order of another?

headline: Under a Shadow in the Moscow Subway
text: James Hill, a photographer with a deep knowledge of Russia, has brought an intimately impressionist eye to the day-after scene in the Moscow subway. (Slides 1 and 2.) These photographs, taken for The Times, are imbued with a sense both of sorrow and fear. An underground realm known for its sparkling tiles and chandeliers is rendered strangely dark and foreboding. “The mood of the city is evident on people’s faces,” said Maria Anzhaurova, 21, a student, at the Lubyanka station, the site of the first attack on Monday. “People are watching each other closely. It is clear that people are afraid, very afraid.”

headline: Ireland Lays Out a Plan to Help Rescue Its Banks
text: Ireland announced sweeping measures on Tuesday to tighten control over the financial sector, which has been brought to its knees by the global crisis and the collapse of the Irish real estate market, The New York Times’s Matthew Saltmarsh reports.

headline: In Revival of Verdi, a New Note of Drama
text: Who would have guessed that a routine revival of “La Traviata” at the Metropolitan Opera could cause such a ruckus? The problem was that the conductor Leonard Slatkin, appearing at the Met for the first time in 12 years, showed up for rehearsals not fully knowing the score. You did not have to believe the reports that spread on opera chat lines to know this. Mr. Slatkin conceded as much on his personal Web site, leonardslatkin.com.

headline: Would You Like Fries With That Diploma?
text: New York University and Michigan State are not the only organizations christening new campuses in China. McDonald’s is now trying to get a foothold on China’s wealth of human capital, too. From The Associated Press:

headline: Insurers to Comply With New Rules on Children
text: Under pressure from the White House, health insurance companies said on Tuesday they would comply with rules to be issued soon by the Obama administration requiring them to cover children with pre-existing medical problems.

headline: Russian TV on Sidelines After Attacks in Subway
text: MOSCOW — As frantic Muscovites turned to Russia’s main television channels for information in the first hours after suicide bombers struck here on Monday morning, they were astonished to find only the usual lineup of cooking shows and police dramas, along with a Soviet-era spy film called “The Road.”

headline: An Empty Warehouse Holds Dreams of Industrial Jobs
text: To hear it described by one broker, the football-field-long former Navy warehouse off the Brooklyn waterfront inspired awe from all but a few of the prospective buyers invited on a tour of the long-vacant site last month.

headline: California Queries Banks About Swaps on State Debt
text: California’s state treasurer, Bill Lockyer, has sent a letter to six big banks that underwrite the state’s municipal bond sales, asking about the banks’ involvement in selling credit-default swaps on California debt, Reuters reports.

headline: South African Runner Plans Return
text: Caster Semenya, a teenage South African runner, announced Tuesday that she planned to resume her career on the international circuit, attempting to force track and field’s world governing body to make a decision about gender verification in her case.

headline: Crist Backer Uses Ethnic Terms About Rubio
text: MIAMI — Gov. Charlie Crist proudly announced the endorsement of Col. Bud Day, the Vietnam veteran beloved by conservatives for his membership in the Swift Boat Veterans for Truth. Then Colonel Day complicated matters.

headline: A Wine Panel Tastes Rioja Crianzas
text: Over the years I’ve made it clear how I feel about Rioja: I love it. I feel most strongly about old-fashioned, well-aged gran reserva Riojas, a style of wine that these days seems somewhat marginalized but is still available to those who seek it out. But what of younger, less-expensive Riojas, intended for early drinking rather than long-term aging?

headline: Vote for the Worst Company in America
text: If you have strong feelings about who the worst company in America is, here’s one way to express them.

headline: A Pea in the Prada
text: When I was pregnant, I made a vow that no matter how much poundage I piled on I would not devolve into one of those slovenly sweat-pants-wearing preggos that you see waddling down the street leaving a trail of Saltine crumbs. Making an effort, after all, is what separates us from the animals, and nowhere is this truer than during that distinctly mammalian experience of childbirth. Even when I could no longer see my toes, I could rest assured that they were freshly pedicured.

headline: InterContinental Plans Hotels Across China
text: InterContinental, the largest foreign hotel operator in China, said in a statement that it would open a 320-room property near Sanlitun, an entertainment area in the Chaoyang district of Beijing.

headline: That Synthy, Dancey European Club Sound
text: Delorean, from Barcelona, had just finished its sold-out show at the Mercury Lounge on Monday night, and Ekhi Lopetegi, the band’s bassist and singer, was trying to say something. The sound system had been cut off, so his words weren’t easy to make out. But they seemed to involve the location of an after-party, which would only make sense. A four-piece synth-pop outfit originally formed in the Basque region of Spain, Delorean traffics in airy atmospherics and enveloping rhythm: ideally, music for a dance floor in the hours preceding dawn.

headline: Six Senses Offers ‘Voluntourism’ in the Maldives
text: Two Six Senses resorts in the Maldives, the Soneva Gili and Soneva Fushi, will encourage travelers to engage in what is being called ‘‘voluntourism,’’ the company said Tuesday in an e-mailed statement.

headline: ‘All About Me’ to Close on Sunday
text: The new Broadway musical “All About Me,” in which Michael Feinstein and Dame Edna Everage, above, have dueling acts on stage, will close on Sunday after 27 preview performances and 20 regular performances. Directed by Casey Nicholaw, the production opened at Henry Miller’s Theater on March 18 to mixed and negative reviews and never built much of an audience. The show grossed $216,425 last week, only 23 percent of the maximum possible, with more than half of the seats empty at some performances. Asked for the cost of the musical and whether it would close at a loss to investors, a spokesman for Jeffrey Richards, one of the lead producers, did not immediately reply.

headline: Stewart Back on Broadway in a Mamet Play
text: Patrick Stewart, right, will return to Broadway next season for the first time since his Tony Award-nominated turn as Macbeth in 2008, starring in the David Mamet play “A Life in the Theater,” according to a statement on BroadwaysBestShows.com. The lead producers of the project  Jeffrey Richards, Jerry Frankel and Steve Traxler  have mounted two recent productions of Mamet plays on Broadway: “Race,” which is still running, and “Speed-the-Plow,” from last season. Mr. Stewart will star as a veteran actor, Robert, whose complicated mentoring relationship with a younger actor forms the central narrative of the play. Mr. Stewart played Robert in a London production of the play in 2005, opposite Joshua Jackson (Pacey on television’s “Dawson’s Creek,” among other roles). Neil Pepe, who directed the “Speed-the-Plow” revival on Broadway last season, will direct.

headline: A ‘Second Life’ for ‘Twilight’ Fans
text: You can burn it, bludgeon it or behead it, but a lucrative literary franchise just doesn’t stay down. (Same goes for vampires, apparently.) If you’ve admired the way the four volumes of Stephenie Meyer’s “Twilight Saga” fit neatly on your bookshelf, you’d better make room for a fifth. On her Web site (stepheniemeyer.com), Ms. Meyer, above, writes that she will be publishing a new work set in the “Twilight” universe, to be released by Little, Brown & Company on June 5. The novella, “The Short Second Life of Bree Tanner,” is told from the perspective of the title character, a newborn vampire who turns up briefly in the third “Twilight” novel, “Eclipse.” Ms. Meyer said the story was originally written for “The Twilight Saga: The Official Guide,” but was ultimately too long to include in that book. If the unsettling notion of newborn vampires keeps you from cracking open “The Short Second Life,” know that one dollar from each copy sold will go to  where else?  the American Red Cross.

headline: Charleston Orchestra Runs Out of Money
text: The Charleston Symphony Orchestra in South Carolina has canceled the rest of its season and suspended operations, saying it has run out of cash to pay its expenses, The Post and Courier of Charleston reported. The board president, Ted Legasey, said in a telephone interview on Tuesday that the critical issue was a decline in fund-raising. He said that major gifts were down 60 percent from last season, creating a shortfall of about $400,000. The orchestra describes itself as the largest professional arts organization in South Carolina, but it is small by national standards, with a budget for this season of $2.3 million. (The budget of the New York Philharmonic is $68.9 million.) The orchestra depends on fund-raising for over half of its budget. Mr. Legasey said the board would work with musicians and the community to try to develop a restructuring plan and would notify ticketholders by May 1 of their options for next season. There is not much room to cut expenses, so “we’ve got to really broaden the base of revenue sources,” Mr. Legasey said.

headline: Trailer to Change for Transgender Film
text: The director of “Ticked-Off Trannies With Knives,” a movie planned for the Tribeca Film Festival that has set off a war of words before being screened there, said he would amend its trailer so it would not refer to real-life victims of violence. In an e-mail message, Israel Luna, who wrote and directed the film, said he was inspired to create the movie “in part by the hate crimes against the trans community.” He said he included references in his trailer to Angie Zapata, a transgender woman who was beaten to death in Colorado in 2008, and to Jorge Mercado, a gay teenager who was murdered in Puerto Rico in 2009, “to give a disturbing reality to my film about transgender violence.” “After listening to some of the voices in the trans community,” Mr. Luna said, “I’ve decided to remove those references from the trailer.” A listing for the movie at tribecafilm.com had drawn angry comments, and the Gay & Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation had sought the movie’s removal from the festival, saying, “The film, its title and its marketing misrepresent the lives of transgender women and use grotesque, exploitative depictions of violence against transgender women.”

headline: ‘Napoleon’ Star Departs Comedy Central Series
text: Was it the 100-episode commitment? Representatives for Jon Heder, below, the “Napoleon Dynamite” star, said he had left a new Comedy Central series that was about to go into production, one that sported a pedigree of prominent comic talents and for which the cable channel had the option to order as many as 100 episodes. Comedy Central announced last summer that it would make a comedy series that would star Mr. Heder and be produced by Gary Sanchez Productions, the company run by Will Ferrell and Adam McKay. At that time the concept for the series was undecided; more recently, its co-stars Chris Parnell and Horatio Sanz said the show would feature Mr. Heder as a fallen financial whiz who returns to his hometown. On Monday night a publicist for Mr. Heder said in a statement: “Comedy Central, Gary Sanchez Productions and Jon Heder have mutually decided to part ways over creative differences with the character.” It is not known who is being considered to replace Mr. Heder if the channel proceeds with the show. Comedy Central did not immediately comment.

headline: ‘Dancing’ to the Top
text: “Dancing With the Stars” waltzed past the competition on Monday as 22.6 million viewers tuned in to the ABC reality show from 8 to 10 p.m., according to Nielsen’s estimates. ABC dominated the night’s ratings over all, as its crime show “Castle” (14.5 million) easily outperformed a rerun of CBS’s “CSI: Miami” (8.1 million). CBS finished runner-up on the night with a lineup of mostly repeats, including “Two and a Half Men” (10.8 million) and “The Big Bang Theory” (9.8 million). Fox ranked third with “24” (8.3 million) following a rerun of “House” (5.5 million), while NBC placed fourth.

headline: Dalai Lama Juggles Dilemmas
text: “The Sun Behind the Clouds: Tibet’s Struggle for Freedom,” a documentary by Ritu Sarin and Tenzing Sonam, is so awkwardly executed that at first it may come across as just another chorus of a familiar song: that Tibetans think they have been done terrible injustices by China. But pay close enough attention, and eventually another, entirely different theme emerges: the Dalai Lama may be losing his ability to keep the more radical elements of the free-Tibet movement in check.

headline: Summer Love, a Sea of Trouble
text: “The Last Song”: if only it were. But it is likely that we can look forward to more movies starring Miley Cyrus, the teenage chanteuse attempting some serious acting in this beachy melodrama. And we will also have many more films based on the work of Nicholas Sparks. We have already had two this year  “Dear John” and this one  and a comparison is instructive, if also exhausting.

headline: A Bullock Double Take: Us and People’s Copycat Covers
text: It’s not just the subject of Us Weekly’s and People’s covers this week that is the same — Sandra Bullock’s marriage. The photo of Ms. Bullock they ran is near-identical: she is looking mournful but glamorous, dressed in a knotted pink sheath.

headline: Whirlwind Off-Season for Yankees’ Trophy
text: It was a relatively quiet off-season for the New York Yankees, but an extremely active one for the team’s 2009 World Series championship trophy. While Derek Jeter presumably spent a relaxing winter at his residence in Florida, the trophy was on a whirlwind global tour, with stops at an international fashion mall in Beijing, a baseball-themed cafe in Tokyo and the national palace of the Dominican Republic.

headline: Plastiki Reports From the Middle of the Ocean
text: It has been 11 days since Plastiki, the 60-foot sea voyager made of recycled plastic bottles, sailed through the Golden Gate Bridge on its way to Australia. Before the crew left, it was visited on deck by Robin Williams, who performed a queen of England riff that was captured on video.

headline: Retro Handsets for a Cellphone
text: Native Union has created a line of handset adapters for mobile phones that can’t quite decide whether they are retro or futuristic. Either way, many people are likely to find its Moshi Moshi02 line an improvement over shouting into a tiny mobile phone.

headline: Amid Desolate Lives and Pitched Battles, One Delicious Anomaly
text: With its close-ups of beautiful people, exquisite cuisine and delirious lovemaking in the hills outside Milan, “I Am Love,” a voluptuous Italian melodrama directed by Luca Guadagnino, is the guilty pleasure of this year’s New Directors/New Films series. The movie, which wallows in luxury, has an elegant lead performance by Tilda Swinton and a throbbing musical score by John Adams.

headline: Verizon Untethers Skype Users From PCs
text: Here’s a head-scratcher partnership: Verizon Wireless and Skype have teamed up to offer free Skype-to-Skype phone calls over the Verizon voice network. That’s potentially a lot of free chatter, considering that 91 million people use Verizon Wireless and Skype counts 600 million users worldwide.

headline: Pennsylvania A.F.L.-C.I.O. Backs Specter
text: Senator Arlen Specter — the Pennsylvania Democrat currently facing a primary challenge – has won the backing of his state’s A.F.L.-C.I.O., the latest in a string of endorsements he has received from organized labor.

headline: A Service Economy in Haiti’s Tent Cities
text: Updated | Wednesday | 12:10 p.m. As my colleagues Deborah Sontag and Simon Romero have reported recently, many Haitians are still living in vast tent cities that sprang up after the earthquake destroyed so many homes in January.

headline: Ruby, It’s You
text: Ruby Ross who? I forgive you for asking. Ruby Ross Wood, the woman Billy Baldwin called “quite simply the finest decorator who ever lived” (take that, Sister Parish!), earned exactly 166 words in The New York Times when she died in 1950. You could argue that the cult of the society decorator had yet to take hold, but then Elsie de Wolfe, whose own light went out just five months later, was buried with many column inches and a picture. It all begins to seem just a little unfair when you consider that Wood is responsible for the way most people today know de Wolfe, as the author of “The House in Good Taste”: Wood ghosted it in 1913. De Wolfe was also an actress and an international hostess, and had hard-working friendships with luminaries like the Duchess of Windsor who were out of Wood’s reach. But still.

headline: International Exchange Is Eyed by Theaters
text: Fresh off its acquisition of 16 additional theaters in the West End of London and across Britain, the Ambassador Theater Group is seeking business deals with theater owners and producers in the United States to create a cross-Atlantic distribution network for shows, one of the company’s co-founders said Monday.

headline: The Pattern of Priestly Sex Abuse
text: Reproduced below is a chart from the John Jay Report on sexual abuse in the Catholic priesthood, commissioned by the U.S. Council of Catholic Bishops, showing the number of credible accusations of abuse across the last half-century. It’s part of the basis for my column’s claim that something in the moral/cultural/theological climate of the 1960s and 1970s encouraged a spike in sexual abuse, and also for my assertion that we’ve since seen the church come to grips with the problem, at least in the United States.

headline: Oil Prices Find a Sweet Spot for World Economy
text: HOUSTON — Oil prices have done something remarkable over the last half-year or so: they have barely budged.

headline: New Directors/New Films Video: Eric Mendelsohn
text: At a screening of his latest film at New Directors/New Films on Sunday, Eric Mendelsohn called himself a “newish director.” The filmmaker brought his first feature, “Judy Berlin,” to the festival in 1999 and is back with “3 Backyards,” a collection of three stories about life in suburbia. After the screening, Mr. Mendelsohn spoke about his film and his desire to avoid cliché in its structure:

headline: A Plan to Spur Growth Away From Haiti’s Capital
text: Even as outsiders feel sympathy for Haiti’s suffering, they tend to look upon it as a country beyond saving.

headline: BlogTalk: All (Health Care) Politics Is Local
text: After voting on the landmark and contentious health care legislation, members of Congress are back in their home districts facing, as my colleague Adam Nagourney put it, “a bewildering crosscurrent of political forces.” In fact, the health care vote is dominating political campaigns across the country, and not just for those running for Congress. Here’s a sampling:

headline:
Risks Seen in Cholesterol Drug Use
 in Healthy People
text: With the government’s blessing, a drug giant is about to expand the market for its blockbuster cholesterol medication Crestor to a new category of customers: as a preventive measure for millions of people who do not have cholesterol problems.

headline: Art + Rock | The Whitney Brings the Noise
text: It’s not often that a prestigious art institution hosts an evening of face-melting noise music. Yet that is exactly what happened on Friday at the Whitney Museum when Ari Marcopoulos, an artist in this year’s Biennial, was invited to curate the museum’s “My Turn” program.
