The series uses artists’ recent work as the jumping-off point — which in this case just happened to be ear-splitting cacophony.

headline: Jerusalem, Two Visions for One City
text: Last week, we looked at how plans for a two-state solution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict seem hamstrung by the fact that both groups want to make Jerusalem their capital. If sharing one country is out of the question, how will two nations find a way to share one city?

headline: Recette
text: A GRAND parade streams along the West Village sidewalks, corner of 12th and Greenwich Streets, crossroads of a particular world. There are dog-walking flâneurs; Westbeth pensioners; the young and desperate en route to the meat markets of the meatpacking district a few blocks north. Here are cabs stopping to let out real housewives. There are young professionals walking home to small apartments filled with books.

headline: Evolving Sexual Tensions
text: Males and females are different.

headline: A SoHo Visionary Makes an Artsy Bet in Miami
text: MIAMI — The developer Tony Goldman is known for envisioning thriving and architecturally appealing neighborhoods where others see only desolation or neglect. He was a major force in the revival of SoHo and South Beach, and has invested his time and money transforming small stretches of Center City Philadelphia and the financial district in New York.

headline: A Touch for Funny Bones and Earlobes
text: MONTECITO, Calif.  “I’ll buzz you in, Dear,” a bright, familiar voice said through an intercom outside a Spanish-style ranch home here. A gate opened, and at the end of a circular drive, crowded inside a doorway to avoid an unusual steady California rain, stood the oblivious Starlett O’Hara, the vainglorious Nora Desmond, the tempestuous Eunice Higgins and the one woman who embodied them all, Carol Burnett.

headline: Judge Dismisses Lawsuit on A.I.G. ‘Red Flags’
text: A federal judge in Manhattan dismissed a shareholder lawsuit on Tuesday that accused current and former executives and directors of the American International Group of ignoring “red flags,” leading to the giant insurer’s near collapse and about $180 billion in federal bailouts, Reuters reports.

headline: Reclaiming Ireland’s Culinary Heritage, One Roast Lamb or Sponge Cake at a Time
text: IN 1968  when Alice Waters had just graduated from Berkeley, when Paula Wolfert was studying couscous in Tangier, when Diana Kennedy was writing recipes after years of research in Mexico  another young woman, this one from the Irish Midlands, went to work at a peculiar new restaurant on the southern coast of County Cork.

headline: Recette, Please
text: This week’s review is of Recette, on Greenwich Street at West 12th in the West Village. It’s an ambitious restaurant in the space of a deeply casual one, with a menu that appears to embrace the small-plates trend. Really it’s more complicated than that: The best way to experience Recette is to order a lot of snacks, and then a couple of other dishes per person, which creates a kind of modified three-course tasting menu for everyone and leads to some serious delights. And the pastry chef, Christina Lee, has much to commend her as well. Save room for s’mores, course number four.

headline: In M.L.S., First Kicks and Last Teams Standing
text: Among the tidbits, factoids and other news in a communique from M.L.S. on Tuesday was a section titled “First Kick Wins vs. Postseason Berths.”

headline: The Rush of Gaming the Casino
text: Josh Axelrad’s “Repeat Until Rich,” his new memoir about winning some $700,000 playing professional blackjack, emits a lively hum from the second you crack it open. Like Dave Eggers in “A Heartbreaking Work of Staggering Genius,” Mr. Axelrad tattoos every available surface of his book’s front matter.

headline: Empty Nesters Still Need a Place to Sit
text: I’M not entirely sure how I got into this mess. I know it started with my husband’s saying we were moving back to New York for his job and with our putting our house up for sale and buying a second smaller one in California to return to some day.

headline: ‘Repeat Until Rich’
text: Chapter 1

headline: Marketers in Warm-Up for World Cup
text: ALTHOUGH March Madness still has a weekend to go, advertisers are already gearing up for June and July Jubilation.

headline: A TV Show and Congress Tackle School Lunches
text: IT’S been an unusually tough month for the people who make school lunches.

headline: Giant Greenhouses Mean Flavorful Tomatoes All Year
text: Madison, Me.

headline: Project Sandwich Offers International Lunch
text: Call it the international house of sandwiches, each filling assembled from combinations of ingredients that are tied to a particular country or region and piled on a length of French bread. Want a taste of Mexico? There is smoked trout seasoned ceviche style with cilantro, lime and cumin. Grilled bulgogi meat and pickled daikon slaw represent Korea. For the Middle East there are grilled vegetables with hummus, and for France, a delicious mustardy egg salad with smoked duck on frisée. The first-rate Brazilian nudged Argentina with steak, chimichurri and mozzarella. Alongside, the organic falafel chips are not to be missed.

headline: Robert, the Wright and Sandwiched
text: Visitors to Manhattan museums have three new places to eat. None threaten the position of The Modern, Danny Meyer’s elegant dining room at the Museum of Modern Art, at the pinnacle of culture-dining in New York; they sit atop metaphorical foothills or, in one case, well below grade.

headline: A Deco Lounge for the Empire State Building
text: It’s hard to believe the cocktail lounge that opened in the Empire State Building on March 29 is brand new because it looks so right. At 3,500 square feet of brushed stainless steel, a generous curved marble bar, tufted banquettes, glass-topped tables and Art Deco chandeliers, it accommodates up to 150 people in sophisticated style in a former postal substation at street level.

headline: Mexican Favorites at El Parador
text: KEEPING up with the sheer volume of new restaurants in New York can be daunting, not to mention disappointing. Being first through the door is never all it’s cracked up to be. Why be a guinea pig?

headline: At a Bespoke Bagel Shop, Cream Cheese Is Customized
text: The angle at Vic’s Bagel Bar is that the cream cheese to be slathered on any of 17 varieties of bagels, hand rolled on the premises, can be custom dressed, like ice cream, with an array of mix-ins. Blueberries, edamame, za’atar (a Middle Eastern spice blend), scallions, almonds, sun-dried tomatoes and, of course, smoked salmon are among the dozens of options. In addition to cream cheese, the spreads include hummus, Nutella and tuna, whitefish and egg salads. Given all these options, you could eat a different bagel sandwich every day for years.

headline: Riojas That Satisfy in Taste and Value
text: WE on the wine panel are subject to the same economic pressures that buffet the rest of the country, so we, too, want to spend less on wine. Of course, we were always concerned with value. Now we are extra concerned with finding not just good, inexpensive wines but also the best values in every category.

headline: Off the Menu
text: Openings

headline: Breaded Jalapeños
text: Adapted from El Parador, Manhattan

headline: New York Auto Show: 2011 Nissan Juke
text: Shown on Tuesday, March 30: 2011 Nissan Juke

headline: On China’s Hainan Island, the Boom Is Deafening
text: SANYA, China — One developer is building what he calls Asia’s largest hotel, with space for a casino and a greyhound racetrack.

headline: New York Auto Show: Test Driving the Chevy Volt
text: By December, two compact cars — the Chevrolet Volt and the Nissan Leaf — will vie for mass-market buyers, and perhaps the green-car mantle that’s been held by Toyota and its hybrids. That battle should also provide early clues as to whether consumers will prefer an all-electric car, the Leaf, or one that is a plug-in hybrid, the Volt.

headline: Maryland: Impeachment Threat Over Gay Marriage
text: Don H. Dwyer Jr., a Republican member of the House of Delegates, plans to bring impeachment charges on the House floor on Wednesday against the state’s attorney general, Douglas F. Gansler. Mr. Dwyer said that Mr. Gansler overstepped his authority in issuing a legal opinion last month saying the state would recognize same-sex marriages from other places and ordering state agencies to give gay married couples the same rights as heterosexual couples. Mr. Gansler’s opinion does not change the law, but it was meant to guide state officials. The impeachment matter is most likely to be dismissed by the House speaker, Michael E. Busch, a Democrat. If so, Mr. Dwyer has said he will probably call for a ruling from the full House, which is controlled by Democrats.

headline: Start-Up Aims to Be a Hub for Location Data
text: Location may be the next mobile frontier for app developers. But for many, the biggest barrier to entry is a lack of access to geographic data, like the locations of businesses near a user.

headline: French Court Upholds Verdict in Oil Spill
text: PARIS — A French appeals court on Tuesday confirmed a ruling that the oil giant Total and related parties were responsible for environmental damage caused by a disastrous oil spill from the tanker Erika off Brittany in 1999.

headline: Volcker Optimistic for Financial Revamping This Year
text: WASHINGTON — The White House and one of its top outside economic advisers, Paul A. Volcker, expressed confidence on Tuesday that legislation to overhaul the nation’s financial system would be completed this year, possibly before the Congressional summer recess.

headline: Pakistan Arrests a Top Crime Official
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — The Supreme Court ordered the arrest of a senior white-collar crime official on Tuesday, and threatened to send the nation’s top anticorruption official to jail if he did not swiftly seek the reopening of corruption cases in Switzerland against President Asif Ali Zardari.

headline: Uproar Over School Cafeteria That Doubled as a Nightclub
text: Books by day, beers by night — at least that is what school district officials in Philadelphia say was offered at a charter school there, where they say the school’s cafeteria was used weekends as a nightclub.

headline: What We’re Reading: Twitter Predictions, ‘Glee,’ Tumblr and the iPad
text: We tried, really, we tried to get through a day without an iPad citation. We failed. But we somehow found a connection to “Glee.”

headline: Suicides, Some for Separatist Cause, Jolt India
text: HYDERABAD, India — Sai Kumar Meegada, a 20-year-old straight-A chemical engineering student at a prestigious university here, came home from breakfast one morning early this month, slipped a length of clothesline around his neck, tied it to the ceiling fan in his dorm room and hanged himself.

headline: Obama Signs Overhaul of Student Loan Program
text: ALEXANDRIA, Va. — President Obama signed legislation on Tuesday to expand college access for millions of young Americans by revamping the federal student loan program in what he called “one of the most significant investments in higher education since the G.I. Bill.”

headline: A Haitian Family’s Hope Grows at a Boston Hospital
text: Jean Paul Coffy, who lives in Chicago, somehow found his parents alive amid the rubble six days after the devastating earthquake that hit Haiti in January, a reunion that attracted international attention as a glimmer of hope amid the destruction.

headline: City Pays $98,000 to Critical Mass Cyclists
text: New York City agreed Tuesday to pay tens of thousands of dollars to five cyclists who filed a lawsuit saying they were harassed during the monthly cycling group-ride Critical Mass — including one man seen on videotape being shoved off his bicycle by an officer. As part of the settlement, the city will pay the cyclists a total of $97,751, with each plaintiff receiving $500 to $30,000 apiece and their lawyers receiving a total of $35,000.

headline: Only a Few Can Multitask
text: Scientists have known for decades that the human brain has trouble simultaneously processing more than one stream of information. A growing body of more recent research has reinforced the notion there are serious cognitive challenges posed by various kinds of multitasking.

headline: With Hirings, Yahoo Steps Up Its News Coverage
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Yahoo has recruited nearly a dozen journalists from traditional and online media outlets and opened a bureau in Washington to push into original content and increase the popularity of its online news site.

headline: In Michelle Wie’s Gallery, Artistry Off the Course
text: PALM DESERT, Calif. — Bloody skulls, a robot mauling a teddy bear, a schoolgirl wearing a plaid skirt and a gas mask. The golfer Michelle Wie looked up from her artwork and said with a laugh, “It’s like drawings you do in fifth grade and someone says, ‘You need help.’ ”

headline: The Government and the Militia Movement
text: The F.B.I.’s raids against members of a Michigan-based Christian militia over the weekend added to concerns about rising far-right activity across the country. Nine members of the group, called the Hutaree, face sedition and weapons charges in a scheme to kill law enforcement officers to incite an antigovernment revolt.

headline: Despite Doubt, Karzai Brother Retains Power
text: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan — Ahmed Wali Karzai, the most powerful man in southern Afghanistan, may maintain links with drug dealers and insurgents, as some American officials and Afghans believe. And he might have played a central role in last summer’s fraudulent presidential election, as Western diplomats charged.

headline: Live at the Masters, Woods’s First Shot, but Not the Second
text: The Augusta National Golf Club, which has the fewest broadcast hours and the highest television ratings of any major golf tournament, has not given ESPN a free hand to show all of Tiger Woods’s shots live in his postscandal return at the Masters.

headline: City Will Stop Paying the Poor for Good Behavior
text: An unusual and much-heralded program that gave poor families cash to encourage good behavior and self-sufficiency has so far had only modest effects on their lives and economic situation, according to an analysis the Bloomberg administration released on Tuesday.

headline: A Bridge to Fame in Boise, Honest
text: BOISE, Idaho — For 14 years Doug Stirling has worked the register at the Airport Chevron and watched as this city and its ambitions grew around him.

headline: In E-Book Era, You Can’t Even Judge a Cover
text: Bindu Wiles was on a Q train in Brooklyn this month when she spotted a woman reading a book whose cover had an arresting black silhouette of a girl’s head set against a bright orange background.

headline: 9th Member of Militia Arrested
text: DETROIT — A ninth member of a Michigan-based militia accused of plotting to kill law enforcement officials was arraigned Tuesday. The accused, Joshua M. Stone, who was arrested Monday evening after the other members appeared in the Federal District Court here, was ordered held without bond until a hearing Wednesday.

headline: On Coaching Go-Round, It’s Hop On, and Hold On
text: St. John’s wants to be a player. Boston College wants to be a player. Everybody wants to be a player.

headline: In Florida, the Seafood Becomes Less Local
text: ISLAMORADA, Fla. — The postcard Florida experience: sun, fun and plenty of local seafood. It was the latter that brought Gary and Vicki Haller from Kansas to Wahoo’s here last week, with its waterfront views, toucan colors and promise of fresh food “from our docks.”

headline: Journalists’ E-Mails Hacked in China
text: BEIJING — In what appears to be a coordinated assault, the e-mail accounts of more than a dozen rights activists, academics and journalists who cover China have been compromised by unknown intruders. A Chinese human rights organization also said that hackers disabled its Web site for a fifth straight day.

headline: Senator Isakson Returns to Hospital
text: Senator Johnny Isakson, a Republican from Georgia who was ill last week and missed the reconciliation vote on health care, has returned to the hospital after doctors found he had an irregular heartbeat.

headline: Gallinari Takes Blame for Loss to Jazz
text: PORTLAND, Ore. – Sometimes the best measures of a young player’s growth come without the basketball in his hands, or the game clock running. Some steps are taken in near solitude, in a quiet corner of the locker room.

headline: Haiti Frets Over Aid and Control of Rebuilding
text: UNITED NATIONS — More than $1.35 billion has been committed to Haiti in humanitarian assistance since the devastating earthquake on Jan. 12, but less than $23 million in cash has been given to the Haitian government so far, leaving President René Préval beleaguered and wary about the reconstruction.

headline: Georgia Attorney General Spurns Suit on Health Care
text: ATLANTA — In 14 states across the country, attorneys general have filed lawsuits challenging the constitutionality of the recent federal health care overhaul. But here in Georgia, the Democratic attorney general has rejected such lawsuits as “frivolous” and “a waste of taxpayer money.” Now that position has led to calls from Republican lawmakers for his impeachment.

headline: Census Day Is Near, Carrying a Weight Far Beyond the Raw Numbers
text: Thursday is Census Day — the date when Americans are urged to fill out their census forms if they want to avoid a visit from a federal worker — and the deadline will put to test a months-long campaign by antigovernment activists who are encouraging people not to complete the questionnaires.

headline: Tiger’s Moral Hazard
text: When Tiger Woods tees up his Nike golf ball at the first hole of the Masters next week, will you be wishing him well? Or will you hope he yanks his drive into the pines and spends four days trudging toward the searing defeat that, in your view, he richly deserves?

headline: In and Out of Love
text: "Ernestine Anderson, a soulful and experienced singer, is at her best weighing the ups and downs of love," writes Nate Chinen. "She should have no problem covering that terrain with help from a frequent foil, the tenor saxophonist Houston Person, and a rhythm section consisting of the pianist Lafayette Harris Jr., the bassist Lonnie Plaxico and the drummer Willie Jones III." She'll be performing through April 4 at 7:30 and 9:30 p.m. at Dizzy's Club Coca-Cola.

headline: Small Plates, High Concept
text: The new West Village eatery Recette, "is small and crowded behind its windows, loud in the way that little Village restaurants can become loud, the sort of place men go wearing blazers, then pull them off halfway through the meal, where women flush and everyone leans into the table to talk," Sam Sifton writes. The restaurant, run by Jesse Schenker, features "American food with Spanish flavors, cooked with French technique; small plates and high concept." Start with snacks, like codfish fritters or the charcuterie plate or, say, the tête de cochon. Then move on to pork belly cooked with a sherry-laced caramel or ocean trout with a dressing of smoked bacon. "The cooking at Recette is smart and imaginative, the food that results from it elegant and full of flavor. The wine list is deep and the service friendly and able, if sometimes overwhelmed. You may have to ask for water a couple of times. There will be the occasional crash of a dropped wineglass. It is casual, almost to a fault. But Recette is a very good restaurant."

headline: ‘The Glass Menagerie’
text: "The Glass Menagerie" might bring to mind memories of overwrought high school productions. So too might "The Miracle Worker," about the life of Helen Keller, which did not fare well in its recent Broadway revival. A new production of "Menagerie" looks like it might have more luck. "Do not come to the Laura Pels Theater, where the Roundabout Theater Company's terrific new revival of Tennessee Williams's career-igniting play opened last week, looking for a standard dose of weepy Southern lyricism," writes Charles Isherwood. "Instead you'll find something unexpected, namely the fiercely moving and seriously funny play Williams actually wrote, in a production directed by Gordon Edelstein that's lightning-lit from within by the tough, compelling and first-rate Amanda Wingfield of Judith Ivey, giving what is surely the performance of her career."

headline: Arms Control May Be Different on Paper and on the Ground
text: WASHINGTON — An official photograph of a B-52 bomber at Barksdale Air Base in Louisiana shows it with a formidable arsenal of nuclear weapons it can carry all at once — 14 air-launched cruise missiles, four B61-7 gravity bombs and two B83 gravity bombs.

headline: Vatican and Pope Stumble in Response to Abuse Crisis
text: VATICAN CITY — The Vatican has been ramping up its defense of how Pope Benedict XVI and the church have handled a growing sexual abuse scandal. But deflecting criticism has proved challenging for this papacy.

headline: Obama Expects U.N. Sanctions on Iran to Be Approved Soon
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama predicted on Tuesday that he would be able to persuade the United Nations to “move forcefully” against Iran with new sanctions within weeks, not months, as he turned up the pressure on Tehran to back off its nuclear program.

headline: Is Polanski Case Nearing Its End?
text: LOS ANGELES — Is the 33-year-old sex-crime prosecution of Roman Polanski finally creeping toward its end-game?

headline: A Drug Maker Targets a New Audience
text: Editors discuss a drug giant's plans to expand the market for its blockbuster cholesterol medication and medical experts' concerns.

headline: Weak Rules on Toxins and Safety
text: For 14 years until just last month, GlaxoSmithKline sold a denture cream called Super Poligrip that contained high levels of zinc.

headline: Moscow After the Attacks
text: Commuters held impromptu memorials while Russian leaders faced pressure to prevent further attacks.

headline: China: Bodies of 21 Babies Are Found
text: The bodies of 21 babies were found in plastic bags in a river in northeast China, state media reported Tuesday. The bodies, some in bags marked “medical waste,” others with hospital identification tags on their toes, were recovered Sunday and Monday from a river in Jining, a city in Shandong Province. The authorities said at least 15 bodies appeared to be of aborted fetuses or infants who had died at Jining Medical College Hospital, state media said. Hospital officials could not be reached for comment.

headline: France: Warning Over Veil Ban
text: France’s top legal advisory body, the Council of State, warned Tuesday that a ban on the full facial veil would most likely be unconstitutional and contravene the European Convention on Human Rights. “There appears to the Council of State to be no legally unchallengeable justification,” the report said in addressing a request by Prime Minister François Fillon, above, about how best to carry out a ban. President Nicolas Sarkozy has said the full facial veil has no place in French society.

headline: The Details on Zinc and Denture Cream
text: My column this week mentions a fair amount of scientific information about zinc in denture cream. If you’re interested in reading more, the following should help:

headline: Tales of Indiana Hoops, as Told by the ‘Hoosier’
text: INDIANAPOLIS — Since leading tiny Milan High School to the Indiana state basketball championship in 1954, storytelling has become a big part of Bobby Plump’s life.

headline: After Patent on Genes Is Invalidated, Taking Stock
text: Many biotechnology stocks fell on Tuesday as investors struggled to understand the impact of a ruling that threw out parts of two gene patents and called into question thousands more.

headline: Amassing a Shrine to His Old School
text: Not many former wards of New York City’s public schools would cherish a splinter that pierced the rear of their public school principal in 1942, but Martin Raskin, it is safe to say, is in a class by himself.

headline: Welcome to Lavin’s World. Enjoy the Ride.
text: A little more than a month before Steve Lavin, with John Wooden as his best man, was to marry the actress Mary Jarou at an exclusive cliffside resort in Laguna Beach in 2007, several hundred wedding guests received an e-mail message from the couple.

headline: Parking Rules
text: Because of the second day of Passover, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Wednesday. Other regulations remain in effect.

headline: Jail Officers Protest Cuts as Assaults Show a Rise
text: New York City correction officials are closely monitoring violence in the municipal jails following a recent increase in serious assaults and a confrontation Saturday night in which four jail officers were injured.

headline: Another Exit From Bloomberg’s Inner Circle
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg so prizes stability and loyalty that he discouraged goodbye parties for employees of his media company, writing in his memoir that he could barely bring himself to wish departing workers good luck. “Why should I?” he asked.

headline: Paterson Delays School Aid, Citing State’s Lack of Money
text: ALBANY — Gov. David A. Paterson ordered the delay of $2.1 billion in aid payments to local school districts on Tuesday, saying the state did not have enough cash to pay bills and still end the fiscal year with its budget balanced.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: March 30, 2010

headline: For Mack, Life Has Imitated Art Imitating Life
text: INDIANAPOLIS — There will be plenty of comparisons to the film “Hoosiers” now that the Butler Bulldogs have made an improbable trip to the Final Four, and the one plot line that may imitate life the most is the Butler guard Shelvin Mack.

headline: Real Estate’s Crash Recasts a Scorned Landlord as a Potential Savior
text: Tenant advocates and many of his own renters regard Laurence Gluck as the scourge of subsidized middle-class housing.

headline: In Patent Fight, Nature, 1; Company, 0
text: For years, women have gone to a genetics clinic at Columbia University, stuck out their arms and watched their blood fill glass tubes.

headline: Upscale Shoe Brand
text: I float like a butterfly and sting like a bee,Your hands can’t hit what your eyes can’t see.

headline: Yankees’ Venditte Remains More a Curiosity Than a Prospect
text: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla. — His afternoon of pitching finished, C. C. Sabathia took a seat in the Yankees’ dugout at Champion Stadium, grabbed a towel, rubbed the sweat off his face and watched the skinny minor league left-hander who replaced him warm up.

headline: Two More Ugly Outings for the Mets’ Rotation
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — The St. Louis Cardinals’ major league hitters were crushing balls in one direction. On an adjacent field, the Cardinals’ minor league batters were smacking them in another. It was a simultaneous assault Tuesday, and two members of the Mets’ starting rotation were the ones absorbing the damage.

headline: Corrections
text: A map on Tuesday with the continuation of an article about the Moscow subway station bombings misidentified two subway lines. The line that crosses the Moscow River and passes the Lenin Library is Serpukhovsko-Timiryazevskaya, not Zamoskvoretskaya. The line that crosses the Moscow River and passes Red Square is Zamoskvoretskaya, not Lyublinskaya.

headline: Corrections
text: A picture caption on Monday with an article about a missing Chinese rights activist, Gao Zhisheng, who has resurfaced a year after being taken into custody by public security personnel, omitted the date of the photograph of Mr. Gao. It was taken in December 2005.

headline: Past Failure a Lesson in Success
text: DAYTON, Ohio — Three years later, the newspaper photograph remains in Tina Charles’s locker at Connecticut. The picture reminds her of being torched as a freshman by Louisiana State’s Sylvia Fowles in the 2007 N.C.A.A. tournament. More broadly, it is a daily admonition against complacency.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Monday about a memorial near the Central Park Reservoir to Alberto Arroyo, who died last week at 94 and was known to joggers as the mayor of Central Park, misspelled, in some editions, the surname of one of the volunteers who pushed Mr. Arroyo around the reservoir in his wheelchair. He is Marty Barolsky, not Barlowsky.

headline: Wishing Doesn’t Make It Law
text: When noncitizens are convicted of aggravated felonies, federal law makes it relatively easy to remove them from the country  and it should. But the law is not a weapon for overzealous immigration officials who want to deny immigrants fair deportation hearings.

headline: Corrections
text: Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about the federal government’s plans to sell its ownership stake in Citigroup misidentified the entity that will hold hearings next week on the roles of several federal financial regulators. It is the Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission, or F.C.I.C.  not the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, or F.D.I.C.

headline: Playing With Passion, Rangers Stay in Playoff Hunt
text: UNIONDALE, N.Y. — The Rangers are not a team associated with displays of joy, but there were two rare and significant ones from Rangers players in their 4-3 victory over the Islanders on Tuesday night at Nassau Coliseum.

headline: Corrections
N.Y.U. Plan for Expansion
text: To the Editor:

headline: Politics and Poverty
text: To the Editor:

headline: Lo-Sweet, Lo-Fat, Lo-Salt
text: PepsiCo has an intriguing new approach to salt. It has reportedly designed a powdery salt crystal that dissolves more efficiently on the tongue, releasing more of its saltiness before it’s swallowed. The company hopes that that will allow it to reduce by a quarter the amount of salt it puts on its Lay’s potato chips.

headline: A Project for Haiti: The Eradication of Two Diseases
text: To the Editor:

headline: Should There Be an Inquisition for the Pope?
text: WASHINGTON

headline: What Makes Chechen Women So Dangerous?
text: Chicago

headline: The Bill Is Passed, but Debate Goes On
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Moscow Bombings
text: Russians, and all of the world, were reminded again of the cruelty and senselessness of terrorism on Monday morning after two rush-hour bombings on the Moscow subway killed 39 people and injured more than 70 others. We share the horror and remember our own anguish. Nearly 10 years after the 9/11 attacks, the memory of innocent lives taken in the midst of a morning’s routine moments has not faded.

headline: Enforcing School Standards, at Last
text: Washington has historically talked tough about requiring the states to reform their school systems in exchange for federal aid, and then caved in to the status quo when it came time to enforce the deal. The Obama administration broke with that tradition this week.

headline: This Time We Really Mean It
text: This newspaper carried a very troubling article on the front page on Monday. It detailed how President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan had invited Iran’s president, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, to Kabul  in order to stick a thumb in the eye of the Obama administration  after the White House had rescinded an invitation to Mr. Karzai to come to Washington because the Afghan president had gutted an independent panel that had discovered widespread fraud in his re-election last year.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Saturday about comparable precedents to Tiger Woods’s expected return to golf in April after a lengthy layoff misstated the time between Ben Hogan’s nearly fatal automobile accident, in February 1949, and his victory in the 1950 United States Open. It was 16 months, not 11 months.

headline: North Carolina to Face Dayton in Title Game
text: Whether it was inexperience, injuries or simply an inability to understand Coach Roy Williams, North Carolina, the reigning N.C.A.A. champion, faltered much of this season, frustrating Williams to no end.

headline: Corrections
text: A picture caption last Wednesday with a television review of “N.Y. Export: Opus Jazz,” a film of a Jerome Robbins ballet on PBS, reversed the identities of two dancers. Robert Fairchild was at the left, and Andrew Veyette was in the center. (As the caption correctly noted, Adam Hendrickson was at the right.)

headline: Corrections
Corrections
text: A review in the “Art in Review” column on March 19 about “#class” at the Winkleman Gallery in Chelsea, using information from the gallery, omitted a moderator of a panel about racial integration in the art world. Besides Joanne McNeil, a writer, the panel was also moderated by An Xiao, an artist. (A correction in this space on March 23 also omitted the artist.)

headline: Colombia: Guerrillas Free Soldier
text: Guerrillas on Tuesday released Sgt. Pablo Emilio Moncayo, a soldier taken captive as a teenager in 1997 by the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, or FARC. His release came almost three years after his father, Gustavo Moncayo, a schoolteacher, walked for 46 days across Colombia to lend attention to the plight of his son and other hostages held by FARC. The group hopes to negotiate an exchange of captives in its control for guerrillas held by the government.

headline: Corrections
text: An obituary on March 22 and in some copies on March 21 about the disc jockey and music historian Charlie Gillett referred incorrectly to his birthplace, Morecambe, England. At the time he was born, in 1942, Morecambe was a separate town, not “a town within the city of Lancaster.” (Lancaster’s boundaries were expanded in 1974 to include Morecambe, although both still tend to be thought of as separate urban centers.) The obituary also misstated the year that “Another Saturday Night,” a compilation of songs by Louisiana performers on Mr. Gillett’s Oval Music label, was released. It was 1973  not 1990, which was the year it was reissued on CD.

headline: Corrections
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Man Dies in Leap Off Empire State Building
text: A 21-year-old man leapt to his death from an observation deck of the Empire State Building on Tuesday, the police said.

headline: Q&A With Johnnie Mac, Street Performer
text: When you travel, you see them everywhere: a guitarist strumming and crooning in the Paris Métro, a juggler in an Italian piazza, a human statue on a New York City corner. They are buskers, and these street performers are not necessarily locals; many are travelers looking to make a bit of extra money and prolong their journeys around the globe.

headline: Left Out Because He’s Not a Righty
text: TAMPA, Fla. — As a left-handed batter on a team that needed a righty off the bench, Jon Weber faced the near-impossible task of making the Yankees this spring no matter how well he hit. But that didn’t make the inevitable any easier for him to take.

headline: France: Burglars Hit Parisian Bank
text: Burglars tunneled their way into a Parisian bank vault late Saturday night and raided about 125 safe deposit boxes, the police said Tuesday. The bank, a branch of Crédit Lyonnais on Avenue de l’Opéra on the Right Bank, was closed for renovations, but a security guard investigating noises was overpowered and tied to a chair. As the robbers left, they set the bank on fire, and the sprinkler system flooded the vault.

headline: Herb Ellis, Jazz Guitarist, Is Dead at 88
text: Herb Ellis, a jazz guitarist whose polished, blues-inflected playing earned him critical acclaim as an outstanding soloist and worldwide recognition as a member of the pianist Oscar Peterson’s trio, died Sunday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 88.

headline: Bloggers Assess the 2010 Yankees, Part 1
text: As opening day draws near, The Times will be previewing the Yankees’ and Mets’ seasons from all angles, with analysis from Tyler Kepner, Ben Shpigel, David Waldstein and others. But with so much happening this off-season, there are a lot of opinions to go around. As we did last season, we have reached out to some Yankees and Mets bloggers for their thoughts on the 2010 season.

headline: Cisco Wi-Fi Router Delivers Simple Set-Up
text: Cisco has begun selling a new line of wireless routers that promises to bring simple set-up to those who have never heard of an IP address. The company says its new Valet Wi-Fi routers have taken advice from the team that created the intuitively easy-to-use Flip pocket video camera, which made video a breeze to shoot and share. Cisco bought Flip a year ago.

headline: Dan L. Duncan, Oil Billionaire, Dies at 77
text: HOUSTON — Dan L. Duncan, a billionaire oilman known for his philanthropy and global hunting of exotic animals, died Sunday at his home here. He was 77.

headline: A Rescued Menagerie
text: In Colombia, the Villa Lorena sanctuary offers a strange window into the excesses and brutalities carried out in Colombia’s endless drug wars.

headline: Footprints, Invisible and Not
text: The terrain of city streets does not impress easily. Hundreds, thousands, millions of people may pass along a stretch of pavement without leaving a trace. Even boot after boot in a Veterans Day parade on Fifth Avenue fail to make a permanent mark. But a puddle of wet paint can change the asphalt canvas dramatically, with a single footfall.

headline: Lexus Invites the Green-Oriented to Take a ‘Dark Ride’
text: To help a new model stand out in an increasingly crowded category of hybrid automobiles, Lexus is turning to a new agency that specializes in strategic ideas — in this instance, to portray a “green” car as one honkin’ fast, hot ride.

headline: Obama to Open Offshore Areas to Oil Drilling for First Time
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration is proposing to open vast expanses of water along the Atlantic coastline, the eastern Gulf of Mexico and the north coast of Alaska to oil and natural gas drilling, much of it for the first time, officials said Tuesday.

headline: I.B.M’s Bid to Woo Software Start-Ups
text: I.B.M. wants to enlist fledgling software companies in its Smarter Planet strategy, which seeks to apply technology to big challenges like improving the efficiency of energy use, water management, transportation and health care.

headline: Interview: Tanya Hamilton
text: Tanya Hamilton, the writer and director of "Night Catches Us," compares the themes of her drama about the final days of the black power movement to coming home from a war.

headline: Edmund P. Pillsbury, Director at Kimbell, Dies at 66
text: Edmund P. Pillsbury, a distinguished American museum director known for adding a string of European masterworks to the permanent collection of the Kimbell Art Museum in Fort Worth, died March 25 near Dallas. He was 66 and lived in Dallas.

headline: Mortgage Bonds Present New Risks
text: The Fed’s decision not to buy mortgage-backed bonds after Wednesday raises hazards for investors thinking of picking up the slack.

headline: Interview: Ben Wheatley
text: Ben Wheatley, the director of "Down Terrace," discusses how he mixed improvisation into his screenplay to give the film's performances a sense of realism.

headline: Man, 29, Found Stabbed to Death at Home in Queens
text: A 29-year-old man was found stabbed to death in his Queens apartment on Tuesday afternoon, the police said. The man, identified as Edelbuerto Gonzalez-Andujar, was found in his home at 69-30 62nd Street in Ridgewood, near Glen Ridge Park, the police said. His body was discovered about 4 p.m. by relatives who were worried because they had not heard from him.

headline: Correction
text: An article last Wednesday about food vendors being brought to Summerstage events in Central Park by organizers of the Brooklyn Flea market reversed the locations for the market on weekends. Starting in April, the market will be in the former Williamsburgh Savings Bank Tower on Sundays, and in its Fort Greene location on Saturdays.

headline: Notable Deaths of 2010
text: Remembering George Steinbrenner, J.D. Salinger, Teddy Pendergrass, Howard Zinn and others who died this year.

headline: News Quiz | March 31, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page.

headline: Aid Promises Don’t Stop Rise in Greek Borrowing Costs
text: Markets drove up Greece’s borrowing costs again on Tuesday, despite last week’s promise of a financial backstop from other European countries, indicating the country’s debt crisis was far from over, The Associated Press reports.

headline: Dayton in N.I.T. Final
text: Dayton’s Chris Johnson, a 6-foot-6 swingman, had 22 points and 9 rebounds to lead the Flyers to a 68-63 victory against Mississippi in a National Invitation Tournament semifinal Tuesday at Madison Square Garden. The Flyers (24-12), who will be playing for their third N.I.T. title and first since 1968 on Thursday, will face the winner of Tuesday’s second semifinal between North Carolina and Rhode Island.

headline: Samsung Life Said to Aim for $4.5 Billion in I.P.O.
text: Samsung Life Insurance, South Korea’s top life insurer, wants to raise up to around 5.1 trillion won ($4.5 billion) in the country’s biggest initial public offering and second largest offering in Asia so far this year, sources told Reuters.

headline: UBS Confirms Fixed-Income Earns Nearly $2.3 Billion
text: UBS expects first-quarter revenue in its rebuilt fixed income business to be slightly below $2.3 billion, the Swiss bank confirmed on Tuesday.

headline: Word of the Day | quell
text: quell •\ˈkwel\• verb

headline: Lars Nilsson: A Look at His Designs
text: Here’s a look at pieces from the designer’s new line, and his work throughout his career, including designs for Gianfranco Ferré, Nina Ricci and Bill Blass.

headline: Redwood Said to Eye Sale of $200 Million in C.D.O.’s
text: Redwood Trust is looking to float at least $200 million worth of securities backed by home mortgage loans, The Wall Street Journal said, citing people familiar with the situation.

headline: Sex.com: Between Bankruptcy and Foreclosure
text: A lender claiming it is owed millions by the operator of the domain name Sex.com is asking a federal bankruptcy court to dismiss an involuntary bankruptcy case against the company, so it can resume a foreclosure auction, according to new court documents.

headline: Ruby, It’s You
text: Christopher Petkanas on the best decorator you’ve never heard of.

headline: How Will Russia Respond?
text: WHO is suspected to have perpetrated the attack on the Moscow subway?

headline: Schottenfeld Reaches Galleon Settlement With S.E.C.
text: Schottenfeld Group, the company where three people charged in the Galleon Group insider trading case worked, agreed to pay $1.2 million to settle a lawsuit brought by the Securities and Exchange Commission, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Wall Street Manages to Stay on Positive Side
text: Wall Street ended slightly higher on Tuesday as an energized technology sector helped offset worries about foreign debt.

headline: Mortgage Bonds Present New Risks
text: Investors seem remarkably relaxed about the end on Wednesday of the Federal Reserve’s $1.25 trillion program to buy mortgage-backed bonds guaranteed by Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, Breakingviews remarks.

headline: Should a Gay Teenager Be Allowed to Take a Date to the Prom?
text: Constance McMillen, a high school senior in Mississippi, was told that she could not take her girlfriend to the prom – and that she had to wear a dress, not a suit, if she did attend. (Later, the school cancelled the event.) Now a federal judge has ruled that the school violated Ms. McMillen’s rights. What do you think?

headline: Mulcahy to Retire From Board of Xerox
text: The Xerox Corporation said Tuesday that its chairwoman, Anne M. Mulcahy, planned to retire in May, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Gainers & Feederism
text: People who deliberately gain weight.

headline: Ambassador Theater Sews Up U.K. Deals
text: Fresh off its acquisition of 16 additional theaters in the West End of London and across Britain, the Ambassador Theater Group is seeking business deals with theater owners and producers in the United States to create a cross-Atlantic distribution network for shows, one of the company’s co-founders said Monday.

headline: Lawmakers Resist Karzai’s Move on Election Panel

headline: Six Shocks of Entrepreneurship
text: There’s nothing like a tough economy – and unemployment – to encourage people to take the plunge and open their own businesses. Some have more business experience than others. Some have more education than others. When I started my company, I went through a series of surprises and shocks and the occasional nightmare. With all of the recent interest in entrepreneurship, I thought I would highlight six warning signs that you are about to be broadsided by one of the classic and inevitable struggles of business ownership. If you hear yourself saying these words, take a step back and think about what you’re doing. My hope is that by being more aware you will be better prepared.

Mr. Wheatley spoke about his method of merging improvisational lines with the words in his screenplay to get fresh performances out of his actors:

headline: Now Tying | Pierrepont Hicks
text: Technically speaking, men have been wearing ties less and less for decades now. Yet anyone who’s moved even slightly in the hipster-trad circles of Brooklyn and Portland, Ore., and Madison, Wisc., knows that a certain kind of man now regularly pairs a tie with his jeans and rumpled button-down and work boots in a way that is perfectly cool. Which goes a long way toward explaining the quiet buzz that has been building around a new necktie label called Pierrepont Hicks, which opened last fall and just recently released its second (spring/summer) collection.

headline: Can Animals Be Gay?
text: The Laysan albatross is a downy seabird with a seven-foot wingspan and a notched, pale yellow beak. Every November, a small colony of albatrosses assembles at a place called Kaena Point, overlooking the Pacific at the foot of a volcanic range, on the northwestern tip of Oahu, Hawaii. Each bird has spent the past six months in solitude, ranging over open water as far north as Alaska, and has come back to the breeding ground to reunite with its mate. Albatrosses can live to be 60 or 70 years old and typically mate with the same bird every year, for life. Their “divorce rate,” as biologists term it, is among the lowest of any bird.

headline: Eyes Have It
text: According to Ver Bien Para Aprender Mejor (‘‘See Well to Learn Better’’), a program sponsored by the Mexican government, about one-tenth of the country’s children do poorly in school simply because they can’t see well. That’s not just because glasses are expensive, but also because in Mexico they’re often perceived as evidence of a handicap. In an attempt to address both problems, Ver Bien turned to the industrial designer Yves Béhar, who, as the creator of the One Laptop Per Child XO (the original $100 computer), has earned a reputation as a maker of inexpensive, attractive products for kids in the developing world. Béhar designed a set of split frames, which makes the glasses less costly to assemble in the field and lets kids customize them using a smorgasbord of color options. ‘‘They’re at the intersection of practicality and personal expression,’’ Béhar says. With the help of Augen, the manufacturer, Ver Bien can keep the total cost — including an eye exam and shipping — at just $10. This year alone, it will give away 400,000 pairs. ‘‘This is about using the very best not to make the most expensive product,’’ Béhar says, ‘‘but to make the most valuable product — and to make it efficiently.’’

The campus is wired end-to-end and students also get a new Macbook, which sounds like a bonanza, except the part about a $500 fee per semester for all the digital convenience. Nobody ever said the future would be cheap.

headline: Art Institute of Chicago Cuts Some Gallery Hours
text: The Art Institute of Chicago has begun closing some galleries for one to two hours a day in an effort to close a budget gap, Carrie Heinonen, the museum’s vice president for public affairs, said. The rotating closures are an experiment so far, but the museum projects being able to save $150,000 annually if they are continued, Ms. Heinonen said. She added that none of the most-visited galleries – like those displaying Impressionist paintings or famous works like Edward Hopper’s “Nighthawks” or Grant Wood’s “American Gothic” – had been closed and that the museum had received very few complaints. The closures were reported by Time Out Chicago.

headline: Justin Bieber Tops the Chart
text: Justin Bieber, the shaggy-haired, baby-faced Usher protégé, is barely 16, but he now has a No. 1 album on the Billboard chart. “My World 2.0” (Island), his first full-length LP, sold 283,000 copies in its first week, according to Nielsen SoundScan. Billboard reported that Mr. Bieber is the youngest solo male artist to top its album chart since a 13-year-old Stevie Wonder reached No. 1 in 1963 with “Little Stevie Wonder/The 12 Year Old Genius.” (Upon receiving the chart news on Wednesday, Mr. Bieber tweeted about how he was celebrating: “SCHOOL … buzzkill”). Mr. Bieber’s minialbum, “My World,” released in November, rose five spots to No. 5 this week with 50,000 sales; together the two records have sold just under 1.4 million copies.

headline: ‘Glee,’ ‘Modern Family’ and Craig Ferguson Win Peabody Awards
text: What could be more exciting for those singing, dancing, impregnating glee-club kids at William McKinley High School than a victory at sectionals? How about a Peabody Award? On Wednesday “Glee,” the hit Fox series, was named one of the recipients of a George Foster Peabody Award, given annually by the University of Georgia’s Grady College of Journalism and Mass Communication for excellence in electronic media, the college said in a news release. The ABC comedy “Modern Family” was also recognized by the Peabody board, as were “The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson” on CBS, the HBO series “In Treatment” and “The No. 1 Ladies Detective Agency” and the PBS movie “Endgame,” about the end of the apartheid era in South Africa.

headline: Feeling For | Rolex Redux
text: We’re all familiar with the fashion crowd’s fixation with black, but if you’re also obsessed with watches, check out Black Limited Edition, a series of vintage stainless steel Rolexes turned into “Tron”-like collector’s items. Alejandro Alcocer, a watch fanatic and design entrepreneur who has previously delved into skateboarding, catering and handbag design, followed the legend of a black watch supposedly released by Rolex in the late 1960s for the Royal British Army soldiers stationed in South Africa. It was thought that only 500 were made, but Rolex never confirmed their distribution and they became the holy grail of watch collecting. So Alcocer decided to make his own, with the help of a Pennsylvania-based company that had previously done contract work for the U.S. Army but had fallen on tough times. Aside from the dial and crystal, which remain in vintage original condition, the watches were transformed into matte black beauties using highly specialized chemical applications. Black is the new black, and I’m feeling for the Rolex redux.

headline: Tricks of Math and Physics
text: The Census Bureau counted about 2,500,000 people in Kings County, N.Y., also known as Brooklyn, in 2000, spread over 70 square miles. This is roughly 35,000 people per square mile, a fact that the following graphic, circulating online, uses to present an interesting question: If every American — all 300 million of us — lived in one state, how big would that state have to be for everyone to fit as comfortably as Brooklynites?

headline: ‘The New Health Care Law’

headline: Floral Accessories Are Big for Spring
text: IF the sudden onset of 60-degree weather hasn’t fully spurred your spring fever, try slipping on a pair of Valentino’s Fairy Tale booties. The blush-colored flower-festooned shoes are some of the sweetest, frilliest (some might say silliest) accessories of the season. And, in contrast to all those strictly tailored on-trend pieces that are presumably hanging in your closet, such blooming femininity has a saucy appeal.

headline: A Critic’s Place, Thumb and All
text: TWO weeks ago I went to Atlanta to give a talk at a conference devoted, in part, to “The Future of Criticism.” The gist of my remarks was that there is one. This was a contrarian, and perhaps also somewhat self-serving, position to take. After all, the countervailing evidence is hard to avoid.

headline: ‘Census Deadline’
text: Monologue | Tuesday night on “Jimmy Kimmel Live” on ABC: Thursday is census deadline day. The census would like every resident of the United States to fill out their form and mail it in. If you don’t know how many people live in your house, just count the number of iPods.

headline: After Fight, a Brooklyn Brownstone’s Costly Rescue
text: When he worked at one of New York’s most respected preservation firms, Timothy Lynch would have spared no effort to save brownstones like the two that stood before him on a January morning.

headline: Snowbirds Cast Off Their Inner Fashionistas
text: TAMPA, Fla.

headline: New York Auto Show: Rodents Rule as Kia Spot Is Named Top Car Ad
text: Unleashing some hipster hamsters paid off for Kia Motors: a commercial for its trend-surfing Soul box car was named Automotive Ad of the Year on Wednesday at the New York auto show.

headline: New York Auto Show: Ford, Microsoft and E.V.’s
text: The electric version of the Ford Focus, to be released next year, will be the first car to benefit from a collaboration between Ford and Microsoft that uses wireless connectivity to make it easier (and presumably less costly) to charge electric vehicles.

headline: Leave New York? Maybe Not
text: If you’d asked me a year ago whether I would be considering going to college in New York City, I would have laughed. Loudly. For some time now I’ve felt that I need a change of scenery — a break away from my comfort zone, including my supportive, big family and the New York City transit system. I need to know that I can survive in an entirely new environment without having the option of a 30-minute train ride home.

headline: Opening Day Questionable for Mets’ Murphy
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. – Mets first baseman Daniel Murphy walked through the clubhouse with a noticeable limp Wednesday, casting doubt on his ability to be ready for opening day.

headline: New York Auto Show: Ford Chief Stresses Growth as Crucial to Success
text: 5:30 p.m. | Updated

headline: What We’re Reading …
text: An interview with Nobel laureate Elinor Ostrom, and other links from around the Web.

headline: Forgotten Florida, Through a Writer’s Eyes
text: THINK of Florida and some well-worn images are likely to spring to mind: gaudy seaside hotels, palm-studded avenues, beaches dotted with towels and umbrellas.

headline: Behind-the-Screens Help
text: EAST LANSING, Mich. — Jordan Ott’s role in Michigan State’s Final Four preparations involves staring at a computer screen nearly nonstop for three days in a windowless room, his sleeping bag stashed nearby. His goal of logging every screen, jump shot, inbounds play and trap-laden defense of the Final Four teams Butler, Duke and West Virginia has not yet been reached.

headline: Hutchison Reverses Course, Will Stay in Senate
text: And she’s staying.

headline: Banning Texting in Trucks Raises Other Questions
text: The Department of Transportation on Wednesday proposed to make permanent a rule prohibiting cross-country truckers from sending text messages while driving.
